1
1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF EQUIPMENT
                                                                 
                                                                 
The 1633 EA Acoustic Electronics Cartridge is a single-conductor
electronics cartridge responsible for the data acquisition,
downhole analysis, and telemetry interface for the 1421 XA Micro
CBL or the 1424 XA Segmented Bond Tool.
The 3504 communications protocol specifications govern the
telemetry interface with the surface system and are briefly
summarized in DATA ACQUISITION, document component 130363-995.*  
The 1633 EA cartridge--attached to the top of the SBT or Micro CBL
acoustic mandrel--controls and receives signals from the mandrel. 
Acquired data from the 1633 EA is sent to the surface at a rate of
20.8 kbits/s.  Acquisition tables dictate the way in which the
data is acquired for a given request from the surface system.
Acoustic data is acquired simultaneously from two receivers. 
This is accomplished by the two-channel 8-bit A/D card under the
control of the CPU card, both of which are located in the flasked
electronics section of the 1633 EA cartridge.  
Figure 935-1 shows the major components of the 1633 EA.
During an acquisition sequence, the acoustic mandrel is
configured to select a transmitter, two receivers, and gains
based on the acquisition table.  Control of the mandrel is
accomplished through a serial communication link.
*
Documentation found in CLS Manual behind the Cement Bond Log
tab
2
1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF EQUIPMENT

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION


3
1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION 

POWER SUPPLY ASSEMBLY
Refer to schematic C149266-100.
The power supply assembly provides regulated +15 V, -15 V, and +5 V
for the 1633 EA cartridge as well as for the mandrel.*
The 150-VDC cablehead supply comes down on conductor 7 and is
taken off the Flask Connector Board C143328 on terminal T18.  The
150 VDC is routed to a filter network on the power supply
assembly consisting of L1, C12, R6, and C11 which drops the
voltage down to approximately 140 VDC.
The voltage is then routed through a negative voltage protector
diode (D13) to the 160-V regulator circuit.  This circuit,
comprised of Q3, Q4, R5, C10, and D14, provides over-voltage
protection.  The maximum voltage seen on the output of the
regulator is approximately 157 VDC, but under normal operation is
approximately 135 VDC.
This voltage is applied to the primary of the self-oscillating
power supply.  There an imbalance bias voltage is set through R4
that turns on first Q1.  Feedback windings then provide the
continual switching for Q1 and Q2 necessary to sustain
oscillation.
One secondary winding of T1 provides an output that is rectified
(by bridge D1, D2, D3, D4) to supply approximately +24.5 VDC and
-24.5 VDC to the input of the +15 V and -15 V regulators,
respectively.  The other secondary winding provides an output
that is rectified (by bridge D5, D8) to supply approximately +13
VDC to the input of the +5 V regulator.
The output for all the micropac regulators (+15 V, -15 V, +5 V)
should be within 1% of the nominal output voltage.  The inputs to
these regulators are filtered by 82-microfarad caps (C1, C3, C4).
The regulator output is filtered by 1-microfarad caps (C5, C7,
C8).
The 1633 EA will draw approximately 85-90 mA from the surface
power supply when not connected to the mandrel.
*
Mandrel refers to the 1424 XA or 1421 XA instrument that is
run with the 1633 EA.
NOTE:
Early production tools contained additional components to
support a - 5 Vdc power supply.  These have been removed

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION

topic: Circuit Description - 2.2 SINGLE-CONDUCTOR TRANSCEIVER CARD B142767 . . . .
chunk_text:
2.2.1
RECEIVER SECTION
4
2.2.2

SINGLE-CONDUCTOR TRANSCEIVER CARD B142767
Refer to schematic C142767-100.
The Single-Conductor Transceiver Card is responsible for the
reception and transmission of Manchester data on the wireline.
As a single conductor instrument, the 1633 EA communication
signals ride on the 150-VDC cablehead voltage.  The 150 VDC comes
in on conductor 7, referenced to 10, at the top of the 1633 EA and
is routed to both the power supply filter and the Single-
Conductor Card (at P4-14).
2.2.1
RECEIVER SECTION
Data sent down to the 1633 EA is coupled off the incoming 150 VDC
on P4-14 by C1 into the first stage of the receiver section.  The
first stage of amplification (1/2 U1) has gain adjustment (R28
and R3) which can be adjusted accordingly for given line
conditions.  (Refer to REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURE, document
130364-956.)
The signal is then coupled by C7 to the second stage (1/2 U1) and
by C10 to the third stage (1/2 U2), with each stage having a
fixed gain.
The other half of U2 acts in the last stage as a comparator which
is switched by the received signal that provides the logic level
necessary for the Unipolar Data In (UDI) to the Manchester chip
on the CPU Board.  The UDI signal is routed from the Single-
Conductor Board at P4-6.
2.2.2
TRANSMITTER SECTION
When transmitting data back to the surface system, a Bipolar Zero
Out (BZO) signal from the Manchester chip on the CPU Board

C143318 is routed to the Single-Conductor Card via P4-3.  This
signal provides the switching logic to the hex FET U3.
The output driving FET's of U3--tied to R25 and R26--switch the
+15-V drive voltage to ground and to +15 V, depending on the
transmitted data bits. This signal is coupled to the 150-VDC line

topic: Circuit Description - 2.3 RUC INTERFACE BOARD C154459 . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
RUC INTERFACE BOARD C154459 5
2.3.1
GR AND NEUTRON DATA 5
2.3.2

RUC INTERFACE BOARD C154459
The RUC Interface board acts as a conduit for information from
other instruments in the logging string to the CPU in the 1633 EA.
Four Remote Unit Controller (RUC) chips on the board store
accumulated data from the 1309 XA GR and the 2420 XA (or 2435 XA)
Neutron instruments until the CPU is able to retrieve the data,
process the information, and transmit it uphole.  In addition,
the cable head voltage and the CCL signal from the 2330 XA or
2346 XA instrument are routed through the RUC Interface board.
Note
The RUC chip is a custom-designed
integrated circuit developed by
Western Atlas.  A detailed breakdown
of the internal circuitry may be
found in any one of the maintenance
manuals for the 8000 series PCM
Production Logging tools.  Only a
generalized description of the chip's
function will appear here.
2.3.1
GR AND NEUTRON DATA
Tool measurement data (GR, SSN, and LSN signals) enter the RUC
Interface board on the appropriate pin at J1.  (See schematic
C154459-100.)  Each signal is routed through a 1-kilohm resistor
and a Schmitt trigger inverter (IC-5) which converts the signal
to a square wave and improves noise immunity.  The output from
the Schmitt trigger feeds into the RUC 16-bit counter at pin 2
(of IC2, IC3, or IC4) where tool measurement data accumulates.
Each RUC chip has a unique address strapped to pins 9 through 13.
By means of an 8-bit address/command byte that is composed of a
5-bit address and a 3-bit command, the CPU (IC-1 on CPU board

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
2.3.1
GR AND NEUTRON DATA (CONTINUED)
To issue an address/command byte to the RUC chips, the CPU places
a high on the RCMD line (J1-3) and sends the address/command byte
to pin 14 of each RUC via the RDTA line (J1-5).  Eight pulses on
the RCLK line (J1-3) from the CPU ensure that the byte is clocked
into each RUC, after which the RCMD line goes low.  Figure 945-2
shows the signal path of each line from the RUC Interface board
to the CPU board.
The RUC whose address strapping (on pins 9-13) matches the 5-bit
address in the address/command byte is the RUC that responds to
the CPU's request for data.  The internal 16-bit counter on the
RUC is reset after the low-order bits have been loaded into the
register.  The internal counter than continues to accumulate data
counts for the next data request.
Upon receiving a READ command from the CPU, the RUC loads its
data into the RUC 8-bit shift register.  The 8 high-order bits
are loaded first followed by the 8 low-order bits.  The CPU sends
17 clock pulses down the RCLK line to clock data out RUC pin 14,
over the RDAT line, and to the CPU for processing.
The RUC counter remains empty until the next address/command byte
is clocked into RUC pin 14, at which time the counter begins to
accumulate tool measurement data again.
2.3.2
CCL DETECTION CIRCUIT
To compensate for various CCL magnet strengths as well as varying
casing sizes, R1 is used to adjust CCL signal amplitudes coming
into the RUC interface board at J1-13.  The CCL signal is then
converted to a unipolar signal by full-wave active rectifier IC7.
In the next stage, IC8--with a fixed gain of 3--amplifies the CCL
signal before it is sent to the CPU board.
The CCL signal is multiplexed by IC9 with cablehead voltage and
routed from the RUC interface board via J1-14 to the CPU board
where it is converted by the on-board A/D on the microcontroller.
The A/D is a 10-bit converter but is used only as a 9-bit
converter (0 min to 511 max).
The CCL signal is sampled each subcycle in an acquisition
sequence.  These values are averaged to yield a composite value
that is included in the data package sent to the surface.
Cablehead voltage is divided down by R5/R6 and routed through IC6
to IC9, where it is multiplexed with the CCL signal and then
routed from the RUC interface board via J1-14.  Tool software
controls the output of IC1, which controls the multiplexer
selection of CCL or cablehead voltage.

RUC INTERFACE BOARD C154459  (CONTINUED)

8-BIT A/D BOARD D142762 8

CONNECTOR DISTRIBUTION BOARD B143320
Refer to schematic C143320-100 or to drawing D151202.
This board serves as a distribution center for the I/O Bus as
well as a channel for signals entering and leaving the flasked
electronics.  Three I/O Bus inlets--avaliable through CJ2, CJ5,
and CJ6--allow peripheral devices to be tied to the 20-conductor
I/O Bus.
The two-channel 8-bit A/D Card D142762 is connected (via P2 on
the A/D board) to the Distribution Board at CJ5.
Connector J1 on the CPU Board is tied to the Distribution Board
at CJ3 and CJ4.
Power supplies, grounds, and communications and auxiliary signals
which must extend outside the flasked electronics are routed
through CJ1.

8-BIT A/D BOARD D142762
Refer to schematic D142762-100.
The 8-Bit A/D Board has two channels that allow simultaneous
conversions of two receive signals, and an I/O Interface Bus that
provides data transfer to the CPU Board.  The following
description given for channel 1 is identical in operation to the
second channel (shown on the bottom half of schematic D142762-
100).
The selected bipolar receive signal enters the 8-Bit A/D Card via
terminal T1 (referenced to T2) at the input of operational
amplifier IC1 which has unity gain.  A resistor network (R3-R9
and R41) allows varying amounts of signal attenuation to be
selected by 8-to-1 multiplexer IC2, which is under the control of
the latched bits of IC10.  The signal output of the multiplexer
is routed to IC3 which has a fixed gain of 2.
The signal output of IC3 rides on the 2.5-V reference voltage of
IC23 to provide the necessary offset voltage for the A/D system
which requires unipolar data to the input of the A/D (IC5).  This
unipolar data is provided via the output of IC4 to the input of
the A/D (IC5-28).

8-BIT A/D BOARD D142762  (CONTINUED)
The A/D +ref (IC5-17) is supplied by IC6 (typically 5.05 V) and
the -ref (IC5-27) is tied to ground.  During an acquisition
cycle, conversion clocks (IC5-1) are provided to the A/D via the
I/O Bus from the CPU Board.  Figure 945-3 shows a timing diagram
for the A/D.
The conversion clock present at the A/D (IC5-1) consists of
31.25-ns wide low-level pulses at a frequency determined by the
sample rate set in the data acquisition table.  The 31.25-ns
pulse provides the data conversion, and the remainder of the
clock cycle (period) writes converted data into the 4 K X 9 FIFO
(IC9).  The number of conversion pulses for a given subcycle
(again refer to DATA ACQUISITION) is dictated by the data
acquisition table.
An I/O Bus--consisting of a 4-bit address bus, 8-bit data bus,
I/O line, and conversion clock--allows the A/D to interface with
the CPU Board.  (See Section 3.3.4 for more detail on the I/O
Bus.)
One half of IC7 provides decoding for the selected channel, while
the second half of IC7 handles decoding for the specific device
on the selected channel.
Status information such as Empty Flag (IC9-21), Full Flag (IC9-
8), and gain settings can be read from the A/D board through the
buffer IC8.
An onboard control latch (IC10) controls devices on its
associated channel such as the variable attenuation (IC2), FIFO
Reset (IC9-22), and FIFO Retransmit (IC9-23).
The conversion clock is inverted and buffered by IC20 to provide
the necessary drive and logic for the A/D (IC5-1) and FIFO Write

CPU BOARD C143318
Unless otherwise noted, all component references in this section
pertain to schematic D143318-100.
3.3.1
CPU SPECIFICATIONS
PROCESSING UNIT:
Intel LA80 C196 KB-12 16-bit Microcontroller
@ 12 MHz

32 K X 8 EPROM Mitsubishi
(This EPROM is programmed for SBT only.  Future
EPROM will include Micro CBL.)

64 K X 8 Static RAM (Two 32 K X 8 pages)

6408 Manchester Decoder/Encoder (20 Kbits/s)

SERIAL CHANNEL:
3504 Instrument Bus
Acoustic Serial Channel

I/O Control
The CPU Board controls data acquisition, downhole data analysis,
and communication with the surface system.  Several system paths
allow the CPU Board access to its various data and support
circuitry.  These system paths can be divided up into the
following functional blocks:
Memory Map
Communication Interface
I/O Bus
A/D Control
Serial Communications
Each path is described separately in Sections 3.3.2 through 3.3.6

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
3.3.2

3.3.3
COMMUNICATION INTERFACE
Communication is handled through an interrupt-driven system.  The

Kbits/second) for receiving and transmitting.  The 6408 is
comprised of a Decoder and Encoder as described in the following
sections.
DECODER SECTION
---------------
A dual binary counter (IC20) divides down a 16-MHz base
oscillator (IC28) to provide the 250-kHz source clock to the
decoder clock input (IC11-5).  Data is received serially through
the buffer-protected UDI input of the 6408 (IC11-8) which
monitors the data for a valid sync pattern.
Once a valid sync pattern is recognized, the take data output
(IC11-3) goes high, and if the sync pattern is that of a command
type the command data sync line (IC11-10) will also go high.  The
falling edge of the take data and command sync lines causes a
corresponding interrupt to be triggered through the flip-flop
(IC19, pin 5 & 1).
If the word received is of a data type, the flip-flop output
(IC19-9) set by take data will be the only interrupt set which is
then responded to by the microcontroller.  If the word received
is of a command type, then both outputs of the flip-flop (IC19-
9&12) are set and the microcontroller--handling the interrupts on
a priority basis--recognizes the word received as a command.
The microcontroller responds to a data-received interrupt
(command or data type) by reading the word from the parallel
outputs of the shift registers (IC14 & IC13). The interrupts
generated by a word being received are cleared when the reset
lines (IC19-6&2) are pulled low for the duration of the READ
cycle on the low byte of the word received (stored in IC14).

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION


16
1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
3.3.3
COMMUNICATION INTERFACE  (CONTINUED)
ENCODER SECTION
---------------
The base 16-MHz oscillator (IC28) is divided down through the
dual binary counter (IC20) and the encoder clock (IC11-23) is
selected (by jumper X to Y) to deliver a 250-kHz clock.
The encoder is enabled when the microcontroller (IC1) sets a
control latch bit (IC27-2) high, which is gated with the system
reset (IC31-3).  This gating is required to keep the T2 mode
encoder disabled until the microcontroller has properly
initialized setups upon power up.
The 6408 encoder shift clock (IC11-2) is gated with the encoder
of the 6409 (IC12)--which is not used in the 1633 EA--to provide a
shift clock output on IC32-11.  When the encoder is enabled, the
bit counter IC17 will be clocked.
Note
The 6409 (IC12) is only used on the 1667 EA
for high-speed data transmission to the
surface.
Before the encoder is enabled for a data transmission, the
buffered parallel-to-serial shift registers (IC16 & IC15) are
loaded with the first two words (16 BIT) to send to the surface.
The shift registers have a buffered latched input which allows
the word being sent to be loaded, as well as the word following.
A control latch bit (IC27-4) must be set low when the first word
is loaded into the shift registers (IC16 & IC15) to allow the
word to be transferred to the output latches of the shift
register.  The control latch bit is then set high and the second
word is loaded into the input buffer of the shift registers.

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
3.3.3
COMMUNICATION INTERFACE  (CONTINUED)
ENCODER SECTION  (Cont'd)
-------------------------
When the encoder is disabled, the output of gate IC32-3 holds the
bit counter (IC17) in a load mode and the word boundary indicator
(IC18) in a reset mode.  Enabling the encoder causes the bit
counter to be incremented by the gated encoder shift clock (IC32-
11).
When the 16th bit has been clocked, the falling edge of the bit
counter (IC17-7) causes the word boundary indicator (IC18-8) to
go low, which causes the following events to occur:
1)
A low output on IC18-8 results in a low-level output on
IC31-11 which loads in the next word from the input-to-
output buffers on IC16 & IC15.
2)
The falling edge of IC18-8 generates an encoder
interrupt, causing a high level on IC18-12 which is
recognized on the NMI (IC1-7) input of the
microcontroller.  This interrupt prompts the
microcontroller to load the next word of the transmission
block into the input buffers of the shift registers (IC16
& IC15).  When the low byte of the word is loaded (WRITE
to IC16-12), the encoder interrupt (IC18-12) is disabled
by the reset line (IC18-2) being pulled low for the
duration of the WRITE cycle.
3)
The low output of the word boundary indicator (IC18-8)
also resets the indicator and the bit counter by pulling
low the indicator's reset line (IC18-6) and the bit
counter's load line (IC17-11).  The bit counter is
reloaded with a value of zero before the next word is
shifted.
The above process occurs for each word transmitted to the surface
until the last word of the data block is transmitted.  Due to the
double buffering in the shift registers (IC16 & IC15), it is

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION


19
1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION


3.3.4
I/O Bus
A universal 20-conductor bus allows the CPU to access data from
peripheral boards tied to the bus.  This 20-conductor I/O bus is
made available to peripheral boards through a Connector
Distribution Board (B143320) connected to the CPU Board.  See
Section 3.1 for a description of the Connector Distribution
Board.
Below are the bus specifications:
-
An I/O control line (IC41-11) which enables the decoding
logic on each board connected to the bus
-
A 4-bit address bus (IC41, pins 2,4,6, and 8) which uses the
upper two bits (AD3 and AD2) to decode the particular board
and the lower two bits (AD1 and AD0) to decode the specific
device on the addressed board
-
An 8-bit data bus (IC40, pins 2 through 9) which serves as a
bi-directional path for data transfer
-
A conversion clock (IC41-13) which is available for the A/D
modules connected to the bus but is active only during an
acquisition cycle
-
Power supplies and grounds:  +15 V, -15 V, +5 V, DGND, and
AGND.

The 8-bit, bi-directional data bus is buffered through an octal
transceiver (IC40).  The 4-bit address bus is buffered by one
half of an octal buffer (IC41), with the I/O control line and
conversion clock buffered in the other half.

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
3.3.5
A/D CONTROL
The sample rate for A/D modules is programmable from 62.5 kHz to
8 MHz, and the number of samples accumulated is programmable from
1 to 4095.  The variable sample rate is achieved by dividing down
a 16-MHz base clock (IC28) (via cascaded binary counters IC25 and
IC26) with a value stored in a latch (IC21).  Due to timing
synchronization, the base clock frequency is always divided down
by one more than the value stored in the latch (IC21).
to zero from the value stored in the latch, a borrow is generated
(IC26-13) which clocks flip-flop IC30.  The high out on IC30-12
is the high period of the conversion clock and is gated with the
base 16-MHz clock to allow a 31.25-ns high pulse before resetting
IC30.  At the same time IC30-13 is low, which reloads the
cascaded counters (IC25 and IC26) with their original count value
to restart the process.
This process goes on continually, with the high state of the
continuous clock IC30-12 at a fixed period of 31.25 ns but with
the low state varying based on sample rate.  (This non-
symmetrical duty cycle is necessary to meet A/D module and FIFO
set-up specs.)
The continuous conversion clock IC30-12 is present at the
synchronization flip-flop IC29-5.  Therefore, as soon as a source
fire sync (IC29-1) is issued by the microcontroller (IC1-46) to
initiate the start of an acquisition cycle, the conversion clock
is immediately enabled (IC29-9).
This rising edge fire sync (IC29-9) is sent to the mandrel to
fire the transmitter, as well as to enable the A/D converter
clock (IC31-8).  The fire sync is routed through a level
translator (IC6-3) where it is sent to the mandrel at a 15-volt
level (IC6-4).
Once the converter clock is enabled (IC3-8), it decrements the
sample counters (cascaded binary counters IC22, IC23, IC24)
which--when decremented to zero (end of sample accumulation)--
cause a borrow (IC24-13) that disables the A/D conversion clock.
These sample counters are loaded with the number of samples to
accumulate (1 to 4095) prior to each transmitter firing
(acquisition cycle).  The converter clock is buffered by IC41
where it is available on the I/O bus.
21
1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION


22
1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
3.3.6
SERIAL COMMUNICATIONS
The CPU Board has two serial communication interfaces with
external peripheral devices.  Each uses three lines to control
the transfer of data.
MANDREL COMMUNICATION INTERFACE
-------------------------------
The 1633 EA uses one of these serial interfaces for the control of
transmitter, receiver, and gain selections in the mandrel.  The
lines for this interface are summarized below:
R/W ----- (IC1-47 P1.6) ----- Controls direction of data
transfer (i.e., send or
receive).
DATA ---- (IC1-48 P1.5) ----- Serial data transmission line.
Provides serial data out.
(IC1-6  P0.3) ----- Serial data transmission line.
Receives serial data.
CLOCK --- (IC1-55 P1.4) ----- Clocks data into and from
remote serial devices at
approximately 100 kHz.  Data
is shifted on the rising edge.
The above lines are routed through a level translator (IC6)
that steps up signals leaving the CPU Board to +15 V.
Incoming serial data is routed through a step-down
translator (IC39), with the serial R/W line controlling
which translator is enabled.  A set- up sequence is executed
before each acquisition which consists of setting the
correct receiver, transmitter, and gain selections.
AUXILIARY DATA COMMUNICATION INTERFACE
--------------------------------------
The 1633 EA uses the other serial interface to read auxiliary data
(e.g., GR, N, or CN) from the RUC Interface Board C143319.
RCMD -----(IC1-57 P1.2) ----- This line serves as a command
control or R/W line.
RDAT ---- (IC1-58 P1.1) ----- This is a bi-directional
serial data transmission line.
RCLK ---
(IC1-59 P1.0) ----- Clocks serial data into or
from remote serial devices at
approximately 100 kHz.

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION

1 
 
1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- MECHANICAL DESCRIPTION 
 
Refer to drawing R152302. 
 
The 1633 EA is housed in a 3.38-inch O.D. housing with an I.D. of 2.75 inches and a length of 
84 inches.  
 
 
The top sub has standard 3.38-inch WTS threads (AP-108) which mate with the housing, and 
standard 3.38-inch (AP-43) outer threads which mate to the standard Western Atlas cablehead. 
The bottom sub is a standard 3.38-inch WTS joint.  
 
The top sub allows 0.30 inch of thermal expansion for the enclosed electronics. A vacuum flask 
2.5 inches O.D. by 42 inches long houses the CPU, Distribution, and Two-Channel 8-bit A/D 
boards. The heat sink contains 10 pounds of Cerrobend alloy to absorb heat and slow the 
heating process.  
 
Install a “dummy” flask (P/N F197172000) as required, where the temperature difference 
between the borehole environment and the electronics rating of less than 257°F (125°C) will 
allow advantageous heat transfer and dissipation to the borehole. 
 
Both the external and internal electronics are supported by an H-beam type chassis.

topic: Disassembly/Assembly Procedures - 2.2 ASEMBLY OF BOTTOM WTS SUB
chunk_text:
ASSEMBLY OF BOTTOM WTS SUB
All numbers in brackets refer to callouts on drawing C148965 of
Bottom Sub.
1.
Ensure that O-rings [5] are seated correctly on 32-pin
bulkhead [2].
2.
Using the bulkhead insertion tool to align the keyed
bulkhead, draw the bulkhead into the sub housing [1] by
turning the split collar with a pin wrench.
3.
With snap ring pliers, install snap ring [3] into the sub.
Make sure snap ring seats properly in its groove.
4.
Lubricate and seat the outer O-rings [4] into their
respective O-ring grooves.

topic: Disassembly/Assembly Procedures - 2.3 ASSEMBLY OF TOP WTS SUB
chunk_text:
ASSEMBLY OF TOP WTS SUB
All numbers in brackets refer to callouts on drawing C148957 of
Top Sub.
1.
Set spring [7] inside the sub housing.  Insert the travel
sleeve [6] into the center of the spring.
2.
Position the retainer ring [4] over the travel sleeve with
the countersink holes facing upward.
3.
Compress the spring and secure the ring with 3 flat head
socket screws [5].  NOTE:  The hole pattern for this
retainer ring allows it to be installed in only one
alignment configuration.
4.
Lubricate and install O-rings [2 and 3].

topic: Disassembly/Assembly Procedures - 2.4 INSTALLATION OF ELECTRONICS INTO
chunk_text:
INSTALLATION OF ELECTRONICS INTO PRESSURE HOUSING
All numbers in brackets refer to callouts on drawing R152302.
1.
After the WTS subs are assembled and the threads lubricated,
install the bottom WTS sub [16] first.  Secure the housing
with a strap wrench, and use a pin wrench to rotate the sub.
2.
Insert the electronics [19] (keyed snout first) into the
housing [1].  IMPORTANT:  Make sure the flat ribbon cable is
on the upper side of the electronics when sliding it into
the housing to avoid dragging or damaging the cable during
installation.
3.
When the electronics bottoms against the housing, screw the
1/4-20 T-Handle wrench [3] into the top of the flask adapter
on the pigtail end of the electronics.  Then rotate the
electronics while pushing inward until it keys up with the
bottom sub.  Make sure the keyed snout on the electronics
aligns with the timing marks on the housing and subs.
4.
To install the top WTS sub, feed the pigtail in through the
throat of the sub.  Then hold the pigtail with slight
tension while screwing the sub into the housing.
5.
Connect the 28-pin black block [7] to the pigtail.
Carefully twist the pigtail into the throat of the top sub
to seat the block inside the sub.  Seat the retainer clip
[6] into the locking groove to secure the block.
7.
Install top and bottom [2 and 4] thread protectors to

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES

chunk_text:

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES

REMOVAL OF ELECTRONICS FROM PRESSURE HOUSING
Unless otherwise noted, all numbers in brackets refer to callouts
on drawing R152302.
1.
Remove the thread protectors.  Remove the retainer clip [6]
on the top sub with a screwdriver.  Use a small T-Handle (PN
078902) to remove the 28-pin block [7] connected to the
pigtail.
2.
Disconnect the block from the pigtail.  While securing the
housing with a strap wrench, remove the top sub with an open
end wrench.
3.
Screw the 1/4-20 T-Handle [3] into the flask adapter and
carefully slide the electronics [19] from the housing.
Avoid damaging the flat ribbon strip.
Note
The ribbon strip should be on top
when removing the electronics to
avoid abrasions resulting from
wires dragging against the housing.
4.
Disconnect the flask connector [10 on D150317] with an allen
wrench and remove the three #6 binder head screws from the
mouth of the flask.  WHILE CAREFULLY SUPPORTING THE FLASKED
ELECTRONICS, remove the flask.

1
INTRODUCTION 2
1
INTRODUCTION
The Micro CBL/SBT Test System exercises the 1633 EA Acoustic
Electronics Cartridge (ACES208), 1421 XA Micro CBL, and the
1424 XA Segmented Bond Tool.  The system allows the user to
easily verify instrument operation, modify instrument
parameters, analyze acquired data, and troubleshoot the
instrument.
The SBT/MCBL program is a user friendly system utilizing
menus that take the user through various levels of the
program.  The <ESC> key allows the user to return from sub
menus or abort operations throughout the program.

2
REQUIREMENTS 2
2
REQUIREMENTS 

REQUIRED HARDWARE
o
IBM or Highly Compatible Personal Computer -- The test
system will operate with a PCXT/286/386-based machine
running at 4.77-25 MHz.  [Machine must have EGA
graphics capability for EGA display menu].
o
3788 PC Test System or 5721 XA Telemetry Test System --
Each of these systems is comprised of an interface
board that plugs into one of the PC expansion slots.
The board provides the digital telemetry interface to
the 1633 EA.
An interface box provides the required cabling and
line drivers to communicate from the PC to the
instrument over a wireline.
Please see the operation manual for the 3788 PC Test
System or 5721 XA Test System Manual for detailed
instruction on each system.

o
PC to ACES208 Acoustic Electronic Cable -- This optional
cable (P/N 152320-000) connects the 3788 PC interface
board directly to the 1633 EA instrument's
communication interface cable.
o
3773 or Equivalent DC Power Supply -- Provides the
required instrument operating power.
o
Standard Lab Equipment (optional):
-
Oscilloscope (digital storage capability preferred).
-
DVM or Simpson Meter.

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- PC TEST SYSTEM GUIDE

REQUIRED SOFTWARE
o
Operating System DOS 3.0 or higher revision.
o
SET49 H.EXE -- Sets up the operating environment for the
program.  It should be called in the AUTOEXEC.BAT
file when the system is booted.
o
SBT.EXE -- Exercises the 1633 EA ACES208 Acoustic
Electronics and the 1424 XA Segmented Bond Tool.
o
MCBL.EXE -- Exercises the 1633 EA ACES208 Acoustic
Electronics and the 1421 XA Micro CBL Instrument.
o
SETPANEL.EXE -- Only when using the 5721 XA Test System.
Note
In the config.Sys file both buffers and
files must be set to 20 or greater.  For
example:
BUFFERS=20
FILES=20
DEVICE=ANSI.SYS

3

3
3

Before running the test program, the environment must be set
up by running the following:
SET49 H.EXE
(Failure to do so will abort operation of SBT.EXE/MCBL.EXE.)
Upon program initialization, the default Waveform
Acquisition Table is downloaded to the instrument.  The
system provides an audible beep if an error occurs during
initialization.
After initialization, the main menu screen is displayed.
The editing bar is moved around by the cursor keys.  To
access one of the menu choices, position the edit bar over
the desired option and press <CR>.
All further sub-menu selections are made with either the
edit bar or by typing the highlighted keys (red).  Pressing
the <ESC> key returns you to the next higher level in the

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- PC TEST SYSTEM GUIDE

MAIN MENU SUMMARY
The following summarizes the main menu selections, each of
which is discussed in further detail in Sections 4 through
9.
CGA Waveform Display -- Allows user to view any of the
acoustic signatures from the selected transmitter and
receivers.  A cursor is available to measure travel time
and t.
EGA Waveform Display -- Allows user to view any of the
acoustic signatures from the selected transmitter and
receivers.  Both the near and far waveforms are displayed
simultaneously.  Dual cursors are available to measure
travel time, amplitude, and t.
Data Analysis Display -- Allows user to continuously acquire
data from the instrument.  The updated display allows the
user to view the travel times picked by the instrument,
AGC gain settings, measured amplitudes, calculated
attenuations, and compensated attenuation calculations.
Waveform Acquisition Table -- Allows user to modify
parameters in the Waveform Acquisition Table.*
Instrument Diagnostics -- Accesses subroutines that test and
verify instrument operation:
Reset Instrument
Run Instrument Diagnostics
Read Instrument Version
Transmit STCW
Acquire Data Dump
Acquire Signature Dump
Communication Test
Load/Save Setup -- All parameters used by the program can be
saved to disk in a file called SBT.FLE or MCBL.FLE.  This
file is read on program initialization to configure the
Micro CBL/SBT Instrument.
*
For a detailed description of the Waveform Acquisition
1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- PC TEST SYSTEM GUIDE

4
CGA WAVEFORM DISPLAY 5
4
CGA WAVEFORM DISPLAY
This sub menu:
1. Allows the user to view any of the acoustic signatures
from the selected transmitter and receivers
2. Allows the user to acquire and view data without EGA
graphics capability
3. Displays all auxiliary data transmitted to the surface
A cursor is available to measure travel time and t.
The screen divides into four separate areas.  The upper left
half of the screen displays the signature.  To the right of
this section is an area that displays the auxiliary data,
and waveform data "transmitted from" the instrument.  The
lower eighth of the screen provides a display area for the
cursor time, cursor amplitude, relative bearing, and the
computed deviation.  The last line is the function key
command list.
WARNING
IF THE SYSTEM IS REQUESTING DATA, THE USER MUST
ENTER A VALUE.  FAILURE TO DO SO, WILL CAUSE A

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- PC TEST SYSTEM GUIDE

topic: Operating Guide - 4.1 DESCRIPTION OF DISPLAYED VARIABLES . . . .   6
chunk_text:
DESCRIPTION OF DISPLAYED VARIABLES
Service:
Micro CBL or SBT, based on LOG MODE variable.
CHV:
Measured Cablehead Voltage.  Valid only if
data is being updated.
FLTM:
Internal Flask Temperature (not implemented).
ETIME:
Elapsed time since the last acquisition.
Near DL:
Near Delay setting in microseconds.
Far DL:
Far Delay setting in microseconds.
Status:
Telemetry Status Word (OK or NOT OK).
CSTAT:
Cycle Status (see DATA ACQUISITION, document
130364-995).
MODE:
Standby or Manual (see Section 4.2).
SCALES:
YMIN - Minimum Y axis scale
YMAX - Maximum Y axis scale
XMIN - Minimum X axis scale (microseconds).
XMAX - Maximum X axis scale (microseconds).
SIGNATURE DATA:
TX -
Transmitter Code of the Acquired
Waveform.
RX -
Receiver Code of the Acquired
Waveform.
START -
Start time of the Acquired
Waveform.
PERIOD -
Sample period of the Acquired
Waveform.
GAIN -
Gain in dB of the Acquired
Waveform.
Auxiliary Data:
GR -
Gamma ray counts.
SSN-
Short Spaced Neutron Counts.
LSN-
Long Spaced Neutron Counts.
Relative Bearing:
Computed RB from the X and Y accelerometers
(degrees).
Deviation:

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- PC TEST SYSTEM GUIDE

FUNCTION KEY COMMANDS
F1 - Acquire data from instrument and update the display.
F2 - Y Axis Scale.
F1 - Bipolar. Set Y Max and then set YMIN = - YMAX.
F2 - Set Y Max Scale.
F3 - Set Y Min Scale.
F4 - Exit.
F3 - Reserved.
F4 - Waveform Control.  Select parameters for the waveform
to be transmitted to the surface.
F1 - Transmitter Code (0 = No Transmitter).
F2 - Receiver Code (0 = Reference).
F3 - Sample Period in nanoseconds.
F4 - Start Time to transmit waveform in microseconds.
F5 - Gain of Waveform in Decibels.
F6 - Number of Samples to "Acquire" (Only 250 samples
are transmitted to the surface).
F5 - Reserved.
F6 - Mode Selection.  The system allows you to acquire data
automatically at fixed-time intervals.
F1 - Set system into manual mode.
F2 - Set system into Standby (continuous acquire).
User must enter the time between acquisitions in
seconds.
F3 - Exit.
F7 - Go to the Waveform Acquisition Table Menu.

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- PC TEST SYSTEM GUIDE

AUXILIARY KEY COMMANDS
C  - Set the cursor at the specified time in microseconds.
5  - Numeric key pad [num lock off].  This allows the user
to vary the step size of the cursor.
Cursor Left  - Decreases the position of the cursor.
Cursor Right - Increases the position of the cursor.
<ESC>        - Exit current submenu.

5
EGA WAVEFORM DISPLAY 8
5
EGA WAVEFORM DISPLAY
The EGA Waveform Display menu allows the user to view any of
the acoustic signatures from the selected transmitter and
receivers.
The display divides into four sections:
Signature display-
Up to 16 pairs of waveforms (near and
far) may be displayed on the screen at
one time.  User has complete control of
X-Y scales, and cursor positions.
Commands         -
Listing of the function Key commands.
Cursor Data      -
The system uses two cursors to evaluate
the acoustic data.  The enabled cursor
is  "highlighted."  The difference
between the two cursors is also
displayed.
Sections 5.1 through 5.3 describe the function of the
keyboard in this menu.

FUNCTION KEYS
F1 - Acquire Data.  Send system command to have the
instrument acquire a new data set.
F2 - Send Signatures.  A command is sent to the instrument
to transmit all subcycle signatures to the surface.
F3 - Modify the time axis scales for the acoustic wave
display.  UNITS are in microseconds ( s)

FUNCTION KEYS (CONTINUED)
F5 - Command to select the waveforms displayed on the
screen.
A user-friendly menu indicates which of the waveforms
are displayed.  To make changes, use the cursor keys to
position the highlight bar next to your selection and
strike the "X" key.  (Any other key removes the
selection).  To return to the displayed signatures, hit
<ESC> or <CR>.  (Selections will be saved.)
F6 - Send user to the Waveform Acquisition Table menu.  (See
Section 7.)
F7 - TSTART, TNUM.  TSTART is the start time in microseconds
for the transmission of the subcycle signatures.  TNUM
is the number of transmitted samples per signature.
F8 - Set operation mode of the instrument.
MODE = 0
Manual (must use F1/F2 to Get Data from tool)
MODE = 1
Acquire only (automatic acquire data only)
MODE = 2
Acquire and Send data (automatic)
Modes 1 and 2 are automatic modes.  The user must input
the time between acquisitions in SECONDS.

This sub menu allows the user to continuously acquire data
from the instrument.  An updated display allows the user to
view the travel times picked by the instrument, AGC gain
settings, measured amplitudes, calculated attenuations, and
compensated attenuation calculations.
Commands are entered by moving the highlighted bar (cursor
keys) over the selection and hitting the <CR> key.
ACQUIRE -- The system will display the data previously
acquired by the instrument, and tell the instrument to
acquire another data set.
CONTINUOUS UPDATE -- The system will continuously ACQUIRE
data from the instrument and update the display.

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- PC TEST SYSTEM GUIDE

COLUMN DEFINITION
Column 1  --
The Subcycle number for the acquired data.
Column 2  --
Transmitter and receiver selections for the
subcycle.  Transmitter Code/Near Receiver
Code/Far Receiver Code.
Column 3  --
Gain in decibels: Near/Far Receivers.
Column 4  --
Measured Amplitude: Near/Far Receivers.
Column 5  --
Subsurface travel time pick: Near/Far
Receivers.
Column 6  --
Calculated Delta Time : Far - Near.
Column 7  --
Computed attenuation: 20 Log [AFAR/ANEAR].

COMMANDS
S - Transmit Table
Transmits the displayed Waveform
Acquisition Table to the
instrument.  (NOTE: All changes to
the display will be updated).
R - Receive Table
Reads the Waveform Acquisition
the instrument.  The instrument
will also acquire a new data set
(the instrument double-buffers the
data acquired).
G - Gain
Changes all current GAIN settings.
Units for GAIN are decibels.  Both
the Near and Far Gains can be
changed independently.
N - Near Delay
Changes all current NEAR DELAY and
FAR DELAY settings.  Units are in
microseconds.
W - Window
Changes all current WINDOW (near
and far) settings.  Units are in
microseconds.
T - Threshold
Changes all current THRESHOLD
settings.  Units are absolute A/D
steps.
# - Number of Samples
Changes the number of samples to
acquire for the subcycle data.

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- PC TEST SYSTEM GUIDE

8
INSTRUMENT DIAGNOSTICS 14
8
INSTRUMENT DIAGNOSTICS
The Instrument Diagnostic sub menu allows the user to access
several test programs falling in the category of
diagnostics.  These programs can be used to either verify
the operation of the instrument, or as an aid in adjusting
the system.  See PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE LEVEL 3 (component -
953) or REPAIR/MAINTENANCE (component -956).
Reset Tool -- Sends the command 0 to the instrument which
tells tool to initialize itself to power-up state.
Read Instrument Version -- Diagnostic command that reads the
version of firmware installed in the instrument.  The
received data is displayed on the CRT.
Transmit STCW -- User may transmit any of the 3504 tool
commands. User is prompted for the tool command word.
For example, if the user wants to open the SBT pads, he
enters 5 (HEX).  User is then requested to enter data
(0-4095).  To open the pads, the data is 2.*
Acquire Data Dump -- Diagnostic command that allows the user
to view the actual raw data transmitted to the surface.
Raw data from the tool scrolls across the screen.
Acquire Signature Dump -- Diagnostic command that allows the
user to view the transmitter code, receiver code, gain
code, sample period, and start time from the SEND
SUBCYCLE SIGNATURES TO SURFACE command (Command 8).
The actual wave data can be viewed in the EGA Waveform
Display Menu.
*
See DATA ACQUISITION, document 130363-995 in the CLS Manual

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- PC TEST SYSTEM GUIDE
8
INSTRUMENT DIAGNOSTICS (CONTINUED)
Communication Test -- Allows the user to verify the
telemetry system.  Two different tests are available--
ECHO WORD and INCREMENT.  Each test transmits 2048-word
blocks to the instrument and compares the data echoed
from the instrument to verify the communication.
ECHO WORD
The PC prompts the user for a Word to
echo to the instrument.  Data is entered
in HEX.  The test continues until it is
aborted by pressing <ESC>.
INCREMENT
The PC sequences through all possible
bit patterns.  The test ends after all
patterns have been transmitted and
received.
The communication test is continuously monitored on the
CRT.  Errors can be printed out after the test is
completed or aborted.
The CONTINUOUS TRANSMIT MODE is used to set up the
telemetry to the instrument or to continuously repeat a
command.
The user must enter a word to ECHO, the type of sync:
data/command, and the delay between transmissions.
The program will continuously send this word until the
program is aborted with the <ESC> key.

1633 EA ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS -- PC TEST SYSTEM GUIDE 
LOAD/SAVE SETUP
This sub menu allows the user to save all current Waveform
Acquisition parameters to disk in a file called SBT.FLE or
MCBL.FLE.
On power-up, the program searches for this file to
initialize the instrument.
Use the Up or Down cursor key to position the highlight bar
over the LOAD SETUP or SAVE SETUP position.  Strike the <CR>
key to begin execution.
Use the <ESC> key to exit if necessary.

topic: Brief Description of Service - BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE/EQUIPMENT -- 1668MA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG 1.0 INTRODUCTION
chunk_text:
1
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE/EQUIPMENT -- 1668 MA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG 
INTRODUCTION
The Multipole Array Acoustilog Instrument (MAC) integrates a conventional monopole acoustic
array with a dipole acoustic array.  The arrays are independent, with separate compressional and
shear transducers optimized for each array.  The MAC is a WTS instrument and must operate in
conjunction with the 1667 EA Acoustics Electronics Cartridge and the 3510 XA WTS Common
Remote.
The MAC consists of four major components: Receiver Mandrel, Acoustic Isolator, Transmitter
Mandrel and Transmitter Electronics.

1668 MA RECEIVER MANDREL
The 1668 MA includes the pressure compensated receiver section and the receiver electronics of
the Multipole Array Acoustilog Instrument.  It is 3-5/8 inches in diameter and can be run at
400 F and 20,000 psi.
o
The receiver section of the mandrel contains an array of eight dipole and an array of eight
monopole piezoelectric receiver crystals.  The monopole transducers are conventional
piezoelectric cylinders with a broadband response from 1-20 kHz.  The dipole array's
transducers are gradient hydrophones of the flexural disk type, optimized for the 0.5-5 kHz
band.  The flexural disk design inherently provides good common mode (P-wave) rejection.
In the standard In-Line configuration (8x8), the dipole receivers are all lined up on the same
axis.  The dipole receiver modules are designed such that, after pulling the sleeve, every other
shear receiver can be rotated 90  to provide a 2-axis-dipole/monopole (4x4x8) configuration.
o
The arrays are physically interleaved so the spacing between similar transducers is 6 inches.
Hence, in the standard 8x8 configuration, both arrays have 6 inch spacings, but in the 4x4x8
configuration, each of the 2-axis dipole arrays has 12 inch spacings.  The 8x8 and 4x4x8
configurations are illustrated on the MAC System diagram found behind the Equipment
Information tab.
The receiver electronics section, which is above the receiver section, is an integral part of the
mandrel.  The signals generated by the receivers pass into the mandrel through a 67 pin
bulkhead connection, which is not intended to be a field joint.  The purpose of the receiver
electronics is to amplify, filter and multiplex the signals, under control of the 1667 EA Acoustic
Electronics Cartridge.  The bandwidth of the receiver electronics is software controlled to select
one each of 3 high and 3 low cutoff frequencies.  The high frequency cutoff serves as the anti-
aliasing filter for the analog to digital converters.  Signal selection and the Automatic Gain
Control (AGC), is governed by the acoustic serial channel.

topic: Brief Description of Service - BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE/EQUIPMENT -- 1668MA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG
chunk_text:
2
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE/EQUIPMENT -- 1668 MA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG

1668 PA ACOUSTIC ISOLATOR
The acoustic isolator has no active components.  The purpose of this section is to attenuate and
delay the direct tool arrival (sound that is propagated along the tool body).  This device is a rigid
clamshell structure of proprietary design.
In all configurations of the 1668 XA MAC system, the acoustic isolator must be run between the
transmitter and receiver mandrels.  This instrument may also be used in the 1670 XA DAC
system to increase the transmitter to receiver spacing.
The isolator is pressure compensated with silicon oil and has standard WTS joints on top and
bottom.  It is 3e inches in diameter and may be run at 400 EF and 20,000 psi.
NOTE
The Acoustic Isolator is a fairly flexible instrument and will buckle in
compression.  Buckling failure will occur if the bending deflection of the isolator
is not constrained and an excessive compressive load is applied.

1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL
The transmitter mandrel houses two monopole transmitters, two dipole transmitters and four
high voltage pulse transformers.  The purpose of this section is to produce broadband acoustic
pluses, either compressional or shear, upon receipt of fire pulses from the 1668 FA transmitter
electronics.
The transmitter mandrel may be configured in two ways.  The dipole transmitters may be align
forming a completely redundant system; or, the dipole transmitters may be orthogonal, oriented
at 90 E to each other.  The in-line transmitter configuration corresponds to the 8 X8, single axis,
receiver configuration.  The 2-axis dipole configuration corresponds to the 4 X4 X8 receiver
configuration.
NOTE
The MAC System can be set up to run in either an in-line (8 X) or 2-axis (4 X4)
configuration.  The in-line configuration is suggested for most cases.  If the
1668 MA receiver mandrel is configured in-line, the 1668 BA mandrel must be
run with the dipole transmitters aligned (i.e., the "Dipole Orientation" at "- 0 -E"
).  If the 1668 MA receiver mandrel is configured in the 2-axis dipole mode, the
1668 BA mandrel must be run with the dipole transmitters orthogonal (i.e., the
"Dipole Orientation" at "- 90 -E" ).
The transmitter mandrel is pressure compensated with silicon oil and has standard WTS joints
on top and bottom.  It is 3e inches in diameter and can be run at 400 EF and 20,000 psi.

topic: Brief Description of Service - BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE/EQUIPMENT -- 1668MA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG
chunk_text:
3
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE/EQUIPMENT -- 1668 MA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG

1668 FA TRANSMITTER ELECTRONICS
The transmitter electronics includes the high voltage pulse circuitry and the serial channel
interface.  The purpose of this section is to provide electrical fire pulses to the transmitter
mandrel on command from the surface.  It is 3d" in diameter and may be run at 400 EF and
20,000 psi.
NOTE
The 1668 FA must be run in conjunction with/below the
1668 BA MAC Transmitter Mandrel.  It may also be run
with/below the 1670 BA DAC Transmitter Mandrel as a
replacedment for the 1670 FA.  All further technical
details are contained in the 1668 FA Manual, P/N 130492-
915.

1667 EA ACOUSTIC COMMON
The Multipole Acoustic tool operates in conjunction with the 1667 EA Acoustics Electronics
Cartridge and the 3510 Telemetry Repeater.  The acoustic common contains the low voltage
power supply, WTS Instrument Bus Interface, 4 channel simultaneous 12 bit A/D converters, 12
MHz CPU, 64 Kbytes RAM, 32 Kbytes EPROM, I/O Bus Interface and the acoustic serial
channel interface.  The purpose of this section is to provide timing and control for the
transmitter and receiver mandrels, to digitize the received acoustic waves, to analyze the
acquired waveforms and to transmit data to the WTS repeater sub.

topic: Brief Description of Service - 2.0 DATA ACQUISITION OPERATING MODES
chunk_text:
DATA ACQUISITION OPERATING MODES
The operation mode is software selected: receiver, sample period, type of analysis and customer
presentation.  Engineer interaction is minimal (user friendly).
Full Waveform data is available from either (or both) dipole directions, and from the monopole
transducers.  The number of modes that can be activated during one trip through the well is a
function of the logging speed.  The use of four A/D converters increases the data acquisition
rate, facilitating the use of stacking to improve the signal-to-noise ratio.
Both real time compressional and shear slowness measurement, via first arrival picking
(threshold detection), and full wave processing are available.  The log consists of a minimum of
three tracks.  The Vp/Vs ratio is presented on track 1 along with Gamma Ray and Caliper data.
Tracks 2 and 3 present the monopole, dipole and cross dipole slownesses.  A fourth track is
commonly provided for a quality control curve.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION -- 1668MA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG 1.0 INTRODUCTION . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 2
chunk_text:
1
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION -- 1668 MA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG


Page
----------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
------- 

INTRODUCTION
The following descriptions are for printed circuit assemblies that are a part of the Multipole
Acoustic Instrument.  The text is organized in two sections: the first section presents an
overview of the serial communications format and the second presents the Receiver electronics.

SERIAL COMMUNICATIONS OVERVIEW

Serial communications issued from the Acoustic Common consists of four specialized lines.
These lines are: Serial Data, Clock, R/W, and Fire.  The Clock and R/W lines are made
concurrently available to all assemblies which operate on the serial data communications bus.
Serial Data is passed through receiving shift registers and then made available to the next using
assembly.  The Serial Data line is serially linked (as contrasted to the paralleling linking of the
Clock and R/W lines).  The Fire line is made available to the transmitter interface board which
uses this control signal to initiate the firing sequence of the transmitters.
In the Multipole Array Acoustilog, there are four assemblies which use the serial
communications bus; the S-Wave and P-Wave Xmitter Interface boards in the 1668 FA
Transmitter Electronics and the two Analog Receiver boards in the 1668 MA Receiver
Electronics.
The Acoustic Common serially writes to all assemblies by using an 8 BYTE serial data
message.  BYTE 1 on the line is used to select and control the firing of the S-Wave
Transmitters.  BYTE 2 is used to select and control the firing ofthe P-Wave Transmitters.
BYTES 3, 4 & 5 select and control receiver input, Log-Test option, signal attenuation, amplifier
gains and High Pass and Low Pass filter settings of the Receiver Electronics assembly on Side 1
of the chassis (Channel 1 & 2 Refer to Dwg. 157025-000).  BYTES 6, 7 & 8 are used for that
same purpose with the Receiver Electronics assembly on Side 2 of the chassis (channels 3 & 4).

SERIAL COMMUNICATIONS OVERVIEW (CONTINUED)
The serial data line is received first by the Side 2 Receiver Electronics assembly (channel 3&4),
passed through its 3 shift registers and then made available to the Receiver Electronics assembly
mounted on Side 1 of the chassis (Channel 1 & 2).  The serial data is again shifted through 3
registers and then passed to the Transmitter Electronics.  In this way, the first byte on the line
shifts through 7 registers before being received at the S-Wave Xmitter Interface.  Figure 945-1
shows the serial data flow and the order of the control bytes sent to the instrument.

ANALOG RECEIVER
(REFERENCE SCHEMATIC P/N 157025-100)
The Receiver subassembly houses two Receiver Boards (157016-000).  The boards are mounted
on the Receiver backbone (R157025-000).  Figure 945-2 illustrates the functional representation
of assembly 157025-000.
Each assembly (Receiver board) has two channels through which the signals are routed (Even
and Odd).  The EVEN channel has 4 inputs, 2 P-Wave and 2 S-Wave and the ODD channel also
has 4 inputs, 2 P-Wave and 2 S-Wave.  Each MAC Electronic Assembly has two Analog
Receiver assemblies, therefore, a total of four P-Wave or four S-Wave signals can be processed
simultaneously.
The Analog Receiver assembly receives serial communications from the Acoustic Common and
responds to its commands.
Four command specifications are implemented:
1.
Selection of two inputs (one signal from the EVEN data channel and one from the
ODD channel) on each board
2.
Log or test selection for all channels
3.
Independent gain settings for the ODD and EVEN channels on each board
4.
Selection of low and high filter cutoff frequencies for each board

MAC RECEIVER BOARD
(REFERENCE SCHEMATIC P/N 157016-100)
This board contains two identical channels, each of which contains multiplexers, amplifiers, an
attenuation network and bandpass filters for processing signals from both
Monopole (P-wave) and Dipole (S-wave) receivers.
In addition, shift registers U8, U9, and U10 receive strobe, clock and serial data from the
1667 EA Acoustic Electronics Common cartridge for controlling the various multiplexers.  Serial
data is shifted out of U8 to P-02 for transmission to the second Receiver Board or to the
Transmitter Electronics for controlling the transmitter firings.
+15 VDC and -15 VDC power is also supplied from the Acoustic Electronics Cartridge.

MAC RECEIVER BOARD (CONTINUED)
Since both channels are identical, only one is described from input to output.
Four differential signals, two P-wave and two S-wave, enter the board from connector
P-01.  They are connected to multiplexer U1.  The software selected signal passed by U1 is
connected to input 1 of multiplexer U2.  U2 is controlled by software to pass the signal from U1;
a test signal, which is connected to both channels, or to tie input of the following  circuitry to
ground.  Figure 945-4 contains codes and code sources for controlling Receiver Select
multiplexers U1 and U11 and Log-Test multiplexers U2 and U12.  Additionally, the receiver
selected for both side 1 and side 2 boards is shown.
resistor network RN3 and multiplexer U4.  The output of U3 can be attenuated in 8 steps,3db
per step, and is software controlled.

MAC RECEIVER BOARD (CONTINUED)
The output of the attenuator is sent to input amplifier U5 (1/4 of an OP471 Quad Amp). One half
of multiplexer U6 switches resistors in the feedback of amplifier U5 to give 4 software
controlled steps of gain.  The second half of U6 controls the gain of the output amplifier, another
section of U5, therefore both amplifiers are switched to the same gain settings by the serial data
input.

The output of amplifier U5 is sent to the input of a 4 pole high pass filter which has three
software controlled cutoff frequencies.  The frequencies are 500 Hz,1000 Hz,and1500 Hz and are
determined by resistors switched by multiplexers U16 and U17.  The throughput gain of the
filter section is 2.57 V/V (8.2dB).  Figure 945-7 shows the code and code source for the
selection of the high pass cutoff frequencies.

MAC RECEIVER BOARD (CONTINUED)
The output of the high pass filter is passed to the input of a 4 pole low pass filter which has three
software controlled cutoff frequencies.  The frequencies are 3kHz, 5kHz and 23kHz, and are
determined by resistors switched by multiplexers U18 and U19.  The throughput gain of the
filter section is 2.57 V/V (8.2 dB).  Figure 945-8 shows the code and code source for the
selection of the low pass cutoff frequencies.
been previously discussed.
The output of amplifier U5 is routed to connector P-2 for transmission to the 1667 EA Acoustic
Electronics Cartridge.
