PRELIMINARY PROCEDURE
1.
Study all of the assembly drawings and parts lists to become familiar with the layout of
the assembly.
2.
Make up a instrument history folder for each 1668 BA MAC TRANSMITTER
MANDREL.   Record the instrument ASSET NUMBER.  Obtain a copy of the In-Process
and Final Inspection Check-Out records for this folder.
3.
Verify that all the required parts, tools, and equipment are available.
4.
Secure a clean storage area, work area, and work bench with a vise.
5.
Inspect parts for cleanliness.  Clean all parts of dirt and foreign particles.  Set aside
in a clean storage area.
NOTE
During the assembly process, do not allow dirt or any foreign material particles
to contaminate the parts.  Keep hands, tools, and work area clean.
6.
Inspect all threaded parts for any dings and/or nicks in the threads.  Small dings may be
cleaned up with a thread file if necessary.
7.
At each stage in the assembly, trial fit mating parts, without O-Rings, to insure that all fits
are free of interference and that no conditions exist that would prevent easy assembly.
8.
This completes the preliminary procedure.

3.63" OD WTS TOP SUB 5
#


3.63" OD WTS TOP SUB ASSEMBLY
1.
Refer to assembly drawing [C-156985-000] and parts list for the 3.63"OD WTS TOP
SUB MECHANICAL ASSEMBLY.
2.
One WTS TOP SUB ASSEMBLY is required per 1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL.
3.
Lubricate O-ring and groves lightly with LUBRIPLATE GREASE [03].  Install two AS-
230 O-Rings [09] on the slotted end of the 3.63" TOP SUB [01].  Install two AS-233 O-
Rings [10] on the threaded end of the 3.63" TOP SUB.
4.
Remove the four screws from the SPLIT COLLAR [02] and separate the two halves.
Lubricate the 2.5" wide collar groove of the 3.63" TOP SUB with a liberal coat of
LUBRIPLATE GREASE.  Install the two halves around the collar groove of the 3.63"
TOP SUB and replace the four screws in the SPLIT COLLAR with LOCTITE [11].
NOTE
Make sure the SPLIT COLLAR is well lubricated and turns freely on the 3.63"
TOP SUB.
5.
Install the RING RETAINER [06] on the threaded end of the 3.63" TOP SUB with the
three 6-32 SST FLAT HEAD SCREWS [07] and LOCTITE.
6.
Refer to assembly drawing [C-180006-000] and parts list for the 32-PIN WTS
#
FEMALE CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY.
7.
The 32-PIN WTS CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY [04] should already be assembled at this
stage.  Install the 32-PIN WTS CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY with the RETAINER RING
[08] into the WTS TOP SUB ASSEMBLY for temporary storage.
8.
This completes the WTS TOP SUB ASSEMBLY.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 4.2 CABLE ASSEMBLY FOR WTS TOP SUB . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
4" CRYSTAL TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY 9

CABLE ASSEMBLY FOR WTS TOP SUB
1.
Refer to assembly drawing [C-153675-000] and parts list for the CABLE ASSEMBLY
FOR 1670 MA WTS TOP SUB.
2.
One WTS CABLE ASSEMBLY is required per 1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL.
3.
The WTS 32-PIN CABLE [01] is supplied with 35" leads.  Cut off the leads to 16" overall
(or 4" below the coils).  Strip the insulation 3/16" from the ends with a THERMAL
STRIPPER [226804-000].
4.
Feed the free end of the cable through the "D-hole" end of the BACKSHELL [03] as
shown in the assembly view and temporarily slide the BACKSHELL towards the Cannon
Connector end.
5.
Crimp the leads into the removable SOCKET CONTACTS of the 32-PIN FEMALE
CONNECTOR [02] per the [093703-000] CRIMPING SPEC.  Following the [C-153675-
000] wiring diagram, install the SOCKET CONTACTS in the CONNECTOR [02] using
the contact insertion tool [244710-000].
6.
Check electrical continuity and insulation of the WTS CABLE ASSEMBLY.
7.
Fasten the BACKSHELL to the 32-PIN FEMALE CONNECTOR with the four 4-40 UNC
SCREWS [04].
8.
This completes the WTS CABLE ASSEMBLY.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 4.5 TRANSFORMER HTC X1778B ASSEMBLY . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 11
chunk_text:
TRANSFORMER HTC X1778 B ASSEMBLY
1.
Refer to the assembly drawing [B-157067-000] and parts list for the TRANSFORMER
HTC X1778 B ASSEMBLY.
2.
Two TRANSFORMER ASSEMBLIES are required per 1668 BA TRANSMITTER
MANDREL.
3.
Cut off the head of four 4-40 X 1.25" LONG SCREW [04] and grind the threaded shaft to
1.00" ± .01 long.  Take special care not to damage the threads on these 4-40 STUDS.
WARNING
ALWAYS WEAR EYE PROTECTION WHEN CUTTING OR GRINDING.
4.
Take each 4-40 STUD and install a 4-40 SPACER [02] with GREEN LOCTITE [05].
Screw the STUD partially into the SPACER leaving .20" of the internal threads free.  A
4-40 screw with two nuts locked together may be used as a spacing tool to obtain the
specified clearance within the SPACER.
5.
Working on one side at a time, remove the existing mounting hardware from the HTC
X1778b TRANSFORMER [01] and replace it with the 4-40 STUD/SPACER ASSEMBLY
and a SMALL PATTERN WASHER [03].
6.
One the other end of the 4-40 STUD, use as many WASHERS [03] as necessary to obtain
the total specified height of 1.47" ± .02.
7.
After the appropriate number of WASHERS HAS BEEN DETERMINED, install and
tighten another SPACER with the GREEN LOCTITE onto the 4-40 STUD.
8.
Double check that the specified height has been obtained.  Also check that each SPACER
has at least .20" of the internal threads available; if not, the 4-40 stud may have to be
ground further.
9.
Repeat steps "5" thru "8" on the other side of the TRANSFORMER.
10.
This completes the TRANSFORMER HTC X1778 B ASSEMBLY.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 5.0 TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
chunk_text:
TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
Refer to the assembly drawing [R-156905-000], parts list, and wiring diagram [D-156905-
100] for the 1668 BA MAC TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY.
The assembly of the 1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL may be divided into several distinct
tasks.  These are:

Bender-Plate Transducer Mounting,

Transducer Section Assembly and Testing,

Transformer Section Assembly and Wiring,

Pressure Compensation Assembly,

WTS Field Joint Assemblies,

Silicone Fluid Filling.
Study the transmitter mandrel's assembly drawing and wiring diagram to become familiar with
the layout.  Inspect and inventory all of the required parts and tools.

BENDER-PLATE TRANSDUCER MOUNTING
1.
Refer to the assembly drawing [R-156905-000], parts list, and wiring diagram [D-
156905-100] for the 1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY.
2.
Two BENDER-PLATE TRANSDUCER ASSEMBLIES [23] are mounted within each
1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL.
WARNING
THE BENDER-PLATES CAN DEVELOP AN EXTREMELY LARGE
ELECTRICAL CHARGE.  ALWAYS DISCHARGE THE PIEZOELECTRIC
CRYSTALS TO THE CONDUCTIVE SUBSTRATE BEFORE HANDLING.
CAUTION
THE BENDER-PLATES ARE FRAGILE.  ALWAYS HANDLE WITH GREAT
CARE AND NEVER PULL ON THE ELECTRICAL LEADS.
3.
Without the TEFLON INSULATORS [33], trial fit the BENDER-PLATES [23] into the
UPPER and LOWER HOUSINGS [08 & 09] with the JAWS [40], CLAMPS [39], and
SHOULDER SCREWS [43].  Note that the SCREWS should slide into place easily once
the components are aligned.  The SCREWS should clamp the assembly together without
any binding.

BENDER-PLATE TRANSDUCER MOUNTING (CONTINUED)
NOTE
The BENDER-PLATES must be oriented with the positive "+" side (i.e., the
red wire) facing upward toward the CLAMPS.  This is required for the correct
polarization of the dipole signal.
4.
Work on one BENDER-PLATE and HOUSING at a time.
5.
Remove the four SHOULDER SCREWS from the HOUSING.  Disassembly the
BENDER-PLATE, JAWS, AND CLAMPS.
6.
On one of the CLAMPS, install two INSULATED TERMINALS [37] with one drop of
LOCTITE [59].  Install one TERMINAL with a WIRE LUG [45] and the other with a
LOCK WASHER [38].
7.
With dial calipers, measure the width of the open in the HOUSING.  Record the exact
value.  It should be within the range of 2.040 ± .005."
8.
Measure the width of the BENDER-PLATE with two TEFLON INSULATORS [33] in
place, one on each of the long edges.
9.
On a flat surface with sandpaper, sand each of the TEFLON INSULATORS equally to
produce a .002" to .005" clearance between each of the INSULATORS and the
HOUSING.  Trail fitting the BENDER-PLATE and INSULATORS into the HOUSING
frequently during the sanding.
CAUTION
DO NOT OVER SAND OR SAND THROUGH THE TEFLON INSULATORS.
THE BENDER-PLATE WILL SHORT CIRCUIT WITHOUT PROPER
INSULATION.
10.
When the proper clearance has been obtained, clean and degrease the TEFLON
INSULATORS and the BENDER-PLATE.  From this point on, do not touch the edges of
the BENDER-PLATE.
11.
Install the BENDER-PLATE and TEFLON INSULATORS into the HOUSING with the
four JAWS, two CLAMPS, and the four SHOULDER SCREWS.  Hand tighten the screws
to secure the assembly in place.  Check that the BENDER-PLATES are oriented with the
positive "+" side, i.e. the red wire, facing upward towards the CLAMPS.  Also check
that the electrical leads on the BENDER-PLATES and the CLAMP with the insulated
terminals are orientated in the downhole direction.

BENDER-PLATE TRANSDUCER MOUNTING (CONTINUED)
12.
Inspect the clearance between the INSULATORS and the HOUSING.  Double check the
orientation of the BENDER-PLATE.  Repeat steps 6-11, if necessary.
NOTE
The BENDER-PLATE and INSULATORS should slide easily into the
HOUSING.  The clearance should allow a piece of paper to slide between the
INSULATORS and the HOUSING over the entire length of the BENDER-
PLATE without any sticking.
13.
One at a time, Remove each of the SHOULDER SCREWS, apply LOCTITE [59], and re-
install tightly.
14.
Inspect the clearance between the INSULATORS and the HOUSING again.  Repeat steps
6-13, if necessary.
15.
Repeat steps 5-14 for the remaining BENDER-PLATE and HOUSING.
16.
Cover the BENDER PLATES' black lead with a piece of TEFLON TUBING [57] and
feed it through the aligned holes in the JAWS and BENDER-PLATE.
17.
Referring to the wiring diagram, connect the electrical leads from the BENDER-PLATES
and a twisted triplet of wire to the INSULATED TERMINALS and GROUND LUGS on
the downhole CLAMPS.  Use HI-TEMP SOLDER [52].  Note the color code for the
wiring from the diagram.  The twisted triplets should have 3 to 5 turns per inch to
suppress crosstalk.
18.
Carefully inspect the BENDER-PLATES' mounting and orientation.  Inspect the electrical
connections.  Double check that the sides of the BENDER-PLATES and INSULATORS
have sufficient clearance with the HOUSINGS.
NOTE
The physical mounting of the BENDER-PLATES is crucial for their correct
operation.
19.
This completes the BENDER-PLATE TRANSDUCER MOUNTING.

TRANSDUCER SECTION ASSEMBLY
1.
Refer to assembly drawing [R-156905-000], parts list, and wiring diagram [D-156905-
100] for the 1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY.
2.
The Transducer Section Assembly contains four acoustic transmitters, two monopole
transducers [06] and two dipole transducers [23].
3.
Insert the CABLE ASSEMBLY [24] thru the center of the TOP ADAPTOR [04].  Install
the GUIDESCREW [25] with LOCTITE [59] and the RETAINER RING [28] into the
TOP ADAPTOR to secure the CABLE ASSEMBLY in place.  Note that the orientation of
the CABLE ASSEMBLY is keyed by the GUIDE-SCREW and the slot of the SST CUP
[P/N 153243-000] of the CABLE ASSEMBLY.
4.
Lubricate the single external O-Ring groove on downhole end of the TOP ADAPTOR
with LUBRIPLATE GREASE [51].  Lubricate and install a 70-Durometer AS-231 O-Ring
[65] into the groove.  Lubricate the gland surfaces, the internal diameter, of the P-WAVE
ACOUSTIC WINDOW [32] and gently slide it over the O-Ring and onto the TOP
ADAPTOR.
5.
Carefully slide the 11.6" TOP SLEEVE [05] over the P-WAVE ACOUSTIC WINDOW
and onto the TOP ADAPTOR.  Secure the TOP SLEEVE in place with six ½-13 FLAT
HEAD SCREWS [18], as shown in SECTION J-J.  Install the SCREWS with RTV
ADHESIVE [47] and tighten to 50 ft-lbs torque.
6.
Refer to the 1668 BA Wiring Diagram [D-156905-100] and Wire Requirements List [M-
156905-870].  Connect a twisted pair of TEFLON WIRE to each of the TRANSMITTER
CRYSTAL ASSEMBLIES [06] with HI-TEMP SOLDER [52].  The color code for the
twisted pairs is shown on the Wiring Diagram.  The twisted pairs of TEFLON WIRE
should be at least 60" long and have 3 to 5 turns per inch to suppress crosstalk.  As a
strain relief, tie off the twisted pairs to an unused INSULATED TERMINAL with
LACING CORD [55] on each of the TRANSMITTER CRYSTAL ASSEMBLIES.
NOTE
Inspect all the wires for any defects such as cuts, nicks, pinches, flats, or scuffs
on the insulation.  Double check the color code of this wiring and the diode
orientation with Wiring Diagram.
7.
Note that the upper TRANSMITTER CRYSTAL ASSEMBLY, designated as
TRANSMITTER #2, is connected with a RED/BRN twisted pair of Teflon wire.  Also
note that the orientation of this TRANSMITTER is with the INSULATED TERMINALS
directed uphole.  The RED/BRN twisted pair of Teflon wire is routed downhole thru the
center of TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY #2.

TRANSDUCER SECTION ASSEMBLY (CONTINUED)
8.
Insert both shielded bundles of the CABLE ASSEMBLY thru the center of the upper
TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY #2.  Gentle pull the slack wire thru the TRANSMITTER
ASSEMBLY and slide it into the TOP SLEEVE and the P-WAVE ACOUSTIC
WINDOW.  The TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY should shoulder against the TOP
ADAPTOR.
9.
Lubricate the internal gland surfaces of an S-WAVE ACOUSTIC WINDOW [07] with
LUBRIPLATE GREASE.  Slide the S-WAVE WINDOW over the shielded bundles of the
CABLE ASSEMBLY and the RED/BRN twisted pair.  Note that the upper S-WAVE
ACOUSTIC WINDOW is to be installed with the smaller internal gland surface orientated
towards the uphole end.
10.
Identify the UPPER HOUSING [08], designated as TRANSMITTER #4.  Lubricate all of
the gland surfaces with LUBRIPLATE GREASE.  Lubricate and install the three correct
O-Rings [65,66, & 67] onto the UPPER HOUSING.
11.
Insert each of the shielded bundles of the CABLE ASSEMBLY and the RED/BRN twisted
pair from TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY #2 thru the holes in the UPPER HOUSING.
Referring to the wiring diagram  [D-156905-100], the smaller bundle, designated as #1,
and the RED/BRN twisted pair should be routed thru the top hole of the UPPER
HOUSING.  Also insert the RED/BLK/YEL twisted triplet from the BENDER-PLATE
TRANSDUCER thru this hole with shielded bundle #1 and RED/BRN twisted pair.  All of
the wires, except for bundle #2, should be routed over the positive face of the BENDER-
PLATE TRANSDUCER, which is marked by the red "+".  Bundle #2 should be routed
thru the bottom hole in the UPPER HOUSING and below the BENDER-PLATE
TRANSDUCER.  Note that a piece of Teflon tubing may be used to guide the wires thru
these long holes.
NOTE
The "DIPOLE ORIENTATION" timing mark on the UPPER HOUSING [08]
should be aligned with the timing mark on the TOP ADAPTOR [04].
12.
Gentle pull the slack wire thru the UPPER HOUSING and slide the S-WAVE ACOUSTIC
WINDOW into place.  Use the 11.6" TOP SLEEVE [05] to seat the S-WAVE ACOUSTIC
WINDOW onto the UPPER HOUSING.  Be careful not to pinch the wiring during this
step.  The TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY #2 and the BENDER-PLATE TRANSDUCER
will be sealed when the UPPER HOUSING is mated into the TOP SLEEVE and the P-
WAVE ACOUSTIC WINDOW.  Secure the UPPER HOUSING in place with six ½-13
FLAT HEAD SCREWS [18], as shown in SECTION H-H.  Install the SCREWS with
RTV ADHESIVE [47] and tighten to 50 ft-lbs torque.

TRANSDUCER SECTION ASSEMBLY (CONTINUED)
13.
Identify the LOWER HOUSING [09], designated as TRANSMITTER #3.  Lubricate all of
the gland surfaces with LUBRIPLATE GREASE.  Lubricate and install the four correct
O-Rings [63,65,66, & 67] onto the LOWER HOUSING.
14.
Insert each of the shielded bundles of the CABLE ASSEMBLY, the RED/BRN twisted
pair from TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY #2, and the RED/BLK/YEL twisted triplet from
the BENDER-PLATE TRANSDUCER thru the holes in the LOWER HOUSING.
Referring to the wiring diagram  [D-156905-100], the smaller bundle, designated as #1,
the RED/BRN twisted pair, and the RED/BLK/YEL twisted triplet should be routed thru
the top hole of the LOWER HOUSING.  Also insert the RED/BLK/BLU twisted triplet
from the BENDER-PLATE TRANSDUCER thru this hole with shielded bundle #1.  All
of the wires, except for bundle #2, should be routed over the positive face of the
BENDER-PLATE TRANSDUCER, which is marked by the red "+".  Bundle #2 should
again be routed thru the bottom hole in the UPPER HOUSING and below the BENDER-
PLATE TRANSDUCER.
NOTE
The "-90- DEG" timing mark on the LOWER HOUSING [09] should be aligned
with the "DIPOLE ORIENTATION" timing mark at this time.
15.
Gentle pull the slack wire thru the LOWER HOUSING and seat the LOWER HOUSING
into the UPPER HOUSING.  The O-Ring on the LOWER HOUSING should slide in
smoothly.  Be careful not to pinch the wiring during this step.  Secure the LOWER
HOUSING in place with four ½-13 FLAT HEAD SCREWS [18], as shown in SECTION
G-G.  Install the SCREWS with RTV ADHESIVE [47] and tighten to 50 ft-lbs torque.
16.
Lubricate the internal gland surfaces of a S-WAVE ACOUSTIC WINDOW [07] with
LUBRIPLATE GREASE.  Slide the S-WAVE WINDOW over the shielded bundles of the
CABLE ASSEMBLY and the twisted wiring.  Note that the lower S-WAVE ACOUSTIC
WINDOW is to be installed with the smaller internal gland surface orientated towards the
downhole end.  Slide the S-WAVE ACOUSTIC WINDOW over the LOWER HOUSING.
Use the 30" LOWER SLEEVE or the MAC TRANSMITTER FIXTURE TOOL [P/N
157069-000] to seat the S-WAVE ACOUSTIC WINDOW onto the LOWER HOUSING.
The lower BENDER-PLATE TRANSDUCER will be sealed at this point.
17.
Lubricate the gland surfaces, i.e. the internal diameter, of the P-WAVE ACOUSTIC
WINDOW [32] and gently slide it onto the LOWER HOUSING.  A 70-Durometer AS-231
O-Ring should already be in place on the LOWER HOUSING; and, the ACOUSTIC
WINDOW should slide on smoothly.

TRANSDUCER SECTION ASSEMBLY (CONTINUED)
18.
Note that the lower TRANSMITTER CRYSTAL ASSEMBLY [06], designated as
TRANSMITTER #1, should already be connected with a RED/VIO twisted pair of Teflon
wire.  Also note that the orientation of this TRANSMITTER is with the INSULATED
TERMINALS directed downhole.
19.
Insert both shielded bundles of the CABLE ASSEMBLY and all of the twisted wires thru
the center of the lower TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY.  Gentle pull the slack wire thru the
TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY and slide it into the lower P-WAVE ACOUSTIC
WINDOW.  The TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY should shoulder against the LOWER
HOUSING.
20.
Identify the UPPER TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR [21].  Lubricate the gland surfaces
with LUBRIPLATE GREASE.  Lubricate and install a 70-Durometer AS-231 O-Ring [65]
onto the UPPER TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR.
21.
Insert both shielded bundles of the CABLE ASSEMBLY and all of the twisted wires thru
the center of the TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR.  Gentle pulling the slack wires thru and
slide it into the lower P-WAVE ACOUSTIC WINDOW.  The lower TRANSMITTER
ASSEMBLE #1 will be sealed at this point.
22.
If available, install the MAC TRANSMITTER FIXTURE TOOL [P/N 157069-000] over
the TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR and onto the LOWER HOUSING. Temporarily, secure
the FIXTURE TOOL in place with at least two of the six ½-13 FLAT HEAD SCREWS
[18], as shown in SECTION F-F.  Also temporarily secure the  TRANSFORMER
ADAPTOR in place with at least two of the three 1/4-20 SST FLAT HEAD SCREWS
[18], as shown in SECTION E-E.
NOTE
The FIXTURE TOOL [P/N 157069-000] was designed to protect the P-WAVE
ACOUSTIC WINDOW during final assembly and will facilitate the wiring of
the transformer section.  The assembly may occur without this TOOL; but,
foremost care should be taken to insure that an excessive amount of bending
moment is not applied across the P-WAVE ACOUSTIC WINDOW and
TRANSDUCER ASSEMBLY.
23.
Cover the twisted wires individually with protective SHRINK TUBING [53].
24.
This completes the TRANSDUCER SECTION ASSEMBLY.
5.2.1
TRANSDUCER SECTION TESTING
1.
Refer to the assembly drawing [R-156905-000], parts list, and wiring diagram
[D-156905-100] for the 1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY.
2.
The Transducer Section Assembly may be tested separately to insure quality before
the Transformer Section is attached.  The Transducer Section contains four acoustic
transmitters, two monopole and two dipole:
a.
The two monopole transmitters, designated as TRANSMITTER #1 & #2, are
each constructed of two piezoelectric cylinders and are independent sub-
assemblies, see section 4.4.  The piezoelectric cylinders are excited in parallel
and in-phase to produce a monopole signal, i.e. an omni-directional acoustic
wave pulse.  The two TRANSMITTER CRYSTAL ASSEMBLIES are items #06
on the mandrel assembly drawing.
b.
The two dipole transmitters, designated as TRANSMITTER #3 & #4, are
bender-plate transducers constructed of two piezoelectric plates mounted on a
Kovar substrate.  The two piezoelectric plates are excited in parallel and out-of-
phase to produce a dipole signal, i.e. an bi-directional acoustic wave pulse.  The
two BENDER-PLATE ASSEMBLIES are items #23 on the mandrel assembly
drawing.
3.
Transducer Specifications for the dry, mounted transducers:
a.
Monopole Transmitter [06]
Resonant Frequency
15.0 ± 2.0 KHz
b.
Dipole Transmitter [23]
Resonant Frequency
1.1 ± 0.1 KHz
4.
Test the TRANSMITTER TRANSDUCERS
a.
Atlas Manufacturing Department: Refer to Manufacturing Check-Out
Procedures for the 1668 BA Transmitter Mandrel, A-130475-856.
b.
Field Testing Procedure: Refer to Preventive Maintenance Level 3 Procedures
for the 1668 BA Transmitter Mandrel, A-130475-953.
5.
File a copy of the in-process inspection in the instrument history folder.
6.
This completes the TRANSDUCER SECTION TESTING.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 5.3 TRANSFORMER SECTION ASSEMBLY AND WIRING . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 22
chunk_text:
TRANSFORMER SECTION ASSEMBLY AND WIRING
1.
Refer to the assembly drawing [R-156905-000], parts list, and wiring diagram [D-
156905-100] for the 1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY.
2.
Cover each of the shielded bundles with two layers of protective SHRINK TUBING [54],
approximately 4" long,  at the large opening of TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR as shown
on the 1668 BA Transmitter Mandrel Assembly drawing.
3.
Secure the TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY [22], P/N 157061-000, to the
UPPER TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR [21] with two 3/8" long 10-32 BUTTON HEAD
SCREWS [15] and LOCTITE.  The orientation of the UPPER TRANSFORMER
ADAPTOR is symmetrical about the "-0- DEG" timing mark; thus, the  TRANSFORMER
CHANNEL ASSEMBLY should also be in-line.  At this point, you may rotate the
TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR as necessary.
CAUTION
DO NOT ALLOW THE TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY TO HANG
FROM THE UPPER TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR.  THIS MAY DAMAGE
THE P-WAVE ACOUSTIC WINDOW.
4.
The MAC TRANSMITTER FIXTURE TOOL, P/N 157069-000], was designed to protect
the P-WAVE ACOUSTIC WINDOW during assembly and wiring of the transformer
section.  The assembly may occur without this TOOL; but, foremost care should be take
to insure that an excessive amount of bending moment is not applied across the P-WAVE
ACOUSTIC WINDOW.
5.
Refer to the TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY Drawing, D-157061-000, and
the 1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL Wiring Diagram, D-156905-100.
6.
Note that all of the wiring terminates at a ceramic INSULATED TERMINAL [07].  These
terminals are designated as "Tie Points" and are referenced on each of the drawings as
TP1, TP2, TP3 ... TP17.
7.
Note that Bundle #2 and the twisted wiring are routed below the TRANSFORMER
CHANNEL ASSEMBLY and that Bundle #1 will be routed above the TRANS-FORMER
CHANNEL COVER [04] after the transformers have been wired.
8.
With HI-TEMP SOLDER [P/N 203238-000], connect all of the wires from the Acoustic
Transmitters to the secondary side of the Pulse Transformers.  The routing of these wires
should be as neat as possible and incorporate service loops wherever possible.  RUBBER
GROMMETS [14] have been provided in the TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY.

TRANSFORMER SECTION ASSEMBLY AND WIRING (CONTINUED)
9.
Referring to the wire requirements list, M-156905-870, connect 24" long TEFLON WIRE
from the primary side of the Pulse Transformers, out of the bottom of the
TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY, and downhole.
10.
Carefully inspect the wiring of the TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY section.
Double check the color coding of the wiring with the wiring diagram.  Examine the
quality of the solder joint connections; and, rework as necessary.
11.
Remove the four 1/4" long 4-40 SCREWS [11] which should be in the top of the X1778 B
TRANSFORMER ASSEMBLIES [10] for temporary storage.
12.
Noting the position of the alignment chamfer, install the TRANSFORMER COVER
CHANNEL [04] onto the TRANSFORMER ASSEMBLY.  Route Bundle #1 thru the slot
in the chamfered end of the COVER CHANNEL.  Start the four 1/4" long 4-40 SCREWS
into the tops of the X1778 B TRANSFORMER ASSEMBLIES with LOCTITE.  Do not
completely tighten at this time.
CAUTION
DOUBLE CHECK THAT NONE OF THE WIRING HAS BEEN PINCHED
BETWEEN THE CHANNELS OR THE TRANSFORMERS.
13.
Install two 3/8" long, 10-32 BUTTON HEAD SCREWS [15] with LOCTITE thru the
COVER CHANNEL and into the UPPER TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR with LOCTITE.
Install two more 3/8" long, 10-32 BUTTON HEAD SCREWS thru the COVER
CHANNEL and into the TRANSFORMER PLUG [03].
14.
Align the TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY axially with the TRANSMITTER
MANDREL ASSEMBLY so that it is not being pulled off line.
15.
Tighten the four 3/8" long 10-32 BUTTON HEAD SCREWS and the four 1/4" long 4-40
SCREWS.
16.
Route Bundles #1 thru the downhole slot in the COVER CHANNEL and thru the center
of the TRANSFORMER PLUG.  Route Bundles #2 and the TEFLON WIRES from the
primaries of the Pulse Transformers thru the downhole slot in the MOUNTING
CHANNEL and through the center of the TRANSFORMER PLUG.
17.
Cover each of the shielded bundles with two layers of protective SHRINK TUBING [54],
approximately 4" long,  at the large opening of TRANSFORMER PLUG as shown on the
1668 BA Transmitter Mandrel Assembly drawing.

TRANSFORMER SECTION ASSEMBLY AND WIRING (CONTINUED)
18.
Cover the bundle TEFLON WIRES from the primaries of the Pulse Transformers with
protective SHRINK TUBING [53].
19.
With LACING CORD [55], tie together the two shielded Bundles and the twisted
TEFLON WIRES every 2 inches so they may be coiled up into a service loop.
20.
This completes the TRANSFORMER SECTION ASSEMBLY and WIRING.

PRESSURE COMPENSATION ASSEMBLY 24
#

PRESSURE COMPENSATION ASSEMBLY
1.
Refer to the assembly drawing [R-156905-000], parts list, and wiring diagram [D-
156905-100] for the 1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY.
2.
Lubricate the gland surface of the TRANSFORMER PLUG [P/N 157063-000] with
LUBRIPLATE GREASE [51].  Lubricate and install an AS-214 O-Ring [60].
3.
Lubricate the external flanges of the UPPER TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR [21] with
GREASE.  Slide the RUBBER BOOT [20] over the wiring and the TRANS-FORMER
CHANNEL ASSEMBLY and onto the TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR.
4.
From the assembly drawing, note the orientation of the LOWER BOOT ADAPTOR [11]
in comparison to the TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR.  The keyed slot for the BULKHEAD
[14] on the LOWER BOOT ADAPTOR should be in-line with the horizontal 1/4-20
threaded hole in the TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR, as show in SECTION C-C.  The three
1/4-20 threaded holes in the TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR are at 135 E so take care in
identifying the correct hole.
NOTE
The orientation of the BULKHEAD slot on the LOWER BOOT ADAPTOR is
in-line with the center 1/4-20 threaded hole in the TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR
and also in-line with the "-0- DEG" timing mark on the LOWER HOUSING.
5.
After the orientation has been determined, install the LOWER BOOT ADAPTOR.
Lubricate the external flanges and the internal gland surface of the BOOT ADAPTOR
with GREASE.  Also grease the internal diameter of the RUBBER BOOT to prevent
sticking.  Insert the BOOT ADAPTOR over the wiring and slide it into the RUBBER
BOOT and onto the TRANSFORMER PLUG.

PRESSURE COMPENSATION ASSEMBLY (CONTINUED)
6.
Using the BAND-IT TOOL [P/N 225217], install a .25" wide, Band-It Type STRAPPING
BAND [42] and Band-It Type BUCKLE [41] on each of the flanges.  Tighten the
STRAPPING BAND until it firmly squeezes the RUBBER BOOT but is not cutting the
surface.
CAUTION
OVER TIGHTENING THE BAND-IT TYPE STRAP-PING WILL CAUSE
FLUID LEAKS.
7.
Remove the 1668 BA TRANSMITTER FIXTURE TOOL.
8.
Slide the 30" SLEEVE [10] over the LOWER BOOT ADAPTOR, UPPER
TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR, and onto the LOWER HOUSING [09].
9.
Secure the 30" SLEEVE to the LOWER HOUSING with six ½-13 FLAT HEAD
SCREWS [18], as shown in SECTION F-F.  Install the SCREWS with RTV ADHESIVE
[47] and tighten to 50 ft-lbs torque.
10.
Secure the UPPER TRANSFORMER ADAPTOR to the 30" SLEEVE with three 1/4-20
FLAT HEAD SCREWS [18], as shown in SECTION E-E.  Install the SCREWS with
RTV ADHESIVE [47] and tighten.
11.
Secure the LOWER BOOT ADAPTOR to the 30" SLEEVE with six ½-13 FLAT HEAD
SCREWS [18], as shown in SECTION C-C.  Install the SCREWS with RTV ADHESIVE
[47] and tighten to 50 ft-lbs torque.
12.
Cut the excess wiring off 6" from the LOWER BOOT ADAPTOR.  This length will be
coiled in the ADAPTOR to form a service loop.
13.
Strip back the SST BRAIDED SHIELDING approximately 2 inches.  Insert two, 3 inch
long pieces of SHRINK TUBING [54] under each end of the BRAIDED SHIELDING to
prevent the sharp ends from puncturing the wires' Teflon insulation.
14.
Cover each end of the BRAIDED SHIELDING with two more, 3 inch long pieces of
SHRINK TUBING [54] to prevent the sharp ends from puncturing the other wires' Teflon
insulation.
15.
Strip and crimp the wires into the CONNECTOR SOCKETS [160467-100] supplied with
the 32-PIN LOWER FEMALE CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY [15] using CRIMPING TOOL
[093704-000].

PRESSURE COMPENSATION ASSEMBLY (CONTINUED)
16.
Refer to assembly drawing [C-180009-000] and parts list for the 32-PIN LOWER
#
FEMALE CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY.
a.
Install the PULL-TOOL INSERT [01] with an AS-008 O-Ring [03] into the
FEMALE INSERT MOLDING [07].
b.
Discard the 10-32 NUT [02] supplied with the CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY.
c.
Screw onto the back of the PULL-TOOL INSERT with LOCTITE [10], a number
10 LOCK WASHER [15] and SST the STRAIN RELIEF [P/N 157259-000], which
is item #17 on the assembly drawing R-156905-000.
17.
Cover the crimp connections on pins 1, 4, and 18 thru 22 with a ½" long piece of .125"
DIA. SHRINK TUBING.
18.
Insert CONNECTOR SOCKETS [04] into FEMALE INSERT MOLDING as shown on the
Wiring Diagram D-156905-100.  Fill the two empty connections with un-used SOCKETS.
19.
Wrap THERMAL SET TAPE [56] around the STRAIN RELIEF; then, bundle the wires
around the STRAIN RELIEF and cover with more THERMAL SET TAPE.  Secure the
THERMAL SET TAPE and wires in place with a Hi-Temp CABLE TIE [46].
20.
Install the SST CUP [16] onto the back of the FEMALE INSERT MOLDING with the
four long 4-40 SCREWS [P/N 239106] and the four AS-0015 O-Rings supplied with the
CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY.  Cover these SCREWS with 3/16" SHRINK TUBING [53]
before installing with LOCTITE.
21.
Back coil the wire bundle into the LOWER BOOT ADAPTOR; and, secure the
CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY and SST CUP with three 6-32 SST SOCKET HEAD
SCREWS [19] and LOCTITE, as shown in SECTION K-K.
22.
This completes the PRESSURE COMPENSATION ASSEMBLY.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 5.5 WTS FIELD JOINT ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 27
chunk_text:
WTS FIELD JOINT ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
5.5.1
LOWER WTS FIELD JOINT ASSEMBLY
1.
Refer to the assembly drawing [R-156905-000] and parts list for the 1668 BA
MAC TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY.
2.
Lubricate two AS-231 O-Rings [63].  Also lubricate the gland surfaces and
threads on the LOWER BOOT ADAPTOR [11] with LUBRIPLATE GREASE
[51].  Install the O-Rings onto the threaded end of the LOWER ADAPTOR.
3.
Lubricate the internal threads and gland surfaces of the LOWER WTS SUB [12]
with GREASE.  Screw the LOWER WTS SUB onto the LOWER BOOT
ADAPTOR taking care not to scar the gland surfaces.
4.
Tighten the LOWER WTS SUB with a spanner wrench to at least 75 ft-lbs torque.
Orientation of this LOWER WTS SUB is not critical since the PRESSURE
BULKHEAD [14] is keyed into the LOWER BOOT ADAPTOR.
5.
Lubricate two AS-229 O-Rings [61] and the gland surfaces on the PRESSURE
BULKHEAD with GREASE; and, install the O-Rings onto the BULKHEAD.
6.
The PRESSURE BULKHEAD will be installed into the LOWER WTS SUB using
the BULKHEAD INSTALLATION TOOL [150208-000].  Note that the correct
orientation of the BULKHEAD is with the short alignment key turned up-hole.
7.
Lubricate the internal gland surface of the LOWER WTS SUB with GREASE.
8.
Engage the PRESSURE BULKHEAD into the INSTALLATION TOOL and gently
push the it into the LOWER WTS SUB.  Rotate the BULKHEAD until it keys into
the slot in the LOWER BOOT ADAPTOR.  Use the threaded collar on the
INSTALLATION TOOL to push the BULKHEAD into its final seated position.
The BULKHEAD should seat against the LOWER BOOT ADAPTOR and the long
key should be aligned with the Oil Fill Hole.
9.
Install the RETAINER RING [27] in the LOWER WTS SUB using the
MODIFIED PLIERS [150259-000].  Take special care not to scar the gland
surface inside the bore of the LOWER WTS SUB.
10.
Lubricate an AS-230 O-Rings [62] and the gland surfaces on the PIN THREAD
PROTECTOR [13] with LUBRIPLATE GREASE.  Install the O-Rings onto the
PIN THREAD PROTECTOR; and, screw the PROTECTOR into the LOWER
WTS SUB.
11.
This completes the LOWER WTS FIELD JOINT ASSEMBLY.
5.5.2
TOP WTS FIELD JOINT ASSEMBLY
1.
Refer to the assembly drawing [R-156905-000] and parts list for the 1668 BA
MAC TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY.
2.
Lubricate two AS-233 O-Rings [64], the gland surfaces and threads of the TOP
ADAPTOR [04] with LUBRIPLATE GREASE [51].  Install the O-Rings onto the
threaded end of the TOP ADAPTOR.
3.
Lubricate the internal threads and gland surfaces of the 3.63"OD COLLAR [03]
with LUBRIPLATE GREASE.  Screw the COLLAR onto the TOP ADAPTOR
taking care not to scar the gland surfaces.
4.
Tighten COLLAR with a spanner wrench to at least 75 ft-lbs torque.
NOTE
The timing marks on the COLLAR and the TOP ADAPTOR must align
to within ±3 E (i.e., ±0.1 inches).
5.
Lubricate two AS-229 O-Rings [61] and the gland surfaces on the CONNECTOR
BULKHEAD [26] with LUBRIPLATE GREASE; and, install the O-Rings onto
the BULKHEAD.
6.
The CONNECTOR BULKHEAD will be installed into the COLLAR using the
1/4-20 T-HANDLE TOOL [056036-000].  Note that the correct orientation of the
BULKHEAD is with the short alignment key turned downhole, i.e. towards the
TOP ADAPTOR.
7.
Using the 1/4-20 T-HANDLE TOOL, insert the CONNECTOR BULKHEAD into
the top of COLLAR.  Rotate the BULKHEAD until it keys into the slot in the
TOP ADAPTOR.
8.
Remove any O-Rings which may have come on the WTS TOPSUB ASSEMBLY
[02].  Also temporarily remove the 32-PIN CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY [30] and
the RETAINER RING [48] from the uphole end of the WTS TOPSUB
ASSEMBLY.  Use the WTS TOPSUB ASSEMBLY without any O-Rings to push
CONNECTOR BULKHEAD into place.  Remove WTS TOPSUB ASSEMBLY.
BULKHEAD should seat against TOP ADAPTOR.
CAUTION
USE THE WTS TOPSUB ASSEMBLY TO INSTALL THE
BULKHEAD, SO IT WILL REMAIN PERPENDICULAR TO O-
RING BORE OF THE COLLAR.  IF THE BULKHEAD TURNS
SLIGHTLY, IT MAY JAM AND GALL IN THE BORE.
5.5.2
TOP WTS FIELD JOINT ASSEMBLY (CONTINUED)
9.
Align number one socket of TOPSUB CABLE ASSEMBLY [29] with number one
pin of CONNECTOR BULKHEAD and push them together for full engagement.
Take care not to bend any of the connector pins or to damage any of the wires
in the CABLE ASSEMBLY.
10.
Lubricate two AS-233 O-Rings [64], the gland surfaces and threads on the
downhole end of the WTS TOPSUB ASSEMBLY with LUBRIPLATE GREASE.
Install the O-Rings onto the WTS TOPSUB ASSEMBLY.
11.
Using the PIGTAIL PULLING TOOL [148154-000], guide the CABLE
ASSEMBLY thru the WTS TOPSUB ASSEMBLY.  Screw the WTS TOPSUB
ASSEMBLY into the COLLAR.   Take care not to pinch the CABLE
ASSEMBLY between the BULKHEAD and the WTS TOPSUB ASSEMBLY.
12.
With a 3-5/32" HEX SPANNER WRENCH [P/N 501545-000], tighten the WTS
TOPSUB ASSEMBLY to approximately 75 ft-lbs torque.
NOTE
The timing marks on the WTS TOPSUB and the COLLAR must align to
within ±3 E (i.e., ±0.1 inches).
13.
Remove the PIGTAIL PULLING TOOL from the CABLE ASSEMBLY.  Plug the
32-PIN CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY [30] onto the CABLE ASSEMBLY.  Insert
the CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY into TOPSUB ASSEMBLY and secure it with the
RETAINER RING [48].  Note that the CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY is supplied
with one 70-Durometer AS-031 O-Ring [31].
14.
Lubricate two AS-230 O-Rings [62], the gland surfaces and the spin collar on the
uphole end of the WTS TOPSUB ASSEMBLY with LUBRIPLATE GREASE.
Install the O-Rings onto the WTS TOPSUB ASSEMBLY.
15.
Lubricate the internal gland surfaces and threads of the BOX THREAD
PROTECTOR [01] and screw it onto the WTS TOPSUB ASSEMBLY.
16.
The completes the TOP WTS FIELD JOINT ASSEMBLY.

SILICONE FLUID FILLING
1.
Refer to OIL FILLING PROCEDURES for pressure equalized instruments, [P/N
099194-000].
2.
Using the LAB VACUUM SYSTEM [P/N 078810-000] and two OIL FILLER FITTINGS
[36], evacuate and fill the 1668 BA MAC TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY with
200-100 CS SILICONE OIL [50].
NOTE
The fluid capacity of the 1668 BA MAC TRANSMITTER MANDREL
ASSEMBLY is approximately 3 quarts.
3.
After the MANDREL has been properly filled, re-install the OIL PLUGS [34] with AS-
011 O-Rings [35] into the ports on the TOP ADAPTOR [04] and the LOWER BOOT
ADAPTOR [11].
4.
This completes the SILICONE FLUID FILLING.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 6.0 PRESSURE TESTING AND FINAL INSPECTION . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 31
chunk_text:
PRESSURE TESTING AND FINAL INSPECTION
1.
Identification Marking:  Stamp the ASSET NUMBER and the SERIES NUMBER:
"1668 BA" on the O.D. of the TOP ADAPTOR [04].
2.
Following the DIPOLE CONFIGURATION MODIFICATION PROCEDURE, Section
7.0, align the dipole transmitters to the desired configuration.
3.
Using a MULTIMETER [P/N 156331-000] and referring the 1668 BA Wiring Diagram
[D-156905-100], check the insulation and continuity of each of the thru conductors.
Insulation resistance should be infinite between any two conductors or to the housing.
Conductor continuity should be #1 S.
4.
Test the functional operation of the assembly and perform any addition checks as
specified:
a.
Atlas Manufacturing Department: Refer to Manufacturing Check-Out Procedures
for the 1668 BA Transmitter Mandrel, A-130475-856.
b.
Field Testing Procedure: Refer to Preventive Maintenance Level 1 Procedures for
the 1668 BA Transmitter Mandrel.
5.
Pressure and temperature test the 1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL per the Atlas
Pressure Test Procedure, A-130473-650 .  Retain a copy of the Pressure Test records and
file a copy in the instrument history folder.
6.
Re-check the insulation and continuity of the thru conductors.
7.
Re-check the functional operation of the assembly.
8.
Check the SILICONE OIL [72] level in the instrument.  A small quantity, 1 ounce, may
need to be added after the pressure test.
9.
File a copy of the final inspection records in the instrument history folder.
10.
This completes the 1668 BA MAC TRANSMITTER MANDREL.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 7.0 DIPOLE CONFIGURATION MODIFICATION PROCEDURE . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 32
chunk_text:
DIPOLE CONFIGURATION MODIFICATION PROCEDURE
This section outlines the modification procedures to convert the 1668 BA MAC TRANSMITTER
MANDREL between the IN-LINE dipole configuration and the 2-AXIS dipole configuration.
CAUTION
SERIOUS DAMAGE WILL OCCUR TO THE 1668 BA MAC
TRANSMITTER MANDREL IF THE DIPOLE TRANSMITTERS ARE
ROTATED WHILE THE ROTATION JOINT IS SUBJECTED TO EITHER
A BENDING OR TENSILE LOAD.
1.
Refer to the assembly drawing [R-156905-000] and parts list for the 1668 BA MAC
TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY.
2.
Disconnect the 1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL from the 1668 PA Acoustic Isolator
and the 1668 FA Transmitter Electronics.
3.
If TRANSMITTER MANDREL has been logged, use a high pressure water or similar
manner to thoroughly clean the rotating joint, Section G-G.
4.
Support the entire length of the TRANSMITTER MANDREL so that no bending moment
or tensile load is generated across the rotating joint.
5.
Remove the four ½-13 FLAT HEAD SCREWS [18] from the rotating joint, referenced as
Section G-G on assembly drawing R-156905-000.  Replace any or all of the ½-13 FLAT
HEAD SCREWS if the hex sockets have been damaged.
NOTE
The rotating joint has a "DIPOLE ALIGNMENT" mark which may be
orientated to either the "-0- DEG" or "-90- DEG" positions for the In-Line or 2-
Axis configurations, respectively.

DIPOLE CONFIGURATION MODIFICATION PROCEDURE (CONTINUED)
6.
To modify the configuration turn the rotating joint 90 E.  With a spanner wrench, rotate
the uphole portion of the TRANSMITTER MANDREL so that either the "-0- DEG" or "-
90- DEG" timing mark aligns with the DIPOLE ALIGNMENT mark.  Do not rotate more
than 90 E.  The rotating joint should turn easily with less than 20 ft-lbs of torque.  If this
joint does not turn easily, do not try to force it; instead, reposition the TRANSMITTER
MANDREL to insure that no bending moment is applied across the joint and apply some
lubricant.
DIPOLE ALIGNMENT
CONFIGURATION
-0- DEG
IN-LINE
-90- DEG
2-AXIS
CAUTION
THE ROTATING JOINT SHOULD TURN EASILY AND SHOULD NEVER BE
ROTATED MORE THAN 90 E.  FORCING THE JOINT TO TURN OR OVER
ROTATING WILL CAUSE SIGNIFICANT DAMAGE.
7.
Install the four ½-13 FLAT HEAD SCREWS [18] with RTV ADHESIVE [47].  Tighten
with a torque wrench to 50 ft-lbs torque.
8.
This completes the DIPOLE CONFIGURATION MODIFICATION PROCEDURES.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 8.0 TRANSMITTER MANDREL DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 34 8.1 PRELIMINARY PROCEDURE
chunk_text:
TRANSMITTER MANDREL DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 

PRELIMINARY INSTRUCTIONS
1.
The REFERENCE DRAWINGS, TOOLS, AND EXPENDABLE MATERIALS
REQUIRED are the same as for assembly.
2.
The disassembly procedures are essentially the same as the assembly procedure except in
reverse.
3.
Preparations of disassembly include washing the unit  to remove all mug, grease. dirt, and
other foreign particles if the unit has been run in a well.
4.
Special attention is required to thoroughly clean the transducer and pressure compensation
sections of the since excessive foreign material may be trapped in the slotted sleeves.
5.
Each successive step in the disassembly includes cleaning as required to restore all
components to an as-new condition.

SPECIAL INSTRUCTIONS
1.
Refer to the assembly drawing [R-156905-000] and parts list for the 1668 BA MAC
TRANSMITTER MANDREL ASSEMBLY.
2.
CAUTION: The BOTTOM BULKHEAD [14] must be remove before the LOWER WTS
SUB [14] may be unscrewed.  Failure to remove the BULKHEAD will result in these
parts galling.
3.
CAUTION: The TOP BULKHEAD [26] must be remove before the COLLAR may be
unscrewed.  Failure to remove the BULKHEAD will result in these parts galling.
4.
NOTE: Replacement to the 4-40 INSULATED TERMINALS [37] is recommended
whenever the solder joint is broken.
5.
WARNING: Be very careful when removing the Band-It Type STRAPPING BAND [42].
The edges are very sharp and will cut.
6.
NOTE: Use the special WINDOW REMOVAL TOOL [P/N 157068-000] to remove the S-
WAVE ACOUSTIC WINDOWS [07].
7.
This completes the 1668 BA TRANSMITTER DISASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG
chunk_text:
2
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668 BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG
(This page left blank intentionally.) 3
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668 BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG
chunk_text:
4
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668 BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG 5
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668 BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG
chunk_text:
6
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668 BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG 7
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668 BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG

1668 BA CABLE ASSEMBLY FOR TRANSMITTER MANDREL
1.
Refer to assembly drawing [C-157062-000], parts list, and wire requirements list [M-
157062-870] for the 1668 BA CABLE ASSEMBLY.
2.
One 1668 BA CABLE ASSEMBLY is required per 1668 BA TRANSMITTER MANDREL.
3.
Referring to the wire requirement list [157062-870], prepare the following:
Four 84" 1-cnd Shielded Cables
Six
84" 22 GA. Single Wires
Five 84" 24 GA. Single Wires
One
84" 22 GA. Twisted Pair of Conductors
Four 84" 24 GA. Twisted Pair of Conductors
The twisted pairs should have 3 to 5 turns per inch.
4.   Inspect all of the wires for any defects such as cuts, nicks, pinches, flats or scuffs on the
insulation.
5.
Prepare one end of the shielded cables by:
a.
Strip back the shielding jacket approximately 9."  Fold shielding over the outer
jacket and trim shield to ½."
b.
Cut a 6" long jumper of black 24 GA Teflon wire.
c.
Rap shields and jumper wire with 24 gage buss wire.  Cover with high temperature
SOLDER [203238-000].  Leave one end of 6" long jumper free.  Cover solder joint
with SHRINK TUBING.
6.
Combine all of the wires into a single bundle and temporarily secure one end with lacing
cord.
7.
Strip and crimp one end of all the wires into the CONNECTOR SOCKETS [160467-100]
using CRIMPING TOOL [093704-000] as per the CRIMPING SPECIFICATION
A-093703-000.  The CONNECTOR SOCKETS are supplied with the 32-PIN
CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY w/ CABLE CLAMP [01].
8.
Cover each Wire/Socket connection with a .25" long piece of 3/16" SHRINK TUBING
[237883-000] and shrink into place.
9.
Cut a second 8" long jumper of black 24 GA Teflon wire.  Insert this jumper into the
CONNECTOR SOCKET #2 with the 84" Black 22 GA Wire which will be the digital
ground.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG
chunk_text:
8
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668 BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG

1668 BA CABLE ASSEMBLY FOR TRANSMITTER MANDREL (CONTINUED)
10.
Refer to assembly drawing [B-150599-000] and parts list for the 32-PIN
CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY w/ CABLE CLAMP.
a.
Install an AS-008 O-Ring [03] onto the PULL-TOOL INSERT [01] and insert into
the MOLDED CONNECTOR [07].  Install a #10 LOCK WASHER [15] and screw a
10-32 NUT [02] onto the PULL-TOOL INSERT with LOCTITE [12].
b.
Insert CONNECTOR SOCKETS [04] into MOLDED CONNECTOR per the wiring
RETAINER [05] and an AS-0015 O-Ring [06].
c.
Attach the SST CUP [09] onto the MOLDED CONNECTOR with the four long 4-
40 SCREWS [08] and LOCTITE.  These SCREWS should be covered with 3/16"
SHRINK TUBING [237883-000] to protect the Teflon wires.
d.
Screw the MOUNTING PLATE [10] onto the CABLE CLAMP [14].  Insert the
wires thru the CABLE CLAMP.  Rap with TAPE [08] if necessary to secure wires
in the CABLE CLAMP.
The 8" long jumper from SOCKET #2 should also extend thru the CABLE
CLAMP.
e.
Secure the CABLE CLAMP's MOUNTING PLATE to the SST CUP with two 4-40
SCREWS [11] and LOCTITE.  Tighten the CABLE CLAMP to firmly secure the
Teflon wires.
11.
Separate the wires into two bundles as specified on the assembly drawing, D-157062-000.
Cover each bundle with 3/8" SHRINK TUBING [02] and a SST BRAID [03].  Fold the
end of the SST BRAID over; and, insert another 3" long piece of SHRINK TUBING
under the end to protect the Teflon wires.

12.
Connect the 6" jumper from the shielded conductors and 8" jumper from SOCKET #2 to
the SST BRAID by rapping with 24 gage buss wire and covering with HIGH
TEMPERATURE SOLDER.  Cover this connection with two pieces of SHRINK
TUBING.
13.
Final inspection: Check continuity and insulation.
14.
This completes the 1668 BA CABLE ASSEMBLY.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG
chunk_text:
9
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668 BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG

4" CRYSTAL TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY
1.
Refer to the assembly drawing [B-153291-000] and parts list for the 4" CRYSTAL
TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY.
2.
Two CRYSTAL TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLIES are required per 1668 BA
TRANSMITTER MANDREL.
3.
Trial assemble the two end PLATES [04], INSULATOR [02], SPOOL [11], and the NUT
[10] together.  Trial fit this assembly into the P-WAVE ACOUSTIC WINDOW [B-
157055-000].  It should slip easily into the bore and slide freely.  If no problems are
evident, continue the assembly.
4.
Carefully unpack the TRANSMITTER CRYSTALS [03].  Two CRYSTALS are required
for each CRYSTAL TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY.  The CRYSTALS are supplied with
two 10" leads attached to the inside and outside silver coated surfaces and have stress-
wrapping on the outside.
WARNING
THE CRYSTALS ARE FRAGILE AND CAN DEVELOP A LARGE
ELECTRICAL CHARGE.
5.
Assemble two CRYSTALS together end-to-end with the center SPACER [08] between
them and with the lead wires exiting to opposite outward ends.  Slide the CRYSTALS
over the Teflon INSULATOR [02]; and, align the inside leads of the CRYSTALS with the
flats on the INSULATOR for clearance.  Add an end SPACER [07] on each end of the
crystal assembly.  Align the slots on the end SPACERS with the outside wires.
6.
Turn the Crystals as required to align the inside and outside lead wires to each other and
the flats on the INSULATOR.  With masking tape, temporarily secure these parts
together.
7.
On the left-hand end, loop the outside lead wire over and around the left end SPACER
and insert it thru the CRYSTALS in the space formed by the flat on the INSULATOR.
Also loop the inside lead wire back thru the CRYSTALS by forming a 180 E bend.  At this
point, all the leads should exit the right-hand end.
8.
On the right-hand end, loop the outside lead wire over the right end SPACER and bend
into an "s" form as shown.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG
chunk_text:
10
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668 BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG

4" CRYSTAL TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY (CONTINUED)
9.
Insert the SPOOL [11] through one end PLATE [04] from the counterbored side, i.e.
opposite the slotted side.  Insert the end PLATE and SPOOL assembly through the
INSULATOR [02] from the right-hand side.  Turn the end PLATE so that the .278" dia.
hole is aligned with the inside leads and the .313" wide slot is aligned with the outside
leads.  Carefully guide the inside leads thru the .278" hole and the outside leads thru the
.190" hole in the end PLATE.  Cake care not damage the leads.  Gently push the end
PLATE and SPOOL to bottom against the INSULATOR and SPACER.
10.
Install the left end PLATE [04] onto the threaded end of the SPOOL [11] with the
counterbore facing outward.  Align the .313 wide slot with the outside lead so that the
wire does not get pinched.  Install the NUT [10] onto the SPOOL; but, only hand tighten.
11.
Remove all the temporary masking tapes from the CRYSTALS and SPACERS.  Check all
the lead wires to make sure they are not pinched.  Check the CRYSTAL TRANSMITTER
ASSEMBLY to make sure that all of the parts are properly aligned and positioned.
Tighten the NUT [10] on the SPOOL [11] to approximately 15 lb-ft torque.  Apply
LOCTITE [12] to the NUT/SPOOL thread.
12.
On the right end of the CRYSTAL TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY, install the four
STANDOFF TERMINALS [06], each with one drop of LOCTITE.  Cut off the excess
length of the lead wires and strip the insulation 3/16" from the ends with a THERMAL
STRIPPER [226804].  Bend a service loop in the DIODE [05] and cover with SHRINK
TUBING.  Install the lead wires and the DIODE to the STANDOFF TERMINALS using
HI-TEMP SOLDER [13].  The DIODE should be suspended between two terminals for
maximum electrical isolation.
13.
Double check the DIODE orientation.
NOTE
As assembled, the CRYSTAL TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY should be resonant
around 14 KHz.  A function generator or gain/phase analyzer may be used to
check the resonant frequency.
14.
This completes the 4" CRYSTAL TRANSMITTER ASSEMBLY.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG
chunk_text:
11
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668 BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG 12
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668 BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG

1668 BA TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY
1.
Refer to the assembly drawing [B-157061-000] and parts list for the 1668 BA
TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY.
2.
One TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY is required per 1668 BA TRANSMITTER
MANDREL.
NOTE
Assemble the TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY without the COVER
CHANNEL [04] to facilitate wiring at the next assembly level.
3.
Insert the three RUBBER GROMMETS [14] into the TRANSFORMER MOUNTING
CHANNEL [02].
4.
Note that the orientation of the TRANSFORMER MOUNTING CHANNEL [02] and
CHANNEL COVER [14] are indicated by matching chamfers.  Reference the position of
the chamfers during assembly
5.
Install fifteen ceramic INSULATED TERMINALS [07] into the TRANSFORMER
MOUNTING CHANNEL [02].  Thirteen of the TERMINALS are secured with #4 LOCK
WASHERS [08].  Two INSULATED TERMINALS, TP8 & TP13, are secured with
TERMINAL LUGS [19].  Note the orientation of these TERMINAL LUGS on the
assembly drawing.  Four of the thread holes on the TRANSFORMER MOUNTING
CHANNEL remain empty.
6.
Double check that the INSULATED TERMINALS have not been damaged.  The
TERMINALS are ceramic and may be easily cracked and loosened.
7.
Install each of the two HTC X1778 B TRANSFORMER ASSEMBLIES [10] into the
TRANSFORMER MOUNTING CHANNEL with two 1/4" long 4-40 SCREWS [11] and
LOCTITE [09].  Note that the orientation of these TRANSFORMER ASSEMBLIES is
indicated by the brown wire on the assembly drawing.  Screw two more 1/4" long 4-40
SCREWS into the top of each of the TRANSFORMER ASSEMBLIES for temporary
storage.
8.
Install the HTC X1112 C TRANSFORMERS [12] into the TRANSFORMER MOUNTING
CHANNEL with 1.5" long 10-32 BRASS SCREWS [13] and LOCTITE.  Note that the
orientation of these TRANSFORMERS is indicated by the brown wire on the assembly
drawing.  Do not over tighten.  The HTC X1112 C TRANSFORMERS are fragile and
may be crushed.
9.
Install a 1 MEG RESISTOR [17], covered with SHRINK TUBING [16], between
terminals TP4--TP6 and TP11--TP14.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG
chunk_text:
13
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES -- 1668 BA MULTIPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG

1668 BA TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY (CONTINUED)
10.
Install a .47 MF CAPACITOR [18] between terminals TP4--TP5 and TP14--TP15.  These
CAPACITORS should be rapped with enough SILICON TAPE [20] to trap them between
the HTC X1778 B TRANSFORMER ASSEMBLIES and the COVER CHANNEL to
prevent vibration.
11.
Install the TRANSFORMER PLUG [03] onto the TRANSFORMER MOUNTING
CHANNEL with two 3/8" long 10-32 BUTTON HEAD SCREWS [15] and LOCTITE
[P/N  244147-000].
12.
The six remaining 3/8" long 10-32 BUTTON HEAD SCREWS will be used to install the
CHANNEL COVER at the next assembly level where the TRANSFORMER CHANNEL
ASSEMBLY is secured to the UPPER TRANS-FORMER ADAPTOR [01] and wired to
the acoustic transmitters.
13.
The O-Rings [05 & 06] will be installed at the next assembly level.
14.
This completes the 1668 BA TRANSFORMER CHANNEL ASSEMBLY.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 3.1 SPECIAL EXPENDABLE MATERIALS REQUIRED . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 4.0 INSTRUMENT DISASSEMBLY . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
SPECIAL EXPENDABLE MATERIALS REQUIRED
235218-000 Strapping Buckles .25 Wd Band-It Type 201
235219-000 Strapping Band .25 Wd Band-It Type 201
259260-xxx Assorted O-Rings 90-Durometer (As Required)

259261-xxx Assorted O-Rings 70-Durometer (As Required)
157054-000 Rubber Boot (Qty 1x)
160467-100 Socket Connectors 031-9174-004 (Qty 40x)
203208-000 Silicon Oil Dow-Corning 200-100cs 

INSTRUMENT DISASSEMBLY
1.
Refer to the assembly/disassembly procedures in this manual, section 130475-955, for step
by step instructions.  Refer to the disassembly procedures and special instructions in this
section.
2.
Drain and discard the SILICON OIL.
3.
Disassemble the 1668 BA Transmitter Mandrel down to the sub-assembly level.  Clean all
components as necessary during the disassembly to return them to an as-new condition.
4.
Remove and discard all O-Rings.
5.
Remove and discard any damaged screws.  Note that the FLAT HEAD SCREWS, Item 18,
used on the MAC Transmitter are special, high strength screws.  Do not replace with
standard, off-the-shelf screws.

PRELIMINARY INSPECTION
1.
Inspect all mechanical parts for damage, wear, or corrosion.  Closely inspect all O-Rings
gland surfaces and threads.  Replace any parts with damaged or corroded gland surfaces or
threads.
2.
Inspect the PRESSURE BULKHEADS, Items 14 & 26, for cracks or chips in the pin
insulation, bent or burnt pins, scared O-Ring glands, and any other damage.  Check for
electrical leakage.
3.
Inspect the RUBBER BOOT, Item 20, for any damage such as cracking or hardening.
Replacement on a regular basis is suggested.
4.
Inspect the fiberglass acoustic WINDOWS, Items 07 & 32, for any damage such as cracking
or delamination.

INSTRUMENT ASSEMBLY
1.
Refer to the assembly/disassembly procedures in this manual, section 130475-955, for step
by step assembly instructions.
2.
Perform the in-process inspection, section 8.0, during the assembly process and before the
installation of the Transformer Channel Assembly, P/N 157061-000.
3.
Replace all O-Rings.
4.
Replace any damaged screws.
5.
Refill with fresh SILICON OIL.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 7.0 TEST EQUIPMENT FOR 1668BA INSPECTION . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
TEST EQUIPMENT FOR 1668 BA INSPECTION
1.
Multimeter (Fluke 8020 DVM) or equivalent
2.
500 Volt Megger
3.
In-Process Inspection Equipment
a.
Function Generator
4.
Operational Check with Acoustic Test Box
a.
2061 AC Power Control Panel
b.
286 or 386 Computer with MS-DOS
c.
Digital Acoustic Test Box, P/N 157035-000
d.
Shearbox Software
e.
1668 FA Electronics
5.
Operational Check with 1668 Tool String
a.
CLS-K or ECLIPS Logging System
b.
3510 XA Common Remote Electronics
c.
1667 EA Acoustic A-D Electronics
d.
1668 MA Receiver Mandrel
e.
1668 FA Transmitter Electronics
f.
WTS 32-Conductor Jumper

IN-PROCESS INSPECTION OF THE ACOUSTIC TRANSMITTERS
NOTE:
The following inspection should be performed during the assembly process and
before the installation of the Transformer Channel Assembly, P/N 157061-000.
1.
Refer to assembly drawing [R-156905-000], parts list, and wiring diagram [D-156905-100]
for the 1668 BA Transmitter Mandrel Assembly.
2.
Before installing the Transformer Channel Assembly (Item 22) perform the following checks.
3.
For the Monopole Transmitters 1 and 2, Item 06:
C
Use a 25 volt sinusoidal function generator to excite the piezoelectric cylinders.  Sweep
the frequency range from 1000 to 20,000 Hz.
C
The frequency response of the monopole transmitters will have only one strong
resonance in this range.  This primary resonant mode of the monopole transmitters will
be between 13,900 Hz and 16,430 Hz.  You should be able to hear a distinct peak in
the amplitude.
4.
For the mounted Dipole Transmitters 3 and 4, Item 23:
C
Use a 25 volt sinusoidal function generator to excite the piezoelectric Bender Plates.
Sweep the frequency range from 100 to 5,000 Hz.
C
The frequency response of the dipole transmitters will have only one strong resonance
in this range.  This primary resonant mode of the dipole transmitters will be between
900 Hz and 1300 Hz.  You should be able to hear a distinct peak in the amplitude.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 9.0 CONTINUITY AND RESISTANCE CHECKS . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
CONTINUITY AND RESISTANCE CHECKS
Refer to the Transmitter Mandrel Assembly drawing [R-156905-000] and Wiring Schematic
[D-156905-100].

CONTINUITY CHECKS
Using a Multimeter, check the WTS thru wiring for continuity (#.5 S).  Check continuity from
Upper 32-Pin Block Assembly (Item 30) to Lower 32-Pin Bulkhead (Item 14), as shown.

RESISTANCE CHECKS
1.
Set MEGGER to 500 Volts.  At the uphole connector (Item 30), check for leakage to mass on
all of the WTS thur conductors, except conductor #2 which is grounded to mass.  Insulation
must be $300 MS at room temperature.
2.
Set MEGGER to 500 Volts.  At the uphole connector (Item 30), check for leakage between any
of the WTS thur conductors.  Insulation must be $300 MS at room temperature.
CAUTION:
DO NOT USE THE HIGH VOLTAGE MEGGER ON THE TRANSDUCER WIRES
(i.e., CONDUCTORS 18, 19, 20, 21, and 22).

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 10.0 OPERATIONAL CHECKOUT SETUP WITH TEST BOX . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
OPERATIONAL CHECKOUT SETUP WITH TEST BOX
1.
Connect the 1668 FA Transmitter Electronics, P/N 130492-000, to the bottom of a 1668 BA
Transmitter Mandrel, P/N 130475-000, as shown in Figure 2.  Connect either the Digital
Acoustic Test Box or the entire 1668 MAC Tool String to exercise the transmitter mandrel.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 10.1 TRANSMITTER OPERATIONAL CHECK . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
10.1 TRANSMITTER OPERATIONAL CHECK 9

TRANSMITTER OPERATIONAL CHECK
1.
Turn ON the Digital Acoustic Test Box.
2.
With AC power supply, set the tool head voltage at 180 VAC.  Check the AC voltage at the
tool head with a multimeter.
3.
Run the SHEARBOX program.
4.
Under the main menu, press 4, to select and fire 1 on P-Wave Transmitter.  Press 8 to
continuously fire the selected transmitter.  The downhole monopole transmitter should fire
repeatedly.  A short, audibly 12 KHz pulse will be generated from this transmitter.  Press ESC
to return to the main menu.
5.
Under the main menu, press 5, to select and fire 2 on P-wave.  Press 8 to continuously fire the
selected transmitter.  The uphole monopole transmitter should fire repeatedly.  A short, audibly
12 KHz pulse will be generated from this transmitter.  Press ESC to return to the main menu.
6.
Under the main menu, press 6, to select and fire 1 on S-wave.  Press 8 to continuously fire the
selected transmitter.  The downhole dipole transmitter should fire repeatedly.  A short, audibly
1 KHz pulse will be generated from this transmitter.  Press ESC to return to the main menu.
7.
Under the main menu, press 7, to select and fire 2 on S-wave.  Press 8 to continuously fire the
selected transmitter.  The uphole dipole transmitter should fire repeatedly.  A short, audibly 1
KHz pulse will be generated from this transmitter.  Press ESC to return to the main menu.
8.
Power down the instrument.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 11.0 CHECKOUT LIST PROCEDURE . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
CHECKOUT LIST PROCEDURE
1.
The technician performing the checkout shall print their Name in the space provided on the
following Checkout List.
2.
Fill in the Date and Location that the checkout was performed.
3.
Fill in the Asset # of the instrument.
4.
Complete the following Checkout List.
5.
The completed checkout list shall be included in the instrument history folder.

LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE -- 1668 BA MULITPOLE ARRAY ACOUSTILOG
CAUTION:
DO NOT CONNECT 1668 FA TRANSMITTER ELECTRONICS DIRECTLY TO
1668 MA RECEIVER MANDREL, 1667 EA COMMON REMOTE, OR DIGITAL
ACOUSTIC TEST BOX.  SEVERE DAMAGE TO THE UNITS WILL RESULT.
2.
Setup the Digital Acoustic Test Box, P/N 157035-000, and PC as follows:
a.
Connect Parallel Port Cable to P-1 of Test Box and to the Parallel Port, LPT1, of the PC.
b.
Connect Cable Assembly from P-2 of Test Box to top of Transmitter Mandrel.
c.
Connect DH Power Cable from J-2 of Test Box to Power Control Panel.
d.
Plug in the Test Box power cord to 110 VAC 60 Hz power source.
e.
Load Shearbox software into the PC.
f.
The MAC test program may be executed by typing:   Shearbox<enter>
A test menu will appear on screen.

1
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE - 1671 EB/MB CBIL
                                                                                                                                 
      CBIL  is a service mark of the Western Atlas Logging
1
SM
Services, A Division of Western Atlas International, Inc.
                                                                                                                                 
INTRODUCTION
The Circumferential Borehole Imaging Log (CBIL
)  is an acoustic device designed to produce detailed
SM 1
images of the wellbore wall (or casing).  The CBIL pulse-echo transducer emits a high frequency
acoustic pulse and measures the amplitude and the time of flight of the reflected wave.  The amplitude
of the reflected wave is affected by variations in the borehole surface.  The travel time is indicative of
the distance from the transducer to the wellbore wall.  The acoustic transducer is mounted on a rotating
section, allowing the CBIL to scan the full 360 degrees of the wellbore producing two images or maps.
The Reflectance Amplitude image will show borehole surface features.  Highly reflective formation
features are represented as white, while less reflective features are represented as black.  All values
between the extremes are assigned a shade of gray, varying proportionally to the value of the measured
property. This map is especially useful for detection of such low reflective features as fractures.  The
reflectance amplitude is affected by mud attenuation, tool eccentering and borehole rugosity.
The travel time image is a sensitive measurement of borehole ellipticity, rugosity, and tool position. 
Combined with the mud slowness measurement, the time of flight data can be used to produce an
accurate measurement of the borehole radius.  The shade of gray assigned to the travel time value is
proportional to the distance the tool is from the wellbore wall, where darker shades are indicative of an
enlarged borehole.  This measurement is affected by mud slowness, tool eccentering and borehole
rugosity.
DCBIL system applications include:
• Orientation and depth matching of whole cores.
• Detection and measurement of fractures, vugs, and washouts.
• Determination of bedding planes and fracture orientations.
• Determination of detailed borehole geometry with high-resolution acoustic caliper      
  data. 
• Determination of sand/shale distributions in thinly bedded intervals.
• Location and evaluation of internal casing corrosion, mechanical wear, defects, and    
perforations.
• Dip Determination

topic: Mechanical Description - MECHANICAL DESCRIPTION - 1671EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG 1.0 INTRODUCTION
chunk_text:
1
MECHANICAL DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG 
INTRODUCTION
The Digital CBIL instrument is configured in two sections, separated by a field joint:
•
1671 EB Electronics Cartridge
(Reference drawing R182480-000)
•

1671 EB
The 1671 EB contains the power supply and flask sub-assembly, with digital electronics.

1671 MB
The 1671 MB is configured from three main sub-assemblies, bottom to top:
•
Rotating Section
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
•
Mud Sub
(Reference drawing D182468-000)
•
MB Electronics Section
(Reference drawing R182461-000)

ROTATING SECTION
The rotating section contains the motor, gearbox, rotary transformers, imaging transducer, and
magnetometer sub-assemblies.  This section of the instrument is oil filled and pressure compensated.
The motor/gear box assembly contains an AC induction motor and a double reduction gearbox.
Magnetic pickup units are used in the gearbox to provide speed and tool orientation information.
Power from the gear-box is transmitted through an offset shaft to the rotating transducer assembly.
The rotating assembly consists of four rotary transformers, two transducers, and a magnetometer
mounted on a tube shaft.  This shaft is supported at each end by Vespel sleeve bearings.  The four rotor
cores of the transformers carry the signals from the rotating transducers and magnetometer back to the
fixed portion of the transformers (stators).  Transducers transmit acoustic energy that is reflected off the
borehole wall and received by the same transducer.  The magnetometer is mounted on the lower end of
transducer unit and provides compass orientation data that is used with the signal received by the
transducers.
Volume/pressure compensation is provided by an oil filled bellows at the bottom of rotating
mechanism.  A groove on the bellows housing provides a reference mark showing the tool is full at
room temperature.  Oil filling ports are mounted in the bellows and in the mud sub-assembly.

topic: Mechanical Description - MECHANICAL DESCRIPTION - 1671EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG 3.2 MUD SUB
chunk_text:
2
MECHANICAL DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG 
MUD SUB
(Reference drawing D182468-000)
The mud sub performs several tasks in the Digital CBIL instrument:
•
Mud slowness measurement
•
Mechanical crossover
•
Electrical connection and pressure isolation
•
Mounting for magnetometer tuning capacitors
a)
Mud Slowness
The mud slowness is measured in a mud channel across which a transducer is pulsed.  The
spacing of the channel is adjusted by installing or removing an auxiliary target.
b)
Crossover
The mud sub acts as a mechanical crossover between the rotating section (3-5/8") and the MA
electronics (3-3/8").
c)
Electrical Connection/Pressure Isolation
A bulkhead at the top of the mud sub provides electrical feedthroughs and pressure isolation
between the lower and upper sections of the mandrel assembly.
d)
Magnetometer Capacitors
The space immediately above the pressure bulkhead is utilized to mount a PCB upon which the
magnetometer tuning capacitors are mounted.

MB ELECTRONICS SECTION
(Reference drawing R182461-000)
The MB electronics section contains the motor start capacitor, transformers, and PCB sub-assemblies.

SAFETY PRECAUTIONS (LABORATORY) - 1671 EB/MB CBIL

1671 EB DCBIL TOOL HANDLING
-
Thread protectors are always installed when transporting the instrument; to aid in securing or
handling the tool.
-
The flasked electronics assembly are always supported when removed from the flask.
WARNING
THE THERMAL ISOLATOR WILL NOT SUPPORT WEIGHT OF
FLASKED ELECTRONICS. 
HIGH VOLTAGES
When the instrument is powered-up outside of the housing care  is taken to avoid a HIGH VOLTAGE
shock from the following points (Reference drawing R182481-000).
Q1 AND Q2
-
Cases (collectors) of these transistors have switching voltage of 300
Vdc.
Q3 & Q4
-
Case (collector) of transistor has approximately 150 Vdc.
D1
-
Diode D1 has approximately 155 Vdc on the cathode.
TERM
-
The terminals on the side of the AC transformer shelf have 180 Vac on
one shelf and 190 Vdc on the other shelf.

2
SAFETY PRECAUTIONS (LABORATORY) - 1671 EB/MB CBIL

1671 MB DCBIL TOOL HANDLING
1.
Thread protectors are always be installed with the cover sleeve protecting the rotating section
when transporting the instrument to aid in securing or handling the tool.
2.
Care must be taken when lifting the rotating section to ensure no damage is done either to the
rotating transducers or rotary transformers.

HIGH VOLTAGES
When the instrument is powered-up outside of the housing care must be taken to avoid HIGH
VOLTAGE shock from the following points (Reference drawing R182461-101, and B182470-
000) on the transmitter board.
Chassis Reference drawing  R182461-101.
Terminals located on the half-moon shelves supporting
the AC transformers (T1 and T2) have 180 Vac on one
side and terminals located on the half moon shelves
supporting the motor cap (C1) have 115 Vac.
Firing Circuit Reference drawing B182470-000.
P7 Pin 19, P7 Pin 20 have approximately 100 Vac
across them.
D8 has approximately 100 Vac on one side and
approximately 220 Vdc on the other side to ground.
D9 has approximately 100 Vac on  the cathode side.
The node from C24 to C29 will have approximately
220 Vdc across them.
From the source of Q1 to ground will have 180 Vdc.
R8 and C9 will have 180 Vdc across them.  T1, T2,
and T3 pin 1 to AGND (P7 pin 2) will have 180 Vdc.
D1 will have approximately 181 Vdc across it.

The output of IC3 is controlled by (internal) tristate gates.  The converted digital value is passed from
IC3 to the FIFO (IC4) by the falling edge of CLK (IC3 pin 1).
The flash converter IC3 requires a 0.0 to +5 V unipolar signal.  This requires that the ±2.5 volt bipolar
signal from the PHA Board be level shifted by +2.5 volts.  This is accomplished by adding +2.5 Vdc
from pin 22 of the flash converter chip to the signal at the positive input of IC1.  The +2.5 Vdc is
jumpered to point A.

INTRODUCTION 3

INTRODUCTION
The 1671 EB and MB Electronics includes the following assemblies:

A block diagram of these assemblies is shown in Figure 945-1.  A circuit description of each of these
assemblies is given in the following sections.

POWER SUPPLY 3
2.0  DC POWER SUPPLY
(Reference drawings 182481-000 and 182481-100)
The 1671 EB Electronics houses the ±15 and +5 Volt dc power supplies for the EB and MB
electronics.
Transformer T2 steps down the 180 Vrms from conductors 1 and 4 to about 150 Vrms.  This voltage is
full-wave rectified by BR01 and filtered by C9, C10, C11, C12, R6, R7, and L1.  With all PC boards
in the EB connected, and no MB attached, the voltage across C10 will measure about 155 Vdc.  This
voltage is applied to the 160 V Regulator circuit through protector diode D10.  The regulator circuit
maintains it output voltage between 150 and 160 Vdc.  This voltage provides an imbalance bias voltage
through R4 to turn on Q1 and start the required oscillation in the primary of T1.
Transformer T1's top secondary circuit provides about ±27.5 Vdc to the ±15 Vdc regulators, IC2 and
IC3.  The bottom secondary circuit of T1 provides about 15 Vdc to the input of the +5 Vdc regulator
IC1.  The output of the IC regulators should be within 1% of their nominal output voltage.  The
approximate current supplied by each regulator is -
+15 V -
85 mA dc
-15 V -
110 mA dc
+ 5 V -
115 mA dc
1671 EB
1671 MB
1671 MB

WTS BUS DRIVER 5
%

WTS BUS DRIVER
(Reference drawing B182852-100)
%
The WTS bus driver card serves as the interface to the WTS instrument bus for the 1671 EB.
Commands and data are received (T2 mode) on conductors 27 (CMD+) and 28 (CMD-) of the WTS
instrument bus.  These signals are routed to P1-13 and P1-6 respectively on the WTS bus driver board.
The signals are transformer coupled off the line by T2 and are received through the dual differential line
receiver U2.  This provides a single ended signal (UDI) which is routed to the decoder section of the
6408 Manchester located on the CPU board.  If the 1671 EB is transmitting up T2 mode, the BZO (P1-
2) and BOO (P1-3) outputs of the 6408 Manchester on the CPU board are driven by the dual line driver
U1, and then transformer coupled by T1 onto the WTS instrument bus.  The signals go out on P1-9 and
P1-8 which are tied to conductors 29 and 30 respectively on the WTS instrument bus.
In a T5 mode of transmission the BZO (P1-4) and BOO (P1-5) outputs of the high speed 6409 Harris
Manchester on the CPU board are driven by the dual line driver U3, and then transformer coupled by
T3 onto the WTS instrument bus.  The signals are taken off the line driver board, through P1-11 and
P1-10, and tied to the instrument bus on conductors 31 and 32 respectively.
In a T7 mode of transmission the BZO (P1-4) and BOO (P1-5) outputs of the high speed 6409 Harris
Manchester on the CPU board are driven by the dual line driver U4, and then transformer coupled by
T4 onto the WTS instrument bus.  The signals are taken off the line driver board, through P1-15 and
P1-16, and tied to the instrument bus on conductors 15 and 16 respectively.
Below is a summary of the modes of transmission supported by the 1671 EB.
T2 -
41.6 kbits/sec (to surface)
Mode T5 -
93.75 kbits/sec (to surface only)
Mode T7 -
93.75 kbits/sec (to surface only)
