COMMUNICATION INTERFACE 10
4.3.1
DECODER SECTION 10
4.3.2

COMMUNICATION INTERFACE
Communication is handled through an interrupt driven system.  Data rate for T2 mode is 20.8 kbits/sec
receiving and 41.6 kbits/sec transmitting.  T5 mode is unidirectional and is only used for transmitting to
the surface at a rate of 93.75 kbits/sec.  T2 mode is controlled by the 6408 Harris Manchester chip
(IC11).  The 6408 is comprised of a Decoder and Encoder section which are described separately
below.  T5 mode transmission is controlled by the Encoder section of the 6409 Harris Manchester chip
(IC12) described in the Encoder Section (Section 6.2).
4.3.1
DECODER SECTION
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG




4.3.1
DECODER SECTION (Cont'd)
A 16 MHz base oscillator (IC28) is divided down by the dual binary counter (IC20) to provide the 250
kHz source clock to the decoder clock input (IC11-5).  Data is received serially through the buffer
protected UDI input of the 6408 (IC11-8) which monitors the data for a valid sync pattern.  Once a
valid sync pattern has been recognized the take data output (TD) (IC11-3) will go high, and if the sync
pattern was that of a command type the command data sync line (CDS) (IC11-10) will also go high.
The falling edge of the take data and command sync lines cause a corresponding interrupt to be
triggered through the flip-flop (IC19 pin 5 and 1).  If the word received was of data type the flip-flop
output (IC19-9) set by take data will be the only interrupt set which is  responded to by the
microcontroller.  If the word received was of command type, then both outputs of the flip-flop (IC19-
9and12) are set and the microcontroller, handling the interrupts on a priority basis, recognizes the word
received as being a command.  The microcontroller responds to a data received interrupt (command or
data type) by reading the word from the parallel outputs of the shift registers (IC14 and IC13).  The
interrupts generated by a word being received are cleared when the reset lines (IC19-6and2) are pulled
low for the duration of the read cycle on the low byte of the word received (stored in IC14).
The valid word output (VW) (IC11-1) is monitored by the microcontroller to indicate the validity of the
word received.
4.3.2
ENCODER SECTION
Timing diagrams for each encoder section can be found in Figures 945-4 and 945-5.  Transmission of
data to the surface system for the 1671 EB is controlled by either the encoder section of the 6408 (T2
mode) or the 6409 (T5 mode) Harris Manchester chips (IC11 and IC12).  The encoder used is
determined by the type of data sent to the surface.  The encoder clock (IC11-23) for T2 mode is selected
(jumper X to Z) to deliver a 500 kHz clock which is derived from the base 16 MHz (IC28) oscillator
being divided down through the dual binary counter (IC20).  The encoder clock for the T5 mode

MHz clock to the input of the encoder of the 6409 (IC12-12).
Enabling of the T2 mode encoder is accomplished by the microcontroller (IC1) setting a control latch
bit (IC27-2) high which is gated with the system reset (IC31-3).  This gating is required in order to keep
the T2 mode encoder disabled until the microcontroller has initialized setups properly upon power-up.
The T5 mode encoder is enabled by pulling a control latch bit (IC27-5) low.  The encoder shift clocks
for both encoder sections (6408 and 6409) are gated together for an output on IC32-11.  When either of
the encoders are enabled, but never both, the bit counter IC17 will be clocked.

I/O BUS

I/O BUS
A universal 20 conductor bus has been established which allows the CPU to access data from peripheral
boards which are tied to this bus.  Below are the bus specifications.
BUS SPECIFICATIONS
-
An I/O control line (IC41-11) enables the decoding logic on each board connected to the
bus.
-
A 4-bit address bus which uses the upper two bits (AD3 and AD2) to decode the particular
board and the lower two bits (AD1 and AD0) to decode the specific device on the addressed
board.
-
An 8-bit data bus which serves as a bi-directional path for data transfer.
-
A conversion clock is available for the A/D modules connected to the bus, but it is only
active during an acquisition cycle.
-
The remainder of the bus is made up of the power supplies and grounds which consist of the
following: +15 V, -15 V, +5 V, DGND, and AGND.
The 8-bit bi-directional data bus is buffered through an octal transceiver (IC40).  The 4 bit address bus
is buffered by one half of an octal buffer (IC41) with the I/O control line and conversion clock being
buffered in the other half.  The supply voltages and grounds emanate from the power supply external to
the flasked electronics.  This 20 conductor I/O bus is made available to peripheral boards through a bus
distribution board which is connected to the CPU board.

A/D CONTROL 16

A/D CONTROL
Sample rate for A/D modules is programmable from 62.5 kHz to 8 MHz and the number of samples
which are to be accumulated is programmable from 1-4095 samples.  The variable sample rate is
achieved by dividing a base clock (IC28) of 16 MHz down (with cascaded binary counters IC25 and
IC26) with a value which is stored in a latch (IC21).  Due to timing synchronization the base clock
frequency is always divided down by one more than the value stored in the latch (IC21).  The relative
timing for the variable conversion clock is shown in Figure 945-6 on the following page.

SERIAL COMMUNICATIONS
The CPU board has two serial communication interfaces with external peripheral devices.  Both use
three lines which control the transfer of data.  The 1671 EB uses one of these serial links for the control
of transmitter, receiver, and gain selections in the mandrel.  These lines are summarized below.
DATA TRANSFER LINES
-
R/W -
(IC1-47 P1.6) Controls direction of data transfer i.e. (send or receive).
-
DATA -
Serial data transmission line.
(IC1-48 P1.5) Provides serial data out.
(IC1-6 P0.3) Receives serial data.
-
CLOCK - (IC1-55 P1.4) Clocks data into and out of remote serial devices at approximately
100 kHz.  Data is shifted on the rising edge.

CBIL CONNECTOR BOARD
(Reference drawing C154442-100 )
This board serves as a distribution center for the I/O Bus as well as a channel for signals coming in and
going out of the flasked electronics.  Three I/O Bus inlets are available through CJ1, CJ3, and CJ4
which allow peripheral devices to be tied to the 20 conductor I/O Bus.  Power supplies, grounds,
communications, and other signals which must extend outside the flasked electronics are routed through
CJ1.  The CPU board has access to the distribution board through CJ3 and CJ4.

PULSE HEIGHT ANALYZER (PHA)
(Reference Drawing C182471-000)
The PHA printed circuit assembly includes the following four circuits:
Gain Control
Peak Detector and A/D Converter
First Arrival Detector
Logic/Control.
These circuits facilitate the measurement of the ultrasonic transducers pulse-echo amplitude and arrival
time.  The pulse-echo signal enters the PHA Board on P3-2 from the Transmitter Board.
Gain Control of the pulse-echo signal is accomplished with U1,U2,U3,U4,U5,U12,U14 and their
associated passive components. U12 provides the required gain control codes.  U3 and U4 are
noninverting, amplifiers stages with a fixed gain of 16.  U1, U2, and RN01 form a varialbe gain stage
with gain step listed below:

&&&&&&&

FLASH CONVERTER
(Reference drawing 148682-100)
The Flash Converter is high speed 8 bit A/D.  In this application, the input signals are the pulse-echo
signals from the Rotating Section's ultrasonic transducers.  There are five circuits that compose this
assembly:
. Clock/Reset control
. Flash Converter
. Data Store
. Decoder
. Level shifting.
Clock/Reset control: IC5 receives the A/D clock signal from the PHA board and provides the inverted
value to the CLK input of IC3.  Jumper options are provided to connect pins 12 and 13 together, or to
allow for external control.  In the 1671 CBIL these pins are NOT connected as seperate A/D CLOCK
and A/D ENABLE signals are used.
Pin 2 of IC5 receives the Reset (eg, reset IC3) command from IC7 and provides adequate timing delay
(approximately 15 n seconds) to cause Write to remain high for the required period after Reset (bar RS,
pin 22 of IC4) goes high.
Flash Convert Sequence: A/D CLOCK is input from the PHA board to IC 5-12 during every positive
MSYNC cycle.These 31 n second, positive A/D CLOCK pulses are 0.25  seconds apart (as selected in
the EDIT TABLE).  A/D CLK ENABLE (IC 5-13) is high during one of these MSYNC cycles, as
selected in the CBIL EDIT TABLE as SIGNATURE NUMBER (element number 11).This enables the
A/D CLK pulses at IC 5-12 to pass through IC5-11 to become the CLK for FLASH CONVERTER IC3-
1.As long as RESET (IC4-22) is held high, these same pulses also propagate through the remaining
gates of IC5 to become FIFO WRITE at IC4-1.  The falling edge of CLK (IC3-1) puts the digital word
on IC3 outputs where it is written into the FIFO on the falling edge of FIFI WRITE, IC4-1.
Subsequent FIFO READS will place the digital conversions on the data bus.

MAGNETOMETER BOARD
(Reference drawing 148681-000)
The Magnetometer Board accepts the three magnetic sensor signals from the Rotating Section and
provides the following three signals:

MARK  - Tool Body Mark orientation
TREF  - Fire pulse (prompts transducer firing)
NORTH - Compass orientation
The Tool Body Mark magnetic sensor in the Rotating Section generates a 150 mVpp (± 50 mVpp)
signal when the 1.5" rotating transducer rotates past the tool body mark scribe on the outside surface of
the Rotating Section.  This signal is received by the differential amplifier circuit U1.  The diff amp has
a gain of about 60.  The output of the diff amp is compared to the -1.79 Vdc reference threshold by
comparator U4.  The output of U4 goes HIGH, generating the MARK pulse, when the input on pin 5 is
below the -1.79 Vdc threshold.
Signal TREF originates in the Rotating Section.  The signal is produced from a magnetic pickup
transducer activated by an indexed wheel on the rotating shaft.  The wheel has 25 holes and rotates 5
revolutions for each rotation of the imaging transducer platform. With the transducers rotating at
approximately 6 revolutions per second the magnetic transducer pickup will produce an analog signal of
approximately 750 cycles per second (6 rev./sec)(125 cycles/rev) = 750 cycles/sec.
The analog signal from the magnetic pickup is coupled as a differential input.  These two signals TREF
- and TREF + connect to the two inputs of differential amplifier U1 pin 9 and pin 10 through R10 and
R11 respectively.  U1 has a gain of approximately 30.9 which is obtained by resistors R12/R10 and
R13/R11.The output of U1 pin 8 is connected to the inverting input of comparator U4 (pin 10).  The
voltage divider network of R14 and R15 produces a threshold voltage of approximately -.18 volts at the
positive input (pin 9) of U4.  R16 is used for hysteresis.  The output of U4 swings from high (+15
volts) to low (0 volts) when VREF (-.18 volts) exceeds the voltage at the inverting input of U4.  This
produces a square wave signal which is sent through buffer U5 pins 1 and 2.  The combination of the
second and third stage of U5 along with R18,C6, and R19,C7 form a pulse doubler with a pulse width
of approximately 300 s.  This signal is sent to the PHA Board as 2*TREF to initiate firing of the
selected ultrasonic transducer.
The Magnetometer senses magnetic North by use of a flux gate circuit consisting of a coil of wire
wound on a core of saturating, high permability iron alloy.  It detects the intensity of the component of
the earth's magnetic field parallel to the axis of the core.

TRANSMITTER ELECTRONICS
(Reference drawing C182470-100)
WARNING
*DANGEROUS VOLTAGE LEVEL*  ASSEMBLY P/N 182470-000 HAS HIGH
VOLTAGE THAT CAN CAUSE SERIOUS INJURY.  THERE IS BOTH 100 VAC,

CPU SPECIFICATIONS (Cont'd)
The CPU board is responsible for the control of data acquisition, downhole data analysis, and
communication control with the surface system.  There are several paths through which the CPU board
has access to its various data and support circuitry.
These system paths can be divided up into the following functional blocks:  Memory Map,
Communication Interface, I/O BUS, A/D Control, and Serial Communications.  Each of these paths are
described separately in the following sections.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG
chunk_text:
13
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG






4.3.2
ENCODER SECTION (Cont'd)
The remainder of the encoder section description applies to either mode of transmission (T2 or T5).
Before the encoder is enabled for a data transmission the buffered parallel to serial shift registers (IC16
and IC15) are loaded with the first two words (16 BIT) to send to the surface.  The shift registers have a
buffered latched input which allows the word being sent as well as the word following to be loaded.  A
control latch bit (IC27-9) must be set low when the first word is loaded into the shift registers (IC16
and IC15) to allow the word to be transferred to the output latches of the shift register.  The control
latch bit is then set high and the second word is loaded into the input buffer of the shift registers.  This
preloading of the output latches is only necessary for the first word sent as the remainder of the words
are automatically loaded into the output latches through hardware timing described below.
When the encoder is disabled the output of gate IC32-3 holds the bit counter (IC17) in a load mode and
the word boundary indicator (IC18) in a reset mode.  Enabling the encoder causes the bit counter to be
incremented by the gated encoder shift clock (IC32-11).  When the 16th bit has been clocked the falling
edge of the bit counter (IC17-7) causes the word boundary indicator (IC18-8) to go low which causes
the following events to occur.
-
A low output on the word boundary indicator (IC18-8) results in a low level output on IC31-
11 which loads in the next word from the input to output buffers on IC16 and IC15.
-
An encoder interrupt is generated as a result of the word boundary indicator (falling edge of
IC18-8) causing a high level on IC18-12 which is recognized on the NMI (IC1-7) input of
the microcontroller.  This interrupt prompts the microcontroller to load the next word of the
transmission block into the input  buffers of the shift registers (IC16 and IC15).  When the
low byte of the word is loaded (Write to IC16-12) the encoder interrupt (IC18-12) is
disabled by the reset line (IC18-2) being pulled low for the duration of the write cycle.
-
The low output of the word boundary indicator (IC18-8) also resets itself and the bit counter
by pulling its reset line (IC18-6) and the bit counters load line (IC17-11) low which sets
them both back to their reset conditions.  The bit counter is reloaded with a value of zero
before the shifting of the next word.
The above process is carried out for each word transmitted to the surface until the last word of the data
block is transmitted.  With the utilization of the double buffering in the shift registers (IC16 and IC15),
it is necessary to write one more word than is actually sent, in order to actuate the loading of the last
word in the data block from the input to output buffers of the shift registers.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG
chunk_text:
16
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG 17
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG

A/D CONTROL (Cont'd)
Once the cascaded counters (IC25 and IC26) have decremented down to zero from the value stored in
the latch, a borrow is generated (IC26-13) which clocks flip-flop IC30.  The high out on IC30-12 is the
high period of the conversion clock and is gated with the base 16 MHz clock to allow a 31.25 ns high
pulse before resetting IC30.  At the same time IC30-13 is low, which reloads the cascaded counters
(IC25 and IC26) with their original count value to start the process over.  This process goes on
continually with the high state of the continuous clock IC30-12 at a fixed period of 31.25 ns but the low
state will vary based on the sample rate.  This non-symmetrical duty cycle was necessary to meet A/D
module set up specifications.  The continuous conversion clock IC30-12 is present at the
synchronization flip-flop IC29-5 so as soon as a source fire sync (IC29-1) has been issued by the
microcontroller (IC1-46) to initiate the start of an acquisition cycle, the conversion clock will be
enabled (IC29-9) at the same time.  This rising edge fire sync (IC29-9) is sent to the mandrel to fire the
transmitter as well as enable the A/D converter clock (IC31-8).  The fire sync is routed through a level
translator (IC6-3) where it is sent to the mandrel at a 15 V level (IC6-4).
Once the converter clock is enabled (IC31-8) it decrements the sample counters (cascaded binary
counters IC22, IC23, IC24)  which when decremented to zero (end of sample accumulation) causes a
borrow (IC24-13) which disables the A/D conversion clock.  These sample counters are loaded up with
the number of samples to accumulate (1 to 4095) prior to each transmitter firing (acquisition cycle).
The converter clock is buffered by IC41 where it is available on the I/O bus.

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG

SERIAL COMMUNICATIONS (Cont'd)
All of the above lines are routed through a level translator (IC6) to step the signals up to +15 V going
out of the CPU board.  Incoming serial data is routed through a step down translator (IC39) with the
serial R/W line controlling the ENABLE pin of IC39 pin 2.  Read (high) enables IC39.IC 6 is always
enabled via pin 2 being tied to Vcc.  A set up sequence is executed before each acquisition, which
consist of setting the correct receiver, transmitter, and gain selections.
The other serial interface is not currently used by the 1671 EB but is available and is summarized below.
SERIAL INTERFACE
-
CMD    -
(IC1-57 P1.2) This line serves as a command control or R/W line.
-
DATA  -
(IC1-58 P1.1) This is a bi-directional serial data transmission line.
-
CLOCK - (IC1-59 P1.0) Clocks serial data into or out of remote serial devices at
approximately 100 kHz.

PULSE HEIGHT ANALYZER (Cont'd)
The outputs of U1, U3 and U4 are inputs to U5.  By controlling the address code of U5, the output at
U5 pin 8 is connected to either U1, U3 or U4.  Note that the same code is present at pins 5 and 4 of
U14.  U14 is used to connect\disconnect the outputs of the individual gain stages to minimize the
crosstalk at the input pins of U5.
U5 and U14 provide 24, 3 dB (X1.414) gain steps.  For example, for a voltage gain of 2895, the gain of
U1 is set to 11.31 and the code at U5 is set to select the output from U4.  U14 switches to connect U1,
U3 and U4.  Sinc U3 and U4 provide fixed gains of 16, the net gain at pin 8 of U5 is 11.31*16*16
2895 = 69 dB.  U5 also provides attenuation through R38, R39, R40, R41, and R42.
The following is a summary of the ways in which pin 8 of U5 can be connected:
A2  A1  A0
Connection
0
0

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG
chunk_text:
22
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG

PULSE HEIGHT ANALYZER (Cont'd)
Integrated circuits U6,U7 and U8 make up the Peak Detector circuit.  This circuit detects and holds the
positive peak value of the pulse-echo signal from U5 pin 8.  When pin 15 of IC switch U6 is high, the
circuit is in peak detect mode.  Capacitor C23 is allowed to charge to the positive peak value of the
output of U7 through D2.  The positive peak value is held by C23 and applied to the 12 bit A/D
Converter U9 through buffer U8 and input protection diodes D4 and D5.  The first A/D read, HBEN
"LOW", puts the low byte on the bus.  The second read, HBEN "HIGH", put the four higher order bits
on the bus.  When U6 pin 15 is low the circuit is in reset mode, C23 discharges through U6 pins 3 and
4 and D9 making the circuit ready to accept the next peak value.
Integrated circuits U10 and U11 make up the First Arrival Detector.  U10 is used as a buffer. The
input signal to the comparator is compared to the threshold voltage developed by U12.  This threshold
varies from .2 to 3.1 Vdc.  When the first arrival of the pulse-echo signal is detected, the output of the
comparator goes HIGH.  This stops the 10 MHz, 16 bit counter in U12.  The value of the counter then
represents the elapsed time from transducer firing to the first arrival of the pulse-echo signal.
The portion of the pulse echo signal developed across R12 is sent to the input of the Flash Converter
Board, P/N 148682-000.
General Logic\Control: Integrated circuit U12 is an ACTEL `Logic Cell Gate Array' that provides
general control of the other networks.  U15 is a 10 MHz crystal oscillator.
U12 interfaces with the CPU Board via the 8-bit data bus and the control line MSYNC.  U12 includes
the following logic :
. 16-bit binary counter for time measurement of first  data arrival (this is the Transient
Time counter)
.  8-bit Status Register
.  Clock divide logic that outputs 2.5 MHz for the A/D Converter (U9)
.  Decode logic used to output control signals:
.. HBEN (HighByteENable used by U9)
.. CS (ChipSelect used by U9)
., RESET PK (Used to place Peak Voltage Hold circuit in Acquire\Reset mode)

PULSE HEIGHT ANALYZER (Cont'd)
On receipt of MSYNC, U12 begins to accumulate the 10 MHz clock in a 16-bit binary counter.  The
count accumulation continues until the voltage at pin 7 of U11, the output of the First Arrival Detector,
is high.
U12 decodes address lines AD0 through AD3 (orignating at the CPU Board) to cause required actions.
The following codes are used:
1    0    0     0
Reset internal counters and registers
1    0    0     1
Unused
1    0    1     0
Enable passage of logic levels on 8 bit bus to U12 pins
G11, K11, L10, L5, J11. (These lines are used to
control U2, U5, and U14 gain stages.)
1    0    1     1
Enable passage of logic levels on 8 bit bus to U12 pins:
D1, RESET PEAK; D2, HBEN; H1, A/D CLK
ENABLE; A1, A2, C1, C2, THRESHOLD for TT
1    1    0     0
Put Low Byte of the T.T.  on the bus.
1    1    0     1
Put the High Byte of the T.T. on the bus.
1    1    1     0
Put the contents of the internal status register on the
bus.
1    1    1     1
Pulse CS (from +5 V to 0 V) at pin B3 to enable U9
pin 21.

Signals marked * are generated by U12 "internal" logic.
STOP_CLK is latched when the First Arrival Detector is enabled and pin 7 of U11 has a positive
transition.  L_MSYNC is latched when the signal MSYNC makes a positive transition. CTR_OVR is
latched when the (internal) TT counter overflows, ie. a STOP_CLK did not occur.
The A/DCLK IN signal comes from the CPU board, and generates clock pulses for the Flash Converter
board.  U12 counts the clock pulses until the signature gate value is reached, then U12 sets A/DCLK
EN high and the Flash Converter board begins saving samples in the fifo.

chunk_text:

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG

FLASH CONVERTER (Cont'd)
Data Store: IC4 is a CMOS First-in/First-out 4096 by 9-bit memory device.  The reads and writes are
internally sequential through use of ring pointers, with no address information required to load and
unload data.  Data is moved in and out of memory through control of the Write and Read pins.  In this
application, bit position Q8 (the 9th bit) is not used.
Write operations are controlled `automatically' by the connection of IC5 pin 8.  When the input A/D
CLK is active, data from IC3 is stored into IC4.
Read operations are controlled by firmware in the CPU board.  When address lines are at
AD3    AD2   AD1   AD0
&&&&&&&&&&&&
0       0       0        1
and D I/O is low, pin 15 of IC4 is low, thereby placing IC4 in Read.
Reset is accomplished whenever the bar Reset input (pin 22) is low.  During reset, both internal read
and write pointers are set to the first location.
Decoder: IC6 decodes the input Address lines and the D I/O line to control IC4.  Decoded commands
are:
AD3    AD2   AD1   AD0     Command
&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&

0          0       0        0       Read FIFO status
0          0       0        1       FIFO Read
0          0       1        0       FIFO Retransmit
0          0       1        1       FIFO Reset

chunk_text:
28
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG 29
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG

MAGNETOMETER BOARD (Cont'd)
(Reference drawing 148681-000)
If a coil is placed around the core and driven with a current to generate sufficient flux density, the iron
alloy will saturate and permability will be reduced, causing the flux lines due to the earth's field to be
driven out of the core.
The iron alloy core and coil arrangement act as a flux gate to the earth's magnetic flux lines.  When
current is absent from the drive winding, the gate is open and the flux lines tend to locally concentrate
in the core.  When a high current is applied to saturate the core, the gate is closed to the earth's field
flux lines and they resume their original paths undisturbed by the presence of the core.
See Figures 945-7 and 945-8.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG
chunk_text:
30
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG


Flux Lines
due to
Earth's Field
a.
Flux Lines due to Earth's magnetic field with core in an unsaturated state.
b.
Flux Lines with core in saturated state.
NOTE
Only flux lines due to the earth's magnetic field are shown.


a.
Winding configuration due to drive current.
b.
Flux lines with core saturated.
c.

MAGNETOMETER BOARD (Cont'd)
(Reference drawing 148681-000)
U8 is a crystal oscillator operating at 42.5 kHz.  U6 pin 12 is used to produce the correct
frequency/phase drive signal needed for the demodulaton of the Magnetometer signal.  The 0 V to +15
V output of U6 pin 1 is shifted to a +7.5 to -7.5 V square wave by network R27, C12, R26, and on U6
pin 12 by network C21, R42.  U2, Q1 and Q2 provide the current gain necessary to saturate the
magnetometer coil.  Resistor R22 limits the current drain from Q1,Q2.
U1 (pins 2,3 and 1) buffers the received magnetometer output.  C20, R41 remove the dc component at
pin 1 of U1 and drives the Y1 input of U7.  U7 is the Burr-Brown 634 SM Precision Analog Multiplier,
used as a phase detector.  The output of U7 contains unwanted frequency components that are filtered
by U1 (pins 5,6 and 7).  Resistors R46, R47 together with capacitors C24, C25 and with resistors
R48,R49 are components used with U1(pins 5,6 and 7) as an active 2-pole Butterworth filter. The
corner frequency of this filter is about 1 kHz.
U3 is a voltage comparator which `squares' the analog orientation signal output from U1 pin 7 ; the
orientation signal North is now represented by the leading edge of the pulse at P6 pin 15.
The phase relationship of the orientation reference signals is critical.  The correct phase is illustrated by
a +7.5 V to -7.5 V signal; resistors R36,R37 scale the voltage to a low value.  (This is intended to
work with the variable gain circuits on the PHA Board.) The control signal at pin 16 of P6 enables the
output of Test Wave when it is high.  EN TEST WAVE originates at the Transmitter board.(Assembly,
P/N 182470-000)

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG
chunk_text:
35
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG

TRANSMITTER ELECTRONICS (Cont'd)
(Reference drawing C182470-100
Xmitter: The function of the transmitter circuits are to provide a fire pluse to one of three possible
transducers.
Signal MSYNC follows the receipt of serial data; serial data stored in U5 specifies which transmitter is
to be fired.  The rising edge of MSYNC causes a 1.8 µ second pulse at pin 1 of U3.  Stored values in
U3 select one of three possible transmitter circuits.  When the pulse at U3 pin 1 is received, it passes
through U3 to the specified transmitter (eg, transmitter 1, or transmitter 2), or the fluid transmitter
circuit (e.g., transmitter 3).
U4 and U6 are used to select the Fire Pulse width. When IN1 of U6 is selected (default mode) the pulse
width is  1.8 s, when IN2 is selected the pulse width is  .6 s.
NOTE
The components which fire the selected transducer are identical.
Capacitor C09 is the common capacitor which transfers its stored energy (via transformer) to the
specified transducer. Field Effect Transistor(FET) Q2 and Q3 are current amplifiers needed to drive
Q4.  FET Q4 connects C09, through transformer T1, to the 1 ½ inch transducer.  FET's Q4,5,6 or
FET's Q7,8,9 work in a similar manner through T2 or T3 to fire the 2 inch or the FLUID transducers
respectively.  When U3 enables the appropriate FET gate,the 180 Vdc on the primary of the selected
transformer goes to 0 Vdc for 1.8  second .This pulse causes a 600 to 700 V p-p pulse on the
secondary which will fire the selected transducer.  Current limiting resistor R33, R34, and R35 protects
Q2, Q3, Q5, Q8, and Q9.
Serial interface: U5 and U3 are the serial interface, decode circuits.  U5 is a 8-stage shift/store register
with three state outputs; it receives and stores data (commands) from the 1671 EB.  U3 decodes stored
values output from U5.
Data is serially shifted into U5 pin 2 by signals MDATA and MCLK.  Signal MR/W is held low when
U5 is receiving; thereafter, MR/W is returned high.  The rising edge of MR/W strobes the received
(serial) value to the output pins.  While U5 is inputting, the output pins of U5 are static
(tri-stated).

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG
chunk_text:
36
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG

TRANSMITTER ELECTRONICS (Cont'd)
(Reference drawing C182470-100)
Multiplexer/buffer: U2 is used to select 1 of 4 differential inputs.  The value stored in U5 controls
which of the inputs is passed to U1.  Resistor pairs R11-R12, R13-R14, and R15-R16 are part of the
gain setting network for U1; additionally, they limit the current drawn through diode combination D2-
D3, D4-D5, and D6-D7.
D2 through D7 limit the voltage presented at the respective input terminals of U2: they will conduct
when the respective transducer is fired.
U1 is a differential unity gain buffer amplifier, U7 is a buffer/line driver, whose output is sent to the
PHA Board as signals MUX + and MUX -.

TOOLS REQUIRED

-
¼ - 20 T-handle puller (P/N 056036)
-
Pliers - Lock Ring (P/N 150259)
-
Assorted Allen Wrenches and Screwdrivers
-
32-pin bulkhead inserter (P/N 150208)
-
Pin wrench (P/N 104582)
-
Strap wrench (P/N 230545)
-
Open End Wrench (P/N 501545) 
REFERENCE DRAWINGS

-
1671 EB DCBIL Electronics Assembly (R182482-000)
-
Vacuum Flask Assembly (D182473-000)
-
1671 EB DCBIL Power Supply Assembly (R182481-000)
-
Pigtail and Ribbon Cable Assembly (D182474-000)

Assembly WTS Bottom Sub (C148965-000)
-
Assembly WTS Top Sub (C182475-000)

Mechanical Assembly (R182480-000)

1671 DCBIL Flasked Electronics Assembly (R182483-000)

SUPPLIES REQUIRED

-

-
Kapton tape (a.k.a. Rootbeer tape) (P/N 223378)
-
Loctitetm #532 (P/N 244147) 
DCBIL 1671 EB ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES

Reference Workmanship Standards N80807.
Carry out a visual inspection of all the components on the instrument while it is disassembled to
check for loose and missing pieces, bare wires, loose and worn connections, etc. Repair or replace
any suspect components.  On the Power Supply Power Supply P/N F182481000, tack all fasteners
with RTV before final assembly to ensure that they do not loosen due to vibration.

VACUUM FLASK INSTALLATION
(Reference drawings R182482-000, D182474-000, and R182481-000)

1.
While supporting the flasked electronics assembly (item 4 of R182482-000), carefully slide the flask
assembly (item 5 of R182482-000) over the electronics chassis (item 4 of R182482-000).

2.
The flask mouth needs to be flush against the power supply assembly bulkhead before securing the
flask to the bulkhead.  Attach with three #6 socket head cap screws (item 7 of R182482-000).

3.
The flask connector (item 10 of C182474-000) is then secured to the flask connector board (item 38
of R182481-000).  Use an Allen wrench to bring together the two mating connectors.

4.
At this juncture, the flask has been mounted securely to the electronics assembly.  Kapton tape (i.e.
Rootbeer tape, P/N 223378) is used to protect and to adhere the flat 26-conductor ribbon strip to the
flask.  Wrap the tape over the ribbon strip and around the flask mouth.

ASSEMBLY WIRELINE TELEMETRY BOTTOM SUB
(Reference drawing C148965-000)

1.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) o-ring grooves on the 32-pin bulkhead (item 2), and then install o-rings
(item 5).

2.
Install the 32-pin bulkhead (item 2) into the WTS Bottom Sub (item 1).  Use the 32-pin bulkhead
inserter (P/N 150208) to align the keyed bulkhead.  Push the bulkhead into the bottom sub using a
pin wrench to turn the split collar on the insertion tool.

3.
Install the snap ring (item 3) into the bottom sub using snap ring pliers (150259-000).  Make sure
the snap ring is seated properly into its groove.

4.
Apply lubrication (P/N 205933) to the external o-ring grooves on the WTS Bottom Sub.  Seat the
outer o-rings (item 4) into their respective grooves.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 2.3 ASSEMBLY WIRELINE TELEMETRY TOP SUB ................................................5
chunk_text:
ASSEMBLY WIRELINE TELEMETRY TOP SUB
(Reference drawing C182475-000)
1.
Install the thermal expansion unit into the WTS Top Sub by first sliding the spring (item 4) into
the top sub (item 1).
2.
Next; set the travel sleeve (item 3) into the center of the spring.
3.
Retainer ring (item 5) hole pattern allows for installation in one alignment configuration only.
Set the retainer ring over the travel sleeve with the countersunk holes facing upward.
4.
While compressing the spring, install the 3-flat head socket screws (item 6) to secure the
retaining ring.  Use Loctite  (P/N 244147) on the screw threads.
tm
5.
Apply lubricant (P/N 205933) to the throat of the split collar (item 2).  Secure the split collar
around the neck of the top sub (item 1) by installing the socket head cap screws.
6.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) the o-ring grooves on both ends of the WTS Top Sub (item 1).  Install
both o-rings (item 9) onto split collar end of the top sub.  Install the o-rings (item 10) onto the
other end.

INSTALLATION OF ELECTRONICS INTO PRESSURE HOUSING
(Reference drawing R182480-000 and C182475-000)
Thusfar, the subs are assembled and the threads lubricated as described in Section 2.2 and Section 2.3.
1.
Secure the pressure housing (item 1 of R182480-000) with a strap wrench.  Then, install the
WTS Bottom Sub (item 7 of R182480-000) using a pin wrench to rotate the sub.
2.
Orient the timing marks on the pressure housing in an up position for installation of the
electronics assembly.
3.
Rotate the electronics assembly so that the flat ribbon cable is facing upward.  This will reduce
damage to the ribbon cable during insertion into the pressure housing. Insert the electronics
(item 10 of R182480-000) into the pressure housing (item 1 of R182480-000) with the keyed
snout entering first.
4.
The electronics are now resting against the bottom of the housing.  Screw in the
¼-20 T-handle puller (P/N 056036) into the top of the flask adapter on the pigtail end of the
electronics assembly.  The instrument is then twisted while pushing inward until it keys-up with
the bottom sub.
5.
Begin top sub installation.  First feed the pigtail of the electronics assembly through the throat
of the WTS Top Sub (item 6 of R182480-000).
6.
Hold the pigtail with slight tension while screwing the top sub into the pressure housing.
7.
Connect the 32-pin black block (item 7 of C182475-000) to the pigtail.  Carefully, twist it back
into the throat of the WTS Top Sub while seating the block into the sub itself.
8.
Seat the retainer clip (item 8 of C182475-000) into the lock ring groove to secure the black
block.
9.
Install thread protectors for the top sub (item 2 of R182480-000) and the bottom sub
(item 4 of R182480-000) to protect and aid in handling of the instrument.

DCBIL 1671 EB DISASSEMBLY 
TOOLS REQUIRED
-
¼ - 20 T-handle puller (P/N 056036)
-
Pliers - Lock Ring (P/N 150259)
-
Assorted Allen Wrenches and Screwdrivers
-
32-pin bulkhead puller (P/N 150210)
-
Pin wrench (P/N 104582)
-
Strap wrench (P/N 230545)
-
Open End Wrench (P/N 501545)

REFERENCE DRAWINGS
-
1671 EB Pigtail CBIL (MECH) (R182480-000)
-
1671 EB DCBIL Electronics Assembly (R182482-000)
-
Vacuum Flask Assembly (D182473-000)
-
1671 EB DCBIL Power Supply Assembly (R182481-000)
-
Pigtail and Ribbon Cable Assembly (D182474-000)
-
Assembly WTS Bottom Sub (C148965-000)
-
Assembly WTS Top Sub (C182475-000)
-
Mechanical Assembly (R182460-000)
-
1671 DCBIL Flasked Electronics Assembly (R182483-000) 
DCBIL 1671 EB DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 4.1 REMOVAL OF ELECTRONICS FROM PRESSURE HOUSING .........................7
chunk_text:
REMOVAL OF ELECTRONICS FROM PRESSURE HOUSING
(Reference drawings C182475-000 and R182480-000)
1.
Remove the thread protectors (items 2 and 4 of R182480-000) from both ends of the pressure
housing.
2.
Remove the retainer clip (item 8 of C182475-000) from the WTS Top Sub.
3.
Remove the 32-pin block (item 7 of C182475-000) with a ¼-20 T-handle puller
(P/N 056036).  Disconnect the black block from the pigtail.
4.
Secure the pressure housing (item 1 of R182480-000) with a strap wrench.  Unscrew the WTS
Top Sub (item 6 of R182480-000) with an open-end wrench.
5.
Orient the timing marks on the pressure housing in an up position so that the electronics
assembly will not be resting on the ribbon cable.

VACUUM FLASK REMOVAL
(Reference drawings R182482-000, D182474-000 and R182481-000)
1.
Remove the Kapton tape (P/N 223378) from around the vacuum flask assembly at the mouth of
the flask.
2.
Unscrew the flask connector (item 10 of D182474-000) from the flask connector board (item 38
of R182481-000) Use an allen wrench to separate the two mating connectors.
3.
Remove the three #6 socket head cap screws (item 7 of R182482-000) that secure the mouth of
the flask assembly to the power supply bulkhead.
4.
Carefully, slide the flask assembly (item 5 of R182482-000) off of the electronics chassis (item
4 of R182482-000).
NOTE
Support the flasked electronics at all times after it is removed from
the flask.

DCBIL 1671 MB ASSEMBLY 
TOOLS REQUIRED
-
Refer to P/N 152194, Tool Kit
-

#1 phillips screwdriver
-
#2 phillips screwdriver

¼" open end wrench
-
Small adjustable pin spanner wrench (P/N 257660)

Soldering iron
-
Open-end wrench (P/N 501545)

Transducer installation tool (P/N 153429)

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 6.0 DCBIL 1671MB ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES...................................................................10 6.1 TRANSMISSION ASSEMBLY TO JACKSHAFT BULKHEAD.........................10
chunk_text:
DCBIL 1671 MB ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
TRANSMISSION ASSEMBLY TO JACKSHAFT BULKHEAD
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Feed the four shielded cables through the Jackshaft Bulkhead (item 4), two per side, until the
motor transmission (item 3) contacts the Jackshaft Bulkhead.
2.
Orient the cut out slot on the motor transmission (item 3) to align with the cut out slot in the
Jackshaft Bulkhead (item 4).
3.
Align the countersunk holes in the Jackshaft Bulkhead (item 4) to the tapped holes in the motor
transmission (item 3) and fasten with four #10-32 flat head screws (item 23).  Use Loctitetm
(P/N 244147) on screw threads.
4.
Remove the excess slack from the shielded cables inside of the motor transmission (item 3).

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 6.2 STATOR HOUSING ASSEMBLY TO JACKSHAFT BULKHEAD....................10
chunk_text:
STATOR HOUSING ASSEMBLY TO JACKSHAFT BULKHEAD
(Reference drawings C153423-100 and R182464-000)
1.
Slide the wavy washer (item 31) over the Jackshaft (item 30) and rest it against the jackshaft
bulkhead (item 4).
2.
Slide the Stator Housing Assembly (item 24) over the Jackshaft (item 30) and orient the cut out
in the Stator Housing with the offset drive shaft running through the jackshaft bulkhead (item
4).
3.
Install the Bushing Assembly (items 26, 27 and 28), as shown in View "A" Reference drawing
R182464-000, and secure with a #6-32 hex head screw (item 25).  Use Loctite  (P/N 244147)
tm
on screw threads.
4.
Assemble the three bushing assemblies and tighten with a ¼" open end wrench.
5.
Solder the four shielded cables to the eight ceramic terminals (item 29), located on the uphole
end of the Stator Housing (item 24).  Refer to electrical schematic C153423-100.
6.
Pull the excess cable back through the jackshaft bulkhead (item 4) and motor transmission (item
3).
7.
Tie the cables running through the jackshaft bulkhead (item 4) to the two cables coming from
the motor transmission magnetic pick-ups with high temperature lacing cord
(P/N 203206).  Create two bundles and tie approximately every four inches.  Include the three
wires running from the uphole end of the motor in one of the two bundles.  Leave
approximately 8 to 10 inches of cable untied at the boot-end of the cables.

MOTOR HOUSING ASSEMBLY
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) the threads and o-ring grooves on the motor transmission end of the
jackshaft bulkhead (item 4).
2.
Install the two o-rings (item 12) on the motor end of the bulkhead.
3.
Feed the motor housing (item 2) over the cables and motor transmission and screw onto the
jackshaft bulkhead (item 4).  Tighten with a strap wrench and large pin spanner wrench.

ROTARY TRANSFORMER HOUSING ASSEMBLY
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) the threads and o-ring grooves on the stator housing end of the
jackshaft bulkhead (item 4).
2.
Install the two o-rings (item 12) on the stator housing end of the bulkhead.
3.
Slide the rotary transformer housing (item 5) over the stator housing (item 24) and screw onto
the jackshaft bulkhead (item 4).  Tighten with a strap wrench and a large pin spanner wrench.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 6.5 AWS MUD SUB CALIBRATION TRANSDUCER ASSEMBLY........................11
chunk_text:
AWS MUD SUB CALIBRATION TRANSDUCER ASSEMBLY
(Reference drawing D182468-000)
1.
Lubricate the o-ring groove on the calibration transducer (item 23) and install the
o-ring (item 22).
2.
Turn the mud sub body (item 30) on end to allow access to the bore for the calibration
transducer.
3.
Set the calibration transducer (item 23) into the bore.  Orient the installation tool
(P/N B153429-000) so that the transducer wires will not be damaged, and press the calibration
transducer into the mud sub body (item 30).
4.
Set the retaining plate (item 21) over the transducer and align with the tapped holes in the mud
sub body (item 30).
5.
Fasten the retaining plate (item 21) to the mud sub body (item 30) with #10-32 cap screws (item
19) and #10 lock washers (item 20).
6.
Install the o-ring (item 28) onto the fill plug (item 27).
7.
Screw the fill plug assembly (item 27) into the mud sub body (item 30) and tighten.

AWS MUD SUB ASSEMBLY
(Reference drawings D182468-000 and R182464-000)
1.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) the external thread and o-ring gland on the mud sub body (item 30 of
D182468-000).
2.
Install o-ring (item 29 of D182468-000) against the shoulder on the mud sub body (item 30 of
D182468-000).
3.
Individually slide the boots from each of the shielded cables and the boots from the motor wires
through the mud sub body (item 30 of D182468-000).  Be sure that the colored identifications
on each cable can be seen on the calibration transducer end of the mud sub body.
4.
Once all of the cables are through the body, tuck the cables along side the motor into the motor
housing (item 2 of R182464-000) so that about one inch of wire extends out of the calibration
transducer end of the mud sub body (item 30 of D182468-000).
5.
Carefully screw the mud sub body (item 30 of D182468-000) onto the motor housing (item 2 of
R182464-000) using a strap wrench and a large pin spanner wrench.

PRESSURE BULKHEAD ASSEMBLY
(Reference drawings C153423-100 and D182468-000)
1.
Cut 18 pieces of teflon wire (item 41 of D182468-000), approximately 12 inches long, per the
color code on drawing C153423-100 for pins 11 through 28.
2.
Strip and crimp the teflon wire (item 41 of D182468-000) to the terminals (item 13 of D182468-
000).
3.
Crimp the terminals (item 13 of D182468-000) to the thread end of each of the pressure
terminals (item 11 of D182468-000).
4.
Cut 18 one inch long pieces of shrink tubing (item 14 of D182468-000).  Slide one piece over
each terminal (item 13 of D182468-000) and shrink over the terminal and wire.
5.
Ensure each of the pressure terminal (item 11 of D182468-000) has an o-ring (item 12 of
D182468-000) seated properly in the o-ring groove.  Lubricate (P/N 205933) the threads and o-
rings on each terminal.
6.
Install each of the pressure terminal assemblies (item 11 of D182468-000) into the pressure
bulkhead (item 17 of D182468-000) as per the wiring scheme for the pin numbers on C153423-
100.
7.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) o-ring grooves on the pressure bulkhead (item 17 of D182468-000) and
install o-rings (item 15 of D182468-000).

MAGNETOMETER TUNING BOARD ASSEMBLY
(Reference drawings A154450-000, D182468-000 and C153423-100)
1.
Apply RTV (item 4 of A154450-000) to Magnetometer Tuning Board (item 1
of A154450-000) in the locations for mounting the capacitors (item CD and CS).
2.
Mount the capacitors to the board using stress loops on the capacitor leads.
3.
Solder the capacitor leads to the board using high temperature solder (P/N 226055).
4.
Cut the four wires coming from pins 10, 11, 12 and 13 of the pressure bulkhead assembly (item
17 of D182468-000), six inches long, from the pressure bulkhead face.  Save the trimmed
wires.
5.
Strip the four trimmed wires and solder (P/N 226055) to the terminal posts on the
magnetometer tuning board (item 10 of D182468-000) per the wiring schematic C153423-100.
6.
Strip the four trimmed wires coming from the pressure Bulkhead Assembly (item 17 of
D182468-000) and solder (P/N 226055) them to the magnetometer tuning board (item 10 of
D182468-000) per the wiring schematic C153423-100.
7.
Crimp the contacts from the Airborn Connector (item 1 of D182468-000) to the wires coming
from the pressure Bulkhead Assembly (item 17 of D182468-000) and the magnetometer tuning
board (item 10 of D182468-000).
8.
Insert the contacts into the Airborn Connector (item 1 of D182468-000) per the wiring diagram
C153423-100.
9.
Use high temperature lacing cord (P/N 203206) to secure the wires a few places along the
length of the wire bundle.

PRESSURE BULKHEAD INSTALLATION
(Reference drawings C153423-100 and D182468-000)
All item numbers in this section refer to Reference drawing D182468-000, unless otherwise indicated.
1.
Connect the boots from the wires coming through the mud sub assembly (item 30) to the
pressure bulkhead assembly (item 17) per the wiring diagram C153423-100.
2.
Connect the two boots coming from the calibration transducer (item 23) to the pressure
bulkhead assembly (item 17) per the wiring diagram C153423-100.
3.
Slide the pressure bulkhead (item 17) into the mud sub body (item 30) taking care not to pinch
any of the wires.
4.
Align the pressure bulkhead (item 17) with the bore in the mud sub body (item 30).  Insert the
bulkhead to where the inner most o-ring is trying to compress into the bore.
5.
Lubricate the thread and o-ring grooves on the end of the coupler sub (item 6) that has the
extension on the threaded end.
6.
Seat both o-rings (item 5) into their respective grooves.
7.
Slide the coupler sub (item 6) over the Airborn Connector (item 1) and magnetometer tuning
board (item 10).  Be careful not to pinch any wires between the coupler sub and the pressure
bulkhead.
8.
Screw the coupler sub (item 6) into the mud sub body (item 30) by hand.  Tighten the coupler
sub into the mud sub body (item 30) with two large pin spanner wrenches.  As the coupler sub
is tightened, the pressure bulkhead will be set to the correct depth inside of the mud sub body
(item 30).

CONNECTOR HOUSING ASSEMBLY
(Reference drawing R182468-000)
1.
Slide the wires coming from the pressure bulkhead (item 17) through the cut out in the front
face of the connector housing (item 3).
2.
Mount the magnetometer tuning board (item 10) over the wire bundle with the #6-32 binder
head screws (item 8), #6 lock washers (item 9) on the top side and the .25 inch long spacers
(item 7) below the board.  Use Loctite  (P/N 244147) on the screw threads.
tm
3.
Slide the Airborn Connector (item 1) into the Connector Housing (item 3).
4.
Align the four mounting holes in the face of the Airborn connector (item 1) with the tapped
holes in the Connector Housing (item 3).  The orientation of the holes allows for the connector
to be mounted by all four screws in only one orientation.
Secure with the four #4-40 Filister head screws (item 2).
5.
Slide the connector housing (item 3) into the coupler sub (item 6) taking care not to pinch
wires.
6.
Align the counter sunk holes in the face of the connector housing (item 3) to the tapped holes on
the face of the coupler sub (item 6).  Secure with four #6-32 flat head screws (item 4).  Use
Loctite  (P/N 244147) on the screw threads.
tm
7.
Set the cover plate (item 33) over the cut out on the face of the connector housing (item 3) and
secure with two #6-32 flat head screws (item 4).  Use Loctite  (P/N 244147) on the screw
tm
threads.

ROTATING PLATFORM INSTALLATION
(Reference drawings R182464-000, C158198-000 and C158195-000)
1.
Slide the rotating platform assembly (item 13 of R182464-000) over the jackshaft (item 30 of
R182464-000) and engage with the power train.
2.
Time the 1.5 inch rotating transducer to the internal tool body mark transducer and the external
machined tool body mark using procedure in component P/N 130609-956, section 10.0.
'
3.
Adjust the magnetometer coil (item 10 of C158198-000) for North alignment coincident to the
1.5 inch transducer and the external machined tool body mark using procedure in component
P/N 130609-956, section 10.0.
'

TEFLON WINDOW ASSEMBLY
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) the external o-ring groove on the rotary transformer housing (item 5)
and install o-ring (item 14) into the groove.
2.
Slide the two anti-extrusion cups (item 6) onto both ends of the teflon window (item 7).
3.
Slide one end of the teflon window assembly (item 7) over the o-ring seal on the rotary
transformer housing (item 5).
4.
Insert the teflon thrust washer (item 15) into the counter bore in the bellows-jackshaft adapter
(item 8).
5.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) the external o-ring groove on the bellows-jackshaft adapter (item 8) and
install o-ring (item 14) into the groove.
6.
Screw the bellows-jackshaft adapter (item 8) onto jackshaft (item 30) and tighten with two large
pin spanner wrenches.

BELLOWS INSTALLATION
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Set the o-ring (item 16) into the face seal groove in the bellows-jackshaft adapter (item 8).
2.
Screw the bellows (item 17) into the bellows-jackshaft adapter (item 8) and tighten with a small
pin spanner wrench while backing up with a large pin spanner wrench on the bellows-jackshaft
adapter (item 8).
3.
Install the o-ring (item 19) into the o-ring groove on the bellows guide rod (item 18).
4.
Slide the bellows guide rod (item 18) through the bellows (item 17) and secure with three #4-40
binder head screws (item 22).  Use Loctite  (P/N 244147) on the screw threads.
tm
5.
Install o-ring (item 21) onto the seal screw (item 20).
6.
Screw the seal screw assembly (item 20) into the end of the bellows guide rod (item 18) and
tighten.

OIL FILLING THE LOWER MANDREL
(Reference drawings R182464-000, and D182468-000)
1.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) the thread on the bellows-jackshaft adapter (item 8 of R182464-000).
2.
Screw the bellows housing (item 10 of R182464-000) onto the bellows-jackshaft adapter (item 8
of R182464-000) and tighten.  Be sure the end marked uphole is towards the uphole end.
3.
Tighten the two set screws (item 9 of R182464-000) in the uphole end of the bellows housing
(item 10 of R182464-000) onto the bellows-jackshaft adapter (item 8 of R182464-000).
4.
Remove the adapter sub (item 11 of R182464-000) from the bellows housing (item 10 of
R182464).
5.
Remove the fill plug (item 27 of D182468-000) from the mud sub body (item 30 of D182468-
000).
6.
Install o-ring size 568-011 (P/N 201227) on the thread relief of the filler plug (P/N 158629).
7.
Screw the filler plug (P/N 158629) into the mud sub body (item 30 of D182468-000) and
tighten.
8.
Position the tool in a vertical position with the bellows up.  Connect the filler plug (P/N
158629) in the mud sub body (item 30 of D182468-000) to the inlet of an air evacuation system.
9.
Remove the seal screw (item 20 of R182464-000) from the end of the bellows assembly (item
17 of R182464-000).
10.
Use the bellows retainer assembly (P/N 181748-000) and ensure that the O-ring (item 3 of

OIL FILLING THE LOWER MANDREL (Cont'd)
(Reference drawings R182464-000, and D182468-000)
11.
Insert the tube into the bellows housing (item 5 of figure 1) with the 1/4-20 threaded end first.
It will be necessary to have the weldment (item 1 of figure 1) threaded to the other end of the
tube to allow clearance.
12.
Thread the 1/4-20 thread into the end of the bellows (item 7 of figure 1) and turn until hand
tight.  This will ensure a good seal.
13.
Pull the bellows out until the end of the bellows is approximately one inch from the end of the
bellows housing (see figure 1).  This is the correct position for evacuation, and in this
configuration the bellows will not collapse during evacuation.
14.
Attach the required tubing (item 6 of figure 1) from the evacuation/filling apparatus onto item 2
of figure 1.
15.
Evacuate the air from the rotating head/mud sub assembly for 30 to 45 minutes, pressure should
pull down to 4 to 5 Torr absolute.
16.
Carefully remove the bellows retainer assembly to prevent air from entering the bellows.
Screw the seal screw (item 20 of R182464-000) and tighten.
17.
Slide a long screwdriver through the slots in the bellows housing (item 10 of R182464-000) at
the base of the bellows assembly (item 17 of R182464-000).  Gauge the length of the bellows
assembly (item 17 of R182464-000) to the radial mark machined on the bellows housing (item
10 of R182464-000).  Ensure the length of the bellow extends at least ½ inch past this mark.
18.
Carefully remove the filler plug from the mud sub body (item 30 of D182468-000) while
holding the position of the bellows to prevent air from entering the assembly.  Screw in the fill
plug (item 27 of D182468-000) into the mud sub body (item 30 of D182468-000) and tighten.
19.
Slide a long screwdriver through the slots in the bellows housing (item 10 of R182464-000) at
the base of the bellows assembly (item 17 of R182464-000).  Apply pressure to the bellows
with the screwdriver while loosening the fill plug (item 27 of D182468-000) in the mud sub
body (item 30 of D182468-000).  Allow oil to flow from the fill hole until the end of the
bellows reaches radially machined mark on the outside of the bellows housing.  Replace the fill
plug (item 27 of D182468-000) in the mud sub body (item 30 of D182468-000) and tighten.
20.
Screw the adapter sub (item 11 of R182464-000) onto the bellows housing (item 10 of
R182464-000) and tighten.
21.
Slide the protective cover sleeve (item 32 of R182464-000) over the rotator assenbly and secure
with the thread protector (item 33 of R182464-000).

DCBIL 1671 MB ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
(Reference drawings C182475-000, R182461-000, D182468-000 and R182460-000)
1.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) the threads and o-ring grooves on the uphole end of the coupler sub
(item 6 of D182468-000).  Install o-rings (item 5 of D182468-000) in their respective grooves.
2.
Screw the pressure housing (item 1 of R182460-000) onto the coupler sub (item 6
of D182468-000) and tighten with a strap wrench while securing the coupler sub with a large
pin spanner wrench.
3.
Slide the electronics assembly (item 4 of R182460-000) into the pressure housing (item 1 of
R182460-000).
4.
Screw a ¼-20 T-handle puller (P/N 056036) into the upper bulkhead of the electronics assembly
(item 4 of R182460-000).  Rotate the T-handle until the alignment pin on the other end of the
electronics engages with the alignment hole in the connector housing (item 3 of R182460-000).
Press on the T-handle to engage the pins on the Airborn connectors.  Remove the T-handle.
5.
Assemble the WTS Top Sub per section 2.3 of this component.
6.
Feed the pigtail of the electronics assembly through the throat of the WTS Top Sub (item 3
of R182460-000).
7.
Hold the pigtail with slight tension while screwing the top sub into the pressure housing.
8.
Connect the 32-pin black block to the pigtail.  Carefully, twist it back into the throat of the
WTS Top Sub while seating the block into the sub itself.
9.
Seat the retainer clip into the lock ring groove to secure the black block.
10.
Install the thread protector for the top sub (item 2 of R182460-000).

TOOLS REQUIRED
-
Refer to P/N 152194, Tool Kit
-
3.75" diameter large pin spanner wrenches (2)
-
#1 phillips screwdriver
-
#2 phillips screwdriver

-
¼" open end wrench
-
small adjustable pin spanner wrench
-
large strap wrench
-
soldering iron
-
4-quart or larger container for used oil
-
10-32 T-handle puller (P/N A95420) 
REFERENCE DRAWINGS
-
1671 MB DCBIL Mechanical Assembly (R182460-000)
-
1671 MB DCBIL Electronic Assembly (R182461-000)
-
Assembly Top Sub for WTS (C182475-000)
-
Assembly Pulse Echo Mud Sub (D182468-000)
-
Electrical Schematic Rotating Section (C153423-100)
-
Assembly Rev. D Rotating Section (R182464-000)
-
Assembly Power Train (D182465-000)
-
Assembly Rotating Transformers (C158195-000)

DCBIL 1671 MB DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
NOTE
Preparations include washing the unit to remove mud, grease, dirt,
and other foreign material if the unit has been run in a well. Blow
dry with compressed air or dry off the unit with clean rags or paper
towels. Each step of disassembly will include cleaning as required.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 8.1 REMOVAL OF ELECTRONICS AND PRESSURE HOUSING ..........................22
chunk_text:
REMOVAL OF ELECTRONICS AND PRESSURE HOUSING
(Reference drawings (D182460-000 and C182475-000)
1.
Remove the thread protector from the uphole end of the assembly.  Leave the cover sleeve and
the thread protector on the rotator end of the assembly.
2.
Use a screwdriver to remove the retainer clip (item 8 of C182475-000) on the top sub.
3.
Remove the 32-pin block (item 7 of C182475-000) with a ¼-20 T-handle.
4.
Disconnect the block from the pigtail.
5.
Secure the pressure housing (item 1 of D182460-000) with a strap wrench.
6.
Remove the WTS Top Sub (item 3 of D182460-000) using an open-end wrench.
7.
Extract the electronics (item 4 of D182460-000) using a ¼-20 T-handle puller (P/N 056036) in
the upper bulkhead of the electronics assembly.
8.
Secure the coupler sub (item 6 of D182460-000) with a pin wrench.  Then, remove the
pressure housing (item 1 of D182460-000) with a strap wrench.

BELLOWS HOUSING
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Remove the thread protector and cover sleeve from rotator assembly (items 32 and 33).
2.
Remove the two ¼-20 set screws (item 9) from the uphole end of the bellows housing (item
10).
3.
Remove the bellows housing (item 10) using a large pin spanner wrench (P/N 104582-000).
While securing the assembly on the jackshaft bellow adapter (item 8) with a second wrench.
NOTE
There is no need to disassemble the bellows housing (item 10) from
the centralizer adapter (item 11).
No service needs to be performed.

BELLOWS REMOVAL
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Rotate the Assembly so that the upper fill screw in the calibration transducer sub (item 27 of
D182468-000) is up.
2.
Use a small adjustable pin spanner wrench at the upper end of the bellows assembly (item 17) to
loosen it from the jackshaft to bellows adapter bulkhead (item 8).
3.
Once the assembly is loose, finish unscrewing it by hand taking great care not to damage or
drop it.
4.
Remove the o-ring and discard (item 16).
5.
Remove the upper fill screw (item 27 of D 182468-000) in the calibration transducer sub.
6.
Drain the oil into a 4-quart or larger container.

BELLOWS GUIDE ROD REMOVAL
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Drain oil from the bellows (item 17).
2.
Remove the lower fill screw (item 20) in the end of the bellow's assembly.
3.
Remove the o-ring and discard (item 21).
4.
Remove the three #4-40 x 3/16 large Phillips head screws (item 22) from the flange (item 18).
5.
Insert a ¼-20 T-handle puller (P/N 056036) into the fill screw hole and remove guide rod (item
18) from bellows. The smaller flange and guide rod will slide straight out.
6.
Remove the o-ring and discard (item 19).

JACKSHAFT TO BELLOWS ADAPTER BULKHEAD
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Place the tool in a vise, with the vise clamping on the Motor Housing (item 2).
2.
Using a large pin spanner wrench (P/N 104582-000), remove the Bellows Adapter Bulkhead
(item 8) while securing the tool with a large pin spanner wrench on the Center Sub (item 4).
3.
Once the Adapter Bulkhead (item 8) is loosened, remove by hand and allow oil to drain from
the lower section.
4.
Remove o-ring and discard (item 14).

WINDOW REMOVAL
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Insert a thin screwdriver blade between the Rotary Transformer Housing (item 5) and the anti-
extrusion cup (item 6) and gently separate.
2.
Once loosened, grasp the teflon window (item 7) near the center, with both hands, and with a
twisting and rocking action, pull the window off the Rotary Transformer Housing (item 5).
3.
Remove the o-ring and discard (item 14).
NOTE
The teflon window can be removed and replaced without affecting
the timing of the rotating transducers to the tool body mark.
However, if the rotary platform is disengaged from the power train,
the rotating transducers will have to timed to the power train during
reassembly.

ROTARY PLATFORM REMOVAL
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Slide the rotary platform (item 13) off of the jackshaft (item 30).
2.
Inspect each of the following items:
•
the rotary transformers for cracks
•
the drive gear for excessive wear
•
inspect electrical connections on the magnetometer coil
•
inspect the 1.5" and 2.0" transducers for cracks.
•
inspect the upper and lower drive shaft bearings (items 13 and 17 of C158198-000) for
wear. If bearings are worn, replace them.

ROTARY TRANSFORMER HOUSING
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Remove the Rotary Transformer Housing (item 5) using a strap wrench while securing the
center sub (item 4) with a large pin spanner wrench.
2.
Remove the o-rings and discard (item 12).

STATOR HOUSING
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Unsolder the four twisted shielded pairs of wires from the eight ceramic terminals (item 29),
located on the uphole end of the Stator Housing (item 24).
2.
Remove the three #6-32 hex head screws, (item 25) using a ¼" open wrench.
3.
Remove the three flanged mounting bushings (item 26) and o-rings (item 27) and (item 28).
4.
Carefully slide the Stator Housing (item 24) off the jackshaft (item 30).
5.
Remove the wavy spring washer (item 31).

AWS MUD SUB DISASSEMBLY
(Reference drawing D182468-000 and R182464-000)
1.
Loosen the contact block (item 1 of D182468-000) from the connector housing (item 3 of
D182468-000) by removing the 4 retaining screws (item 2 of D182468-000).
2.
Insert a 10-32 T-handle puller (P/N A95420), once secure pull the connector
(item 1 of D182468-000) out about 1 inch.
3.
Remove the 6-32 screws (item 4 of D182468-000) that retain the connector housing (item 3 of
D182468-000) and the cover plate (item 33 of D182468-000).
4.
Slide the connector housing (item 3 of D182468-000) out of the coupler sub (item 6 of
D182468-000) to access the magnetometer tuning board (item 10 of D182468-000).
5.
Remove the 4 screws (item 8 of D182468-000) that retain the magnetometer tuning board (item
10 of D182468-000) to the connector housing (item 3 of D182468-000).
6.
Slide the wire bundle through the slot in the connector housing (item 3 of D182468-000).
7.
Remove the coupler sub (item 6 of D182468-000) from the mud sub body (item 30 of D182468-
000) using 2-large pin spanner wrenches.
8.
Slide the coupler sub (item 6 of D182468-000) off of the wire bundle.  Remove 4 o-rings (item
5 of D182468-000) and discard.
9.
Spread the wires at the pressure bulkhead (item 17 of D182468-000) to allow access to the ¼-
20 pulling thread.
10.
Extract the pressure bulkhead (item 17 of D182468-000) from the mud sub body (item 30 of
D182468-000) using pulling tool (P/N 150210-000).  Remove the bulkhead far enough to access
the internal wires.
11.
Remove the boots for the mud velocity transducer from pins 5 and 6.  Cut lacing cord bindings
to allow the wires to be separated and identified.
NOTE
The color markings identifying the shielded wires may no longer be
distinguishable.  It is advisable that the wires be flagged with the pin
numbers of the pressure bulkhead for ease of reassembly.

MOTOR HOUSING TO JACKSHAFT BULKHEAD
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Remove the two exposed o-rings (item 12) from the lower end of the jackshaft bulkhead and
discard.
2.
With the tool securely clamped on the motor housing, use a large pin spanner wrench and
remove the jackshaft bulkhead (item 4).
3.
Remove and discard the two o-rings (item 12) on the uphole end of the jackshaft bulkhead.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 8.12 TRANSMISSION ASSEMBLY TO JACKSHAFT BULKHEAD.........................28
chunk_text:
TRANSMISSION ASSEMBLY TO JACKSHAFT BULKHEAD
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
1.
Remove the four #10-32 flat-head screws (item 23) from the jackshaft bulkhead.
2.
Slowly pull the transmission from the bulkhead while feeding the shielded pairs of wires
through the holes in the bulkhead.

ROTARY PLATFORM REMOVAL (Cont'd)
(Reference drawing R182464-000)
Note:
The upper drive shaft bearing normally does not wear.  To determine
wear of the lower bearing, coompare it with the upper bearing.  If
the lower bearing is worn, replace it.
3.
When removing the lower drive shaft, lossen the magnetometer split collar (item 11 on drawing
158198-000).
4.
Use a small blade screwdriver to pry off the bearing.
5.
Use a rubber mallet to tap the new bearing into place.
6.
Tighten the split collar.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1671EB/MB CBIL DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1671EB/MB CBIL
chunk_text:
26
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1671 EB/MB CBIL 27
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1671 EB/MB CBIL

AWS MUD SUB DISASSEMBLY (Cont'd)
(Reference drawing D182468-000 and R182464-000)
12.
Remove the boots from pins 7, 8, and 9 going to the motor.
13.
Remove the remaining boots from the pressure bulkhead.
NOTE
The mud velocity transducer (item 23 of D182468-000) can be
removed at this point of disassembly.
14.
With motor housing (item 2 of R182464-000) in a vise untorque the mud sub body (item 30 of
D182468-000).  Untorque the center sub (item 4 of R182464-000) from the motor housing.  Be
careful that the wires going to the mud velocity transducer (item 23 of D182468-000) do not
tangle with those going through mud sub (item 30 of D182468-000).  Remove the mud sub
body and let the oil drain from the motor housing (item 2 of R182464-000).
NOTE
The majority of the oil will have drained from the tool by this step.
The remaining disassembly will be done on a work bench.
15.
The motor housing can be unscrewed from the center sub without pulling the wires through the
mud sub.  The wires are long enough to allow the motor housing to be slid back from the center
sub. This provides a visual inspection of the power Train.  If power Train maintenance is
required the wires must be pulled through the mud velocity sub.
16.
The wires and boots can be pulled through the mud velocity sub in the following order.  Cut off
any lacing cord tying the wires together on the bulkhead end of the mud velocity sub.
First, individually pull each of the three motor wires through the mud sub by lightly pulling on the
wires ensuring that the boots do not tangle with the other wires.
Next, individually pull each shielded cable through the mud sub.
17.
Remove o-ring (item 29 of D182468-000) and discard.

28
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1671 EB/MB CBIL
