CONDITIONS/TEST REQUIREMENTS 3

DOCUMENTATION REQUIREMENTS


ECLI-DCBIL-20-00-001
ECLIPS Instrument Operating Procedures

130609-975


Field Drawings (schematics, wiring diagrams, and assemblies) 

CHECK FOR TBS (TECHNICAL BULLETIN - FMN & OTB) RELATED TO THIS

PREREQUISITE TESTING

Before initiating system level testing, individual tests must be successfully completed.  The following
prerequisite tests are required:

CHECK FOR TBS (TECHNICAL BULLETIN - FMN & OTB) RELATED TO THIS
INSTRUMENT SERIES

Condition Base Maintenance:
OTB 2001-28, Rev. B

VERIFY WIRE PATHS
(Reference drawing F182461101 and F182481101)

Before electrical power is applied, wire paths must be confirmed:

Remove the Flask assembly from the EB electronics (Reference P/N 130609-955 and disconnect all
connectors from all printed circuit boards (printed circuit boards in the EB and MB assemblies.  Do a
complete point-to-point check of all wiring. Verify that all conductors are isolated from mass according to
diagrams.

VERIFY DC POWER SUPPLY

After verification of wire routing, but before installing any printed circuit boards, electrically connect
the EB and MB assemblies using part P/N F156590000 (32-pin male assembly) and part 146860 (32-pin
female assembly).  Do not attach the Rotating Sub.  Using the 2061 power supply, apply 180 Vac at the
Instrument's top connector; verify the following:

The ac current drawn from the 2061 is within the range 90 to 120 mA.
The dc input voltage to each voltage regulator (Reference drawing P/N F182481100):
- IC1 must be in the range of 13 V to 16 V.(+ side of C 1)
- IC2 must be in the range of 25 V to 28 V.(+ side of C 2)
- IC3 must be in the range of -25 V to -28 V.(- side of C 3)


NOTE

These input voltages drop by 20% when the MB (rotating section) is attached.

Measure the dc output of each voltage regulator.  The acceptable voltage range of each regulator is listed
in Table 956.1.

IC1

4.9 V to 5.1 V ( C 4 )

IC2

14.8 V to 15.2 V ( C 5 )

IC3

-14.8 V to -15.2 V ( C 6 )

topic: Repair Maintenance Procedures - 2.4 VERIFY AC MOTOR VOLTAGE AND TRANSMITTER DC POWER SUPPLY ................... 5
chunk_text:
VERIFY AC MOTOR VOLTAGE AND TRANSMITTER DC POWER SUPPLY
(Reference drawing P/N F182470000)

Adjust the 2061 until 180 Vrms ± 2 Vrms is measured between terminals 1 and 2 of the Terminal Board,
P/N 148669-000 in the MB Electronics.  Verify that 100 Vrms ± 5 Vrms is measured between C24 (+
side) and C26 (- side), and that 180 Vdc ± 20 Vdc is measured across R28 on the Transmitter Board, P/N
F182470000.

Also, set up the scope (channel 1) to measure the ±15 Vdc supply, connect channel 2 of the scope across
R7, and set for 50 V/div.  Set the scope to trigger off of channel 1 at approximately 3.5 Vdc.  Set the time
base on the scope to .1 sec. and slowly power up the Instrument to 180 Vac ±2 Vac.  Verify that the 180
Vdc (channel 2) stays off until the ±15 Vdc supply reaches +11 Vdc ±10%.

END PREREQUISITE TEST

Power down the instrument and reinstall printed circuit board assemblies.


*** PREREQUISITE TEST COMPLETED ***

SYSTEM TEST PROCEDURE

The test procedures described in sections 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, and 3.4 require the following Rotating Sub setup:

1.
Place the Rotating Section and 12" Aluminum Calibrator Sleeve (P/N F157851000) in the
Rotating Sub test tank (If available, use Calibration Stand P/N F156855000).  Fill test tank with
deionized tap water or distilled water which has been completely degassed (by boiling or
standing).  ANY air bubbles will prevent repeatable accurate test results.  Note: If tap water is
used allow it to set for 24 hours for degassing.  If this is not done, the signal will be highly
attenuated due to the thousands of microscopic air bubbles.

2.
Elevate the aluminum sleeve so that it is centered vertically about the Teflon window of the
Rotating Section.  If the Calibration Sleeve is used, the sleeve is automatically positioned.

3.
Align the aluminum sleeve so that it is precisely centered and parallel to the rotating section. If
the Calibration Stand is used, put the pegs in the 12 inch position and place the inside of the
aluminum sleeve against the pegs.  This centralizes the sleeve about the rotating section.  Precise
alignment is assured when the ultrasonic echo signal measured at U7 pin 6 of Transmitter Board,
P/N F182470000 does not vary in time or amplitude.

VOLTAGE GAIN

1.
Connect the 1671 EB and MB.

2.
Perform Rotating Sub setup procedure described in section 3.0.

3.
Connect the Rotating Sub to the MB electronics via Test Cable, P/N F156793000.

4.
Remove U7 from Transmitter Board assembly, P/N F182470000.

5.
Power the tool: Adjust the 2061 until 180 Vrms ± 2 Vrms is measured between terminals T3 and
T23 of the Flask Connector Board, P/N F143328000in the EB.  Verify that the downhole current
is between 500 and 800 mA.

6.
Apply a 250 kHz, 1.0 Vp-p ±.01% sine wave to P3 pin 2 on the PHA Board assembly, P/N
F182471000.

7.
Connect 10 X scope probes to "Vi" at U1 pin 3 and "Vo" at U5 pin 8 of the PHA Board assembly,
P/N F182471000.  Ground the scope probes to mux- (SIG COM).

8.
Use the CBIL keyboard commands to step through each Reflectance Gain (AGC OFF).  Verify
that the voltage gain Vo/Vi is within the allowable output range listed in Table 956.2.
At each step, verify that there is no change in input amplitude or output waveform fidelity.

9.
Power down the instrument and reinstall U7 on Transmitter Board, P/N F182470000.

PEAK DETECTOR

1.
Connect the 1671 EB and MB.

2.
Perform Rotating Sub test setup procedure described in section 3.0.

3.
Connect the Rotating Sub to the MB electronics via Test Cable, P/N F156793000.

4.
Power the tool: Adjust the 2061 until 180 Vrms ± 2 Vrms is measured between terminals T3 and
T23 of the Flask Connector Board, P/N F143328000in the EB.  Verify that the downhole current
is between 500 and 800 mA.

5.
Connect the external trigger of the scope to D6 of PHA Board assembly, P/N F182471000.

6.
Adjust the CBIL Reflectance Gain until the signal measured with a 10 X scope probe at U8 pin 6
is 2 to 3 volts peak.

7.
Simultaneously measure the signal waveforms at U5 pin 8 and U8 pin 6.  Verify that the signal at
U8 pin 6 follows the signal at U5 pin 8 up to its peak value.  Also verify that the signal at U8 pin
6 droops less than 50 mV from its maximum value.  Reference Figures 956-1 and 956-2.

VOLTAGE THRESHOLD

1.
Connect the 1671 EB and MB.

2.
Perform Rotating Sub test setup procedure described in section 3.0.

3.
Connect the Rotating Sub to the MB electronics via Test Cable, P/N F156793000.

4.
Power the tool: Adjust the 2061 until 180 Vrms ± 2 Vrms is measured between terminals T3 and
T23 of the Flask Connector Board, P/N F143328000 in the EB.  Verify that the downhole current
is between 500 and 800 mA.

5.
Using the CBIL keyboard commands to change the Reflectance Threshold Values (AGC OFF),
verify that the voltage at U11 pin 3 on the PHA Board (use a scope probe), P/N F182471000
changes per Table 956-3 ± 5%.  The threshold indicator on the PC Signature window should also
indicate the change in threshed voltage, although it will not be an accurate reading.


*** VOLTAGE THRESHOLD TEST COMPLETED ***

TRAVEL TIME MEASUREMENT

1.
Connect the 1671 EB and MB.

2.
Perform Rotating Sub test setup procedure described in section 3.0.

3.
Connect the Rotating Sub to the MB electronics via Test Cable, P/N F156793000.

4.
Power the tool: Adjust the 2061 until 180 Vrms ± 2 Vrms is measured between terminals T3 and
T23 of the Flask Connector Board, P/N F143328000 in the EB.  Verify that the downhole current
is between 500 and 800 mA.

5.
With the AGC on, verify that the first pulse at U11 pin 7 occurs between 166 and 178 μs and
corresponds to the second or third positive voltage at U10 pin 6.  (The 12 μs variation in time
allows for test tank water temperatures of 0 to 40°C.)

7.
Power down the tool.


*** TRAVEL TIME MEASUREMENT TEST COMPLETED ***

FLASH CONVERTER, STATIC TEST 13

FLASH CONVERTER, STATIC TEST
(Reference drawing F182471000, F182471000, and F148682100)

1.
Connect the 1671 EB.

2.
Remove U10 from PHA Board P/N F182471000.

3.
Power the tool:  Adjust the 2061 until 180 Vrms ± 2 Vrms is measured between terminals T3 and
T23 of the Flask Connector Board, P/N F143328000 in the EB.  Verify that the downhole current
is between 500 and 800 mA.

4.
Apply 0.0 Vdc ± 1 mVdc from a dc voltage source to U10 pin 6 referenced to AGND on the PHA
Board.

5.
Vary the dc voltage source as tabulated in Table 956.4.  Verify the measured values in Table
956.4 with a digital volt meter for each increment of the dc voltage source.

6.
Turn off and disconnect the dc voltage source, power down the tool and replace U10 on the PHA
Board.


*** FLASH CONVERTER, STATIC TEST COMPLETED ***


U10 PIN 6
(PHA BOARD)
[Vdc]
ADATA+
WITH RESPECT
TO ADATA-
(FLASH BOARD)
[Vdc]  ±5%
IC1, PIN 6
(FLASH BOARD)
[Vdc]  ±5%

ORIENTATION VERIFICATION

1.
Connect the 1671 EB and MB.

2.
Place the Rotating Section in the Rotating Sub test tank.  Fill test tank with deionized tap water or
distilled water which has been completely degassed (by boiling or standing).  ANY air bubbles
will prevent repeatable accurate test results.

3.
Use a magnetic compass to locate North.  Suspend the non-magnetic Target (Section 1.0, item 8)
at magnetic North on the inside surface of the Rotating Sub test tank.

4.
Align the Tool Body Mark on the Rotating Sub with the Metal Target.

5.
Connect the Rotating Sub to the MB electronics via Test Cable, P/N F156793000.

6.
Power the tool: Adjust the 2061 until 180 Vrms ± 2 Vrms is measured between terminals T3 and
T23 of the Flask Connector Board, P/N F143328000 in the EB.  Verify that the downhole current
is between 500 and 800 mA.

7.
Using the CBIL keyboard commands -
• Select the 1.5" Transducer.
• Select Tool Body Mark Orientation.
• Turn AGC ON.
• Select Reflectance Gate to obtain the signal on PC screen.

8.
Verify that the non-magnetic target is visible at the 12 o'clock position in Time of Flight and A/D
Input windows as shown in Figure 956-3.

9.
Change the Orientation to Magnetometer and verify that the position of the non-magnetic target
does not move from the 12 o'clock position.


*** ORIENTATION TEST COMPLETED ***

TRANSDUCER SENSITIVITY

1.
Connect the 1671 EB and MB.

2.
Perform Rotating Sub test setup procedure described in section 3.0.

3.
Connect the Rotating Sub to the MB electronics via Test Cable, P/N F156793000.

4.
Power the tool: Adjust the 2061 until 180 Vrms ± 2 Vrms is measured between terminals T3 and
T23 of the Flask Connector Board, P/N F143328000 in the EB.  Verify that the downhole current
is between 500 and 800 mA.

5.
Using the CBIL keyboard commands -
• Select the 1.5" Transducer.
• Select Tool Body Mark Orientation.
• Turn AGC ON.

6.
Verify that the peak amplitude of the waveform on the Signature Plot is between 2.5 and 3.85
volts peak.

7.
Select the 2.0" Transducer and verify that the waveform on the Signature plot is between 2.5 and
3.85 volts peak.

8.
Install the plastic jacket (Section 1, item 6) around the Mud Sub transducer chamber and fill with
clean water.  Insure that there are no air bubbles in the chamber.

9.
Change element 11 of the CBIL EDIT table to a value of 251 to display the Mud Sub transducer
waveform on the Signature Plot.

10.
Record the peak amplitude measured on the Signature Plot.


*** TRANSDUCER SENSITIVITY TEST COMPLETED ***

MAGNETOMETER TUNING

Reference Drawings

-  Magnetometer Tuning Board Assembly (P/N F154450000)
-  Magnetometer Tuning Board Schematic (P/N F154450100)
-  Pulse-Echo Mudsub Assembly (P/N F182468000)
-  Pulse-Echo Mudsub Wiring Diagram (P/N F153423100)
-  Magnetometer Board Assembly (P/N F148681000)
-  Magnetometer Board Schematic (P/N F148681100)


Using a dual trace oscilloscope, measure the signals at the emitter of Q1 and U7-pin 3 on the 1671 MB
Electronics Magnetometer Board, P/N F148681000.

As shown in the sinusoidal signal at U7-pin 3 should cross zero when the square wave signal at the
emitter of Q1 changes polarity.  The allowable time difference between zero crossings is ±10 μs.

The zero crossing of the sinusoidal signal can be varied by adjusting the value of R1 on the
Magnetometer Tuning Board, P/N F154450000 located in the top sub of the rotating section.  Typical
values for R1 range from 180 Ω to 280 Ω.  R1 should be a RS-2 B (3 watt, ±20 PPM TC) type resistor.

MOTOR ROTATION PERIOD

1.
Connect the EB, MB and Rotating Section.

2.
Power the tool: Adjust the 2061 until 180 Vrms ± 2 Vrms is measured between terminals T3 and
T23 of the Flask Connector Board, P/N F143328000 in the EB.  Verify that the downhole current
is between 500 and 800 mA.

3.
Measure the "MARK" signal at U4 pin 12 on the Magnetometer Board, P/N F148681000.
Correct motor rotation speed is verified when the frequency of this signal is measured to be 9.9 to
11.7 Hz.


*** MOTOR ROTATION TEST COMPLETED ***

topic: Repair Maintenance Procedures - 9.0 VERIFICATION OF TRANSMITTER ONE SHOT PULSE WIDTH ................................... 19
chunk_text:
VERIFICATION OF TRANSMITTER ONE SHOT PULSE WIDTH

1.
Connect the EB, MB Electronics.

2.
Power the tool: Adjust the 2061 until 180 Vrms ± 2 Vrms is measured between terminals T3 and
T23 of the Flask Connector Board, P/N F143328000in the EB.  Verify that the downhole current
is between 500 and 800 mA.

3.
Using the CBIL keyboard commands -
• Select the 1.5" Transducer.
• Select HI for item 8 on CBIL Edit Table.
• Down Load the Edit Table.

4.
Verify that the pulse width of the one-shot signal at U3 pin 5 is 1.8 μs ± 5%.

5.
Using the CBIL keyboard commands -
• Select the 1.5" Transducer.
• Select LO for item 8 on CBIL Edit Table.
• Down Load the Edit Table.

6.
Verify that the pulse width of the one-shot signal at U3 pin 5 is 0.6μs ± 5%.


*** VERIFICATION OF TRANSMITTER ONE SHOT PULSE WIDTH COMPLETED***

topic: Repair Maintenance Procedures - 10.0 TOOL BODY AND MAGNETOMETER ALIGNMENT PROCEDURE 1671 CBIL
chunk_text:
TOOL BODY AND MAGNETOMETER ALIGNMENT PROCEDURE 1671 CBIL
ROTATING SECTION (MANDREL)

This procedure covers the alignment procedure for the Tool Body Mark and Magnetometer on the 1671
CBIL instrument.  This procedure is required whenever the rotating platform is disengaged from the
power train.  This procedure mechanically aligns the 1.5" rotating transducer to external tool body mark
on the CBIL tool, and verifies the alignment of the magnetometer coil to the 1.5" rotating transducer.

LAB TEST EQUIPMENT REQUIRED

-
Kit Strobe Adapter (P/N F132324000)
-
Power Supply +15 Vdc
-
Transducer Alignment Test Stand (P/N F244781300)
-
Cable Assy Test Rev D Rotator (P/N F156793000)
-
Cable Assy Jumper 32-Cnd (P/N F148988000)
-
Cable Assy 8-Cnd (P/N 77685-000)
-
Panel 5721 Analog Test System (P/N F151759000)
-
Panel 2061 AC Power Supply (P/N 083279-000) 

REFERENCE DRAWINGS

-
1671 MB DCBIL Mechanical Assembly (P/N F182460000)
-
1671 MB DCBIL Electronic Assembly (P/N F182461000)
-
Assembly WTS Top Sub (P/N F182475000)
-
Assembly Rev. D Rotating Section (P/N F182464000)
-
Card PC 1671 MB DCBIL Magnetometer (P/N F148681000)
-

ALIGNMENT PROCEDURE

1.
Tool Preparation
(Reference drawings F182475000, F182460000, F182464000, and F158196000)

a.
Remove the WTS Top Sub, 1671 MB electronics, and pressure housing from the top of
the Coupler Sub (Reference 130609-955, Section 8.1).

b.
Remove the Bellows Housing, Bellows, Jackshaft to Bellows Adapter Bulkhead, and
Teflon Window from the 1671 MB rotating section (Reference 130609-955, Sections
8.2, 8.3, 8.5, and 8.6).

c.
Screw the retaining nut (item 17 of F158196000) onto the jackshaft (item 30 of
F182464000) to secure the rotating platform (item 13 of F182464000).

d.
Slide the split aluminum collar assembly (item 6 of F158196000) over the rotating
platform (item 13 of F182464000) and onto the stator housing (item 5 of F182464000).

e.
Align the key way on the stator housing (item 5 of F182464000) with the key way in the
split aluminum collar (item 6 of F158196000) and key with a piece of bus wire.

f.
Secure the split aluminum collar (item 6 of F158196000) to the stator housing (item 5 of
F182464000) with the two socket head cap screws (item 16 of F158196000).

13.

14.

equivalent).

topic: Repair Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES - 1671EB/MB CBIL
chunk_text:
23

REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES - 1671 EB/MB CBIL

ALIGNMENT PROCEDURE (Cont'd)

2.
Test Stand Setup (Reference drawing F158196000)

a.
Position the test stand (item 1) on a reasonably flat surface away from strong magnetic
fields.

b.
Position the compass assembly (item 7) on top of the test stand (item 1) and key to the
stand with the alignment pin (item 9).

c.
Rotate the test stand (item 1) until the compass (item 8) reads North.  Do not move any
magnetic objects in the proximity of the test stand during transducer alignment.

d.
Level the test stand (item 1) by adjusting the leveling screws (item 5) on the base of the
stand until the bubble level (item 10) is centered.

e.
Continue repeating steps c and d until the test stand is oriented to North and the bubble
level is centered.

f.
Carefully remove the alignment pin (item 9) and compass assembly (item 7) from the test
stand.

g.
Carefully insert the rotating section into the test stand.  Do not disturb the test stand
orientation.  Rotate the tool until the alignment pin (item 9) can be inserted through the
split aluminum collar (item 6) and into the top plate (item 2) on the test stand.

h.
Connect the rotating section to the 1671 MB electronics with test cable
P/N F156793000.  Connect the 1671 MB electronics to the 1671 EB electronics.  Connect
the 1671 EB electronics to the 5721 Analog Test Panel with test cable P/N F148988000.
Connect the 5721 Analog Test Panel to the 2061 Power Supply with test cable P/N
77685-000.  The electronics, rotating section and panels are cabled as shown in Figure
956-6.

topic: Repair Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES - 1671EB/MB CBIL
chunk_text:
24

REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES - 1671 EB/MB CBIL

ALIGNMENT PROCEDURE (Cont'd)

3.
Tool Body Mark Alignment
(Reference drawings F182464000 and F148681000)

a.
Power up the 2061 power supply to 180 Vac, the current should read approximately
550 ma.

b.
Assemble the strobe adapter kit (P/N F132324000) as shown in Figure 956-7.  Connect
the strobe adapter box to a 15 Vdc power supply.

c.
Connect the positive probe (red lead) to R9 on the magnetometer board as shown in
Connect the negative probe (black lead) to C1 on the magnetometer board as shown in
Aim the timing light at the tool body mark machined on the stator housing and depress
the trigger on the timing light.  Refer to Figure 956-9 for the location of the timing marks
on the stator housing and the rotating platform.


NOTE
Both the 1.5" and 2.0" rotating transducers have machined marks
above them on the rotating platform.  The 1.5" rotating transducer
can be identified while the platform is spinning by the brass
mounting plate in which it is assembled.


f.
The strobe timing light will "freeze" the alignment mark above the 1.5" transducer on the
rotating platform.  Note the angular offset between the center mark on the rotating
platform and the tool body mark machined on the stator housing.

g.
Power down the 2061 power supply.  Rotate the rotating platform to the orientation seen
by the strobe of the timing light.  Loosen the retaining nut on the bottom of the jackshaft
about 3/8 of an inch.  Slide the rotating platform straight down to disengage from the
power train.  Rotate the rotating platform to align the timing marks.  Slide the rotating
platform back up to engage the power train.  Tighten the retaining nut.

h.
Power up the 2061 power supply and repeat steps e through g.  Alignment is achieved
when the two timing marks coincide within 2 machined marks on the rotating platform,
each machined mark is 1 degree.

topic: Repair Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES - 1671EB/MB CBIL
chunk_text:
25

REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES - 1671 EB/MB CBIL

ALIGNMENT PROCEDURE (Cont'd)

4.
Magnetometer Alignment
(Reference drawings F182464000 and F148681000)

a.
If the magnetometer coil is not rotated with respect to the rotating platform while the
platform was removed from the tool the orientation should still be correct; however, the
orientation must still be verified.

b.
Power up the 2061 power supply to 180 Vac, the current should read approximately
550 ma.

c.
Connect the strobe adapter box to a 15 Vdc power supply.

d.
Connect the positive probe (red lead) to R53 on the magnetometer board as shown in
Connect the negative probe (black lead) to C1 on the magnetometer board as shown in
Aim the timing light at the tool body mark machined on the stator housing and depress
the trigger on the timing light.

g.
The strobe timing light will "freeze" the alignment mark above the 1.5" transducer on the
rotating platform.  Note the angular offset of the two timing marks.  Refer to Figure
956-9 for the location of the timing marks on the stator housing and the rotating platform.

h.
Power down the 2061 power supply.  Rotate the rotating platform to the orientation seen
by the strobe of the timing light.  Loosen the screw on the lock ring retaining the
magnetometer coil.  Rotate the magnetometer coil in the direction of the noted offset
between the tool body mark on the stator housing and the center mark machined on the
rotating platform.  Tighten the retaining screw to secure the magnetometer coil.

i.
Power up the 2061 power supply and repeat steps f through h.  Alignment is achieved
when the two timing marks coincide within 2 machined marks on the rotating platform,
each machined mark is 1 degree.

LABORATORY HEAT TEST PROCEDURES - 1671 EB/MB CBIL

Place the 1671 MB rotating section in the water filled test barrel.  Center the 12" aluminum test
sleeve, P/N 157851-000, around the teflon window.
Using a compass, locate magnetic north and align the Tool Body Mark exactly with the compass
needle.

Connect the bottom of the 1671 MB electronics to the top of the rotating section and power up
Instrument to 180 Vac.

Using CBIL keyboard commands, select: AGC off; 2" Transducer; T.B.M; Signature gate to
140.  Set Reflectance Gain to 36 dB (Reference 1671 EA/MA Gain values in component -976,
Section 8.0).  This will ensure that at least 2 stages of gain are in use on the PHA Board.

Using clip leads and a resistive decade box, connect across R31 on Transmitter Board, P/N
182470-000 such that the observed signal on the A/D Input on the PC screen is between 2 V
and 3 V.  The value of the resistor used across R31 will be approximately equal to 2 K ohms.

Power the Instrument down and remove the clip leads.  Solder a resistor with the value
determined in step 4 across R31 using high temperature solder.
Solder a wire on U4 pin 7 of PCB, P/N 182470-000.  Solder a wire on ground; negative side of
C10 on PCB, P/N 182470-000.
NOTE
Make the wires long enough to reach outside of the oven.

Place the 1671 EB and 1671 MB electronics in the oven.  The 1671 EB electronics will have the
Heat Flask installed.

Repeat steps 2 and 3.

Place a non magnetic target in the water filled barrel such that one edge is aligned directly with
signature number one; i.e. 12 o'clock on the Travel Time Polar Plot.  This target will be used
to determine TBM and Magnetometer drift, so it is critical there is no movement of the rotating
section or target from this point on.  Verify the edge of the target is aligned with the TBM on

LABORATORY HEAT TEST PROCEDURES - 1671 EB/MB CBIL

The procedure will be to record the data in Table 959.1 Temperature Test at room
temperature.  Use whatever CBIL Keyboard commands are necessary to fill in the table for the
following times and temperatures.
200  F
30 MINUTES
o
300  F
30 MINUTES
o
400  F
60 MINUTES
o
10.
To make accurate measurements of the Reflectance Amplitude Plot, set the Shade Levels
(Display Options on the PC screen) for a min/max range of 200 m Volts so the signal plot is in
the middle of this range.  Adjust min/max levels accordingly to maximize the accuracy of your
measurements.  The maximum reflectance amplitude should not vary more than ±10% from the
measurement taken at room temperature.
11.
Use the signature indicator on the Travel Time Polar Plot to determine TBM and Magnetometer
drift.   At room temperature one edge of the target should align with signature number one. 
The edge of the target should not move more than ±1 signature; i.e. the edge of the target
should stay between signature number 250 and signature number 2.
12.
Fire Pulse Width will be measured using a scope connected across the two wires soldered in
step 5, and should not vary more than ±15% from the room temperature measurement.
13.
Travel Time measurement will be made using the signature wave display and cursors on the PC.
NOTE
Be sure to use the same signature number during each measurement.
The measurement should not vary more than ±2% from the room temperature measurement.
3

topic: Test Systems Guide - TEST SYSTEM GUIDE - 1671EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG 1.0 INTRODUCTION . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3

1
TEST SYSTEM GUIDE - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG


Page
---------
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------   ------ 

INTRODUCTION
The current DCBIL 5721 PC test system software (version 1.01) was not designed to test a
1671 EB/MB STAR Compatible DCBIL.  But it can be made to work by using the work around
instructions at the beginning of section 8.0 (CBIL TABLE EDIT).  Sometime in the future the 5721
PC test system software will be modified to make it easier to test a 1671 EB/MB DCBIL.
The purpose of PC Tool-Diagnostic software (DCDIAG.EXE, and called DCDIAG hereafter) is to aid
the manufacture of quality instruments by providing standardized test methods, and to provide
standardized data records.
This software is for WALS manufacturing personnel and WALS field repair personnel.  This software
operates stand-alone in PC with WTS1 PC printed circuit assembly.
DCDIAG has the same capabilities as Digital CBIL software (DCBIL.EXE) for 3798 Auxiliary
Processor, e.g. Realtime processing and Realtime output, except that DEPTH representation is replaced
by ELAPSE TIME.

SOFTWARE/HARDWARE REQUIREMENTS 3
1.1.1
SOFTWARE REQUIREMENTS 3
1.1.2

SOFTWARE/HARDWARE REQUIREMENTS
1.1.1
SOFTWARE REQUIREMENTS
DOS
MS-DOS Version 3.30 or higher
DOS
In the CONFIG.SYS file both BUFFERS and FILES must be set to 20
ENVIRONMENT
or greater.
SET49 H.EXE
This program is used to set up the operating environment for the DCDIAG
program.  If you normally run under the WDS environment, this is already set
up.  Otherwise, it (SET49 H) should be included in the AUTOEXEC.BAT file,
or it can be entered at the DOS prompt.  (For an example of how it should
appear in an autoexec.bat file, refer to the sample DIAG.BAT file (see  Section
1.2) which is included with the DCBIL software.)
DCDIAG.EXE This program monitors, processes, and records data from the 1671 DCBIL tool.
SETPANEL.EXE
This program is to set WTS1 PC Interface card.  Prior to calling DCDIAG (or
DIAG.BAT), this must be called.  Command is "> setpanel /i".
DIAGHELP.HLP
This is the text file explaining how to operate the system.
1.1.2
HARDWARE REQUIREMENTS
PC (386/25)
The DCDIAG.EXE requires a minimum 386 PC 25/33 MHz.
-
EGA Graphics Capability
-
300 MByte Hard Disk. (600 Mbyte preferred).
-
80387 Coprocessor
-
WTS1 PC Interface Card for PC (P/N 150690-000)
RAYTHEON PLOTTER, (WALS P/N 140144-000)
5721 TEST PANEL
2061 POWER SUPPLY
ALL ASSOCIATED CABLES

HOW TO START 4
1.2.1
SAMPLE DIAG.BAT 4

HOW TO START

Remove the old setup file (SETUPDIA.FLE) if any.

Make sure SET49 H was called since system was booted.

Set panel by calling "SETPANEL /i" at DOS prompt.

Invoke DCDIAG program.

(OPTIONAL) If DIAG.BAT is properly set, the user can replace the above steps by calling
DIAG.BAT (see the sample DIAG.BAT in the following section).
1.2.1
SAMPLE DIAG.BAT
@echo off
if "%W49 H%"=="" call set49h
set W49 H=ON
set fort9=a3791:
call setpanel /i
call dcdiag.exe

BASIC MENU OPERATION
The main menu has five options:  Display Setup, Operating Mode, System Utilities, CBIL Table Edit
and Begin Data Acquisition.  Selections are made by moving the cursor bar, which highlights an option
in white.  The cursor bar is moved by using the arrow keys.  Move the highlight bar to the desired
selection and depress the <CR> key.  Choosing an option from this main menu presents other sub-
menus or system prompts.  To exit a menu without making a selection or a change, depress the
<ESC> key.  Using the <CR> will enter a selection.
To exit the program depress the <ESC> key while in the main menu, then enter Y at the prompt.

CONTROL KEYS 5
2.1.1
FUNCTION KEYS 5
2.1.2
ALPHA NUMERIC KEYS 5
2.1.3

CONTROL KEYS
2.1.1
FUNCTION KEYS
<F1>
On line HELP displays the entire User's Guide.
<F2>
In STANDBY mode, this toggles between IMAGE and POLAR CRT.
<F3>
Toggles (Switches) the Auxiliary curve table to System status table.
<F4>
If you have enough memory available, you can return to DOS without exiting DCBIL,
by using the F4 key. To return to the CBIL program, type `exit<CR>'.
<F5>
Starts STANDBY, PLAYBACK or RECORD.
<Alt-F2>
Toggles either Aux. curve table or system table to A/D input amplitude polar plot.
<Alt-F3>
Toggles Travel time polar to reflectance polar plot.
2.1.2
ALPHA NUMERIC KEYS
<I>
Increments the cursor step size.
<SPACE>
Toggles the arrow keys between MENU and CURSOR control.
<ESC>
Exits current submenu, exits acquisition of data or exits program entirely.
NOTE
<I> and <SPACE> are used only for the Signature wave display.
2.1.3

Moves the menu display bar up or moves the cursor up
<DOWN>
Moves the menu display bar down or moves the cursor down
<RIGHT>
Moves the cursor right
<LEFT>
Moves the cursor left

topic: Test Systems Guide - 3.0 SCREEN DISPLAY SUMMARY . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 6
chunk_text:
SCREEN DISPLAY SUMMARY
The CRT screen allows the user to view acoustic signatures from the CBIL tool, and auxiliary curves.
There are two CRT displays: POLAR CRT and IMAGE CRT.  The display screen for POLAR CRT
and IMAGE CRT is divided into seven sections (see Figure 976-1) and four sections (see Figure 976-2),
respectively.

POLAR CRT
1.
Function Key Labels
These are displayed as a menu bar.  <Alt-F2> and <Alt-F3> are not
displayed in this area.
2.
Main Menu
Listing of entries for system functions (Display Setup, Operating Mode,
System Utilities, CBIL Table Edit and Data Acquisition)
3.
Signature Plot
Signature wave with wave ID is displayed as wave form.  The cursor key is
available to measure the timing and the peak to peak voltage of the wave.
The threshold marker is also displayed.  The cursor key control is enabled
by pressing the space-bar.
4.
Polar Plot
Travel time polar with 250 wave IDs is displayed.  For Travel Time polar
plot, the innermost blue circle represents the tool.  The first inner green
circle represents a radius of 2 inches (50 mm in Metric).  The spacing of
each successive circle represents an increase in radius of 0.5 inch (10 mm
in Metric).  <Alt-F3> toggles Travel time polar plot to Reflectance polar
plot.  A red line on the polar plot denotes Wave Id of the wave displayed in
the Signature plot area.  Reference North is displayed in PLAYBACK
mode.  It is denoted by a blue line.
5.
Submenu / Table / Extra Polar Plot
Most entries in the main menu prompt the submenus. Those submenus
appear in this area.
During data acquisition, value of auxiliary curves is shown in this area too.
Pressing <F3> toggles auxiliary curve table to system status table.
<Alt-F2> toggles one of those tables to A/D Input Amplitude Polar plot.
A red line in the polar plot denotes Wave Id of the wave displayed in the
Signature plot area.  Reference North is displayed in PLAYBACK mode.  It
is denoted by a blue line.
6.
Dialogue Box
Specific menu entries show a message dialogue box in this area to prompt
the user to confirm that entry.  If the user selects the improper menu item
or provides an improper response, the error message dialogue box appears.
7.
Status Line
At the bottom of the screen, the status and messages are displayed.  The
first message is Elapse Time in data block.  For example, if elapse time in
data block is 327.4 second, ETIME :   327.4 SEC will be displayed.  The
second and the third are the plot device and the operating mode,
respectively.
F u n c t i o n      K e  y      L a  b  e  l  s
B o t t o m      S t a t u s      L i n e
Reflectance Amplitude
Travel Time
1000
1001
1002
1003
1
2
3
4

IMAGE CRT
1.
Function Key Labels
Same as POLAR CRT.
2.
Reflectance Amplitude Color image of Reflectance amplitude.  The range of color shade level is
selected by the user.
3.
Travel Time
Color image of Travel Time.  The range of color shade level is selected by
the user.
4.
Status Line
Same as POLAR CRT.


WTS Digital CBIL
Display Setup
Operating Mode
System Utilities
CBIL Table Edit
Begin Data Acquisition

MAIN MENU
The main menu consists of 5 entries: Display Setup, Operating Mode, System Utilities, CBIL Table Edit
and Begin Data Acquisition.  Each entry is described in the next section.

topic: Test Systems Guide - 5.0 DISPLAY SETUP . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 5.1 PLOT OUTPUT DEVICE
chunk_text:
DISPLAY SETUP 
PLOT OUTPUT DEVICE
10
5.1  PLOT OUTPUT DEVICE
Selecting this entry allows the user to select the type of data display and the output device.
3791 Plotter
Selects the Atlas Series 3791 XA thermal plotter.  The user must have Set
FORT9=A3791: before execution of the program.
CBIL Image (CRT)
Selects the Amplitude/Travel Time Color image to the screen.  The images along
with depth are plotted with 14 different colors levels (scrolling display).
Polar Plot (CRT)
Select the polar plot option.  Both Amplitude and Travel Time Polar plots are
presented on the CRT except during RECORD MODE.  In RECORD MODE only
the travel time polar plot is shown.
No Plot
No plot will be on the CRT.
Disk: Raster
A raster image is stored on disk to allow high speed playback of the data.  Program
RCBIL.EXE or RCOPY.EXE is used to playback raster files.  Note: Prior to
running the program, DCBIL.EXE, the user must set logical device FORT9 to the
name of the disk Raster File.  (SET FORT9 = Atlas.001)

topic: Test Systems Guide - 5.2 LOG PLOT OPTIONS . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
LOG PLOT OPTIONS 11
5.2  LOG PLOT OPTIONS
Selecting this entry presents the plot options.
Plot Dual Image
If ON, both Amplitude and travel time images are plotted in the R Track.
If OFF then only the Amplitude image is plotted in the R track (amplitude
image will be expanded). Default is ON.
Amplitude min..max
If ON and not in Log Mode, a histogram of the Amplitude data is
computed.  The Minimum, Maximum, and Median amplitude curves are
computed. Default is OFF.
Plot Header/Scales
If ON, the system will plot scales, parameters and a short header at the
beginning and end of the log.  Default is ON.
Mirror Plot
If ON, the system will plot a mirror image of the data to the specified plot
device.  Default is OFF.
Image Rotation
<CR> at this entry turns The Image Alignment to Magnetometer North (if Tool
orientation was TBM when the data were recorded) or TBM (if Tool orientation
was MAG when the data were recorded) ON or OFF.  This option is enabled only
in PLAYBACK mode.  Default is OFF.
Auxiliary Orientation
<CR> at this entry turns Magnetometer North (if Tool orientation is
TBM) / TBM (if tool orientation is MAG North) marker ON or OFF.
Default is OFF.
The user can select the option either by toggling it or by providing the proper value, and press <ESC> to
return to the parent menu at the end of selecting the option(s).

CURVE SCALES 12
5.3  CURVE SCALES
This entry displays a table of the auxiliary curves.  This allows the user to modify curve names, select the
curves to be plotted, set curve scales, and choose the type of line plotted.
Curve Names
The user may modify the ASCII names of the curves plotted on the log.  The user
should be aware that changing a curve name does not change the value stored in the
curve. (Changing SPD to TENSION will not generate a tension curve,  the speed
curve will just be named TENSION).
Minimum
Minimum scale, the lowest value that will be plotted on the log.  (This will affect
Aux. curve values displayed on the CRT)
Maximum
Maximum scale, the largest value that will be plotted on the log.  (This will affect
Aux. curve values displayed on the CRT)
TYPE
Line Type:
0
Solid curve
>0
Dash curve (length of dash determined by value of type)
Thickness
Width of the curve in paper dots.
Enable
The curve will be plotted only if Enable is equal to 1.

SHADE LEVELS 13
5.4  SHADE LEVELS
Selecting this entry presents the table with high and low cut-off values for amplitude image and travel time
image.  The shade level cut-off for the images is determined by the user.
Reflectance (Amplitude)
The values shown represent millivolts (0..5000 mV).  The Minimum
represents the cutoff for black, and any value less than minimum will be
black.  The Maximum represents the shade cutoff for white, and any value
greater than Maximum will be white.  Values between Min and Max are
represented by a grey shade.
Range (Travel Time)
The values shown represent the borehole radius in inches.  The minimum
radius represents the cutoff for white, and any values less than Min will be
White.  The Maximum Radius represents the cutoff for black, and any
values greater than the Max will be black.  Values between Min and Max
are represented by a grey shade.  The scaling for the range is Opposite from
the Amplitude Presentation.  The Maximum radius is used for scaling of the
Polar Plot (see Polar Plot).  The unit is inch in English.  (In Metric, default
unit is mm.  However, if user's response to "Display Caliper in INCH?
[N]:" is YES, this unit becomes inch.

CURVE FILTER
13
5.5  CURVE FILTER
Selecting this entry presents FILTER option and allows the user to filter auxiliary curves as necessary.
Binomial Filter
an eleven point filter similar to the CLS Medium Filter.  However, four acoustic
radius curves (R001, R062, R125 and R187) are not filtered at all.
No Filter
"none" of the curves will be filtered.

PARALLEL PORT 13
5.6  PARALLEL PORT
The 1669 XA Raytheon TDU-850 thermal plotter utilizes the parallel port on the PC as the interface.  The
address of this port can be selected as LPT1 or LPT2.  The actual hardware definition of the address of
LPT1 and LPT2 may vary depending on the manufacturer of the IBM compatible PC.

OPERATING MODE
In this system, there are 4 different modes; IDLE, STANDBY, PLAYBACK and RECORD. However,
IDLE mode is not in Operating Mode submenu.  Whenever data acquisition is done, system becomes IDLE
mode.  <F1>, <F2>, <F4> and <F5> work in this mode.

PLAYBACK
Selecting this mode pops up the cascading menu, Input File/Device, and the user must select one of the
followings:
Disk File:
<CR> here prompts the user to input a filename.
FILE: ___________________
Enter the filename here.  If the file does not exist, the error message box will be shown, "FILE DOES
NOT EXIST".  However, if the file is in a different directory, the user needs to go back to the main
menu, press <F4> to enable DOS shell, change directory where that file is located, and exit to return to
the main menu.  Then select this menu option.
FILE_01.TAP
Select default tape file number.
Set File Number
<CR> here prompts the user to enter a tape file number.
NONE
Select NO FILE.

RECORD
Selecting this mode pops up the cascading menu, Output File/Device, and the user must select one of the
followings to record the data.
Disk File
<CR> here prompts the user to input a filename.
FILE: ___________________
Enter the filename here.  If the file exists already, the warning message box will be shown, "FILE
ALREADY EXISTS".  If the user hits <ESC>, then the new data will be overwritten to this file.  If the
user does not want to overwrite data to that file, he must select another file name.
FILE_01.TAP
Select default tape file number.
Set File Number
<CR> here prompts the user to enter a tape file number.
NONE
Select NO FILE.
In this mode, data will be acquired and recorded as a disk file in the tape image file format.  While data is
recorded, the polar and signature wave will be displayed on the CRT.  If the user requests an image plot,
the reflectance amplitude, travel time and auxiliary curves will be plotted on the thermal plotter. Note that
<F3>, <Alt-F2> and <Alt-F3> work in this mode.

STANDBY
In this mode, all data is updated at each depth interrupt, but no data is recorded.  The user can select any
plotting device.  Note that <F2>, <F3>, <Alt-F2> and <Alt-F3> work in this mode.

INTERVAL
This interval means how often the data needs to be recorded.  Default is 0.3 second.  The smallest interval
will be the minimum system time to process one data block.  To illustrate this, suppose the user changes
this to 0.01 second.  However, if system spends more than 0.01 second to process 1 data block, the data
will not be recorded every 0.01 second.  In other words, the data will be recorded every minimum system
elapse time.

SYSTEM UTILITIES
This utility provides a conventional method of saving specific display and plotting setups.
Selecting this entry presents the following cascading menu entries:

SETUP UTILITY
Selecting this menu item presents the SETUP UTILITY menu.
Save Setup File
<CR> at this entry will store all current setup parameters to the
SETUPDIA.FLE disk file.
Restore Setup File
<CR> at this entry will load the setup parameters stored in the
SETUPDIA.FLE into the program and override the previous setup
parameters.

HEADER UTILITY
<CR> at this selection opens the HEADER UTILITY menu.  The options are (recording) Date, Job
Number, 1st Tool ID & Asset #, 2nd Tool ID & Asset #, 3rd Tool ID & Asset #, 4th Tool ID & Asset #,
Test Technician Name, Q.A. Technician Name and Test Condition.
Entering a <CR> at any of those menus allows the user to change value of the item in the header.

UNITS
<CR> at this entry toggles the log units ENGLISH or METRIC.  Note that Metric units are fully
supported.
NOTE:
If Metric is selected, system will prompt Display Caliper in INCH? [N]: and Y will result
in all caliper units in "inch" (default answer is NO, and default unit is "mm").  Then
system will prompt English Unit for Slowness? [N]: and Y will result in Mud Slowness
unit to be "µs/ft" (default answer is NO, and default unit is "µs/m").

topic: Test Systems Guide - 7.4 MUD VELOCITY CAL. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
MUD VELOCITY CAL.
The mud slowness is calibrated to the units of µs/ft (µs/m in Metric), and <CR> at this entry allows the
user to change the M (multiplicative) factor and the A (additive) factor.

topic: Test Systems Guide - 7.5 ACOUSTIC RADII CALIBRATION
chunk_text:
ACOUSTIC RADII CALIBRATION
The acoustic radii calibration values are used by the system to determine the computational factors
necessary to convert the raw travel time image data to a distance or range.  <CR> at this entry opens the
CALIPER CALIBRATION menu.
Mud slowness
<CR> at this entry will ask the user to provide the correct Mud Slowness.
Default Mud Slowness is 189 µs/ft (620.079 µs/m in Metric).
Delay Time
<CR> at this entry will ask the user to provide the correct Delay Time.
Default Delay Time is 30 µs.  Delay time is the 2 way travel time for the
beam to travel through the oil filled void between transducer and window.
Auto Slowness Calc.
<CR> at this entry will toggle the manual option ON or OFF.  If this
option is OFF, then Mud Slowness and Delay Time are fixed to the values
in this CALIPER CALIBRATION menu, and acoustic radii will be
calculated based on these values.  If this option is ON, then for each tool
rotation, Mud Slowness will be calculated based on the current fluid travel
time (FLTT), and M & A factor values in MUD VELOCITY
CALIBRATION menu.  Default is OFF.

topic: Test Systems Guide - TEST SYSTEM GUIDE - 1671EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG 9.0 BEGIN DATA ACQUISITION . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
2
TEST SYSTEM GUIDE - 1671 EB/MB CIRCUMFERENTIAL BOREHOLE IMAGING LOG


Page
---------
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------   ------ 

BEGIN DATA ACQUISITION
Selecting this menu item starts the data acquisition in STANDBY, PLAYBACK or RECORD mode.
In STANDBY or PLAYBACK mode, this entry has the same effect as pressing the function key, F5, except
that since the main menu is disappeared when the image CRT is chosen as the plot device, only F5 starts the
data acquisition.
In STANDBY mode, selecting this entry will start data acquisition.
In RECORD mode, selecting this entry brings the header information, i.e. "HEADER UTILITY" on the
screen and the user may need to update the header information, and depressing <ESC> will start the data
acquisition in RECORD mode.
In PLAYBACK mode, either selecting this entry or pressing F5 displays the header information and a start
time: and end time: request to give the user a chance to change the default values and <CR> accepts the
default values.
To quit STANDBY, PLAYBACK or RECORD, press the ESC key.  The system responds with an EXIT
ACQUISITION [Y/N]? prompt.  Enter Y and the system returns to the ILDE mode.

topic: Test Systems Guide - 10.0 OUTPUT CURVES FOR AUXILIARY PROCESSOR . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
OUTPUT CURVES FOR AUXILIARY PROCESSOR
The followings are the polar plot (as well as gray shade image) curves :
RAMP:
the array of the measured reflectance peak amplitudes
RTIM: the array of the measured acoustic travel times
The followings are the processed acoustic radius curves :
R001:
the acoustic radius in the first quadrant
R062:
the acoustic radius in the second quadrant
R125:
the acoustic radius in the third quadrant
R187:
the acoustic radius in the fourth quadrant
Note that these curves are not filtered, and when tool sends no data for any one of them for some reason,
the value of that curve will be -999 and that curve will not be plotted, i.e. there will be gap on that curve.
The followings are the calculated curves after sorting 250 reflectance amplitudes in ascending order.
AMPL:
the 247th amplitude
AMAX:
the 200th amplitude
AMED:
the 125th amplitude
AMIN:
the 50th amplitude
Finally, SFLD is Mud slowness curve.

PROGRAM HISTORY
DCDIAG.EXE   PROGRAM HISTORY

January 1992
o
Displays the current depth when logging down on Image CRT.
o
Removed ARQC curves.  Instead, Radius curve will have a gap.
o
Prints all system parameters on header.
o
Locates the file pointer to the desired location faster and safer in PLAYBACK mode.
o
Changed "Sig. Attenuation" to "Xmit Power Level".

topic: Brief Description of Service - BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE 1.0 INTRODUCTION
chunk_text:
1

1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS
P/N 130802-935
MAY 2001 1.0 INTRODUCTION
The 1677 EA 8-channel Acoustic Electronics is WTS compatible and simultaneously acquires up to 8
full waveforms from up to 8 receivers. It is responsible for the data acquisition, downhole analysis,
and telemetry interface for the XMACII (XMAC EliteSM).  The 1677 EA is backward compatible with
the 1680 DAL and 1678 MA XMAC† acoustic instruments by means of a 45 pin to 32 pin crossover
block (P/N 194754-000). The 1677 EA obtains power and communicates with the surface system
through the WTS instrument bus.  The telemetry interface between the 1677 EA and the surface system
meets WTS communication specifications. These specifications are briefly summarized in the
equipment specifications section of this manual.
The 1677 EA attaches to the top of the XMACII receiver mandrel to control reception of signatures
from the mandrel.  Acquired data from the XMACII instrument is sent to the surface via WTS Mode 5
or Mode 7. The telemetry channel is selected via OCT.  Other communications (commands,
downloading and uploading tables, etc.) are conducted on WTS Mode 2.  A tool control table for a
given subset dictates how data is acquired for a given request from the surface system. (Refer to
Interface Specifications, P/N 193329-000.)  The 1677 EA has two 4-channel digital signal processor
(DSP) acquisition cards. Each 4-channel DSP acquisition card has four 16 bit A/D’s and low-noise
preamplifiers.  The CPU card controls communications with the surface and with the DSP acquisition
cards as well as mandrel settings. During an acquisition sequence, the mandrel is set up to select the
transmitter, receivers, and gains based on the acquisition table. (Refer to Interface Specifications, P/N
193329-000).  Mandrel control based on the acquisition table is accomplished through a serial
communication link with the mandrel.

† limited acquisition system support

topic: Brief Description of Service - BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE 2.0 GENERAL DATA ACQUISITION
chunk_text:
2

1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS
P/N 130802-935
MAY 2001 2.0 GENERAL DATA ACQUISITION
The 1677 EA acquires data based on a tool control table (for each subset) which has been down-
loaded to the instrument. Software specifications allow as many as 16 different subsets, with a limit of
four resident in the instrument at one time. Each table (for each subset) contains parameters dictating
the way the instrument acquires the data and where it will originate. Each subset may have one or
more subcycles, with a subcycle consisting of a selected transmitter to be fired and the eight (four)
corresponding receivers to be monitored. Each subcycle has its own parameters associated with it
which govern the acquisition for the specific subcycle. The following outlines the sequence of events
for the 1677 EA to acquire data.
1. Waveform acquisition table (subset) must is downloaded from the surface. Required if subset is
not already resident in the instrument.
2. Request from surface for data acquisition is based on a subset residen t in the instrument.  Data
from the last acquisition is sent up for a current request.
3. The mandrel is set for the correct receiver, gain, and transmitter selection based on the requested
subset.
4. DSP table control (from the CPU board) is set up for the correct number of samples and the
correct sample rate.
5.  The firing sequence is initiated by the DSP, which provides a fire sync for transmitter firing and
starts simultaneous A/D conversions on the eight (four) receiver signals selected in the mandrel
setup.
6.  Data is acquired by the DSPs at a 8 µs sample rate (When DSP filter is 'On' (Normal mode)) for
25 msec (3125 samples).
7. Data is processed by the DSPs.
7.1 Data is averaged (If stacking is used).
7.2  Data decimated (filtered) to selected sample rate.
7.3  Maximum amplitude and time for AGC window is determined.
7.4  Data is compacted or compressed as required.
7.5  Data is then transferred to the CPU board’s memory via two 4-Mbit/Sec Synchronous Serial
Channels connected to the DSP boards.
8. If multiple subcycles, the instrument waits for subcycle time-out, and then begins the next
acquisition sequence as described in steps 3-7.
9. When all subcycles have been completed the instrument waits for the next request from the
surface.

topic: Brief Description of Service - BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
chunk_text:
3

1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS
P/N 130802-935
MAY 2001

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 1.2 ACQUISITION TIMING EXAMPLE - STACK OF 2...............................................................4
chunk_text:
ACQUISITION TIMING EXAMPLE - STACK OF 2
Reference Figure 3.
A typical XMACII subset 6 acquisition cycle using a stack of 2 is shown in figure 3.  Subset 6
acquires 3 subcycles.  The first subcycle is a full wave monopole acquiring 330 words of data per
channel (8 channels).  The second subcycle is a inline dipole acquiring 300 words of data per
channel (8 channels).  The third is a delta T  acquiring 100 words of data per channel (4 channels).
The following is a step by step description of the sequence of events that take place.
1.  Ten bytes of mandrel parameters (i.e. transmitter selection, receiver selection, and gains) are
transmitted to the mandrel by the CPU via a 100 KHz synchronous serial communications link.
2.  Next 26 words of DSP parameters (i.e. sample rate, start time, #of words to acquire, etc.) are
sent to all eight DSPs simultaneously by the CPU via a 4 MHz synchronous serial
communications link. The first word of the parameter table contains the command, address,
and number of words.  The first word (in this case) would be hex “5 F1 A,” where 5 is the
command “LOAD TABLE,” F is the universal address, and 1 A is the number of words.  For
more information on DSP commands, tables, etc., see Section 15 in the repair/maintenance
procedures of this manual.
3.  Once the DSPs have received the parameters, the CPU sends a single acquire/stack command
to all eight DSPs simultaneously.
4.  DSP number 1 synchronizes the trigger clock then sends a fire pulse.  The fire pulse is sent
back to the CPU board, then through a level shifter and on to the transmitter.  Note:  The
DSPs acquire data for 25 msec but only process and transmit data as per the acquisition
parameters.
5.  When the 50 msec subcycle length has been reached the CPU sends an acquire/process
command to all eight DSPs simultaneously.
6.  After 36 msec the CPU transmits the next subcycle mandrel parameters.  This allows time for
the completion of gain and receiver switching before the beginning of the next subcyle
acquisition.
7.  After 44 msec the CPU begins to request and receive header data from each DSP (1 word of
max amplitude and 1 word of time of max amplitude). Asking for data at 44 msec of a 50
msec subcycle allows for all of the data to be collected before the end of the 50 msec’s.
8.  When the CPU is finished receiving header data, it begins requesting and receiving channel
data from each DSP.  Since there are two separate 4 MHz receive-serial-communications links
(one per DSP board) two channels of data can be transmitted simultaneously.
9.  When the 50 msec subcycle length has been reached, the process begins again with Step 2
until all subcyles have been acquired.

POWER UP / DOWN RESET LOGIC7
3.1.1
POWER UP RESET
7
3.1.2

POWER UP / DOWN RESET LOGIC
3.1.1
POWER UP RESET
The RESETIN/ signal from U7-6 will be inactive until the +5 V signal is above 4.4 V.
3.1.2
POWER DOWN RESET
The RESETIN/ signal from U7-6 will become active when the +5 V signal < 4.4 V. 

CLOCK
U6 is a 24 MHz oscillator and provides a clock signal to U8-10 and U5-22 (CLKIN).  The CPU
internally uses a divide-by-2 clock function to produce a 12 MHz CPU clock.  The CPU uses this
clock signal to generate internal timers.

MEMORY
U9 (Low byte) and U10 (High byte) together form program memory consisting of 256 K bytes of
Sector Erase Flash Memory, and U11 (low byte) and U12 (high byte) together is a data memory of
256 K bytes of RAM.  The EPROM is addressed at F0000 to FFFFF and the RAM is addressed at
00000 to 3 FFFF.   UCS selects EPROM addresses and LCS selects RAM addresses.

ACTEL LOGIC FUNCTIONS (U5)8
3.4.1
CLOCK GENERATION
9
3.4.2
WTS INTERFACE (MODE 2, MODE 5, AND MODE 7)
10
3.4.3
SYNCHRONOUS SERIAL TRANSMIT/RECEIVE LOGIC
12
3.4.4
U5 DATA BUS INTERFACE TO CPU
17
3.4.5
LATCHED ADDRESS BUS
18
3.4.6

ACTEL LOGIC FUNCTIONS (U5)
U5 has these interface logic functions:
1. Clock Generation
2. Mode2  Command / Data interface and Decoder
3. Mode2  Data out interface and Encoder
4. Mode5 Encoder / Interface
5. Mode7 Encoder / Interface
6. 4 Mbit/Sec Synchronous Serial Input Channel 1 and Channel 2
7. 4 Mbit/Sec Synchronous Serial Output Channel 1 and Channel 2
8. 100 Kbit/Sec Synchronous Serial Output
9. Multiplexed Data-Bus to CPU
10. Latched Address bus
11. Miscellaneous Logic
3.4.1
CLOCK GENERATION
U5 divides the 24 MHz clock signal (CLKIN) by 2 when JMP2 is installed on CLKSEL (U5-91).
U5 then divides the 12 MHz clock signal by 3, 12, 24, 48, 64, 120, and 12000 to provide:
1. a 4 MHz clock (SCLK) for U5 4 Mbit synchronous serial transmit / receive or an optional 1
MHz clock selectable by firmware.
2. a 500 KHz clock for Mode 2 transmitter logic (U5 internal).
3. a 250 KHz clock signal for the Mode 2 receiver logic (U5 internal).
4. a 187.5 kHz clock for U5 transmitter logic (Mode 5 and Mode 7).
5. a 100 kHz clock signal for the mandrel synchronous serial transmitter.
6. a 1 kHz clock signal used to send a 1 ms reset to the DSPs (DSP_RESET).

1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS
P/N 130802-945
MAY 2001
3.4.2
WTS INTERFACE (MODE 2, MODE 5, AND MODE 7)
Reference Drawing 193325-100 and Figure 5.
Mode 2 Receive Command / Data:  Mode 2 commands / data are sent from the surface and
transformer-coupled via T2 on the CPU board.  U2 converts line signals to TTL levels. The
equivalent of a 6408 Harris Manchester Encoder / Decoder has been incorporated into Actel (U5).
U5 decodes this Manchester protocol data (MD2 UDI) and converts the serial data to parallel data.
U5 checks the received data for a universal address 00 or tool address 03. If either address is
received, interrupt M2 RXIRQ (INT1) is sent to the CPU (U8) and the command is transferred to a
buffer. M2 RXIRQ is reset by the CPU after the command is read by the CPU. If data follows the
WTS command, interrupt M2 RXIRQ (INT1) is sent to the CPU (U8) and the data is transferred to
a buffer. M2 RXIRQ is reset by the CPU after each data word is read.
Mode 2 Transmit Data:  On receipt of a command from the surface to transmit data via Mode 2
(Such as tool tables or tool status) the CPU enables interrupt INT2 (M2 TXIRQ) and sends the
requested data via the 16 bit data bus to U5, Mode 2 encoder logic.  U5 converts the data from
parallel to serial format and the U5 6408 Harris Manchester equivalent encoder, encodes
MD2 BZO data and MD2 BOO data. Data is then sent to line driver (U1).  Data is then transformer
coupled to the WTS buss via T1.  Whenever the U5 data buffer is empty, U5 generates an
interrupt (M2 TXIRQ); and the CPU sends the next word.
Mode 5 and Mode 7 DMA Control:  The equivalent of two 6409 Harris Manchesters have been
incorporated into Actel (U5) for Mode 5 and Mode 7 data transmission. Mode 5 or Mode 7 data is
transmitted using DMA channel 0 (DRQ0).  SMD57 DRQ (See Figure 5) selects which mode will
provide the DMA request.  When SMD57 DRQ is set to ‘0’ Mode 5 uses DMA channel 0
controlled by MD57 DRQ. When SMD57 DRQ is set to ‘1’ Mode 7 uses DMA channel 0
controlled by MD57 DRQ.  SMD57 DRQ is set by firmware in response to the MAP command sent
from the Surface.
Mode 5 Transmit Data:  On receipt of a command from the surface to transmit Mode 5 data the
CPU enables DMA channel 0 and writes the requested data via the 16 bit data bus to U5, Mode 5
encoder logic.  The data is converted from parallel to serial format by U5.  Serial data is received
by the U5 6409 Harris Manchester equivalent encoder and the encoded data (BZO5 and BOO5) is
sent to line driver U3.  Mode 5 data is then transformer coupled to the WTS buss via T3.
Whenever the data buffer is empty, MD57 DRQ is active; and the CPU writes the next data word
via the 16 bit data bus to U5.
Mode 7 Transmit Data:  On receipt of a command from the surface to transmit Mode 7 data the
CPU enables DMA channel 0 and writes the requested data via the 16 bit data bus to U5. The data
is converted from parallel to serial format by U5.  Serial data is received by the U5 6409 Harris
Manchester equivalent encoder and the encoded data (BZO7 and BOO7) is sent to line driver U4.
Mode 7 data is then transformer coupled to the WTS buss via T4.  Whenever the data buffer is
empty, MD57 DRQ is active; and the CPU writes the next data word via the 16 bit data bus to U5.
The CPU is also capable of sending Mode 5 and Mode 7 simultaneously. Mode 5 data is sent
using DMA channel 0 (MD57 DRQ) and Mode 7 data is interrupt driven using MD57 IRQ (INT0).
Simultaneously transmission of data is currently used only when sending Subset E.
3.4.3
SYNCHRONOUS SERIAL TRANSMIT/RECEIVE LOGIC
The CPU board has three synchronous serial communication interfaces with external peripheral
devices.
Two of these serial links are used to transfer data back and forth to the two DSP boards.  These
two serial links consist of a common serial clock (SCLK). The clock speed is set by firmware.  A
clock speed of 4 MHz is used for acquisition, while a clock speed of 1 MHz is used for
programming the DSP flash PROMs. Each of these serial links has a transmit-frame sink (TFS_x)
for beginning and ending a transmission, and a data transmit (DT_x) line for transmission of data
to the two DSP boards (i.e. tables, commands, etc.).  Each of these serial links also has a receive-
frame sink (RFS_x) and a data receive (DR_x) line for receiving data from the two DSP boards.
U5 provides the 4 MHz synchronous serial 1 and 2 transmit logic along with two 4 MHz
synchronous serial receive channels.
The mandrel serial link uses three lines to control the transfer of data.  This serial link is used for
control of transmitter, receiver, and gain selections in the mandrel. U5 provides the logic for the
100 KHz mandrel-synchronous-serial-transmit channel.
A description of the synchronous serial transmit / receive logic follows.

MASTER BOARD VERSUS SLAVE BOARD
Reference Drawing 194749-100.
The master and slave concept arose while trying to keep all the eight DSP channels synchronized
yet independent.  To avoid a complicated board design to implement this concept the idea was
applied at the chassis level.  The DSP chassis connectors contain address jumpers that set the
master and slave relationship.

The following list explains differences in the chassis wiring, refer to drawing 194749-100:
1.  Connector pin D11-3 (M/S) is grounded by joining it with pin D11-18 (DGND).

The M/S signal is taken by the DSP board as a channel address bit.  Two other bits are
hardwired on each channel during assembly.  On the DSP board that mates with connector
D11, the M/S signal is zero (grounded), the channel addresses then range from “000” to
“011”, making this the master board.  Note, that connector D11 is on the same side as the
CPU board.

2.  Connector pin D21-3 (M/S) is left unconnected.

The M/S signal on the DSP board is pulled up to +5 V.  When the DSP board plugs into
connector D21, the M/S signal remains at +5 V (high).  Thus, the channel addresses range from
“100” to “111”, making this the slave board.

3.  Connector pin D21-17 (B_AD TRIG OUT) is not wired.

The B_AD TRIG OUT signal is the sampling clock generated by both DSP boards, but the
master board’s B_AD TRIG OUT signal is the only one used.

4.  Connector pin D11-17 (B_AD TRIG OUT) is joined to pin D11-14 (AD_TRIG_IN) and
D21-14 (AD_TRIG_IN).

The AD_TRIG_IN signal is used by the boards to create the trigger signals for the A/Ds.
B_AD TRIG OUT signal from the ‘Master’ board is used to drive the AD_TRIG_IN of both
the boards.  This keeps the A/Ds of all eight channels synchronized.

RESET LOGIC
Reference Drawing 193334-100.
The reset signal, GRESET/ (U8-44), on the DSP board is the reset signal for the entire board.
GRESET/ is an output of Xilinx FPGA (U8).  Xilinx FPGA outputs GRESET/ based on the inputs
from three separate sources.  Only one source at a time can be selected to control GRESET/ on the
DSP board.  This is accomplished by soldering a 0 Ohm resistor (R1 or R2 or R3) between the
source and Xilinx FPGA’s PROGRAM/ pin (U8-74).  Note that only one of the three resistors
can be installed.

FPGA (XILINX U8)
The Xilinx FPGA incorporates several logic functions described below.
4.5.1
GRESET/ SIGNAL
Reference Drawing 193334-100 and 193336-100.
The reset signal enters the Xilinx FPGA at PROGRAM/ (U8-74).  This causes the Xilinx FPGA to
go into a reset mode.  The FPGA outputs a low on Greset/ (U8-44) resetting DSP Channels
(e.g.U10), until the Xilinx FPGA downloads the program from the Xilinx PROM (U5).
Additionally, logic is added to the GRESET/ (U8-44) so that after power-up or a CPU reset the
DSP channels can be reset again (if needed) without resetting the Xilinx FPGA.  RESET/ (J1-3)
from the CPU comes into Xilinx from another pin (U8-87) and is wired to GRESET/ through an
AND gate.  The other input of the AND gate is controlled by the first DSP (U10).  When the DSPs
want to load the acquisition firmware (193338-000), the first DSP writes to I/O address 2 which
prompts the FPGA to reset the DSPs and clear the A16 bit to the DSP PROMs.  The DSPs are
reset for about 1 ms; then the DSPs load the acquisition firmware from the DSP PROMs.
SOURCES OF GRESET
SETUP
1
Power Up Reset

4.5.2
M/S SIGNAL
Reference Drawing 193334-100 and 193336-100.
The master/slave signal enters the board through the connector, J1-3 (M/S), and is inverted by the
driver, U3-10 (BM/S).  BM/S is then inverted again by Xilinx FPGA, M/S* (U8-68) to return it to
it’s original state.  This signal is used internally and is sent to the DSPs.
4.5.3
BUSY SIGNAL
Reference Drawing 193334-100 and 193336-100.
The CPU board monitors the output busy signal (BBUSY_OUT/, J1-15) from the DSP board and
sends commands only when the DSP channels are not busy.  The output busy signal is made up of
individual busy signals from each DSP channel and an input busy signal (BUSY_IN, J1-4).  The
input busy signal is pulled up on the DSP board to avoid a floating driver input if the CPU side of
this connector pin is not wired.
The Xilinx FPGA ANDs the input busy signal with the master/slave signal.  Then the output of the
AND-gate is summed with all of the channel-busy signals to produce the output busy signal.
Note, that the input busy signal for the master DSP board is the sum of the busy signals
from the channels of the slave DSP board.  For the slave DSP board, the input busy signal
(when ANDed with the master/slave signal) is ignored.
SERIAL PORT SIGNALS
Reference Drawing 193334-100  and 193336-100.
The serial port signals coming from the CPU board are simply inverted inside the Xilinx FPGA.
The serial clock (B(1)SCLK, U8-77), receive frame sync (B(2)RFS, U8-78), and receive data
(B(3)DR, U8-79) are inverted to counter the effect of the driver (U3 and U4).  The serial clock is
split in two: SCLKB (U8-115) to channels 1 (U10) and 2 (U18), and SCLKA (U8-116) to
channels 3 (U26) and 4 (U34), respectively.  CMD*/ (U8-122) is generated in the FPGA from the
receive frame sync. It provides an interrupt to the DSP(s) indicating the beginning of the data
transmission from the CPU.  This is important because the channels’ DSPs need to know in
advance whether the information being shifted into their receive registers is a command or data.
1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS
P/N 130802-945
MAY 2001
For the serial port signals from the Channels to the CPU board, the Transmit Frame Sync (U8-129
to 132) of all the Channels are AND-ed together.  The Transmit Data of each Channel (U8-133 to
136) is AND-ed with the inverted Transmit Frame Sync of that Channel and then all outputs are
OR-ed together.  This is done to prevent noise from other Channels to interfere with the Channel
that is transmitting data back to the CPU.  For example, if Channel one is sending data to the CPU,
the Transmit Frame Sync of the other Channels will be high and therefore the Transmit Data from
the other Channels will be ignored.  All the Transmit Frame Sync signals are pulled high inside the
FPGA, to avoid problems due to floating Frame Sync signals.  Figure 18 shows data being
transmitted to the CPU board.  Note, only one DSP transmit at a time.

4.5.5
A/D TIMER
Reference Drawing 193334-100 and 193336-100.
The A/D trigger clock is selected by the CPU board.  In the Acquisition Firmware, the sampling
clock parameter in the DSP Parameter Table dictates the period of the trigger clock, if non-filter
mode is selected.  If the filter mode is on, in the Acquisition Firmware, then a fixed period trigger
clock of 8us width is generated.  Note, in the Diagnostic Firmware, the trigger clock is fixed
9us wide and can’t be changed.

The first DSP (U10) latches the trigger clock period into the FPGA through I/O address 0.  This
initiates an internal counter counting down inside the FPGA running on a 1 MHz clock.  When the
counter ends the count, a low pulse 1 us wide is generated.  The counter gets loaded again from the
latch and begin another count down.  Note, only the first DSP on the DSP board is capable of
writing the trigger clock period into Xilinx FPGA.  The trigger clock is free running once
initialized.  The FPGA keeps generating it, which means the A/D keeps converting signal to digital
data, until a trigger clock period of 0us is latched into the FPGA.
1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS
P/N 130802-945
MAY 2001
4.5.6
A/D SEQUENCER
Reference Drawing 193334-100, 193336-100 and Figure 14.
The A/D trigger clock (AD_TRIG_IN, J1-14) that comes into the board is used by the Xilinx
FPGA to generate a chip select signal (CS/) and a run-convert signal (R/C/) that is fed to each
Channel’s A/D through individual FPGA pins.  For example, CS1 A/ is the select signal and
R/C1 A/ is the run-convert signal for Channel 1’s A/D.  These signals start the A/D conversion.
The timing of these signal’s active edges relative to each other and their widths are important to
initiate a successful conversion.  Figure 20 gives important timing and pulse width information.
The DSPs assert the CS/ signal through the FPGA when the DSPs are reading the converted data
from it’s A/D.  The R/C/ signal stays high (inactive) at this time.  The DSPs activate the CS/ signal
by doing an I/O read.  This causes the IOMS/ signal (e.g. IOMS1/) to go low (active) and the
FPGA then asserts the CS/ signal.  The A/D responds to this by outputting the data on the data
bus.  For the first DSP on the DSP board, the FPGA also looks at the RD/ signal.  This is done to
avoid generating a CS/ signal when the first DSP is writing the trigger clock period into the FPGA
(also an I/O operation involving IOMS/).
1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS
P/N 130802-945
MAY 2001
4.5.7
A/D INTERRUPT
Reference Drawing 193334-100 and 193336-100.
The DSPs need to read their A/D’s data once it’s converted.  Thus, the A/Ds indicate the end of
conversion to the DSPs through the A/Ds’ busy signal (e.g. U12-26).  The busy signal
(ADBUSY1, U8-32) goes through the FPGA into DSPs’ interrupt pin (e.g. IRQ2-1/, U10-38).
The FPGA NORs the busy signal with a mask (AD_BUSY_MASK).  The mask blocks the status
of the A/D busy signal if the command to generate a fire pulse is received.  This prevents the DSPs
from responding to any false interrupts which may happen as the fire pulse takes minimum one
trigger clock pulse before becoming synchronized.  The following figure, Figure 22 shows the
internal signal mask created when the fire pulse command is issued.

4.5.8
FIRE PULSE LOGIC
Reference Drawing 193334-100 and 193336-100.
The DSP board (‘Master’ DSP board) creates the fire pulse for the XMAC II Transmitter.  When
the DSP board receives the command from the CPU board to acquire data, it issues a command to
the FPGA to generate a fire pulse.  The fire pulse is synchronized with the B_AD_TRIG_IN to
synchronize the A/D with the fire pulse.  A mask is created to prevent false DSP A/D interrupts
until the fire is synchronized.  The fire pulse is passed out to the CPU board through connector pin
J1-5 (BFIRE).
Note, fire pulse is created by both the DSP board in the 1677 EA tool, but only the fire pulse
of the Master DSP board reaches the CPU board.
1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS
P/N 130802-945

DSPs (ANALOG DEVICES U10, U18, U26, U34)
Reference Drawing 193334-100 and Figure 14.
The DSP, as mentioned earlier, is the brain of the DSP Channel (see Figure 14).  This part is
responsible for collecting the signal as digitized data and processing it.  All the DSP commands
and signals, except for a few, goes to the other parts in the DSP Channel through the Xilinx FPGA
(U8).  The DSP shares the data bus with the DSP PROM and A/D.  For more information some
topics related to the DSPs are organized below into separate sections.
4.6.1
DSP’S PROM
The DSP PROM contains two independent programs.  The DSP PROM 128 Kbytes in size, is split
into two 64 Kbytes sections by controlling the most significant address bit (A16).  A16 is
controlled by the Xilinx FPGA (U8).  The section of the PROM that has the lower memory
addresses (0x0000 - 0x0 FFFF) contains the Acquisition Firmware and the section that has the
higher memory address (0x1000 - 0x1 FFFF) contains the Diagnostic Firmware.
The Diagnostic Firmware is burned into the DSP PROM at the time of board assembly.  The
Acquisition Firmware is programmed later at the time of board testing.
When the DSP power up, it loads the Diagnostic Firmware because A16 is set by the FPGA.  The
Diagnostic Firmware checks the programming jumper J8, if J8 is jumped than the first DSP
commands the FPGA to clear A16 and reset the DSPs to force a program reload.
If J8 is not jumped A16 is still cleared but the DSP is not reloaded and stays in Diagnostic Mode.
A16 is cleared so that the lower memory section of the DSP PROM is available in Diagnostic
Mode for programming if needed.  Figures 25 and 26 illustrates this process.

4.6.3
CHANNEL #1’S DSP VERSUS OTHER CHANNELS’ DSPs
Reference Drawing 193334-100 and 193336-100.
The first DSP is special compared to the other three DSPs on the DSP board in a few ways.

The difference listed in the table above are described in detail below:
4.6.3.1 DSP WIRING
Only the first DSP has it’s write (WR1/, U8-41) and read (D1_RD1/, U8-42) signals and second
address bit (D1_A1, U8-30) connected to the Xilinx FPGA (U8).  This allows the first DSP to do
an I/O write or read into the FPGA.  The other DSPs have address bit A0 going into the FPGA like
the first DSP, but unlike the first DSP, these address bits A0 are not used.
4.6.3.2 DSP PROM A16 BIT & DSP RESET
Because each of the DSPs have identical firmware installed they all respond to common
commands such as GO and FIRE.  However, only the first DSp is wired to the FPGA and can
effect the required change.
When the DSPs power-up into Diagnostic Mode, only the first DSP on the DSP board, on
checking the programming jumper J8 condition, has the capability to request the FPGA to clear
A16 and reset all the DSPs.  If the DSPs have to stays in Diagnostic Mode, only the first DSP has
the capability to clear A16 without resetting the DSPs.  Even when the GO command is issued to
the DSPs, all the DSPs wait in a wait loop to be reset by the first DSP through the FPGA.
4.6.3.3 TRIGGER CLOCK
Once again the first DSP can write the trigger clock into the FPGA and the other DSPs can’t.  This
operation occurs as an I/O write into the FPGA.
4.6.3.4 FIRE PULSE
The fire pulse is requested by all the DSPs during acquisition, but only the first DSP is able to
latch the request because it is the only DSP wired to the FPGA.

Reference Figure 1.
The 1677 EA 8-channel acoustic electronics is WTS compatible and simultaneously acquires up to
8 full waveforms from up to 8 receivers. It is responsible for data acquisition, downhole
digitization, digital DSP filtering, and provides a telemetry interface.  It is backward compatible
with DAL (1680 MA), using a 45 pin to 32 pin crossover block (P/N 194754-000). The 1677 EA
contains a power supply, CPU, and two DSP boards.  The chassis is extruded aluminum standard
for a 3-3/8 inch housing.
1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS
P/N 130802-945
MAY 2001

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 1.1 ACQUISITION TIMING EXAMPLE - STACK OF 1
chunk_text:
ACQUISITION TIMING EXAMPLE - STACK OF 1
Reference Figure 2.
A typical XMACII subset 6 acquisition cycle using a stack of 1 is shown in figure 2.  Subset 6
acquires 3 subcycles.  The first subcycle is a full wave monopole acquiring 330 words of data per
channel (8 channels).  The second subcycle is a inline dipole acquiring 300 words of data per
channel (8 channels).  The third is a delta T acquiring 100 words of data per channel (4 channels).
The following is a step by step description of the sequence of events that take place.
1.  Ten bytes of mandrel parameters (i.e. transmitter selection, receiver selection, and gains) are
transmitted to the mandrel by the CPU, via a 100 KHz synchronous serial communications
link.
2.  Next 26 words of DSP parameters (i.e. sample rate, start time, #of words to acquire, etc.) are
sent to all eight DSPs simultaneously by the CPU, via a 4 MHz synchronous serial
communications link.  The first word of the parameter table contains the command, address,
and number of words.  The first word (in this case) would be hex “5 F1 A,” where 5 is the
command “LOAD TABLE,” F is the universal address, and 1 A is the number of words.  For
more information on DSP commands, tables, etc., see Section 15 in the repair/maintenance
procedures of this manual.
3.  Once the DSPs have received the parameters the CPU sends a single acquire/process
command to all eight DSPs simultaneously.
4.  DSP number 1 synchronizes the trigger clock then sends a fire pulse.  The fire pulse is sent
back to the CPU board, then through a level shifter and on to the transmitter.  Note:  The
DSPs acquire data for 25 msec but only process and transmit data per the acquisition
parameters.
5.  After 36 msec the CPU transmits the next subcycle mandrel parameters.  This allows time for
the switching of the gains and receivers to settle before the beginning of the next subcyle
acquisition.
6.  After 44 msec the CPU begins to request and receive header data from each DSP (1 word of
max amplitude and 1 word of time of max amplitude). Asking for data at 44 msec of a 50
msec subcycle allows all data to be collected before the end of the 50 msec’s.
7.  When the CPU is finished receiving header data it begins requesting and receiving channel
data from each DSP.  Because there are two separate 4 MHz receive serial communications
links (one per DSP board), two channels of data can be transmitted simultaneously.
8.  When the 50 msec subcycle length is reached, the process begins again with Step 2 (above)
until all subcyles have been acquired.
