Reference Drawing 193330-000 and 194749-100.
The 1677 EA power supply provides regulated ±15 Vdc @ 350ma and +5 Vdc @ 1.5 amps for the
electronics and the DAL. The XMAC and XMACII provide their own power.

Normal power required at the top sub is 180 VAC.  Power supply will maintain regulation from
150 VAC to 220 VAC.

Reference Drawing 193330-100.
Note: Regulator U4 (not installed) and its associated components are not used at this time.
Transformer T1 steps-down the nominal 180 VAC cablehead voltage to levels suitable for the
required outputs.  The cablehead voltage is applied to T1's primary via the terminal board
(162758-000) and the 32 pin block.  Two center-tapped secondaries on T1 provide the stepped-
down AC voltages for three rectifier/ripple filter circuits.
Unregulated ±34 VDC is provided to the power supply PCB (193330-000) from T1's first
secondary winding via bridge rectifier BR1 and chokes L1 A and L1 B.  Likewise, unregulated
+16 VDC is provided to the PCB from T1's last secondary winding via BR2 and L2.  Each choke's
winding with its respective filter capacitor(s) on the power supply PCB is a choke input ripple
filter.  The ripple filter averages the 120 Hz pulsating dc received from the bridge rectifiers before
application to the regulator circuits.
Unregulated power is applied to the power supply PCB via connector PS1.  Each of the three
unregulated inputs is filtered by a polarized capacitor(s) or banks of polarized capacitors: C1, C2,
C9-C13, and C18-C20.  Each unregulated input is also applied to the input pin of its respective
three terminal regulator IC, U1-U3.
The regulators reduce and "regulate-down" the unregulated input voltage to its required output
voltage and, in the process, attenuate any 120 Hz input ripple passed through the input filters.
Output short-circuit protection and overload protection are provided by the regulator ICs.  Diodes
D1-D6 provide reverse-voltage protection for the regulator ICs and polarized capacitors.
Capacitors C5-C8, C14, and C15, across the regulated output lines, serve to minimize output
voltage transients during load changes and maintain a low power supply output impedance at
higher frequencies.  Capacitors C3, C4 and C15 across the regulator's inputs serve to ensure the
regulator "sees" a low impedance at high frequency.

1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS
P/N 130802-945
MAY 2001 3.0 CPU
Reference Drawing 193325-100.
The 1677 EA operates as a demand-response system.  For each data request a single data word
answer, tool table, or data block is sent.  The WTS Manchester encoder-decoder protocol for
M2/M5/M7 communications is used.  Mode 5 or Mode 7 is selectable by the WTS ‘map to mode’
command.  The ECLIPS acquisition system automatically sends the ‘map to mode’ WTS
command when the OCT is initialized or when TOOL Re-Init is selected.
WTS command signals and DC power are connected to the CPU board by connector P1.  The DSP
boards are connected to the CPU board by connector P2.
The CPU board has these functions:
1. Power up / down reset signal for the CPU and DSPs at ~+4.40 V.
2. Clock, 24 MHz oscillator.
3. Interface to CPU,  Mode 2, Mode 5 and Mode 7.
4. Memory, data memory of 256 Kbyte’s RAM and program memory of 256 Kbyte’s sector erase
flash memory.
5. Two, 4 Mbit/sec synchronous serial input / output ports.
6. One, 100 Kbit/sec synchronous serial output port.
7. One, Actel field programmable gate array is used for the "glue logic" functions.

3.4.3.2 SYNCHRONOUS SERIAL RECEIVE CHANNEL 1
Reference Drawing  193325-100, Figure 8 and Figure 9.
The serial data of DR_1 is shifted into two 8-bit serial-in, parallel-out shift registers on the positive
edge of SCLK when RFS_1 frame signal is active (high).  The Actel (U5) inverts DR_1 before it
is shifted into the shift registers. A 16 bit counter and flip flop are used to latch the data into two 8-
bit latches.  The flip flop is also used to indicate to the CPU that data has been received
(S1 RXDRQ).  The flip flop is reset when the CPU reads the data.  The S1 RXDRQ signal is
connected to the CPU DRQ1 signal.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS 4.0 DSP / 16-BIT A/D CONVERTER
chunk_text:
18

1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS
P/N 130802-945
MAY 2001 4.0 DSP / 16-BIT A/D CONVERTER
Reference Drawing 194749-100, 193334-100  and Figure 1.
The 1677 EA instrument requires two DSP boards as shown in Figure 1.  Each DSP board contains
four DSP channels.  The DSP boards are identical, but functionality is determined by their
physical position.  The DSP board on the same side as the CPU is considered the master DSP
board; and the other is designated the slave DSP board.  The reason for this distinction is described
in section 4.1 “MASTER BOARD VERSUS SLAVE BOARD.”
Both DSP boards are connected on one end to the CPU board through separate connectors (D11
and D21). On the other end, the DSP boards are connected to the 45 pin acoustic buss (bottom
sub, J2) through separate coaxial cables (J17, J19, J111, J113 and J27, J29, J211, J213).
The connector on the CPU side provides DC power, reset and serial communication signals
between the CPU and the DSP boards, and some signals between the ‘Master’ and the ‘Slave’
DSP boards.  The coaxial cables from the 45 pin bottom sub bring signals from the 1678 MB
XMAC II Receiver.
The DSP Channel numbering starts from the ‘Master’ DSP board and ends with the ‘Slave’ DSP
board.  Thus the DSP Channels, as shown in Figure 1, are labeled Channel #1 through Channel
#8.  Each Channel is directly addressable by the CPU board during acquisition.

5.  Connector pin CP2-20 (BBUSY/) is connected to pin D11-15 (BBUSY_OUT).

The CPU board checks BBUSY/ to monitor the status of all eight DSP Channels.
BBUSY_OUT is the status of all channels on the master board and BUSY_IN summed up.
BUSY_IN brings the status of the four Channels from the slave board.  Refer to Figure 16.

6.  Connector pin D11-4 (BUSY_IN) is connected to pin D21-15 (BBUSY_OUT) and Connector
pin D21-4 (BUSY_IN) is a no-connect.

The BBUSY_OUT signal on a DSP board is the sum of the BUSYs of all channels on that
board and BUSY_IN.  On the slave board, the BUSY_IN signal is not wired; therefore, the
BBUSY_OUT signal on this board is only the sum of all its four channels.

7.  Connector pin D11-5 (BFIRE) is connected to pin CP2-18 (BFIRE/).  Connector pin D21-5
(BFIRE) is a no-connect.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedure - 3.0 ASSEMBLY OF WIRELINE TELEMETRY SYSTEMS SUBS
chunk_text:
(Reference Drawings R194738-000 for Bottom Sub and C148964-000 for Top Sub)
The bottom WTS sub must have the 45 pin bulkhead (item 4) installed into the WTS bottom sub
housing (item 5) making sure proper O-Rings (items 11) have been seated correctly.  The bulkhead
insertion tool is used to align the keyed bulkhead while drawing it into the sub housing by turning the
sub with a pin wrench.  Once the bulkhead has been inserted completely the snap ring (item 10) must
be installed into the sub with snap ring pliers making sure the snap ring is seated properly into its
groove.  Finally the outer O-Rings (items 4) must be seated into their respective O-Ring grooves with
proper lubrication.
The thermal expansion unit is housed in the WTS top sub which is installed by first setting the spring
(item 4) inside the WTS top sub housing.  This procedure is followed by setting the travel sleeve
(item 3) into the center of the spring.  The retainer ring (item 5) is set over the travel sleeve with the
countersink hole facing upward.  While compressing the spring, 3 flat head socket screws (items 6)
are used to secure the ring.  The hole pattern for this retainer ring allows it to be installed in only one
alignment configuration.  The split collar (item 2) should now be secured around the throat of the sub
housing (item 1) by first coating the throat with lubricant, and then securing the collar with socket
head screws.  Finally, the O-Rings for the outer nose (items 9) as well as for the O-Rings at the back
of the sub (items 10) should be installed using proper lubricant.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedure - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 4.0 INSTALLATION OF ELECTRONICS INTO PRESSURE HOUSING
chunk_text:
2

1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS
P/N 130802-955
MAY 2001 4.0 INSTALLATION OF ELECTRONICS INTO PRESSURE HOUSING
(Reference Drawing R194738-000)
The subs are assembled and the threads are lubricated, the lower sub should be installed first using a
pin wrench to rotate the sub while securing the housing with a strap wrench.  The electronics (item
3) is now inserted into the housing (item 2) with the keyed snout end going in first and the pigtail at
the opposite end last. Once the electronics are against the bottom of the housing the 1/4-20 T-Handle
wrench is screwed into the bulkhead on the pigtail end and then the instrument is twisted while
pushing inward until it keys up with the bottom sub.  The keyed snout on the electronics should align
with the timing marks on the housing and subs which will aide in installation.  The top sub is now
ready to be installed by first feeding the pigtail in through the throat of the top sub.  Once the pigtail is
through, it should be held with slight tension while the sub is screwed into the housing. The 32-pin
block (item 15) is connected to the pigtail and carefully twisted back into the throat of the WTS top
sub while seating the block into the sub itself.  The retainer clip (item 14) is then seated into the
locked groove to secure the block.  Thread protectors for the top (item 7) and the bottom (item 8)
are installed to protect and aid in handling of the instrument.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedure - 5.0 DISASSEMBLY OF ELECTRONICS FROM PRESSURE HOUSING
chunk_text:
(Reference Drawing R194738-000)
Once the thread protectors have been removed then the retainer clip (item 14) on the top sub may be
removed with a screwdriver and a 1/4-20 T-Handle is used to remove the 32-pin block (item 15)
connected to the pigtail.  The block is disconnected from the pigtail and the WTS top sub may be
removed with an open end wrench while securing the housing with a strap wrench.  Removal of the
electronics may now be accomplished by screwing the 1/4-20 T-Handle into the bulkhead and sliding
the electronics (item 3) out of the housing.

TROUBLESHOOTING26
14.0     TROUBLESHOOTING

This section contains information that can be useful in the diagnosis and repair of an individual board
or the power supply section. 14.1.1 VISUAL CHECKOUT
26
14.1.2 POWER ON TEST
26
14.1.3 POWER SUPPLY TROUBLESHOOTING

14.1     POWER SUPPLY
14.1.1
VISUAL CHECKOUT
1. Verify transformers, chokes, diode bridges, regulators, and other chassis parts are properly
installed.
2. Verify all fasteners are properly installed.
3. Visually inspect the 1677 EA Power Supply PCB (P/N 193330-000).  Examine P.C. board for
broken capacitors, contaminants between printed circuits traces, open or shorted traces.
4. If all the preceding checks fail to uncover any potential problems, proceed with the POWER
ON TEST.
14.1.2
POWER ON TEST
1. Remove all P.C. board connectors except for PS1 and PS2.
2. Connect resistive loads per step 9.8.
3. Apply 180 ±3 Vrms power while monitoring the current indicated by the AC current meter of the
2061 power supply or equivalent. Monitor 180 Vac on terminals 1 and 4 of terminal board TB1.
At no time should the current exceed 450 mA.  If the current exceeds 450 mA immediately turn
tool-power off and skip to Power Supply Troubleshooting to determine the fault.  If current is less
than 450ma continue with step 4 to isolate the problem.
4. Measure output voltage and ripple, on power supply board (193325-000) test points TP6-TP11.
Verify per following table that all readings are within the required tolerance.  Limit oscilloscope
bandwidth to 20 MHz for ripple measurements.  If any of the measurements are out of
tolerance, refer to Power Supply Troubleshooting Section.

Output Ripple

5. Measure input voltage and ripple, on PCB test points TP1-TP5, and verify per following table
that all reading are within the required tolerance.  Limit oscilloscope bandwidth to 20 MHz for
ripple measurements.  If any of the measurements are out of tolerance, refer to Power Supply
Troubleshooting Section.  Note:  Input voltage tolerance only applies for ambient
temperature measurements.
14.1.3        POWER SUPPLY TROUBLESHOOTING

Locate the paragraph that most accurately describes the symptoms and follow the suggested
troubleshooting procedure.

1. One or more regulated outputs too high, input current may be excessive.
Probable cause:   Defective Regulator IC’s.
Action:
Test / Replace applicable regulator - U1, U2, or U3.

2. One or more regulated outputs too low, input current excessive.
Probable cause:   Shorted or leaky capacitors.
Action:
Test / Replace applicable capacitors -  C1-C19.

Probable cause:   Shorted bridge rectifier.
Action:
Test / Replace applicable rectifier - BR1 or BR2.

Probable cause:   Short in wiring or on PCB or excessive load.
Action:
Locate and repair.

3. All regulated outputs are zero, no input current.
Probable cause:
T1's primary winding open, or open in primary wiring.
Action:
Measure resistance: pin 1 to pin 4 (on 32 pin connector) should be 16.9Ω
+20%.  Locate open and repair.

4.   One or more regulated outputs measure zero and corresponding unregulated voltages are zero.
Probable cause:
Open secondary on T1 or break in secondary wiring.
Action:
Locate open secondary and repair / replace component.  Measure Sec. #1
resistance (Red - Red), should be 1.6Ω +20%.  Measure Sec. #1 center-tap
resistance (either Red wire to TP5) .8Ω +20%.  Measure Sec. #2 resistance
(Yel - Yel), should be 7.6Ω +20%

Probable cause:
Open choke winding.
Action:
Locate open choke and replace.

L1 A, Resistance from TP1 - BR1 (+) 2.3Ω +20%

L1 B, Resistance from TP3 - BR1 (-) 2.3Ω +20%

L2, Resistance from TP4 - BR2 (+) .4Ω +20%

14.2   CPU BOARD

NOTE:  The following procedure for the CPU Board, and the scope pictures are in the step by step
chronological events of various signals.  Performance of the CPU Board can be verified if
checked as shown in the proper sequence.   Additionally refer to the circuit description
section -945 of this manual.
14.2.1
VISUAL CHECKOUT
1. Verify all components are properly installed.
2. Visually inspect the 1677 EA CPU P.C. board (P/N 193325-000).  Examine P.C. board for broken
capacitors, contaminants between printed circuits traces, open or shorted traces.
3. If all the preceding checks fail to uncover any potential problems, proceed with the CPU POWER
ON TEST.
14.2.2
CPU POWER ON TEST
1. Reconnect all P.C. board connectors if they were previously disconnected.
2. Connect an ECLIPS-C or ECLIPS-S Acquisition System and 3510 XA or 3514 XA to the 1677 EA
using cable assembly 148986-000 and quick change connectors.  When using an ECLIPS-S
Acquisition System it is recommended that a wireline be used in place of a dummy line.
3. On the ECLIPS-C or ECLIPS-S load an XMACII OCT that contains subset 6.  Example OCT 833.
Refer to XMACII Instrument Operating Instructions in manual 130802.915.
4. Apply 180 ±5 Vrms power using the ECLIPS to monitor cable head voltage.

and Gnd at U6-7.  If the voltages are correct, replace U6.  Repeat this step again.


Communication:

Execute subset E (OCT 894) on the ECLIPS-C or ECLIPS-S Acquisition System.  It should acquire
subset E.  If it fails, check the following:

14.3.1
VISUAL CHECKOUT
1. Verify all components are properly installed.
2. Visually inspect both the 1677 EA DSP P.C. boards (P/N 193334-000). Examine P.C. boards for
broken capacitors, contaminants between printed circuit traces, and open or shorted traces.
3. If all the preceding checks fail to uncover any potential problems, proceed with the next section.
14.3.2
DSP BOARD POWER ON TEST
1. Power down the tool, if the tool-power is not already turned off.
2. Reconnect all P.C. board connectors if they were previously disconnected.
3.  Setup a sine wave generator like HP 3310 A Function Generator or similar near the bottom
connector (J2) of the tool.  Set the output function to sine wave, frequency knob to 500 Hz, and
output voltage to 3 Vp-p with 0 V dc.
4. Chain together 8 discrete male pins and plug them into connector (J2) pins 19, 20, 21, 22, 33, 34,
35, and 36.  Make a second chain and connect connector (J2) pins 18, 37, and 45.  Connect sine
wave generator output to pin 19 and generator ground to pin 18.  See drawing 194749-100.
5. Connect an ECLIPS-C or ECLIPS-S Acquisition System and 3510 XA or 3514 XA to the 1677 EA
using cable assembly 148986-000 and quick change connectors.  When using an ECLIPS-S
Acquisition System it is recommended that a wireline be used in place of a dummy line.
6. On the ECLIPS-C or ECLIPS-S load an XMACII OCT that contains subset 6.  Example OCT 833.
Refer to XMACII Instrument Operating Instructions in the ECLIPS Instrument Operating
Manual.
7. Apply 180±5 V rms power using the ECLIPS to monitor cable head voltage.
8. On the DSP P.C. boards check the voltage at +5 VD1 referenced to GND1 to make sure +5 V±5%
is present.  If this step passes continue to next step otherwise disconnect the D11 and D21
connectors and check the +5 V power supply on D11-8 and D21-8 referenced to D11-18 and D21-
18 respectively.  If it is not there, check the 1677 EA power supply, otherwise there is a short on
the board(s).  Check all ICs and possible shorts on the board(s).
9. Using the ECLIPS-C or ECLIPS-S Acquisition System establish Mode 2 communication with the
3510 or 3514 and establish Mode 5 communication with the 1677 EA.  Open XMACII:STATUS,
XMACII:MONOPOLE TOOL CONTROL, and XMACII:DIPOLE TOOL CONTROL windows
from the TOOL menu.  Set STACKING to "1" in both XMACII:MONOPOLE TOOL CONTROL
and XMACII:DIPOLE TOOL CONTROL windows.  Select DOWNLOAD to download the tool
ACQUIRE STATUS button and observe the DSP errors.
14.3.3
DSP BOARD TROUBLESHOOTING

Locate paragraph that most accurately describes the symptoms and follow the suggested
troubleshooting procedure.
1. If sine waves are not observed on all of the channels and none of the DSP error bits are set in the
Status window.

Probable cause:
Connection between the sine wave generator and connector (J2) or the coaxial
connectors to the DSP boards.
Action:
Check that the output of the sine wave generator is connected to channel 1
through 8 on connector (J2).  Also verify the connectors J17, J19, J111, J113,
J27, J29, J211, and J213, are plugged into the DSP boards.  Refer to drawing
194749-100.

Probable cause:
Connection between DSP board 1 (DSP1, see 194749-100) B_AD TRIG OUT
to DSP boards (DSP1 and DSP2) AD_TRIG_IN.
Action:
Connect D11-17 (DSP1, B_AD TRIG OUT) to D11-14 (DSP1,
AD_TRIG_IN) and D21-14 (DSP2, AD_TRIG_IN).  See drawing 194749-
100.

2. If sine waves are not observed on all of the channels and the Status window has any or all DSP
error bits set.

Probable cause:
DSP boards are not in acquisition mode.
Action:
Check if the DSP boards have J8 buss-wired. See scope pictures 14.3.3 and
14.3.4.  Buss-wire J8 if it’s not jumped.

Probable cause:
DSP PROMs (U11, U19, U27, U35) of both DSP boards are not programmed.
See schematic 193334-100.
Action:
Compare scope picture 14.3.4 with 14.3.5, 14.3.7 with 14.3.8, and see scope
picture 14.3.11.  Refer to in-circuit DSP PROM programming procedure
193334-856 to program the DSP PROM.

Probable cause:
The interface between the DSP and CPU boards is broken.
Action:
Check the receiver side of the serial interface between the DSP and CPU
boards to make sure the commands are making it to the DSP’s by checking the
wires between CP2-5 and D11-1, CP2-15 and D21-1,  CP2-6 and D11-11,
CP2-16 and D21-11, CP2-7 and D11-2, CP2-17 and D21-2, and by probing
points on the DSP boards, see scope picture(s) 14.3.12 through 14.3.15.

RESET/ coming into the board resets Xilinx (U8).  Xilinx downloads its program from the PROM
(U5) and in the meantime holds the rest of the board in reset (GRESET/).  GRESET/ goes low a
second time which is a software reset to boot the DSPs (U10, U18, U26 and U34) from Diagnostic
program into Acquisition program.

These figures show the DSPs (U10, U18, U26 and U34) booting from the DSP PROMs (U11, U19,
U27 and U35).  The figure above has two segments, the first is where the Diagnostic program is
loaded into the DSPs and the second is where a larger program, the Acquisition program, is loaded.
Below as the jumper (J8) is not installed the DSPs stay in Diagnostic program.

Xilinx (U8) creates a sampling clock (B_AD_TRIG_OUT) that is used to periodically trigger the A/D.
The rising edge of the sampling clock is used to generate CS1 A and R/C1/A.  ADBUSY1 stays low
while the A/D is busy converting input signal.

ADBUSY1 is converted in Xilinx (U8) into an interrupt signal (IRQ2-1/) for DSP1 (U10).  The DSP
chip is interrupted through the IRQ2 line when the A/D finishes a conversion and the DSP chip reads
the data by asserting IOMS.

SCLKA and to DSP3 (U26) and DSP4 (U34) as SCLKB.

This picture shows a typical acquisition cycle.  CPU board sends a parameter table (104us long
(2)RFS).  DSPs (U10, U18, U26 and U34) go busy for some small time.  CPU board sends command
to acquire/process (stacking of 1). DSPs go busy for about 35ms of which 25ms is used to acquire the
data.  Then the CPU board asks for header data from all 8 channels and then the A/D data from all 8
channels.

1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS

APPENDICES

This section contains a description of the STATUS WINDOW that can be useful in the diagnoses and
repair of an individual board.

Selected Status

ACOUSTIC RESET -
Pressing this button will reset the tool to its power up state.

TOOL SERIES -

When this button is pressed the tool will send the acoustic common tool
series (1677 EA).

PROGRAM STATUS -
When this button is pressed the tool will send the program status, Logging
(RAM based program) or Kernal (ROM based program). Kernal is the
default.

ROM VERSION -

The tools firmware version.

SELF TEST RESULTS -
Pressing this button after a tool power up or reset will display whether the
tools self test passed or failed.  If the self test failed the tool will return
and error code (see error code table section 15.3 for results).

MAPPED TO MODE -
When this button is pressed the tool will return the mode that subset x is
mapped to (subset x is displayed next to the ACQUIRE STATUS
button). On power up or reset all subsets are mapped to mode 5.

Acquire Status

When this button is pressed the tool will return the tool status word.  The following is a description of
each error.

RAM -
Displays ERROR if memory test failed on power up or after a reset.

ROM CHECKSUM -
Displays ERROR if there was a checksum error in the firmware flash
memory.

DOWNLOAD TABLE STATUS -

in tool memory.

MODE 2 OVERRUN -
Displays ERROR if new data is received before previous data has been
read.

UNKNOWN COMMAND -
Displays ERROR if tool did not recognize command.

INVALID COMMAND -
Displays ERROR if tool has a command sync error.

4.0 MECHANICAL CHECKOUT ‡

Remove the electronics from the housing.  Follow the electronics removal procedure
130802-955 for 1677 EA.

Check the top connector, and the bottom pressure bulkhead connector for any damage
to the pins.  If there is any damage correct it.

Look inside the housing and clean off any debris or fallen parts.

Check and make sure all shelves are secure on the backbone.

5.0 BOARD REVISION LEVEL CHECKOUT ‡
Verify all boards on the instrument are to the correct revision levels listed in SAP.  Verify if any
of the boards need modifications.


6.0 PRELIMINARY CHECKOUT ‡

Remove the electronics chassis from the pressure housing if necessary.

Verify that regulators U1, U2, and U3 are correctly installed on chassis.

Verify that regulator U4 is not installed on chassis.

Verify all boards and components are securely attached to the chassis.

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - 8.0 SCREENING 9.0 DC POWER SUPPLY CHECKOUT
chunk_text:
After continuity checks have been completed and any wiring errors eliminated manufacturing
must screen the tool per section 6.2.3.1.1 (Method 201 S) of the System Standards document
number 070060-002. 9.0 DC POWER SUPPLY CHECKOUT
NOTE
For trouble-shooting help on the power supply section refer to the Troubleshooting Section.

Connect PS1 and PS2 connectors to the Power Supply Board (P/N 193330-000).

Connect an ECLIPS-C or ECLIPS-S Acquisition System and 3510 XA or 3514 XA to the
1677 EA using cable assembly 148986-000 and quick change connectors.  When using an
ECLIPS-S Acquisition System it is recommended that a wireline be used in place of a dummy
line.

On the ECLIPS-C or ECLIPS-S load an XMACII OCT that contains subset 6.  Example OCT
833.  Refer to XMACII Instrument Operating Instructions in manual 130802-915.

Connect true RMS voltmeter to terminals 1 and 4 of terminal board TB1.

17

Apply 180 ±5 Vrms power while monitoring the current indicated by the AC current meter of
the 2061 power supply or equivalent. Monitor 180 Vac on terminals 1 and 4 of terminal board
TB1. At no time should the current exceed 270 mA.  If the current exceeds 270 mA
immediately turn tool-power off and troubleshoot to determine the fault.  With 180 Vrms
power applied total current should be 200 ±40 mA.

10.0 CPU / COMMUNICATION CHECKOUT ‡
NOTE
This section checks operation of the CPU Board P/N 193325-000 while checking telemetry
integrity.  Refer to the Troubleshooting section for the CPU board to troubleshoot the board itself.

Verify  DS2 (Red LED) and DS3 (Green LED) are ‘On’.  If both LED’s are ‘On’ the CPU has
initialized properly and is waiting for a command.  Proceed to the next step.  If either of the
LED’s are ‘Off’ refer to Troubleshooting section for the CPU board to troubleshoot the board
itself.

Using the ECLIPS-C or ECLIPS-S Acquisition System establish Mode 2 communication with
the 3510 XA or 3514 XA.

Using the ECLIPS-C or ECLIPS-S Acquisition System establish Mode 5 communication with
the 1677 EA.  If communication with the 1677 EA cannot be established refer to the
Troubleshooting section for the CPU board to troubleshoot the board itself.

Once communications is established select TOOL then XMACII: STATUS to bring up the
XMACII STATUS window. Starting at TOOL SERIES select each button.  The expected
results are shown in figure 1. Note:  For a full description of XMACII STATUS refer to
the Appendices of this document.

Next select TOOL then XMACII:MONOPOLE TOOL TABLE to bring up the MONOPOLE
TOOL TABLE window.  Download a TOOL TABLE for subset 6.  NOTE: After the tool
CHECKSUM for the results of the table download. The expected results are shown in Figure
2.  If you do not get the expected results try adjusting wts mode 2 transmit gain.  If it still
does not work refer to the Troubleshooting section for the CPU board to troubleshoot the
board itself.

Next turn the Switch ACT for subset 6 ‘ON’.  The green LED (DS3) should be blinking.  This
LED is like a heart beat, when the tool enters an acquisition cycle the LED is turned on, when
the tool exits an acquisition cycle the LED is turned off.  If the LED is not blinking refer to the

XMACII STATUS refer to the Appendices of this document.



Change the frequency of the input signal at the function generator from 500 Hz to 200 Hz.
Verify the sine wave on the FULL WAVE MONOPOLE WAVEFORM window updated.
Select the ACQUIRE STATUS button.  If waveforms did not update or the STATUS window
flag DSP errors then refer to the troubleshooting section for DSP board to trouble shoot the
board itself.
11.10 Strike the side of the chassis with a rubber mallet while monitoring the tool’s signals.  Look
for intermittent signals or abnormal operation.  This is to simulate vibration to find any
intermittent problems before they show up while vibrating in Environmental Testing.
11.11 Turn tool-power off.  On the ECLIPS-C or ECLIPS-S Acquisition System exit or hide the

12.0  HEAT/COLD TEST ‡

NOTE:  Restrict the temperature to 0 to 177°C. Restrict the maximum heating/cooling
rate to 5°C per minute. A typical heat run is 1 hour after reaching temperature.


Avoid thermal shocks.

Place the 1677 EA electronics (without housing) into oven. Care must be given to support
the chassis.  Connect signal generator per step 11.2 and 11.3 with high temp wires long
enough to keep signal generator outside of the oven.

Connect an ECLIPS-C or ECLIPS-S Acquisition System and 3510 XA or 3514 XA to the
1677 EA using cable assembly 148986-000 and quick change connectors.  When using an
ECLIPS-S Acquisition System it is recommended that a wireline be used in place of a
dummy line.  See Appendices section 15.10 through 15.12 for optional set-ups and
cable information.

On the ECLIPS system load an XMACII OCT that contains subset 6.  Example OCT 833.
Refer to XMACII Instrument Operating Instructions in the ECLIPS Instrument Operating
Guide.

Apply 180 ±5 Vrms power while monitoring the current indicated by the AC current meter
of the 2061 power supply or equivalent.  At no time should the current exceed 270 mA.
If the current exceeds 270 mA immediately turn tool-power off and troubleshoot to determine
the fault.  With 180 Vrms power applied total current should be 200 ±40 mA.

Setup Communications.

In Data Acquisition Main Menu, select “TOOL” then select “XMACII: MONOPOLE TOOL
CONTROL”.

In “XMACII: MONOPOLE TOOL CONTROL” select “Subset 6” and change stacking to 1.

In Data Acquisition Main Menu, select “TOOL” then select “XMACII: DIPOLE TOOL
CONTROL”.

In “XMACII: DIPOLE TOOL CONTROL” change stacking to 1 then select download to
download the table.
12.10 In Data Acquisition Main Menu, select “TOOL” then select “XMACII: STATUS”,
“ACQUIRE STATUS”.  Verify no errors occurred.  If a table status error occurred try
downloading again or adjusting communications.
12.11 Turn the SwACT “ON” for subset 6.
12.12 8 non-stationary sine waves should appear in “XMAC Subset 10:8 Wave Monopole -
xmac_mb6_10_8fw.wave” window and in “XMAC Subset 6:XX Cross Dipole -
xmacii6_xx.wave” window.
12.13 4 non-stationary sine waves should appear in “XMAC Subset 5,6,10:4 Wave Delta-T -
xmac_mb5,6,104dt.wave” window.

12.15 Exercise the instrument using the ECLIPS Acquisition system while performing the
temperature test.  Monitor the waveform, telemetry, and Tool Status throughout the
temperature test.  Occasionally change the sample period and download the table then verify
a time change in the waveform window.
12.16 Cycle instrument power a couple of times during the temperature test.  Do this to make sure
the instrument comes back to life at temperature.
12.17 Turn tool-power off.

on tool settings.
Make sure all boards are mounted with proper hardware and are secured with RTV.

Make sure all connectors are mounted properly and are secured with RTV.

Make sure all the shelves are mounted properly and secured with RTV where needed.

Make sure all the transformers, chokes and terminals are mounted properly and secured with
RTV where needed.

Make sure all wires are secure and use RTV where needed.

Make sure all IC’s  are inserted properly and then apply RTV as needed.

Assemble the electronics in its swabbed out housing. Follow the assembly procedure in
130802-955 for 1677 EA.

Probable cause:
Open PCB lands.
Action:
Locate open and repair / replace PCB.

5. One or more regulated outputs measures too low.
Probable cause:
Defective Regulator ICs.
Action:
Test / replace applicable regulator - U1, U2, or U3.

Probable cause:
Leaky or open polarized input capacitor.
Action:
Test / replace: C1-C4, C9-C13, C18, or C19.

6. Excessive output ripple and/or input ripple.
Probable cause:
Leaky or open polarized input capacitor.
Action:
Test / replace: C1-C4, C9-C13, C18, or C19.

Probable cause:
Defective bridge rectifier.
Action:
Test / replace BR1 or BR2.

5. On the CPU P.C. board check the voltage at TP13 (+5 V) referenced to TP14 (DGND) to make
sure +5 V ±5% is present. If this step passes continue to next step otherwise disconnect the CP1
connector and check the +5 V power supply on CP1-1 referenced to CP1-3 of the P.C. board
connector. If it is not there, check the 1677 EA power supply, otherwise there is a short on the
board.  Check all ICs and possible shorts on the board.

6. When 180 Vrms is applied to the instrument or when the instrument is reset using Tool Re-Init the
two LED’s DS2 (Red) and DS3 (Green) should be on.  This indicates that the CPU has initialized
O.K. and is waiting for a command.  If these to LED’s are on continue to the CPU Scope pictures
to determine the possible fault. If they are not check the following.

Probable cause:
EPROMS (U9 and U10) are not programmed.
Action:
Program EPROMS.

Probable cause:
Actel (U5) not programmed.
Action:
Program Actel.

Probable cause:
EPROMS not properly installed or seated correctly.
Action:
Reinstall EPROMS.

Probable cause:
Short or bad solder joint around U5 - U12.
Action:
Inspect and repair short or solder joint.

If problem is not found, check the transmit side of the serial interface
between CPU and DSP boards to make certain the data is making it to the
CPU connector by probing points on the DSP boards (see scope picture(s)
14.3.16 through 14.3.18), and check wires D11-16 and CP2-1, D21-16 and
CP2-3, D11-7 and CP2-2, and D21 and CP2-4.  See drawing 194749-100.

3. If first four channels have sine waves but channels 5 through 8 do not and Status window has no
DSP errors.

Probable cause:
B_AD TRIG OUT wire from DSP board 1 (DSP1, see 194749-100) is not
connected to DSP board 2 (DSP2).
Action:
Connect D11-17 (DSP1, B_AD TRIG OUT) to D21-14 (DSP2,
AD_TRIG_IN).  See drawing 194749-100.

Probable cause:
Connection between the sine wave generator and connector (J2) channels 5
through 8 or the coaxial connectors to DSP board 2.
Action:
Check the output of the sine wave generator is connected to channel 5 through
8 on connector (J2).  Also verify the connectors J27, J29, J211, and J213 are
plugged into DSP board 2.  See drawing 194749-100.


4. If first four channels have sine waves but channels 5 through 8 do not and Status window has DSP
errors.
Probable cause:
DSP board 2 is not in acquisition mode.
Action:
Check if the DSP boards have J8 buss-wired. See scope pictures 14.3.4 and
14.3.5.  Buss-wire J8 if it’s not jumped.

Probable cause:
DSP PROMs (U11, U19, U27, U35) of DSP board 2 are not programmed.  See
picture 14.3.11.  Refer to in-circuit DSP PROM programming procedure
193334-856 to program the DSP PROM.

5. If one or two of the channels are not working.

Probable cause:
Connection between the sine wave generator and connector (J2) pin of that
channel or the coaxial connector to DSP board of that channel, if Status
window doesn’t have error bit set.
Action:
Check the output of the sine wave generator is connected to that channel on
connector (J2).  Also verify the coaxial connector of that channel is plugged
into the respective DSP board.  See drawing 194749-100.

Probable cause:
DSP PROM of that channel is not programmed.
Action:
Compare scope picture 14.3.4 with 14.3.5, 14.3.7 with 14.3.8, and see scope
picture 14.3.11.  Refer to in-circuit DSP PROM programming procedure
193334-856 to program the DSP PROM.


6. If sine wave is observed only on the first channel, all the other channels have flat lines and the
Status window has DSP SERIAL CH1 TIMEOUT error bit set.

Probable cause:
DSP board 1 (DSP1) channel 1 is bad.
Action:
Check the DSP chip (U10, see schematic 193334-100) of the first channel
(DSP board 1).  See scope picture 14.3.4, 14.3.5 and 14.3.7 through 14.3.18.
Replace the DSP chip if it has the problem.

Probable cause:
DSP PROM (U11) of DSP board 1 is not programmed.  See schematic
193334-100.
Action:
Compare scope picture 14.3.4 with 14.3.5, 14.3.7 with 14.3.8, and see scope
picture 14.3.11.  Refer to in-circuit DSP PROM programming procedure
193334-856 to program the DSP PROM.

DSP BUSY TIMEOUT -
Displays ERROR if any of the DSP channels did not finish its task in
time.

DSP TABLE ERROR -
Displays ERROR if the DSP subcycle acquisition table had a checksum
error.  A DSP subcycle acquisition table is sent from the CPU to both
DSP boards on every subcycle.

DSP SERIAL CH1 TIMEOUT -

Displays ERROR if the CPU did not receive data from DSP board
number 1 in the allotted time.

DSP SERIAL CH2 TIMEOUT -

Displays ERROR if the CPU did not Receive data from DSP board
number 2 in the allotted time.

ANY BIT ERROR -
Displays ERROR if any of the above has an ERROR.

D0 - DSP Busy
= 1 when the DSP is busy doing some task

D1 - Table Status
= 1 when the acquisition program gets a table checksum error

D2 - Diagnostic Checksum
= 1 when the diagnostic program fails the checksum routine on the

diagnostic part of the flash (sector #0-3)

D3 - Acquisition Checksum
= 1 when the diagnostic program fails the check-sum routine on the

acquisition part of the flash (sector #4-7)

D4 - A/D Failure
= 1 when the diagnostic program fails to get data from A/D

D5 - Acquisition Failure
= 1 when acquisition fails

D6 - Unused

D7 - Unused

D8 - Write Protect Mode
= 1 when in the acquisition program.  Flash can only be written in

diagnostic mode.

D9 - Erase Failure fails
= 1 when the flash sector erase fails

D10 - Write Failure
= 1 when writing to the flash

D11 – Unused

15.14 DSP Firmware Update Procedure


Note: During this procedure all XMACII ACTs must be 'OFF'. The two LEDs on
the CPU board (DS3 (Green) and DS2 (Red)) will be used as an aid.  Refer to
Section 15.14 for additional information regarding LED indications

1.
Load OCT '1667diag', then setup communications on the ECLIPS system.

2.
On the ECLIPS system, select 'TOOL', '1677 EA:DSP ACQUISITION STATUS'.

3.
Select 'ACQUIRE CHANNEL STATUS'.  Verify that the channel status for all 8
channels read '100' or '102'.
Note:
This is the first hint of the DSP acquisition program version and revision.  A
'100' indicates revision XA while a '102' indicates revision XB or A.  Note: XB
and A revisions are identical.  The entire channel status description can be found
in Section 15.6 of this document.

4.
Select 'ACQUIRE PROGRAM VERSION'.  Verify that all eight channels 'ACQ'
version read the same value, indicating that the DSP firmware (flash PROMs) are up-
to-date; continue to the Programming Checkout Procedure.  If any of the 8 channels
'ACQ' version are different then the DSP firmware needs to be updated; continue to the
next step.

5.
Close the '1677 EA:DSP ACQUISITION STATUS' and turn tool power off.

6.
Copy the DSP acquisition program file (193338x.bin, where x is the revision) to the
dat1a/pass directory. Note: make sure that the file name extension is .bin.

7.
On both DSP boards (P/N 193334-000) remove jumper J8. See Figure 10 for J8
location. The easiest way to do this is to simply cut it with a pair of cutters.  Be sure
that the buss wire is not touching after being cut.

8.
Apply 180 ±5 Vrms tool power.

9.
Before continuing turn 'OFF' any ACT associated with the 1677 EA/XMACII.
This will prevent any overwriting of the DSP program in the tool buffer.

10.
Select 'TOOL', '1667 EA:DSP DIAGNOSTIC CONTROL'.  This window is used for
DSP diagnostics and programming the DSP flash PROMs.  The window has been setup
in a sequential selection order.  In other words, select the commands in the order that
they appear in the window. If everything is okay, continue to the next command.

11.
Select 'ACQUIRE SERIAL STATUS'.  If both channels are okay continue to next step.
If either channel has an error resolve the problem before continuing.  First verify J8 is
out, if it is not it will cause an error on both serial channels.  Refer to Section 14.0 of
this document for further trouble shooting.

82


1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS


P/N 130802-956
MAY 2008
12.
Select 'ACQUIRE CHANNEL STATUS'.  If channel status for all eight
channels read '0' continue to the next step. If bit eight is set (i.e. 1xx) then J8 is
not out and the DSP boards are not in the diagnostic mode.  Remove J8 and
check status again.  Resolve the problem before continuing.

13.
Select 'SELECT DSP PROGRAM FILE'.  This will be the program file that was
copied to dat1a/pass in step 6.  Note: make sure that the file name extension
is .bin.

14.
The following is useful information.  The next step is to download the file to the
CPU buffer (Tool buffer).  The file is a fixed 64 K bytes in size.  The ECLIPS
system downloads the file in 2 K byte increments using Mode 2. After each 2 K
bytes are downloaded the ECLIPS system automatically uploads it and
compares it.  If it is o.k. the next 2 K bytes are downloaded and so on.  If it is
not o.k. the ECLIPS system will try to download and compare one more time.
If the second time fails the ECLIPS system will abort.  If this happens try
adjusting Mode 2 and Transmit settings then try downloading again.  When
complete the 'SELECT CHANNEL(S) TO FLASH BUTTON' 'ALL' will be
sensitized as an indication of a successful download. If all works the first time
it takes approximately 2 minutes to download.

15.
Select 'DOWNLOAD TO TOOL BUFFER'.  While the download is progressing
the green LED will be 'ON' and the red LED will change transitions on each 2 K-
byte download.  This can help indicate that the download is in process.  When
the download is complete the 'SELECT CHANNEL(S) TO FLASH BUTTON'
'ALL' is sensitized, the red LED is 'OFF' and the green LED is 'ON'.

16.
After downloading is complete select 'SELECT CHANNEL(S) TO FLASH
BUTTON' 'ALL'.

17.
Select 'WRITE TO DSP FLASH' this will program all eight DSP Flash PROMs
via the two serial ports (Note this is why the serial status was checked in step
11).  Do not do anything else to the tool while programming is in process.
The green LED will be 'OFF' and the red LED will be 'ON' indicating that the
Flash PROMs are being programmed.  A successful programming process takes
approximately seven minutes.

18.
When the red LED goes 'OFF' and the green LED goes 'ON' programming is
complete.  Continue to the next step to find out if the programming was a
success.

19.
Select 'ACQUIRE PROGRAM STATUS'; if all eight channels read ok
programming was a success - go to step 23.

20. If any channel indicates an error it must be reprogrammed. Select 'SELECT
CHANNEL(S) TO FLASH BUTTON', 'CH X', where X is the channel to be
programmed.  Note: If all channels had errors then go back to step 17.

83


1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS


P/N 130802-956
MAY 2008
21.
Next select 'WRITE TO DSP FLASH' to program the DSP channel that was selected.
This process takes about 45 seconds.  The LED response is the same as in steps 17
and 18.

22.
Select 'ACQUIRE PROGRAM STATUS' if all 8 channels read ok programming was a
success.  If not repeat steps 20, 21, and 22 until there are no errors.

23.
This step is optional.  The 'DSP A/D CONTROL' window can be used to exercise the
tool by reading the A/D values.  The options are 'OFF', 'ONCE' (Acquires the A/D
values one time and displays them), and 'CONTINOUS' (Acquires the A/D values
continuously and updates the display).  The A/D values are displayed in volts and the
hexadecimal equivalent.  If the A/D values are acquired with the inputs floating the
will results will be unpredictable, but it can indicate that the tool is functional.  To get
predictable results induce a known DC voltage less than ±5 volts at the input of all 8
channels.  Refer to the 130802-945 Circuit Description document in this manual
(DSP's A/D topic) for information on what the A/D voltage/hex value should be with a
given input.

24.
The following steps are necessary due to a bug in the DSP Diagnostic firmware.  The
bug exists in Diagnostic versions 1.0 and 1.1.  The DSP Diagnostic firmware does not
clear its program data buffer so if it cannot write or read the Flash PROM it will return
the same data back to the CPU causing the CPU to verify ok and not set any program
status errors. There is a small chance that this could happen; if it does and continued
attempts to program the PROM fails the PROM will need to be replaced. Note: The
CPU reads the programmed data back from the DSPs after the flash PROMs have been
programmed and compares the programmed data to the data it sent.

25.
Connect a clip lead across J8 on both DSP boards.

26.
On the ECLIPS select 'TOOL', 'XMACII: STATUS', then select 'ACOUSTIC RESET'
to reset the tool.

27.
On the ECLIPS system select 'TOOL', '1677 EA:DSP ACQUISITION STATUS'.

28.
Select 'ACQUIRE PROGRAM VERSION'.  Verify that all of the channels 'ACQ'
versions are the same as the file used; this indicates that the DSP's firmware (flash
PROMs) are programmed - continue to step 30.

29.
If any of the channels 'ACQ' version is the same, then the DSP firmware did not
program properly. If this happens remove the clip lead across J8 on both DSP boards.
Select 'ACOUSTIC RESET' to reset the tool.  Now go back to step 20 and reprogram
the channel(s) that did not program properly.

30.
Turn tool power off.

31.
Solder a jumper across J8 on both DSP boards.  Use a 22-gauge buss wire for the
jumper and use high temperature solder

84


1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS


P/N 130802-956
MAY 2008
32.
Continue to Section 15.16 - Firmware Checkout.





Note: During this procedure all XMACII ACTs must be 'OFF'. The two LEDs on the CPU
board (DS3 (Green) and DS2 (Red)) will be used as an aid.  Refer to Section 15.17 for additional
information regarding LED indications.

1.
Load OCT 1677diag and setup communications on the ECLIPS system.

2.
On the ECLIPS select 'TOOL', 'XMACII: STATUS'.

3.
Select 'ROM VERSION'. Verify ROM Version is 1.2 or greater.  Anything less will not program
the flash prom.

4.
Close the 'XMACII:STATUS' and turn tool power off.

5.
Copy the CPU acquisition program file, (193327x.bin) where x is the revision, to the dat1a/pass
directory. Note: make sure that the file name extension is .bin.

6.
While holding a jumper across EP1 and EP2 on the CPU board apply 180 ±5 Vrms tool power.
The two LED's on the CPU board (DS3 (Green) and DS2 (Red)) will alternate blinking for
approximately 10 seconds indicating the tool is running the 'flash loader program'.  The
jumper can be removed as soon as the blinking begins. Note: A tool reset or cycling power will
put the tool back into the acquisition program.

85


1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS


P/N 130802-956
MAY 2008
7.
Before continuing turn 'OFF' any ACT associated with the 1677 EA/XMACII.  This will
prevent any overwriting of the CPU program in the tool buffer.

8.
Select 'SELECT CPU PROGRAM FILE'.  This will be the program file that was copied to
dat1a/pass in step 5.  Note: make sure that the file name extension is .bin.

9.
The following is useful information.  The next step is to download the file to the CPU buffer
(Tool buffer).  The file is a fixed 64 K bytes in size.  The ECLIPS downloads the file in 2 K byte
increments using Mode 2. After each 2 K bytes are downloaded the ECLIPS automatically uploads
it and compares it. If it is o.k. the next 2 K bytes are downloaded and so on.  If it is not o.k. the
ECLIPS will try to download and compare one more time.  If the second time fails the ECLIPS
will abort.  If this happens try adjusting Mode 2 and Transmit settings then try downloading again.
When complete the 'WRITE TO CPU FLASH' button will be sensitized as an indication of a
successful download. If all works the first time it takes approximately 2 minutes to download all
64 K bytes.

10.
Select 'DOWNLOAD TO TOOL BUFFER'.  While the download is progressing the green led will
be 'ON' and the red led will change transitions on each 2 K-byte download.  This can help indicate
that the download is in process.  When the download is complete the 'WRITE TO CPU FLASH'
button is sensitized, the red led is 'OFF' and the green led is 'ON'.

11.
Select 'WRITE TO CPU FLASH' this will program the CPU Flash PROM's.  Do not do anything
else to the tool while programming is in process.  The green led will be 'OFF' and the red led
will be 'ON' indicating that the Flash PROM's are being programmed.  A successful programming
process takes approximately 10 seconds.

12.
When the red led goes 'OFF' and the green led goes 'ON' programming is complete.  Continue to
the next step to find out if the programming was a success.

13.
On the ECLIPS select 'TOOL', 'XMACII: STATUS', then select 'ACQUIRE STATUS' verify
'ROM CHECKSUM' is 'O.K.'.  If it is programming was a success.

14.
If there was an error the flash proms must be reprogrammed. Go back to step 11.

15.
On the ECLIPS select 'TOOL', 'XMACII: STATUS', then select 'ACOUSTIC RESET' to reset the
tool.  Resetting the tool or cycling power will put the tool into the acquisition program.

16.
On the ECLIPS select 'TOOL', 'XMACII: STATUS', then select 'ROM VERSION'.  Verify version
is the same as the 193327x.bin file.

17.
Continue to Section 15.16 - Firmware Checkout.

86


1677 EA 8 CH ACOUSTIC ELECTRONICS


P/N 130802-956
MAY 2008

15.16 Firmware Checkout

1. If a 1678 MB Receiver Mandrel is available reassemble the tool and continue with this
checkout procedure.  If it is not available go to the alternate checkout procedure.

2. Connect the 1677 EA electronics (in housing) to the 1678 MB as shown in Figure 10.

3. Apply 180 ±5 Vrms tool power and setup communications.

4. In 'XMACII: DIPOLE TOOL CONTROL' select 'Subset 6', then select 'DOWNLOAD' to
download the table.

5. In Data Acquisition Main Menu, select 'TOOL' then select 'XMACII: STATUS',
'ACQUIRE STATUS'.  Verify no errors occurred.  If a table status error occurred try
downloading again or adjusting communications.

6. In Data Acquisition Main Menu, select '1677 EA:XMACII DIAGNOSTIC CONTROL'.

7. Select '1678 MB TEST CHANNEL' 'ON'.  This option selects a test signal located in the
1678 MB electronics.

8. Turn the ACT 'ON' for subset 6. In Data Acquisition Main Menu, select 'Proc', 'General
Parameters' and turn all acoustic waveform filters to 'OFF'.

9. Eight stationary test waveforms should appear in 'XMAC Subset 10:8 Wave Monopole –
xmacii 5,6,10_8fw.wave' window and in 'XMAC Subset 6:XX Cross Dipole – xmacii
6_xx.wave' window.  Refer to Figure 12 for an example.

10. Four stationary test waveforms should appear in 'XMAC Subset 5,6,10:4 Wave Delta-T
– xmacii 5,6,104dt.wave' window.

11. Exercise the instrument using the ECLIPS acquisition system.  Monitor the waveform,
telemetry, and tool status. Occasionally change the sample period and download the table
then verify a time change in the waveform window.

12. Turn tool-power off, checkout complete.

topic: Description of Service - 1.0 BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
chunk_text:
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
Refer to 1690 Series Equipment Specification Sheet F131271025 for tool application and
measurement principles.

INTRODUCTION
High voltage is present in the 1690 FA HTHP WTS Acoustic Transmitter Electronics Instrument at
various times. Follow the safety guidelines provided in this section.

topic: Lab Safety - 1.1 GENERAL SAFETY GUIDELINES 1.2 ELECTRICAL SAFETY PRECAUTIONS
chunk_text:
GENERAL SAFETY GUIDELINES
Follow the general safety guidelines listed below when handling the 1690 FA.
•
Observe proper lifting techniques when handling this instrument.
•
Thread protectors should always be installed when transporting or handling the tool.
•
Steel-toe shoes must be worn while handling the tool assembly.
•
Wear safety glasses when soldering
•
Where static-guard wristbands when working around electronics
131014-954
AUGUST 2010
2
Lab Safety
1690 FA HTHP XMAC Acoustic Transmitter Electronics 
ELECTRICAL SAFETY PRECAUTIONS
High voltage (180 Vac and ≤450 Vdc) are present at various points on the electronics chassis
when the pressure housing is removed and power is applied to the instrument. The following
electrical safety precautions apply.
•
Clear the area of all non-essential personnel and post the appropriate electrical warning
signs.
•
Never leave the tool unattended while power is on.
•
Turn off power to the tool if it not necessary to the task being performed.



High voltage shock
Possible death or serious injury
•
Turn off power when not required
•
Post appropriate warning signs
•

Tool Weight
The 1690 FA section weighs 186 pounds (see F131271025). Titanium has been utilized for all
structural components in an effort to reduce the total weight of the instrument(s). Never hoist or
lift the tool when the Electronics and Mandrel are connected together unless properly supported
at three or more points. THE EA, FA, AND MA SHOULD BE ASSEMBLED VERTICALLY
OVER THE WELL TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE MANDREL.






Instrument is heavy.
Possible death or serious injury
•
Wear safety boots
•
Use proper lifting methods and equipment to
lift and move instrument


131014-954
AUGUST 2010

FIRING CIRCUIT / BOOST COMVERTER5

FIRING CIRCUIT / BOOST COMVERTER
Refer to Schematic drawing F184260100 during this discussion.
Dangerous voltage level are present in assemblies p/n F184260000, p/n F157018000, and p/n
F157019000. These high voltages can cause serious injury or death. Assembly p/n F184260000
has both 180 Vac, 60 Hz power and DC potentials exceeding 300 volts. Uninsulated terminals of
these assemblies have these high voltages. The cases and heat sinks of power FETs on boards p/n
F157018000 and p/n F157019000 have high-voltage DC present. Use caution when
troubleshooting and be aware of test equipment grounding.



High voltage shock
Possible death or serious injury
•
Turn off power when not required
•
Post appropriate warning signs
•
Avoid distractions while working on equipment with
power applied
•
Do not leave powered instrument unattended

The functions of this network are to:
1. Rectify and filter AC input voltage.
2. Boost the converted input voltage to about 410 Vdc. This voltage is applied to externally
mounted firing capacitor C1.
3. Provide regulation of input AC line voltage.
U1 is a quad comparator. One of the comparators is used to regulate the output voltage; this is
accomplished by sampling the voltage present at the node of resistors R6 and R7. When the voltage at
that point exceeds the reference value on U1 pin 7, that comparator switches ON and thereby alters
the control voltage at pins 5, 9, and 11; the result is to change the frequency of the oscillator portion
of U1. The frequency of the oscillator controls the placement of charge on the firing capacitor
(backbone mounted capacitor C1). The three remaining comparators are paralleled and connected as
the oscillator.
Two active circuit elements are used to produce +410 Vdc: Q1 is switched by action of U1 and draws
current through L2 (a 50 milli-Henry choke mounted on the transmitter chassis). The induced voltage
adds to that stored on the string of input capacitors (C1 through C5), and is transferred to backbone
mounted capacitor C1.
131014-945
AUGUST 2010
6
Circuit Descriptions
1690 FA HTHP XMAC Acoustic Transmitter Electronics
131014-945
AUGUST 2010

When backbone capacitor C1 is discharged (e.g., Assembly P/N F184260000 has fired a transmitting
crystal), the regulation action previously described automatically starts to recharge C1. The
approximate time to recharge is 30 milliseconds. When discharge of C1 occurs, the AC input line
voltage will drop because of the high demand of recharge current. To some extent, backbone inductor
L1 and the board mounted capacitors C1 through C5 reduces the transient affect.

PASSIVE TEMPERATURE SENSOR
A passive temperature sensor (RTD100) is located on the electronics chassis, inside the pressure
housing and is connected to topsub pins 9 and 10 via the top pigtail. This “passive” arrangement
is read by connecting a hand-held meter to the topsub. The sensor should read 100Ω at 0° C. The
purpose of this measurement is to provide the operator with the internal temperature so he can
determine if the temperature is low enough for the housing to be safely removed.

TRANSMITTER ELECTRONICS
Functional elements of the Transmitter electronics are illustrated in Figure 1. There are three
electronic assemblies mounted on the 1690 FA Transmitter Electronics Chassis Assembly
(Reference Drawing A3001001000). The printed circuit board assembly part numbers are: Firing
Circuit / Boost Converter Board (P/N F184260000), P-Wave Transmitter Board (P/N
F157018000) and S-Wave Transmitter Board (P/N F157019000). The terms Monopole and P-
Wave are synonymous, as are the terms Dipole and S-Wave.

P-Wave Transmitter Board
Refer to schematic drawing F157018100.
This board receives and interprets serial input commands from the 1690 EA Acoustic Main
Electronics. The board controls the switching of one of two output transformers (mounted in the
1690 BA Transmitter Mandrel), which drive the P-Wave transmitters. The serial input format for
this assembly is shown in Figure 2. Bits 0, 1, 2, 5, 6, and 7 are not interpreted.



Serial data is received with U1 (a 8-bit shift register). Serial data is latched and stored by U1, and
then made available to NAND gate U2 (2nd half of U2) (see Figure 2, Serial Communications).
Serial data is transmitted from QS of U1 to supply Serial format to the S- Wave Transmitter
Board.
The FIRE pulse is received by one-shot U3; the positive going edge of FIRE triggers the one shot
and produces a signal going from 0 V to +15 V on pin 6 of U3. The duration of the +15 V signal at
pin 6 is set by R5 and C5; the duration is approximately 50 microseconds. Pin 6 of U3 connects
with both pins 9 and 12 of U2, Input pins 8 and 13 of U2 connect with pins 14 and 7 of shift
register U1. When both inputs of one section of U2 are at +15 V, the output of that section is at
0 V. The 0 V level represents selection of a particular transmitting transducer.

Note: The circuits following output pins 10 and 11 of U2 are identical. The description of one is
equally true for the other.

The Field Effect Transistor (pair Q3 and Q4) are current amplifiers; the pair also inverts the input
voltage. Current amplification is needed to rapidly switch power FETs Q8,Q9,Q10 from the OFF
state through the linear region and then into the ON state. Rapid switching insures that FETs Q8,
Q9, and Q10 dissipate minimum power. When the serial data sets (pin 13 of U2 high and the 50
microsecond positive pulse) is applied to pin 12, the output of pin 11 of U2 will be at 0 V for 50
microseconds and the associated power FETs (Q8, Q9, and Q10) will be ON.
131014-945
AUGUST 2010
3
Circuit Descriptions
1690 FA HTHP XMAC Acoustic Transmitter Electronics

The primary winding of the pulse transformer (mounted in 1690 BA Transmitter Mandrel) associated
with transmitting transducer 1 connects between terminals T7 and T9. Also connected to T7, is
backbone capacitor C1, which stores the DC voltage that "fire" the transducers. When FETs Q8, Q9,
and Q10 are ON, the charge on backbone capacitor C1 is dumped through the primary winding and
the transducer (connected to the transformer secondary) is excited. The power FETs remain ON for
the pulse period established by U3. When pin 6 of U3 returns to 0 V, the power FETs are turned OFF
and are held OFF by the low voltage at the drain of Q4.
Power FETs are connected in parallel to handle the current discharged from backbone capacitor C1.
The discharge current has a peak value in excess of 140 Amperes.

S-Wave Transmitter Board
Refer to drawing F157019000 and schematic F157019100.
This board receives and interprets serial input commands from the 1690 EA Acoustic Main
Electronics. The board controls the switching of one of two output transformers (mounted in the
1690 BA Transmitter Mandrel), which drive the P-Wave transmitters. The serial input format for this
assembly is shown in Figure 3. Bits 0, 1, 2, 5, 6, and 7 are not interpreted.



and then made available to NAND gate U2 (2nd half of U2). (See Figure 4 Serial
Communications.)
The FIRE pulse is received by one-shot U3; the positive going edge of FIRE triggers the one shot
and produces a signal going from 0 V to +15 V on pin 6 of U3. The duration of the +15 V signal at
pin 6 is set by R5 and C5; the duration is approximately 210 microseconds. Pin 6 of U3 connects
with both pins 9 and 12 of U2, Input pins 8 and 13 of U2 connect with pins 14 and 7 of shift
register U1. When both inputs of one section of U2 are at +15 V, the output of that section is at
0 V. The 0 V level represents selection of a particular transmitting transducer.

Note:
The circuits following output pins 10 and 11 of U2 are identical. The description of one is equally
true for the other.
131014-945
AUGUST 2010
4
Circuit Descriptions
1690 FA HTHP XMAC Acoustic Transmitter Electronics

The Field Effect Transistor pair Q3 and Q4 are current amplifiers; the pair also inverts the input
voltage. Current amplification is needed to rapidly switch power FET Q10 from the OFF state
through the linear region and then into the ON state. Rapid switching insures that FET Q10
dissipate minimum power. When the serial data sets pin 13 of U2 high and the 210 microsecond
positive pulse is applied to pin 12 the output of pin 11 of U2 will be at 0 V for 210 microseconds
and the associated power FET Q10 will be ON.
The primary winding of the pulse transformer (mounted in 1690 BA Transmitter Mandrel)
associated with transmitting transducer 1 connects between terminals T7 and T9. Also connected
to T7, is backbone capacitor C1; this capacitor stores the DC voltage used to "fire" the
transducers. When FET Q10 is ON, the charge on backbone capacitor C1 is dumped through the
primary winding and the transducer (connected to the transformer secondary) is excited. The
power FET remains ON for the pulse period established by U3. When pin 6 of U3 returns to 0 V,
the power FET is turned OFF and is held OFF by the low voltage at the drain of Q4.



AUGUST 2010
5
Circuit Descriptions
1690 FA HTHP XMAC Acoustic Transmitter Electronics

DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
I. DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURE 1826 MA MECHANICAL SECTION 
 
 
Read, understand, and follow applicable HS&E policies.  Familiarize yourself with 
the Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) for chemicals and compounds used. 
 
Personal protective equipment is provided as appropriate to the work being performed.   
 
 
 
 
Sub housings and assemblies may be extremely 
heavy 
Possible death or serious injury 
• 
Wear safety boots 
• 
Use proper lifting methods and equipment 
to lift and move subs and assemblies 
 
 
 
 
Flying or falling objects 
Potential eye, toe, or foot injury 
• 
Wear safety glasses 
• 
Wear safety shoes 
 
 
A. TOOLS REQUIRED 
Allen wrench, screwdriver and open end wrench assortments. 
 
B. MANDREL CLEANING 
Refer to Drawing A3001654000. 
The tool must be thoroughly cleaned with a steam pressure washer to remove all the mud and 
debris accumulated outside and inside the mandrel openings. 
a) Remove the front plate (item 22), bit cover door (item 20), and cover assembly (item 67). 
b) Rotate the tool so the right side plate (item 16) is facing up and remove it; this allows access 
to the right drive plate.  Thoroughly clean inside of the tool and the drive plate area.  
Reinstall the right side plate and repeat the operation with the left side plate. (item 17)  
Reassemble.   
 
: 
DO NOT REMOVE BOTH PLATES AT THE SAME TIME. DOING SO 
CAN RESULT IN BENDING OF THE MANDREL; THIS CAN CAUSE 

DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
C. DISASSEMBLY OF THE MANDREL 
Refer to Drawing A3001654000 for Production tools 
Removal of the Cover and Side Plates 
1) Remove core measuring lower cover (item 15); wet joint cover (item 57); upper lock arm 
manifold covers (items 59 & 60); quad cylinder manifold covers (items 41 & 42); center 
manifold covers (items 55 & 56); transmission mount covers (items 58, 61 & 62); lower right, 
left and top covers (items 63, 64, 65 & 66) at the dual cylinder manifold; and lower lock arm 
covers (items 52, 53 & 54). 
2) Remove left side plate (item 16) by removing the eight screws (item 6 BOM A3001654000). 
 
Wire Tube Assembly Removal A3000979000 
To remove the wire tube assembly (item 8), start at lower end of the dual cylinder manifold (item 
1) perform the following: 
1) Remove the lower fitting. 
2) Rotate the lower section of the tube counter 90 degrees clockwise and pull back slowly until 
the end connector is disengaged from the manifold (item 1). Very carefully, disconnect the 
11-pin contact blocks. If replacement of the wire tube without any further disassembly is 
desired, do not pull from the wires; this would cause the harness to disengage from the 
pressure bulkhead recessed deep inside the manifold.  
3) Center tee fitting removal. 
4) Move towards the top of the tool, to the center manifold (item 3) and locate the wire tube tee 
connector. Remove the wire way plug (item 2, drawing A3001657000) on the bottom side of 
the center manifold. Detach the connectors J8 & J2 (items 4 and 12, drawing A3000979000) 
and slowly pry the wire tube tee fitting out while feeding the wires and the connectors 
through the wire way (very carefully to prevent nicking or stripping the wires). 
5) Upper 45 degrees fitting removal. 
6) Move to the top of the tool, at the bottom of the wet joint (item 6).  Very carefully, pry the 45 
degrees fitting out and pull the 15-pin contact (P1 of drawing A3000979000) block through 
the hole. Avoid nicking or stripping the wires. Disconnect and remove the wire tube 
assembly. 
 
DC Wire tube removal A3001187000 
1) At the center manifold (item 3) opposite side of the tool disconnect J22 6 pin Lemo. 
2) Gently pry up on the 90 degree connector until the o-ring is disengaged. 
3) At the top of the tool at the wet joint (item 6) side entry 45 degree fitting pry back to expose 
the P21 6 pin Lemo, disconnect and remove the wire tube from the tool assembly. 
 
Removal of the Bit Box 
1) At the center section of the mandrel, where the bit box section is exposed, locate and remove 
the retaining ring (item 94) from the left side tilt arm bracket and disengage the left tilt arm 
link (item 23). Swing the tilt arm bracket out and replace the left side plate (item 17) onto the 
mandrel. Temporarily secure the plate with two screws (item 6 of BOM A3001654000). 
2) Rotate the tool 180°, remove the right side plate (item 16) and remove the retaining ring 
(item 94) from the right tilt arm bracket. Disengage the right tilt arm link (item 24). 

DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
4) Remove the bit box assembly by lifting the drive right plate (item 29) up slightly and pulling 
the bit box up until the bit box drive pins and rollers are out of the guides of the drive plates. 
To avoid bending the linkages, do not force the drive plate. Once disengaged, pull the bit box 
assembly out through the bit side or the top of the mandrel. 
 
Tubing removal 
1) Unscrew from to Lower wet joint (item 6 of A3001654000) all lines. 
2) Trace each back to its termination point and unscrew and remove. 
3) Disconnect all T-fittings and elbows from the line runs. 
 
Mandrel Separation (Three Sections) 
Lower lock arm housing assembly removal F164526000-A3001654000 
1) Remove bull plug (item 27) from the bottom of the mandrel. 
2) Remove screw (item 93) retaining the core tube assembly (item 38) and remove core tube. 
3) Completely loosen the fittings of the lower lock arm cylinder feed lines; union fitting (item 
123) in the close arm line and the T- fitting (item C-3 View D) for the open arm line which 
runs to the bulkhead assembly manifold (item 4 of F164526000).  
4) Using a drift punch drive out pin (item 9, drawing 164526-000) at the appropriate thru hole 
located on the lower lock arm housing (item 1 -drawing 164526-000).  
5) Remove the arm housing pin (item 11- drawing 164526-000) in the same manner and lift the 
locking arm assembly out of the lower lock arm housing. 
6) Remove the two screws (item 14) which secures the wire tube fitting (item 8). 
7) Remove the four screws (item 14, drawing 164526-000) which secure the bulkhead assembly 
(item 4, drawing 164526-000). 
8) Loosen the nut of the run tee fitting of the open arm feed line at the back of (item 4, drawing 
164526-000). Carefully lift the bulkhead assembly up off the lower lock arm housing far 
enough to disengage the wire tube fitting (item 39 @A4 of a3001654000) from the underside 
of the bulkhead assembly F163681000. Remove the pressure plug (item 10, drawing 163681-
000). Carefully pull the wiring out through the cavity and disconnect the 6-pin Lemo 
connector (item 3). Hold the bulkhead connector (item 2, drawing 163681-000) firmly, and 
with a crescent wrench unthread the connector bulkhead (item 2 -  drawing 163681-000). 
Disconnect the female contact block (item 5, J19, drawing 163681-000) from the six pin 
bulkhead connector (item 4, drawing 163681-000). 
9) Remove the six screws (item 15, drawing 164526-000) which secure the two guide plates 
(item 7-drawing 164526-000), and remove the plates. 
10) Remove the two cap screws (item 17&18, drawing 164526-000) which secure the lock arm 
assembly to the lower lock arm housing. Remove the two cap screws (item 14, drawing 
164526-000) that secure the lower cap cylinder plug (item 8, drawing 164526-000). Using 
the 10/32 thread "T" handle puller ( BOM 130586-845), carefully pull the lower cap cylinder 
plug (item 8) off of the lower cap cylinder adapter (item 9 -  drawing 163632-000) and 
disconnect the 11-pin contact block (item 17). Slide the lower cap cylinder plug out through 
the slot on the lower end of the lock arm housing. 
11) Lift the Piston and drive plate arm assembly (item 3, drawing 164526-000) out of the lower 
lock arm housing. Unthread the split collar (item 3, drawing 164526-000) from the feed-thru 
manifold (item 10, drawing 164533-000) and separate the lower lock arm housing. Set aside

12) Rotate the tool clockwise 90° and firmly support the lower dual manifold assembly. Remove 
the left side plate (item XX). 
The mandrel is now separated in three sections. 
 
Separating the Manifolds 
1) Start with the lower half of the mandrel.  Locate the core measurement housing assembly 
(item 14) and remove its four retaining screws (item 83). 
2) At the bottom of the feed-thru manifold remove the two screws (item 83) retaining the feed 
thru plug (item 43). Raise the core measuring housing (item 14) out of the transition 
manifold, and pry the feed thru plug (item 43) out of the manifold. While holding the 
assembly, disconnect the 6-pin contact block (item 110- J16) and remove the entire core 
measurement assembly, including the equalizer cylinder. Oil will drip off the assembly. 
3) Locate and remove the left and right drive plates (items 29 and 30), by loosening the jam 
nuts (item 89) and completely unscrewing the two bit advance adjusting rods (item 31) from 
the plates (items 29 and 30). 
4) Remove the two adjusting rods (item 31) from the advance/retract cylinder rods (items 2 and 
13, drawing 164533-000). 
5) Remove the drive plate rod bracket (item 33) from the cylinder rods by locating and 
removing the two threaded pins (items 32).  
6) Detach the transition manifold (item 2 of A3001655000) from the dual cylinder manifold 
(item 1) by removing all four bolts (item 40) (sheet 1). 
7) Unscrew the tilt arm right and left links (items 23 and 24) from both of the tilt arm pull rods 
(item 18). 
8) Transmission removal. Locate and remove four screws (item 82) and two screws (item 18 of 
A3001657000) retaining the transmission bulkhead housing assembly. Gently pull item 18 
out of the transmission assembly, disconnect the 17 pin connector from the bulkhead (item 9). 
The transmission can now be removed. 
9) The transmission mount manifold (item 1 of A3001655000) can be detached from the center 
manifold (item 3 of A3001654000) by removing the four holding bolts (item 40) and by then 
sliding it straight out over the two tilt arm pull rods (item 18). 
10) Remove the four bolts (item 40) attaching the center manifold (item 3) to the guide housing 
(item 11). Remove the center manifold by sliding it straight out over the two tilt arm rods. Be 
careful not to bend any of the pull rods. 
11) Remove the two tilt rod clamps (item 35) from the left and right sides of the guide housing. 
Locate and remove the four bolts (item 40) securing the guide housing (item 11) to the quad 
cylinder manifold (item 4).  Separate these manifolds and remove spacer (item 131) from the 
guide housing.  Then remove stabilizer (item 46) from the upper lock arm piston.. 
12) Quad cylinder coupling assembly removal.  
13) Unscrew both tilt arms pull rods (item 18) from the tilt arm coupling (item 14, drawing 
181836-000).   
 
Note: 
Mark a "0" point on both rods and count the revolutions to disengage the thread, record this 

DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
14) Remove two threaded pins (item 16, drawing 181836-000) from the tilt arm coupling (item 
14, drawing 181836-000). Remove the coupling (item 14) from the bit box tilt piston rods 
(items 11 &19, drawing 181836-000) by pulling it straight off. 
15) Remove flex lock nuts (item 125,of A3001654000) with a back-up wrench on the hex of the 
pull rods (item 37).  Separate the quad cylinder manifold (item 4) from the upper lock arm 
manifold (item 10) by removing the four bolts (item 40) and sliding the quad manifold off 
over the pull rods (item 37).  Collect the belleville spring washers (item 124) as the manifold 
is removed.  Once these manifolds have been parted, the two 6-pin connectors can be 
unplugged from the linear transducers of the two cylinders. 
16) Remove the two stops (item 128) from the upper lock arm manifold (item 10) by removing 
four flat head screws (item 129).  Remove set screws (item 130) from each side and then 
unscrew pull rods (item 37). 
17) Separate the upper lock manifold (item 10) from the wet joint (item 6) by removing all four 
of the bolts (item 40) attaching them together. Once parted, disconnect the two connector 
blocks (J-10 and J-12) (item 9, drawing 181835-000) from the pressure bulkheads in the wet 
tool joint. 
At this time the mandrel is totally disassembled into its main subassemblies. For further 
disassembly of the manifolds, follow the corresponding disassembly procedures described below. 
 
D. MANIFOLDS DISASSEMBLY 
Dual Cylinder Manifold Drawing A3002075000 & A3002594000 
1) Place this assembly in a vice or suitable tie down fixture, loosen and remove the four bolts 
(item 40) from the lower feed-thru manifold from (item 1) Dual cylinder manifold. Support 
the feed-thru manifold with one hand, and pull straight back away from the dual cylinder 
manifold to pull them apart. Set the feed-thru manifold aside. 
2) Locate the bit advance/retract cylinder, without potentiometer, (item 9).  Push the piston rod 
in until it displaces the piston spacer (item 12) from the bottom of the manifold.  Then push 
the piston (item 9) out through the same hole. 
3) A3002594000, Locate the sensor piston (item 1). Push the piston rod until the piston, the 
retainer plug (J6), the contact block and the linear transducer (item 5) will come out together.  
It may be necessary to dislodge the O-ring (item 11) of the retainer plug (J6) by bumping the 
cylinder rod with a soft blunt object. 
4) Separate the transducer from the cylinder rod by removing the retaining ring (item 4) from 
the bottom of the cylinder rod (item 1). In the event the transducer is to be replaced, remove 
the retaining ring (item 4) in the top of the retainer plug (item 9) and the set screw (item 10) 
located at the bottom of the retainer plug.  This will allow the connector block (items 6-8) to 
be disassembled and expose the three sockets (item 7).  These are crimp connections and 
must be cut off to remove the contact block (items 6-8). 
5) To remove the wire bundle (item 5 of A300207500), grasp the 11-pin contact block (P5) and 
gently pull until the contact block  (J13) is disconnected from the 6-pin bulkhead (item 6). 
6) Remove the 6-pin bulkhead (item 6) by inserting extraction tool (P/N 164506-000) through 
the uphole opening where the wire bundle (item 5) was removed. With a soft mallet knock 
out the bulkhead. An extra hand may help to prevent damage to 6-pin bulkhead (item 6) 
should it be propelled out. 
7) Remove insert feed through assembly (item 13), by inserting extraction tool (P/N 16450-000) 
through the bottom of  the feed-thru manifold and knocking with a mallet, the entire

Coring Chassis Disassembly Drawing A3001655000&A3002653000 
1) Begin by removing the flat head screw (item 13) located at the uphole end of the coring 
chassis assembly (item 1). 
2) Remove core plunger end (item 9, drawing A3001654000). 
3) Locate the wrench hex on the push rod above the core separator assembly, and place the 
7/16" special wrench supplied in the tool kit, on the flats to hold the rod stationary. 
4) Use a 11/16" open end wrench on the separator body flats, and while holding the push rod 
stationary, start turning the separator assembly counterclockwise until is totally disengaged. 
 
: 
FAILURE TO MAINTAIN THE PUSH ROD STATIONARY WHILE 
REMOVING THE SEPARATOR ASSEMBLY WILL DAMAGE THE 
POTENTIOMETER LOCATED INSIDE THE PUSH ROD. 
 
5) Then push the piston rod assembly (item 14) in and out through the up hole end of the 
transmission mount manifold.  
6) A3002653000 – The transducer (item 4) can be removed from piston rod (item 5) by 
removing the retaining ring (item 7) from the lower end of the piston rod. 
7) To remove the transducer from the resistor plug (item 1) remove the retaining ring (item 7).  
Then remove set screw (item 3) from the resistor plug (item 1) and pull the connector 
assembly (item 2) out.  The wires must be cut at the contact block if the transducer is to be 
replaced. 
8) A3001655000 – To remove the elbow fitting (item 9), remove the screw (item 6) and pry the 
fitting (item 9) out. 
9) To remove the wipers (item 8) and the T-seals (item 7 and 15) a sharp soft metal pick is 
required. 
 
Note: 
Avoid scratching the cylinder bores or the seal glands. 
 
Center Manifold Drawing A3001657000 
1) Remove the transducer housing plug (item 3) by inserting the 8-32 tee handle puller (P/N 
164518-000) and pulling the plug out. 
2) Grasp wire bundle (P22) and gently pull to disconnect the contact block from the 5-pin 
bulkhead (item 7). Insert the pressure bulkhead extraction tool (P/N 164506-000 or adaptor 
P/N A1005325000) through the access hole where P22 was removed, and with a small mallet 
knock out the 5-pin bulkhead (item 7) or pull it with a ¼-20 T-handle and adaptor 
A1005325000. 
   
Note: 
When reinstalling the 5-pin bulkhead (item 7); pin #1 on bulkhead must be oriented 
with pin #1 on contact block ( Item 2) of the transmission mount manifold assembly 
A3002653000.
