Quad Cylinder Manifold  Drawing F181836000  
1) Place the manifold in a vice.  
2) Remove tilt arm piston (dummy) (item 19) by pushing the piston in and out through the back 
of the manifold, plug (item 13) will come out with piston.  
3) Pull tilt arm hydraulic plug (item 5) straight out using a 1/4 - 20 tee handle. 
4) Remove tilt arm plug (item 26) by pushing the piston rod (item 11) in and out through the 
back cavity. A bump with a soft mallet on rod end may be required. 
5) Remove piston (item 11), linear transducer (item 12), and resistor plug (item 26) together by 
pushing piston rod in and out through the plug cavity. 
6) Remove Yoke (item 16) from piston (item 2) by removing screw (item 17). 
7) Repeat above procedure for removal of lock arm piston. Piston (item 2), the transducer (item 
6) and plug (item 4) will come out as one.  
8) To remove the linear transducers of either cylinder remove the retaining rings (item 36) from 
bottom of cylinders and top of resistor plugs. Pull 11-pin contact blocks (item 8) from 
holders (item 9). Contact block (item 8) can now be parted by removing screw (item 41).  If 
transducer replacement required, wires must be cut off and new contact sockets installed. 
9) To remove the wipers (item 34 ) and the t-seals (item 22) a sharp soft metal pick is required. 
10) Remove seal plug (item 18) with a small face spanner or tap with soft brass drift punch in the 
face holes until loose. Remove T-seal (item 42) with metal pick. 
 
Note: Avoid scratching the cylinder bores or the seal glands. 
 
Upper Lockarm Manifold Drawing F181835000  
1) Drive pin out (item 26) of link (item 5) using a punch, then remove threaded pin (item 6) 
from link (item 5). 
2) Drive pin (item 4) out to remove arm (item 2) from manifold (item 1).  Remove the 
remainder of Spirol pin (item 15) from the hole in manifold (item 1) using a punch. 
3) To remove connectors "J-10" or "J-12" (item 9) wire bundles disassemble the contact block 
"J4" and "J3" and cut wires loose from contact pin (item 13).  Then pull wires out from 
uphole end of manifold. Remove wire way plugs (item 17x2) from manifold to pull "J12" 
box position wire bundle through. 
4) Remove plugs (items 18, 3,), then remove screw (item 19) and fitting (item 10). 
 
Wet Tool Joint Sub Drawing A3001658000 
1) Remove screw (item 58) and standoff (item 17). Place a screwdriver between bulkhead (item 
9) and body of wet tool joint (item 1) and pry out the bulkhead. 
2) Grasp and pull bulkhead connector (item 19) and separate from bulkhead. 
3) To remove wire bundle, start by removing both 5-pin bulkheads (item 16) using puller 
adaptor P/N A1005325000.  Once the bulkhead is out the contact block (item 30 2x) can be 
unplugged. If the wire harness is to be removed the wires must be cut off at the contact block 
of "J9" and "J10", because the contact block will not pass through the manifold cavities on 
the 1826 MA.  The remaining 15-pin contact block and 6 pin Lemo (item 11 and 7) will pass 
through their cavity into the wet tool joint. The entire bundle can then be removed through

1. Wash all metal parts in a cleaning bath and dry with dry compressed air. Ensure all machine parts 
are clean and free of burrs, cuttings and oil residue. 
2. Install Lee Plug [53] into the Wet Tool Joint [1].  
 
Preassemble the Cable Assembly.  
Refer to DWG A3001658000.  
1. Cut all wires for the J15 Cable Assembly to 25” (635mm) long. 
2. Strip the Shielded wire at for the J21 Connector 2” (50.8mm) from one end of the wire. Un-ravel 
the Shield and pull Shield back over the insulation of the wire. 
3. Install a 24 ga Black wire from the J1 Connector bundle and a 2” (50.8mm) long 24 ga black 
wire to the Shield. Use 26 ga Buss wire and wrap 4 to 5 times. Then solder the Shield to the wire.  
4. On the 1-1/2” (38mm) end of the wire, un-ravel the Shield and pull Shield back over the 
insulation of the wire. 
5. Install 20” (508mm) of Shrink Tubing (F238362000) over the 2 large bundles of wires and 
Shrink Tubing (F238363000) over the 2 smaller bundles of wires.  
 
40-Pin J15 Connector Assembly:  
1. Install the wires through the appropriate holes in the Connector Body [19].  
2. Solder the wires to the Sleeve Connectors [29]. (Refer to Section A-A of the drawing.)  
3. Install the Sleeve Connectors [29] into the 40-Pin Bulkhead Connector Body [19].  
4. Install the remaining Sleeve Connectors [29] into the Connector Body [19].  
5. Position the Face Plate [18] in place with index grooves aligned, as shown on View D, and 
secure with 2 Screws [57].  
6. Slide a 3” (76mm) piece of Shrink Tubing (F238360000) over the 4 bundles of wires.  
7. Secure the Tubing in place with Lacing Cord [63] about every 1" (25.4mm) below the connector 
assembly.

6-Pin J9 Connector Assembly.

6-Pin J11 Connector  
1. Check the Female Contact Block [30] and Socket Contacts [28] for proper orientation.  
 
Note: It is much easier to mark on the connector which is for pin 1. The “F” on the connector is 
to be positioned toward the outside of the Wet Joint Assembly.  
 
2. Slide the wires into the J11 Female Contact Block [30] appropriate holes.  
3. Crimp the Socket Contacts [28] onto the wires.

1/16" 15.8mm) diameter punch. (Do not install the Connector Block at this time.)  
 
15-Pin J1 Connector

2. Strip the wire ends and crimp the Connector Pins onto the wires.  
3. Insert the Connector Pins into the Contact Block [11]. Secure in place by installing Screw [59].

Wire Harness Assembly 
1. Pre-wire harness 6-Pin J10 to 12-Pin J3, only at the J10 end. (Refer to Wiring Diagram location 
D3-4.) 
2. Cut 3 Wires [12] 14” (355.6mm) long and strip the wires approximately 3/16” (4.7mm) from one 
end.  
3. Thread the Wires [12] into a Female Contact Block [9], and crimp three Female Contacts [11] 
onto the wire. 
4. Push the 3 crimped Contacts with 3 blank Female Contacts [11] into the Female Contact Block 
[9].  
5. Cut 14” (355.6mm) of Shrink Tubing [25] and place it over the three wires. Do not shrink tubing 
at this time.  
6. Very carefully, feed the harness through its path in the Lock Arm Manifold [1] to its appropriate 
port (J3 position).  
7. Wire the J3 Connector. Refer to wiring diagram. 
8. Strip the 3 wires [12] approximately 3/16” (4.7mm) from the end. Install a Contact Block [7], 
and crimp the 3 Connector Sockets [13].

Upper Lock Arm Assembly 
1. Install the Upper Lock Arm [2] in the Arm Lock Manifold [1]. Slide Pin [4] in place through the 
holes in the arm and the manifold. Refer to Section C-C on the drawing. 
2. Install a Spiral Pin [15] to secure the pin to the manifold. 
3. Install 2 Upper Pull-rod Links [5]; noting that the counter-bored side of the hole in the link is 
facing downhole. 
4. Install 2 threaded Pins [6] to connect each link to the arm, one on each side. The threaded Pins 
must be flush with the surface of the links.

after the grooves in the links are lined up with the holes in the threaded Pins [5]. 
 
Final Upper Lock-Arm Manifold Assembly 
1. Install two O-rings [23] on the large Wireway Plug [3].

and Parker Plug [18] in the Wireway Plug [3].  
3. Replace the O-ring on the 2 remaining Parhn Plugs [18] with the new O-ring [22]. 
4. Install the two Parker Plugs in the top of the Manifold [1]. 
5. Replace the O-rings on the two Parhn Plugs [17] with new O-rings [24]. Install the two plugs in 
the Manifold Assembly [1]. 
6. Install an O-ring [22] onto the Parhn [20] and thread the fitting into the 90-degree fitting [10]. 
7. Install an O-ring [21] onto the fitting [10]. 
8. Install this assembly into the manifold. Secure the assembly with a screw [19]. 
9. This completes the Upper Lock-Arm Manifold Assembly.

Transducer [12] into the same cavity. Install a Retaining Ring [36] to secure the parts in place.

7. Thread the Transducer wires [12] through the hole of the Resistor Plug [10], and insert the end

transducer to the plug.

and Wiper [34] located in the rear of the Manifold. Continue pushing until the Plug [10] seats 
against the Manifold.

the piston past the "T" seal [22] and Wiper [34] located in the rear of the Manifold.

F. CORING CHASSIS 
 
Note: Unless noted otherwise, numbers in brackets [  ] in this section correspond to the item

The Coring Measurement Chassis is received preassembled from the supplier. The parts have 
been matched drilled and pinned, so an accurate location of parts can be achieved every time they 
are taken apart and re-assembled.  
 
 
EACH PART OF THE CORING CHASSIS HAS BEEN SERIALIZED WITH 
AN IDENTIFICATION NUMBER; DO NOT INTERCHANGE THE PARTS 
WITH THOSE IN ANOTHER CORING CHASSIS. 
FOR CORE CHASSIS ASSEMBLY, REMOVE THE LEFT AND RIGHT 
SIDE PLATES. DE-BURR THE SIDE PLATE HOLES FOR EASE OF 
ASSEMBLY AND DISASSEMBLY.  
 
Transducer/Piston Assembly  
1. Install a T-Seal [23] on the Core Eject Piston [4] and 2 O-rings [17] on the Core Eject 
Plug [8]. 
 
 
THOROUGHLY CLEAN THE INSIDE OF THE PISTON WITH 
DEGREASER AND BLOW DRY WITH AIR. ANY DEBRIS MAY DAMAGE 
THE TRANSDUCER.  
 
2. Cut a piece of Tubing [44] about ½” (12.7mm) in length, and slip it over the wire of the 
Transducer [5] until it rests against the transducer flange. Heat shrink the tubing in place. 
3. Thread the wires of the Transducer through the Core Eject Plug [8].  
4. Insert the flange of the Transducer [5] into the Core Eject Plug [8] and secure with a 
Retainer Ring [27]. 
5. Install 2 Wave Springs [29] into the Core Eject Piston [4]. 
6. Install the slider of the Transducer [5] into the Piston and secure it with a Retaining Ring 
[27].

9. Strip approximately ½” (12.7mm) of insulation from the wires. Fold the stripped wires in 
half and crimp on the Contacts [42]. Trim excess wire from the contacts.

Installing the Transducer/Piston Assembly

top. Reset the Set Screw.  
 
Final Assembly

2. Thread Parhn [26] into the Upper Arm Fitting [3], and install the resulting assembly into 
the Coring Manifold. Secure the assembly with a Screw [35].

L. BIT BOX (A3001369000) 
 
Note: Numbers in brackets [  ] in this section correspond to the item numbers on the BOM for DWG. 
A3001369000. 
 
Bearing Box 
1. 
Using the Installation Tool [40] (F181840000), press 2 Bearings [21] into the Bearing 
Housing [2]. 
2. 
Use the same Installation Tool to partially press the Rotary Seal [24] into the Bearing 
Housing [2]. Ensure the Seal Tension Spring is facing outward. Place the Bearing Housing 
on the table of an arbor press or drill press and apply slight pressure on top of the Installation 
 
 
27 
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
Tool so the Seal starts squarely. Final, insertion is done by hand to prevent damaging the 
Seal. 
3. 
Apply Nyco Oil to the Seal [24] and gearless Mandrel [3]. Slide the gearless Mandrel [3] into 
the Bearing Housing. The Mandrel should fit into the Bearings with a light press fit.  
 
 
DO NOT USE EXCESSIVE FORCE. A LIGHT-DUTY ARBOR PRESS 
SHOULD SUFFICE THE FIRST TIME THE MANDREL IS INSTALLED. 
SUBSEQUENT INSTALLATIONS REQUIRE LESS FORCE AND MAY BE 
DONE BY HAND. 
 
4. 
Install a Spiral Ring [22] onto the Mandrel [3]. Be careful not to scratch the Mandrel's 
sealing surface. 
5. 
Install a Rotary Seal [23] on the Bearing Housing Cover [1] following the same procedure 
described in step 2. 
6. 
Install 2 Seals [33] on the 2 Piston Compensators [11].  
7. 
Slide the 2 Piston Compensators with the Seals into their cylinders in the Bearing Housing 
[2], with the threaded holes facing toward the back of the Housing. 
8. 
Install O-rings [29] on the 2 Fill/Bleed Plugs [18]. Apply Nyco Oil to the O-rings and thread 
the 2 Fill/Bleed Plugs into the Housing [2]. 
9. 
Install the O-ring [27] on the Bearing Housing Cover [1]. Apply Nyco Oil to the O-ring and 
install the Cover [1] onto the Housing [2]. Apply Loctite 532 [42] to the threads of 2 Screws 
[31]. Secure the Cover to the Housing with 2 screws [31]. 
 
Note: The Cover may not fully seat on the Housing. There may be a 0.028” (0.7mm) gap.  
 
10. Press a Drive Pin [17] into each of the 2 Sliders [12], one for each. Make sure to assemble 
form the back side of the Slider.  
11. Install the 2 Sliders [12] on the Bearing Housing [2]. Apply Loctite 532 [42] to 4 Screws [6]. 
Secure the Sliders to the Housing by installing the 4 Screws [6]. 
12. Install the Bit Mandrel Gear [37] onto the Mandrel [3], and carefully match the guide holes 
on the gear with the pins in the mandrel. 
13. Apply Loctite [42] to the 4 Screws [7]. Secure the Gear to the Mandrel using 4 Screws [7]. 
14. Lubricate the shorter threads of the Blank Reaming Shell [30] with Nyco Oil and screw the 
Blank Reaming Shell [30] into the Mandrel [3]. Hold the Bearing Housing in one hand and 
the Blank Reaming Shell in the other, and turn them in opposite directions. The rotation 
should be smooth, requiring only "reasonable" force to achieve make-up. 
15. Slide 2 Rollers [9] onto the 2 Drive Pins [17]. 
16. Set the assembly aside for now.  
 
Bearing Box Oil Filling Procedure 
1. 
Install 2 special fittings [35] at the ends of the Filler and Return Hoses of the oil cart. 
2. 
Remove the 2 Plugs [18] from the bottom of the Bit Box housing [2]. 
3. 

DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
4. 
Start the vacuum and oil circulating pumps. 
5. 
When the vacuum reaches 15” (381mm), shut off the vacuum pump, but keep the oil 
circulating. 
 
 
 
6. 
Open the vacuum to atmosphere and keep the oil circulating for 15 to 20 minutes. Make sure 
the 2 Pistons [11] have been pushed towards the outside of the box. If either or both of them 
have not, close the oil return to the oil cart to build up pressure (not exceeding 20 PSI) in the 
Bearing Box; this will push out the Piston(s).  
7. 
Turn off the oil circulating pumps. Unscrew the Special Fittings and replace one of them 
with the original Plug [18], in such a position that the oil does not escape from the Bit Box. 
8. 
Push one of the two plugs towards the inside of the box, displaced oil will squirt out. 
9. 
Thread the remaining Plug [18] into the Housing. 
 
 
DO NOT BRING THE VACUUM TO MORE THAN 15” (381 MM). DOING 
SO ALLOWS THE VACUUM PUMP TO "SUCK" ATMOSPHERIC AIR 
THROUGH THE SEALS. 
 
Bit Box Assembly 
Refer to DWG A3001369000. 
1. 
The Bit Box [5] is provided as a subassembly from stock, and must be disassembled. The 
components will be re-assembled loosely around the Bearing Box. As the screws are 
tightened it will be necessary to ensure the Bit rotates freely. 
2. 
Press the 2 Bit Box Latch Pins [8] in each Side Plate [35] [36]. Make sure the Latch Pins are 
fully seated, below the surface of the Side Plates.  
3. 
Press the 2 Dowell Pins [25] in each side plate. (Long bevel outward)  
4. 
Assemble the Left Arm Bracket [15] and Bit Box Latch [10] over the Bit Box Latch Pin [8] 
on the Left Side Plate [35] of the Bit Box. Apply Loctite [42] to Screw [34]. Secure Left Arm 
Bracket to Bit Box Latch with Washer [41] and Screw [34]. 
5. 
Assemble the Right Arm Bracket [16] and the Bit Box Latch [10] over the Bit Box Latch Pin 
[8] on the Right Side Plate [36] of the Bit Box. Apply Loctite [42] to Screw [34]. Secure 
Right Arm Bracket to Bit Box Latch with Washer [41] and Screw [34]. 
6. 
Using the Special Spanner Wrench [39], thread a Mandrel Bushing [13] into the front plate 
of the Bit Box [39]. 
 
Note: The Bushing has a left-hand thread. 
 
7. 
Match the Locating Pins and holes and assemble the Left Box Plate [35] to the Front Plate 
[5] and Bottom Plate [28] using Screws [32]. Do not tighten the screws. 
8. 
Install the Bearing Box assembly into the partial assembled Right-side Bit Box. You will 
have to lift the Lift Arm [16] to vertical to install the Bit Box.

9. 
Slide the Blank Reaming Shell [30] into the front Mandrel Bushing [13]. Install 2 Screws 
[32], but do not tighten. 
 
10. Attach the Left-side Plate [35] to the Front and Back End Plates. Secure in place by installing 
6 Screws [32], but do not tighten.  
 
Note: Make sure the gears move freely before continuing.  
 
11. With the Right Plate still loose, carefully drive 6 Pins [40] through the outside plate and into 
the Front, Bottom and Rear Plates.

Note: DC Gears are tighter-meshed and some downward pressure applied by hand to the top of 
the Pinion Gear [4] may be required to align Shaft [26] with Front Plate [5].

Note: 
For ease of tube assembly, do not install the Split Collar [25] on the Lower Arm Housing.

1. Install a Straight Thread Running Tee ([103] on DWG. A3001654000) on the Feedthru Plug 
([43] on DWG. A3001654000). Install Feedthru Plug on Feedthru Manifold ([10] on DWG. 
A3001654000) and secure with 2 Screws ([83] on DWG. A3001654000). 
2. Take wire tube fitting ([39] on DWG. A3001654000) and using a tubing bender for 3/16" 
(4.7mm) O.D. tubing, place a 1/2" (12.7mm) offset to the tube starting the bend 
approximately an 1” (25.4mm) past the fitting. Refer to quadrant A9 on assembly, DWG. 
A3001654000. From the point where the tubing meets the fitting, measure 3 1/8" (80mm) 
length (not including offset] and cut excess tubing off. 
3. Using a file, deburr the tube and blow out with compressed air. Pre-assemble a ferrule and 
nut (F259360000 and F259360003) on the end of the tube. Install the wire tube fitting on the 
end of the running tee ([103] on DWG. A3001654000), but leave the nut loose enough to 
permit the wire tube to rotate with some resistance. 
4. Run a section of 3/16” (4.7mm) stainless steel tubing [99] from the Tee fitting [103] and 
connect to the Union Tee [104] outside of the feedthrough Manifold [10]. Refer to quadrant 
A-10 through A-14 (DWG A3001654000).

Hydraulic Line for the Lower Lock Arm “Open/Close” 
1. For all lines to be formed, first measure from point to point and then add approximately  
8” to 12” (203 to 304.8mm) as required for contouring. The bends can be made with a Parker 
Hannifin tube bending tool or equivalent as follows: for 3/16" (4.7mm) O.D. tubing use a 
Parker Hannifin #4-2829 tool that provides a 9/16" (22mm) inside bend radius, and for 1/4" 
(6.3mm) O.D. tubing use a Parker Hannifin #3-2829 tool that provides an 11/16" (22.5mm) 
inside bend radius. 
2. Rotate the tool to the Left side Up and remove the Left Side Plate [17]. Using a 6’ (1828.8 
mm) long Stainless Steel Tube [22], form the Close Lower Lock Arm hydraulic line that runs 
from the hydraulic fitting on the downhole side of the Center Manifold ([3] DWG 
A3001654000), to the underside of the straight thread Running Tee ([103] on DWG. 
A3001654000), and connect to the Drive Plate Arm assembly ([3] DWG F164526000 D-13) 
through the straight Thread Connector [123].  
 
Note: It is recommended to form offsets of the Tubing, starting from the Straight Thread 
Connector [123].  
 
3. Once the lines have been laid out, following the assembly drawing, remove and deburr the 
ends of the lines. Pre-assemble a ferrule and nut on the ends of the hydraulic lines and 
reassemble to its respective place. 
4. Replace the Left Side Plate [17]. Make sure the Tube is recessed into the groove on the Side 
Plate by holding the Left Drive Plate [29] until it seats properly to the Left Side Plate [17]. 
Secure Side Plate in place by installing 8 Screws [107].  
5. Rotate the tool to the Right side up. Remove the Right Side Plate [16]. At the flat side 
location on the Transmission Manifold, place the 2-Way Splitter Assembly [32] with the 
single fitting oriented uphole or toward the Quad Manifold ([4] Section B-C 24 on DWG

Hydraulic Lines Installation 
1. For all lines to be formed, first measure from point to point and then add approximately  
8” to 12” (203 to 304.8mm) as required for contouring. The bends can be made with a Parker 
Hannifin tube bending tool or equivalent as follows: for 3/16" (4.75mm) O.D. tubing use a 
Parker Hannifin #4-2829 tool that provides a 9/16" (21.8mm) inside bend radius, and for 1/4" 
(6.35mm) O.D. tubing use a Parker Hannifin #3-2829 tool that provides an 11/16" (22.2mm) 
inside bend radius. 
2. Place the mandrel on a tool buggy with the drill bit facing down. Stand at the uphole  
end and rotate the mandrel clockwise 90 degrees so the drill bit is pointing to the left  
(9 o'clock). 
3. Form and install the "Rod-Up" which starts at the wet joint Rod Up Fitting, reference 
location A27 on DWG A3001654000 and ends at the "Rod-Up" port on the Center Manifold, 
reference location C21.  
4. The second “Rod-Up” line from the downhole side of the Center Manifold to the straight 
Thread Connector ([26] on DWG F181843000) on the Core Chassis.  
5. Measure a section of Tubing [99] and cut to the approximate length; again allowing for an 
additional length for bends.  
6. Rotate the Mandrel 180 degrees to run the "Rod Down" circuit. While plumbing the ROD 
DOWN Circuit Tee Fitting ([104] of A3001654000) will be replaced by a 4-way Cross 
Union ([33] on DWG F192830-000). Fabricate a line 1.25" (31.75mm) long and connect one 
end to the fitting located on the uphole side of the Center Manifold.  
Connect the other end of the line to the 4-way Cross Union [33]. Run a line from the 
downhole end of the Rod Down Port on the Wet Joint [6] and a line from the Rod Down port 
at the Quad Cylinder Manifold [4] to the left two ends of the Cross Union [33].  
With the tool positioned on its side, remove the Left Side Plate [17] again. 
7. Install Fitting [24] with O-ring [40] on the Core Separator assembly as seen on DWG 
F192830000, and secure with Screw [37].  
8. Refer to DWG F192830000. The Welded Union Line [33] will overlap the Line [24] along 
the tool body in the area of the Transmission Manifold, use the Parker Union [34] as a guide, 
determine a point along the flat of the Transmission Manifold to cut both lines so that they

both engage [34] approximately 1/4" (6.35mm) from either side. Remove the lines and rinse 
with solvent and blow clear with air. 
9. Re-install [33] and [24], and secure the two together with the Union [34] and two Nuts [43] 
and Ferrules [44]. This completes the ROD DOWN / CLOSE LOWER ARM, CORE 
SEPARATOR RESET circuit. 
Refer to DWG A3001654000 
10. With the mandrel still in the same position, the next circuit to be run is the "Bit Retract" 
which extends from the Wet Joint at location D27 to the Dual Cylinder Manifold at location 
D12. Note that on the removed Side Plate there is a groove to retain this tube; the groove is 
located toward the Bit side of the Mandrel.  
11. Start the tubing at the Dual Cylinder Manifold Bit Retract Port, and form an offset to enter 
the Side Plate groove. Upon exiting the Side Plate groove, offset again to the centerline of 
the Mandrel, reference location D18, 19 and D20. 
12. Follow the Mandrel body contours, then form an offset again at the Upper Lock Arm 
Manifold, reference location D26 – 27.  
13. Continue the run to the "Bit Retract" port at the Wet Joint location D27. Cut the tubing to 
size, de-burr, clean, install ferrules, and make up the connections. 
14. Replace the side plate and rotate the mandrel 180 degrees. Remove the side plate that is now 
facing up and repeat the same procedure described before for the "Bit Advance" circuit; 
starting at the "Bit Advance" port of the Dual Cylinder Manifold and terminating at the Wet 
Joint. Reference location D12 to D27.  
15. Rotate the mandrel so the Bit is facing down. The next circuit to run is the Metal 
Compensation circuit consisting of the two equalizer feed lines. These two lines use 1/8" 
(3.1mm) O.D. tubing [101]. 
 
Note: The bend angles should be the minimum required to make an offset which does not 
impede the flow rate or increase the pressure differential across the drill motor. 
 
16. Start with the "Hydraulic Motor Return" line beginning at the center port connection of the 
Transmission assembly [7]. This line requires numerous offsets, beginning at the Center 
Manifold and then followed by the Guide Housing before running down the center line 
groove. Reference location A19 to A27.  
17. An offset is again required at the Upper Lock Arm Manifold before terminating at the Wet 
Joint. Cut the tubing to size, de-burr, clean, install ferrules, and make up the connections. 
Reference location A26 – A27 
18. Install the "Motor Compensation" lines following the procedure described above. The Motor 
Compensation line should be started at the outer port of the Transmission Assembly [7].

P. TRANSMISSION 
 
Note: Numbers in brackets [  ] in this section correspond to the item numbers on the BOM for 
DWG. A3001275000. 
 
Output Shaft 
1. Slide a Bearing Spacer [18] onto the square end of the Gear Box Shaft [16] and press fit 4 
Ball Bearings [27] until they are firmly seated against the shaft shoulder. 
 
 
DO NOT APPLY FORCE TO THE OUTER RACE OF THE BEARINGS OR 
POUND THEM WITH A HAMMER. THESE ACTIONS WILL DESTROY 
THE BEARINGS. ALWAYS USE A CYLINDRICAL SLEEVE TO APPLY 
THE LOAD AGAINST THE INNER RACE AND A PRESS TO INSTALL 
THEM ON THE SHAFT. 
 
2. Install the Bevel Gear [19] onto the Shaft [16]. Press a Spiral Pin [26] to retain the gear in 
place. 
3. Slide the shaft (with bearings and gear) into the Gear Box Housing [15]. 
4. Insert the Teflon Sleeve [17] over the shaft and into the housing, with the counter bore facing 
away from the gear, and the flat side against the bearing [27]. 
5. To install the Thrust Bearing [30] and 2 Thrust Washers [31], refer to View D on the drawing 
and install the components over the Drive Shaft in the following order: 
6. Install a Thrust Washer [31], Thrust Bearing [30] and a second Thrust Washer [31]. 
7. Install 3 Shims, each .010" (2.54mm) thick, from the Shim Kit [24] and a Cupped Spacer 
[28]. 
8. Install a Retaining Ring [34] in the housing. Position retaining ring so the sharp edges are 
away from the bearing. 
9. Install a Cupped Spacer [28] and 3 Shims [24], each .010" (2.54mm) thick, from the shim kit. 
10. Install a Thrust Washer [31], a Thrust Bearing [30] and a second Thrust Washer [31]. 
11. Check for play in the shaft as follows: 
1. At the end opposite the gear, grab the shaft with one hand.  
2. Use your other hand to grab the housing at the other end.  
3. Push and pull to ensure there is no play either way.  
4. If play is present, add more shims in .001 or .002 inch (0.025 or 0.05mm) increments, to either 
the top or bottom cupped spacer. A general guideline for shim placement is: If there is play on 
pulling motion, add more shims to the lower cupped spacer. If there is play on pushing motion, 
add more shims to upper cupped spacer. 
5. Make sure that the gear does not touch the housing when turned. Add shims as necessary.  
 
Note: 
When the play has been eliminated, the shaft must turn freely and without binding. Due to 
the high rotational speeds, all backlash or shaft play must be minimal.  
 
 
 
44

P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
12. Referring to View E of the drawing, press a Ball Bearing [36] onto the Gear Box Drive Shaft 
[22]. 
13. Press a Ball Bearing [29] onto the other end of the Shaft [22]. 
 
 
DO NOT APPLY FORCE TO THE OUTER RACE OF THE BEARINGS 
OR POUND THEM WITH A HAMMER. THESE ACTIONS WILL 
DESTROY THE BEARINGS. ALWAYS USE A CYLINDRICAL SLEEVE 
TO APPLY THE LOAD AGAINST THE INNER RACE AND A PRESS 
TO INSTALL THEM ON THE SHAFT. 
 
14. Note seal orientation and install a Rotary Seal [37] on the Gear Box Housing [15]. The seal 
must be installed with the spring facing outward.  
 
 
USE EXTREME CAUTION DURING THE SEAL INSTALLATION TO 
AVOID DAMAGING THE SEAL. 
 
15. Check the play in the lower shaft by turning the shaft by hand; it should turn freely. If it does 
not, remove shims or replace with thinner ones, from the cupped back of the gear until the 
shaft rotates freely. Once this adjustment is complete, install an O-ring [44] on the Gear Box 
Cover and secure it back into place with 4 screws [43]. Note orientation of filling port 
clearance hole. 
16. Install the Spur Gear [20] on the Gear Box Drive Shaft [22] using a Screw [38] Flat Washer 
[39], and a Lock Washer [40] below the head of the screw [38]. Use Loctite 242 on the 
screw. 
17. Install the O-rings [46] and [45] on the Drive Shaft Housing [13]. 
 
18. Install a Bevel Gear [21] on the Gear Box Drive Shaft [22] with Shims [24] (0.030" 
(7.62mm) thick from the shim kit) behind both the gear and the shaft. Note the shims have a 
key slot cut. 
19. Install the Key [23] on the above assembly; be careful not to damage the shim(s). The key 
could also be installed first. Be careful not to deform the key during installation. 
20. Look at the gear meshing and check the alignment of the Bevel Gears. The gears must run 
freely, without interference, and without slack. 
21. If the alignment is not satisfactory, add or remove shims between the gear and the shaft. (At 
this time it is NOT possible to check the play between the bevel gears, because the small end 
of shaft is not yet secured). 
22. Slide the Shims [24] from the shim kit onto the shaft and into the back cup of the gear. Start 
with a 0.030" (7.62mm) thickness, and add additional sizes as needed. 
23. Slide the Shaft assembly [22] into the body cavity, making sure the Thrust Bearing assembly 
[30] is seated firmly against the housing. 
24. Install the Thrust Bearing [30] and 2 Thrust Washers [31] over the Bevel Gear [21]. 
25. Install the Thrust Bearing assembly at the back of the shaft in the following order: 
a. Thrust washer [31] 
b. Thrust bearing [30] 
c. Thrust washer [31] 
 
 
45 
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
26. Install the Gear Box Cover [25] and secure it in place with 4 screws [43]. (Do not install the 
O-ring [44] at this time). 
27. Check the “end-play” of the Gear Box Drive Shaft [22] and Gear Box Cover [25] by moving 
the Shaft back and forth by hand. (Zero to 0.05 end-play is preferable, or until shaft 
rotates freely.) Add necessary shims between the Thrust Washer [31] and Beveled Gear 
[21]. 
28. Install O-ring [44] onto the Gear Box Cover [25]. Lubricate O-ring and install Gear Box 
Cover [25] and secure it in place with 4 screws [43]. Make sure the assembly turns smoothly.  
 
Transmission Final Assembly 
1. Install 3 Ball Bearings [27] inside the Drive Shaft Housing [4] and secure them into place 
with a Retaining Ring [33]. (Refer to drawing section 5 D.) 
 
 
BE SURE TO DRIVE BEARING FROM THE OUTSIDE RACE. 
OTHERWISE, BEARINGS MAY BE DAMAGED.  
 
2. Install the Drive Shaft Housing [4] on the Gear Box Housing [15]. Secure it in place with 4 
Screws [57] and Lock Washers [58]. 
 
Note: It may be necessary to file the Lock Washers [37] after installation to make sure it does 
not extend past the side of the Gear Box Housing [1] 
 
3. Thread the Hydraulic Motor Coupler [3] onto the end of the Drive Shaft, finger tight. 
 
Note: This thread is LEFT-HANDED. 
 
4. Install the DC Motor [2] into the Transmission Housing [1]. Align the Motor with the holes 
in the end of the Transmission and install 4 Screws [55] with Washers [56]. Tighten Screws.  
5. Remove the High Temperature shrink tubing from the 3 twisted Pairs Resolver Wires coming 
from the Motor.  
6. Replace the YEL/GRN ground wire from the end of the DC Motor [2] with a 22 ga. BLK 
wire and Lug. Wrap the motor wires and RTD Twisted Pair with Copper Tape [63] in to two 
bundles. Then apply Shrink Tubing [64] over each of the bundles.  
7. Refer to DWG A3001654 WRD. Slide the colored tags close to the Copper Tape [63]. Slide 
the Connector Cap [13] over the wires in their appropriate holes. Cut the wires of the DC 
Motor 2-1/2” (63.5mm) from the Bulkhead Motor Adapter [6].  
8. Strip the wires 1/8” (3.1mm) from the end and install 3/8” (9.5mm) of Shrink tubing 
(F240779000) over each wire. Solder Pins [8] onto the end of each wire. Install the 
Connector Plug [14] over the pins and secure the two halves of the Connector together with 
Screw [11]. We strongly recommend marking the location of Pin 1.  
9. Install an O-ring [47] onto the Bulkhead Motor Adapter [6]. Lubricate the O-ring with oil 
and install Adapter into Transmission Housing [1]. Secure the Adapter in place by installing 
3 Screws [54].  
 
 
46 
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
10. Install O-ring [46] onto the Drive Shaft Housing [4]. Align the Motor Shaft with the Drive 
Shaft Coupling [3] and install the two housing together.  
11. Install 4 Screws [55] with 4 Lock Washers [56], securing the Motor Housing [1] to the Drive 
Shaft Housing [4].  
12. Install a Seal Screw [59] with an O-ring [60] into the filling hole of the housing. 
13. Install a Fill Plug [41] with an O-ring [42] into the Gear Housing through the hole on the 
Gear Cover. 
14. Install the Stop Pinion [76] (on DWG A3001654000) on the end of the Shaft Housing. 
Secure with 2 Screws [78]. 
15. Install O-ring [10] onto the fitting of the Cooling Motor Fitting [9]. Then install the Fitting 
[9] into the Transmission Housing [1]. Then install the Fitting onto the end of the Tube.  
Refer to DWG A3001657000. 
16. Install the PowerCOR Wire Tube into the Center Manifold and slide the J8 Lemo Connector 
up through the large port of the Center Manifold.  
17. Move the Bulkhead Connector [4] to the side. Install the J2 Connector to the P2 Connector, 
making sure the pins align.  
18. Install the Transmission Assembly [1] into the MB Section and connect the Motor wires to 
the Bulkhead Connector.  
19. Slide the Bulkhead Adapter into the end of the Transmission until the Transmission and 
Bulkhead are able to fit into their respective slots in the MB Section.  
20. Compress the two pieces until the Transmission and Bulkhead Adapter fit into the MB Tool.  
21. Cut and bend the Hydraulic line from the Transmission to the Wet Joint. Then install the 
Hydraulic Line to the Wet Joint and Transmission.  
22. Cut and bend the Hydraulic line from the Transmission to the Wet Joint. Then install the 
Hydraulic Line to the Wet Joint and Transmission.  
23. Apply 2 pieces of Shrink Tubing (F238360000) over the two Lemo Connectors. Connect the 
Lemo Connectors and shrink the Shrink Tubing over the connection.  
24. Install 2 Screws [34] to secure the Bulkhead Adapter [4] to the Chassis. 
25. Install 4 Screws [82] (from DWG A3001654000) in the sides of the chassis to secure the 
Transmission in place.  
26. Install the Cap [2] (from DWG A3001657000) onto the Center Manifold.

III. 
TRANSMISSION OIL FILLING PROCEDURE 
1. Place the transmission assembly into the MB Section and connect the tubing. 
2. Connect the 1/8” (3.1mm) Compensation Tubes to the Top Joint Fittings.  
3. Remove the plug and screw in one oil fill and bleed fitting, [3 - Lab Kit 130586-845]. 
4. Attach the pump return hose to the fitting. Elevate the bottom of the MB, if possible.  
5. Remove the seal screw from the motor housing and screw in on the swivel fitting, (F132989000). 
Attach the pump output pressure hose to the fitting. 
6. Turn on the pump and begin circulating until oil flows through the return line.  
7. Purge the 1/8” (3.1mm) Compensation Tube by pressing in on each Staubli [5], opening the 
valve with a 1/8” (3.1mm) brass drift Punch or Allen Wrench. 
8. Oil and air will flow out of the Staubli. Periodically close the Staubli and reopen until clear fluid 
is coming out.  
9. With the pump circulating, start the vacuum pump. Evacuate the system until the gauge reaches 
10 to 15 inches of vacuum. Stop the vacuum pump, and hold the vacuum for fifteen minutes 
while continuing to circulate. 
10. Stop the circulation and start the vacuum pump again. Continue the evacuation for 30 minutes, 
and then start the circulation pump. Repeat this procedure as required until no air is present in the 
return line. Drop the vacuum to 0 and circulate for 5 minutes.  
11. Stop the pump and remove the swivel fitting from the motor housing and replace the seal screw. 
(Allow 1 to 2 minutes for return fluid to diminish.) 
12. Remove the oil feed and bleed fitting from the gear box. 
13. Replace the plug. 
14. Position the Bit Box Cover [20] over the Bit Box. Make sure the Pins [21] of the cover slides into 
the Tilt Arm Bracket. 
15. Install the Bit Box Door [22] over the Bit Box assembly and secure (not tight) in place by 
installing 4 Screws [71].  
 
Note: The Bit Box [5], Bit Box Door [22] and Bit Box Cover [20] need to be removed when the tool 

DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
IV. 
HYDRAULIC FLUID FILLING PROCEDURE 
1. Prepare the Mandrel per  the RCOR System Checkout Setup; refer to the operating manual for 
additional information. 
2. Lock Arm Circuits:  Position the mandrel on stands with the bit opening facing up and elevate 
the Field Joint so that the Mandrel is inclined approximately 10 degrees. 
3. Open the Upper Lock Arm ports [112] on the Upper Lock Arm Manifold.  
4. Open the Lower Lock Arm supply fitting at the lower end of the mandrel, and the Union fitting 
located on the Rod Down-close arm line. Locations B2 and B4 on sheet two, respectively. 
5. Select (low pressure] and power up motors; when oil appears at the Upper Arm Manifold ports, 
turn motors off. Replace the Plugs [112] partially to allow oil flow through the threads. Do not 
seat the O-rings. 
6. Start the motor again at low pressure. Oil should begin to flow slightly through the ports at the 
Upper Lock Arm Manifold and at the Lower Arm Cylinder ports (open and close).  
 
Note: Rod Up must be "On" during this procedure to allow the flow of oil from the arm close circuit 
to the tank or to the open arm close fitting in the Lower Lock Arm assembly. 
 
7. Once the oil flows steadily through the slightly open ports, select Arms Close. Arms will start to 
close. Observe if air bubbles escape through either Lock Arm Cylinders ports or fittings. 
8. Cycle the tool (Arms Open - arms Close] several times until no more air is observed coming out 
of the ports. Tighten plugs and fittings. 
9. Deploy the arms again (Arm Open), with all ports closed, at Max Press.  
10. Once the motion of the arms has stop at the fully open position, toggle Rod Up off , and allow the 
auxiliary pressure to inflate the accumulator and build up to its maximum value.  
11. Let pressure stabilize at its peak for about 10 seconds, and then select Aux Pressure Low . If the 
pressure in the arm circuit does not hold, when observed with a gauge installed at the wet joint 
port, or the peak value drops to a lesser setting, air may still be present in the circuits.  
12. Repeat the bleeding procedure if necessary until all the air is evacuated from the system. 
13. Select (maximum pressure) and power up motors. When pressure peaks, select and observe 
gauge pressure. An initial drop in pressure may be seen and then it should remain steady between 
2500 and 2100 PSI. If the pressure falls off, air is present in the system, and the procedure above 
should be repeated. 
14. Push Rod Circuit: While the Wet Joint is still elevated, position the mandrel so the bit side is 
facing up.  
15. Power up the tool and lock the arms open at Max pressure, then toggle to Low Press. The Rod 
Up and Rod Down bleed plugs [100] are located, on the bit side, at the Center Manifold [3]. 
 
Note: The port closest to the downhole end, on the left side of the tool when looking down from the 
top sub with the bit facing up, is the Rod Down bleeding port. 
 
16. Loosen both plugs, then select Rod Down. Air will begin to escape through the ports. 
17. Wait for about 20 seconds and select Rod Up. Air will escape through the ports. Tighten both 
ports. 
18. With the rod at any position, open the Rod Up port partially, then actuate Rod Down. 
 
 
49 
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
19. Once the rod has completed its stroke down, and no more air is observed coming out of the port, 
tighten the plug then turn Rod Down off. 
20. Partially open the Rod Down port, then actuate Rod Up. Observe oil and air coming through the 
bleeding port.  
21. Once the rod has completed its stroke up, tighten the plug. 
22. Repeat these steps alternating ports until all the air has been evacuated from the system. 
23. Box to Core (BXC] and Box to Eject (BXE] Circuit: Maintain the mandrel with the bit opening 
facing up and the top sub still elevated.  
24. Start the motor and open the lock arms at maximum pressure; once the arms are open, toggle 
auxiliary pressure Low Press. 
25. The Box Core and Box Eject bleed plugs [100] are located, on the bit side, at the Upper Arm 
Manifold [10]. They are side-by-side, close to the downhole end of the manifold. 
 
Note: The port on the left side of the tool, when looking down from the top sub with the bit facing up, 
corresponds to the Box Eject circuit. 
 
26. The same procedure used previously to bleed the push rod circuits applies for this section. 
Loosen both bleeding plugs, then select Box Core. Air will escape through the ports. 
27. Wait for about 20 seconds and select Box Eject. Air will escape through the ports. 
28. Tighten both ports. 
29. With the box at the coring position, open the Box Core port partially, then actuate Box Eject.  
30. Once the box has completed its stroke and no more air is observed coming out of the port, tighten 
the plug then turn Box Eject off. 
31. Partially open the Box Eject port, then actuate Box Core. Observe oil and air coming through the 
bleeding port.  
32. Once the box has completed its stroke, tighten the plug. 
33. Repeat these steps alternating ports until all the air has been evacuated from the system. 
34. Advance and Retract Circuits: Position the mandrel with the bit opening facing up and elevate 
the down hole end of the mandrel approximately 10 degrees. The advance and retract ports [112] 
are on the Dual Cylinder Manifold. 
35. Locations B2 and B3 on sheet three. 
36. Turn on Motors. Loosen both ports, then alternately toggle on and off advance and retract to clear 
the external lines of air. Then continue to toggle on and off; some Drive Plate [29] and [30] 
motion should occur. Turn off Motors. 
37. With the Bit Box in the retract position, install and tighten the Upper Port Plug for the Bit 
Advance circuit, and remove the Lower Port Plug for the Bit Retract circuit.  
38. Turn on Motors and toggle on, Bit Advance. When the stroke is complete, toggle off and install 
and tighten the Retract Port Plug and remove the Bit Advance Port Plug. Toggle on, Bit Retract.  
39. When the stroke is complete, toggle off and install and tighten the Upper Port Plug. Repeat this 
procedure until no air comes from the open ports. 
40. When finished, retract the bit using and return the Bit Box to the eject position using. 
 
 
50 
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
Note: 
The holding pressure can be confirmed by installing pressure gauges on the hydraulic section 
field joint at the Bit Advance and Bit Retract Ports. In all cases, smooth cylinder operation 
should be obtained; a jerking motion or hesitation is a sign of air in the system. The inability to 
hold low pressure on an energized circuit indicates air in the system. 
 
41. Bit Drive Motor Circuit: Position the mandrel horizontal (no elevation) with the bit opening 
facing down. For reference, the Bit Drive Motor is inside the Transmission assembly [7]. 
42. Core Measurement Box Assembly: This circuit consists of the Core Measurement Box [14], the 
Compensation Tube [50], the Feed-thru Plug [43], and the interconnecting Tubing. The oil 
circulation ports are located as follows: the in port is located on the Feed-thru Manifold on the 
left side of tool when looking down from the top sub with the bit facing up. The out port is 
located on the Core Measurement Housing [40], under the right side plate of the mandrel. 
43. The mandrel should be in a horizontal position with the bit opening at 9 o'clock as observed from 
the uphole end of the mandrel. Remove the right side plate (plate facing up), to expose the 
Circulate Out Plug on the Core Measurement Box.  
44. Remove this plug and install a modified #3 SAE fitting [116].  
45. Connect the "from tool" pump cart line to the modified fitting.  
46. Remove the plug [100] at the in port, install a modified #3 SAE fitting [116] and connect the "to 
tool" pump cart line. 
47. Elevate the field joint end of the mandrel slightly. Start the pump and begin circulating hydraulic 
fluid at 20 PSI for 15 to 20 minutes.  
48. Start the vacuum pump, close the "to tool" valve, and stop the circulation pump. Now let the 
vacuum pump run for 30 minutes to 1 hour. 
49. Turn the vacuum pump off and start the circulation pump. Then open the "to tool" valve and 
open the vacuum to atmosphere; continue to circulate at 20 PSI for 20 minutes. 
50. Insert the Tee Handle [115] through Cap [52] located at B8 on sheet one, and then thread the 
handle into the Compensation Piston [51]. Pull the Piston all the way to the downhole end of its 
stroke, then push the Piston all the way to the uphole end. A surge of oil can be observed at the 
"from tool" side of the circulation hose. Repeat this procedure to confirm no escaping air is 
visible. Now restore the Piston to the full downhole position. 
 
Note: Do not use pump pressure to move the Piston; the O-ring on the Core Measurement Box lid will 
not seal internal pressure above 20 PSI. 
 
51. Stop the circulation pump, close the valve and remove the "from tool" circulation line.  
52. Remove the #3 SAE fitting [116] and replace the #3 SAE plug [100]. Replace the Side Plate and 
rotate the mandrel 180 degrees clockwise. The "to tool" circulation hose should be facing up.  
53. Close the line valve and remove the #3 SAE modified fitting [116]. Now thread the Tee Handle 
into the Piston and then move the Compensation Piston inward until the "MA" mark is aligned 
with the end of Cap [52]. Oil will surge from the Connector Cover [48].  
54. Replace the #3 SAE plug and unscrew the Tee Handle. 
 
 
 
 
 
51 
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
 
A. ADJUSTMENTS 
Refer to (FIG 1 on page 58 of F130586855) The objective of the adjustments with the Bit 
Box [1] in the coring position is to provide proper meshing of the gears, solid retention of the 
Bit Box against the Stop Screws (items 2 (see DocA3001654000 and 3). Maintain the 
perpendicularity between the bit axis and the longitudinal axis of the mandrel, and at the same 
time locating the Bit Box Guide Pin [4] at the apex of the Drive Plate [5] in the advance/retract 
slot. In the Box Eject position it is necessary that the Bit Box be properly aligned with the Core 
Receiving Box, and that the axis through the center of the Bit Box is parallel to the center line 
of the mandrel. 
 
1. Position the mandrel horizontal with the bit opening oriented at 9 o'clock as viewed from the 
field joint end.  
2. Turn on motors and if the box is not in the eject position toggle, and then remove the side plate 
that is facing up. Adjust the tilt arm link distance [9] to 3-1/2” (88.9mm) between the lower end 
of the Tilt Arm Link [6] and the lower end of the Transmission Mount [11]. Record the exact 
measurement and then replace the side plate. 
3. Rotate the mandrel 180 degrees, then remove the Side Plate and again adjust the distance 
between the lower end of the Tilt Arm Link and the lower end of the Transmission Mount to the 
same measurement as recorded from the other side.  
4. Replace the Side Plate. 
5. Toggle, Box to Core, and check the degree of meshing between the Bit Drive Gears ([4] on 
DWG. A3001369000, and [6] on DWG. A3001275000). This can be done by turning the Pinion 
Gear back and forth by hand; a slight amount of play between the gears is desirable.  
6. If there is no play or if there is too much play, then toggle and adjust the Stop Screws [2] and [3], 
accordingly. Toggle and again check the gears. Repeat as necessary to obtain the proper 
clearance. Note that while adjusting the screws, make sure the axis of the Core Box [1] is 
perpendicular to the longitudinal axis of the mandrel. 
7. Remove the Side Plate facing up and toggle, Box to Core. Now observe the location of the Box 
Guide Pin [4] in relation to the Drive Plate advance/retract slot [12]. This Pin must be at the apex 
of the slot. To assure this, screw the Drive Plate Adjustment Rod [7] in or out; a slight resistance 
in the Adjustment Rod can be felt when the Guide Pin contacts the slots highest point. Now 
tighten the Adjustment Rod Jam Nut [8]. 
8. Replace the Side Plate, rotate the tool 180 degrees and remove the Side Plate facing up. Adjust 
this Drive Plate following the procedure above and tighten the Adjustment Rod Jam Nut [8]. 
9. With the Side Plate off, toggle, Box to Eject. The Bit Box should be aligned with Core Receiver 
Box, and the axis through the center of the Bit Box should be parallel to the longitudinal axis of 
the mandrel. If not, readjust the Tilt Arm Links at a new distance [9] to correct the Bit Box 
orientation; then readjust the Drive Plates. The distance [10] between the Tilt Arm Links and the 
top of the Drive Plates should be about 11/32" (8.7mm) to assure proper linkage operation.  
10. With both Side Plates installed, sequence between and several times to ensure all of the 
adjustment objectives have been met. 
11. Return the Box to the eject position, install 2 Clamps [35] and secure with 2 Screws [79]. 
 
 
52

V. 1826 MA ELECTRICAL CHECKOUT 
A. WEETECH TEST 
1. Use the WeeTech 1826 MA test program to perform continuity and leakage tests on the 1826 MA 
under test. See BOM of the 1826 MA Equipment Information Sheet (A3001654000) for WeeTech 
software part number. 
 
B. CONTINUITY/RESISTANCE CHECK  
2. Use ohmmeter to confirm pin 17 of the 40-pin connector is connected directly to the MA chassis 
(less than 1 ohm). 
3. Ohm between pins 2 & 9, 9 & 12, and 2 &12.  Each of these readings should be 6.5-7.5Ω. 
4. Ohm between pins 20 & 21 and 22 & 23.  Each reading should be 19-22Ω. 
5. Ohm between pins 31 & 32.  The reading should be 13-15Ω. 
 
 
6. Ohm every pin on the connector individually to pin 17.  All pins should be OPEN to the chassis. 
If using a break-out box on the MA 40-pin, do not connect other side of box to PA for these 
measurements. 
7. Meg pins 2, 9, and 12, individually to pin 17 at 500 V.  All pins should show OPEN (>1 GΩ) to 
the chassis. 
8. Meg pins 20, 21, 22, 23, 31, and 32 individually to pin 17 at 100 V.  All pins should show OPEN 
(>1 GΩ) to the chassis. 
9. Meg pin 2 to each of pins 20, 21, 22, 23, 31, and 32 at 100 V.  All should show >1 GΩ. 
10. Meg pin 9 to each of pins 20, 21, 22, 23, 31, and 32 at 100 V.  All should show >1 GΩ. 
11. Meg pin 12 to each of pins 20, 21, 22, 23, 31, and 32 at 100 V.  All should show >1 GΩ. 
12. Meg pin 20 to each of pins 22 and 31 at 100 V.  Both should show >1 GΩ. 
13. Meg pin 22 to pin 31 at 100 V.  Should show >1 GΩ. 
14. Also check the following pins with an ohmmeter:

VI. 
PREPARATION FOR TEMPERATURE AND PRESSURE TEST 
1. Install the Bit Box Cover [20] making sure that the Pins [21] engage the slots in the Tilt Arm 
Bracket, ([16] on DWG. F162325-000). 
Refer to DWG A3001654000, Sheet 1.  
2. Install the Wet Joint Covers [57] using Screws [80]. Location D26 on sheet one. 
3. Install the Upper Lock Arm Manifold Covers [59] and [60] using Screws [80]. Location D25 on 
sheet one. 
4. Install the Quad Cylinder Manifold Covers [41] and [42] using Screws [80]. Location D24 on 
sheet one. 
5. Install the Center Manifold Covers [55] and [56] using Screws [80]. Location D21 on sheet one. 
6. Install the Transmission Mount Covers [58], [64] and [63] using Screws [80]. Location D20 on 
sheet one. 
7. Install the Lower Right, Left and Top Covers [61], [62] and [65] using Screws [80]. Location 
D13 on sheet one. 
8. Position the Bit Box Cover [20] over the Bit Box. Make sure the pin [21] of the cover slides into 
the Tilt Arm Brackets. (Location D 16 on sheet 1.) 
9. Install the Bit Box Door [22] using Screws [92]. Location C14 on sheet one. 
10. Install the 3 piece Cover [70] using Screws [71]. Location A14 on sheet one. 
11. Apply Nyco Oil and install 2 O-rings [96] to the Wet Joint assembly [6]. Location C28 on sheet 
one. 
12. Using a straight Grease Fitting [102] and a grease gun, inject Lubriplate grease #1444 [118] in 
both Side Plates [16] and [17] Grease Ports (2 on each plate). Remove the grease Fittings [120] 
from the side plates and install Set Screws [79].  
13. Install the Bull Plug [27] at the bottom of the mandrel. 
14. Install the Plug [28] onto the Bull Plug [27] and secure in place with a Spiral Pin [95]. 
15. The tool is ready for QC Inspection. 
 
 
54

VII. 
FINAL ASSEMBLY 
1. Assemble the Rubber Cover Bit Box Assembly. Refer to DWG F183909000. 
2. Place the Rubber bit Box Cover [2] on the inside of the Bit Box Cover Frame [1], as shown. 
3. Place the 2 Cover Spacers [3] over the Rubber Cover [2] and secure to the Frame [1] by applying 
Loctite 532 to the 6 Screws [4] and installing them through the Spacer and Rubber Cover, into 
the Frame.  
4. After the 6 Screws [4] are in place, file the ends of the screws smooth, slightly above the Frame 
[1].  
5. Referring to DWG F193214000, assemble the 6 Clamps [3] to the Core Tube [1]. 
Refer to DWG A3001654000.  
6. Remove the Core Separator Cover [70], Mounting Plate ([19] on DWG F192830000) and 
Washer Housing Assembly ([13] on DWG F192830000) on the Core Separator, location BC 14.  
7. Install the Core Tube [38]. Start from the bottom end of the Lower Arm Housing. (Location BC 
3) Push the Core Tube [38] in the tool assembly until it seats firmly at the Core Combo Housing. 
(Location BC 13)  
8. Secure the Core Tube [38] with Set Screws [93]. (Location BC 3) 
Refer to DWG F192830000 
9. Reinstall the Washer Housing Assembly [13] with its 2 Set Screws [12]. Reinstall the Mounting 
Plate [19] and secure in place by installing 4 Lock Washers [21] and 4 Screws [20].  
10. Reinstall the Cover [70] and secure with a Set Screw [69]. 
Refer to DWG A3001654000. 
11. Using a modified Grease Fitting [102], inject the Grease #1444 [118] into 2 locations on both 
sides (total of 4) of the Lower Lock Arm Housing (DWG F164526-000, Location D 5 & 6). 
Replace the Grease Fitting with a Screw [20] and O-ring [24] (4 total – 2 on each side). 
12. Using a modified Grease Fitting [102], inject the Grease #1444 [118] into 2 locations on both 
sides of the Bit Box Housing (DWG A3001654000, Location D 14). Then fill the Bit Box with 
Grease [118]. 
13. Replace the Grease Fitting with 4 Set Screws [79] (2 on each side). Refer to DWG 
A3001654000, Location D 14. 
14. Install the Bit Box Cover [67] using 4 Screws [85] (Location AB 15).  
15. Install the Arm Locking Cover Top [53] using 6 Screws [80] (Location CD 4-7).  
16. Install the Lower Housing #2 Cover [54] using 4 Screws [80] (Location CD 9). 
17. Install the Lower Housing #3 Cover [66] using 4 Screws [85] (Location BC 9). 
18. Install the Offset Cylinder Cover [52] using 6 Screws [87] and 4 Screws [86] (Location CD 4-9).  
 
 
55 
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
VIII. PRONY BRAKE (HORSEPOWER) TEST 
Before performing the Prony Brake Test, operate the tool (moving the Gear Box, 
advancing the Drill Bit, rotating the Drill Bit and retracting the Gear Box) while 
monitoring the amperage on the 2010 Power Supply. Repeat this operation until a steady 
0.5 to 0.6 amps are constant throughout the operation.  
In order to perform the torque test, a Prony Brake Fixture (P/N 162314000) is required. 
The fixture consists of: 
• 
Prony Brake Shoe with a six inch (152.4mm) lever 
• 
Tachometer 
• 
Force Gauge 
• 
Dummy Bit 
The force gauge measures the force applied to it by a lever assembly, consisting of two 
water-cooled jaws tightened around the PowerCOR bit and lever (movement arm). The 
force gauge is held to the PowerCOR instrument by a clamping assembly, and is 
positioned so that its actuator deforms the force gauge body when acted on by the lever 
assembly.  
The jaws of the lever assembly must be cooled during operation. Cooling capabilities are 
provided by grooves in the jaws, thus allowing water to pass over the jaws near the 
PowerCOR bit. Water is supplied via a barb fitting located at the top clamp; the final 
assembly should incorporate a valve allowing adjustment of water flow.  
 
 
NEVER PERFORM THE TORQUE TEST WITHOUT USING THE 
COOLING FEATURES. 
 
The force gauge measurements (expressed in lbs.) are entered on the test form in the LBS 
column and then multiplied by 6” (152.4mm) (the distance between the force gauge 
actuator and the bit axis when the assembly is properly installed). This result in a torque 
value expressed in lbs/in and entered on the form in the TRO column. This is used with 
the RPM readings from the tachometer to derive a horsepower value from the following 
formula: 
 
Horsepower (HP) ~ = {RPM ~ Times (lb/inch)}  
 
63024 
 
The result of this equation is entered on the form in the HP Out Column. The following 
values are also recorded: 
• 
Set DV Voltage to 750 VDC.  
• 
Surface Motor V (SMV) is the voltage as indicated on the surface panel display. 
• 
Surface Motor 1 (SMI) is the total current sent down the line and is indicated on the surface 
panel display. 
• 
Select Apply. 
• 
Turn on Cooling Pump 
• 
Clamp Prony Brake to 10 lbs. 
• 
Record Bit RPM 
• 
Record current from 2010 Power Supply. (Current is used as a reference to tool efficiency.)  
 
 
56 
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A 
A. TEST SETUP 
1. With the PowerCOR tool on stands, run the tool and place the Bit Box in the Coring position. 
Extend the Bit out to 0.5” (12.7mm) travel (from the face of the tool) and the Bit Box gears 
engage the Transmission gears. 
2. Remove the Coring Bit from the Bit Box and install the Dummy Bit.  
3. Install the Clamp Assembly Fixture [1] with the Force Gauge, as shown below. 
4. Install the Torque Level Fixture [2] onto the Dummy Bit, as shown below. (The bit rotates 
counter-clockwise.) Slightly tighten clamps to hold fixture in place.  
5. Position the contact point of the Force Gauge so it aligns with the Scribe Mark on the Lever of 
the Torque Level Fixture (6” (152.4mm) from the center of the Rotary Pipe). 
6. Install a small piece of reflective tape onto the Dummy Bit.  
7. Place a container with water under the Bit Box area. Using a small sump pump, attach the 
pressure hose to the Torque Level Fixture.  
 
 
AN ADEQUATE FLOW OF WATER MUST BE MAINTAINED DURING 
THE TEST TO PREVENT OVERHEATING OF THE BIT AND BRAKE 
PADS.  
 
B. TEST PROCEDURE 
1. Start the cooling water supply and then start the rotation of the Bit with zero load (Jaws not 
tightened).  
2. Position the Tachometer [4] so it can read the reflective tape on the Dummy Bit, and read the 
RPM.  
3. Record the data (RPM, Torque, Force, etc.) on the test sheet.  
4. Tighten the spring tension adjusting nuts until the Force Gauge read 1 lb (6 lb/in torque).  
5. Record the data (RPM, Torque, Force, etc.) on the test sheet.  
6. Repeat the previous step, increasing the reading on the Force Gauge by one pound each time and 
recording the data, ending at 15 lbs on the Force Gauge. 
 
Note: 
Toward the high end of the torque curve, it may be necessary to increase the flow of water, 
and to average the readings on the Force Gauge since at this point it may bounce around a 
mean value. 
Note: If stalling occurs, loosen and re-tighten the spring compression adjusting nuts to the desired 
force value. 
 
7. At the end of the test, remove Clamp Assembly Fixture, Torque Level Fixture and Dummy Bit. 
8. Reinstall the Coring Bit and rotate Bit Box back into tool.  
 
 
 
57 
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
1826 PowerCOR 
 
 
P/N 131113-955 / 1826 PowerCOR 
REV A

1826 MA PowerCOR Preventive Maintenance Level 3 Procedure 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Electricity (Shock Hazard).  High Voltages are present 
during this test.  Always have a second person present 
ready to shut off power. 
Possible death or serious injury. 
Be careful working with exposed energized electric circuits. 
 
 
 
NOTICE 
RISK OF DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT. 
ESD may damage sensitive electronics components.  
Static guard wristbands shall be worn and connected to 
ground through a 1 megohm resistor by personnel 
when handling electronic circuit assemblies. 
 
 
 
 
This equipment is intended to be operated and maintained only by 
personnel who have received the proper training regarding Baker 
Hughes Wireline Services technology and services.  
This equipment may present hazards which are not obvious to untrained 
personnel. Attempts to operate or maintain this equipment by untrained 
personnel may result in injury or damage to equipment or result in lost time 
or damage to customer equipment and property.

Note: 
Safety Requirements: 
Personal Protective Equipment appropriate to work being performed; in all cases safety 
glasses and safety toe shoes or caps shall be worn. 
Note: 
Use this procedure with Checklist number 131113-953-CHKL. This procedure is designed to 
go step by step along with 131113-953-CHKL. In other words, step 1 in section 4 of this 
procedure is the same as step 1 in section 4 of 131113-953-CHKL. 
Note: 
It is expected that all work performed will conform to the instructions herein and to the 
procedures enumerated in the Workmanship Standards Document N80807. 
Note: 
Records of inspection, maintenance, refurbishment, modifications and repairs shall be 
maintained in SAP ZARM2. 
Note: 
Nonconforming material shall be controlled to prevent its unintended use. 
Note: 
Visual inspection shall be performed, unaided by equipment, at a distance less than 36 
inches. 
Note: 
The Digital MultiMeter used for the electrical checks shall be calibrated annually.   
Note: 
Test system may be a 4503 X*, 4505 X*, 4509 X* or an ECLIPS Test system or equivalent.

1826 MA PowerCOR Preventive Maintenance Level 3 Procedure 
 
 
1. 
Preparation 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Verify that equipment serial number in the ZARM matches the number on the instrument. If the 
numbers on the instrument are difficult to read, they will be remarked later.  
2. 
With thread protectors in place, thoroughly clean housing.  Preparations include washing the tool 
to remove, mud, grease, dirt and other foreign material.  
For instruments with piston type pressure compensator;  
Wash the piston area; visually inspect piston area for oil leakage. If oil leakage is found the fault 
shall be rectified before the Instrument can be placed in service.  
Air dry, Blow dry with compressed air or dry off the tool with clean rags or paper towels. Each 
step of the disassembly will include cleaning as required. 
2. 
Instrument History 
 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Verify the SAP tcode “ZARM” equipment number matches the Serial number on the tool. Record 
the amount of PM points on checklist 131113-953-CHKL. 
2. 
Use SAP tcode “ZEQFMN” to see FMNs / OTBs that have been done and need to be done. 
Ensure FMNs / OTBs are up to date; if they are not up to date you may perform the applicable 
FMNs / OTBs before this PM3 or concurrently with this PM3. 
3. 
Continuity and Resistance Tests 
Step 
Action 
1. 
It is advisable, though not required to test continuity and resistance with a 5722 X* “WEETECH” 
or digital multimeter prior to disassembly. The purpose is that this may reveal defects that can 
be investigated and repaired during the PM. Refer to Section 38 for values. 
 
 
NOTICE 
RISK OF DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT.  
Do NOT use a Megohmmeter on the strain gauge load cell 
wires or Temperature Probe wires. High Voltage will 
damage these components. Check these components using 
a Fluke Model 87 V digital multimeter or equivalent 
 
 
 
 
Page 6 of 43 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
 131113-953  Rev: A 
 
Effective Date: 4-Dec-2015 
1826 MA PowerCOR Preventive Maintenance Level 3 Procedure 
 
 
4. 
Visual and Physical Inspection 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Visually inspect the tool for any exterior damage. Remove thread protectors and visually inspect 
the field joint threads. 
5. 
General Information 
The procedures outlined in this section are the minimum to be performed on coring tools prior to 
an operation in a well. 
Locations that have implemented a stringent cleanliness policy with regard to coring tools 
maintenance have seen a significant reduction in reported problems and tool failures. Because 
of the complexity and economies involved, not performing a coring job can actually be more 
profitable than attempting to perform one without specially trained and properly equipped 
personnel working in the correct maintenance environment. In short - If you cannot do the job 
correctly you will actually save money by not doing it at all. 

Facilities 
A dedicated clean area Coring lab must be established. The maintenance facility should be of 
sufficient size to allow a complete tool to be worked on at any one time. In a remote location a 
20 foot air conditioned tool house can be used for the purpose. 

Personnel 
Personnel performing maintenance work on coring tools must have received appropriate 
training. A dedicated coring maintenance team has proved successful in all cases. 

General Maintenance Requirements 
The valves, solenoids and restrictors, etc… in the hydraulic circuit are not forgiving of 
contamination. There are two in-line filters at the inlet and outlet of the pump that will trap and 
contain small particles or debris and prevent them from travelling through and contaminating the 
entire hydraulic system. These filters cannot remove contamination introduced during the 
maintenance operation, hence the need for a clean environment. 
 
General recommendations: 
− 
 Only use "lint free" cloths 
− 
Use a filter system for cleaning hydraulic oil prior to filling a module or filling the test cart. A 
20 micron filter is acceptable. 
− 
Do not carry out coring tools maintenance work in or adjacent to, any area that is not clean 
(e.g., the workshop, steam clean area, buffing area, etc…). 
 
 
Page 7 of 43 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
 131113-953  Rev: A 
 
Effective Date: 4-Dec-2015 
1826 MA PowerCOR Preventive Maintenance Level 3 Procedure 
 
 
− 
Before using any air source to clean any electrical connector, make sure the air is dry and 
clean. Shop/lab air supplies should have water traps installed. If not, have them installed 
and properly maintain them. 
The two filters that protect the pump in the main hydraulic power supply module are sized 40 
micron and 70 micron. 
 
Particle size comparison 
A tool failure can be caused by a particle larger than 150 micron becoming lodged inside a 
check valve. 







6. 
Consumable Materials 
Consumable materials (typically Loctite, RTV, grease, etc.) are stocked on the production floor 
and used for multiple assembly jobs. They are typically listed on the BOM, but are not always 
supplied as part of the assembly kit since Production procures many of the items directly from 
an outside vendor. 
Grease used shall be free from dust, dirt, or any contamination which can cause seal failure. 
Check Lubriplate 930-AA grease Expiration date or manufacturing date. In the absence of an 
Expiration date, six years from date of manufacturing shall be used as the Expiration date.  
Grease past its Expiration date shall not be used.

7. 
Disassembly Procedures 
Refer to drawing A3001654000. and Wiring Diagram A3001654 WRD. 
During disassembly procedures cabling and connector should be left intact and not cut if at all 
possible. 
 
 
NOTICE 
RISK OF DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT.  
Do NOT use a Megohmmeter on the strain gauge load cell 
wires or Temperature Probe wires. High Voltage will 
damage these components. Check these components using 
a Fluke Model 87 V digital multimeter or equivalent.

8. 
Tool Preparation A3001654000 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Remove the front plate (item 22), bit cover door (item 20), and cover assembly (item 67). 
2. 
Rotate the tool so the right side plate (item 16) is facing up and remove it; this allows access to 
the right drive plate. Thoroughly clean inside of the tool and the drive plate area. Reinstall the 
right side plate and repeat the operation with the left side plate. (item 17) Reassemble. 
 
CAUTION 
 
DO NOT REMOVE BOTH PLATES AT THE SAME TIME. DOING SO 
CAN RESULT IN BENDING OF THE MANDREL; THIS CAN CAUSE 
SEVERE DAMAGE TO THE COMPONENTS. 
 
3. 
Remove core measuring lower cover (item 15); wet joint cover (item 57); upper lock arm manifold 
covers (items 59 & 60); quad cylinder manifold covers (items 41 & 42); center manifold covers 
(items 55 & 56); transmission mount covers (items 58, 61 & 62); lower right, left and top covers 
(items 63, 64, 65 & 66) at the dual cylinder manifold; and lower lock arm covers (items 52, 53 & 
54). 
4. 
Washing the tool to remove, mud, grease, dirt and other foreign material. Blow dry with 
compressed air or dry off the tool with clean rags or paper towels. Each step of the disassembly 
will include cleaning as required.

5. 
Perform Function Test.  Record on 131113-953-CHKL

9. 
Removal of the Cover and Side Plates 
Step 
Action 
1. 
If not already accomplished, remove core measuring lower cover (item 15); wet joint cover (item 
57); upper lock arm manifold covers (items 59 & 60); quad cylinder manifold covers (items 41 & 
42); center manifold covers (items 55 & 56); transmission mount covers (items 58, 61 & 62); 
lower right, left and top covers (items 63, 64, 65 & 66) at the dual cylinder manifold; and lower 
lock arm covers (items 52, 53 & 54). 
2. 
Remove left side plate (item 3) by removing the eight screws (item 6 in BOM A3001655000) 
 
10. Wire Tube Assembly Removal A3000979000 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Remove all atmospheric covers access to wire service. 
2. 
To remove the wire tube assembly (item 8), start at lower end of the dual cylinder manifold (item 
1) remove the lower fitting. 
3. 
Rotate the lower section of the tube counter 90 degrees clockwise and pull back slowly until the 
end connector is disengaged from the manifold (item 1). Very carefully, disconnect the 11-pin 
contact blocks. If replacement of the wire tube without any further disassembly is desired, do not 
pull from the wires; this would cause the harness to disengage from the pressure bulkhead 
recessed deep inside the manifold. 
4. 
Center tee fitting removal. 
5. 
Move towards the top of the tool, to the center manifold (item 3) and locate the wire tube tee 
connector. Remove the wire way plug (item 2, drawing A3001657000) on the bottom side of the 
center manifold. Detach the connectors J8 & J2 (items 4 and 12, drawing A3000979000) and 
slowly pry the wire tube tee fitting out while feeding the wires and the connectors through the 
wire way (very carefully to prevent nicking or stripping the wires). 
6. 
Upper 45 degrees fitting removal. 
 
 
Page 10 of 43 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential

1826 MA PowerCOR Preventive Maintenance Level 3 Procedure 
 
 
Step 
Action 
7. 
Move to the top of the tool, at the bottom of the wet joint (item 6). Very carefully, pry the 45 
degrees fitting out and pull the 15-pin contact (P1 of drawing A3000979000) block through the 
hole. Avoid nicking or stripping the wires. Disconnect and remove the wire tube assembly. 
11. DC Wire tube removal A3001187000 
Step 
Action 
1. 
At the center manifold (item 3) opposite side of the tool disconnect J22 6 pin Lemo. 
2. 
Gently pry up on the 90 degree connector until the o-ring is disengaged. 
3. 
At the top of the tool at the wet joint (item 6) side entry 45 degree fitting pry back to expose the 
P21 6 pin Lemo, disconnect and remove the wire tube from the tool assembly. 
12. Bit Box Removal, A3001369000 
Step 
Action 
1. 
At the center section of the mandrel, where the bit box section is exposed, locate and remove the 
retaining ring (item 94) from the left side tilt arm bracket and disengage the left tilt arm link (item 
23). Swing the tilt arm bracket out and replace the left side plate (item 3) onto the mandrel. 
Temporarily secure the plate with two screws (item 6 of BOM  A3001654000). 
2. 
Rotate the tool 180°, remove the right side plate (item 16) and remove the retaining ring (item 94) 
from the right tilt arm bracket. Disengage the right tilt arm link (item 24). 
3. 
Remove the cover (item 15) by removing the two holding screws (item 92). 
4. 
Remove the bit box assembly by lifting the drive right plate (item 29) up slightly and pulling the bit 
box up until the bit box drive pins and rollers are out of the guides of the drive plates. To avoid 
bending the tilt linkages, do not force the drive plate. Once disengaged, pull the bit box assembly 
out through the bit side or the top of the mandrel.

Step 
Action 
1. 
Lower lock arm housing assembly removal F164526000-A3001654000.  Remove bull plug (item 
27) from the bottom of the mandrel. 
2. 
Remove screw (item 93) retaining the core tube assembly (item 38) and remove core tube. 
3. 
Completely loosen the fittings of the lower lock arm cylinder feed lines; union fitting (item 123) in 
the close arm line and the T- fitting (item C-3 View D) for the open arm line which runs to the 
bulkhead assembly manifold (item 4 of F164526000).Remove Spring clip Item [19] from pistons 
[12] slip off Knife [18]. 
4. 
Using a drift punch drive out pin (item 9, drawing F164526000) at the appropriate thru hole 
located on the lower lock arm housing (item 1 -drawing F164526000). 
5. 
Remove the arm housing pin (item 11- drawing F164526000) in the same manner and lift the 
locking arm assembly out of the lower lock arm housing. 
6. 
Remove the two screws (item 14) which secures the wire tube fitting (item 8). 
7. 
Remove the four screws (item 14, drawing F164526000) which secure the bulkhead assembly 
(item 4, drawing F164526000). 
8. 
Loosen the nut of the run tee fitting of the open arm feed line at the back of (item 4, drawing 
F164526000). Carefully lift the bulkhead assembly up off the lower lock arm housing far enough 
to disengage the wire tube fitting (item 39 @A4 of a3001654000) from the underside of the 
bulkhead assembly F163681000. Remove the pressure plug (item 10, drawing F163681000). 
Carefully pull the wiring out through the cavity and disconnect the 6-pin Lemo connector (item 3). 
Hold the bulkhead connector (item 2, drawing F163681000) firmly, and with a crescent wrench 
unthread the connector bulkhead (item 2 - drawing F163681000). Disconnect the female contact 
block (item 5, J19, drawing F163681000) from the six pin bulkhead connector (item 4, drawing 
F163681000). 
9. 
Remove the six screws (item 15, drawing F164526000) which secure the two guide plates (item 
7-drawing F164526000), and remove the plates 
10. 
Remove the two cap screws (item 17&18, drawing F164526000) which secure the lock arm 
assembly to the lower lock arm housing. Remove the two cap screws (item 14, drawing 
F164526000) that secure the lower cap cylinder plug (item 8, drawing F164526000). Using the 
10/32 thread "T" handle puller ( BOM 130586-845), carefully pull the lower cap cylinder plug 
(item 8) off of the lower cap cylinder adapter (item 9 - drawing F163632000) and disconnect the 
11-pin contact block (item 17). Slide the lower cap cylinder plug out through the slot on the lower 
end of the lock arm housing.

15. Separating the Manifolds 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Start with the lower half of the mandrel. Locate the core measurement housing assembly (item 
14) and remove its four retaining screws (item 83). 
2. 
At the bottom of the feed-thru manifold remove the two screws (item 83) retaining the feed thru 
plug (item 43). Raise the core measuring housing (item 14) out of the transition manifold, and pry 
the feed thru plug (item 43) out of the manifold. While holding the assembly, disconnect the 6-pin 
contact block (item 110- J16) and remove the entire core measurement assembly, including the 
equalizer cylinder. Oil will drip off the assembly. 
3. 
Locate and remove the left and right drive plates (items 29 and 30), by loosening the jam nuts 
(item 89) and completely unscrewing the two bit advance adjusting rods (item 31) from the plates 
(items 29 and 30). 
4. 
Remove the two adjusting rods (item 31) from the advance/retract cylinder rods (items 2 and 13, 
drawing F164533000). 
5. 
Remove the drive plate rod bracket (item 33) from the cylinder rods by locating and removing the 
two threaded pins (items 32). 
6. 
Detach the transition manifold (item 2 of A3001655000) from the dual cylinder manifold (item 1) 
by removing all four bolts (item 40) (sheet 1). 
7. 
Unscrew the tilt arm right and left links (items 23 and 24) from both of the tilt arm pull rods (item 
18). 
8. 
Transmission removal. Locate and remove four screws (item 82) and two screws (item 18 of 
A3001657000) retaining the transmission bulkhead housing assembly. Gently pull item 18 out of 
the transmission assembly, disconnect the 17 pin connector from the bulkhead (item 9). The 
transmission can now be removed. 
9. 
The transmission mount manifold (item 1 of A3001655000) can be detached from the center 
manifold (item 3 of A3001654000) by removing the four holding bolts (item 40) and by then 
sliding it straight out over the two tilt arm pull rods (item 18). 
10. 
Remove the four bolts (item 40) attaching the center manifold (item 3) to the guide housing (item 
11). Remove the center manifold by sliding it straight out over the two tilt arm rods. Be careful not 
to bend any of the pull rods.

11. 
Remove the two tilt rod clamps (item 35) from the left and right sides of the guide housing. 
Locate and remove the four bolts (item 40) securing the guide housing (item 11) to the quad 
cylinder manifold (item 4). Separate these manifolds and remove spacer (item 131) from the 
guide housing. Then remove stabilizer (item 46) from the upper lock arm piston. 
12. 
Quad cylinder coupling assembly removal. 
13.

disengage the thread, record this number on a notebook for 
later use when reassembling and adjusting the rods. 
 
Remove two threaded pins (item 16, drawing F181836000) from the tilt arm coupling (item 14, 
drawing F181836000). Remove the coupling (item 14) from the bit box tilt piston rods (items 11 
&19, drawing F181836000) by pulling it straight off. 
15. 
Remove flex lock nuts (item 125,of  A3001654000) with a back-up wrench on the hex of the pull 
rods (item 37). Separate the quad cylinder manifold (item 4) from the upper lock arm manifold 
(item 10) by removing the four bolts (item 40) and sliding the quad manifold off over the pull rods 
(item 37). Collect the belleville spring washers (item 124) as the manifold is removed. Once 
these manifolds have been parted, the two 6-pin connectors can be unplugged from the linear

16. 
Remove the two stops (item 128) from the upper lock arm manifold (item 10) by removing four 
flat head screws (item 129). Remove set screws (item 130) from each side and then unscrew pull
