17. 
Separate the upper lock manifold (item 10) from the wet joint (item 6) by removing all four of the 
bolts (item 40) attaching them together. Once parted, disconnect the two connector blocks (J-10 
and J-12) (item 9, drawing F181835000) from the pressure bulkheads in the wet tool joint. 
16. Dual Cylinder Manifold Drawing A3002075000 & 
A3002594000 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Place this assembly in a vice or suitable tie down fixture, loosen and remove the four bolts (item 
40) from the lower feed-thru manifold from (item 1) Dual cylinder manifold. Support the feed-thru 
manifold with one hand, and pull straight back away from the dual cylinder manifold to pull them

piston (item 9) out through the same hole.

Step 
Action

24. Wet Tool Joint Sub Drawing A3001658000 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Install screw (item 58) and standoff (item 17). Place a screwdriver between bulkhead (item 9) 
and body of wet tool joint (item 1) and pry out the bulkhead. 
2. 
Grasp and pull bulkhead connector (item 19) and separate from bulkhead. 
3. 
To Install wire bundle, start by removing both 5-pin bulkheads (item 16) using puller adaptor P/N 
A1005325000. Once the bulkhead is out the contact block (item 30 2x) can be unplugged. If the 
wire harness is to be installed the wires must be repaired at the contact block of "J9" and "J10", 
because the contact block will not pass through the manifold cavities on the 1826 MA. The 
remaining 15-pin contact block and 6 pin Lemo (item 11 and 7) will pass through their cavity into 
the wet tool joint. The entire bundle can then be installed through the upper end of the wet tool 
joint. 
4. 
The six fittings (item 16) can be installed by screwing the screws (item 56) and with pliers 
pushing down on each fitting. The two transmission compensating fittings (item 2) are installed in 
the same manner except that they should push in at a 45° angle.

26. Quad Cylinder Manifold Drawing F181836000 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Place the manifold in a vice. 
2. 
Install tilt arm piston (dummy) (item 19) by pushing the piston in and out through the back of the 
manifold, plug (item 13) will go in with piston. 
3. 
Push tilt arm hydraulic plug (item 5) straight in using a 1/4 - 20 tee handle.

Install tilt arm plug (item 26) by pushing the piston rod (item 11) in and out through the back

Install piston (item 11), linear transducer (item 12), and resistor plug (item 26) together by 
pushing piston rod in and out through the plug cavity. 
6. 
Install Yoke (item 16) from piston (item 2) by installing screw (item 17). 
7. 
Repeat above procedure for installation of lock arm piston. Piston (item 2), the transducer (item 
6) and plug (item 4) will go in as one. 
8. 
To install the linear transducers of either cylinder install the retaining rings (item 36) from bottom 
of cylinders and top of resistor plugs. Push 11-pin contact blocks (item 8) from holders (item 9). 
Contact block (item 8) can now be connected by installing screw (item 41). If transducer 
replacement required, wires must be cut off and new contact sockets installed. 
9. 
To install the wipers (item 34 ) and the t-seals (item 22) a sharp soft metal pick is required.

A3002594000 
Step 
Action 
1.

it mounts the piston spacer (item 12) from the bottom of the manifold. Then pull the piston (item 
9) in through the same hole.

A3002594000, Locate the sensor piston (item 1). Pull the piston rod until the piston, the retainer 
plug (J6), the contact block and the linear transducer (item 5) will go in together. Use care not to 
dislodge the O-ring (item 11) of the retainer plug (J6) while bumping the cylinder rod with a soft 
blunt object. 
4. 
Install the transducer from the cylinder rod by installing the retaining ring (item 4) from the bottom 
of the cylinder rod (item 1). In the event the transducer is to be replaced, remove the retaining 
ring (item 4) in the top of the retainer plug (item 9) and the set screw (item 10) located at the 
bottom of the retainer plug. This will allow the connector block (items 6-8) to be disassembled 
and expose the three sockets (item 7). These are crimp connections and must be cut off to 
remove the contact block (items 6-8). 
5. 
To install the wire bundle (item 5 of A300207500), grasp the 11-pin contact block (P5) and gently 
push until the contact block (J13) is connected from the 6-pin bulkhead (item 6). 
6. 
Install the 6-pin bulkhead (item 6) by inserting extraction tool (P/N F164506000) through the 
uphole opening where the wire bundle (item 5) was removed.. 
7. 
Install insert feed through assembly (item 13), by inserting extraction tool (P/N F164506000) 
through the bottom of the feed-thru manifold and knocking with a mallet, the entire assembly will 
install intact.

30. Connecting the Manifolds 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Start with the lower half of the mandrel. Locate the core measurement housing assembly (item 
14) and reinstall its four retaining screws (item 83). 
2. 
At the bottom of the feed-thru manifold install the two screws (item 83) retaining the feed thru 
plug (item 43). Lower the core measuring housing (item 14) into the transition manifold, and push 
the feed thru plug (item 43) into the manifold. While holding the assembly, connect the 6-pin 
contact block (item 110- J16) and install the entire core measurement assembly, including the 
equalizer cylinder. Oil will drip off the assembly. 
3. 
Locate and install the left and right drive plates (items 29 and 30), by tightening the jam nuts 
(item 89) and completely tighten the two bit advance adjusting rods (item 31) from the plates 
(items 29 and 30). 
4. 
Install the two adjusting rods (item 31) to the advance/retract cylinder rods (items 2 and 13, 
drawing F164533000). 
5. 
Install the drive plate rod bracket (item 33) to the cylinder rods by locating and installing the two 
threaded pins (items 32). Set 3-1/4" between the end of Drive Plate to end of Piston Rod. Use 
Loctite 
6. 
Attach the transition manifold (item 2 of A3001655000) to the dual cylinder manifold (item 1) by 
installing all four bolts (item 40) (sheet 1) use anti-seize compound and torque to 48 ft.lbs. (65 N 
m). 
7. 
Screw the tilt arm right and left links (items 23 and 24) to both of the tilt arm pull rods (item 18). 
8. 
Transmission installation. Locate and install four screws (item 82) and two screws (item 18 of 
A3001657000) retaining the transmission bulkhead housing assembly. Gently push item 18 onto 
the transmission assembly, connect the 17 pin connector to the bulkhead (item 9).  
9. 
The transmission mount manifold (item 1 of A3001655000) can be attached from the center 
manifold (item 3 of A3001654000) by installing the four holding bolts (item 40) and by then sliding 
it straight in over the two tilt arm pull rods (item 18). 
10. 
Install the four bolts (item 40) attaching the center manifold (item 3) to the guide housing (item 
11).Install the center manifold by sliding it straight in over the two tilt arm rods. Be careful not to 
bend any of the pull rods. 
11. 
Install the two tilt rod clamps (item 35) from the left and right sides of the guide housing. Locate 
and install the four bolts (item 40) securing the guide housing (item 11) to the quad cylinder 
manifold (item 4). Connect these manifolds and install spacer (item 131) from the guide housing. 
Then install stabilizer (item 46) from the upper lock arm piston. 
12. 
Quad cylinder coupling assembly Installation. 
13. 
Screw both tilt arms pull rods (item 18) to the tilt arm coupling (item 14, drawing F181836000). 
Set 3-1/2" between The tilt Arm Link the shoulder of the Transmission manifold. Use Loctite.

Install the bit box assembly by lifting the drive right plate (item 29) up slightly and pushing the bit 
box up until the bit box drive pins and rollers are in the guides of the drive plates. To avoid 
bending the linkages, do not force the drive plate. Once engaged, push the bit box assembly in 
through the bit side or the top of the mandrel. 
4. 
Install the cover plate (item 15) by securing with the two holding screws (item 92).

Step 
Action 
1. 
At the center manifold (item 3) opposite side of the tool connect J22 6 pin Lemo. 
2. 
Gently push down on the 90 degree connector until the O-ring is engaged. 
3. 
At the top of the tool at the wet joint (item 6) side entry 45 degree fitting pry back to expose the 
P21 6 pin Lemo, connect and install the wire tube from the tool assembly. 
35. Wire Tube Assembly Installation A3000979000 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Install the wire tube assembly (item 8), start at lower end of the dual cylinder manifold (item 1) 
install the lower fitting. 
2. 
Rotate the lower section of the tube counter 90 degrees clockwise and push slowly until the end 
connector is engaged from the manifold (item 1). Very carefully, connect the 11-pin contact 
blocks.  
3. 
Center tee fitting installation. 
4. 
Move towards the top of the tool, to the center manifold (item 3) and locate the wire tube tee 
connector. Install the wire way plug (item 2, drawing A3001657000) on the bottom side of the 
center manifold. Attach the connectors J8 & J2 (items 4 and 12, drawing A3000979000) and 
slowly insert the wire tube tee fitting in while feeding the wires and the connectors through the 
wire way (very carefully to prevent nicking or stripping the wires). 
5. 
Upper 45 degrees fitting installation. 
6. 
Move to the top of the tool, at the bottom of the wet joint (item 6). Very carefully, install the 45 
degrees fitting into and push the 15-pin contact (P1 of drawing A3000979000) block through the 
hole. Avoid nicking or stripping the wires. Connect and install the wire tube assembly.

Step 
Action

Transmission Oil Fill 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Place the transmission assembly into the MB Section and connect the tubing. 
2. 
Connect the 1/8” (3.1mm) Compensation Tubes to the Top Joint Fittings. 
3. 
Remove the plug and screw in one oil fill and bleed fitting, [3 - Lab Kit 130586-845]. 
4. 
Attach the pump return hose to the fitting. Elevate the bottom of the MB, if possible. 
5. 
Remove the seal screw from the motor housing and screw in on the swivel fitting, (F132989000). 
Attach the pump output pressure hose to the fitting. 
6. 
Turn on the pump and begin circulating until oil flows through the return line. 
7. 
Purge the 1/8” (3.1mm) Compensation Tube by pressing in on each Staubli [5], opening the 
valve with a 1/8” (3.1mm) brass drift Punch or Allen Wrench. 
8. 
Oil and air will flow out of the Staubli. Periodically close the Staubli and reopen until clear fluid is 
coming out. 
9. 
With the pump circulating, start the vacuum pump. Evacuate the system until the gauge reaches 
10 to 15 inches of vacuum. Stop the vacuum pump, and hold the vacuum for fifteen minutes 
while continuing to circulate. 
10. 
Stop the circulation and start the vacuum pump again. Continue the evacuation for 30 minutes, 
and then start the circulation pump. Repeat this procedure as required until no air is present in 
the return line. Drop the vacuum to 0 and circulate for 5 minutes.

Step 
Action 
11. 
Stop the pump and remove the swivel fitting from the motor housing and replace the seal screw. 
(Allow 1 to 2 minutes for return fluid to diminish.) 
12. 
Remove the oil feed and bleed fitting from the gear box. 
13. 
Replace the plug. 
14. 
Position the Bit Box Cover [20] over the Bit Box. Make sure the Pins [21] of the cover slides into 
the Tilt Arm Bracket. 
15. 
 
Note 
The Bit Box [5], Bit Box Door [22] and Bit Box Cover [20] 
need to be removed when the tool is going to vacuum and 
filled with hydraulic oil. 
 
Install the Bit Box Door [22] over the Bit Box assembly and secure (not tight) in place by installing 
4 Screws [71]. 

Hydraulic Fluid Filling 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Prepare the Mandrel per the RCOR System Checkout Setup; refer to the operating manual for 
additional information. 
2. 
Lock Arm Circuits: Position the mandrel on stands with the bit opening facing up and elevate the 
Field Joint so that the Mandrel is inclined approximately 10 degrees. 
3. 
Open the Upper Lock Arm ports [112] on the Upper Lock Arm Manifold. 
4. 
Open the Lower Lock Arm supply fitting at the lower end of the mandrel, and the Union fitting 
located on the Rod Down-close arm line. Locations B2 and B4 on sheet two, respectively. 
5. 
Select (low pressure] and power up motors; when oil appears at the Upper Arm Manifold ports, 
turn motors off. Replace the Plugs [112] partially to allow oil flow through the threads. Do not seat 
the O-rings. 
6. 
Start the motor again at low pressure. Oil should begin to flow slightly through the ports at the 
Upper Lock Arm Manifold and at the Lower Arm Cylinder ports (open and close). 
7. 
 
Note 
Rod Up must be "On" during this procedure to allow the flow 
of oil from the arm close circuit to the tank or to the open 
arm close fitting in the Lower Lock Arm assembly. 
 
Once the oil flows steadily through the slightly open ports, select Arms Close. Arms will start to 
close. Observe if air bubbles escape through either Lock Arm Cylinders ports or fittings. 
8. 
Cycle the tool (Arms Open - arms Close] several times until no more air is observed coming out 
of the ports. Tighten plugs and fittings. 
9. 
Deploy the arms again (Arm Open), with all ports closed, at Max Press. 
10. 
Once the motion of the arms has stop at the fully open position, toggle Rod Up off , and allow the 
auxiliary pressure to inflate the accumulator and build up to its maximum value.

Step 
Action 
11. 
Let pressure stabilize at its peak for about 10 seconds, and then select Aux Pressure Low. If the 
pressure in the arm circuit does not hold, when observed with a gauge installed at the wet joint 
port, or the peak value drops to a lesser setting, air may still be present in the circuits. 
12. 
Repeat the bleeding procedure if necessary until all the air is evacuated from the system. 
13. 
Select (maximum pressure) and power up motors. When pressure peaks, select and observe 
gauge pressure. An initial drop in pressure may be seen and then it should remain steady 
between 2500 and 2100 PSI. If the pressure falls off, air is present in the system, and the 
procedure above should be repeated. 
14. 
Push Rod Circuit: While the Wet Joint is still elevated, position the mandrel so the bit side is 
facing up. 
15. 
Power up the tool and lock the arms open at Max pressure, and then toggle to Low Press. The 
Rod Up and Rod Down bleed plugs [100] are located, on the bit side, at the Center Manifold [3]. 
16. 
 
Note 
The port closest to the downhole end, on the left side of the 
tool when looking down from the top sub with the bit facing 
up, is the Rod Down bleeding port. 
 
Loosen both plugs, and then select Rod Down. Air will begin to escape through the ports. 
17. 
Wait for about 20 seconds and select Rod Up. Air will escape through the ports. Tighten both 
ports. 
18. 
With the rod at any position, open the Rod Up port partially, then actuate Rod Down. 
19. 
Once the rod has completed its stroke down, and no more air is observed coming out of the port, 
tighten the plug then turn Rod Down off. 
20. 
Partially open the Rod Down port, and then actuate Rod Up. Observe oil and air coming through 
the bleeding port. 
21. 
Once the rod has completed its stroke up, tighten the plug. 
22. 
Repeat these steps alternating ports until all the air has been evacuated from the system. 
23. 
Box to Core (BXC] and Box to Eject (BXE] Circuit: Maintain the mandrel with the bit opening 
facing up and the top sub still elevated. 
24. 
Start the motor and open the lock arms at maximum pressure; once the arms are open, toggle 
auxiliary pressure Low Press. 
25. 
The Box Core and Box Eject bleed plugs [100] are located, on the bit side, at the Upper Arm 
Manifold [10]. They are side-by-side, close to the downhole end of the manifold. 
26. 
 
Note 
The port on the left side of the tool, when looking down from 
the top sub with the bit facing up, corresponds to the Box 
Eject circuit. 
 
The same procedure used previously to bleed the push rod circuits applies for this section. 
Loosen both bleeding plugs, and then select Box Core. Air will escape through the ports. 
27. 
Wait for about 20 seconds and select Box Eject. Air will escape through the ports.

Step 
Action 
28. 
Tighten both ports. 
29. 
With the box at the coring position, open the Box Core port partially, and then actuate Box Eject. 
30. 
Once the box has completed its stroke and no more air is observed coming out of the port, 
tighten the plug then turn Box Eject off. 
31. 
Partially open the Box Eject port, and then actuate Box Core. Observe oil and air coming through 
the bleeding port. 
32. 
Once the box has completed its stroke, tighten the plug. 
33. 
Repeat these steps alternating ports until all the air has been evacuated from the system. 
34. 
Advance and Retract Circuits: Position the mandrel with the bit opening facing up and elevate 
the down hole end of the mandrel approximately 10 degrees. The advance and retract ports [112] 
are on the Dual Cylinder Manifold. 
35. 
Locations B2 and B3 on sheet three. 
36. 
Turn on Motors. Loosen both ports, then alternately toggle on and off advance and retract to 
clear the external lines of air. Then continue to toggle on and off; some Drive Plate [29] and [30] 
motion should occur. Turn off Motors. 
37. 
With the Bit Box in the retract position, install and tighten the Upper Port Plug for the Bit Advance 
circuit, and remove the Lower Port Plug for the Bit Retract circuit. 
38. 
Turn on Motors and toggle on, Bit Advance. When the stroke is complete, toggle off and install 
and tighten the Retract Port Plug and remove the Bit Advance Port Plug. Toggle on, Bit Retract. 
39. 
When the stroke is complete, toggle off and install and tighten the Upper Port Plug. Repeat this 
procedure until no air comes from the open ports. 
40. 
When finished, retract the bit using and return the Bit Box to the eject position using. 
41. 
 
Note 
The holding pressure can be confirmed by installing 
pressure gauges on the hydraulic section field joint at the Bit 
Advance and Bit Retract Ports. In all cases, smooth cylinder 
operation should be obtained; a jerking motion or hesitation 
is a sign of air in the system. The inability to hold low 
pressure on an energized circuit indicates air in the system. 
 
Bit Drive Motor Circuit: Position the mandrel horizontal (no elevation) with the bit opening facing 
down. For reference, the Bit Drive Motor is inside the Transmission assembly [7]. 
42. 
Core Measurement Box Assembly: This circuit consists of the Core Measurement Box [14], the 
Compensation Tube [50], the Feed-thru Plug [43], and the interconnecting Tubing. The oil 
circulation ports are located as follows: the in port is located on the Feed-thru Manifold on the left 
side of tool when looking down from the top sub with the bit facing up. The out port is located on 
the Core Measurement Housing [40], under the right side plate of the mandrel. 
43. 
The mandrel should be in a horizontal position with the bit opening at 9 o'clock as observed from 
the uphole end of the mandrel. Remove the right side plate (plate facing up), to expose the 
Circulate Out Plug on the Core Measurement Box.

44. 
Remove this plug and install a modified #3 SAE fitting [116]. 
45. 
Connect the "from tool" pump cart line to the modified fitting. 
46. 
Remove the plug [100] at the in port, install a modified #3 SAE fitting [116] and connect the "to 
tool" pump cart line. 
47. 
Elevate the field joint end of the mandrel slightly. Start the pump and begin circulating hydraulic 
fluid at 20 PSI for 15 to 20 minutes. 
48. 
Start the vacuum pump, close the "to tool" valve, and stop the circulation pump. Now let the

49. 
Turn the vacuum pump off and start the circulation pump. Then open the "to tool" valve and open 
the vacuum to atmosphere; continue to circulate at 20 PSI for 20 minutes. 
50. 
 
Note 
Do not use pump pressure to move the Piston; the O-ring on 
the Core Measurement Box lid will not seal internal pressure 
above 20 PSI. 
 
Insert the Tee Handle [115] through Cap [52] located at B8 on sheet one, and then thread the 
handle into the Compensation Piston [51]. Pull the Piston all the way to the downhole end of its 
stroke, then push the Piston all the way to the uphole end. A surge of oil can be observed at the 
"from tool" side of the circulation hose. Repeat this procedure to confirm no escaping air is 
visible. Now restore the Piston to the full downhole position. 
51. 
Stop the circulation pump, close the valve and remove the "from tool" circulation line. 
52. 
Remove the #3 SAE fitting [116] and replace the #3 SAE plug [100]. Replace the Side Plate and 
rotate the mandrel 180 degrees clockwise. The "to tool" circulation hose should be facing up. 
53. 
Close the line valve and remove the #3 SAE modified fitting [116]. Now thread the Tee Handle 
into the Piston and then move the Compensation Piston inward until the "MA" mark is aligned 
with the end of Cap [52]. Oil will surge from the Connector Cover [48]. 
54. 
Replace the #3 SAE plug and unscrew the Tee Handle.

38. Continuity and Resistance Tests 
It is advisable, to test continuity and resistance with a 5722 X* “WEETECH” or digital multi-meter 
prior to disassembly. The purpose is that this may reveal defects that can be investigated and 
repaired during the PM. 
 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Use an ohmmeter to confirm that pin 17 of the 40-pin connector is connected directly to the MA 
chassis (less than 1 ohm). 
2. 
Ohm between pins 2 & 9, 9 & 12, and 2 &12. Each of these readings should be 6.5–7.5 Ω. 
3. 
Ohm between pins 20 & 21 and 22 & 23. Each reading should be 19–22 Ω. 
4. 
Ohm between pins 31 & 32. The reading should be 13–15 Ω. 
5. 
Ohm every pin on the connector individually to pin 17.  All pins should be open to the chassis. If 
you are using a break-out box on the MA 40-pin, do not connect the other side of the box to PA 
for these measurements. 
6. 
Ohm between pins 29 & 25. The reading should be open. 
7. 
Meg pins 2, 9, and 12, individually to pin 17 at 500 V. All pins should show OPEN (>1 GΩ) to the 
chassis. 
8. 
Meg pins 20, 21, 22, 23, 31, and 32 individually to pin 17 at 100 V. All pins should show OPEN 
(>1 GΩ) to the chassis. 
9. 
Meg pin 2 to each of pins 20, 21, 22, 23, 31, and 32 at 100 V. All should show >1 GΩ. 
10. 
Meg pin 9 to each of pins 20, 21, 22, 23, 31, and 32 at 100 V. All should show >1 GΩ. 
11. 
Meg pin 12 to each of pins 20, 21, 22, 23, 31, and 32 at 100 V. All should show >1 GΩ. 
12. 
Meg pin 20 to each of pins 22 and 31 at 100 V. Both should show >1 GΩ. 
13. 
Meg pin 22 to pin 31 at 100 V. Should show >1 GΩ.

41. Tool Setup/Adjustment 
Refer to (FIG 1 on page 58 of 130586-955) The objective of the adjustments with the Bit Box [1] 
in the coring position is to provide proper meshing of the gears, solid retention of the Bit Box 
against the Stop Screws, items 2 and 3 (see drawing A3001654000).  Maintain the 
perpendicularity between the bit axis and the longitudinal axis of the mandrel, and at the same 
time locating the Bit Box Guide Pin [4] at the apex of the Drive Plate [5] in the advance/retract 
slot. In the Box Eject position it is necessary that the Bit Box be properly aligned with the Core 
Receiving Box, and that the axis through the center of the Bit Box is parallel to the center line of 
the mandrel. 
 
Step 
Action 
1. 
Position the mandrel horizontal with the bit opening oriented at 9 o'clock as viewed from the field 
joint end. 
2. 
Turn on motors and if the box is not in the eject position toggle, and then remove the side plate 
that is facing up. Adjust the tilt arm link distance [9] to 3-1/2” (88.9mm) between the lower end of 
the Tilt Arm Link [6] and the lower end of the Transmission Mount [11]. Record the exact 
measurement and then replace the side plate. 
3. 
Rotate the mandrel 180 degrees, then remove the Side Plate and again adjust the distance 
between the lower end of the Tilt Arm Link and the lower end of the Transmission Mount to the 
same measurement as recorded from the other side. 
4. 
Replace the Side Plate. 
5. 
Toggle, Box to Core, and check the degree of meshing between the Bit Drive Gears ([4] on 
DWG. A3001369000, and [6] on DWG. A3001275000). This can be done by turning the Pinion 
Gear back and forth by hand; a slight amount of play between the gears is desirable. 
 
 
Page 42 of 44 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
 131113-953  Rev: A 
 
Effective Date: 4-Dec-2015 
1826 MA PowerCOR Preventive Maintenance Level 3 Procedure 
 
 
Step 
Action 
6. 
If there is no play or if there is too much play, then toggle and adjust the Stop Screws [2] and [3], 
accordingly. Toggle and again check the gears. Repeat as necessary to obtain the proper 
clearance. Note that while adjusting the screws, make sure the axis of the Core Box [1] is 
perpendicular to the longitudinal axis of the mandrel. 
7. 
Remove the Side Plate facing up and toggle, Box to Core. Now observe the location of the Box 
Guide Pin [4] in relation to the Drive Plate advance/retract slot [12]. This Pin must be at the apex 
of the slot. To assure this, screw the Drive Plate Adjustment Rod [7] in or out; a slight resistance 
in the Adjustment Rod can be felt when the Guide Pin contacts the slots highest point. Now 
tighten the Adjustment Rod Jam Nut [8]. 
8.  
Replace the Side Plate, rotate the tool 180 degrees and remove the Side Plate facing up. Adjust 
this Drive Plate following the procedure above and tighten the Adjustment Rod Jam Nut [8]. 
9. 
With the Side Plate off, toggle, Box to Eject. The Bit Box should be aligned with Core Receiver 
Box, and the axis through the center of the Bit Box should be parallel to the longitudinal axis of 
the mandrel. If not, readjust the Tilt Arm Links at a new distance [9] to correct the Bit Box 
orientation; then readjust the Drive Plates. The distance [10] between the Tilt Arm Links and the 
top of the Drive Plates should be about 11/32" (8.7mm) to assure proper linkage operation. 
10. 
With both Side Plates installed, sequence between and several times to ensure all of the 
adjustment objectives have been met. 
11. 
Return the Box to the eject position, install 2 Clamps [35] and secure with 2 Screws [79].

43. Core Separator Magazine Installation 
Step 
Action 
1. 
See drawing A3002666000. Unscrew the plug cap [15] and pull the spring [13,14], stem [10], and 
spring guide [11] out as one unit. 
2. 
Load washers [9] (maximum of 60) into the housing [4]. 
3. 
Be sure the washers [9] are flat in the housing [4] and replace the plug assembly. 
4. 
Mount the Housing [4] A1000232000 to the manifold [1] and secure it with four screws [19]. 
5. 
Place the knife [31] onto pistons [23] and install one each locknut [30] on each piston (the knife is 
omni-directional and must have the leading edge of the blade engaged in the slot of the housing 
[4]).

1 
 LAB SAFETY 
 
1970 BB RCI PUMP/DRAWDOWN PVT 
 
 
 CONFIDENTIAL 
P/N 130634-954 
 MAY 2013 
GENERAL INSTRUMENT SAFETY 
 
This document outlines the safety concern for this particular section of the 1970 RCI 
tool. 
 
 
 
The GENERAL OPERATION MANUAL outlines the safety procedures for Well Site 
conditions and the GENERAL MAINTENANCE MANUAL outlines procedures for 
Lab conditions common for all the RCI subs. 
 
 
 
1. 
Read safety procedures for relieving trapped pressures in the GENERAL 
MAINTENANCE MANUAL before proceeding. 
 
 
CAUTION: Always assume that every section has pressure in it until you confirm 
otherwise.  This can cause personnel injury and should be handled very 
cautiously.  As a minimum wear safety glasses, full-face shield, heavy gloves and 
clear the area of unnecessary personnel. 
 
WARNING: Leaking or faulty Lee plugs must only be replaced with the appropriate size 
Lee plug. Any other form of plugging an access port is forbidden. If rework is necessary, 
contact local AMO management to verify the location of vendors qualified to rework Lee 
plugs. If no locally qualified vendor exists, the asset must be sent to a location that has a 
qualified vendor. 
 
 
WARNING: The 1970 BB instrument is extremely heavy and operates at high hydraulic 
pressures.  Use extreme caution when handling or performing maintenance on this 
section.  
 
 
 
2. 
Use the appropriate lifting devices and techniques to move the instrument. 
 
3. 
Corrosive, noxious and/or poisonous fluids may be recovered from the well.  A 
seal failure could also expose the hydraulic oil to these dangers. 
 
4. 
Always connect “Return Line” between tool and hydraulic test cart (both ends). 
 
5. 
The 1970 BB hydraulic system operates at pressures up to 3,500 PSI.  Use caution 
when testing, disassembling and /or repairing the hydraulic system, including all 
lines and pressure connectors. 
 
6. 
The 1970 BB utilizes Lee plugs to facilitate hydraulic/sample line plumbing.  
During functional and troubleshooting operations in this section, necessary steps 
should be taken to prevent personnel injury if a Lee plug fail and become a 
projectile The following minimum steps shall be implemented. 
 
a. 
Clear the area of unnecessary personnel. 
b. 
Minimize time standing next to the tool when function testing or 
toubleshooting. 

2 
 LAB SAFETY 
 
1970 BB RCI PUMP/DRAWDOWN PVT 
 
 
 CONFIDENTIAL 
P/N 130634-954 
 MAY 2013 
c. 
The sub should be covered to absorb the projectile. 
 
7. 
Make certain all power has been turned off while disassembling, assembling or 
otherwise performing maintenance. 
 
8. 
Oven heat treating of the assembled 1970 BB  is prohibited, as it may result in a 
damaged to the tool or property and injury to personnel due to high pressures 
generated by oil expansion within the tool.  Individual electronic chassis or CDE 
modules should only be tested outside the housing or subs; refer to the 
Repair/Maintenance section of this manual.

1 
 
LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 
1970 BB RCI PUMP/DRAWDOWN PVT 
 
P/N 130634-953 
MAY 2012 
 
NOTE 
 
 
Sockets P/N 161641-000 and P/N 152969-000 are used in 40 pin, 25 pin and 17 pin bulkhead 
connectors, and also use the 40 pin connector block P/N 155799-000.  These sockets must be tested 
for retention force as explained below.  Any found with low retention force must be replaced as 
per FMN 04-56. If the sockets in the 40 pin connector block P/N 155799-000 have a low retention 
force, the entire block must be replaced; the block is not repairable. 
 
RETENTION FORCE TEST: 
 
Insert a new .062” dia. contact pin (such as P/N 104944-000) into the socket.  The pin should be 
firmly held (the specification for new sockets calls for 8 oz. of force required for pin removal, but some 
reduction in retention force over time is unavoidable). If the pin is very loose, the socket must be 
replaced.  
 
The linked data sheets list a step by step process for the PM3 of the 1970 BB and should be used 
in conjunction with the -855 documentation listed in the Assembly/Disassembly section of this 
manual. 
 
During the process of performing preventive maintenance, the data sheets will require a description of 
the failures. The item or items being inspected could have different types of damage or irregularities. In 
helping to describe discrepancies the terms below can be used as reference. 
Mechanical:  Radial scarring 
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something 
rotating in and out of a cavity.  
 
Longitudinal scarring 
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something 
dragging lengthwise 
 
Pitting/Crevice Corrosion 
Usually associated with corrosion of some type where pits 
start to occur on the metal or surface coating. 
 
Flow cut/Jetting 
Usually associated with an area where a high flow rate of 
fluid causes metal to erode. 
 
Dents/dings 
Usually associated with an indentation in the metal that was 
caused by being dropped, hit, or mishandled. 
 
Scratch(es) 
Similar to scarring but grooves start to appear that are 
deeper and less frequent in number. Scratches are usually 
caused by abrasion. For example sand getting into a seal 
area or a metal picks used to remove an o-ring. 
 
Scoring 
Usually an isolated groove caused by something sharp. 
Such as a burr or sharp tool (metal pick). 
 
Galling 
Usually occurs when like metals or similar hardness metals 
are mated to each other and become seized together. Most 
often occurs in threaded connections. 
 
Flaking 
Occurs when coatings start to separate from the base metal. 
 
Fretting/Peeling 
A type of wear resulting from minute reciprocal sliding 
motion which produce fine particulate contamination 
without chemical change. 
 
Fretting 
Usually produces a fine dust. Peeling appears more as 
flakes. 
 
Coining 
Due to over torque in a metal to metal sealing 
configuration. The metal stem or cone becomes distorted 

LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 
1970 BB RCI PUMP/DRAWDOWN PVT 
 
P/N 130634-953 
MAY 2012 
 
When investigating seal damage or failure several factors are taken into account. The location of the 
seal, condition of the seal gland, back-up ring condition, orientation of the seal within the component, 
time between seal change and the environment in which the seal is exposed are helpful in the analysis of 
a failure. Also, simultaneous failure modes can be seen in seal analysis. 
 
Seal: Extrusion 
Occurs when the seal breaks down under pressure and is 
forced out of the seal confinement. The seal will have 
frayed or edges peeling off. 
 
Nibbling 
Associated with dynamic rod or piston seals. Appears as 
little bites taken out of o-ring.  
 
Spiral 
Deep spiral cut (usually at about 45º) into the O-ring.  
 
Abrasion 
Appears as wear lines on the cross section parallel to the 
motion of the seal. Caused be either to rough or to smooth 
metal surface, high temperatures or fluid contamination. 
 
Compression Set 
Sealing area of O-ring being squeezed is flat on both sides. 
Caused by hardening of seal due to high temperature or 
excessive squeeze needed to achieve seal.    
 
Cracking 
Usually caused by weather or ozone. Small cracks on the 
outer surface of seal. 
 
Heat Hardening 
Seal is hard and cracking or pitting. Caused by high 
temperature. 
 
Plasticizer Extraction 
Small cracks in cross-section. Caused by the service fluid 
evaporating and removing the compounds that make up the 
rubber. 
 
Installation Damage 
Cuts, punctures, or notches. Caused by mating parts, misuse 
of installation tools,  or machining details. 
 
Explosive Decompression 
Gas expansion blistering, ruptures or splits deep in the O-
ring. Caused by gas absorbed under high pressure unable to 
escape. 
 
Back-up Ring 
The seal shows similarities of nibbling or extrusion, except 
failure is in area of scarf cut. Caused by temperature and 
pressure changes, or extrusion of back-up ring.  
 
CHECK OUT 
 
1970 BB PM3 Checklist

1970 CB RCI HYDRAULIC SECIONS
P/N 130632-954
APRIL 2002 1.0 GENERAL INSTRUMENT SAFETY
This document outlines the safety concern for this particular section of the 1970 RCI tool.
The GENERAL OPERATIONS MANUAL outlines the safety procedures for Well Site
conditions and the GENERAL MAINTENANCE MANUAL outlines procedures for Lab
conditions common for all the RCI subs.

CAUTION
Always assume that every section has pressure in it  until you confirm otherwise. This
can cause personal injury and should be handled very cautiously.  As a minimum wear
safety glasses, full-face shield, heavy gloves and clear the area of unnecessary
personnel.
1. Read safety procedures for relieving trapped pressures in the General Maintenance Manual
before proceeding.
WARNING
THE 1970 CB INSTRUMENT IS EXTREMELY HEAVY, AND OPERATES AT
HIGH HYDRAULIC PRESSURES AND HIGH VOLTAGE. ALL HANDLING AND
MAINTENANCE MUST BE PERFORMED WHILE
EXERCISING EXTREME
CAUTION.
2. Instrument weight is tremendous. Use the appropriate lifting devices and techniques to move
the instrument.
3. The 1970 CB hydraulic system operates at pressures up to 3,750 PSI. Use caution when
testing, disassembling and/or repairing the hydraulic system, including all lines and pressures
connectors.
WARNING
OVER PRESSURE OF THE 1970 CB CAN CAUSE THE EQUALIZER PISTON TO
EXTEND INTO THE PRESSURE RELIEF PORTION OF THE EQUALIZER SUB.
WHEN THIS OCURRS GAS OR FLUID WILL THEN BE VENTED OUT
THROUGH THE COMPENSATION HOLES LOCATED IN THE TOP OF THE
EQUALIZER SUB.
4. Verify equalizer piston is completely collapsed before removing 40 pin bulkhead or
downhole staublis during disassembly.
5. Corrosive, noxious and/or poisonous fluids may be recovered from the well. A seal failure
could also expose the hydraulic oil to these dangers.

2

1970 CB RCI HYDRAULIC SECIONS
P/N 130632-954
APRIL 2002
6. Make certain all power has been turned off while disassembling, assembling or otherwise
performing maintenance.
7. Oven heat treating of the assembled 1970 CB is prohibited, as it may result in a damaged to
the tool or property and injury to personnel due to high pressures generated by oil
expansion within the tool.  Individual electronic chassis or CDE modules should only be
tested outside the housing or subs; refer to the Repair/Maintenance section of this manual.

1 
 
LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 
1970 CB RCI HYDRAULIC SECTION 
 
P/N 130632-953 
MAY 2012 
 
 
The linked data sheets list a step by step process for the PM3 of the 1970 CB and should be used 
in conjunction with the  -855 documentation listed in the Assembly/Disassembly section of this 
manual. 
 
 
During the process of performing preventive maintenance, the data sheets will require a 
description of the failures. The item or items being inspected could have different types of damage or 
irregularities. In helping to describe discrepancies the terms below can be used as reference. 
 
Mechanical: Radial scarring  
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something rotating 
in and out of a cavity.  
 
Longitudinal scarring 
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something 
dragging lengthwise 
 
Pitting/Crevice Corrosion  Usually associated with corrosion of some type where pits start 
to occur on the metal or surface coating. 
 
Flow cut/Jetting 
Usually associated with an area where a high flow rate of fluid 
causes metal to erode. 
 
Dents/dings 
Usually associated with an indentation in the metal that  was 
caused by being dropped, hit, or mishandled. 
 
Scratch(es) 
Similar to scarring but grooves start to appear that are deeper 
and less frequent in number. Scratches are usually caused by 
abrasion. For example sand getting into a seal area or a metal 
picks used to remove an o-ring. 
 
Scoring 
Usually an isolated groove caused by something sharp. Such as 
a burr or sharp tool (metal pick). 
 
Galling 
Usually occurs when like metals or similar hardness metals are 
mated to each other and become seized together. Most often 
occurs in threaded connections. 
 
Flaking 
Occurs when coatings start to separate from the base metal. 
 
Fretting/Peeling 
A type of wear resulting from minute reciprocal sliding motion 
which produce fine particulate contamination without chemical 
change. Fretting usually produces a fine dust. Peeling appears 
more as flakes. 
 
Coining 
Due to over torque in a metal to metal sealing configuration. 

LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 
1970 CB RCI HYDRAULIC SECTION 
 
P/N 130632-953 
MAY 2012 
 
 
When investigating seal damage or failure several factors are taken into account. The location of the 
seal, condition of the seal gland, back-up ring condition, orientation of the seal within the component, 
time between seal change and the environment in which the seal is exposed are helpful in the analysis of 
a failure. Also, simultaneous failure modes can be seen in seal analysis. 
 
Seal: Extrusion 
Occurs when the seal breaks down under pressure and is forced out of 
the seal confinement. The seal will have frayed or edges peeling off. 
 
Nibbling 
Associated with dynamic rod or piston seals. Appears as little bites 
taken out of o-ring.  
 
Spiral 
Deep spiral cut (usually at about 45Λ) into the O-ring.  
 
Abrasion 
appears as wear lines on the cross section parallel to the motion of the 
seal. Caused be either to rough or to smooth metal surface, high 
temperatures or fluid contamination. 
 
Compression Set 
Sealing area of O-ring being squeezed is flat on both sides. Caused by 
hardening of seal due to high temperature or excessive squeeze 
needed to achieve seal.    
 
Cracking 
Usually caused by weather or ozone. Small cracks on the outer 
surface of seal. 
 
Heat Hardening 
Seal is hard and cracking or pitting. Caused by high temperature. 
 
Plasticizer Extraction 
Small cracks in cross-section. Caused by the service fluid evaporating 
and removing the compounds that make up the rubber. 
 
Installation Damage 
Cuts, punctures, or notches. Caused by mating parts, misuse of 
installation tools, or machining details. 
 
Explosive Decompression Gas expansion blistering, ruptures or splits deep in the O-ring. Caused 
by gas absorbed under high pressure unable to escape.  
 
Back-up Ring 
The seal shows similarities of nibbling or extrusion, except failure is 
in area of scarf cut. Caused by temperature and pressure changes, or 
extrusion of back-up ring.  
 
CHECK OUT 
 
1970 CB PM3 Checklist

1

MAY 2012

1 
Description of Service 
 
1970 DB Straddle Packer Section 
P/N 130896-935 
MAY 2006 
The 1970 DB Straddle Packer section is the proposed solution to broaden the range of operation of 
the RCI service to low permeability, fractured, vuggy and highly laminated formations. This 
translates directly in an increase in market participation and associated revenues generated by the 
service. 
 
The current RCI tool w/conventional probe only addresses the market segment of pressure testing 
and sampling in homogenous formations with relative permeabilities from 1 mDarcy/cp to 1 
Darcy/cp.  Running in fractured, vuggy, shaly, laminated, tight and in some highly invaded soft 
formations is very difficult or impossible due to the inability of the standard packers to create a 
seal to isolate the formation or because the area of the probe is too small to produce any 
reasonable fluid flow. 
 
The Straddle Packer section will also have additional applications: 
! When combined with a standard probe, interference testing can be performed to estimate 
vertical permeability. 
! Interference testing by Injecting / Fall-Off testing as an alternative to pumping out to 
wellbore. 
! Formation strength determination (i.e. Mini-Frac testing) 
! Cased hole Pressure Testing  and Sampling 
 
NOTE: 2. and 3. could require taking an injection fluid such as water in a large sample tank 
from surface. 
 
Tool Description: 
The 1970 DB RCI Straddle Packer consists of two inflatable packers that are set in the borehole 
wall isolating the section of the formation to be tested. The fluid inlet port is placed above the 
center of the isolated section to optimize the sample clean-up process. 
 
A filtration element placed around the entry port prevents the ingression of debris and mud solids 
into the sample line thus reducing the chances of plugging. 
 
Interference testing is achieved by placing a single probe (MB) on top of this section. In order to 
reduce the distance between the isolated zone and the single probe (MB), the electronics module 
(LCDE) and control valves will be placed at the bottom of the tool, contrary to any existing RCI 
section. The sample line Quartz pressure gauge it is located between the inflatable packers, at the 
same level of the fluid inlet thus eliminating the effects caused by fluid columns above or below 
the gauge in the pressure measurement. 
 
To facilitate transportation, handling and installation and removal of the packer elements the 
mandrel is designed in sections: top sub, upper and lower mandrels and bottom sub. 
 
! The top sub consists of the upper RCI standard field joint. This sub is removable to allow 
the installation of the top packer element. 
! The upper mandrel holds the quartz pressure gauge and the fluid temperature probe, and 
their associated electronics. The top packer element is mounted onto this mandrel. 
! The lower inflatable packer element is mounted over the lower mandrel. This mandrel 
will be available in the future in various lengths for 3 ft. or longer sealing intervals. 
! The bottom sub houses all the valves, solenoids, sensors and electronics needed to control 

Description of Service 
 
1970 DB Straddle Packer Section 
P/N 130896-935 
MAY 2006 
! The packer elements are attached to the mandrels from the top with a threaded collar for 
easy replacement. The bottom of the packer elements slide freely during inflation and 
deflation as consequence of the packer grow in the radial direction. The packers will 
automatically deflate in case of a tool power loss. 
 
Most of the parts utilized are standard RCI components proven very reliable in existing designs: 
Quartzdyne QHB-16 K or 25 K quartz pressure gauge, dirty fluid valves (Gilmore’s), hydraulic 
solenoids valves, packer inflation pressure gauges (ISI). Moving the LCDE (Long Common 
Distributed Electronics) to the bottom of the section required a new assembly with connectors 
reversed, so this component it is not longer compatible with other versions of the LCDE.  
 
Three different packer element sizes will be available to provide coverage from 6” to 14” 
diameter boreholes: 
• 
Slim Kit: 
o Tool OD max.: 
 
 
 
 
5.50” 
o Packer Element max OD deflated 
 
 
5.00” 
o Borehole Range: 
 
 
 
6.00” to 8.00” 
• 
Standard Kit: 
o Tool OD max.: 
 
 
 
 
7.25” 
o Packer Element max OD deflated 
 
 
6.25” 
o Borehole Range: 
7.87” to 11.00” 
• 
Large Hole Kit: 
o Tool OD max.: 
 
 
 
 
9.25” 
o Packer Element max OD deflated 
 
 
8.25” 
o Borehole Range: 
10.50” to 14.00” 
 
• 
Packer inflation pressure max: 2500 PSI (A pressure sensor is used to monitor the 
inflation pressure and a relief valve limits the maximum inflation pressure to prevent 
destruction of the elements). 
• 
Safety features: 
• 
Burping slots on the mandrels to limit the maximum packer opening and prevent their 
destruction when opened beyond their design ranges. 
• 
The Packer inflation pressure is immediately released when electric power is interrupted. 
The outer elastomers layer will return the packer to its original shape after the internal 
pressure is released. This operation can take up to 20 minutes.  
• 
Maintenance of the tool as per existing RCI guidelines. The packer elements must be 
replaced after every job. Multiple runs in one job are not recommended but under certain 
environmental condition and after a complete evaluation of risks and benefits is done 
multiple runs may be allowed. Please consult Engineering. 
 
 
Health and Safety requirements:  Special handling equipment will be required during rigging 
operations due to its size and weight. 
 
Transportability: 
The tool could be broken up in sections for easy transportation, and then made up in the catwalk. 
Fluid filling with a vacuum/circulating cart not required after re-assembly.

1 
 
1970 DB STRADDLE PACKER 
HYDRAULIC CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION 
  
P/N 130896-945 
MAY 2006 
 
 
The instrument consists of four sections: Top Sub, Upper Mandrel, Lower Mandrel and 
Downhole Valve Sub. 
 
 
Figure 1 - Hydraulic Diagram 
 
The Downhole Valve Sub section consists of three Dual Pilot (DP) valves and one Normally 
Open (NO) valve controlled by seven (7) solenoids. The inflation pressure of the elements is 
measured by a differential strain gage (DPG1) also contained in this sub. This pressure is 
measured relative to the hydraulic return line (~ hydrostatic). 
 
Formation pressure is measured by a Quartzdyne (APG1) pressure gauge and the sample line 
temperature by a dedicated RTD (RTD2) located in the Upper Mandrel at the fluid inlet of the 
tool.  
 
The Emergency deflate mechanism consists of a NO valve activated by applying electric power 
to SV9 and hydraulic pressure to maintain the valve shut. In the event of a tool malfunction the 
valve will immediately open thus deflating the elements. Once this valve is opened, to close it 
again it is necessary to re-apply motor voltage to activate SV9, and then full buss pressure to 

1970 DB STRADDLE PACKER 
HYDRAULIC CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION 
  
P/N 130896-945 
MAY 2006 
 
 
Figure 2 shows the location of the emergency exit port in the downhole sub. This port is also 
used to purge the elements prior to RIH. 
 
Solenoids SV7 and SV3 are used to control (DP3) the Elements Inflation Valve (EIV). This 
valve connects the elements with the sample line allowing the pumping of fluid to inflate them. 
The Emergency Deflate (NO) and the Sample Isolation (DP1) valves must be closed to inflate 
the packers. 
 
During inflation and deflation the Equalizing Valve (DP2) must remain open to communicate the 
isolated zone to the balance line (L2) thus preventing pressure build-up between the packers. 
 
The line marked L2 (balance) in the tool diagram represents the balance line. This is a passage 
that communicates the borehole above and below the isolated zone between the packers. The 
main purpose of this line is to maintain the borehole above and below the isolated zone at 
constant hydrostatic pressure during operation of the tool. Otherwise a differential across the 
packers could strain the upper mandrel and packers or cause the tool to move. 
 
Figures 3 show the location of the ends of this passage in the top and downhole subs. 
 
       Plug 
 
       Emergency Dump Port 
 
 
 
       Equalizing Port 
 
       Dirty Fluid Relief Valve Port 
 
 
Figure 2 – Emergency Dump and Lower Balance Port location  
 
 
 
 
    Equalizing Port 
 
 
 
 
Figure 3 – Upper Balance Line Port location 
WARNING 
It should be noted that this passage is not designed to allow a high flow rate through it; it is 

1970 DB STRADDLE PACKER 
HYDRAULIC CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION 
  
P/N 130896-945 
MAY 2006 
 
 
Solenoids SV4 and SV8 are used to control DP1 the Sample Isolation Valve (SIV). This valve 
communicates the formation inlet port with the sample line allowing when it is open to pump 
from/to the isolated portion of the formation. In the closed position it isolates the formation and 
the pressure and temperature sensors to make the post-production volume as small as possible. 
This valve must also remain closed while performing pretests with the MB probe. 
 
A Dirty Fluid Pressure Relief Valve (DFPRV) is provided to limit the elements inflation pressure 
to ~2300 PSI.

1 
   LAB SAFETY 
 
1970 DB RCI STRADDLE PACKER  
 
   P/N 130896-954 
           MAY 2013 
GENERAL INSTRUMENT SAFETY 
 
This document outlines the safety concern for this particular section of the 1970 RCI 
tool. 
 
 
 
The GENERAL OPERATION MANUAL outlines the safety procedures for Well Site 
conditions and the GENERAL MAINTENANCE MANUAL outlines procedures for 
Lab conditions common for all the RCI subs. 
 
 
 
WARNING: Leaking or faulty Lee plugs must only be replaced with the appropriate size 
Lee plug. Any other form of plugging an access port is forbidden. If rework is necessary, 
contact local AMO management to verify the location of vendors qualified to rework Lee 
plugs. If no locally qualified vendor exists, the asset must be sent to a location that has a 
qualified vendor. 
 
 
1. 
Read safety procedures for relieving trapped pressures in the RCI GENERAL 
MAINTENANCE MANUAL before proceeding. 
 
 
 
2. 
Instrument weight is very high (over 500lbs/226kgs for the mandrel itself). Use 
the appropriate lifting devices and techniques to move the instrument.  This 
instrument consists of four sections, and when assembled is heavier and longer 
than current RCI modules.  Use the appropriate lifting devices and techniques to 
move the instrument. Suggested techniques would be a three point lift of the 
mandrel to minimize bending. 
 
 
 
3. 
DO NOT inflate the packer elements inside a casing inadequate to the size of 
packer being inflated. Select the appropriate casing size to prevent over expansion 
and possible damage or catastrophic failure of the element. 
 
4. 
Keep hands and fingers clear of the packer elements while inflating and deflating 
them. 
 
CAUTION 
 
Always assume that every section has pressure in it until you confirm otherwise.  
This can cause personnel injury and should be handled very cautiously.  Always 
wear safety glasses, or a full-face shield, heavy gloves and clear the area of 
unnecessary personnel. 
WARNING: 
The 1970 DB Instrument is extremely heavy, has moving external parts and operates 
at high hydraulic pressures.  All handling and maintenance must be performed while 

   LAB SAFETY 
 
1970 DB RCI STRADDLE PACKER  
 
   P/N 130896-954 
           MAY 2013 
5. 
Corrosive, noxious and/or poisonous fluids may be recovered from the well.  A 
seal failure could also expose the hydraulic oil to these dangers. 
 
6. 
Make certain all power has been turned off while disassembling or otherwise 
performing maintenance. 
 
7. 
The 1970 DB hydraulic system operates at pressures up to 3,000 PSI.  Use caution 
when testing, disassembling and /or repairing the hydraulic system, including all 
lines and pressure connectors. 
 
8. 
Always connect “Return Line” between tool and hydraulic test cart (both ends) to 
avoid blowing off the Solenoid Valve Cover located in the downhole section. 
 
9. 
Oven heat testing of the assembled 1970 DB is prohibited, as it may result in a 
damaged to the tool or property and injury to personnel due to high pressures 
generated by oil expansion within the tool.  Individual electronic chassis or CDE 
modules should only be tested outside the housing or subs; refer to the 
Repair/Maintenance section of this manual. 
 
10. 
After tripping out of the hole, if the packer elements have swelled from original 
size, this may be a sign of trapped internal pressure.  Take caution while deflating 
the elements. 
 
RELIEVING PRESSURE IN RCI SUB IN LAB 
 
The following procedure shall be followed for relieving trapped internal pressure for all 
RCI subs mentioned above.  
 
 
If Hydrogen Sulfide is present, special precautions must be taken when disassembling the 
tank assemblies, cleaning sample tanks and disposing of residue. Contact your local 
HS&E representative and refer to the HS&E Operational Control documents “Hydrogen 
Sulfide” and “Respiratory Protection”, available on the HS&E intranet site.  
 
 
 
 
 
1. 
Secure the sub on a tool cart. 
2. 
Referring to assembly drawing, locate the test ports at the uphole end of the sub. 
3. 
Pick the Return Line Test Port, locate an appropriate ball end hex wrench for the 
SAE. 
 
CAUTION 
Always assume that every section has pressure in it until you confirm otherwise.

1 
Level 1 Preventive Maintenance  
 
 
   1970 DB Straddle Packer     
 
 
    P/N 130896-951 
                         MAY 2006 
   
Minimum required service immediately after POOH for the 1970 DB Straddle Packer module. 
 
1. Thoroughly wash tool. 
2. Remove and thoroughly clean all screens (equalizing and inlet) 
3. Thoroughly flush both packer elements with fresh water inside and out to remove any residual drilling 
fluids. Material used in construction of packer elements are easily corroded when left in contact with 
drilling fluids even for short periods. 
4. Thoroughly flush sample and equalizing lines with fresh water before breaking sections apart to prevent 
contamination of electrical connectors with drilling fluids. 
5. Remove and replace all static seals in the field and tool break out joints. 
6. Remove and replace all dynamic and static seals in the packer assemblies. 
7. Replace elements with new ones. Reusing of the elements it is not recommended as the rubber outer 
cover, internal sleeve and the metal ribs can deteriorate with use and exposure to borehole fluids. 
8. Perform continuity and leakage tests as indicated in PM3. 
9. Remove, clean and refill the buffer tube. 
10. Remove, clean, inspect and redress all Gilmore valves. 
11. Replace oil and evacuate tool. 
12. Fully test the tools using ECLIPS, inflating the elements inside a casing section to ~200 psi to verify 
integrity of the new packers and seals.

1 
 
LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 
1970 DB RCI STRADDLE PACKER 
 
P/N 130896-953 
MAY 2012 
 
The linked data sheets list a step by step process for the PM3 of the 1970 DB and should be 
used in conjunction with the 855 documentation listed in the Assembly/Disassembly section of this 
manual. 
 
 
During the process of performing preventive maintenance, the data sheets will require a description 
of the failures. The item or items being inspected could have different types of damage or irregularities. 
In helping to describe discrepancies the terms below can be used as reference. 
 
Mechanical: Radial scarring  
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something rotating 
in and out of a cavity.  
 
Longitudinal scarring 
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something 
dragging lengthwise 
 
Pitting/Crevice Corrosion  Usually associated with corrosion of some type where pits start 
to occur on the metal or surface coating. 
 
Flow cut/Jetting 
Usually associated with an area where a high flow rate of fluid 
causes metal to erode. 
 
Dents/dings 
Usually associated with an indentation in the metal that was 
caused by being dropped, hit, or mishandled. 
 
Scratch(es) 
Similar to scarring but grooves start to appear that are deeper 
and less frequent in number. Scratches are usually caused by 
abrasion. For example sand getting into a seal area or a metal 
picks used to remove an o-ring. 
 
Scoring 
Usually an isolated groove caused by something sharp, such as 
a burr or sharp tool (metal pick). 
 
Galling 
Usually occurs when like metals or similar hardness metals are 
mated to each other and become seized together. Most often 
occurs in threaded connections. 
 
Flaking 
Occurs when coatings start to separate from the base metal. 
 
Fretting/Peeling 
A type of wear resulting from minute reciprocal sliding motion 
which produces fine particulate contamination without 
chemical change. 
 
Fretting  
Usually produces a fine dust. Peeling appears more as flakes. 
 
Coining 
Due to over torque in a metal to metal sealing configuration. 

LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 
1970 DB RCI STRADDLE PACKER 
 
P/N 130896-953 
MAY 2012 
 
 
When investigating seal damage or failure several factors are taken into account. The location of the 
seal, condition of the seal gland, back-up ring condition, orientation of the seal within the component, 
time between seal change and the environment in which the seal is exposed are helpful in the analysis of 
a failure. Also, simultaneous failure modes can be seen in seal analysis. 
 
Seal: Extrusion 
Occurs when the seal breaks down under pressure and is forced out 
of the seal confinement. The seal will have frayed or edges peeling 
off. 
 
Nibbling 
Associated with dynamic rod or piston seals. Appears as little bites 
taken out of o-ring.  
 
Spiral 
Deep spiral cut (usually at about 451) into the O-ring.  
 
Abrasion 
Appears as wear lines on the cross section parallel to the motion of 
the seal. Caused be either to rough or to smooth metal surface, high 
temperatures or fluid contamination. 
 
Compression Set 
Sealing area of O-ring being squeezed is flat on both sides. Caused 
by hardening of seal due to high temperature or excessive squeeze 
needed to achieve seal.    
 
Cracking 
Usually caused by weather or ozone. Small cracks on the outer 
surface of seal. 
 
Heat Hardening 
Seal is hard and cracking or pitting. Caused by high temperature. 
 
Plasticizer Extraction 
Small cracks in cross-section. Caused by the service fluid 
evaporating and removing the compounds that make up the rubber. 
 
Installation Damage 
Cuts, punctures, or notches. Caused by mating parts, misuse of 
installation tools, or machining details. 
 
Explosive Decompression Gas expansion blistering, ruptures or splits deep in the O-ring. 
Caused by gas absorbed under high pressure unable to escape. 
 
Back-up Ring 
The seal shows similarities of nibbling or extrusion, except failure is 
in area of scarf cut. Caused by temperature and pressure changes, or 
extrusion of back-up ring.  
 
CHECK OUT 
 
1970 DB PM3 Checklist

The Main electronic cartridge for the Reservoir Characterization Instrument (RCI) is a
modular chassis assembly designed for ruggedness, ease of service, and space utilization.
All wiring is attached to low maintenance motherboards. This allows the circuit boards to
be easily removed without flexing or removing any wires.
The electronics cartridge is comprised of:
• Glue board interface
• Power supply and motherboards
• Main Electronics board

topic: CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS - 2.0 GLUE BOARD INTERFACE, P/N 180314-000
chunk_text:
The glue board interface is named for its function of “gluing” all of the other main
electronics functional blocks together. Wires coming from the up-hole and down-hole
ends of the electronic cartridge are terminated on the glue board. Power for the entire tool
comes from the switch mode power supply. Power is distributed to the RCI bus thru the
glue board. The main processor is attached to the glue board at connector P1. Power for
the main processor board is routed to P1. Voltage monitors from the power supply, are
routed through the glue board and distributed to P1 for processing by the main processor
board.
Although not presently being used, WTS through wires can be switched on and off with
relays RLY3 through RLY6. Control signals come from the main processor through driver
transistors Q1 and Q2 to operate the WTS relays (RLY3 through RLY6). Motor thru wire
control comes from the main processor board through drive transistors Q1 and Q3 and
operates the relays K1 thru K3 in the hydraulic power section.
A Howland constant current source U32 is used to drive the motor RTD in the hydraulic
power section. Five-volt reference U31 supplies a constant voltage. Amplifier U32
maintains 2.5 ma through the RTD. The voltage across the RTD is acquired on the main
processor board. A second current source (U30) exists but is not used at this time.
RLY1 is used to switch between drives for the hydraulic power pressure sensor. Resistors
R60 or R61 terminate the drive not being used. Control signals for RLY1 originate from
the main processor board and are used by transistor Q2 to drive RLY1
The power for the 30-volt solenoid bus can come from two sources: the 480vac motor
supply or the 180vac-tool supply. The 480vac motor source, has the capability to drive the
solenoids and is used during normal operations. The 180vac-tool power supply is used
during tool initialization, emergency operation, or troubleshooting. The relay that switches
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
1970 EB RCI ELECTRONICS SECTION
P/N 130633-945
FEBRUARY 2002
2
between the two sources is RLY7. Relay RLY7 is normally closed and powers up in the
480vac motor power position. Control signals from the main processors can switch RLY7
through drive transistor Q4. In normal operation, the unregulated solenoid DC power from
the 480vac motor supply drives the 30-volt linear regulator on the switch mode power
supply and is connected to the RCI bus 30 volt DC power. In switched operation, power to
the 30 volt linear regulator is supplied by the unregulated 30 volt DC, generated from
the180vac tool power in the hydraulic power section. Diodes D2 and D3 block the current
from going back into the 30 volt regulator U80, located on the switched mode supply.

topic: CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS - 3.0 POWER SUPPLY MOTHER BOARDS
chunk_text:
The power supply input card (155803-000) is the wire connection point for the unregulated,
rectified 30-volt tool power and unregulated, rectified 30 volt motor voltage, coming from
the hydraulic power section.
Note: These unregulated DC voltages will measure approximately 38vdc.
The power supply output card (155867-000) is the wire connection point for the ± 5 volts,
± 15 volts, + 30volt regulated solenoid power, and power supply voltage/current monitors.

topic: CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS - 4.0 POWER SUPPLY ASSEMBLY P/N 164133-000
chunk_text:
The power supply is a combination switch mode and linear supply.
The +30-volt solenoid output has a linear regulator U80. The approximately 38vdc
unregulated solenoid voltage comes from the hydraulic power section and IC U80 regulates
the output voltage to +30 volts at a maximum of two amps. The maximum operating input
voltage to the regulator (U80) is 40 volts DC. Care must be taken not to exceed 480 vac
motor voltage, which in turns supplies the unregulated solenoid DC. Resistor R99 is for
current sensing. When amplified by U27, this signal yields 1 V/amp.
The +5 volt output is a switch mode output.
U5 is a 12-volt linear regulator supplying operational power to the control circuitry of the
power supply. U1 is a pulse width modular (PWM) which monitors and maintains the +5
volts on the output while limiting excessive current.
Note: +5 volt is used for a reference, when measured directly on the power supply, the
voltage must be between 5.32 to 5.44vdc at the output.
U7, is a 2.5 volt reference, that supplies a constant reference voltage used to regulate the
output voltage. The output voltage is divided across R9, R10 and the difference between
the reference voltage and the output voltage determines the width of the pulse output to
maintain the correct output voltage.  U3 supplies a reference voltage of 10 volts that is
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
1970 EB RCI ELECTRONICS SECTION
P/N 130633-945
FEBRUARY 2002
3
divided across R1 and R2 that provides a primary cycle current limit reference to the I-
SENSE pin of the PWM. Current sense transformer TR2 monitors the current flowing in
the primary of the output transformer TR1. The voltage coming from the TR2 secondary is
rectified and connected to the +CUR_SEN pin of the PWM. This will limit the current of
each cycle to the current determined by the voltage on the I-LIMIT pin.
OUT_A and OUT_B are exclusive square wave 100khz pulses to drive the high-speed
power FET’s Q1 and Q2. Sinking current through the primary of TR1 induces currents in
the secondary. The second currents are full wave rectified by D1 and filtered by L1, C5,
and C8. The output passes through current sensing resistor R16. When amplified by U4,
this signal yields 1 V/amp.
The ±15 volt output is also a switch mode output. Its control circuit is very similar to the +5
volt control circuit.
U15 is a 2.5 volt reference, that supplies a constant reference voltage used to regulate the
output voltage. U11 is a pulse width modular (PWM) which monitors and maintains the
+15 volts on the output while limiting excessive current. U3 supplies a reference voltage of
10 volts that is divided by R51 and R 52 to provide a primary cycle current limit reference
to the I-SENSE pin of the PWM. Current sensing is done with TR52, rectified by D53, and
returned to the PWM. The primary of output transformer TR51, induces currents in the
secondary. The positive pulses are rectified by D51 and filtered by L51, C61, and C62 to
provide the +15 volt output. The negative pulses are rectified by D52 and filtered by L52
and C64, to provide the –15 volt output.
The +15 current passes through sensing resistor R69. When amplified by U19, this signal
yields 1v/amp.
The –5 volt output comes from linear regulator U57 with its input coming from the –15
volt output.
The voltage and current sensing outputs are multiplexed using two, 8-channel multiplexers
U8 and U9. Control and acquisition of the sensing signals are routed through the glue board
and processed by the main processor board.

The main processor board of the RCI tool is the mediator between the WTS bus and the
RCI bus as well as the master controller of all RCI bus communications. Control circuitry
for the hydraulic power section is supplied by the main electronics.
The functionality of this electronics package can be broken down into the following:
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
1970 EB RCI ELECTRONICS SECTION
P/N 130633-945
FEBRUARY 2002
4
• Central Processing Unit and Memory
• WTS Communications
• RCI Bus Communications
• 16-Channel, 12-Bit Acquisition System
• Four-Channel Analog Output System and Solenoid Drivers

CENTRAL PROCESSING UNIT & MEMORY
The central processing unit is built around the Harris RTX 2000 microprocessor, U1. This
processor has a separate 16-bit wide memory address and data bus, as well as a 16-bit
peripheral data bus. This allows DMA transfers from memory at the same time data is
being handled on the peripheral bus.
Two 32k X 8 EPROM’s U21 and U22, from the 16-bit wide program storage memory.
Two 32k X 8 static RAM,s, U23 and U24. Form the 16-bit wide temporary storage
memory.
Reset for the processor comes from the configuration completion of FPGA (field
programmable gate array), U3. The DONE_PG pin will stay low until the part is
completely configured. This signal goes to the TMR_DPIN of U2 where it is inverted and
becomes the high active reset for processor U1. The WAIT pin is used to halt the processor
clock during DMA (direct memory access) operations.
The 16 Mhz system clock, comes from oscillator U51 and is divided by the FPGA U2. The
8 MHZ clock from U2 pin 76 is tied to ICLK (U1 pin B1) to run the processor. The 4 MHZ
processor clock is available at PCLK (U2 pin 59) to use for peripherals.
Memory address bus MA1-MA14 is used to access the RAM and EPROM memory.
Memory address bus MA15-Ma19 goes to FPGA U2 and is used to address multiple
memory pages and generate chip selects. Memory data lines MD0-MD15 carry bi-
directional data to the memory. General data bus GD0-GD15 is used to control the
peripheral operations across the board. GI0, GR/W, and GA0-GA2 are control lines used
when the processor talks to its peripherals through the general data bus. LDS, UDS, and
MR/W- are control lines used when accessing memory. The BOOT and INTA signals are
not used. The nets connected to E11 through E15 are external interrupts that will be
discussed later.
U2 is an FPGA configured to operate as memory interface, Manchester encoder and
decoder interface, and RCI bus RS232 interface. DATA_IN, CCLK, and DONE_PG are
the data, clock and control signals for the FPGA configuration from U6. The memory
interface uses MA15-MA19, UDS, LDS, and MR/W to generate RAM_CS, EPRM_CS,
EEPM_CS (CS is chip select), RAMWE_LO, RAMWE_HI (WE is write enable),
RAMOE_LO, RAMOE_HI, EEPE_HI, EPROE_LO, and EPROE_HI (OE is output).
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
1970 EB RCI ELECTRONICS SECTION
P/N 130633-945
FEBRUARY 2002
5
These signals are used to read and write to RAM, EPROM, and history storage EPROM.
MAN_ESC, MAN_SNDT, MAN_SDO, AND MAN_EE are all Manchester encoder
signals. When the write shift register has shifted its last bit, a WTS-WRIT interrupt is
generated on processor interrupt two, to indicate the next word can be loaded for writing.
MAN_C/D-, MAN_VW, MAN_ID, MAN_TD, MAN_DSC, and MAN_SDI are all
Manchester decoder signals. When a full Manchester word is received into the read shift
register, a WTS_READ interrupt is generated on processor interrupt one, to indicate the
word needs to be read. 232_XLNX is an output RS232 data stream sent to the driver
(through jumper XMT_J3) on the RCI bus. When the last bit has been transmitted, a
232_DONE interrupt is generated on processor interrupt five, to indicate the next data byte
can be loaded for transmission.
RCVR_IN is an input RS232 data stream coming from receive on the RCI bus. When the
last bit has been received, a 232_INPT interrupt (through jumper RCV_J3) is generated on
processor interrupt four, to indicate a byte has been received and needs to be read. The
PWRDWN signal is used if the main processor board is to be shut down in case of failure.
Control circuits U19 and U20 are used to provide the required programming voltages to
EPROM U25. During normal operating conditions, VPP_CTL signal high, Q2 conducts
and both VPP and VCC_EPR voltages are at 5 volts. To enable programming, VPP must be
raised to 12.75 volts and
VCC_EPR must be raised to 6.25 volts. When control signal VPP_CTL goes low, five
volts is applied to the positive (+) input of the OpAmp. The voltage divider on the emitter
of the transistor provides the proper gain to yield the proper output voltages.
U8 is an FPGA configured to operate as a multi-port interface. Bits, grouped in registers,
can be set or reset to control various peripheral devices. The GD bus is the data channel
between the interface and the processor. The GA0-Ga2 bus and ASIC_PG0-ASIC_PG3 bus
are used to address the different registers. The PBUS is a 12-bit bi-directional bus used to
read and write parallel data to other devices. DATA_IN, CCLK, and DONE_PG are the
data, clock, and control signals for the FPGA configuration from U9.

The WTS interface is the same as other WTS tools. CMD signals from the instrument bus
pass through receive transformer T1, are reshaped by receiver U13, and are decoded by
Manchester chip U12. Mode 2 signals come from the Manchester chip and amplified by
driver U14, passing through transmit transformer T2 to the instrument bus. All control
signals and data for the Manchester chip come from U2 as described earlier.
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
1970 EB RCI ELECTRONICS SECTION
P/N 130633-945
FEBRUARY 2002
6

The RCI bus communications is differential RS232 at 38.4k baud. The serial data stream
comes from the UART in U2 and goes to differential driver U10. The outputs from the
driver U10 becomes the HST_TX_HBL (Host Transmit High Base Line) and HST)
TX_LBL (Low Base Line) signals on the RCI bus. Driver output is enabled all of the time.
The HST_RX_HBL and HST_RX_LBL (Host Receive High and Low) signals come from
the RCI bus, and are capacitivly coupled to biasing network R5 through R9, processed by
receiver U11. The biasing network holds the receiver inputs at a differential of 400 to 600
mv allowing the received signals to be detected. The output of the receiver goes to the
UART in U2.

16-CHANNEL, 12-BIT ACQUISITION SYSTEM
Analog signals from the main electronics and hydraulic power sections are multiplexed by
U28. Control signals for addressing and enabling come from the Xilinx U8 interface chip.
U50 is a temperature chip that monitors main electronic temperature. The output of the
multiplexer U28 is connected with the output of the multiplexers from the switch mode
power supply (U8 and U9) thru the glue board, to the main processor card. The output is
buffered by amplifier U30 before going to U31, a 12-bit unipolar successive approximation
A to D converter. The control signals and data bits are processed by the Xilinx U8 interface
chip. The –5 volt reference voltage is supplied by U35. The 500k clock signal comes from
the clock divider in FPGA U2 pin85.
An active low pass filter U102 is used between the 2k RTD mounted on the motor in the
hydraulic power section and the analog mux U28. The hydraulic pressure transducer signal
is amplified by U37, then low-passed filtered by U101 before going to the analog mux
U28.
5.5   FOUR-CHANNEL, EIGHT-BIT ANALOG OUTPUT SYSTEM & SOLENOID DRIVERS
U32 is a quad 8-bit D to A ( D/A ) converter. The D/A output voltage is determined by
values written into the registers from the PBUS. Signals DAC_WR, DAC_A0, and
DAC_A1 are controlled from the Xilinx interface U8. Input reference voltage is supplied
by U34. Outputs A and C are used to control the amount of current supplied to the bypass
solenoid (output A) and dump (output C) solenoid respectively.
The Digital to Analog converter U32 output A is the input to U100. As the current
increases, the output of amplifier U100, feeding the gate of FET Q3, decreases until it
reaches a steady state. The voltage feedback from the current sensing resistor (R4) will then
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
1970 EB RCI ELECTRONICS SECTION
P/N 130633-945
FEBRUARY 2002
7
track the input voltage from the D/A. RLY2 and its drive transistor are used to disable FET
Q3 in the case of a failure.
NOTE: At this time, the current limiting software is not available or supported. The
current is either zero or 100%.
Output B works in the same fashion using components Q4, RLY1, and U110. At present,
the B circuitry is not used.
The drive circuit using Q5, U17, RLY3, U111, and D/A output C works in the same
manner except for one additional function. The digital detect circuit is a means by which
the physical movement of the solenoid plunger can be detected. Current builds in the
solenoid coil after being energized and once the force of the spring is overcome, the
plunger moves into the coil. This change in inductive reactance creates a current fluctuation
in the solenoid current. This fluctuation is filtered and amplified by U18 and fed into a high
speed input pin IN3 of Xlinix interface U8. A timer is started when the solenoid is
energized and is stopped when the digital detect pulse indicates the plunger has moved.
NOTE: The digital detect is not currently supported.

GENERAL INSTRUMENT SAFETY 
 
This document outlines the safety concern for this particular section of the 1970 RCI 
tool. 
 
 
 
The GENERAL OPERATION MANUAL outlines the safety procedures for Well Site 
conditions and the GENERAL MAINTENANCE MANUAL outlines procedures for 
Lab conditions common for all the RCI subs. 
 
 
 
1. 
Read safety procedures for relieving trapped pressures in the GENERAL 
MAINTENANCE MANUAL before proceeding. 
 
 
CAUTION: Always assume that every section has pressure in it until you confirm 
otherwise.  This can cause personnel injury and should be handled very 
cautiously.  As a minimum wear safety glasses, full-face shield, heavy gloves and 
clear the area of unnecessary personnel. 
 
 
WARNING: The 1970 EB instrument is extremely heavy and operates at high hydraulic 
pressures.  Use extreme caution when handling or performing maintenance on this 
section.  
 
 
 
2. 
Use the appropriate lifting devices and techniques to move the instrument. 
 
3. 
Corrosive, noxious and/or poisonous fluids may be recovered from the well.  A 
seal failure could also expose the hydraulic oil to these dangers. 
 
4. 
Always connect “Return Line” between tool and hydraulic test cart (both ends). 
 
5. 
The 1970 EB hydraulic system operates at pressures up to 3,500 PSI.  Use caution 
when testing, disassembling and /or repairing the hydraulic system, including all 
lines and pressure connectors. 
 
6. 
The 1970 EB utilizes Lee plugs to facilitate hydraulic/sample line plumbing.  
During functional and troubleshooting operations in this section, necessary steps 
should be taken to prevent personnel injury should a Lee plug fail and become a 
projectile. The following minimum steps shall be implemented. 
 
a. 
Clear the area of unnecessary personnel. 
b. 
Minimize time standing next to the tool when function testing or 
toubleshooting. 
c. 
The sub should be covered to absorb the projectile. 
 
7. 
Make certain all power has been turned off while disassembling, assembling or 

 LAB SAFETY 
 
 
1970 EB RCI ELECTRONICS  
 
 
 CONFIDENTIAL 
P/N 130633-954 
 FEBRUARY 2002 
 
8. 
Oven heat treating of the assembled 1970 EB  is prohibited, as it may result in a 
damaged to the tool or property and injury to personnel due to high pressures 
generated by oil expansion within the tool.  Individual electronic chassis or CDE 
modules should only be tested outside the housing or subs; refer to the 
Repair/Maintenance section of this manual.
