Cuts, punctures, or notches. Caused by mating parts, misuse of 
installation tools, or machining details. 
 
Explosive Decompression Gas expansion blistering, ruptures or splits deep in the O-ring. 
Caused by gas absorbed under high pressure unable to escape. 
 
Back-up Ring 
The seal shows similarities of nibbling or extrusion, except failure is 
in area of scarf cut. Caused by temperature and pressure changes, or 
extrusion of back-up ring.  
 
CHECK OUT 
 
1970 EB PM3 Checklist

This document outlines the safety concern for this particular section of the 1970
RCI tool.

The GENERAL OPERATIONS MANUAL outlines the safety procedures for
Well Site conditions and the GENERAL MAINTENANCE MANUAL outlines
procedures for Lab conditions common for all the RCI subs.

CAUTION: Always assume that every section has pressure in it until you confirm
otherwise. This can cause personal injury and should be handled very cautiously. as
a minimum wear safety glasses, full-face shield, heavy gloves and clear the area of
unnecessary personnel.

WARNING: Leaking or faulty Lee plugs must only be replaced with the
appropriate size Lee plug. Any other form of plugging an access port is forbidden.
If rework is necessary, contact local AMO management to verify the location of
vendors qualified to rework Lee plugs. If no locally qualified vendor exists, the
asset must be sent to a location that has a qualified vendor.

1.Read safety procedures for relieving trapped pressures in the General
Maintenance Manual before proceeding.

WARNING: The 1970 GB instrument operates at high hydraulic pressures. all
handling and maintenance must be performed while exercising extreme caution.

2.Use the appropriate lifting devices and techniques to move the instrument.

3.Corrosive, noxious and/or poisonous fluids may be recovered from the well. A
seal failure could also expose the hydraulic oil to these dangers.

4.Always connect “Return Line” between tool and hydraulic test cart (both ends) to
avoid over pressuring the return line.

5.The 1970 GB hydraulic system operates at pressures up to 3,750 PSI. Use caution
when testing, disassembling and/or repairing the hydraulic system, including all
lines and pressures connectors.

6.Make certain all power has been turned off while disassembling, assembling or
otherwise performing maintenance.

Note: The following steps will probably be moved to the General Maintenance Manual.

The following procedure shall be followed for relieving trapped internal pressure for all
RCI subs mentioned above:

LAB SAFETY

P/N 130636-954


MAY 2013








WARNING: High pressure can cause personal injury and should be handled very
cautiously. As a minimum, wear safety glasses, full-face shield and heavy gloves when
performing this procedure. Clear the area of unnecessary personnel, set up a barrier
isolating the sub and add a barrier between the technician and the pressurized sub.

If Hydrogen Sulfide is present, special precautions must be taken when disassembling the
tank assemblies, cleaning sample tanks and disposing of residue. Contact your local HS&E
representative and refer to the HS&E Operational Control documents “Hydrogen Sulfide”
and “Respiratory Protection”, available on the HS&E intranet site.

RELIEVING PRESSURE IN RCI SUBS IN THE LAB

CAUTION: Always assume that every section has pressure in it until you confirm
otherwise.

WARNING: While examining sections for trapped pressure, keep yourself and others out
of the line of potential blast from a sudden release of pressure. As a minimum, wear safety
glasses, full-face shield and heavy gloves when performing this procedure.

1. Secure the sub on a tool cart.

2. Referring to the assembly drawing, locate the test ports at the uphole end of the sub.

3. DO NOT assume that all pressure has been relieved if the thread protector is still secure.
The hydraulic quick disconnects could “check the pressure within the field joint cavity.

4. Check to see if pressure exists by using a spanner wrench against the bail and begin
unscrewing SLOWLY. If large resistance is felt, then pressure MUST be present.

5. Pick the RETURN line test port; locate an appropriate ball end hex wrench for the SAE
fitting. Rotate the sub such that the test port is not facing the technician.

6. Tie a 12 inch(30cm) length of strong cord to the handle of the ball end hex driver, then
tie the cord to your wrist. This restricts the travel of the hex driver if it is blown out of your
hand and may prevent it from hitting your face.

CAUTION: If a SAE fitting is difficult to remove, DO NOT PROCEED ANY
FURTHER; red-tag the section, then place in a safe area and leave for 24 hours. The
section may bleed down by itself in this time. Be sure that the section is placed well away
from all personnel. Check the section again for trapped pressure as outlined. If the SAE
fitting is still difficult to remove, let the section set for another 24 hours. Check the section
again for trapped pressure as outlined. If the SAE fitting is still difficult to remove, contact
Operations Engineering for further instructions.



LAB SAFETY

P/N 130636-954


MAY 2013








7. Using the ball end hex driver wrench, unscrew in ¼ turn increments the SAE fitting
SLOWLY until the pressure begins to bleed. Continue to bleed until no resistance is felt
on the SAE fitting and the technician does not hear any pressure bleeding whistling
noise.

8. Repeat steps 5 through 7 for the PRESSURE line test port.

9. Repeat steps 5 through 7 for the SAMPLE line test port.

10. Repeat Steps 3 through 9. Continue to bleed until no resistance is felt on the thread
protector and the technician does not hear any pressure bleeding whistling noise.

11. Cautiously remove the thread protector completely.

12. Perform maintenance and record failures that led to trapped internal pressure.

PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE LEVEL 3 
1970 HA TANK CONTROL 
 
P/N 130776-953 
MAY 2012 
 
The linked data sheets list a step by step process for the PM 3 of the 1970 HA and should be 
used in conjunction with the 855 documentation listed in the Assembly/Disassembly section of this 
manual. 
 
During the process of performing preventive maintenance, the data sheets will require a description 
of the failures. The item or items being inspected could have different types of damage or irregularities. 
In helping to describe discrepancies the terms below can be used as reference. 
 
Mechanical: Radial scarring  
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something rotating 
in and out of a cavity.  
 
Longitudinal scarring 
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something 
dragging lengthwise 
 
Pitting/Crevice Corrosion  Usually associated with corrosion of some type where pits start 
to occur on the metal or surface coating. 
 
Flow cut/Jetting 
Usually associated with an area where a high flow rate of fluid 
causes metal to erode. 
 
Dents/dings 
Usually associated with an indentation in the metal that was 
caused by being dropped, hit, or mishandled. 
 
Scratch(es) 
Similar to scarring but grooves start to appear that are deeper 
and less frequent in number. Scratches are usually caused by 
abrasion. For example sand getting into a seal area or a metal 
picks used to remove an o-ring. 
 
Scoring 
Usually an isolated groove caused by something sharp, such as 
a burr or sharp tool (metal pick). 
 
Galling 
Usually occurs when like metals or similar hardness metals are 
mated to each other and become seized together. Most often 
occurs in threaded connections. 
 
Flaking 
Occurs when coatings start to separate from the base metal. 
 
Fretting/Peeling 
A type of wear resulting from minute reciprocal sliding motion 
which produces fine particulate contamination without 
chemical change. 
 
Fretting  
Usually produces a fine dust. Peeling appears more as flakes. 
 
Coining 
Due to over torque in a metal to metal sealing configuration. 

PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE LEVEL 3 
1970 HA TANK CONTROL 
 
P/N 130776-953 
MAY 2012 
 
 
When investigating seal damage or failure several factors are taken into account. The location of the 
seal, condition of the seal gland, back-up ring condition, orientation of the seal within the component, 
time between seal change and the environment in which the seal is exposed are helpful in the analysis of 
a failure. Also, simultaneous failure modes can be seen in seal analysis. 
 
Seal: Extrusion 
Occurs when the seal breaks down under pressure and is forced out 
of the seal confinement. The seal will have frayed or edges peeling 
off. 
 
Nibbling 
Associated with dynamic rod or piston seals. Appears as little bites 
taken out of o-ring.  
 
Spiral 
Deep spiral cut (usually at about 451) into the O-ring.  
 
Abrasion 
Appears as wear lines on the cross section parallel to the motion of 
the seal. Caused be either to rough or to smooth metal surface, high 
temperatures or fluid contamination. 
 
Compression Set 
Sealing area of O-ring being squeezed is flat on both sides. Caused 
by hardening of seal due to high temperature or excessive squeeze 
needed to achieve seal.    
 
Cracking 
Usually caused by weather or ozone. Small cracks on the outer 
surface of seal. 
 
Heat Hardening 
Seal is hard and cracking or pitting. Caused by high temperature. 
 
Plasticizer Extraction 
Small cracks in cross-section. Caused by the service fluid 
evaporating and removing the compounds that make up the rubber. 
 
Installation Damage 
Cuts, punctures, or notches. Caused by mating parts, misuse of 
installation tools, or machining details. 
 
Explosive Decompression Gas expansion blistering, ruptures or splits deep in the O-ring. 
Caused by gas absorbed under high pressure unable to escape. 
 
Back-up Ring 
The seal shows similarities of nibbling or extrusion, except failure is 
in area of scarf cut. Caused by temperature and pressure changes, or 
extrusion of back-up ring.  
 
CHECK OUT 
 
1970 HA PM3 Checklist

1970 IB SAMPLEVIEW

BRIEF DESCRIPTION

SampleViewSM IB has all the capabilities of SampleView IA described later in this document plus the
following new features:

1. A new optics head that provides more optical channels.
2. Two new optical channels for methane peak detection, which lie just to the left of the liquid-
hydrocarbon peak at Ch_16 and which can be used for estimating Gas-Oil Ratio (GOR).
3. A continuous fluid refractive index reading, n, which can be used to monitor sample cleanup and in the
Clausius Mossotti Ratio, CMR = (n2-1)/(n2+2), which correlates to fluid density.
4. A five-channel ultraviolet fluorescence spectrometer, which is indicative of crude oil type.
The brighter and bluer the fluorescence, the lighter the oil.  It can also monitor cleanup.

DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE

1970 IB SAMPLEVIEW


P/N 130949-935
FEBRUARY 2005

SampleViewSM IA (previously known as the NIR or Fluid Characterization Module) is a module that is
run in conjunction with our wireline formation tester, the Reservoir Characterization Instrument (RCI).
Its primary purpose is to monitor, in real time, the formation fluid that is being pumped from the wall of
the well by RCI, especially in those wells drilled with oil based mud (OBM).  When the optical properties
of the fluid stop changing, the sample has reached its minimum OBM contamination and we can divert
the sample that is being pumped into a sample collection tank.  To get good accuracy from subsequent
PVT analyses of the collected sample, it is essential that the collected samples be as clean as possible.

SampleViewSM IA consists of a visible and near infrared fluid analyzer with 17 optical channels. These
channels are closely spaced over the highly absorbing asphaltene region of the spectrum, which is the
region most often used to monitor contamination levels. Therefore, in most cases, there will be at least
one channel, which can span the entire transition from nearly pure filtrate to nearly pure formation fluid.
When the response of these channels levels off over time, the sample is at minimum oil based mud filtrate
contamination.

The vertical axis on the spectral plot below is Optical Density (OD), which is a logarithmic scale.  One
OD = 10 db is a 101 or 10-fold reduction in light intensity at that color.  Two OD = 20 db is a 102 or 100-
fold reduction in light intensity, and so on.  Spectroscopists use OD, which is also called Absorbance,
because the concentration of an absorbing species is proportional to its absorbance for a fixed pathlength.

600
800
1000
1200
1400
Time (sec)
Absorbance
CH_13




SampleViewSM provides real time near infrared spectra of the fluid that the RCI is pumping from the
formation.  By monitoring its response, we can ensure that samples are at a minimum contamination
level. The graph on the left shows a spectrum of the Gulf of Mexico crude.  The graph on the right
shows a representative sample clean up over time as the SampleViewSM response of a channel levels
off.

topic: DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE - DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
chunk_text:
4


1970 IB SAMPLEVIEW


P/N 130949-935
FEBRUARY 2005


BENEFITS / ADVANTAGES

SampleView IA helps us to determine in real time when we have reached minimum oil based mud
contamination so that we can avoid wasting expensive rig time with unnecessary pumping but still
provide our clients with the cleanest samples possible.  SampleView IB provides additional means for
monitoring fluid cleanup such as monitoring the fluid refractive index or fluid fluorescence over time.
Both of these new techniques are interface techniques so they have low sensitivity to the passage of sand
or other particulates. Although these tools were designed to monitor sample cleanup in wells drilled with
OBM, we found that they can also be used to monitor cleanup in wells drilled with WBM.


In addition to monitoring sample cleanup, SampleView IB provides a measure of the methane content
of a fluid sample.  Also, for a given fluid type, the IB’s refractive index measurement can be correlated
to the fluid’s density. Similarly, the IB provides the color distribution of a crude oil’s UV fluorescence,
which can be correlated to its API gravity. The brighter and more blue the UV fluorescence, the higher
the API gravity, provided that there are aromatics in the oil.  Only aromatics fluoresce.  Therefore, natural
gas and synthetic base oils (which have been designed to be aromatic-free) do not fluoresce.

SAMPLEVIEW™ CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS

The SAMPLEVIEW instrument acquires signals from 24 photo diodes, 2 temperature
probes, and several miscellaneous voltages and currents. Power is provided from standard
180vac WTS power. Separate voltages are generated for electronic operation and the
lamp driver. Furthermore, on instrument power up only the electronic power is applied.
Lamp power is disconnected by the lamp relay.


The SAMPLEVIEW electronics consists mainly of the following sections.

Power Supply
Receiver cards A, B, C
Lamp Driver card
Preamp cards A, B
Motor Control card
CPU

POWER SUPPLY

There are two independent power supplies in the SAMPLEVIEW tool. The main power
supply provides all of the operating voltages for the acquisition electronics and is
operational whenever tool power is applied. The lamp power supply provides power for
the bulbs and the filter wheel stepper motor.

The main supply consists of power transformer T1, rectifiers BR1 & BR2, filter chokes
L1 and L2, and the main regulator board. Output voltages available are +5 D, +5 A, and
-5 A and are easily measured at the terminal post buss.

The lamp supply consists of power transformer T2, filter choke L3, and a capacitor filter
board that also contains the rectifier diodes. The important point to note is that the 180vac
feeding the primary side of T2 is switched through the lamp power relay card. When
instrument power is applied the relays are de-energized and lamp power will be zero.
Upon initializing lamp power with the proper software command the CPU will energize
the relays on the lamp relay card and subsequently provide lamp power.

topic: CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970IB SAMPLEVIEW 3.0 RECEIVER INTERFACE
chunk_text:
2

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970 IB SAMPLEVIEW 

Introduction

The receiver card is designed to individually acquire and process 8 analog
channels. Each channel contains a differential amplifier front end, a D/A
Converter for offset control and eight 24 bit sigma-delta A/D converters with an
input range of -3 to +3 V.
The present SAMPLEVIEW tool uses 3 receiver cards totaling 24 analog
channels.

Circuit Description

Each card has its own power on reset IC to reset the D/A and A/D converters. A
10 MHz oscillator is used to provide a clock for the A/D, FPGA, and D/A. A
single Actel chip provides a Synchronous Serial Interface to the CPU card as
well as all state machine timing and control for each of the A /Ds. A common
Sync line is provided by the CPU to each of the receiver cards and subsequently
to each of the A/Ds. It is important that all of the internal clocks on the 24 A/Ds
are synchronized so that transmission of data to the CPU does not “time out”.

Each of the 3 receiver cards is identical and can be readily swapped with each
other. Address selection jumpers are installed on each of the chassis connectors
and are read by the card during power up. Digital inputs to each card are buffered
by a 74 HC04 hex Schmidt trigger. Outputs are driven by an octal 74 HC244 line
driver. Communication to the CPU is through a synchronous serial protocol
consisting of a common clock and individual Tx and Rx data lines.

Eight sigma-delta A/Ds are used to synchronously acquire the input signals.
Each A/D converter has 2 channels. Channel 1 is connected to the output of its
corresponding differential amp and represents the Voltage produced by the photo
diode. Channel 2 is connected directly to the output of its corresponding D/A,
and is used in test mode.

Eight D/A converters are provided and are configured to inject a DC offset
voltage into its respective input amplifier. This injected voltage is used in two
ways. First in “test mode” this voltage is sampled by channel 2 of its
corresponding A/D and is used to trouble shoot or verify A/D operation.
Second, in “log mode” this voltage “bucks out” any negative offset present
at each photo diode, especially, at higher temperatures.

The command and data protocol can be found in the WTS Firmware
Specifications document (P/N 194898-000)

topic: CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970IB SAMPLEVIEW 4.0 MULTI LAMP INTERFACE
chunk_text:
3

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970 IB SAMPLEVIEW 

Introduction

The lamp driver card has the capability to selectively drive three lamps with up to
1.5 Amps @ 8 V and two UV LEDs.  The present SAMPLEVIEW tool has two
lamps but only one lamp is illuminated at a time. The third lamp driver circuit
drives a Resistor load and is used to dynamically maintain a constant current load
regardless of weather the bulb or the LED is on or off. This “load balancing” is
necessary to maintain a constant cablehead voltage under the changing load
conditions of the SAMPLEVIEW. When the bulb and the UV LED is off, the
resistor load shunts the current that previously went to the bulb. When a lamp is
fully ON, the resistor load will be supplied minimum current. Similar load
balancing is executed with UV LED is ON.

An interlocking protection circuit is incorporated in the UV LED drive circuit to
protect the user from UV radiation. Hall Effect device assembly 198190-000
sense the presence of the top, A3000215-000 and bottom A3000216-000 covers
and enable the lamp driver circuit to power the UV LEDs. The drive circuit will
also be disabled if there is break in the wiring to the Hall Device assembly from
the lamp driver card.

Circuit Description

Address selection jumpers are installed on the chassis connector and are read by
the card during power up. Digital inputs to the lamp driver card are buffered by
a 74 HC04 hex Schmidt trigger. Outputs are driven by an octal 74 HC244 line
driver. Communication to the CPU is through a synchronous serial protocol
consisting of a common clock and individual Tx and Rx data lines.

A single Actel chip provides a Synchronous Serial Interface to the CPU card as
well as all state machine timing and control to each of the A /Ds. A common
Sync line is provided by the CPU to the lamp interface card and subsequently
to each of the A/Ds. It is important that all of the internal clocks on the 4 A/Ds
are synchronized so that transmission of data to the CPU does not “time out”.

The analog section has three D/A converters that set the current to each lamp.
Each of the A/D converters measures the voltage and current on its respective
lamp. Channel 1 of each A/D measures voltage and channel 2 measures current.
One additional A/D is provided and configured to measure the temperature.
Temperature from a probe embedded into the preamp box is sampled on channel
1. Channel 2 converts the temperature from a probe mounted directly on the PC
card.

The command and data protocol can be found in the WTS Firmware
Specifications document (P/N 194898-000)

topic: CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970IB SAMPLEVIEW 5.0 SAMPLEVIEW PREAMPLIFIER (HIGH TEMP VERSION)
chunk_text:
4

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970 IB SAMPLEVIEW 

Introduction

The preamp board is designed to convert the photocurrent produced by each of
the light sensitive diodes to a voltage. There are 12 identical preamplifier circuits
on each of the 2 preamp boards (preamp A & B). Each circuit however, has its
own unique gain. The gain is selected by the value of feedback resistor chosen.
The value of the feedback resistor for each preamplifier depends upon the type of
diode, light input with respect to wavelength and responsivity of the diode at its
operating wavelength.

Each diode is wired using a shielded twisted pair wire with a molded connector.
The anode and cathode of the diode are connected between the two wires of the
twisted pair with the shield left open at the diode end. The shield at the connector
end is connected to AGND (±5 V Return). The Preamplifier box is isolated from
the main instrument chassis, then connected to AGND by an external wire.
This keeps all the diode bodies at GND potential.

Circuit Description:


All 12 preamplifiers are identical so only one preamplifier channel will be
described. Consider channel 10. The diode is connected between two amplifiers,
sections A & B of U1 in such a way that there is zero voltage across the diode.
The light on the photo diode will generate a current that is converted to a voltage
by each amplifier (photocurrent * Feedback resistor). The output of each
amplifier is connected to a Differential Instrument Amplifier. The output of the
first amplifier will be positive while the other one will be negative. The output
of both amplifiers is summed at the differential amp. The output will be negative
because of the polarity of the diode connections.

Each of the input opamps will have a slight input offset voltage. The difference
between the voltages will be seen across the diode and will generate a small
current. Due to the high resistance (1500 G OHMS) of the diode at room
temperature this current will be negligible. This current will increase as
temperature increases due to change in resistance of the diode and input offset
voltage of the amplifiers. The difference in the bias currents of the two amplifiers
will increase as temperature increases. But, since they are fed into opposite
polarities of the differential amplifier they will cancel. The currents are produced
even when the bulb is off.

topic: CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970IB SAMPLEVIEW 6.0 CPU
chunk_text:
5

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970 IB SAMPLEVIEW 
CPU

The 1970 IB operate as a command-response system, where the responses to a command
are defined in the WTS Firmware Specifications document (P/N 194898-000). The WTS
Manchester encoder-decoder protocol for M2/M5/M7 communications is used.  Mode 5
or Mode 7 is selectable by the WTS ‘map to mode’ command.  The ECLIPS acquisition
system automatically sends the ‘map to mode’ WTS command when the OCT is
initialized or when TOOL Re-Init is selected.

NOTE: mode 7 is installed on the SAMPLEVIEW CPU card but is not used.

WTS command signals and DC power are connected to the CPU board by connector P1.
All other cards are connected to P2.

The CPU board has these functions:
1. Power up / down reset signal for the CPU.
2. Clock, 24 MHz oscillator.
3. Interface to CPU, Mode 2, Mode 5 and Mode 7 (not used).
4. Memory, data memory of 256 Kbyte’s RAM and program memory of 256 Kbyte’s
sector erase flash memory.
5. One ACTEL field programmable gate array is used for the "glue logic" functions.

POWER UP / DOWN RESET LOGIC
POWER UP RESET
The RESETIN\ signal from U7-6 will be inactive until the +5 V signal is above
4.4 V.

POWER DOWN RESET
The RESETIN\ signal from U7-6 will become active when the +5 V signal
< 4.4 V.
CLOCK
U6 is a 24 MHz oscillator and provides a clock signal to U8-10 and U5-22 (CLKIN).
The CPU internally uses a divide-by-2 clock function to produce a 12 MHz CPU
clock.  The CPU uses this clock signal to generate internal timers.
MEMORY
U9 (Low byte) and U10 (High byte) together form a program memory consisting of
256 K bytes of Sector Erase Flash Memory, and U11 (low byte) and U12 (high byte)
together is a data memory of 256 K bytes of RAM.  The EPROM is addressed at
F0000 to FFFFF and the RAM is addressed at 00000 to 3 FFFF.   UCS selects
EPROM addresses and LCS selects RAM addresses.

6

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970 IB SAMPLEVIEW



ACTEL LOGIC FUNCTIONS (U5)

U5 has these interface logic functions:

1. Clock Generation
2. Mode2  Command / Data interface and Decoder
3. Mode2  Data out interface and Encoder
4. Mode5 Encoder / Interface
5. Mode7 Encoder / Interface
6. Multiplexed Data-Bus to CPU
7. Latched Address bus
8. Miscellaneous Logic

CLOCK GENERATION

U5 divides the 24 MHz clock signal (CLKIN) by 2 when JMP2 is installed on CLKSEL
(U5-91).
U5 then divides the 12 MHz clock signal by 3, 12, 24, 48, 64, 120, and 12000 to provide:

1. a 500 KHz clock for Mode 2 transmitter logic (U5 internal).
2. a 250 KHz clock signal for the Mode 2 receiver logic (U5 internal).

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970 IB SAMPLEVIEW



WTS INTERFACE (MODE 2, MODE 5)

Mode 2 Receive Command / Data: Mode 2 commands / data are sent from the surface
and transformer-coupled via T2 on the CPU board.  U2 converts line signals to TTL
levels. The equivalent of a 6408 Harris Manchester Encoder / Decoder has been
incorporated into Actel (U5).  U5 decodes this Manchester protocol data (MD2 UDI) and
converts the serial data to parallel data. U5 checks the received data for a universal
address 00 or tool address 5 D. If either address is received, interrupt M2 RXIRQ (INT1)
is sent to the CPU (U8) and the command is transferred to a buffer. M2 RXIRQ is reset by
the CPU after the command is read by the CPU. If data follows the WTS command,
interrupt M2 RXIRQ (INT1) is sent to the CPU (U8) and the data is transferred to a
buffer. M2 RXIRQ is reset by the CPU after each data word is read.

Mode 2 Transmit Data: On receipt of a command from the surface to transmit data via
Mode 2 (Such as tool tables or tool status) the CPU enables interrupt INT2 (M2 TXIRQ)
and sends the requested data via the 16 bit data bus to U5, Mode 2 encoder logic.  U5
converts the data from parallel to serial format and the U5 6408 Harris Manchester
equivalent encoder, encodes MD2 BZO data and MD2 BOO data. Data is then sent to line
driver (U1).  Data is then transformer coupled to the WTS buss via T1.  Whenever the U5
data buffer is empty, U5 generates an interrupt (M2 TXIRQ); and the CPU sends the next
word.

Mode 5 DMA Control: The equivalent of a 6409 Harris Manchester has been
incorporated into Actel (U5) for Mode 5 data transmission. Mode 5 data is transmitted
using DMA channel 0 (DRQ0).  SMD57 DRQ (See Figure 945-5) selects which mode
will provide the DMA request.  When SMD57 DRQ is set to ‘0’ Mode 5 uses DMA
channel 0 controlled by MD57 DRQ.

Mode 5 Transmit Data: On receipt of a command from the surface to transmit Mode 5
data the CPU enables DMA channel 0 and writes the requested data via the 16 bit data
bus to U5, Mode 5 encoder logic.  The data is converted from parallel to serial format by
U5.  Serial data is received by the U5 6409 Harris Manchester equivalent encoder and the
encoded data (BZO5 and BOO5) is sent to line driver U3.  Mode 5 data is then
transformer coupled to the WTS buss via T3.  Whenever the data buffer is empty,
MD57 DRQ is active; and the CPU writes the next data word via the 16 bit data bus to
U5.
Transmission of data is currently used only when sending Subset E.

SYNCHRONOUS SERIAL TRANSMIT/RECEIVE LOGIC

The clock speed is set by firmware and currently 1 MHz is used throughout. Each of these
serial links has a transmit-frame sink (bgateout/TFS_x) for beginning and ending a
transmission, and a data transmit (bdataout/DT_x) line for transmission of data  (i.e.
tables, commands, etc.).  Each of these serial links also has a receive-frame sink
(bgatein/RFS_x) and a data receive (bdatain/DR_x) line for receiving data.


The CPU writes commands and data to U5’s two 8 bit latch’s via the data bus. Data is
converted to the serial format using the 1 MHz SCLK and two 8 bit shift registers.
Bgateout\ is active low, and bdataout  is the serial data signal.  Data is shifted out on the
positive edge of BSCLK while BDATAOUT is low.  STXDRQ (DRQ3) becomes active
whenever the output latch is empty.

10

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970 IB SAMPLEVIEW





2.  On the next positive-going edge of the serial clock (SCLK), the transmit frame sync
(TFS_X) goes low.
3.  On the next negative-going edge of the SCLK, shift / load goes high and data word
number 1 bit 16 is shifted out.  Shifting continues on each SCLK positive going edge
thereafter.
4.  DMA request for data word number 2.
5.  Data word number 2 is loaded into the latch.
6.  On the positive going edge of the SCLK (Bit #1), the shift register is loaded with data
word number 2.
7.  On the next positive going edge of the SCLK, data word number 2 bit 16 is shifted
out.  Shifting continues on each SCLK positive going edge.
8.  DMA request for data word number 3.
9.  Data word number 3 is loaded into the latch.
10.  On the positive going edge of the SCLK (Bit #1), the shift register is loaded with data
word number 3.
11.  On the next positive going edge of the SCLK, data word number 3 bit 16 is shifted
out.  Shifting continues on each SCLK positive going edge.
12.  End of data transmission.

11

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970 IB SAMPLEVIEW



SYNCHRONOUS SERIAL RECEIVE CHANNEL 1

The serial data of is shifted into two 8-bit serial-in, parallel-out shift registers on the
positive edge of BSCLK when BGATIN frame signal is active (high).  The Actel (U5)
inverts the data before it is shifted into the shift registers. A 16 bit counter and flip flop
are used to latch the data into two 8-bit latches.  The flip flop is also used to indicate to
the CPU that data has been received (S1 RXDRQ).  The flip flop is reset when the CPU
reads the data.  The S1 RXDRQ signal is connected to the CPU DRQ1 signal.

serial clock (SCLK).
2.  Data is shifted into shift registers on each positive going edge of the SCLK.
3.  After the 16th SCLK positive going edge, data word number 1 is latched and a DMA
request (SxRXDRQ) is initiated.
4.  Data word number 1 is read from the latch by the CPU and stored into memory.
5.  After the 32nd SCLK positive going edge, data word number 2 is latched and a DMA
request (SxRXDRQ) is initiated. RFS_x goes low ending the transmission.
6.  Data word number 2 is read from the latch by the CPU and stored in memory.

NOTE: When reading data from synchronous serial channel 2 AD2 is high, AD1
and AD3 are low.

12

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                          1970 IB SAMPLEVIEW




LATCHED ADDRESS BUS

Two eight bit latches and three single bit latches, latch address MA0 to MA18 when ALE
signal is high.

SCOPE


This procedure applies to all personnel who perform maintenance on the tool, whether in Houston

or in the field.

REFERENCE


130949-855
1970 IB Assembly/Disassembly Procedures

130949-856
1970 IB Manufacturing Assembly and Checkout Procedures 
SAFETY PRACTICES


The SAMPLEVIEW section weighs over 250 pounds. When lifting the tool, always get adequate
assistance from your co-workers. Use a hoist when appropriate. Use safe lifting techniques to avoid
back strain and injury to fingers.


If the tool is flooded, avoid releasing pressure accidentally and protect eyes from spray or steam jets.
If internal pressure must be vented, remove the retaining ring and slowly back off the relief plug. The
exhaust will exit the tool through a small hole in top sub.


If the UV light package is present in the detector assembly, do not look directly at the light.
See Section 5.0.


When the tool is connected to high voltage supply, take suitable care to avoid shock. Only qualified
technicians and engineers are allowed to work on the tool when powered.


If running the SAMPLEVIEW in lab in conjunction with the rest of the RCI string, refer to the specific
procedures and OTB=s related to RCI safety.

UV EYE SAFETY


The 1970 IB SampleView uses ultraviolet LEDs of peak wavelength, 395 nm.  Intensity drops to 50%
of peak by 374 nm and 414 nm.  For reference, the color violet is roughly 400 - 425 nm.


Each TO-18 package contains 9 UV LEDs, each of which has an intensity of 2.5 mW, so each TO-18
generates 22.5 mW of light.  The 1970 IB SampleView has two TO-18 cans containing a total of 18
UV LEDs generating 45 mW of UV light.  With the 1970 IB housing removed, two long cover plates
can be seen on the chassis.  Some UV light may leak around these long cover plates even though they
remain in place, which is why UV safety glasses or a UV-opaque chassis cover are required when
the housing is removed and power is applied to the tool. By design, if these cover plates are
removed from the chassis, no electrical power will go to the UV lights.

2


1970 IB SAMPLE VIEW



____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

CONFIDENTIAL                                            130949-954 DRAFT
OCTOBER 2005







WARNING:
Do NOT look at these LEDs when they are turned on!





They can damage eyes even with brief exposure!


Although they are BRIGHT, you cannot tell that they are bright because your eyes can only barely
see their light, if at all (bright UV LEDs are used because crude oil fluorescence is weak).




If the 1970 IB SampleView is powered with its housing removed:



UV Safety Glasses should be worn or cover the chassis with a UV-blocking material



Post UV Warning Signs for Any People Passing By.


UV Safety Glasses (PN A2001852000) must be available at each base that is running SampleView
IB.   These glasses provide 6 powers of ten (a million-fold) reduction in UV light intensity.


UV Warning Signs (PN A1000689000) must be posted in areas where the tool might be run with its
housing removed to warn passers by.


An opaque cardboard tube (PN A2001854000) can be slipped over the UV light section of the
chassis to cover it.  Alternatively, Kapton film, which is yellow and absorbs UV light, can be draped
over the tool when the housing is off to protect people who are nearby.


A UV lab safety kit which contains these three items plus a UV light meter (PN A3000526000) has
been created, but as of the date of release of this manual this kit (PN A5000118000) had not been
released in SAP.  Order the above items separately.

topic: LAB SAFETY - 6.0 USE OF UV LIGHT METER (PN A3000526000)
chunk_text:
USE OF UV LIGHT METER (PN A3000526000)


The UV light meter can be used to check for UV light leakage around the protective cover plates. In
the experience of Engineering, such leakage is very minor (typically around 1 Lux).  Although this
meter is originally sold to measure visible light, we convert it to a UV meter by gluing a UV filter
over its photodetector.

Flip the meter’s main switch to the “Lux” position to turn it on.  More detailed manufacturer's
Operating Instructions are included with the meter.  For easier use, the sensor head can be detached
from the body of the meter.  Because standards regarding allowable 8-hour levels of UV exposure
are given in microwatts/cm2, each light meter is individually calibrated in Houston and a label is
attached to the meter, which gives its equation for converting from Lux to microwatts/cm2.  The
calibration equation varies from meter to meter.  A typical equation would be like the one below.

Microwatts / cm2  = 7.57 * Lux  – 21.19.


A UV light leakage check should be performed when the tool first arrives to verify the integrity of
the cover plates.  The check only needs to be performed occasionally (such as at each PM3)
thereafter.  It is performed with housing is removed and the tool powered up.  Check all around the
perimeter of the cover plates in a darkened room; hold the sensor head about 1 inch (2.5 cm) away
from the shield, with the detector facing the shield.  Readings should be below 25 Lux.  If they are

above this level, the cover isn’t fitting well because typical readings should be only 1 Lux.

3


1970 IB SAMPLE VIEW



____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

CONFIDENTIAL                                            130949-954 DRAFT
OCTOBER 2005


Make sure that the cover plates have the correct part number for SampleView 1970 IB and that they
are properly installed.  If the leakage problem persists, contact Engineering for further instructions.


The American Conference of Industrial Hygienists (ACGIH) is an association of health and safety
professionals dedicated to industrial hygiene, environmental, and occupational health and safety.
They are widely recognized for their Threshold Limit Values publications which list the TLV's®* for
over 700 chemical substances and physical agents.

The ACGIH publication "Ultraviolet Radiation: TLV® Physical Agents 7th Edition, 2001" lists 2882
microwatts/cm2 as the maximum allowable combined skin and eye exposure to 395-nm light over an
8-hour period.  Although 395 mm is our peak output wavelength, much of the output of the UV LEDs
in SampleView IB occurs at shorter wavelengths (deeper into the UV) than this peak.  At 375 nm,
these UV LEDs still produce about half of their peak light intensity.  Because shorter-wavelength
UV light is more damaging than longer-wavelength UV light, less exposure is allowed.  The allowable
8-hour combined skin and eye exposure level to 375 nm light is 1354 microwatts/cm2.

For a given number of microwatts/cm2, the corresponding Lux reading will vary from meter to meter.
It can be calculated from the conversion equation label that is placed on each meter.  As an
easy-to-remember guideline, which requires no calculations, we can use the Lux reading of the least
sensitive meter that we calibrated (the one that gave the lowest Lux readings for a given number of
microwatts/cm2).  For that meter, we found that 2882 microwatts/cm2 corresponded to 305 Lux and
that 1354 microwatts/cm2 corresponded to 145 Lux.

Therefore, as a worst case scenario guideline involving making measurements with a lower
sensitivity meter and assuming that all of the light is at the more-damaging shorter wavelength of 370
nm, a very cautious maximum Lux reading for allowable 8-hour exposure is:







145 Lux

We believe that this is a cautious guideline because if we take the UV meter outdoors in bright
sunlight, we usually get readings in excess of 1500 Lux, which is more than ten times greater than
145 Lux.






* TLV is a registered trademark of the American Conference of Industrial Hygienists (ACGIH)

Overview 
Introduction 
The In-Situ Fluid Explorer (IFX) is a near-infrared analyzer module, continuous refractometer 
and fluorescence analyzer module for complete downhole fluid characterization. It also measures 
downhole fluid density and fluid viscosity using a (small) piezoelectric tuning fork sensor.  
The in-situ fluid explorer (IFX) is a module that is run in conjunction with the RCI/RCX wireline 
formation tester. Its primary purpose is to monitor, in real time, the formation fluid that the 
RCI/RCX is pumping from the wall of the well, especially in those wells drilled with oil-based 
mud (OBM). Optimal use of all the sensors in the IFX would ensure the collection of low-
contamination samples, which are needed to get good accuracy from subsequent PVT analysis of 
the collected samples. 
Theory of Operation 
The tool has three primary sensors: the optical fluid analyzer, the tuning fork and the acoustic 
transducer. The last two sensors are located in the SampleView Sample Tube (SST). Below is a 
brief description of the theory of operation of these three sensors. 
Optical Fluid Analyzer 
This consists of: 
• 
A visible and near-infrared fluid analyzer with 19 optical channels. These channels are 
closely spaced over the highly absorbing asphaltene region of the spectrum — the region 
most often used to monitor contamination levels.  
• 
Refractometer. The IFX tool provides a Continuous Refractometer to measure the 
fraction of light, R, reflected at the Sapphire-Fluid interface. The measured value of R 
will determine the refractive index, n. The value of n can help to distinguish between gas, 
water and oil. It provides an effective tool to monitor sample contamination and clean-up. 
Figure 1 uses the equation R = (1– nF/nS)2 / (1+nF/nS)2 to plot the percentage of light 
reflected from a sapphire-fluid interface versus the fluid’s refractive index (nF). Note that 
the minimum reflection (0%) occurs when the fluid’s refractive index exactly equals the 
sapphire window’s refractive index (nS = 1.746). 
• 
Fluorescence Spectrometer. Fluorescence is the emission of longer wavelengths of light 
when a sample is illuminated by shorter wavelengths of light. A 400 nm light (which is at 
the borderline between ultraviolet and visible) is used and the emitted fluorescence is 
measured at the visible colors — blue, green, yellow, red and deep red. All crude oil 
fluoresces, but synthetic oil does not fluoresce. Therefore, fluorescence is an alternative 

DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE  
 
1970 IC IFX 
 
P/N 130999-935  
DECEMBER 2011 
 
Figure 1 – Refractometer Calculation of the Fluids 
Refractive Index 
 
Figure 2 – Fluorescence Showing 
Sample Cleanup 
 
The vertical axis on the spectral plot shown in Figure 3 is Optical Density (OD), which is a 
logarithmic scale. One OD = 10 db is a 101 or 10-fold reduction in light intensity at that 
color. Two OD = 20 db is a 102 or 100-fold reduction in light intensity, and so on. 
Spectroscopists use OD, which is also called absorbance, because the concentration of an 
absorbing species is proportional to its absorbance for a fixed path length. This tool has a 
2 mm path length cell. 
 
Figure 3 – Spectral Plot Showing Optical Density of Heavy Crude 
 
The Optical Fluid Analyzer provides real-time: 
• 
Near-infrared spectra of the fluid that the RCI is pumping from the formation. By 
monitoring its response, one can ensure that samples are at a minimum contamination 
level. Figure 3 is an example of a spectrum of heavy crude.  
• 
Fluorescence spectra characterize crude oil present in the IFX cell. The temporal response 

DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE  
 
1970 IC IFX 
 
P/N 130999-935  
DECEMBER 2011 
• 
Refractive index, n, provides fluid identification and an alternative cleanup monitor (see 
Figure 4). 
The combination of visible and near-infrared spectrometer, continuous refractometer and 
fluorescence models enables the user to assess the fluid clean-up in a wide variety of 
formation fluids and borehole fluid situations. 
 
Figure 4 – Plot of Refractive Index 
Tuning Fork 
The tuning fork sensor, located in the SampleView Sample Tube (SST) is immersed in the 
downhole fluid. The resonant frequency of the tuning fork is a function of the fluid density; it 
decreases with denser fluid density. Fluid viscosity is a complex function of the real and 
imaginary impedance of the fork and the resonant frequency. The ratio of the applied voltage 
to the in-phase and out-of-phase current through the sensor gives the impedance of the sensor 
in the fluid.  
Thus the real impedance would be the ratio of the applied voltage to the in-phase current, 
while the imaginary impedance would be ratio of the applied voltage to the out-of-phase 
current.  The impedance of the sensor is determined for a range of frequencies.  
Below is a plot of the admittance (reciprocal of impedance) versus frequency. In the figure 
below, the real admittance curves are plotted with solid lines, while the imaginary curves are 
plotted with dashed lines. From right to left, the admittance curves are tuning fork admittance 
measured in air, oil and water respectively. The resonance peak corresponds to the amplitude 
or peak of the real admittance curve. This peak moves further to the left with increasing fluid 
density. The imaginary admittance curve appears to the left of the real admittance curve. 
Increasing fluid viscosity dampens the motion of the fork and reduces the amplitude of the 
resonance peak, increasing the width between the real and imaginary admittance curves. Plots

Acoustic Transducer 
The IFX also measures speed of sound through the downhole fluid in the SampleView 
Sample Tube (SST). The acoustic transducer is located on a flat spot on the SST. The 
downhole fluid flows between two parallel surfaces machined inside the SST. The transducer 
is acoustically coupled to the SST and is excited to produce an acoustic pulse.  
The same transducer is also used to receive the echoes of the acoustic pulse. The response is 
digitized at 40 MHz (25 ns) and the responses are plotted as channels with respect to time. 
The very first peaks (channels 0–50) corresponding to the excitation pulse might not be 
displayed, depending on the setup.  
Next are the reverberations of this acoustic pulse within the SST wall, with each 
reverberation amplitude declining with time. The first group of reverberations is the reflection 
inside the SST close to the transducer. The second group of reverberations is from the far wall 
of the SST. Sound speed can be calculated by dividing the round-trip distance by the round-
trip time. Water has higher sound speed (shorter round-trip travel time) than does oil. As 
pressure increases, the sound speed increases, so the round-trip travel time gets shorter (see

topic: Lab Safety - 6.0 USE OF UV LIGHT METER (PN A3000526000) LAB SAFETY
chunk_text:
USE OF UV LIGHT METER (PN A3000526000) 3
LAB SAFETY

1970 IC IFX


P/N 130999-954
NOVEMBER 2011

The UV light meter can be used to check for UV light leakage around the protective cover plates.
In the experience of Engineering, such leakage is very minor (typically around 1 Lux).  Although
this meter is originally sold to measure visible light, we convert it to a UV meter by gluing a UV
filter over its photodetector.
Flip the meter’s main switch to the “Lux” position to turn it on.  More detailed manufacturer's
Operating Instructions are included with the meter.  For easier use, the sensor head can be
detached from the body of the meter.  Because standards regarding allowable 8-hour levels of UV
exposure are given in microwatts/cm2, each light meter is individually calibrated in Houston and a
label is attached to the meter, which gives its equation for converting from Lux to
microwatts/cm2.  The calibration equation varies from meter to meter.  A typical equation would
be like the one below.

Microwatts / cm2  = 7.57 * Lux  – 21.19.


A UV light leakage check should be performed when the tool first arrives to verify the integrity
of the cover plates.  The check only needs to be performed occasionally (such as at each PM3)
thereafter.  It is performed with housing is removed and the tool powered up.  Check all around
the perimeter of the cover plates in a darkened room; hold the sensor head about 1 inch (2.5 cm)
away from the shield, with the detector facing the shield.  Readings should be below 25 Lux.  If
they are above this level, the cover isn’t fitting well because typical readings should be only 1
Lux.

Make sure that the cover plates have the correct part number for IFX 1970 IC and that they are
properly installed.  If the leakage problem persists, contact Engineering for further instructions.

The American Conference of Industrial Hygienists (ACGIH) is an association of health and
safety professionals dedicated to industrial hygiene, environmental, and occupational health and
safety.  They are widely recognized for their Threshold Limit Values publications which list the
TLV's®1

The ACGIH publication "Ultraviolet Radiation: TLV® Physical Agents 7th Edition, 2001" lists
2882 microwatts/cm2 as the maximum allowable combined skin and eye exposure to 395-nm
light over an 8-hour period.  Although 395 mm is our peak output wavelength, much of the output
of the UV LEDs in IFX IC occurs at shorter wavelengths (deeper into the UV) than this peak.  At
375 nm, these UV LEDs still produce about half of their peak light intensity.  Because shorter-
wavelength UV light is more damaging than longer-wavelength UV light, less exposure is
allowed.  The allowable 8-hour combined skin and eye exposure level to 375 nm light is 1354
microwatts/cm2.
for over 700 chemical substances and physical agents.

For a given number of microwatts/cm2, the corresponding Lux reading will vary from meter to
meter.  It can be calculated from the conversion equation label that is placed on each meter.  As
an easy-to-remember guideline, which requires no calculations, we can use the Lux reading of the
least sensitive meter that we calibrated (the one that gave the lowest Lux readings for a given
number of microwatts/cm2).  For that meter, we found that 2882 microwatts/cm2 corresponded to
305 Lux and that 1354 microwatts/cm2 corresponded to 145 Lux.

Therefore, as a worst case scenario guideline involving making measurements with a lower
sensitivity meter and assuming that all of the light is at the more-damaging shorter wavelength of
370 nm, a very cautious maximum Lux reading for allowable 8-hour exposure is:


1 TLV is a registered trademark of the American Conference of Industrial Hygienists (ACGIH)

4

145 Lux

We believe that this is a cautious guideline because if we take the UV meter outdoors in bright
sunlight, we usually get readings in excess of 1500 Lux, which is more than ten times greater than
145 Lux.

A. IFX CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS 
 
The IFX instrument acquires signals from 24 photo diodes, 2 temperature probes, and several 
miscellaneous voltages and currents. Power is provided from standard 180vac WTS power. 
Separate voltages are generated for electronic operation and the lamp driver. Furthermore, on 
instrument power up only the electronic power is applied. Lamp power is disabled. 
 
The IFX 1970 IC electronics consists mainly of the following sections. 
 
Power Supply 
Receiver cards A, B, C 
Lamp Driver card 
Preamp cards A, B 
PULSER/MOTOR CONTROLLER  
CPU with SINGLE ETHERNET 
Triggered Tuning Fork Sound Speed Interface board  
Tuning Fork Impedance board 
Hall Effect board 
 
B. POWER SUPPLY (F197430-000) 
 
There are two independent power supplies in the IFX tool. The main power supply provides all 
of the operating voltages for the acquisition electronics and is operational whenever tool power 
is applied. The lamp power supply provides power for the bulbs and the filter wheel stepper 
motor and Sound Speed transducer. 
 
The main supply consists of power transformer T1, rectifiers BR1 & BR2, filter chokes L1 and 
L2, and the main regulator board. Output voltages available are +5 D, +5 A, and -5 A and are 
easily measured at the terminal post buss. 
 
The lamp supply consists of power transformer T2, filter choke L3, and a capacitor filter board 
that also contains the rectifier diodes. When instrument power is applied the lamp power will be 
zero. Upon initializing lamp power with the proper software command the CPU will energize 

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS 
1970 IC IFX 
 
P/N 130999-945 
NOVEMBER 2011 
C. RECEIVER INTERFACE (F194851-000) 
 
1. Introduction 
 
The receiver card is designed to individually acquire and process 8 analog channels. Each 
channel contains a differential amplifier front end, a D/A Converter for offset control and 
eight 24 bit sigma-delta A/D converters with an input range of -3 to +3 V. The present IFX 
tool uses 3 receiver cards totaling 24 analog channels. 
 
2. Circuit Description 
 
Each card has its own power on reset IC to reset the D/A and A/D converters. A 10 MHz 
oscillator is used to provide a clock for the A/D, FPGA, and D/A. A single Actel chip 
provides a Synchronous Serial Interface to the CPU card as well as all state machine timing 
and control for each of the A /Ds. A common Sync line is provided by the CPU to each of 
the receiver cards and subsequently to each of the A/Ds. It is important that all of the 
internal clocks on the 24 A/Ds are synchronized so that transmission of data to the CPU 
does not “time out”. 
 
Each of the 3 receiver cards is identical and can be readily swapped with each other. 
Address selection jumpers are installed on each of the chassis connectors and are read by 
the card during power up. Digital inputs to each card are buffered by a 74 HC04 hex 
Schmidt trigger. Outputs are driven by an octal 74 HC244 line driver. Communication to the 
CPU is through a synchronous serial protocol consisting of a common clock and individual 
Tx and Rx data lines. 
 
Eight sigma-delta A/Ds are used to synchronously acquire the input signals. Each A/D 
converter has 2 channels. Channel 1 is connected to the output of its corresponding 
differential amp and represents the Voltage produced by the photo diode. Channel 2 is 
connected directly to the output of its corresponding D/A, and is used in test mode. 
 
Eight D/A converters are provided and are configured to inject a DC offset voltage into its 
respective input amplifier. This injected voltage is used in two ways. First in “test mode” 
this voltage is sampled by channel 2 of its corresponding A/D and is used to trouble shoot 
or verify A/D operation. Second, in “log mode” this voltage “bucks out” any negative 
offset present at each photo diode, especially, at higher temperatures.  
 
The command and data protocol can be found in the WTS Firmware Specifications 
document (P/N 194898-000) 
 
 
 
 
 
4 
 
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS 
1970 IC IFX 
 
P/N 130999-945 
NOVEMBER 2011 
D. MULTI LAMP INTERFACE (A3002241-000) 
 
1. Introduction 
 
The lamp driver card has the capability to selectively drive four lamps with up to 1.5 Amps 
@ 8 V and two UV LEDs.  The present IFX tool has two lamps but only one lamp is 
illuminated at a time. The third lamp driver circuit drives an Ultra violet Light Emitting 
Diode. The fourth lamp driver circuit drives a resistor load and is used to dynamically 
maintain a constant current load regardless of whether the bulb or the LED is on or off. 
This “load balancing” is necessary to maintain a constant cablehead voltage under the 
changing load conditions of the IFX. When the bulb and the UV LED are off, the resistor 
load shunts the current that previously went to the bulb. When a lamp is fully ON, the 
resistor load will be supplied minimum current. Similar load balancing is executed when 
the UV LED is ON.  
 
An interlocking protection circuit is incorporated in the UV LED drive circuit to protect the 
user from UV radiation. Hall Effect device assembly 198190-000 sense the presence of the 
top, A3000215-000 and bottom A3000216-000 covers and enable the lamp driver circuit to 
power the UV LEDs. The drive circuit will also be disabled if there is break in the wiring to 
the Hall Device assembly from the lamp driver card.  
 
2. Circuit Description 
 
Address selection jumpers are installed on the chassis connector and are read by the card 
during power up. Digital inputs to the lamp driver card are buffered by a 74 HC04 hex 
Schmidt trigger. Outputs are driven by an octal 74 HC244 line driver. Communication to the 
CPU is through a synchronous serial protocol consisting of a common clock and individual 
Tx and Rx data lines. 
 
A single Actel chip provides a Synchronous Serial Interface to the CPU card as well as all 
state machine timing and control to each of the A /Ds. A common Sync line is provided by 
the CPU to the lamp interface card and subsequently to each of the A/Ds. It is important 
that all of the internal clocks on the five A/Ds are synchronized so that transmission of data 
to the CPU does not “time out”. 
 
The analog section has four D/A converters that set the current to each lamp. Each of the 
A/D converters measures the voltage and current on its respective lamp. Channel 1 of each 
A/D measures voltage and channel 2 measures current. One additional A/D is provided and 
configured to measure the temperature. Temperature from a probe embedded into the 
preamp box is sampled on channel 1. Channel 2 converts the temperature from a probe 
mounted adjacent to the Sound speed transducer. 
 
The command and data protocol can be found in the WTS Firmware Specifications 
document (P/N 194898-000)

E. IFX PREAMPLIFIER (A3000412-000 &A3000413-000) 
 
1. Introduction 
 
The preamp board is designed to convert the photocurrent produced by each of the light 
sensitive diodes to a voltage. There are 12 identical preamplifier circuits on each of the 2 
preamp boards (preamp A & B). Each circuit however, has its own unique gain. The gain is 
selected by the value of feedback resistor chosen. The value of the feedback resistor for 
each preamplifier depends upon the type of diode, light input with respect to wavelength 
and responsivity of the diode at its operating wavelength.  
 
Each diode is wired using a shielded twisted pair wire with a molded connector. The anode 
and cathode of the diode are connected between the two wires of the twisted pair with the 
shield left open at the diode end. The shield at the connector end is connected to AGND 
(±5 V Return). The Preamplifier box is isolated from the main instrument chassis, then 
connected to AGND by an external wire. This keeps all the diode bodies at GND potential. 
 
2. Circuit Description: 
 
All 12 preamplifiers are identical so only one preamplifier channel will be described. 
Consider channel 10. The diode is connected between two amplifiers, sections A & B of U1 
in such a way that there is zero voltage across the diode. The light on the photo diode will 
generate a current that is converted to a voltage by each amplifier (photocurrent * Feedback 
resistor). The output of each amplifier is connected to a Differential Instrument Amplifier. 
The output of the first amplifier will be positive while the other one will be negative. The 
output of both amplifiers is summed at the differential amp. The output will be negative 
because of the polarity of the diode connections. 
  
Each of the input opamps will have a slight input offset voltage. The difference between the 
voltages will be seen across the diode and will generate a small current. Due to the high 
resistance (1500 G OHMS) of the diode at room temperature this current will be negligible. 
This current will increase as temperature increases due to change in resistance of the diode 
and input offset voltage of the amplifiers. The difference in the bias currents of the two 
amplifiers will increase as temperature increases. But, since they are fed into opposite 
polarities of the differential amplifier they will cancel. The currents are produced even

F. IFX CPU/W SINGLE ETHERNET (A3000866-000) 
 
1. Introduction 
 
The IFX CPU with SINGLE ETHERNET is the main CPU board for the 1970 IC Sample 
View instrument.  It is capable of emulating the 1970 IB CPU board with many added 
features.  It provides the WTS instrument Buss interface and the Synchronous Serial Buss 
used to communicate with the 24 optical A/D channels and 5 channels of the Lamp driver 
board.  It also controls the stepper motor drive for the optic filter wheel.  Features available 
on this CPU board include two RS-232 level asynchronous serial ports, a 10baseT Ethernet 
port and a 16 bit parallel bus port for multiple peripheral connections.

1970 IC IFX 
 
P/N 130999-945

2. Circuit Description Boot-up 
 
The CPU is clocked from a 40 MHz oscillator multiplied internally to run the core at 120 
MHZ. The external data bus runs at 40 MHz.   The executable firmware resides in a 256 K 
byte flash memory (128 K by 16 bit).  At boot up, the CPU transfers the executable from 
flash to the 256 K byte SRAM (64 K by 32) for faster execution. At boot up, the CPU 
performs several self tests prior to execution of the IFX code.  The progress of the boot up 
is reported on RS-232 (0 or 1?) serial port.  At boot up the CPU commands the Ethernet to 
request an IP address from a DHCP server.  If the tool is not connected to a DHCP server 
then the request times out and a default IP address is assumed.  The active IP address is 
reported to the RS-232 port. Some troubleshooting utilities reside in the firmware 
accessible by pressing the shift and T key on a terminal emulator connected to the RS-232 
port.  The Rs232 port is configured as 19.2k baud, 8 data bits, 1 stop, bit no parity and “no 
handshake”. 
 
3. Power 
 
The CPU power requirements are +3.3volts for the I/O and 1.8 volts for the core.  On 
power up the 2 supplies must come up together with the 1.8 supply never exceeding the 3.3 
as they ramp up to prevent gate latch up in the CPU.  The Sample View power supply only 
provides a +5 supply voltage therefore on board linear regulators derive the necessary 
voltages locally for the CPU and the Actel FPGA.  The +3.3volt digital logic supply is 
derived by a resistor divider network across the +5 volt supply, buffered by op amp U27 
driving series pass element FET Q1. The 1.8 volt CPU core supply is derived by a resistor 
divider network across the +5 volt supply, buffered by op amp U29 driving series pass 
element FET Q3.  Since its reference is from the 3.3 volt supply it should never exceed the 
3.3 volt at ramp up. The diode network of D5, D6, D7 limit the voltage separation during 
ramp up and diode D12 force them to track each other during power down.  The 2.5 volt 
Actel core supply is derived from a resistor divider network across the +5 volt supply, 
buffered by op amp U28 driving series pass element FET Q2.  The +5 volt supply, +3.3 
volt supply and the 1.8 volt supply are monitored by supply supervisor U1 to provide reset 
to the CPU. 
 
4. Reset 
 
The CPU requires its internal PLL time to stabilize before the boot up process begins. The 
CPU must be clock for a minimum of 2 clock cycles before the CPU reset input is released.  
The RESET OUT (RSTO) of the CPU is release 50 clock cycles after CPU reset giving the 
internal PLL sufficient time to stabilize.  The RSTO output is used to hold the FPGA reset 
which holds the system reset.  During reset the Motorola 5407 CPU configures its initial 
operating conditions from data bus D0 through D7.  These data lines are driven by tri-state 
buffer U7 while RESET is active. The configuration jumpers JP1 through JP8 define the 
desired boot up operating conditions of the CPU.  These jumpers are presented to the CPU 
only during the reset condition.  These jumpers define the source of boot code, boot data 
width, number of wait states, clock scaling rates and programmable parallel port bits 
definition.  Standard configuration for this board is JP3 and JP5 shorted; JP1, JP2, JP4, JP6, 
JP7, JP8 are open.  This defines the boot source as 16 bit wide data from the flash memory 
address with 15 wait states, a clock scale of 3 X and the parallel port bits are programmed 
initially as inputs 
 
8 
 
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS 
1970 IC IFX 
 
P/N 130999-945 
NOVEMBER 2011 
5. Memory Map 
 
The Motorola 5407 has eight programmable Chip Select lines (CS0 through CS7).  CS0 is 
the global chip select used for the boot memory chip select with 15 wait states and Auto-
acknowledge.  The other chip selects must be programmed to define their address 
assignments.  This board uses CS0 as the chip select for the flash memory U6 (1 M by 16), 
CS2 is defined as the enable with auto-acknowledge for SRAM U7 (512 K by 32), CS6 is 
dedicated to the Ethernet controller with external acknowledge, and CS7 is dedicated to the 
FPGA with external acknowledge. The remaining Chip Select lines are not used.   
 
Chip selects configured for external acknowledge require a Transfer Acknowledge (signal 
TA) pulse to terminate the I/O cycle.  The CPU will hold the read or write I/O cycle active 
until the responding device acknowledges the data transfer by asserting TA active low.  An 
external acknowledge permits the I/O device to govern the I/O cycle termination timing.  A 
time out circuit in the FPGA monitors I/O cycles for CS6/ and CS7/ and TA.  If a TA does 
not occur in a reasonable time period then the time out circuit artificially generates TA to 
prevent I/O cycle hang up. The timeout period for the time out generated TA is 800 micro 
seconds. 
 
6. FPGA 
 
The ACTEL APA150 (U19) is the glue logic for the system. The FPGA is an “in circuit” 
programmable, flash memory base device.  Connector J9 is provided for programming the 
device. A significant portion of the devise logic is un-used.  It also contains dedicated 
memory modules that are not used at this time.  More features could be added in the future. 
Programming software, programmers and connection adapters are available from 
Actel.U19 contains status and configuration or control registers for each function designed 
into the FPGA.  The functions are Ethernet control decoding, Serial Bus control, Filter 
Wheel Motor control, Parallel port control, Interrupt multiplexer and mask register, Mode 2 
Manchester encoder, Mode 2 decoder, Mode 5 Manchester encoder and Mode 7 
Manchester encoder.  
 
Only Ethernet’s control functions are gated through the FPGA.  Ethernet data and 
addressing is directly from the CPU I/O bus. The Davicom DM9008 Ethernet controller 
was intended for the P.C. environment. It has individual read and write control lines, a high 
active reset and IRQ and a low active Address Latch Enable (ALE).  It also uses the signal 
IOCHRY (low active) to extend read and write I/O cycles to insure data transfer integrity.  
The Motorola 5407 has a single Read/Write line (high= read, low = write), a low active 
reset, IRQ, Chip Select and Address Strobe. The Motorola can use a pulsed input signal 
TA/ low active to indicate the transfer is complete.  The Ethernet circuitry in the FPGA 
translates the discrepancies in control functions between the two chips.  The CS6/ and 
Read/Write from the CPU are used to create a low active ALE/ and either ENET _RD/ or 
ENET_WR/.  The Ethernet chip asserts IOCHRDY low to extend the duration of the read 
or write cycle as needed to ensure data transfer. If IOCHRDY does not asset low or if it 
asserts low then returns high the logic causes TA/ to pulse low to the CPU to terminate the 
I/O cycle. The Ethernet controller is held reset by ENET_RST being forced high at power 
up.  The CPU will write to the control register to de-assert ENET_RST (low) after boot up 
is complete. The Ethernet IRQ signal is inverted and presented to the interrupt multiplexer 
and mask register in the FPGA. The firmware will command which IRQ signal will be used 

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS 
1970 IC IFX 
 
P/N 130999-945 
NOVEMBER 2011 
The Serial Bus is the CPU’s means of communicating with the optical functions of the IFX.  
The Serial Bus (S BUS) consists of a parallel to serial converter to transmit data and a serial 
to parallel converter to received data from the Lamp Driver, and A/D boards. The main 
clock is divided down to 1 MHz for the Serial Clock to the S Bus.  The SCLK signal is 
used for transmit and receive during optical data acquisition.  The signal SDATAOUT is 
the transmitted data and is framed by SGATEOUT.  The signal SDATAIN is received data 
and is framed by SGATEIN.   SCLK is gated off during Tuning Fork or Sound Speed 
acquisitions to reduce system noise on the low level analog signals. 
 
The Filter Wheel Motor is controlled through the S bus configuration register.  Three of the 
control bits in the register correlate to three signals MOTO1, MOTO2 and MOTO3.  The 
CPU writes to the SBUS configuration register setting or clearing the bits to sequence the 
signals to step the motor.  The micro switch on the Filter Wheel provides position feedback 
in the form of an INDEX signal.  The falling edge of INDEX is captured and synchronized 
with internal clocks to create an interrupt if enabled.  The input signal INDEX is the most 
significant bit of the S BUS status word

7. Parallel Port Control 
 
The Parallel Port is a custom 16 bit parallel interface creating a bus intended to facilitate 
the stacking of up to 7 peripheral printed circuit boards above and below the host CPU.  
The CPU board has a 50 pin connector on the top of the board and a 50 socket connector on 
the bottom of the board.  Each peripheral should have a similar connector and mounting 
hole configuration to accommodate stacking of boards.  The parallel bus can be extended 
with cables to adjacent chassis locations.  
 
The parallel port has three latched Chip Select signals (PPCS0, PPCS1 and PPCS2) to 
enable a peripheral to respond to the bus.  Each peripheral will compare the combination of 
Chip Selects to their on board address jumpers.  Only the peripheral with matching address 
jumpers can respond to bus cycles.  A Chip Select of ‘000” is reserved to provide an 
inactive bus.  The port also has five latched address lines (PPA0-PPA4) to select the target 
register or function in the selected peripheral. The chip selects and address signals remain 
active once latch until the CPU selects another peripheral. This permits the CPU to perform 
multiple reads or writes to a selected function with out having to readdress the function.  
The bus has individual read (PP_RD/) and write (P_WR/) control lines to define the 
direction in I/O cycles. Each I/O cycle must be terminated by an Acknowledge (T_ACK, @ 
TP43) from the responding peripheral.  If the peripheral does not provide the acknowledge, 
an internal “time out” circuit will provide an artificial acknowledge after 800 micro seconds 
and set a timeout flag in the status register.   
 
The port has three inputs for interrupts from peripherals.  The signals ATTEN1, ATTEN2 
and ATTEN3 are individual “wired OR’ signals each with a pull up resistor on the CPU 
board.  Each of the interrupt signals is captured on a falling edge and synchronized with 
internal clocks.  The latched interrupts are presented to a multiplexer and can be 
programmed to drive any of the 4 CPU interrupt signals (IRQ1, IRQ3, IRQ5 and IRQ7).  
The CPU has control over a MASK register to independently block interrupts from 
reaching the CPU board.  This allows the interrupt to be queued either in the peripheral or 
in the FPGA.  The CPU must clear the interrupt in the peripheral and in the MASK register.  
The CPU also has the ability to force any of the CPU interrupts active through an interrupt 
preset register.  
 
The FPGA also provides a parallel port reset (PP_RST/) to allow the CPU to reset the 
peripheral by setting the reset bit in the control register or to force the peripheral reset if the 
CPUs supervisor resets the system. 
 
8. M2 Decode 
 
The WTS Mode 2 Decoder mimics a Harris 6408 Manchester decoder and is completely 
contained in the FPGA. The UDI input is shifted in and decoded.  If the tool address field 
matches IFX address (5 D) then an interrupt is generated and the command is held in the 
M2 data register until the CPU can read the data.  The Manchester status (NVM, CDS, 
PARITY, BUSY etc.) is held in the M2 status register. The Mode 2 control register 

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS 
1970 IC IFX 
 
P/N 130999-945 
NOVEMBER 2011 
The Mode 2 Encoder mimics a Harris 6408 Manchester encoder and is completely 
contained in the FPGA.  The outputs signals BZO and BOO are present at Test Points TP3 
and TP4.  The encoder control register containing the Sync Select and speed select bits is 
shared with the encoder.  The CPU writes a word to the encoder.  The encoder will begin to 
transmit a Data Sync followed by shifting of the data out in Manchester format and attach a 
parity bit a the 40.1 KHz. 
 
9. M5 Decode 
 
The Mode 5 Manchester encoder mimics a Harris 6409 Manchester encoder and is 
completely contained in the FPGA. When the CPU writes to the Mode 5 data register. The 
encoder begins to output the preamble followed by the data word.  After each word is 
shifted out an interrupt is generated on the selected IRQ to alert CPU to write the next 
word.  The data continues to shift out as long as the CPU continues to write to the mode 5 
data register.  If the data register is allowed to empty the encoder will close the data frame. 
The outputs signals M5 BZO and M5 BOO are present at Test Point TP10 and TP11 
 
10. M7 Decode 
 
The Mode 7 Manchester encoder mimics a Harris 6409 Manchester encoder and is 
completely contained in the FPGA. When the CPU writes to the Mode 7 data register. The 
encoder begins to output the preamble followed by the data word.  After each word is 
shifted out an interrupt is generated on the selected IRQ to alert CPU to write the next 
word.  The data continues to shift out as long as the CPU continues to write to the mode 7 
data register.  If the data register is allowed to empty the encoder will close the data frame. 
The outputs signals M7 BZO and M7 BOO are present at Test Point TP14 and TP15. 
 
11. WTS Instrument Buss 
 
The 1970 IC Sample view is a WTS instrument and must conform to all WTS protocol.  It 
receives commands from Mode 2 and responses on Mode 2 and Mode 5.  The WTS MODE 
2 Command differential input is present at Test Point TP5 and TP6.  A Mode 2 Command 
receiver made up of modal transformer T2 and line receiver U16 convert the differential 
signal to singled ended, 3.3 volt level.  The received command is presented to Test Point 
TP7 and feed into the FPGA’s M2_UDI input. The Mode 2 decoder inside the FPGA 
decodes the address field and latches the command byte.  If the address field matches the 
tool address, the FPGA will interrupt the CPU on the programmed IRQ.  The CPU will 
read the received command from the FPGA and take the required action.  The tool can 
respond on MODE 2, Mode 5 and MODE 7.  The CPU would write 16 bit data to the Mode 
2 encoder in the FPGA (primarily Subset E responses). The encoder will generate the 
Manchester word (data sync, data and parity) and shift it out the FPGA on M2_BOO and its 
compliment M2_BZO.  These signals are present at Test Point TP3 and TP4 and to line 
driver U15.  Line driver U15 drives Mode 2 data transformer T1. The differential signal of

NOVEMBER 2011 
The 1970 IC usually returns data over the WTS bus using Mode 5.  The CPU will write to 
the Mode 5 encoder in the FPGA. The encoder generates the Sync then follows it with 
Manchester encoded data. The FPGA complimentary output signals M5_BOO and 
M5_BZO are presented to the test Points TP10 and TP11 and line driver U17.  Line driver 
U17 drives Mode 5 transformer T3. The differential signal of the MODE 5 instrument bus 
is present at test points TP8 and TP9. 
 
Mode 7 can be used to return Subset E or tool data. The CPU will write 16 bit words to the 
Mode 7 encoder in the FPGA.  The encoder generates the Sync then follows it with 
Manchester encoded data.  The FPGA complimentary output signals M7_BOO and 
M7_BZO are presented to the test Points TP14 and TP15 and line driver U18.  Line driver 
U18 drives Mode 7 transformer T4. The differential signal of the MODE 7 instrument bus 
is present at test points TP13 and TP3. 
 
12. S Buss 
 
The Synchronous Serial Buss provides communication link between the CPU board and the 
Optics Receiver boards and the Lamp Driver board. All data transfers are initiated by the 
CPU.  The CPU issues commands to the peripheral boards (receiver and lamp driver).  The 
peripheral boards respond by returning data, adjusting lamp current, or adjusting gain etc. 
Not all commands return data. This data bus is a 5 volt level signals that must be level 
shifted to 3.3 volt level for interfacing to the CPU FPGA.   
 
The serial communications link is based on SCLK, a continuous 1 MHz clock used to 
synchronize the transfer of data in each direction.  The data transfers are qualified with a 
framing signal to indicate when valid data is present on the data lines.  The signal DATAIN 
is a data line from the CPU to the peripheral board.  DATAIN is only valid when GATEIN, 
the framing signal associated with DATAIN, is active low.  The peripheral returns data by 
pulling GATEOUT low on a rising edge of SCLK and presenting data on DATAOUT.  The 
gate signal remains active for the duration of the data block transfer.   
 
The CPU initiates data transfers by issuing a command to the peripheral of interest (Optical 
receivers or lamp driver).  The CPU writes commands and data to the Actel FPGA (U19) 
via the data bus. Data is converted from parallel to the serial format using the 1 MHz SCLK 
and shift registers in the FPGA.  Data is shifted out on the positive edge of SCLK when 
GATEIN frame signal is active (low).  The 16 bit command word is contains address and 
command information.  Bits 15 down to 13 of the command word are the address of the 
peripheral of interest.  Bits 12 down to 8 make up the command to the addressed peripheral 
and bits 7 down to 0 are not used.   The command can be to set A/D gains, send data or 
adjust lamp power. The command could be a single 16 bit word or it could be multiple 16 
bit words.  In the case of multiple 16 bit words, the first word is the command and each 
additional word is data for the addressed peripheral. The responding peripheral performs
