13. Motor 
 
The MOTOR output signals along with INDEX input signal control the stepper motor on 
the optics filter wheel.  The three motor signals are pulsed in sequence to turn the filter 
wheel on command.  As the filter wheel rotates, a micro switch tracks the wheel edge.  The 
Index indentation on the filter wheel will open/ close the micro switch creating a pulse on 
the Index signal to the CPU to verify the wheel position.  The Filter Wheel is rotated to find 
the index at power up.  The filter wheel can be rotated on command for calibration 
purposes. The signals MOTO1, MOTO2 and MOTO3 from the FPGA are 3.3 volt signal. 
They are level shifted to +5volt and driven out by U22. 
 
14. Parallel Port 
 
The parallel port is a 16 bit bi directional tri state port capable of controlling up to 7 
peripheral devices. The port has 8 address lines from the CPU to the peripheral to facilitate 
selection of up to 7 peripheral devices each with 31 addressable registers for control or 
status. Three of the address lines (PPCS0, PPCS1 and PPCS2) are a qualifier to enable the 
selected device on the port (peripheral 1 through 7,  0 is reserved).  The remaining 5 
address lines (PPA0 through PPA4) are used to select the specific register in the enabled 
peripheral.  
 
The port has 3 interrupt request lines (ATTEN1, ATTEN2 and ATTEN3) to allow 
peripherals to interrupt the CPU. Each peripheral has a driver (open drain or tri state) 
connected in a “wired OR” capable of asserting an ATTTENx line (active low).  Each 
ATTENx line has a pull up resistor on the CPU board.  Logic in the FPGA capture the 
ATTENx inputs and under program control routes them to IRQ1, IRQ 3, IRQ5, or IRQ7 
output to the CPU.  The CPU can configure the FPGA to force the interrupt, or mask the 
interrupt allowing the interrupt to queue the interrupt. The CPU must service the peripheral 
to clear the interrupt from the device.   
 
The CPU writes to the parallel port register in the FPGA to select the specific peripheral 
and address a specific peripheral register.  This asserts the appropriate PPCS and PPA 
signals to enable the specified peripheral to communicate over the port.  The CPU can then 
read or write to the peripheral register with out having to re-address the register each cycle.  
The selected port remains enabled until the CPU addresses another peripheral.   Each I/O 
cycle to the parallel port is terminated with a Transfer Acknowledge (T_ACK at TP43) 
from the peripheral. The T_ACK from the peripheral is gated through the FPGA and 
returned to the CPU as TA.  If the peripheral fails to acknowledge the transfer, the FPGA 
will generate a false TA to the CPU after 800 micro seconds to allow the CPU to continue 
with program execution.   
 
The port has a reset line from the CPU to allow the CPU to execute a software reset of the 
all peripherals on the bus peripheral.  See port specification document number ***** for 
more detail

15. Ethernet 
 
The Ethernet interface on this board is primarily to interface with a P.C. for running 
Test/Calibration software.  The Davicom DM9008 (U13) is the Ethernet MAC and PHY in 
a single chip.  The CPU interface to the controller is designed for P.C. industry and 
operates on 5 volt logic. All interface signals must be level shift to interface with the 3.3 
volt logic.  The Motorola processor control signals to the Davicom are translated in the 
FPGA.  The CPU’s CS6/ enables the FPGA to convert Motorola’s single Read/ Write line 
to ENET_ALE and ENET_RD and ENET_WR to qualify the I/O transfers (all low active). 
Ethernet control register in the FPGA generates the high active ENET_RST.   These signals 
are level shifted from 3.3 volt level to +5 volt level by buffer U25.   
 
Address bits A1 through A4 and A6 are also level shifted by buffer U25. The address bit 
A6 is level shifted and renamed as EA0 (Ehernet Address 0) to allow a means for the 16 bit 
I/O of the Motorola to communicate with the byte oriented control registers in the Davicom 
DM9008. All odd byte addressed locations are offset by 64 address locations in the 
Motorola memory map.(i.e. Davicom register “0 F” is map to Motorola “2 E”)   
 
The Davicom 16 bit data bus interfaces to the Motorola CPU through bi-directional, level 
shifting, tri-state bus transceivers ( U23, U30).  The buffers are enabled when CS6/ is 
asserted low active. The direction of the buffer is controlled by ENET_RD. The signals 
CS6/ and ENET_RD are level shifted to +5 volts by buffer U24.  Some of the I/O cycles to 
the Davicom require more time to transfer data.  This transfer timing is governed by 
IOCHRDY output of the Davicom. IOCHRDY is a mechanism for the Davicom to extend 
an I/O cycle if needed.  If the Davicom needs more time to move data, it will assert 
IOCHRDY low until it has move the data.  The generation of TA to the CPU will be 
delayed until the IOCHRDY is asserted high.     
 
The Davicom is capable of interrupting the CPU by asserting the signal NET_IRQ high 
active.  The signal is level shifted from +5volts to +3.3 volts by U12 and routed to the 
FPGA for gating.  The FPGA can route the interrupt to any of the 4 IRQ signals to the CPU 
(IRQ1, IRQ3, IRQ5, and IRQ7). The Davicom requires a stable 20 MHz clock.  The main 
40 MHz oscillator is divided to 20 MHz by the FPGA then level shifted from 3.3 volts to +5 
volt by buffer U31 to clock the Ethernet controller.   
 
The physical layer is a designed to interface through 10baseT (10 mega bit, twisted pair).  
Transformers T5 and T6 are custom 1:1 transformers wound on a high temperature toroid 
core.  
 
At boot up the CPU commands the Ethernet to request an IP address from a DHCP server.  
If the tool is not connected to a DHCP server then the request times out and a default IP 
address is assumed and reported to the RS-232 port

16. RS-232 Port 
 
The Motorola 5407 has two UARTS serial ports available.  These two ports interface to 
connector J2 through RS-232 driver / receiver U14 for voltage level translation.  An 
internal charge pump in U14 generates the positive and negative voltage required for RS-
232 voltage levels.   Serial port ‘0’ is used for debug messaging and accessing utility 
functions. The connection is intended for interface to a P.C. terminal emulator setup as 19.2 
KHz, 8 data bits, 1 stop bit, no parity and no handshake. The connector J2 is wired to allow 
cable to attach to either serial port by simply rotating the cable 180 degrees (cable pin 1 to 
connector pin 10 for port ‘1’ or cable pin 1 to connector pin 1 for port ‘0’).  Serial port ‘0’ 
reports events as the CPU boots up and reports received commands along with the response 
taken.  This port also provides access to some utility functions available to the CPU kernel.  
These utilities are remnants of development debug code but they can be helpful in 
troubleshooting.   
 
Serial port ‘1’ is used to communicate with the Dual Tuning Fork Impedance Analyzer 
Board (A3001762000).  This port is configured as 57.6 KHz baud rate, 8 data bits and 1 
Stop bit with no flow control. The CPU forwards WTS commands to the Impedance 
Analyzer Board using this serial port.  It also downloads Calibration data to the Impedance

G. TRIGGERED TUNING FORK & SOUND SPEED BOARD 
A3001505000 
 
1. General 
 
The Tuning Fork and Sound Speed Interface board provides a host CPU an interface to 
control the Tuning Fork stimulus frequency, selection and digitizing of the selected Tuning 
Fork and sequence of the charging, firing and digitizing of the Sound Speed.  This board 
stacks above the CPU board and connects through a 50 pin board to board connector J4 on 
the solder.  Power and analog signals interface through the 26 pin connector J1.  This board 
is powered by the tools +5 volt digital supply. The majority of the logic on this board runs 
on 3.3 volts. The Actel FPGA core runs on +2.5 volts.  A local regulator must regulate the 
+5 volt in down to 3.3 volts and +2.5 volt for the logic devices.

2. FPGA 
 
The Actel FPGA (U10) is the heart of the board. It is an “in circuit programmable” Actel 
APA150.  The FPGA controls data flow to the CPU interface, the output frequency of the 
DDS, sampling of the Tuning Fork A/Ds, charging of the Sound Speed high voltage, firing 
the Sound Speed transducer and sampling of the Sound Speed A/D.  The DDS interface to 
the FPGA is a synchronous serial interface.  The host CPU writes DDS data parallel to the 
FPGA and the FPGA shifts the data words out serially to the DDS.  
 
There are several state machines designed into the FPGA to control Tuning Fork and Sound 
Speed acquisition. The host CPU commands these processes through several control 
registers and status registers at unique addresses through the parallel interface.   One State 
machine controls the sequence of reading the TFTX A/D and the TFRX A/D and writing 
the data into individual 16 bit by 256 word FIFOs.   (this feature is not used when a Dual 
Tuning Fork Impedance Analyzer is installed). A set of nested state machines controls 
charging of the Sound Speed High Voltage and subsequent firing of the Sound Speed 
transducer and reading of Sound Speed A/D converter and writing of data into the 12 bit by 
1024 word Sound Speed FIFO. This state machine also controls the stacking of data for 
multiple firing sequences 
 
3. Parallel Port 
 
This interface to the CPU is defined in document ****.  It is a 16 bit parallel bus consisting 
of 16 bi-directional, tri-state Data lines with address and control lines.  The bus has three 
Board Select lines to enable the desired peripheral on the bus.  There are five Port Address 
lines to address functions within the enabled peripheral device.  There is a Read control 
input, Write control input and a Reset input from the host CPU. There are three IRQ 
outputs to interrupt the host CPU board.  There is a TA output signal as Transfer 
Acknowledge as a handshake to the host CPU to terminate I/O cycles.   
 
The Host CPU drives the Board Select line to match the Board Select jumpers (J1, J2, J3) 
to enable this board to respond to bus activity.  The Board Select lines are compared to the 
Board Select jumpers in the FPGA and Port Enable (TP2) is driven low to enable the data 
bus transceivers to pass data. The Port Address lines are driven to select function or register 
in the enabled board.  Then the host CPU will drive Write control line Low to write to the 
port or drive the Read control line low to read from it.  The Host CPU will hold the Read or 
Write control line active until a TA is returned or times out occurs at a maximum of 800 
micro seconds. The FPGA will generate a low active 25 nano second pulse on TA to 
acknowledge the data transfer and allow the CPU to de-assert the Write or Read to 
terminate the I/O cycle. The TA signal is “wire ORed” with any other peripheral on the bus 
and requires a pull up resistor. The host CPU should have a pull up resistor and all 
peripherals should not have a pull up resistor installed.  The Port Enable remains active 
until the host CPU de-asserts the Board Select signals. The host CPU can communicate

NOVEMBER 2011 
4. Sound Speed 
 
The Sound Speed measurement consist of “pinging” a 10 Mhz acoustic transducer attached 
to the sample line then digitizing the echoes through the fluid sample.  This apparatus 
“pings” the transducer by applying a 25 nano-second negative high voltage pulse to the 
transducer. This causes the transducer to ring at its resonant frequency of 10 Mhz.  The 
transducer ringing is then dampened by a 25 nano-second pulse to short the transducer to 
ground. The transducer serves as a receiver also.  The transducer’s output is amplified by a 
differential amplifier circuit on the PULSER/MOTOR CONTROLLER and digitized by a 
differential input, 12 bit, 40 mega sample per second A/D converter on the Tuning Fork 
Sound Speed Interface.  The 40 mega sample per second conversion rate is to fast for the 
CPU to read so the data is read by a state machine in the FPGA which stores the data in a 
12 bit by 1024 word FIFO inside the FPGA.  The FIFO accumulates a 25.6 micro second 
long digitized acoustic waveform for processing by the host CPU. 
 
When the host CPU initiates the Sound Speed acquisition, the sound Speed state machine in 
the FPGA controls the sequence of events to collect the data. The state machine first selects 
the High Voltage monitor as the source of data to the TFRX A/D converter to verify a 
consistent charge is present on the high voltage capacitor.  If the charge is below a 
threshold defined in the FPGA, then the charge cycle begins.  The FPGA will output a 93 
KHz square wave on the signal Trigger3.  This signal is supplied to the PULSER/MOTOR 
CONTROLLER to charge the high voltage capacitor. A divided sample of the capacitor 
charge is returned through HV_MON input to analog switch (U27) to the TFRX A/D 
(U18), read by the FPGA to regulate charge level.  Once the charge is at the desired 
threshold level or if the charge time exceeds 150 milliseconds (timeout), the FPGA 
discontinues charging and begins the fire cycle.  The FPGA clears the internal FIFO and 
starts the high speed A/D converter (U25).  Then the FPGA asserts Trigger1 for 25 
nanoseconds to “ping” the transducer and followed by asserting Trigger2 for 25 
nanoseconds to dampen the ringing of the transducer.  The Sound Speed A/D converter 
samples the transducer from the “ping” until the FIFO is full. The 1024 samples at 40 MHz 
yields a 25.6 microsecond long digitized waveform stored in the FPGA’s 12 bit by 1024 
word FIFO. The host CPU will retrieve the data via the parallel port. 
 
The Sound Speed has features available that permit fine tuning of the transducer firing 
pulse and improving signal to noise.  The duration of the Trigger1 and Trigger2 can be 
modified individually (4 steps, 25 naono-second increments ie, 25, 50, 75, 100) to optimize 
the energy exerted during the “ping”.  The signal to noise ratio is improved by stacking 
multiple firings per acquisition accumulated in the FIFO.   The acquisition cycle can be 
modified by issuing a WTS command 5 D90 with a parameter “WXYZ” from the 
Acquisition system ( Eclips or Tests System). The parameter value Y field represents 
Trigger1 duration and Trigger 2 duration in a binary form.  The most significant two bits of 
the field represent the fire duration and the least significant two bits of the field represent 
the dampen duration. (00= 25 ns, 01 = 50 ns, 10 =75 ns, 11= 100ns).   The parameter X 
field represents X+1 number of fire sequences stacked in the FIFO. The W field represents 
the delay between stacked firing in 8 microsecond increments.  The default parameter used 
is 0 F32 which represents 25 nanosecond ping, 75 nanosecond dampening, and 16 firings 
stacked ((F= 15 )+1) with minimum delay between firings. The Z field must be 2 to enable 
the Sound Speed FIFO.  The host CPU will send the parameter value to the Tuning Fork

5. Miscellaneous 
 
There are several miscellaneous circuits provide service to the design. A “zero crossing” 
detector (comparator U33) monitors the input of the TFTX A/D to provide a signal 
TF_TRIGGER to the FPGA. This provides a phase synchronized start point for the Tuning 
fork acquisition. This signal is not currently used by the FPGA.  The 2.5 volt Reference 
chip U16 provides the reference voltage and bias to the Tuning Fork A/Ds. These A/Ds 
have an input range of +/- 2.5 volts.  The IFX tool power supply only provides +5 volts yet 
much of the logic on this board runs on 3.3 volts.  The Actel core requires 2.5 volts.  The 
additional voltages are derived from the +5 volt on board by linear regulator circuits 
consisting of a voltage divider network, an op amp buffer and an FET series pass element.  
The 3.3 volt digital is regulated by U19 and Q1. The 3.3 volt analog supply for the high 
speed A/D is regulated by U24 and Q3.  The 2.5 volt is regulated by U21 and Q2. The 47 
uF capacitor on the output of the regulator must be of a LOW ESR type to reduce ripple on 
the supply output. The reset to the logic is provided by voltage monitor U23 which 
monitors the +5 volt, +3.3 volt and 2.5 volt supplies.  
 
H. PULSER/MOTOR CONTROLLER BOARD (F198200-000) 
 
1. Introduction 
 
The PULSER/MOTOR CONTROLLER is the interface from the digital controller to the 
analogue filter wheel motor and to the Sound Speed transducer. It provides the driver 
circuit to the motor, a high voltage charge circuit for Sound Speed, a trigger circuit and 
dampening circuit for Sound Speed firing, and an amplifier for the Sound Speed received 
signal. This board also passes LAMP power to lamp assembly.  
 
2. Filter Wheel 
 
The Filter Wheel Motor turns on command from the CPU board (p/n. A3000866000).  The 
CPU board provides three drive signals in sequence to step the motor, MOTO1, MOTO2, 
and MOTO3. These 5 volt level signals are received and buffered by U7.  The output of U7 
drives the gate of the FETs Q4, Q5 and Q6.  When the FET conducts, current is drawn 
through the windings of the motor. The diode and capacitor network between the Source 
and Drain of the FET is to suppress the reverse EMF induced by the motor winding when 
the FET turns off.  These three MOTO signals are pulsed in sequence to rotate the motor.  
An INDEX micro switch on the filter wheel provides an INDEX signal (connector P1-11) 
pulled up by resistor R31 (schematic sheet 2 B5) passed through this board back to the 
CPU board (connector P2-19) for position verification. 
 
3. Lamps 
 
Lamp #1 and Lamp #2 power is routed on traces -L1 / +L1 and -L2 / +L2 respectively.

4. Sound Speed 
 
The network of L4, L5, C4, D7, Q7 and associated resistors and capacitors make up a 
regulated +8 volt supply for the Sound Speed firing level shifters from the unregulated 
Lamp power supply.  
 
 The SOUND SPEED transducer is a 10 MHz acoustic transducer.  It requires a short 
duration, high voltage, fire pulse to emit acoustic energy into the sample line.  Then the 
acoustic echoes from the near wall to fluid interface and the fluid to far wall interface are 
reflected back and received by the same transducer.  The received signal is amplified and 
returned to the Tuning Fork / Sound Speed Interface board (p/n. A3001505000) for 
digitizing.  The Tuning Fork / Sound Speed Interface board has the ability to fire multiple 
times (1 to 16 firings without recharging C2) and stack the digitized data for better signal to 
noise ratio.  
 
When it is time to sample the Sound Speed, The Tuning Fork / Sound Speed Interface 
board will first charge the high voltage to by toggling the signal TRIG3 (3.3 volt level) at 
93 KHz.  The incoming square wave is level shifted from 3.3 volts to +5volts by U10 to 
drive the gate of Q1. Q1 pulses the unregulated lamp power (signal labeled +8 A) through 
the primary of transformer T1. The output on the secondary of T1 is rectified by the diode 
bridge made up of D14, D15, D16, and D17 to charge capacitor C2 to -175 volts dc. The 
charge voltage is divided by resistor network R1 and R2 to a level suitable for digitizing.  
The buffered signal (HVMON) is sent to the A/D converter on the Tuning Fork / Sound 
Speed Interface board.  Toggling of TRIG3 continues to charge capacitor C2 until it 
reaches -45 volts or 150 msec charge time is reached. Then it discontinues charging and 
begins the transducer firing sequence.  
 
Once capacitor C2 is fully charged or the 150 msec time out occurs,   the Tuning Fork / 
Sound Speed Interface board begins the fire sequence.  It provides a 25 nsec pulse to 
TRIG1 (P1-pin 5) to fire the transducer.  This pulse is level shifted from 3.3 volts to +8 
volts by U2 to the gate of Q2. Then Q2 turns on for 25 nsec to dump the charge from 
capacitor C2 through R10 to the transducer connected across J1 and J2.   Next, the Tuning 
Fork / Sound Speed Interface board will provide a 25 nsec pulse to TRIG2 (P1 pin 4), level 
shifted from 3.3 volts to +8 volts by U5 to the gate of Q3.  Q3 turns on for 25 nsec duration 
to dampen ringing in the transducer.  This produces a sharp, 10 MHz acoustic ring in the 
sample line and quietens the transducer in time to listen for the reflected echo through the 
fluid in the line.  The received echoes are amplified but U3 with a gain of 2 and driven out 
differentially by U4 to be digitized by a 40 Mega sample per second A/D converter on 
Tuning Fork / Sound Speed Interface board.  The digitized samples are stored in a FIFO for

I. 
DUAL TUNING FORK IMPEDANCE ANALYZER BOARD 
(A3001762000) 
 
1. Introduction 
 
The fluid density and viscosity measurements derived from the Tuning Fork are controlled 
by the Dual Tuning Fork Impedance Analyzer board. The Impedance Analyzer performs a 
sweep of a frequency range searching for the resonant response of the tuning fork. The 
density and viscosity can be determined from the from the peak frequencies of the real and 
imaginary curves. 
 
Two tuning fork assemblies, two Analog Devices AD5933 (U2, U3) Impedance Analyzer 
chips, a MicroChip PIC micro-controller (U1, PIC24 FJ128 GA006) and a RS-232 interface 
to the IFX CPU board make up the Dual Tuning Fork Impedance Analyzer. There are two 
tuning forks and two impedance analyzers for redundancy in the event a tuning fork is 
broken will logging. The PIC micro-controller communicates with each Impedance 
analyzer through individual I2 C serial interfaces. The PIC micro-controller acquires data 
from only one Impedance Analyzer chip at a time. 
 
2. Calibration Tables 
 
Each tuning fork is associated with two calibration tables stored in IFX CPU flash memory. 
These tables are unique to a specific, serial numbered Tuning Fork assembly.  The Tuning 
Fork calibration table 28 and acquisition table 38 are transferred to the Dual Tuning Fork 
Impedance Analyzer board during boot up. The PIC micro-controller has a default set of 
tables hard coded in its’ flash memory.  These are used  by the PIC micro-controller until 
communications with the IFX CPU is established and valid tables can be transferred to the 
PIC micro-controller RAM.  A total of 4 tables are transferred, tables 28 and 38  for Tuning 
Fork #1 and  tables 28 and 38 for Tuning Fork #2. 
 
3. Initialization and Start 
 
The PIC micro-controller must initialize each Impedance Analyzer chip with a Start 
Frequency, a Frequency Step size, number of steps, and a step dwell time.  These 
parameters are from Table 28 for calibration or table 38 for logging. Once parameters are 
established in the impedance analyzer chip, the PIC micro-controller tells the impedance 
analyzer to start.  The analyzer will generate a sine wave at the start frequency for the 
duration of the dwell time to stimulate the tuning fork while measuring the response of the 
tuning fork received signal.  The analyzer calculates a real and imaginary impedance value 
for the given frequency. The PIC micro-controller will read the real and imaginary values 
and store the values in a memory buffer.  Then the PIC micro-controller issues a command 
to the Impedance analyzer to step to the next frequency. The Impedance Analyzer generates 
the next frequency for the same dwell time while measuring the response. This sequence 
repeats for the predefined number of steps, building a response table held in a memory 

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS 
1970 IC IFX 
 
P/N 130999-945 
NOVEMBER 2011 
The IFX CPU forwards Impedance related WTS commands over the RS-232 to the PIC 
micro controller.  The PIC interprets the command and responds accordingly.  The PIC 
micro-controller has 128 K bytes of internal Flash memory and 8 K bytes of RAM. The 
response table is double buffered in RAM.  One buffer is used for accumulation of the 
response while the other buffer is available for transmitting to the IFX on request.  The PIC 
micro-controller switches buffers when the frequency sweep is complete.  Tuning fork 
calibration table 28 and acquisition tables 38 are stored in the flash memory.  The unique 
tables must be downloaded with data from calibration for each serialized tuning fork. 
 
4. Power and Signal Levels 
 
The Impedance Analyzer board is powered by the +5 volt digital supply of the tool.  The 
majority of the circuitry runs on a +3.3 volt supply locally generated by a Texas 
Instruments TPS62203 (U7) and filtered to create Vccd and Vcca. Vccd powers the digital 
section while Vcca powers the analog portion. U5 provides the Master Reset to the PIC 
micro controller on power up.  U4 is a precision, high temperature, 16 MHz oscillator to 
provide clocks for the PIC Micro Controller and the Impedance analyzer chips. The RS-232 
interface is a Maxim Max3222 (U6).  This device has an internal charge pump to translates 
the 3.3 volt level serial signals of the PIC micro –controller’s UART port to the +/- 10 volt 
level signal of the RS-232 signal to the IFX CPU.   DS1 is an LED to indicate power to the 
board.  
 
The board is power by +5 volts on terminal E4 with reference to E5.  
The RS-232 transmit is on E1 and receive signal is on E3 with reference to E2.   
J3 is used for in circuit programming and debug.  Tuning Fork #1 connects to terminal T1 
and R1 and Tuning Fork # 2 connect to T2 and R2. 
 
J. 
HALL EFFECT BOARD (A3003019000) 
 
1. Introduction 
 
The Hall Effect board provides an interlock for the UV lamp driver.  This is to protect 
personnel from exposure to the high intensity Ultra violet light source while servicing the 
tool.  The covers of the tool have magnets attached aligned with the Hall Effect sensor. Each 
board has Hall Effect sensor to sense the magnet on the cover.  Power for the sensor is +5 
volts and ground from the lamp driver board. The signal output is low when the covers are in 
place and high when the cover is removed. Each board has a pull up resistor and the lamp 
driver board has a pull up resistor on its input.  The two boards signal out are connected in a 
“wired or” configuration.  Any time a cover is removed the UV lamp driver is disabled.   
The UV lamp driver will be disabled if breaks in the wiring to the Hall Effect exist.

CALIBRATING THE 1970 IFX WITH THE ECLIPS SYSTEM 
 
Note: 
Calibration is invalid if any change is done to the preamp assembly or adaptor assembly. 
Overview 
The purpose of the 1970 IC optical calibration is to account for and then compensate any temperature drifts 
within the optical and supporting electronic circuitry, which could affect the ultimate accuracy of the 
measurement.  During the calibration run absolute readings from the individual photo diodes are measured at 
1°C intervals from 25°C up to 160°C.  Calibration can be terminated at any time before reaching 160°C. 
 
Note: 
ECLIPS requires a calibration range of at least 40 to 160° C.  Any calibration that does not have this 
minimum range will not be accepted by ECLIPS. 
 
The path through the optical sensor chamber during calibration must be completely clean, empty and DRY 
(contain only air).  As a result, the calibrated response of the tool in air should indicate a value of 0.0 ±0.05 
O.D. (optical density).  The temperature is measured internally to the 1970 IC with the probe located within the 
pre amplifier section of the tool.  The calibration data consists of both increasing and decreasing temperature 
runs. 
 
Both SAMPLE VIEW bulbs are calibrated across a range of temperature.  The goal is to sample the light and 
dark curve values across this range of temperature for both bulbs, and compute the difference at discrete 
temperatures and then use these results to calculate optical density for each channel.  Furthermore, the optical 
density for each channel may additionally be corrected for change in bulb intensity by using a multiplicative 
factor derived from a reference, channel 24.

_____1.   √  This is an example of a step that needs to be initialed in the PM-3 Verification 
Sheet. 
 
During the process of performing preventive maintenance, the PM-3 Verification sheets will 
require a description of the failures. The item or items being inspected could have different types of 
damage or irregularities. In helping to describe discrepancies the terms below can be used as 
reference. 
 
Mechanical: Radial scarring  
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something 
rotating in and out of a cavity. 
Longitudinal scarring  
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something 
dragging lengthwise 
Pitting/Crevice Corrosion  Usually associated with corrosion of some type where 
pits start to occur on the metal or surface coating. 
Flow cut/Jetting 
Usually associated with an area where a high flow rate 
of fluid causes metal to erode. 
Dents/dings  
Usually associated with an indentation in the metal that 
was caused by being dropped, hit, or mishandled. 
Scratch(es)  
Similar to scarring but grooves start to appear that are 
deeper and less frequent in number. Scratches are 
usually caused by abrasion. For example sand getting 
into a seal area or a steel pick used to remove an o-ring. 
Scoring  
Usually an isolated groove caused by something sharp. 
Such as a burr or sharp tool (metal pick). 
Galling  
Usually occurs when like metals or similar hardness 
metals are mated to each other and become seized 
together. Most often occurs in threaded connections. 
Flaking  
Occurs when coatings start to separate from the base 
metal. 
Fretting/Peeling  
A type of wear resulting from minute reciprocal sliding 
motion, which produce fine particulate contamination 
without chemical change. Fretting usually produces a 
fine dust. Peeling appears more as flakes. 
Coining 
Due to over torque in a metal to metal sealing 
configuration. The metal stem or cone becomes

When investigating seal damage or failure several factors are taken into account. The 
location of the seal, condition of the seal gland, back-up ring condition, orientation of the seal 
within the component, time between seal change and the environment in which the seal is 
exposed are helpful in the analysis of a failure. Also, simultaneous failure modes can be seen 
in seal analysis. 
 
Seal:  
Extrusion  
Occurs when the seal breaks down under pressure and 
is forced out of the seal confinement. The seal will have 
frayed or edges peeling off. 
Nibbling  
Associated with dynamic rod or piston seals. Appears 
as little bites taken out of o-ring. 
Spiral  
Deep spiral cut (usually at about 45°) into the O-ring. 
Abrasion  
Appears as wear lines on the cross section parallel to 
the motion of the seal. Caused be either to rough or to 
smooth metal surface, high temperatures or fluid 
contamination. 
Compression Set  
Sealing area of O-ring being squeezed is flat on both 
sides. Caused by hardening of seal due to high 
temperature or excessive squeeze needed to achieve 
seal. 
Cracking  
Usually caused by weather or ozone. Small cracks on 
the outer surface of seal. 
Heat Hardening  
Seal is hard and cracking or pitting. Caused by high 
temperature. 
Plasticizer Extraction  
Small cracks in cross-section. Caused by the service 
fluid evaporating and removing the compounds that 
make up the rubber. 
Installation Damage 
Cuts, punctures, or notches. Caused by mating parts, 
misuse of installation tools, or machining details. 
Explosive  
Gas expansion blistering, ruptures or splits deep in the 
O-ring. 
Decompression  
Caused by gas absorbed under high pressure unable to 
escape. 
Back-up Ring  
The seal shows similarities of nibbling or extrusion, 
except failure is in area of scarf cut. Caused by 
temperature and pressure changes, or extrusion of back-

GENERAL INSTRUMENT SAFETY 
 
This document outlines the safety concern for this particular section of the 1970 RCI 
tool. 
 
 
 
NOTICE 
This equipment is intended to be operated and 
maintained only by personnel who have received the 
proper training regarding Baker Hughes services and 
technology.  
This equipment may present hazards which are not obvious 
to untrained personnel. Attempts to operate or maintain this 
equipment by untrained personnel may result in injury or 
damage to equipment or result in lost time or damage to 
customer equipment and property. 
 
 
 
The GENERAL OPERATION MANUAL outlines the safety procedures for Well Site 
conditions and the GENERAL MAINTENANCE MANUAL outlines procedures for 
Lab conditions common for all the RCI subs.  
 
WARNING: Leaking or faulty Lee plugs must only be replaced with the appropriate size 
Lee plug. Any other form of plugging an access port is forbidden. If rework is necessary, 
contact local AMO management to verify the location of vendors qualified to rework Lee 
plugs. If no locally qualified vendor exists, the asset must be sent to a location that has a 
qualified vendor. 
 
SAFETY REQUIREMENTS: 
Personal protective equipment is provided as appropriate to the work being performed. In 
all cases, safety glasses and steel-toe safety shoes are worn during the assembly process.  
 
Read safety procedures for relieving trapped pressures in the GENERAL 
MAINTENANCE MANUAL before proceeding 
 
1. 
High-Pressure Hazard. Assume that every section of the tool has high pressure in 
it until you confirm otherwise. Possible serious injury to eyes, face and hands. 
Wear safety glasses, full-face shield, and heavy gloves. Clear the area of non-
essential personnel. 
 
2. 
Instrument is heavy. Possible death or serious bodily injury. Wear safety shoes. 
Use appropriate lifting devices and techniques to move the instrument.  
 
3. 
Pinch points on moveable arms. Possible serious bodily injury. Keep body parts 
clear of moving machine parts. Wearing heavy gloves may mitigate a hand injury. 
 
4. 
Keep hands and fingers clear of the backup pad assembly and packer piston while 
 
2 
   LAB SAFETY 
 
1970 MB RCI PACKER  
 
       P/N 130635-954 
                MAY 2013 
extending and retracting the pads. 
 
5. 
Hydrogen Sulfide is a corrosive, noxious and/or poisonous gas that may be 
recovered from the well. A seal failure could also expose the hydraulic oil to 
these dangers. See the Enterprise Operation Control Hydrogen Sulfide 
Document. 
 
6. 
Make certain all power has been turned off while disassembling or otherwise 
performing maintenance. 
 
7. 
The 1970 MB hydraulic system operates at pressures up to 3,500 PSI.  Use caution 
when testing, disassembling and /or repairing the hydraulic system, including all 
lines and pressure connectors. 
 
8. 
Always connect “Return Line” between tool and hydraulic test cart (both ends) to 
avoid blowing off the Solenoid Valve Covers. 
 
9. 
In Packer section, the Packer Snorkel and Backup Pistons extend and retract 
circuits are held by 3000 PSI.  This pressure needs to be bled off before 
performing maintenance. 
10. 
The Accumulator Assembly located in the 1970 MB needs to have its 
Accumulated Pressure, approximately 1700 PSI, bled off via MV1 either when 
shipping the section or before Maintenance. 
 
11. 
In the Generation 5 version packer kits the rubber packer fitted to the Snorkel, 
must be “Secured” before operating the tool or the Snorkel will pop out and cause 
the hydraulic seal to be lost.  The Backup pads should also be attached before 
operating the tool to prevent seal lose or damage to the tool components. 
 
The following procedure shall be followed for relieving trapped internal pressure for all 
RCI subs mentioned above.

LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 
1970 MB RCI PACKER 
 
P/N 130635-953 
MAY 2012 
 
 
The linked data sheets list a step by step process for the PM3 of the 1970 MB and should be 
used in conjunction with the 855 documentation listed in the Assembly/Disassembly section of this 
manual. 
 
 
During the process of performing preventive maintenance, the data sheets will require a description 
of the failures. The item or items being inspected could have different types of damage or irregularities. 
In helping to describe discrepancies the terms below can be used as reference. 
 
Mechanical: Radial scarring  
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something rotating 
in and out of a cavity.  
 
Longitudinal scarring 
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something 
dragging lengthwise 
 
Pitting/Crevice Corrosion  Usually associated with corrosion of some type where pits start 
to occur on the metal or surface coating. 
 
Flow cut/Jetting 
Usually associated with an area where a high flow rate of fluid 
causes metal to erode. 
 
Dents/dings 
Usually associated with an indentation in the metal that was 
caused by being dropped, hit, or mishandled. 
 
Scratch(es) 
Similar to scarring but grooves start to appear that are deeper 
and less frequent in number. Scratches are usually caused by 
abrasion. For example sand getting into a seal area or a metal 
picks used to remove an o-ring. 
 
Scoring 
Usually an isolated groove caused by something sharp, such as 
a burr or sharp tool (metal pick). 
 
Galling 
Usually occurs when like metals or similar hardness metals are 
mated to each other and become seized together. Most often 
occurs in threaded connections. 
 
Flaking 
Occurs when coatings start to separate from the base metal. 
 
Fretting/Peeling 
A type of wear resulting from minute reciprocal sliding motion 
which produces fine particulate contamination without 
chemical change. 
 
Fretting  
Usually produces a fine dust. Peeling appears more as flakes. 
 
Coining 
Due to over torque in a metal to metal sealing configuration. 

LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 
1970 MB RCI PACKER 
 
P/N 130635-953 
MAY 2012 
 
 
When investigating seal damage or failure several factors are taken into account. The location of the 
seal, condition of the seal gland, back-up ring condition, orientation of the seal within the component, 
time between seal change and the environment in which the seal is exposed are helpful in the analysis of 
a failure. Also, simultaneous failure modes can be seen in seal analysis. 
 
Seal: Extrusion 
Occurs when the seal breaks down under pressure and is forced out 
of the seal confinement. The seal will have frayed or edges peeling 
off. 
 
Nibbling 
Associated with dynamic rod or piston seals. Appears as little bites 
taken out of o-ring.  
 
Spiral 
Deep spiral cut (usually at about 451) into the O-ring.  
 
Abrasion 
Appears as wear lines on the cross section parallel to the motion of 
the seal. Caused be either to rough or to smooth metal surface, high 
temperatures or fluid contamination. 
 
Compression Set 
Sealing area of O-ring being squeezed is flat on both sides. Caused 
by hardening of seal due to high temperature or excessive squeeze 
needed to achieve seal.    
 
Cracking 
Usually caused by weather or ozone. Small cracks on the outer 
surface of seal. 
 
Heat Hardening 
Seal is hard and cracking or pitting. Caused by high temperature. 
 
Plasticizer Extraction 
Small cracks in cross-section. Caused by the service fluid 
evaporating and removing the compounds that make up the rubber. 
 
Installation Damage 
Cuts, punctures, or notches. Caused by mating parts, misuse of 
installation tools, or machining details. 
 
Explosive Decompression Gas expansion blistering, ruptures or splits deep in the O-ring. 
Caused by gas absorbed under high pressure unable to escape. 
 
Back-up Ring 
The seal shows similarities of nibbling or extrusion, except failure is 
in area of scarf cut. Caused by temperature and pressure changes, or 
extrusion of back-up ring.  
 
CHECK OUT

This document outlines the safety concern for this particular section of the 1970 RCI
tool.
The GENERAL OPERATION MANUAL outlines the safety procedures for Well Site
conditions and the GENERAL MAINTENANCE MANUAL outlines procedures for
Lab conditions common for all the RCI subs.
1.
Read safety procedures for relieving trapped pressures in the GENERAL
MAINTENANCE MANUAL before proceeding.
CAUTION: Always assume that every section has pressure in it until you confirm
otherwise.  This can cause personal injury and should be handled very cautiously.
 As a minimum wear safety glasses, full-face shield, heavy gloves and clear the
area of unnecessary personnel.
WARNING: The 1970 OB instrument is operates at high hydraulic pressures.  Use
extreme caution when handling or performing maintenance on this section. 
2. 
Use the appropriate lifting devices and techniques to move the instrument.
3. 
Caution: Before breaking any field joints, check for internal trapped pressure.  
The OB incorporates a plug for venting the atmosphere area. A seal failure could
expose corrosive, noxious and/or poisonous fluids to the atmospheric area or the
hydraulic oil.
The following minimum steps shall be implemented.
a. 
Clear the area of unnecessary personnel.
b. 
Position the vent hole away from the equipment and personnel.
c. 
Remove the plug slowly and cautiously.
4. 
Always connect “Return Line” between tool and hydraulic test cart.
5. 
The 1970 OB hydraulic system operates at pressures up to 3,500 PSI.  Use caution
when testing, disassembling and /or repairing the hydraulic system, including all

 LAB SAFETY
1970 OB AUXILIARY POWER
P/N 130851-954
JANUARY 2002
6. 
The OB utilizes hydraulic piping to facilitate hydraulic/sample line plumbing. 
During functional and troubleshooting operations on this section, necessary steps
should be taken to prevent personnel injury if an O-ring seal fails and pressurizes
the atmospheric area, the following minimum steps shall be implemented.
a. 
Clear the area of unnecessary personnel.
b. 
Minimize time standing next to tool when function testing or
troubleshooting.
7. 
Make certain all power has been turned off while disassembling/assembling or
otherwise performing maintenance.
8.
Oven heat treating of the assembled 1970 OB  is prohibited, as it may result in a
damaged to the tool or property and injury to personnel due to high pressures
generated by oil expansion within the tool.  Individual electronic chassis or CDE
modules should only be tested outside the housing or subs; refer to the
Repair/Maintenance section of this manual.

PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE LEVEL 3 
1970 OB AUXILIARY POWER SECTION 
 
P/N 130851-953 
MAY 2012 
 
 
The linked data sheets list a step by step process for the PM3 of the 1970 OB and should be 
used in conjunction with the 855 documentation listed in the Assembly/Disassembly section of this 
manual. 
 
 
During the process of performing preventive maintenance, the data sheets will require a description 
of the failures. The item or items being inspected could have different types of damage or irregularities. 
In helping to describe discrepancies the terms below can be used as reference. 
 
 
Mechanical: Radial scarring  
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something rotating 
in and out of a cavity.  
 
Longitudinal scarring 
Usually associated with wear that occurs by something 
dragging lengthwise 
 
Pitting/Crevice Corrosion  Usually associated with corrosion of some type where pits start 
to occur on the metal or surface coating. 
 
Flow cut/Jetting 
Usually associated with an area where a high flow rate of fluid 
causes metal to erode. 
 
Dents/dings 
Usually associated with an indentation in the metal that was 
caused by being dropped, hit, or mishandled. 
 
Scratch(es) 
Similar to scarring but grooves start to appear that are deeper 
and less frequent in number. Scratches are usually caused by 
abrasion. For example sand getting into a seal area or a metal 
picks used to remove an o-ring. 
 
Scoring 
Usually an isolated groove caused by something sharp, such as 
a burr or sharp tool (metal pick). 
 
Galling 
Usually occurs when like metals or similar hardness metals are 
mated to each other and become seized together. Most often 
occurs in threaded connections. 
 
Flaking 
Occurs when coatings start to separate from the base metal. 
 
Fretting/Peeling 
A type of wear resulting from minute reciprocal sliding motion 
which produces fine particulate contamination without 
chemical change. 
 
Fretting  
Usually produces a fine dust. Peeling appears more as flakes. 
 
Coining 
Due to over torque in a metal to metal sealing configuration. 

PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE LEVEL 3 
1970 OB AUXILIARY POWER SECTION 
 
P/N 130851-953 
MAY 2012 
 
 
When investigating seal damage or failure several factors are taken into account. The location of the 
seal, condition of the seal gland, back-up ring condition, orientation of the seal within the component, 
time between seal change and the environment in which the seal is exposed are helpful in the analysis of 
a failure. Also, simultaneous failure modes can be seen in seal analysis. 
 
Seal: Extrusion 
Occurs when the seal breaks down under pressure and is forced out 
of the seal confinement. The seal will have frayed or edges peeling 
off. 
 
Nibbling 
Associated with dynamic rod or piston seals. Appears as little bites 
taken out of o-ring.  
 
Spiral 
Deep spiral cut (usually at about 451) into the O-ring.  
 
Abrasion 
Appears as wear lines on the cross section parallel to the motion of 
the seal. Caused be either to rough or to smooth metal surface, high 
temperatures or fluid contamination. 
 
Compression Set 
Sealing area of O-ring being squeezed is flat on both sides. Caused 
by hardening of seal due to high temperature or excessive squeeze 
needed to achieve seal.    
 
Cracking 
Usually caused by weather or ozone. Small cracks on the outer 
surface of seal. 
 
Heat Hardening 
Seal is hard and cracking or pitting. Caused by high temperature. 
 
Plasticizer Extraction 
Small cracks in cross-section. Caused by the service fluid 
evaporating and removing the compounds that make up the rubber. 
 
Installation Damage 
Cuts, punctures, or notches. Caused by mating parts, misuse of 
installation tools, or machining details. 
 
Explosive Decompression Gas expansion blistering, ruptures or splits deep in the O-ring. 
Caused by gas absorbed under high pressure unable to escape. 
 
Back-up Ring 
The seal shows similarities of nibbling or extrusion, except failure is 
in area of scarf cut. Caused by temperature and pressure changes, or 
extrusion of back-up ring.  
 
CHECK OUT 
 
1970 OB PM3 Checklist

This document outlines the safety concern for this particular section of the 1970 RCI tool.

The GENERAL OPERATIONS MANUAL outlines the safety procedures for Well Site
conditions and the GENERAL MAINTENANCE MANUAL outlines procedures for
Lab conditions common for all the RCI subs.

1.
Read safety procedures for relieving trapped pressures in the General
Maintenance Manual before proceeding.

CAUTION: Always assume that every section has pressure in it until you confirm otherwise.
This can cause personal injury and should be handled very cautiously. As a minimum wear
safety glasses, full-face shield, heavy gloves and clear the area of unnecessary personnel.

WARNING: Leaking or faulty Lee plugs must only be replaced with the appropriate size
Lee plug. Any other form of plugging an access port is forbidden. If rework is necessary,
contact local AMO management to verify the location of vendors qualified to rework Lee
plugs. If no locally qualified vendor exists, the asset must be sent to a location that has a
qualified vendor.

WARNING: the 1970qc instrument is extremely heavy, and operates at high hydraulic
pressures. use extreme caution when handling or performing maintenance on this section.

1.
Use the appropriate lifting devices and  techniques to move the instrument.

2.
Corrosive, noxious and/or poisonous fluids may be recovered from the well. A
seal failure could also expose the hydraulic oil to these dangers.



3.
Always connect “Return Line” between tool and hydraulic test cart (both ends).

4.
The 1970 QC hydraulic system operates at pressures up to 3,500 PSI. Use caution
when testing, disassembling and/or repairing the hydraulic system, including all
lines and pressures connectors.


5.
The QC utilizes Lee plugs to facilitate hydraulic/sample line plumbing. During
functional and troubleshooting operations on this section, necessary steps should
be taken to prevent personnel injury if a Lee plug failed and became a projectile
the following minimum steps shall implemented.
A.
Clear area of unnecessary personnel.
B.
Minimize time standing next to tool when function testing or
troubleshooting.
C.
The sub should be covered to absorb the projectile.

5.
Make certain all power has been turned off while disassembling, assembling or
otherwise performing maintenance.



6.
Oven heat treating of this assembly 1970 QC is prohibited, as it may result in a
damage to the tool or property and injury to personnel due to high pressures
generated by oil expansion within the tool.  Individual electronics chassis or CDE
modules should only be tested outside the housing or subs; refer to the
Repair/Maintenance section of this manual.

LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 
1973 XA SAMPLE TANK
P/N 130663-953 
APRIL 2000
Refer to the assembly/disassemly and repair/maintenance procedures (-855 and -856) in this manual to
complete the level 3 preventive maintenance procedures.
PERSONNEL
Recommended RCI maintenance practices require an experienced General Maintenance Engineer (GME)
that has completed the mechanical and electrical maintenance courses (and preferably the operational
course) to supervise RCI maintenance.  In the event the RCI instrument is used for multiple runs, the
properly trained GME should accompany the tool to location to ensure full operational capabilities. 
Untrained personnel performing maintenance on the RCI are an invitation for equipment trouble.
PROCEDURE
1. 
Pressure wash the tank assembly prior to disassembly.
2. 
Disassemble the tank assembly.
3. 
Clean and inspect the tank bore.  Pressure wash internally until no oil residue remains.
4. 
Inspect the hard seat valves and replace them if necessary.   Inspect the seat and stem using a
microscope, there should be no scars or signs of galling.  If in doubt replace the seat and stem.
5. 
Inspect the mixing ball. If the outside of the ball shows signs of nicks or dents, replace it with a
new mixing ball.  Left unchanged, a defective mixing ball could scratch the bore beyond repair.
NOTE
Do not contaminate the tank with petroleum products. Use of lubricants must be kept
to a minimum. Seals should only have a ‘shine’ of lubricant.
6. 
Replace all seals detailed on the –843 parts list included in this manual.
CAUTION
DO NOT OVER TORQUE THE MANUAL HARD SEAT VALVE.  REFER TO
THE ASSEMBLY DRAWING AND THE ASSEMBLY PROCEDURE FOR
PROPER VALVE SEAT/STEM COINING.
7. 
Complete reassembly and use compressed air to check tanks for leaks.
8. 
Blow the piston back to the top and leave the hard seat valve open.
CHECKOUT
Test tanks in compliance with local rules and regulations.

1 
 
LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 
1974 XA SAMPLE TANK 
 
 
  
P/N 130710-953 
MAY 2012 
Refer to the assembly/disassembly and repair/maintenance procedures (-855 and -856) in this manual to 
complete the level 3 preventive maintenance procedures. 
 
PERSONNEL 
 
Recommended RCI maintenance practices require an experienced General Maintenance Engineer (GME) 
that has completed the mechanical and electrical maintenance courses (and preferably the operational 
course) to supervise RCI maintenance.  In the event the RCI instrument is used for multiple runs, the 
properly trained GME should accompany the tool to location to ensure full operational capabilities.  
Untrained personnel performing maintenance on the RCI are an invitation for equipment trouble. 
 
PROCEDURE 
 
1. 
Pressure wash the tank assembly prior to disassembly. 
2. 
Disassemble the tank assembly (see 190058-855). 
3. 
Clean and inspect the tank bore.  Pressure wash internally until no oil residue remains. 
4. 
Inspect the hard seat valves and replace them if necessary.   Inspect the seat (P/N 
190057-000 in the sub) and stem using a microscope, there should be no scars or signs of 
galling.  If in doubt replace the stem and sub.  If structural parts such as the sub are 
replaced, update the instrument history folder with certification documentation. 
5. 
Inspect the mixing ball. If the outside of the ball shows signs of nicks or dents, replace it 
with a new mixing ball.  Left unchanged, a defective mixing ball could scratch the bore 
beyond repair. 
 
NOTE 
 
Do not contaminate the tank with petroleum products. Use of lubricants 
must be kept to a minimum. Seals should only have a >shine= of lubricant. 
 
6. 
Replace all seals detailed on the B843 parts list included in this manual. 
 
CAUTION 
 
THIS TANK DOES NOT HAVE A REPLACEABLE SEAT; DO NOT 
OVER TORQUE THE MANUAL HARD SEAT VALVE.  REFER TO 
THE ASSEMBLY DRAWING AND THE ASSEMBLY PROCEDURE FOR 
PROPER VALVE SEAT/STEM COINING. 
 
7. 
Complete reassembly and use compressed air to check tanks for leaks. 
8. 
Blow the piston back to the top and leave the hard seat valve open.

PERSONNEL 
Recommended RCI maintenance practices require an experienced General Maintenance Engineer 
(GME) that has completed the mechanical and electrical maintenance courses (and preferably the 
operational course) to supervise RCI maintenance.  In the event the RCI instrument is used for multiple 
runs, the properly trained GME should accompany the tool to location to ensure full operational 
capabilities.  Untrained personnel performing maintenance on the RCI are an invitation for equipment 
trouble. 
 
PROCEDURE 
1. Pressure wash the tank assembly prior to disassembly 
2. Disassemble the tank assembly (see 199890-855). 
3. Clean and inspect the tank bore.  Pressure wash internally until no oil residue remains. 
4. Inspect the hard seat valves and replace them if necessary.  Inspect the seat (P/N 190057-000 in the 
sub) and stem using a microscope, there should be no scars or signs of galling.  If in doubt replace 
the stem and sub.  If structural parts such as the sub are replaced, update the instrument history 
folder with certification documentation. 
5. Inspect the mixing ball.  If the outside of the ball shows signs of nicks or dents, replace it with a new 
mixing ball.  Left unchanged, a defective mixing ball could scratch the bore beyond repair. 
6. Replace all seals detailed on the –843 parts list included in this manual. 
 
NOTE 
 
Do not contaminate the tank with petroleum products.  Use of lubricants must be kept to a minimum.  
Seals should only have a ‘shine’ of lubricant. 
 
CAUTION 
 
THIS TANK DOES NOT HAVE A REPLACEABLE SEAT, DO NOT OVER TORQUE THE 
MANUAL HARD SEAT VALVE.  REFER TO ASSEMBLY DRAWING AND THE ASSEMBLY 
PROCEDURE FOR PROPER VALVE SEAT/STEM COINING. 
 
7. Complete reassembly and use compressed air to check tanks for leaks. 
8. Blow the piston back to the top and leave the hard seat valve open. 
 
CHECK OUT

REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES  
1976 XA RCI SAMPLE TANKS 
1 
 
 
Cleaning & Visual Inspection 
 
The condition of sample tanks should be addressed following the job.  After 
disassembly, discard all seals and thoroughly clean all components.  The preferred 
cleaner is steam or hot water.  If this is not practical, biodegradable citrus-based solvent 
(P/N 263143-000) may be used.  The use of solvents or cleaners containing chlorides 
should be avoided because of their environmental effects, reaction to elastomers, and 
their reaction to certain metals.  Exercise care in removing all sample debris from 
passageways within the subs. 
 
Visually inspect the surfaces of all parts; give seal areas special attention.  Ensure the 
surfaces do not show evidence of defects that render the tank assembly unsafe.  If 
defects are present, or if any observance is questionable, return the assembly to 
Houston Repair for evaluation. 
 
Disposal of Residue & Unsafe Sample  
 
Dispose of any remaining sample, sample residue, cleaning rags, etc….according to the 
environmental requirements in the BHI HS&E Management System Global Level 2 
procedures and by local regulations. Companies licensed to dispose of hazardous 
material may be employed to ensure compliance with the environmental codes and 
regulations. 
 
Storage Duration 
 
Storage of a pressurized sample within a sample tank assembly should not exceed 10 
days following the retrieval of the sample from a well.  The tank assembly must them be 
emptied, disassembled, and cleaned. 
 
Sample Tank Testing 
 
New tank assemblies described in this manual are certified for service by an 
independent lab according to the U.S. Department of Transportation’s code or federal 
Regulations and the assigned exemption (number E11380).  The licensed laboratory 
ensures each tank assembly is successfully tested at an internal pressure of 5/3 times 
the operating pressure (33333 psi).  All seals and valves are tested to 25,000 psi.  
Additional tests conducted by the lab include materials evaluation and certification, 
volume analysis, plus a check for proper markings and the preparation of certification 
report. 
 
Re-Testing of the tank assembly should be accomplished every 5 years; it is also 
recommended that the tans assembly be submitted for re-testing if 120 jobs have been 
completed prior to the 5 year limit.  As stated above, if during the visual inspection a 
questionable defect is observed, the tan assembly should be re-tested.  Records of all 
tests should be maintained in the asset history folder. 
 
 
 
P/N 130895-956 
NOVEMBER 2014

For the purposes of rework only, the pressure housing bore diameter may be increased

CERT folder and update the RCI CERT table in SAP.

INTRODUCTION
This document provides the minimum PM3 procedures required to maintain the 1979 EA in good
working order.

GENERAL SAFETY INSTRUCTIONS

•
WEIGHT: The weight of the 2223 XA Z-Density instrument is 200 pounds (see
130873-025).  Two-man lifting is recommended to prevent injury and/or damage to
the instrument.
•
POTENTIOMETER ASSEMBLY: The potentiometer assembly is filled with silicone
oil for pressure equalization.  The instrument should not be oven heated without
hydrostatic pressure present to oppose the expansion of the oil.
•
MOTORING: If motoring is accomplished in the lab, be sure to keep body parts clear
of any moving parts, as they can cause personal injury.
•
ELECTRICAL: Beyond precautions normal for electronic equipment, this instrument
does not require special considerations as far as safety goes.  High voltages are
generated internally, but should be well protected from user contact when instrument
is fully assembled.
•
RADIATION: Normal practices should not require the installation of a source into the
pad while instrument resides in a lab condition.  All circuit testing is done without the
use of a source.


130873-954 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas

+5 VOLT DC POWER SUPPLY 3 

INSTRUMENT BUS INTERFACE BOARD
Refer to the Density Instrument Bus Interface schematic drawing 198756-100
during the following discussion of this circuitry.  It is the main function of this
board is to interface with the Telemetry.
•
The main component in the Bus Interface board is U7, a micro-controller
integrating multiple peripheral functions including RAM, internal temperature
sensing, I/O interfacing, a programming port, etc.  The micro-controller
operates at +3.3 volts, so provision has to be made to reduce the supplied +5
volts using regulator U1.
•
U4 is a 20 MHz crystal controlled oscillator providing the necessary clock
signals.
•
U2 is a 4.5 volt reference that provides a stable 4.096 reference voltage to
the micro-controller’s internal A/D converter.  It also has a temperature
sensor built into it and this signal is input to one of the channels of the A/D via
amplifier U3 and its associated circuitry
•
The tool measurements are received via connector J3 from the Controller
board and routed through U7 to be presented to the communication port of
connector J2 (or Matrix Instrument Bus) as Mode 2 or Mode 5 data.  Data can
be sent on Channel 1 through circuitry associated with transformer T3, on
Channel 2 through transformer T2 and/or on Channel 3 through transformer
T1.  Controlled by commands from the surface, U7 outputs which signal(s)
are routed to the Telemetry for transmission to the surface.
•
Reception of Telemetry commands is accomplished with transformer T4 and
buffer amplifier U14.
•
This tool has the capability to store tables containing calibration, hardware
data, firmware revision information, etc.  The Flash EEPROMs U13 and U15
are used for this purpose and is connected to the main processor.
•
U5 provides a Reset signal to the micro-controller when power is missing or
inadequate.  With sufficient power applied, this chip removes the Reset and
allows the micro-controller to operate normally.
130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
5

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description
•
One of the unique features of this board is its ability to change firmware
stored in the memory of the micro-controller.  This feature is accomplished
via the three contact points TP1, TP2 and TP3 using a special programming
fixture.  The fixture puts the micro-controller into a programming mode and
actual programming occurs through the programming port (J1) when
connected to the serial port of a PC.
•
J1, and the circuitry that includes U9, U11 and associated components, is
also a test port.  It can be connected to a PC serial port, using a test
connection 198760-000.  The micro-controller firmware provides a series of
routines that are useful for testing/ troubleshooting this board.  See document
130873-953 Level 3 PM for details.
•
LED’s PL1, PL2 and PL3 give a visual indication of the operation of the
board.  PL1 is not used at present, PL2, a red LED indicates abnormal
conditions.  PL3 lights each time the tool sends data to the surface.

CONTROLLER BOARD
Refer to the Density Controller schematic drawing 198753-100 during the
following discussion of this circuitry.  It is the main function of this controller to
pass the spectrum counts from the two detectors to the Instrument Bus Interface
board when instructed.  Secondarily, it controls opening and closing of the motor,
and thirdly, processes the position of the caliper arm and pad potentiometers.
•
The main component in the controller board is U4, a micro-controller
integrating multiple peripheral functions including RAM, internal temperature
sensing, I/O interfacing, a programming port, etc.
•
U3 is a 20 MHz crystal controlled oscillator providing the necessary clock
signals.
•
U1 is a 4.5 volt reference that provides a stable 4.096 reference voltage to
the micro-controller’s internal A/D converter.  It also has a temperature
sensor built into it and this signal is input to one of the channels of the A/D via
amplifier U2 and its associated circuitry.
•
Amplifier U9 buffers the 4.5 volt reference signal to supply a stable voltage for
the Caliper Arm potentiometer via connector J3-1.
•
Amplifier U10 buffers the 4.5 volt reference signal to supply a stable voltage
for the Pad Arm potentiometer via connector J3-4.
•
Amplifier U11 buffers the 4.5 volt reference signal to supply a stable voltage
for the Motor Position potentiometer via connector J5-8.
•
Optocouplers U16, U17, U18 and U19 control application of voltage to the
motor via their associated FETs Q3, Q4, Q6 and Q7.  Depending on the pair
of switches that are activated, motor voltage from the Instrument Bus is
applied in one polarity to open the backup arm and pad, or in the opposite
polarity to close them.
130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
6

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description
•
Amplifier U15 and associated circuitry monitors the current to the motor.  Its
output is routed to one of the A/D inputs of the micro-controller.  Firmware
within the controller makes decisions as to slowing the motor down or
stopping it completely when needed.
•
The output of driver U22 A controls Q8 to complete the path for the motor to
run.  The micro-controller drives U22 A in such a way that the motor is started
and stopped slowly.
•
Amplifier U14 monitors the current used by the Density Pad electronics.  Its
output is routed to the controller’s A/D. In case of high current draw, the
micro-controller removes temporarily the power to the pad.
•
Transceiver chips U7 (Long Spacing) and U8 (Short Spacing) provide two-
way communication between this board and the Pulse Height Analysis (PHA)
boards.  It is through this connection that data is sent from the Detector
electronics to the Controller board.  Data is then sent through J4 to the IB
Interface board and ultimately to the Telemetry.
•
U5 provides a Reset signal to the micro-controller when power is missing or
inadequate.  With sufficient power applied, this chip removes the Reset and
allows the micro-controller to operate normally.
•
One of the unique features of this board is its ability to change firmware
stored in the memory of the micro-controller.  This feature is accomplished
via the three contact points TP1, TP2 and TP3 using a special programming
fixture.  The fixture puts the micro-controller into a programming mode and
actual programming occurs through the programming port (J2) when
connected to the serial port of a PC.
•
J2, and the circuitry that includes U12, U13 and associated components, is
also a test port.  It can be connected to a PC serial port, using a test
connection 198760-000.  The micro-controller firmware provides a series of
routines that are useful for testing/ troubleshooting this board.  See Appendix
B for details.
•
LED’s PL1, PL2, PL3 and PL4 are used to give a visual indication of the
operation of the program.  PL3, a red LED, is used to show abnormal
conditions.  The other three LEDs serve different purposes, depending on the
task running on the processor.  For example, PL1 will light while the motor is
being connected, PL2 will light when the speed of the motor is being ramped
up or down, and PL4 will light when the motor is running, or when information
from the pad PHA’s is being transferred.

130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
7

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description

INTERCONNECT BOARD
This simple board is full of wiring terminal posts used for connecting wires
coming from the top connector and connecting either to other points within the
instrument or as through wires to the bottom connector.
See assembly drawing 198757-000 and schematic drawing 198757-100 for
further details.

PAD MECHANISM
Refer to Density Pad Carrier assembly drawing 198440-000 for the location of
components cited in the following descriptions.  Although this section of the instrument is
heavily mechanical, there are a few electrical components worthy of mentioning.

MOTOR POSITION POTENTIOMETER
Control over getting the motor to run and position the Density Pad assembly
against the wellbore wall is the function of the Controller board already
discussed.  The motor itself resides in this section of the instrument.  It is linked
mechanically to a potentiometer that assists the Controller in measuring where
the motor has positioned the Caliper Arm and Density Pad assembly.
The Motor Position Potentiometer (item 22 in the drawing) is mounted in a
special holder and attached to Mandrel Weldment assembly.  The plunger of the
potentiometer rides against a surface on the Power Nut specifically made for this
measurement.

CALIPER POT HOUSING ASSEMBLY
Refer to drawing 198587-000 for details of this assembly.
The Caliper Pot Housing assembly contains two potentiometers – one for the
Caliper Arm position and one for the Density Pad position.  These pots are
excited using two separate and buffered +5 volts.  The wiper arms of the pots,
positioned by the displacement of the two mechanical arms, yield independent
measurements that indicate their current extension.
Separate channels of the internal A/D converter found in the micro-controller on
the Controller board (198753-000) process the two wiper signals.

130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
8

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description

LIMIT SWITCHES
Although firmware controls the operation of the motor that extends the Caliper
Arm and Density Pad assembly, two limit switches are placed within the
mechanical section to act as a backup system for interrupting power to the motor
and prevents possible mechanical damage.
Switch S1 is placed such that it will trip when movement of the Power Nut
reaches a fully closed position for the two arms.
Similarly, switch S2 is placed such that it trips when movement of the Power Nut
reaches a fully open position.
A specifically contoured surface of the Power Nut travels between these two limit
switches and depresses the actuating arms attached to the switches.  When the
actuating arm depresses the button of the switch, it interrupts the current path to
the motor and stops it.  Remember, this comes into play only if the firmware fails
to properly control the motion of the motor.

130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
9

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description

DENSITY PAD ASSEMBLY
Refer to the Pad assembly drawing 198704-000 and the Detector Electronics assembly
199146-000 for the location of components cited in the following circuit descriptions.
See the block diagram below for major components of the Pad.

assembly connected to a Pulse Height Analyzer (PHA).  The detector assembly has four
main components; a scintillation crystal optically coupled to a photomultiplier, a
preamplifier, and a high voltage power supply.
In the tungsten shield, an opening is cut above each crystal detector to form a window
for returning radiation.  Inside each window next to the crystal is a cadmium filter.
The Cs-137 source in the pad cap below the detectors bombards the formation with
gamma radiation, creating photons through multiple scattering in the formation.  As
these photons enter the NaI crystals through the windows in the tungsten shield, the
crystals emit bursts of light.  The PM tube that is optically coupled to the crystal then
receives this light and outputs corresponding electrical signals.
Both crystal/PM tube combinations are housed within sleeves containing a spring that
keeps pressure on the assembly.  When the detectors are assembled, the spring
compresses and forces the crystal and PM tube together to ensure a good optical
coupling and allows for thermal expansion differences of all the materials.
130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
10

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description

SOURCE
Although it is not electrical in nature, the radioactive source is the starting place
for the density measurement and is a 2 Curie cesium-137 source.  It is housed in
a specially designed container and should always be handled using the
designated installation and removal tool.
Warning:
Remember to exercise extreme caution when working
around radioactive sources.  Keep all unauthorized
personnel away.  Only the person directly involved with the
source installation/removal should be in the immediate
area.  All other personnel must remain clear.
The source catcher must be installed prior to source
installation/removal if the instrument is vertically positioned
over the well bore.
To keep radiation exposure to a minimum, the handling
process is to be performed expeditiously without
compromising safety.  Remember: to minimize exposure,
minimize time and maximize distance.

DETECTOR ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY 10
4.2.1
SCINTILLATION CRYSTAL AND PHOTOMULTIPLIER 10
4.2.2
PREAMPLIFIER 10
4.2.3

DETECTOR ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
Refer to the Detector Electronics assembly 199146-000 and the Pad Electronics
Chassis assembly 199163-000 for the location of components cited in the
following descriptions.  For a further breakdown of the electronics, the Long
Space (LS) and Short Space (SS) detector assemblies are 199165-000 and
199166-000, respectively.  The PHA circuits are discussed in the next section;
see section  4.3.
Except for mechanical configuration and placement within the Detector
assembly, both the LS and SS electronic circuits are identical.  See the block
The crystal used in this tool includes its own Cs137 reference source.
The photomultiplier is an off-the-shelf unit that has no resistor dividers
and connects through socket/ pin contacts to the preamplifier and power
supply.
4.2.2 PREAMPLIFIER
Refer to the Density Preamplifier schematic drawing 198759-100 during
the discussion of this circuitry.
130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
11

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description
The signal coming from the photomultiplier enters at R1, is inverted by
U1 A, and amplified by U1 B; the signal is then sent to the PHA board.
The input of U1 A is also connected to R2 and a DC negative voltage
coming from the PHA, sets the DC level at the output of U1 B at a known
value.  Through this input, the PHA can also apply pulses to test the gain
of the entire signal chain without any additional instrumentation.
R6, R7 and R8 are connected to the tube anode, and are used to
measure the PM tube high voltage.
This board is plugged directly on the back of the PM tube socket, and the
HV power supply is, in turn, plugged into it.  The male/female connectors
route the HV voltages to the PM tube dynodes.
4.2.3 HIGH VOLTAGE POWER SUPPY
Refer to HVPS Driver schematic drawing 198751-100 and HVPS Rectifier
components of the detector assembly.  Sandwiched between the two PC
boards is the transformer that develops the high voltage for the
photomultiplier (PM) tube.
Refer to the Density HV Power Supply Rectifier schematic drawing
198759-100, and to the Detector HVPS Driver schematic drawing
189751-100 during the discussion of this circuitry.
The rectifier assembly consists of six almost identical stages that output
the voltages required to the different dynodes of the PM tube.  The first
stage has two diodes in series, to account for the higher voltage that
stage provides.
The driver is composed of an HV switch Q1 A&B, Q2 A&B, driven by
micro-controller U1, driving the switches in the proper sequence.  The
programming pads allow the micro-controller to be programmed in-circuit,
if desired.
U2 is an EEPROM, used to store coefficients, models, and serial
numbers of the detector components.  At power up, the PHA interrogates
the EEPROM to retrieve the coefficients used to set the initial operating
point of the detector.

130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
12

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description
