chunk_text:
PULSE HEIGHT ANALYZER (PHA) CIRCUITS 12
APPENDIX A – POWER SUPPLY CIRCUITRY14

130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
2

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description

PULSE HEIGHT ANALYZER (PHA) CIRCUITS
Refer to the Density PHA schematic drawing 198750-100 during the following
discussion of this circuitry.  It is the main function of this analyzer to detect the
peaks and valleys of the radioactive spectrum from the two detectors and pass
this information to the Controller board located in the Upper Electronics Chassis
assembly.
•
The main component in the PHA board is U12, a micro-controller integrating
multiple peripheral functions including internal temperature sensing, I/O
interfacing, high voltage control, peak and valley detection, a programming
port, etc.
•
U3 is a 20 MHz crystal controlled oscillator providing the necessary clock
signals.
•
U1 is a 4.5 volt reference that provides the supplied 4.096 reference voltage
to the micro-controller’s internal A/D converter.  It also has a temperature
sensor built into it and this signal is input to one of the channels of the A/D via
amplifier U2 and its associated circuitry.
•
Transceiver chip U15 provides two-way communication between this board
and the Controller board in the upper electronics.  Transceiver U16 is
connected to U16 in the other channel PHA, and allows routing of the
spectrum data through that PHA, in the event of a failure in the cable
connecting to the upper electronics.
•
U13 provides a Reset signal to the micro-controller when power is missing or
inadequate.  With sufficient power applied, this chip removes the Reset and
allows the micro-controller to operate normally.
•
One of the unique features of this board is its ability to change firmware
stored in the memory of the micro-controller.  This feature is accomplished
via the three contact points TP1, TP2 and TP3 using a special programming
fixture.  The fixture puts the micro-controller into a programming mode and
actual programming occurs through the programming port (J3) when
connected to the serial port (RS232) of a PC.
•
J3, and the circuitry that includes U21, U22 and associated components, is
also a test port.  It can be connected to a PC serial port, using a test
connection 198760-000.  The micro-controller firmware provides a series of
routines that are useful for testing/troubleshooting this board.  See Appendix
B for details.
•
U17, driven by one of the micro-controller PWM (Pulse Width Modulation)
outputs, and its associated components, provide a variable DC voltage that is
fed to the input of the preamplifier in the detector section.  The purpose of this
DC voltage is to produce a DC offset at the output of the preamplifier such
that its response is linear over the entire input signal range.  If a test signal is
required, U12 will apply that signal to R26.  C33 and C34 will AC couple the
test signal to the preamplifier.  The micro-controller can also open R25 or
130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
13

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description
connect it to a high level, providing a way to change the test signal amplitude.
Also, note that the preamplifier output DC level is monitored by R11 and sent
to one of U12 A/D inputs.  A routine running on the micro-controller keeps this
voltage within an appropriate range.
•
U18 and its associated components takes one of the micro-controller PWM
outputs, and generates the Low Level Discriminator (LLD) voltage.  This
voltage is sent to U11 circuitry, and is set above the noise level of the input
signal.
•
A sample of the PWM high voltage is received at J1-6, which is converted to
a DC voltage proportional to the PM high voltage at the output of U11.  The
high voltage power supply driver is composed of pass transistor Q2, R31,
R30, Q1, R32, R29 and R33.  The gain command changes the duty cycle of
one of the micro-controller PWM outputs, generating the high voltage drive at
the output of U19.  This is sent to the non-inverting input of the regulator and
the measured high voltage drives its inverting input.  This forms a feedback
loop that keeps the high voltage stable.
•
The High Voltage power supply takes its power between pins 5 and 1 of J2.
R38 samples the current going into the power supply, and at the output of
U20, there is a voltage proportional to the current consumed by the power
supply.  R34 and R35 form a voltage divider that is connected to one of the
A/D inputs of U12.  The micro-controller then knows (1) the drive signal (gain
command), (2) the voltage applied to the High Voltage power supply, (3) the
current flowing through that power supply and (4) the high voltage applied to
the photomultiplier.  This allows for a full diagnostic of the high voltage power
supply through the test port, without any additional instrumentation.
•
U7, U6 and A/D converter U4 form the pulse valley measuring circuit, while
U8, U9 and A/D converter U5 form the pulse peak measuring circuit.  The
micro-controller can then appropriately measure the pulse amplitude
regardless of the DC level present at the output of the preamplifier.  In order
for any conversion to be started, the pulse height must have a minimum
amplitude.  This objective is filled by the low level discriminator circuitry,
made up of U10 and its associated components.
130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
14

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description
APPENDIX A – POWER SUPPLY CIRCUITRY
The 2223 XA Density has only one power supply mounted on the electronics
backbone.  Refer to the assembly drawing 199880-000 and the associated PC
boards 198384-000 (-100 for schematic) and 198385-000 (-100 for schematic).
Along with the supply is an EMI filter module to drastically reduce interference and
interaction between supplies of other Matrix instruments.  These self-contained,
modular supplies mount on a heat-sinking channel and have additional circuitry
mounted on a PC board that is soldered directly to the pins of the supply.  It is this
additional circuitry that will be the topic of discussion for this section.
Because the power supply is modular, there is no repair of the brick.  It either
works or it doesn’t.  The only circuitry external to the module (U1) is some
inhibiting control and some additional output filtering.

Single Power Supply
See the schematic below for a typical configuration of these external components
for a single output power module.


just an indicator that a connection is made to this point.  Design changes have
removed capacitor C2 and a wire is soldered to the pad that connects to pin 2 of
the module.  The other end of this wire connects to the control circuit found on the
PC board associated with the EMI filter.
Instrument power is defined as +28 volts for the Matrix tool string.  This voltage
first passes through an EMI filter module before being applied to a DC to DC
converter module; thus, the voltage at terminal E1 is a filtered +28 V.  E2 is tied to
the return line of the EMI filter output.  Pins 6, 7 and 8 are tied to chassis ground
which, in turn, is tied to cable armor.  Two independent windings of a choke, L1,
filter voltage spikes on the output of the converter module.  Provision is made at J1
for trimming the output voltage under expected loads.  In most cases, this
130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
15

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description
provision is left unused.  Additional output filtering is provided by capacitors C3, C4
and C5.

Power Control Circuit
Associated with the DC to DC power supply module is an EMI filter module.  The
PC board attached to this module performs several control functions.  These
control functions are described below.
A +5 volt supply is generated for other chips on the PC board.  The supply
consists of a single dropping resistor (R3) and reference Zener diode (D1) to
establish the voltage.  This supply is connected to the output of the EMI filter
module (U1).  It is this +28 V EMI filter output that connects to the input of other DC
to DC converter modules within the instrument.  See the schematic below.


Refer to schematic diagram of the Power Supply Control circuit on page 17.  The
heart of the power control circuitry is a programmable micro-controller (U3).
Values for resistor R7 and capacitor C3 have been selected to give an operating
frequency of approximately 1 MHz.  Supplied with +5 volts from the supply of
, the micro-controller acts as a timer to control the turn-on time of anything
tied to its output.  There are basically three functions concerning this circuit.  They
are (1) a voltage threshold, (2) the delay circuit and (3) the control/inhibit circuit.
(1) A threshold voltage is established using chip U4.  The voltage divider
consisting of R6 and R8 are chosen such that when 20 volts or more (for
instrument power) is present on R6, the reset chip removes the LOW on pin 7
which in turn removes the reset from the micro-controller, U3, allowing it to do
its job.
(2) Jumper inputs to the micro-controller chip, U3, set different length delay
times.  Delay times are established for different tools to limit the current
demand when the Matrix tool sting is first powered up.  Delay times, in
milliseconds, and their jumpers are shown in the table below.

SEPT 2003

(3) When power is first applied to the micro-controller, output RA1 of U3 pin 18
is floating (open collector circuit).  Resistor R4 pulls the base of Q1 HIGH
turning it ON.  This state applies a ground potential to all power supplies tied to
the Q1 collector.  Diodes (D2 – D4) form an OR function in the collector circuit,
allowing control over different power supplies.  By tying the INHIBIT pin (active
low) of each DC-to-DC converter module within an instrument to one of these
control terminals (E5, E6 or E7), you can independently control its ON/OFF
function.  With Q1 initially turned ON, no power supply module can turn ON.  It
is not until the time-out function is completed by U3 that output RA1 can
transition LOW, turning OFF Q1.  With Q1 turned OFF, power supplies are
allowed to turn ON because their INHIBIT is removed.  As the power supplies
turn ON, their current demand is confined to that particular instrument.  Again,
see the control circuit on page 17.
130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
17

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description

Baker Atlas
18

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description
130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
Refer to drawing 198384-100 for the complete schematic of the Power
Controller board.  As an added feature of this circuit, Power Supply #2 or
Power Supply #3 (if they are present) can be turned OFF by an external source
via opto-isolator U2.  Terminal E8 is tied to a positive voltage.  Taking control
terminal E9 or E10 LOW causes its respective switch to close.  This applies a
ground potential to the INHIBIT input of the supply that is tied to its control
terminal, E6 or E7.  This LOW turns OFF the respective power supply.
Terminal E9 controls a power supply (P.S.2) connected to terminal E6, while
E10 controls a supply (P.S.3) connected to terminal E7.  Thus, independent
control is available if needed.  Power supplies connected to E5 are solely
controlled by the timing function associated with the operation of transistor Q1.
See the schematic below.

INTRODUCTION
The Z-Density instrument for the Matrix tool string is the series 2223 XA.  It consists of
three major sections: the upper electronics assembly, the pad mechanism assembly and
the density pad.  See Figure 1: 2223 XA Density Instrument.
The upper electronics assembly is encased in a steel pressure housing and contains the
following electronics.
1. A +5 Volt DC power supply,
2. Interface circuitry for communication to the Telemetry instrument,
3. Controller circuitry for signals and opening and closing the instrument arms,
4. Interconnection PC board.

The pad mechanism assembly contains electro-mechanical components.
1. Motor position potentiometer,
2. Caliper potentiometer assembly,
3. Limit switches.

The density pad assembly includes the following parts.
1. A 2-Curie Cs-137 source,
2. Two scintillation detector assemblies containing individual high voltage power
supplies,
3. Signal amplification circuitry for the detector outputs,
4. Pulse height analysis circuitry.



the block diagram of Figure 2: Z-Density Block Diagram
130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
3

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description

Refer to Electronics Chassis assembly drawing 198422-000 for the location of
components cited in the following circuit descriptions.

+5 VOLT DC POWER SUPPLY
All Matrix instruments are powered from a downhole +28 volt power source.  This
voltage is part of the Instrument Bus that is supplied to each tool in the tool
string.
In the block diagram of Figure 2, this power supply is denoted as the block
labeled “Power Supply and Filter.”  For a detailed description of the PC boards
and circuitry associated with this block, see
.
APPENDIX A – POWER SUPPLY
CIRCUITRY
Before the +28 volts is applied to a converter module, it passes through a special
“brick”1 used to filter noise from other instruments hanging on this common power
source.  It is mechanically mounted to the chassis via a metal channel used for

1 The word “brick” is used to denote a single encapsulated module containing components that
perform a specific electronic function, like filtering or DC to DC conversion.
130873-945 / 2223 XA
SEPT 2003
Baker Atlas
4

2223 XA Z-Density – Circuit Description
heat sinking purposes.  It is the output of this filter brick that is applied as an input
to the converter module.
This +28 volts is reduced to +5 volts using a DC-to-DC converter module to
provide power to the electronics of the instrument.  The converter module is a
“brick” installed on the chassis with the same metal channel used to mount the
filter brick.
The filtered and regulated +5 volt output of the converter module routes to the
various PC boards of the instrument providing a source of power to all
electronics.  If the filter brick or the converter brick fails, nothing within the
instrument will work properly.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 2.0 TEST USING SELF-TEST FIRMWARE ............................................................... 2
chunk_text:
TEST USING SELF-TEST FIRMWARE 2
2.0 TEST USING SELF-TEST FIRMWARE
The 2223 XA Density contains on-board firmware to assist in testing the functionality of
the instrument.  The steps contained in this section pertain to the use of a dumb terminal
or PC to exercise the firmware.

TEST USING LOGGING SYSTEM 
TEST USING MATRIX TEST FIXTURE 12
4.0 TEST USING MATRIX TEST FIXTURE

CONNECTING TO A PC
The 2223 XA Density has built-in test routines – which run concurrently with the logging
software – to help in testing/troubleshooting each individual assembly.  A dumb terminal
or a PC running terminal emulation software can be used.
Physical connections:
All three PCB’s (IB interface, Controller, and PHA’s) have the same connection, built
around a 2mm 3x2 connector.  This interface is galvanically isolated, allowing for
potentials more than 1000 V between the grounds of the PC/Terminal and the PCB being
tested.
The standard test cable is 198760-000, and allows connecting any of the boards to a 9-
pin serial port of a PC.
Pin assignments for the connector (2 mm pitch) on PHA, Controller, and IB interface
PCB’s are as follows.
PC DTR  1
2
Not connected
PC GND  3

GENERAL PROCEDURE
Testing equipment required for Level 3 PM depends on the test mode being used to
check the tool’s functionality.  There are three modes available (1) using the built-in test
firmware, (2) using a logging system, or (3) using the Matrix Test Fixture.  However,
there are certain common items that should be checked and repaired/replaced before
attempting any of the electronic tests which follow in the subsequent sections.

•
Inspect O-rings and replace as necessary.
•
Remove the caliper pot assembly cover and check piston travel (1/2”
exposed). Clean off mud debris and reinstall.
•
Remove the pressure housing and replace all O-rings.
•
Disassemble the pad linkage so the springs can be removed.  Inspect the
springs for corrosion and damage.  Inspect pad linkage for damage, broken
pins, corrosion, “sticky” movement, etc.
•
Run a tap through all threaded screw holes.
•
Tighten all screws on all electrical and mechanical assemblies.
•
Disengage the pad arm assembly from the pad and check the pad cable for
damage.  Replace O-rings.
•
Inspect pad surface for wear.
•
Inspect all sealing surfaces of the pad housing for corrosion.
•
Inspect the beryllium window and replace the O-ring.  Replace the window if
damage is evident.  Apply a thin coat of Lubriplate over the window and the
pad pocket.
•
If necessary, remove the detector assembly from the pad and apply fresh
Sylgard 184 between crystal and PMT.  Refer to 198704-855 procedures.
130873-953 / 2223 XA
MAR 2014
2

2223 XA Z-Density – Level 3 PM

EQUIPMENT REQUIRED
•
DC power supply capable of delivering 28 V @ 4 A or more.
•
Dumb terminal or a PC running terminal emulation (i.e. HyperTerminal,
ProCommPlus, etc.) software.  Set communication parameters to 9600 baud,
8 bits, no parity, hardware handshake.
•
Test cable 198760-000.  See Section  5.0 for details of connecting this cable
to the PC and to the tool’s PCB connectors.
•
Digital oscilloscope, two channels, 100 Ms/S, or better.

GENERAL / ELECTRICAL
•
Complete PM1 electrical tests
•
Refer to drawing 198440-100
•
The firmware has a “Help” function, showing the available commands and a
short explanation of how the commands work.  Help is activated by the
?<CR> command.  In the instructions below, command codes are shown in
bold.
•
Be aware that due to sampling rate limitations some scope waveforms,
especially at low sweep rates, may show distortions that are not present in
the original signal.  If in doubt, re-check with an analog scope.
•
Also, note that because the tool is tested alone, the I.B. is not loaded.  In the
I.B. waveform tests, to prevent excessive ringing, connect a 5 K resistor
across the scope terminals.

Focus Surface System 3.2 GENERAL / ELECTRICAL
•

Note that the following tests do not fully check all of the tool capabilities or
functionality.  For a complete test, use either the built-in tool software, or the

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 3.3 POWER SUPPLY TESTS 3.4 IB INTERFACE TEST
chunk_text:
•
On filter PCB (198385-000) check for a voltage of 4.75 to 5.25 V at the output of
the 5 V brick, terminals +V and COM. 3.4 IB INTERFACE TEST
•
Check that the I.B. Interface is able to send internal information on Mode 5 by
verifying an error free Subset E.
•
Check that the I.B. Interface is able to send to the surface information coming
from the Controller board, using the M5 SPI channel by checking an error free
subset 0.  Monitor values such as controller temperature (w0df) and 5 volt power
supply (w0d5) voltage.
•
Retrieve the calibration tables (0 through 7), the auxiliary calibration tables (also
0 through 7), and the hardware tables.  This checks the storage device on the
I.B. PCB.

•
Establish communications with the tool.  Verify proper operation of the open and
close commands.  There should be no telemetry errors, and the motor should
start and stop gradually.  If the motor stops abruptly at the end of the travel, it
means that the motion is terminated by the activation of the limit switches.  If this
happens, refer to the 130873–956 Repair / Maintenance procedures for
correcting this problem.
•
Open the sonde arm, and verify that the motor current (moti) is between 400 and
600 mA.
•
Close the sonde.  The current while closing should be approximately 600 mA,
increasing to about 1 A during the last two inches of the arm travel.

command is also a test of the communications between the Controller and the
I.B. interface, between the controller and the PHA’s, and between each PHA and
its associated HV power supply.  A faulty communication will typically show as
“??.??” on its revision level.

cable, providing for proper orientation.
The wiring of the test cable 198760-000 is as follows.

topic: Description of Service - DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE                  2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY 1.0 SERVICE OVERVIEW
chunk_text:
1

DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY 
SERVICE OVERVIEW

The 2234 XA Dual Spectrum Z-Densilog measures both formation bulk density (ρ) and the
photoelectric absorption index (pe).  These measurements allow evaluation of complex
formations through advanced lithology/porosity determination techniques.
Because the photoelectric absorption of gamma rays depends strongly on atomic number (Z),
the measured values of pe are directly related to the formation's composition.  The pe
measurement is not significantly dependent on porosity or fluid content, making it particularly
useful in determining formation lithology.

NOTE: Refer to APPENDIX A of the Operating Procedure P/N 131078-977 for a discussion
of Z-Densilog theory.
Features of the 2234 XA ZDL instrument include:
•
Scintillation detectors for increased count rate and improved repeatability.
•
256 channel spectrum recording on both detectors for advanced signal processing.
•
Real-time gain compensation for temperature-related changes in detector response.
•
Compensation of bulk density for variable mud-cake composition and thickness.
This WTS instrument is compatible with other WTS instruments.  When combined with other
logging data such as Compensated Neutron and Gamma Ray, the pe values and bulk densities
obtained from the Compensated Z-Densilog enable accurate determination of the following
characteristics:
•
Formation porosity and lithology
•
Formation Minerals
•
Gas zones
•
Fluid properties

The 2234 XA ZDL instrument mechanical construction is designed with the source and sensors
housed in a semi-articulated pad which can be extended out of the main mandrel body slightly to
provide optimum contact with the borehole wall.
A powerful motorized backup arm is used to firmly press the sensor section against the borehole
wall.  A caliper potentiometer attached to this arm provides a measurement of borehole diameter.

topic: Lab Safety - LAB SAFETY                                             2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY 1.0 GENERAL SAFETY INSTRUCTIONS
chunk_text:
1

LAB SAFETY                                             2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                               P/N 131078-954                               FEBRUARY 2008 
GENERAL SAFETY INSTRUCTIONS

•
WEIGHT: The weight of the 2234 XA Z-Density instrument is 365 pounds (see 131078-025).
Two-man lifting is recommended to prevent injury and/or damage to the instrument.
•
POTENTIOMETER ASSEMBLY: The potentiometer assembly is filled with silicone oil for
pressure equalization.  The instrument should not be oven heated without hydrostatic pressure
present to oppose the expansion of the oil.
•
MOTORING: If motoring is accomplished in the lab, be sure to keep body parts clear of any
moving parts, as they can cause personal injury.
•
ELECTRICAL: Beyond precautions normal for electronic equipment, this instrument does not
require special considerations as far as safety goes.  High voltages are generated internally, but
should be well protected from user contact when instrument is fully assembled.
•
RADIATION: Normal practices should not require the installation of a source into the pad
while instrument resides in a lab condition.  All circuit testing is done without the use of a
source.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY 2.0 UPPER ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY..............................................................................4
chunk_text:
1

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008


INTRODUCTION2 

UPPER ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
For the location of components cited in the following circuit descriptions refer to:
A3000812 WRD Wiring Diagram, Dual Spectrum WTS Z-Density

INTERCONNECT PCB
Please refer to the interconnect PCB schematic A3000961 SCH.
•
Power transformer T1, located on the chassis and not shown on the schematic, has its
primary connected to the Tool Power AC (wireline 1 & 4).  Tied to terminals that are
labeled according to its wire colors, the two secondaries of T1 are connected to the
interconnect PCB to supply the power needed by the tool circuitry.
•
The pad electronics gets its +28 V power from the circuitry located in the lower portion
of schematic A3000961 SCH.  Raw DC is obtained by rectifying one of T1 secondary
outputs with bridge rectifier D16 through D19, and filtering with C21.  U8 and its
associated components form a switching rectifier.  Resistors R20 and R23 sample the
output for regulation.  The output – at C23, C24 & C25 – is filtered by L3 and C26,
C27 & C28 to reduce the residual ripple.
•
The controller circuitry requires both +5 V and +3.3 V.  These voltages are supplied by
the circuitry located above the pad power supply.  The bridge rectifier composed of
D10, D11, D14 and D15 and capacitor C13 provide the raw DC.  Note that this raw DC
is also used to supply U8 on the pad power supply circuitry.  The switching regulator U6
produces the +5 V DC voltage, while U7, powered from the +5, lowers that to +3.3 V
•
The circuitry in the upper left comprise the motor voltage monitor.  The readings are
galvanically isolated.  The circuitry produces pulses whose frequency is proportional to
the voltage on the motor terminal.  The frequency is measured by the controller CPU,
and converted to a voltage that is sent to the surface.  U1, U2, T1, D1, D2 and associated
components form a floating +5 V power supply that provides power to the measuring
circuit.  The motor voltage is present on the resistor divider formed by R8 through R11
and applied to U4, a V/F converter.  U5 is the reference clock for that converter.  The
output is fed to the optocoupler U3.  At the output of U3 we have a series of pulses,
galvanically isolated from the motor power, that represent the motor power voltage.
•
On the upper right we have a bridge rectifier that assures the same polarity is applied to
the motor, even if AC is supplied to the motor power wires (during emergency close).
Relay K1, activated by the motor mode signal, is the motor on/off function.  Its contacts
are wired such that the motor is on when no power is present on wireline conductors 1
& 4.  Relay K2, which is driven by the motor direction signal, runs the motor in the open
direction when activated, and in the close direction when de-energized.  The wiring of K1
and K2 thus assures that when no power is applied to the tool, any power sent on the
motor wires, either AC or DC will drive the motor closed.  This is done to facilitate the
emergency close function.
•
D3 and D6 are connected in series with the limit switches, and the associated resistors
and capacitors form a filter to reduce the noise produced by the motor brushes.

CONTROLLER BOARD
Refer to the Controller PCB schematic drawing A3000962 SCH during the following discussion
of this circuitry.
•
The main component in the Controller PCB is U5, a micro-controller integrating multiple
peripheral functions including ROM, RAM, timers, I/O interfacing, a programming port, etc.
The micro-controller core operates at +3.3 volts, and its peripherals at +5 volts.
•
The support circuitry for U5 is composed of U2, a 12.0 MHz crystal controlled oscillator,
providing the necessary clock signals.  U3 is the reset chip, which prevents the CPU from
working if the +5 volt supply is outside the range of 4.75 V to 5.25 V.  U3 also keeps U5 in
reset mode for about 300mS after the power is constant.  U4 activates U5 internal flash
programming circuit when pins 2 and 6 of J1 – the programming/test port – are shorted
together.  It sets the microcontroller to single chip mode (internal RAM/ROM) when these
pins are left unconnected.
Note: When troubleshooting this PCB, check all of the above functions before targeting U5 as
the cause of the failure.  Knowing that this chip is functional, we can use a terminal connected to
the test port to allow us the use of the microcontroller built-in test firmware to easily troubleshoot
the rest of the circuitry.
•
Optocouplers U7and U8, diodes D2 through D4, and the components connected to all them
form the test/programming port.  J1 is connected to a terminal – or a PC, if programming –
serial RS232 port, using the programmer adapter A2003981000.  The power for the circuitry
is obtained from the serial port itself.  U8 is the receiver, while U7 sends the microcontroller
output to the terminal/PC serial port.  This galvanically isolated arrangement, allows for more
than 2000 volts between the controller and terminal/PC without damage.  The port is also
“hot-swap,” meaning that power doesn’t need to be turned off to connect or disconnect.  If a
switch connected between pins 2 & 6 of J1 is turned on, it produces a negative-going spike on
the supply of U3, which resets U5, while at the same time U4 activates the flash
programming circuit on U5.  When Hitachi FDT software is running on the PC, the
microcontroller can be erased/reprogrammed in about 30 seconds.

PAD MECHANISM
Refer to Dual Spectrum WTS Z-Density Pad Carrier assembly drawing A3000812000 for the location of
components cited in the following descriptions.  Although this section of the instrument is heavily
mechanical, there are a few electrical components worthy of mentioning.

CALIPER POT HOUSING ASSEMBLY
Refer to drawing F161177-000 for details of this assembly.
The Caliper Pot Housing assembly contains one potentiometer for the Caliper Arm position. The
pot is excited using a buffered +4.00 V originating on the controller PCB (A300962000).  The
wiper arm of the pot, positioned by the displacement of the mechanical arm, yields a
measurement that indicates its current extension.
One of the channels of the internal A/D converter found in the micro-controller on the Controller
board (A3000962000) process the wiper signal.

LIMIT SWITCHES
Please refer to drawing A3000812 WRD
Two limit switches are placed within the mechanical section to interrupt the power to the motor
when the arm is in its fully open or fully closed position.
Switch S1 is placed such that it will trip when movement of the Power Nut reaches a fully open
position of the arm.
Similarly, switch S2 is placed such that it trips when movement of the Power Nut reaches a fully
closed position.
Contoured with a specifically designed surface, the Power Nut travels between these two limit
switches and depresses the actuating arms attached to the switches.  When the actuating arm
depresses the button of the switch, it interrupts the current path to the motor and stops it.

DENSITY PAD ASSEMBLY
Refer to the Pad assembly drawing A3000862000 and the Detector Electronics assembly A3000863000
for the location of components cited in the following circuit descriptions.  See the block diagram below
for major components of the Pad.

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008

The pad electronics consists of two identical channels.  Each channel has a detector assembly connected
to a Pulse Height Analyzer (PHA).  The power coming from the controller PCB in the upper electronics
assembly is routed to the Pad Power Supply (A3000932000), which in turn supplies power to all of the
electrical assemblies in the pad electronics.  The detector assembly has four main components (1) a
scintillation crystal optically coupled to (2) a photomultiplier, (3) a preamplifier, and (4) a high voltage
power supply.
In the tungsten shield, an opening is cut above each crystal detector to form a window for returning
radiation.
The Cs-137 source in the pad cap below the detectors bombards the formation with gamma radiation,
creating photons through multiple scattering in the formation.  As these photons enter the NaI crystals
through the windows in the tungsten shield, the crystals emit bursts of light.  The PM tube that is optically
coupled to the crystal then receives this light and outputs corresponding electrical signals.
Both crystal/PM tube combinations are housed within sleeves containing a spring that keeps pressure on
the assembly.  When the detectors are assembled, the spring compresses and forces the crystal and PM
tube together to ensure a good optical coupling and allows for thermal expansion differences of all the
materials.

DETECTOR ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY9
4.1.1
SCINTILLATION CRYSTAL AND PHOTOMULTIPLIER9
4.1.2
PREAMPLIFIER9
4.1.3

DETECTOR ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
Refer to the Detector Electronics assembly A3000863000 for the location of components cited in
the following descriptions.  For a further breakdown of the electronics, the Long Space (LS) and
Short Space (SS) detector assemblies are A3000862000 and A3000865000, respectively.  The
PHA circuits are discussed in the next section; see section 4.2.
Except for mechanical configuration and placement within the Detector assembly, both the LS
and SS electronic circuits are identical.  See the block diagram of Figure 3 on page 8.
4.1.1
SCINTILLATION CRYSTAL AND PHOTOMULTIPLIER
The crystal used in this tool includes its own Cs137 reference source.  The
photomultiplier is an off-the-shelf unit that has no resistor dividers and connects through
socket/pin contacts to the preamplifier and power supply.
4.1.2
PREAMPLIFIER
Refer to the Dual Spectrum WTS Z-Density Preamplifier schematic drawing
A3000966 SCH during the discussion of this circuitry.
The signal coming from the photomultiplier enters at R8, is inverted by U1 A, and
amplified by U1 B.  This amplified signal is then sent to the PHA board.  The input of
U1 A is also connected to R4.  Through this input, the PHA can apply pulses to test the
gain of the entire signal chain without any additional instrumentation.  The resistor
divider R5 and R11 sets the DC level at the output of U1 B at a known value.
R1, R2 and R3 are connected to the tube anode, and are used to measure the PM tube
high voltage.
4.1.3
HIGH VOLTAGE POWER SUPPY
Refer to HVPS Driver schematic drawing A3000964 SCH and HVPS Rectifier schematic
drawing A3000965 SCH.
The physical construction of the HVPS ties the two small printed circuit boards together
in close proximity to each other as well as other components of the detector assembly.
Sandwiched between the two PC boards is the transformer that develops the high voltage
for the photomultiplier (PM) tube.
The rectifier assembly consists of six almost identical stages that output the voltages
required to the different dynodes of the PM tube.  The first stage has two diodes in series,
to account for the higher voltage that stage provides.
The driver is composed of an HV switch Q1 A&B, Q2 A&B, driven by micro-controller
U1, driving the switches in the proper sequence.  The value of the high voltage output is
proportional to the voltage present on the DRV terminal (pin 2 of J1), coming from the
regulator in the PHA.
U2 is an EEPROM, used to store coefficients, models, and serial numbers of the detector
components.  At power up, the PHA interrogates the EEPROM to retrieve the
coefficients used to set the initial operating point of the detector.

PAD POWER SUPPLY
Refer to the Pad Power Supply schematic drawing A3000932 SCH during the following
discussion of this circuitry.  This assembly provides +28 V, +5 V and +3.3 V to the PHA circuitry.
It routes the communication channels to the PHA’s, providing overload and short circuit
protection.  It also provides the identification signal for each PHA.
•
The +28 V coming from the controller on pin 1 of J1 is routed to pin 8 of P1 and P2.  Diode
D1 protects from inverted polarity in case of faulty wiring.
•
The +5 V regulator is composed of U1 and its associated components.  The current is
monitored by R5, and limits the power output in case of an overload or short circuit.
•
The +3.3 V regulator is very similar to the 5 V regulator.  Pin 4 of U2 is grounded in this case,
setting the regulating voltage to +3.3 V.  In the same manner as with R5, R13 limits the
current in case of overload.
•
Pilot lights PL1 (+5 V) and PL2 (+3.3 V) series resistors are calculated such that their
brightness is the same when the voltages are at their nominal values.  A difference in
brightness gives a visual clue of any abnormal condition.
•
All the outputs are routed to the PHA’s through an RC filter.  In the event of an overload in
any of those voltages, the voltage drop across the series resistors give a good indication of
the power consumption of the PHA on that particular output.

topic: Circuit Description - 4.3 PULSE HEIGHT ANALYZER (PHA) CIRCUITS ...........................................................11
chunk_text:
PULSE HEIGHT ANALYZER (PHA) CIRCUITS 11
APPENDIX A – PROGRAMMING ADAPTER/ FIRMWARE DOWNLOADING/ BUILT-IN

PULSE HEIGHT ANALYZER (PHA) CIRCUITS
Refer to the Density PHA schematic drawing A3000963 SCH during the following discussion of
this circuitry.  It is the main function of this analyzer to sort the incoming pulses according to its
amplitude (hence, its energy) and send the resulting histogram of pulses vs. energy to the
Controller board located in the Upper Electronics assembly.
•
The main component in the PHA board is U7, a micro-controller integrating multiple
peripheral functions including I/O interfacing, A/D converter, serial ports, a programming
port, etc.
•
The support circuitry for U7 is composed of U5, a 12 MHz crystal controlled oscillator,
providing the necessary clock signals.  U2 is the reset chip, which prevents the CPU from
working if the +5 volts are outside the range of 4.75 through 5.25 V.  U2 also keeps U7 in a
reset condition for about 300mS after power-up.  U3 activates U7 internal flash programming
circuit when pins 2 and 6 of J1 – the programming/test port – are shorted together.  It sets the
microcontroller to single chip mode (internal RAM/ROM) when these pins are left
unconnected.

Note: When troubleshooting this PCB check all of the above functions before targeting U7 as the
cause of the failure.  Knowing that this chip is functional, we can use a terminal connected to the
test port to allow us the use of the microcontroller built-in test firmware to easily troubleshoot the
rest of the circuitry.

•
Optocouplers U1 and U6, diodes D1, D2, and D3, and the components connected to all them,
form the test/programming port.  J1 is connected to a terminal – or a PC, if programming –
serial RS232 port, using the programmer adapter A2003981000.  The power for the circuitry
is obtained from the serial port itself.  U6 is the receiver, while U1 sends the microcontroller
output to the terminal/PC serial port.  This galvanically isolated arrangement, allows for more
than 2000 volts between the controller and terminal/PC without damage.  The port is also hot-
swap, meaning that power doesn’t need to be turned off to connect or disconnect.  If a switch
connected between pins 2 & 6 of J1 is turned on, it produces a negative-going spike on the
supply of U2, which resets U7, while at the same time U3 activates the flash programming
circuit on U7.  When Hitachi FDT software is running on the PC, the microcontroller can be
erased / reprogrammed in about 30 seconds.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY 1.0 INTRODUCTION
chunk_text:
2

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008 
INTRODUCTION
The 2234 XA Dual Spectrum Z-Density WTS instrument consists of three major sections: the upper
electronics assembly, the pad mechanism assembly and the density pad.  See Figure 1: 2234 XA Density
Instrument.
The upper electronics assembly is encased in steel pressure housing and contains the following
electronics.
1. Interconnection PC board: This assembly incorporates the open/close relays, the pad and controller
power supplies, and the motor voltage monitor.
2. Controller PC board: This board contains circuitry to handle the communications with the surface
and with the pad electronics. It also controls the open and close relays.

The pad mechanism assembly contains electro-mechanical components.
1. Caliper potentiometer assembly,
2. Limit switches.

The density pad assembly includes the following parts.
1. A 2.5-Curie Cs-137 source,
2. Two scintillation detector assemblies containing individual high voltage power supplies,
3. Signal amplification circuitry for the detector outputs,
4. Pulse height analysis circuitry.



For an overview of how the various instrument components electrically tie together, see Figure 2.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
chunk_text:
3

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008 5

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008

•
All the Instrument Bus (IB) and the wireline conductors are present at J1 terminals,
which get routed to the carrier lower head, through the wire tube.  From these conductors,
the IB signals are tapped, and routed to J3, making them available to the Controller PCB.
•
On connector P1, the pad, caliper pot, limit switches, and motor terminal connections are
made.  The pad wires are routed to J4, which also connects to the Controller PCB.
•
The third connector going to the Controller PCB is J2.  The pad power, +5 V, +3.3 V,
caliper and motor voltage measurements are routed here.  The relays are controlled by the
signals Motor Mode and Motor Dir coming from the Controller PCB.
•
When the +5 V and +3.3 V power supplies operate at their nominal voltages, PL1 and PL2
will illuminate with about the same brightness.  This gives a visual indication that power
is being sent to the controller.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
chunk_text:
6

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008

•
U1 is a 4.096 volt reference that provides a stable reference voltage to the micro-controller’s
internal A/D converter.
•
The pad wires are connected to J4.  Power to the pad is routed through Q1, which is turned
on-off by optocoupler U18 plus Q2.  U20 and sampling resistor R54 measure the pad current.
If the pad current is too high, the controller shuts down the power, to prevent further damage.
Pins 2 & 3 of J4 are reserved for the LS communication channel, while 4 and 5 are dedicated
to the SS channel.  These lines are bidirectional, LVDS1 type.  Both channels are identical,
comprised of an LVDS transceiver (U13, U15), a bus terminator (R31, R45) and over-voltage
protection network (D7, D8, R27, R35 and D9, D10, R38, R49)
•
U10 and U11 are 2-wire I2 C bus2 EEPROMS used to store caliper and density calibrations /
tool hardware revision table (U10).  There are 8 tables of each type available.  The hardware
revision table can be edited by maintenance personnel (using 4509 test box and Benchmark
software) to reflect major maintenance events over the life of the tool.  U11 holds the current
tool address.
•
LED’s PL3, PL4 and PL5 are used to visually check and monitor error conditions.  PL3
signals a command parity error, PL4 a Data Parity error.  PL5 is reserved for other internal
errors.  A detailed report of any error of abnormal condition is always sent to the surface on
the status words.
•
U16 is a 3-wire SPI3 (*) serial bus device that measures the controller PCB temperature.
•
On the lower portion of the schematic, Q3 A and Q3 B drive the Motor Mode and Motor
Direction relays, respectively, on the Interconnect PCB.  D13 and D14 limit any inductive
over-voltage during turn-off and prevent the breakdown of Q3 A and Q3 B.
•
The 4.096 reference voltage at U1 output is buffered by both U17 and U19.  Both op-amps
have a 121 Ohm resistor in series.  The caliper potentiometers have a nominal resistance of
5 kOhms.  The attenuation provided by those resistors sets the voltage across the caliper
potentiometers at a value very close to 4.00 V.  This information is very useful for
troubleshooting, since any deviation from that value is a sign of either leakage, or an open
circuit, on the potentiometer wiring.  The outputs are protected from voltage transients by
TVS diodes D11 and D12.  The caliper measurement is made using two of the
microcontroller A/D channels.  R50/C24 and R58/C27 are the caliper measurement input
noise filters.  There are two caliper measurement circuits available; in the present design,
only one of them is used, but still both measurements are sent to the surface.
•
Transformer T4 and line receiver U14 compose the tool command receiver.  LED PL7 has
been added to help troubleshoot communication problems.  Command length times are very
short, but looking carefully, one can tell if the tool is receiving commands or not.
•
Modes 7, 5 and 2 transmitters have identical topology.  Mode 7 components are T1, D1, U6
and LED PL1, which lights up each time the tool is transmitting in that mode.  This provides
a visual indication of tool response without the need of an oscilloscope.  For Mode 5 the

1 LVDS= Low Voltage Differential Signaling, is a high speed / low power interface bus developed by Texas
Instruments
2 I2 C bus/IIC bus= A two–wire bus interface connecting in a master/slave fashion peripherals and controllers
developed by Philips Corp
3 SPI = Serial Peripheral Interface, a 3-wire bus developed by Motorola Inc.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
chunk_text:
7

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008

components are T2, D5, U9, with PL2 providing a visual indication of the tool sending on
Mode 5.  A very similar arrangement is used for Mode 2, T3, D6, U12 and PL6 are the
components used here.  T3 is different than T1 and T2, to account for the different data rate
of Mode 2.
•
A/D channels monitor critical voltage points.  Resulting measurements are then sent to the
surface.  R11 and C12 provide the +3.3 V measurement.  R32, R33 and C21 monitor the +5 V.
Finally R64, R65 and C33 monitor the pad power supply voltage.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
chunk_text:
8

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008 10

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008

This board is plugged directly on the back of the PM tube socket, and the HV power
supply is, in turn, plugged into it.  The male/female connectors route the HV voltages
to the PM tube dynodes.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
chunk_text:
11

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008

•
TVS diodes D3, D4, D5 and D6 in conjunction with resistors R1, R2, R3 and R4, prevent
damage to the PHA bus drivers in case of a voltage spike on the bus.
•
Both PHA’s have the same hardware and firmware configuration.  The long spacing PHA
is connected to P1.  Pin 5 on P1 is connected to R7, in turn connected to +5 V, and generates
a logic one on pin 5 of P1.  P2 is the SS PHA output.  Pin 5 on this connector is connected to
R11, which is grounded, providing logic 0 on P2-5.  The PHA’s then sense the voltage level
on that pin to determine to which detector they are connected to.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
chunk_text:
12

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008

•
U4 is a 4.096 volt reference that provides the reference voltage to the micro-controller’s
internal A/D converter.
•
Transceiver chip U8 provides two-way communication between this board and the Controller
board in the upper electronics.
•
The preamplifier has an extra signal input, present on pin 5 of J3.  If a test signal is required,
U7 will apply that signal to C23, R21, and R27.  This allows for a very thorough test of all
the PHA signal chain; this is possible, even with the tool downhole.  When the test signal is
activated, a sharp peak should appear on a given portion of the spectrum, giving a very good
quality test of the signal chain.
•
U15 and its associated components take one of the micro-controller PWM outputs, and
generates the Low Level Discriminator (LLD) voltage.  This voltage is sent to U16 circuitry,
which is set above the noise level of the input signal.
•
A sample of the high voltage is received at J1-6, which is converted to a DC voltage
proportional to the PM high voltage at the output of U20, and sent to the high voltage power
supply driver, and one of the A/D inputs.  The high voltage power supply driver is composed
of pass transistor Q1, Q2 A&B, R29, R32, R33, R34, R36 and R42.  The gain command
changes the duty cycle of one of the micro-controller PWM outputs, generating the high
voltage drive at the output of U12.  This is sent to the non-inverting input of the regulator
while the measured high voltage drives its inverting input.  This forms a feedback loop that
keeps the high voltage stable.  U18 measures the current consumption of the high voltage
power supply.  R44 and R49 form a voltage divider that is connected to one of the A/D inputs
of U7.  The micro-controller, and the surface system, then knows (1) the drive signal (gain
command), (2) the voltage applied to the High Voltage power supply, (3) the current flowing
through that power supply and (4) the high voltage applied to the photomultiplier.  This
allows for a full diagnostic of the high voltage power supply through the test port, or from the
surface with the tool downhole, without any additional instrumentation.
•
U10, U11 and A/D converter U9 form the pulse valley measuring circuit, while U14, U17
and A/D converter U13 form the pulse peak measuring circuit.  The micro-controller can then
appropriately measure the pulse amplitude regardless of the DC level present at the output of
the preamplifier.  For any conversion to be started, the pulse height must have minimum
amplitude.  This objective is filled by the low level discriminator circuitry, made up of U16
and its associated components.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
chunk_text:
13

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 131078-945                                  FEBRUARY 2008

APPENDIX A – PROGRAMMING ADAPTER/ FIRMWARE DOWNLOADING/
BUILT-IN TEST FIRMWARE

Programming Adapter

Both the PHA’s and Controller boards can be connected through the test port to a PC using the
Programmer Adapter A2003981000.  The connection is hot-swap, which doesn’t require any
special precaution in connecting/disconnecting.  It is also galvanically isolated, making it safe
to use in high ESD environments.

Firmware Downloading / Built-in Test Firmware

The microcontrollers in the PHA’s and Controller PCB’s are flash type devices.  The parts are
field-programmable using the software package FDT.  Flash Development Toolkit, is free software
installed on the PC.  It is available from Renesas/Hitachi, and is included as part of the firmware
installation files.
The firmware running on both controller and PHA has a series of built-in test routines, intended for
lab use, that allows troubleshooting the tool with minimal or no instrumentation.  This is useful
when troubleshooting at the well site or in situations where a 4509 test system is not available.
When a PC is connected to the test port and running terminal emulation software (Hyperlink or
similar), during power-up the terminal will show a message describing the firmware version
running in the microcontroller, and a command prompt.
Typing a question mark (?) will display a short list of available commands.  If you type the first
letter of the command followed by the question mark, a description of that particular command’s
options is displayed.  All the built-in routines are designed with troubleshooting in mind, using a
minimum of instrumentation, all of which should provide a skilled technician with most of the
elements needed for proper maintenance and troubleshooting of the tool.

1

ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY


INTRODUCTION2 

DISASSEMBLY

Item numbers in brackets refer to drawing A3000812000 and its BOM unless otherwise noted.
Be sure to wear proper protective gear when working on this instrument.

EXPOSING THE ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
1. Remove the Thread Protector [100] from the uphole end by rotating the Spin Collar with
a Spanner Wrench.
2. Remove Retaining Ring [8, F153188-000] holding the 32-Pin Connector [7, F153188-
000].  Use a T-handle to pull the Connector out of the Top Sub [1] and unscrew the
pigtail wiring from the back of it.
3. Remove Top Sub [1] by rotating it with a large C-wrench.
4. Using a large strap wrench, rotate the Pressure Housing [6] off.  Carefully slide the
housing over the electronics being careful not to damage any components or wiring.
5. The electronics assembly [171] resides within the Cradle [165], but can be removed for
troubleshooting as needed.  Simply remove the seven (7) screws [167] holding it onto the
Cradle and disconnect the two connectors (P1 & J1) attached to the Interconnect PCB
(A3000961000).
Note: If repair work is to be done on the Electronics, proper ESD conditions should be
present.

REMOVING DETECTOR PAD
1. For ease of disassembly and assuming a horizontal position, rotate the instrument so that
the Detector Pad is toward the sky and the Backup Arm [73] is toward the earth.  Motor
the instrument to the fully opened position.  Use a large screwdriver to prop the Pad Arm
[75] such that the Pad is sufficiently out of the carrier body.
2. Remove the screw [123] and washers holding the Pad Arm Pin [120]; see cross-section
R-R for details.  From the opposite side, use a small punch to tap the Pad Arm Pin out.
3. Remove the screws [10, A3000861000] holding the Short Wear Plate [11, A3000861000]
onto the Detector Pad Assembly [171].
4. Removing the Short Wear Plate exposes the Spin Collar holding the Detector Pad to the
Pad Plug Assembly.  Rotate this Spin Collar with a small spanner wrench to disconnect
the Pad.
Caution:  Do not allow the Detector Pad to drop freely when disconnecting the Pad Plug.
Ensure it is properly supported by someone or something.

Caution: The Detector Pad Assembly is very heavy; ensure good footing before lifting it
off of the carrier.

5. Inspect the O-rings on the Pad Plug and replace if needed.

REMOVING DETECTOR ELECTRONICS
1. First remove the Detector Pad as per the previous topic.
2. See drawing A3000861000 and its BOM.  With the Pad situated on a workbench, remove
the two screws [5] holding the locking pin [4].  Use a 10-32 screw or T-handle to remove
the locking pin itself.  Inspect the O-rings [12] on the locking pin and replace if needed.
3. Once the locking pin is removed, the Detector Electronics can be pulled out of the Pad
housing.

REMOVING THE MOTOR
1. Expose the electronics assembly [171] following the steps found in section 2.1.  This
process will also expose the motor [166].
2. Remove the four screws [16] holding the motor mounts [168].  This will free the motor.
However, the motor shaft is still connected to the coupling [17].  Carefully slide the
motor towards the PC boards and the coupling will separate.  Leave the coupling spacer
(middle piece) with the coupling half that remains with the cradle --- this will keep you
from losing it.

REMOVING THE BOTTOM SUB 4 

UPPER ARM ASSEMBLY REMOVAL
1. Slip the horseshoe bracket (P/N 141859-100) over the back up arm to prevent its full
deployment.  This will help raise the pad up away from the carrier.
2. Motor the tool open and remove the pad pins [51].   If the Detector Pad Assembly is still
installed, remove it according to instructions found in section 2.2.

REMOVING THE PAD ARM

1. Remove the Detector Pad Assembly [171] according to the steps found in section 2.2.
2. Use a hammer and punch to remove the Stop pin [92].  It has two roll pins; drive it hard
enough in one direction to shear off the spirol pin [79] on one side, then drive in the
opposite direction to shear off the second spirol pin.  When the second spirol pin is
sheared, you can drive the stop pin completely out.  Figure 2 shows the location of this
stop pin.
This stop pin is reused during reassembly, so it must be cleared of the remnants of the
spirol pins.  Use a small punch to clear the holes.


apply power and motor it until the open limit switch is activated.  Carefully lift the upper
arm assembly up.  Place a large screwdriver or wrench between it and the carrier to keep
the arm supported.
4. See section I-I of the drawing.  With a punch, drive out the pad arm pin [88]; it will shear
the spirol pin(s) [79].  See Figure 3.  This pin is reused during reassembly, so it must be
cleared of the remnants of the spirol pins.  Use a small punch to clear the holes.

REMOVING THE BACKUP ARM
1. Motor the tool fully open and support the pad arm [72] with a wrench or screwdriver,
similar to that seen in the right side graphic of Figure 4.
2. See section G-G of drawing A3000812000.  With a small punch, drive out the two
spirol pins [79] of this view.  This frees up the pad pin [84].  Use a larger punch to
drive out the pad pin.  See Figure 5.



linkage.
4. Knock out pin 82 using a punch.  Hit it hard enough to sheer the spirol pin [79] holding it
in place.  With this pin removed the arm is free to be removed from the carrier assembly.
Clean out the remnants of the spirol pin before reusing pin 82 in the assembly process.

REMOVING THE CALIPER POT ASSEMBLY

Refer to Caliper Pot Assembly (P/N 161177-000)

1. To remove the caliper pot assembly [50], remove the 4 screws [112] holding the cover
plate [111] to the tool.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 2.10 SPRING AND LINKAGE ASSEMBLY REMOVAL .................................................8
chunk_text:
SPRING AND LINKAGE ASSEMBLY REMOVAL

CAUTION:

BEFORE PROCEEDING, ENSURE THE INSTRUMENT
ARMS ARE FULLY OPEN TO RELIEVE THE SPRING
ASSEMBLY FORCES.

1. See assembly drawing A3000812000 and its BOM.  Remove the four screws [112]
holding cover [111] to access the spring assembly.
2. Remove the cap screw [44] and the stop block [43].
3. Remove the pressure cap [42] and the packing nut [38] on the lower end of the pull rod
[37] by pulling them toward the caliper pot assembly [50].
4. Along one side of the mandrel, remove the retaining rings [47 and 49] from either end of
the connector strap [46].  Refer to drawing A3000812000, sections B-B and E-E.
Remove the connector strap and remove a second set of retaining rings [47 and 49].
5. At the uphole end of strap, punch the pin [45] out.  Slide the spacer [41] from the pull rod
[37] and out through the mandrel opening.
6. At downhole end of the strap, punch the pin [48] out and remove the second strap.  Refer
to drawing A3000812000, section E-E.
7. Expose the spring assembly by removing the upper pad arm assembly.  See instructions
for doing this in section 2.6.  Remove the 2 lock nuts [66] and the 2 screws [65].  Remove
the side load bracket [126] and punch the pin [137] out from the large screw [62].
8. Remove the 4 cap screws [57] from the spring mount plate [56].
9. Remove the caliper pot assembly according to instructions found in section 2.9.
10. Slide the spring mount plate, the springs [58 and 59], the retainer plate [60], the spring
rod [54], the screw [62], and the link connector ring [61] uphole; and then lift out from
mandrel opening.

ASSEMBLY
Item numbers in brackets refer to drawing A3000812000 and its BOM unless otherwise noted. 

INSTALLING THE ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
1. Slide the Electronics assembly back into the Cradle [165] leaving the pigtail wiring
hanging out the end.
2. Fasten the Electronics to the Cradle using the seven (7) screws removed earlier.
3. Plug in connectors (P1 & J1) into their respective receptacles on Interconnect PCB
(A3000961000).
4. Carefully slide the Pressure Housing [6] over the electronics being careful not to damage
any components or wiring.  Ensure O-rings are in place and coated with Lubriplate.  Use
a large strap wrench to rotate the housing until it is tight.
5. Install Top Sub [1] at the end of the housing by rotating it with a large C-wrench.
6. Twist the pigtail connector onto the 32-Pin Connector [7, F153188-000] and shove it and
the wiring up into the Top Sub.
7. Install the Retaining Ring [8, F153188-000] to hold the 32-Pin Connector [7, F153188-
000] in place.
8. Install the Thread Protector [100] by rotating the Spin Collar with a Spanner Wrench.

INSTALLING THE DETECTOR PAD
1. If not already in position, motor the arms to the fully opened position.  Use a large
screwdriver to prop the Pad Arm [75] such that the Pad is sufficiently out of the carrier
body.  Ensure O-rings on the Pad Plug Assembly are in good condition and coated with
Lubriplate.
2. This step is probably best done as a two-man operation --- have one man raise the upper
arm assembly and prop it up with a screwdriver while the other man carefully guides the
Detector Pad [171] into place.  Both men work together to mate the two pieces together
so that the spin collar engages the threads of the detector.  Start threads with hand
pressure only to ensure that no damage is done in the event that threads get crossed.
Then, with a small spanner wrench, rotate the spin collar until it bottoms out against the
shoulder.
Caution: The Detector Pad Assembly is very heavy; ensure good footing when installing
it onto the carrier.
3. Install the Short Wear Plate [11, A3000861000] onto the Detector Pad Assembly [171]
using the screws [10, A3000861000] removed earlier.

INSERTING DETECTOR ELECTRONICS
1. This step assumes that the Detector Pad [171] is removed from the carrier.  See drawing
A3000861000.
2. If installed, remove the screws [5] and locking pin [4] so that the Detector Electronics can
be inserted unobstructed.
3. Slide the Electronics into the Pad Housing [1] such that the hole in the Electronics lines
up with the locking pin hole.
4. Inspect the O-rings [12] on the locking pin and replace if needed.
5. Reinstall the locking pin [4] and secure it with screws [5].

INSTALLING THE MOTOR
1. If the motor has been replaced, ensure that the coupling [17] and spacer are in place when
assembling.  Also, ensure that motor mounts [168] are in place.
2. If the motor has been replaced, ensure that the two motor wires are reconnected to the
proper pins of connector P1 --- red wire to pin S; black wire to pin T.
3. Align the motor coupling [17] with the actuator coupling and engage fully.
4. The holes of the motor mounts must align with the holes of the Cradle.  You may need to
momentarily apply power to the motor for this alignment to happen.
5. Install and tighten the four screws [16] to fasten the motor mounts to the Cradle.
6. Complete the assembly by following the steps found in section 3.1.

INSTALLING THE BOTTOM SUB
1. If the connector sub [151] was also removed, it must be reinstalled first.  Ensure O-rings
[139] are good and coated with Lubriplate.  Screw it onto the carrier using a large
Spanner wrench.  Also ensure that O-rings [147] are good and coated with Lubriplate.
2. Push wiring back into the connector sub and seat 32-pin connector assembly [157].
Align hole in connector body with hole in sub.  Fasten connector in place using socket
head screw [155].

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 3.6 INSTALLING THE UPPER ARM ASSEMBLY ......................................................11
chunk_text:
INSTALLING THE UPPER ARM ASSEMBLY
1. Carefully set the upper pad arm plate [74], the upper pad arm [75] and pad plug onto the
carrier mandrel, aligning the holes.
2. If wiring was cut or disconnected, reconstruct the wires of the upper arm assembly at the
center sub.  Refer to section A-A on drawing A3000812000.
3. Install the eight screws [160] on the upper pad arm plate [74].
4. Fasten the upper arm assembly to the carrier with the upper pad pin [78]; see section D-D
of the drawing.  Locate the pin in the middle of the hole using a slender punch to “feel”
for the groove.  Hammer in a spirol pin [79] to lock the pad pin in place.
5. Motor the tool open and slip the horseshoe bracket (P/N 141859-100) over the back up
arm to prevent its full deployment.  This will help raise the pad up away from the carrier.
Install the pad pins [51] and secure them in place with spirol pins [83].

INSTALLING THE BACKUP ARM

Note: This step is best accomplished when the Detector Pad is not installed.
1. Motor the tool fully open and support the pad arm [72] with a wrench or screwdriver,
similar to that seen in the right side graphic of Figure 4.
2. Pull the rocker arm assembly out of the carrier body as far as possible.
3. Insert the Backup arm [73] into the slot of the available rocker arm [70].  Install pin 82
and secure it with a spirol pin [79].
4. Push the backup arm [73] into the carrier far enough to align the holes in the carrier to the
hole in the backup arm.
5. See section G-G of drawing A3000812000.  Slide pin 84 through all of these aligned
holes and secure in place with two spirol pins [79].

INSTALLING THE PAD ARM
1. Lift the arms of the rocker assembly.  See section I-I of the drawing A3000812000.
Install the pad arm [72] and insert pin [89].  Use snap-ring pliers to install the Truarc ring
[90] holding pin [89] - see graphic of Figure 6.


2. See section I-I of the drawing.  Insert pad arm pin [88] and secure in place with spirol
pin(s) [79].  Note: some of these arm pins only have one slot and will require only one
spirol pin.

INSTALLING THE CALIPER POT ASSEMBLY

Refer to Caliper Pot Assembly (P/N 161177-000)

1. See section A-A of drawing A3000812000.  Connect the 3 caliper assembly wires at the
center sub and install the caliper assembly [50] into the carrier.  Connect the linkage near
section D-D by driving in spirol pin [55] that holds the caliper pot assembly to the spring
rod [54].
2. Secure the caliper assembly [50] to the carrier using the 4 cap screws [53] removed
earlier.  See section C-C for details.
3. Motor the tool fully closed.  Install the cover plate [144] using screws [135].
4. Install cover plate [111] using screws [112].
5. Install cover plate [101] using six screws [135].

SPRING AND LINKAGE ASSEMBLY INSTALLATION
1. Slide the link connector ring [61], the retainer plate [60], the springs [58 and 59], the
spring mount plate [56], and the spring rod [54] into the carrier.  Insert the spring screw
[62] into the spring rod from the downhole end and make up the spring package.  Secure
this to the carrier with 4 screws [57].
2. Install the pressure cap [42], with the packing nut [38], onto the pull rod [37].  Secure it
in place with the stop block [43].
3. Link the pull rod to the spring assembly with connector straps [46].  Secure the pull rod
to the spring assembly using connector pins [45 and 48].
4. Slide the linkage bracket [64], the links [70, 71, and 67], and the arms [72 and 73] onto
the end of the spring screw.  Secure them in place with the pin, side load bracket, and
screws [137, 126 and 65].
5. Install density screws [87] through the side of the carrier and into the slots on the linkage
bracket [64].

OF THE FOLLOWING PROCEDURES. SOURCE REMOVAL
INSTRUCTIONS ARE IN COMPONENT -977 OF THIS
MANUAL.

The 2234 XA can be taken apart for repair or for normal maintenance.  Although the order found
in this component of the manual can be considered sequential, each topic can also be considered
as stand-alone, if the need arises.  Topics covered disassemble the instrument first and later topics
cover the reassembly of those same items.

1 
 
 INSTALLATION/REMOVAL                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY   
 
 CONFIDENTIAL                              P/N 131078-952                            FEBRUARY 2008 
 
 
 
 
 
WARNING 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS 
ARE USED IN THE TESTING AND 
CALIBRATION OF THIS INSTRUMENT, 
AS WELL AS ITS NORMAL OPERATION 
 
Always wear your assigned film badge/personal dosimeter.   
Store the radioactive materials when not in use.  Limit your 
exposure to that necessary to perform the task.  You must be 
familiar with all rules and regulations concerning the use of 
radioactive materials.  Refer to the "BA Safety Manual", 

 INSTALLATION/REMOVAL                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY   
 
 CONFIDENTIAL                              P/N 131078-952                            FEBRUARY 2008 
 
1.0 SOURCE INSTALLATION (Refer to Pad Drawing A3000861000). 
 
 
WARNING 
 
KEEP ALL UNAUTHORIZED PERSONNEL AWAY.  ONLY THE PERSON 
DIRECTLY INVOLVED WITH THE SOURCE INSTALLATION SHOULD BE 
IN THE IMMEDIATE AREA.  ALL OTHER PERSONNEL MUST REMAIN 
CLEAR.  THE SOURCE CATCHER MUST BE INSTALLED PRIOR TO 
SOURCE INSTALLATION IF THE 2234 XA Z-DENSITY INSTRUMENT IS 
VERTICALLY POSITIONED OVER THE WELL BORE. 
 
1. Place the shipping container/shield (P/N 080729-000) and the source handling tool (P/N 
095447-000) in the area designated for source installation. 
 
2. Position the shipping container/shield so that there is a clear path allowing unobstructed 
movement of the handling tool (arms fully extended) from the shield to the instrument source 
receptacle. 
 
NOTE 
 
It is not necessary to motor the pad open.  The source can be installed with                                    
the pad motored closed.  The individual installing the source must have a    
thorough understanding of the mechanical operation required to secure                 
the source in the source receptacle. 
 
3. Simulate installing source and verify the following: 
 
a. The instrument is positioned to facilitate access of the source receptacle. 
 
b. The path of the handling tool (with your arms fully extended) from the shield to the 
source receptacle may be covered with one fluid movement. 
 
c. The securing screws [18 and 19] and washer [13] are not damaged and do function 
properly. 
 
WARNING 
 
TO KEEP RADIATION EXPOSURE TO A MINIMUM, THE FOLLOWING 
STEPS: MINIMIZE EXPOSURE, MINIMIZE TIME, AND MAXIMIZE 
DISTANCE MUST BE PERFORMED QUICKLY WITHOUT COMPROMISING 
SAFETY. 
 
4. Ensure handling tool is securely attached to the source, and with your arms fully extended to 
maximize the distance between you and the source, remove the source [15] from the shield. 
 
5. Install the source and verify it is properly positioned in the receptacle.  Unscrew the handling 
tool from the source.  Use the opposite end of the handling tool to install the source securing 
screws [18 and 19].  Ensure washer [13] is installed onto screw 18 before inserting it. 
 
3 
 
 INSTALLATION/REMOVAL                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY   
 
 CONFIDENTIAL                              P/N 131078-952                            FEBRUARY 2008 
NOTE 
 
Install screw [19] before screw [18]. 
 
The washer [13] on screw [18] will overlap the edge of the source. 

SOURCE REMOVAL (Refer to Pad Drawing P/N A3000861000) 
 
WARNING 
 
KEEP ALL UNAUTHORIZED PERSONNEL AWAY.  ONLY THE PERSON 
DIRECTLY INVOLVED WITH THE SOURCE REMOVAL SHOULD BE IN 
THE IMMEDIATE AREA.  ALL OTHER PERSONNEL MUST REMAIN  
CLEAR.  IF THE 2228 XA Z-DENSITY IS VERTICALLY POSITIONED OVER 
THE WELL BORE, THE SOURCE CATCHER MUST BE INSTALLED PRIOR 
TO SOURCE REMOVAL. 
 
1. Place the shipping container/shield (P/N 080729-000) and the source handling tool (P/N 
095447-000) in the area designated for source removal. 
 
2. Position the shipping container/shield so that when using the handling tool (with your arms 
fully extended) there is a clear path allowing unobstructed movement from the instrument 
source receptacle to the shield. 
 
WARNING 
 
TO KEEP RADIATION EXPOSURE TO A MINIMUM, THE FOLLOWING 
STEPS: MINIMIZE EXPOSURE, MINIMIZE TIME, AND MAXIMIZE 
DISTANCE MUST BE PERFORMED QUICKLY WITHOUT COMPROMISING 
SAFETY. 
 
3. With the handling tool (and with your arms fully extended), remove the securing screw [18] 
and then remove the other screw [19]. 
 
4. Thread the handling tool into the source [15].  Once the source is securely attached to the 
handling tool, remove the source from the receptacle and install it in the shipping 
container/shield. 
 
5. Lock the shipping container/shield and return it to proper storage. 
 
6. Reinstall screws [19 and 18] into pad housing for safe keeping.

1 
 
  REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURE             2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY 
 CONFIDENTIAL                             P/N 131078-956                             FEBRUARY 2008 
 
The “standard” –956 section does not exist for this manual.  Instead, this section contains the  
significant Manufacturing Test Procedure P/N 131078-856. 
This document targets a manufacturing audience and may contain statements, equipment, 
drawings, procedures and other references that may not be applicable or available for field use.  
Some equipment and documents listed in these procedures is specific in nature, but equivalent 
devices can be easily substituted in most cases.  Included in (but not necessarily limited to) the 
lists are the following: 

ESD Protection Specification 
 
PIII or better with WIN 2000 and SP2 
 
Benchmark Software 
 
4509 XA Test Rack 
A7000398 PRC

Fluke 87 or equivalent with a x100 HV probe 
Digital Multimeter 
148986-000 & 189566-000 
Jumper Cable / Male adapter 
156143-000 
DC Power Cable  
Tektronix 2245 A or equivalent 
100 MHZ. Oscilloscope

1 
 
 HEAT TEST PROCEDURES                  2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY  
P/N 131078-959  
FEBRUARY 2008 
 
 
In anticipation of use in a high-temperature environment (within tool specifications), the 
electronics only1 may be operated in an oven to verify performance.  Otherwise, no heat  
test for this instrument is required. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                
1 The potentiometer assembly is filled with silicone oil for pressure equalization.  The instrument as a 
whole should not be oven heated without hydrostatic pressure present to oppose the expansion of the oil.  
Therefore, the electronics section is the only part that should be tested at oven temperatures.

FUNCTIONAL TEST 2
2.0 FUNCTIONAL TEST 

TEST USING LOGGING SYSTEM

HEAT RUN
Caution: place only the cradle electronics section of instrument into oven for this heat test.

•
Connect instrument to 4509 XA Test system for this test.  Use cable A3000332000 to
connect directly to the instrument and to J9 (WTS-IB) on the back of the panel.
•
Apply 180 VAC from 2020 or 2021 power supply.
•
Make sure total current draw is approximately 40mA ±10mA.
•
Launch Benchmark software.  In the Workspace Explorer pane, right click on the 2234 XA
Tool #1 (0 D) and select “Connect” to the “4509 Panel.”


•
Set the oven temperature to 350ºF but do not turn on the heater.
•
In the Benchmark software, select the sequence Subset E from the drop-down list of the
Sequence Toolbar,
and click the Play button
to execute it.
Leave it running for at least 1 minute.
•
View the results by selecting the Test Subset View for Tool#1
tab in the
upper-right pane.  There should be no errors in either Mode 5 or Mode 7.  See graphic of
•
Click the Stop button
to stop the test.
•
Select and run Subset 0 test,
.
P/N 131078-953
JANUARY 2015

CONNECTING TO A PC
The 2234 XA Density has built-in test routines – which run concurrently with the logging software –
to help in testing/troubleshooting each individual assembly.  A dumb terminal or a PC running
terminal emulation software can be used.
Physical connections:
All three PCB’s (IB interface, Controller, and PHA’s) have the same connection, built around a 2mm
3x2 connector.  This interface is galvanically isolated, allowing for potentials more than 1000 V
between the grounds of the PC/Terminal and the PCB being tested.
The standard test cable is 198760-000, and allows connecting any of the boards to a 9-pin serial port
of a PC.
Pin assignments for the connector (2 mm pitch) on PHA, Controller, and IB interface PCB’s are as
follows.
PC DTR  1
2
Not connected
PC GND  3

GENERAL PROCEDURE
Testing equipment required for Level 3 PM depends on the test mode being used to check the tool’s
functionality.
COMMON MAINTENANCE REGARDLESS OF TEST
•
Inspect O-rings and replace as necessary.
•
Remove the caliper pot assembly cover and check piston travel (1/2” exposed). Clean off
mud debris and reinstall cover.
•
Remove the pressure housing and replace all O-rings.
•
Disassemble the pad linkage so the springs can be removed (see section 131078-955 for
disassembly instructions).  Inspect the springs for corrosion and damage.  Inspect pad
linkage for damage, broken pins, corrosion, “sticky” movement, etc.  Reassemble using
reliable parts only.
•
Run a tap through all threaded screw holes.
•
Tighten all screws on all electrical and mechanical assemblies.
•
Disengage the pad arm assembly from the pad and check the pad wiring for damage.
Replace O-rings.
•
Inspect pad surface for excessive wear.  Replace as needed.
•
Inspect all sealing surfaces of the pad housing for corrosion.

sweep rates, may show distortions that are not present in the original signal.  If in doubt,
re-check with an analog scope.
