topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - LEVEL 3 PM                                                 2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY 3.1 EQUIPMENT REQUIRED
chunk_text:
9

LEVEL 3 PM                                                 2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY 
EQUIPMENT REQUIRED
ECLIPS Surface System
Multimeter

GENERAL / ELECTRICAL
•
Complete PM1 electrical tests.
•
Refer to instrument wiring diagram A3000812 WRD.
•
Note that the following tests do not fully check all of the tool capabilities or functionality.
To test some functions that do not appear below, use the built-in test signal.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 3.3 POWER SUPPLY TESTS
chunk_text:
POWER SUPPLY TESTS
•
Remove hardware and unplug Controller board from Interconnect board.
•
On Interconnect PCB (A3000961000), check for the following voltages (±10%) on pins of
connector J2.  Use pin 12 for voltmeter common.  See the pin location in connector graphic
below.
1. +5 VDC on pin 7

2. +3.3 VDC on pin 8

3. +28 VDC on pin 11

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 3.4 IB INTERFACE TEST
chunk_text:
IB INTERFACE TEST
•
Plug Controller board back into Interconnect board and fasten with removed hardware.
•
Run Eclips software and send Subset E.  Verify that error-free data is sent using Mode 5 by
checking Subset E.
•
Check that the I.B. Interface is able to send information coming from the Controller board,
using the M5 SPI channel, by checking an error-free Subset 0.  Monitor values such as
controller temperature (CTEMP) and 5 volt power supply (CONT5 V) voltage.

CONTROLLER TEST
•
Establish communications with the tool.
•
Verify motor operation using the open and close commands.  There should be no telemetry
errors, and the motor should stop abruptly at the end of the travel.  This means that the
motion is terminated by the activation of the limit switches.
•
Open the sonde arm, and verify that the motor current is between 150 and 250 mA.
P/N 131078-953
JANUARY 2015

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - LEVEL 3 PM                                                 2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
chunk_text:
10

LEVEL 3 PM                                                 2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
•
Close the sonde arm.  The current while closing should not exceed 350 mA, but increases to
about 385 mA during the last two inches of the arm travel.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 3.6 PAD ELECTRONICS TEST
chunk_text:
PAD ELECTRONICS TEST
•
Manually send a gain command of 2000.  Check the measurements coming from the PHA’s.
The temperature (LTEMP, STEMP) should be close to the room temperature.  The +5 V
power supply (L5 VPS, S5 VPS) should be within the range of 4.75 to 5.25.  Verify that the
high voltage power supply measurements are within the ranges established in Table 2.
•
Manually send a gain command of 3000. Verify that the HV current of the LS and SS
(LHVI/SHVI) are within the range established in Table 2.
•
If the current increases more than 4 mA (400 units), or if it reads out of tolerance, replace the
HVPS, preamp board or PM tube in that order and repeat the test.
•
Write down the LHVI and SHVI values at gain 2000 and 3000 in the ZARM order and use
them as reference for future preventive maintenance.
•
Manually set the gain back to 2000.

Long Spacing
LHVDR
LPMHV
LHVI
Short Spacing
SHVDR
SPMHV
SHVI
Value range
1200 to 1850 V
1100 to 1475 V
250 to 1250
Activate the test signal (tool cmd 0 D99 0001 for long spacing, and 0 D9 A 0001 for the short
spacing).  A sharp peak, two channels wide, should be observed around channel 26.  A
displaced peak implies an incorrect gain in the signal path.  A peak wider than two channels
implies that there is noise or ringing on the signal.
Preamp Board Visual Inspection
•
Inspect both preamp boards using a flashlight from behind the board and look for some
marks of internal leakage within the PCB wafer in the area between the HV pin and ground.
•
Replace any board with signs of internal leakage as shown in Figure 4.













1 If desired, check additional quality curves and compare with the values found on Page 16.

P/N 131078-953
JANUARY 2015

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - LEVEL 3 PM                                                 2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
chunk_text:
11

LEVEL 3 PM                                                 2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY


The HV circuit leakage is more noticeable at higher temperatures. Look for some RDR files
of the tool from previous recent jobs, where the well temperature has exceed 250ºF, and
playback the files to verify that the HV current has remained within tolerance.
•
If the HV current is not within its limits, change either the HVPS module (A3000977500) or
the Preamp board (A3000966500) or the PM tube to fix the problem. A bad preamp board
normally cause a short in the HVPS, however a leakage in the preamp board can cause the
HV current to increase.
•
The leakage in the preamp board is normally found in the area where the PM HV is close to
the ground plate. If a new preamp board is not available, drilling a hole (0.040”, bit #60) in
the board, as shown in Figure 5, will make the short disappear. Order a new preamp board
(A3000966500 rev B) and replace it as soon as it arrives.

P/N 131078-953
JANUARY 2015

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - LEVEL 3 PM                                                 2234XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY
chunk_text:
12

LEVEL 3 PM                                                 2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY

A new revision of the preamp board is being implemented which will include one cut
between the PM highest voltage pins and the feed-thru ground pin. See Figure 6.


FMN to replace all the boards in the field. However, this new board revision will be included
in new manufactured tools. The new board has the same part number and will be available at
the end of Q3-2013.
•
For high profile jobs or PCL jobs, in addition to the above tests it is recommended to
perform a heat test and monitor the behavior of the HV current.

LEVEL 3 PM                                                 2234 XA WTS DUAL SPECTRUM Z-DENSITY


•
Verify that HRD1_S + HRD2_S does not change more than ±2% over temperature.




If “drifts” for Longspace and Shortspace are in opposite directions, differences in LS and SS
must be less than 2% drift.  Example: LS is +0.9% and SS is –1.0%, total drift is 1.9%. That is,
add the absolute drift values and result does not exceed 2%.
•
Now, ramp oven temperature to 350 F.  Let kit soak for 30 minutes once oven reaches 350 F.
Take ten minute data points after the 30 minute hold.  Compare averages to room
temperature values using formulas above.  Maximum drift for each detector should not
exceed ±2.5%.
If “drifts” for Longspace and Shortspace are in opposite directions, differences in LS and SS
must be less than 2% drift.

•
With Subset 0 running, turn the oven’s heater OFF but leave the circulating fan running.
•
After tool has cooled to room temperature, turn the oven completely OFF, click the Stop
button
to stop the test and remove power from tools.

topic: Brief Description of Service - 1.0 BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
chunk_text:
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
The 2334 XA CCL Instrument measurement is based upon the principle that a changing
magnetic flux within the instruments sensor coil generates a voltage across the terminals of
that sensor coil. The magnetic field of a CCL magnet is affected by any magnetically
sensitive material close to it, such as the casing in a borehole. A collar or joint in the casing
changes the magnetic flux field including the flux passing through the sensor coil ends
adjacent to the magnets, causing an electric voltage to be generated.
As the south pole of the magnet enters a collar, the flux field is changed within the coil and
generates a voltage of negative polarity, for example. In turn, the north magnetic pole
generates a positive voltage as it passes. Therefore, as the instrument passes by each collar or
discontinuity in the casing, there is generated across the terminals of the coil a voltage
approximating a sine wave.
The in-tool CCL board processes the sine-wave voltage from the coil into digital signals. The
surface acquisition requests data via the telemetry from the CCL instrument at regular
intervals. The CCL instrument answers by sending data in a formatted block called Subset 0.
After each transmission, the tool electronics reset and resumes accumulating data. The tool is
also capable of storing tables containing revision-level data in non-volatile memory.
The data from the CCL instrument is processed in the surface system and converted into a
collar location versus depth curve.
The 2334 XA Focus CCL training supplement was not available at the time this manual was
printed. It will be added when it becomes available for publication.
130997-936 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005

BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
Refer to block diagram in Figure 1. The Focus CCL (casing collar locator) instrument is part
of the Focus instrument string. The Focus CCL instrument locates collars in flush-joint casing
as well as standard casing collars. Magnets on either side of the CCL coil induce a magnetic
field in the casing (or collars). As the tool crosses a casing joint, the induced magnetic field is
disturbed. This disturbance is detected by the CCL coil and the internal electronics process
the coil signals for transmission to the surface through the wireline.
The Focus CCL has a “full” 27-pin Focus bus and can be run above or below the telemetry
tool.
The Focus CCL contains a detector section and an electronics section. The main components
of these two section are as follows.
•
Detector Section:
�
Two magnets and a coil
•
Electronics Section:
�
DC power supply that includes the following:
– Filter PCB assembly
– Controller PCB assembly
�
CCL Board that includes the following:
– mode 2 communications channel
– acquisition timing
– A/D control
130997-945 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
3
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Circuit Descriptions


DC POWER SUPPLY
The 2334 XA CCL Electronics uses one EMI input filter Hybrid and one ±5 V power supply.
They both are mounted directly onto the main chassis.
To save space and provide a convenient place for wire connections, a PC board is mounted to
the chassis side directly opposite each potted Hybrid and soldered to pins from each Hybrid
that extend through holes in the chassis. The power-up timing and inhibit circuitry PCB is
mounted on the chassis opposite the EMI input filter Hybrid and the Common mode output
filter PCB is mounted on the chassis opposite the power supply Hybrid.


130997-945 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
4
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

DC POWER SUPPLY3 

INPUT FILTER AND POWER CONTROL CIRCUIT
The power control board provides the following functions. Refer to Figure 2 during the
following discussions.
1. EMI input filter for 28 V bus
2. Local +5 V control voltages
3. Power up reset, low bus voltage shutdown (20 V)
4. Timed startup delays (microprocessor)
5. Isolated individual power inhibits

JUNE 2005
5
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

2.1.1
EMI Filter Circuit
EMI filter hybrid U1 is shown in Figure 3. It should be noted that U1 does NOT reside on
the PCB but is bolted to the chassis. The power control board is mounted on the chassis side
directly opposite the potted Hybrid. This filter keeps any noise generated by the local power
supply module from getting out of the tool and contaminating the raw 28 V supply. The 28 V
bus power source comes into the EMI filter through its associated PCB terminals E1 and E2,
through the filter hybrid U1, back onto the PCB and eventually leaves the board through
terminals E3 and E4. The 28 V output on terminals E3 and E4 go to the input terminals of the
power supply.
Because the hybrids are sealed, there is no repair of the unit. It either works or it doesn’t.
Components on the PCB however can be replaced if needed.

Local 5 V Control
A +5-volt supply is generated locally with a ground reference to the 28 V power bus to
keep the tool power floating with respect to input power, As you will see, the control
board is isolated optically and magnetically from tool power. The supply consists of a
single dropping resistor (R3) and reference Zener diode (D1) to establish the voltage.
This supply is connected to the output of the EMI filter module (U1). See Figure 3.

130997-945 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
6
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

2.1.3
Power-Up Reset
U4 is a power monitor IC that monitors the local 5 V supply and will release a reset line to
the microprocessor when the 5 V supply exceeds 4.75 V. A second purpose of this chip is
to provide a power hold-off or reset if the bus voltage is below 20 volts. The precise
threshold voltage is established by the voltage divider consisting of R6 and R8. These
values were chosen such that when 20 volts or more (for instrument power) is present on
pin 4 of U4 the reset chip removes the LOW on pin 7. The LOW on pin 7 removes the
reset from microcontroller U3, allowing it to run. 20 volts was chosen as the minimum
bus value necessary to insure proper startup of the hybrid power supplies. Figure 4
shows the power-up circuit.

Power Startup Delay (microprocessor)
The CCL is just one of many instruments connected to the focus power bus. When power
is first applied the hybrid power modules draw significant “startup” current. If all the
modules were allowed to start at the same time an overload condition would result. The
purpose of the “Startup delay” circuit is to insure an orderly, progressive start up
sequence. Each tool is assigned a startup time as indicated by Table 1.
Putting solder dots on the appropriate jumper pads enables the microprocessor to set the
delay time required. Delay times are in milliseconds, and their jumpers are shown in the
JUNE 2005
7
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

Delay Time (milliseconds)
Jumpers
Telemetry
0
None
TTMA
200
JP1
Neutron
400
JP2
Caliper
600
JP1 + JP2
Density
800
JP3
Acoustic / NT
1000
JP3 + JP1
Minilog
1200

CCL

JP1 + JP2 + JP3
Induction

JP4
Future
Add 200 milliseconds for each new jumper
JP4 + JP1, etc.


Refer to the microprocessor schematic Figure 5. The heart of the power control circuitry
is a programmable microcontroller (U3). Operating power comes from the local +5-volts
supply discussed earlier. The microprocessor clock is generated by an internal RC
oscillator. The frequency of the clock is approximately 1 MHz and is set by selecting
appropriate values for resistor R7 and capacitor C3. The oscillator only runs for the brief
time between release of reset and the completion of the delay cycle. At the end of the
delay cycle the microprocessor is put into sleep mode and the oscillator is stopped. To
keep the oscillator running, to observe it, or check its frequency you can put a solder dot
across JP 5. Jumper JP5 must be installed before power is applied or it will not take
effect. Installing JP5 will prevent the timer from timing out and the oscillator can be
observed on TP 5.

JUNE 2005
8
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

The microprocessor is held in reset until sufficient bus voltage is achieved and reset pin 4
of U3 goes high, starting the CPU. Control port (pin 18) is configured as an input during
the time the CPU is in reset the. This input configuration allows the pull-up resistor R4 to
hold Q1 on. With Q1 on; D2, D3, and D4 are effectively grounded. This board can
control up to 3 hybrid power modules. Typically, each hybrid inhibit pin will be
connected to E5, E6, or E7. The CCL only has one power hybrid and it is connected to
E6. Diodes D2, D3, and D4 isolate the hybrid supplies from each other in the case of
multiple hybrids.
The first task of the microprocessor is to read the input ports tied to the program jumpers
JP1, JP2, JP3, and JP4. The program calculates the delay necessary from the combination
of jumpers, waits the required time, then lowers inhibit control line TP2. This low turns
off Q1 allowing any inhibit lines attached to go high, turning on there respective power
hybrids.
2.1.5
Isolated Individual Power Inhibits
Startup delay jumpers and how they inhibit the output of the power supply during the
power up sequence was discussed previously. There is an additional method to inhibit
individual power supplies(Figure 6) if required by tool design. The CCL only uses one
power supply and does not use the manual inhibit feature of this board.


130997-945 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
9
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

U2 shown in Figure 6 is a dual opto-coupled switch. The switch is controlled by passing
a current thought its input LED causing the switch to close. Power to operate the LED’s
comes from a tool’s main +5 V supply via terminal E8 and through limit resistors R1 and
R2 to the LEDs within U2. To activate the switch, the cathode of each LED should be
brought to ground via terminal E9 or E10. Part 1 of the switch is tied across the inhibit
control line BKI3 and GND. Grounding E10 will inhibit the power supply connected to
inhibit control pin E7. In a similar manor grounding E9 will inhibit control on E6. Diodes
D2, D3, D4 keep the inhibit controls from interacting with each other.

POWER SUPPLY
Refer to Figure 7 during this discussion.
As previously discussed, U1 is bolted directly to the chassis and a PCB containing filter
components is mounted on top of U1’s pins. Input power comes from the EMI filter
previously discussed, through terminals E1 and E2 of the PCB and finally to pins 1 and
10 of the DC-to-DC converter module U1. Pins 6, 7, and 8 are tied to chassis ground to
guarantee any noise generated by the DC-DC converter will return to the converter. Pin 2
of U1 is the Inhibit control pin. When held low (GND ref to pin 10) the converter is held
in shut down. The internal PWM is stopped and no output voltage will be generated
during this time. The inhibit signal comes from the control PCB via terminal E9. Three
independent windings of choke L1 and capacitors C3, C4, C5, C6, and C7 form a
common mode output filter. Terminals E3 – E8 provide +5 V, common, and -5 V to the
tool circuits. No provision is made for trimming the output voltage.

10
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

FOCUS CCL PCBA
Refer to Focus CCL PCBA drawing A3000425000 and Schematic A3000425 SCH during the
following discussion. Waveforms for many of the test points are included at the end of this
section to support the following discussions.
The Focus CCL PCBA Schematic A3000425 SCH has 3 sheets.
Sheet1 –  Power distribution and filtering, CPU, Reset, and firmware programming port.
Sheet 2 –  CCL coil input circuits, Gain selection, Signal filtering, and A/D.
Sheet 3 –  FPGA contains address decoders, timers, I-bus, Manchester encoder / decoder, I-
bus line drivers and receivers.

INTRODUCTION
It is advantageous to review the block diagram shown in Figure 1 to understand how the
CPU interacts and controls the whole CCL system. The 28 V instrument power is filtered
and regulated to ±5 V by the power supply section and fed to the CPU. The CPU further
divides and filters instrument power into the ±5 V analog and +5 V digital voltages.
The CCL coil converts disturbances in the magnetic field produced by the interaction
between the casing collar and the tools internal magnets into a voltage whose amplitude
is proportional to pipe size, collar size, and speed. The voltage from the coil is buffered
and presented to a mux with a gain of one (1 X). The buffered signal is then amplified
times two (2 X) and also presented to the mux. The operator can select the 1 X or 2 X
signal by surface commands. The selected signal is filtered by a low pass filter before
being received by the A/D. The A/D samples the signal asynchronously at a rate of 25
samples per second (40 msec). Each sample is stored in a ring buffer that is periodically
sent to the surface once/second. Commands from the surface control the gain and data
block transmission. The FPGA provides 2 functions. First, it encodes and decodes the
Manchester signals to and from the I-bus. Second, it generates a 40-msec interrupt to the
CPU. The CPU in turn samples data from the A/D at this 40-msec rate. Refer to operating
guide 130997-977 for data block content and subset definition.

SHEET 1
The bottom left corner of sheet 1 shows how operating power enters the board at P1-1,
P1-3, and common at P1-2. P1-4 labeled AGND is not used. L1, C15, C16 decouple
digital noise on +5 VDC from analog power +5 VA.
The top right corner shows the CPU oscillator and reset chips. U2 provides a reset signal
to the CPU after VCC is applied. U3 is the main oscillator and runs at 11.0592 MHz. This
frequency allows a precise baud rate to be generated internal to the CPU (U1) for proper
firmware downloading using Analog Devices MicroConverter® Windows Serial
Downloader (V6.02), which is included with Hex code Zip File.
The bottom middle of sheet 1 shows U4, an RS-232 level converter chip and connector
JP3. JP3 provides a connection point to a PC for downloading firmware to the CPU. U4

® MicroConverter is a registered trademark of Analog Devices, Inc.
130997-945 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
11
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Circuit Descriptions
and its associated components provide level shifting between the RS-232 signal levels of
the PC and the CMOS levels required by the CPU. U4 and JP3 are only used during
programming at the surface and have no other function.
The CPU (U1) located at the center of sheet 1 controls communication to the Ibus, data
acquisition, and timing. Some components of interest are:
•
D1 and D2 are required to prevent a differential voltage between AVDD and DVDD
greater than 0.5 V during power up.
•
JP2, pin 41, when installed, puts the CPU into “programming mode.”
•
R2, pin 40 (signal “EA”) is used by the CPU chip to select internal or external
program access. This pin must be held high, internal program access. There is no
external program storage in this application.
•
Data and address bus are provided through pins 28 – 39 and 49 – 52.
•
Pins 24 and 25 provide read / write control when transferring data to the FPGA. Pins
43 and 44 are control signals for the A/D and pin 45 and 46 control channel selection
on the input multiplexer.
•
Pin 22 (AD_PD) allows for reduced power consumption by the A/D and must be held
low for A/D to run (never activated).
•
Pin 18 is an interrupt from the FPGA and happens whenever a command with
address “00” (Universal) or “67” (Primary) is decoded by the FPGA from the serial
Manchester stream.
•
0-ohm resistor R8 makes the connection between AGND and DGND.
•
Pin 10 is an output from the internal DAC and is used as a test signal connected to
input mux channel 7. It is set up as a fixed signal of 2.0 Volts and used when “Cal”
mode is selected.
•
Pin 11, 19, and 26 are the control / data signals for the A/D.
•
JP2, pin 4 is not used.

SHEET 2
Sheet 2 contains the analog recovery circuitry. The detector coil, external to the CPU
PCBA, is hard wired to terminals E4 and E5 (top left) to present the shortest, noise-free
path to the input instrument amplifier U6. D5 protects U6 from any high voltage
transients produced by the detector coil. Terminals E6 and E7 are connected to CPU
PCBA traces that run the length of the board and are connected to P1-10 and P1-5. It was
intended that a jumper could be installed between E4 / E6 and E5 / E7 to allow the
detector coil to connect to P1, when used in a different application.
The output of U6 is presented to mux channel 1 of U8. The output of U6 also goes to
U11 A where it is amplified by 2 and presented to mux channel 2. The operator can
selects either output using the Gain high command or Gain low command, when in log
mode. Should a large signal be present such as in a small hole at high speed, the signal
output at U11 A will be “clipped” by virtue of the output hitting the supply rails and
distorting the signal. The output of U6 at this time will still be unsaturated and if selected
by the operator will produce a clean signal as the log curve.
U8 has one additional input signal, DAC1. This signal has a fixed value of 2.0 Vdc
generated by the CPU DAC. The signal can be selected by mux U8 and is used as a “cal”
reference signal. All other inputs to U8 are grounded and used as a “zero” reference.
130997-945 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
12
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Circuit Descriptions
Channel output selection on U8 is controlled by the A0 and A1 signals, originating from
the CPU.
The selected output of U8 is presented to low-pass filter U11 B, buffered by U12, and
then presented to the A/D (U7) input “IND”.
U5 is the reference source (2.5 V) for the A/D (U7). U9 A is a buffer that is required by
the A/D and is used to drive the A/D’s internal ladder network.
Control of the A/D is accomplished directly by the CPU signals AD_CS, AD_CNVST,
AD_BUSY. Data is transferred over AD_Data using AD_CLK.

SHEET 3
Communications to and from the instrument is via the Focus instrument bus. Sheet-3
shows the instrument bus interface for Mode 2 communication as well as the FPGA
(U13) that encodes / decodes Manchester signals from the bus. T1, U14, and associated
components provide the bus receiver and convert the differential signals from the bus to
CMOS-level signals presented to the FPGA decoder T2, U16, and associated components
for the bus driver. The driver converts the CMOS level Manchester-encoded signals to
differential signals that are compatible with the I-bus. Chip U15 is the 12-MHz oscillator
that drives the decoders inside the FPGA.
The first function of FPGA (U13) is to receive the Manchester serial stream (UDI) from
U14, decode it, and present it as a 16-bit parallel word. When a word has been decoded
with the proper sync and parity, and contains the CCL address, an interrupt (M2-INTR) is
generated that alerts the CPU to get the data. The CPU (U1) reads the 16-bit word as two
8-bit bytes.
When the CPU needs to send data, it writes 2 bytes to the FPGA. Upon writing the last
byte, the encoder begins sending the 16-bit word out serially (BZO/, BOO/) through bus
driver U16 and T2. Some signals of interest are supported by waveforms that are located
at the end of the section. See Table 2.
The second function of the FPGA is to generate and maintain a 32 bit real-time clock that
increments at a 1.0-msec rate as long as the tool is powered. This clock is read during
every acquisition cycle and sent to the surface to tag each block of data for later depth
correlation. Additionally, an interrupt is generated every 40 msec and sent to the CPU,
which triggers an A/D cycle.
130997-945 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
13
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

WAVEFORMS 13

FIGURES
Focus CCL Power Control Schematic 4

INTRODUCTION
The 2334 XA Focus Casing Collar Locator Instrument Assembly should never need to be
completely disassembled. This procedure disassembles the CCL assembly to the point where
troubleshooting, repair, parts replacement, and routine preventive maintenance can be easily
done.

REQUIRED DRAWINGS

pin Female Focus CCL

Connector Assembly, 27-pin Female Focus CCL

2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly Procedures

DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
Disassembly of the 2334 XA Focus CCL is done in two stages. First, the detector / electronics
assembly is removed from the pressure housing. Second, the detector section is separated
from the electronics section and the detector section is completely disassembled.

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 4.1 REMOVING DETECTOR / ELECTRONICS FROM HOUSING
chunk_text:
REMOVING DETECTOR / ELECTRONICS FROM HOUSING
Refer to drawing A3000449000 and its BOM during this disassembly procedure.
Numbers in brackets [  ] in this section correspond to the item numbers on this drawing
unless specified otherwise.
CAUTION:
Do not attempt to separate the bottom sub [item 4] from the
housing [item 2] until after the detector / electronics assembly
[item 1] has been removed from the housing / bottom sub
assembly.
____  1.
Unscrew and remove the top and bottom thread protectors [items 8 and 9,
respectively].
____  2.
Remove the retainer ring [item 7] from the top groove on the top sub [item 3]
and pull the 27-pin female connector block [item 6] and pigtail out of the top
sub.
____  3.
Remove the 27-pin female connector block [item 6] from the pigtail by
rotating the lock ring on the 32-pin KPT connector.
____  4.
Secure the CCL instrument in a chain vise. Wrap the chain around the
pressure housing [item 2].
____  5.
Use the 2.75-inch wrench to unscrew the top sub [item 3] from the housing
[item 2]. Slide the top sub off the 32-pin KPT connector and pigtail.
____  6.
Screw the 1/4-20 T-handle puller tool [item 13] into the top of the detector /
electronics assembly [item 1] and pull the detector / electronics assembly
straight out of the housing [item 2].
____  7.
Use a small pin spanner wrench to unscrew the bottom sub [item 4] from the
housing [item 2].
Further disassembly is not required for troubleshooting, preventive maintenance, and for
parts replacement other than the coil or magnets. Coil or magnet replacement requires
complete disassembly of the detector section. Section  4.2 provides complete disassembly
of the detector section.
130997-955 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
3
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly Procedures

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 4.2 DETECTOR / ELECTRONICS DISASSEMBLY
chunk_text:
DETECTOR / ELECTRONICS DISASSEMBLY
This disassembly procedure should only be done if magnets, the coil, or one or more
through-wires require replacement.
Refer to drawing A3000450000 and its BOM during this disassembly procedure.
Numbers in brackets [  ] in this section correspond to the item numbers on this drawing
unless specified otherwise.
____  1.
Remove the two screws from the cable-clamp halves and unscrew the cable
clamp [item 29] from the 32-socket connector [item 28]. Slide the cable
clamp out of the way. Do not discard the two cable clamp screws.
____  2.
Remove and discard the silicone tape [item 30] and 0.75-inch wide tape [item
31] from the wire bundle.
____  3.
Individually push the contact sockets out of the 32-pin connector [item 28].
Cut from the wires and discard the contact sockets. Cut as close as possible
to the contact sockets to conserve wire length.
____  4.
Unsolder the black and white coil wires from terminals E4 and E5 of the
Focus CCL PCBA. These terminals are located at the top end (opposite end
from the 10 pin connector) of the CCL PCBA.
____  5.
Unscrew and remove the four 8-32 X 2.375-inch screws [item 26] from the
bottom side of the top flange of the electronics assembly.
____  6.
Grip the CCL coil [item 5] and pull the detector components [items 35,7,6, 8,
9, and 3] straight away from the electronics section far enough (about 2 to 3
inches) to access the wires feeding into the top of the electronics section. Do
not twist the CCL coil.
____  7.
Reach into the gap created between the detector components and the
electronics section and pull two or three of the untwisted wires out of the
detector components. Removing these wires from the bundle will allow the
detector components to more easily slide off the wire bundle.
____  8.
Grip the CCL coil [item 5] and carefully pull the detector components [items
35,7,6, 8, 9, and 3] straight off the wire bundle. Again, do not twist the CCL
coil as it is being removed.
____  9.
Slide the CCL header [item 2] off the wire bundle.
____  10.
Unscrew and remove the four 8-32 X 2.00-inch screws [item 35] holding the
top mounting plate [item 7] and CCL coil header [item 6]. Discard the tie-
wraps [item 39].
____  11.
Bend the tabs of the modified washer [item 9] away from the flats of the top
pole piece connector [item 8]. Unscrew the top pole piece connector from the
CCL coil [item 5].
____  12.
Repeat step 9 for the bottom modified washer [item 9] and pole piece
connector [item 8].
130997-955 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
4
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly Procedures
____  13.
Separate the top and bottom pole pieces [item 3], top and bottom magnets
[item 4], and the CCL coil [item 5]. These pieces are held together with RTV
3145 adhesive. Remove the RTV 3145 adhesive from these pieces after
separation. Do not discard the 13.00-inch piece of 0.375-inch shrink tubing
[item 41] associated with the CCL coil.

ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
Assembly of the 2334 XA Focus CCL is done in two stages. First, the detector and electronics
sections are assembled. Second, the detector / electronics assembly is assembled into its
pressure housing.

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 5.1 DETECTOR / ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
chunk_text:
DETECTOR / ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
Refer to drawing A3000450000 and its BOM, wiring diagram A3000450 WRD, and
Insert the black and white wires from the coil [item 5] through the 1/8-inch
hole in the 0.375-inch shrink tubing [item 41]. The wires must be oriented
toward the bottom end (7-inch) of the shrink tubing as shown in Figure 2.
Tape or twist the ends of these two wires together to make it easier to
identify them later in this procedure.

130997-955 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
5
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly Procedures

____  2.
Align the 1/8-inch hole in the shrink tubing with the notch in the OD of the
top flange of the coil [item 5] as shown in Figure 2. Hold the ends of the
black and white wires and push the top end of the 0.375-inch shrink tubing
[item 41] up through the bottom end ID of the coil. Do not twist the shrink
tubing. The shrink tubing will stop when the 1/8-inch hole in the shrink
tubing and the wire entry point in the coil ID align.
____  3.
Assemble detector components as described in the following steps. Refer to
NOTE:
Work quickly through Steps A through G to prevent the RTV 3145
adhesive [item 36] from setting before these steps are completed.

A.
Apply a thin coat of RTV 3145 adhesive [item 36] to the top and bottom flats
of each of the two CCL magnets [item 4]. Spread the adhesive such that it
covers the magnet circumference, starting ~1/4-inch from the ID hole and
extending out to ~1/4-inch from the magnet OD.
B.
Slide the magnets [item 4] over the 0.375-inch shrink tubing [item 41] and up
against the top and bottom flanges of the coil [item 5].
C.
Slide the top and bottom pole pieces [item 3] over the 0.375-inch shrink
tubing [item 41] and up against the top and bottom magnets [item 4]. The
milled out surfaces must face away from the magnets.
D.
Slide the modified washer [item 9], single tang end first, over the 0.375-inch
shrink tubing [item 41]. Insert the tang into the hole in the milled out surface
of the top pole piece [item 3].
E.
Slide the pole piece connector [item 8] over the 0.375-inch shrink tubing
[item 41], through the ID of the modified washer [item 9], top pole piece, and
top magnet. Screw the pole piece connector into the coil [item 5] and tighten.
Bend the top tangs of the modified washer against the flats of the pole piece
connector.
F.
Repeat Steps D and E for the bottom modified washer [item 9] and pole
piece connector [item 8].
G.
Wipe away any RTV 3145 adhesive [item 36] that may have squeezed out
during tightening of the pole piece connectors [item 8].
____  4.
Slide the CCL header [item 2], milled-out side toward the top of the tool,
over the wire bundle and up against the top flange of the electronics
assembly.
____  5.
Separate two or three of the untwisted wires from the wire bundle.
____  6.
Make a fishing wire from 16-gauge buss wire (F222803000) and solder to
the top end of the wire bundle. Do not solder the straight wires separated in
step 5 to the buss wire.

130997-955 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
6
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly Procedures

____  7.
Push the bus wire up through the 0.375 shrink tubing [item 41] from the
bottom end of the detector section. Hold the detector section stationary and
pull the buss wire until the wire bundle appears at the top of the 0.375-inch
shrink tubing [item 41].
____  8.
Hold wire bundle stationary and slide the detector components down over the
wire bundle until the bottom pole piece [item 3] is two to three inches from
the CCL header [item 2]. Do not twist the detector components while
pushing down over the wire bundle.
____  9.
Cut and remove the buss wire. Remove 1/8-inch of insulation from the top
end of each wire.
____  10.
Solder the two or three untwisted wires separated in step 5 to the 16-gauge
buss wire and carefully work the buss wire up through the shrink tubing and
out the top of the detector components.
____  11.
Use the buss wire to carefully pull the straight wires up through the detector
components. Avoid kinking or twisting the wires. Cut and remove the buss
wire.
____  12.
Push the black and white coil wires down through the center hole in the top
flange of the electronic assembly.
____  13.
Install a cable ties [item 39] around the 0.375-inch shrink tubing / wire
bundle to form strain relieves and snug. Install the cable ties flush with the
heads of the top and bottom pole pieces [item 8] as shown on the assembly
drawing and Figure 1.
____  14.
Hold the top of the wire bundle stationary and push the detector components
down firmly against the CL header [item 2] / top flange of the electronics
assembly.
____  15.
Align the holes in the top flange of the electronics chassis [item 1] with the
holes in the CCL header [item 2] and push the electronics chassis against the
CCL header.
____  16.
Apply thread lock adhesive #532 [item 27] to the threads of the 8-32 X
2.375-inch screws [item 26]. Insert the screws through the top flange of the
electronics chassis [item 1],  CCL header [item 2] and tighten into the pole
piece [item 3].
130997-955 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
7
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly Procedures

____  17.
Verify that the following wires are still made up as twisted pairs.
Wire Gauge
Colors
Function
22
Red / Black
± Instrument Power
22
Orange / Yellow
± Motor Power
24
Gray / White
± TDO
24
Black / White
± Mode 7
24
Brown / White
± Command
24
Red / White
± Channel 1 / Mode 2 Data
24
Orange / White
± Channel 2 / Mode 5 Data
____  18.
Slide the CCL coil header [item 6] and then the top mounting plate [item 7]
over the wires and 0.375-inch shrink tubing [item 41] and up against the top
pole piece [item 3] at the top of the detector assembly.
____  19.
Double 1/4-inch Benha 686 tubing [item 40] over the wires and shrink tubing
at the top of the detector assembly. Push the tubing into the top mounting
plate [item 7] about 0.25-inch as shown in Figure 3.

NOTE:
Orient the raw ends of the 1/4-inch Benha 686 tubing [item 40] toward the
top end. Heating the raw ends of the tubing with a heat gun will help
reduce fraying of the tubing fibers.


Apply thread lock #523 adhesive to the threads of the four 8-32 X 2.00-inch
screws [item 35]. Align the screw holes in the top mounting plate [item 7],
CCL coil header [item 6], and pole piece [item 3]. Insert the screws through
the top mounting plate [item 7], CCL coil header, and tighten into the pole
piece [item 3].

130997-955 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
8
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly Procedures

____  21.
Use Hi-Temp solder [item 32] to solder the black and white wires from the
CCL coil [item 5] to the CCL PCBA [item 10], black wire to terminal E4 and
white wire to terminal E5. These terminals are located at the top end
(opposite end from the 10 pin connector) of CCL PCBA.
____  22.
Individually crimp the contact sockets (F230462000) onto the free end of
each wire using the contact crimping tool. Refer to crimping instructions in
document 093703-000.
____  23.
Slide the cable clamp [item 29] onto the wire bundle, threads toward the top
of the tool.
____  24.
Refer to wiring diagram A3000450 WRD. Use the contact insertion/removal
tool (typically supplied with the cannon connector kit) to push the contacts
into the correct cavity of the 32-socket connector [item 28].
____  25.
Wrap the top end of the 1/4-inch Benha 686 tubing [item 40] with the 0.75-
inch wide tape [item 31]. Wrap the tape flush with the top of the tubing. Do
not wrap the tape tightly.
____  26.
Wrap silicone rubber tape [item 30] tightly around the 0.75-inch wide tape
[item 31].
____  27.
Slide the cable clamp [item 29] up the cable and screw it into the 32-socket
connector [item 28]. Secure the cable-clamp halves with the two screws
supplied with the cable clamp. Check to ensure that the cable clamp is
holding the wire bundle securely. If not, wrap the taped area with additional
silicone rubber tape [item 30].
____  28.
Perform the Preliminary Checks and Continuity / Resistivity Checks
described in the Repair / Maintenance Procedure section 130997-956.

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 5.2 ASSEMBLE DETECTOR / ELECTRONICS INTO HOUSING
chunk_text:
ASSEMBLE DETECTOR / ELECTRONICS INTO HOUSING
Refer to drawing A3000449000 and its BOM during this assembly procedure. Numbers
in brackets [  ] in this section correspond to the item numbers on this drawing unless
specified otherwise.
Replace O-Rings and inspect and threads and O-Ring grooves for pitting, damage, or
wear. Replace all damaged or worn parts prior to assembly. Refer to the Level 3 PM
procedure document (130997-953) for inspection, repair, and parts replacement.
____  1.
Secure the housing [item 2] in a chain vise such that the bottom sub [item 4],
detector electronics assembly [item 1], and top sub [item 3] can be easily
installed.
____  2.
Lubricate the O-Ring and threads of the bottom sub with Lubriplate grease
[item 11]. Screw the bottom sub [item 4] into the bottom of the housing [item
2]. Use the appropriate size spanner wrench to tighten the bottom sub.
130997-955 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
9
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly Procedures

____  3.
Align the alignment pin on the top flange of the detector electronics
assembly [item 1] with the alignment mark on the bottom sub [item 4] and
fully seat the detector electronics chassis into the pressure housing / bottom
sub [items 2 and 4]. If necessary, use the 1/4-20 T-handle puller tool [item
13] to seat the chassis in the pressure housing.
____  4.
Liberally apply Lubriplate grease [item 11] to the threads of the top sub.
____  5.
Push the 32-pin KPT connector and pigtail up through the top sub [item 3]
and screw the top sub into the top of the pressure housing [item 2]. Use the
2.75-inch wrench to tighten the top sub.
____  6.
Plug the 32-pin KPT connector into the bottom of the 27-pin female
connector block assembly [item 6] and rotate the lock ring to secure.
____  7.
Twist the cable three turns, align the alignment pin on the Focus CCL 27-pin
connector [item 6] with the top sub [item 3], and push the Focus CCL 27-pin
connector into the top sub. If necessary, use the 10-32 T-handle puller tool
[item 14] to seat the 27-pin connector into the top sub.
____  8.
Install the retainer ring [item 7] into the top groove on the top sub [item 3] to
lock the Focus CCL 27-pin connector [item 6] in place.
____  9.
Perform the Charge Magnets procedure described in the Repair /
Maintenance Procedure section 130997-956 if magnets were replaced.
____  10.
Lubricate the threads of the two-piece split collar [item 5] and ID threads on
the top thread protector [item 8] with Lubriplate grease [item 11].
____  11.
Install and tighten the top thread protector [item 8].
____  12.
Lubricate the ID threads of the bottom sub [item 4] and the OD threads of the
bottom thread protector [item 9] with Lubriplate grease [item 11].
____  13.
Install and tighten the bottom thread protector [item 9].
130997-955 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005

INTRODUCTION
This section contains a series of tests that will help with troubleshooting the Focus CCL. A
magnet charging procedure is also included.

CONTINUITY / RESISTIVITY CHECKS 4

CONTINUITY / RESISTIVITY CHECKS
Perform all insulation and continuity checks with the ohmmeter set in the relative (REL)
mode. This setting will null the resistance of the test leads. Continuity is defined as less than
0.1 ohm after deducting test-lead resistance. Open is defined as greater than 100 Meg-ohms.
Refer to assembly drawing A3000450000 and wiring diagram A3000450 WRD during the
following checks.
____  1.
Use a DMM to verify insulation between all pins of the top 27-socket Focus
female connector and chassis backbone, and the bottom 27-pin Focus male
connector and chassis backbone as follows.
From
To
Reading
Chassis
All pins except 11 and 12 of 27-socket Focus
Female Connector
Open
Chassis
All pins except 11 and 12 of 27-pin Focus male
connector
Open
Chassis
27-socket / pin focus connectors pins 11 and 12
>1 Meg ohm

____  2.
Use a DMM to check for wire-to-wire leakage between the top 27-socket Focus
female connector sockets; socket 1 to socket 2, etc. All should read open except
pins 11 to 12. Repeat for the bottom 27-pin Focus male connector.
P/N 130997-956
JUNE 2005
Baker Atlas
5
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

____  3.
Use a DMM to check for continuity of through wires between the top 27-socket
Focus female connector and the bottom 27-pin Focus male connector. Resistance
must be ≤ 0.2 ohm1. Point-to-point checks are listed in the table below.

FOCUS CCL TEST SYSTEM SETUP
Connect the 2334 XA Focus CCL to the test system as shown in Figure 1.


JUNE 2005
Baker Atlas
8
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

PC SETUP FOR TEST SOFTWARE
Refer to the 4509 XA Lab PC Test System Operating / Maintenance Manual P/N 140614-915
for detailed test system operating instructions. The Test Software, P/N 199633-000, should be
installed on the PC used for testing. Configure the test setup as shown in Figure 1. The
following sequence is critical, because the Test Software monitors instrument current and will
shut down if certain criteria are not met.
____  1.
Power up the PC and allow it to boot normally. Do not launch the Test Software
yet.
____  2.
Use the designated cable to connect the 4509 XA Test Panel to the tool to be
tested. Apply power to the test panel.
____  3.
Launch the Test Software as detailed in Section 6 of the Lab PC Test Panel
Operating Procedures (140614-915). Fill in the appropriate edit or combo boxes
with the information that you wish to save with the current test. Only the top two
combo boxes require an input to continue. See Figure 2 for an example of this
Welcome dialog. Fill in the boxes as follows:
•
Select the Tool Type combo box lists all available tools that can be
currently tested using this system. Choose MatriX CCL V1.
•
Select Telemetry Type as 4509 XA2 if you are communicating directly to
the Test Panel as shown in Figure 2.
All edit and combo boxes below are optional.
•
Operator’s Name – type in the tester’s name.
•
Note and enter the serial number of the instrument you are testing in the
Tool Serial Number edit box.
•
Department is another combo box. Choose an appropriate department from
the available list.
•
Enter into the Location edit box anything that describes where you are
located.
•
Enter anything that may be beneficial in remembering the conditions under
which you performed the test in the Description of Test edit box.
•
Software errors of any kind are recorded in a file. You can limit the
maximum number of error entries into this file by typing a number into the
Maximum Number of Errors to Log to ErrorLog.txt edit box.

2  The Focus Test Panel has evolved through several different series number changes, but functionally remains
the same throughout. The 4509 NA, 4509 NB and 4509 XA are all equivalent.
P/N 130997-956
JUNE 2005
Baker Atlas
9
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures


Click the OK button when you are satisfied with all your entries.
If you selected the “4509 XA” as the Telemetry Type, another combo box opens.
It is the 4509 XA Configuration dialog box and will be similar to the one shown
in Figure 3.

JUNE 2005
Baker Atlas
10
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

•
Every 4509 XA Test Panel display should show a different IP Address. Enter
the displayed address into the Panel IP Address edit box. Figure 3 shows an
example IP Address only – do not use this as your entry.
•
The Mode combo box lists available configurations that are used by the Test
Panel. Select "focus Instrument Bus" for this type of testing.
____  5.
When testing Focus instruments, a safety feature is established in the 28 V
Current Limit Settings section. This feature is activated if the Enable Tool
Power-Off option box is checked. The current entered in the Trigger Level edit
box is the absolute current limit for the instrument under test. Set the level
according to the current draw of your instrument. Check the instrument
specification sheet (130997-025) if you are unsure.

NOTE:
The current value you enter is absolute. Power to the tool will be turned off if
tool current exceeds the set value. The test software will also need to be
restarted. So, the current value you enter should allow for variances between
tools of the same type.

____  6.
Click the OK button to close the dialog box.
____  7.
Perform the tests in the following sections.

VOLTAGE MEASUREMENTS
It is important to check for proper voltages before performing the dynamic checks with the
PC.
____  1.
Ensure that connector P2 from the Focus CCL PCBA is disconnected to
minimize damage in case of incorrect wiring.
____  2.
Turn on the PC and test panel, and the apply 28 V to the Focus CCL under test.
____  3.
Verify that the voltages listed in the following table are present.

____  4.

INTRODUCTION
Level 3 maintenance should be performed on the 2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument Assembly
every four months to ensure the integrity of the instrument. 
REQUIRED DRAWINGS AND DOCUMENTS

Instrument Assembly
•

Repair / Maintenance Procedure, 2334 XA Focus CCL
Instrument Assembly
130997-953 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
2
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Level 3 PM

PROCEDURE
Refer to assembly drawings A3000449000 and A3000450000 and their BOMs, and wiring
2334 XA Asset No.
_______________________
Date Completed:
_______________________
Technician’s Name:
_______________________
Check off (�) each step in the procedure as it is completed, and place the completed
document in the tool’s history folder when Level 3 PM is complete. Item numbers in this
procedure are referenced to drawing A3000449000 and its BOM unless otherwise specified.
____  1.
Thoroughly pressure-wash the Focus CCL Instrument with thread protectors
installed and wipe dry.
____  2.
Remove the top and bottom thread protectors [items 8 and 9].
____  3.
Remove the Focus CCL Detector / Electronics section from the pressure housing
following the disassembly instructions in the Disassembly / Assembly section
(130997-955) of this manual.
____  4.
Inspect external parts for nicks, thread dings, and other obvious deficiencies.
Replace any item that is unserviceable.
____  5.
Check the sockets of the 27-pin female connector [item 6]. Check to ensure that
the sockets are free of debris. Test fit a male pin into each socket to ensure that
they are all a tight fit. Replace loose-fitting sockets.
____  6.
Check the 27-pin male connector [item 25, A3000450000] for bent or broken
pins. Straighten bent pins and replace damaged pins as necessary.
____  7.
Visually inspect the detector / electronics assembly for loose, damaged, or
broken components and wires. Tighten, repair, or replace as necessary.
____  8.
Replace all O-Rings, including the bottom sub O-Ring and 27-pin male and
female connector OD O-Rings. Use Lubriplate grease [item 11] to lubricate O-
Rings and O-Ring grooves prior to assembly.

NOTE: The bottom sub [item 4] must be removed from the pressure housing [item 2]
to replace O-Ring [item 10].

____  9.
Remove the 2-piece split collar [item 5] from the top sub [item 3] and clean the
split collard IDs and the mating surface on the top sub.
____  10.
Lubricate the Split collar IDs and the mating surface of the top sub with
Lubriplate grease [item 11]. Reassemble the two piece split collar onto the top
sub and verify free movement.
130997-953 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005
3
2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument – Level 3 PM
____  11.
Reassemble the CCL instrument as instructed in the Disassembly / Assembly
section (130997-955) of this manual.
____  12.
If a logging job is imminent, verify field strength of the magnets as instructed in
the "Charge Magnets" section of the Repair / Maintenance Procedures section
(130997-956) of this manual. Charge magnets as necessary.
____  13.
Check the operation of the Focus CCL as described in the Repair / Maintenance
Procedures section (130997-956) of this manual.
____  14.
Install the top and bottom thread protectors [item 8 and 9].
130997-953 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005

INTRODUCTION
Follow the safety guidelines listed below when handling the 2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument
Assembly.
•
Observe proper lifting techniques when handling this instrument.
•
Thread protectors should always be installed when transporting or handling the tool.
•
Steel-toe shoes must be worn while handling the tool assembly.
•
Wear safety glasses when soldering
•
Where static-guard wristbands when working around electronics
•
Remove all unnecessary magnetic material and equipment from the immediate area when
working on the 2334 XA.

130997-954 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005

INTRODUCTION
Refer to the Temperature Testing section (P/N 130997-956) of this manual for 2334 XA
temperature testing procedures.

130997-959 / 2334 XA
JUNE 2005

INTRODUCTION
Refer to the 4509 XA Lab PC Test Panel Operating / Maintenance Manual (P/N 140614-915)
for test system operation. Refer to the Repair / Maintenance section (130997-956) of this
manual for test routines that are specific to the 2334 XA Focus CCL Instrument.

The 4509 XA Lab PC Test Panel Operating / Maintenance Manual (P/N 140614-
915) is available on the OTM.

topic: Brief Description of Service - DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE                                                                     2346XA 4-ARM CCL 1.0 INTRODUCTION
chunk_text:
1

DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE                                                                     2346 XA 4-ARM CCL
CONFIDENTIAL                                      P/N 130153-935                                    SEPTEMBER 2008 
INTRODUCTION

The 2346 XA instrument is a 3.38 in. (85.7mm) OD, 26 conductor powered or non-powered CCL
/Centralizer/Decentralizer. It is designed to locate collars in flush joint casing as well as standard
casing collars. The four bow springs are adjustable for optimum spring force and contain a magnetic
shoe assembly (See Figure 1). The magnetic shoe assembly contains small magnets that are used to
induce a magnetic field in the casing as the tool passes it. When the assembly crosses a casing joint,
the induced magnetic field is disturbed and the CCL coil detects these disturbances and the internal
electronics processes the coil signal for transmission through the wireline.


The 2346 XA tool is designed for multi or single conductor operations and can be used with OH, CH,
or production logging tools and has an internal PFC relay to allow it to be used with perforating
operations. The output is the amplitude modulated 2 KHz AC signal when used in the powered mode
and a varying amplitude, alternating polarity signal when used in the non-powered and production
logging mode. Two internal rotary switches select the signal carrying conductors and the mode of
operation.

Hughes). By accepting or accessing this document the recipient agrees this document (together with its contents) is confidential and is an unpublished copyright work with all rights

Page 1 of 5 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
Effective Date: 24-APR-2015 
2346 XA 4-Arm CCL Centralizer/Decentralizer 
Doc. No.: 130153-946 
 
 
 
1. Mechanical Description 
The 2346 XA CCL/Centralizer/Decentralizer (Figure 3) is designed to work with Open Hole, Cased 
Hole, Production Logging, and Perforating operations, in casing with flush joint or standard collars. 
The tool is 81.5" (2.06 m) long, weighing 97 lbs (43.9 kg), with an outside diameter of 3.38" (85.7 
mm). It is designed to be run in casing with a minimum size of 4.5" (114.3 mm) OD up to a 
maximum of 16.31" (414.3 mm) OD, with extensions 18.5" (469.9 mm). Maximum temperature is 
350 deg. F. for 10 hours at a maximum pressure of 25 K psi. The tool has 4 bow springs assemblies 
extending from the sides with magnetic shoes on each spring. 
For centralizing perforation tools or other heavy strings, optional bow springs are available with 
greater spring force. A sleeve on the lower end of the tool turns to adjust the diameter of the bow 
springs and another sleeve adjusts the coil spring force. The coil spring gives additional tension to 
the bow springs. 
The magnetic shoe assemblies, which are mounted on each bow spring, contain Alnico 5 magnets 
which must be checked before the tool is used each time for the correct polarity and their magnetic 
field strength. The polarity of the magnet can be checked using a compass and a magnetic strength 
meter can be used to determine the magnets strength. 
The procedure for using the compass and the field strength meter are described in section  
130153-951, Level 1 PM. The magnetic strength should be at least 450mV in magnitude. 
Samarium Cobalt is not rechargeable. Samarium cobalt magnets with low readings are likely 
cracked and must be replaced. Alnico magnets with low readings may be charged with a magnet 
charger. 
 
 
 
 
The difference between the two magnets may be verified by placing them on their sides and visually 
inspecting the magnets. Alnico 5 has a uniform body (Figure 1) and SmCo has a layered body 
(Figure 2) 
 
Figure 1: Alnico 
 
 
Note 
New tools are assembled using Alnico 5. Some shoe assemblies 
may have been converted from using Alnico 5 Magnets to SmCo 
permanent magnets. The SmCo magnets are never to be placed in 
the magnet charger to be recharged. 
Page 2 of 5 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
Effective Date: 24-APR-2015 
2346 XA 4-Arm CCL Centralizer/Decentralizer 
Doc. No.: 130153-946 
 
 
Figure 2: Samarium Cobalt 
 
 
An optional slide collar has been designed to permit quick centralizer/decentralizer conversion by 
collapsing three of the four bow springs, leaving one extended for decentralizing. The three 
collapsed springs must then be secured with two hose clamps. 
To give additional coil spring compression, for greater force and to increase the maximum diameter 
of the bow springs, an optional split collar has been designed for the tool. The procedures for using 
it are described in 130153-955, Disassembly/Assembly procedure. 
The electronic package for the tool is designed to be inserted from the uphole end only. Both black 
block connectors are held in the tool by a retainer ring which is easily removed by a screwdriver. To 
remove the electronic package no subs need to be removed if in multi-conductor configuration. The 
connector on the downhole end of the tool is connected to the electronic backbone through a pigtail. 
The uphole connector connects directly to the backbone. The internal electronic package has two 
rotary switches that are used to control the conductor utilization and the operation of the tool. To 
access these switches, the electronic package must be pulled a few inches out of the housing. A 
legend printed on the internal cartridge indicates the functions for each switch position. 
The 2346 XA is designed to be run as a single conductor tool, if desired. Special subs have been 
designed to be installed onto the existing top and bottom subs of the tool. The only change that 
must take place on the tool is the changing out of the 26 pin connectors for single conductor 
connectors. The electronics inside the tool remains fully operational with single conductor 
operations. 
A special hoisting bridle has been designed for the 2346 XA when it is to be used with heavy tools. 
The optional bridle relieves the tool housing from the extra weight of the other tools and prevent the 
slender parts of the tool housing from becoming bent. Figure 4 illustrates how the bridle is to be 
used.

1
SAFETY PRECAUTIONS (LAB) -- 2346 XA 4-ARM CCL
                                                                                                                                
In general, there are few special safety requirements for the 2346 XA CCL/Decentralizer/Centralizer
tool. There are no radioactive or emitted fields that can be hazardous.
General safety procedures should be followed in regards to voltage present on the electronics (180
VAC or 150 VDC) when the tool is operating. 
Care should be exercised when handling and changing the bow springs because edges can become
razor sharp due to casing wear. Also when hammering out the spirol pins that hold the bow springs
to the tool body. 
A careful examination of the magnetic shoe assemblies mounted on the bow springs should be done
before handling the tool at this point because of the magnets in this assembly which may attract and
hold on to any metal shavings that were in the well. Care should be exercised to remove any metal
shavings that are on the tool before handling to prevent possible injury. 
                                                                                                                               
P/N 130153-954 
JANUARY 21, 1991

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                                        2346XA 4-ARM CCL CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                                        2346XA 4-ARM CCL
chunk_text:
1
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                                        2346 XA 4-ARM CCL
CONFIDENTIAL                                      P/N 130153-945                                    SEPTEMBER 2008
1  AC DECENT
180 VAC
HIGH
AM ELECTRONICS 2
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                                        2346 XA 4-ARM CCL
CONFIDENTIAL                                      P/N 130153-945                                    SEPTEMBER 2008
2  AC CENT
180 VAC
LOW
AM ELECTRONICS

INTRODUCTION

The 2346 XA CCL/Centralizer/Decentralizer tool was designed to be used in Open Hole, Cased Hole,
Production Logging, and Perforating operations. The tool allows the user to connect the output from the
CCL coil to the wireline using five different methods. The coil output can be connected 1) directly to the
wireline without any additional circuit, 2) directly to the wireline with a zener diode in series with the
coil to prevent low voltage from passing through the tool, 3) directly to the wireline with a resistor in
parallel with the coil, 4) through a powered circuit designed for use with production logging tools, or 5)
through an Amplitude Modulation circuit for use with open hole and cased hole logging tools. The output
of the tool will vary according to the specific circuitry that is being used. The output can be 1) the actual
CCL coil signal, 2) a varying amplitude alternating polarity signal or DC pulse, or 3) a 2 KHz amplitude
modulated signal.

To have such versatility, the 2346 XA contains two rotary switches for controlling tool operations. Switch
SW1 is used for selecting conductor utilization, and Switch SW2 is used to select the function and/or the
signal output desired.

The Amplitude Modulation circuit (PCB 1) of the 2346 XA is compatible with the Cement Bond Log
Summing Junction circuitry in the 1415 and 1417 tools or it can be modified to work with a gating sync
pulse coming from the Cement Bond Log for time sharing applications. The circuit can be powered by
either 180 VAC or 150 VDC. It produces a 2 KHz. sine wave that is modulated by the absolute amplitude
of the detector coil signal. The circuitry allows the user to select ether a high or a low sensitivity for the
electronics. The high sensitivity is particularity useful when the tool is logged in its decentralized mode
of operation, or when short samarium cobalt magnets are used in its arms.

The 2346 XA has a relay designed into it to disconnect both the power supply input and the signal output
of the amplitude modulation circuit from the wireline any time the cable head voltage exceeds 180 VDC
and will reconnect them once the cable head voltage is lowered below 164 volts D.C. This is to isolate
and protect the electronics during perforating operations.

The Production Logging circuit (PCB 3) of the 2346 XA uses 20 VDC to 180 VDC and produces a
varying load resistance according to the amplitude of the detector coil signal as an output signal.

SWITCHING

The 2346 XA CCL/Centralizer/Decentralizer was designed to be used with as many different tools and
logging combinations as possible. To get this versatility, the tool contains two rotary switches that are
used to select the signal carrying conductors (Table 1) and the mode of operations (Table 2).

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 3.0 POWER SUPPLY / AMPLITUDE MODULATION BOARD P/N 125844-000
chunk_text:
POWER SUPPLY / AMPLITUDE MODULATION BOARD P/N 125844-000

The power supply sections on the Amplitude Modulation electronics board converts either 180 VAC
or 150 VDC line voltage to plus and minus 11.8 volts for the electronics (Figure 1). Refer to drawing
P/N 127775-000.

In the AC mode, AC power that is on conductors 4 and 6 is connected to transformer T2 which steps
down the 180 VAC to a lower voltage which is passed to a full wave bridge rectifier D11. The rectified
voltage is then regulated and protected from excessive supply voltages by resistor R18, transistor Q3,
& diode D10 and filtered by capacitors C10 & C11 to produce approximately 25 to 30 VDC at TP8.
TP8 is connected to TP9 via SW2 deck 2 positions 1 or 2 to supply power to the AM circuitry board
PCB 1.

In the DC mode, DC power that is on conductors 2 and 10 is connected through a NC contact on the
PFC relay and through resistor R3 which drops the 150 VDC down to approximately 25 to 30 VDC.
Power is then routed through SW2 deck 2 positions 3 or 4 to TP9 to supply power to the AM circuitry
board PCB 1.

The 25 to 30 VDC present at TP9 passes through choke L1 which blocks any AC voltages that might
be present, such as the 2 KHz signal from the AM circuit. Diode D7 protects against any reverse
voltages while zener diodes D5 and D6 further regulate the voltage to 23.6 VDC. Referencing the
analog circuit ground to the junction point between the zener diodes D5 and D6 produces the required
+ 11.8 volts to power the circuit on PCB1. Capacitors C7, C8 and C9 provide additional filtering for
regulated power supply.

NOTE: The case ground and the electronics common are not the same.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 4.0 AMPLITUDE MODULATION BOARD P/N 125844-000
chunk_text:
AMPLITUDE MODULATION BOARD P/N 125844-000

On the Amplitude Modulation Board, the CCL detector coil is connected to the input points, TP1 &
TP2, of the electronics by switch SW2 decks 3 and 4 in positions 1 through 4. (Refer to Figure 2 for
a block diagram of the circuit. For more details refer to the schematic P/N 125844-100.) At TP2, one
side of the CCL coil is connected to the analog circuit ground of the electronics. Capacitor C3 and
zener diodes D1 and D2 are placed across the input terminals to act as a low pass filter and to protect
the input of amplifier C of IC1, a 4741 QUAD OP AMP, from voltages above 12.7 volts.

PFC RELAY

The 2346 XA CCL was designed for use with perforating operations. To permit it to be used with the high
voltages associated with perforating, a relay was designed into the tool to disconnect the power to the
tool's electronic circuits from the line whenever these high voltages were applied. The PFC relay circuit
(Figure 6) is designed so that DC supply voltage, that is on conductor 2, will passes through a normally
closed relay contacts to the Power Supply / Amplitude Modulation printed circuit board or the Production
Logging printed circuit board to supply power to the electronics. As long as this voltage stays below 180
VDC the relay contact remains closed. If the DC voltage ever exceeds the 180 VDC limit, the rectifier
diode D12 will reach its 150 volt avalanche voltage point and it will start to conduct.

5
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                                        2346 XA 4-ARM CCL
CONFIDENTIAL                                      P/N 130153-945                                    SEPTEMBER 2008

When D12 begins to conduct, the relay K1 will be energized through resistors R1 and R2 and the
zener diode D13 to chassis ground. The power to and the output from the Power Supply / Amplitude
Modulation board or Production Logging board is disconnected. The power and signal output from
the electronics will be reconnected when the supply voltage is reduced below 164 volts. R1 & R2
are adjusted for the above specified voltages.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 6.0 PRODUCTION LOGGING BOARD P/N 129593-000
chunk_text:
PRODUCTION LOGGING BOARD P/N 129593-000

To use the 2346 XA CCL for production logging operations, the CCL coil output is switched by SW2
in position 8 to connect the input points, TP29 & TP30, on the production logging board (Figure 7).
The transistor Q2 and its associated circuitry form a voltage regulator that produces a 5.0 volts at the
emitter of Q2. With no detector coil signal resistor R1 forward biases transistor Q1 so that it draws the
maximum current from its source. When the detector coil is stimulated and a signal applied to the input,
diode D1 will block the positive portion of the signal only allowing the negative portion to be present
on the base of Q1.

This negative voltage cancels the positive bias created by R1 causing Q1 to draw less or minimum
current. This greatly increases the circuits load resistance and causes the circuit to draw less current
from the surface power supply producing a momentary positive pulse on the line. Conductor utilization
is determined by switch SW1.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 7.0 DETECTOR COIL SIGNAL AND VECTOR BOARD P/N 127733-001
chunk_text:
DETECTOR COIL SIGNAL AND VECTOR BOARD P/N 127733-001

The detector coil output can be switched directly on to the line by switch SW2 in positions 5, 6 or 7 and
on the conductors chosen by switch SW1, bypassing both the amplitude modulation electronics and the
production logging electronics.

In switch SW2 position 6, only the detector coil is connected to the line with out any other circuitry.
In switch position 5, the coil is connected to the line and zener diode D12 on the Vector PC board
(Figure 3) is placed in series on the conductor chosen between the detector coil and the downhole
connector J2. In perforating operations this zener diode blocks any low voltage produced by the detector
coil from reaching the perforating gun attached to bottom of the tool but allows high voltages to pass in
order to fire the gun.
In switch position 7, the coil is connected to the line with resistor R25 on the Vector PC board (Figure 3)
connected in parallel with the detector coil.

7
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                                        2346 XA 4-ARM CCL
CONFIDENTIAL                                      P/N 130153-945                                    SEPTEMBER 2008

9
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                                        2346 XA 4-ARM CCL
CONFIDENTIAL                                      P/N 130153-945                                    SEPTEMBER 2008

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURE -- 2346XA 4-ARM CCL 1.0 MECHANICAL DISASSEMBLY . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
chunk_text:
1
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURE -- 2346 XA 4-ARM CCL

Page 

MECHANICAL DISASSEMBLY
1.
If the tool is being used for single conductor operations the special adapter subs will need to
be unscrewed and set aside to be cleaned and to have new o-rings installed.
2.
Remove the retainer rings that are holding in the black block connector from both ends of the
tool using a small screwdriver in the notches provided.
3.
Using the proper T-Wrench, remove the black block connector from the lower end of the tool
and disconnect it from the cable assembly.
4.
With the T-Wrench again, withdraw the electronic stick from the upper end of the tool.
This completes the disassembly of the tool to remove the electronic
package.
5.
Remove the topsub by unscrewing it from the main tool body. Set it aside to be cleaned and
to have new o-rings installed.
6.
To remove the bottom sub (Figure 1) the following steps must be followed:
A.
Remove the tension form the bow springs and the coil spring.
B.
Remove one end of each of the bow springs.
C.
Remove the snap ring and washer from the slide collar and push out of the way.
D.
Unscrew the coil spring adjustment free of the bow spring adjustment.
E.
Remove the snap ring from the small end of the bow spring adjustment and unscrew
the bow spring adjustment free from the lower sub.
F.
If the electronics are in the tool body, remove the retaining clip from the connector
and use a T-wrench to extract the connector. Disconnect the connector and push the
cable assembly inside the tool housing.
G.
Drive out the spirol pin with a hammer and punch. Unscrew the lower sub from the
tool housing.
H.
Set the bottom sub aside to be cleaned and to have new o-rings installed.

P/N 130153-955
JANUARY 21, 1991

MECHANICAL ASSEMBLY
1.
To reassemble the tool, follow the disassembly instructions in reverse order.
2.
Upon re-assembling the tool, pay careful attention to the coils when pulling the cable
assembly through the housing with the cable pull through tool P/N 129560.
3.
Upon inserting the electronic stick in to the housing, rotate it only clockwise, so as not to
unscrew the mag coils from the stick.
4.
Rotate it not more than two revolutions, until the connector notch aligns with the
corresponding notch in the tool housing.
5.
This completes the assembly of the tool.

26 CONDUCTOR / SINGLE CONDUCTOR

3
26 CONDUCTOR / SINGLE CONDUCTOR CONNECTOR CONVERSION
An optional connector converts the 26 internal conductors to a single conductor for perforation or
other single conductor connections. This connector must be used with the corresponding uphole or
downhole sub for single conductor conversion. These subs adapt from a 3-3/8 make-up collar to a 3-
1/2 single conductor collar. Either or both subs may be used. To install the connector do the
following:
1.
Remove the retaining ring the is holding in the black block connector, using a small
screwdriver in the slot provided.
2.
Remove the connector with the proper T-wrench.
3.
Disconnect the present connector and connect the desired connector to the assembly.
4.
Replace the new connector in the tool, being careful not to bind the coils in the cable
assembly.
5.
Replace the retainer ring so that the gap is not aligned with the notch in the tool.
6.
Repeat the procedure on the other end of the tool if desired.
7.
If the conversion is to single conductor configuration, install the correct adapter sub on the
end(s) of the tool that has been changed.

P/N 130153-955
JANUARY 21, 1991

COIL SPRING ADJUSTMENTS
The 2346 XA has two adjustments which affect the bow spring action: Bow spring diameter and coil
spring force. Coil spring force is independent of the mechanism which is used to adjust bow spring
diameter (Figure 2). To adjust the bow springs properly do the following:
1.
Loosen locknuts with pin wrenches.
2.
Adjust bow spring diameter no smaller than 1/2 inch larger than the maximum casing
diameter.
3.
Adjust the coil spring force to the desired strength.
4.
Tighten locknuts to secure adjustments.

BOWSPRING ADJUSTMENTS
1.
The smaller the casing diameter, the greater the tension exerted by the bow springs and the
coil spring. However, the ability to centralize is reduced in small casings.
2.
The upper slide assembly connected to the bow springs has four set screws that "fix" the
position of the bow springs so that they do not rotate separate from the housing. This may be
desirable for decentralized or other operations where orientation is required. The normal
mode of operations is to let the bow springs rotate freely.
3.
If the tool gives false readings or does not centralize, first increase coil spring force and if
not enough, replace springs with optional thicker bow springs.
4.
To improve centralization of loads in slanted holes, use thicker bow springs for:
A.
Heavier loads
B.
Greater slant
C.
Smaller diameter casing
5.
Decentralized operations requires greater housing to shoe diameter, but less coil spring force.
6.
If the bow spring diameter adjustment does not give a large enough diameter, installing the
optional split collar P/N 129582 will increase the coil spring length, thus increasing the
maximum diameter (Figure 3). Installation requires 2 people.
A.
Compress the coil spring with tool P/N 129565. If the spring force is too great,
loosen it with the coil spring adjustment.

P/N 130153-955
JANUARY 21, 1991

DECENTRALIZED OPERATIONS
An optional slide collar is available with this tool to permit quick centralizer/decentralizer conversion
by collapsing three of the four bow springs, leaving one extended for decentralizing. The three
collapsed springs must then be secured with two hose clamps. Also, the arm directly opposite the
decentralizing arm should have two cover plates installed on the shoe assembly.

SPECIAL HANDLING INSTRUCTIONS
Airline regulations require that a magnetic shield be used during air transportation. Sleeve P/N
129563 slides over the shoes to prevent the shoe magnets from affecting the airplane's compass
(Navigation System).

P/N 130153-955
JANUARY 21, 1991

5


JANUARY 21, 1991
5
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURE -- 2346 XA 4-ARM CCL

BOWSPRING ADJUSTMENTS (Cont'd)
B.
Assemble the two halves of the split collar around the housing, loosely installing all
screws before tightening.
7.
Installing a set of optional thicker bow springs increases the bow spring tension. Standard
bow springs are 0.093" thick. (See Table 1 for optional springs.)
A.
Loosen the bow spring and coil spring adjustments until the bow springs are free of
tension.
B.
Drive out the two spirol pins retaining each bow spring and remove the bow springs.
C.
Remove the shoes by unscrewing the screws from the back of each shoe. While
disassembling, inspect the magnets of each shoe and replace any broken or cracked
magnets.
D.
When assembling the shoes on the new bow springs replace the spacers with the
spacers corresponding to the replacement bow spring (Refer Table 1).
E.
Put two cover plates on the shoe opposite the decentralizing arm. The decentralizing
arm is the one which remains extended after collapsing three bow springs with the
slide collar.
F.
Before attaching the bow springs with the spirol pins, position each spring so that the
magnetic polarity of each shoe is oriented the same. Use a compass to determine
polarity, keeping it at least 3" away from the shoe (Figure 4).
G.
For greater sensitivity, the rollers can be removed from the shoes, but not that this
will give more friction and shoe wear.
