  REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                             2346 XA 4-ARM CCL  
 
For repair or maintenance, this section contains the manufacturing checkout document listed 
below. 
This document targets a manufacturing audience and may contain statements, equipment, 
drawings, procedures and other references that may not be applicable or available for field use.  
Some equipment and documents listed in this procedure is specific in nature, but equivalent 
devices can be easily substituted in most cases.  Included in (but not necessarily limited to) the 
lists are the following: 

ESD Protection Specification 
Model 260 or equivalent 
Simpson Meter 
Fluke 87 (F245130000) or equivalent  
Digital Multimeter 
B033 or equivalent 
AC Power Supply 
Lambda LPD-424 A or equivalent 
DC Power Supply  
HP 5215 A or equivalent 
Frequency Meter 
Tektronix 455 or equivalent 
Oscilloscope 
127712-000 
Samarium Cobalt Magnet 
 
100 mH inductor 
 
5 KΏ Resistor (10 W) 
MADA Devices or equivalent 
Magnetic Field Detector 
Clarostat 240 C or equivalent 
Resistor Decade Boxes 
B069 
CBL Gate Off Test Box 
 
Weetech Test Equipment 
 
 
TABLE OF CONTENTS 
 
 
HTC Manufacturing Test Procedure130153-856

1 
 LAB HEAT TEST PROCEDURES                                                                  2346 XA 4-ARM CCL 
 CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 130153-959                                   SEPTEMBER 2008 
 
1. Set the two switches to A1. See Table 1 for the switch positions to be used for the desired 
functions.

Table 1 
 
 
2. Check out the tools responses prior to heat testing. Record the tool's response for comparison  
to the tool's response during and after the heat test.  
 
3. Place the tool in the oven.  
 
4. Apply 180 VAC between conductors 4 and 6 of the bottom connector. 
 
5. Verify conductor 3 and 10 maintains a 2 KHz ±10%, .8 V p-p to 1.2 V p-p sinewave for the  
 
entire heat run.  
 
6. Heat test the tool at 360º F for one half hour. 
 
7. Allow the tool to cool down and recheck the tool's response.  
 
8. Correct any problems that have been detected and retest.

1
TEST SYSTEMS GUIDE  --  2346 XA 4-ARM CCL
                                                                                                                                
                                                                                                                                
This tool is designed to work with the present CLS system with analog input and is not at present
designed for use with the WTS telemetry system or for PCM operation.

2346 XA CCL Preventive Maintenance Level 3 
 
This equipment is intended to be operated and maintained only 
by personnel who have received the proper training regarding 
Baker Hughes Wireline Services technology and services.  
This equipment may present hazards which are not obvious to 
untrained personnel. Attempts to operate or maintain this equipment 
by untrained personnel may result in injury or damage to equipment 
or result in lost time or damage to customer equipment and property.

(Baker Hughes). By accepting or accessing this document the recipient agrees this document (together with its contents) is confidential and is an unpublished copyright work with all 
rights reserved to Baker Hughes and is further subject to return on demand. It may not be copied, reproduced, or disclosed in any form, in whole or in part, without express consent 
of Baker Hughes. It may not be used directly or indirectly in any way detrimental to Baker’s interest and is not rented, loaned or sold, either alone or in conjunction with equipment or 
product, and does not comprise a part of any customer project or service. 
 
Page 1 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 
2346 XA CCL Preventive Maintenance Level 3 
 
 
 
Note: 
Safety Requirements: 
Personal Protective Equipment appropriate to work being performed; in all cases safety glasses 
and safety toe shoes or caps shall be worn. 
Note: 
Definitions: 
Shall denotes a minimum requirement in order to conform to this procedure. 
Should denotes a recommendation which is advised but not required. 
May is used where alternatives are equally acceptable. 
Note: 
Use this procedure with Checklist document number 130153-953-CHKL. This procedure is 
designed to go step by step along with 130153-953-CHKL. In other words, step 5.1 in this 
procedure is the same as step 5.1 in 130153-953-CHKL. 
Note: 
It is expected that all work performed will conform to the instructions herein and to the procedures 
enumerated in the Workmanship Standards Document N80807. 
Note: 
Records of inspection, maintenance, refurbishment, modifications and repairs for PM3 of this 
Instrument shall be maintained in SAP ZARM2. 
Note: 
Nonconforming material shall be controlled to prevent its unintended use. 
Note: 
Visual inspection shall be performed, unaided by equipment, at a distance less than 36 inches. 
Note: 
The Digital Meter used for the electrical checks shall be calibrated annually.   
Note: 
Pin Gage .18 inch, Grainger part number 5 YZPO or equivalent shall be verified annually.  
OD = .1795 to .1900 inch. 
Note: 
Pin Gage F259872000, .093 inch or equivalent for WTS 32-pin sockets shall be verified annually. 
OD = .092 inch to .094 inch. 
Note: 
Banana pin gauge F090632000 or equivalent shall have the ID .145 inches verified annually. 
ID = .14 to .15 inches. 
Note:  Pin Gage .039 inch Grainger part number 5 MAV9 or equivalent shall be verified annually,  
OD = .038 inch to .040 inch. 
Note: 
The Torque Wrench(s) used shall be calibrated annually. Do NOT loosen Bolts, Nuts, Screws or 
Subs to check the torque value. Tighten and ensure the part is equal to or greater than the 
specified torqued value.  
Note: 
Check Lubriplate 930-AA grease Expiration date or manufacturing date. In the absence of an 
Expiration date, six years from date of manufacturing shall be used as the Expiration date. 
Grease past its Expiration date shall not be used. 
Note: 
Grease used shall be free from dust, dirt, or any contamination which can cause seal failure.   
Note: 
Check O-rings discard date. IE, 2024 Q2 is year 2024; Q2 is second quarter of year. O-rings past 
their discard date shall not be used. 
 
 
 
 
 
Page 2 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 
2346 XA CCL Preventive Maintenance Level 3 
 
 
 
 
Equipment Required: 
 
• 
5722 X* WEETECH Continuity/Leakage Tester  
• Digital multimeter, Fluke Model 87 V or equivalent  
• 
Brass O-ring Extractor Tool Kit F245210000 or equivalent 
• 
Banana pin gauge F090632000 or equivalent  
• 
Pin Gage F259872000  or equivalent used with Test gage  F181967000 (WTS 32-pin sockets)  
• 
Pin Gage .18 inch, Grainger part number 5 YZPO or equivalent to check Banana socket. 
• 
Pin Gage .039 inch Grainger part number 5 MAV9 or equivalent 
• 
Current Issue Solvent Degreaser,  F263143000 or equivalent   
• 
Lubriplate 930 AA, F205933000 or equivalent 
• 
Magnetic Field Detector P/N A5000432000 or equivalent  
• 
Compass; BHI # F242475000 or Grainger Suunto Compass part number 8 CLW6 or equivalent. 
• 
Spanner Pin Wrench F840272000 or equivalent. 
• 
Spanner Hex Wrench F501545000 or equivalent. 
• 
3145 RTV silicone adhesive, F223376000 or equivalent 
• 
Torque Wrench with Capacity of 5 in. lbs (0.5 Nm. 
 
 
Page 3 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 
2346 XA CCL Preventive Maintenance Level 3 
 
 
 
 
1. Preparation 

Verify that equipment serial number in the ZARM matches the number on the instrument. If 
the numbers on the instrument are difficult to read, they will be remarked later.  

With thread protectors in place, thoroughly clean housing.  Preparations include washing 
the tool to remove, mud, grease, dirt and other foreign material. Air dry, Blow dry with 
compressed air or dry off the tool with clean rags or paper towels. Each step of the 
disassembly will include cleaning as required. 
2. Instrument History 

Verify the SAP tcode “ZARM” equipment number matches the Serial number on the tool. 
Record the amount of PM points on Checklist document number 130153-953-CHKL.  

Use SAP tcode “ZEQFMN” to see FMNs/ OTBs that have been done and need to be done. 
Ensure FMNs / OTBs are up to date; if they are not up to date you may perform the 
applicable FMNs / OTBs before this PM3 or concurrently with this PM3. 
3. Continuity and Resistance Tests 

It is advisable, though not required to test continuity and resistance with a 5722 X* 
“WEETECH” or digital multimeter prior to disassembly. The purpose is that this may reveal 
defects that can be investigated and repaired during the PM. Circle Yes or No as to 
whether or not Pretest before disassembly was performed. Refer to step 9 for values. 
4. Disassembly Procedures 
In the 2346 XA CCL Supplemental Drawing List, refer to Drawing F127776000. Use SAP tcode 
CS11 for the F127776000 BOM. 
In the 2346 XA CCL Drawing List refer to Wiring Diagram F127775000. 

Disassemble per 2346 XA CCL Assembly/Disassembly Procedures 130153-955.  
 
 
 
Page 4 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 
2346 XA CCL Preventive Maintenance Level 3 
 
 
5. Visual and Physical Inspection 

Visually inspect the components during disassembly; if there are any cracks, regardless of size, 
the component shall be replaced. Visually inspect for moisture; if there is any moisture, clean the 
part with solvent and dry it. Ensure all electronics are dry before applying electric power.  

Grease used shall be free from dust, dirt, or any contamination which can cause seal failure. 
Check Lubriplate 930-AA grease Expiration date or manufacturing date. In the absence of an 
Expiration date, six years from date of manufacturing shall be used as the Expiration date. 
Grease past its Expiration date shall not be used. 

For O-rings used; record Manufacturer name ______________________ and batch number 
___________. Check discard date. IE, 2024 Q2 is year 2024; Q2 is second quarter of year.   
O-rings past their discard date shall not be used. 

Verify instrument model and equipment/serial numbers are legible and should be legible until the 
next scheduled PM3. If numbers are not legible (reinstall Top Sub Thread protector if stamping) 
remark as needed the Model Number and the Serial Number with 1/4 inch to 3/8 inch characters 
on the Top Sub Hex Wrench Flats.  

Visually inspect all mechanical components’ exterior surfaces (Electronic Cartridge will be done 
later). If there are any cracks, regardless of size, component shall be replaced. Mark defective 
component(s) for analysis or dispose of it. 
 
 
Page 5 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 

On Top Sub, Item [8] F127550000; 
Remove Top sub thread protector and visually inspect threads for damage and cracks. If there 
are any cracks, regardless of size, the component shall be replaced. If there is major damage 
as exhibited in the pictures below then the component shall be replaced. If there is minor 
damage of one or two threads that is 1/8 inch (0.125 inch, 3.2 mm) or less on each thread, then 
the thread(s) may be reworked with appropriate tooling or the component replaced.  
 
If the component is reworked; afterwards clean the threads with solvent then visually inspect the 
component using the following criteria; Crests and Flanks: Raised material shall be removed. A 
maximum of two threads with a maximum of two imperfections per thread which do not exceed 
1/16 inch (0.0625 inch, 1.6 mm) in depth and 1/8 inch (0.125 inch, 3.2 mm) in total length per 
thread is acceptable. If thread(s) look good, apply a little Lubriplate grease onto the thread (s) 
and install the thread protector. The thread protector shall screw onto the sub easily without any 
snags or jerking motion. If the thread protector screws on acceptably then it is ok to use the 
component. If the threads cannot be repaired acceptably then the component shall be replaced.  
 
 
 
 
 
Page 6 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 

On Top Sub, Item [8] F127550000; 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Remove two Top Sub O-rings with brass O-ring extractor tool; cut and discard used O-rings. 
Remove any debris in the O-ring grooves and clean with solvent. 
NOTICE 
RISK OF DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT. DO NOT USE a 
screwdriver to remove O-rings; it will scratch the O-ring 
groove. Use Brass O-ring extractor tool. 

On Top Sub, Item [8] F127550000; 
 
 
 
Visually inspect the Top Sub two O-ring GROOVES. If an O-ring groove is defective the 
component shall be replaced. 
Note: 
According to Workmanship Standards document N80807; …O-ring 
mating surface shall be free from dust, dirt, or any contamination or 
imperfection (i.e., burr, scratches, pitting, etc.) on the metal which 

Inside Top Sub, Item [8] F127550000; 
Remove any debris on the Top Sub INTERNAL O-ring GLAND and clean with solvent.  

 Inside Top Sub, Item [8] F127550000; 
Visually inspect the Top Sub INTERNAL O-ring GLAND. If the O-ring GLAND is defective the 
component shall be replaced. 
 
 
Page 7 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 

On Top Sub, Item [8] F127550000; 
 
 
 
Use Lubriplate 930 AA to coat the Top Sub O-ring grooves and the internal O-ring gland.  
Note: 
According to Workmanship Standards document N80807; …O-ring 
glands shall be lubricated with approved grease in accordance with 
assembly documentation. …  

On Top Sub, Item [8] F127550000; 
 
 
Visually inspect new O-rings (F259260228) for defects while flexing or bending the O-ring which 
can reveal hidden cuts, scratches or other imperfections on the O-ring surface.  Apply a light 
coating of Lubriplate 930 AA around O-rings then install O-rings into top sub O-ring grooves. 
Note: 
According to Workmanship Standards document N80807; …  
O-rings shall exhibit evidence of proper installation and shall be 
free of physical imperfections (i.e., nicks, abrasions, twisting, and 
over-stretching). O-rings shall be clean, seated properly, and fit 
snug in the O-ring groove. O-rings/O-ring glands shall be lubricated 
with an approved grease in accordance with assembly 
documentation. … 

On Pressure Housing, Item [18] F125574000; 
Remove four O-rings Item [9] F259260222 with brass O-ring extractor tool and discard. 

 On Pressure Housing, Item [18] F125574000; 
Remove any debris in the Pressure Housing four O-ring grooves and clean with solvent.  
 
 
Page 8 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 

On Pressure Housing, Item [18] F125574000; 
Visually inspect the Pressure Housing four O-ring grooves. If any O-ring groove is defective the 
component shall be replaced. 

 On Pressure Housing, Item [18] F125574000; 
Use Lubriplate 930 AA to coat the four Pressure Housing O-ring grooves. 

On Pressure Housing, Item [18] F125574000; 
 
Visually inspect four O-rings Item [9] F259260222 for defects while flexing or bending the O-ring 
which can reveal hidden cuts, scratches or other imperfections on the O-ring surface. 
Use Lubriplate 930 AA to coat the four O-rings, and then install the four O-rings into the Pressure 
Housing, Item [18] F125574000 O-ring grooves. 

Inside Bottom Sub, Item [45] F127553000;
 
Remove any debris and clean with solvent. Visually inspect the Bottom Sub internal O-ring 
glands at the top of the sub and at the bottom of the sub. If an O-ring gland is defective the 
component shall be replaced. 

Inside Bottom Sub, Item [45] F127553000; 
 
 
 
 
Use Lubriplate 930 AA to coat the Bottom Sub internal O-ring glands. 
Note: 
According to Workmanship Standards document N80807; …O-ring 
glands shall be lubricated with approved grease in accordance with 
assembly documentation. …  

 Visually inspect the bow springs, Item [19] F125575093, for cracks. If there are any cracks, 
regardless of size, the bow spring shall be replaced.  
 
 
Page 9 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 

Use an annually calibrated measuring device to measure bow springs wear. If the thickness of 
any part of the standard bow spring, Item [19] F125575093, is less than 1/32 inch (. 031 inch, 
.787 mm) then the bow spring shall be replaced. 

 If logging flush joint pipe or need greater sensitivity or hole conditions is causing false collars; 
the rollers may be removed. If doing so, ALL rollers on ALL shoes shall be removed. 

Examine shoe rollers; refer to picture below. Except for step 5.22, if a roller is missing or seized 
and does not turn, or is Flush with the shoe then the roller and spirol pins shall be replaced. 
 
 
 
Page 10 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 

Refer to the picture below to measure Pad Shoe Wear. Use an annually calibrated measuring 
device to measure wear. For shoes on a standard bow spring (F125575093) with a single 
backplate (F125608000); if the Maximum diameter of the area between the Pole Pieces is less 
than 3/4 inch (.75 inch, 19.05 mm), then the Shoe and Pole Pieces shall be replaced.     

Use Digital multimeter with Magnetic Field Detector P/N A5000432000 to check the magnetic 
strength of each shoe. Ignore the ± sign. The reading shall be equal to or greater than 450 
millivolts. Pads with readings less than 450mv shall be repaired before being placed in service.  
Reference document 130153-946, 2346 XA Mechanical Description. 
 
 
 
Page 11 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 

Check the magnetic polarity of each shoe with Compass F242475000 or equivalent.  All of the 
shoe’s magnet’s North poles shall be on the downhole side. Mark the side with the North pole. 

 When re-assembling, all spirol pins Item [12] F224315000 shall be replaced with new pins. 

 Do NOT reinstall Electronics Cartridge F127779000 at this time. Re-assemble Mechanical 
section per 2346 XA CCL Assembly/Disassembly Procedures 130153-955.  
 
6. Electronics Cartridge F127779000 Physical Inspection.  

Visually inspect Electronic Cartridge F127779000 for debris and/or moisture. With the 
exception of silicone adhesive or insulating tape, remove foreign particles and clean with 
solvent. If there is moisture, remove and clean with solvent. Ensure pcbs are dry before 
applying Electric Power. 

Visually inspect Electronics Cartridge F127779000 for missing or broken parts. Except for 
valid modifications, missing or broken parts shall be replaced before instrument can be 
placed in service. 

Visually inspect the case grounding springs Item [29] F104785000. If a spring is cracked 
regardless of size the spring shall be replaced.  

Visually inspect wiring for defects that could adversely affect Instrument performance; 
such as nicks, cuts, or pinholes. Wiring with defects, regardless of size, shall be repaired 
or replaced per Workmanship Standards N80807 before instrument is placed in service. 

Visually inspect the Electronics PC boards for broken or burnt parts. Broken or burnt parts 
shall be replaced before the instrument can be placed in service.  
 
 
Page 12 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 

Visually inspect the Electronics PC boards for broken solder joint connections; any broken 
solder joint connection shall be repaired before the instrument can be placed in service. 

If there are any Discrete or Integrated components that are in sockets, reseat the 
component and apply 3145 RTV silicone adhesive F223376000 to secure the component.  
7. Electronics Cartridge F127779000 Functional Test. 

This procedure is for instruments with the switches configured for an SBT service. With 
SW1 set to Position F and SW2 set to Position 6 the configuration is COIL ONLY; Electric 
Power is not applied. 

Measure continuity of Top connector Item [4] F189554000, Conductor 10 to ALL case 
grounding springs; they shall measure less than 1 Ω. If a case grounding spring measures 
greater than 1 Ω, the fault shall be rectified before the instrument is placed in service. 

Use an annually calibrated Oscilloscope. Connect Oscilloscope signal probe to conductor 
16 and the Oscilloscope ground lead to conductor 10. Use a magnet to stroke across the 
CCL coil, Item [L2/L3] F125605000.  
 
Observe a 20 to 30 volt pulse riding on a 3 to 6 volt triangle wave.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Page 13 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 
2346 XA CCL Preventive Maintenance Level 3 
 
 
8. Reinstall Electronics Cartridge F127779000 into 
Pressure Housing. 

Reinstall Electronics Cartridge F127779000 into Pressure housing and reassemble 
Instrument per 2346 XA CCL Assembly/Disassembly Procedures 130153-955. 

On top connector; visually inspect for debris and/or moisture. If there is debris and/or 
moisture, remove debris and clean the connector with solvent.  

On top connector; visually inspect for bent or broken sockets. If there are any bent or 
broken sockets, regardless of size, they shall be replaced. 

On top connector; use Pin Test Gage F259872000 to push WTS sockets towards the 
connector. Ensure sockets do not go into the connector; if any WTS socket goes into the 
connector it shall be replaced. 

On top connector; use Pin gage .18 inch, Grainger part number 5 YZPO or equivalent to 
check Banana sockets. Pin gage shall not go into the sockets. If Pin gage goes into any 
banana socket it shall be replaced.  

On top connector; Ensure connector screws are tight. Torque => 5 in. lbs (0.5 N m). 
 
 
Page 14 of 17 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 

On top connector; visually inspect to ensure the snap ring is in place.      

On bottom connector; visually inspect for debris and/or moisture. If there is debris and/or 
moisture, remove debris and clean the connector with solvent. 

On bottom connector; Ensure connector screws are tight. Torque => 5 in. lbs (0.5 N m). 

 On bottom connector; check banana pins using Banana pin gauge.  If any Banana Pin is 
broken or crushed it shall be replaced.  

 On bottom connector; push WTS pins towards bottom connector. Ensure pins do not go 
into the connector. If any WTS Pin goes into the connector it shall be replaced. 

 On bottom connector; visually inspect for bent or broken pins. If there are any bent or 
broken pins, regardless of size, they shall be replaced. 

 On bottom connector; visually inspect and ensure the snap ring is in place. 

The Bottom Sub internal O-ring gland is between the guide pin and the bottom of the sub 
where the instrument below the 2346 XA will plug into the bottom of the 2346 XA. Remove 
any debris on the Bottom sub internal O-ring gland and clean with solvent. 

In Bottom Sub; 
Note: 
According to Workmanship Standards document N80807; …O-ring 
mating surface shall be free from dust, dirt, or any contamination or 
imperfection (i.e., burr, scratches, pitting, etc.) on the metal which can 
cause accelerated O-ring wear and lead to seal failure
Visually inspect the O-ring gland. If the O-ring gland is defective the defective component 
shall be replaced.

Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130153-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  8/16/2015 

In Bottom Sub; 
 
Note: 
According to Workmanship Standards document N80807; …O-ring glands 
shall be lubricated with approved grease in accordance with assembly 
documentation. …  
Use Lubriplate 930 AA to coat the Bottom sub internal O-ring gland. 

On Bottom Sub, Item [45] F127553000; 
Remove thread protector and collar and visually inspect the threads for damage and 
cracks. If there are any cracks, regardless of size, the component shall be replaced. If 
there is major damage as exhibited in the pictures below then the component shall be 
replaced. If there is minor damage of one or two threads that is  
1/8 inch (0.125 inch, 3.2 mm) or less on each thread, then the thread(s) may be reworked 
with appropriate tooling or the component replaced.  
 
If the component is reworked; afterwards clean the threads with solvent then visually 
inspect the component using the following criteria; Crests and Flanks: Raised material 
shall be removed. A maximum of two threads with a maximum of two imperfections per 
thread which do not exceed 1/16 inch (0.0625 inch, 1.6 mm) in depth and 1/8 inch (0.125 
inch, 3.2 mm) in total length per thread is acceptable. If thread(s) look good, apply a little 
Lubriplate grease onto the thread (s) and install the thread protector. The thread protector 
shall screw onto the sub easily without any snags or jerking motion. If the thread protector 
screws on acceptably then it is ok to use the component. If the threads cannot be repaired 
acceptably then the component shall be replaced.

2346 XA CCL Preventive Maintenance Level 3 
 
 
 
9. Electrical Checks: 

This procedure is for instruments with the switches configured for an SBT service. If the 
2346 XA Four-Arm CCL is being run with the SBT, the CCL must have SW1 set to  
Position F and SW2 set to Position 6.  

Top multi-conductor connector to Bottom connector. Continuity check shall measure less 
than 1 Ω for conductors 1 through 26. 

Top multi-conductor connector to housing. Conductors 1 thru 7 shall measure greater 
than 30 Megohms. 

Top multi-conductor connector to housing. Conductor 8 shall measure a Cap kick to 
greater than 30 Megohms. 

Top multi-conductor connector to housing. Conductor 9 shall measure greater than 30 
Megohms. 

Top multi-conductor connector to housing. Conductor 10 shall measure less than 1 Ω. 

Top multi-conductor connector to housing. Conductors 11 thru 15 shall measure greater 
than 30 Megohms. 

Top multi-conductor connector. Fluke positive lead is on conductor 16 and Fluke negative 
lead is on housing. Measurement shall be between 120 KΩ to 180 KΩ. Resistance value 
shall fluctuate as a large ferrous object (example: 3-5/32 HEX Wrench F501545000) is 
passed across the magnetic field generated by the pads.  

Top multi-conductor connector to housing. Conductors 17 thru 26 shall measure greater 
than 30 Megohms.

2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Training Supplement 
The training supplement P/N 130872-936 was not available at the time this manual was printed. The 
training supplement will be added when completed. 
130872-936 / 2436 XA 
JAN 2004

SERVICE OVERVIEW
The 2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron (CN) Instrument is an all-new design. Although
new, years of CN design experience went into its development.
The 2436 XA CN is shorter and lighter than previous CN instruments, and is designed to
operate in a non-H2 S environment where temperature and pressure do not exceed 260° F
(127° C) and 10,000 psi (68.95 Mpa), respectively. Although smaller than previous CN
instruments, measurements obtained with the 2436 XA compare favorably with measurements
obtained from previous CN models.
The 2436 XA Compensated Neutron Instrument provides an indication of formation porosity
based on the interaction of neutrons emitted from a chemical source with the formation. The
2436 XA CN instrument has two detectors. These detectors are called short space (SS) and
long space (LS) based on their relative distance from the neutron source. An analog section
detects and amplifies pulses representing neutrons. The downhole controller counts these
pulses. The surface acquisition requests data via the telemetry from the CN instrument at
regular intervals. The CN tool answers by sending data in a formatted block called Subset 0,
which includes the stored counts and other auxiliary parameters. After each transmission, the
tool resets the counters and resumes accumulating counts. The tool is also capable of storing
tables containing calibration and revision-level data in non-volatile memory.

2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Operating Procedures           130872-977

EQUIPMENT SPECIFICATIONS
Refer to document 130872-025 for 2436 XA Compensated Neutron Instrument Assembly
specifications. 

FIELD SAFETY

PERSONNEL SAFETY
Reference Document: HSES-UG-RAD-015 Neutron Source Maintenance
User Guide

Source Installation

WARNING:

PERSON DIRECTLY INVOLVED WITH THE SOURCE
INSTALLATION AND REMOVAL WILL BE IN THE IMMEDIATE
AREA. ALL OTHER PERSONNEL REMAIN CLEAR.
THE SOURCE CATCHER MUST BE INSTALLED PRIOR TO
SOURCE INSTALLATION AND REMOVAL IF THE INSTRUMENT
IS POSITIONED VERTICALLY OVER THE WELLBORE.

Any individual(s) directly handling the source must be fully qualified and thoroughly
familiar with the RADIOLOGICAL SAFETY procedures.

Place the source carrier P/N F085455000 and handling tools assembly P/N
F092924000 in the designated area for installation and removal.
2.
Position the source carrier so that when using the source-handling tool (with arms
fully extended) there is an unobstructed path between the source carrier and the
instrument source holder.
Note: It is the responsibility of the individual installing the source to
thoroughly understand the mechanical operation of the instrument
source holder prior to source installation.
3.
Verify the following prior to installing the source.
•
Path of handling tool (with arms fully extended) from source carrier to
instrument can be made in one movement
•
Instrument is positioned for easy access to the source holder
•
Source holder mechanism functions properly
•
Source cavity is clean and free of obstructions
•
All unnecessary personnel are clear of the source handling area

With arms fully extended, screw the source-handling tool onto the source. Unscrew
the source and pull it from the source holder. Quickly place the source in the source
carrier and secure.
6.
Lock the source carrier and return it to proper storage or to a secure, readily

2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Operating Procedures           130872-977

3.1.3
Using the Verification Jig
Note: An internal oscillator in the 2436 XA CN instrument is currently used for
before and after verifications. A verification jig (P/N 199847-000) is
available should clients require its use.
The CN verification jig (199847-000) contains a 400 mC neutron source. The source is
positioned in the verification jig on the side opposite the hinges. To minimize exposure,
the jig must be carried from the hinge side only.
1.
Position the jig over the detectors and engage the index pin in one of the holes in
the source sub spin collar.
2.
Close the jig around the instrument and secure with the two latches.

EQUIPMENT SAFETY
The 2436 XA require no special procedures to avoid damage. 

DOWNHOLE PRECAUTIONS
The 2436 XA Compensated Neutron uses a powerful chemical neutron source. If the
instrument is stuck in the well, extreme care must be exercised during fishing operations
to avoid rupturing the source.
Verify that the decentralizer is securely attached and is in its proper location. Refer to
Section  4.1.1.

SURFACE SETUP 

WELLSITE PROCEDURES
1.
Attach the cablehead and power up the toolstring. The 2436 XA should draw about
95 mA at 28 Vdc. Allow 15 minutes for the tool to warm up before attempting an
Internal Before Log verification. See Section  6.4 for procedure.

UNATTENDED ON THE CATWALK WITH LOGGING SOURCES
INSTALLED. REMOVE ALL LOGGING SOURCES AND
RETURN THEM TO THEIR PROPER CARRIERS AS SOON AS

WELLBORE.

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 6.0 CALIBRATION / VERIFICATION PROCEDURES .................................................... 12
chunk_text:
CALIBRATION / VERIFICATION PROCEDURES 12

CALIBRATION / VERIFICATION PROCEDURES
A new primary calibration should be done every 30 days, whenever possible. The maximum
period between calibrations should not exceed 90 days. A new primary calibration is also
required after any maintenance work, except routine preventive maintenance.

CALIBRATION THEORY
6.1.1
Normalized Ratio
The raw ratio measured during calibration is used to determine a normalizing factor
(MCF).
LS
SS
Ratio
Nominal
MCF
/
=

SS = short spaced counts
LS = Long spaced counts
During acquisition, the normalizing factor is used to correct the raw ratio to the
normalized ration.
MCF
LS
SS

Normalized
×
=

The primary calibration for the 2436 XA Compensated Neutron instruments is made in
the district calibration area using an environmental calibrator that accurately represents a
pre-defined porosity value.
The district environmental calibrator is matched to the Atlas Master Calibrator, located in
Houston. The Atlas Master Calibrator is referenced to the industry standard, which is the
API test pit at the University of Houston.
6.1.2
Primary Calibration
Responses of the long-space and short-space detectors to the environmental calibrator are
recorded during this calibration. The ratio of these responses is then calibrated to achieve
the porosity value that the calibrator represents.
6.1.3
Primary Verification
Primary verification is currently only done at the factory.
The 2436 XA Wellsite Verification Jig P/N 199847-000 (ice block) is required for
Primary verification. The porosity value the wellsite verifier represents is calculated

2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Operating Procedures           130872-977
CONFIDENTIAL                                                                                                       REV A
6.1.4
Internal Before Log Verification
The response of the 2436 XA electronics is verified against an internal oscillator when
internal before log verification is selected.
6.1.5
Internal After Log Verification
The response of the 2436 XA electronics is verified against an internal oscillator when
internal after log verification is selected. The internal after log verification should match
the internal before log verification, which indicates that the instrument has remained
stable during the logging operation.
6.1.6
Before Log Verification
This verification requires the use of the 2436 XA CN verification Jig (P/N 199847-000)
and is not normally done unless specifically requested by the customer. The instrument’s
response to the same verification standard used for primary calibration is obtained just
before running an instrument in the well. These results should match the primary
calibration within specified tolerances, and confirm that no change has occurred during
transportation to the wellsite. This before log verification establishes a stability reference
during logging. Refer to Section  21.0 for the before log verification procedure.
6.1.7
After Log Verification
This verification requires the use of the 2436 XA CN verification Jig (P/N 199847-000)
and is not normally done unless specifically requested by the customer. The instrument’s
response to the same calibration standard is again measured and recorded shortly after
completing logging. These results should match both the primary calibration and the
before log verification within specified tolerances, which indicates that the instrument has
remained stable during the logging operation. Refer to Section  21.0 for the after log
verification procedure.

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 6.2 PRIMARY CALIBRATION PROCEDURE ........................................................... 13

PRIMARY CALIBRATION PROCEDURE
6.2.1
Loading the Instrument into the 2437 XB Calibrator
Ensure that the calibrator has been properly set up and filled with the water/propylene
glycol mixture before proceeding.
1.
Pull out the eye-pin and let it dangle on its clevis to release the shielding plug
assembly. Slide out the plug assembly and let it also dangle.
2.
Ensure that the instrument to be calibrated and/or verified has a clean housing and
source sub. Remove attached labels, tape, etc. as excessive buildup could cause
calibration problems.
Note:

2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Operating Procedures           130872-977

3.
Connect the instrument to a 3518 Telemetry and Gamma Ray. Connections may be
made with umbilicals if desired. Connect the cablehead to the top of the 3518.
4.
Insert the instrument, without the source installed, into the central tube until the
source holder just protrudes from the source end of the tube. Two people are
required for this operation, or one if using a hoist to support the middle of the
instrument.
5.
Rotate the instrument as necessary to position the source holder facing down.
Note:
The instrument should rest securely on the two edges of the groove
machined along the bottom of the central tube’s bore.
6.
Turn on power to the 3518 and 2436 XA. Allow the instruments to warm up for 30
minutes before proceeding.
7.
Loosen the two source holder shear screws to allow the source holder to open.
8.
Verify that the source holder threads are clean and lubricated.
9.
Keep fingers clear of the source holder closing area and rotate the instrument until
the source holder is at the 9:00 o’clock position.
10.
Carefully push in the instrument to bring the source holder as close as possible to
the main tube, without interfering with installation of the source.
Note:
If the instrument cannot be easily prevented from rotating, one

2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Operating Procedures           130872-977

6.2.2
Source Installation
WARNING: THE PERSON CONTROLLING THE SIDE DOOR TOOL SHOULD
TAKE MAXIMUM ADVANTAGE OF THE SHIELDING PROVIDED
BY THE LIQUID CONTENT OF THE CHAMBER TO REDUCE
RADIATION EXPOSURE. ALL PERSONNEL INVOLVED WITH
THE INSTALLATION OF THE NEUTRON SOURCE, AND
FURTHER OPERATION OF THE SYSTEM, SHOULD ENSURE
THEIR FULL FAMILIARITY AND CONFORMITY WITH THE
REGULATIONS AND GUIDELINES PUBLISHED IN THE
WELLSITE USAGE SECTION (BEHIND THE IONIZING
RADIATION SAFETY TAB) IN THE RADIATION SAFETY
MANUAL.
1.
Loosen the shear screws and open the source holder.
2.
Insert the source directly into the open source holder using the source-handling tool
and tighten securely. Remove the source-handling tool.
3.
Move to the side of the chamber where the shear screws are accessible.
4.
Tap downward on the source holder with the source-handling tool to close.
Immediately tighten the shear screws, withdraw the side door tool, and move to the
cablehead side of the instrument.
5.
Pull the cablehead end to bring the source sub into the central tube. Allow enough
clearance to reinstall the plastic shielding plate.
Note:
Verify that the instrument still rests securely on the two edges of
the bore groove to prevent skewing.
6.
Reinstall the plastic shielding and plug by sliding it into the tube with its handle
vertical until the handle contacts the end of the tube. Align the holes and lock it
into position with the eye pin.
7.
Push the instrument from the cablehead end, without rotating it, until it bears
against the V-groove in the plastic plug. This is the operating position.
8.

2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Operating Procedures           130872-977

Moderator Rod Configuration
Use rod configuration B for the 2436 XA Compensated Neutron.
1.
Carefully insert the moderator rods into the cylindrical void outside the instrument
and inside the central tube to achieve the distribution designated for calibration of
the instrument as shown in Figure 2. Insert the rods, eyebolt ends last, from the

Push in each rod until it contacts the plastic end plug. Avoid bending the rods.
Note:
Do not allow any of the rods to pull away from the tube bore by
riding into the V-groove portion of the end plug.

Calibration Procedure
1.
Start the acquisition system and establish communications per normal practice.
2.
Allow the instrument to warm up for at least 30 minutes prior to performing
calibration. Do not install the source until after the warm-up period.
3.
Click Calibrate from the main menu and then click Comp Neutron from the drop
down menu. See Figure 3.

The Calibration – Comp Neutron dialog, similar to Figure 4, should now be

Enter the asset number of the 2437 XB calibrator in the Calb Asset window.

Enter the asset number of the 4718 XA source assembly in the Source Asset

6.2.5
Source Removal
1.
Turn off instrument power.
2.
From the cablehead end, rotate the instrument 180°. The source holder should be
facing down.
3.
Ensure that the source carrier is positioned such that the path from instrument to
carrier is unobstructed.
Note:
If two people are present, one should be ready to push the
instrument from the cablehead end. The other person takes the
side door tool and source-handling tool to a position where he can
access the source holder shear screw, while taking advantage of
the shielding provided by the calibration chamber. This position is
normally to the right side of the chamber, as viewed from the
cablehead end.
4.
Unlock and withdraw the plastic shielding and position control plug from the
source end of the chamber.
5.
Push the instrument from the cablehead end just far enough to expose the entire
length of the source holder. Ensure that the source holder is still facing down.
6.
From a well-shielded position, use the side door tool to loosen the shear screws just
enough to allow the source holder to swing open. Open the side door.
7.
Rotate the instrument from the cablehead end 180° or until the source holder is in
the 9:00-o’clock position.
Note:
Ensure that the instrument is stable in this position. If not, one
person must support the instrument from the cablehead end while
the other removes the source.
8.
Quickly remove the source with the source-handling tool and return it to its carrier.
9.
Close the source holder. Tighten both shear screws to lock the source holder in
place.
10.
Disconnect the cablehead and 3518 Telemetry and Gamma Ray instrument, and

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 6.3 PRIMARY VERIFICATION PROCEDURES ........................................................ 19
chunk_text:
PRIMARY VERIFICATION PROCEDURES
Currently, Primary Verification is only done at the factory, but may need to be performed
by field personnel in the future.
1.
Connect the instrument to a 3518 Telemetry and Gamma Ray. Connections may be
made with umbilicals if desired. Connect the cablehead to the top of the 3518.
2.
Place the 2436 XA on tool stands that are at least one-foot (0.31 m) above the
ground, and ensure that the area from the source sub to about two feet up on the
main housing weldment is unobstructed.
3.
Position the  verification jig (P/N 199847000) over the detectors and engage the
index pin in one of the holes in the source sub spin collar. Close the verification jig
around the instrument and secure with the two latches. Make sure that no source is
installed in the 2436 XA CN instrument, in any other instrument in the string, or
within 30 feet (9.14 m) of the 2436 XA.
4.
Click Verify from the main menu, click Primary from the Verify drop-down
menu, and then click Comp Neutron from the Primary menu. See Figure 5.

2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Operating Procedures           130872-977

5.
The Primary Verification – Comp Neutron Tool dialog, similar to Figure 6,
should now be displayed. View the date and time in the Time window to check the
date and time of the active calibration. If the wrong calibration (or no calibration) is
loaded, click the Latest check box and then click the Load from Tool or Load
from Disk button to retrieve the correct calibration from disk or from the tool.

Enter the asset number of the verification jig in the Jig Asset window.
7.
Click the Read Jig button to start the primary verification. The progress indicator,
located just above the Abort and Help buttons, should begin to increment.
8.
The Primary Verification is a "relative" value and does not have a tolerance.
9.
If the primary verification just completed is valid, click Apply to save the
completed primary verification to disk. Click the Save to Tool check box then the
Apply button to save to disk and to the tool.
If additional Primary Verifications are desired using different wellsite verification jigs,
they must be performed at this time, and by repeating Steps 1 through 9.

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 6.4 INTERNAL WELLSITE VERIFICATION PROCEDURE ...................................... 20
chunk_text:
INTERNAL WELLSITE VERIFICATION PROCEDURE
The Internal Before-Log and After-Log verifications are performed at the wellsite and
verifies the tool's electronics against an internal oscillator. The two detectors are not
verified. See Section  21.0 if before and after log verifications are desired.
The instrument may be verified vertically, suspended over the borehole at the wellsite or

2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Operating Procedures           130872-977
CONFIDENTIAL                                                                                                       REV A
6.4.1
Internal Before-Log Verification
1.
Start the acquisition system and establish communications per normal practice.
2.
Allow the instrument to warm up for at least 30 minutes prior to performing the
internal before log check.
3.
Click Verify from the main menu, Internal Before Log from the drop down menu,
and then Comp Neutron as shown in Figure 7.

The Internal Before Log Verification – Comp Neutron Tool dialog, similar to
2436 XA CN Internal Before-Log Verification Dialog
5.
Click the Start button to start the internal before log verification. The progress
indicator, located just above the Abort and Help buttons, should begin to

2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Operating Procedures           130872-977

6.
When the progress indicator reaches 100%, the internal before calibration is
complete. Click Apply to save the completed internal before log verification to
disk.
6.4.2
Internal After-Log Verification
1.
The system should already be running and communication with the tool
established. If not, do so at this time.
2.
Click Verify from the main menu, Internal After Log from the drop down menu,
and then Comp Neutron. See Figure 9.

The Internal After Log Verification – Comp Neutron Tool dialog, similar to the
Internal Before Log Verification – Comp Neutron Tool shown in Figure 8, should
now be displayed.
4.
Click the Start button to start the internal after log verification. The progress
indicator, located just above the Abort and Help buttons, should begin to

OUTPUT CURVES
The main output curves for the 2436 XA Compensated Neutron are CN and CNC. CN is
uncorrected compensated neutron porosity and CNC is the compensated neutron porosity
index computed for a particular rock matrix and corrected for the effects of borehole size
and salinity.
An alternative curve is CNCF, which incorporates a limit at the high end to produce a
better correlation with tools from other companies.

chunk_text:
COMPENSATED NEUTRON PARAMETERS
Click Parameters from the job main menu and then click Comp Neutron from the drop
down menu. See Figure 10.

can setup specific parameters for the job to be run. The parameters dialog has three panes:
CN Processing, Borehole Corrections, and Casing and Cement Correction. The panes are
explained in the following paragraphs.

2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Operating Procedures           130872-977

CN PROCESSING PANE
8.1.1
Matrix
Selects the porosity transform (Sandstone, Limestone, or Dolomite) that will be used to
compute the corrected CN curves (CNC or CNCF). This parameter should be selected to
match the anticipated lithology of the formation of interest.
Zone
Clicking the Zone button opens the Matrix Density Zoning dialog (Figure 12). Use this
dialog to enter the expected formation type (Dolomite, Limestone, or Sandstone) and the
depth at which to expect each type.

Log Hole Type
Clicking the down arrow in the Log Hole Type window opens a drop-down menu where
you can select Open Hole or Cased Hole. The choice you make affects whether cement /
casing corrections will be applied. If Open Hole is selected, cement correction is not
applied to the processing. If Cased Hole is selected the Casing and Cement
Corrections pane becomes active.
8.1.3
Salinity
Entering a value greater than 0 (zero) in the Salinity window will enable the salinity
correction. Entering 0 (zero) turns off the correction.

Apply

8.2.2
Borehole Correction
Click the Borehole Correction down arrow to view the list of options. Choices are:
•
USE FIXED– When selected, the corrected CN curves (CNC, CNFC) will be
computed using the value entered in the Fixed Diameter window. This setting
assumes that the borehole is a constant diameter throughout the logging interval. A
value of 7-7/8-inches will apply zero correction.
•
USE CAL – When selected, the corrected CN curves (CNC, /CNFC will be
computed using the Realtime CAL curve, which can be selected from any of the
available calipers, or an average or minimum of two of them.
8.2.3
Fixed Diameter
This is only active if Use Fixed is selected in the Borehole Correction window.

RIG UP PROCEDURES
The procedures for installation and removal of the logging source should be reviewed prior to

The source catcher must be installed prior to source installation and removal if the instrument

No other special procedures are required.

The Focus Acquisition System software comes with online help. The online help is updated

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 11.0 INSTRUMENT COMBINATIONS 11.1 FOCUS SYSTEM OPERATION
chunk_text:
11.1 FOCUS SYSTEM OPERATION
The 2436 XA Compensated Neutron can be combined with all Focus instruments. A 3518
Telemetry and Gamma Ray instrument is required. Normally, the 2436 XA Compensated
Neutron instrument is connected immediately below the 3518 Telemetry and Gamma
Ray.

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 11.2 ECLIPS SYSTEM OPERATION
chunk_text:
The 2436 XA can also be run on an ECLIPS system with most current WTS instruments
using a 3526 Focus to WTS Adapter. The 3526 adapter must be positioned between the
bottom WTS instrument and the top Focus instrument, normally the 2436 XA
Compensated Neutron. The 3518 Telemetry and Gamma Ray instrument is not required
for ECLIPS system operations.
A 4430 XB Downhole Power Adapter is required for operations that require the use of the
3526 Focus to WTS Adapter.

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 12.0 HOSTILE ENVIRONMENT OPERATING PROCEDURES 13.0 LOG QUALITY CONTROL
chunk_text:
The 2436 XA CN instrument is not designed to operate in an H2 S environment, or in wells
where temperature exceeds 260° F (127° C) and/or pressure exceeds 10,000 psi (8.97 Mpa).

29
2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Operating Procedures           130872-977
CONFIDENTIAL                                                                                                       REV A 13.0 LOG QUALITY CONTROL
A quick-look log quality check can be made by looking at the separation of the ZDEN and
CNC curves when plotted on compatible scales; e.g., ZDEN scaled 1.95 to 2.95 gm/cc and
CNC scaled 45 to -15 p.u. for limestone or ZDEN scaled 1.65 to 2.65 gm/cc with CNC scaled
60 to 0 (zero) p.u. for sandstone.
•
Limestone-scaled curves should overlay in clean water-bearing limestone in water-based
mud systems.
•
When a sandstone formation is presented on compatible limestone (1.95 to 2.95 gm/cc,
45 to -15 p.u.) scales, you should see a negative 6 to 8 p.u. separation (CNC < ZDEN) in
water-based mud systems.
•
The ZDEN and CNC curves show some separation (CNC porosity < ZDEN) in clean,
light-hydrocarbon zones. The magnitude of the separation depends on the hydrocarbon
types, the depth of invasion, and the mud filtrate density. The characteristics of the mud
filtrate differ in oil or water based mud systems.
If automatic caliper corrections are applied, CN log accuracy is affected in washed out or
rugose boreholes. Note that at 20 p.u., the caliper correction changes by one p.u. per inch.
Ensure that accurate values for borehole and formation salinities are used to apply salinity
corrections.

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 13.1 LOG HEADING REMARKS
chunk_text:
•
The matrix used for neutron porosity must be clearly indicated on the log scale.
•
Whether the displayed neutron curve is borehole corrected (CNC) or not (CN)
•
Justification for any log run without a decentralizer
•
If run in casing, state whether casing correction has been applied.
•
Note depth and angle of maximum borehole deviation
•
Note chloride concentration (gm/1 or ppm) in the mud
•
Convert mud chloride concentration to equivalent NaCI concentration for calculation
of borehole salinity correction.
•
Note whether borehole or borehole salinity corrections have been applied. Formation

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 13.4 LOG DATA ACCURACY
chunk_text:
Below 7 p.u. porosity = ±0.5 p.u.
Above 7 p.u. porosity = ±7 % of recorded value

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 13.5 LIMITATIONS AND ANOMALOUS RESPONSES
chunk_text:
Decentralization is critical in neutron logging. Log accuracy is degraded in rugose
boreholes and washouts where CN detectors are unable to conform to the borehole wall.
Caliper corrections applied in elliptical boreholes may be incorrect. The correction
algorithm assumes a circular borehole. The caliper usually measures the longest axis of
the borehole, whereas the CNC correction is better obtained using the borehole diameter
equivalent to the curvature at the CN tool’s point of contact.
Statistical variations are directly dependent on logging speed. Reading accuracy can
therefore be improved in zones of interest by reducing logging speed to as low as 10
ft/min (3.1 m/min).
Differences between repeat and main log compensated neutron curves are also caused by
erratic variations in logging speed and recorded depth due to sticking or to tracking of the
instrument on different sides of the borehole in heterogeneous formations.

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 17.0 ENVIRONMENTAL CORRECTIONS 18.0 TROUBLESHOOTING

formation salinity, mud weight, mud cake, and thermal neutron absorber are available in post-

The 2436 XA is similar to earlier CN tools and is subject to the same types of problems. No

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 19.2 POST-JOB INSPECTION AND CLEANING
chunk_text:
_____1.
Ensure that the thread protectors (with O-Rings) are installed and open the
source holder.
_____2.
Thoroughly clean the instrument to remove mud, grease, dirt, and other
foreign materials, if the instrument has been run in a well. Dry with
compressed air, or dry the instrument with rags or paper towels.
_____3.
Place the 2436 XA CN in a vise and tighten the vise on the pressure housing.
Clean the subs and check for thread damage.
_____4.
Remove and discard all external O-Rings. Also check the O-Ring seats for
pitting. Lubricate and install new external O-Rings.
_____5.
Inspect the internal threads in the source holder for damage.
A. Chase damaged threads with a 1-1/8-12 Stub Acme thread tap.
B.
Clean threads after chasing with a drill and correct size rotary wire
brush.
C.
Clean out residue and apply a protective coat of oil.
_____6.
Remove the two modified 1/2-13 shear-screws from the source sub.
A. Verify that the correct modified shear screws (P/N F097409000) are
being used. These screws are modified so that they can be sheared if
necessary to remove the source.
B.
Inspect the screws for damage and replace as necessary.
C.
Chase the threads in the source sub as necessary with a 1/2-13 N.C. tap.
_____7.
Perform continuity and leakage checks as described in Section  19.1.
_____8.
Reinstall the top and bottom thread protectors.

topic: Instrument Operating Procedures - 20.0 TRANSPORTATION AND HANDLING
chunk_text:
The 2436 XA has no special transport requirements. Observe all regulations and safety
practices regarding the transport of the source and field verification jig.
21.0 APPENDIX A – WELLSITE VERIFICATION USING EXTERNAL
VERIFIER
The Before-Log and After-Log verifications are performed at the wellsite and use the same
field verification standard as the Primary Verification.
Position the 2436 XA CN instrument (without the source installed) on tool stands if a
horizontal verification is to be performed.
The instrument may be verified vertically, suspended over the borehole at the wellsite. The
Before-Log and After-Log verifications must be performed in the same environment to
ensure verification validity. The verifications must be performed with all radioactive logging

2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Operating Procedures           130872-977

Connect the 2436 XA to the 3518 Telemetry and Gamma Ray. Other tools may be
connected to the string, but are not required. Connections may be made using
umbilicals if desired.

Position the 2436 XA on tool stands for horizontal verification or over the wellbore
for vertical verification. Make sure that access to the detector section is
unrestricted.
3.
If the instrument is horizontal, rotate the instrument such that the one of the wrench
holes on the source sub spin collar is at the 12:00 o’clock position. Ensure that no
sources are installed in the 2436 XA or any other instrument in the string, or within

4.
Start the acquisition system and establish communications per normal practice.
5.
Allow the instrument to warm up for at least 30 minutes (one hour is preferred)

GENERAL DESCRIPTION
The 2436 XA Compensated Neutron Instrument has two thermal-neutron detectors located at
different spacings from the Americium-Beryllium neutron source. The two detectors are
referred to as LS (long space) and SS (short space) during this discussion, based on their
relative position in the tool. Figure 1 is a simplified block diagram that shows the main
components of this instrument.

thermal neutrons. The LS and SS detectors, LS and SS preamplifier boards, neutron
controller board, ±5 V and ±12 V power supplies, high voltage power supply, and terminal
board are all located on or in the detector/electronics chassis assembly.
The LS and SS detectors require a positive high voltage bias (1,350 Vdc) that is supplied by
the high voltage power supply. When a neutron is detected, a pulse is generated. The pulses
from the LS and SS detectors are amplified and discriminated (separated from noise) in their
respective preamplifier boards. Digital counters in the neutron controller board accumulate
these pulses. The information in the neutron controller board is sent to the surface when the
telemetry requests data.
130872-945 / 2436 XA
JAN 2004
3
2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Circuit Descriptions

ELECTRONICS CHASSIS ASSEMBLY
The Detector / Electronics Chassis Assembly includes the LS and SS detector, LS and SS
neutron moderator assemblies, LS and SS preamplifier boards, neutron controller board, ±5 V
and ±12 V power supplies, high voltage power supply, and the terminal board. 

DETECTORS
The LS and SS detectors are high-pressure Helium-3 (He3) proportional counters.
They are mounted along the tool axis and isolated from the 18-curie source by the
Boron Carbide-filled LS and SS moderator assemblies. The detectors consist of a
center electrode – anode – mounted inside a metal cylinder that is pressurized with
He3 gas. The bias voltage (1,350 Vdc) is applied to the anode, the external metal
cylinder (connected to common ground) acting as the cathode. A strong electric field
is then created between the anode and the cathode.
Thermal neutrons enter the detector and are captured by helium atoms, producing
protons and tritium particles.
Electrons are stripped away from these positively charged particles as they pass
through neutral helium atoms, creating primary ion pairs. The Electrons accelerate
rapidly toward the anode and the neutral helium atoms move toward the cathode in
this strong magnetic field. The electrons collide with other neutral helium atoms to
produce secondary ion pairs. This process repeats itself several times until an
avalanche of electrons at the anode produce a negative output pulse. A quenching
gas, typically CO2, is added to keep the discharge under control.
The output of the detector is a small electric charge, typically 3 to 4 pico-Coulombs.
After converting this charge to voltage and applying a large amount of amplification,
a pulse is obtained with a height that is characteristic of the detected neutron. Gamma
rays and thermal noise can also cause output pulses, but these pulses are smaller than
those caused by thermal neutrons. The difference allows the gamma ray and noise
pulses to be discriminated, allowing only neutron pulses to be counted.
The SS detector has an active dimension of 1.25 by 4 inches and is filled with four
atmospheres of He3. The LS detector is 2.25 by 8 inches and is filled to six
atmospheres.
130872-945 / 2436 XA
JAN 2004
4
2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Circuit Descriptions

LS AND SS PREAMPLIFIER BOARDS
These two boards are functionally similar. Because of this functional similarity, only the
LS preamplifier board is discussed. Refer to LS Preamp Board schematic drawing
199125-100 and SS Preamp Board schematic drawing 199126-100 during the following
discussions.
Preamplifier, pulse shaping, and discriminator functions are incorporated into these
boards. Both the analog and discriminator functions are discussed.
2.2.1 Analog Circuit
The simplified schematic example (Figure 2) is a subset of schematic drawing 199125-
100. The R2-C1 network is configured as a filter to reduce noise in the high voltage
input. R3 is the load resistor of the detector and is kept large to avoid excessive loading
of the detector. Capacitor C9 de-couples the DC bias voltage. R2, R3, C1, and C9 are all
high-voltage, low-noise components. D2 and R10 protect the inputs of operational
amplifier U1, because of the presence of elevated potential. This stage is configured as a
charge-sensitive amplifier (very low input impedance to reduce stray capacitance effects)
with C2 as the storage capacitor and R4 as the bleed resistor. These two components (C2
and R4) are critical components in determining pulse shape.
Two conventional voltage amplifiers (U2 A and U2 B) that have a total gain of about 750
follow the U1 amplifier. The neutron peak of the resultant spectrum (main band seen on
an oscilloscope) should be 3 V at this point. Resistor R21 is adjusted to obtain this 3 V
output, which should remain constant over time. A rapid change indicates a problem.

JAN 2004
5
2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Circuit Descriptions
2.2.2 Discriminator Circuit
The discriminator circuit takes the pulses produced in the preamplifier section, corrects
the reference baseline, detects pulses larger than threshold, and shapes the output that is
sent to the controller board. Figure 3 is a simplified schematic that shows the primary
components and functions of the discriminator circuit.

polarity. Such unipolar pulses will produce a baseline shift when coupled through a
capacitor that is proportional to the average area of the pulse (i.e., more shift at higher
count rates). The problem is significant because of the high-count rates obtained with this
instrument (particularly in low porosity, small hole situations), and the relatively low
discriminator level. The circuit formed by C12, R5, R17, and D1 acts as a simple baseline
restorer, returning a value similar to the reference voltage. The reference voltage is
generated by U5.
The pulses present on R14 are compared in the U3 voltage comparator against a threshold
voltage set by U5. Resistors R7 and R19/R20 form a positive feedback loop to avoid
multiple triggering. The digital pulses on U3 pin 7 are of different lengths, depending on
130872-945 / 2436 XA
JAN 2004
6
2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Circuit Descriptions
their amplitude above the threshold. Monostable U4 A is then added to conform to the
minimum timing requirements of the neutron controller board. R8 and C5 determine the
period. R12 is used only for protection.
The power supply section is shown in the lower right of schematic drawing 199125-100.
It is straightforward and requires no further explanation.

NEUTRON CONTROLLER BOARD
Refer to the Neutron Controller Board schematic drawing 199135-100 during the
following discussion. The main component in the controller board is U5, a micro-
controller integrating multiple peripheral functions including ROM, RAM, A/D
converter, timers, etc. U8 is a 16 MHz crystal-controlled oscillator that provides the
necessary clock signals. The main function of this controller is to accumulate the counts
from the two detectors and to send them to the telemetry when so instructed. This
information is formatted in a data block that also contains several auxiliary parameters.
The counts from both detectors are received via connectors J1 and J2 and routed to the
data selector U1. R1-D1 and R2-D2 provide protection. Controlled by commands from
the surface, U1 selects which pulses are counted, either detector data or pulses generated
by dividing the auxiliary oscillator U3 to verify proper tool function. The outputs of U1
are routed to two of the processor internal counters.
The communications between this tool and the telemetry are established using the Mode
2 protocol. The Manchester encoder-decoder U7 provides the necessary interface
functions supported by the clocks generated by U3 and divider U2. Transmission to the
tool bus is implemented with line driver U6, transformer T1, and associated hardware.
Reception is accomplished with transformer T2 and line receiver U9.
This tool has the capability to store tables containing calibration and hardware data. The
Flash EEPROM U10 is used for this purpose and is connected using a serial SPI bus to
the main processor.
Finally, the operational amplifiers in U11 condition analog signals that are then digitized
in the processor’s A/D converter for inclusion in the tool data block. The analog signals
monitored are:
•
value of the high voltage,
•
+5 V,
•
and tool temperature.

DC-DC POWER SUPPLY ASSEMBLIES
The tool uses two standard power supply modules. One produces ±5 volts and is used by
the analog circuits and the processor board. The other module generates ±12 volts and is
used exclusively to power the high voltage power supply. This has been done to isolate
grounds because the detectors are mechanically and electrically connected to chassis,
which is also the signal return path. By using this module we avoid the galvanic
connection between the tool bus 28 V return line and chassis.
130872-945 / 2436 XA
JAN 2004
7
2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Circuit Descriptions
Along with one of the supplies is an EMI filter module to drastically reduce interference
and interaction between supplies of other Focused Logging System instruments. These
self-contained, modular supplies mount on a heat-sinking channel and have additional
circuitry mounted on a PC board that is soldered directly to the pins of the supply. It is
this additional circuitry that will be the topic of discussion for this section.
Because the power supplies are modular, there is no repair of the unit. It either works or it
doesn’t. The only circuitry external to the module (U1) is some inhibiting control and
some additional output filtering.
2.4.1 Dual Power Supply
Instrument power first passes through an EMI filter module before being applied to any
DC to DC converter module; thus, the voltage at terminal E1 is a filtered +28 V. E2 is tied
to the return line of the EMI filter output. Pins 6, 7 and 8 are tied to chassis ground,
which is tied to cable armor. Three independent windings of a choke, L1, filter voltage
spikes on the output of the module. No provision is made for trimming the output
voltage. Additional output filtering is provided by capacitors C3, C4, C5, C6 and C7. See
the schematic (Figure 4) below.










130872-945 / 2436 XA
JAN 2004
8
2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Circuit Descriptions
2.4.2 Power Control Circuit
Associated with the ±12 V-power supply module is an EMI filter module. The PC board
attached to this module performs several control functions. These control functions are
described below.
A +5 volt supply is generated for other chips on the PC board. The supply consists of a
single dropping resistor (R3) and reference Zener diode (D1) to establish the voltage.
This supply is connected to the output of the EMI filter module (U1). It is this +28 V EMI
filter output that connects to the input of other DC to DC converter modules within the
instrument. See the schematic (Figure 5) below.

circuit. The heart of the power control circuitry is a programmable microcontroller (U3).
Values for resistor R7 and capacitor C3 have been selected to give an operating
frequency of approximately 1 MHz. Supplied with +5 volts from the supply shown in
(1) A threshold voltage is established using chip U4. The voltage divider consisting of
R6 and R8 are chosen such that when 20 volts or more (for instrument power) is
present on R6, the reset chip removes the low on pin 7. The low on pin 7 removes the
reset from microcontroller U3, allowing it to do its job.
130872-945 / 2436 XA
JAN 2004
9
2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Circuit Descriptions
(2) Jumper inputs to the microcontroller chip (U3) are set for different length delay
times. Delay times are established for different tools to limit the current demand
when the tool string is first powered up. Delay times, in milliseconds, and their
jumpers are shown in the table below.

(3) Output RA1 of U3 pin 18 is floating (open collector circuit) when power is first
applied to the microcontroller. Resistor R4 pulls the base of Q1 HIGH turning it ON.
This state applies a ground potential to all power supplies tied to the Q1 collector.
Diodes D2 – D4 form an OR function in the collector circuit, allowing control over
different power supplies. By tying the INHIBIT pin (active low) of each DC-to-DC
converter module within an instrument to one of these control terminals (E5, E6 or
E7), you can independently control its ON/OFF function. With Q1 initially turned
ON, no power supply module can turn ON. It is not until the time-out function is
completed by U3 that output RA1 can transition LOW, turning OFF Q1. With Q1
OFF, power supplies are allowed to turn ON because their INHIBIT is removed. As
the power supplies turn ON, their current demand is confined to that particular
instrument. Again, see the control circuit on page 10.












130872-945 / 2436 XA
JAN 2004
10
2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Circuit Descriptions




130872-945 / 2436 XA
JAN 2004
11
2436 XA Focus Compensated Neutron – Circuit Descriptions
Refer to drawing 198384-100 for the complete schematic of the Power Controller board.
As an added feature of this circuit, Power Supply #2 or Power Supply #3 can be turned
OFF by an external source via opto-isolator U2. Terminal E8 is tied to a positive voltage.
Taking control terminal E9 or E10 LOW causes its respective switch to close. This
applies a ground potential to the INHIBIT input of the supply that is tied to its control
terminal, E6 or E7. This LOW turns OFF the respective power supply. Terminal E9
controls a power supply (P.S.2) connected to terminal E6, while E10 controls a supply
(P.S.3) connected to terminal E7. Thus, independent control is available if needed. Power
supplies connected to E5 are solely controlled by the timing function associated with the
operation of transistor Q1. Figure 7 is the schematic diagram of the opto-isolated power
supply control circuit.

HV POWER SUPPLY
The ±12 V Power Supply provides ±12 V to the inputs of the high voltage power supply
module. An external resistor adjusts the output value of the HV module to 1,350 Vdc. A
filter capacitor is installed across its output to reduce ripple noise. The resistor and
capacitor are mounted to terminal posts that are screwed directly into the chassis.

assembly every four months to ensure the integrity of the instrument.
A check-off sheet is provided at the end of this document. Copy and complete this check-off

Place the completed check-off sheet in the tool’s history folder.

INTRODUCTION
High voltage and neutron radiation are both present in the 2436 XA Compensated Neutron
Instrument at various times. Both are discussed in the following paragraphs.

ELECTRICAL SAFETY PECAUTIONS
High voltage (1,350 Vdc) is present at various points on the compensated neutron
electronics chassis when the pressure housing is removed and power is applied to the
instrument. The following precautions apply.
•
Clear the area of all non-essential personnel and post the appropriate electrical
warning signs.
•
Never leave the tool unattended while power is on.
•
Turn off power to the tool if it not necessary to the task being performed.
•
High voltage is present at the following points on the electronics chassis when power
is on.
HV power supply and electrical components in the immediately vicinity
Pin 8 of the 10-pin connector at the top of the neutron controller PCB
Pin 6 (at neutron controller PCB) and pin 1 (at LS preamp PCB) of the LS
preamp cable
J2 on the LS preamp PCB
Pin 6 of the SS preamp cable at the controller PCB
High voltage is also present at the SS preamp PCB, LS detector, and the SS
detector. These points; however, are not typically exposed during normal
testing.
RADIATION SAFETY PRECAUTIONS
At times, both low-yield and high-yield neutron sources are used in the lab environment.
The following safety precautions apply.
Sources should only be handled by personnel that are trained in radiation safety.
Store sources in their correct storage container when not in use.
Clear the area of all personnel not directly involved in the installation, removal, or
other activities involving the nuclear source.
Post the appropriate warning signs and visual indicators when sources are out of their
storage containers or loaded in the tool.
Remember, radiation exposure is directly related to exposure time and distance from
the source. Use the correct source-handling tool and perform source handling
quickly, taking advantage of available shielding.

INTRODUCTION
Laboratory functionality checks using the Lab PC Test System for the 2436 XA Compensated
Neutron instrument begins with resistance checks of wiring from the top connector pins to
chassis common. Once wiring is proven, other testing can begin.
Use the Lab PC Test System to check the operation of the circuitry. For details of how to
setup and use this test system, see the Manufacturing Checkout Procedure 130872-856.
Actual test steps to be performed on the 2436 XA are noted within the context of that
document (130872-856).

topic: Brief Description of Service - BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON 1.0 BRIEF DESCRIPTION
chunk_text:
1
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON 1.0 BRIEF DESCRIPTION
The 2446 XA Compensated Neutron instrument is a radiation logging device used to indicate formation
porosity in open or cased boreholes.  Two thermal neutron detectors are positioned at different spacings
from an 18-Curie, Americium 241 - Beryllium (AmBe) neutron source.  The near detector is referred to
as the "short-spaced" (SS) detector.  The far detector is referred to as the "long-spaced" (LS) detector.
The 2446 XA instrument is the latest in a long line of Compensated Neutron devices.  The 2446 XA
instrument is a conventional Compensated Neutron instrument and shares some components with the
older tools.  However, the 2446 XA is NOT a variation of the 2435/38 family.  The detectors,
corrections, response, calibration and software are all new.  The instrument offers many improvements
over the 2438 XA, including: increased long space count rate, decreased statistics, reduced borehole
salinity, more linear transform, etc.
The neutron source continuously emits fast neutrons. When the fast neutrons collide with the various
nuclei in the formation, they lose energy, slow to an epithermal energy level and then to a thermal
energy level. The proportional-counters used as detectors are designed to respond primarily to thermal
neutrons.  For well-logging applications, it is significant that hydrogen is one of the most effective
neutron thermalizers.  Therefore, a decreasing detector count indicates an increasing amount of
hydrogenous material between the source and the detectors.  This, in turn, indicates a higher formation
porosity.
The count rates from both the long-spaced detector and the short-spaced detector are processed in the
instrument and transmitted to the surface. Each signal passes through a three stage amplifier (Neutron
Pulse Processor board).
The surface computer calculates the short-spaced (SSN) count rate and the long-spaced (LSN) count
rate.  A SSN/LSN ratio is derived and used to compute the apparent limestone porosity curve (CN).
Corrections are also applied to the ratio to compute CNC.  The corrections include:  other lithologies,
borehole size and salinity, stand-off, pressure, temperature, etc.
Both detectors and the main electronic components are placed inside a vacuum flask to protect them
from excessive temperatures.
