BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON

1
GENERAL DATA ACQUISITION DESCRIPTION    2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
SAMPLED DATA
Long spaced and short spaced count rates are acquired and recorded as curves named LSN and SSN,
respectively.  Counts are accumulated downhole, and transmitted to the surface using digital telemetry.
CN CURVES
 SSN
Short Spaced Counts from CN
 LSN
Long Spaced Counts from CN
LSN and SSN are typically acquired at 4 samples/foot; 1 or 2 samples/decimeter.  This is a finer
resolution than the vertical bed resolution of the instrument.
DEADTIME CORRECTION
Radiation detectors are subject to a phenomenon referred to as "deadtime".  Deadtime may be defined
simply as the amount of time that must elapse before another event can be detected.  Any events that
occur during the deadtime of a detector are missed.
The count rates of the 2446 XA CN instrument are dead time corrected.  The current values used for
dead time correction are 20 microseconds for the short space detector and 24 microseconds for the long
space detector.  Dead time correction is applied using the following formula:
CR   = CR
 /(1-CR
t)
dtc
raw
raw
where CR
 is the count rate for either the SS or LS detector in counts per second (cps),  is the
raw
t
appropriate dead time for the detector system expressed in seconds, and CR  is the dead time corrected
dtc
count rate.
  
COMPUTED CURVES AVAILABLE
*CPP
Crossplot Porosity (must have PORD)
*CPCZ
Crossplot Porosity from PORZ and CNC
*CN
Compensated Neutron Porosity
 CNC
Corrected CN (Caliper, Salinity, Casing, Lithology, etc.)
*CNRA
CLSN/CSSN
*CNCF
Field Normalized Response
 FCCZ
Formation Factor from CPCZ
 FCN
Formation Factor from CN
 RWAN
RWA from RT, RD, RILD, or RIPD and from CNC
 RWCZ
RWA from RT, RD, RILD, or RIPD and from CPCZ
*NOTE:  No computer input is required.
2
GENERAL DATA ACQUISITION DESCRIPTION    2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
Previous versions of Western Atlas CN instruments typically had a "CHI SMOOTH" filter applied to
the CN curve.  This filtering technique is not allowed with the 2446 XA CN instrument.  The filtering
technique used with the 2446 XA accomplishes two things.  The first is to average the SSN count rate
over the number of levels corresponding to 1 foot (or 0.4 meters) ("box car type filter") to
approximately match the vertical resolution of the two detectors.  The number of levels averaged is
dependent on the sample rate.  After this, the normal Atlas 11 point filter is applied to both the SSN and
LSN.  The standard filter weights are available (0=no filtering, 1=normal filtering, 2=weak filtering,
and 3=strong filter).  In all cases, SSN and LSN are recorded to tape as unfiltered curves.
Filter weight is selected by the service table.  Service tables used for 2438 XA WTS CN instruments
can be used for the 2446 XA instrument with the addition of one curve, "CNRT".  The curve CNRT
must be added as a computed curve after the sampled curves and before CN.

RECORDED DATA/TAPE FORMAT
Typically LSN, SSN, SPD (cable speed), CN, TEN (differential cable tension), and TTEN (total cable
tension) are recorded on tape.  LSN and SSN are mandatory, but CN, CNC or CNCF may be played
back to film as required, so they may or may not be recorded.
If the "MERGE" capability of FSYS is used, the CN and/or CNC curve(s) will be copied from the
"BASE TAPE" to the "MERGE TAPE".
All CN data is recorded using the BIT tape format (refer to Atlas Tape Format Manual).  All pertinent
information about the instrument calibration, log display, well data and variable parameters are saved in

1
CALIBRATION TAIL          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
INTRODUCTION
The primary calibration for Compensated Neutron (CN) instruments is made in the district calibration
area using a 2437 XB CN calibrator to accurately represent a pre-defined porosity value.
The district calibrator is matched to the Atlas Master Calibrator, located in Houston, which is
referenced to the industry standard, the API test pit at the University of Houston.
PRIMARY CALIBRATION
During the calibration, the response of the long spaced and short spaced detectors to the 2437 XB 
calibrator are recorded.  The ratio of these responses is then calibrated to achieve the porosity value that
the calibrator represents.
PRIMARY VERIFICATION
After an instrument has been calibrated, its response to a field verification standard (either an "ice
block" or a single-point verification jig) is recorded (again in the district calibration area) and the
porosity value the block or jig represents is calculated using the calibration data just obtained.  This
field verification standard will go with the instrument for subsequent verifications.
BEFORE LOG VERIFICATION
Shortly before running an instrument in the well, its response to the field verification standard is
obtained.  These results should match the Primary Verification within specified tolerances, and confirm
that no change has occurred during transportation to the wellsite.  This establishes a reference for
stability during logging.
AFTER LOG VERIFICATION
Shortly after completing logging, the instrument's response to the field verification standard is again
measured and recorded.  These results should match both the Primary Verification and the Before Log
Verification within specified tolerances, indicating that the instrument has remained stable during the
logging operation.
DESCRIPTION OF CN LOG CALIBRATION/VERIFICATION RECORD
1.
Calibration made in the district calibration area at the date and time indicated.
1a.
Response of the LS and SS detectors to the calibrator in counts/sec (no scalers).
1b.
Response of the LS and SS detectors to the calibrator in counts/sec after dead time correction.
Additive factor always set to 0.000 and multiplicative factor always set to 1.000 for CN count
rates.
1c.

CALIBRATION TAIL          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
1d.
The standard ratio for the porosity value represented by the calibrator.
1e.
Calibration factor (standard ratio/measured ratio).  The range for this value is 1.02 ± .05.
2.
Primary verification made with the verification jig in the district calibration area at the date and
time indicated, which should be immediately after the calibration (1).
2a.
Response of the LS and SS detectors to the field verification standard in counts/sec.
2b.
Response of the LS and SS detectors to the field verification standard in dead time corrected
counts/sec.
2c.
Count rate ratio from 2a.
2d.
Porosity value represented by the verification jig.
The primary verification determines the equivalent porosity of the individual block.
3.
The before log verification made at the wellsite with the same field verification standard as
used for the primary verification (2) at the date and time indicated.  This should be within 30
days of the calibration (1).
3a.
Response of the LS and SS detectors to the verification standard in counts/sec.
3b.
Response of the LS and SS detectors to the field verification standard in dead time corrected
counts/sec.
3c.
Count rate ratio from 3a.
3d.
Porosity value represented by the field verification jig.
4.
The after log verification made at the wellsite on the date and time indicated, with the same
field verification standard as used for the primary verification (2).  This should be done
immediately after the logging operation.
4a.
Response of the LS and SS detectors to the verification standard in counts/sec.
4b.
Response of the LS and SS detectors to the field verification standard in dead time corrected
counts/sec.
4c.
Count rate ratio from 4a.
4d.

CALIBRATION TAIL          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
MEASUREMENT TOLERANCES
The before log verification value must be within ±2 porosity units of the primary verification value.
The after log verification value must be within ±2 porosity units of the before log verification value.

GENERAL DESCRIPTION 1
1.0 GENERAL DESCRIPTION
(Ref. Dwg C150145-000)
The 2446 XA Compensated Neutron Instrument has two thermal-neutron detectors located at
different spacings from an Americium-Beryllium chemical neutron source.  For this discussion the
detectors will be referred to as SS (short spaced) and LS (long spaced), based on their relative
position in the tool.  The simplified block diagram (below) describes the main components of this
instrument.
Both detectors are Helium-3 ( He) proportional counters, which are sensitive primarily to thermal
3
neutrons.  The detectors, the analog and digital processing boards and the high voltage regulator
are located inside a thermal flask.  These neutron detectors require a positive high voltage bias
(+1150 Vdc), which is provided by a high voltage power supply module located in the upper
chassis.  When a neutron is detected, a pulse is generated.  The pulses for both the LS and SS
channels are amplified and discriminated (separated from noise) in the analog board.  Digital
counters in the processor board accumulate these pulses.  When the telemetry requests the data, the
information is sent to the surface via the WTS bus.
On the chassis outside the flask, an I/O board provides the interface between the processor and the
external WTS bus.  A power supply converts the AC power on the WTS bus to low voltage used in
the tool and also feeds the high voltage module with 24 volts DC.

Controller Board 5
2.0 DETECTOR ASSEMBLY
(Ref. Dwg. B163800-000)
The Dual He Detector Assembly includes the LS detector, the SS detector, mounting and shielding
3
hardware, the Neutron Pulse Processor board (which contains the analog circuits), the processor
board where all the digital processing is done, and the high voltage regulator.  This entire
assembly is located inside a thermal flask.  The flask also contains a stainless steel heatsink.  The
detector assembly is covered with an aluminum cover tube that helps to equalize the internal
temperature in addition to its mechanical function.

I/O Board (DWG B150116-100) 3.0 CHASSIS ASSEMBLY
(Ref. Dwgs. 150122-000, 150145-000)

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON

+1150 V
VREF
OUT
He3

The LS and SS detectors are high pressure ( He) proportional counters.  They are mounted on
3
the tool axis, and surrounded by different materials selected for their neutron related
properties.  The detectors themselves consist of a center electrode -- the anode -- mounted
inside a metal cylinder is pressurized with helium  gas.  The bias voltage (+1150 VDC) is
3
applied to the anode, with the metallic external cylinder (connected to common ground) acting
as a cathode.  A strong electric field is then created between the anode and cathode.
Thermal neutrons enter the detector and are captured by helium atoms, producing protons and
tritium particles.  As these positively charged particles pass neutral helium atoms, electrons
are stripped away creating primary ion pairs.  In the strong electric field, the electrons
accelerate rapidly toward the anode, and the positive helium atoms move to the cathode.  The
electrons collide with other neutral helium atoms to produce secondary ion pairs.  This
process repeats itself several times until an avalanche of electrons at the anode produces a
negative output pulse.  A quenching gas, typically CO , is added to keep the discharge under
2
control.
The output of the detector is a small electric charge, about 3 or 4 pico-Coulombs.  After
converting this charge to voltage and applying a large amount of amplification, a pulse is
obtained with a height characteristic of a detected neutron.  Although output pulses can also
be caused by gamma rays and thermal noise, that type of pulse is smaller than those caused by
thermal neutrons.  This difference allows the gamma ray pulses to be discriminated so that
only neutron pulses are counted.
The SS detector has an active dimension of 1 by 3 inches and is filled with 4 atmospheres of
He.  The LS detector is 1.75 by 8 inches long and filled to 6 atmospheres of pressure.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 11.7 SS OUT CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON

SS OUT

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
DISCRIMINATOR AND BIAS CIRCUITS
The U1 amplifier is followed by two conventional voltage amplifiers with a total gain of about
1800 times.  At this point the neutron peak of the resultant spectrum (main band seen in an
adequate analog oscilloscope) should be 3 V.  Resistor R10 is selected to obtain this output,
which should remain constant over time.  A rapid change will indicate a need for
troubleshooting and repair.
Because this tool does not have a split power supply, the op-amps are referenced to a voltage
(V ) that is about half the supply voltage.  Capacitor C5 helps keep noise levels low.
ref
2.3 NEUTRON PULSE PROCESSOR BOARD - Discriminator Circuit
(Ref. Dwg. B142258-100)
The discriminator circuit takes the pulses produced in the preamplifier section, corrects the
reference base line, detects any pulse larger than a threshold, and shapes the output that is
then sent to the controller board.  The simplified circuit shown below is used to descibe
primary components and functions.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
chunk_text:
5
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
The pulses produced in the preamplifier section (nominal 3 V peak) are of a single polarity.
Such unipolar pulses will produce a shift in the base line when coupled through a capacitor
that is proportional to the average area of the pulses, i.e. more shift at higher count rates.
This problem is significant because of the high count rates obtained with this instrument
(particularly in low-porosity, small-hole situations), and the relatively low discriminator level.
The circuit formed by C16, R21, R22, D3, and D4 acts as a simple base line restorer,
returning a value similar to the reference voltage V .  This V  voltage is generated by Zener
ref
ref
diode Z1 and filtered by C28.
The pulses present on R28 are compared in the U3 voltage comparator against a threshold
voltage (V
) set by the R40-R43 voltage divider, which divides the voltage regulated by the
disc
reference diode Z2 (very stable).  The R29-R27 net forms a positive feedback loop to avoid
multiple triggering.  The digital pulses generated on R30 are of different length, depending on
their amplitude above the threshold.  Monostable U4 is then added to conform with the
minimum timing requirements of the controller board microcontroller, with R31-C23
determining the period, and R32 used only for protection.  Note than in this instrument there
is no provision for direct line transmission, so scalers are not used.
The power supply section is shown in the lower section of the schematic.  It is
straightforward, with the only distinction being that two different grounds are shown,
connected by a jumper.  The digital circuits put high currents on the ground return path, and
their ground (DGND) was kept separated from the analog ground (GND) used in the high gain
preamplifiers to avoid noise problems.

(Ref. Dwg. B150118-100)
The operation of the board is controlled by microcontroller IC5.  All command executions,
data acquisitions, and data transmissions are controlled by IC5.  The controller can be
operated at 8 or 16 MHz.  This tool uses the 8 MHz jumper.  The power up reset is generated
by IC3 using timing components R1, C10, and R2, C11.  Resistors R5 and R6 protect IC3.  In
this tool, the controller board provides the following 5 functions:
1)
WTS T2 MODE COMMUNICATIONS (in conjunction with the I/O board)
Command Reception
Unipolar Data Input (UDI Pin 5 J1) are the Manchester encoded commands from the
instrument bus.  The commands for all tools in the string will be present.  This signal is
buffered by one gate of IC1 and then input to IC4 pin 8 to be decoded.  The decoded
command (IC4 Pin 4) is sent to IC5 to be processed.  If the command is not for the 2446, the
decoding process is halted; and IC4 is reset to accept the next command.  If the command is
for the 2446, the decoding process continues to completion.  IC5 verifies that this is a valid
command word by testing the level of Command/Data Sync (IC4 pin 10) and by looking for a
Valid word (IC4 pin 1).  The reception process is interrupt driven.  The interrupt is generated
by nanding Take data (IC4 pin 3) and the decoder shift clock (IC4 pin 9) using one gate of
IC7.  The decoder clock (IC4 pin 5) is a 500 KHz square wave from IC6.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
chunk_text:
6
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
Data Transmission
Transmission begins when encoder enable (IC4 pin 19) is set.  The data to be transmitted is
presented on serial data input (IC4 pin 18).  The data is then encoded in bipolar Manchester
format, buffered by two gates of IC1, and put on pins 3 and 4 of J1.  The transmission process
is interrupt driven.  The interrupt is generated by nanding shift data (IC4 pin 21) and the
encoder shift clock (IC4 pin 2).  The encoder clock (IC4 pin 23) is a 250 khz square wave
from IC6.
2)
VOLTAGE MONITORS -
Monitor flask temperature and the 24 VDC instrument
supply.
Flask Temperature
The +5 (J1 pin 13) and Ground (J1 pin 12) supply the power for a temperature sensor
mounted on the chassis.  A voltage of 10 mV per degree F is produced by the sensor.  This
voltage is connected to J1 pin 10.  The voltage is then applied to one input (IC2 pin 2) of the
A/D converter.
24 VDC Power Supply
The 24 VDC power supply used by the flask electronics is connected to J1 pin 11.  The
voltage is divided by 10 using R3 and R4.  The attenuated voltage is applied to the second
input (IC2 pin 3) of the A/D converter.  This results in a full-scale input voltage of +50 VDC
at J1 pin 11.
3)
FREQUENCY COUNTERS - Count pulses from the long and short space detectors
The long-space pulses are applied to J1 Pin 2, buffered by one gate of IC1, and input to IC5
pin 15.  The short-space pulses are applied to J1 pin 1, buffered by one gate of IC1, and input
to IC5 on pin 14.  The pulses from both channels are counted up to a maximum of 65,535.
The counters are read, buffered using IC5 internal RAM, and reset when data is requested
from the tool.
4)
TWO BUFFERED OUTPUTS - J1 pins 8 and 9 not used for this design.
5)

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
chunk_text:
7
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
POWER SUPPLY

This assembly obtains AC power from the instrument bus and converts it into DC power for
the tool.  The outputs are +5 VDC for the logic circuit, +24 VDC for the analog circuits,
and +1150 VDC (the high voltage necessary for detector operation).
The primary winding of the power transformer is connected to conductors 1 and 4 of the WTS
instrument bus.  These two conductors provide AC power at a nominal voltage of 180 VAC
RMS.  There are three secondary windings.  The first winding is rectified by bridge D6 and
filtered by capacitor C6.  The unregulated voltage on C6 is then regulated to +5 VDC by
series voltage regulator IC1 and filtered by C5.  Diode D1 protects IC1 against reverse
voltage on power down conditions.
The output from the second winding is rectified by D5 and filtered by C3.  This unregulated
voltage is then regulated by parallel regulator R2-D3 to 24 VDC with C4 as a filter.  This
+24 volt output is used to power the analog circuits of the tool.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 3.2 HIGH VOLTAGE POWER SUPPLY
chunk_text:
The circuit connected to the third winding (D4, C1, R1, D2, and C2) follows the previous
description, but this 24 VDC supply is used to power the high voltage supply.  This module
produces a high voltage output controlled by the value of resistor R3.  The output is filtered
by the pi-filter comprised of C8, R4, and C7.  Resistor R6 functions as a voltage bleeder
resistor.  The voltage on C8 (nominal 1350 VDC) is the output regulated voltage of the high
voltage supply.  The voltage on C7 (nominal 1150 VDC) is determined by a parallel corona
regulator in the flask assembly.  The regulating current for the regulator in the flask assembly
is set by the value of R4.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 3.3 I/O BOARD (REFER TO DWG B150116-100)
chunk_text:
This board is the interface between the WTS instrument bus and the tool electronics.  The
WTS bus and the circuit design of this board are the company standard (059448-926).  The
only additional components are for decoupling capacitors and two gates for multiple T5 mode
transmissions.  The schematic indicates three separate circuits providing the following
functions:
1.
M2 Command Reception (T2)
2.
M2 Data Transmission (T2)
3.
M5 Data Transmission (T5)
M2 Command Reception
This section converts Manchester encoded signals on the WTS instrument bus (the command
channel) into a ground-referenced, Manchester encoded, unipolar, serial data stream that can
be analyzed by the tool.  The tool will analyze this data stream to determine if a valid tool
specific command has been received.  The WTS command bus is input to the board on P1 pin
18 and 19.  The signal is transformer coupled to a resistive network for termination and
voltage biasing.  The signal across R6, R7, and R8 is applied to a differential input of IC3
(Pin 1 and 3).  With no signal present, IC3 Pin 1 will be slightly more positive than IC3 pin 3
causing the output of IC3 (pin 6) to be low.  When a signal is present on the command bus,
the output of IC3 (pin 6) should produce pulses of approximately 5 volts.
M2 Data Transmission
This section puts Manchester encoded data from the tool onto the WTS instrument bus (mode
2 channel).  A biphase Manchester encoded signal produced by the tool is applied to pins 5
and 4 of P1.  This signal causes IC2 to alternately draw current through one half of the
primary winding in output transformer T102.  The resistors and diodes in each driver channel
control current flow.  The signal produced at the secondary is connected to the WTS
instrument bus (mode 2 channel) through pins 1 and 20 of P1.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 1.2 REFERENCE DRAWINGS NEEDED DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURE
chunk_text:
a.
R-164444-000 Instrument Assembly
b.
C-146872-000 Top Sub Assembly
c.
R-150128-000 Source Shield Assembly
d.
D-164447-000 Package Electronics W/Flask 2
DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURE
NOTE
Preparations include washing the unit to remove mud,
grease, dirt, and other foreign material if the unit has been
run in a well. Blow dry with compressed air or dry the unit
off with clean rags or paper towels. Each step of the
disassembly will include cleaning as required.
2.1 HOUSING & SUBS
(Reference Drawing R-164444-000)
a. Place the 2446 XA CN in a vise and tighten the vise on the pressure housing (item 4).
b. Remove the top thread protector (item 9) from the top sub.
c. Remove the bottom thread protector (item 7) from the bottom sub.
2
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
NOTE
Normal preventive maintenance for the Airborne
connectors consists of degreasing and drying the
contacts and body using a Sure Shot sprayer, P/N
222638, and solvent such as Freon, P/N 230271.
Then blow dry with compressed air.
c.
Remove the top sub (item 1) from the pressure housing.
d.
Pull the electronics section from the pressure housing using the T-handle tool. Inspect the
connectors at both ends of the electronics; and, if necessary, clean and dry the contacts.
NOTE
At this time, the electronics may be checked out.
Refer to the Repair/Maintenance Procedures.
2.4 BULKHEAD & SOURCE SUB
a.
Remove the retaining ring (item 30) from the source shield (item 2) using the modified
pliers. Take care not to damage or scar the surface finish inside the bore of the source
shield.
b.
Pull the bulkhead (item 29) from the source shield. This will require using the pulling
tool, P/N 150208. Screw the pulling tool into the center hole of the bulkhead, and gently
knock with the slide hammer to pull the bulkhead.
NOTE
Support the pulling tool to preclude breaking off the
1/4-20 threaded stud and to prevent damaging the
threaded hole in the bulkhead. Use care when pulling
the bulkhead, so the pins do not get bent or the glass
seals damaged. Remove the pulling tool from the
bulkhead.
c.
Remove the short housing extension (item 37) from the source shield.
d.
Remove the source shield (item 2) from the pressure housing (item 4).

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 2.2 REMOVING THE AIRBORNE CONNECTOR
chunk_text:
(Reference Drawing C-146872)
a.
Pry the retaining ring (item 8) from the top sub using a small screw driver. Pull the
Airborne connector (item 7) from the top sub using the T-handle tool.
b.
Disconnect the Airborne connector from the pigtail of the electronics section. At this
time, check the Airborne connector (item 7) for electrical insulation and continuity using
the multimeter.

DETAILED ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS - DETECTOR ELECTRONICS
(Reference Drawing R163800-000)

1.
Carefully buff the anode (center electrode) of the SS detector (item 16) with very fine
emory cloth to help facilitate soldering.  Use the emory cloth only to provide a good
soldering surface; excess buffing can ruin the detector.
2.
Insert the SS detector into the SS moderator tube (item 15).  Use Kapton tape (item 45)
to ensure snug fit (if needed).
3.
Install the SS detector/moderator assembly into the SS detector housing (item 14).
Ensure proper alignment of the SS detector to the SS detector housing.  Mount the SS
detector/moderator to the detector housing using 4-40 binder head screws (item 11) and
associated hardware (items 27 and 48).
4.
Install O-rings (items 18 and 19) into the lower SS mount (item 17).  Lightly lubricate O-
rings with DC-4 lubricant or equivalent.
5.
Attach lower SS mount on the SS detector housing.  Ensure proper alignment of the
lower SS mount to the SS detector housing.  Secure using 4-40 flat head screws (item
21).
6.
Install the moderator plate (item 20) on the lower SS mount using 4-40 binder head
screws (item 47).
7.
Strip approximately 3" of insulation from the shielded cable (item 29) and insert the
cable through the hole of ground lug (item 48).  Solder the ground of the shielded cable
to the ground lug and carefully solder the center wire to the anode of the SS detector.
Total length of the shielded cable should be approximately 16".

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON 4.2 LS DETECTOR ASSEMBLY
chunk_text:
5
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON 4.2 LS DETECTOR ASSEMBLY
1.
Carefully buff the anode (center electrode) of the LS detector (item 10) with very fine
emory cloth to help facilitate soldering.  Use the emory cloth only to provide a good
soldering surface; excess buffing can ruin the detector.
2.
Install an O-ring (item 12) into the LS detector housing (item 8).  Lightly lubricate with
DC-4 lubricant or equivalent.
3.
Lightly lubricate (using DC-4 or equivalent) the LS detector and install it in the LS
detector housing.  Ensure proper alignment of the LS detector with the LS detector
housing.  Use 4-40 binder head screws (item 11) and associated hardware (items 27 and
48) to secure the LS detector to the LS detector housing.
4.
Carefully solder Gore HV wire (P/N 221995) to the anode of the LS detector.  A 3"
length should suffice.  Solder a 3" black wire  (P/N 205961) to the solder lug on the LS
detector housing.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 4.3 SS DETECTOR TO LS DETECTOR ASSEMBLY
chunk_text:
1.
Install the moderator block (item 13) into the lower end of the LS detector housing.
2.
Carefully feed the SS detector cable through the hole on the LS detector housing and
slide the SS detector assembly into the end of the LS detector assembly.  Secure with 4-
40 flat head screws (item 6).

1.
Mount component clip (item 36) using 2-56 binder head screws (item 37).  Wrap the
corona regulator tube (VR01-221999) with Kapton tape and carefully insert it into the
component clip.  Carefully guide the transistor pad (item 39) onto the leads of the corona
regulator tube.
2.
RTV (item 43) the component cradle (item 38) onto the detector electronic chassis.  RTV
C1 (C01-238133) into the component cradle.
3.
Install terminals (items 33 and 34) with associated hardware (item 40) on the electronic
chassis and mount R1 (R1226988) as shown on drawing.
4.
Mount 2446 neutron pulse processor card to the detector electronic chassis using 4-40
binder head screws (item 25) and associated hardware (items 26, 27, and 28).

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
chunk_text:
6
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
5.
Mount the microcontroller card (item 24) to the electronic chassis using 4-40 binder head
screws along with fillister head screws (item 35) and associated hardware.
6.
Wire the electronic chassis assembly according to drawing 158501.  When wiring the
Airborne connector (item 31), leave enough slack in the wires to allow removal of the
connector when the microcontroller card is lifted from the electronic chassis.  Allow
approximately 16" in length from the end of the electronic chassis for wires that will
connect to P2 (item 22).  Leave the three wires for temp sensor IC-1 (IC01-244096) open

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 4.5 HEAT SINK TO ELECTRONICS CHASSIS ASSEMBLY
chunk_text:
1.
Carefully guide the wires from the electronic chassis assembly through the wire tube on
the heat sink assembly (item 4).  Mount the heat sink assembly to the electronic chassis.
2.
Solder the L.M. 23 CAH 11 temperature sensor (IC01-244096) into the modified solder
lug (item 41) and mount it to the electronic chassis assembly using 4-40 binder head
screw (item 46) and associated hardware (item 27).  Wire according to drawing 158501.
3.
Wrap the wires extending from the heat sink assembly with approximately 33" of felt
insulation (item 2), and install the thermal isolator sleeve (item 1) over the felt insulation.
Attach the thermal isolator sleeve to the heat sink assembly using 6-32 flat head screws
(item 3).
4.
Solder the wires extending from the thermal isolator assembly to P2.  Allow
approximately 5" for the wires extending from the thermal isolator assembly to P2.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 4.6 DETECTOR ASSEMBLY TO ELECTRONIC CHASSIS ASSEMBLY
chunk_text:
1.
Carefully guide the wires from the LS detector through the large opening on the
electronic chassis assembly.  Orient the detector assembly to allow alignment of the wire
groove on the detector assembly to the chamfer on the electronic chassis assembly.
Attach the detector assembly to the electronic chassis assembly with 6-32 binder head
screws (item 7) and associated hardware (item 30).
2.
Solder the detector assembly to the electronic chassis assembly as shown on drawing
158501.  Try to keep the wires from the detector assembly to the electronic chassis as
short as reasonably possible.

topic: Installation/Removal Procedures - INSTALLATION/REMOVAL PROCEDURES          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON 1.0 SOURCE INSTALLATION AT JOB SITE
chunk_text:
1
INSTALLATION/REMOVAL PROCEDURES          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON 1.0  SOURCE INSTALLATION AT JOB SITE
WARNING
ALL WORKERS TO BE INVOLVED IN THE INSTALLATION OF THE
NEUTRON SOURCE, AND FURTHER OPERATION OF THE SYSTEM,
SHOULD ENSURE THEIR FULL FAMILIARITY AND CONFORMITY
WITH THE REGULATIONS AND GUIDELINES THAT ARE
PUBLISHED IN THE WELLSITE USAGE SECTION (BEHIND THE
IONISING RADIATION SAFETY TAB) IN THE AWS SAFETY
MANUAL.
WARNING
BEFORE BEGINNING SOURCE INSTALLATION NEAR THE
WELL BORE, INSTALL A SOURCE CATCHER.
1.
Place source carrier 85455 (or 238179) and handling tools 91240 and 92924 in designated area
for source installation/removal.
2.
Position carrier so that when using handling tool 91240 (with arms fully extended), there is a
clear path that allows unobstructed movement between the carrier and the instrument side
door.
NOTE
It is the responsibility of the individual installing the source to
thoroughly understand the mechanical operation of the instrument side
door prior to source installation.
3.
Verify the following prior to installing source:
a.
Path of handling tool (with arms fully extended) from source carrier to instrument can
be made in one fluid movement.
b.
Instrument is positioned for ease of access to side door.
c.
Side door mechanism functions properly.
d.
Source cavity is clean and free of any obstructions.
WARNING
PERFORM THE FOLLOWING STEPS QUICKLY WITHOUT
COMPROMISING SAFETY.  REMEMBER:  TO MINIMIZE
EXPOSURE, MINIMIZE TIME AND MAXIMIZE DISTANCE AND
SHIELDING.

topic: Installation/Removal Procedures - INSTALLATION/REMOVAL PROCEDURES          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
chunk_text:
2
INSTALLATION/REMOVAL PROCEDURES          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON
SOURCE INSTALLATION/REMOVAL (Cont'd)
4.
Screw handling tool 91240 (with arms fully extended) onto source.  Then unscrew and
remove source from source carrier.  Make sure handling tool is securely attached to source.
5.
Install source into instrument side door.  Verify source is properly positioned and door is fully
closed.  With side door tool 92924, tighten both shear screws to secure side door in closed
position.  Check  integrity of all hardware on side door mechanisms.  Check that shear screws
are properly tightened.
6.
If removing source, first loosen the two shear screws in the instrument side door, using the
hex end of side door tool B92924.
7.
If instrument is in horizontal position, rotate instrument so that side door faces sideways.
With side door tool on shoulder screw, pull source door fully open.  If door is stuck, push
crossbar of tool through instrument hole opposite side door and force door open.
NOTE
If tool is in vertical position, a second person must hold side
door open placing crossbar of 92924 tool under door.  This
person should stand on side of tool opposite side door.
8.
With arms fully extended, screw source handling tool 91240 onto end of source.  Unscrew
source from tool and pull from recess in door.  Quickly place source in carrier and secure.
9.
Lock the source carrier and return it to proper storage or to a secure, readily accessible
location (as appropriate).

topic: Installation/Removal Procedures - INSTALLATION/REMOVAL PROCEDURES          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON 2.0 SOURCE REMOVAL AT JOB SITE
chunk_text:
3
INSTALLATION/REMOVAL PROCEDURES          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON 2.0  SOURCE REMOVAL AT JOB SITE
1.
Ensure that the source can be safely returned to its storage unit.
NOTE
If two workers are present, one should be ready to push the
instrument from the cablehead end, while the other takes
the side door tool (P/N B92924) and source handling tool
(P/N B91240) to a position where there will be access to the
source door set screws with effective shielding provided by
the bulk of the chamber.  Viewed from the "cablehead
end", this position is normally to the right hand side of the
chamber for Atlas CN instruments.
2.
Loosen the lower source-door set screw (closest to the bull plug) just enough to let the source
door swing open.
3.
Once the door swings open, tighten the set screw about two turns to prevent the door from
closing.
4.
Remove the source with the source handling tool, and return it to the designated storage unit.
5.
Loosen the lower set screw again, so that the source door closes, and then re-tighten both set
screws to lock it.  The instrument can now be moved.

topic: Installation/Removal Procedures - INSTALLATION/REMOVAL PROCEDURES          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON 3.0 SOURCE INSTALLATION AT CALIBRATOR
chunk_text:
4
INSTALLATION/REMOVAL PROCEDURES          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON 3.0  SOURCE INSTALLATION AT CALIBRATOR
WARNING
TO REDUCE PERSONAL RADIATION EXPOSURE,
THE WORKER CONTROLLING THE SIDE DOOR
TOOL SHOULD TAKE MAXIMUM ADVANTAGE OF
THE NEUTRON SHIELDING PROVIDED BY THE
LIQUID CONTENT OF THE CHAMBER.  ALL
WORKERS TO BE INVOLVED IN THE
INSTALLATION OF THE NEUTRON SOURCE, AND
FURTHER OPERATION OF THE SYSTEM, SHOULD
ENSURE THEIR FULL FAMILIARITY AND
CONFORMITY WITH THE REGULATIONS AND
GUIDELINES THAT ARE PUBLISHED IN THE
WELLSITE USAGE SECTION (BEHIND THE
IONISING RADIATION SAFETY TAB) IN THE AWS
SAFETY MANUAL.
1.
Insert the source directly into the propped-open source door with the source handling tool,
tighten it securely, and withdraw the handling tool.
2.
Move to the side of the chamber where the source door set screws are readily accessible.
3.
Loosen the set screw just enough so that the source door swings shut (aided, if necessary, by a
downward tap with the source handling tool).  Immediately re-tighten the set screw, withdraw
the side door tool, and move towards the cablehead end of the instrument.
4.
From the cablehead end, pull the instrument to bring the source sub into the central tube with
enough clearance beyond the bull plug to leave room for the plastic shielding plug to be
reinstalled.
NOTE
Verify that the instrument still rests securely on the two
edges of the bore groove, to prevent skewing.
5.
Reinstall the plastic shielding and plug by sliding it into the tube with its handle vertical until
the handle contacts the end of the tube.  Align the holes, and lock it into position with the eye-
pin.
6.
From the cablehead end, push the instrument, without rotating it, until it bears against the V-
groove in the plastic plug.  This is the operating position.
7.
Power the instrument with 180 Vac CHV, and verify that the count rates are acceptable.

topic: Installation/Removal Procedures - INSTALLATION/REMOVAL PROCEDURES          2446XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON 4.0 SOURCE REMOVAL AT CALIBRATOR
chunk_text:
5
INSTALLATION/REMOVAL PROCEDURES          2446 XA WTS COMPENSATED NEUTRON 4.0  SOURCE REMOVAL AT CALIBRATOR
1.
Turn the instrument power off.
2.
From the cablehead end, rotate the instrument 180  degrees so the source door faces down.
3.
Ensure that the source can be safely returned to its storage unit.
NOTE
If two workers are present, one should be ready to push the
instrument from the cablehead end, while the other takes
the side door tool (P/N B92924) and source handling tool
(P/N B91240) to a position where there will be access to the
source door set screws with effective shielding provided by
the bulk of the chamber.  Viewed from the "cablehead
end", this position is normally to the right hand side of the
chamber for Atlas CN instruments.
4.
From the source end, unlock and withdraw the plastic shielding and position control plug
assembly.
5.
From the cablehead end, push the instrument just enough for the whole length of the source
door to protrude out of the other end of the central tube, ensuring that the source door still
faces down.
6.
From a well shielded position, control the side door tool to loosen the lower set screw (closest
to the bull plug) just enough to let the source door swing open.
7.
Once the door swings open, tighten the set screw about two turns to prevent the door from
closing.
8.
Withdraw the side door tool.  From the cablehead end, rotate the instrument so the source
door faces up, and is propped open by the set screw.
NOTE
Ensure that the instrument is stable in this position.  If it is
not, one worker must support it at the cablehead while the
other removes the source.
9.
Remove the source with the source handling tool, and return it to the designated storage unit.
10. Loosen the lower set screw again, so that the source door closes, and then re-tighten both set
screws to lock it.  The instrument can now be removed from the calibrator.

1. EQUIPMENT REQUIRED
Refer to the service master list in SAP(component -840) for the required tools and test
equipment needed to service the instrument.
2. DC VOLTAGE CHECK

1.
Place the electronics assembly in a laboratory cradle.
2.
Connect a test system (CLS, WTS1 PC, etc..) to the electronics assembly.
3.
Apply 180 Vac to conductors 1 & 4.  Current should be 60 ± 6 mA.

be 5.0± 0.1 VDC.

3. SIGNAL CHECK - NEUTRON PULSE PROCESSOR

The high gain of the amplifier circuits makes the 2446 XA sensitive to noise, particularly
induced line frequency noise and cross talk between channels. Proper grounding will
reduce the noise. A metal work bench connected to common ground is recommended.

4. DISCRIMINATOR ADJUSTMENT


Note
The checkout procedures in Sections 3.0 through 3.5  should be
made before adjusting the discriminator.

1.
Disassemble the instrument.  Refer to Section 955.
2.
Place the electronics assembly in a calibration cradle.
3.
Connect a test system to the electronics assembly.
4.
Apply 180 Vac to the electronics.  Current should be 60 ± 6 mA.



Note
Discriminator adjustments should not be necessary.  The gain and
discriminator settings influence instrument dead time.  Dead time
is fixed in software; therefore, the gain and discriminator levels
should be constant.  If a discriminator curve is required for trouble
shooting purposes, R43 must be removed and a decade box
connected in its place.

Record the count rate at each Voltage setting.
6.
Continue until only a few pulses are detected.

5. FINAL CHECK
This test reveals the relative sensitivity of both detectors and verifies that there is no
cross talk between the SS and LS channels.

1.
Reassemble the tool and position it a minimum of 2' above ground level, using a
tool dolly or sawhorses.
2.
Connect a test system and apply 180 Vac to the instrument.
3.
Place the A97712 lab source so that it is centered at a point 8 inches from the
bottom of the housing.  This is the approximate center of activity of the SS detector.
4.
Take a 200-second reading and record the results for both detectors.

6. DETECTOR CHECKOUT  (Optional)
(Ref. Dwgs. A142258-000 and C142258-100)

Perform this task if a problem is suspected in the 2446 XA detectors.  The following
procedure should indicate if the 3 He detector operating position has shifted.

1.
Disconnect the high-Voltage wire from terminal T1 (HV) on the neutron pulse
processor board.
2.
Connect an adjustable high-Voltage power supply to the HV terminal on the neutron
pulse processor board.
3.
Apply 180 Vac to the electronics on conductors 1 and 4.
4.
Place the neutron check source over the detector in question.
5.
Adjust the high-Voltage power supply down from 1100 Volts until relatively few
counts are noticed at the test system.
6.
Set the high-Voltage power supply to the next higher 25 Volt increment (i.e. 25, 50,
75, or 100).
7.
Take a 100 second reading (both high Voltage and counts) at this Voltage.
8.
Record this reading (both high Voltage and counts).
9.
Turn the high-Voltage supply up 25 Volts.
10.
Repeat steps 6-9 until a large change in count rate is observed (from the rate in the
previous Voltage step).

OVERVIEW
Refer to the block diagram in Figure 1. The 2809 XA Focus Noise/Temperature instrument is
part of the Focus instrument string. The Focus Noise/Temperature instrument detects gas
entry in air filled boreholes using acoustic and temperature measurements. The acoustic
portion of the tool consists of two transducer arrays spaced approximately 42-inches apart.
These transducer arrays along with the electronics are capable of detecting gas entry in the 20
kHz to 60 kHz ultrasonic range. In addition, the acoustic portion is capable of detecting gas
entry in fluid filled boreholes in the 100 Hz to 20 kHz range. The temperature portion of the
instrument consists of four RTD elements, each 90˚ from the next and connected serially to
provide greater circumferential sensitivity. The four RTDs are located near the bottom of the
instrument.

ELECTRONICS
The Focus Noise/Temperature electronics chassis is located between the two acoustic
transducer arrays. The Focus Noise/Temperature electronics is MIB compatible and
simultaneously acquires two acoustic waveforms from the two transducer arrays and one
temperature measurement from the four RTDs. The electronics are responsible for
selecting mode of acquisition, gain control, down-hole digitization, digital DSP filtering
as required, and FFT of waveform data as required. The chassis is extruded aluminum,
which is standard for Focus instruments.
The electronics main components are:
•
±5 Vdc Analog Power Supply Brick, EMI Filter Brick, and Filter PCB Assembly
•
+3.3 Vdc Power Supply Brick, and Filter PCB Assembly
•
Data Acquisition PCB which includes the following:
�
two 16-bit SAR A/Ds
�
one 24-bit Sigma Delta A/D with RTD current source
�
one 12-bit DAC
�
mode 2, 5, and 7 communications channels


130972-945 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
4
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Circuit Descriptions


130972-945 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
5
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

DC POWER SUPPLIES
The 2809 XA Noise / Temperature Electronics have two power supplies mounted on the electronics
backbone. Along with one of the supplies is an EMI filter module to drastically reduce interference
and interaction between supplies of other Focused Logging System instruments. These self-contained,
modular supplies mount on a heat-sinking channel and have additional circuitry mounted on a PC
board that is soldered directly to the pins of the supply. It is this additional circuitry that will be the
topic of discussion for this section.
Because the power supplies are modular, there is no repair of the unit. It either works or it doesn’t.
The only circuitry external to the module (U1) is some inhibiting control and some additional output
filtering.

SINGLE POWER SUPPLY
See the schematic (Figure 2) below for a typical configuration of these external
components for a single output power module.


The E7 terminal shown on the INHIBIT pin of U1 is used to delay the output for a
specific time after power is applied. Combinations of J1 through J4 shorted on the power
control PC board provide the various delays. Refer to the delay table located in the power
control circuit section for the actual settings for a given tool. The control circuit for
inhibit is located on the power control PC board, above the EMI filter.
Instrument power is defined as +28 V for the tool string. This cablehead voltage first
passes through an EMI filter module before being applied to a DC-to-DC converter
module; thus, the voltage at terminal E1 is a filtered +28 V. E2 is tied to the return line of
the EMI filter output. Pins 6, 7 and 8 are tied to chassis ground which, in turn, is tied to
cable armor. Two independent windings of choke, L1 filter voltage spikes on the output
of the converter module. Provision is made at J1 for trimming the output voltage under
expected loads. In most cases, this provision is left unused. Additional output filtering is
provided by capacitors C3, C4 and C5.
130972-945 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
6
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

DUAL POWER SUPPLY
In the case where a power supply module generates an output of dual polarity, the
associated circuitry is slightly modified. See the schematic (Figure 3) below.

The E9 terminal shown on the INHIBIT pin of U1 delays the output for a specific time
after power is applied. Combinations of J1 through J4 shorted on the power control PC
board provide the various delays. Refer to the delay table located in the power control
circuit section for the actual settings for a given tool. The control circuit for inhibit is
located on the power control PC board, above the EMI filter.
Again, instrument power first passes through an EMI filter module before being applied
to any DC-to-DC converter module; thus, the voltage at terminal E1 is a filtered +28 V.
Terminal E2 is tied to the return line of the EMI filter output. Pins 6, 7 and 8 are tied to
chassis ground, which is tied to cable armor. Three independent windings of choke L1
filter voltage spikes on the output of the module. No provision is made for trimming the
output voltage. Additional output filtering is provided by capacitors C3, C4, C5, C6 and
C7.
130972-945 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
7
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

Power Control Circuit: An EMI filter module is associated with at least one of the
DC-to-DC power supply modules. The PC board attached to this module performs
several control functions. These control functions are described below.
A +5 volt supply is generated for other chips on the PC board. The supply consists of a
single dropping resistor (R3) and reference Zener diode (D1) to establish the voltage.
This supply is connected to the output of the EMI filter module (U1). It is this +28 V EMI
filter output that connects to the input of other DC-to-DC converter modules within the
instrument. See the schematic (Figure 4) below.


Refer to schematic diagram of the Power Supply Control circuit on page 9. The heart of
the power control circuitry is a programmable microcontroller (U3). Values for resistor
R7 and capacitor C3 have been selected to give an operating frequency of approximately
1 MHz. Supplied with +5 volts from the supply of Figure 4, the microcontroller acts as a
timer to control the turn-on time of anything tied to its output. There are basically three
functions concerning this circuit. They are (1) a voltage threshold, (2) the delay circuit
and (3) the control/inhibit circuit.
(1)
A threshold voltage is established using chip U4. The voltage divider consisting of
R6 and R8 are chosen such that when 20 volts or more (for instrument power) is
present on R6, the reset chip removes the LOW on pin 7 which in turn removes the
reset from microcontroller U3, allowing it to do its job.
130972-945 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
8
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

(2)
Jumper inputs to the microcontroller chip U3 set different length delay times.
Delay times are established for different tools to limit the current demand when the
tool sting is first powered up. Delay times, in milliseconds, and their jumpers are
shown in the table below.

INSTRUMENT

(3)
Output RA1 of U3 pin 18 is floating (open collector circuit)when power is first
applied to the microcontroller. Resistor R4 pulls the base of Q1 HIGH turning it
ON. This state applies a ground potential to all power supplies tied to the Q1
collector. Diodes D2 – D4 form an OR function in the collector circuit that allows
control over different power supplies. By tying the INHIBIT pin (active low) of
each DC-to-DC converter module within an instrument to one of these control
terminals (E5, E6 or E7), you can independently control its ON/OFF function.
With Q1 initially turned ON, no power supply module can turn ON. It is not until
the time-out function is completed by U3 that output RA1 can transition LOW,
turning OFF Q1. With Q1 turned OFF, power supplies are allowed to turn ON
because their INHIBIT is removed. As the power supplies turn ON, their current
demand is confined to that particular instrument. Again, see the control circuit
(Figure 5) on page 9.

2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

Refer to drawing 198384-100 for the complete schematic of the Power Controller board.
As an added feature of this circuit, Power Supply #2 or Power Supply #3 can be turned
OFF by an external source via opto-isolator U2. Terminal E8 is tied to a positive voltage.
Taking control terminal E9 or E10 LOW causes its respective switch to close. This
applies a ground potential to the INHIBIT input of the supply that is tied to its control
terminal, E6 or E7. This LOW turns OFF the respective power supply. Terminal E9
controls a power supply (P.S.2) connected to terminal E6, while E10 controls a supply
(P.S.3) connected to terminal E7. Thus, independent control is available if needed. Power
supplies connected to E5 are solely controlled by the timing function associated with the
operation of transistor Q1. See the schematic (Figure 6) below.



DATA ACQUISITION / RECEIVER BOARD
The Data Acquisition Board (DAQ) board is mainly responsible for digitizing and processing
the receiver and RTD signals, and communicating to the surface system via the instrument
bus. The DAQ board, on command from the surface system, can send data on Mode 5 or
Mode 7. The DAQ board obtains power from the 3.3 V digital and ±5 V analog power
supplies. Additionally, the 3.3 V digital is boosted to 5 V digital for the modal drivers.
2. Digital-to-Analog Converter
3. Analog-to-Digital Converter
4. Clock and Reset Logic
5. Digital Signal Processor
6. Field-Programmable Gate Array
7. Modal Communication
8. Temperature Sensor

2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

DATA ACQUISITION / RECEIVER BOARD 10 

RECEIVER TEST CIRCUIT
Refer sheet 1 of schematic drawing A3000343 SCH and Figure 7 during this discussion.
The 2809 XA has two receiver crystals (Rx1 and Rx2) connected to the DAQ boards
instrumentation amplifiers U29 and U33 as differential inputs. The gain of the
instrumentation amplifier is given by G = (50500/RG) +1. Therefore, with a gain resistor
value of 10.0k-Ω, the gain of the instrumentation amplifier circuit is approximately 15.6
dB. This gain value was selected to optimize frequency response while providing high
common mode rejection. These two analog signals are multiplexed via U32. The
multiplexers output is controlled by M1 and M2, which are set by firmware via flag 10
(M1) and flag 11 (M2) on the DSP (U15). There are four possible modes selected by M1
and M2. Table 1 shows the M1 and M2 settings for each particular mode.



Flag 10 (M1)
Receiver Mode
0
0
Rx1 and Rx2 (Noise)
0

RECEIVER STAGES
Refer to Figure 7 and sheet 1 of schematic drawing A3000343 SCH during this
discussion.
The 2809 XA has two receiver transducer assemblies (Rx1 and Rx2) connected to the
DAQ boards amplifiers U4/U1 and U6/U2 to provide a gain of 100 V/V at 40kHz.  These
two analog signals are multiplexed by U5. The multiplexers output is controlled by M1
and M2 which are set by firmware via flag 10 (M1) and flag 11 (M2) on the DSP (U15).
There are four possible modes selected by M1 and M2. Table 1 shows M1 and M2
settings for each particular mode.
130972-945 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
12
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

3.2.1
Rx1 and Rx2 Mode
Noise mode passes Rx1 and Rx2 receiver signals through the multiplexers to the two
analog channels.
3.2.2
Test Signal
Refer to sheets 1 and 4 of schematic drawing A3000343 SCH during this discussion. The
test signal (TS) is a single step function delayed 1.0 ms after the rising edge of the test
fire pulse (TP53). The test signal and the test fire pulse are generated in the FPGA. The
test signal is level shifted from 3 volts to 5 volts by U36, divided down by R72 and R73,
and then passed through multiplexer U5 to both analog channels when M2 is high and
M1 is low. M2 and M1 are set in the firmware during initialization and the test signal is
used to verify the gain and band-pass filter response of the analog stages.
3.2.3
Ground Signal
The ground signal input to the multiplexer is provided so that the DC offset in the last
band-pass filter and gain stages can be software corrected on each transmitter firing when
needed.
3.2.4
Analog Gain/Filter
Referring to Channel One on A3000343 SCH. The noise transducer signals are amplified
by 100 V/V at 40kHz by U4 and U1. After the multiplexer U5, the signal is
amplified/attenuated by U39. The signal is than band-pass filtered at 40 kHz with a gain
of 6.5 V/V by the four stages of U9. The signal is then amplified/attenuated by U11. The
combined gain/attenuation of U39 and U11 is given in Table 2. The signal is then
amplified by 2 V/V above 100 Hz by U12.

topic: Circuit Description - 3.3 DIGITAL TO ANALOG CONVERTER (DAC) .....................................................14
chunk_text:
DIGITAL TO ANALOG CONVERTER (DAC)
The VCO amplifier’s gain is controlled by a 12-bit, 4-channel DAC (U11). Voltage from
U11 pins 7 (GAIN1) and pin 6 (GAIN2) are individually set by the firmware’s automatic
gain control (AGC) routine by writing four 16-bit words via a serial link that includes DT
(Data Transmit), DACCS/ (DAC Chip Select), TCLK (Transmit Clock), and LD/ (Load).
actual gain applied from U31 A and U31 B inputs to U28 A and U28 B outputs. Table 3
shows the DAC bit definitions.



JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
15
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

ANALOG-TO-DIGITAL CONVERTER
The DAQ board uses two 16-bit charge redistribution SAR A/D’s (U1 and U2) to digitize
signals from both analog channels. Both A/Ds start sampling simultaneously at the
leading edge of a sync pulse (i.e. the Sync Pulse or the Test Sync Pulse) and sample at the
same rate. Refer to Figure 9 for timing. The A/D’s can be set to digitize at 4 µs, 8 µs, 16
µs, 24 µs, or 72 µs sampling rates. The convert signal that initiates sampling is generated
from the Field-Programmable Gate Array (U20) at the specified sampling rate. The Field-
Programmable Gate Array generates a discontinuous serial clock exactly 2-µs after the
convert signal to clock out the digitized data.
As mentioned earlier, each A/D services an analog channel. Each A/D shifts data to a
serial channel of the Digital Signal Processor (U15). A/D channel 1 is connected to one
port of the Digital Signal Processor’s serial channel 0. Similarly, A/D channel 2 is wired
to the other port of the Digital Signal Processor’s serial channel 0.
The A/D is setup as a Slave Serial Device on the DAQ board. As the read and chip-select
signals on the A/Ds are made permanently active, the serial clock causes the data to
serially shift out of the A/Ds. The serial clock becomes inactive after all 16 bits are
shifted out. The serial clock frequency is 12 MHz.
The data shifted out is in 2s complement format, with the most significant bit first.



CLOCK AND RESET LOGIC
The DAQ board has one 24 MHz master clock (U14). The Digital Signal Processor (U15)
and the Field-Programmable Gate Array (U20) use this 24-MHz clock for all their timing
needs.
The DAQ board has an additional 10-MHz clock that is used by the RTD A/D (U17).
The DAQ board is held in reset when the voltage-monitoring pin MR/ on reset chip U26
is less than or equal to 2.96 V. Pressing the S1 button can also reset the board.


130972-945 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
16
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

CLOCK AND RESET LOGIC15 

DIGITAL SIGNAL PROCESSOR
The DAQ board’s Digital Signal Processor (DSP) is responsible for receiving and
responding to surface commands. Together with the Field-Programmable Gate Array, the
DSP controls the entire noise / temperature tool.
The DSP firmware is stored in a flash memory on the DAQ board. At power up the DSP
loads the program from this flash memory and then runs the program in its internal
program memory. Some internal memory and two external RAMs are used for data
memory space.
Some of the DSP sections are described in detail below.
Clock: The DSP is provided with a 24-MHz clock that translates internally to a 42-MHz
instruction rate. Please refer to the data-sheet for timing diagrams and timing delays. For
timing calculation use the following value of the symbol DT (de-rating).
•
DT = (tCK-33.3)/32
•
CLKIN = 24 MHz
•
tCK = 1/24 MHz in ns
•
DT = (41.67-33.3)/32 = 0.26
Transmit Serial Port 0: The DSP uses this port to control the Digital-to-Analog
converter via the Field-Programmable Gate Array. The port is configured with the
following settings:
•
Transmit Serial Port A enabled
•
Most Significant Bit shifted out first
•
Data size 16 bits
•
Serial Clock Internal
•
Operation Mode Standard
•
Serial Clock Active Edge is Rising Edge
•
Sync Required
•
Sync Source Internal
•
Frame Sync Active Low
•
Frame Sync Mode Late
•
Serial Port Transmit Port A DMA Enabled
•
Transmit Serial Port B Disabled
•
Transmit Clock 250 kHz (TCLKDIV=0xbf)
•
Inactive Cycles between Transmit Frame Sync 16 (TFSDIV=0xE)

topic: Circuit Description - 3.7 FIELD PROGRAMMABLE GATE ARRAY (FPGA) U20.....................................19
chunk_text:
FIELD PROGRAMMABLE GATE ARRAY (FPGA) U20
3.7.1
Clock Generation
Refer to Figure 10 during this discussion.
U20 divides the 24-MHz clock signal (CLKIN) by two to produce a 12-MHz clock,
which all other clocks are derived from. U20 then divides the 12-MHz clock signal by 12,
24, 48, and 64 to provide:
1. A 12 MHz continuous serial clock (SCLK) for U15 synchronous serial received data
from the A/D’s.
2. A 12 MHz discontinuous serial clock (DSCLK) for A/D’s synchronous serial
transmission of data to the DSP (U15).
3. A 500-kHz clock for Mode 2 transmitter logic (U20 internal).
4. A 250-kHz clock signal for the Mode 2 receiver logic (U20 internal).
5. A 187.5-kHz clock for U20 transmitter logic (Mode 5 and Mode 7).
6. A 1-MHz clock signal for the temperature sensor (U22).
7. In addition, the 250-kHz clock is divided by 2 to provide a 125 kHz (8 µs) A/D
sample clock and TCLK0 from the DSP (U15) is routed into and out of the FPGA to
provide the DAC transmit clock.




130972-945 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
20
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

3.7.2
WTS Interface (Mode 2, Mode 5, and Mode 7)
Refer to Figure 11 during this discussion.
Mode 2 Receive Command / Data: Mode 2 commands / data are sent from the surface
and transformer-coupled via T1 on the DAQ board. U19 converts the line signals to TTL
levels. The equivalent of a 6408 Harris Manchester Encoder / Decoder has been
incorporated into Actel (U20). U20 decodes this Manchester protocol data (MD2 UDI)
and converts the serial data to parallel data. U20 checks the received data for a universal
address 00 or tool address 04. If either address is received, interrupt MD2 RXIRQ/
interrupts the DSP (U15) on IRQ1/ and the command is transferred to a buffer.
MD2 RXIRQ/ is reset by the FPGA after the command is read by the DSP. If data follows
the WTS command, interrupt MD2 RXIRQ/ interrupts the DSP and the data is transferred
to a buffer. MD2 RXIRQ is reset by the FPGA after each data word is read.
Mode 2 Transmit Data: On receipt of a command from the surface to transmit data via
Mode 2 (such as tool tables), the DSP enables interrupt IRQ0/ (MD2 TXIRQ) and sends
the requested data via the 16-bit data bus to the FPGA’s (U20) Mode 2 encoder logic.
U20 converts the data from parallel to serial format and the U20 6408 Harris Manchester
equivalent encoder, encodes MD2 BZO/ data and MD2 BOO/ data. Data is sent to line
driver (U21), and then is transformer coupled to the WTS buss via T2. Whenever the U20
data buffer is empty, U20 generates an interrupt (MD2 TXIRQ) that interrupts the DSP
and the DSP sends the next word.
Mode 5 and Mode 7 Transmit Data: The equivalent of two 6409 Harris Manchesters
have been incorporated into the FPGA (U20) for Mode 5 and Mode 7 data transmission.
Mode 5 or Mode 7 data is transmitted using interrupt IRQ2/ (MD5 IRQ/). MD57 SW (See
to the MAP command sent from the surface acquisition system.
Mode 5 Transmit Data: On receipt of a command from the surface to transmit Mode 5
data the DSP enables interrupt MD5 IRQ/ and writes the first word of the requested data
via the 16-bit data bus to the FPGA’s (U20) Mode 5 encoder logic. The data is converted
from parallel to serial format by U20. The U20 6409 Harris Manchester equivalent
encoder receives serial data and the encoded data (M5 BZO/ and M5 BOO/) is sent to line
driver U23. Mode 5 data is then transformer coupled to the WTS buss via T3. Whenever
the data buffer is empty, MD5 IRQ/ is active; and the DSP writes the next data word via
the 16-bit data bus to U20. When all words have been sent the DSP disables MD5 IRQ/.
Mode 7 Transmit Data: On receipt of a command from the surface to transmit Mode 7
data, the DSP enables interrupt MD5 IRQ/ and writes the first word of the requested data
via the 16-bit data bus to the FPGA’s (U20) Mode 7 encoder logic. The data is converted
from parallel to serial format by U20. The U20 6409 Harris Manchester equivalent
encoder receives serial data and the encoded data (M7 BZO/ and M7 BOO/) is sent to line
driver U52. Mode 7 data is then transformer coupled to the WTS buss via T4. Whenever
the data buffer is empty, MD5 IRQ/ is active; and the DSP writes the next data word via
the 16-bit data bus to U5. When all words have been sent the DSP disables MD5 IRQ/.

TEMPERATURE SENSOR (U22)

completely disassembled. This procedure disassembles the 2809 XA to the point where
