2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly 

DISASSEMBLY
Procedures are provided for nearly complete disassembly of the 2809 XA Focus Noise /
Temperature Instrument. The instrument will rarely need to be completely disassembled
under normal operating conditions.

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 4.1 BOTTOM CRYSTAL HOLDER SUB / LOWER HOUSING ......................................3
chunk_text:
BOTTOM CRYSTAL HOLDER SUB / LOWER HOUSING 3

BOTTOM CRYSTAL HOLDER SUB / LOWER HOUSING
Refer to assembly drawing A3000353000 and its BOM during disassembly of the bottom
crystal holder sub unless otherwise specified. Numbers in brackets [  ] are references to
this assembly drawing.
4.1.1
Remove Bottom Crystal Holder Sub / Lower Housing from
Instrument
____  1.
Use a spanner wrench to unscrew the non-field joint split collar [15] to
remove the bottom crystal holder sub assembly from the bottom of the
housing weldment [16]. Support the crystal holder sub while unscrewing the
split collar.
____  2.
Use a spanner wrench to unscrew the non-field joint split collar [15] to
remove the housing weldment [16] from the upper housing [29]. Slide the
housing weldment off the electronics assembly [17].
The 2809 XA is sufficiently disassembled at this point to troubleshoot, repair, or perform
routine and level 3 preventive maintenance on the electronics assembly.
4.1.2
Bottom Crystal Holder Sub / Lower Housing Disassembly
Typically, the bottom crystal holder sub assembly is disassembled to replace one or more
broken or defective temperature probes [22], or a defective transducer assembly [4].
____  1.
Place the bottom crystal holder sub assembly on a stable work surface.
____  2.
Unscrew the eight 8-32 X 0.25-inch flat-head machine screws [25] from the
two protector sleeves [5] and remove the two protector plates.
____  3.
Unplug and set aside the two mud cell jumpers [12].
____  4.
Thoroughly clean the recess area where the mud cell jumpers were removed
in the previous step.
____  5.
Unscrew the three 4-40 X 1.875-inch screws that secure the 45-pin female
connector [19] to the lower housing [20].
____  6.
Install the 1/4-20 T-handle weldment pulling tool [15, 181737-000] into the
center threads of the connector and carefully pull the 45-pin female
connector [19] out of the lower housing [20].
____  7.
Remove the three 0.60-inch pieces of 10 gauge Teflon tubing from the three
4-40 X 1.875-inch screws and then remove the screws. Do not discard the
Teflon tubing.
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
4
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

____  8.
Unscrew and remove the nut and washer [7 and 8, 181737-000] from the 45-
pin female connector [19].
____  9.
Separate the two halves of the 45-pin connector [19].
____  10.
Cut the wires connected to the 45-pin connector as close as possible to the
female contact sockets [3, 181737-000] and discard the sockets. Do not
discard the unused sockets.
____  11.
Use the temperature probe socket (199393-000) to unscrew and remove the
four temperature probes [22] from the bottom crystal holder sub [21].

Note: If disassembling the bottom crystal holder sub [21] to replace one or more defective
temperature probes [22], further disassembly is not necessary.

____  12.
Use a deep wall socket to unscrew the two pressure terminal assemblies [13]
from the lower housing [20]. Be careful not to crack or break the peek
material when unscrewing the pressure terminals.
____  13.
Pull the pressure terminal assemblies [13] out of the lower housing [20].
____  14.
Unscrew and remove the four 1/4-20 X 0.50-inch socket set screws [27] from
the lower housing [20].
____  15.
Unscrew the four 4-40 X 1.875-inch screws that secure the bottom Matrix
27-pin male connector [23] to the bottom crystal holder sub [21].
____  16.
Install the 10-32 T-handle pulling tool into the center threads of the
connector and carefully pull the Matrix 27-pin male connector [23] out of the
bottom crystal holder sub [21].
____  17.
Remove the four 0.60-inch pieces of 10 gauge Teflon tubing from the four
4-40 X 1.875-inch screws and then remove the screws. Do not discard the
Teflon tubing.
____  18.
Grip the wire bundle just above the Matrix 27-pin male connector [23] and
carefully pull the wire bundle, with connector attached, out the bottom of the
bottom crystal holder sub [21].

Note: Unless there is a broken wire(s) or damaged pin(s), it is not necessary to disassemble the
Matrix 27-pin connector [23] and wire bundle.

____  19.
Install the two halves of the support tool (A1001243000) (Figure 1) onto the
bottom sub [21] as shown in Figure 2. The pins of the support tool  are
inserted into the holes in the bottom sub. Screw in and tighten the two
socket-head screws supplied with the tool and lock the support tool in a vise
as shown in Figure 2.
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
5
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly






____  20.
Use the long-handled spanner wrench to break the lower housing [20] loose
from the bottom crystal holder sub [21] as shown in Figure 3. Considerable
force is needed to break the lower housing loose from the bottom crystal
holder sub. Finish unscrewing the lower housing from the bottom crystal
holder sub by hand.
____  21.
Slide the transducer assembly off the bottom crystal holder sub [21].
The bottom crystal holder sub assembly is sufficiently disassembled to perform all
necessary repair or maintenance work.
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
6
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly



TOP SUB / UPPER HOUSING
Refer to assembly drawing A3000353000 and its BOM during disassembly of the top sub
/ upper housing assembly unless otherwise specified. Numbers in brackets [  ] are
references on this assembly drawing.
4.2.1
Separate Top Sub / Upper Housing Assembly from Electronics
____  1.
Unscrew the eight 8-32 X 0.25-inch flat-head machine screws [25] from the
two protector sleeves [5] and remove the two protector sleeves.
____  2.
Unplug and set aside the two mud cell jumpers [12].
____  3.
Thoroughly clean the recess area where the mud cell jumpers were removed
in the previous step.
____  4.
Unscrew the four 4-40 X 2.00-inch screws that secure the top Matrix 27-pin
female connector [6] to the top sub [2].
____  5.
Install the 10-32 T-handle pulling tool into the center threads of the
connector and carefully pull the Matrix 27-pin female connector [6] out of
the top sub [2].
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
7
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

____  6.
Remove the four 0.60-inch pieces of 10 gauge Teflon tubing [9] from the
four 4-40 X 2.00-inch screws [8, 198100-000] and then remove the screws.
Do not discard the Teflon tubing.
____  7.
Unscrew and remove the hex lock nut and flat washer [5and 6, 198100-000]
from the bottom of the Matrix 27-pin female connector [6] and separate the
two halves of the connector.
____  8.
Cut the lacing cord that is closest to the connector.
____  9.
Cut the connector wires as close as possible to the connector sockets [3,
198100-000]. Discard the connector sockets. Do not discard unused
connector sockets.
____  10.
Unscrew and remove the four 8-32 X 0.875-inch socket-head cap screws [28]
that secure the upper housing [29] to the top of the electronics assembly [17].
____  11.
Separate the upper housing [29] from the electronics assembly [17] 2.0 to 3.0
inches.
____  12.
Cut the red and black pressure terminal [13] wires where they are spliced to
the two-wire shielded cable and carefully slide the top sub [2] / upper
housing [29] of the wire bundle.
4.2.2
Separate Top Sub from Upper Housing
____  1.
Unscrew and remove the four 1/4-20 X 0.50-inch socket set screws [27] from
the upper housing [29].
____  2.
Use a deep wall socket to unscrew the two pressure terminal assemblies [13]
from the upper housing [29]. Be careful not to crack or break the peek
material when unscrewing the pressure terminals.
____  3.
Pull the pressure terminal assemblies [13] out of the upper housing [29].
____  4.
Move the top sub [2] / upper housing [29] assembly to a bench vise. Install
the two halves of the support tool (A1001243000) as shown in Figure 1.
Engage the pins of the support tool in the holes in the upper housing [29] as
shown in Figure 2 and install the two socket head screws supplied with the
support tool.
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
8
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

____  5.
Lock the support tool and upper housing / top sub in a vise as shown in
upper housing [29] as shown in Figure 4. Considerable force is needed to
break the top sub loose from the upper housing. Finish unscrewing the top
sub from upper housing by hand.
____  7.
Slide the top sub [2] off the upper housing [29].



JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
9
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

4.2.3
Disassemble Transducer Assembly
Refer to Figure 5 and assembly drawing A3001257000 during disassembly of the
transducer assembly. The transducer assembly should rarely require complete
disassembly.

Note: Numbers in brackets [  ] correspond to the item numbers on the BOM for drawing
A3001257000.


____  1.
Place the transducer assembly in a pan or other container suitable for oil
recovery. Remove the two 5/16-24 plugs [6] and drain the oil out of the
transducer assembly. Remove and discard the two O-Rings from the 5/16-24
plugs if they show signs of damage or have taken a set.
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
10
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

____  2.
Carefully cut and remove the Beryllium copper wire [1] from the sensor boot
[4] at the two places shown in Figure 6.
____  3.
Slide the sensor boot [4] off of the sensor housing [15]. Inspect the boot for
cracks and other signs of aging. Discard the sensor boot if found to be
defective.
____  4.
Cut and remove lacing cord (F203206000) from wires if replacing individual
sensors [11].
____  5.
Cut the red and black wire of each defective sensor [4] from the pressure
terminals [2].
If replacing pressure terminals or pressure terminal O-Rings [3], cut all red
and black wires from the pressure terminals. Use a 3/16-inch deep-wall
socket and handle to unscrew each pressure terminal from the sensor housing
[15].
____  6.
Unscrew the retainer ring(s) [7] from the defective sensor(s) [11] and remove
the retainer sensor washer(s) [9] and wave spring(s) [8].
____  7.
Insert two flat blade (common) screwdrivers, 180° apart, into the groove in
the sensor [11] and gently pry the sensor up and out of the sensor housing
[15].
____  8.
Repeat steps 5 and 6 to remove other defective sensors [11].


JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
11
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

TOP SUB / UPPER HOUSING 6 

ASSEMBLY
Refer to assembly drawing A3000353000 and wiring diagram A3000353 WRD during these
assembly procedures unless otherwise specified.

Note: Numbers in brackets [  ] correspond to the item numbers on drawing A3000353000 and its
BOM.

Before starting the assembly process, it is a good idea to replace all O-Rings. Refer to the
assembly drawings associated with the 2809 XA Noise / Temperature Instrument for required
O-Rings.

TRANSDUCER ASSEMBLY
Refer to Figure 5 and assembly drawing A3001257000 during assembly of the
transducer assembly.

Note: Numbers in brackets [  ] correspond to the item numbers on drawing A3001257000 and its
BOM.

____  1.
Apply a small amount of Lubriplate grease to the O-Rings [3] on the two
pressure terminal [2] and install the pressure terminals into the alignment pin
end of the sensor housing [15]. Use a 3/16-inch deep-wall socket with handle
to snug the pressure terminals.
____  2.
Use a marker to draw a “+” (plus) symbol on the OD of the sensor housing
[15], as close as possible to the pressure terminal [2] that is located between
the two alignment pins.
____  3.
Use a marker to draw a “ – ” (minus) symbol on the OD of the sensor
housing [15], as close as other pressure terminal [2].

Do not over-tighten the pressure terminals. To much force can strip or crack
the peek material on the pressure terminals.
____  4.
Install the six sensor assemblies [11] into the sensor housing [15] using the
following procedure.
A.
Apply a small amount of Lubriplate grease [13] to the O-Rings [10] on
the ODs of the six sensor cups [11].
B.
Insert the wires of the first sensor assembly [11] into one of the six
large threaded holes in the sensor housing [15]. Push the wires down
through the large hole and out of the smaller hole in the sensor housing
that aligns with the large hole. Gently pull on the wires as you insert
the sensor assembly into the large threaded hole.
C.
Seat the sensor assembly [11].
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
12
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly
D.
Install the wave spring [8], retainer sensor washer [9], and retainer ring
[7] as shown in Figure 5 and tighten the retainer ring.
E.
Repeat steps B through D for the five remaining sensor assemblies
[11].
F.
Route the red wires from the six sensor assemblies [11] to the positive
pressure terminal [2].
G.
Use the shortest route possible to neatly route individual wires to the +
(plus) terminal post, while allowing for a ~1.5-inch service loop. Avoid
stressing wire connections to the two pressure terminals [2] or the six
sensor assemblies [11]. Trim excess wire and solder the six red wires
to the + (plus) pressure terminal [2].
H.
Route and solder the black wires to the – (minus) pressure terminal [2]
using the procedures in Steps F and G.
I.
Check for capacitance between the "+" and "–" terminals. Reading
should be 14 nF ±20%.
J.
Use an approved solvent to remove excess solder flux.
K.
Use lacing cord (F203206000) to neatly bundle wires and secure them
to the sensor housing [15].
____  5.
Slide the sensor boot [4] onto the sensor housing [15] and up against the
flange as shown in Figure 6. Apply a light coat of DC 200-100 cs silicone oil
[14] to the ID of the sensor boot if needed to make installation easier.
____  6.
Wrap 20 gauge Beryllium copper wire [1] tightly around the sensor boot [4]
at two places as shown in Figure 6 and solder. Two wraps at each position is
sufficient.
____  7.
Use instructions in the Oil Fill Procedure for Pressure Equalized Instruments
document (099194-000) to vacuum fill the transducer assembly with DC
200-100 cs silicone oil [14].
____  8.
Disconnect the vacuum fill system.
____  9.
Apply a small amount of Lubriplate grease [13] to the O-Rings [5] and the
threads of the two 5/16-24 plugs [6]. Install the plugs as shown on the
assembly drawing and in Figure 5.

130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
13
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 5.2 ASSEMBLE BOTTOM CRYSTAL HOLDER SUB..................................................13
chunk_text:
ASSEMBLE BOTTOM CRYSTAL HOLDER SUB

Note: This procedure assumes that the bottom crystal holder sub [21] is positioned on the
workbench with its top (uphole) end to your left.

____  1.
Lubricate the two O-Rings on each of the four temperature probe assemblies
[22] with Lubriplate grease [30].
____  2.
Rotate the bottom crystal holder sub [21] until the alignment mark on the
sub’s OD is facing up. Apply thread lock adhesive to the threads of the first
temperature probe assembly [22]. Push the wires of the first temperature
probe assembly into the threaded hole that is aligned with the alignment
mark on the OD of the bottom crystal holder sub. Use the temperature probe
socket (199393-000) to screw in and tighten the temperature probe assembly.
See Section F-F of the assembly drawing.
____  3.
Label the two wires from the first temperature probe assembly RTD1.

Note:
The wire colors are identical for all four temperature probe assemblies [21]. Labeling the
wires ensures correct identification of the individual temperature probes when the top 45-
socket female connector is wired later in this procedure.

____  4.
Rotate the bottom crystal holder sub [21] away from you (counterclockwise
when viewed from the bottom of the sub) until the second milled out section
of the bottom crystal holder sub is facing up.
____  5.
Repeat Step 2 for the second temperature probe assembly [22]. Label the
wires from the second temperature probe assembly RTD2.
____  6.
Rotate the bottom crystal holder sub [21] away from you (counterclockwise
when viewed from the bottom of the sub) until the third milled out section of
the bottom crystal holder sub is facing up.
____  7.
Repeat Step 2 for the third temperature probe assembly [22]. Label the wires
from the third temperature probe assembly RTD3.
____  8.
Rotate the bottom crystal holder sub [21] away from you (counterclockwise
when viewed from the bottom of the sub) until the fourth milled out section
of the bottom crystal holder sub is facing up.
____  9.
Repeat Step 2 for the fourth temperature probe assembly [22]. Label the
wires from the fourth temperature probe assembly RTD4.
____  10.
Strip about 1/8-inch of insulation from one end of each twisted and non-
twisted wire bundle connected to the Matrix 27-pin male connector [23].
____  11.
Insert the four 1.875-inch screws [3, 198097-000] through the 27-pin
connector from the bottom and slide one 0.60-inch piece of Teflon tubing [9]
onto the threads of each screw. Apply thread-lock adhesive [26] to the
exposed threads of each of the four screws.
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
14
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly
____  12.
Lubricate the O-Ring on the OD of the 27-pin connector [23] with Lubriplate
grease [30].
____  13.
Push the wire bundle up through the bottom crystal holder sub [21] from the
bottom, align the screw holes in the 27-pin male connector [23] with the
threaded holes in the bottom crystal holder sub and insert the connector into
the housing. Screw in and tighten the four 4-40 X 1.875-inch screws supplied
with the connector.
____  14.
Stand the bottom crystal holder sub [21] on the work surface, top end up.
____  15.
Lubricate the O-Ring [11] with Lubriplate grease [30]. Slide the O-Ring
down over the neck of the bottom crystal holder sub [21] and into the O-Ring
groove on the flange at the base of the neck.
____  16.
Slide the transducer assembly [4], terminal side up, down over the neck of
the bottom crystal holder sub [21] until it contacts the O-Ring [11].
____  17.
Lubricate the two O-Rings [14] with Lubriplate grease and install them into
the two O-Ring grooves near the top of the bottom crystal holder sub [21].
____  18.
Lubricate the threads at the top of the bottom crystal holder sub [21] with
Lubriplate grease [30].
____  19.
Use a marker to draw a “+” symbol on the OD of the lower housing [20], just
to the right of the milled out area at the bottom as shown in Figure 7.
Alignment pin holes in the bottom of the lower housing indicates the location
of the “+” terminal hole. See Section D-D of the assembly drawing.


JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
15
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

____  20.
Push the wires at the top of the bottom crystal holder sub [21] up through the
lower housing [20] and slide the lower housing [20] down over the neck of
the bottom crystal holder sub and engage the threads. See Figure 8. Maintain
tension on the wires while sliding the lower housing down over the bottom
crystal holder sub to avoid pinching the wires.



____  21.
Screw the lower housing [20] onto the bottom crystal holder sub [21] by
hand until the bottom of the lower housing is just above the terminal pins of
the transducer assembly [4] shown in Figure 8.
____  22.
Pull the transducer assembly [4] terminals up into the bottom housing [20].
Hold the transducer assembly in place and tighten the bottom crystal holder
sub [21] by hand until snug against the bottom of the transducer assembly.
Make sure that the O-Ring [11] remains in its groove while tightening.
____  23.
Move the assembly to a bench vise.
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
16
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

____  24.
Install the two halves of the support tool (A1001243000) (Figure 1) onto the
bottom sub [21] as shown in Figure 9. The pins of the support tool are
inserted into the holes in the bottom sub. Screw in and tighten the two
socket-head screws supplied with the tool and lock the support tool in a vise
as shown in Figure 9.



JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
17
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly
____  25.
Use a long-handled spanner wrench to tighten the lower housing [20] onto
the bottom crystal holder sub [21] as shown in Figure 10. Considerable force
is needed to properly tighten the lower housing onto the bottom crystal
holder sub.


____  27.
Apply thread lock adhesive to the threads of the four 1/4-20 X 0.50-inch
socket head set screws [27]. Individually insert and tighten the four 1/4-20 X
0.50-inch socket head set screws into the lower housing [20] as shown in
Section D-D of the assembly drawing and Figure 11.


Baker Atlas
18
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

____  28.
Lubricate the O-Rings of two pressure terminal assemblies [13] with
Lubricate grease [30].
____  29.
Push the red wire of the “+” pressure terminal assembly up through the hole
in the upper end of the milled-out area of the lower housing [20] as shown in
Do not over-tighten the pressure terminals. Over-tightening can cause the
peek material to strip or crack.


Repeat Step 29 for the “–” (minus) pressure terminal [13]. The minus
pressure terminal has a black wire.
____  31.
Clean the two mud cell jumper assemblies [13], including the contacts.
____  32.
Plug a mud cell jumper assembly [12] onto the plus pressure terminal [13]
and the plus transducer assembly [4] terminal as shown on the assembly
drawing. When properly connected, the mud cell jumper assembly should
have a loop in the wire similar to the one shown on the assembly drawing.
____  33.
Repeat Step 32 for the minus mud cell jumper assembly [12].
____  34.
Completely fill the mud cell cavities with Lubriplate [30] or other suitable
grease.
____  35.
Apply thread lock adhesive [26] to the threads of the eight 8-32 X 0.25-inch
flat-head machine screws [25]. Individually install the two protector sleeves
[5] and secure each with four 8-32 X 0.25-inch flat-head machine screws as
shown in Sections B-B and C-C of the assembly drawing.
____  36.
Pull the wires at the top of the lower housing [20] to remove all slack and
strip about 1/8-inch of insulation from one end of each twisted and non-
twisted wire.
____  37.
Refer to wiring diagram A3000353 WRD during the wiring of the top 45-
socket female connector [19]. Push the wires up through the bottom half (no
O-Ring) of the 45-socket female connector. Verify proper connector half
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
19
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly
orientation and correct wire-to-hole number, because the crimping
operation is a one-time process.
____  38.
Crimp the female sockets [3, 181737-000] to the wires.
____  39.
Fill all unused holes in the top half of the 45-socket female connector [19]
with sockets [3, 181737-000]. If the top half of the connector does not have
an O-Ring [12, 181737-000] installed, lubricate it with Lubriplate grease [30]
and install it into the O-Ring groove.
____  40.
Insert the wired connector sockets into the top half of the 45-socket female
connector [19] per wiring diagram A3000353 WRD. Slide the bottom half of
the 45-socket female connector up against the top half. Lubriplate grease [30]
applied to the holes in the top connector half or the connector socket O-Rings
will make it easier to insert the connector sockets. Secure the two halves of
the connector together with the screw, washer, and nut [6, 7, 8, 181737-000].
____  41.
Insert the three 1.875-inch screws [4, 181737-000] through the 45-socket
connector from the top and slide one 0.60-inch piece of Teflon tubing [9]
onto the threads of each screw. Apply thread-lock adhesive [26] to the
exposed threads of each of the three screws.
____  42.
Lubricate the O-Ring on the OD of the 45-socket female connector [19] with
Lubriplate grease [30].
____  43.
Make an “S” bend in the wire bundle and push the wire bundle into the top of
the lower housing [20], align the screw holes in the 45-socket female
connector [19] with the threaded holes in the ID of the lower housing and
insert the connector into the housing. Screw in and tighten the three 4-40 X
1.875-inch screws supplied with the connector.
____  44.
Clean and liberally lubricate the ID of the two piece non-field joint split
collar [15] and the wide groove near the top of the lower housing [20] with
Lubriplate grease [30]. Install the non-field joint split collar (threads toward
the top) into the wide groove in the lower housing and secure with the
hardware provided with the split collar. Apply thread lock adhesive [26] to
the screw threads. Verify free movement of the assembled split collar.
____  45.
Lubricate the two O-Rings [7] with Lubriplate grease [30] and install them
into the top two O-Ring grooves on the OD of the lower housing [20].
____  46.
Set the assembled bottom crystal holder assembly aside for now.
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
20
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

ASSEMBLE TOP SUB

Note: This procedure assumes that the top sub [2] is positioned on the workbench with its top
(uphole) end to your left.

____  1.
Lubricate the two O-Rings [7] with Lubriplate grease [30] and install them
into the top two O-Ring grooves on the OD of the top sub [2].
____  2.
Liberally lubricate the ID of the two piece split collar [3] and the wide
groove near the top of the top sub [2] with Lubriplate grease [30]. Install the
split collar (threads toward the top) into the wide groove in the top sub and
secure with the hardware provided with the split collar. Apply thread lock
adhesive [26] to the screw threads. Verify free movement of the assembled
split collar.
____  3.
Liberally lubricate the ID of the two piece non-field joint split collar [15] and
the wide groove near the bottom of the upper housing [29] with Lubriplate
grease [30]. Install the split collar (threads toward the bottom) into the wide
groove in the upper housing and secure with the hardware provided with the
split collar. Apply thread lock adhesive [26] to the screw threads. Verify free
movement of the assembled split collar.
____  4.
Lubricate the two O-Rings [7] with Lubriplate grease [30] and install them
into the bottom two O-Ring grooves on the OD of the upper housing [29].
____  5.
Stand the top sub [2] on the work surface, top end down.
____  6.
Lubricate the O-Ring [11] with Lubriplate grease [30]. Slide the O-Ring
down over the neck of the top sub [2] and into the O-Ring groove on the
flange at the base of the neck.
____  7.
Slide the transducer assembly [4], terminal side up, down over the neck of
the top sub [2] until it contacts the O-Ring [11].
____  8.
Lubricate the two O-Rings [14] with Lubriplate grease and install them into
the two O-Ring grooves near the top sub’s [2] neck.
____  9.
Lubricate the threads on the neck of the top sub [2] with Lubriplate grease
[30].
____  10.
Use a marker to draw a “+” symbol on the OD of the upper housing [29], just
below the milled out area at the top as shown in Figure 13. The two
alignment pin holes in the top of the upper housing indicates the location of
the “+” terminal hole. See Section D-D of the assembly drawing.
____  11.
Slide the upper housing [29], “+”(plus) marked end first, down over the neck
of the top sub [2] and engage the threads. See Figure 13.
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
21
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly



____  12.
Screw the upper housing [29] onto the top sub [2] by hand until the top of the
upper housing is just above the terminal pins of the transducer assembly [4].
____  13.
Pull the transducer assembly [4] terminals up into the upper housing [29].
Hold the transducer assembly in place and tighten the top sub [2] by hand
until snug against the top of the transducer assembly. Make sure that the O-
Ring [11] remains in its groove while tightening.
____  14.
Move the assembly to a bench vise. Install the two halves of the support tool
(A1001243000) as shown in Figure 1. Engage the pins of the support tool in
the holes in the upper housing [29] as shown in Figure 2 and install the two
socket head screws supplied with the support tool.
____  15.
Lock the support tool and upper housing / top sub in a vise as shown in
upper housing [29] as shown in Figure 14. Considerable force is needed to
properly tighten the top sub onto the upper housing.
130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
22
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly



____  17.
Move the assembly to the work surface, top sub [2] to the left.
____  18.
Apply thread lock adhesive to the threads of the four 1/4-20 X 0.50-inch
socket head set screws [27]. Individually insert and tighten the four 1/4-20 X
0.50-inch socket head set screws into the upper housing [29] as shown in
Section D-D and Figure 15.



____  19.
Assembly the two pressure terminal assemblies [13], one with red wire and
one with black wire, per drawing 199649-000.
____  20.
Lubricate the O-Rings of the two pressure terminal assemblies [13] with
Lubricate grease [30].

130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
23
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly
____  21.
Push the red wire of the pressure terminal assembly (+ terminal) [13] up
through the hole in the bottom end of the milled-out area of the upper
housing [29] as shown in Figure 16. Use a 3/16-inch deep wall socket to
screw the pressure terminal assembly into the lower housing.

Do not over-tighten the pressure terminals. Over-tightening can cause the
peek material to strip or crack.


____  22.
Repeat Step 21 for the “–” (minus) pressure terminal [13]. The minus
pressure terminal has a black wire.
____  23.
Clean the two mud cell jumper assemblies [13], including the contacts.
____  24.
Plug a mud cell jumper assembly [12] onto the plus pressure terminal [13]
and the plus transducer assembly [4]terminal as shown on the assembly
drawing. When properly connected, the mud cell jumper assembly should
have a loop in the wire similar to the one shown on the assembly drawing.
____  25.
Repeat Step 24 for the minus mud cell jumper assembly [12].
____  26.
Completely fill the mud cell cavities with Lubriplate [30] or other suitable
grease.
____  27.
Apply thread lock adhesive [26] to the threads of the eight 8-32 X 0.25-inch
flat-head machine screws [25]. Individually install the two protector sleeves
[5] and secure each with four 8-32 X 0.25-inch flat-head machine screws as
shown in Sections B-B and C-C of the assembly drawing.

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 5.4 ASSEMBLE MAJOR SUBASSEMBLIES ...............................................................24
chunk_text:
ASSEMBLE MAJOR SUBASSEMBLIES
This procedure assembles the three major subassemblies of the 2809 XA Noise /
Temperature Tool together. Refer to assembly drawing A3000353000 and its BOM
during this assembly procedure unless otherwise instructed.

Note:
This procedure assumes that the top sub /upper housing assembly, electronics assembly, and
bottom crystal holder sub / lower housing assembly are positioned on the workbench with
their top (uphole) ends to your left.

____  1.
Refer to assembly drawing A3000345000 for this step. Remove the four axel
wheel roller pins [20] and four roller shelf wheels [18] from the top of the
electronics assembly. Unscrew the two 8-32 X 0.625-inch socket head cap
screws [19] and remove the two roller shelves [17] from the top of the
electronics assemble and set aside.
____  2.
Push all wires at the top of the electronics assembly [17] except the two
conductor shielded cable [48, A3000345000] and red and black wire from
the pressure terminal assemblies [13], up through the bottom of the upper
housing and out the top of the top sub [2].
____  3.
Cut two 0.50-inch pieces of 0.187-inch shrink tubing [34] and slide one piece
over the black wire and one piece over the red wire of the two conductor
shielded cable [48, A3000345000].
____  4.
Remove 1/4-inch of insulation from the red and black pressure terminal wires
and from the red and black two-conductor shielded cable wires [48,
A3000345000].
____  5.
Splice the two red wires together and the two black wires together and solder
using SN96 solder (F249566000). Use the splicing technique recommended
in the Quality and Workmanship Standards Manual P/N N80807.
____  6.
Slide the shrink tubing down over the soldered joints, center, and shrink in
place.
____  7.
Bend the two pressure terminal wires and the two-conductor shielded cable
[48] as shown in Figure 17. Use lacing cord [10] to dress the wire bundle.

130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
25
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly



Note:
Be careful not to pinch wires between the upper housing [29] and the chassis adapter block
[3, A3000345000] during the next two steps. Generally, if the two surfaces can be pushed
flush together, no wires are pinched.

____  8.
Push the wires into the bottom of the upper housing while pushing the top
sub /upper housing assembly against the chassis adapter block [3,
A3000345000], located at the top of the electronics assembly [17].
____  9.
Apply thread lock adhesive [26] to the four 8-32 X 0.875-inch socket head
cap screws [28]. Align the threaded holes in the bottom of the upper housing
[29] with the holes in the chassis adapter block [3, A3000345000].
Individually insert and tighten the four 8-32 X 0.875-inch socket head cap
screws. The screws are inserted through the chassis adapter block.

Note: The two socket-head cap screws [19], two roller shelves, four axel wheel roller pins [20], and
four roller shelf wheels [18] removed in Step 1 will be re-installed in the next step.

____  10.
Refer to assembly drawing A3000345000 for this step. Apply thread lock
adhesive to the threads of the two 8-32 X 0.625-inch socket head cap screws
[19]. Align the two roller shelves [17] at the top of the electronics chassis [1]
and secure them to the electronics chassis with the two 8-32 X 0.625-inch
socket head cap screws. Apply thread lock adhesive to the threads of the four
axel wheel roller pins [20]. Individually insert the four roller shelf wheels
[18] into the roller shelves and secure in place with the four axel wheel roller
pins.
____  11.
Pull lightly on the wires at the top of the top sub [2] to remove any slack in
the wires. Strip about 1/8-inch of insulation from the end of each wire.


130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
26
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

____  12.
Refer to wiring diagram A3000353 WRD during the wiring of the top 27-
socket female connector [6]. Push the wires up through the bottom half (no
O-Ring) of the 27-socket female connector. Verify proper connector half
orientation and correct wire-to-hole number, because the crimping
operation is a one-time process.
____  13.
Crimp the female sockets [3, 198100-000] to the wires.
____  14.
Fill all unused holes in the top half of the 27-socket female connector [6]
with female sockets [3, 198100-000]. If the top half of the connector does not
have an O-Ring [10] installed, lubricate it with Lubriplate grease [30] and
install it into the O-Ring groove.
____  15.
Insert the wired connector sockets into the top half of the 27-socket female
connector [6] per wiring diagram A3000353 WRD. Slide the bottom half of
the 27-socket female connector up against the top half. Lubriplate grease [30]
applied to the holes in the top connector half or the connector socket O-Rings
will make it easier to insert the connector sockets. Secure the two halves of
the connector together with the screw, washer, and nut [4, 5, 6, 198100-000].
____  16.
Insert the four 2.00-inch screws [8, 198100-000] through the 27-socket
connector [6] from the top and slide one 0.60-inch piece of Teflon tubing [9]
onto the threads of each screw. Apply thread-lock adhesive [26] to the
exposed threads of each of the four screws. Use lacing cord [10] to tie a
strain relief in the wire bundle, as close as possible to the connector without
stressing the wires. Figure 18 shows the completed 27-socket female
connector.



____  17.
Lubricate the O-Ring on the OD of the 27-socket female connector [6] with
Lubriplate grease [30].
____  18.
Make an “S” bend in the wire bundle and push the wire bundle into the top of
the top sub [2], align the screw holes in the 27-socket female connector [6]
with the threaded holes in the ID of the top sub [2] and insert the connector
into the housing. Screw in and tighten the four 4-40 X 2.00-inch screws
supplied with the connector.

130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
27
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

____  19.
Check out the assembled tool as instructed in the Maintenance / Repair
section (130972-956) of this manual before installing the housing weldment
[16].

Note:
Plug the 45-socket female connector at the top of the bottom crystal holder sub / lower
housing assembly into the bottom 45-pin male connector of the electronics assembly for
testing purposes.

FINAL ASSEMBLY27
FIGURES
Install Support Tool on Lower Housing5
Loosen Top Sub 8
Location of Sensor Boot and Wire10
Install Lower Housing onto Crystal Holder Sub15
Tighten Lower Housing17
Location of Red Wire Pressure Terminal Assembly18

130972-955 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas

2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Disassembly / Assembly

FINAL ASSEMBLY
Refer to drawing A3000353000 and its BOM during this procedure.

Note: This procedure assumes that the bottom crystal holder sub / lower housing assembly and the
housing weldment are positioned on the workbench with their top (uphole) ends to your left.

____  1.
Disconnect the bottom crystal holder sub / lower housing assembly from the
electronics assembly.
____  2.
Lubricate the threads of the non-field joint split collars [15] with Lubriplate grease
[30]. One is located on the upper housing [29] and one is located on the lower
housing [20].
____  3.
Place the housing weldment [16] on a tool dolly or other stable work surface
equipped with a chain vise with its alignment slot up. Secure the housing weldment
with the chain vise.
____  4.
Align the alignment notch on the upper housing [29] with the alignment slot in the
housing weldment [16] and push the top sub /upper housing assembly and attached
electronics assembly into the top of the housing weldment. Use a spanner wrench
to tighten the split collar [15] into the housing weldment.
____  5.
Align the alignment notch on the lower housing [20] with the alignment slot in the
bottom of the housing weldment and push the bottom crystal holder sub / lower
housing assembly straight into the bottom of the pressure housing [16]. Use a
spanner wrench to tighten the split collar [15] into the housing weldment.
____  6.
Lubricate the threads of the split collar [3] with Lubriplate grease [30]. Screw on
and tighten the top thread protector.
____  7.
Lubricate the O-Ring [7] with Lubriplate grease [30] and install it into the O-Ring
groove on the OD of the bottom thread protector [24]. Lubricate the threads of the
bottom thread protector with Lubriplate grease. Screw in and tighten the bottom
thread protector.

topic: Repair / Maintenance Procedures - 4.0 CONTINUITY AND RESISTIVITY CHECKS ..............................................................6
chunk_text:
CONTINUITY AND RESISTIVITY CHECKS
Before power is applied for the first time, make continuity and isolation checks to ensure proper
wiring and to eliminate possible shorts. Repair or replace defective wiring discovered during this
test before proceeding to the next step.
Perform all insulation and continuity checks with the ohmmeter set in the relative mode. This
setting will null the resistance of the test leads. After deducting test-lead resistance, continuity is
defined as less than 0.1 ohm. Open is defined as greater than 100 Meg-ohms.
Refer to assembly drawing A3000345000, A3000353000, and wiring diagram A3000353 WRD
during the following checks.
1.
Verify insulation between all pins of the top 27-socket connector (J1) and chassis
backbone, and the bottom 27-pin connector (J4) and chassis backbone as follows.


From

To
Expected
Reading
Chassis
J1, all pins except 13 and 14
Open
Chassis
J4, all pins except 13 and 14
Open
Chassis
J1 and J4 pins 13 and 14
>1 Meg ohm


2.
Check for wire-to-wire leakage between top 27-socket female connector (J1) sockets;
socket 1 to socket 2, etc. All should read open. Repeat for the bottom 27-pin male
connector (J4).

topic: Repair / Maintenance Procedures - 6.1 VERIFY VOLTAGE ON DAQ BOARD.................................................................10
chunk_text:
VERIFY VOLTAGE ON DAQ BOARD
1.
Turn off the Test Panel, 4509 NA.
2.
Plug connectors P1 and P4 into DAQ board A3000343000.
3.
Turn on the 4509 NA Test Panel. Verify 3.3 V (±0.1 V) at the 3.3 VD terminal (P4-1)
referenced to the DGND terminal (P4-2) on the DAQ board (A3000343000).
4.
Verify +5 V (±0.1 V) at the +5 V terminal (P1-10) referenced to AGND (P1-11).
5.
Verify -5 V (±0.1 V) at the -5 V terminal (P1-12) referenced to AGND (P1-11).
6.
Verify wiring if any of the above are not present (reference drawing
A3000353 WRD).
7.
Verify +5 V (±0.1 V) at the +5 VD terminal  referenced to DGND. Check U32 and
components around U32 if this voltage is not present. U32 is shown on last page of

130972-956 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006

POWER SUPPLY STARTUP DELAY (Inhibit)
1.
Connect channel 2 of the oscilloscope to E5 on the Power Control PCB,
198384-000.
2.
Set channel 1 and 2 to 5 V and the time scale to 200 ms. Set the scope to trigger on
channel 1 at approximately 2.6 V. Refer to Figure 2.
3.
Hold the channel 1 scope probe on U4, pin 7 (RESET/). Turn on the 4509 NA Test
Panel. Verify that channel 2 (Brick Inhibit 1) goes high one second, ±10%, after
channel 1 goes high (see Figure 2). See the Power Supply Troubleshooting
section for possible causes if this check fails.


130972-956 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas

2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

PC SETUP FOR TEST SOFTWARE
Refer to the 4583 XA Instrument Test System User’s Guide, P/N 198164-000, for details on
the test system. The Test Software, P/N 199633-000, should be installed on the PC used for
testing. Configure the test setup according to Figure 1. The following sequence is critical,
because the Test Software monitors instrument current and will shut down if certain criteria
are not met.
1.
Power up the PC and allow it to boot normally. Do not launch the Test Software yet.
2.
Apply power to the Test Panel only after it is properly connected to the instrument to
be tested using the designated cable.
3.
Launch the Test Software. See the "running the software" Section for proper
operating sequence.

RUNNING THE SOFTWARE
1.
Launch the Test System Software by clicking on the desktop icon or by locating the
TClient3.exe program and executing it. When the program opens, the last-used tool
DLL will automatically populate the Welcome dialog. This may, or may not, be the
instrument you are testing now.
2.
Regardless of whether the correct tool type is established, you must fill in the
appropriate edit boxes with the information that you wish to save with the current test.
Only the top two combo boxes require an input to continue. See Figure 3 for an
example of this Welcome dialog.



130972-956 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
13
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

3.
Fill out the boxes according to the following:
•
Select the Tool Type combo box lists all available tools that can be currently tested
using this system. Choose the instrument you are testing.
•
Select Telemetry Type as Ethernet if you are communicating directly to the Test
Panel as shown in Figure 3.
•
Operator’s Name – type in the tester’s name.
•
Note and enter the serial number of the instrument you are testing in the Tool
Serial Number edit box.
•
Department is another combo box. Choose an appropriate department from the
available list.
•
Enter into the Location edit box anything that describes where you are located.
•
Enter anything that may be beneficial in remembering the conditions under which
you performed the test in the Description of Test edit box.
•
Software errors of any kind are recorded in a file. You can limit the maximum
number of error entries into this file by typing a number into the Maximum
Number of Errors to Log to Error Log txt edit box.
4.
Click the OK button when you are satisfied with all your entries.
5.
TCP / IP Configuration Dialog box; see Figure 4. Every Test Panel display should
show a different IP Address.
6.
Enter the displayed address into the Panel IP Address edit box. Figure 4 shows an
example IP Address only – do not use this example as your entry.
7.
The Mode combo box lists available configurations that are used by the Test Panel.
Select "focus Instrument Bus" for this type of testing.



8.
Click the OK button to close the dialog box.
130972-956 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
14
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

9.
Functionality of the instrument can be checked with an established script file or by
executing individual commands.
10.
Perform the tests outlined in the FUNCTIONAL TESTING section to check
functionality.
11.
If the Client Information Window (Figure 5) appears with these error messages, check
the connection to the Lab PC Test System and verify that it is turned ON. Also, verify
all PC setups. Re-start the Focus Test Fixture software if all appears normal.



12.
Exit the test software and turn the Test Panel OFF.

FUNCTIONAL TESTING
This section downloads the acquisition firmware to the DAQ flash prom and checks operation of
the DAQ Board P.N. A3000343000, while checking telemetry integrity. Refer to the Trouble-
shooting section for the DAQ board to troubleshoot the board itself.

ESTABLISHING MODE 2 COMMUNICATIONS
1.
Connect the 2809 XA to the test panel. Refer to Figure 1.
2.
Activate the LEDs (D1 and D2) by shorting JP2.
3.
Jumper from EP1 to EP2 or alternately jumper from EP1 to DGND. This jumper
will cause the DAQ board to load the Flash Loader firmware upon power up or
reset.
4.
Apply power to the 2809 XA and verify that the green and red LEDs are alternately
blinking for approximately 10 seconds. This blinking indicates that the DAQ board
is in the Flash Loader mode. Once the LEDs begin blinking the jumper from EP1
to EP2 can be removed. Refer to the Troubleshooting section for the DAQ board if
the LEDs do not respond as indicated. The tool will remain in the Flash Loader
mode until power is cycled or the tool is reset. Refer to Appendix A -
1630 EA/2809 XA DAQ Board LED Response Descriptions section for all LED
responses / conditions.
130972-956 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
15
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

5.
Restart the test software and select Matrix_NT Vx (see Figure 3) from the Select
the Tool Type combo box in the Welcome dialog.
6.
Click Commands, Subset E Test (Figure 6) to establish Mode 2 communications
with the test system.




7.
The Subset E Test dialog (Figure 7)should appear. Select Mode2 from the Subset
E Test combo box and click the Execute button. The tool should respond by
sending Subset E once. Repeat a few times to verify good communications on
Mode2 by checking the Client Information Window.



JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
16
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

8.
Click Commands, Show Telemetry Statistics to open the Client Information
Window (Figure 8), Telemetry statistics can also be checked in this window.
Refer to the Troubleshooting section if Mode2 communications cannot be
established.



PROGRAMMING ACQUISITION FIRMWARE
The files needed for programming the device can be obtained by using SAP transaction
code ZARAI, then select the eyeglass symbol and unzip the file A7000071 FW.zip. The
file needed for programming is A7000071 FWppp.bin (program file) (where ppp is the
SAP Part Field).

Note: While completing this section, do not attempt to run any acquisitions or download any
commands other than the ones in this section.


1.
Click Commands, Download Firmware (see Figure 6).
2.
Click the Browse button in the Download Firmware combo box (Figure 9) and
find and select the file A7000071 FWppp.bin. Click the OK button to start
downloading the file to the DAQ board's RAM.
3.
The file is fixed at 64k-bytes in length and is downloaded to the tool in 2k-byte
blocks. After each 2k-bytes block is downloaded it is automatically uploaded and
compared with what was downloaded. If all compares with what was sent, the next
2k-byte block is downloaded. If there was a compare error, the test software will
ask if you want to retry or cancel. Retry once or twice and if the download
continues to fail, cancel the download and fix the problem. Check Mode2
communications and possibly reset the tool and test setup. It takes approximately
two minutes to download the file. There are a number of indicators that can be
monitored while the file is downloading. The green LED (D2) will change
transitions on each 2k-byte download. There is a progress bar (Figure 10) on the
PC test software that can be monitored. Also, the Client Information Window
(Figure 11) will update on each 2k-byte download.
130972-956 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
17
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures






4.
The Write To Flash window appears (Figure 12) when the entire 64k-byte file has
been downloaded successfully. Click the OK button to write the file to flash. Do
Not interrupt this process! It takes approximately five seconds. When the DAQ
board is writing to flash, the green LED (D2) will be off and the red LED (D1) will
be on as an indicator that the file is writing to flash. There will also be a progress
bar indicating progress. If there were no errors there will be a Firmware Download
Successful message in the Client Information Window.
130972-956 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
18
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures



5.
As a final verification select Upload Status Table from the Commands menu
(Figure 6) and then select Status Table from the Displays menu to display the
status table. Verify that the only box checked in the third column is the Flash
Loader Running box (see Figure 13).



JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
19
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

PROGRAMMING ACQUISITION FIRMWARE16 

INITIALIZATION TEST
1.
Remove the jumper between EP1 and EP2 and press the reset button (S1) on the
DAQ board. Verify that the two LEDs (D1 and D2) are operating as described in
the LED response under normal conditions part of Appendix A. The tool is now in
acquisition mode.
2.
Click Commands, Upload Status Table (Figure 6), and then select Status Table
from the Displays menu to display the status table. Verify that there are no boxes
checked in the second column (see Figure 13). See the Troubleshooting section on
Analog Data if there are boxes checked.

MODE 5 AND MODE 7 TEST
1.
Create a script using Notepad that will send subset E on Mode 5 and Mode 7. See
Appendix B for an example. Alternately use the one provided with the Test System
Software. The name of the script file provided with the test software is
Script_NT_SendE_Mx.txt.
2.
Select Execution from the tool bar then Select Script to select the script file. Open
the script you created to send subset E. Next select Run from the tool bar. This will
open an Executing Script dialog (Figure 14).



3.
Verify that there are no communication errors by using the Client Information
Window and checking the Telemetry Statistics as you did earlier for Mode 2. See
the Troubleshooting section on communications if there are communications
errors.

130972-956 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
20
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

ACQUIRE AND SEND SUBSET 0
1.
Create a script using Notepad that will acquire and send subset 0 on Mode 5. See
Appendix B for an example. Alternately use the one provided with the Test System
Software. The name of the script file provided with the test software is
Script_NT_Acquire_Send0.txt.
2.
Click Commands, Map Subset from the menu (see Figure 6). The Map Subset to
WTS Mode dialog (Figure 15) should be displayed. Select 0 from Map Subset
combo box, Mode5 from the To WTS Mode box, and then click the Execute
button to send the command to the tool.



3.
Select Displays, Waveform Plot. On the next window use the default values and
click the OK button to display the Waveform Plot window.
4.
Click Commands, Download TCT (Figure 6). Disable the AGC, change the
sample rate to 4 us, the gains to 10, and click on Download. Verify a successful
download in the Client Information window.
5.
Run the script (click on the run icon) and verify that the waveforms and
temperatures similar to those shown in Figure 16 are present.
130972-956 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
21
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures


6.
Lightly scratch several of the Receiver Body transducers with your finger and
verify that the waveform amplitude changes. Pinch the end of the RTD sensors
between your thumb and forefinger and verify that the temperature changes.
7.
Verify that the chassis temperature is reading ambient or slightly higher due to
electronics heating (see Figure 16). If temperature is not reading correctly, refer to
Troubleshooting section on Temperature.
8.
Also verify that Status Word 1 equals 0x0000 and Status Word 2 equals 0x0000.
Note that Status Word 1 can also be found in the first column of the Status Table
and Status Word 2 can also be found in the second column of the Status Table (see
JUL 2006

2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

HEAT TESTING22
11.0 HEAT TESTING
Restrict the test temperature to the maximum rated temperature (125° C) of the 2809 XA.
Restrict the maximum heating/cooling rate to 5° C per minute. A typical heat run is 1 hour
after reaching temperature. Avoid thermal shocks.
1.
Place the 2809 XA (without housing) into oven. Care must be given to support the
chassis. DO NOT PLACE RECEIVER BODIES IN OVEN. Connect receiver bodies
via umbilical cords
2.
Connect the 2809 XA to the test setup (see Figure 1).
3.
Apply Power.
4.
Verify Mode 5 communications (see Figure 7).
5.
Repeat Steps 1-8 in the Acquire and Send Subset 0 section of this document.

130972-956 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
23
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures
6.
Start heat test and monitor test signals in waveform plot and Chassis Temperature in
the Last Subset Status window. Verify that there are no drop outs or spikes in the test
signals throughout the heat test. Verify that the two status words remain the same.
7.
Verify communications throughout the heat test.
8.
Occasionally scratch the receiver body sensor surfaces with your fingernail and watch
the signals respond, and pinch the RTD to watch the temperature change.
9.
Occasionally click Commands, Download TCT and change the period from 4 µs to 8
µs. Verify that the test signals move in time.
10.
Occasionally select Upload Status to verify that Mode 2 receive is working.
11.
Cycle power two to three times during the temperature test. Cycle power at least once
when the tool has reached maximum temperature to make sure that the instrument
powers up properly. The test system software may need to be restarted.
12.
Turn power off.

TROUBLESHOOTING23
12.0 TROUBLESHOOTING
This section contains information that can be useful in the diagnoses and repair of an individual
board or the power supplies.

POWER SUPPLIES 23
12.1.1
Visual Checkout23
12.1.2
Power Supply Troubleshooting24
12.1 POWER SUPPLIES
Refer to drawings A3000343000, A3000343 SCH, 198384000, 198384100, 198385000,
198385100, 198386000, 198386-100, and A3000353 WRD during checkout of the power
supplies.
12.1.1
Visual Checkout
1.
Verify that power supply, boards, and other parts are properly installed.
2.
Verify all fasteners are properly installed.
3.
Visually inspect all power supply PCBs (198384-000, 198385-000, and
198386-000). Examine for broken capacitors, contaminants between printed
circuits traces, open or shorted traces.
4.
If all the preceding checks fail to uncover any potential problems, proceed to the
next section.

JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
24
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

12.1.2 Power Supply Troubleshooting
Connect the 2809 XA to the Test equipment as shown in Figure 1. Apply power to the
Test Box. Locate the numbered step that most accurately describes the symptoms and
follow the suggested troubleshooting procedure. The PC test system is only required to
supply power to the tool during this procedure.
1.
No output voltage.
Probable cause:
No 28 Vdc
Action:
Verify 28 Vdc between E1 and E2 on PCB’s 198384-000,
and 198385-000, 198386-000, and between E3 and E4 on
PCB 198384-000. If 28 Vdc is missing, check wiring
(reference A3000353 WRD) and EMI filter brick on
assembly 198387-000.
Probable cause:
28 Vdc is present but one or more of the regulated
outputs is missing; i.e., ±5 Vdc or 3.3 Vdc.
Action:
Verify that the inhibit line on PCB 198384-000 is working
properly. Refer to the power supply startup delay
(inhibit)section of the document.
Probable cause:
The inhibit line is working but the delay length is
incorrect.
Action:
Verify that JP1 and JP3 are shorted and JP2 and JP4 are
open.
Probable cause:
The inhibit line is working and the delay length is ok.
Action:
Verify that the Inhibit line is present on PCBs 198385-000
and 198386-000. If the inhibit is present, check the choke
and power supply bricks and replace as needed. Also ensure
power supply bricks are not installed backwards.
Probable cause:
Inhibit line is not working.
Action:
Verify +5 Vdc at TP1 on PCB 198384-000. Check D1 if it
is not present and replace if needed. Verify that the Reset
line (U4 pin 7) goes from low to high after power up.
Replace U4 if the low to high transition is not present.
Verify that there is a delay at TP2 (refer to power supply
startup delay (inhibit) section of this document, but put
channel 2 scope probe on TP2). Verify that U3 is
programmed if it is replace it. If the inhibit is present at TP2
but not at E5, check Q1 and D2 and replace if needed.
130972-956 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
25
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

2.
Output voltage is incorrect.
Probable cause:
Power supply brick is bad or installed backward.
Action:
Replace brick or re-install correctly.
Probable cause:
Choke on power supply filter board (198385-000 or
198386-000) is bad.
Action:
Replace choke.

12.2 DAQ BOARD TROUBLESHOOTING
Refer to drawings A3000343000, A3000343 SCH, A3000353000, and A3000353 WRD
during checkout of the DAQ PC board.
12.2.1
Visual Checkout
1.
Verify all components are properly installed.
2.
Visually inspect the DAQ board (PN A3000343000). Examine board for broken
capacitors, contaminants between printed circuit traces, open or shorted traces.
3.
Verify that program labels are installed on U35 and U26. If labels are not present
the ICs may not be programmed.
If all the preceding checks fail to uncover any potential problems, proceed with the DAQ
Power-Up Reset Test.
12.2.2
DAQ Power-Up Reset Test


OBSERVE:
Channel one reaches approximately 3.08 volts and channel
2 (RESETIN/) and channel 3 (RESET_DSP/) are held low
for 160 ms to 280 ms then they both go high.

If channel 2 fails (RESETIN/):

Probable cause:
Bad reset chip (U26)
Action:
Replace U26
Probable cause:
Shorts around U26
Action:
Find shorts and repair

If channel 2 is OK but channel 3 fails (RESET_DSP/):
Probable cause:
FPGA (U26) not programmed
Action:
Replace U26 with programmed part
Probable cause:
Short around RESET_DSP/ on or around U26 or U22
Action:
Find and repair

12.2.4
DAQ EPROM Booting
1.
Connect the 2809 XA to the test panel as shown in Figure 1.
2.
Activate LEDs D1 and D2 by shorting JP2.
3.
Jumper between EP1 and EP2 or alternately jumper between EP1 and DGND.
Installing jumpers causes the DAQ board to load the Flash Loader firmware upon
power up or reset.
4.
Apply power to the 2809 XA and verify that the green and red LEDs are alternately
blinking for approximately 10 seconds. This blinking indicates that the DAQ board
is in the Flash Loader mode. Refer to the Appendix A section for all LEDs
responses / conditions. If the LEDs do not respond as indicated check the
following.
Probable cause:
LED’s D1 or D2 not installed properly or bad.
Action:
Replace LED
Probable cause:
FPGA (U26) is not programmed.
Action:
Continue to the Verify FPGA is Programmed section to
verify if FPGA is not programmed.
Probable cause:
Flash Prom (U26) is not programmed.
Action:
Continue to the Verify Flash Prom is Programmed
section to verify if Flash Prom is not programmed.
Probable cause:
U22, U35, U33, U26, or U34 not installed properly or
bad.
Action:
Replace as needed.

2809 XA Focus Noise / Temp. Instrument – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

12.2.5
Verify FPGA is Programmed



OBSERVE:
TP48 (BMS/) or TP46 (RD/). If they are different or
missing:
Probable cause:
U22 may be bad.
Action:
Replace U22.
OBSERVE:
U26-105 (ROMCS/). If it is different or missing:
Probable cause:
U26 (FPGA) may be bad or not programmed.
Action:
Replace U26 with a programmed part.

12.4.4
DAC Setup
1.
Connect the PC Test System (Figure 1).
2.
Remove Jumper between EP1 and EP2 if it is in place.
3.
Apply power to the tool if it is not already powered and start PC Test Software.
4.
Connect the scope as indicated and press the reset button (S1). This will cause the
DAQ board to go through a series of eight test acquisitions using the test signal
shown in Figure 16. Each test acquisition changes the DAC gain value starting
with gain step 8, and the FPGA produces a step function that is synchronized to the
Test Fire (TP53). Figure 35 shows the gain value (G1) on scope channel 1, what
the test signal looks like at test point 1 B and what it looks like at 1 C after the filter
section. Table 1 lists the gain steps and values. This is a good test for checking the
DAC, Analog circuits and A/Ds.


OBSERVE:
DAC output data (GAIN1) on channel 2. Each step
represents a new acquisition and a change in gain. Verify
that each step is the same value as indicated in the
following table. The first step is gain step 8 the next is gain
step 9 and the second to last one is gain step 15 then the
DAC is reset back to gain step 0. Also check G2 (GAIN2),
G3 (GAIN3), and G4 (GAIN4). If Channel 2 does not look
similar to the scope picture continue on to the next step to
verify references.

13.3 THINGS TO KNOW
13.3.1
Test Box Does Not Support Mode 7
Some Test Boxes (PN 199620000) do not support Mode 7 on Ethernet. The boxes that do
support Mode 7 have a switch on the back of the box to switch from Mode 5 to Mode 7.
Only one mode can be used at a time.
13.3.2
Test Box Hangs Up
Sometimes the Test Box / Software will hang up when you send the first command; e.g.,
Subset E Test. Try sending it again if it does hang up. You may have to exit the software
and then restart it if it hangs up a second time.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 3.0 LEVEL 3 PM PROCEDURE
chunk_text:
LEVEL 3 PM PROCEDURE
Refer to drawing A3000353000 and its BOM unless specifically instructed otherwise. Also
refer to the Assembly Procedure document 130972-955 while performing this Level 3 PM.
Bracketed item numbers are direct references to the item number on the drawing’s BOM
unless otherwise instructed.
Copy pages 2 and 3, and fill in the following information before beginning this procedure.

130972-953 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
2
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Level 3 PM

2809 XA Asset No.  _______________________
Date Completed:
_______________________
Technician’s Name: _______________________

Check (�) each step in the procedure as it is completed, and place it in the tool’s history
folder when Level 3 PM is complete.
____  1.
Thoroughly pressure-wash the electronics assembly and wipe dry.
____  2.
Remove the top and bottom thread protectors [1 and 24].
____  3.
Inspect external parts for nicks, thread dings, and other obvious deficiencies.
Replace any item that is unserviceable.
____  4.
Check the sockets of the 27-socket female connector [6]. Check to ensure that the
sockets are free of debris. Test fit a male pin into each socket to ensure that they
are all a tight fit. Replace loose fitting sockets.
____  5.
Check the 27-pin male connector [23] for bent or broken pins and damaged
ceramic around each pin. Straighten bent pins and replace damaged pins as
necessary.
____  6.
Remove the two protector sleeves [5] and clean the cavities.
____  7.
Inspect the rubber boots of the four mud cell jumpers [12]. Replace the mud cell
jumpers if the rubber boots show signs of deterioration. Spray the contacts with
contact cleaner and allow to dry. Fill the cavities with grease if desired and
replace the two protector sleeves [5].
____  8.
Lubricate and install two new O-Rings [7) at the top of the tool and the two O-
Rings [7] at the top of the lower housing [20].

Note: The housing weldment [16] must be removed to replace the O-Rings [7] at the top of the
lower housing [20].


____  9.
Remove one plug [6, A3001257000] from the top transducer assembly [4] and
verify that the oil level is correct. Remove and replace the O-Ring [5,
A3001257000]. Reinstall the plug. Remove the second plug, replace the
O-Ring, and reinstall the plug.
____  10.
Repeat Step 9 for the bottom transducer assembly [4].
____  11.
Remove the first sensor assembly [11, A3001257000] from the top transducer
assembly [4] as instructed in the Transducer Disassembly section of the
Disassembly and Assembly section (130972-955). DO NOT disconnect the
wires. Lubricate and install a new O-Ring [10, A3001257000]. Reinstall the first
sensor assembly as instructed in the Transducer Assembly section of
Disassembly and Assembly section 130972-955.
____  12.
Repeat Step 11 for the remaining 5 sensor assemblies.
____  13.
Inspect roller shelf wheels [18, drawing A3000345000] and axle wheel roller
pins [20, drawing A3000345000] for damage or flat spots. Replace as necessary.
130972-953 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas
3
2809 XA Focus Noise / Temperature Instrument – Level 3 PM

____  14.
Inspect the four temperature probe assemblies [22] for obvious damage. Replace
temperature probes as needed. Be aware that you must remove the housing
weldment [16] and 45-pin female connector [19] to replace the temperature
probes or temperature probe O-Rings [2, A3000397000]. Refer to Disassembly /
Assembly procedures section 130972-955 of this manual.
____  15.
Perform the inspection, continuity checks, and voltage checks described in
Repair Maintenance section 130972-956 of this manual.
____  16.
Reassemble as instructed in Disassembly / Assembly procedures section
130972-955 of this manual.
____  17.
Install the top and bottom thread protectors [1 and 24].

130972-953 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas

topic: Lab Safety - 1.0 INTRODUCTION 1.2 PERSONNEL SAFETY GUIDELINES
chunk_text:
INTRODUCTION
Follow the Personnel and Mechanical safety guidelines listed below when handling the
2809 XA Noise / Temperature Instrument Assembly. 
PERSONNEL SAFETY GUIDELINES
•
Thread protectors should always be installed when transporting or handling the tool.
•
Steel-toe shoes must be worn while handling the 2809 XA instrument.
•
Lumbar support belt 24652-003 S, -004 M, -005 L, -006 XL, or -007 XXL must be
worn when lifting the 2809 XA instrument.
•
Wear safety glasses when soldering.
MECHANICAL SAFETY GUIDELINES
The temperature probes and transducer assemblies can be easily damaged. Do not place tie-
downs over the transducer assemblies or the temperature probes.
130972-954 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas

INTRODUCTION
An instrument may be operated in an oven to verify performance in anticipation of its use in a
high-temperature environment (within tool specifications). Otherwise, no heat test for this
instrument is required.
See the Heat Test section of Maintenance / Repair document 130972-956 for the heat test
procedure.

130972-959 / 2809 XA
JUL 2006
Baker Atlas

GENERAL INFORMATION
THIS TOOL PRESENTS SEVERAL UNIQUE SAFETY ISSUES.  IT IS IMPORTANT THAT
THEY BE REVIEWED AND MADE KNOWN TO ALL PERSONS IN CLOSE PROXIMITY
TO THE TOOL DURING ITS TRANSPORT AND OPERATION.
IN ORDER TO PREVENT PERSONAL INJURY AND/OR EQUIPMENT DAMAGE, IT IS
ALSO IMPORTANT THAT ONLY TRAINED PERSONNEL OPERATE AND/OR
MAINTAIN THIS TOOL.
This module captures potential equipment failure hazards that are located throughout the 3212 PA and
3206 MRIL Manuals as "CAUTION" items because with their occurrence they can present a human
hazard.

TRANSPORTATION AND HANDLING
3212 PA SPECIFIC:
WARNING
THE 3212 PA OPERATES AT DANGEROUS VOLTAGE LEVELS (600 TO 900
VOLTS).  THE TOOL CAN ALSO STORE A DANGEROUS AMOUNT OF
ELECTRICAL ENERGY (630 J).  TO INSURE THAT THE TOOL IS FULLY
DISCHARGED AFTER A LOGGING RUN, ALWAYS USE THE FOLLOWING
PROCEDURE:
!
After NMR data acquisition is complete, reduce the output of the surface DC+/DC- power
supply (2010 or 2085) to zero while the NMR transmitter is firing.
!
Next, turn off the High Voltage Enable relay in the 3206 ED via the ECLIPS system.
!
Then turn off the DC+/DC- power supply unless it is needed by another tool.
!
Leave the WTS AC power on until the tool is near the surface if the well bore temperature is
above 85 C (185 F).  The 3212 PA contains a low voltage charger circuit which is powered
o
o
by the 180 Vac supply (refer to 130766-945 CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION).  This circuit
supplies 100 Vdc to the capacitor bank whenever the 180 Vac is applied to the tool - even
when the High Voltage Enable is disabled.  Be sure to set the Amplitude to "0" when cycling
the tool with the magnet exposed on the surface or inside casing.  This voltage protects the
electrolytic capacitors from damage at high temperature.
!
Avoid touching any of the contacts on either the top or bottom of the 3212 PA while handling
the tool, unless it has first been verified with a meter that there is no voltage between any of
the pins/sockets.  ALWAYS ASSUME THE TOOL MAY HAVE RETAINED AN

3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- FIELD SAFETY

TRANSPORTATION AND HANDLING   cont'd
!
Caution should be used when testing or working on the tool outside of its housing.  The
capacitor array is normally insulated by a fiberglass sleeve.  However, DANGEROUS
VOLTAGE IS EXPOSED ON ALL OF THE CIRCUIT BOARDS.  Therefore, power
down the tool and, before touching any component or terminal on the circuit boards or chassis
mounted components:
VERIFY THAT THE CAPACITORS ARE DISCHARGED BY USING A METER TO
READ THE VOLTAGE BETWEEN TERMINALS E5 & E6 ON THE JUMPER
BOARD LOCATED NEAR THE TOP OF THE TOOL.
!
Use care when handling the 3212 PA as with other heavy equipment.
3212 PA in MRIL Tool String:
!
The magnet will permanently loose all magnetism at wellsite/transportation temperatures at or
below -20 CE (-4 EF).  This is an immediate-action occurrence with no graduation affects.
The magnetism will not return as the temperature warms above -20 EC (-4 EF).  It will need to
be re-characterized at the NUMAR facilities.
!
Persons who wear cardiac pacemakers, have ferro-metal particularly or any other metal type
in/on their bodies MUST NOT BE NEAR the MRIL Tool due to its potentially hazardous
effects from the permanent magnetic field and/or from accidental RF radiation exposure.
Mechanical wrist watches also can be affected by the magnetic field.
!
Remove all magnetic retention media such as credit cards/bank cards, computer discs, logging
tapes, CRTs and other analyzer screens, from close proximity to the Antenna /Magnet probe.
The Probe's magnetic field will alter these magnetized media devices.
!
Do not transport other logging tools with the Antenna/Magnet Probe.  Keep all instruments
with photo-multiplier tubes at least 12 feet from the magnet probe.  The Probe's magnets will
change the alignment of the plates in a PM-tube causing the output to change, the
discriminator to need adjustment, and the tools to need re-calibration.  Tool housings in close

3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- FIELD SAFETY

TRANSPORTATION AND HANDLING   cont'd
!
Never attempt to stop a Antenna/Magnet Probe from being drawn magnetically towards a
metal wall, floor, or drill pipe.  The Probe can very forcefully roll or move towards the metal
surface without personnel being able to stop it.  Persons close to the tool must be warned of
the hazards of having a hand, arm, or foot caught between the metal wall, floor, or pipe and
the Antenna/Magnet Probe.
!
Thread protectors must be installed when lifting or transporting the tool sections.  Use of a
crane, hoist, or other mechanical device is required to lift the instrument.  The 3206 MRIL
Tool/Antennae/Magnet Probe weighs about 1900 lb (860 kg) when this cartridge is in its
transport case.  The tool, when fully assembled, weighs over 1100 lbs (408 kg) with 45% of
this weight at the Antenna/Magnet Probe.
!
The 3207/8 MB magnet and the 3206 ED, 3212 PA (or 3206 PA) must be lifted and transported
separately or tool damage can occur.  When shipping by commercial aircraft, the 3207/8 MB
magnet must be shipped inside its transport container to conform to IATA shipping
regulations for magnetic devices.  This container is very heavy (. 1350 lbs/613 kg) and will
require special handling.
WARNING
CUPRIC SULFATE (CuSO ) IS POISONOUS.  BEFORE HANDLING ANY CUPRIC

topic: Field Safety - SULFATE SOLUTION, REVIEW THE MSDS.  CLEARLY MARK ALL
chunk_text:
4

CONTAINERS CONTAINING CuSO  WITH A SIGN: ‘CuSO  - POISON - DO NOT
4
4
DRINK’ ALONG WITH THE MIXING DATE.  IT IS ALSO REQUIRED THAT ALL

3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- FIELD SAFETY

ON-SITE HAZARDS
!
Never operate the transmitter in open air with the antenna cartridge connected.
The only exception is when the tool is inside of the FARADAY CAGE/CALIBRATOR.  The
tool emits a powerful electromagnetic field (RF signal) that is a potential human HEALTH
RISK.  It is a violation of Government regulations to transmit on the surface; doing so could
result in a fine.
!
The 3212 PA contains a low voltage charger circuit that is powered by the 180 Vac supply
(see Circuit Description).  This circuit supplies 100 VDC to the capacitor bank whenever 180
Vac is applied to the tool - EVEN WHEN THE HIGH VOLTAGE ENABLE IS DISABLED.
Be sure to set the Amplitude to "0" when cycling the tool with the magnet exposed on the
surface or inside casing.
!
The 3206 MRIL Tool operates at very high power levels.  Be aware that whenever the tool
has exposed electrical contacts - feed throughs and cartridge connectors - that this condition is
a potentially lethal voltage source and should be considered as such until it is CERTAIN that
no danger exists.
!
If any checkout procedures are attempted while the tool is warm/hot, all personnel
should be positioned well away from directly over the Probe's check valve.  The
valve could be at or close to its pressure release point and unexpectedly spray a 12 -
18" stream of hot hydraulic oil.

RIGGING UP - (At the Well Site)
!
The 3207/8 MB Antenna/Magnet Probe should be rigged up independently of the 3206 ED.
!
The instrument must be made up vertically over the wellhead using tool head clamp (WALS
P/N 103100-000) and the rig make-up stand (WALS P/N 094427-000).  Never attempt to
pick up a horizontally assembled tool as one piece.  Tool damage will occur.
!

3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- FIELD SAFETY

TOOL DAMAGE HAZARDS
!
The 3206 PA MRIL Energy Cartridge and 3206 ED MRIL Electronics Cartridge are identical in
size and external appearance and can easily be switched in the tool string. Transmitting in the
wrong tool configuration is fatal to the tool!  If there is no tool gain in the MRIL curves
window this may be the problem.
!
Powering up the transmitter before performing a frequency sweep can cause tool damage due
to off-frequency operation.
!
Never power up the transmitter prior to establishing telemetry with the tool.
!
Never power up the transmitter without a load.  In the open hole, have a 3207/8 MB Probe
attached.  On the surface, havea 3203 XB Black Box attached.
!
Unless a 3212 PA or 3213 QB is in the tool string, never exceed 600 VDC as seen on the DC
power supply; tool damage can result.  Never exceed the circuit breaker amperage rating for
the power supply.
When using a 3212 PA or 3213 QB, do not exceed 900 VDC as seen on the DC power supply;
tool damage can result.
If the tool seems to be drawing excessive current, verify the cause before increasing voltage
to the tool.
!
Do not remove AC power with high voltage applied from the MRIL tool as this will
immediately put 600 VDC on the Density tool motor.
!
Never transmit while in metal casing, into a non-existent or unknown load, or if Gain is near
zero.  Tool damage is very likely to be the result.
!
Never power up the transmitter if the tool gain is less than 75.  Powering up the transmitter
before performing a frequency sweep can cause damage due to off-frequency operation.

GENERAL INFORMATION
THIS TOOL PRESENTS SEVERAL UNIQUE SAFETY ISSUES.  IT IS IMPORTANT THAT
THESE BE REVIEWED AND MADE KNOWN TO ALL PERSONS IN CLOSE
PROXIMITY TO THE TOOL DURING ITS TRANSPORT AND OPERATION.
IN ORDER TO PREVENT PERSONAL INJURY AND/OR EQUIPMENT DAMAGE, IT IS
ALSO IMPORTANT THAT ONLY TRAINED PERSONNEL OPERATE AND/OR
MAINTAIN THIS TOOL.

SAFETY CONSIDERATIONS
