3.0  DISASSEMBLY 2
3.0  DISASSEMBLY
WARNING
THIS TOOL IS DESIGNED TO STORE A DANGEROUS AMOUNT OF
ELECTRICAL ENERGY.  ALWAYS ASSUME THE TOOL HAS RETAINED AN
ELECTRICAL CHARGE.  AVOID TOUCHING ANY OF THE CONTACTS ON
EITHER THE TOP OR BOTTOM TOOL JOINT BEFORE CHECKING THE
VOLTAGE ON THE CAPACITORS.  DANGEROUS VOLTAGE IS EXPOSED ON
ALL OF THE CIRCUIT BOARDS AND CAPACITOR CONNECTIONS.
1.
Refer to Dwg. 192500-000 .  Remove the three screws, Item #3, near the upper end of the top
sub.
2.
Refer to Dwg. 192547-000 .  Using the T-handle pulling tool, p/n 056036-000, carefully pull
the upper connector block, Item #1, far enough out of the top sub to expose o-ring, Item #2.
Remove the o-ring.
3.
Refer to Dwg. 192500-000.  Remove the upper sub, Item #5.
CAUTION
IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT TWO PEOPLE HANDLE THE
CARTRIDGE WHEN NOT IN THE PRESSURE HOUSING.  THE 3212 PA
HAS A SHORT ALUMINUM CHASSIS AT THE TOP OF THE TOOL.  THE
CHASSIS IS JOINED TO A LONG FIBERGLASS COVERED CAPACITOR
ARRAY SECTION BY A NUT ON A THREADED THIN WALL TUBE AT
THE TOP OF THE CAPACITOR MANDREL. THIS JOINT IS
STRUCTURALLY WEAK.
DO NOT ALLOW THE CARTRIDGE TO BEND - ESPECIALLY AFTER
THE FIBERGLASS SLEEVE IS REMOVED.  OBSERVE THE
FOLLOWING PRECAUTIONS.  FAILURE TO DO SO WILL LIKELY
RESULT IN PHYSICAL DAMAGE TO THE CARTRIDGE.
4.
Refer to Dwg. 192547-000 .  Grasp the "snout" and only pull the cartridge far enough out of
the pressure housing to expose the Jumper Board (top-most circuit board), Item #14.

5.
Use a Fluke 87 (or equivalent) voltmeter to measure the DC voltage between E5 and E6 on
the Jumper Board.  Normally, this should be < 1 V.  If this condition is met, then it is safe to

3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
3.0  DISASSEMBLY   cont'd
WARNING
IT IS POSSIBLE FOR UP TO 600 VOLTS TO BE PRESENT AT THESE
POINTS.  IF GREATER THAN 10 V IS MEASURED BETWEEN E5 AND E6,
CAREFULLY DISCHARGE THE CAPACITOR ARRAY THROUGH A 2 K
OHM,  50 W RESISTOR (RECOMMENDED VALUE).  THIS CONDITION IS
NOT NORMAL - THE CAPACITOR ARRAY SHOULD NOT BE CHARGED
AT THIS TIME.  THE CAUSE OF FAILURE MUST BE DETERMINED.
CHECK R9 AND R10 ON THE OVP (OVER VOLTAGE PROTECTION)
CLIPPER BOARD , ITEM #15 (P/N 190376-000).

6.
When removing the cartridge from the pressure housing, keep the aluminum chassis as straight
as possible.  Do not pull at an angle as bending the cartridge may crack the top of the
fiberglass sleeve, Item #35.

7.
Once the fiberglass capacitor sleeve is sufficiently out of the pressure housing, support the
aluminum chassis section (we recommend obtaining assistance here).  Pull on the fiberglass
sleeve to complete the removal of the cartridge.
CAUTION
DO NOT LIFT OR CARRY A CARTRIDGE BY GRASPING ONLY THE
ENDS WHILE LEAVING THE CHASSIS-TO-CAPACITOR JOINT
UNSUPPORTED.  IF THIS IS DONE, THE FIBERGLASS SLEEVE MAY
SPLIT ALLOWING THE CARTRIDGE TO BREAK APART.
8.
Once the cartridge is out of the housing, place it in a tray, or carry it by the fiberglass section
with both hands while an assistant supports the upper aluminum chassis section to prevent
bending.
9.
To expose the capacitor modules, remove the eight screws, Item #32, securing the  fiberglass
sleeve, Item #35, to the chassis.  Using care not to bend the cartridge, the fiberglass sleeve

3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES

4.0  ASSEMBLY 4
1
3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
4.0  ASSEMBLY
1.
Reverse the procedure when returning the cartridge to the pressure housing. Insert the
fiberglass section in as far is possible while supporting the chassis section. Grasp the "snout"
and continue to push the cartridge in as straight as possible.
2.
Rotate the cartridge until the alignment pin mates with the hole in the lower end and complete
the insertion.
3.
Install the upper sub and o-ring on the upper connector block.
4.
Press the upper block into the upper sub.  Line up the mounting holes on the upper block and
install the screws.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures - 1.0 TOOLS REQUIRED 2.0 DRAWINGS REQUIRED
chunk_text:
1.0  TOOLS REQUIRED
056036-000
Tool, T-handle Pulling 1/4-20
Tools, Assorted Hand 2.0  DRAWINGS REQUIRED
192500-000
Instrument, 3212 PA Booster Sub
192547-000
Assembly, Electrical Wiring 3212 PA
2
3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES

1.0  TOOL DESCRIPTION 2
1.0  TOOL DESCRIPTION
Capacitor Array:  (Ref. dwg. #’s 192547-100 and 192498-000).  The capacitor array is made up of
1260 individual 220 FF/100 V wet-slug tantalum capacitors.  These capacitors are connected in a
series-parallel network of 36 modules with 35 capacitors each.
The capacitors in each module are wired in parallel.  Nine modules are wired in series to form a
string.  Four series strings are then wired in parallel to form an array.  The array has 3,500 FF of
capacitance and is rated for 600 V at 175 EC.  The capacitance of the array is nearly flat (+.024%/EC)
with temperature and DC voltage.
Capacitor Description:  The wet-slug tantalum capacitor is primarily used in high reliability and
harsh environmental applications (military, aerospace and downhole) where cheaper capacitor
technologies, such as aluminum electrolytic and solid tantalum, are inadequate.
Capacitor Failure Modes:  Capacitor failure can be generally divided into three types; excessive
loss or gain of capacitance, excessive leakage current, and physical failure.
The capacitance of wet-slug tantalum capacitors increases early in life, then slowly decreases late in
life.  Similarly, their insulation leakage currents decrease early in life and slowly increase late in life.
Insulation leakage currents also increase with temperature.
These capacitors are virtually immune to internal short-circuit failure.  Their most common problem is
seal or case failure usually caused by excessive AC ripple current, which causes self-heating, or
mechanical damage of the seal from mishandling during assembly.
The AC ripple current seen by each capacitor is very low (<3.3mA RMS in a 880mA at 1kHz rated
capacitor) in this tool.
The leads on these capacitors are bent on a special bending jig to minimize stress on the seals and
weld joints.
WARNING
THE WET-SLUG TANTALUM CONTAINS A LIQUID, ACIDIC ELECTROLYTE
WHICH IS POISONOUS AND CORROSIVE.  THE CAPACITORS ARE
ENCAPSULATED IN THE MODULES TO CONTAIN THE ELECTROLYTE
SHOULD A LEAK DEVELOP.
Service Life:  Below 85 EC, wet-slug tantalum capacitors have a service life of 10 to 20 years.  At
higher temperatures, their life gets shorter.  The capacitor manufacturers claim lifetimes of 300 to 900
hours continuous duty at 175 EC.  One of the manufacturers states that the tantalum case of the
capacitor can become brittle and crack after 900 hours at 175 EC.  Since this tool is only rated for
150 EC, such embrittlement should be of little concern as tantalum is inert at temperatures below

3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES
1.0  TOOL DESCRIPTION   cont'd
Loss of electrolyte will cause a capacitor to become an open circuit.  If electrolyte leaks from the
encapsulated modules into the interior of the tool, corrosion and insulation leakage problems will
result.
Life testing shows only a slight increase in capacitance (.042% for Mallory THD220) and a decrease
(-53.5% for Mallory THD220) in leakage current after 320 hours of simulated NMR service at 175 EC
with no failures.  The operational lifetime of the capacitors should be at least 1500 hours of NMR
logging operation.
Maintenance:  Perform the leakage tests listed in this document and record the results.  If an abrupt
decrease in capacitance or increase in leakage current (> -3% for capacitance and > +20% for
leakage) is observed, inspect the capacitor modules and wiring for signs of physical damage.  If none
is found, then determine which of the four banks of modules is the source of the problem.  Next,
locate the defective module.
Replacement modules are available in groups of nine (192498-500).  If a module is defective, all of
the modules in that series string should be replaced as a group.  The failure of one module will
possibly over-stress the other modules in the same series string.
A series string of modules forms a voltage divider.  Modules with capacitors from  different
manufacturers, or even manufacturing lot numbers, will have different characteristics.  This
will cause an uneven division of voltage across the modules and cause poor reliability.
All of the 3212 PA tools (to date) have been assembled with either Tansitor or Mallory capacitors.  In
either case, only one vendor’s capacitors have been used in a tool.  This was primarily done to insure
that all capacitors within each series string have similar capacitance, leakage current and aging
characteristics.
Tansitor and Mallory capacitors may be used in the same tool, ONLY if all the capacitors in a
series string are from the same vendor, and preferably from the same lot.
To determine which vendor’s capacitors are in a given module, inspect the glass seals around the wire
at the positive end of the module.  The letter “P” is machined into the top of the positive end of each
module.  The glass seal (.14 in. dia.) on the Mallory caps is noticeably smaller in diameter than the
glass seal (.19 in. dia.) on the Tansitor caps.
Periodically inspect the capacitor module wiring in the slot in the sides of the modules, as listed in the
LEVEL 3 MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES  (130766-953).  Look for signs of charred insulation or
vaporized wires.  Be certain the capacitor module wire slot is kept clean and free of metal fragments
and other conductive debris.
A short circuit in this area can cause wires to vaporize and char insulation!
The capacitors are very well protected and conservatively rated for any well logging job that is within
the temperature specifications of the NMR tool.  As a result, they should have a long lifetime.
4
3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES

2.0  CAPACITOR ARRAY TEST 4
2.0  CAPACITOR ARRAY TEST
Check the capacitor array between jobs for leakage and capacitance value using the following
procedure. 2.1  EQUIPMENT REQUIRED 4
2.1  EQUIPMENT REQUIRED
!
Two Fluke 87 meters (P/N 245130-000)
!
2010 (or 2085) power supply
!
CR50 capacitance meter (P/N 243073-000)
!
3212 PA leakage test cable (P/N 193685-000)

topic: % Repair/Maintenance Procedures - 2.2 CAPACITOR ARRAY TEST PROCEDURE . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 4
chunk_text:
2.2  CAPACITOR ARRAY TEST PROCEDURE 4
2.2  CAPACITOR ARRAY TEST PROCEDURE
NOTE:
Vmax for this test: 600 V.
1.
Remove just enough of the tool from the housing to expose the Jumper board.  Please refer to
the 130766-955 ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY procedures.
2.
Set both Plug boards (190378-000) to the "OFF" position by unplugging them (if necessary)
and rotating them until the word "OFF" is upright and beneath the function names on the
Jumper board (190377-000).  Then re-seat the Plug boards in the "OFF" position.
3.
Connect the equipment as shown in Figure 1.  DMM1 is in mA current mode and DMM2 is
in VDC mode.
4.
Make sure the 2010 high voltage is off.
5.
Turn on the AC POWER switch on the 2010.  The VOLTS control pot on the 2010 (or
2085) must be set  to zero (fully CCW), or the high voltage will not come on.   Push the red
HV ON button to turn the high-voltage on.  Slowly advance the VOLTS pot while watching
the CURRENT display on the 2010 and the two DMMs.  Note, the CURRENT pot must be
set to maximum (fully CW).
6.
DMM2 should show a rising voltage and the current shown in DMM1 should remain low
(<.30 A; it will go higher if the VOLTS pot is advanced too rapidly).  DMM1 should go to
near zero when advancing of theVOLTS pot is stopped.  If these conditions are met, continue

3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES
2.2  CAPACITOR ARRAY TEST PROCEDURE   cont'd
7.
Continue advancing the VOLTS pot until DMM2 reaches 600 V.  The current shown by
DMM1 should continue to decrease as the capacitor array charges.  Switch DMM1 to the µA
scale as needed.  After several minutes the leakage current should fall below 140µA.  It will
be necessary to temporarily disconnect DMM2 to get this result.  If the leakage current fails
to fall to at least 140µA (allow at least 10 min.), a leakage failure in the capacitor array may
exist.  Record the final leakage value.  Change DMM1 to the Amps position and reconnect
DMM2.
8.
Turn the VOLTS pot down to zero.  Then push the green HV OFF button to turn off the high
voltage.  After DMM2 is below 1 V, turn the 2010 power supply AC POWER switch off.
Then short-out the capacitor array by connecting a jumper wire from E5 to E6 on the Jumper
board.
9.
Remove the jumper wire between E5 and E6.  Use the CR50 capacitance meter to measure
the capacitance of the capacitor array.  Please observe polarity.  The positive lead (red) from
the CR50 is connected to E5 on the Jumper board.  The negative lead (black) is connected to
E6.  The capacitance meter should read between 3.40mF (milli Farad) and 3.8mF.
Disconnect the CR50 and record the capacitance value.
10.
Set the Capacitor Charger Conn.  Plug board to the "ON" position.  The Tandem Capacitor
Cartridge Plug board should stay in the "OFF" position.  Push the tool back into the housing
and close it up.  Please refer to 130766-955 ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES.
6
3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES
2.2  CAPACITOR ARRAY TEST PROCEDURE   cont'd
7
3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES
2.2  CAPACITOR ARRAY TEST PROCEDURE   cont'd
8
3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES

3.0  CHARGER TESTS 8
3.0  CHARGER TESTS
If the 3212 PA Field Test Box (192230-000) is available, the following additional test should be
performed.  It is intended that the tool be in the housing for these tests.

3.1  EQUIPMENT REQUIRED 8
3.1  EQUIPMENT REQUIRED
!
Series 2010 (a 2085 may be used, if a 2010 is not available) power supply
!
ECLIPS System
!
A 3514 Common Remote
!
A 7-Conductor wireline that is typical for your base to use in the field
!
Field Test box for series 3212 PA & 3213 QB NMR (192230-000).  Make sure the batteries
are good .
!
Two Fluke Digital Multimeters Model 87 (245130-000) or equivalent, with standard meter
leads and "grabber" leads.  Make sure the batteries are good.

3.2  CHARGER TEST PROCEDURE 8
%
1
3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES
REPAIR/MAINTENANCE OVERVIEW
SAFETY WARNING
THIS TOOL OPERATES AT DANGEROUS VOLTAGE (600 TO 900 V)! THIS TOOL
CAN ALSO STORE A DANGEROUS AMOUNT OF ELECTRICAL ENERGY (630 J)!
AVOID TOUCHING ANY OF THE CONTACTS ON EITHER THE TOP OR BOTTOM OF
THIS TOOL WITH BARE HANDS OR FINGERS UNLESS SURE THAT THE
CAPACITORS ARE DISCHARGED (CHECK IT WITH A METER).  ALWAYS ASSUME
THAT THIS TOOL MAY RETAIN AN ELECTRICAL CHARGE.
CAUTION SHOULD BE USED WHEN TESTING THE TOOL OUTSIDE OF ITS
HOUSING, OR WHEN WORKING ON IT.  THE CAPACITOR ARRAY IS NORMALLY
PROTECTED BY A INSULATING FIBERGLASS SLEEVE.  HOWEVER, DANGEROUS
VOLTAGE IS EXPOSED ON ALL OF THE CIRCUIT BOARDS!  THEREFORE, POWER-
DOWN THE TOOL (VERIFY IT WITH A METER BY CHECKING THE VOLTAGE
BETWEEN E5 AND E6 ON THE JUMPER BOARD LOCATED NEAR THE TOP OF THE
TOOL), BEFORE TOUCHING ANY COMPONENT OR TERMINAL ON THE CIRCUIT
BOARDS OR CHASSIS MOUNTED COMPONENTS.
The level one maintenance procedures are intended to observe and catch deficiencies in the 3212 PA
before they cause a serious problem.
Perform the FIT test before and after logging jobs.
Observe the hvmin and hvmax values from the NMR 3206 ED tool during logging operation. Does
hvmax exceed 610 V?  (Remember: the meter in the 3206 ED is not very accurate).  If so, the charger

3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES
3.2  CHARGER TEST PROCEDURE
1.
Test the 3212 PA Field Test box (192230-000) by itself using the following test procedure:
Test the batteries by using a Fluke 87 DMM to measure the battery voltage between the
following test points (the positive DMM lead is always connected to the first test point listed
in each step):
!
B1+ to HV-: 7.0 V min.
!
B2+ to ARMOR: 7.0 V min.
2.
Test the power MOSFETs by measuring the resistance between the specified test points with
a DMM and actuating the specified switch.
!
HV+ to HV-: Resistance. = 988k - 1.008m.  Push the DISCHARGE switch.
%
Resistance = 600 S ± 10 S.
!
HV+ to ARMOR: Resistance. =494k - 504k.  Push the SHORT switch to the HV+
%
position.  Resistance. = <2.0 S.
!
ARMOR to HV-: Resistance. = 494k - 504k.  Push the SHORT switch to the HV-
%
position.  Resistance. = <2.0 S.
9
3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES
3.2  CHARGER TEST PROCEDURE   cont'd
3.
Connect the Common Remote to the top end of the 3212 PA tool, and connect the Field Test
box  to the bottom end of the tool.  The common Remote is to be connected to an ECLIPS
system via a 7-conductor wireline.
4.
Connect one of the Fluke 87s (DMM1 in DC mA mode) across the CURRENT test jacks on
the test box.  Connect the other Fluke 87 (DMM2 in DC V mode) across the HV+ and HV-
test jacks.
5.
Make sure that the Capacitor Charger Conn. Plug board is in the “ON” position and that the
Tandem Capacitor Cartridge Plug board is in the “OFF” position.
6.
Turn on the AC POWER switch on the 2010.  The VOLTS control pot on the 2010 must
be set  to zero (fully CCW), or the high voltage will not come on.  Push the red HV ON
button to turn the high-voltage on.  Slowly advance the VOLTS pot while watching the two
DMMs.  NOTE: the CURRENT pot must be set to maximum (fully CW).
7.
DMM2 should show a rising voltage and the current shown in DMM1 should remain low
(<.30 A; it will go higher if the VOLTS pot is advanced too rapidly).  DMM1 should go to
near zero when you stop advancing the VOLTS pot.  If these conditions are met, continue
advancing the VOLTS pot while watching the DMMs.
8.
Continue advancing the VOLTS pot until DC+ to DC- is set to 620 V (connect DMM2 to
DC+ & DC-to measure this).
9.
HV+ to HV- should stop advancing and stay fixed at 600 V ± 2 V (reconnect DMM2 to
%
HV+ & HV-).
10.
Advance the VOLTS pot again until DC+ to DC- is set to 700 V (connect DMM2 to DC+
& DC-to measure this).
11.
DMM1 should show an idle current between 7.0mA and 8.0mA and DMM2 should be
%
between 598 V and 602 V.
%
12.
Use DMM2 to verify that the voltage between HV+ and ARMOR is within 6 V of the
voltage from ARMOR to HV-.
13.
Set DMM1 to the DC A mode and enable record mode to catch the peak current. Briefly
(about 3 sec.) push the DISCHARGE button on the test box a few times. The following
%
conditions should be observed:
!
DMM2 should fall to about 515 V (affected by wireline length), then return to 600 V
%
±2 V.
%
!
DMM1 should show a maximum current of about 860mA (affected by wireline
%

3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES
3.2  CHARGER TEST PROCEDURE   cont'd
14.
Set DMM1 to record mode to capture the peak tool input current.  Push and hold the
SHORT switch to the HV+ position for about five seconds.
Verify the following:
!
HV+ to HV- as shown on DMM2 will immediately start falling, and continue to
fall toward zero.
!
DMM1 should capture a peak current between 600mA and 800mA (affected by
%
wireline length).
15.
Now, turn the VOLTS pot toward zero.  When DC+ to DC- is about 75 V to 125 V, the
relays will close again.
16.
Power up the tool again and repeat steps 14 and 15.  Exception in step 14; push and hold the
SHORT switch to the HV- position for about five seconds.
17.
Turn the VOLTS pot down to zero.  Push and hold the DISCHARGE button on the test
box down.  After HV+ to HV- falls to about 20 V, push the green HV OFF button to turn
off the high voltage (This is the preferred power-down procedure.)
18.
Remove DMM1.  Turn on the ECLIPS TOOL AC power supply and set it to 180 VAC
(measure at the 3514 sub).
%
!
DMM2 should rise to 100 V ±10 V after a few minutes.  This tests the 5% charger
%
on the OVP Clipper board (190376-000).
!
Turn off the tool AC power supply.  Push the DISCHARGE button until the
DMM2 drops to < 10 V.
19.
Remove the DMMs and remove the test box from the tool.
If all of these tests are good, the tool passes the Level 1 test.  Otherwise, find and correct the
problem.

topic: % Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 1.0 OPERATOR SAFETY NOTES . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1
chunk_text:
1.0  OPERATOR SAFETY NOTES 1
1.0  OPERATOR SAFETY NOTES
The 3212 PA NMR Capacitor & Charger operates at high input (up to 900 V) and output (up to
600 V) voltages.  These voltages are present on the circuit boards.  The charger has a 3µF capacitor
on the back-side of the spine that in normal operation can be charged as high as 900 V, and the
3,500µF (3.5mF) capacitor array is normally charged to 600 V.  These capacitors can hold a charge
for 90 minutes if the standard power-down procedure described in this document is not followed.

2.0  EQUIPMENT REQUIRED 1
2.0  EQUIPMENT REQUIRED
1.
Series 2010 (a 2085 may be used if a 2010 is not available) power supply.
2.
ECLIPS System.
3.
A 3514 Common Remote.
4.
A 7-Conductor wireline that is typical for your base to use in field operations.
5.
Field Test box for series 3212 PA & 3213 QB NMR (192230-000).  Make sure the batteries
are good .
6.
One, 32-pin pressure bulkhead (Ref. Drawing 145245-000...not included in manual).
%
7.
Two Fluke Digital Multimeters Model 87 (245130-000) or equivalent, with standard meter
leads and "grabber" leads.  Make sure the batteries are good.
8.
Resistance decade box, such as an OHMITE OHM-RANGER or IET Labs RS-200 (only if
recalibration is required).
9.
One clip lead.
10.
Capacitance meter: Wavetek CR50 (243073-000).
2
3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE

3.0  PRELIMINARY STEPS 2
%
3.0  PRELIMINARY STEPS

Remove tool from housing using the procedure listed in 130766-955.

Perform the capacitor array tests listed in 130766-956.

Inspect the cases of R8, R9, R20 and R21 on the Main board (190375-000) for cracks, loose
epoxy end-caps and poor epoxy-to-wire seals.

Inspect the wiring slot in the sides of the capacitor modules.  Look for signs of charred
insulation or vaporized wires.  Be certain that the wiring slot in the modules is kept clean of
metal fragments and conductive debris.  A short circuit in this area can cause wires to
vaporize and char insulation!
3.4.1
Test the 3212 PA Field Test box (192230-000) by itself using the following test
procedure: Test the batteries by using a Fluke 87 DMM to measure the battery
voltage between the following test points:
!
B1+ (TP8)  to HV- (TP7): 7.0 V min.
!
B2+ (TP9)  to ARMOR (TP6): 7.0 V min.
3.4.2
Test the power MOSFETs by measuring the resistance between the specified test
points with a DMM and actuating the specified switch.
!
HV+ (TP5) to HV- (TP7): Resistance. = 988k - 1.008m.  Push
%
DISCHARGE switch. Resistance. =  600 S  ± 10 S.
!
HV+ (TP5) to ARMOR (TP6): Resistance. = 494k - 504k.  Push the
%
SHORT switch to the HV+ position. Resistance. =  <2.0 S.
!
ARMOR (TP6) to HV- (TP7): Resistance. = 494k - 504k.  Push the
%
SHORT switch to the HV- position. Resistance. =  <2.0 S.
3
3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE

4.0  STATIC TESTS 3
%
4.0  STATIC TESTS

Connect the Common Remote to the top end of the 3212 PA tool, and connect the Field Test
box to the bottom end of the tool.  The common Remote is to be connected to an ECLIPS
system via a 7-conductor wireline.

Connect one of the Fluke 87s (DMM1 in DC mA mode) across the CURRENT test jacks on
the test box.  Connect the other Fluke 87 (DMM2 in DC V mode) across the HV+ and HV-
test jacks.

Make sure that the Capacitor Charger Conn. Plug board is in the “ON” position and that the
Tandem Capacitor Cartridge Plug board is in the “OFF” position.

Turn on the AC POWER switch on the 2010. The VOLTS control pot on the 2010 must be
set  to zero (fully CCW), or the high voltage will not come on.  Push the red HV ON button
to turn the high-voltage on.  Slowly advance the VOLTS pot while watching the two
DMMs.  Note, the CURRENT pot must be set to maximum (fully CW).

DMM2 should show a rising voltage and the current shown in DMM1 should remain low
(<.30 A; it will go higher if the VOLTS pot is advanced too rapidly).  DMM1 should go to
near zero when you stop advancing the VOLTS pot.  If these conditions are met, continue
advancing the VOLTS pot while watching the meters.

Continue advancing the VOLTS pot until DC+ to DC- is set to 620 V.

HV+ to HV- should stop advancing and stay fixed at 600 V ± 2 V.
%

Advance the VOLTS pot again until DC+ to DC- is set to 700 V.
4.8.1
DMM1 should show an idle current between 7.0mA and 8.0mA and DMM2 should
%
be between 598 V and 602 V.
%
4.8.2
Use DMM2 to verify that the voltage between HV+ and ARMOR is within 6 V of
the voltage from ARMOR to HV-.

Use DMM2 to measure the following voltages on the Main board (DMM2 negative lead on
E2 on the Main board unless otherwise specified):
+8.2_OV @ R3 = 7.70 V to 8.60 V (8.2 V nominal)
+8.2_CH @ R11 = 7.70 V to 8.60 V (8.2 V nominal)
5 V_OV @ A2 pin 4 = 4.99 V to 5.01 V
5 V_CH @ TP1 = 4.99 V to 5.01 V
Q1 gate = 0 V to .01 V
Q3 gate = 2.50 V to 2.90 V (2.74 V nominal)
E15 to E24 = 8.55 V to 9.45 V (9.0 V nominal)
E25 to E26 = 3.10 V to 4.00 V (3.5 V nominal)
If all of these tests are good, proceed to the next paragraph. Otherwise, find and correct the

3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE
4.0  STATIC TESTS   cont'd

Set DMM1 to the DC A mode and enable record mode to catch the peak current. Briefly
(about 3 sec.) push the DISCHARGE button on the test box a few times. The following
%
conditions should be observed:
!
DMM2 should fall to about 516 V (affected by wireline length), then return to 600 V
%
±2 V.
%
!
DMM1 should show a maximum current of 880mA (affected by wireline length).
%

Turn the VOLTS pot down to zero.  Push and hold the DISCHARGE button on the test
box down.  After HV+ to HV- falls to about 20 V, push the green HV OFF button to turn
off the high voltage (this is the preferred power-down procedure.)

After HV+ to HV- has fallen to near zero, feel all of the components.  Some of the large
resistors will be slightly warm to the touch, but none of the components should be too hot to
touch comfortably.  If a component is hot, find out why.

Temporarily remove the test box from the bottom of the 3212 PA.  Connect DMM2 across
E5 and E6 of the Jumper board (190377-000).
4.13.1
Turn on the ECLIPS TOOL AC power supply and set it to 180 VAC (measure at the
%
3514 sub).
%

DMM2 should rise to 100 V ±10 V after a few minutes.  This tests the 5% charger
%
on the OVP Clipper board (190376-000).
4.13.3
Turn off the AC power supply.  Reconnect the test box to the bottom of the
3212 PA, and push the DISCHARGE button until the DMM2 drops to near zero

topic: % Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 5.0 OVERVOLTAGE PROTECTION TEST . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 5
chunk_text:
5.0  OVERVOLTAGE PROTECTION TEST 5
5.0  OVERVOLTAGE PROTECTION TEST

Place a jumper wire from E24 to E26 on the Main board.  This will short-out the pass
transistor array and disable the charging control circuit.  Reconnect DMM1 and DMM2 to
the test box.

Turn on the 2010, as before, and increase the DC+ to DC- voltage to about 590 V.

Now, slowly advance the VOLTS pot while watching HV+ to HV- on DMM2. Somewhere
between 628 V and 631 V the OVP circuit should trip and turn on the relays K1 and K2 (you
should hear the click).  If it does not open before 633 V, there is a problem that will either
require repair or recalibration.
5.3.1
Verify the following, at the trip point:
!
HV+ to HV- shown on DMM2 will immediately start falling all the way to
zero.
!
DMM1 should show 20mA to 30mA. (25mA nominal)

Now, turn the VOLTS pot toward zero.  When DC+ to DC- is about 75 V to 125 V, the
relays will close again.

Repeat this test a few times to verify the repeatability of the OVP trip point.

Power down the charger and turn off the 2010 power supply and remove the jumper from
E24 to E26 after successfully completing the test.  Otherwise, identify and correct the error.
6
3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE

topic: % Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 6.0 PASS-TRANSISTOR ARRAY CURRENT BALANCE . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 6
chunk_text:
6.0  PASS-TRANSISTOR ARRAY CURRENT BALANCE 6
%
6.0  PASS-TRANSISTOR ARRAY CURRENT BALANCE
During this test, you will be using DMM2 to measure the voltage across the source resistors (1.5 S
WW) in the pass-transistor array.  For best accuracy, make these measurements directly across each
one of the source resistors (R26 on the Main board and R5 - R8 on the Pass-Transistor board).  You
will use DMM1 to measure the total tool current.  The back of the test box should be near room
%
temperature (not hot) before starting this test.
%

Make sure the 2010 high voltage is off.

2010 Vmax for this test: 620 V
%

Turn on the 2010 and advance the VOLTS pot until DC+ to DC- equals 620 V.
%

Carefully connect DMM2 directly across source resistor R26.  Hold down the
DISCHARGE button until the voltage across R26 stabilizes.  Then, record the voltage.

Repeat the measurement for the other source resistors.  Calculate the source current by
dividing each voltage by 1.5 S.  The sum of the source currents should be within ±5% of the
steady-state "on" current, shown on DMM1.  If the back of the text box is too warm to
%
touch, allow it to cool before continuing.
%

The current in (voltage across) each source resistor should be within ±5% of the average
source current (voltage drop).  If these conditions are not met, find and correct the problem.


3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE

7.0  OVP CLIPPER TEST 7
%
7.0  OVP CLIPPER TEST

Make sure the 2010 high voltage is off.

2010 Vmax for this test: 700 V

Advance the VOLTS pot until DC+ to DC- is 700 V.

Set DMM1 to record mode to capture the peak tool input current.  Push and hold the
SHORT switch to the HV+ position for about five seconds.

Verify the following:
!
HV+ to HV- as shown on DMM2 will immediately start falling, and continue to
fall toward zero.
!
DMM1 should capture a peak current between 600mA and 800mA (affected by
%
wireline length).

Now, turn the VOLTS pot toward zero.  When DC+ to DC- is about 75 V to 125 V. the
relays will close again.

Repeat steps 7.2 through 7.6.  However, when performing step 7.4 on this repetition, push
and hold the SHORT switch to the HV- position for about five seconds (instead of the HV+
position).

If no problems are observed, power down the tool.

%
1
3212 PA NMR CAP/CHARGER -- LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE
8.0  CALIBRATION
This step should only be required if reference components (A1, A3, R8 - R10 or R20 - R22 on the Main
board) have been replaced.  Have the resistor substitution box and the following RN55 D resistors
available for R10 and R22.  Remove the old R10 before calibrating OVP circuit, and remove the old
R22 before calibrating charger circuit.
R10: 100k, 124k, 127k, 130k, 133k, 137k & 140k
R22: 140k, 143k, 147k & 150k.
8.1 Make sure the 2010 high voltage is off.
8.2 2010 Vmax for this test: 700 V
8.2.1
First, calibrate the OVP circuit (if required).  Place a jumper wire from E24 to E26 on the
Main board, and set the resistor substitution box to 133kS, and connect it between E11 and
E12 on the Main board.  Advance the VOLTS pot until the relay opens (do not go above
640 V); notice the highest value of the HV+ to HV- voltage.  If the trip point is below 630 V,
decrease the resistor box setting using standard 1% resistor values.  If the trip point is above
630 V, increase the resistor box setting.  If the voltage is between 629 V and 630 V, measure
the resistor box value and clip-lead the nearest value resistor between E11 and E12.
8.2.2
Verify the trip-point with the new resistor and power down the tool.  Solder it in place,
power up, and verify it again.
8.2.3
Power down and remove the clip lead between E24 and E26.
8.3 Next, calibrate the charger control circuit (if required).  Set the resistor substitution box to 143kS,
and connect it between E19 and E20 on the Main board.  Advance the VOLTS pot until DC+ to
DC- is 700 V.  Adjust the resistor substitution box until HV+ to HV- equals 600 V.  To get the best
resistor value, find and note the resistor box settings for 599 V and 601 V.  Then set the resistor box
to the value half way in between the 599 V and 601 V values (DMM2 should show 600 V).
Remember, decrease the resistance to raise the output voltage.
Power down the tool.  Remove the resistor box and measure its value and clip-lead the nearest value
%
resistor between E19 and E20.  Power up the tool.
%
8.4 Push the DISCHARGE button a few times and verify that the HV+ to HV- returns to 600 V.  Power
down the tool and solder the resistor in place.  Power up the tool and verify the reading.
8.5 The calibration procedure is now complete.

1.0  OVERVIEW
The 3213 QB was designed and built to provide faster charging rate to one or two MRIL 3206 PA
Energy Storage Sections.
The 3213 QB Capacitor Charger was designed primarily to provide a fast capacitor charging circuit
necessary for newly introduced logging programs with additional energy requirements for the MRIL
service.  This capability is needed when recording long echo trains (carbonate logging) and when
logging in low Q boreholes (salt based muds).

THEY BE REVIEWED AND MADE KNOWN TO ALL PERSONS IN CLOSE PROXIMITY

IN ORDER TO PREVENT PERSONAL INJURY AND/OR EQUIPMENT DAMAGE, IT IS
ALSO IMPORTANT THAT ONLY TRAINED PERSONNEL OPERATE AND/OR
MAINTAIN THIS TOOL.

3206 MRIL Manuals as "CAUTION" items because with their occurrence they can present a human

3213 QB in MRIL Tool String:
!
The magnet will permanently loose all magnetism at wellsite/transportation temperatures at or
below -20 CE (-4 EF).  This is an immediate-action occurrence with no graduation affects.
The magnetism will not return as the temperature warms above -20 EC (-4 EF).  It will need to
be re-characterized at the NUMAR facilities.
!
Persons who wear cardiac pacemakers, have ferro-metal particularly or any other metal type
in/on their bodies MUST NOT BE NEAR the MRIL Tool due to its potentially hazardous
effects from the permanent magnetic field and/or from accidental RF radiation exposure.
Mechanical wrist watches also can be affected by the magnetic field.
!
Remove all magnetic retention media such as credit cards/bank cards, computer discs, logging
tapes, CRTs and other analyzer screens, from close proximity to the Antenna /Magnet probe.
The Probes magnetic field will alter these magnetized media devices.
!
Do not transport other logging tools with the Antenna/Magnet Probe.  Any orientation tools
must be kept at least 10 ft (3 m) from the Antenna/Magnet Probe.  Keep all instruments with
photo-multiplier tubes at least 12 feet (3.6 m) from the magnet probe.  The Probe's magnets
will change the alignment of the plates in a PM-tube causing the output to change and the
discriminator to need adjustment and the tools' re-calibration.  Tool housings in close


TRANSPORTATION AND HANDLING   cont'd
!
Never attempt to stop a Antenna/Magnet Probe from being drawn magnetically towards a
metal wall, floor, or drill pipe.  The Probe can very forcefully roll or move towards the metal
surface without personnel being able to stop it.  Persons close to the tool must be warned of
the hazards of having a hand, arm, or foot caught between the metal wall, floor, or pipe and
the Antenna/Magnet Probe.
!
Thread protectors must be installed when lifting or transporting the tool sections.  Use of a
crane, hoist, or other mechanical device is required to lift the instrument.  The 3206 MRIL
Tool/Antenna/Magnet Probe weighs about 1900 lb (860 kg) when this cartridge is in its
transport case.  The tool, when fully assembled, weighs over 1100 lbs (408 kg) with 45% of
this weight at the Antenna/Magnet Probe.
!
The 3207/8 MB magnet and the 3206 ED, 3212 PA (or 3206 PA) must be lifted and transported
separately or tool damage can occur.  When shipping by commercial aircraft, the 3207/8 MB
magnet must be shipped inside its transport container to conform to IATA shipping
regulations for magnetic devices.  This container is very heavy ( . 1350 lbs/613 kg) and will
require special handling.

to the tool.

zero.  Tool damage is very likely to be the result.
!
Never power up the transmitter if the tool gain is less than 75.  Powering up the transmitter
before performing a frequency sweep can cause damage due to off-frequency operation.

1.0  CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
SAFETY WARNING
THE 3213 QB OPERATES AT DANGEROUS VOLTAGE (600 TO 900 V)!  THIS TOOL,
WHEN COMBINED WITH A 3206 PA, CAN ALSO STORE A DANGEROUS AMOUNT OF
ELECTRICAL ENERGY (310 J)!  TO INSURE THAT THE TOOL IS FULLY
DISCHARGED AFTER A LOGGING RUN, ALWAYS USE THE FOLLOWING
PROCEDURE:
AFTER NMR DATA ACQUISITION IS COMPLETE, TURN THE SURFACE DC+/DC-
POWER SUPPLY (2010 OR 2085) DOWN TO ZERO WHILE THE NMR TRANSMITTER IS
FIRING.  THEN TURN OFF THE HV RELAY IN THE 3206 ED VIA THE ECLIPS
SYSTEM.  NEXT, TURN OFF THE DC+/DC- POWER SUPPLY, UNLESS IT IS NEEDED
BY ANOTHER TOOL.
CAUTION SHOULD BE USED WHEN TESTING THE TOOL OUTSIDE OF ITS
HOUSING, OR WHEN WORKING ON IT.   DANGEROUS VOLTAGE IS EXPOSED ON
ALL OF THE CIRCUIT BOARDS!  THEREFORE, POWER-DOWN THE TOOL (VERIFY
IT WITH A METER BY CHECKING THE VOLTAGE BETWEEN E1 AND E2 ON THE
MAIN BOARD LOCATED NEAR THE TOP OF THE TOOL)  BEFORE TOUCHING ANY
COMPONENT OR TERMINAL ON THE CIRCUIT BOARDS OR CHASSIS MOUNTED
COMPONENTS.
INTRODUCTION
The primary reason for using this capacitor charger tool is to provide more power to the NMR tool, so
that it can produce more echoes in each echo train.  This requirement is typical of total-porosity
logging.  This is accomplished by charging the capacitor cartridge from a power supply that may be up
to 300 V higher than the 600 V specified NMR Vmax.  By using a higher supply voltage, the capacitor-
charging is always done on the faster part of the RC exponential curve.  The 3213 QB is compatible
with true-mode 7 telemetry.  It can also be used in tool strings with RCI and other tools.  The 3213 QB

3213 QB NMR CAP CHARGER -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
1.0  CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION   cont'd
The capacitor charger tool has two principal circuit functions:
!
The first function is to control the charging of the capacitor cartridge.
!
The second function is to protect the capacitor cartridge and the NMR transmitter from
overvoltage. The most likely cause of overvoltage is the failure of some component in the
charging control circuit. For this reason, the overvoltage protection (OVP) and the charging
control circuits share no components.
The OVP circuit is designed to disconnect the charging control circuit from its power source if the
capacitor cartridge voltage rises above 630 V.  The charging circuit will remain disconnected until the
surface high-voltage power supply is reduced to about 75 V.  The OVP circuit will also discharge the
capacitor cartridge, after it has been tripped.
Detailed Circuit Description: (See the 3213 QB block diagram for an overall view of tool)
Input protection: (See Main board drawing P/N 188353-100).  Both the OVP and charging control
circuits have diodes (D1-D4, D19, & D20) that protect both circuits from possible application of
reverse polarity power.
Overvoltage Protection Circuit: (See Main board drawing P/N 188353-100).  The OVP circuit
contains a +8.2 V zener voltage regulator (R3 & D5), a +5 V precision voltage reference (A1) and a
comparator (A2a).  It also has two relays (K1 & K2) driven by a power MOSFET (Q1).
The comparator (A2a) compares the output of the voltage reference (5 V_OV) to OVSEN.  OVSEN is
the charger’s output, after it has been attenuated by the voltage divider formed by R8, R9 and R10.
When the signal OVSEN rises above 5 V_OV, the comparator turns on Q1.  Q1 energizes the OVP
relays (K1 & K2).  The relays are wired such that they latch in the "on" position.  Thus, they will stay
on after Q1 turns off.  Notice that when Q1 is "off" it will have the full DC+ to DC- line voltage
across it (this may be as high as 900 V).  The capacitor cartridge is discharged through R1 after the
OVP relays have been turned on.  Diodes D7 and D8 limit the relay coil voltages and provide an
alternate current path in case one of the relay coils is "open."
3
3213 QB NMR CAP CHARGER -- CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
1.0  CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION   cont'd
Charging Control Circuit: (See Main board drawing P/N 188353-100 and Pass Transistor Array
board drawing P/N 188352-100).  The charging control circuit contains a +8.2 V zener voltage
regulator (R11 & D10), a +5 V precision voltage reference (A3), and a control loop amplifier (A4 &
Q3).  It also has a power zener equivalent circuit (D11, D12, R14, R15 & Q2) and an array of
MOSFET pass-transistors (Q4 on the Main board & Q1 - Q4 on the Pass-Transistor board).
The control loop amplifier tries to keep the output (HV+ to HV-) at 600 V. It does this by comparing
the signal 5 V_CH from the precision voltage reference to HVSEN.  HVSEN is the charger’s output,
after it has been attenuated by the voltage divider formed by R20-R22.  The control op-amp (A4)
drives a power MOSFET (Q3) that is the bottom leg of the voltage divider formed by R16, R18 and
Q3.  The gate control signal (QVGR) for the pass-transistor array is produced at the junction of R16
and R18.
Maximum pass-transistor Vgs drive voltage is produced when Q3 is "off."  When Q3 is fully "on," the
Vgs drive voltage of the pass-transistor array is near zero.  Zener diode D14 limits the Vgs range of
QVGR to a maximum of +10 V and a minimum of -.6 V.  The power zener circuit (D11, D12, R14, R15
& Q2) insures that the pass-transistor array always receives at least +8.5 V of Vgs drive as needed for
full enhancement of the power MOSFETs.
In normal operation, the pass-transistor array is fully "on" while the capacitor cartridge is being
charged.  After the capacitor cartridge is fully charged to 600 V, the control op-amp lowers the Vgs of
the pass-transistor array to about 3.3 V.  This allows just enough current to go through the pass-
transistor array to maintain 600 V across the capacitor cartridge.  Resistor R19 stabilizes the charging
controller by providing some isolation between the charging controller and the capacitor cartridge.
Balance  circuit: (See Main board drawing P/N 188353-100) The voltage balance network (R23 &
R24) insures that HV+ and HV- are equally balanced with respect to ARMOR.  These resistors also
serve as bleeder resistors that can discharge one 3206 PA from 600 V down to a safe voltage (12 V) in
about 90 min.  They also will  prevent a static charge from building up in a 3206 PA tool when the
3213 QB sub is attached.

THIS TOOL, WHEN COMBINED WITH A 3206 PA, IS DESIGNED TO STORE A
DANGEROUS AMOUNT OF ELECTRICAL ENERGY.  ALWAYS ASSUME THE
TOOL HAS RETAINED AN ELECTRICAL CHARGE.  AVOID TOUCHING ANY
OF THE CONTACTS ON EITHER THE TOP OR BOTTOM TOOL JOINT
BEFORE CHECKING THE VOLTAGE ON THE CAPACITOR.  DANGEROUS
VOLTAGE IS EXPOSED ON BOTH OF THE CIRCUIT BOARDS.
1.
Refer to Dwg. 186891-000.  Remove the lock-ring, Item #1.
2.
Refer to Dwg. 186891-000.  Using the T-handle pulling tool, p/n 056036-000, carefully pull
and remove the upper connector block, Item #2. Disconect it and remove completely.
3.
Refer to Dwg. 192591-000.  Remove the upper sub, Item #5, with wrench.
4.
Refer to Dwg. 186891-000.  Using the T-handle pulling tool, p/n 056036-000, grasp the top of
the electronics assembly, Item #12, and pull it out just far enough to expose the top of the
Main board.

5.
Use a Fluke 87 (or equivalent) voltmeter to measure the DC voltage between E1 and E2 on
the Main Board.  Normally, this should be < 1 V.  If this condition is met, it is safe to remove
the electronics assembly  from the housing.
WARNING
IT IS POSSIBLE FOR UP TO 600 VOLTS TO BE PRESENT AT THESE
POINTS.  IF GREATER THAN 10 V IS MEASURED BETWEEN E1 AND E2,
CAREFULLY DISCHARGE THE CAPACITOR ARRAY THROUGH A 2 K
OHM,  50 W RESISTOR (RECOMMENDED VALUE).  THIS CONDITION IS
NOT NORMAL - THE CAPACITOR  SHOULD NOT BE CHARGED AT
THIS TIME.  THE CAUSE OF FAILURE MUST BE DETERMINED.
CHECK R23 AND R24 ON THE MAIN BOARD, ITEM #14 (P/N 186899-000).

3

4.0  ASSEMBLY
1.
Reverse the procedure when returning the electronics assembly to the housing. Insert the
lower section of the electronics assembly into the housing.
2.
Rotate the electronics assembly with the T-handle until the alignment pin mates with the hole
in the lower end and complete the insertion.
3.
Install the upper sub and reconnect upper connector block.
4.
Press the upper block into the upper sub and install the lock-ring.

3213 QB NMR CAP CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES
1.2  CHARGER TEST PROCEDURE
1.
Test the 3212 PA Field Test box (192230-000) by itself using the following test procedure:
Test the batteries by using a Fluke 87 DMM to measure the battery voltage between the
following test points (the positive DMM lead is always connected to the first test point listed
in each step):
!
B1+ to HV-: 7.0 V min.
!
B2+ to ARMOR: 7.0 V min.
2.
Test the power MOSFETs in the test box by measuring the resistance between the specified
test points with a DMM and actuating the specified switch.
!
HV+ to HV-: Resistance. = 988k - 1.008m.  Push the DISCHARGE switch.
%
Resistance = 600 S ± 10 S.
Safety Note: When testing the 3213 QB DO NOT push the SHORT switch to either the
HV+ or the HV- positions. This switch is only used for testing the 3212 PA tool.
3
3213 QB NMR CAP CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES
1.2  CHARGER TEST PROCEDURE   cont'd
3.
Connect the Common Remote to the top end of the 3206 PA tool, and connect the 3213 QB
to the bottom end of the 3206 PA. Next, connect Field Test box to the bottom end of the
3213 QB. The common Remote is to be connected to an ECLIPS system via a 7-conductor
wireline.
4.
Connect one of the Fluke 87s (DMM1 in DC mA mode) across the CURRENT test jacks on
the test box. Connect the other Fluke 87 (DMM2 in DC V mode) across the HV+ and HV-
test jacks.
5.
Turn on the AC POWER switch on the 2010.  The VOLTS control pot on the 2010 must
be set  to zero (fully CCW), or the high voltage will not come on.  Push the red HV ON
button to turn the high-voltage on.  Slowly advance the VOLTS pot while watching the two
DMMs.  Note: the CURRENT pot must be set to maximum (fully CW).
6.
DMM2 should show a rising voltage and the current shown in DMM1 should remain low
(<.30 A; it will go higher if the VOLTS pot is advanced too rapidly).  DMM1 should go to
near zero when you stop advancing the VOLTS pot.  If these conditions are met, continue
advancing the VOLTS pot while watching the DMMs.
7.
Continue advancing the VOLTS pot until DC+ to DC- is set to 620 V (connect DMM2 to
DC+ & DC-to measure this).
8.
HV+ to HV- should stop advancing and stay fixed at 600 V ± 2 V (reconnect DMM2 to
%
HV+ & HV-).
9.
Advance the VOLTS pot again until DC+ to DC- is set to 700 V (connect DMM2 to DC+
& DC-to measure this).
10.
DMM1 should show an idle current between 7.0mA and 8.0mA and DMM2 should be
%
between 598 V and 602 V(reconnect DMM2 to HV+ & HV-).
%
11.
Use DMM2 to verify that the voltage between HV+ and ARMOR is within 6 V of the
voltage from ARMOR to HV-.
12.
Set DMM1 to the DC A mode and enable record mode to catch the peak current. Briefly
(about 3 sec) push the DISCHARGE button on the test box a few times.  The following
%
conditions should be observed:
!
DMM2 should fall to about 515 V (affected by wireline length), then return to 600 V
%
±2 V.
%
!
DMM1 should show a maximum current of about 860mA (affected by wireline
%

3213 QB NMR CAP CHARGER -- REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES
1.2  CHARGER TEST PROCEDURE   cont'd
13.
Turn the VOLTS pot down to zero.  Push and hold the DISCHARGE button on the test
box down.  After HV+ to HV- falls to about 20 V, push the green HV OFF button to turn
off the high voltage (this is the preferred power-down procedure.)
14.
Remove the DMMs and remove the test box from the tool.
If all of these tests are good, the tool passes the Level 1 test.  Otherwise, find and correct the
problem.

topic: % Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 1.0 OPERATOR SAFETY NOTES . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1
chunk_text:
1.0  OPERATOR SAFETY NOTES 1
1.0  OPERATOR SAFETY NOTES
The 3213 QB NMR Capacitor Charger operates at high input (up to 900 V) and output (up to 600 V)
voltages.  These voltages are present on the circuit boards.  The charger has a 3µF capacitor on the
back-side of the spine that in normal operation can be charged as high as 900 V. The 3206 PA is
normally charged to 600 V. These capacitors can hold a charge for 90 minutes when connected to a
3213 QB if the standard power-down procedure described in this document is not followed. A
3206 PA by itself has no bleeder resistors and can hold a charge indefinitely unless properly
discharged.

2.0  EQUIPMENT REQUIRED 1
2.0  EQUIPMENT REQUIRED
1.
Series 2010 (a 2085 may be used if a 2010 is not available) power supply.
2.
ECLIPS System.
3.
A 3514 Common Remote.
4.
A 7-Conductor wireline that is typical for your base to use in field operations.
5.
Field Test box for series 3212 PA & 3213 QB NMR (192230-000).  Make sure the batteries
are good .
6.
One, 32-pin pressure bulkhead (Ref. Drawing 145245-000).
7.
Two Fluke Digital Multimeters Model 87 (245130-000) or equivalent, with standard meter
leads and "grabber" leads.  Make sure the batteries are good.
8.
Resistance decade box, such as an OHMITE OHM-RANGER or IET Labs RS-200 (only if
recalibration is required).
9.
One clip lead.
10.

Remove tool from housing using the procedure listed in 130783-955.

Inspect the cases of R8, R9, R20 and R21 on the Main board (188353-000) for cracks, loose
epoxy end-caps and poor epoxy-to-wire seals (only if resistors have black epoxy cases).

voltage between the following test points:

points with a DMM and actuating the specified switch.

HV+ or the HV- positions. This switch is only used for testing the 3212 PA tool.

4.0  STATIC TESTS

Connect the Common Remote to the top end of the 3206 PA tool. Connect the 3213 QB sub
to the bottom end of the 3206 PA. Connect the Field Test box to the bottom end of the
3213 QB.  The common Remote is to be connected to an ECLIPS system via a 7-conductor
wireline.

Connect one of the Fluke 87s (DMM1 in DC mA mode) across the CURRENT test jacks on
the test box.  Connect the other Fluke 87 (DMM2 in DC V mode) across the HV+ and HV-
test jacks.

Turn on the AC POWER switch on the 2010. The VOLTS control pot on the 2010 must be
set  to zero (fully CCW), or the high voltage will not come on.  Push the red HV ON button
to turn the high-voltage on.  Slowly advance the VOLTS pot while watching the two
DMMs.  Note, the CURRENT pot must be set to maximum (fully CW).

DMM2 should show a rising voltage and the current shown in DMM1 should remain low
(<.30 A; it will go higher if the VOLTS pot is advanced too rapidly).  DMM1 should go to
near zero when you stop advancing the VOLTS pot.  If these conditions are met, continue
advancing the VOLTS pot while watching the meters.

Continue advancing the VOLTS pot until DC+ to DC- is set to 620 V.

HV+ to HV- should stop advancing and stay fixed at 600 V ± 2 V.
%

Advance the VOLTS pot again until DC+ to DC- is set to 700 V.
4.7.1
DMM1 should show an idle current between 7.0mA and 8.0mA and DMM2 should
%
be between 598 V and 602 V.
%
4.7.2

the voltage from ARMOR to HV-.

Use DMM2 to measure the following voltages on the Main board (DMM2 negative lead on
E2 on the Main board unless otherwise specified):
+8.2_OV @ R3 = 7.70 V to 8.60 V (8.2 V nominal)
+8.2_CH @ R11 = 7.70 V to 8.60 V (8.2 V nominal)
5 V_OV @ A2 pin 4 = 4.99 V to 5.01 V
5 V_CH @ C10 +term. = 4.99 V to 5.01 V
Q1 gate = 0 V to .01 V
Q3 gate = 2.50 V to 2.90 V (2.74 V nominal)
E15 to E24 = 8.55 V to 9.45 V (9.0 V nominal)
E25 to E26 = 3.10 V to 4.00 V (3.5 V nominal)
If all of these tests are good, proceed to the next paragraph. Otherwise, find and correct the

Turn the VOLTS pot down to zero.  Push and hold the DISCHARGE button on the test

After HV+ to HV- has fallen to near zero, feel all of the components.  Some of the large

topic: % Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 5.0 OVERVOLTAGE PROTECTION TEST . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 5
chunk_text:
5.0  OVERVOLTAGE PROTECTION TEST 5
5.0  OVERVOLTAGE PROTECTION TEST

Place a jumper wire from E24 to E26 on the Main board.  This will short-out the pass
transistor array and disable the charging control circuit.  Reconnect DMM1 and DMM2 to
the test box.

Turn on the 2010, as before, and increase the DC+ to DC- voltage to about 590 V.

Now, slowly advance the VOLTS pot while watching HV+ to HV- on DMM2. somewhere
between 628 V and 631 V the OVP circuit should trip and turn on the relays K1 and K2 (you
should hear the click).  If it does not open before 633 V, there is a problem that will either
require repair or recalibration.
5.3.1
Verify the following, at the trip point:
!
HV+ to HV- shown on DMM2 will immediately start falling all the way to
zero.
!
DMM1 should show 20mA to 30mA. (25mA nominal)

Now, turn the VOLTS pot toward zero.  When DC+ to DC- is about 75 V to 125 V, the
relays should close again.

Repeat this test a few times to verify the repeatability of the OVP trip point.

Power-down the charger and turn off the 2010 power supply and remove the jumper from
E24 to E26 after successfully completing the test.  Otherwise, identify and correct the error.
6
3213 QB NMR CAP CHARGER -- LEVEL 3 MAINTENANCE

topic: % Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 6.0 PASS-TRANSISTOR ARRAY CURRENT BALANCE . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 6
chunk_text:
6.0  PASS-TRANSISTOR ARRAY CURRENT BALANCE 6
%
6.0  PASS-TRANSISTOR ARRAY CURRENT BALANCE
During this test, you will be using DMM2 to measure the voltage across the source resistors (1.5 S
WW) in the pass-transistor array.  For best accuracy, make these measurements directly across each
one of the source resistors (R26 on the Main board and R5 - R8 on the Pass-Transistor board).  You
will use DMM1 to measure the total tool current.  The back of the test box should be near room
%
temperature (not hot) before starting the test.
%

Make sure the 2010 high voltage is off.

2010 Vmax for this test: 620 V
%

Turn on the 2010 and advance the VOLTS pot until DC+ to DC- equals 620 V.
%

Carefully connect DMM2 directly across source resistor R26.  Hold down the
DISCHARGE button until the voltage across R26 stabilizes.  Then, record the voltage.

Repeat the measurement for the other source resistors.  Calculate the source current by
dividing each voltage by 1.5 S.  The sum of the source currents should be within ±5% of the
steady-state "on" current, shown on DMM1.  If the back of the test box is too warm to
%
touch, allow it to cool before continuing.
%

The current in (voltage across) each source resistor should be within ±5% of the average
source current (voltage drop).  If these conditions are not met, find and correct the problem.


3213 QB NMR CAP CHARGER -- LEVEL 3 MAINTENANCE

7.0  CALIBRATION 7
%
1
3213 QB NMR CAP CHARGER -- LEVEL 3 MAINTENANCE
7.0  CALIBRATION
This step should only be required if reference components (A1, A3, R8 - R10 or R20 - R22 on the Main
board) have been replaced.  Have the resistor substitution box and the following RN55 D resistors
available for R10 and R22.  Remove the old R10 before calibrating OVP circuit, and remove the old
R22 before calibrating charger circuit.
R10: 100k, 124k, 127k, 130k, 133k, 137k & 140k
R22: 140k, 143k, 147k & 150k.
7.1 Make sure the 2010 high voltage is off.
7.2 2010 Vmax for this test: 700 V
7.2.1
First, calibrate the OVP circuit (if required).  Place a jumper wire from E24 to E26 on the
Main board, and set the resistor substitution box to 133kS, and connect it between E11 and
E12 on the Main board.  Advance the VOLTS pot until the relay opens (do not go above
640 V); notice the highest value of the HV+ to HV- voltage.  If the trip point is below 630 V,
decrease the resistor box setting using standard 1% resistor values.  If the trip point is above
630 V, increase the resistor box setting.  If the voltage is between 629 V and 630 V, measure
the resistor box value and clip-lead the nearest value resistor between E11 and E12.
7.2.2
Verify the trip-point with the new resistor and power down the charger. Solder the new
resistor in place, power up and verify it again.
7.2.3
Power down and remove the clip lead between E24 and E26.
7.3 Next, calibrate the charger control circuit (if required).  Set the resistor substitution box to 143kS,
and connect it between E19 and E20 on the Main board.  Advance the VOLTS pot until DC+ to
DC- is 700 V.  Adjust the resistor substitution box until HV+ to HV- equals 600 V.  To get the best
resistor value, find and note the resistor box settings for 599 V and 601 V.  Then set the resistor box
to the value half way in between the 599 V and 601 V values (DMM2 should show 600 V).
Remember, decrease the resistance to raise the output voltage.
Power down the tool.  Remove the resistor box, measure its value and clip-lead the nearest value
%
resistor between E19 and E20.  Power up the tool.
%
7.4 Push the DISCHARGE button a few times and verify that HV+ to HV- returns to 600 V. Power
down the charger and solder the resistor in place. Power up and verify it again.
7.5 The calibration procedure is now complete.
