BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
3514 XA and 3514 XB WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-935
JULY 2002
This instrument is the downhole telemetry interface for WTS type instruments.  The primary function of the
3514 CR is to act as a repeater of the telemetry channels and to create the WTS Instrument Bus (WTS-IB). 
The 3514 CR does not interpret or take any action with commands that are targeted to other instruments of the
tool string.  This is also true for the data that is sent to the surface from the tools. 
A secondary function is to acquire data from several sensors located in its electronic cartridge and outside of
it.
The curves the instrument is capable of acquiring are the following: Cablehead Tension (with optional
TTRmSM Sub), Caliper (with optional caliper instrument), Borehole Temperature (with optional TTRm
Sub), CCL (with optional CCL instrument), Downhole SP (measured between a tool electrode or a bridle
electrode and armor) and Mud Resistivity (with optional TTRm Sub).
NOTE:
Operations that require an orientation sub should utilize a 4401 XB
instrument.  Operations that require a downhole power sub should use a
4430 XB.
The 3514 XB WTS Common Remote was developed to provide improved long-line performance when using
wirelines up to 40,000 feet in length.  However, the 3514 XA is preferred when using shorter wirelines up to
20,000 feet in length.
The 3514 XB also incorporates improvements in RCI communications and NMR high voltage capabilities.

1.1.1
POWER-ON RESET
1
1.1.2
CLOCK OSCILLATOR
1
1.1.3
MANCHESTER INTERFACE
2
1.1.4
RELAY INTERFACE
2
1.1.5
OTHER SWITCHES
3
1.1.6
DIAGNOSTICS INTERFACE
3
1.1.7

CONTROLLER SECTION
This is a 6805 based microcontroller circuit designed to perform the following three functions:
1.
Interface directly to the Manchester chip to receive the serial data, interpret and execute
commands and serialize data for Manchester encoding and transmission.
2.
Control the sequence of the data acquisition process and the gathering of data from the A/D.
3.
Finally, all instrument relays and analog switches are energized, latched, or switched by the
controller, and its associated driver circuits.
In addition to the functions noted above, a test socket is provided on board.  (NOT FOR FIELD
USE).
1.1.1
POWER-ON RESET
On power-up, the microcontroller unit or MCU (U18) is held reset by R27 and C11 for a period of
three seconds.  The long time constant was chosen to allow correct startup under various conditions of
instrument power-up, in particular when the variac voltage is turned up very slowly.  D4 across R27
allows rapid discharge of the reset circuit when the instrument is de-energized.  D9 protects U18's
reset pin from negative overshoot and balances out the leakage of D4, at temperature.
1.1.2
CLOCK OSCILLATOR
A crystal clock oscillator package (U16) supplies a 4 MHz clock to the MCU.  Internally, the MCU
divides the clock by 2 and runs at 2 MHz with a period of 0.5 µs.
Observe that U16 has built-in divider stages with outputs supplied to other parts of the system.  One
of these outputs is the 977 Hz clock at pin 1 of U16.  This clock is buffered by a dedicated gate
(U15), to provide a constant amplitude square wave to the mud resistivity circuit.  Regulation is made
possible by deriving the +5 V power supply for U15 from a precision voltage reference in the data
acquisition section rather than using the main logic supply.  The buffered output is made available at
the terminal labeled 977 Hz.
1.1.3
MANCHESTER INTERFACE
Like other instruments in the WTS system, the 3514 Common Remote has its own designated remote
address, which is $80 in this case.  However, with both repeater and local remote residing in the same
package, there was no need to interface its local remote to the Instrument Bus.  Instead, the UDI and
BZO/ signals of the Manchester (U19) tap directly into the repeater via logic elements, thus
eliminating the two coupling transformers, receiver, driver and passive components normally used in
a typical remote.
Interface between U19 and the MCU is straight forward.  Nine of the MCU's programmable I/O ports
were configured for direct handshaking with the Manchester chip.
R28 keeps the Manchester encoder disabled during the brief power-up cycle to avoid unwanted
transmission to the surface.
R29 combines SDI and TD signals to save one MCU port, taking advantage of the fact that, in this
design, the two signals are not required to be active simultaneously.
R33 is a special case pull-down resistor.
1.1.4
RELAY INTERFACE
There are four latching relays in the 3514 CR, one of which, (K2), is located in the controller section
of this card and is used for SP and bridle switching.  The other three are located on the Mud
Resistivity card for mode switching.  In addition, there is the non-latching power relay (K1) mounted
on the chassis for motor supply and other signal routing.  All these relays can operate with a 24 volt
supply.
To avoid having a separate power supply, approximately 24 volts was derived from across the filtered
but unregulated inputs to the ±15 volt regulators, i.e. (V+ to V-).  The common return would be
floating in this supply with V- becoming the return.  The hefty power supplies deliver a fairly stable
voltage when properly powered.  Zener diode (D6) develops 18 volts across its leads leaving about 24
volts to power the relays.  C12 provides additional filtering.
Although load conditions vary widely as one or more relays are switched in different combinations,
this arrangement provides adequate regulation.  The steady state current is low because only K1
requires current to hold it energized.  Pulse duration for the latching relays is 10 msec.
Darlington array (U22) with its built-in EMF protection diodes provides the drive to the individual
coils.  Shift-and-store register (U21) supplies the control signals at its latched outputs to U22.  Data
from the MCU is clocked serially into U21 while the latched outputs of U21 are held undisturbed
until strobed.
Interface between the +5 V logic control signals and the relay driver circuit is accomplished by a
voltage level translation circuit.  Obviously, doing the translation at the three input lines of U21
instead of at the outputs requires fewer components.  For this reason, note that U21 has to be powered
by a net 5 volt supply developed across Zener diode D5 with Vss = -15 V and VDD= -10 V; an
important detail to keep in mind when servicing the circuit.  PNP transistor array (U20) and resistors
R20 through R25 accomplished the translation.
1.1.5
OTHER SWITCHES
When not AC motoring, conductor 7 of the wireline can be utilized for transmitting the mode 7 C
channel.  The channel is transformer-coupled by T6 to the wireline.  T6 is AC coupled to keep from
interfering with SP and DLL remote on Conductor 7 (in the Mode-7 state).  U17 is a CMOS switch
with low 25 ohm on-resistance.  It is configured in the circuit as dual SPDT switches connected in
parallel, thus dropping the on-resistance to one half the noted value.
The MCU controls U17 directly.  In one setting, line 7 gets connected to the SP conductor to provide
an SP signal uphole.  In the other setting, line 7 becomes connected to line 13 of the instrument bus
below the 3514 CR and acts as a DLL surface reference.  It may also be used as an analog signal path
to the surface by some instruments if the need arises.  L4 filters Mode 7 C signals out of the downhole
SP signal.
This switch is open to experimentation.  Being an analog switch, it is well suited for multiplexing
applications.
1.1.6
DIAGNOSTICS INTERFACE
In the course of developing the system, a test socket was provided on board.  NOT FOR FIELD
SERVICE.
1.1.7
DATA ACQUISITION INTERFACE
By far, this interface is the largest user of I/O ports, 15 in all.  These are divided into four functional
control and data busses to facilitate the data acquisition process.

DATA ACQUISITION SECTION 3
1.2.1
OVERVIEW
3
1.2.2
ANALOG CHANNEL MULTIPLEXER
4
1.2.3
SIGN INVERTER
4
1.2.4
GAIN RANGING AND TRACK/HOLD
5
1.2.5

DATA ACQUISITION SECTION
1.2.1
OVERVIEW
Dictated by the requirements for wide dynamic range, bipolar operation and accuracy of
measurement, the data conversion circuit was designed to accommodate these specifications.  A
reference to the 3514 CR subset documentation should be made for additional information concerning
the application of the converted data.  Further information on each channel is described in the section
about the Sensors Card.
A brief highlight of the configuration is provided below:
Basic converter
Industry standard 574 A/D chip, operated in the unipolar mode for 12-bit
resolution and with a 0-10 V input range.
Other features
Two-step Auto-Gain-Ranging scale:
1)
Gain of 2 for input signals exceeding about 600 mV.
2)
Gain of 16 for signals below that value.
Separate sign bit for bipolar signals.
Track and hold amplifier.
External precision 10 V reference for calibration.
16 data channels with a ±5 V input range.
First two dedicated to drift corrections.
1.2.2
ANALOG CHANNEL MULTIPLEXER
As depicted in the circuit diagram, U3 and U4 form the 16-channel analog multiplexer.  All input
terminals, except the first three, are wired to signal channels outside the board.  Ch1 is A/D Zero
reference.  Ch2 is a 580 mV A/D Cal reference derived from the precision 10 V output of U1 by the
voltage divider network R1, R2, and R3.  The third channel represents the flask temperature
(10 mV/° C) and is supplied by U2, a single package, voltage output, temperature sensor.  The three
terminals, connected locally on board, serve as test points.
Channel selection is controlled by four MCU output ports: three directly address one of eight channels
in each multiplexer and a fourth (pin 8 of U18) is the enable control line for U4.  The control signal is
also coupled via R35 to the base of PNP transistor (pin 2 of U20) where it is complemented and used
for driving the enable input of U3.
1.2.3
SIGN INVERTER
The selected analog output, buffered by one of the dual Op Amps in U5, passes through a switchable
sign inverter made up of the second Op Amp in U5, resistors R8, R9, R10 and half of the analog
switches in U10.  When a positive signal is available at both inputs of this amplifier, U5 acts as a
voltage follower with a gain of one, independent of the gain resistor ratios.  For negative signals, the
switch disconnects the non-inverting input from the signal, grounding it through R10 to form an
inverting amplifier with a gain of -1.  Thus, the signal at the output of U5 will always be positive
except possibly during a small window around the zero-crossing threshold for switching.  Precision
resistors R8 and R9 assure a negative unity gain, while a positive 30 mV nominal offset in the
succeeding stage adds to the signal to make it positive all the time in order to satisfy the converter's
unipolar input requirement.
Such offset, conveniently introduced at the track and hold amplifier (U9) by biasing its trim inputs,
must be accounted for after data recovery, together with any other offset and gain drift errors.  The
method involves multiple sampling of the same ZERO and CAL channels under different gain and
sign settings.  Hence, for these channels, the MCU overrides the free running Auto-gain, Auto-sign
operations periodically as will be described shortly.  For other channels, sign control is accomplished
by comparator 2 of U7, which monitors the buffered analog signal in reference to zero.
A comparator offset, if large enough, can shift the zero point beyond the allowable 30 mV window,
leading to erratic sign results.  To avoid using a null trimpot, the signal into the comparator was first
boosted ten times by a low offset amplifier (Op Amp 2 of U6).  In effect, any comparator offset would
then seem reduced by the same factor (in comparison to the input signal of interest) in the vicinity of
the zero-crossing region.
Back-to-back zener diodes D1 and D2 protect U7 by limiting the boosted signal range to safe values.
The sign bit formed at the output of this comparator must be read with the data after conversion.  Its
logic level must be the same immediately before and after conversion to eliminate the possibility of
coding the wrong sign with the converted data.  The output of the comparator itself is not restricted.
Its output through R12 is OR-Tied at pin 3 of U8 with another sign control signal from the MCU.  Pin
3 is the input of one of two latches enabled by a second MCU control signal (pin 7 of U18). When
enabled, the output of the latch (pin 15 of U8) follows the logic state of pin 3.  This is the case during
the signal tracking period in the data acquisition cycle where the latch output dynamically controls the
inverter.  The comparator output is granted control when the MCU floats its output to a high
impedance state.  At other times, the MCU may bring its output high or low to force the sign one way
or the other.
1.2.4
GAIN RANGING AND TRACK/HOLD
Comparator 1 in the dual unit package (U7) generates the Gain Bit.  It compares the signal at the
output of the sign inverter with VTH.  The set point VTH was made slightly higher than the 580 mV
CAL to trip the comparator output high when CAL is sampled.  The desired outcome is a gain of 16.
The reasoning of this should become evident later in the discussion.
Another gain bit control line from the MCU is OR-Tied with the output of the comparator through D3
and R14 to allow either gain bit to appear at the input of the controlled latch (pin 2 of U8).  The latch
output at pin 16 is the Gain Ranging control signal that actually switches the gain at pin 10 of U10,
and it is read with the converted data.  This latch and the sign bit latch have a single enable line
controlled by the MCU signal (pin 7 of U18) mentioned earlier.  Incidentally, the same MCU signal
controls the enable line of a second latch in U8 at pin 4.  The latch holds the CCL Gain Bit generated
at the Sensors card steady during the conversion cycle.
The MCU can grant gain-ranging control to the comparator by bringing its output to a high logic state.
In the calibration cycle, it can force the gain bit low only for a gain of two, unlike in the sign case.
Indirectly, however, the gain can be made 16 for both ZERO and CAL by default under comparator
control.  What makes this possible is the fact that the two signals fall below the comparator threshold
point VTH.
Resistors R15, R16, and R17 form a feedback network around U9 selectable by analog switches in
U10 for gains of 2 or 16.  U9 doubles in function, as a Track and Hold amplifier.  It constantly tracks
the signal present at its input and holds it constant before the conversion cycle starts on command
from the MCU.
R18, in the signal path from U9 to the A/D converter (U11), increased the input range of the
converter by a small amount when an HI1-574 ATD (HARRIS) A/D was used in the 3510 CR.
1.2.5
DATA CONVERSION AND ENCODING
The A/D is configured to convert and provide all 12-bits at its outputs simultaneously when initiated
with a single control pulse at pin 5.  The digital data plus four other binary signals are multiplexed
into four nibbles by data selectors U12 and U13.  The MCU uses a 2-bit "Nibble Select Bus" to read
each nibble onto its 4-bit Data Bus as shown in schematic B129980-100.
A third data selector (U14) is controlled by the same MCU port associated with gain ranging;
however, it has nothing to do with gain ranging.  The Manchester data word can accommodate only
16 bits.  Out of those, 12 are occupied by the converted data and one by the Gain Bit; that leaves three
bits.  The SP channel requires that a 3-bit code be transmitted with the data.  One of the bit lines, B2,
is permanently wired for MSB in the 16-bit word while the remaining two, B0 and B1, are routed to
U14.  The SP sign is implied positive and it is not transmitted.  In this case, U14 selects the two code
bits to fill the data word.
In another special case, applicable to the CCL channel, a unique CCL Gain bit must be transmitted.
Here, U14 selects that bit and the sign bit for transmission.  It also retains this selection for other
channels, excluding the SP channel, of course.

COMMAND CHANNEL
This channel receives Manchester words from the surface panel and repeats the words on the
command bus.  Words can be commands or data as determined by the Manchester Sync bits.  A
standard defining the shape and polarity of the signals used in the WTS transmission system has been
specified.
Signals entering the command channel at the 20 kb/s rate of surface to downhole transmission are
amplified and inverted by Op Amp 1 of U1.  Gain pot P1 adjusts the signal level to suit the length,
type, and condition of the wireline in service.  Ideally, the signal should be about 8 to 10 volts p-p as
measured at the COMP IN test terminal.
Mode 2 channel couples to the mode 2 winding on the same modal transformer connected to the
command channel.  The induced command signal in this winding is fed into the non-inverting input of
differential amplifier U1, effectively doubling the signal strength and improving the signal to noise
ratio.  On the other hand, data words on mode 2 channel coupled back into the command channel are
undesirable and are attenuated by this echo cancellation arrangement.
A cascaded RC filter followed by the equalization filter implemented with the second Op Amp of U1,
will reduce the noise and harmonic distortion added to the signal by the wireline.
R6 A (on the repeater card) can be replaced with an optional high-pass active filter card (191656-000).
This filter card filters out 60 Hz noise from the AC motor in an RCI instrument.  (See FMN 99-28.)
This "Damped Mode 2 Filter" card allows a greater Mode 2 Tx gain range than was possible with the
1971's Mode 2 filter.
Comparator U2 converts the signal to digital form, triggering at approximately a +/- 2 volt hysteresis
established by its resistor network.  The trigger reference at the non-inverting input of the comparator
flips from one level to another as the output of the comparator changes state and feeds back into R10
at pin 15 of the programmable logic device (U5).    R47 is used to trim R11, to center the trigger
points around the signal baseline.  This centering adjustment removes timing skew in the signal edges
and improves communication (see FMN 95-78 for the 3510).  The feedback, gated by an AND gate in
U5, is inhibited during data transmission on mode 2.  Pin 15 of U5 is forced low during this period to
reset the comparator to a predetermined state.  There are two reasons for this action:  First, to prevent
mode 2 data, induced into the Command channel, from reaching the instrument bus where it may be
interpreted as command words.  Second, to prepare the comparator to trigger on the first edge of the
next command sync.  Otherwise, the comparator may already be in that state and fail to repeat the
correct sync on the Instrument Bus.  The comparator state would have been dependent on the ending
bit in the preceding mode 2 data transmission.

MODE 2 CHANNEL
Receives Mode 2 data, processes it, filters it, and sends it up the wireline on Mode 2.
Reliable reception of data at the other end of the wireline requires that the manchester encoded logic
level signal (0,5 V) be modified before transmission. The transmission system is designed to put
shaped, filtered bipolar pulses on the wireline. This process limits the bandwidth required for a
transmission, reduces line charging, and reduces crosstalk to the other data channels. All the data and
clocking information encoded in a manchester signal is represented in the transitions of the logic level
signal. Narrow pulses are generated by the transitions as will be seen in the following description.
At the front end of the receiver, data enters from two separate sources before being OR-tied and
shaped digitally within U5. One source is the Manchester BZO/ output of the local remote.  BZO/
interfaces directly to pin 2 of U5.  The other is the Instrument Bus coupled through T2 to one of the
differential receivers in U4.  The output of U4 is connected to pin 11 of U5. The two merged signals
inside U5 form a single Mode 2 data path which is processed as follows:
First, a logic level change in the merged Mode 2 data in U5 initiates a positive pulse at one of two
corresponding outputs M2 H and M2 L.  In turn, that enables a counter incremented by a 4 MHz
reference clock.  When the count reaches a predetermined number, the counter toggles a flip-flop
ending the pulse and clearing itself.
The pulse width generated on Mode 2 is 5.125 +/- 0.125 µs.  The uncertainty is due to the variable
time difference between the data transition edge and the first clocking edge of the 4 MHz clock.  This
one count jitter amounts to less than 5% and translates into periodic, slight amplitude modulations in
the filtered signal output.  The frequency beating is nonexistent on data emanating from the remote of
the 3514 CR because all system clocks are synchronous.
Second, the data pulses alternating from pins 9 and 10 of U5 are fed into the inputs of a unity-gain
differential amplifier made of Op Amp 2 in U6 and four resistors.  The amplifier passes the pulses at
its noninverting input and inverts the pulses at the other input, converting the two level signal (0, 5 V)
to a three level (-V, 0, +V) alternate mark inversion (AMI) signal. This AMI signal is passed through
a two-pole low-pass Bessel filter (Op Amp 1 in U6) to remove the high frequency edges. The shaped

MODE 5 CHANNEL
This channel receives data only from Mode 5 of the Instrument Bus.  It has a higher bit rate (93.75
kb/s) as specified in the WTS specifications.  Being coupled to the wireline through a separate modal
transformer, feedback into the Command channel is negligible.  No comparator controls were
required.
The Instrument Bus coupling transformer has a higher frequency response than the ones used for
lower speed channels.  The differential input circuit is similar to that of Mode 2, as is the shaping
circuit of U9, which generates narrower pulses in a proportionate manner.  Using an 8 MHz clock, the
jitter remains below 5% for this channel too.
The other stages are practically the same as those of the previous channel with the exception of the
filter circuit.  A single pole RC filter was sufficient for this channel.

MODE 7 C CHANNEL
This channel works at the same speed as the Mode 5 channel.  On the wireline side, the circuit is
transformer-coupled (T6) through a capacitor (C7) and relay (K1) to line 7 and the centertap of the
Mode 5 transformer.  On the instrument-bus side, the interface connects to "Mode 7 A."  The circuits
for both modes are identical, sharing the same dual receiver package (U8) and dual shaping sections
implemented in U9.  U9 consumes about 30 mA when running at the 8 MHz speed.

VOLTAGE REFERENCES
Next in line on the card, one inverter attenuator circuit (half of U13) scales down the precision 10v
reference input to generate a -1.35 volt reference for channels 9, 10, 12 and 13.  The second Op Amp
in U13 inverts this reference to obtain the positive complement +1.35 V.  Only channels 12 and 13
require it.
Q1, acting as a current buffer at the output of Op Amp U12, supplies the necessary current to power
the force and/or pressure gages.  When the Sensor sub is installed, the Drive and Sense lines become
connected remotely inside the sub. The closed loop formed around U12 maintains a precise 10 V
excitation voltage at the load cell bridge.  R43 keeps the loop closed if the load is disconnected.  It has
a large value so it will not interfere with the normal sensing operation.

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE

This card is divided into two major sections.  The circuit on the right half of the board is the
Controller section, the remaining half comprises the Data Acquisition portion.

topic: CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION 2.0 REPEATER CARD (P/N 191641-000)
chunk_text:
6

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-945
JULY 2002 2.0 REPEATER CARD (P/N 191641-000)
While other cards in the 3514 CR perform needed functions and gather a multitude of data channels
vital to the logging service, the Repeater card is essential for WTS operation.  It forms the link
between the surface panel, via modal transmission on the wireline, and downhole instruments
communicating on the Instrument Bus.  The three modal transformers that couple signals between the
card and the line are mounted on the backbone of the power supply section.
Functionally, the card's circuit is subdivided into four channels: Command, Mode 2, Mode 5 and
Mode 7 C.

7

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-945
JULY 2002
The comparator reset signal is generated by a retriggerable oneshot implemented inside U5.  Its 192
µs timing period allows the oneshot to stay triggered while mode 2 data bits are present, even during
the longer sync period.
The comparator reset signal generated above is also available at pin 21 of U5 to disable the line
driver, again to prevent interference.
The Command Instrument Bus is coupled to the command channel by T1.  The transformer is driven
by differential line driver U3 with its open collector outputs pulled high at the center tap through the
diodes and current limiting resistors.  One of the U3 inputs is driven directly by the comparator.  The
remaining input is connected to the complemented comparator output via U5.
The local 3514 CR Manchester decoder receives the command signal at its UDI input from the gated
comparator output (pin 15 of U5).  D1 keeps a damaging -15 V from appearing at UDI if U5 is not
inserted.

8

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-945
JULY 2002
and filtered signal is put on the wireline through the Mode 2 coupling transformer, capacitively driven
by the current buffer (U7).
For lower power dissipation in the current driver, the output stage of this hybrid device was powered
with +/- 6 V.  The voltages were obtained by dropping the +/- 15 V supplies thru 9 volt zener diodes
D5 and D6.

topic: CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION 3.0 SENSORS CARD (P/N 129982-000)
chunk_text:
9

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-945
JULY 2002 3.0 SENSORS CARD (P/N 129982-000)
The Sensors Card is a collection of independent circuits on a single board, the card processes and/or
filters a dozen analog channels in preparation for sampling.  It also receives the system's precision
10 V reference from the controller and Data Acquisition card to provide a buffered, stable, bridge
supply for the force gage and pressure sensors.  Other references required by some of the sensor
circuits are derived from the 10 volt reference as well.
To a large extent, all circuits were physically partitioned for ease of layout, identification and
servicing.  The channels were labeled from 4 through 15 and are positioned on the card in a sequential
order from left to right.  The same order will be followed here in describing the circuits.

CHANNEL 4 (Unused Ax)
Unused filter Ax.  See CH6 circuit description.  Op Amp U1 is not installed.
3.2 CHANNEL 5 (Unused Ay)
Unused filter Ay.  See filter description below.  Op Amp U2 is not installed.

CHANNEL 6 (Unused Az)
Unused filter Az.
Each filter circuit in the above three channels consists of a 4-pole low pass Bessel filter having a
roll-off frequency of 2 Hz.  It is a classic two stage 2-pole design with parameters yielding an overall
gain of 1.906.  Op Amp U3 is not installed.
A 1 megohm pull down resistor at the input of each circuit keeps it from floating in the absence of a
signal source.

CHANNEL 7 (Force)
Gain and filter circuit for the Force Gage sensor.  The tension/compression load cell in the sensor sub
delivers about 1 mV signal per 1000 lbf, based on the 10 volts of excitation used.  The force scale
required in tension is 12,000 lbf, and is much less in compression.  A ±12 mV input range
specification covers both scales equally, however, with the positive polarity implying tension.
Input instrumentation amplifier U4 has its gain set at 401.  The resulting full scale signal would be
approximately ±4.8 volts, well within the ±5v input range of the data conversion section.  At this
scale, the system can resolve three lbs.
A 2-pole low-pass filter following the gain stage rolls off the signal (-3dB) at about 6 Hz.
When the sensor sub is not installed, resistors at the input of the amplifier keep the output from
saturating.  Input capacitor C53 filters high frequency noise on the input lead wires.

10

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-945

CHANNEL 8 (Caliper)
This channel is for processing the caliper signal.  The circuit is similar to that for channel 7. U6 has a
gain of 1, with no connection between its pins 1 and 4.  R33 and R34, together with resistor R92,
form a "divide by 3" attenuator similar to the caliper input in the 3506 PCM and 3516 SLAM adapter.
The low-pass filter rolls off (-3db) at about 4 Hz.
R93 works with C54 to provide additional high-frequency noise filtering.  R93 is also a dropping
resistor for the input protection zeners.  This circuit protects the input if top block #2 is accidentally
installed when the 3514 is below a 4430 XB (see FMN 00-13).

CHANNEL 9 (Input Grounded)
This is an unused pressure sub temperature channel.  OpAmps U8 and U9 are not installed.  The "TP"
input wire is connected to circuit common and provides an isolated return path for the "TH" RTD in
the sensors sub.  (See 3510/3981 FMN 94-37/94-37 A.)

CHANNEL 10 (Hole Temp)
Hole temperature circuit Th.  A constant current source, implemented using differential amplifier
U10, drives the RTD.  The signal developed across the sensor is amplified by U11.  C18, in the
feedback loop, filters any high frequency noise past the 11 Hz roll off frequency.
Offset and Scale adjustments were avoided in this circuit, and Channel 10's accuracy relies on the
precision of the components used.  A formula derived in terms of the output voltage is solved for
temperature.  A 500 ohm RTD with an alpha=.00385 is in the sensors sub; consequently, the gain of
the output amplifier was set to 5 by the ratio of resistors R38 and R37.  If the sensors sub uses a 2000
ohm RTD in the future, then R38 and R37 can be swapped for a gain of 1.25 while continuing to use
the same formula.

CHANNEL 11 (Unused TA)
This is an unused buffer channel, and the circuit is simply a buffer for an AD590 temperature sensor
with a 10 K scale resistor.  At the time of this manual's publication, no signal input is connected to
terminal TA.
The other half of U12 is used in the load cell excitation circuit.

11

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-945
JULY 2002 
CHANNEL 12 (CCL)
Channel 12 focuses on the CCL signal.  When digitizing the CCL pulse, it is desirable to preserve the
shape and polarity of the waveform.  This requires higher sampling rates in general.  The multiple
sampling capabilities of ECLIPS will make it feasible to achieve this result, as the circuit does not
employ any peak detectors.
The level of CCL signal can span a wide dynamic range due to large variations in the strength of the
magnetic field encountered and more than one type of CCL subs that may be adapted for use with the
WTS system.
Normally, the measurement is not intended for cased hole operations with flush joints.  Nevertheless,
the sensitivity range of the circuit was extended to cover weak signals.
The signal received on conductors 16 and 10 of the upper instrument bus is passively filtered by the
input RC stage leading to instrumentation amplifier U14.  D1 and D2 protect the device from peaks
exceeding ±12 volts.  Additional filtering is done by the 2-pole active filter around Op Amp 1 in U15
for an overall flat response up to about 4 Hz.  From there, the signal splits entering a window
comparator and a two-step scale adjustment circuit encompassing the 2nd Op Amp in U15 and analog
switch U17.  The output of the comparator, CCL GB, is latched on the Controller and A/D card
before data conversion and the latched output, Q2, is used to control the scale.  For signals outside the
range of ±80 mV, the window comparator selects the node between R58 and R59 as the feedback path
to the inverting amplifier.  In this case, the circuit behaves as an attenuator, stepping down the input
voltage by a factor of 2.5 in order to accommodate signals approaching the ±12 V level.  Signals
within the ±80 mV set the comparator in the opposite logic state, boosting the gain from .4 to 48.  The
set point references defining the window were chosen low enough to provide adequate tolerance to
any offsets at high gain and temperature.
The latched comparator output representing the gain status is transmitted with the data as a CCL
Gain Bit.
D8 and D9 protect the comparators inputs (U16) from overvoltage. R88 prevents D8 and D9 from
clamping the CCL signal at the output of U15 and also limits the input current to the comparators.

CHANNEL 13 (SP)
Auxiliary measurement of the SP signal, in reference to armor, is performed by this channel using an
instrument electrode, or the lower bridle electrode.  The low level SP signal must be amplified to
improve the resolution of the received signal.  Yet, the inherent offset associated with the SP can
quickly saturate the amplifier.  The practice with the surface reference SP has been to add a pot on a
panel to null out the constantly changing SP offset.
Tailored for downhole operation, the auto-offset-ranging feature of the circuit acts on the signal to
bring it within the high resolution range of the A/D (i.e. gain of 16) at all times.  The introduced offset
is one of eight defined reference voltages covering the -750 mV to +1350 mV range.  Armed with the
three-bit code (B2 B1 B0) denoting the selected value, the digitized SP can be easily reconstructed on
the surface to recover the true SP.
In a more detailed description, the noisy signal enters the circuit through an RC filter with an
overvoltage protection network (bidirectional zener diodes D3 and D4).  Common mode rejection and
buffering is carried out by U18 operating at unity gain.  The signal is filtered further by a two-pole,

12

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-945
JULY 2002
low pass, active filter for an overall 6 HZ response.
Unity gain differential amplifier (U25) functioning as a summing node, in combination with a
digital/analog feedback network, provide an offset to the filtered SP signal.  This works to keep the
output positive and to maintain it below the 600 mV threshold required for high gain.
The resistor divider network across the reference voltages ±1350 mV establish the eight signed
references in 300 mV increments.  Analog mux U21 in concert with counter U22 select one of the
eight offsets. A second voltage divider derives the band limit references +50 mV and +550 mV for the
window comparator (U20).  The comparator enables the counter to increment when the signal exceeds
550 mV or to decrement when it falls below 50 mV.  The range of the SP signal in which the
feedback control action can function is ±1.3 volts.
Of particular importance is the magnitude of the coarse 300 mV increment, because it represents a
hysteresis large enough for operating with less frequent code switching.  This minimizes any
discontinuities or spikes that could be introduced in the process.  Hopefully, the circuit searches
initially only for the correct range at the 250 KHz clock rate of the counter, and then it settles.  Note
that if the raw SP signal is close to zero, one of two possible offset codes (100 for 150 mV or 011 for
450 mV) may be generated, depending on whether the count proceeds up or down on startup.  This is
normal.
For a fast response, the control network works on the SP signal after the filtering stage.

CHANNEL 14 (CHV)
Channel 14 measures the Cablehead Voltage for instrument power.  A secondary winding on the main
power transformer T1, supplies about 9 VRMS signal at the normal 180 VRMS of input voltage.
U23 is an RMS to DC converter IC requiring only a few external components for operation, and it is
utilized here for the simplicity of the design.  Unfortunately, the device does not work above 145° C.
Of course, the flasked electronics with its heat sink can solve the problem, as long as the operating
time is not exceeded.  Component values for DC averaging time constant (C40) and 2-pole post filter
(C41, C42 and R78) were chosen to yield 1% total DC and ripple error.
The scaling pot P1 should be trimmed for 1.8 VDC at channel output with 180 VRMS applied at the
cable head (conductors 1 and 4). Use an AC voltmeter which measures true RMS to measure the 180
VRMS.

CHANNEL 15 (AC MTR VOLTS)
Channel 15 measures the Motor Voltage at the cablehead, and more precisely it measures between
conductor 10 and the phantom center tap of wireline mode 5.  This voltage can be as high as 440
volts, AC or DC.  A special transformer T2, mounted on the backbone, supplies about 9 VRMS to
this channel when its primary is powered with the rated 440 VRMS.  A resistor or capacitor in series
with T2 keeps the full DC voltage from being applied across T2.
For instruments requiring AC power between mode 5 center tap and 10, as in the case of RCI,
conductor 7 should first be disconnected by setting relay K1 to the AC MOTOR state. This improves
mode 2 and mode 5 communications.  Mode 7 is not usable while motoring the RCI.
Channel 15 is similar to channel 14 except that the scaling factor used is 5 mVDC per 1 VRMS
instead of 10 mVDC per 1 VRMS.  Therefore, pot P2 must be adjusted for 2.2 VDC at the channel
output when the motor voltage between conductor 10 and the center tap of T1 is 440 VRMS.

topic: CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION 4.0 CHANNEL 16 (MUD RESISTIVITY CARD) (P/N 129983-000)
chunk_text:
13

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-945
JULY 2002 4.0 CHANNEL 16 (MUD RESISTIVITY CARD) (P/N 129983-000)
The circuit utilizes an input square wave at 977 Hz for a precision reference voltage.  This square
wave is filtered by a two stage, stagger tuned, bandpass filter (U1 A and U1 B) to generate a low
harmonic content sine wave to drive the constant current amplifier.  A voltage of about 1.2 Vp-p is
applied to the primary of transformer T1. T1 provides isolation from the current driver U2.
Transformer T1 has a 1:1 turns ratio such that the 1.2 Vp-p is applied through the power amplifier to
resistor R12.  In the configuration shown, the circuit adjusts to maintain this fixed voltage drop across
R12 and in so doing provides a constant current to any load placed from the junction of T1 and R12
to ground.  R26 prevents the circuit from oscillating if E1 is directly shorted to E4.
The voltage drop across the mud column between electrodes 2 and 3 is sensed by instrumentation
amplifier U3.  The upper and lower electrodes of both E2 and E3 are bussed together internally to
obtain an average voltage drop over both the upper and lower current paths.  The high impedance
inputs on the amplifier prevent loading of the measure current in the fluid.  Capacitors C5 and C6 are
used to block any DC voltage generated in the borehole from amplifier U3.
The output from U3 is supplied to phase splitter stage U4 to drive the output isolation transformer T2.
T2 has a 1:2 turns ratio.  However, the signals add up at the center-tapped input resulting in a voltage
gain of 1.  U5 is a double pole FET switch IC which is driven by the input reference signal at 977 Hz.
The alternate opening and closing of the switches provides a full wave, synchronous detection of the
received signal.  This voltage is supplied to the A/D converter and is sent uphole as VRM.

1

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-956
JULY 2002 1.0 INTRODUCTION
The 3514 XA WTS Common Remote electronics was designed with minimum adjustment
provisions to ease the calibration and maintenance procedures.  The normal checkout routine is
employed as with other downhole instruments to insure the equipment stays in good working
condition.

Based on observations of log quality and accuracy of the signals, replacement of some parts and/or
recalibration may become necessary after demanding jobs, especially if the temperature of the
flasked electronics exceeds the recommended limit.
Normally, the tool operates reliably for 10 hours in a 200° C downhole environment assuming the
initial flask temperature was less than 30° C.  The flask temperature sensor is located at the closed
end of the flask..  When the reading is 125° C, the temperature at the open end of the flask could
be as much as 30° C higher or 150° C.  So, as a rule of thumb, a 125° C flask temperature reading
is the maximum permissible operating temperature.
Higher temperatures lead to component degradation or accelerated failure.  As such, part of good
maintenance is preventive maintenance.  The maintenance technician should feel free to remind
the engineer to adhere to the maximum temperature limitation recommended for reduced risk
operation. On reruns of deep wells or if the flask temperature was high to begin with -- due to a
previous job or instrument exposed to sunlight -- it is advisable to swap common remotes.  Where
time is short between instrument usage, it may be necessary to remove the flask and allow the heat
sinks to cool down.
As a precaution, avoid operating the instrument needlessly for extended periods of time when
inside the flask.  Internal power dissipation raises its temperature, thus reducing the available
operating time.
Perhaps these and other basic rules in the foregoing discussion may seem overemphasized.
Nevertheless, they are explicitly stated here because they are important and should not be
overlooked.
Ensure that the chassis and heat sink O-rings are in place.  These O-rings prevent damage to the
electronics due to vibration and shock.  Damage to the flask by the heavy heat sinks inside is
another concern.  The O-rings make flask installation smoother and avoid scarring the inner
surface of the flask.
When reassembling parts, always use a locking compound on the screws that hold the electronics'
mechanical sections together.

2

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-956
JULY 2002
In addition, the screws that hold the thermal isolator tube should be regularly tightened to maintain
rigidity between the flasked chassis and the power supply chassis.  Take the following precautions
when handling the electronics with the flask removed:
-
Always place the electronics on three balanced stands. Place one under each heat sink.
Place the third under the connector body of the power supply section.
-
NEVER put any stands under the transformers or other components.
-
Because the flasked section is smaller in diameter than the power supply section, support
must be given to the electronics at the heat sink end, by using a 1/4 inch thick shim board
whenever it is necessary to lay the assembly on a flat surface.  This helps alleviate stress
on the thermal isolator.
A round cable to bypass the flask is available as an accessory item for use when servicing the
electronics (see the -840 or -845 [accessory and lab equipment lists] in this manual).  Separating
part of the flat cable from the flask and using it as a bypass is not recommended.  However, if it is
done in an emergency situation, be certain to retape the flat cable precisely within the center of the
slot in the flask open-end adapter.  Due to the tight tolerance, the edge of the flat cable can be
smashed by the housing if the cable is not positioned properly.
When servicing the instrument, apply the following practices:
1.
Use the correct screw length when replacing screws.  A flat head screw would feel tight if
it bottoms out, but it would not have a firm hold on the countersunk hole.  It may also
stick out, though a small amount, to cause wear problems or scratches on the inner surface
of the flask.
2.
Use the correct screw driver i.e., with a tip width and thickness that conform to the slot
dimensions of the target screw.  Further, support the work section from below to obtain a
rigid grip and to prevent slippage.  Narrow or worn tips, incorrect use, etc., deform the slot
and leave burrs which are hazardous when handling the instrument.
3.
Secure mounting screws, larger components, and loose wires with RTV.  Reinstall
insulation sheets under PC boards to protect the wiring.  Make sure wires do not get
pinched between standoffs and PC boards.
4.
When servicing the electronics of the 3514 XA, use miniature micro-clips to connect the
scope or test equipment to the various test points.  Avoid using alligator clips which can
inadvertently short to the crowded, adjacent contacts on the boards.  Use clips with leads
shorter than 12 inches, to minimize noise pickup.  Always turn the power off before
attaching a clip to an IC lead or attaching IC test clips.
5.
All PC cards in the 3514 XA have single layer double sided PC boards with plated through
holes.  This construction simplifies debugging and board repair.  The PC boards are
densely populated, and consequently require some patience and skill when desoldering
components. Deflux the soldered area after a soldering job.  An erratically noisy signal is a
symptom of a dirty board.

3

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-956
JULY 2002
6.
After lifting the PC cards for maintenance, rearrange the crowded wires properly before
remounting.  The cards stand only 0.25 inch high above the chassis.  Assembly workers
were instructed to layout the harness in small bundles, and in such a way as to avoid the
stacking of the wires.  Do the layout in this manner while keeping the mounting hole areas
clear of any wires.  The cards must not be forced in place by merely tightening the screws.
Rather, they are to level comfortably on all spacers when lightly held in place.  If not, the
consequences are the eventual piercing of some wires by the sharp component leads.  Use
sheet insulation (F255582000) between PC boards and wires.
7.
The occasional replacement of the O-ring in the bottom sub is part of Preventive
Maintenance.  The O-ring seals the 32-pin pressure bulkhead to the housing.  Normally,
the sub is not disturbed, and requires less service.  The frequency of replacing the O-ring
has not been determined.  Log hours and other factors play a role.  Use field experience as
a guide.
Other aspects of the 3514 XA are detailed in specific components in this manual, including one
relating to its theory of operation, circuit descriptions, communication protocols, etc.  A system
checkout diagram identifies test points and other pertinent information on all four cards.  These
should prove effective in servicing the instrument when used in conjunction with the related
waveform diagrams, schematics and repair/maintenance procedures.

1
LAB SAFETY
3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-954
JULY 2002
Beyond precautions normal for electronic equipment, this tool does not require special safety considerations. 
No high voltages are generated in the tool. Transformers are used to reduce the 180 V instrument power in the
WTS bus to relatively low levels.

3514 XA WTS Common Remote Level 3 Preventive Maintenance Procedure and Checklist 
 
 
1 Introduction 
In performing this maintenance procedure, use the Reference Drawings and Bill of Materials, P/N 
130767-975 supplied in the manual as necessary. The checkout diagram identifies most of the test 
points on the PC cards and signal setups needed to test the instrument. Schematics and various 
waveforms are provided to help in understanding and debugging the circuits. Certain waveforms 
need not be verified or reproduced as shown in the diagrams except when troubleshooting. 
2 Mechanical Inspection 
1. Disassemble instrument and remove flask to access electronics. Observe precautions given 
in the Repair/Maintenance Procedures component, P/N 130767-956. 
2. Inspect the assemblies for loose screws on the thermal isolators, transformers, and other 
components. 
3. Inspect the wear ring/s on the heat sink. Some units have teflon tape and a Slydring. 
Replace if worn out. 
4. Inspect the bottom Airborn Connector J2 for any sockets that are not retained in the correct 
position. 
5. Ensure socketed components are firm in sockets and other components or wires are not 
broken, loose or dirty. Clean boards as necessary. 
6. Inspect the Ribbon Cable/Pigtail assembly. The inspection should include the sliding back of 
the tan mesh tubing so that visual inspection of the pigtail portion of the assembly can be 
done. This will require removal of the adapter cap F149088000, to check for insulation wear 
under the adapter cap and at the cable clamp. Refer to the figures 1 and 2 below. 
7. Replace Ribbon Cable/Pigtail assembly if older than 10 years. 
Figure 1: Ribbon Cable/Pigtail Inspection 
 
 
Page 3 of 33 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130767-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  1/21/2016 
3514 XA WTS Common Remote Level 3 Preventive Maintenance Procedure and Checklist 
 
 
Figure 2: Damaged wires observed 
 
8. Perform tests as outlined in the following sections, and then reassemble instrument per 
Repair/Maintenance Procedures component, P/N 130767-956. 
3 Supply Voltage Measurements 
1. Using a dummy or actual line, connect the electronics to the WTS Analog Test Panel 
operating with a PC and the TEST3510.EXE program or other updated versions. 
2. *Use a 28 pin patch box (F123560000) to insert a true RMS current meter (Fluke 87 DMM) 
in series with conductor 1 at the top of the 3514. Power-up the instrument with Instrument 
Power using a voltmeter to measure 180 VAC at the cablehead. Verify current is 80 to 110 
mA (100 to 140 mA above the sensors simulator box, F156150000). See Figure 3. 
3. *Check the power supplies for proper voltages as follows: 
− 
Controller Card (V+) 
− 
Controller Card (V-) 
− 
Power Supply Card (IN) 
− 
Analog positive supply bus 
− 
Analog negative supply bus 
− 
Digital power supply bus 
− 
Relay supply on Controller Card, across D6/V- 
− 
(D6 anode to V-reading varies with ON/OFF state of relay K1). 
 
* Record readings on Preventive Maintenance Level 3 Checklist. The step numbers on the Checklist 
correspond to the step numbers on the instruction portion on these pages. 
* Record readings on Preventive Maintenance Level 3 Checklist. The step numbers on the Checklist 
correspond to the step numbers on the instruction portion on these pages.

On the next measurements use a small clip or an insulated 
probe with exposed tip to avoid shorts. 
 
 
− 
U21 supply (across D5) on Controller Card 
− 
Driver positive supply on Repeater Card 
− 
Driver negative supply on Repeater Card 
4 Reference Voltage Measurements 
1. After a few minutes of instrument warm-up, use a voltmeter with 3 1/2 digits or better 
precision, to measure and adjust the 10.000 VDC reference voltages. Take the 
measurement between the 10 V REF terminal and the analog common terminal on the A/D 
section of the controller card. 
2. *Verify calibration reference at A/D CH2 
3. *Jumper the DRV and SENse terminals and take a measurement across the DRV terminal. 
4. Remove jumper. 
5. *Check the following derived references on the Sensors Card: 
− 
Positive SP reference (R53) 
− 
Negative SP reference (R54) 
− 
SP HI reference (R69) 
− 
SP LO reference (R69) 
− 
CCL HI reference (R55) 
− 
CCL LO reference (R55) 
6. On all voltage measurements, if out-of-range tolerances are noted, then compare results 
with previous records. Isolate and correct any problem. 
 
Page 5 of 33 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130767-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  1/21/2016 
3514 XA WTS Common Remote Level 3 Preventive Maintenance Procedure and Checklist 
 
 
5 Power Supply Channels Calibration 
1. Power the tool to 180 VAC at the cablehead. Run TEST3510.EXE and acquire subset 0. 
2. *Adjust the PWR CHV potentiometer (P1), on the sensors card (129982), for 1.80 VDC CRT 
reading at CH14 terminal, while 180 VAC is applied to the tool. 
3. Set up an ECLIPS system to adjust the MTR CHV potentiometer (P2). 
A. Verify the ECLIPS software is Release 3.0 Update 3 or later. 
B. Install block #1 at the top of the 3514 XA. Install a 4430 XB power sub above the 3514 XA. 
If a 4430 XB is not available, ensure that DC power will not be applied while testing with 
Block #1. 
C. On the 5756, select the following switch positions: 
Input 
MULTI and M5 CT 
Service 
Modal 
Motoring 
HVAC 
D. Verify all power supplies are turned down. Then, under EI CONTROL, choose OCT 
SELECT. Select Yes for True Mode 7. Select OCT x800 A (RCI) and start it (the letter x 
will vary depending upon the release level of the ECLIPS software). 
E. Apply 180 VAC instrument power. 
 
 
 
Note 
 
Relay K1 in the tool should be in its default motor state on power-
up. If software has been running and K1 is in EXIT mode, reset it to 
MOTOR state. 
 
 
 
F. Adjust the AC MOTOR supply to obtain 480 VAC between IB-12 and IB-10. 
4. *Adjust the MTR CHV potentiometer (P2) (on the sensors card) to obtain a MTR CHV 
reading on the CRT display equal to the AC voltage between IB-12 and IB-10, ±5 VAC. 
5. Remove motor and instrument power. 
6. Set up the ECLIPS system to test high voltage DC. 
 
 
 
 
Disconnect any RCI tools (1970) from the 3514 before 
applying high voltage dc power. 
 
 
A. Verify the ECLIPS software is Release 3.0 Update 3 or later. 
B. Install block #2 at the top of the 3514 XA. Do not place a 4430 XB power sub in the string 
when using block #2. However, a 4430 XA may be used with block #2 but not with block 
#1 - the reverse of 4430 XB usage. 
* Record readings on Preventive Maintenance Level 3 Checklist. The step numbers on the Checklist 
correspond to the step numbers on the instruction portion on these pages. 
 
Page 6 of 33

3514 XA WTS Common Remote Level 3 Preventive Maintenance Procedure and Checklist 
 
 
C. On the 5756, select the following switch positions: 
Input 
MULTI and TM7 
Service 
Modal 
Motoring 
TM7 
D. Route the output of the DC motor supply to J7, AUX DC PWR, on the back of the 5756. 
E. Verify all power supplies are turned down. Then, under EI CONTROL, choose OCT 
SELECT. Select Yes for True Mode 7. Select OCT x821 A (MRIL) and start it (the letter x 
will vary depending upon the release level of the ECLIPS software). 
F. Apply 180 VAC instrument power. 
G. Adjust the DC MOTOR supply to obtain 100 ± 1 VDC. 
H. *Verify +50 ± 3 VDC between IB-11 (+) and IB-10(-). 
I. 
*Verify -50 ± 3 VDC between IB-12 (+) and IB-10(-). 
J. Slowly adjust the DC MOTOR supply to obtain 900 ± 1 VDC. Verify that the DC power 
supply's current does not increase with voltage. 
7. *Verify +900 ± 5 VDC between IB-11(+) and IB-12(-). 
8. Turn the DC voltage down. Push the HV OFF button. Remove AC instrument power. 
6 Repeater Checkout 
Perform the following checks on the repeater card: 
6.1 *Command Channel (Mode 2 Down) 
1. Run the TEST3510.EXE program on the 5721 test system and issue a continuous 
loopback command for the 3514. 
2. Monitor the command signal at the CMP IN terminal on the repeater card. The 
recommended signal amplitude is 8 Vp-p as depicted in Figure 8, CMD Calibration. The 
signal level may vary due to the surface equipment used (5721 or logging system) and the 
surface system's TX settings. The amplitude of the Command signal transmitted down the 
line is set depending on whether a line, a line simulator, or no line is used in the setup, as 
well as the type and length of the line and the associated voltage drop in the line or line 
simulator. For more details, refer to the 5721 or 5710 manuals. 
3. A trimpot on the 3514 repeater card, P1, is factory adjusted to yield a gain proven to allow 
successful operation in most cases. One convenient way to verify this calibration is to take a 
resistance measurement across P1, at the points indicated on the checkout diagram 
 (Figure 3). Take the measurement with the tool power off and without removing U1. The 
reading should be about 5 K. 
* Record readings on Preventive Maintenance Level 3 Checklist. The step numbers on the Checklist 
Correspond to the step numbers on the instruction portion on these pages. 
 
Page 7 of 33 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
                                               
 
130767-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  1/21/2016 
3514 XA WTS Common Remote Level 3 Preventive Maintenance Procedure and Checklist 
 
 
4. Check the selection of R47 across R11 to center the waveform at U2-2 above and below 
ground. Use a scope vertical scale of 1 VIdiv. Ensure that the ground baseline is on top of 
the center, horizontal gridline. If adjustment is needed, use a resistance decade box to 
select the value. Use DC coupling in the scope channel's input. Install a 0.1 watt, 1% metal 
film resistor (spec 059246-000). Refer to Appendix 1 of this document for waveform pictures 
and a more detailed procedure. 
5. *Recheck that the ground baseline is still on the center horizontal gridline and that the 
positive and negative excursions of the U2-2 waveform are equal, to within 0.1 VDC of each 
other. The waveform should have a 50% duty cycle. 
6.2 *Common Remote (Mode 2 Up) 
With the program still in loopback, monitor mode 2 data up at the output of the repeater line driver 
(Test point 2-F on the checkout diagram). Verify the alternating pulses are clean with the correct 
levels of +(3 to 6)V and -(3 to 6)V. There should be no dropout. Also note any errors in the 
transmission and determine if the fault lies in the tool or is due to misadjustments in the surface 
receiver. 
6.3 *Checking Instrument Bus, Communication on Modes 2, 5, and 7 C 
At this stage, perform communication tests as outlined in the Test Systems Guide component, P/N 
130767-976, of this manual. 
6.4 Checking I.B. Modes 2, 5, And 7 C with a Signal Generator 
This option can be used if a tool simulator is not available and for troubleshooting. The test verifies 
circuit operation with a continuous tone. Therefore, it is meaningless for surface reception. 
The following steps are applicable for this procedure: 
1. Disconnect the tool simulator or any other tool that may be connected on the instrument 
bus. 
2. Terminate any surface commands. 
3. Feed a 50 kHz sinusoidal wave, not exceeding 4 Vp-p, between the M2 IBUS terminals on 
the repeater card. Monitor the signal between pins 29 and 30 of the bottom connector J2 to 
check connections. 
4. Verify the existence of the +5 V AMI pulses at BN output terminal (test point 2-F on the 
checkout diagram). 
5. Repeat the test for M5 mode, this time applying a 100 kHz signal between M5 IB terminals 
while monitoring the signal at pins 31 and 32 of J2. 
6. Verify the presence of the AMI pulses at test point 2-R5 
7. Move the same 100 kHz signal to M7 IBUS terminals. Monitor it at pins 15 and 16 of J2. 
8. Check the AMI pulses at test point 2-R7. 
* Record readings on Preventive Maintenance Level 3 Checklist. The step numbers on the Checklist 
Correspond to the step numbers on the instruction portion on these pages. 
 
Page 8 of 33

3514 XA WTS Common Remote Level 3 Preventive Maintenance Procedure and Checklist 
 
 
In the above tests, if any of the M2, M5 or M7 C pulses are missing, check the various clocks on this 
board. Trace back the intermediate signals, guided by the waveforms at the test points indicated on 
the checkout diagram. 
7 Testing the Analog Channels 
The analog channels can be tested using methods 1 or 2. 
7.1 Method 1: Using Simulators 
In this method, a sensors simulator box (P/N 156150) is used to simulate force, pressure (caliper), 
pressure sensor temperature, hole temperature, CCL, SP and mud resistivity. 
Method 1 is adequate but it does not check the dynamic response of the filters since only DC 
voltages are simulated. The procedure is as follows: 
1. Connect a patch box (P/N F123560000) above the simulator; power instrument; and run the 
TEXT3510.EXE program. 
 
 
 
Note 
 
With the sensors simulator connected, total tool current is 120 to 
140 mA. 
 
 
 
2. *Exercise Acquire subset F routine and verify the following: 
 
CaL LO (WCLPOS) and CaL HI (WCHPOS) 
Both = 580 mV ± 15 mV 
Zero LO+ (WZLPOS), Zero HI+ (WZHPOS),  
Zero LO- (WZLNEG), and Zero HI- (WZHNEG) 
All = 0 to 50 mV 
3. Exercise Acquire Subset 0 routine. 
4. *Verify the flask temperature reads ambient temperature. 
5. *Set the HI/ZERO/LO switch on the simulator box to HI. Allow a few acquisition cycles to 
occur while observing the % change of reading from cycle to cycle. Normally, changes 
should be within 1% or less for quiet signals. Take readings after five minutes of cycling. 
 
Tension Force 
+4 V ± .2 V or other simulated reading 
Pressure (Caliper) 
+3.3 ± .1 V or other simulated reading. 
Hole Temp. 
+200°C ± 10°C or other simulated reading 
CCL 
+42 mV ± 5 mV or other simulated reading 
6. Set the switch to LO. 
7. *Verify the following readings: 
 
Tension Force 
+4 V ± .2 V or other simulated reading

Correspond to the step numbers on the instruction portion on these pages.

Appendix 1 Comparator Adjustment 
1. Remove the 3514 XA from its housing. 
2. Take the 3514 XA out of its flask and then reconnect the flask cable to the 3514 XA. 
3. Apply 180 VAC instrument power to the 3514 XA and begin acquiring data. 
4. Reference the appropriate drawings for the instrument being adjusted

Appendix 2 Checkout Procedure 
1. Connect the 3514 XA to a long wireline. 
2. Apply 180 VAC cablehead voltage to the 3514 XA. 
3. Adjust P1 on the Repeater card to a value of 5 Kohms. Refer to Figure 5 in the Preventative 
Maintenance Level 3 component. 
4. Adjust the surface TX gain to obtain an 8 Vp-p to 10 Vp-p mode 2 command signal at the repeater card's 
CMP IN terminal. 
5. Verify that there are no 3514 XA timeout errors (Should be < 10 in 100 minutes). 
6. Remove AC instrument power, give the tool a visual inspection, and re-install the 3514 XA into its 
housing. 
7. Acquire Mode 2 data from the 3514 to verify that the instrument is operating properly. 
 
Page 33 of 33 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential

FLASK TEMPERATURE
The flask temperature is monitored while logging.  This important curve helps the field engineer in
estimating whether or not he or she can continue logging at the current borehole conditions.

CABLEHEAD VOLTAGE
The cablehead voltage is useful at power-up.  The CLS system can be requested to display the
downhole AC voltage on the CRT.  Some downhole instruments can take more or less current
depending on their acquisition modes.  For example, the 1507 EA/MA Dual Phase Induction Log
tool requires more or less current, depending on the frequency of the transmitter.  If the frequency
of the transmitter is changed from one run to the next, it is necessary to readjust the surface
voltage.  The cablehead voltage reading is helpful to determine proper downhole voltage.  This
curve operates correctly only if the flask temperature is below 125° C.

MOTOR VOLTAGE
The AC motor voltage can be monitored on the surface when using a 3514 CR.  The surface
current meter displays the total current that is delivered by the surface AC Motor power supply.
As the surface motor voltage increases, more current is taken by the capacitance of the wireline
conductors.  The ability to measure the downhole motor voltage helps the user determine the
proper surface voltage.  This curve operates correctly only if the flask temperature is below
125° C.

CABLEHEAD TENSION
The Cablehead Tension subsystem consists of a strain-gage bridge type sensing device affixed to a
vertical shaft.  The bridge gets its power from the 3514 CR.  The bridge has its own temperature
compensation.
The sensor can work under mechanical tension or compression.  In normal wireline operations,
Atlas Wireline Services are only interested in tension.  In pipe conveyed operations, the cablehead
tension curve is monitored for both tension and compression.
The total measurement range is from -12,000 lbf to +12,000 lbf.  The negative numbers
correspond to compression.  The curve can be presented in any of the standard force units: lbf
(pounds-force), N (newton), or kgf (kilograms-force).  A differential curve in units of force per
unit of the primary index is available.  Primary index is the independent variable of the acquisition,
that is depth or time.
Tension/compression sensing devices usually do not have a high absolute accuracy, but they can
have an acceptable relative accuracy.  A differential curve may give acceptable results while the
total curve may be affected by environmental conditions to the point of seriously degrading the
readings.

BOREHOLE TEMPERATURE
The borehole temperature sensor is an RTD type sensor exposed to the borehole fluids.  The
sensor does not touch the walls of the well.  A constant current circuit located in the 3514 CR
produces a voltage drop proportional to the sensor resistance.  This resistance is proportional to the
temperature of the sensing element.
The inclusion of the sensor in the 3981 XA Sub makes it possible to monitor the temperature of the
well, from top to bottom, in every run.  The inclusion of the temperature sensor in the TTRm sub
was not intended as a substitute for dedicated temperature instruments.

MUD RESISTIVITY
The mud resistivity measuring system utilizes the lateral, electrolog principal to determine the
resistivity of the fluid within a radius of approximately 3 inches of the center line of the tool.  A
constant current is generated within the tool and is passed from the center electrode in the array
(E1),  to an upper and lower return section of the housing.  Two voltage sensing electrodes (E2,
E3, inner and outer) are used to sense the voltage drop within the fluid due to the current being
emitted from the center electrode.
The current flow is restricted to the borehole (the mud) for borehole sizes of 6 inches and larger
because the return electrodes for the current are only 0.625 of an inch away from the source.
Calculations have shown that for borehole sizes of 8 inches or more, the apparent resistivity is
within 90% of the actual resistivity for Rt/Rm contrasts of from 0.1 to 10,000.

DOWNHOLE SP
The conventional SP is measured between a surface electrode and a downhole electrode.  On some
offshore jobs, the noise on the SP curve may be unacceptably large.  In some of these cases a
better quality SP log can be obtained by measuring the SP between two downhole electrodes.  This
measurement could be made from the surface using two wireline conductors or made downhole by
one of the tools.  The 3514 CR has the capability of acquiring the SP curve downhole.  Cable
armor is used as one electrode and the other electrode is usually on a tool. In some cases, the lower
electrode on the bridle is substituted for the tool electrode.
Simultaneous acquisition of Downhole SP and conventional SP is possible.

CCL
The CCL sensor is the 26-pin feedthrough conductor Series 2330. 

CALIPER
Use the MRIL switch position (position 3) in the 4209 caliper to put the caliper signal on
conductor #9 versus #10.  Then, use BLOCK #2 in the top of the 3514 to route the caliper signal
on #9 to the caliper input on #11.  See 4209 caliper schematic 120450-000 and 3514 XA conductor
usage diagram 130767-550.

topic: DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE - DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
chunk_text:
1

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-936
JULY 2002
1.0 3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE FUNCTIONS
The primary function of the 3514 CR is to act as a repeater of the telemetry channels and to create
the WTS Instrument Bus (WTS-IB).  The 3514 CR does not interpret or take any action with
commands that are targeted to other instruments of the tool string.  This is also true for the data
that is sent to the surface from the tools.
A secondary function is to acquire data from several sensors located in its electronic cartridge and
outside of it.
2.0 3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE HARDWARE
The 3514 CR is a flasked instrument designed for operation at 400° F (204°C) for 10 hours.  It is
over six feet long, 3-5/8 inches in diameter and runs on 180 VAC, 60 Hz.
There are four printed circuit cards inside the flask.  In addition, a DC voltage regulator card is
mounted in the non-flasked power supply section.  Three transformers, used to drive the line, are
also located outside the flask.  The circuit cards inside the flask are:
-
The Acquisition and Control card.
-
The Repeater card.
-
The Sensors card.
-
The Mud Resistivity card.
The system is based on a 6805 type Motorola processor.  It controls the acquisition of the data
curves.  The processor does not take any active role in the communications with the surface panel
or the other instruments in the tool string.
The acquisition section sends six zero and calibration values to the surface with the periodicity
dictated by the surface software.  These calibration and zero values are derived from a precision
reference supply and insure a continuous compensation for offset changes due to temperature and
aging.

topic: DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE - DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE 3.0 MODAL TRANSMISSION
chunk_text:
2

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-936
JULY 2002 3.0 MODAL TRANSMISSION
In a multiconductor cable WTS uses modes as communication channels.  Modes are special
conductor configurations that have better communication characteristics than random pairs of
conductors.  There are seven modes in a 7-conductor wireline cable but the WTS System uses only
4 of them.  The ECLIPS system communicates with WTS tools in the tool string through three
digital telemetry channels.
Modes are labeled with numbers in increasing order of wave propagation velocity.  Mode 1 is the
slowest and mode 7 is the fastest.  Modes used by the WTS are shown in the table below:
2
Commands to the tool string and data to the surface
5
Data to the surface at high bit rates
7
Data to the surface at high bit rates

topic: DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE - DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE 4.0 WIRELINE COMMUNICATIONS
chunk_text:
3

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-936
JULY 2002 4.0 WIRELINE COMMUNICATIONS
The surface panel is responsible for driving the line and receiving the data from the tools.  The
wireline attenuates the digital signals.  The higher frequency components of the digital signals are
more attenuated than the lower frequency components of the signal.  The digital signal traveling
from the downhole instruments is amplified and equalized in the surface panel.  The equalization
consists of emphasizing the amplitude of the high frequency components.
The WTS telemetry system in a multiconductor environment requires a 3514 CR.  All the WTS
compatible instruments are required to reside below the 3514 CR in the tool string.  The WTS
compatible instruments cannot communicate to the surface by themselves.  Analog signals from a
TTRm sub, caliper, and/or a CCL, above the 3514, are digitized in the CR.
Mode 2 is bi-directional and half duplex. It is used either as a command channel to send
commands from the surface panel to the tools, or to send data from the tools to the surface.  When
used to send commands to the tools, the bit rate is 20.83 kilobits per second (kbps).  When the
channel is used by the tools to send data to the surface the rate is 41.66 kbps.
The other two telemetry channels, modes 5 and 7, are simplex and used as data channels only.
The data rate for these channels is 93.75 kbps.  Modes 2, 5 and 7 can be used simultaneously.
Manchester code is used to send commands to the tools, and to send data from the tools to the
surface.  Mode 2 uses fixed-length 16-bit words, while modes 5 and 7 use variable length streams
of bits.  The transmission overhead of mode 2 is 4 bits out of 20, while the mode 5 and mode 7
overhead is equal to 11 bits, regardless of the length of the block of bits being transmitted.
Mode 5 and mode 7 are ideal to send large volumes of data in large blocks, both for their intrinsic
high bit rate and for its reduced overhead.
The encoder/decoder used for mode 2 has a parity bit included in the overhead while modes 5 and
7 do not have any built-in error detection.
The WTS software flags the host computer when the data being received is not valid.  The data is
not valid if there is a communication error.  The WTS software does not make any interpretation of
the data received from the downhole instruments.  The instruments are not requested to retransmit
if there are communication errors.
Up to 20 channels of data can be acquired and transmitted by the 3514 CR including 6 calibration
channels.  The data is grouped into 9 subsets that can be requested by the host depending on the
service required and system level of the surface equipment.  For example, systems that do not
support multiple sampling rates can use the subsets that include the calibration channels in their
repertoire.
Some of the signals are available as standard measurements in the 3514 CR.  Others rely on
optional subs that must be placed above the 3514 CR in the tool string.

topic: DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE - DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE 5.0 INTERNAL SENSORS
chunk_text:
4

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE

JULY 2002 6.0 EXTERNAL SENSORS AS OPTIONAL SUBS
All of these sensors are passive devices, that is, they are not stand-alone and they depend on the
3514 CR for power and/or acquisition.  The sensors and sensor measurements that the 3514 CR
can support are listed below:

Cablehead Tension, Borehole Temperature, and Mud Resistivity sensors are located in the optional

type.
Whenever one or more TTRm data curves is required, a TTRmSM sub needs to be in the tool
string, immediately above the 3514 CR.

topic: DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE - DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
chunk_text:
6

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-936
JULY 2002

1 
 
MECHANICAL DESCRIPTION 
3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE 
 
 
The 3514 XA WTS Common Remote is a 3.62" O.D., WTS compatible instrument with a DA Top Sub and 
a WTS Bottom Sub.  The 3514 XA WTS Common Remote instrument operates in conjunction with all 
WTS compatible instruments and must be placed at the top of the WTS instrument bus string. 
 
The electronics are thermally isolated in a specially designed Dewar type vacuum flask, and are housed in 
a 66.0" long Pressure Housing that is fabricated from 16-6 PH SST.   
 
Install a “dummy” flask (P/N F197174000) as required, where the temperature difference between the 
borehole environment and the electronics rating of less than 257°F (125°C) will allow advantageous heat 
transfer and dissipation to the borehole. 
 
The DA Top Sub is fabricated from titanium and utilizes a DA 26-Pin Female Connector.   
 
The WTS Bottom Sub is fabricated from titanium and utilizes a WTS 32-Pin Bulkhead Connector.
