topic: GENERAL DESCRIPTION OF DAT ACQUISITION - GENERAL DESCRIPTION OF DATA ACQUISITION 1.0 ACQUISITION SYSTEM
chunk_text:
1

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-995
JULY 2002 1.0 ACQUISITION SYSTEM
The 3514 CR acquires signals generated inside and outside of its housing.  All signals are filtered
before being converted to digital.  The cutoff frequencies of these filters are different, depending
on the expected maximum sampling rate for the particular curve and its frequency contents.
The acquisition system consists of a 12 bit A/D converter with a 0 to 10 VDC input range.  An
inverter circuit before the A/D converter adjusts for negative signals.  It makes the system a 13-bit
equivalent converter.  For expanded dynamic range the analog signals are multiplied by a factor of
2 or 16, depending on the magnitude of the signals.  The CCL signal passes through an extra gain
ranging system of 0.4 or 48 times, for more dynamic range.  The downhole SP circuit has an
automatic offset system in order to improve its dynamic range.
In order to cancel out the effects of drifts in the analog circuitry, the input of the A/D associated
circuitry is periodically shorted and the drift measured, at different gains.  The values are sent to
the surface as data items.  The surface software compensates for the drift.  A precision reference of
580 mV is also used as an input to the A/D system to measure the changes in total gain and
compensate for them.  Depending on the acquisition mode (subset being acquired), the correction
in the surface can take place at each sampled level or less often.

topic: COMBINATION LOGGING PROCEDURES - COMBINATION LOGGING PROCEDURES 1.0 COMBINATION LOGGING CAPABILITIES
chunk_text:
1

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-992
JULY 2002 1.0 COMBINATION LOGGING CAPABILITIES
All logging tools which have been designed with a WTS interface may be connected to the
instrument bus below the 3514 CR. The interface and instrument through-wiring is standard in
WTS instruments.  This allows placement of WTS compatible instruments in any order in the tool
string, limited only by sensor interaction or mechanical considerations.  The 3206 ED MRIL
contains relays which can disconnect the HVDC from the instrument bus below it (to protect a
1970 RCI if run below the MRIL).
The 3981 TTRm sub, 2330 CCL, and 4209 caliper (switch position 3) do not connect to the WTS
instrument bus. They must be placed immediately above the 3514 CR and connect to its sensor
ports.

topic: COMBINATION LOGGING PROCEDURES - 2.0 COMPATIBILITY OF WTS TOOLS WITH NON-WTS TOOLS
chunk_text:
Generally speaking there are two ways to combine old and new technology logging instruments.
One is to use a 3516 Slam Adapter and the other is to use a 3517 Modal Adapter and a 3514 CR
with a modified top connector (M2 block).
The 3516 Slam Adapter has a WTS interface looking up and a 3506 PCM interface looking down.
This arrangement allows WTS tools to be positioned above the 3516 Slam Adapter and tools
compatible with the 3506 PCM to be positioned below the 3516 Slam Adapter.
Using a 3517 Modal Adapter and a 3514 CR with an M2 block allows old technology instruments
to be run above some WTS instruments.
Caliper signals placed between the center tap of the power transformer and armor are recovered in
the surface acquisition system.
NOTE:There are some exceptions to combining old and new technology instruments.
Please refer to the ECLIPS Operating Manuals for more details.

WTS INSTRUMENT BUS USAGE 1
1.2.1
TELEMETRY CHANNELS
1
1.2.2
ELECTRODE LINES
1
1.2.3
ARMOR
1
1.2.4
RESISTIVITY SYNCH LINE
1
1.2.5

WTS INSTRUMENT BUS USAGE
1.2.1
TELEMETRY CHANNELS
The WTS Common Remote instrument is the top instrument of a WTS tool string.  It is the one
that creates the WTS Instrument Bus.  The instrument uses Mode 2 Command and Mode 2 Data.
It does not use Mode 5 and Mode 7.
When relay K1 is in the "AC MTR" position, conductor 7 and the Mode 7 output are disconnected
However, the "Mode 7" position of K1 allows rhe use of Mode 7 while DC motor power is
applied.  This is an improvement in capability compared to the 3510 Common Remote.
When an instrument that requires a surface electrode is in the string, the wireline conductor #7 is
connected to pin #13 of the 32-pin I.B. connector through the Mode 7 blocking choke L4.  The
line connected to pin #13 is used to provide surface reference to some resistivity instruments, such
as Dual Laterolog.
1.2.2
ELECTRODE LINES
SP is read downhole.  If a DLL surface reference is not required, SP can be connected through L4
to wireline #7  In this configuration, SP can also be measured at the surface.
This instrument can use the Spontaneous Potential line (pin #14 of the 32-pin black block
connector) .  Or, if the service requires an SP to be acquired and there is no tool with an SP
electrode in the string, then a latching relay can be switched so that the SP can be measured from
the bottom bridle electrode.  In this case, the bottom bridle electrode line is disconnected from pin
#8 of the 32-pin connector.
1.2.3
ARMOR
The housing of the 3514 instrument is not directly connected to armor, but it is used as an
electrode for the Mud Resistivity sub-system, when a TTRmSM sub is in the tool string.  The
housing of the 3514 is not isolated from the top and bottom subs, however.
1.2.4
RESISTIVITY SYNCH LINE
This line (I.B. 17) is connected to Mode 5 CT and I.B. 12, and is used for AC MTR and -DC
MTR.  I.B. 17 provides extra current carrying capacity for AC motor power.
1.2.5
POWER LINES
The primary of the power transformer is connected to wireline conductors 1 and 4, which are also
connected to pins 1 and 4 of the 32-pin connector.  When top block #2 is installed in the 3514, the
center tap of the primary of this transformer is connected to pin 11 of the 32-pin bottom connector.
When top block #1 is installed in the 3514, the centertap of the primary coil in the 4430 XB is
connected to pin 11 of the 32-pin bottom connector of the 3514.  This scheme separates the DC
power from AC instrument power below the 4430 XB.  This is required when running the RCI
with MRIL.  For more information, refer to FMN 98-10, which converts a 4430 XA to a 4430 XB.
I.B. 11 is used to provide motoring power to DC motors of other tools in the tool string, as well
high voltage DC to the NMR tool.  The return of the motoring current is on the centertap of Mode
5 (wireline conductors 2, 3, 5 and 6).  Mode 5 centertap is connected to pins 12 and 17 of the 32-
pin connector.  These lines also carry AC motor power.  AC motor current returns on armor, via
pins 9 and 10 of the 32-pin connector.

LIST OF THE ACQUISITION COMMANDS
(Command Synch) Acquire Subset #
801# & 001#
(Command Synch) Send Subset #
804#
where # is the subset number. 

LIST OF NON-ACQUISITION COMMANDS
(Command Synch) Instrument Reset
8000 & 0000
When this command is executed, the tool returns to the power-up state, which will disconnect the
Mode 7 signal path and the uphole SP path or DLL return path from the wireline conductor 7.
This disconnects the 3514 circuitry from the potentially damaging AC Motor crosstalk induced
onto conductor 7 by the presence of high voltage AC.  This configuration ensures higher quality
Mode 2 communications during RCI operations.
(Command Synch) Connect M7 and SP/LL Return to Surface
8004 & 0004
See 8082 and 8083

DATA TYPE(S)6
2.1.1
CCL CASE
6
2.1.2

DATA TYPE(S)
The data words coming from the downhole instrument are 16-bit words. The least significant 12
bits are used for magnitude.  For all the curves, the magnitude is to be interpreted as an unsigned
12-bit word, ranging from hex 000 to hex FFF.
The four most significant bits are used for sign, offset, and gain encoding.  They are to be
interpreted according to the curve being considered. Note: the encoding is not 2's complement.
MSB
LSB
|
|

WXYZ MMMM MMMM MMMM
Where:
M (12 bits), is the magnitude of the converted analog signal.
Z is the A/D Gain Bit.
The A/D conversion system has an automatic gain of either 2 or 16. This is valid for all curves.  If
the gain bit (shown as Z) is 0, a gain of 2 was used by the A/D.  If the gain bit is 1, a gain of 16
was used by the A/D.  The automatic gain adds 18 dB of dynamic gain to the system.
Y is the A/D sign bit.
The system also has the capability of inverting the analog signal before it sends it to the A/D.  If
the sign bit is 1, the sign of the magnitude is positive.  If the sign bit is 0, the sign of the magnitude
is negative.  The sign bit adds 6 dB of dynamic range to the system.
2.1.1
CCL CASE
The CCL circuitry has another automatic gain of either 0.4 or 48, in addition to the A/D gain of 2
or 16.  If the CCL gain bit (shown as X) is 0, the CCL gain used was 0.4.  If the CCL gain bit is 1,
a CCL gain of 48 was used.  In computing CCL values, both gains are to be considered.
2.1.2
SPONTANEOUS POTENTIAL CASE
SP is always acquired with the gain bit set to 1 (explicit, Z = 1), that is an A/D gain of 16.  The
sign bit is implicit, and it should be always assumed to be 1, that is, the magnitude is always
positive.
The BITS WXY are to be interpreted as an SP OFFSET, according to the formula that follows:
SPOFST (in E.U. millivolts) = 1350 mV - 300 mV * (binary
code)
where the binary code is formed by the WXY bits.

topic: INTERFACE SPECIFICATIONS - 2.2 PROCEDURE FOR CORRECTING THE RAW VALUES .....................................................7
chunk_text:
PROCEDURE FOR CORRECTING THE RAW VALUES 7
2.2.1
GENERAL CASE
7
2.2.2
CCL FORMULAS
9
2.2.3

PROCEDURE FOR CORRECTING THE RAW VALUES
2.2.1
GENERAL CASE
The WTS Common Remote sends 6 calibration values:
WZLP
A/D Zero, acquired at low gain, input not inverted.
WZLN
A/D Zero, acquired at low gain, input inverted.
WZHP
A/D Zero, acquired at high gain, input not inverted.
WZHN
A/D Zero, acquired at high gain, input inverted.
WCLP
A/D Cal reference value, acquired at low gain.
WCHP
A/D Cal reference value, acquired at high gain.
Let RL+ be any raw curve acquired with low gain (gain of 2) and positive; let RH+ be any raw
curve acquired with a high gain (gain of 16) and positive; let RL- be any raw curve acquired with a
low gain (gain of 2) and negative; let RH- be any raw curve acquired with a high gain (gain of 16)
and negative.
2.2.2
CCL FORMULAS
For CCL the formulas are:
Correct_Reading(mV) = 580 mV/CCLG*[(RL+)-(WZLP)]/[(WCLP)-(WZLP)]
Correct_Reading(mV) = 580 mV/CCLG*[(RH+)-(WZHP)]/[(WCHP)-(WZHP)]
Correct_Reading(mV) = -580 mV/CCLG*[(RL-)-(WZLN)]/[(WCLP)-(WZLP)]
Correct_Reading(mV) = -580 mV/CCLG*[(RH-)-(WZHN)]/[(WCHP)-(WZHP)]
CCLG is the CCL gain. If bit X = 0, then CCLG = 0.4.
If bit X = 1, then CCLG = 48.
2.2.3
SPONTANEOUS POTENTIAL CASE
For SP there is only one formula because it is acquired always with a gain of 16 and with the
implicit sign bit = 1 (positive).
Correct_Reading(mV) = 580 mV*[(RH+)-|(WZHP)|]/[(WCHP)-|(WZHP)|] - SPOFST
SPOFST is calculated as follows:
SPOFST (in E.U. millivolts) = 1350 mV - 300 mV * (binary code)
The binary code for the offset ranges from dec 0 (WXY = 000) to dec 7 (WXY = 111).

DOWNHOLE DEFAULTS AT POWER-UP
At power-up the 3514 defaults are as follows:
1.
The Mud Resistivity latching relays (LOG/CAL/ZERO) are in LOG state.
2.
The AC Motor/Mode 7 non-latching relay is in AC Motor state.
3.
The Tool SP/Bridle SP latching relay is in Tool SP state.
4.
The Uphole SP/DLL analog switch (non-latching) is in Uphole SP state.
NOTE:The default at power-up is not set for testing Mode 7.

TOOL STRING COMMANDS
In order to guarantee that all the instruments in the tool string are reset, in the No-Motor mode and
in LOG, the following commands are required:

Reset all instruments(C)0000+(W)0014

Exit Motor Mode all(C)0004+(W)0014

Log all(C)0009+(W)0014 

TOOL COMMANDS
The surface system initializes the Common Remote before attempting to acquire data from it.
The commands are:

ACTION
COMMAND/DATA STRING
Exit AC Motor Mode (C)8004+(W)0014

Tool SP(C)8080+(W)0014 OR

Bridle SP (C)8081+(W)0014

Uphole SP(C)8082+(W)0014 OR

DLL(C)8083+(W)0014

MOTORING COMMANDS
This tool does not have a motor.  The AC and DC motoring condutors are hardwired and donot
need relay switching in the 3514 to complete the circuits.  If the tool power is turned off, the tool
will re-initialize itself.  Refer to Section 3.1 for the defaults of the tool at power-up.
DC motoring can be performed while communicating on "True Mode 7" (M7 C).
Assume that a tool with WTS address hex 99 is to be opened, and that the tool does not require a
parameter.  The following is the required sequence of commands and tests:
Exit AC Motor Mode (C)8004+(W)0014
ACTION
COMMAND/DATA STRING
--------------------------------
--------------------------------------
Force all instruments in the
tool string to exit motor mode:
All instruments exit motor mode (C)0004+(W)0014
Open Tool(C)9905+(D)0000+(W)0014
Check status of tool:
Tool Send Motor Status(C)990 F+(D)0001
The tool should send the word[D]0001
Increase motor supply voltage and
hold  it until the motoring action
is complete.
Check status of tool:
Tool Exit Motor Mode(C)9904+(W)0014
Tool Send Motor Status(C)990 F+(D)0001
The tool should send the word[D]0000
The procedure for closing is the same as the one described above, except that all the OPEN
commands are changed to CLOSE commands.
NOTE: Before applying AC Motor Power (RCI), perform the sequence
(C)8000 + (D)0000 + (W) 0014 to open wireline conductor 7.  Then, request the status word with
(C)800 F + (D)0001.  The 3514 should send the word [D]0001.  When AC motoring is completed,
turn down the AC power and perform the sequence (C)8004 + (W)0014 to reconnect to wireline
conductor 7.  Check the status of the 3514 with (C)800 F + (D)0001 - it should send [D]0000.

topic: INTERFACE SPECIFICATIONS - 1.1 TOOL ADDRESS INTERFACE SPECIFICATIONS
chunk_text:
TOOL ADDRESS
Tool NameWTS Common Remote
WTS Tool Address80 hex
Duplicate Tool AddressNot supported 2
INTERFACE SPECIFICATIONS
3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-926
JULY 2002

3

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-926
JULY 2002
(Command Synch) Motor Open  (DC Motor)
8005
(Data Synch) parameter
0000
or
(Command Synch) Motor Close (DC Motor)
8006
(Data Synch) parameter
0000
The WTS Common Remote does not have a motor. Any of the two commands above set the
non-latching relay AC Motor/Mode 7 of the Common Remote to the AC Motor State (default at
power-up).
In the 3514, the AC and DC motoring conductors are hardwired, without requiring switching
relays to complete the motoring circuits.  Either of these commands could be used to prepare the
3514 for RCI operations.  Either command will disconnect the Mode 7 signal path and the uphole
SP path or LL return path from wireline conductor 7.  See additional comments under command
8000.
(Command Synch) Internal Zero
8007 & 0007
The instrument switches to Internal Zero state (only for Mud Resistivity).
(Command Synch) Internal Cal
8008 & 0008
The instrument switches to Internal Cal state (only for Mud Resistivity).
(Command Synch) Log
8009 & 0009
The instrument switches to Mud Resistivity Log state (default at power-up).
(Command Synch) Tool SP
8080
When this command is executed, the latching relay Tool SP/Bridle SP is set to Tool SP.  This is
the default state at power-up. In the default state, SP is allowed to come from any instrument
below the Common Remote connected to the SP line.  Also, the lower bridle electrode will be
routed to pin #8 of the lower 32-pin instrument bus connector in the 3514.
(Command Synch) Bridle SP
8081
When this command is executed, the latching relay Tool SP/Bridle SP is set to the Bridle SP state.
In this case, the lower bridle electrode is disconnected from pin #8 of 32-pin instrument bus
connector.  If there is an instrument in the string that uses the Lower Bridle Electrode, the Tool
SP/Bridle SP relay has to be in the Tool SP position.   The 3514 measures downhole SP versus
armor (conductor 10).
(Command Synch) Uphole SP
8082
When this command is executed, an analog switch connects the selected SP signal through a choke
to Mode 7/AC MTR relay.  This is the default at power-up.
(Command Synch) DLL
8083
When this command is executed, an analog switch connects the DLL  (HDLL) line of the
instrument bus through a choke to the Mode 7/AC MTR relay.  Command 8004 must also be sent

4

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-926
JULY 2002
to energize his relay and complete the Laterolog return path.
(Command Synch) Loop Back
809n
When this command is executed, the Common Remote sends 16 words with the pattern 'nnnn',
where n is any hexadecimal number. It can be used to check Telemetry Channel 2, both ways.
(Command Synch) Send Status
800 E
[Data Synch] Status Word - The instrument answers with its status word.
The WTS Common Remote Status Word is defined as follows:
MSB
LSB
|
|
PONM LKJI HGFE DCBA
Where:
A = SP
IF A = 1, SP COMES FROM THE BRIDLE ELECTRODE, ELSE
FROM THE TOOL.
B = DLL/UPHOLE SP
IF B = 1, TOOL IS IN DLL MODE, ELSE IT IS IN MODE 7.
C = MODE 7/AC MOTOR
IF C = 0, NO-MOTOR, ELSE MOTOR.
ED = MODE
IF ED = 00, INTERNAL ZERO,
IF ED = 01, INTERNAL CAL,
IF ED = 10, LOG.
I = ACCELEROMETER FLAG
IF I = 1, IT COULD NOT READ THE ACCELEROMETER
COEFFICIENT TABLE DUE TO THE ABSENCE OF THE MODULE,
AND NO TABLE IS UPLOADED.
The rest of the bits are not used.
(Command Synch) Send Selected Status
800 F
(Data Synch) Send Motor Status
0001
The instrument answers with
[Data Synch] [0000] Mode 7 State or

[0001] AC Motor (AC Motor Close or AC Motor Open)
(The command 8084 produces the same effect)

5

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-926
JULY 2002
(Command Synch) Upload Table [NOT USED]
800 A
(Data Synch) (Table_Number)
0010
(Data Synch) (Word_Cnt)
0080
The instrument answers with hex 0080 (dec 128) words or (dec 256) bytes on mode 2 with Data
Synch.  The Word_Cnt can be any number from hex 1 to hex 80.
In some prototype 3510 instruments, table number hex 0010 (dec 16) contained the coefficients of
the accelerometers and some other information.  This table is not used in the 3514.
(The command 80 A0 produced the same effect, sending all hex 80 elements of the table # hex 10.)
If the command gets no response, bit I of the status word can be checked.

topic: INTERFACE SPECIFICATIONS - INTERFACE SPECIFICATIONS 2.0 DATA FORMAT
chunk_text:
6

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-926
JULY 2002 2.0 DATA FORMAT

7

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-926
JULY 2002
SP (mV) = Corrected_Reading_SP - SPOFST
For convenience, the offset formula given above is tabulated below for all states of the binary code
XYZ.
The rationale for choosing the offset range would not be apparent without the following desirable
results:
At the lowest end of the SP signal range, SPOFST would be: +50 mV -1350 mV = -1300 mV.
At the highest end: +550 mV + 750 mV = +1300 mV.
The total SP range is then +/- 1300 mV.
WXY
SPOFST
000
+1350
001
+1050
010
+ 750
011
+ 450
100
+ 150
101
- 150
110
- 450
111
- 750
The SP offset is assumed to be exact, that is, it needs no correction.  The SP offset adds dynamic
range to the SP subsystem, with the same resolution over the overall range.  It is added downhole
to the Spontaneous Potential signal before the X16 gain stage, to limit the swing of the signal
between +50 mV and +550 mV.

8

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-926
JULY 2002
The following formulas are used, depending on the sign and gain bits of the curve:
If the sign bit is 1 (positive), and the gain bit is 0
(gain = 2):
Correct_Reading(mV) = 580 mV * [(RL+) - (WZLP)] / [(WCLP) - (WZLP)]
If the sign bit is 1 (positive), and the gain bit is 1
(gain = 16):
Correct_Reading(mV) = 580 mV * [(RH+) - (WZHP)] / [(WCHP) - (WZHP)]
If the sign bit is 0 (negative), and the gain bit is 0
(gain = 2):
Correct_Reading(mV) = -580 mV * [(RL-) - (WZLN)] / [(WCLP) - (WZLP)]
If the sign bit is 0 (negative), and the gain bit is 1
(gain = 16):
Correct_Reading(mV) = -580 mV * [(RH-) - (WZHN)] / [(WCHP) - (WZHP)]
All the values in the above formulas are the values received from the tool, ANDed with (hex)
0 FFF to mask off the high order nibble, and floated before use.  580 mV is a tool internal
reference value.
The preceding formulas are used for:
-Flask Temperature
-Cablehead Tension
-Caliper *
-Borehole Temperature
-Cablehead Voltage
-Motor Voltage
-Mud Resistivity
* - note: in addition to the above formulas, the Caliper "correct reading (mV)" must be
multiplied by a factor of three, to compensate for the circuit's voltage divider.
The additive and multiplicative factors to convert to Engineering Units are to be applied after the
raw values are corrected as indicated above.

Convention:
(C)WXYZ means a word with command synch that is sent to the tool string, WXYZ are hex
digits.
(D)WXYZ means a word with data synch that is sent to the tool string.
[D]WXYZ means a word sent to the surface by a downhole tool.
(W)WXYZ means that the surface system waits for a period of time expressed by hex WXYZ in
milliseconds (maximum time 65536 milliseconds).
NOTE: THIS IS ONLY A NOTATION CONVENTION; THIS IS NOT A
COMMAND BEING SENT TO THE DOWNHOLE TOOL.
Example: (W)03 E8 means wait for 1000 milliseconds before proceeding.

topic: LEVEL 1 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE - PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE LEVEL 1 1.0 VISUAL INSPECTION AND CLEANING
chunk_text:
1

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-951
JULY 2002 1.0 VISUAL INSPECTION AND CLEANING

Clean pressure housing thoroughly before removing thread protectors.

Remove thread protectors, clean subs and inspect threads for damage.

Before replacing O-Rings, clean seats and look for any marks, rust or pitting.

topic: LEVEL 1 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE - 2.0 CONTINUITY AND LEAKAGE CHECKS
chunk_text:
Inspect the connectors for any contacts that are not retained or show signs of damage.

Check continuity between the top and bottom connectors for conductors 1, 4, and 10.

Check for any leakage between DC supply Common (conductor 18 or 25 of the 3514 XA top
Airborn connector), and chassis or housing.

topic: TEST SYSTEMS GUIDE - TEST SYSTEMS GUIDE 1.0 COMMUNICATION WITH THE COMMON REMOTE
chunk_text:
1

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-976
JULY 2002 1.0 COMMUNICATION WITH THE COMMON REMOTE
Using a dummy or actual line, connect the electronics to the WTS Analog Test Panel operating
with a PC and the TEST3510.EXE program or other updated versions.  (see the Preventive
Maintenance Level 3 document, Figure 953-1, Setup for Testing 3514 Common Remote).
Use a 28 pin patch box (F123560000) to insert a true RMS current meter (Fluke 87 DMM) in
series with conductor 1 at the top of the 3514.
Power-up the instrument with Instrument Power using a voltmeter to measure 180 VAC at the
cablehead.  Verify current is 80 to 110 mA (100 to 140 mA above the sensors simulator box,
F156150000).
Verify communication by exercising the loopback command.  Common Remote errors produce
audible tones in the PC when the sound option is enabled.
Verify correct data acquisition operation by acquiring some subsets and monitoring various data
channels of signals originating inside the Common Remote.
If using a classic ECLIPS system instead of the PC, run the 3514 software program WTSCOM to
verify the above responses.
If using ECLIPS-S, from the Acquisition menu, select "Communication Utilities".  Then select the
RAP card and "Multiple Telemetry Setcom".  In the pop-up menu, select the telemetry type you
want to test, and select the tool (3514).  Other selections are GAIN SET; and then TRAIN, or LCP
(to set LCP relays).
OCT's were developed to request subset E from the tools and display the received data, compared
to the expected data. One of these OCT's  should be used to verify the data coming back is correct.
There are two OCT's which can display the subset E data:  _894 A1 and _894 T.  Probably _894 A
gets the most use.

1. Edit _894 A to correspond to the string you have connected.
2. Start the OCT.
3. Open the all.show display, and scroll down to see the subset E curves.
4. The curves are grouped by tool address.

For mode 2, the data will be displayed as E2 C1.xx through E2 C8.xx, where xx is the tool address
(Common Remote address = 80; Spectralog = 08; HDIL = 15; Acoustic = 03; etc.)
The STM2.xx curve displays the checksum status of E2 C2.xx through E2 C8.xx.  E2 C1.xx is not
included in the checksum.  If the checksum is correct, STM2.xx = 0.  If there is an error in the
returned subset E data, STM2.xx = 1.


1 The _ denotes the letter identifier (e, f, g, etc.) for the current ECLIPS database revision, and will
vary according to the current ECLIPS release.

topic: TEST SYSTEMS GUIDE - TEST SYSTEMS GUIDE
chunk_text:
2

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-976
JULY 2002
For mode 5, the data will be displayed as E5 C1.xx through E5 C17.xx, with checksum status
curve STM5.xx.

For mode 7, the data will be displayed as E7 C1.xx through E7 C17.xx, with checksum status
curve STM7.xx.

If the system recognizes a tool as not containing a M5 or M7 line driver, M5 or M7 curves will not
be displayed.

If there are a lot of tools in the string, the Spectralog's data for E2 C1 might be displayed as 08yy,
where yy is the address of the tool connected below the 1329.  For example, 0815 could be
displayed, if an HDIL is connected below the Spectralog.  The data sent from the 1329 should be
0808.  This is a WTS bug.  E2 C1.xx is not included in the checksum.

NVM only checks that the words are in valid Manchester format.  NVM does not check that the
data is correct.  The value of -894 A is that it checks that the data received matches the data the tool
is supposed to send, for each enabled mode.

topic: TEST SYSTEMS GUIDE - TEST SYSTEMS GUIDE 2.0 CHECKING INSTRUMENT BUS, COMMUNICATION ON MODES 2, 5 AND 7C
chunk_text:
3

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-976
JULY 2002 2.0 CHECKING INSTRUMENT BUS, COMMUNICATION ON MODES 2, 5 AND 7 C
Communication on modes 2, 5, and 7 C can be checked either by operating an actual WTS tool
string that transmits on these modes, or by using a tool simulator.  The latter assumes using a PC.
In the first case, if using the WTS system, run the corresponding services and verify correct
reception.
In the second case, connect the Tool Simulator to the bottom connector of the Common Remote.
Select the option Tool Simulator from the menu of the TEST3510.EXE PC software.  Run
Acquire Subset 0.
The simulator is exercised in a background cycle during the 3514 data acquisition loop.  Errors
produce audible clicks.  Note that for Mode 7 C to function, two settings must be in the correct
position to route the signal.  The required Mode 7 C settings are as follows:
1.
The motor switch of the Analog Test Panel must be in the NO MOTOR position.
2.
Relay K1 in the Common Remote must be set in EXIT mode.
Verify the above settings noting that the last K1 setting should be indicated on the status line of the
Acquire Menu.  If incorrect, hit the Enter key to bring up the command window.  Select EXIT
mode and hit ENTER again, or the EXIT key, to continue acquiring.
Hit the space bar to observe communication on Modes 2, 5, and 7 C and any communication errors.
Isolate and correct any problems.
Verify the switching of relay K1 by changing the command from EXIT mode to MOTOR mode.
Conductor 7 becomes disconnected from the mode 7 C channel causing communication on this
mode to cease.
Restore mode 7 C communication by switching back to EXIT mode.
For more extensive testing of these modes and faster repetition rates, the software program
TESTW1 PC is provided.  The faster cycles are helpful in obtaining steadier waveforms on an
analog scope for monitoring or debugging purposes.

topic: TEST SYSTEMS GUIDE - TEST SYSTEMS GUIDE 3.0 TESTING THE ANALOG CHANNELS
chunk_text:
4

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-976
JULY 2002 3.0 TESTING THE ANALOG CHANNELS
The analog channels can be tested by acquiring certain subsets and verifying the readings for
expected values, tolerances, and noise levels.
Channels with sensors that connect to the Upper Bus of the Common Remote require the use of
these devices in a controlled environment, or the use of a sensors simulator box (P/N 156150). The
box is used to simulate force, caliper, hole temperature, CCL, SP and mud resistivity.
Other channels measured inside the Common Remote such as the six calibration values, flask
temperature, cablehead voltage, motor voltage, internal zero, and cal values for the mud resistivity
can all be verified directly.
These tests can best be performed by using the exhaustive method given in the Preventive
Maintenance Level 3 document in this manual.  (see section 7.1 Method 1: Using Simulators).
However, the following simplified procedure is adequate for this section:
Connect a patch box (F 123560000) above the simulator, power instrument; and run the Common
Remote test program if using a PC.
Exercise Acquire subset F routine and verify the following:
A/D CAL HI (WCHPOS) and CAL LO (WCLPOS) values = 580 mV + 15 mV.
All four A/D Zero Reference (WZxxxx) values are within 50 mV.
Exercise Acquire Subset 0 routine.
Verify the Flask Temperature reads ambient temperature.
Verify the Cablehead Voltage reads the value applied to tool.
CAUTION
DO NOT USE THE ANALOG TEST PANEL TO VERIFY THE MOTOR VOLTAGE
CHANNEL READING.
The 5721 analog test panel applies AC motor voltage on AC-centertap vs. 10, whereas the 3514
expects AC motor voltage on Mode 5-centertap vs 10.  Use an ECLIPS system to verify the AC
motor voltage channel reading as follows:
Verify the ECLIPS software is Release 3.0 Update 3 or later.
If a 4430 XB power sub is being used, install block #1 at the top of the 3514.  If a 4430 XB
is not in the string, use block #2.

3514 XA WTS COMMON REMOTE
P/N 130767-976
JULY 2002
On the 5756, select the following switch positions:
INPUT: MULTI and M5 CT; SERVICE: Modal; MOTORING: HVAC
Verify all power supplies are turned down.  Then, under EI CONTROL, choose OCT
SELECT.  Select "Yes" for True Mode 7.  Select OCT "x800 A" (RCI) and start it (the
letter x will vary depending on the release level of the ECLIPS software).
Apply 180 VAC instrument power.
NOTE
Relay K1 in the tool should be in its default motor state on power-up.  If
software has been running and K1 is in EXIT mode, reset it to MOTOR state.
Adjust the AC MOTOR supply to obtain 480 VAC between IB-12 and IB-10.
Verify the MTR CHV reading on the CRT display is equal to the AC voltage between
IB-12 and IB-10, ± 5 VAC.
Remove motor and instrument power.
Set the HI/ZERO/LO switch on the simulator box to HI.  Allow at least a few acquisition cycles
while observing the % change of reading from cycle to cycle.  Normally, changes should be within
1% or less for quiet signals.  Take readings after five minutes of cycling:
Tension
+4 V + .2 V or other simulated reading
"Pressure" (Caliper)
+1.67  + .1 V or other simulated reading
Holetemp
+200°C + 10°C or other simulated reading
CCL
+42 mV + 5 mV or other simulated reading
Set the switch to LO.
Verify the following readings:
Tension
-4 V + .2 V or other simulated reading
"Pressure" (Caliper)
-2.0 V  + .1 mV or other simulated reading
Holetemp
-200°C + 10°C or other simulated reading
CCL
-10 V + 1 V or other simulated reading
Set the switch to ZERO and note the offsets for the above channels.  The numbers may deviate
from zero depending on the noise and offset of each channel.  Compare with previous calibration
records.

The SP signal in the simulator uses conductor 8 as an electrode.  Therefore, latch the Tool
SP/Bridle SP relay on the controller card in the Bridle SP mode, using the command menu,
before taking this measurement.
Check the SP circuit by advancing the switch through its 10- position settings and verify each
reading.  Indicated numerals 0-9 are for the decimal thumbwheel switch used in some prototype
units.  The production simulator box has a rotary switch.
0:  ≤ + 10 mV offset
5:    ≤ + 10 mV offset
1:  +1200 mV
6:   -300 mV
2:   +900 mV
7:   -600 mV
3:   +600 mV
8:   -900 mV
4:   +300 mV
9:  -1200 mV
Accuracy of the SP values depends on the simulator calibration as well as the 3514 circuit.  Output
of the simulator itself can be checked by monitoring the input of the SP channel on the Sensors
card.  Recalibrate the simulator if necessary.
Latch the analog switch (U17) in the uphole SP position by selecting "Mode 7" in TEST3510's
command menu.  Select SP position #1 (+1200 mV) on the simulator.  Measure +1.2  ±.1 VDC
between conductors 7(+) and 10(-) on the patch box (F123560000).  Select "DLL" in the
command menu and measure < 50 mVDC.
Set the tool mode to Internal CAL (for Rm CAL) using the command menu.
Acquire Subset 0 and verify Rm CAL = 10 Ωm ± .1 Ωm.
Switch the tool to internal ZERO.
Acquire Subset 0 and verify Rm ZERO = 1 Ωm ± .05 Ωm.
Switch the tool to LOG.
Acquire subset 0 and verify Rm LOG = 5 Ωm ± .5 Ωm or other simulated value.
NOTE
The following curves are not used in the 3514:
ACCELX
ACCELY
ACCELZ
PRESTEMP
ACCELTEMP

130961-956 / 3518 FB 
JUL 2004

OVERVIEW
The power supply uses a half-bridge switching power supply topology to convert a
nominal 250 Vdc to 28 Vdc. The half-bridge topology (see Figure 2) consists of two
alternately-conducting MOSFETs (Q1, Q2), input energy storage capacitors (C11, C14),
switched mode power transformer (T1), rectifier diodes (D1, D3), switched mode choke
(L1), and output filter capacitors (C1, C2).

conduction time (ton) of MOSFETs Q1 and Q2, which are switching at a frequency of
120 kHz (1/T). A closed loop feedback system compares Eo to a reference voltage and
adjusts the MOSFETs conduction time (ton) to maintain a constant output voltage (Eo).
For example, as Ein increases, ton decreases proportionally to maintain a constant Eo.
Mathematically, this can be written as:

Ein
Np
Ns
T
ton
Eo
*
*
=


Where:

Ein is the nominal 250-Vdc input voltage to the Power Supply

Ns/Np is the turns ratio of power transformers T1

1/T is the 120 kHz switching frequency

ton is the MOSFET’s conduction time

Eo is the regulated 28 Vdc output





130961-945 / 3518 FB
JUL 2004
4
3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions
Tracing through one cycle of operation, assume Q1 has been biased off and Q2 on.
Current flows from C14 through T1, C12, and Q2, applying 1/2 Ein across the primary
(Np) of T1. This primary voltage pulse is inductively coupled to the secondary winding
(Ns) of T1. The coupled secondary voltage forward biases diode D1, permitting
secondary current to flow through C1 and C2 and returning through L1 to the secondary
center tap of T1.
The conduction period ends when the conducting MOSFET (Q2) is commanded off, but
L1 ensures that current continue to flow to the load. Secondary current continues to flow
since the current through an inductor cannot change instantaneously. This is referred to as
the “freewheeling” period, which is the interval inductor L1 maintains the load current
until the opposite MOSFET begins conducting. Current flows from L1, through D1, D3
and returns through C1 and C2 during the “freewheeling” period.
When the opposite MOSFET (Q1) is commanded on, the “freewheeling” period ends, D3
is now forward biased, D1 is reverse biased, and current flows through C1, C2 again,
returning through L1 to the secondary center tap of T1.
The cycle repeats with the next “freewheeling” period followed by Q2 being commanded
on again. The MOSFET’s conduction time is controlled by the feedback circuitry to
maintain a constant 28-Vdc output in spite of the varying load and Ein.
Waveform 2 = Q1 source
Waveform 3 = T1 Center tap (TP1)
Waveform 4 = L1 Current

POWER SUPPLY CONTROLLER BOARD
Refer to schematic drawing 199005-100 during the discussion of the Power Supply
Controller board.
130961-945 / 3518 FB
JUL 2004
6
3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

VOLTAGE MODE PWM CONTROLLER
Voltage mode PWM (Pulse Width Modulator) Controller U1 provides the nucleus for the
converter control circuitry. U1 provides the building blocks for the control circuitry that
consists of an error amplifiers, clock, PWM circuitry, and shutdown circuitry.
Converter switching frequency is set by the PWM’s clock, which operates at twice the
switching frequency. Components R16, C19, and C20 set the oscillator frequency and
dead time. The PWM’s Sync signal (pin 10) is used on the Output Filter PCB. U8 and
U9 A buffer the signal (CLKOUT) before it is transformer (T3) coupled to the Output
Filter PCB.
Control of the MOSFET conduction time is accomplished with PWM circuitry internal to
U1. The PWM circuitry functions by comparing the error voltage at U1, pin 5 with a
ramp signal synchronized with the PWM’s clock. Q3 buffers the ramp signal, which is
then applied to U1, pin 4. The PWM circuitry provides a duty cycle modulated waveform
that is alternately directed to DrvA and DrvB. Figure 4 shows the PWM (U1) waveforms.

Where:
Waveform 1 = CLKOUT  Waveform 3 = DRVA
Waveform 2 = Ramp at U1-4
Waveform 4 = DRVB
JUL 2004
7
3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

MOSFET DRIVERS
DrvA and DrvB of U1 are buffered by high-speed MOSFET driver ICs U2 and U4. U2
and U4 provide the high current gate drive, via transformer T1, to rapidly turn Q1 and
Q2, on and off. Dual secondary transformer T1 provides the necessary high side/low side
drive capability required for the Half-Bridge topology. Resistors R4 and R15 serve to
control Q1 and Q2 turn-on gate current and dampen ringing at the gate. Components R2,
R9, D1, and D2 provide an additional path for gate current (at turn-off) to ensure the
rapid turn-off of Q1 and Q2. Figure 5 shows the gate drive waveforms.

Where:
Waveform 1 = CLKOUT
Waveform 2 = Q2 gate – source
Waveform 3 = DRA – DRB




130961-945 / 3518 FB
JUL 2004
8
3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

SOFT START
Soft start (SS) is a controlled start-up process that reduces stress on the Power Supply
components and minimizes output overshoot during start-up. Soft start is accomplished
by controlling the rate at which the voltage on pin 1 (C/S SS) of the PWM IC ramps-up,
which in turn controls Vout’s rise time. The controlled start-up is provided by the time
constant provided by R53 and C62. The voltage across C62 is buffered by U11 and drives
the PWM’s C/S SS pin. Note that the 28 volt output takes ~160 ms to reach full output.
PSEN = 1, Run goes high and turns off Q5 and Q8, which allows the voltage on C62 to
start increasing exponentially, allowing Vout to start ramping up. Comparator-generated
signals SSRST/ and SSCMP indicate SS status. Signal SSRST/ is low when C62 is fully
discharged and conversely SSCMP=1 when SS is complete. These signals control the SS
process when HCL (high current limit) goes high. Under a sustained HCL condition, SS
is invoked and the signals force each SS cycle to terminate before the next cycle starts.

Where:
Waveform 1 = SS (U1-1)
Waveform 3 = SSCMP (U14-6)
Waveform 2 = SSRST (U12-6) Waveform 4 = 28 volt output (P2-1 to P2-6)
JUL 2004
9
3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

CONTROL LOOP CIRCUITRY
The demodulated error voltage provided by the Output Filter PCB is received via the
Sense+ and Sense- lines. Choke T2 provides common-mode filtering and the
demodulated error voltage is buffered by a differential amplifier consisting of U3 and
associated components. The buffered error voltage (VERROR) is applied through and an
RC network to pin 5 (E/A+) of the PWM U1. Internal to U1, the error voltage is
compared to the voltage ramp on U6, pins 4. This comparison produces the ton pulse that
is alternately connected to A Out or B Out of U1. As previously discussed, a change in
Eo is detected by the control-loop circuitry and the circuit adjusts ton proportionately to
correct Eo. Refer to Figure 4 and Figure 7.

Where:
Waveform 1 = VEER3 – Output Filter PCB
Waveform 2 = CLKOUT – Controller PCB
Waveform 3 = D12 A – Output filter PCB
Waveform 4 = VERROR – Controller PCB
130961-945 / 3518 FB
JUL 2004
10
3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

OUTPUT OVER-CURRENT PROTECTION
Refer to Figure 8, Figure 9, and Figure 10 during this discussion. Current transformer T4
samples the current pulses, delivered by Q1 and Q2 to the primary of transformer T1 to
provide over-current protection. The primary current is used to detect output overload
conditions since the primary current is equal to the secondary current reflected by Np/Ns.
Components R22, D3, and D4 convert the bipolar current pulse to a unipolar voltage
pulse. Components R21, R23, C71 and C21 serve to divide and filter the signal prior to
application to U7 and U13, which are the over current detection comparators. Transistor
Q4, IC U6, and associated components blank the leading edge current spike, on R22, to
prevent false over-current limiting.

Where:
Waveform 1 = Sync
Waveform 2 = VBLANK
Waveform 3 = Across R22
Waveform 4 = Ipri

130961-945 / 3518 FB
JUL 2004
11
3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

20% or greater, only LCL current limit is invoked. Figure 9 the low-current level
waveforms. If the overload is 40% or greater, The HCL current limit is invoked, the
output is temporarily removed, and a soft-start restart sequence is initiated. Figure 8
shows the high-current level waveforms.

Waveform 2 = Ipri
Waveform 3 = LCL
Waveform 4 = SS

Where:

INPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION
Operation at excessively high or low CHV is inhibited to prevent possible damage to the
Focus/WTS Adapter Power Supply. Detection of out-of-range CHV is accomplished on
the PIC (Power Inhibit Controller) PCB and the Power Supply is controlled by the Power
Supply Enable Line (PSEN). A logic high enables the Power Supply.

topic: Circuit Description - 2.6 INPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION ..........................12 2.7 OUTPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION ......................12
chunk_text:
INPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION 12 
OUTPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION 12

OUTPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION
Output over- and under -voltage protection is also provided, should the Power Supply
output drop below 25 Vdc or exceed 33 Vdc. Power Fault Monitor IC U1 on the output
filter PCB monitors the Output Voltage and will pull either OUV/ or OOV/ low if Vout is
either too low or too high, respectively. An Optical coupler (U10) on the Controller PCB,
conveys these signals to logic array U16. The logic in U16 latches the fault condition and
commands the Power Supply off, only in the case of output over-voltage, by raising
130961-945 / 3518 FB
JUL 2004
13
3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions
Shutdown (SD) and dropping RUN. The latched status' LOUV/ and LOOV/ are sent over
to the PIC PCB for diagnostic purposes. U1 also controls a Green LED (D11) that
illuminates whenever the Power Supply is up and Vout is within tolerance.

CONTROLLER OPERATING POWER
Operating power for the controller is provided by an external 15 Vdc from the PIC PCB.
Three simple linear regulators provide +5 V, +5 VD, and +10 V to power the Controller
PCB electronics. The regulators are composed of transistors Q6, Q7, Q9, and associated
passive components.

LOW-PASS FILTER
Refer to schematic drawing 199004-100 during this discussion. The chassis mounted
output rectifiers D1, D3, and switched mode choke L1 are connected to the Output Filter
Board. Components L1, C1, and C2 comprise a low-pass filter that averages the voltage
pulses from the rectifiers to produce 28 Vdc. Additional differential filtering and
common-mode filtering is provided by three cascaded low-pass filter stages. These filter
stages are comprised of L2, L3, L4, and associated capacitors. Figure 11 shows the 28-
volt output ripple and noise.

JUL 2004
14
3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

RECTIFIER SNUBBER
RC snubbers (R1 – R3, R5, R28, R29, C11, C18, and C35) across each rectifier diode and
transformer secondary dampen rectifier turn-on ringing, which is caused by the resonance
of the rectifier’s junction capacitance and the transformer’s secondary leakage
inductance. 

HOUSEKEEPING POWER SUPPLY
The housekeeping power supply (HKPS) is a two transistor Flyback Switching Power
Supply that is controlled by a Si9120 PWM IC. Operation is similar to the previously
discussed PWM circuitry in that the MOSFET’s conduction time is modulated to
maintain a constant output voltage.
The voltage ramp required for PWM is provided by capacitor C53 charging through
resistors R45 and R59. Diode D16 serves to reset the ramp after each cycle. Output over-
current protection is provided via resistor R13 and diode D20.
For regulation purposes, the 15 Vdc is fed back through R12 and R17; with C21, C25,
and R11 setting the loop gain.
Resistor R6 sets the PWM’s switching frequency to 200 kHz, while resistor R16
establishes the PWM’s bias current. The PWM’s pin-5 output drives the two MOSFETs
concurrently, each through its own DC restoration circuit (C23, D19, R56, C17, D13, and
R53). Energy is stored in the air gap of T1 while transistors Q2 and Q1 are conducting.
During the conduction interval, diode D1 is reverse biased. When Q1 and Q2 are turned
off, energy stored in T1 is released, D1 is forward biased, and the output capacitors (C6-
C15, C46, and C47) are charged. During the conduction interval, when D1 is reverse-
biased, energy stored in the output capacitors maintains the 15-Vdc output.
Start-up power is provided to the PWM through diode D12 and resistor R3. Once the
HKPS commences operation, PWM operating power is supplied from the 15-Vdc output
via components D4, R45, D5, D9, and D10.
130961-945 / 3518 FB
JUL 2004
15
3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions
Comparators U1 A and U1 B set the HKPS input operating voltage range and turn-on
voltage. Like the Focus/WTS Adapter Power Supply, the HKPS input voltage operating
range is controlled to prevent damage. U3 provides a reference voltage to the
comparators as well as the PWM chip.

Where:
Waveform 1 = PWM Output (U2-5)
Waveform 2 = Q1, Drain – Source
Waveform 3 = Q2, Drain – Source
Waveform 4 = SENSE (U2-4)



130961-945 / 3518 FB
JUL 2004
16
3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

Where:
Waveform 1 = +15 Vdc Output
Waveform 2 = D1 Anode
MICRO-COMPUTER CONTROLLER
The PIC16 F873, U5, is an 8-bit microcontroller with an internal 10-bit A/D and data
EEPROM. Chip U6 and related components translate CHV to a 0 Vdc to 5 Vdc signal
(ACHV) that is compatible with U5. Likewise, U10 and related components translate
temperature dependent current from the chassis-mounted AD590 to a signal (ATEMP)
that is compatible with U5. Chip U8 permits monitoring of the 15-Vdc supplied by the
HKPS.
Power Supply Enable (PSEN) and Over Current reset (OCR) are output command lines
to the Controller PCB. A logic high from PSEN turns on the 28-Vdc output and OCR
resets a latch internal to U16 on the Controller PCB.
Latched output under voltage (LOUV), latched output over-voltage (LOOV), and latched
over current (LOC) are 28-Vdc output status signals sent back from U16 on the
Controller PCB. The status of these signals is saved in the microcontroller’s EEPROM
for diagnostic purposes.
130961-945 / 3518 FB
JUL 2004
17
3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions
The microcontroller monitors cable-head voltage, chassis temperature, and housekeeping
voltage to ensure these parameters are within limits before enabling the 28 Vdc power
supply. Once the 28 Vdc power supply has been enabled, the microcontroller continues
monitoring the three parameters and will disable the power supply if any fall out-of-
range.
The typical ON/OFF set points determined by the microcontroller are:
•
Cablehead voltage set points:
�
Turn – ON:
Vch >225 Vdc or < 300 Vdc
�
Turn – OFF:
Vch < 160 Vdc or > 330 Vdc
•
Over-Temperature set points are as follows:
�
Power Supply OFF: Chassis temperature equal or greater than 175º C
�
Power Supply ON:
Chassis temperature 170º C or less
•
Vcc set points
�
Power Supply ON: 14.5 Vdc – 15.5 Vdc
When the cable-head voltage or chassis temperature goes out of range, the
microcontroller disables the power supply and waits for these conditions to fall within
range again before restarting the power supply. The microcontroller behaves slightly
differently to Vcc. If Vcc drifts out of range while the power supply has been enabled, the
PIC will permanently disable the power supply. In this situation, the microcontroller must
be reset by cycling the housekeeping voltage (i.e., lower the cablehead voltage below 150
Vac).
The PIC board monitors three power supply status signals (LOC, LOUV, LOOV) while
the 28 Vdc power supply is enabled. The PIC will record any change in the state of these
signals in its internal EEPROM. The PIC board will permanently disable the power
supply if the LOOV signal is asserted, indicating an over-voltage condition on the 28-
Vdc bus. Similar to a Vcc out-of-range condition, the microcontroller must be reset to
exit this condition.
LED D14 provides an indication of the microcontroller’s state. The LED blinks at a rate
of twice per second when the microcontroller is holding the 28 Vdc power supply off and
waiting for cablehead voltage, chassis temperature, and Vcc to fall in range. Once the 28
Vdc power supply has been turned on, the PIC will leave the LED on continuously. The
LED will blink at a rate of once per second when the PIC permanently disables the power
supply in the event of a Vcc out-of-range or assertion of LOOV.
Jumper JP1 is a 10-pin header used to connect the PIC board to a PC for diagnostic
purposes. Four shunts are installed across the jumper when the diagnostic port is not in
use.
P3 is a header used for in-circuit programming and debugging. J2 is a jumper with a
shunt that is removed only during in-circuit programming of the microcontroller. The
shunt needs to be installed for normal board operation.


130961-945 / 3518 FB
JUL 2004

MICRO-COMPUTER CONTROLLER 16

3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions 
INTRODUCTION
The 3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument Assembly is comprised of four circuit
boards and several chassis mounted components, as shown on wiring diagram
A30000101 WRD and Figure 1. Figure 1 is a block diagram of the 3518 FB Telemetry Power
Section Instrument Assembly. The four power supply boards are:
•
Power Supply Controller – 199005-000
•
Output Filter – 199004-000
•
Input Filter – 197993-000
•
Power Inhibit Controller (PIC) – A3000305000
The 3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument Assembly provides a regulated +28 Vdc at
4.0 amps, maximum, to the toolstring from a DC cable-head voltage (CHV) of 160 Vdc to
330 Vdc. However, a CHV of 225 Vdc is required to start the power supply to ensure the
CHV does not drop below 160 Vdc, due to the voltage drop in the cable as the power supply
comes up.

OUTPUT FILTER PCB 
INPUT FILTER PCB
Refer to schematic drawing 197993-100 during this discussion. A balanced, three-section,
low-pass filter prevents (attenuates) differential mode and common-mode switching noise at
Vin from contaminating the converter’s HV DC inputs, P1-1 and 10. The filters consist of L1
through L6 and associated capacitors. Resistors R1 through R24 serve as bleeders and to
equalize the voltage across their respective capacitors.

POWER INHIBIT CONTROLLER
Refer to schematic drawing A3000305 SCH during this discussion. Figure 12 and Figure 13
are scope shots that are provided to help understand the operation of the PIC PCB. The Power
Inhibit Controller (PIC) PC board consists of two major circuits: Micro Controller and related
acquisition circuitry, and the Housekeeping Power Supply (HKPS). The HKPS converts
Cable head voltage to +15 Vdc and Vcc to operate the Controller PCB (CB), the resident
Micro Controller, and associated acquisition circuitry. The Micro Controller monitors various
parameters and controls, and turns the main 28-Vdc output on or off.

INTRODUCTION
Level 3 maintenance should be performed on the 3518 FB Telemetry Power Section
Instrument Assembly every four months to ensure the integrity of the tool.

____  9.

Test Procedure 130961-856.

Dangerous voltage is present in the 3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument Assembly

the tool unattended when power is on and the pressure housing is removed.

3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument − Test System Guide 
The 3518 FB Telemetry Power Section Instrument is always run and tested with the 3518 EB 
Telemetry and Gamma Ray Sub Instrument. Refer to the 3518 EB Test System Guide document P/N 
130960-976 for testing procedures. 
 
130961-976 / 3518 FB 
JUL 2004

SERVICE OVERVIEW

The 3518 Focus Telemetry is a communications device for the Focus downhole
system.  This is a combination instrument comprised of the 3518 FB, the power
module, the 3518 EB, the communications module and the 3518 EG, the Gamma
Ray module.

The 3518 FB, the power module, converts a nominal wireline 250 VDC voltage to
+28 VDC as part of the Matrix1 Instrument Bus (MIB).  +28 VDC is generated to
provide power for instrument electronics and motors.  For more details, see
manual 130961-915.

The primary role of the 3518 EB module is to serve as a communications bridge
between the wireline and the MIB.  To do this, the Focus Telemetry accepts
surface commands in the AMI format.  The Telemetry determines if the received
word is valid, and if so, the entire word is regenerated in Manchester UDI format
and sent out on the MIB.  Focus instruments connected to the MIB are
responsible for their own interpretation and response to the Manchester signal.
Conversely, instrument data sent back to the surface is received by the
Telemetry and converted to AMI pulse format before being placed onto the
wireline.

Another role of the 3518 EB is to provide Cablehead Voltage (CHV) and
Spontaneous Potential (SP).

Also, as an integrated part of its mechanical makeup, there resides a Gamma
Ray (GR) instrument within the 3518 EB housing --- electrically, it responds as
any other Focus instrument connected to the Instrument Bus, sharing only
common power supplies with the Telemetry circuits.

Although still in development, the Telemetry has hardware support for Hybrid and
Battery Mode.  In these modes, the Telemetry autonomously acquires data from
the tools and stores the data in memory.  The Telemetry has a 10 base-T
Ethernet interface to allow fast dumping of data from memory.


1 Early naming of this engineering project was “Matrix” and much of the terminology associated
with it still contains references to Matrix.  As the engineering project became a public service,
Marketing decided the name should be changed to “Focus.”  References in older support and
requirements documents were not changed to reflect this name change.  Throughout much of the
documentation, the terms “Focus” and “Matrix” are used interchangeably, i.e. - Matrix Instrument

3518 EB Telemetry – Training Supplement
130960-936 / 3518 EB
JULY 2004
Baker Atlas
Wireline Considerations:
In the Focus system, instruments can operate with 7-conductor wirelines, a
single conductor wireline, or without an electrical line.  When there is no electrical
wireline, the Focus string can operate with battery power.  A Focus Battery
Module is required.
If there is no electrical wireline, or if the bandwidth of the wireline is very limited,
the 3518 EB/FB can record data in local memory, instead of sending it to the
surface.  The downhole Telemetry can be sent tables containing the list of
instruments to be sampled at regular intervals.  This is the standard mode of
operation when using batteries.

Matrix Instrument Bus
The standard Focus field joint uses either a 27 or 18-pin connector.  The only
difference is the 9 outside ring of pins – they are reserved for connecting to the
wireline according to Table 1.  Any instrument intended to be placed above the
Telemetry must include these wireline pins.  This allows Telemetry access to the
wireline.

3518 FB POWER SUPPLY
The power supply assembly of the 3518 FB is comprised of four circuit boards
and several chassis mounted components, as shown in the wiring diagram of
A3000072 WRD and Figure 2.  Figure 2 is a block diagram of the 3518 FB
Telemetry Power Section Instrument Assembly.  The four power supply boards
are:
•
Power Supply Controller – 199005-000
•
Output Filter – 199004-000
6

3518 EB Telemetry – Training Supplement
130960-936 / 3518 EB
JULY 2004
Baker Atlas
•
Input Filter – 197993-000
•
Power Inhibit Controller (PIC) – A3000305000
The 3518 FB Telemetry Power Section converts the nominal 250 VDC Cablehead
voltage to the required +28 VDC (4 Amps max.) bus voltage.  The normal
operating range for Cablehead voltage is 150 – 320 VDC.  If the Cablehead
voltage is set outside this window, the power supply will shut down and can only
be restarted by lowering the surface supply to zero.  To insure the power supply
does not oscillate on power-up, the instrument requires a minimum of 225 VDC to
start.  The upper limit, lower limit and the starting point are all controlled by the
PIC board.

3518 EB TELEMETRY
As mentioned earlier, the 3518 EB Telemetry instrument plays an important role
in the communications link between surface and downhole equipment.  For
Hybrid or Battery operated modes, the role of the Telemetry changes somewhat.
Since each Focus downhole instrument has the ability to receive and interpret
surface commands, the Telemetry instrument need only regenerate these signals
from wireline signals.  The 3518 EB contains an FPGA (Field Programmable Gate
Array) chip that converts wireline AMI signals into standard Manchester (and vice
versa) and ensures received and transmitted words are viable before passing
them to the appropriate recipient, whether downhole instrument or surface panel.
7

3518 EB Telemetry – Training Supplement
130960-936 / 3518 EB
JULY 2004
Baker Atlas
Focus instruments respond in the same way as WTS instruments, in that they
communicate using Mode 2, Mode 5 or Mode 7.  For more details on WTS
communications, see WTS-Tool Interface Specifications 059448-000.
The 3518 EB Telemetry receives AMI surface commands and regenerates it into
Manchester format before passing it down to the tool string via the Matrix
Instrument Bus (MIB).  Conversely, it receives tool data and converts it bit for bit
into AMI format to place it back onto the wireline.  Modal transformers mounted
on the backbone of the Telemetry combine/split wireline signals and tool power.
Power is returned to the 3518 FB while data signals are routed to the Wireline
Interface Board.  The Wireline Interface Board’s function is to decode and route
signals between the CPU, wireline and MIB.
When the need arises for the Telemetry to respond to surface commands, the
FPGA routes signals accordingly in response to the CPU Board.
Another function of the Telemetry is to acquire data from CHV and SP (both
surface and armor) measurements.  Theses circuits can be found on the CPU
board.

GAMMA RAY
The Telemetry also contains an integrated Gamma Ray module.  It is designed
into the Telemetry to shorten the overall tool string length.  As a stand-alone tool,
another instrument like the Gamma Ray would add weight and length because of
the field joints and power supplies.  By combining this tool with the Telemetry, it
eliminates those extra pieces.
The Gamma Ray electronics is fashioned after many of its predecessors.  It
begins with detecting the pulses from the Photomultiplier Tube, sending them
through a discriminator circuit and then to a counter where they can be ultimately
sent to the surface.
The Gamma Ray module of this instrument is slightly more sophisticated.  It uses
a microprocessor to handle the counts, A/D conversion, high voltage gain control,
measuring elapsed time, measuring temperature and communicating with the
surface.

3518 EB Telemetry – Training Supplement
130960-936 / 3518 EB
JULY 2004
Baker Atlas

MECHANICAL OPERATION

The 3518 EB/FB Telemetry is designed to operate as a pair.  It can be
mechanically broken down into two parts.  The 45-pin electro/mechanical joint
between them is a non-rotating thread joint2 that can easily separate the two
pieces.
Thread protectors should be inserted at any exposed joint to avoid thread
damage.
The 3-1/8” steel housings protect sensitive electronics from high pressure
conditions found in the wellbore (max. 10,000 psi).  Once connected together,
the 3518 EB and FB top and bottom sub of the pair appear as 27-pin standard
Focus field joints.  This configuration allows any Focus instrument containing
feedthrough wires 1 – 9 to be operated above the Telemetry, since these pins
connect to wireline conductors.
A special feature of the 3518 FB is an integrated Ethernet port embedded into the
heat sink at the top sub.  Removing the cover with an Allen wrench reveals a 6-
pin pressure bulkhead that allows connection to a computer for downloading data
stored in memory after running either in Hybrid or Memory Mode.  Connection to
this port requires a special cable and interface box.

2 Considered as a “lab joint” that should remain connected except for preventive maintenance,
this joint is made from Titanium.  The spin collar contains smaller wrench holes which alerts field
personnel that it is not a field joint where the tool string is broken apart.

CONTROLLER BOARD 3
2.0 CONTROLLER BOARD
Refer to drawing 197392-000 and schematic 197392-100 for component locations
for the following descriptions. 

CPU AND MEMORY

The circuitry of the CPU board centers around U2, a Motorola MCF5407 (Coldfire)
microprocessor.  The Coldfire is a 32-bit embedded microprocessor.  U1 controls
the power up reset for the CPU.

U3 is a tri-state buffer used to drive the Coldfire’s configuration pins during reset.
The lower byte of the Coldfire’s data bus, D7 through D0, serves as configuration
pins during reset.  The Coldfire latches the configuration setting, driven by U3, on
the rising edge of the reset signal (RESET–).  When the reset signal is high, U3 is
tri-stated.  Among other things, the configuration pins are used to set the Coldfire’s
internal clock frequency and port size of chip-select 0.

See sheet 4 of the schematic for memory circuits.  U16 provides 2 Mbytes of Flash
Memory.  The Flash Memory interface is 8 bits wide.  U17 provides 2 Mbytes of
synchronous static RAM.  The Coldfire has a fast 32-bit wide interface to RAM.
After reset, the CPU copies its code from Flash Memory into RAM and begins
executing from RAM.

BOARD RESET

The board’s reset signal is generated by U1.  The reset threshold is 2.93 V.  Two
reset signals are generated by U1, RESET– and RESETA–.  RESETA– provides a
glitch-free reset signal valid down to 0 volts.  RESET– provides the reset signal for
the Coldfire and Actel FPGA.  The RESET– signal is subject to glitches as the
3.3 V ramps up because the Coldfire and FPGA will momentarily drive this signal
while the supply voltage ramps up.

The CPU can initiate a board-level reset by writing to a control register in the
FPGA.  This write function will cause the FPGA to turn ON transistor Q1, causing
U1 to reset the microprocessor (U2) and the rest of the board.

Finally, a reset switch, SW1, is located near U2 and can be pressed to reset the

3518 EB Telemetry – Circuit Description
130960-945 / 3518 EB
JULY 2004
Baker Atlas

SYSTEM CLOCK

Oscillator Y1 (lower left corner of sheet 1) generates a 40 MHz system clock for the
board.  The clock is buffered by a low-skew clock buffer, U5.  The four outputs of
the buffer are fed to the Coldfire (U2), RAM (U17), Actel FPGA (U6), and
CoolRunner II CPLD (U8).

RELAY CONTROL

A non-latching relay is located on the terminal board (197673-000).  The function
of this relay is to switch pin 7 of the top 45-pin connector (P1) for use as conductor
7 in multi-conductor mode or as data signal in single-conductor mode.  Since the
normal resting state of the relay is the single-conductor mode, the coil must be
energized when the tool is operating in the multi-conductor mode.

Refer to the upper left corner of sheet 4 for this circuit.  The Coldfire provides two
relay control signals, RLYSW and RLYHOLD.  RLYSW and RLYHOLD control
transistors Q7 and Q8, respectively.  When the Coldfire first switches the relay into
multi-conductor mode, it turns ON both transistors.  After holding both transistors
ON for at least 1msec and allowing the armature to switch over, it turns transistor
Q7 OFF to conserve power by reducing the relay’s coil current by half.  Transistor
Q9 acts as a gate for transistors Q7 and Q8.  When Q9 is OFF, the relay is
prevented from turning ON regardless of the state of Q7 and Q8.  Q9 is controlled
by RESETA– so that it will be in the OFF condition while the board is in reset.  The
gating mechanism was put in place because the Coldfire will momentarily assert
RLYSW and RLYHOLD while it is powering up.

SERIAL PORT

The CPU Board has a serial port interface to the PIC Board (A3000305000) which
is located in the 3518 FB.  The CPU Board interrogates the PIC to collect
Cablehead Voltage and chassis temperature readings, which are reported in
Subset 2.  The serial port interface (sheet 4) operates at a baud rate of 57600, with
a format of 8 data bits, even parity, and one stop bit.  Optocoupler U15 isolates the
serial port receive signal.  Transistor Q4 acts as an inverter and driver for the serial
port transmit signal.  The PIC Board has a similar arrangement, so the two boards

3518 EB Telemetry – Circuit Description
130960-945 / 3518 EB
JULY 2004
Baker Atlas

LDO REGULATORS

Refer to the lower part of sheet 4.  Two low-dropout (LDO) regulators provide the
core voltages needed for the Coldfire and the Actel FPGA.  The Coldfire requires a
1.8 V core voltage and a 3.3 V IO voltage.  The FPGA requires a 2.5 V core voltage
and a 3.3 V IO voltage.  U4 provides a 1.8 V reference for both regulators.  A 1.8 V
regulator is formed by U18 and Q5.  Q5 increases the current output capability of
op amp U18.  A PNP pass transistor arrangement is used to achieve a low-dropout
voltage.  A 2.5 V regulator is formed by U19 and Q6.  Resistor values R34 and R50
are chosen to generate a 2.5 V output from the 1.8 V reference.  Diodes D7, D8,
and D9 are in place to make sure the 1.8 V does not trail too far below the 3.3 V
when the supply voltage ramps up.  Diode D10 ensures that the 3.3 V supply does
not drop too far below the 1.8 V supply when the board is powered down.

ETHERNET CONTROLLER

U12 on sheet 3 is a 10 base-T Ethernet controller.  Transformers T1 and T2 isolate
the TX and RX lines.  The Actel FPGA generates the proper timing of the IOR–
and IOW– control signals when the CPU accesses the Ethernet controller.  The
FPGA maps the Ethernet Controller to chip-select CS3.  The Ethernet Controller
provides an active-high interrupt signal.  This signal, ETH_IRQ, is fed into the
FPGA where it is inverted and routed to the Coldfire’s IRQ1 interrupt.  The data
lines to the Ethernet Controller are byte swapped to accommodate the Ethernet
Controller’s ISA based interface.
The 20 MHz clock required by U12 is generated by the FPGA.  The FPGA simply
divides the 40 MHz system clock by 2 to generate the clock (ETH_CLK) for the
Ethernet controller.

SP MEASUREMENT

The CPU Board measures Spontaneous Potential (SP) with respect to both the
surface-electrode and to armor.  The measurements are performed simultaneously
and independent of each other.  These measurements are reported in Subset 2.
SP is sampled at a rate of 5 K samples per second.  When Subset 2 is requested
from the Telemetry, the CPU will report the average of the last 128 samples
measured.

U22 (sheet 5) is an instrumentation amplifier that measures the SP voltage with
respect to the surface-electrode.  The SP inputs are protected with back-to-back
diodes, D1 & D2, which clamp the voltage to 8.5 V.  This SP signal is first filtered
by R23, C114, and R24.  The differential voltage is converted to a single-ended
6

3518 EB Telemetry – Circuit Description
130960-945 / 3518 EB
JULY 2004
Baker Atlas
voltage and fed into U23.  U23 and its associated components form a two pole
70 Hz low-pass Butterworth filter.

U13 generates a 2.5 V reference for the analog-to-digital converter, U29.  The ADC
is a 16-bit SAR.  It is configured for a measurement range of -2.5 V to +2.5 V.  U21
buffers the 2.5 V reference and feeds it into the resistor scaling network in the
ADC’s front end.

The circuit for measuring SP with respect to armor is similar to that described
above.

The ADC’s are read serially by the Actel FPGA (U6 on sheet 2).  Every 200µs, the
FPGA will initiate a conversion by strobing CNVST/ low.  After sensing both ADC’s
busy signals (BUSY_SUR and BUSY_DWN) go inactive, the FPGA will clock out
32 data bits from the ADC’s.  The first 16 clocks shift the surface SP and the
second 16 clocks shift the armor SP.  Serial data for both ADC’s is shifted over the
same SD line since they are daisy-chained together.  The serial clock line (SCLK)
is discontinuous, and will remain inactive when the FPGA is not reading data from
the ADC’s.  The FPGA contains two 128 word FIFOs to store the last 128 samples
from each ADC.  The CPU reads the FIFOs and reports the average when Subset
2 is requested by the surface system.

TIMER CIRCUIT

Because it is still under development, many of the components of this circuit are
not installed.  Later, in cases where these components will be required, they can
be easily installed.
The Timer circuit (left side of sheet 3) is needed only for the Hybrid and Battery
modes.  In the Battery mode, the Timer allows the tool string to be powered down
with just the Timer Circuit powered, and automatically power up again after a
programmed time has been reached.  This feature allows a battery-powered tool
string to remain OFF while being lowered into the borehole, and then automatically
turn ON to log the well.  While the tool string is OFF, only the Timer Circuit on the
CPU board remains powered ON.  The Timer Circuit’s power is provided by a
small auxiliary power supply located in the 4444 XA Battery Module.  In both the
Hybrid and Battery modes, the CPU depends on the Timer to provide a periodic
interrupt that the CPU uses to acquire data from the tools on a time-driven basis.

The Timer is implemented in a Xilinx CoolRunner II CPLD (U8).  The Timer’s
responsibility is to maintain time and provide a periodic interrupt at a
programmable rate to the CPU.  The Timer Circuit has a separate power input (pin
16 of connector P1) to supply power to it while the rest of the board is powered
down.  Diodes D4 and D5 form an OR circuit and are power diodes that allow the
Timer to obtain power from the 12 V supply when it’s available.  The Timer
produces a power enable signal that feeds to transistor Q3.  The power enable

3518 EB Telemetry – Circuit Description
130960-945 / 3518 EB
JULY 2004
Baker Atlas

Oscillator Y2 provides a 10 kHz clock for the CPLD.  U9 resets the CPLD when the
Timer’s 3.3 V supply drops below 2.93 V.  The CPU has access to the Timer
registers through an 8-bit wide data bus.  The CPU uses chip-select CS4 to select
the Timer.  The Timer monitors the RESETA– signal and will lock out its interface
to the CPU when the RESETA– signal is asserted LOW.  This feature is necessary
to prevent unintentional writes to the Timer’s internal register when the CPU is
powering up or powering down.  The Timer also goes into a tri-state mode for all of
its outputs when RESETA– is asserted.

Transistor Q2 and resistors R36 and R37 are used to generate a signal
(BATT_FLG) that the CPU reads to determine when it’s in the battery mode.
BATT_FLG is asserted low when timer power is present on pin 16 of connector
P1.

SYNCHRONOUS SERIAL PORT7
2.10 SYNCHRONOUS SERIAL PORT

The CPU Board is linked to the Memory Board (197390-000) through a 10 Mbit/sec
synchronous serial port.  The CPU and Memory Board each control a frame sync
and data line.  They share a common clock.  The Serial Port logic is implemented
in the Actel FPGA.  The CPU can poll on ready flags or configure the FPGA to
generate an interrupt when the receiver contains new data or when the transmitter
has finished transmitting a word.  The CPU can also transfer data to or from the
serial port interface via DMA.  The FPGA uses DREQ0 and DREQ1 to pace the
flow of data for DMA operations.

U20 buffers the clock (SPI_CLK), frame sync (TFS), and data (DT) signals that are
driven by the CPU Board.  U14 is a Schmitt trigger inverter that buffers the
incoming frame sync (RFS) and data signal (DR) driven by the Memory Board.

MANCHESTER ENCODERS/DECODERS7
2.11 MANCHESTER ENCODERS/DECODERS

In addition to the functionality already discussed, the Actel FPGA (U6) also
contains the Manchester encoders, decoders, and regenerator logic.

In the legacy (WTS/Focus) mode of operation, the FPGA autonomously decodes
Mode 2 commands on the wireline and regenerates it on the CMD channel of the
Instrument Bus.  The FPGA fully decodes the command and then writes it into an
encoder to pass it onto the Instrument Bus.  The FPGA will only regenerate the
command if it has detected no NVM or parity errors.  Since the FPGA decodes the
command and then encodes it, there is a one word delay from the time the
command appears on the wireline, to the time it appears on the instrument bus.

The FPGA passes data from the instrument bus to the wireline in a different
manner.  Instead of decoding a word and re-encoding it, the FPGA repeats the
8

3518 EB Telemetry – Circuit Description
130960-945 / 3518 EB
JULY 2004
Baker Atlas
data from the instrument bus to the wireline on an edge-for-edge basis.  When the
FPGA detects that the signal level on a particular channel changes state, the
FPGA generates a positive or negative AMI pulse on the wireline for that channel’s
corresponding mode.  The AMI pulse is one-fourth of a bit period.  For Mode 2, the
pulse is 12µs wide.  For Modes 5 and 7, the pulse is 2.67µs wide.

The FPGA contains decode logic that will generate an interrupt to the CPU when a
command is received that is addressed to the telemetry.  When an error-free
command is received that is addressed to the telemetry, the FPGA will enable the
decoder interrupt to notify the CPU that a command for it has been received.  The
FPGA will leave the interrupt enabled to allow the CPU to receive any parameters
that may follow.  The FPGA will not disable the interrupt until it detects an error-
free command addressed to another tool.  In this manner, the CPU is not bothered
by traffic directed to other tools.

In Hybrid or Battery mode, the CPU needs direct control of the instrument bus to
send commands and receive data from other tools.  In these modes, the CPU
configures the FPGA to disable the regenerator and repeaters, and enable the
encoder and decoders for the instrument bus.  In this configuration, the CPU can
transmit commands and receive data from the instrument bus.

U7 is a Schmitt trigger inverter used to perform 5 V to 3.3 V level conversion of the
Manchester signals received from the Wireline Interface Board (F197394000).

The FPGA contains an internal Phase Lock Loop (PLL), which is used to generate
a 12 MHz clock for the encoder and decoder logic.  This clock output can be
monitored on TP19.

WIRELINE INTERFACE BOARD8
3.0 WIRELINE INTERFACE BOARD

Refer to assembly 197394-000 and associated five-page schematic 197394-100
for the following descriptions. 

WIRELINE TRANSMITTERS – MODE 2, 5, 7 10

WIRELINE MODE 2 RECEIVER

The top half of Sheet 1 contains the Mode 2 receiver circuit.  Mode 2 signals enter
at connector P1 on pins 5 and 12 and feed into a unity-gain differential amplifier,
U4.  The signal then gets amplified by two non-inverting amplifiers formed by op
amps U3 and U2.  The overall gain is 6 V/V.  Some minor filtering is performed to
suppress any high-frequency noise.
The amplified and filtered signal then feeds into two comparators (U1 and U5) that
create two digital signals, WM2 R_HI and WM2 R_LO.  WM2 R_HI is high whenever
the amplified receive signal is greater than 200mV.  WM2 R_LO is high whenever
9

3518 EB Telemetry – Circuit Description
130960-945 / 3518 EB
JULY 2004
Baker Atlas
the amplified receive signal is less than -200mV.  The 200mV threshold for
comparator U1 is set by resistors R9 and R12.  The -200mV threshold for
comparator U5 is set by resistors R19 and R20.
The two digital signals, WM2 R_HI and WM2 R_LO, feed into the Actel FPGA on
the CPU Board.  The FPGA internally creates a UDI and feeds it into a Manchester
Decoder.  The FPGA also routes the internally created UDI signal back out to an
external pin.  The UDI signal can be seen on the Wireline Interface Board at TP18.

Note the graphic of Figure 1.  In the scope capture, observe the signals at the
identified test points on the Wireline Interface Board.

WIRELINE TRANSMITTERS – MODE 2, 5, 7

The bottom half of Sheet 1 contains the Mode 2 transmitter circuit.  The Mode 2
transmitter consists of two identical driver circuits, each driving one end of a
winding of chassis-mounted modal transformer T2.  The two driver circuits are
used in a complimentary fashion to double the voltage applied to the modal
transformer.  With each driver capable of delivering ±9 V, the transmitter can
provide up to ±18 V (depending on the load) to drive the modal transformer.

U6 and U10 [U11 and U15]2 are Schmitt trigger inverters used to buffer the control
signals from the FPGA on the CPU board (197392-000).  U9 [U14] and its
associated resistors form a difference amplifier that is used to convert the two 3.3 V
unipolar input signals into a single bipolar ±9 V signal at TP7 [TP9].  A two pole
low-pass filter, formed by U8 [U13], filters the signal to reduce cross-talk.  A high-
current output buffer, U7 [U12], is used to drive the modal transformer.  The output
buffer is enclosed within the feedback loop of U8 [U13] to remove any offset that
may be introduced by the buffer.

SINGLE-CONDUCTOR INTERFACE

Sheet 4 contains the single-conductor transmitter and receiver.  The single-
conductor receiver is located in the top half of the sheet.  This circuit is very similar
to that found in the 8248 EA Telemetry Tool.  The receiver contains three op amp
stages with a T-network feedback to correct for the frequency dependent
attenuation and phase-shift that signals suffer as they travel through the wireline.
The receiver is tuned to a particular wireline by selecting the appropriate jumpers
and potentiometer settings.  After equalization, the signal is fed into a comparator
formed by op amp U47.  U47 forms an inverting comparator with a threshold level
of approximately ±2 V.  U44 is used to convert the bipolar output of U47, into a TTL
