The lower half of the sheet contains the single-conductor transmitter.  The data is
driven on the wireline using MOSFET’s to drive the line high or low.  A P-channel
MOSFET and N-channel MOSFET is contained in U42.  U43 is a dual SPDT
analog switch used to drive the gates of the MOSFET’s.

INSTRUMENT BUS INTERFACE

Sheet 3 of the schematic contains the instrument bus interface.  U36 contains two
high-current drivers with open collector outputs.  U36 drives the commands onto
the instrument bus through transformer T1.  U37, U38, and U39 are differential
receivers for channels 1, 2, and 3 on the instrument bus.

LED’S 12

TRANSMIT POWER

Sheet 5 contains both a P-channel and an N-channel MOSFET, U45.  The
MOSFETs switch power to the multi-conductor transmitters.  When the CPU is
operating in a mode that does not require the multi-conductor transmitters, i.e.
single-conductor or Battery mode, the CPU will turn off the transmitters to
conserve power.  U46 is a dual SPDT switch used to control the gate voltage of
the MOSFETs.  To turn ON the MOSFETs, the switch connects the gates to
ground.  To turn OFF the P-channel MOSFET, the switch connects the gate to
+12 V.  The switch connects the gate to -12 V to turn OFF the N-channel MOSFET.
TXPOWEN is a signal driven by the CPU Board to control the state of the
transmitter power.

LED’S

Five LED’s are provided on the Wireline Interface Board.  They are controlled by
the CPU board, but they are placed on the Wireline Interface Board so that they
may be visible when the two boards are installed on the chassis.  D10, D11, and
D12 are controlled by the microprocessor.  D8 and D9 are controlled by the
Ethernet Controller.  D8 is the activity LED, which blinks when the Ethernet
controller is sending or receiving packets.  D9 is the LINK LED, which turns ON
whenever a host is connected to the Ethernet port, or when the Ethernet controller
is placed in the loopback mode during testing.  Jumper JP7 is used to disable all of
the LED’s by disconnecting them from 3.3 V.

which has a pull-up resistor on the CPU board.  The CPU will enter Flash Loader

GAMMA RAY CIRCUITRY 13
4.0 GAMMA RAY CIRCUITRY
The Matrix Telemetry has an integrated Gamma Ray module.  It is designed into
the Telemetry to shorten the overall tool string length.  As a stand-alone tool,
another instrument like the Gamma Ray would add weight and length because of
the field joints and power supplies.  By combining this tool with the Telemetry, it
eliminates those extra pieces.
The electronics is fashioned after many of its G/R predecessors.  It begins with
detecting the pulses from the Photomultiplier Tube, sending them through a
discriminator circuit and then to a counter where data can be ultimately sent to the
surface.
The Gamma Ray module of this instrument is slightly more sophisticated.  It uses
a microprocessor to handle the counts, A/D conversion, high voltage gain control,
measuring elapsed time, measuring temperature and communicating with the
surface.
The following graphics illustrate the interconnecting wiring associated with the
Gamma Ray module.  Some early-built Telemetries contain the board 198877-000;
it appears in the first graphic (Figure 3).  Later models of the Telemetry contain the
board A3000493000; its hookup is seen in the second graphic (Figure 4).  All

3518 EB Telemetry – Circuit Description

JULY 2004

MICROPROCESSOR
The heart of the Gamma Ray PC board is the microprocessor, U3, which controls
all of the action of the circuit.  This unique chip contains several counters, an A/D
converter and inputs/outputs necessary to handle communications.  It also has
internal ROM that contains processing firmware and internal RAM for holding data.
Support devices of the microprocessor are:
•
U7 – a 16 MHz oscillator,
•
U9 – flash memory for holding tool parameters,
•
U4 – a precision voltage reference for the A/D converter,
•
U12 – a frequency divider chip for deriving communication frequencies.

MICROPROCESSOR 14 

COMMUNICATIONS
Communications with surface equipment, like other tools in the Matrix tool string, is
accomplished using Manchester words.
The Matrix Instrument Bus (MIB) carries commands for all tools of the tool string.
Only when a command contains the correct address for a given tool does it
respond.  Commands enter the Gamma Ray PC board via pins 8 and 9 of
connector J1.  Commands are transformer-coupled (T2) to one of the differential
amplifiers of U8.  The output of U8 connects to the UDI pin of the Manchester
Encoder/Decoder chip, U6.  Decoding commands, the Manchester chip
determines whether the word is valid, and if so, passes the 16-bit word to the
microprocessor via the SDO pin.  Firmware determines which command has been

3518 EB Telemetry – Circuit Description
130960-945 / 3518 EB
JULY 2004
Baker Atlas
If answering that command requires sending data back to the surface, the
microprocessor passes serial data to the Manchester chip for encoding on the SDI
pin.  As the data word is encoded into Manchester format, it is clocked out the
BZO\ and BOO\ outputs to driver chip U5.  This chip drives transformer T1 which
couples the data to the MIB.  The instrument bus data lines tie to connector J1,
pins 3 and 4.  Modal transformers within the Telemetry drive the wireline with
signal levels necessary to reach the surface.

DETECTING PULSES
As with other G/R detectors, hardware consists of a detecting crystal, coupled to a
photomultiplier (PM) tube.  Gamma rays from the formation enter the crystal where
they ionize and give off energy.  This ionization energy is converted into tiny
flashes of light (photons).  In the PM tube, these photons are changed into
electrical pulses that are amplified through a series of ten dynodes.
Voltage variations from the tube are proportional to the energy of the incident
gamma rays.  Since different levels of gamma radiation (i.e., count rates) are
associated with different types of rock, the information from the detector can be
used to indicate formation lithology.  Higher gamma ray count rates are commonly
associated with the presence of shale.
Pulses from the PM tube enter the G/R circuit at terminal J4 and are capacitor-
coupled from its high voltage source to the input of amplifier U10.  A calibrating pot
(R25) adjusts the signal strength to give a 2 V peak at TP1 when a Cesium 137
source is brought near to the detector working with the nominal high voltage
applied.
The pulses are then sent to a discriminator, U11, to eliminate base-noise and
shape the valid pulses into a square-wave signal.  It is the output of U11 that is
coupled to an internal counter of the microprocessor, U3.  Here the pulse count
accumulates until the acquisition cycle stops the counting.

GAIN STABILIZATION
During actual operation, increased downhole temperatures cause the gain of the
photomultiplier tube to decrease.  To keep the sensitivity of the detector to gamma
rays constant, this drop in gain must be corrected.  This correction is accomplished
by increasing the high voltage applied to the PM Tube in a quantity that is
proportional to the temperature change.  Two relationships – gain vs. temperature
and gain vs. high-voltage – are characteristic of a particular tube type and are
used to stabilize the gain by means of a control loop.  Below is a discussion of the
various parts of this loop.
4.4.1 TEMPERATURE SENSING

A special combination chip, U4, contains a high precision voltage reference
circuit, which is its primary function.  However, it also contains a circuit that
16

3518 EB Telemetry – Circuit Description
130960-945 / 3518 EB
JULY 2004
Baker Atlas
compensates the voltage output with variations in temperature.  The output
of this circuit is available as a voltage that is proportional to the absolute
temperature (°K) that it senses.  It is this temperature sensitive circuit’s
output that is amplified at U2 A.  The output of U2 A becomes a signal that is
measured by another input of the microprocessor’s internal A/D converter.
Firmware within the microprocessor handles the processing of the data.
Eventually this data is sent to the surface as part of Subset 0.
4.4.2 HIGH VOLTAGE MONITOR

The next stage of the control loop monitors the high voltage.  This stage
consists of amplifier U2 B and associated components.  The amplifier ties to
the lower end of the resistive voltage divider network that biases the
dynodes (also the PM tube cathode connection) and has a gain of 10.  The
output of this amplifier is fed into one of the inputs of the A/D converter
internal to the microprocessor.  Capacitor C28 is used to provide low
impedance to the A/D converter input.
4.4.3 HIGH VOLTAGE CONTROL
The High Voltage Power Supply (HVPS) is a commercial item that is housed
in modular fashion.  It has an input pin that allows circuitry to control the
output voltage level.  The HV output is inversely proportional to the voltage
applied to this control input.
The microprocessor uses the measured temperature to determine the proper
value of the high voltage for those conditions.  This nominal value is
compared to the measured HV value and a correction is applied if needed.
The compensation is gradual.  This gradual change keeps the process from
over-compensating and putting the loop into a constant up-and-down
pattern.
The HVPS control is derived from a Pulse Width Modulated (PWM) output of
the microprocessor.  The average value of the pulse train is amplified by U1,
configured as a voltage follower, which has its positive input connected to a
potentiometer.   The network of R1, R2 and R6 establishes a limited
adjustment range for the amplifier.  The amplifier output connects through
resistor R3, to pin 11 of the connector J1, which ties to the control pin of the
HVPS.  Note: At room temperature, pot R2 is adjusted until the output of the
HVPS is 1300 volts.
4.4.4 START-UP
When the tool is powered up at high temperatures (i.e. downhole) the
initialization portion of the downhole software measures the tool temperature
and applies an approximate initial value to the PWM circuitry to provide for a
fast turn-on.  The control loop just described takes over from this point to

SELF TEST
A constant frequency of 9.766 KHz scaled down from the system crystal oscillator
is fed to a counter input of the microcontroller (pin 6).  When requested by the
surface system, these counts replace the detector counts in the tool data block.
This is a check to ensure proper communications and basic tool functioning.

+5 V, +3 V SINGLE POWER SUPPLY 17
6.0 DC POWER SUPPLIES
The 3518 EB has three power supplies mounted on the electronics backbone.
Along with one of the supplies is an EMI filter module to drastically reduce
interference and interaction between supplies of other Matrix instruments.  These
self-contained, modular supplies mount on a heat-sinking channel and have
additional circuitry mounted on a PC board that is soldered directly to the pins of
the supply.  It is this additional circuitry that will be the topic of discussion for this
section.
Because the power supplies are modular, there is no repair of the unit.  It either
works or it doesn’t.  The only circuitry external to the module (U1) is some
inhibiting control and some additional output filtering.

+5 V, +3 V SINGLE POWER SUPPLY

3518 EB Telemetry – Circuit Description
130960-945 / 3518 EB

Instrument power is defined as +28 volts for the Focus tool string.  This instrument
power first passes through an EMI filter module before being applied to a DC to
DC converter module; thus, the voltage at terminal E1 is a filtered +28 V.  E2 is tied
to the return line of the EMI filter output.  Pins 6, 7 and 8 are tied to chassis ground
which, in turn, is tied to cable armor.  Two independent windings of a choke, L1,
filter voltage spikes on the output of the converter module.  Provision is made at J1
for trimming the output voltage under expected loads.  In most cases, this
provision is left unused.  Additional output filtering is provided by capacitors C3, C4
and C5.

are tied to chassis ground, which is tied to cable armor.  Three independent

Refer to drawing 198384-100 for the complete schematic of the Power

This LOW turns OFF the respective power supply.  Terminal E9 controls a

below.

The 3518 Focus Telemetry is a communications device for the Focus downhole
system.  This is a combination instrument comprised of the 3518 FB, the power
module, the 3518 EB, the communications module and the 3518 EG, the Gamma
Ray module.


The 3518 FB, the power module, converts a nominal wireline 250 VDC voltage to
+28 VDC as part of the Matrix1 Instrument Bus (MIB).  +28 VDC is generated to
provide power for instrument electronics and motors.  For more details, see
manual 130961-915.

The primary role of the 3518 EB module is to serve as a communications bridge
between the wireline and the MIB.  To do this, the Focus Telemetry accepts
surface commands in the AMI format.  The Telemetry determines if the received
word is valid, and if so, the entire word is regenerated in Manchester UDI format
and sent out on the MIB.  Focus instruments connected to the MIB are responsible
for their own interpretation and response to the Manchester signal.  Conversely,
instrument data sent back to the surface is received by the Telemetry and
converted to AMI pulse format before being placed onto the wireline.

Another role of the 3518 EB is to provide Cablehead Voltage (CHV) and
Spontaneous Potential (SP).

Also, as an integrated part of its mechanical makeup, there resides a Gamma Ray
(GR) instrument within the 3518 EB housing --- electrically, it responds as any
other Focus instrument connected to the Instrument Bus, sharing only common
power supplies with the Telemetry circuits.

Although still in development, the Telemetry has hardware support for Hybrid and
Battery Mode.  In these modes, the Telemetry autonomously acquires data from
the tools and stores the data in memory.  The Telemetry has a 10 base-T Ethernet
interface to allow fast dumping of data from memory.

No pun intended, the focus of this document is to present the details of 3518 EB
communications module.

Inspect all wiring for nicks, cuts, pinholes or abrasion.  Check the
wiring for electrical leakage and continuity.  Refer to A3000069 WRD.
Replace all defective wiring with new wires.
____  4.
Inspect all electrical connectors for damage: chips, cracks, water
absorption, broken contacts, corroded contacts or gascut.  Check for
electrical leakage and continuity.  Replace any electrical connectors
that are not fit for service in the downhole environment.
____  5.
Inspect all mechanical parts for evidence of damage, wear and
corrosion on critical O-ring seal surfaces and threads.  Replace any
parts that show excessive damage and are unfit for use.

GENERAL SAFETY INSTRUCTIONS

•
WEIGHT: The weight of the 3518 EB Telemetry instrument is only 63 pounds (see
130960-025).  If combined with the 3518 FB, total weight is 111 pounds.  Care should
be used when handling the instrument and the wearing of steel-toed shoes is
required.  A two-person lift is recommended when carrying the EB/FB combination.
•
ELECTRICAL: Beyond ESD precautions normal for electronic equipment, this
instrument does not require special considerations as far as electrical safety goes.
However, when powered outside of its housing, voltages in excess of 200 volts are
present and caution should be exercised.

In anticipation of use in a high-temperature environment (within tool specifications), an
instrument may be operated in an oven to verify performance.  Otherwise, no heat test
for this instrument is required.

POWER SUPPLY 

COMMUNICATIONS CONTROL

The 3518 XA Matrix Telemetry instrument plays an important role in the communications link
between surface and downhole equipment.  It is especially critical in Hybrid1 or Battery2
operated modes.  Since each Matrix downhole instrument has the ability to receive and
interpret surface commands, the burden for doing this is no longer solely the function of the
telemetry instrument.  However, the 3518 XA contains an FPGA (Field Programmable Gate
Array) chip that ensures received and transmitted Manchester words are viable before
passing them to the appropriate recipient, whether downhole instrument or surface panel.
Matrix instruments respond very much like WTS instruments, in that they communicate
using Mode 2, Mode 5 or Mode 7.  For more details on WTS communications, see WTS-
Tool Interface Specifications 059448-000.
The Matrix Telemetry passes the surface commands down to the tool string via the Matrix
Instrument Bus (MIB) and passes the tool data to the surface without acting as anything
more than a conduit.  Modal transformers mounted on the backbone of the Telemetry couple
wireline signals to the Transceiver Board and on this board is an FPGA (Field
Programmable Gate Array) chip that routes these signals to the tools.
When the need arises for the Telemetry circuits to respond to surface commands, the FPGA
routes signals according to the response of the CPU Board.
A secondary function of the Matrix Telemetry is to acquire data from several sensors located
in different places and send their measurements to the surface via the CPU Board.  The
Sensor Board carries out this function.

GAMMA RAY SECTION

The third part of the Matrix Telemetry is an integrated Gamma Ray section.  It is designed
into the Telemetry to shorten the overall tool string length.  As a stand-along tool, it would
add weight and length because of the extra field joints and power supplies.  By combining
this function with the Telemetry, it rids the tool string of this unnecessary burden.
The electronics is fashioned after many of its predecessors.  It begins with detecting the
pulses from the Photomultiplier Tube, sending them through a discriminator circuit and then
to a counter where they can be ultimately sent to the surface.
The Gamma Ray section of this instrument is slightly more sophisticated.  It uses a
microprocessor to handle the counts, A/D conversion, high voltage gain control, measuring
elapsed time, measuring temperature and communicating with the surface.
The following graphic illustrates the interconnecting wiring associated with the Gamma Ray
section.  All Telemetry wiring connects to the Gamma Ray PC board, 198877-000, via a
single connector.  From there, voltage is provided to the High Voltage Power Supply (HVPS)
and pulses return to be processed.  For ease of assembly, wiring to the connector comes
from the Gamma Ray Terminal board, 198879-000.

HIGH VOLTAGE STARTUP PROTECTION PCB
Refer to schematic drawing 199678-100 during this discussion.  This PCB controls
activation of the gated current regulator U2, as discussed in Section  2.2.8.  The
Protection PCB enables U2 for 30 seconds only during power-up.  The Protection
PCB activates and starts its internal timeout function once Vin crosses 50 volt.
During this timeout interval, TP is pulled “high”, which allows U2 to operate.  At the
end of the 30-second timeout period, TP is pulled “low”, deactivating U2.  TP remains
“low “until the Protection PCB circuitry is reset, which happens when Vin drops below

130871-945 / 3518 XA
APRIL 2004
Baker Atlas
APPENDIX A: DC POWER SUPPLY MODULES

The Matrix tool string has two basic types of power supplies mounted on the individual
instrument’s backbone.  Along with one of the supplies is an EMI filter module to
drastically reduce interference and interaction between supplies of other Matrix
instruments.  These self-contained, modular supplies mount on a heat-sinking channel
and have additional circuitry mounted on a PC board that is soldered directly to the
pins of the supply.  It is this additional circuitry that will be the topic of discussion for
this section.
Because the power supplies are modular, there is no repair of the unit.  It either works
or it doesn’t.  The only circuitry external to the module (U1) is some inhibiting control
and some additional output filtering.

TYPE 1: Single Power Supply
See the schematic below for a typical configuration of the external components for a
single output power module.


Note: An unlabeled circle representing a terminal is shown on the INHIBIT pin of U1.  In reality,
it is not there; this is just an indicator that a wire is connected is to this point.  Design changes
have removed capacitor C2 and a wire is soldered to the pad that connects to pin 2 of the
module.  The other end of this wire connects to the control circuit found on the PC board
associated with the EMI filter.
Instrument power is defined as +28 volts for the Matrix tool string and originates from
other circuitry found in the Telemetry/GR instrument.  This voltage first is routed to an
EMI filter module before being applied to a DC to DC converter module; thus, the
voltage at terminal E1 is a filtered +28 V.  Terminal E2 is tied to the return line of the
EMI filter output.  Pins 6, 7 and 8 of U1 are tied to chassis ground which, in turn, is tied
to cable armor.  Two independent windings of a choke, L1, filter voltage spikes on the
output of the converter module.  Provision is made at J1 for trimming the output

output filtering is provided by capacitors C3, C4 and C5.

TYPE2: Dual Power Supply
In the case where a power supply module generates an output of dual polarity, the
associated circuitry is slightly modified from that of the single supply.  See the
Typical Dual Power Supply Filter Circuit

Note: An unlabeled circle representing a terminal is shown on the INHIBIT pin of U1.  In reality,
it is not there; this is just an indicator that a wire is connected is to this point.  Design changes
have removed capacitor C2 and a wire is soldered to the pad that connects to pin 2 of the
module.  The other end of this wire connects to the control circuit found on the PC board
associated with the EMI filter.

Again, instrument power first passes through an EMI filter module before being
applied to any DC to DC converter module; thus, the voltage at terminal E1 is a filtered
+28 V.  Terminal E2 is tied to the return line of the EMI filter output.  Pins 6, 7 and 8 of
U1 are tied to chassis ground, which is tied to cable armor.  Three independent
windings of a choke, L1, filter voltage spikes on the output of the module.  No
provision is made for trimming the output voltage.  Additional output filtering is
provided by capacitors C3, C4, C5, C6 and C7.

Power Control Circuit
Associated with at least one of the DC to DC power supply modules is an EMI filter
module.  The PC board attached to the EMI module performs several control
functions.  These control functions are described below.
A simple +5 volt supply is generated for other chips on the PC board.  This simple
supply is connected to the output of the EMI filter module (U1).  It is this +28 V EMI
filter output that also connects to the input of other DC to DC converter modules within
the instrument.  The supply consists of a single dropping resistor (R3) and reference
Zener diode (D1) to establish the voltage. See the schematic below.


Refer to schematic diagram of the Power Supply Control circuit on page 33.  The heart
of the power control circuitry is a programmable microcontroller (U3).  Values for
resistor R7 and capacitor C3 have been selected to give an operating frequency of
approximately 1 MHz.  Supplied with +5 volts from the supply of Figure 19, the
microcontroller acts as a timer to control the turn-on time of anything tied to its output.
There are basically three functions concerning this circuit - (1) a voltage threshold, (2)
a delay circuit and (3) a control/inhibit circuit.
(1) A threshold voltage is established using chip U4.  The voltage divider consisting
of R6 and R8 are chosen such that when 20 volts or more (for instrument power) is
present on R6, the reset chip removes the LOW on pin 7 which in turn removes the
reset from the microcontroller, U3, allowing it to operate.
(2) Jumper inputs to the microcontroller chip, U3, set different length delay times.
Delay times are established for different tools in an effort to limit the current
demand when the Matrix tool sting is first powered up.  Delay times, in
milliseconds, and their jumpers are shown in the table below.

(3) When power is first applied to the microcontroller, output RA1 of U3 pin 18 is
floating (open collector circuit).  Resistor R4 pulls the base of Q1 HIGH turning it
ON.  This state applies a ground potential to the INHIBIT pine of all power supplies
tied to the Q1 collector.  Diodes (D2 – D4) form an OR function in the collector
circuit, allowing control over different power supplies.  By tying the INHIBIT pin
(active low) of each DC-to-DC converter module within an instrument to one of
these control terminals (E5, E6 or E7), you can independently control its ON/OFF
function.  With Q1 initially turned ON, no power supply module can turn ON.  It is
not until the time-out function is completed by U3 that output RA1 can transition
LOW, turning OFF Q1.  With Q1 turned OFF, power supplies are allowed to turn
ON because their INHIBIT is removed.  As the power supplies turn ON, their
current demand is confined to the power supply modules of that particular
instrument.  Again, see the control circuit on page 33.

Refer to drawing 198384-100 for the complete schematic of the Power Controller
board.  As an added feature of this circuit, Power Supply #2 or Power Supply #3
can be turned OFF by an external source via opto-isolator U2.  Terminal E8 is tied
to a positive voltage.  Taking control terminal E9 or E10 LOW causes its respective
switch to close.  This switch closure applies a ground potential to the INHIBIT input
of the supply that is tied to its control terminal, E6 or E7.  This LOW turns OFF the
respective power supply.
Terminal E9 controls a power supply (P.S.2) connected to terminal E6, while E10
controls a supply (P.S.3) connected to terminal E7.  Thus, independent control is
available if needed.  Power supplies connected to E5 are solely controlled by the
timing function associated with the operation of transistor Q1, as discussed
previously.  See the schematic below.

INTRODUCTION

The 3518 XA Matrix Telemetry contains circuitry that can be divided into three major
functions (1) power supply, (2) communications control and (3) an integrated Gamma Ray.
The power supply converts the incoming DC voltage into +28 Volts DC to power all Matrix
instruments of the tool string.  The major function of the Telemetry is, of course,
communications and this is controlled via a piggyback set of PC boards.  In an effort to
reduce overall tool string length and weight, a Gamma Ray instrument was designed into a
single package with the Telemetry.

INTRODUCTION
The Power Supply Subassembly is comprised of four circuit boards and several chassis
mounted components, as shown on Telemetry Chassis Wiring Diagram – 198601-100.
The four power supply boards are:
•
Input Filter – 199001-000
•
Power Supply Controller – 199161-000
•
Output Filter – 198162-000
•
Auxiliary Power – 199000-000

The Telemetry Power Supply provides a regulated +28 Vdc at 4.0 amps maximum for the
MatriX tool string and Telemetry electronics from a cable head voltage (CHV) of 150 to
300 Vdc.  However, a CHV of 250 Vdc is required to start the power supply to ensure the
CHV does not drop below 150 Vdc, due to the voltage drop in the cable as the power
supply comes up.  The nominal operating voltage for the power supply is approximately
280 Vdc.  Should the applied voltage (CHV) exceed 320 Vdc, the power supply will
automatically shut down.
Note: This description does not take into account the chassis-mounted Power Supply
modules that provide power to the internal circuits of the Telemetry itself.  These supplies
are used throughout the tool string and information covering them can be found in
Appendix A and at the end of this document.
2.1.1 DC-DC CONVERTER OVERVIEW
The Telemetry Power Supply uses a half-bridge switching power topology which
consists of two alternately conducting MOSFETs (Q2, Q4), input filter energy storage
capacitors (C13-C20), switched mode power transformer T6, rectifier diodes (D1, D2),
switched mode choke (L1), and output filter capacitors (C1, C2, C5, C6).
4

Where:

Regulation of the 28 Vdc output (Eo) is provided by alternately controlling the
conduction time (ton) of the Q2 and Q4 MOSFETs, which are switching at a frequency
of 120 kHz (1/T).  A closed loop feedback system compares Eo to a reference voltage
and adjusts the MOSFETs conduction time (ton) to maintain a constant output voltage
(Eo).  For example, as Ein increases, ton decreases proportionally to maintain a
constant Eo.

conduction time (ton) of MOSFETs Q2 and Q4, which are switching at a frequency of
120 kHz (1/T). A closed loop feedback system compares Eo to a reference voltage
and adjusts the MOSFETs conduction time (ton) to maintain a constant output voltage
(Eo). For example, as Ein increases, ton decreases proportionally to maintain a
constant Eo. See Figure 1 and Figure 2.

3518 XA Telemetry/GR – Circuit Descriptions
130871-945 / 3518 XA
APRIL 2004
Baker Atlas
Tracing through one cycle of operation: Assume Q2 has been biased on, applying ½
Ein across the primary of T6 (Np).  The primary voltage pulse is inductively coupled to
the secondary winding (Ns) of T6.  The coupled secondary voltage forward biases
diode D1, permitting secondary current to flow through C1, C2, C5, C6, and returning
through L1 to the secondary center tap of T6.
When the conducting MOSFET (Q2) is turned off by U6, secondary current continues
to flow since the current through an inductor can not change instantaneously.  This is
referred to as the “freewheeling” period, which is the interval inductor L1 maintains the
load current until the opposite MOSFET begins conducting.  Current flows from L1,
through C1, C2, C5, C6, and returns through D1 and D2 during the “freewheeling”
period.
When the opposite MOSFET (Q4) is commanded on, the “freewheeling” period ends,
D2 is now forward biased, D1 is reverse biased, and current flows through C1, C2, C5,
and C6 again, returning through L1 to the secondary center tap of T6.  See Figure 3.
The cycle repeats with the next “freewheeling” period followed by Q2 being
commanded on.  U6 controls the MOSFET’s ton to maintain a constant 28-Vdc output
in spite of the varying load and Ein.

“freewheeling” interval current ramps down)

POWER SUPPLY CONTROLLER BOARD
Refer to schematic drawing 199161-100 during the discussion of the Power Supply
Controller board.
2.2.1 VOLTAGE MODE PWM CONTROLLER
Voltage mode PWM (Pulse Width Modulator) Controller U6 provides the nucleus for
the converter control circuitry.  U6 provides the building blocks for the control circuitry
consisting of: error amplifiers, clock, PWM circuitry, and shutdown circuitry.  See
frequency and maximum duty cycle.  See Figure 4.

Trace 1 – Q4 (Source to Drain)
Trace 2 – PWM Continuous Ramp – U6-6
Trace 3 – PWM Clock, U6-4

3518 XA Telemetry/GR – Circuit Descriptions
130871-945 / 3518 XA
APRIL 2004
Baker Atlas
Control of the MOSFET conduction time is accomplished with PWM circuitry internal
to U6.  The PWM circuitry functions by comparing the error voltage at U6, pin 2 with
an internal ramp signal synchronized with the PWM’s clock to produce a duty cycle
modulated waveform, which is alternately directed to OUT A and OUT B.  See Figure
5.

Trace 1 – Q4 (Source to Drain)
Trace 2 – U6, Out A
Trace 3 – U6, Out B
current detection and shutdown, which protects the converter.  This
protection circuitry is discussed more fully in a later paragraph.
Capacitor C22 on the SS pin controls Soft Start, which is the rate that the

3518 XA Telemetry/GR – Circuit Descriptions
130871-945 / 3518 XA
APRIL 2004
Baker Atlas
2.2.2 MOSFET DRIVERS
OUT A and OUT B of U6 are buffered by high-speed MOSFET drivers U3 and U11.
U3 and U11 provide the high current gate drive necessary to rapidly turn the
MOSFETs on and off.  Transformers T1 and T3 provide DC isolation between the
MOSFETs and analog ground.  Resistors R11 and R49 serve to control the MOSFETs
turn-on gate current and to dampen ringing at the gate.  Components R10, R50, D3,
and D9 provide an additional path for gate current, at turn-off, to ensure rapid turn-off
of Q2 and Q4.  See Figure 6.

Trace 1 – Q4 (Source to Drain)
Trace 2 – TP1, U DRV
Trace 3 – TP10, L DRV

3518 XA Telemetry/GR – Circuit Descriptions
130871-945 / 3518 XA
APRIL 2004
Baker Atlas
2.2.3 CONTROL-LOOP CIRCUITRY
The control loop circuitry monitors Eo and controls ton to maintain a constant Eo as
changes occur at Ein and Io.
Sampled output voltage from the Output Filter Board is connected at Sense+ and
Sense- (P2-1, 6) and then to the first stage of differential amplifier U7, where the
sense voltage is attenuated (TP3).  The second stage of U7 produces the error
voltage (TP5) for U6 by integrating the difference of the sampled signal and reference
voltage derived from U8.  U8 provides a stable 5.0-Vdc reference.  R34 is a select
resistor used to adjust the 28-Vdc output. R34 is selected during test.  See Figure 7.
The error voltage (TP5) is applied through R19 to pin 2 (NI) of the PWM IC, U6.
Internal to U6, the error voltage is compared to the voltage ramp on U6 pins 6 and 7
(Figure 4, trace 2).  This comparison produces the ton pulse that is actually connected
to Out A or Out B of U6.  As previously discussed, a change in Eo is detected by the
control-loop circuitry and the circuit adjusts ton proportionately to Eo to correct.

2.2.4 OUTPUT OVER-CURRENT PROTECTION
Current transformer T2 samples T6’s primary current to provide over current
protection.  The primary current is used to detect output overload conditions since the
primary current is equal to the secondary current reflected by Np/Ns.  Resistors R29
and R35 function as turnover resistors, converting T1's secondary current to a voltage.
Components R40, R43, and C18 serve to divide and filter the signal prior to
application to U6, pin 9 [Ilim (TP6)].
The current signal at U6, pin 9 is compared to an internal reference voltage in U6 to
provide pulse-by-pulse current limiting or DC-DC converter shutdown.  If the voltage at
pin 9 of U1 exceeds 1.0 Vdc, MOSFET conduction is terminated, limiting the output
current.  The output current will continue to be limited until the overload condition is
removed.  Circuitry internal to U6 blanks any leading edge spikes present at pin 9 to
prevent false over-current limiting.  See Figure 8.

2.2.5 INPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION
Operation at excessively high or low CHV is inhibited to prevent possible damage to
the DC-DC converter.  Vin (P1-1) is divided by R1, R57, and R5 and applied to a dual
voltage comparator (U1).  The OV\ output inhibits DC-DC converter operation if Vin
exceeds 300 Vdc, while the UV\ output controls the input voltage operating range of
the DC-DC converter.  The UV\ signal prevents the DC-DC converter from turning on
until Vin is approximately 250 Vdc and will terminate operation if the Vin drops below
150 Vdc.
2.2.6 OUTPUT OVER VOLTAGE PROTECTION
Output over-voltage protection is also provided, should the DC-DC converter output
exceed 33 Vdc.  The over-voltage condition is detected by circuitry on the output filter
board.  Should an over-voltage condition occur, the signal OVS will go active.  Optical
coupler U4 serves to isolate the controller and output filter.  When the input of U4 goes
active, the coupler’s output, which is inverted by U5 and U12, pulls U9 pin 6 low.  This
sets the output of the RS latch (L28 VF\) and shuts down the DC-DC converter.  The
input power must be recycled to reset the latch.
L28 VF\, OV\, and UV\ are inputs to an Inverting NAND gate resulting in INHIBIT\ going
low if any one of the three abnormal operating conditions are detected.  INHIBIT\
controls U5 and Q1, which control the application of 15 Vdc operating power to U6.
INHIBIT\ is high and 15 Vdc operating power is provided to U6, permitting normal DC-
DC converter operation.
2.2.7 CONTROLLER OPERATING POWER
Operating power for the controller is provided by an external 15 Vdc from the Auxiliary
Power PCB.  The DC-DC converter is “said” to be self sustaining, i.e., it provides it
own 15 Vdc operating power, derived from an additional secondary on T6, once the
DC-DC converter is up and running.  However, a bootstrap circuit is required to initially
start the DC-DC converter (see next paragraph).  A linear regulator provides 5 Vdc
from the 15 Vdc to power the controllers digital components.  The 5 Vdc regulator is
composed of Q3, U13, U8, and associated passive components.
12

2.2.8 BOOTSTRAP CIRCUIT
Gated current regulator U2 and associated components form the bootstrap circuit.  At
start-up, U2 is initially biased on and supplies 30 mAdc to power the bootstrap circuit
components and charge the capacitor bank (C2-C5) on the Auxiliary Power PCB.
Zener D5 clamps the start-up voltage to 15 Vdc.  When Vin exceeds the power
supplies’ start threshold, the INHIBIT\ line is raised and Vccs ramps up.  When Vccs
exceeds 8.4 Vdc, the PWM IC starts pulsing the MOSFETs, via U3 and U11, resulting
in Vout (28 Vdc) starting to ramp up to its final value.  As Vout ramps up so does the
15 Vdc supplied by the auxiliary regulator.  Comparator U13 detects when Vcc
achieves its final value and pulls PSUP\ low.  U12 inverts PSUP\, which biases U10
on. With U10 on, U2’s gate-source junction is reverse biased and U2 is turned off.
The DC-DC converter is now self-sustaining, generating its own operating power via
the Auxiliary Power PCB.
Once the capacitor bank is charged and prior to Vccs exceeding 8.4 Vdc, U13 will
periodically turn off U2 to maintain Vcc at approximately 14 Vdc. See Figure 9. U2
remains on for 30 seconds after Vin crosses 50 Vdc. At the end of the 30-second
timeout period, U2’s gate-source junction is reverse biased by U10 and U2 is turned
off (refer to section  5.0 for additional information).

2.2.9 MISCELLANEOUS COMPONENTS
Turn-off ringing, due to resonance of the MOSFET's output capacitance and the
transformer’s primary leakage inductance is dampened by R62, R63, and C12 across
the primary of T6.  C20 on the Controller Board ensures that no DC flows in the
primary winding of T6.  C7 and C13 provide localized decoupling for the MOSFETs.

OUTPUT FILTER BOARD
Refer to schematic drawing 198162-100 during this discussion.  The output rectifiers D1-
D2 and switched mode choke L1 are connected to the Output Filter Board.  Components
L1, C1, and C2 comprise a low-pass filter that averages the voltage pulses from the
rectifiers to produce 28 Vdc.  Additional differential filtering is provided by three cascaded
low-pass filter stages comprised of L4 with C5 and C6; L5’s leakage inductance with C14,
C15; and C19 and L6’s leakage inductance with C20, C21 and C22.  Common mode
inductors L5 and L6 with capacitors C5-C9, C10, C12, and C13 form two cascaded
common mode filters.  See Figure 10.

AUXILLARY POWER BOARD
Refer to schematic drawing 199000-100 during this discussion.  Secondary 2 of T6

Directing signals (commands & data) via control over the FPGA located on the

As with all microprocessor systems, there are a number of support devices that

U10 – controls the power up reset for the CPU,

Ethernet support – see next paragraph.

Although not fully utilized at the present time, a 10 M-bit per second Ethernet

TRANSCEIVER BOARD
Refer to the four sheets of the Transceiver Board schematic 198871-100 to locate the
components discussed in the following description.  This discussion applies to those
prototype instruments that have XC revision boards only.
3.2.1 RECEIVER AND LINE DRIVER CIRCUITS
Sheet 1 of the schematic 198871-100 contains the WTS receiver and transmitter
circuits for Mode 2 and Mode 5.  Mode 7 transmitter circuits are found on Sheet 3.
At the top of the drawing is the receiver circuit.  Mode 2 signals (commands and data)
enter at connector P1 on pins 7 and 14 and connect to differential amplifier U3.
Amplifier U4 provides wireline compensating and gain.  At U5 the signal gets amplified
to a stronger signal level before being passed along to the voltage level shifter circuit,
U6.  Comparator U1 converts the bipolar signal to a unipolar level of +5 volts.  It is this
unipolar output (UDI signal) of U1 that connects to the Manchester decoder circuitry of
the FPGA (U17) found on sheet 2.
Note the graphic of Figure 14.  In the scope capture, observe these signals as those
belonging to the Send Command as found on the Transceiver board at the identified
test points.
•
The top trace is seen at test point E1;
•
the second trace is the amplified version of the same signal (at test point E3);
•
the third trace is the Manchester edge detector at test point E4 and
•
the bottom trace is the UDI signal that feeds the FPGA (test point E5).



3518 XA Telemetry/GR – Circuit Descriptions

Baker Atlas
Note Figure 15; it shows the BOO waveforms of Mode 2 transmit signals (data) that
originate on the right side of sheet 1.
•
The top trace of this graphic is seen at resistor R27,
•
the second trace is observed at resistor R30,
•
third trace is a combined and amplified version of first two traces; (test point E7)
•
the bottom trace is the signal that drives the modal transformer (test point E6).
These BOO signals (top two traces) are output from the Manchester encoder circuitry
of the FPGA (U17).  Ultimately, both BZO and BOO signals are utilized and each one
used in a complementary fashion to provide up to a ±12 volt swing (depending on the
reflected load) to drive the modal transformer.
For the BOO signal, the gain stage of U10 amplifies the signal from a +5 volt level to a
±12 volt level.  The stages between test points E7 and E6 contain a 2-pole filter (U9)
and buffering (U8) to drive the modal transformer.  It is, ultimately, the detection of
these edges that are important in determining a proper Manchester signal.  Finally, the
output of buffers U8 and U11 apply a differential signal to drive the transformer.  This
bipolar output is found on connector P1 at pin 6.
In a similar manner, for the BZO signal, the gain stage of U13 amplifies the signal from
a +5 volt level to a ±12 volt level.  The stages between test points E9 and E8 contain a
2-pole filter (U12) and buffering (U11) to drive the modal transformer. Finally, the
output of buffers U11 and U8 apply a differential signal across the transformer.  This
bipolar output is found on connector P1 at pin 5.  BZO signals that drive the modal
transformer (bottom two traces) are opposite in polarity of those seen in Figure 15 to
give greater driving power for the Data signal.

SENSOR BOARD
The purpose of the Telemetry Sensor board is to provide isolation and processing for the
Spontaneous Potential (SP) measurement and monitoring for several other items.  Power
supplied to this board comes from the two chassis mounted power modules, one being a
+5 Volt supply and the other a ±12 Volt supply.  The +5 Volt supply powers the digital
circuitry.  The ±12 Volt supply powers most analog circuits and is used to produce a ±5
Volt supply for any remaining analog circuitry.

Refer to the 4 sheets of schematic drawing 198875-100 and note that monitoring is
provided for the following conditions:
•
Internal temperature
•
+5 Volts (digital)
•
+12 Volts (analog)
•
-12 Volts (analog)
•
Cablehead voltage
•
+28 V Supply
•
Current draw for +28 V supply

In addition to monitoring these points, an RS232 interface is provided for serial
communication.
All of these functions are provided by the CPU (U10) located on the Sensor board and its
data is passed over, via the serial port, to the Telemetry’s main controller on the CPU
board 198870-000 to be transmitted to the surface.
To begin the discussion of the Sensor board, let’s start with the CPU and its support
circuitry.
3.3.1 CPU CIRCUITRY
Analog Devices is the manufacturer of the CPU found on this board.  It contains an
integrated A to D converter to handle much of the signal processing.
U17 is a chip that controls the reset function of the CPU during power up.  An external
connection is made to control this chip via pin 7 of connector P2, but is currently not
being used.
The CPU operates with a crystal oscillator, U6, at 11.0592 MHz.
Pull-up resistors, R67 – R72, are required for driving their respective SP control lines.
Diodes D2 and D3 are protection devices that prevent damage to the CPU in the
unlikely event that the analog and digital +5 Volt supplies do not come up together.
22

3518 XA Telemetry/GR – Circuit Descriptions

APRIL 2004
Baker Atlas
Diode D6 glows continuously whenever the digital +5 Volts is present, while diode D7
glows only upon the receipt of a valid command.
Jumper position, JP2, is normally open.  It is shorted only when programming the CPU
internal memory.
RS232
U11 acts as a level shifter for RS232 communications.  Jumper positions associated
with JP1 are normally shorted.  Without these connections, data associated with the
Sensor board cannot be communicated to the CPU Controller board.  Jumpers are
from pin 1 to pin 2, pin 3 to pin 4 and pin 5 to pin 6.
To change the operating program of the CPU (U10), these jumpers are removed and
a specially designed serial cable that plugs into JP1 is inserted in their place.  The
new program can then be communicated via RS232 from the computer to the chip.
To make this work, JP2 (mentioned earlier) must be shorted.
3.3.2 MONITORING CIRCUITS

Internal Temperature
U7 is a special chip with a built-in temperature sensor.  It is processed by the CPU
(U10) and passed on to the CPU Controller board as required, over the RS232
communication link.  This measurement is for the ambient temperature surrounding
the chip, or to state it another way, the general operating temperature of the
electronics.

+5 V Monitoring
Voltage divider network R32 and R35 establish a 1 volt signal that is buffered by
amplifier U20 A.  Filter circuit R27 and C57 smoothes the output and passes it on to
one of the A/D multiplexed inputs of the CPU (U10).

+12 V Monitoring
Voltage divider network R59 and R57 establish a 1.2 volt signal that is buffered by
amplifier U20 B.  Filter circuit R28 and C56 smoothes the output and passes it on to
one of the A/D multiplexed inputs of the CPU (U10).

-12 V Monitoring
U16 A circuitry is used to monitor the -12 volt supply.  Filter circuit R33 and C54
smoothes the output and passes it on to one of the A/D multiplexed inputs of the CPU
(U10).  Diode pair D11 protects the input of the A/D to keep the input from exceeding
the supply limits.
To complete the description of circuits on sheet 1 … buffer amplifier U16 B takes the
built-in voltage reference of the CPU (U10) and applies it to a voltage divider (R62,
R65, R66) and multiplexer (U26) on sheet 2.

Cablehead Voltage
The cablehead voltage circuit appears on sheet 3 of the schematic drawing.
Voltage applied to the Telemetry instrument passes through the Power Supply PC
boards and is ultimately passed on, in a filtered state, to the Sensor board via
connector P1 at pins 5 and 10 (return).
Current device U4 (chassis mounted) and Zener diode D8 supply +5 Volts of power to
the active circuit components.  This supply is isolated from the +5 Volts of the digital
circuitry.  Magnetic coupling devices U3 and U5 provide connections between the
circuit components of this CHV sensing circuit and those of the digital circuits.
Voltage divider R4 and R1 create a low voltage sample of the applied CHV and C13
provides filtering.  This sample is amplified and shifted by U1 A to create a 0 to –2.5
Volt signal at test point TP4.  Shifting is accomplished by the Reference Output of the
A/D converter (U2) and buffered by U1 B before it is applied to the summing junction of
U1 A.  Diode pair D1 protects the input of the amplifier to keep the input from
exceeding the supply limits.
Data (SDATA) is serially shifted out of the A/D using the chip select (CS) and clock
(SCLK) passing through the isolating chips U3 and U5 as mentioned previously.

+28 V Monitoring
Refer to sheet 4 of the schematic drawing to note the components involved with
monitoring the +28 V supply.
Voltage applied to the Telemetry instrument passes through the Power Supply PC
boards and creates the +28 Volts that is ultimately passed on, in a filtered state, to the
Instrument Bus for all instruments in the tool string to use.  To monitor its voltage, it is
also routed to the Sensor board via connector P1 at pins 1 and 6 (return).
Dropping resistor R30 and Zener diode D13 provide +5 Volts to the active circuit
components.  This supply is isolated from the +5 Volts of the digital circuitry.  Magnetic
coupling devices U18 and U24 provide connections between the circuit components of
this Power Supply sensing circuit and those of the digital circuits.
Voltage divider R37 and R38 create a low voltage sample of the +28 Volts and C70
provides filtering.  This sample is amplified and shifted by U22 A to create a 0 to –2.5
Volt signal at test point TP21.  Shifting is accomplished by the Reference Output of the
A/D converter (U23) and buffered by U22 B before it is applied to the summing junction
of U22 A.  Diode pair D16 protects the input of the amplifier to keep the input from
exceeding the supply limits.

+28 V Current Monitoring
Continue to refer to sheet 4 of the schematic.
A resistor located on the Output Filter PC board (198162-000) is used as a current
sensing device.  The voltage drop across this resistor is what is used as a signal for
the +28 V Current sensing circuit.  It is routed from P2 pins 5 (-) and 10 (+) to the
Sensor board at P1 pins 2 and 3, respectively.
Dropping resistor R26 and Zener diode D10 provide +6.8 Volts to the active circuit
components.  This supply is isolated from the +5 Volts of the digital circuitry.  Opto-
coupling device U14 A provides connection between the circuit components of this
sensing circuit and those of the digital circuits.
The incoming voltage signal, proportional to the sensed current, is greatly amplified by
U12 A.  For protection, diode pair D9 is used to prevent the input from exceeding the
supply rails.  To reduce wild fluctuations in the signal, a two-pole filter is set up using
U12 B before being routed to the Voltage-to-Frequency Converter (VFC) chip of U13.
The VFC output drives the LED of the Opto-coupler U14 A.  It then passes the signal
on to the digital circuitry in the form of a frequency (at TP11).
3.3.3 SP CIRCUIT
The SP circuit is found on sheet 2 of the schematic drawing.
The SP signal is sensed at the bottom of the 1530 XA Induction instrument and passed
through the tool string until it reaches the Telemetry Sensor board at connector P2 pin
13.  Signal reference for the SP circuit is configurable either to the surface electrode
(P2 pin 14) or the cable armor (P2 pin 12).
The two amplifiers (U21 & U27) are configured identically with the SP signal applied to
the non-inverting input.  The difference is that the inverting input is tied to either the
surface electrode (U21) or to cable armor (U27).  Capacitors C62 and C71 reduce
noise on the signal and the back to back diodes prevent damage to the amplifiers in
the event that the input tries to exceed 12 Volts.
Outputs of the two amplifiers are tied to the multiplexer chip U26.  The default state
utilizes the surface electrode, so the output of U21 is applied to the first Mux input
(TP18).  Should the SP signal need to be referenced to cable armor, the second Mux
input passes the output signal of U27 (TP24).
Regardless of which signal is selected, including one of the test signals, it appears at
TP17 and is routed on to the two-pole filter circuit of U25 A.  From the output of this
filter circuit (TP23), it then is buffered by U19 (TP13) before entering the input of a 16-
bit A/D converter (U9).  Control over the A/D converter comes from the Sensor board
CPU and passes the digital data (SP_DATA) when requested, using the chip select
(SP_CS) and clock (SP_CLK) control signals.
The A/D converter, U9, uses an external +2.5 Volt reference (U8) for data conversion.
This reference is buffered by U15 A before being applied to an input of the A/D.  This

MICROPROCESSOR
The heart of the Gamma Ray PC board is the microprocessor, U3, which controls all of
the action of the circuit.  This unique chip contains several counters, an A/D converter
and inputs/outputs necessary to handle communications.  It also has internal ROM that
contains processing firmware and internal RAM for holding data.
Support devices of the microprocessor are:
•
U7 – a 16 MHz oscillator,
•
U9 – flash memory for holding tool parameters,
•
U4 – a precision voltage reference for the A/D converter,
•
U12 – a frequency divider chip for deriving communication frequencies.

COMMUNICATIONS
Communications with surface equipment, like other tools in the Matrix tool string, is
accomplished using Manchester words.
The Matrix Instrument Bus (MIB) carries commands for all tools of the tool string.  Only
when a command contains the correct address for a given tool does it respond.
Commands enter the Gamma Ray PC board via pins 8 and 9 of connector J1.
Commands are transformer-coupled (T2) to one of the differential amplifiers of U8.  The
output of U8 connects to the UDI pin of the Manchester Encoder/Decoder chip, U6.
Decoding commands, the Manchester chip determines whether the word is valid, and if
so, passes the 16-bit word to the microprocessor via the SDO pin.  Firmware determines
which command has been sent and what it must do to respond to that command.
If answering that command requires sending data back to the surface, the
microprocessor passes serial data to the Manchester chip for encoding on the SDI pin.
As the data word is encoded into Manchester format, it is clocked out the BZO\ and BOO\
outputs to driver chip U5.  This chip drives transformer T1 which couples the data to the
MIB.  The instrument bus data lines tie to connector J1, pins 3 and 4.  Modal
transformers within the Telemetry drive the wireline with signal levels necessary to reach
the surface.

DETECTING PULSES
As with other G/R detectors, hardware consists of a detecting crystal, coupled to a
photomultiplier (PM) tube.  Gamma rays from the formation enter the crystal where they
ionize and give off energy.  This ionization energy is converted into tiny flashes of light
(photons).  In the PM tube, these photons are changed into electrical pulses that are
amplified through a series of ten dynodes.
Voltage variations from the tube are proportional to the energy of the incident gamma
rays.  Since different levels of gamma radiation (i.e., count rates) are associated with
different types of rock, the information from the detector can be used to indicate formation
27

3518 XA Telemetry/GR – Circuit Descriptions
130871-945 / 3518 XA
APRIL 2004
Baker Atlas
lithology.  Higher gamma ray count rates are commonly associated with the presence of
shale.
Pulses from the PM tube enter the G/R circuit at terminal J4 and are capacitor-coupled
from its high voltage source to the input of amplifier U10.  A calibrating pot (R25) adjusts
the signal strength to give a 2 V peak at TP1 when a Cesium 137 source is brought near
to the detector working with the nominal high voltage applied.
The pulses are then sent to a discriminator, U11, to eliminate base-noise and shape the
valid pulses into a square-wave signal.  It is the output of U11 that is coupled to an
internal counter of the microprocessor, U3.  Here the pulse count accumulates until the
acquisition cycle stops the counting.

GAIN STABILIZATION
During actual operation, increased downhole temperatures cause the gain of the
photomultiplier tube to decrease.  To keep the sensitivity of the detector to gamma rays
constant, this drop in gain must be corrected.  This correction is accomplished by
increasing the high voltage applied to the PM Tube in a quantity that is proportional to the
temperature change.  Two relationships – gain vs. temperature and gain vs. high-voltage
– are characteristic of a particular tube type and are used to stabilize the gain by means
of control loop.  Below is a discussion of the various parts of this loop.
4.4.1 TEMPERATURE SENSING
A special combination chip, U4, contains a high precision voltage reference circuit,
which is its primary function.  However, it also contains a circuit that compensates the
voltage output with variations in temperature.  The output of this circuit is available as
a voltage that is proportional to the absolute temperature (°K) that it senses.  It is this
temperature sensitive circuit’s output that is amplified at U2 A.  The output of U2 A
becomes a signal that is measured by another input of the microprocessor’s internal
A/D converter.  Firmware within the microprocessor handles the processing of the
data.  Eventually this data is sent to the surface as part of Subset 0.
4.4.2 HIGH VOLTAGE MONITOR
The next stage of the control loop monitors the high voltage.  This stage consists of
amplifier U2 B and associated components.  The amplifier ties to the lower end of the
resistive voltage divider network that biases the dynodes (also the PM tube cathode
connection) and has a gain of 10.  The output of this amplifier is fed into one of the
inputs of the A/D converter internal to the microprocessor.  Capacitor C28 is used to
provide low impedance to the A/D converter input.
4.4.3 HIGH VOLTAGE CONTROL
The High Voltage Power Supply (HVPS) is a commercial item that is housed in
modular fashion.  It has an input pin that allows circuitry to control the output voltage
level.  The HV output is inversely proportional to the voltage applied to this control

3518 XA Telemetry/GR – Circuit Descriptions
130871-945 / 3518 XA
APRIL 2004
Baker Atlas
The microprocessor uses the measured temperature to determine the proper value of
the high voltage for those conditions.  This nominal value is compared to the
measured HV value and a correction is applied if needed.  The compensation is
gradual.  This gradual change keeps the process from over-compensating and putting
the loop into a constant up-and-down pattern.
The HVPS control is derived from a Pulse Width Modulated (PWM) output of the
microprocessor.  The average value of the pulse train is amplified by U1, configured
as a voltage follower, that has its positive input connected to a potentiometer.   The
network of R1, R2 and R6 establishes a limited adjustment range for the amplifier.
The amplifier output connects through resistor R3, to pin 11 of the connector J1, which
ties to the control pin of the HVPS.  Note: At room temperature, pot R2 is adjusted
until the output of the HVPS is 1300 volts.
4.4.4 START-UP
When the tool is powered up at high temperatures (i.e. downhole) the initialization
portion of the downhole software measures the tool temperature and applies an
approximate initial value to the PWM circuitry to provide for a fast turn-on.  The control
loop just described takes over from this point to keep the system gain stabilized.

SELF TEST
A constant frequency of 9.766 KHz scaled down from the system crystal oscillator is fed
to a counter input of the microcontroller (pin 6).  When requested by the surface system,
these counts replace the detector counts in the tool data block.  This is a check to ensure
proper communications and basic tool functioning.

PROCEDURE
____  1.
Clean and disassemble the 3518 XA instrument, referring to the step-
by-step Assembly Procedure 198600-855 in the Assembly/
Disassembly section of this manual.  Perform steps in reverse order.
Disassemble only to the level of removing the pressure housing to
expose the electronics chassis.
____  2.
Remove and discard all O-rings.  Replace with new O-rings.
____  3.
Inspect all wiring for nicks, cuts, pinholes or abrasion.  Check the
wiring for electrical leakage and continuity.  Refer to 198601-100.
Replace all defective wiring with new wires.
____  4.
Inspect all electrical connectors for damage: chips, cracks, water
absorption, broken contacts, corroded contacts or gascut.  Check for
electrical leakage and continuity.  Replace any electrical connectors
that are not fit for service in the downhole environment.
____  5.
Inspect all mechanical parts for evidence of damage, wear and
corrosion on critical O-ring seal surfaces and threads.  Replace any
parts that show excessive damage and are unfit for use.
____  6.
To reassemble the instrument, follow the applicable steps in the
Assembly Procedure 198600-855.
____  7.
Set up the Lab PC Test System according to Figure 1 below.  Start

GENERAL SAFETY INSTRUCTIONS

•
WEIGHT: The weight of the 3518 XA Telemetry instrument is 100 pounds (see
130871-025).  Care should be used when handling the instrument and the wearing of
steel-toed shoes is required.  A two-person lift is recommended.
•
ELECTRICAL: Beyond ESD precautions normal for electronic equipment, this
instrument does not require special considerations as far as safety goes.  However,
when powered outside of its housing, voltages in excess of 200 volts are present and
caution should be exercised.

THEORY OF OPERATION
The 3526 EB Focus to WTS Adapter Transformer Sub Instrument Assembly w/Alignment
Topsub provides a nominal 225 Vdc to Vin (top 27-socket female connector pins 1 and 2) on
the 3526 FB Focus to WTS Power Section Instrument Assembly. The 3526 EB and 3526 FB
must be connected together for operational use. The four transformers, full-wave bridge
rectifier, and two capacitor bank assemblies in the 3526 EB supply filtered DC voltage to the
3526 FB from nominal 180 Vac cablehead voltage.
The four transformers are connected in parallel to provide the necessary line isolation. The
full-wave bridge rectifier (BR1) converts the secondary voltage to DC and the two series
capacitor modules filter the rectified voltage. Chassis mounted 15k resistor R1 is connected
across the rectifier outputs to bleed off the charge on the capacitors modules when power is
removed.

instructions in the Manufacturing Assembly Procedure A3000061 ASP.

INTRODUCTION
Dangerous voltage is present on the 3526 EB Focus to WTS Adapter Transformer Sub
Instrument Assembly w/Alignment Topsub when power is applied and the pressure housing
is removed. Post the appropriate warning signs and do not leave the tool unattended when
power is on and the pressure housing is removed.
The 3526 EB weighs 112 pounds (50.8 kg) [126 pounds (57.2 kg) with thread protectors
installed]. More importantly, the tool is awkward to handle, requiring two people to lift and
carry it safely. Observe proper lifting techniques when handling this instrument.

3526 EB WHEN POWER IS APPLIED. EXERCISE APPROPRIATE
CAUTION AT ALL TIMES.

SECONDS FOR CAPACITORS TO BLEED DOWN BEFORE
WORKING ON THE 3526 EB.

OVERVIEW
The power supply uses a half-bridge switching power supply topology to convert a
nominal 250 Vdc to 28 Vdc. The half-bridge topology (see Figure 2) consists of two
alternately-conducting MOSFETs (Q1, Q2), input energy storage capacitors (C11, C14),
switched mode power transformer (T1), rectifier diodes (D1, D3), switched mode choke
(L1), and output filter capacitors (C1, C2).

conduction time (ton) of MOSFETs Q1 and Q2, which are switching at a frequency of
120 kHz (1/T). A closed loop feedback system compares Eo to a reference voltage and
adjusts the MOSFETs conduction time (ton) to maintain a constant output voltage (Eo).
For example, as Ein increases, ton decreases proportionally to maintain a constant Eo.
Mathematically, this can be written as:

Where:

Ein is the nominal 250-Vdc input voltage to the Power Supply

130963-945 / 3526 FB
MAR 2004
4
3526 FB Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions
Tracing through one cycle of operation, assume Q1 has been biased off and Q2 on.
Current flows from C14 through T1, C12, and Q2, applying ½ Ein across the primary
(Np) of T1. This primary voltage pulse is inductively coupled to the secondary winding
(Ns) of T1. The coupled secondary voltage forward biases diode D1, permitting
secondary current to flow through C1 and C2 and returning through L1 to the secondary
center tap of T1.
The conduction period ends when the conducting MOSFET (Q2) is commanded off, but
L1 ensures that current continue to flow to the load. Secondary current continues to flow
since the current through an inductor cannot change instantaneously. This is referred to as
the “freewheeling” period, which is the interval inductor L1 maintains the load current
until the opposite MOSFET begins conducting. Current flows from L1, through D1, D3
and returns through C1 and C2 during the “freewheeling” period.
When the opposite MOSFET (Q1) is commanded on, the “freewheeling” period ends, D3
is now forward biased, D1 is reverse biased, and current flows through C1, C2 again,
returning through L1 to the secondary center tap of T1.
The cycle repeats with the next “freewheeling” period followed by Q2 being commanded
on again. The MOSFET’s conduction time is controlled by the feedback circuitry to
maintain a constant 28-Vdc output in spite of the varying load and Ein.
Waveform 2 = Q1 source
Waveform 3 = T1 Center tap (TP1)
Waveform 4 = L1 Current

3526 FB Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

VOLTAGE MODE PWM CONTROLLER
Voltage mode PWM (Pulse Width Modulator) Controller U1 provides the nucleus for the
converter control circuitry that consists of an error amplifiers, clock, PWM circuitry, and
shutdown circuitry.
Converter switching frequency is set by the PWM’s clock, which operates at twice the
switching frequency. Components R16, C19, and C20 set the oscillator frequency and
dead time. The PWM’s Sync signal (pin 10) is used on the Output Filter PCB. U8 and
U9 A buffer the signal (CLKOUT) before it is transformer coupled (T3) to the Output
Filter PCB.
Control of the MOSFET conduction time is accomplished with PWM circuitry internal to
U1. The PWM circuitry functions by comparing the error voltage at U1, pin 5 with a
ramp signal synchronized with the PWM’s clock. Q3 buffers the ramp signal, which is
then applied to U1, pin 4. The PWM circuitry provides a duty-cycle-modulated waveform
that is alternately directed to DRVA and DRVB. Figure 4 shows the PWM (U1)
waveforms.

Where:
Waveform 1 = CLKOUT
Waveform 3 = DRVA
Waveform 2 = Ramp at U1-4
Waveform 4 = DRVB
MAR 2004
7
3526 FB Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

MOSFET DRIVERS
DRVA and DRVB of U1 are buffered by high-speed MOSFET driver ICs U2 and U4. U2
and U4 provide the high current gate drive, via transformer T1, to rapidly turn Q1 and
Q2, on and off. Dual secondary transformer T1 provides the necessary high side/low side
drive capability required for the Half-Bridge topology. Resistors R4 and R15 serve to
control Q1 and Q2 turn-on gate current and dampen ringing at the gate. Components R2,
R9, D1, and D2 provide an additional path for gate current (at turn-off) to ensure the
rapid turn-off of Q1 and Q2. Figure 5 shows the gate drive waveforms.

Where:
Waveform 1 = CLKOUT
Waveform 2 = Q2 gate – source
Waveform 3 = DRA – DRB


130963-945 / 3526 FB
MAR 2004
8
3526 FB Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

SOFT START
Soft start (SS) is a controlled start-up process that reduces stress on the Power Supply
components and minimizes output overshoot during start-up. Soft start is accomplished
by controlling the rate at which the voltage on pin 1 (C/S SS) of the PWM IC (U1)
ramps-up, which in turn controls Vout’s rise time. The controlled start-up is provided by
the time constant provided by R53 and C62. The voltage across C62 is buffered by U11
and drives the PWM’s C/S SS pin. Note that the 28 volt output takes ~160 ms to reach
full output. Figure 6 shows the soft-start waveforms at power-up.
When Power Supply operation is inhibited (PSEN =0 ), Run is held low by holding
transistors Q5 and Q8 on, which keep C62 discharged such that Soft start = 0. When
PSEN = 1, Run goes high and turns off Q5 and Q8, which allows the voltage on C62 to
start increasing exponentially, allowing Vout to start ramping up. Comparator-generated
signals SSRST/ and SSCMP indicate SS status. Signal SSRST/ is low when C62 is fully
discharged and conversely SSCMP=1 when SS is complete. These signals control the SS
process when HCL (high current limit) goes high. Under a sustained HCL condition, SS
is invoked and the signals force each SS cycle to terminate before the next cycle starts.

Waveform 1 = SS (U1-1)
Waveform 3 = SSCMP (U14-6)
Waveform 2 = SSRST (U12-6) Waveform 4 = 28 volt output (P2-1 to P2-6)

130963-945 / 3526 FB
MAR 2004
9
3526 FB Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

CONTROL LOOP CIRCUITRY
The demodulated error voltage provided by the Output Filter PCB is received via the
Sense+ and Sense– lines. Choke T2 provides common-mode filtering and the
demodulated error voltage is buffered by a differential amplifier consisting of U3 and
associated components. The buffered error voltage (VERROR) is applied through an RC
network to pin 5 (E/A+) of the PWM U1. Internal to U1, the error voltage is compared to
the voltage ramp on U6, pins 4. This comparison produces the ton pulse that is alternately
connected to A Out or B Out of U1. As previously discussed, a change in Eo is detected
by the control-loop circuitry and the circuit adjusts ton proportionately to correct Eo.
Refer to Figure 4 and Figure 7.

Waveform 2 = CLKOUT – Controller PCB
Waveform 3 = D12 A – Output filter PCB
Waveform 4 = VERROR – Controller PCB

3526 FB Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

OUTPUT OVER-CURRENT PROTECTION
Current transformer T4 samples the current pulses, delivered by Q1 and Q2 to the
primary of transformer T1 to provide over-current protection. The primary current is used
to detect output overload conditions since the primary current is equal to the secondary
current reflected by Np/Ns. Components R22, D3, and D4 convert the bipolar current
pulse to a unipolar voltage pulse. Components R21, R23, C71 and C21 serve to divide
and filter the signal prior to applying it to U7 and U13, which are the over current
detection comparators. Transistor Q4, IC U6, and associated components blank the
leading edge current spike, on R22, to prevent false over-current limiting.
The two comparators provide two levels of over current protection. If the overload is
20% or greater, only LCL current limit is invoked (Figure 8). If the overload is 40% or
greater, The HCL current limit is invoked, the output is temporarily removed, and a soft-
start restart sequence is initiated. Figure 9 shows the high level current level waveforms.

Waveform 2 = Ipri
Waveform 3 = LCL
Waveform 4 = SS

INPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION
Operation at excessively high or low CHV is inhibited to prevent possible damage to the
Focus/WTS Adapter Power Supply. Detection of out-of-range CHV is accomplished on
the PIC (Power Inhibit Controller) PCB and the Power Supply is controlled by the Power
Supply Enable Line (PSEN). A logic high enables the Power Supply.

topic: Circuit Description - 2.6 INPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION ..........................12 2.7 OUTPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION ......................12
chunk_text:
INPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION 12 
OUTPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION 12

OUTPUT OVER-VOLTAGE, UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION
Output over- and under -voltage protection is also provided, should the Power Supply
output drop below 25 Vdc or exceed 33 Vdc. Power Fault Monitor IC U1 on the output
filter PCB monitors the Output Voltage and will pull either OUV/ or OOV/ low if Vout is
either too low or too high, respectively. An Optical coupler (U10) on the Controller PCB,
conveys these signals to logic array U16. The logic in U16 latches the fault condition and
commands the Power Supply off, only in the case of output over-voltage, by raising
Shutdown (SD) and dropping RUN. The latched status LOUV/ and LOOV/ are sent to
130963-945 / 3526 FB
MAR 2004
13
3526 FB Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions
the PIC PCB for diagnostic purposes. U1 also controls a Green LED (D11) that
illuminates whenever the Power Supply is up and Vout is within tolerance.

CONTROLLER OPERATING POWER
Operating power for the controller is provided by an external 15 Vdc from the PIC PCB.
Three simple linear regulators provide +5 V, +5 VD, and +10 V to power the controller
PCB electronics. The regulators are composed of transistors Q9, Q6, Q7, and associated
passive components.

LOW-PASS FILTER
Refer to schematic drawing 199004-100 during this discussion. The chassis mounted
output rectifiers D1, D3, and switched mode choke L1 are connected to the Output Filter
Board. Components L1, C1, and C2 comprise a low-pass filter that averages the voltage
pulses from the rectifiers to produce 28 Vdc. Additional differential filtering and
common-mode filtering is provided by three cascaded low-pass filter stages. These filter
stages are comprised of L2, L3, L4, and associated capacitors. Figure 11 shows the 28
volt output ripple and noise.

MAR 2004
14
3526 FB Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

RECTIFIER SNUBBER
RC snubbers (R1 – R3, R5, R28, R29, C11, C18, and C35) across each rectifier diode and
transformer secondary dampen rectifier turn-on ringing, which is caused by the resonance
of the rectifier’s junction capacitance and the transformer’s secondary leakage
inductance. 

HOUSEKEEPING POWER SUPPLY
The housekeeping power supply (HKPS) is a two transistor Flyback Switching Power
Supply that is controlled by a Si9120 PWM IC. Operation is similar to the previously
discussed PWM circuitry in that the MOSFET’s conduction time is modulated to
maintain a constant output voltage.
The voltage ramp required for PWM is provided by capacitor C53 charging through
resistors R45 and R59, with diode D16 serving to reset the ramp after each cycle. Output
over-current protection is provided by resistor R13 and diode D20.
For regulation purposes, the 15 Vdc is fed back through R12 and R17; with C21, C25,
and R11 setting the loop gain.
Resistor R6 sets the PWM’s switching frequency to 200 kHz, while resistor R16
establishes the PWM’s bias current. Output pin 5 of the PWM drives the two MOSFETs
concurrently, each through its own DC restoration circuit (C23, D19, R56, C17, D13, and
R53). Energy is stored in T1’s air gap while transistors Q2 and Q1 are conducting.
During the conduction interval, diode D1 is reverse biased. When Q1 and Q2 are turned
off, energy stored in T1 is released, D1 is forward biased, and the output capacitors (C6-
C15, C46, and C47) are charged. During the conduction interval, when D1 is reversed
biased, energy stored in the output capacitors maintains the 15-Vdc output.
Start-up power is provided to the PWM through diode D12 and resistor R3. Once the
HPS commences operation, PWM operating power is supplied from the 15-Vdc output
via components D4, R45, D5, D9, and D10.

130963-945 / 3526 FB
MAR 2004
15
3526 FB Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions
Comparators U1 A and U1 B set the HKPS input operating voltage range and turn-on
voltage. Like the Focus/WTS Adapter Power Supply, the HKPS input voltage operating
range is controlled to prevent damage. U3 provides a reference voltage to the
comparators as well as the PWM chip. Figure 12 and Figure 13 are scope shots of the
HKPS at full load.

MICRO-COMPUTER CONTROLLER
The PIC16 F873 (U5) is an 8-bit microcontroller with an internal 10-bit A/D and data
EEPROM. Chip U6 and related components translate CHV to a 0 Vdc to 5 Vdc signal
(ACHV) that is compatible with U5. Likewise, U10 and related components translate
temperature dependent current from the chassis-mounted AD590 (U1) to a signal
(ATEMP) that is compatible with U5. Chip U8 permits monitoring of the 15-Vdc
supplied by the HKPS.
Power Supply Enable (PSEN) and Over Current Reset (OCR) are output command lines
to the controller PCB. A logic high from PSEN turns on the 28-Vdc output and OCR
resets a latch internal to U16 on the controller PCB.
Latched Output under Voltage (LOUV), Latched Output Over-voltage (LOOV), and
Latched Over current (LOC) are 28-Vdc output status signals sent back from U16 on the
controller PCB. The status of these signals is saved in the microcontroller’s EEPROM for
diagnostic purposes.
130963-945 / 3526 FB
MAR 2004
17
3526 FB Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions
The microcontroller monitors cable-head voltage, chassis temperature, and housekeeping
voltage to ensure these parameters are within limits before enabling the 28 Vdc power
supply. Once the 28 Vdc power supply is enabled, the microcontroller continues
monitoring the three parameters and will disable the power supply if any fall out-of-
range.
The typical ON/OFF set points determined by the microcontroller are:
•
Input voltage set points:
o Turn – ON:
225 Vdc < Vch < 300 Vdc
o Turn – OFF: Vch < 160 Vdc or Vch > 330 Vdc
•
Over-Temperature set points are as follows:
o Power Supply OFF: Chassis temperature equal or greater than 175º C
o Power Supply ON:
Chassis temperature 170º C or less
•
Vcc set points
o Power Supply ON:
14 Vdc < Vcc < 16 Vdc
When the cable-head voltage or chassis temperature goes out of range, the micro-
controller disables the power supply and waits for these conditions to fall within range
again before restarting the power supply. The micro-controller behaves slightly
differently to Vcc. If Vcc drifts out of range while the power supply has been enabled, the
PIC PCB will permanently disable the power supply. In this situation, the micro-
controller must be reset by cycling the housekeeping voltage (i.e., lower the cable-head
voltage below 150 Vac).
The PIC PCB monitors three power supply status signals (LOC, LOUV, LOOV) while
the 28 Vdc power supply is enabled. The PIC PCB will record any change in the state of
these signals in its internal EEPROM. The PIC PCB will permanently disable the power
supply if the LOOV signal is asserted, indicating an over-voltage condition on the 28-
Vdc bus. Similar to a Vcc out-of-range condition, the micro-controller must be reset to
exit this condition.
LED D14 provides an indication of the microcontroller’s state. The LED blinks at a rate
of twice per second when the micro-controller is holding the 28-Vdc power supply off
and waiting for cable-head voltage, chassis temperature, and Vcc to fall in range. Once
the 28-Vdc power supply has been turned on, the PIC PCB will leave the LED on
continuously. The LED will blink at a rate of once per second when the PIC PCB
permanently disables the power supply in the event that Vcc is out-of-range or that
LOOV is asserted.
Jumper JP1 is a 10-pin header used to connect the PIC PCB to a PC for diagnostic
purposes. Four shunts are installed across the jumper when the diagnostic port is not in
use.
Header P3 is used for in-circuit programming and debugging. J2 is a jumper with a shunt
that is removed only during in-circuit programming of the micro-controller. The shunt
needs to be installed for normal operation of the board.
