3526 FB Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions 
INTRODUCTION
The 3526 FB Focus to WTS Power Section Instrument Assembly is comprised of four circuit
boards and several chassis mounted components, as shown on wiring diagram
A3000072 WRD and Figure 1. Figure 1 is a block diagram of the 3526 FB Power Adapter
Heat Sink Instrument Assembly. The four power supply boards are:
•
Power Supply Controller – 199005-000
•
Output Filter – 199004-000
•
Input Filter – 197993-000
•
Power Inhibit Controller (PIC) – A3000305000
The 3526 FB Focus to WTS Power Section Instrument Assembly provides a regulated +28
Vdc at 4.0 amps, maximum. The 3526 FB works in conjunction with the 3526 EB to convert
180 Vac from a WTS Telemetry the 28 Vdc used by the Focus instrument string. AC voltage
is received by the 3526 EB and a DC voltage in the range of 160 Vdc to 330 Vdc is provided
to the 3526 FB. Although the operating range of the 3526 FB is 160 Vdc to 330 Vdc, an input
of at least 225 Vdc to start. This input voltage provides the necessary hysteresis to ensure that
the input does not drop below 160 Vdc, due to the voltage drop in the cable as the power
supply comes up.

MAR 2004
3
3526 FB Power Section Instrument – Circuit Descriptions

topic: Circuit Description - 3.0 OUTPUT FILTER PCB 4.0 INPUT FILTER PCB
chunk_text:
OUTPUT FILTER PCB 
INPUT FILTER PCB
Refer to schematic drawing 197993-100 during this discussion. A balanced, three-section,
low-pass filter prevents (attenuates) differential mode and common-mode switching noise at
Vin from contaminating the converter’s HV DC inputs, P1-1 and 10. The filters consist of L1
through L6 and associated capacitors. Resistors R1 through R24 serve as bleeders and to
equalize the voltage across their respective capacitors.

POWER INHIBIT CONTROLLER
Refer to schematic drawing A3000305 SCH during this discussion. Figure 12 and Figure 13
are scope shots that are provided to help understand the operation of the Power Inhibit
Controller (PIC) PCB. The PIC PCB consists of two major circuits: Micro-Controller and
related acquisition circuitry, and the Housekeeping Power Supply (HPS). The HPS converts
Cable head voltage to +15 Vdc and Vcc to operate the Controller PCB (CB), the resident
Micro-Controller, and associated acquisition circuitry. The Micro-Controller monitors
various parameters and controls, and turns the main 28 Vdc output on or off.

INTRODUCTION
Level 3 maintenance should be performed on the 3526 FB Focus to WTS Power Section
Instrument Assembly every four months to ensure the integrity of the tool. Check (�) each
step in the procedure as it is completed and place this page in the tool history folder.

PROCEDURE
____  1.
Thoroughly clean the 3526 FB instrument with the thread protectors installed.
____  2.
Remove the thread protectors and clean the threads at the top and bottom of
the adapter.
____  3.
Inspect external parts for nicks, thread dings, and other visible damage.

Remove the instrument chassis from its pressure housing. Use the
Disassembly Procedure in the Manufacturing Assembly Procedure
A3000072 ASP.
____  5.
Inspect for loose hardware and components. Tighten as necessary.
____  6.
Inspect the top 27-socket Matrix female connector and the bottom 27-pin
Matrix male connector for visible damage. Inspect for bent or loose contacts
and pins. Replace all damaged sockets and pins.
____  7.
Check out the tool per the “Final Test” section of Manufacturing Test
Procedure 130963-856.
____  8.

____  9.
Re-assemble the 3526 FB instrument assembly using the Final Assembly
instructions in the Manufacturing Assembly Procedure A3000072 ASP.

not leave the tool unattended when power is on and the pressure housing is removed.
The tool is awkward to handle, requiring two people to lift and carry it safely. Observe proper
lifting techniques when handling this instrument.

topic: Brief Description of Service - 1.0 BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
chunk_text:
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
Refer to 3590 XA Equipment Specification Sheet F131034025 for tool application and
measurement principles.

INTRODUCTION
The 3590 XA HTHP WTS Telemetry Transceiver Instrument is heavy and contains high voltage
(180 Vac) when power is applied to the instrument. Observe the Electrical and Tool Weight safety
procedures that follow.

ELECTRICAL SAFETY PRECAUTIONS
High voltage (180 Vac) is present at various points on the electronics chassis when the pressure
housing is removed and power is applied to the instrument. The following electrical safety
precautions apply.



High voltage in use
Potential Electrical Shock
•
Turn off power when not required
•
Post appropriate warning signs
•
Avoid distractions while working on equipment with
power applied
•

Tool Weight
The 3590 XA weighs 279 pounds (see F131034025). Titanium has been utilized for all structural
components in an effort to reduce the total weight of the instrument(s).







Instrument is heavy
Possible serious bodily injury
•
Wear safety boots and gloves
•
Use proper lifting methods and equipment
to lift and move instrument



131034-954
JULY 2010

OVERVIEW
The primary function of the 3590 XA Wireline Telemetry (WTS Common Remote) is to act as a
wireline repeater of the telemetry channels and to create the WTS Instrument Bus (WTS-IB). The
3590 XA Wireline Telemetry does not interpret or take any action with commands that are targeted
to other instruments of the tool string. This is also true for the data that is sent to the surface from
these tools.  A secondary function is to acquire data from several internal sensors and/or optional
external sensors.

Downhole Telemetry Interface
The 3590 XA HTHP Wireline Telemetry (WTS Common Remote) was developed to provide
downhole telemetry in High Temperature and High Pressure boreholes. It also provides improved
long-line performance when using wireline greater than 20,000 feet and up to 40,000 feet in
length.

Internal Temperature Sensors
Refer to Drawing A3000659 SCH, Figure 1, and wiring diagram A3000659 WRD.

temperature measures Zone 3 temperature and is exposed directly to the borehole environment.
The temperature is measured via a sensor in the 2890 XB. The electronics for this sensor are
located on the Sensor board and explained in Section 4.7.
The electronics flask internal temperature (Zone 1) is monitored by U2 located on the A/D &
Controller board (A3001573000) and is explained in Section 2.2.2. The temperature outside the
electronics flask yet inside the housing flask (Zone 2) is monitored by RTD2 located on the
power supply chassis (A3000659 SCH). Electronics associated with RTD2 are on the sensor
board (F129982000) Channel 9 Section 4.6. Both of these temperatures are read and sent to the
surface while logging.
The third temperature sensor, RTD1, is also located inside the housing flask (Zone 2) on the
power supply chassis in close proximity to RTD2 and is connected directly to Top sub pins 26
and 10. This “passive” arrangement is read by connecting a hand held meter to the top sub. The
measurement provides the operator with the internal temperature, so he can determine if the
temperature is low enough that the housing can be safely removed.

topic: Circuit Description - 2.0 CONTROLLER AND DATA ACQUISITION BOARD
chunk_text:
CONTROLLER AND DATA ACQUISITION BOARD
Refer to assembly drawing A3001573000 and schematic A3001573 SCH during the circuit
discussions of the Controller and Data Acquisition board.
This board is divided into two major sections. The circuit on the right half of the board is the
controller section, the remainder of the board comprises the data acquisition section.

Controller Section
This microcontroller based circuit performs the following functions:
•
Interface directly to the Manchester chip (U19) to receive the serial data, interpret and
execute commands and serial data from Manchester encoding and transmission.
•
Control the sequence of the data acquisition process and the gathering of data from the A/D.
•
All instrument relays and switches are energized, latched, or switched by the controller and
its associated driver circuits.
In addition to the functions noted above, a test socket is provided on board, but is NOT FOR
FIELD USE.
2.1.1 Power-On Reset
Upon power up, the microcontroller or MCU (U18) is held reset by R27 and C11 for a period of
three seconds. The long time constant was chosen to allow the correct startup under various
conditions of instrument power-up, particularly when the variac voltage is turned up very slowly.
D4 across R27 allows rapid discharge of the reset circuit when the instrument is de-energized. D9
protects U18’s reset pin from negative overshoot and balances out the leakage of D4 at
temperature.
2.1.2 Clock Oscillator
A crystal clock oscillator package (U16) supplied a 4 MHz clock to the MCU. The MUC divides
the clock by 2 internally and runs at 2 MHz with a period of 0.5 µs.
Observe that U16 has built in divider stages with outputs supplied to other parts of the system.
One of these outputs is the 7812.5-Hz clock at pin 1 of U16. This clock is buffered by a dedicated
gate (U15), to provide a constant amplitude square wave to the mud resistivity circuit. Regulation
is made possible by deriving the +5 V power supply for U15 from a precision voltage reference in
the data acquisition section rather that using the main logic supply. The buffered output is made
available at the terminal labeled 7812.5 Hz.

2.1.3 Manchester Interface
Like other instruments in the WTS system, the 3590 common remote has its own designated
remote terminal address, which is $80 in this case. However, with both repeater and local remote
residing in the same package, there is no need to interface its local remote to the instrument bus.
Instead, the UDI and BZO/ signals of the Manchester (U19) tap directly into the repeater via logic
elements, and this eliminate the two coupling transformers, receiver, driver, and passive
components normally used in a typical remote.
Interface between U19 and the MCU (U18) is straight forward. Nine of the MCU’s I/O ports are
configured for direct handshaking with the Manchester chip (U19).
R28 keeps the Manchester encoder disabled during the brief power-up cycle to avoid unwanted
transmission to the surface.
R29 combines SDI and TD signals to save one MCU port, because the two signals are not
required to be active simultaneously.
R33 is a special case pull-down resistor.
2.1.4 Relay Interface
There are four latching relays in the 3590, one of which, is located in the controller section of this
board and is used for SP and bridle switching. The other three relays are located on the mud
resistivity board and used for mode switching. There is a non-latching power relay (K1) mounted
on the chassis for motor supply and other signal routing. All of these relays can operate with a
24 V supply.
A separate 24 V power supply is derived from the unregulated inputs of the ±15 V regulators; i.e.,
V+ and V-. The common return is floating in this supply, with V- used as the return. The power
supplies deliver a fairly stable voltage when properly powered. Zener diode (D6) develops 18 V
across it leads, leaving 24 volts to power the relays. C12 provides additional filtering.
Although local conditions vary widely as one or more relays are switched in different
combinations, this arrangement provides adequate regulation. The steady state current is low
because only K1 requires current to hold it energized. Pulse duration for the latching relays is 10
µs.
Darlington array (U22) with its built-in EMP protection diodes provides the drive to the
individual coils. Shift-and-store register (U21) supplies the control signals at its latched outputs to
U22. Data from the MCU is clocked serially into U21, while latched outputs of U21 are held

Interface between the +5 V logic control signals and the relay driver circuit is accomplished by a
voltage level translation circuit. Obviously, doing the translation at the three input lines of U21
instead of the outputs required fewer components. For this reason, U21 must be powered by a net
5 V supply, which is developed across Zener diode D5 with Vss = -15 V and VDD = -10 V. This is
an important detail to keep in mind when servicing the circuit. PNP transistor array (U20) and
resistors R20 through R25 accomplish the translation.
2.1.5 Other Switches
When not AC motoring, conductor 7 of the wireline can be used for transmitting the mode 7 C
channel. The channel is transformer-coupled by T6 to the wireline. T6 is AC-coupled to keep
from interfering with SP and DLL remotes on conductor 7 (in Mode 7 state). U17 is a CMOS
switch with a low 25 ohm-on resistance. It is configured in the circuit as dual SPDT switches
connected in parallel, thus dropping the on-resistance to one-half the noted value.
The MCU controls U17 directly. In one setting, line 7 gets connected to the SP conductor to
provide the SP signal uphole. In the other setting, line 7 becomes connected to line 13 of the
instrument bus below the 3590 and acts as a DLL surface reference. It may also be used as an
analog signal path to the surface by some instruments if the need arises. L4 filters mode 7 C
signals out of the downhole SP signal.
2.1.6 Diagnostic Interface
A test socket is installed on the PC board, but is NOT FOR FIELD USE.
2.1.7 Data Acquisition Interface
By far, this interface is the largest user of I/O ports, 15 in all. These are divided into four


Data Acquisition Section
2.2.1 Overview
The data acquisition circuit accommodates a wide dynamic range, bipolar operation, and accuracy
of measurement. Refer to the 3590 XA subset documentation for additional information
concerning the application of converted data. Further information on each channel is described in
the Sensor board discussion.
A brief highlight of the configuration follows:
•
Basic Converter – Industry standard 574 A/D chip, operated in the bipolar mode for 12-bit
resolution and with a 0 – to 10 V input range.
•
Other Features –
Two-step auto-gain -ranging scale:
1)
Gain of 2 for input signals exceeding about 600 mV
2)
Gain of 15 for signals below 600 mV

Separate sign bit for bipolar signals

Track and hold amplifier

External precision 10 V reference for calibration

16 data channels with ±5 V input range

First two for dedicated drift corrections
2.2.2 Analog Channel Multiplexer
As shown on the schematic, U3 and U4 form the 16-channel analog multiplexer. All but three
input terminals are wired to signal channels outside the board. Channel 1 is an A/D Zero
reference. Channel 2 is a 580 mV A/D Cal reference, derived from the precision 10 V output of
U1 by a voltage divider network R1, R2, and R3. The third channel represents the flask
temperature (10 mV / ºC and is supplied by U2, a single package, voltage output, temperature
sensor. The three terminals, connected locally on board, serve as test points.
Channel selection is controlled by four MCU output ports: three directly address one of eight
channels in each multiplexer and a forth (pin 8 of U18) is the enable control line for U3 and
U4.The enable signal routed through U8 generates an enable and it’s complement to exclusively

2.2.3 Sign Converter
The selected analog output, buffered by one of the dual op-amps in U5, passes through a
switchable sign converter made up of the second op-amp in U5, resistors R8, R9, and R10 and
one half of the analog switches in U10. When a positive signal is available at both inputs of this
amplifier, U5 acts as a voltage follower with a gain of 1, independent of the gain resistor ratios.
For negative signals, the switch disconnects the non-inverting input from the signal, grounding it
through R10 to form an inverting amplifier with a gain of -1. This signal at the output of U5 will
always be positive except possibly during a small window around the zero-crossing threshold for
switching. Precision resistors R8 and R9 assure a negative unity gain, while a 30 mV nominal
offset in the succeeding stage adds to the signal to make it positive all the time to satisfy the
converter’s unipolar input requirements.
Such offset, conveniently introduced at the track and hold amplifier (U9) by biasing it trim inputs,
must be accounted for after data recovery, together with any other offset and gain drift errors. The
method involves multiple sampling of the ZERO and CAL channels under different gain and sign
settings. Hence for the channels, the MCU overrides the free running auto-gain, auto-sign
operations periodically as will be described later. For other signals, sign control is accomplished
by comparator 2 of U7, which monitors the buffered analog signal in reference to zero.
A comparator offset, if large enough, can shift the zero point beyond the allowable 30 nV
window, leading to erratic sign results. The signal into the first comparator is boosted 10 X by a
low offset amplifier (op-amp 2 of U6) to eliminate the need for a null trim pot. In effect, any
comparator offset would then seem reduced by the same factor (compared to the input signal of
interest) in the vicinity of the zero-crossing region.
Back-to-back Zener diodes D1 and D2 protect U7 by limiting the boosted signal range to safe
values. The sign bit formed at the output of the comparator must be read with the data after
conversion. Its logic level must be the same immediately before and after conversion to eliminate
the possibility of coding the wrong sign with the converted data. The output of the comparator
itself is not restricted. The output through R12 is OR-tied at pin 3 of U8 with another sign control
signal from the MCU. Pin 3 is the input of one of the two latches enabled by a second MCU
control signal (pin 7 of U18). When enabled, the output of the latch (pin 15 of U8) follows the
logic state of pin 3. This is the case during the signal tracking period in the data acquisition cycle,
where the latch output dynamically controls the inverter. The comparator output is granted control
when the MCU floats its output to a high impedance state. At other times, the MCU may bring its

2.2.4 Gain Ranging and Track / Hold
Comparator one in the dual unit package (U7) generates the gain bit. It compares the signal at the
output of the sign inverter with VTH. The set point VTH was made higher that the 580 mV CAL to
trip the comparator output high when CAL is sampled. The desired outcome is a gain of 16. The
reasoning for this gain will be explained later in this discussion.
Another gain bit control line from the MCU is OR-tied with the output of the comparator through
D3 and R14 to allow either gain bit to appear at the input of the controlled latch (pin 2 of U8).
The latch output at pin 16 is the Gain Ranging control signal that actually switches the gain at pin
10 of U10, and it is read with the converted data. This latch and the sign bit latch have a single
enable line controlled by the MCU signal (pin 17 of U18) mentioned earlier. Incidentally, the
same MCU signal controls the enable line of a second latch in U8 at pin 4. The latch holds the
CCL gain bit generated at the sensors board steady during the conversion cycle.
The MCU can grant gain-ranging control to the comparator by bringing its output to a high logic
state. In the calibration cycle, it can force the gain bit low only for a gain of two, unlike the sign
case. Indirectly, however, the gain can be made 16 for both ZERO and CAL by default under
comparator control. What makes this possible is that the two signals fall below the comparator
threshold point VTH.
Resistors R15, R16, and R17 form a feedback network around U9 that is selectable by analog
switches in U10 for a gain of 2 or 16. U9 doubles in function as a track and hold amplifier. It
constantly track the signal present at its input and holds it constant before the conversion cycle
starts on command from the MCU.
2.2.5 Data Conversion and Encoding
The A/D (U11) is configured to convert and provide all 12-bits at its outputs simultaneously when
initiated with a single control pulse at pin 5. The digital data plus four other binary signals are
multiplexed into four nibbles by data selectors U12 and U13. The MCU uses a two-bit “Nibble
Select Bus” to read each nibble onto its 4-bit data bus as shown on schematic A3001573 SCH.
A third data selector (U14) is controlled by the same MCU port associated with gain ranging;
however, it has nothing to do with gain ranging. The Manchester word can accommodate only 16
bits. Out of those 16-bits, 12 are occupied by the converted data and one by the gain bit, which
leaves three bits. The SP channel requires that a 3-bit code be transmitted with the data. One of
the bit lines, B2, is permanently wired for MSB in the 16-bit word while the remaining two, B0
and B1, are routed to U14. The SP sign is applied positive and it is not transmitted. In this case,
U14 selects the two code bits to fill the data word.
In another special case, applicable to the CCL channel, a unique CCL gain bit must be
transmitted. Here, U14 select that bit and the sign bit for transmission. It also retains this selection
for other channels, excluding the SP channel of course.

REPEATER BOARD
Refer to assembly drawing F191663000 and schematic F191663100 during the circuit
discussions of the repeater board.
While other boards in the 3590 perform needed functions and gather a multitude of data channels
vital to the logging service, the repeater card is essential to WTS operation. It forms the link
between the surface panel, via modal transmission on the wireline, and downhole instruments
communicating on the instrument bus. The three modal transformers that couple signals between
the board and the line are mounted on the backbone of the power supply section.
Functionally, the board’s circuit is subdivided into four channels: Command, Mode 2, mode 5,
and Mode 7.

Command Channel
This channel receives Manchester words from the surface panel and repeats the words on the
command bus. Words can be commands or data as determined by the Manchester Sync bit. A
standard defining the shape and polarity of the signals used in the WTS transmission system has
been specified.
Signals entering the command channel at the 20 kb/s rate of the surface to downhole transmission
are amplified and inverted by op-amp 1 of U1. Gain pot P1 adjusts the signal level to suit the
length, type, and condition of the wireline in service. Ideally, the signal should be about 8 to 10
volts p-p as measured at the CMP IN test terminal.
Mode 2 channel couples the mode 2 winding on the same modal transformer connected to the
command channel. The induced command signal in this winding is fed to the non-inverting input
of differential amplifier U1, effectively increasing the signal strength and improving the signal to
noise ratio. On the other hand, data words on the mode 2 channel coupled back into the command
channel are undesirable and are attenuated by this echo cancellation arrangement.
A cascaded RC filter followed by the equalization filter implemented in the second op-amp of U1
reduces the noise and harmonic distortion added to the signal by the wireline.
In the 3514 XB, R6 A is replaced with a band-pass filter on board F191658000. U1 gain resistors
are selected to obtain the overall system response.
Comparator U2 converts the signal to digital form, triggering at approximately a ±2 volt
hysteresis established by its resistor network. The trigger reference at the non-inverting input of
the comparator flips from one level to another as the output of the comparator changes state and
feeds back into R10 at pin 15 of the programmable logic device (U5). R47 trims R11 to center the
trigger point around the signal baseline. This centering adjustment removes timing skew in the
signal edges and improves communication. The feedback, gated by an AND gate in U5, is
inhibited during data transmission on mode 2. Pin 15 of U5 is forced low during this period to
reset the comparator to a predetermined state. There are two reasons for this action: first to
prevent mode 2 data, induced in the command channel, from reaching the instrument bus where it

may be interpreted as a command word. Second, to prepare the comparator to trigger on the first
edge of the next command sync. Otherwise, the comparator may already be in that state and fail
to repeat the correct sync on the instrument bus. The comparator state would have been dependent
on the ending bit in the preceding mode 2 data transmission.
The comparator reset signal is generated by a retriggerable one shot implemented inside U5. Its
192 µs timing period allows the one shot to stay triggered while mode 2 data bits are present,
even during the longer sync period.
The command interrupt bus is coupled to the command channel by T1. the transformer is driven
by differential line driver U3 with its open collector outputs pulled high at the center tap through
the diodes and current limiting resistors. One of the U3 inputs is driven directly by the
comparator. The remaining input is connected to the complemented comparator output at U5.
The local 3590 CR Manchester decoder receives the command signal at its UDI input from the
gated comparator output (pin 15 of U5). D1 keeps a damaging -15 V from appearing at UDI if U5
is not inserted.

Mode 2 Channel
Receives Mode 2 data, processes it, filters it, and sends it up the wireline on mode 2.
Reliable reception of data at the other end of the wireline requires that the Manchester-encoded
logic level signal (0 V, 5 V) be modified for transmission. The transmission is designed to put
shaped, filtered bipolar pulses on the wireline. This process limits the bandwidth required for a
transmission, reduces line charging, and reduces crosstalk to the other data channels. All the data
and clocking information encoded in a Manchester signal is represented in the transition of the
logic-level signal. Narrow pulses are generated by the transitions as will be seen in the following
description.
At the front end of the receiver, data enters from two separate sources before being OR-tied and
shaped digitally within U5. One source is the Manchester BZO/ output of the local remote. BZO/
interfaces directly to pin 2 of U5. The other is the instrument bus coupled through T2 to one of
the differential receivers in U4. The output of U4 is connected to pin 11 of U5. The two merged
signals inside U5 form a single Mode 2 data path, which is processed as follows:
First, a logic level change in the merged Mode 2 Data in U5 initiated a positive pulse at one of
two corresponding outputs M2 H (pin 9) and M2 L (pin 10). In turn, that enables a counter
incremented by a 4 MHz reference clock. When the count reaches a predetermine number, the
counter toggles a flip-flop ending the pulse and clearing itself. In the 3590, if the time after the
previous pulse has been long, M2 H or M2 L will appear at pin 18 (N2 H_short) or pin 20
(M2 L_short) instead.
The pulse width generated on Mode 2 is 5.125 µs ±0.125 µs. the uncertainty is due to the variable
time difference between the data transition edge and the first clocking edge of the 4 MHz clock.
This one-count jitter amounts to less than 5% and translates into periodic, slight amplitude
modulation in the filtered signal output. The frequency beating is nonexistent on data emanating

JULY 2010

Second, the data pulses emanating from pins 9/18 and 10/20 of U5 are fed into the inputs of a
unity gain differential amplifier made up of op-amp 2 in U5 and six resistors. The op-amp
provides unity gain for signals from U5, pins 9 and 10, but reduced gain (shorted amplitude) for
signals from U5, pins 18 and 20. The amplifier passes the pulses at its non-inverting input and
inverts the pulses at the outer input, converting the two-level signal (0 V, 5 V) to a five-level (-V, -
short, +short, +V) alternate mark inversion (AMI) signal. This AMI signal is passed through a
two-pole low-pass Bessel filter (op-amp 1 in U6) to remove the high-frequency edges. The
shaped and filtered signal is put on the wireline through the Mode 2 coupling transformer,
capacitively driven by the current buffer (U7).
For lower power dissipation in the current driver, the output stage of this hybrid device is
powered with ±12 V. The voltages are obtained by dropping the ±15 V supplies through 3.0-volt
Zener diodes D5 and D6.

Mode 5 Channel
This channel receives data only from Mode 5 of the instrument bus. It has a higher bit rate (93.75
kb/s) as specified in the WTS specification. Being coupled to the wireline through a separate
modal transformer, feedback into the command channel is negligible. No comparator controls are
required.
The instrument bus coupling transformer has a higher frequency response than the ones used for
lower speed, Mode 2 channels. The differential input circuits are similar to that of Mode 2, as is
the shaping circuit of U9, which generates narrower pulses in a proportional manner. Using an 8
MHz clock, the jitter remains below 5% for this channel also.
The other stages are practically the same as those for the previous channel with the exception of
the filter circuit. A single pole RC filter is sufficient for this channel.

Mode 7 Channel
This channel works at the same speed as the mode 5 channel. On the wireline side, the circuit is
transformer-coupled (T6) through a capacitor (C7) and relay (K1) to line 7 and the center tap of
the Mode 5 transformer. On the instrument bus side, the interface connects to Mode 7 A. The
circuit for both modes is similar, sharing the same dual receiver package (U8) and dual shaping
sections implemented in U9. U9 consumes about 30 mA when running at 8 MHz speed.

SENSOR BOARD
Refer to assembly drawing F129982000 and schematic F129982100 during the circuit
discussions of the sensor board.
The sensor board is a collection of independent circuits on a single board. The board processes
and/or filters a dozen analog channels in preparation for sampling. It also receives the system’s
precision 10 V reference for the controller and data acquisition board to provide a buffered, stable,
bridge supply for the force gauge and pressure sensors. Other references required for same of the
sensor circuits are derived form the 10 V reference as well.
To a large extent, all circuits are physically partitioned for ease of layout, identification, and
servicing. The channels are labeled from 4 through 15 and are positioned on the board in a
sequential order from left to right. The same order will be followed in describing these circuits.

Channel 4 (Ax)
Unused filter Ax. See CH6 circuit description. Op-amp U1 is not installed.

Channel 5 (Ay)
Unused filter Ay. See filter description below. Op-amp U2 is not installed.

Channel 6 (Ax)
Each filter circuit in the above three channels consists of a 2-pole low-pass Bessel filter having a
role-off frequency of 2 Hz. It is a classic two-stage two-pole design with parameters yielding an
overall gain of 1.906. Op-amp U3 is not installed.
A one megohm pull-down resistor at the input of each circuit keeps it from floating in the absence
of a signal source.


Channel 7 (Force)
Gain and filter circuit for the force strain gauge sensor. The tension/compression load cell in the
sensor sub delivers about a 1 mV signal per 1,000 lbf, based on the 10 V of excitation used. The
force scale required in tension is 20,000 lbf, and is much less in compression. A ±20 mV input
range specification covers both scales equally, but with the positive polarity implying tension.
Input instrumentation amplifier U4 has a gain of 201. the resulting full-scale signal will be
approximately ±4.0 V, well within the ±5 V input range of the data conversion section.
A 2-pole low-pass filter following the gain stage rolls off the signal (-3 dB) at about 6 Hz.
Resistor at the input of the amplifier keep the output from saturating when the sensor sub is
installed. Input capacitor C53 filters high-frequency noise on the input lead wires.

Channel 8 (Caliper)
This channel processes the caliper signal. The circuit is similar to that for channel 7. U6 has a
gain of 1, with no connections between pins 1 and 4. R33 and R34 together with R92 form a
divide-by-three attenuator similar to the caliper input in the 3506 PCM and 3516 SLAM adapter.
R93 works with C54 to provide additional high-frequency noise filtering. R93 is also a dropping
resistor for the input protection Zeners. This circuit protects the input of top block #2 if
accidentally installed with the 3590 below the 4431 XA power adapter.

Channel 9 (Zone 2 Flask Temperature)
This circuit is used to recover the Zone 2 flask temperature from RTD2
A constant current source, implemented using differential amplifier U10, drives the RTD2. The
signal developed across the sensor is amplified by U11. C18, in the feedback loop, filters any
high-frequency noise past the 11 Hz roll-off frequency.
Offset and scale adjustments were avoided in this circuit, and channel 9’s accuracy relies on the
precision of the components used. A formula derived in terms of output voltage is solved for
temperature. A 1000 ohm RTD with an alpfa = 0.00385 is mounted on the power supply chassis;
consequently, the gain of the output amplifier is set to 5 by the ratio of resistors R38 and R37.

Channel 10 (Borehole Temp)
A constant current source, implemented using differential amplifier U10, drives the RTD. The
signal developed across the sensor is amplified by U11. C18, in the feedback loop, filters any
high-frequency noise past the 11 Hz roll-off frequency.
Offset and scale adjustments were avoided in this circuit, and channel 10’s accuracy relies on the
precision of the components used. A formula derived in terms of output voltage is solved for
temperature. A 500 ohm RTD with an alpfa = 0.00385 is in the sensor sub; consequently, the gain
of the output amplifier is set to 5 by the ratio of resistors R41 and R42.

Channel 11 (Unused TA)
This is an unused buffer channel. The circuit is simply a buffer for an AD590 temperature sensor
with a 10k scale resistor. At the time of this manual’s publication, no signal input is connected to
terminal TA.
The other half of U12 is used in the load cell excitation circuit.

Voltage References
Next in line on the card, one inverter attenuator circuit (half of U13) scales down the precision
10 V reference input to generate a -1.35 V reference for channels 9, 10, 12, and 13. the second op-
amp in U13 inverts this reference to obtain the positive complement +1.35 V, though only
channels 12 and 13 require it.
Q1, acting as a current buffer at the output of op-amp U12, supplies the necessary current to
power the force and/or pressure gauges. The driver and sensor lines become connected remotely
inside the sensor sub when it is installed. The closed loop formed around U12 maintains a precise
10 V excitation voltage at the load cell bridge. R43 keeps the loop closed if the load is
disconnected. It has a large value so that it will not interfere with the normal sensing operation.
4.10 Channel 12 (CCL)
Channel 12 focuses on the CCL signal. It is desirable to preserve the shape and polarity of the
waveform when digitizing the CCL pulse. This generally requires higher sampling rates . the
multisampling capabilities of ECLIPS makes it feasible to achieve this result, as the circuit does
not employ any peak detectors.
The level of CCL signal can span a wide dynamic range because of the large magnetic fields
encountered and more than one type of CCL subs that may be adapted for use with the WTS
system.
Normally, the measurement is not intended for cased hole operations with flush joints, but the

The signal received on conductors 16 and 10 of the upper instrument bus is passively filtered by
the input RC stage leading to instrumentation amplifier U14. D1 and D2 protect the device from
peaks exceeding ±12 V. Additional filtering is done by the 2-pole active filter around op-amp U15
for an overall flat response up to about 4 Hz. From there, the signal splits entering a window
comparator and a two-step scale adjustment circuit encompassing the second op-amp in U15 and
analog switch U17. The output of the comparator, CCL GB, is latched on the controller and A/D
board before data conversion and the latched output, Q2, controls the scale. For signals outside
the range of ±80 mV the window comparator selects the node between R58 and R59 as the
feedback path to the inverting amplifier. In this case, the circuit behaves as an attenuator, stepping
down the input voltage by a factor of 2.5 to accommodate signals approaching the ±12 V level.
Signals within the ±80 mV level set the comparator in the opposite logic state, boosting the gain
from 0.4 to 48. The set point references defining the window were chosen low enough to provide
adequate tolerance to any offset at high gain and temperature.
The latched comparator output representing the gain status is transmitted with the data as a CCL
Gain Bit.
D8 and D9 protect the comparator inputs (U16) from over-voltage. R88 prevents D8 and D9 from
clamping the CCL signal at the output of U15 and also limits the input current to the comparator.
4.11 Channel 13 (SP)
Auxiliary measurement of the SP signal, in reference to armor, is performed by this channel using
an instrument electrode or the lower bridle. The low-level SP signal must be amplified to improve
resolution of the received signal. Yet, the inherent offset associated with the SP can quickly
saturate the amplifier. The practice with the surface reference SP has been to add a pot on a panel
to null out the constantly changing SP offset.
Tailored for downhole operation, the auto-offset-ranging feature of the circuit acts on the signal to
bring it within the high resolution range of the A/D (i.e., gain of 16) at all times. The introduced
offset is one of eight defined reference voltages covering the -750 mV to +1,350 mV range.
Armed with the three-bit code (B2, B1, B0) denoting the selectable value, the digitized SP can be
easily reconstructed on the surface to recover the true SP.
In a more detailed description, the noisy SP signal enters the circuit through an RC filter with an
over voltage protection network (bidirectional Zener diodes D3 and D4). Common mode
rejection and buffering is performed by U18, operating at unity gain. The signal is further filtered
by a two-pole, low-pass filter for an overall 6 Hz response.
Unity gain differential amplifier (U25) functioning as a summing node, in combination with a
digital/analog feedback network, provides an offset to the filtered SP signal. This works to keep

The resistor divider network across the reference voltages (±1,350 mV) establish the eight signed
references  in 300 mV increments. Analog mux U21 in concert with counter U22 select one of the
eight offsets. A second voltage divider derives the band limit references +50 mV and +550 mV
for the window comparator (U20). The comparator enables the counter to increment when the
signal exceeds 550 mV or decrement when it falls below 50 mV. The range of the SP signal in
which the feedback control action can function is ±1.3 volts.
Of particular importance is the magnitude of the coarse 300 mV increment, because it represents a
hysteresis large enough for operating with less frequent code switching. This minimizes any
discontinuities or spikes that could be introduced in the process. Hopefully, the circuit searches
initially only for the correct range at the 250 kHz clock rate of the counter and then settles. Note
that if the raw SP signal is close to zero, one of two possible offset codes (100 for 150 mV or 011
for 450 mV) may be generated, depending on whether the counts proceeds up or down on startup.
This is normal.
The control network works on the SP signal after the filtering stage for a faster response.
4.12 Channel 14 (chv)
Channel 14 measures the cablehead voltage for instrument power. A secondary winding on the
main power transformer T1 supplies about a 9 VRMS signal at a normal 180 VRMS input
voltage. U23 is a RMS to DC converter that requires only a few external components for
operation. Unfortunately, the device does not work above 145º C. A flask and heatsink solve the
temperature problem as long as operating time of the instrument is not exceeded. Components
values for DC averaging time constant (C40) and 2-pole post filter (C41, C42, and R78) yield a
1% total DC and ripple error.
The scaling pot P1 should be trimmed to 1.8 Vdc at channel output with 180 VRMS applied at
the cablehead (conductors 1 and 4). Use an AC voltmeter that measures true RMS to measure the
180 VRMS.
4.13 Channel 15 (AC Mtr Volts)
Channel 15 measures the motor voltage at the cablehead. More precisely, it measures between
conductors 10 and the phantom center tap of wireline mode 5. this voltage can be as high as 440
volts, AC or DC. A special transformer, T2, mounted on the backbone, supplies 9 VRMS to this
channel when its primary is powered with the rated 440 VRMS. A capacitor in series with T2
keeps the full DC voltage from being applied across T2.
For instruments requiring AC power between mode 5 center tap and pin 10, as is the case for RCI,
conductor 7 should first be disconnected by setting relay K1 to the AC MOTOR state. This
improves mode 2 and mode 5 communications. Mode 7 is not usable while motoring the RCI.
Channel 15 is similar to channel 14 except that the scaling factor used is 5 mVdc per 1 VRMS
instead of 10 mVdc per 1 VRMS. Therefore pot P2 must be adjusted for 2.2 Vdc at the channel

Circuit Description
3590 XA HTHP WTS Telemetry
131034-945
JULY 2010

MUD RESISTIVITY BOARD
Refer to assembly drawing A3001574000 and schematic A3001574 SCH during the circuit
discussions of the mud resistivity board.
The circuit utilizes an input square wave at 7812.5 Hz for a precision voltage reference. The
square wave is filtered by a two-stage, stagger-tuned band-pass filter (U1 A and U1 B) to generate
a low harmonic content sine wave to drive the constant current amplifier. A voltage of about 1.2 V
p-p is applied to the primary of transformer T1. T1 provides isolation from the current driver U2.
Transformer T1 has a 1:1 turns ratio such that the 1.2 V p-p is applied through the power amplifier
to resistor R12. In the configuration shown in the schematic, the circuit adjusts to maintain this
fixed voltage drop across R12 and in so doing provides a constant current to any load placed from
the junction of T1 and R12 to ground. R26 prevents the circuit from oscillating if E1 is directly
shorted to E4.
In Log mode, a constant current travels from the driver U2 through R26, K1, and out terminal E1.
Terminal E1 is connected to the upper mud sense electrode. Current then travels through the
MUD to the lower MUD Electrode, finally returning to terminal E4.
The voltage drop across the mud column between the upper and lower electrodes (via terminals
E2 and E3) is sensed by instrumentation amplifier U3. The high impedance inputs on the
amplifier prevent loading of the measure current in the fluid. Capacitors C5 and C6 block any DC
voltage generated in the borehole from amplifier U3.
The output from U3 is supplied to phase splitter stage U4 to drive the isolation transformer T2.
T2 has a 1:2 turns ratio. However, signals add up at the center tap input resulting in a voltage gain
of 1. U5 is a double pole FET switch IC that is driven by the input reference signal at 7812.5 Hz.
The alternate opening and closing of the switches provide a full wave, synchronous detection of
the received signal. This voltage is supplied to the A/D converter and is sent uphole as VRM.
Relay K1 switches the drive current from externally driving the borehole to a internal resistor
divider R13/R14. This in conjunction with relays K2 and K3 provide a method to inject a zero or
cal signal into the acquisition stream. Relay control M1 through M5 originates from the A/D

Circuit Description
3590 XA HTHP WTS Telemetry
131034-945
JULY 2010

FILTER/DRIVER BOARD
Refer to assembly drawing F191658000 and schematic F191658100 during the circuit
discussions of the filter/driver board.

Filter
The bottom side of this board is a band-pass filter for the M2 receiver. The first two stages make
up a four-pole, high-pass filter that blocks 60 Hz RCI motor noise. The third stage is a low-pass
filter. The filter circuit is connected in place of R6 A on the repeater board (F191663000). Output
resistor R5 is the first element of a cascaded RC filter on the repeater board.
The filter circuit on the filter/driver board works with the filter and equalization circuits on the
repeater board to form a filter system. This system attenuates undesired frequencies and provides
a flat response for desired signal frequencies, while reducing signal baseline ringing to a
minimum. See the Manufacturing Checkout document (F131034856) included with this manual
for filter/driver board checkout. A tested board may be purchased as F191658500.

Driver
The top half of the filter/driver board outputs the inverted half of the mode 5 line driver signal.

PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE
Refer to assembly drawings A3000658000 and A3000659000, schematic A3000659 SCH, and

Mechanical Inspection
1. Disassemble instrument and remove flask to access electronics.
2. Inspect the assemblies for loose screws on the thermal isolators, transformers, and other
components.
3. Remove and discard O-Rings. Inspect backup rings and replace if damaged.
4. Inspect the peek rings on the heat sink and chassis assembly. Units have Teflon tape under
the peek rings. Replace tape if they have taken a compression set.
5. Verify that thermally conductive foam (P/N 10094401) is installed to transfer heat from the
Filter/Driver Amp U3 to the heat sink. See Figure 1.


6. Inspect the 32-pin bottom connector (J2) for any sockets that are not retained in the correct
position.
7. Inspect the 26-pin winch connector at the downhole end of the flask cable assembly for
damaged pins and skinned or broken wires.
8. Ensure socketed components are firm in sockets and other components or wires are not
broken, pinched, loose, or dirty. Clean boards as necessary.
9. Perform tests as outlined in Manufacturing Test Procedures document F131034856. Record
test results on the Data Sheet at the end of Manufacturing Test Procedures document
F131034856 and place in the tool history folder.

Mechanical Assembly
1. Replace all parts listed in the Level PM3 Parts list (F131034843).
2. Use Loctite #532 each time that you replace a screw in it original position. Use RTV 3145
Adhesive to secure wire bundles and hardware as needed.
3. Reassembly the tool per Manufacturing Assembly Procedure F131034855.
4. Lubricate threads, split collar, and O-Rings with Krytox grease.

GENERAL PROCEDURES
1. Check for FMNs and OTBs related to the 3590 XA tool series.
2. Order parts required for PM3 level preventive maintenance per Level 3 Parts List
F131034843 and Spare Parts List F131034841.
3. Check operation of the instrument per Manufacturing Test Procedure document F131034856.

Note: If any of the measurements are not within the recommended tolerances, refer to component
F131034856 for repair or adjustment.

The 3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle Instrument should rarely need to be completely
disassembled. This procedure disassembles the 3929 XA to the point where troubleshooting,
repair, parts replacement, and PM3 preventive maintenance can be easily done. ONLY
disassemble the 3929 XA to the point necessary to affect the required repair, perform PM3, or
replace defective parts.

3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle – Disassembly / Assembly

DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES3 

DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
Detailed procedures are provided for removal of the cable harness assembly from the knuckle
joints. General procedures are provided for disassembly of the cable harness assembly. The
instrument will rarely need to be completely disassembled under normal operating conditions.
REMOVE CONNECTORS FROM TOP SUB
Refer to drawings A3001242000 and A3001267000 during this procedure unless
specifically instructed otherwise. Numbers in [  ] refer to item numbers on these drawings
and their BOMs.
1.
Thoroughly clean the 3929 XA with water and dry with compressed air. Do not use
a pressure washer, steam, or solvents on the boot [21]. Pressure washers, steam,
and solvents will accelerate aging of the boot.
2.
Place the 3929 XA on a clean flat work surface that allows easy access to the fill
port screws [16] at both ends of the tool. Chock the tool to prevent it from rolling
off the work surface.
3.
Unscrew the fill port screws [16] and drain the Dow Corning DC-200 100 cs oil
(F203208000). Elevating one end of the tool will help the oil drain quicker.
4.
Remove the top thread protector [20] and bottom thread protector [19]. Discard
O-Ring [18] on the top sub [2] and bottom thread protector [19].
5.
Use the lock nut tool (198642-000) to remove the 2.125-12 locking nut [9] from the
top ID of the top sub [2].
6.
Screw a 10-32 T-handle into the center threaded hole in the 27-pin female / male
bulkhead connector [8] and carefully pull the connector out of the top sub.

Note: The 27-pin female connector [25] may come out with the 27-pin female / male bulkhead
connector [8].


7.
If not already out, screw a 10-32 T-handle tool into the center threaded hole in the
27-pin female connector [25] and carefully pull the connector out of the top sub
[2].
8.
Cut the cable ties [26] that secure the cable assembly [10] to the strain relief at the
bottom of the 27-pin female connector [25].
9.
Unscrew and remove the four 4-40 X 3/8-inch standoffs [7, A3001267000] from
the 4-40 X 1.25-inch screws [6, A3001267000] and remove the screws. Discard the
O-Rings. Retain the screws and standoffs.
131108-955 / 3929 XA
SEP 2006
Baker Atlas
4
3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle – Disassembly / Assembly


10.
Unscrew and remove the connector screw [3, A3001267000] and strain relief [4,
A3001267000] from the 27-pin female connector [25]. Rotate the connector back
half [2, A3001267000] clockwise to unlock the connector sockets [5,
A3001267000]and separate the front half [1, A3001267000] from the back half of
the 27-pin female connector. Discard the O-Rings [8 and 9, A3001267000]. Retain
the strain relief, connector screw, and the connector body front half.
11.
Push all connector sockets [5, A3001267000] out of the 27-pin female connector
body back half [2, A3001267000]. Mark wires with their socket number as you
remove them. Retain the connector body back half.
12.
Tape together the female connector sockets [5, A3001267000]at the top end of the
cable assembly [10] if no further disassembly is planned.

Note:
Cut the wires as close as possible to the connector sockets [5, A3001267000]and discard the
connector sockets, if wires or the rubber boot require replacement. Otherwise do not remove
connector sockets. Tape together the free ends of the cable assembly [10] wires after
removing the connector sockets.

REMOVE THE TOP SUB
Refer to drawing A3001242000 during this procedure unless specifically instructed
otherwise. Numbers in [  ] refer to item numbers on this drawing and it's BOM.
1.
Unscrew the two socket head screws from the split collar [7] and separate the two
halves of the split collar. Clean the threads and the ID of the split collar halves. Set
aside the split collar halves and the two screws.
2.
Unscrew the two 10-32 X 0.375-inch screws [14] and remove boot adapter bracket
[13] from one side of the top sub [2]. Repeat for the boot adapter bracket on the
opposite side of the top sub. Retain the two brackets and four screws.
3.
Repeat Step 2 to remove the two boot adapter brackets [13] from the bottom sub
[1]. Retain the screws and brackets.
4.
Use the lock nut tool (198642-000) to remove the 2.125-12 locking nut [9] from the
ID of the bottom sub [1].
5.
Use a 1/8-inch drive punch to drive out the two slotted spring pins [4] at the top
end of the top center knuckle joint [5]. Discard the slotted spring pins.
6.
Use the 1/4-20 T-handle tool to remove the two locking pins [3] and carefully
separate the top sub [2] from the center knuckle joint [5]. Slide the top sub off the
top boot adapter [12] / cable assembly [10]. Be careful not to snag the female pins
on the free end of the cable assembly. Clean the top sub, install new O-Rings [18],
and set aside.
131108-955 / 3929 XA
SEP 2006
Baker Atlas
5
3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle – Disassembly / Assembly

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 4.3 SEPARATE MIDDLE ADAPTER SECTION FROM BOTTOM SUB..........................5 4.4 REMOVE CABLE ASSEMBLY FROM BOTTOM SUB..............................................5
chunk_text:
SEPARATE MIDDLE ADAPTER SECTION FROM BOTTOM SUB5 

SEPARATE MIDDLE ADAPTER SECTION FROM BOTTOM SUB
Refer to drawing A3001242000 during this procedure unless specifically instructed
otherwise. Numbers in [  ] refer to item numbers on this drawing and it's BOM.
1.
Unscrew the two 10-32 X 0.375-inch screws [14] and remove boot adapter bracket
[13] from one side of the bottom sub [1]. Repeat for the boot adapter bracket on the
opposite side of the bottom sub. Retain the two brackets and four screws.
2.
Use a 1/8-inch drive punch to drive out the two slotted spring pins [4] at the bottom
end of the bottom center knuckle joint [5]. Discard the slotted spring pins.
3.
Use the 1/4-20 T-handle tool to remove the two locking pins [3] and carefully slide
the middle adapter section [6] / center knuckle joint [5] off the bottom sub [1] /
cable assembly [10].
4.
Use a 1/8-inch drive punch to drive out the two slotted spring pins [4] at the top
middle knuckle joint [5] and the two slotted spring pins at the bottom middle
knuckle joint. Discard the slotted spring pins.
5.
Use a 1/4-20 T-handle tool to remove the two locking pins [3] at the top middle
knuckle joint [5] and the two locking pins at the bottom middle knuckle joint.
Separate the top and bottom middle knuckle joints from the middle adapter section.
Clean the two middle knuckle joints, middle adapter section, eight locking pins,
and set aside.
REMOVE CABLE ASSEMBLY FROM BOTTOM SUB
Refer to drawings A3001242000 and A3001298000 during this procedure unless
specifically instructed otherwise. Numbers in brackets [  ] refer to item numbers on these
drawings and their BOMs.
1.
Use the lock nut tool (198642-000) to remove the 2.125-12 locking nut [9] from the
ID of the bottom sub [1]. Clean and set aside.
2.
Very carefully pull the rubber boot [21] off the cable assembly [10] about 1.0 inch.
Grip the cable to prevent it from stressing the wires soldered to the bottom male
bulkhead connector [1, A3001298000] and slide the rubber boot off the cable
assembly.
3.
Inspect the rubber boot [21] for severe aging and cracks. If the rubber boot must be
replaced, cut the beryllium copper wire [22] and remove both boot adapters [12].
Discard the rubber boot and beryllium copper wire. Clean the two boot adapters
and set aside. If the rubber boot is in good condition, clean and set aside without
cutting and removing the beryllium copper wire and boot adapters.
4.
Insert the 10-32 T-handle tool into the center threaded hole in the bottom male
bulkhead connector [1, A3001298000] and carefully pull the bulkhead connector
out of the bottom sub [1].
5.
Carefully pull the cable assembly [10] out of the bottom sub [1]. Remove the two
O-Rings [11] from the bottom male bulkhead connector [1, A3001298000] and
discard.
6.
Individual wires in the cable assembly [10] can be replaced at this point.
131108-955 / 3929 XA
SEP 2006
Baker Atlas
6
3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle – Disassembly / Assembly

ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES6 

ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
ASSEMBLE BOOT
Refer to assembly drawing A3001242000 during this assembly procedure unless
otherwise specified. Numbers in brackets [  ] in this section correspond to the item
numbers on the assembly drawing and it's BOM.
1.
Cut the boot [21 A, 21 B or 21 C] to 22 3/16-inches. A clean cut can be made by
inserting a piece of metal tubing into the ID of the boot and cutting the boot with a
tubing cutter.
2.
Install an O-Ring [15] into the O-Ring groove in the OD of each boot adapter [12].
3.
Insert a boot adapter [12] into each end of the boot [21 A, 21 B, or 21 C]. Maintain a
0.05 to 0.08 wide gap between the shoulder of the sleeve and the end of the rubber
boot.

Use LMP solder P/N F261795000 to secure the beryllium copper wire to the
cold rubber boot [21 C] option in the next step. Using solder other than LMP
will damage the cold rubber boot. Use hi-temp solder P/N F266055000 for
the HNBR rubber boot [21 A] or Viton rubber boot [21 B] options.
4.
Secure the boot [21 A, 21 B, or 21 C] to the boot adapters [12] with Beryllium
copper wire [22]. Wrap four turns of wire and maintain sufficient tension while
applying solder [23]. Solder the wire again at 180° on each end.

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 5.2 INSTALL CABLE ASSEMBLY INTO BOTTOM SUB.................................................6
chunk_text:
INSTALL CABLE ASSEMBLY INTO BOTTOM SUB
Refer to assembly drawings A3001242000 and A3001298000, and the wiring diagram on
drawing A3001298000 during assembly of the 3929 XA unless otherwise specified.
Numbers in brackets [  ] in this section correspond to the item numbers on these assembly
drawings and their BOMs.
1.
Lubricate with grease [24 A or 24 B] and install two O-Rings [11] into the O-Ring
grooves on the OD of the 27-pin male bulkhead connector [1, A3001298000].
2.
Tape together the free ends of the cable assembly [10] and insert the free wire end
of the cable assembly up through the bottom sub [1] from the bottom.
131108-955 / 3929 XA
SEP 2006
Baker Atlas
7
3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle – Disassembly / Assembly


3.
Insert the 27-pin male bulkhead connector [1, A3001298000] into the bulkhead
installer tool (199741-000) such that the alignment pin on the 27-pin male
bulkhead connector engages the slot in the bulkhead installer tool as shown in

4.
Insert the 10-32 T-handle tool (078902-000) through the ID of the bulkhead
installer tool and screw it into the center tapped hole in the 27-pin male bulkhead
connector [1, A3001298000] as shown in Figure 1.
5.
While maintaining tension on the T-handle tool, align the slot on the bulkhead
installer tool with the alignment key in the bottom of the bottom sub [1] as shown
in Figure 2. Insert the bulkhead installer tool into the bottom of the bottom sub,
engage the threads in the bottom sub, and thread the installer tool into the bottom
sub by hand as far as possible. Finish installing the 27-pin male bulkhead connector
[1, A3001298000] by tightening the split collar on the bulkhead installer tool with
a spanner wrench. Remove the T-handle tool and bulkhead installer tool.



6.
Apply thread-lock adhesive (F244147000) to the threads of the 2.125-12 X 0.50-
inch locking nut [9]. Use the lock nut tool (198642-000) to install and tighten the
2.125-12 X 0.50-inch locking nut into the bottom of the bottom sub [1].
7.
Feed the free end of the cable assembly [10] up through the assembled boot [21 A,
21 B, or 21 C]. Lubricate the O-Ring [15] on the bottom boot adapter [12] with
grease [24 A or 24 B]. Hold the free end of the cable assembly stationary and push
the bottom boot adapter fully into the bottom sub [1].
131108-955 / 3929 XA
SEP 2006
Baker Atlas
8
3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle – Disassembly / Assembly


8.
Install one boot adapter bracket [13] onto the bottom sub [1] in the position and
orientation shown on the assembly drawing. The beveled edge of the bracket fits
into the gap between the boot [21] and the shoulder of the boot adapter [12].
9.
Apply one drop of thread lock adhesive to the threads of the two 10-32 X 0.375-
inch screws [14] and secure the boot adapter bracket [13] to the bottom sub [1]
with the screws.
10.
Repeat Steps 8 and 9 to install the second boot adapter bracket [13].

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 5.3 ASSEMBLE MIDDLE ADAPTER SECTION ..............................................................8 5.4 INSTALL SPLIT COLLAR AND O-RINGS ONTO TOP SUB.....................................8
chunk_text:
ASSEMBLE MIDDLE ADAPTER SECTION 8 

ASSEMBLE MIDDLE ADAPTER SECTION
Refer to assembly drawing A3001242000 during this assembly procedure unless
otherwise specified. Numbers in brackets [  ] in this section correspond to the item
numbers on the assembly drawing and it's BOM.
1.
Place the middle adapter section [6] on chocks.
2.
Install one center knuckle joint [5] onto one end of the middle adapter section [6]
and insert the two locking pins [3] into the position shown on the drawing. Align
the two locking pins such that they do not obstruct the holes for the slotted spring
pins [4].
3.
Slide the chock under the center knuckle joint [5] and middle adapter section [6]
such that it supports the area where the slotted spring pins [4] will be installed.
4.
Individually drive the slotted spring pin [4] ~0.25-inch into the center knuckle joint
[5] with a hammer. Use a 3/8-inch drive punch and hammer to finish installing the
slotted spring pin. Apply grease [24 A or 24 B] to the slotted spring pin to help
prevent galling and to make installation easier. Repeat for the second slotted spring
pin.
5.
Repeat Steps 1 through 4 to install the second center knuckle joint [5] and slotted
spring pins [4] onto the other end of the middle adapter section [6].
INSTALL SPLIT COLLAR AND O-RINGS ONTO TOP SUB
Refer to assembly drawing A3001242000 during this assembly procedure unless
otherwise specified. Numbers in brackets [  ] in this section correspond to the item
numbers on the assembly drawing and it's BOM.
1.
Remove the screws and separate the split collar [7] halves.
2.
Liberally apply grease [24 A or 24 B] to the IDs of the two split collar [7] halves.
3.
Apply thread-lock adhesive (F244147000) to the two split collar screws. Install the
split collar [7] onto the top sub [2] in the location and orientation shown on the
assembly drawing and secure with the two split-collar screws. Rotate the
assembled split collar in both directions to ensure free movements.
4.
Install two O-Rings [18] into the two O-Ring grooves near the top of the top sub
[2].
131108-955 / 3929 XA
SEP 2006
Baker Atlas
9
3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle – Disassembly / Assembly

ASSEMBLE MAJOR SUBS
Refer to assembly drawing A3001242000 during this assembly procedure unless
otherwise specified. Numbers in brackets [  ] in this section correspond to the item
numbers on the assembly drawing and it's BOM.
1.
Push the free-wire end of the cable assembly [10] up through the middle adapter
section [6] from the bottom. Align the center knuckle joint [5] at the bottom of the
middle adapter section and the bottom sub [1] as shown on the assembly drawing.
Insert the two locking pins [3] and align the two locking pins such that they do not
obstruct the holes for the slotted spring pins [4].
2.
Slide a chock under the center knuckle joint [5] and bottom sub [1] such that it
supports the area where the slotted spring pins [4] will be installed.
3.
Individually drive the slotted spring pin [4] ~0.25-inch into the center knuckle joint
[5] with a hammer. Use a 3/8-inch drive punch and hammer to finish installing the
slotted spring pin. Apply grease [24 A or 24 B] to the slotted spring pin to help
prevent galling and to make installation easier. Repeat for the second slotted spring
pin.
4.
Lubricate the O-Ring [15] on the boot adapter [12] with grease [24 A or 24 B].
5.
Push the free-wire end of the cable assembly [10] up through the top sub [2] from
the bottom. Align the center knuckle joint [5] and the top sub [2] and push the top
boot adapter [12] fully into the top sub. The alignment key on the top sub and the
alignment mark on the bottom sub [1] MUST align. Insert the two locking pins [3]
into the center knuckle joint and align the two locking pins such that they do not
obstruct the holes for the slotted spring pins [4].

Note:
You may need to compress the boot [21 A, 21 B, or 21 C] slightly to align the top sub [2] with
the center knuckle joint [5]. Push the top sub toward the center knuckle joint to compress the
boot.


6.
Slide a chock under the center knuckle joint [5] and top sub [2] such that it
supports the area where the slotted spring pins [4] will be installed.
7.
Individually drive the slotted spring pin [4] ~0.25-inch into the center knuckle joint
[5] with a hammer. Use a 3/8-inch drive punch and hammer to finish installing the
slotted spring pin. Apply grease[24 A or 24 B] to the slotted spring pin to help
prevent galling and to make installation easier. Repeat for the second slotted spring
pin.
8.
Install one boot adapter bracket [13] onto the top sub [2] in the position and
orientation shown on the assembly drawing. The beveled edge of the bracket fits
into the gap between the boot [21 A, 21 B, or 21 C] and the shoulder of the boot
adapter [12].
131108-955 / 3929 XA
SEP 2006
Baker Atlas
10
3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle – Disassembly / Assembly


9.
Apply one drop of thread lock adhesive to the threads of the two 10-32 X 0.375-
inch screws [14] and secure the boot adapter bracket [13] to the top sub [2] with the
screws.
10.
Repeat Steps 8 and 9 to install the second boot adapter bracket [13].

INSTALL TOP CONNECTORS
Refer to assembly drawings A3001242000 and A3001267000 and their BOMs, and the
wiring diagram on drawing A3001298000 during this assembly procedure.
1.
Verify that all O-Rings [8, 9, 10, A3001267000] for the 27-socket female
connector [25] are installed.
2.
Gently pull on the wires at the top of the top sub [2] to remove slack.
3.
Use the crimping tool (F111870000) to crimp the female sockets [5,
A3001267000] to the wires.
4.
Push the female connector sockets [5, A3001267000] up through the back half [2,
A3001267000] (no O-Ring) of the 27-socket female connector [25] per the wiring
socket female connector [1, A3001267000] per the wiring diagram on drawing
A3001298000. Slide the back half of the 27-socket female connector [2,
A300126700] up against the front half. Grease [24 A or 24 B] applied to the holes in
the front connector half or the connector socket O-Rings will make it easier to
insert the connector sockets.
6.
Hold the front half of the 27-socket female connector [1, A3001267000] stationary
and twist the back half of the connector [2, A3001267000] counterclockwise to
lock the female sockets in place.
7.
Apply a drop of thread-lock adhesive (F244147000) to the threads of the connector
screw [3, A3001267000] and secure the two halves of the 27-socket female
connector [25] together with the connector screw and strain relief [4,
A3001267000].
8.
Use cable ties [26] to secure the connector wires to the strain relief [4,
A3001267000]. Do not stress the wires.
9.
Insert the four 4-40 X 1.25-inch screws [6, A3001267000] into the 27-socket
female connector [25].
10.
Apply thread lock adhesive (F244147000) to the exposed threads at the bottom of
each 4-40 X 1.25-inch screw [6, A3001267000].
11.
Screw one female standoff [7, A3001267000] onto each of the four 4-40 X 1.25-
inch screw [6, A3001267000] and tighten.
12.
Install the two O-Rings [11] into the O-Ring grooves in the 27-pin female / male
bulkhead connector [8].

SEP 2006
Baker Atlas
11

13.
Align and plug the male pins of the 27-pin female / male bulkhead connector [8]
into the 27-socket female connector [25].
14.
Make three to four twists in the cable assembly [10], align the alignment pin on the
27-pin female / male bulkhead connector [8] with its matching slot in the ID of the
top sub [2], and carefully push the 27-pin female / male bulkhead connector into
the top end of the top sub [2].
15.
Apply thread lock adhesive (F244147000) to the threads of the 2.125-12 X 0.50-
inch locking nut. Use the lock nut tool (198642-000) to screw in and tighten the
locking nut.

section (131108-956) of this manual.

CONTINUITY / LEAKAGE CHECKS

Flexing of the 3929 XA creates pinch hazards at the knuckle joints. The
knuckle joints can flex enough to pinch or cut fingers. Keeps fingers away
from pinch points.
____  1.
Use the DMM to check for continuity between top and bottom conductors 1
through 27. Flex the 3929 XA to its maximum limits of movement while
performing the continuity check.
____  2.
Use the Megger to check for electrical leakage between connector
pins/sockets and tool body. The minimum electrical leakage must be equal to
or greater than 100 Meg-ohms at 500 Volts. Flex the 3929 XA to its
maximum limits of movement while performing the leakage test.
____  3.
Check for wire-to-wire leakage between the top 27-socket female / male
bulkhead connector [8] sockets; socket 1 to socket 2, etc. All readings should
be >100 Meg-ohms at 500 Volts. Repeat for the bottom 27-pin male
bulkhead connector [1, A3001298000].
131108-956 / 3929 XA
SEP 2006
Baker Atlas
2
3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

____  4.
If problems are found, internal checks of crimp connections, solder
connections, and wire insulation will be necessary. Disassemble as necessary
following instructions in Disassembly / Assembly section 131108-955.

INTRODUCTION
The following are the safety guidelines for handling the 3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle
Instrument.
•
Wear required safety equipment when handling or servicing the knuckle joint.
•
Turn off electrical test equipment before connecting or disconnecting.
•
Do not lift the knuckle instrument by the knuckle joints. The knuckle joints can flex
enough to pinch or cut fingers.
131108-954 / 3929 XA
SEP 2006
Baker Atlas

INTRODUCTION
The 3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle Assembly can be heat tested to rated temperature in
preparation for a high-temperature job. It cannot be heat tested without being under pressure.

WARNING!
The 3929 XA cannot be heat tested without being under pressure. Heat without
pressure will expand the silicon oil, which may cause the rubber boot to burst
and expose service personnel to hot spraying oil.

131108-959 / 3929 XA
SEP 2006
Baker Atlas

SERVICE OVERVIEW
The 3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle Assembly has a make-up length of 36.0 inches and a 3-
3/8-inch diameter. The knuckle joint has through-wires for Focus operation. The double
knuckle design permits toolstring centralization in an 12.25-inch diameter borehole, while
permitting adjacent instruments to be positioned against the borehole wall.

EQUIPMENT SPECIFICATIONS
Refer to document 131108-025 for 3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle Assembly specifications. 

FIELD SAFETY
The following are the safety guidelines for handling the 3929 XA.

PERSONNEL SAFETY
•
Turn off electrical test equipment before connecting or disconnecting.
•
Do not lift the knuckle joint by the flex joints. The joints can flex enough to pinch or
cut fingers.

RIG-UP PROCEDURES
Check the 3929 XA for free mechanical movement.
Knuckle joints are typically installed in the toolstring immediately below the bottom most
decentralized instrument (e.g., density mandrel), and immediately above the electronics
instrument of the top-most centralized tool (e.g., induction instrument). Other than placement
in the toolstring, the 3929 XA has no special rig-up requirements.

INSTRUMENT COMBINATIONS
The 3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle Assembly can be combined with all 3-1/8-inch
instruments with field joints that are mechanically and electrically compatibility.

HOSTILE ENVIRONMENT OPERATING PROCEDURES
The 3929 XA is not designed to operate in an H2 S environment, in wells where temperature
exceeds 347° F (175° C), and/or pressure exceeds 20,000 psi (137.90 Mpa).
131108-977 / 3929 XA
SEP 2006
Baker Atlas
3
3929 XA Focus Double Knuckle – Operating Procedures 

TROUBLESHOOTING

MECHANICAL
•
Check the knuckle joints for free mechanical movement.
•
Visually inspect the rubber boot for signs of deterioration and for oil leaks. 

ELECTRICAL
Electrical troubleshooting of the 3929 XA is limited to checking for electrical continuity
and leakage (Section  8.0). Replace the knuckle joint if it fails either of these tests.

steam, high pressure water, or solvents on the rubber boot [21]. Steam, high

conductors 1 through 27.

connector sockets; socket 1 to socket 2, etc. All readings should be >40-Meg-ohms.
Repeat for the bottom 27-pin male bulkhead connector.
6.
Replace the O-Rings [18] on the top sub [2] and bottom thread protector [19].

Apply grease [24] to the O-Rings [18], split collar [7] threads, and top and bottom
thread protector [20 and 19] threads.
8.
Install the top and bottom thread protectors [20 and 19].

3930 XA Knuckle Joint Assembly – Heat Test Procedures 
Although not recommended, an instrument may be operated in an oven to verify performance in 
anticipation of use in a high-temperature (within tool specifications) environment. Otherwise, no heat 
test for this instrument is necessary. 
 
130868-959 / 3930 XA 
OCT 2003

BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE 
 
3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY 
 
 
131058-935  
MARCH 2006 
 
 
The 3944 XD Swivel Assembly allows different portions of the tool string to rotate independently.            
It allows unrestricted 360° rotation by means of an internal slip-ring assembly. 
 
A swivel isolates an instrument from the normal torque induced as the spiral-wound wireline is lowered 
into and pulled out of the well. This torque causes the tool string to rotate slowly — typically one or    
two rotations per 100 ft. (30 m) of depth for a seasoned line. Typically, this rotation does not cause any 
problems.  
 
However, excessive rotation may degrade some well log data, such as the data from Diplog-type tools.    
In addition, some instruments (notably the Density and Z-Density tools) feature a powerful motorized 
caliper arm that causes the tool to “seek” and hold orientation across the widest axis of the wellbore. 
Other tools have positioners to force this orientation or to hold another specific orientation. This forced 
orientation prevents wireline torque from rotating the string.  
 
The built-up torque can cause the tool to break loose suddenly and spin, resulting in an interval of reduced 
log quality. In severe cases, the built-up torque can actually damage the wireline by causing the armor 
wires to “unlay,” resulting in high strands or “birdcages.” The use of a swivel in these situations allows 
the upper portion of the string to rotate, relieving wireline torque, while the lower portion (below the 
swivel) is able to maintain the preferred orientation. 
 
The 3944 XD Swivel Assembly has a Dresser Atlas (DA) tool joint connection at each end. The swivel 
must therefore be located above the 3510 or 3514 WTS Telemetry instrument. The 3939 XA WTS Swivel 
has WTS connections, and is used below the telemetry instrument.

MECHANICAL DESCRIPTION 
 
3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY 
 
 
 
131058-946 
MARCH 2006 
 
The complete 3944 XD 3-3/8" Swivel Assembly consists of a one-piece 3-3/8" housing with 
accompanying sub and a quick-change connector at each end. The shipping length of the entire             
unit is 4 ft. 11.2 in. (1.25 m), and it cannot be broken down into smaller sections for shipping. 
 
The cavity between the floating piston in the lower housing and the stop ring is filled with silicone         
oil. This equalizes internal and external pressures that act on the Swivel Assembly, thus preventing        
the failure of its housing under downhole conditions. At high temperatures the expanding oil pushes    
down the compensator, thus establishing pressure equilibrium. In high downhole pressures, external 
pressure pushes the piston in, thus increasing internal oil pressure; equilibrium is again achieved. 
 
Refer to the Brief Description of Service (Section -935 in this manual) for additional details.

1

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 15.1 FILLING THE SWIVEL ASSEMBLY WITH SILICONE OIL
chunk_text:
27

1.
Fill the vacuum pump (P/N F078810000) with silicone oil (P/N F203208000).
2.
Hang the swivel assembly upside down in an approximately vertical position.
This will facilitate the oil filling process.
3.
Connect the suction line fitting on the vacuum pump to the top adapter sub port [9].
4.
Connect the oil return line on the vacuum pump to the lower housing port [56].
5.
Close the valve on the oil return line and open the valve on the suction line. Turn
on the vacuum pump to draw a vacuum on the swivel assembly.
6.
When the vacuum reaches 30 inches Hg, close the valve on the suction line.
7.
Turn off the vacuum pump.
8.
Watch the vacuum gauge for about 10 minutes for a quick check of leaks in the
system. If the system leaks, the vacuum will drop.
9.
Open the circulating valve on the vacuum pump to allow oil to flow into the swivel
assembly.
10.
Open the valve on the suction line and turn on the vacuum pump to let oil
circulate. It will take approximately 30 minutes to 11/2 hours before the system
is well vacuumed. Once the system is well vacuumed no air bubbles should be
in the suction line coming from the swivel assembly.
11.
Lay the swivel assembly down and close all valves on the vacuum pump.
12.
Remove the return line hose from the lower housing. Install the plug [12].
13.
Turn on the pump and pressurize the swivel assembly until the floating piston [58]
is fully extended. Relieve the pressure to allow the piston to move approximately 2”.
14.
Remove the hose from the top adapter sub and quickly install the plug.
15.
Hold the depth-setting gauge [62] against the uphole side of the opening in the lower
housing. Loosen the plug [12] to bleed excess oil, until the floating piston [58] is
positioned at 2.50 inches against the end of the gauge. See DWG. P/N 197027-000.

27

1.
Place the swivel assembly in an oven.
2.
Heat the oven to 200°F and keep the oven at this temperature for approximately
30 minutes.
3.
Thoroughly check for oil leaks. If oil leaks do exist, fix the leaks and repeat
the oil-filling procedures described in Section 14.1 above.

28

WARNING
The swivel assembly is filled with silicone oil, which expands with increased
temperatures, such as those that might be encountered during downhole
operations or heat testing. THE RESULTING INCREASE IN OIL PRESSURE
IS POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS. Do not attempt to drain the oil until the swivel
assembly has cooled down.
1.
Place the swivel assembly on tool stands using the upper cable sub and the bottom quick-
change sub to support the swivel assembly.
2.
Using an Allen wrench, remove the two plugs [12] — one each in the top adapter sub and in
the lower housing.
3.
Turn the swivel assembly so that the oil-filling hole in the lower housing is facing the floor.
4.
Lift at the top end of the swivel assembly to help the oil drain.
CAUTION
If the color of the silicone oil is whitish, well fluids (water) have penetrated
the system. If this has happened, completely clean the inside of the swivel
assembly before reassembly.

2
