topic: Assembly/Disassembly - ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 2.0 THE SWIVEL BEARING SUB-ASSEMBLY
chunk_text:
3

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014 2.0 THE SWIVEL BEARING SUB-ASSEMBLY
NOTE: The number in brackets II ] corresponds to the item number on the BOM
for drawing P/N 197027-000.
1.
Lubricate the O-ring groove on the bearing sub [38] and the O-ring [28] with
Lubriplate grease [54], and then install the O-ring on the sub.
2.
Use a cotton-tip stick to apply a layer of Molykote lubricant to the bore of the
bearing sub.

3.
Apply a layer of Molykote lubricant to the outside surface of the bearing [25].

4

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014
4.
Use a press to insert the bearing into the sub until the bearing contacts the bore
shoulder.

5.
Use a press to insert the bearing spacer [26] into the sub until it contacts the bearing.
6.
Lubricate the outer surface of the remaining bearing [25] and press it in place until it
contacts the spacer.

NOTE
Disassembly is in the reverse order of the assembly steps described above.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 3.0 THE SWIVEL SHAFT SUB-ASSEMBLY
chunk_text:
5

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014 3.0 THE SWIVEL SHAFT SUB-ASSEMBLY
1.
Apply Molykote lubricant to both sides of the roller bearing [24] and place the roller
bearing between two thrust washers [16], as shown below.

2.
Lubricate the bottom of the swivel shaft [23] with Molykote and install the bearing and
washers. Apply Molykote to the bottom portion of the shaft above the bearings.
3.
Insert the bearing sub [38] over the swivel shaft, as shown below.

6

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014
4.
Apply Lubriplate to the O-ring groove on the retaining ring [31] and to the O-ring [4].
Then install the O-ring on the retaining ring.
5.
Apply Lubriplate to the bearing sub bore, inner retaining ring bore and to the Viton
component (the black part) of the T-seal [32]. This T-seal is also called the rotary seal.
6.
Install the white T-seal bands in the black Viton component, as shown below.

NOTE: Install the curved side of each band against the Viton component.
7.
Install the retainer ring in the bearing sub and align the mounting holes with the tapped
holes in the bearing sub. Apply Loctite #532 to the attachment screws [27] and secure
the retaining ring on the bearing sub.
8.
Install the T-Seal assembly in the retainer ring by pushing the assembly in as far as
possible by hand.
9.
Remove the upper band and use a curved pick to press in the Viton component and the
bottom band, as shown below.

7

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014
10.
Install the upper band in the Viton component.
11.
Apply Lubriplate to the seal ring [33] and install it over the T-seal assembly,
as shown below.

NOTE
Disassembly is in the reverse order of the assembly steps described above.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 4.0 THE SLIP RING ASSEMBLY INSTALLATION
chunk_text:
1.
Securely place the bearing sub-assembly in a bench vise.

2.
Measure out an 11-inch length of woven tubing [76] and burn-cut it.

8

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014
3.
Wrap Kapton tape around the ends of the slip ring wire bundle. Then insert
the bundle into the woven tubing.
4.
Push the woven tube up against the slip ring assembly base and tie the bundle
with lacing.
5.
Apply Loctite #532 to the slip ring assembly attachment screws [21].
6.
Insert the wire bundle through the bearing assembly and secure the slip ring
assembly using the screws and lock washers [22], as shown below.

7.
Wrap the ends of the brush wire bundle with Kapton tape. Align the key slot in the fluid
displacer with the keyway in the brush. Then slide the fluid displacer [15] over the
bundle, as shown below.

9

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY


8.
Secure the displacer key [75] with two screws [74], as shown below.

9.
Burn-cut a 10-inch length of woven tubing [76] and fold it inside itself, so it is
double thickness.
10.
Slide the woven tubing over the brush wire bundle and up against the slip ring cap.
11.
Secure the brush wire bundle by tying lacing near the fluid displacer.
NOTE
Disassembly is in the reverse order of the assembly steps described above.

1.
Apply Lubriplate to the O-ring grooves on the top adapter sub [9] and to the O-rings.
2.
Loop a length of lacing cord through the O-rings: first install [7] and then install [28].

10

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014
NOTE
Install each O-ring by tugging downward on the lacing cord. Then make
a circular motion around the top adapter sub, to drag each O-ring into
the appropriate groove.
3.
Place the brush holder pin [18] onto the top adapter sub, so that the tab extension
points upwards.
4.
Apply Loctite #532 to the attachment screws [17] for the brush holder pin. Secure
the pin on the top adapter sub.

1.
Apply Lubriplate to the threads of the pressure housing [19] and install over the
displacer [15] as shown below.

2.
Tighten the pressure housing securely using a strap-wrench. Secure the brush wire bundle
extending from the pressure housing with lacing.
3.
Apply Lubriplate to the threads on the top adapter sub [9] and in the pressure housing.
4.
Slide the tab of the brush holder pin into the key slot of the fluid displacer. Thread the top
adapter into the pressure housing and tighten with a spanner wrench. (The fluid displacer
spins as the top adapter sub turns.)

NOTE
Disassembly is in the reverse order of the assembly steps described above.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 7.0 THE TOP CONNECTOR BOOT ASSEMBLY

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY

131058-955
January 2014 7.0 THE TOP CONNECTOR BOOT ASSEMBLY
1.
Measure a 4-inch length of wire extension beyond the top adapter sub and cut
all wires.

2.

3.
Feed each brush wire through a connector boot.
4.

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY

131058-955
January 2014
6.

the boot over it (see below).

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 8.0 THE BULKHEAD SUB-ASSEMBLIES
chunk_text:
13

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014 8.0 THE BULKHEAD SUB-ASSEMBLIES
1.
Crimp a terminal sleeve [8] to all twenty feed-through terminals [13].
NOTE
The procedure for connecting wires to the two bulkheads is identical. Unless
noted otherwise, use the images in this section for wiring both bulkheads. To
avoid confusion, stamp the number 5 on the top bulkhead.

[44], as shown below.

[45] then cut.
4.

5.
Unwind the wire bundles and strip about 1/4 inch of insulation from the wires.

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955

Solder the cable wires to the terminal sleeves [8] using the wiring color code
Slide the heat-shrink tubing over the soldered connections and shrink in place.
NOTE: On the lower housing bulkhead [44], use a pick to push the tubing
into the terminal well before shrinking.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 9.0 THE TOP ADAPTER BULKHEAD
chunk_text:
15

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014 9.0 THE TOP ADAPTER BULKHEAD
1.
Apply Lubriplate [54] to the pressure terminals [13]) on the bulkhead [10].
2.
Pinch and push the connector boots over the terminals, as shown below.

NOTE: Remove any air within the boots by “milking” the boots toward
the bulkhead and pushing them over the terminals.

Secure the wire bundle with lacing a short distance from the connectors.
4.
Apply the Lubriplate grease to the O-ring on the bulkhead [10].

Apply the Lubriplate grease to the O-ring grooves in the upper cable sub [6].
7.
Install the O-rings [7] in the upper cable sub.
8.
Screw the end of the cable assembly [5] into the connector fitting on the female
connector assembly [2].

the upper cable sub into the top adapter and tighten with a large hex wrench.

16

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014

Coil the upper cable assembly into the upper cable sub and install the connector in
the sub, rotating the connector so the alignment ridge rests in the internal groove.

12.
Secure the connector assembly with retainer clip [1].

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 10.0 THE LOWER SWIVEL ASSEMBLY

1.
Apply Lubriplate to the groove on the inside of the upper section sub [34].
Then install the O-ring [36] into that groove, as shown below.

2.
Apply Lubriplate to the O-ring groove and the copper-coated threads on the outside
of the upper section sub. Then install the O-ring [28] into that groove.
3.
Apply Lubriplate to the contact surface, insert the cable wires through the upper
section sub and slide the sub over the swivel shaft [23].
4.
Place the dowel pin [35] into the small recessed area on the side of the swivel
shaft, as shown below.

5.
Apply Lubriplate to the swivel shaft area near the dowel pin.

18

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
M January 2014
6.
Insert the cable wires through the upper section sub, with the six-grooved surface
first. Then slide the sub all the way over the swivel shaft up to the retaining ring.
Ensure the small indentation in the upper section sub is aligned over the dowel pin.
7.
Apply Lubriplate to the O-ring groove on the outside of the swivel nut [39]. Install
the O-ring [77] onto the swivel nut.
8.
Apply Lubriplate to the outer threads of the swivel shaft and to the inner threads
of the swivel nut.
9.
Insert the wires into the swivel nut and install the nut onto the swivel shaft, as
shown below.

10.
Securely hold the swivel assembly in a vise and with a spanner wrench. Tighten
the swivel nut by turning it with an adjustable wrench, as shown below.

19

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014

11.
Tie off the wire bundle by using lacing around the woven tubing about
halfway between the end of the swivel nut and the end of the tubing.
12.
Install the retaining ring [68] onto the end of the swivel nut and snap it into place with a
pair of Truarc pliers, as shown below. Ensure the flat side of the retaining ring is facing the
swivel nut.

13.
Measure the wire bundle 8-inch length from the end of the swivel nut, as shown
below and mark the wires at this point.

14.
Cut a piece of expanded tubing to a length that covers this 8" measurement, and
also allows for a double-layer area to attach to the existing tubing.
NOTE
Disassembly is in the reverse order of the assembly steps described above.

1.
Apply Lubriplate to the inner surface of the floating piston [58].
2.
Apply Lubriplate to the inner T-ring seal [61] and install it in the piston.
3.
Install the Type T “Slydring” piston seal [72] in the wide recessed area
inside the floating piston.
4.
Apply Lubriplate to the outer grooves, then, install the Type W "Slydring"
piston seal [71] and the outer T-ring [60].
5.
Apply Lubriplate to the O-ring groove on the piston support [57] and install
the O-ring [37].

20

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014

6. Place the piston [58] on the piston support [57], then place the stop ring [67]
on the piston, as shown below.

7.
Apply a Lubriplate to the outer threads on the sub and to the inner threads
at both ends of the lower housing [56].


NOTE
Disassembly is in the reverse order of the assembly steps described above.

21

3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY
CONFIDENTIAL
131058-955
January 2014

8. Slide the lower housing [56] over the piston assembly.
9. With the small hole for the test adaptor closest to the swivel nut, insert the wire bundle through the stop
ring [67], then the piston assembly as shown below.

10. Maintain tension on the end of the wire bundle as you thread the housing to the sub to avoid pinched
wires. Continue maintaining tension as the housing is tightened with a wrench.

wire with Lap-tie loop.

• 5722 X* WEETECH Continuity/Leakage Tester; if not available use Digital Multimeter

3944 XD PM Level 1 Checklist 
Doc. No.: 131058-951 
 
 
 
1. Mechanical Checks: 
    Can also be performed at the wellsite 
 
Step 
Action 
Initials 
1. 
Visually inspect threads and exterior surface for signs of damage and/or wear. 
______ 
2. 
Verify instrument model and equipment/serial numbers are legible. 
______ 
3. 
Check top and bottom connectors for moisture, debris, misaligned, broken or worn 
pins, worn or damaged sockets and deformed retaining rings. Ensure top and 
bottom connector retaining rings are in place. Clean the top connector and bottom 
connector with contact cleaner. 
______ 
4. 
Check the integrity of socket number 10 on the uphole connector with a worn 
Banana pin (F510740000) to test the worst case condition. 
______ 
5. 
Check integrity of bottom connector banana pins using Banana pin gauge 
(F090632000).  Gently turn Banana pin gauge clockwise to ensure banana pins are 
tight. 
______ 
6. 
Ensure the swivel rotates freely when turning by hand. 
 
______ 
7. 
Remove used O-rings from uphole end of tool with brass O-ring extractor tool. Cut 
and discard used O-rings. Clean O-ring grooves with solvent. Inspect 0-ring 
grooves for dust, dirt, scratches; pitting, or corrosion. They shall not have any 
damage or condition which can cause seal failure. Apply Lubriplate 930 AA in O-ring 
grooves. 
______ 
8. 
Inspect new O-rings for defects and then apply a light coating of Lubriplate 930 AA 
around O-rings then install O-rings on top sub. 
______ 
9. 
Ensure that all subs are torqued to prevent accidental “backing off”. 
______ 
 
 
Page 3 of 5 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
 
Effective Date: 4-Feb-2015 
3944 XD PM Level 1 Checklist 
Doc. No.: 131058-951 
 
 
 
2.  Hydraulic Checks: 
 
Step 
Action 
Initials 
1. 
Ensure that silicone oil is not leaking; especially, thoroughly check the piston area. 
______ 
2. 
Insert and hold the Piston Depth Gauge against the uphole side of one of the 
openings in the lower housing. You should feel the piston when the gauge is 
against the piston at approximately 2.5 inches.  If the piston is beyond this point 
(more than 2.5 inches) so that you cannot feel the piston, then the tool oil will need 
to be circulated to remove the gas. 
 
______ 
3. 
Remove the screw (10-32 X .25 sst soc hd set, F230245000) from the center sub. 
Screw the 10-32 grease fitting into the hole in the center sub.  Use a grease gun to 
fill with Lubriplate grease until the grease oozes out from the gap. 
 
 
______ 
4. 
Remove the grease fitting and install the 10-32 X .25 socket head set screw. 
______ 
5. 
Ensure the swivel rotates freely when turning by hand. 
______ 
 
 
 
Page 4 of 5 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
 
Effective Date: 4-Feb-2015 
3944 XD PM Level 1 Checklist 
Doc. No.: 131058-951

Step 
Action 
Initials

Top connector to Bottom connector. Continuity is less than 1 Ω  for conductors 1 
through 10 (i.e. 1 to 1; 2 to 2; 3 to 3 and etc.) while rotating tool a few turns. 
______ 
2.

______

1 to 3; 1 to 4; etc; 2 to 3; 2 to 4; etc; 3 to 4 and etc.) at 1000 volts must be greater 
than 30 MΩ.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 1.0 REQUIRED AND OPTIONAL TEST EQUIPMENT
chunk_text:
1


3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY


131058-953
MARCH 2006 
REQUIRED AND OPTIONAL TEST EQUIPMENT
•
Volt-ohm-milliammeter (Simpson 260 or better)
•
Insulation tester (Megger)
•
Resistance decade box (range: 1 K – 10 Megohm)
•
AC power supply panel (Dresser 2061)
•
Depth setting gauge (P/N 197041000)
•
5722 XB Continuity/Leakage Tester (optional)


NOTE: These procedures must be done at four-month intervals.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 2.0 INSPECTING THE SWIVEL
chunk_text:
INSPECTING THE SWIVEL
Wash off the exterior of the swivel assembly with fresh water to remove mud, salt water, and other
debris. Make sure no silicone oil is leaking from the piston area.

Completely disassemble the swivel assembly down to, but not including, the slip ring assembly:
follow the disassembly instructions in Section -955 of this manual. Inspect all the parts to
determine if any corrosion or damage exists.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 3.0 REMOVE MOISTURE 4.0 REPLACE DAMAGED PARTS
chunk_text:
REMOVE MOISTURE
Remove moisture from all parts by spraying them with a degreaser. 
REPLACE DAMAGED PARTS
•
If corrosion, damage or oil is evident, replace the parts affected.
•
Make sure that all bearings can be hand-turned and move freely.
•
Check all O-ring sealing surfaces; if necessary, replace any worn-out O-rings. If the small
O-rings on the 20 feed-through terminals (installed in both bulkheads) are worn out, use the
O-ring installation tool (P/N 188385-000) to help reinstall the new O-rings.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 5.0 LUBRICATE PARTS 6.0 REFILL THE SWIVEL ASSEMBLY WITH OIL
chunk_text:
LUBRICATE PARTS
As you reassemble each part, refer to the applicable lubrication instructions listed in Section -955
of this manual. 
REFILL THE SWIVEL ASSEMBLY WITH OIL
Follow the procedures described in Section -955 of this manual for reassembling the swivel
assembly. Then refill the swivel assembly with silicone oil (P/N 203208-000).

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 7.0 TESTING CONTINUITY AND LEAKAGE
chunk_text:
2


3944 XD 3-3/8" SWIVEL ASSEMBLY


131058-953
MARCH 2006 

Test Procedure Using the Required Test Equipment
1. Set the Simpson on R×1. Check for continuity (0.5 ohm) between the top and bottom 10-pin
connectors on conductors 1 through 10.
2. Turn the swivel assembly slowly as each conductor is checked. There should not be any
intermittence.
3. Set the Megger on the 500 V scale. Check that there is no leakage to mass on conductors
1 through 10. (The minimum electrical leakage acceptable is 30 Megohms.)
4. With the Megger set at 500 V, check that there is no leakage between the 10 conductors. (The
minimum electrical leakage acceptable is 30 Megohms.)
5. Insert and hold the depth-setting gauge against the uphole side of the opening in the lower
housing. Make sure the floating piston is positioned at 2.50 inches (6.3 cm), against the end
of the gauge. See drawing P/N 197027-000 for more details.

Test Procedure Using the Optional 5722 XB Continuity/Leakage Tester
1. Complete the setup of the tester interface cables and box per drawing P/N 186002000.
2. Run the test program for the 3944 XC swivel assembly, filename 3944xb-185985d.
3. Select Test and press the SPACEBAR or the ENTER key to run the test program.
4. Follow the instructions displayed by the program. The program must PASS.

INTRODUCTION
Level 3 maintenance should be performed on the 3950 XA Swivel assembly every four
months to ensure the integrity of the rubber boot. The plasticizer will leach out over time
causing the rubber boot to become brittle. Frequent inspection of the rubber boot during the
four-month period is also recommended.

topic: Field Reference Drawings and BOM - F164329975 INDEX 3950XA SWIVEL FOCUS

chunk_text:
SERVICE OVERVIEW

The series 3980 XA TTMA is a 3-1/8” O.D. self-contained Matrix compatible instrument
containing transducers for measurement of cablehead Tension/compression borehole
Temperature, Mud resistivity and 3-axis Acceleration as explained below.  The acquired
information is sent via the Telemetry instrument to the surface.

The instrument operates with its own unique address for running in a Matrix tool string.
Communications with the instrument is via the Matrix telemetry protocol. Matrix
communication is patterned after the WTS protocol and this instrument operates on
Mode 2 for commands and data, but also has provision for transmitting data via Mode 5
and Mode 7.  Matrix surface equipment includes a DC power supply, Line Control panel,
Real-time Acquisition panel, a PC (personal computer) with data storage facilities, and
necessary software for running the service.

Tension:
A load cell, located near the top of the TTMA and O-ring sealed from the borehole
environment, is used to measure longitudinal stresses.  The load cell is geometrically
compensated for borehole pressure changes and does NOT require balancing using the
traditional silicon oil and rubber boot.  Its measurement range is from –12,000 lbs
(compression) to +12,000 lbs (tension).

Temperature:
The temperature sensor is a Platinum element RTD probe protruding from a side pocket
machined into the TTMA body.  Its measurement range is 0º to 150º C.

Mud Resistivity:
A recessed, 2-electrode, cylindrical array is used to collect Mud Resistivity information.
The geometry of the design provides a measurement with an extremely shallow depth of
investigation.  That parameters measured are the voltage across, and the current
between, the two electrodes.  The Mud Resistivity measurement range is 0.02 to 3 ohm-
m.

Accelerometers:
Three accelerometers mounted orthogonally measure acceleration in the X, Y and Z axis
of the tool body.  These measurements provide the raw data to compute borehole
inclination, tool face (high side), and a depth correction for “stick and pull.”  The
measurement range is +3 to –3 g.

Note: The 3980 is typically run above the Telemetry to get the best results from
the cablehead tension measurement.  However, it can be run anywhere in the
string should it be required.
130870-936 / 3980 XA
OCT 2003
Baker Atlas

1.5.1 CLOCK GENERATION

U5 divides the 24 MHz clock signal (CLKIN) by 2 when JMP2 is installed
on CLKSEL (U5-91).
U5 then divides the 12 MHz clock signal by 3, 12, 24, 48 and 64 to
provide: (1) a 500 KHz clock for Mode 2 transmitter logic (U5 internal), (2)
a 250 KHz clock signal for the Mode 2 receiver logic (U5 internal).

Mode 2 Receive Command / Data: Mode 2 commands / data are sent
from the surface and transformer-coupled via T2 on the CPU board.  U2
converts line signals to TTL levels.  The equivalent of a 6408 Harris
Manchester Encoder / Decoder has been incorporated into Actel (U5).
U5 decodes this Manchester protocol data (MD2 UDI) and converts the
serial data to parallel data.  U5 checks the received data for a universal
address 00 or TTMA tool address.  If either address is received, interrupt
M2 RXIRQ (INT1) is sent to the CPU (U8) and the command is transferred
to a buffer.  M2 RXIRQ is reset by the CPU after the command is read by
130870-945 / 3980 XA
OCT 2003
Baker Atlas
4

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description
the CPU.  If data follows the WTS command, interrupt M2 RXIRQ (INT1)
is sent to the CPU (U8) and the data is transferred to a buffer.  M2 RXIRQ
is reset by the CPU after each data word is read.

Mode 2 Transmit Data: On receipt of a command from the surface to
transmit data via Mode 2 (such as tool tables or tool status), the CPU
enables interrupt INT2 (M2 TXIRQ) and sends the requested data via the
16 bit data bus to U5, Mode 2 encoder logic.  U5 converts the data from
parallel to serial format and the U5 6408 Harris Manchester equivalent
encoder, encodes MD2 BZO data and MD2 BOO data.  Data is then sent
to line driver (U1).  Data is then transformer coupled to the WTS buss via
T1.  Whenever the U5 data buffer is empty, U5 generates an interrupt
(M2 TXIRQ); and the CPU sends the next word.

Mode 5 / Mode 7 DMA Control: The equivalent of a 6409 Harris
Manchester has been incorporated into Actel (U5) for Mode 5/7 data
transmission.  Mode 5/7 data is transmitted using DMA channel 0
(DRQ0).  SMD5 DRQ (see
) selects which mode will be used
for the transmitter Mode 5 or Mode 7.
surface to transmit Mode 5/7 data the CPU enables DMA channel 0 and
writes the requested data via the 16 bit data bus to U5, Mode 5/7 encoder
logic.  The data is converted from parallel to serial format by U5.  Serial
data is received by the U5, a 6409 Harris Manchester equivalent encoder
and the encoded data (BZO5 and BOO5) is sent to line driver U3 or
BZO7 and BOO7 is sent to line driver U4.  Mode 5/Mode 7 data is then
transformer coupled to the WTS buss via T3 and T4 respectively.
Whenever the data buffer is empty, MD57 DRQ is active; and the CPU
writes the next data word via the 16 bit data bus to U5.

Transmission of data is currently used only when sending Subset E.

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description
1.5.3 SYNCHRONOUS SERIAL TRANSMIT / RECEIVE LOGIC
The clock speed is set by firmware and currently 1 MHz is used
throughout.  Each of these serial links has a transmit-frame sink
(bgateout/TFS_x) for beginning and ending a transmission, and a data
transmit (bdataout/DT_x) line for transmission of data (i.e. tables,
commands, etc.).  Each of these serial links also has a receive-frame sink
(bgatein/RFS_x) and a data receive (bdatain/DR_x) line for receiving
data.

The CPU writes commands and data to U5’s two 8 bit latch’s via the data
bus.  Data is converted to the serial format using the 1 MHz SCLK and two
8 bit shift registers.  Bgateout\ is active low, and bdataout is the serial
data signal.  Data is shifted out on the positive edge of BSCLK.
STXDRQ (DRQ3) becomes active whenever the output latch is empty.



Baker Atlas
7

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description
Refer to Figure 945-3 for the transmission description.
1.  DMA is initialized and 1st data word is loaded into the latch and shift
register.
2.  On the next positive-going edge of the serial clock (SCLK), the
transmit frame sync (TFS_X) goes low.
3.  On the next negative-going edge of the SCLK, shift / load goes high
and data word number 1 bit 16 is shifted out.  Shifting continues on
each SCLK positive going edge thereafter.
4.  DMA request for data word number 2.
5.  Data word number 2 is loaded into the latch.
6.  On the positive going edge of the SCLK (Bit #1), the shift register is
loaded with data word number 2.
7.  On the next positive going edge of the SCLK, data word number 2 bit
16 is shifted out.  Shifting continues on each SCLK positive going
edge.
8.  DMA request for data word number 3.
9.  Data word number 3 is loaded into the latch.
10.  On the positive going edge of the SCLK (Bit #1), the shift register is
loaded with data word number 3.
11.  On the next positive going edge of the SCLK, data word number 3 bit
16 is shifted out.  Shifting continues on each SCLK positive going
edge.
12.  End of data transmission.
130870-945 / 3980 XA
OCT 2003
Baker Atlas
8

(high).  The Actel (U5) inverts the data before it is shifted into the shift
registers.  A 16 bit counter and flip flop are used to latch the data into two
8-bit latches.  The flip-flop is also used to indicate to the CPU that data
has been received (S1 RXDRQ).  The flip-flop is reset when the CPU
reads the data.  The S1 RXDRQ signal is connected to the CPU DRQ1

1.  DMA is initialized and receive frame sync (RFS_x) goes high on the
next positive serial clock (SCLK).
2.  Data is shifted into shift registers on each positive going edge of the
SCLK.
3.  After the 16th SCLK positive going edge, data word number 1 is
latched and a DMA request (SxRXDRQ) is initiated.
4.  Data word number 1 is read from the latch by the CPU and stored into
memory.
5.  After the 32nd SCLK positive going edge, data word number 2 is
latched and a DMA request (SxRXDRQ) is initiated. RFS_x goes low
ending the transmission.
6.  Data word number 2 is read from the latch by the CPU and stored in
memory.

OCT 2003
Baker Atlas

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description
1.5.4 LATCHED ADDRESS BUS

Two eight bit latches and three single bit latches, latch address MA0 to
MA18 when ALE signal is high.
1.5.5 CONTROL OF ANALOG POWER SUPPLIES

When operating in battery mode, control over the power supplies
becomes essential to prolonging battery life.  Control signals emanating
from the FPGA (U5) cntrl2 and cntrl3 control the ON/OFF time of the
±12 V and ±5 V power supplies respectively.  Normally both of these bits
are 0 to keep theses supplies turned ON.  Bits change to a 1 when it is
necessary to turn them OFF.
Control signal cntrl2 ties to the base of transistor Q2.  Since it is normally
low, it does nothing to the transistor and the collector is allowed to float at
the level of the opto-isolator voltage that controls the INHIBIT pin1 of the
power supply.  When it is necessary to turn OFF the supply, the control
signal goes high, turning the transistor ON and driving the INHIBIT pin
low.
In similar fashion, control signal cntrl3 controls transistor Q3.

1.5.7 READ/WRITE SERIAL EEPROM

Serial read and write functions to the EEPROM (U13) are controlled by
microcontroller U8.
•
I/O port 2 – bit 7 (pin 23) is serial data in from the EEPROM.
•
I/O port 3 – bit 0 (pin 24) is serial data out to the EEPROM.
•
I/O port 3 – bit 2 (pin 26) is a clock signal that shifts data to the
EEPROM.
All three of these bits are controlled by software.

SENSOR BOARD10
APPENDIX A: DC POWER SUPPLIES 14

SENSOR BOARD 
CONTROLLER BOARD

INTRODUCTION

The TTMA operates as a demand-response system and the Controller (or CPU)
board is the heart of this system.  For each data request a single data word
answer, tool table, or data block is sent.  The WTS Manchester encoder-decoder
protocol for M2/M5 or M7 communications is used.

WTS command signals and DC power are connected to the CPU board by
connector P1.  All other cards are connected to P2.

130870-945 / 3980 XA
OCT 2003
Baker Atlas
2

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description
The CPU board has these functions:
1. Power up / down reset signal for the CPU.
2. Clock, 24 MHz oscillator.
3. Interface to CPU, Mode 2, Mode 5 and Mode 7.
4. Memory, data memory of 256 Kbyte’s RAM and program memory of 256
Kbyte’s sector erase flash memory.
5. One Actel field programmable gate array is used for the "glue logic"
functions.
6. Read/Write serial EEPROM of Accelerometer
7. Control ON/OFF Time of ±12 V and ±5 V analog power supplies.

topic: Circuit Description - 1.2 POWER UP / DOWN RESET LOGIC
chunk_text:
POWER UP / DOWN RESET LOGIC

POWER UP RESET: The RESETIN\ signal from U7-7 will be inactive until the
+5 V signal is above 4.4 V.
POWER DOWN RESET: The RESETIN\ signal from U7-7 will become active
when the +5 V signal is  < 4.36 V.

CLOCK

U6 is a 24 MHz oscillator and provides a clock signal to U8-10 and U5-22
(CLKIN).  The CPU internally uses a divide-by-2 clock function to produce a 12
MHz CPU clock.  The CPU uses this clock signal to drive internal timers.

MEMORY

Program Memory
U9 (Low byte) and U10 (High byte) together form a program memory consisting
of 256 K bytes of Sector Erase Flash Memory.  The EPROM is addressed at
F0000 to FFFFF.  UCS selects EPROM addresses.
Data Memory
U11 (low byte) and U12 (high byte) together form a data memory of 256 K words
of RAM.  The RAM is addressed at 00000 to 7 FFFF.  LCS selects RAM
addresses.

INTRODUCTION
This board is designed to interface with the following sensors.
1. Accelerometer to measure X, Y and Z Acceleration
2. Strain Gauge to measure Tension and Compression
3. Platinum RTD to measure Mud temperature
4. Temperature Sensor to measure Accelerometer Temperature
130870-945 / 3980 XA
OCT 2003
Baker Atlas
11

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description
5. Current and Voltage sensing across two conductive rings to measure the MUD
Resistivity.
The circuit of the board divided in two parts.  Sensors 1, 2, 3 and 4 are found on
page 1 of the schematic of 199666-100.  Sensor 5 is found on page 2 of the
Accelerometer:
Accelerometer outputs are X+, X-, Y+, Y-, Z+, Z- and are differential in nature.
These signals are inputs for the circuitry and are filtered at cut off frequency
0.2 Hz (U5, U6, U7 and U8).  Also, the Z input is filtered at 8 HZ which is called
FZ (Fast Z).  X, Y, Z and FZ are converted into digital signals every 40 ms by
U13 (a Multiplexed 16 Bit A/D).  Maximum amplitude of the input is an expected
+/- 5 V signal, but the actual A/D input range is +/- 10 V.
ATEMP is the voltage output of the accelerometer’s temperature sensor (AD592
in the accelerometer module).  The signal is buffered by U14 and filtered by R35
and C148 before entering U15, a 12 bit A/D.  It is sampled every 40 milliseconds.

Mud Temperature:
A constant current of 400 microamperes, from U11, is generated and flows
through R10, the RTD sensor and R69 (1 K).  This constant current across R10
(5.1 K) provides a voltage reference of +2.04 Vdc for the A/D converter. Voltage
across the Platinum RTD sensor (Temp+ and Temp– inputs) is converted to 24
bits (channel 1 of U11) every 100 milliseconds.  In CAL mode, it reads a 40 mV
signal across resistor R69 on channel 2 of U11.

Tension:
+5 VT and -5 VT provides a constant voltage across the bridge circuit of the strain
gauge.  Strain Gauge output signals, T+ and T–, are filtered using capacitors
C162, C163 and C164 and interfaced using Instrument Amplifier U1.  R1 makes
gain of 100 for U1.  R91 and C143 is also a filter before the A/D.  This signal is
converted to 24 bits (channel 1 of U12) every 100 milliseconds.  In CAL mode,
the input switched to channel 2 and reads a 2 volt signal across R93.

FPGA:
FPGA, U17 has the following logic functions.
1. Synchronous Communication: Convert Data Serial to Parallel (datain/,
gatein, sclk/) and Parallel to Serial output of data (dataout, gateout/).
2. Interpretation of the Commands:
Software reset
Write Control words to Mud Temperature A/D (U11)
130870-945 / 3980 XA
OCT 2003
Baker Atlas
12

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description
Write Control words to Tension A/ D (U12)
Send Data (to the controller)
Send Atime (latches Atime when acquire command is received by the
CPU)
Software Sync to Sigma Delta A/Ds (U11, U12)
3. Read Mud Temperature 24 bit A/D data whenever DRDY0/ is active (low
level).  It shifts serial data (rsdata0) to Parallel register and transfers it to a 24 bit
latch.
4. Read Tension 24 bit A/D data whenever DRDY1/ is active (low level).  It shifts
serial data to parallel and then transfers it to a 24 bit latch.
5. Generate signals (tfs0/, tfs1/, AD0, AD1) to write data into A/D
6. To read Accelerometer Temperature data by shifting serial data to 16 bit
Parallel (atcs, atsdata, atsclk).  Actual A/D data output is 12 bit.
7. To generate a 1 ms timer signal from 5 MHz clock.  Use 1 ms tick to increment
Atimer of 32 bits.  At every 40 ms, it reads X, Y, Z and FZ sequentially from U13
and Atemp from U15.  Also, it transfers Mud temperature and Tension data from
the input buffer to the transmit buffer.  Generate ZRDY interrupt to the CPU.
Whenever the send command is received, it sends data to the controller.
8. To select the channel to read X, Y, Z or FZ (ch0, ch1, wr1/, wr2/).  To send
r_c/ pulse to sample the data, and read-and-convert serial to parallel when busy
is not active.
9. Whenever U17 receives DRDY0/ and DRDY1/ from U11 and U12, it reads and
stores data in 24 bit buffers.
10. It also drives LED DS1 to indicate the proper function of the logic.

Resistivity:
The Mud Resistance measurement circuitry is divided into the following sections.
1. To generate a 7.8125 KHz sine wave signal
2. To measure the current and voltage across the two electrodes
3. To control relay for LOG/ZERO/CAL operation
4. To interface with the controller
5. To select gain for the voltage measurement
This section of the circuit is isolated from the rest of the electronics using opto
isolator for the communication and floating power supply using separate +/-5 V
Power supply.
U36, U37 and U41 are making the isolation between mud driver ground and
Controller ground.

130870-945 / 3980 XA
OCT 2003
Baker Atlas
13

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description
Controller:
2181 DSP processor (U34) runs at 32 MHz with a clock input of 16 MHz (U32).
On power up, U33 generates PRESET signal low for 200 ms and then the DSP
loads its operating program from the Flash memory (U42).  JMP4 decides which
program is to be loaded into the DSP.  Without JMP4, it loads the Application
Program. With JMP4 installed, a boot program is loaded.  The boot program
allows updating of the Application Program contained in the lower 64 Kbytes of
U42.
On power up, the DSP configures U31 for a 7.8125 KHz frequency.  Clkin to U31
is 4 MHz.  The output seen at terminal E12 is 2 Vp-p.  U22 and U23 are used as
filter and buffer.  Output from U23 is an input of U31 to generate a ZREF signal.
This signal is used in U30 to synchronize sampling of the data.  U21 is the driver
power operational amplifier (opamp) to drive the constant voltage signal.  R27 is
the current limiting resistor and is set for 2 Amps.
Current Sensing Resistor is R21 (3 Ohm).  Voltage across this is input to U24
which has a gain of 2.  This signal is then passed through buffer U43 and
converted to a digital signal by U28, a 16 bit A/D.  Voltage across the mud rings
is input to the U27 which has gain of 2.  The signal is passed through a buffer
U44 and converted to digital by U29, a 16 bit A/D.  Both U28 and U29 are
sampled at the same time every 8 microseconds and data read sequentially and
Transferred to DSP on serial port 1.  Interrupt IRQ2 is generated every 8
microseconds.
To select LOG, U34-I/O port bit PF4 is set high for 20 ms.  This generates a
positive pulse at LOGCAL (U39) and switches relays K1 and K2.  This, in turn,
connects drive signals to the driver and return signals sens+, sens– to vs+, vs–,
respectively.
To select CAL, U34-I/O port bit PF5 and PF6 are set high for 20 ms.  These
generate a negative (–5v) signal at LOGCAL (U39) and a positive pulse at
HIGHLOW (U40).  These signals switch K1 and K2 to into the 10 ohm position,
and K3 to vs+, vs– across resistor R19.
To select ZERO, U34-I/O port bit PF5 and PF7 are set high for 20ms.  These
generate negative pulses at LOGCAL and HIGHLOW.  This causes the switching
of K1 and K2 to 0.25 ohm, K3 to vs+, vs– across resistor R20.
Gain for the Voltage input is always 2 (U34 output port FL2 is set to 1).

130870-945 / 3980 XA
OCT 2003
Baker Atlas
14

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description
APPENDIX A: DC POWER SUPPLIES
The 3980 XA TTMA has three power supplies mounted on the electronics
backbone.  Along with one of the supplies is an EMI filter module to drastically
reduce interference and interaction between supplies of other Matrix instruments.
These self-contained, modular supplies mount on a heat-sinking channel and
have additional circuitry mounted on a PC board that is soldered directly to the
pins of the supply.  It is this additional circuitry that will be the topic of discussion
for this section.
Because the power supplies are modular, there is no repair of the unit.  It either
works or it doesn’t.  The only circuitry external to the module (U1) is some
inhibiting control and some additional output filtering.
A ±5 volt supply mounts with an EMI filter module to make up the main supply.
Circuitry on the EMI filter PC board controls the ON/OFF function of the other two
supplies, another ±5 volt supply and a ±12 volt supply.  See the generic
descriptions of the associated circuitry below for common details.

Dual Power Supply
All three of the power supply modules are dual polarity.  That is, they have a plus
and a minus voltage output with respect to a common return.  See the schematic
below for a typical configuration of these external components for a dual output
power module.


130870-945 / 3980 XA
OCT 2003
Baker Atlas
15

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description
Instrument power first passes through an EMI filter module before being applied
to any DC to DC converter module; thus, the voltage at terminal E1 is a filtered
+28 V.  E2 is tied to the return line of the EMI filter output.  Pins 6, 7 and 8 are tied
to chassis ground, which is tied to cable armor.  Three independent windings of a
choke, L1, filter voltage spikes on the output of the module.  No provision is
made for trimming the output voltage.  Additional output filtering is provided by
capacitors C3, C4, C5, C6 and C7.

Power Control Circuit
Associated with at least one of the DC to DC power supply modules is an EMI
filter module.  The PC board attached to this module performs several control
functions.  These control functions are described below.
A simple +5 volt supply is generated for other chips on the PC board.  The supply
consists of a single dropping resistor (R3) and reference Zener diode (D1) to
establish the voltage.  This supply is connected to the output (pin 2) of the EMI
filter module (U1).  See the schematic below.


Refer to schematic diagram of the Power Supply Control circuit on page 17.  The
heart of the power control circuitry is a programmable microcontroller (U3).
Values for resistor R7 and capacitor C3 have been selected to give an operating
frequency of approximately 1 MHz.  Supplied with +5 volts from the supply of
, the microcontroller acts as a timer to control the turn-on time of
anything tied to its output.  There are basically three functions concerning this
circuit.  They are (1) a voltage threshold, (2) the delay circuit and (3) the
control/inhibit circuit.
(1) A threshold voltage is established using chip U4.  The voltage divider
consisting of R6 and R8 are chosen such that when 20 volts or more (for
instrument power) is present on R6, the reset chip removes the LOW on pin
7 which in turn removes the reset from the microcontroller, U3, allowing it to
do its job.
130870-945 / 3980 XA
OCT 2003
Baker Atlas
16

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description

(2) Jumper inputs to the microcontroller chip, U3, set different length delay
times.  Different turn-on times are established for tools to limit the current
demand when the Matrix tool sting is first powered up.  Delay times, in
milliseconds, and their jumpers are shown in the table below.

(3) When power is first applied to the microcontroller, output RA1 of U3 pin 18
is floating (open collector circuit).  Resistor R4 pulls the base of Q1 HIGH
turning it ON.  This state applies a ground potential to all power supplies tied to
the Q1 collector.  Diodes (D2 – D4) form an OR function in the collector circuit,
allowing control over different power supplies.  By tying the INHIBIT pin (active
low) of each DC-to-DC converter module within an instrument to one of these
control terminals (E5, E6 or E7), you can independently control its ON/OFF
function.  With Q1 initially turned ON, no power supply module can turn ON.  It
is not until the time-out function is completed by U3 that output RA1 can
transition LOW, turning OFF Q1.  With Q1 turned OFF, power supplies are
allowed to turn ON because their INHIBIT is removed.  As the power supplies
turn ON, their current demand is confined to that particular instrument.  Again,
see the control circuit on page 17.
130870-945 / 3980 XA
OCT 2003
Baker Atlas
17

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description

Baker Atlas

3980 XA TTMA – Circuit Description
130870-945 / 3980 XA
OCT 2003
Baker Atlas
Refer to drawing 198389-100 for the complete schematic of the Power
Controller board.  As an added feature of this circuit, Power Supply #2 or
Power Supply #3 can be turned OFF by an external source via opto-isolator
U2.  Terminal E8 is tied to a positive voltage.  Taking control terminal E9 or
E10 LOW causes its respective switch to close.  This applies a ground potential
to the INHIBIT input of the supply that is tied to its control terminal, E6 or E7.
This LOW turns OFF the respective power supply.  Terminal E9 controls a
power supply (P.S.2) connected to terminal E6, while E10 controls a supply
(P.S.3) connected to terminal E7.  Thus, independent control is available if
needed.  This feature is utilized in the TTMA to control two supplies – 199671-
000, the other ±5 V supply and 199672-000, the ±12 V supply – when in battery
mode.  Power supplies connected to E5 are solely controlled by the timing
function associated with the operation of transistor Q1 at initial power-up.  See
the schematic below.

____  1.
Clean and disassemble the 3980 XA instrument, referring to the step-

____  2.
Remove and discard all O-rings.  Replace with new O-rings.
____  3.
Inspect all pressure terminals for evidence of cracks, chips or other
damage.  Check for electrical leakage and continuity.  Remove and
replace all O-rings on the pressure terminals.
____  4.
Inspect all wiring for nicks, cuts, pinholes or abrasion.  Check the
wiring for electrical leakage and continuity.  Refer to 199410-100.
Replace all defective wiring with new wires.
____  5.
Inspect all electrical connectors and boots for damage: chips, cracks,
water absorption, broken contacts, corroded contacts or gascut.
Check for electrical leakage and continuity.  Replace any electrical
connectors that are not fit for service in the downhole environment.
____  6.
Inspect all mechanical parts for evidence of damage, wear and
corrosion on critical O-ring seal surfaces and threads.  Replace any
parts that show excessive damage and are unfit for use.
____  7.
To reassemble the instrument, follow the applicable steps in the
Assembly Procedure 199410-855.
____  8.
Set up the Lab PC Test System according to F
below.  Load
test system software “TEST3980.exe” (P/N 194904-000).  NOTE:

called out to power the box.  The adapter box will generate the
28 VDC required to power the TTMA instrument.  The tool
igure 1
DOES

INTRODUCTION
The 3981 XA TTRm is a 3-5/8" diameter sub containing three types of transducers for
measurement of cablehead tension/compression force, borehole temperature, and mud
resistivity.
The sub is optional and does not contain any electronics. It is supported by the 3510 XA
WTS Common Remote, which contains the electronics portion of the 3981 XA.
The block diagram of the 3981 XA, Figure 935-1, shows a reference diagram of the pertinent
circuits in the 3510 XA. See the circuit descriptions (130220-945) in the 3510 XA manual and
the circuit descriptions (section -945) in this manual.

3981 XA TTRm SENSOR SUB FUNCTIONS
The functions of the 3981 XA are to detect and measure borehole temperature, mud resistivity
(Rm), and external cablehead tension and compression forces at the top of the tool string and
send this information to the aquisition unit via the 3510 Common Remote.
The Strain Gauge Load Cell of the Force Gauge portion of the 3981 XA has the capability to
measure from -10,000 lbs (compression) to +14,000 lbs (tension). The electronic circuit in
the 3510 XA, which processes the Strain Gauge signal, can accomodate a range of +/-12,000
lbf.
The Temperature Sensor is an RTD probe with a range of -55°C to 245°C.
The Mud Resistivity Sensor is a cylindrical electrode array with geometry designed for
extremely shallow depth of investigation and a measurement range of 0.01 Ohm-M to 10.0
Ohm-M. The corresponding output signal varies from 4.8 mv to 4.8 volts.

NOTE
The 3981 XA must be run above the 3510 WTS Common Remote
Instrument.
A Remote Meter and cabling are available as optional equipment with the 3981 XA TTRm
Sensor Sub for use with pipe conveyed logging and coiled tubing conveyed logging
operations. See CHT Remote Meter operating instructions in CLS Operations Volume 5 for
further details.
P/N 130330-935
NOVEMBER 1994
2
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE - 3981 XA TTRm SENSOR SUB

FORCE GAUGE
Refer to figure 945-1.
The strain gauge load cell in the 3981 XA is comprised of four active strain gauge arms
bonded to a tensile member in a balanced Wheatstone Bridge configuration. Each sensing
arm combines two 350 ohm foil elements, in series, to yield the specified 700 ohm bridge.
Bridge excitation is supplied by the 3510 XA electronics as an active 10 VDC source. The
bridge node is sensed by another feedback line referenced to a precision voltage to maintain
an accurate 10 V supply.
The sensitivity of the bridge is about 0.1 mV/V/1000 lbf or, 1 mV/1000 lbf with the 10 V
excitation. The small signal is handled by a high gain instrumentation amplifier to reject any
common mode noise and cover the required ±12000 lbf range.

BOREHOLE TEMPERATURE
A platinum Resistance Temperature Device was selected as the sensing element for borehole
temperature measurement. The RTD is wire wound inside a custom-made 1" long metal
probe. The resistance of the RTD element is specified as 500 ohm at 0°C. The platinum
wire has a standard change in resistance of Alpha = 0.00385 ohm/ohm/°C. The temperature
of the probe is measured as a function of the change in its resistance. A constant current
source supplied by the 3510 XA electronics develops the corresponding measured voltage
across the RTD. The 1 mA current is small enough to minimize self-induced heating of the
probe to a negligible value.

MUD RESISTIVITY (Rm)
Some services require knowledge of the mud resistivity for computed logs. A miniature array
of cylindrical electrodes mounted around the lower third section of the Sensor Sub provides
this capability.
The electrodes are spaced 0.125" apart. Using the lateral principle from the electrolog, Rm is
measured across electrodes #2 and #3. Return electrodes #4 are only 0.625" away from
center electrode #1 to limit the depth of investigation to the surrounding mud column.
The K factor for the electrode geometry in the 1 ohm-m homogeneous case is calculated to be
1.6522 ohm-m/ohm. The Zero and Cal values of the resistor arrangement in the 3510 Rm
circuit was based on this factor.
P/N 130330-945
NOVEMBER 1994
2
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS - 3981 XA TTRm SENSOR SUB

topic: PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE LEVEL 3 - 1.0 LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES
chunk_text:
1.    Clean and disassemble the tool, referring to the step-by-step Disassembly Procedures in the
Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (section -855) of this manual.

2.
Remove and discard all o-rings.  Replace with new o-rings.

3.
Inspect all pressure terminals for evidence of cracks, chips or other damage.  Check for electrical

leakage and continuity.  Remove and replace all o-rings on the pressure terminals.

4.
Inspect all wiring for nicks, cuts, pinholes, or abrasion.  Check the wiring for electrical leakage and

continuity.  Replace all defective wiring with new wires.

5.
Inspect all electrical connectors and boots for damage: chips, cracks, water absorption, broken contacts,
corroded contacts or gascut.  Check for electrical leakage and continuity.  Replace any electrical
connectors that are not fit for service in the downhole environment.

6.  Inspect all parts for evidence of damage, wear, and corrosion on critical o-ring seal surfaces and threads.
Replace any parts that have excessive corrosion on o-ring seal surfaces or excessively worn or damaged
threads.

7.
Inspect the metal bellows assembly for signs of wear, damage or corrosion. Replace any parts that are
not fit for service in the downhole environment.

8.    Check out the Strain Gauge Load Cell P/N 144305-000 per Specification A059403-000 in the

reference section of this manual.  Replace the Strain Gauge Load Cell if it does not meet the

specifications. Do not attempt any field repairs to the Strain Gauge Bridge.  It is acceptable only to

make minor repairs to the external ends of the bridge leads at the crimp joints to the female connector

boots.

9.
Check out the RTD Temperature Probe P/N 137737-000 per the Repair/Maintenance Procedures
(section -856) of this manual. Replace if defective.

10.  Check out the Rm Electrode P/N 144500-000 per the Repair/Maintenance Procedures (section -856)
of this manual. Repair or replace if defective.

11.  To reassemble the tool, follow the instructions in the Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (section -855)
of this manual.

12.  Check out the 3981 XA instrument following the Continuity/Resistivity Checks (section 3.0) and
Function Test (section 4.0), in the Repair/Maintenance procedures (section -856) of this manual.

INTRODUCTION


The 3981 XB TTRm is a 3.63 in. (92.1 mm) diameter high strength forge gauge sensor sub

containing three types of transducers for measurement of cablehead tension/compression force,

borehole temperature, and mud resistivity.


The sub is optional and does not contain any electronics. It is supported by the 3510 XA WTS

Common Remote, which contains the electronics portion of the 3981 XB.

3981 XB TTRm HIGH STRENGTH SENSOR SUB FUNCTIONS


The functions of the 3981 XB are to detect and measure borehole temperature, mud resistivity

(Rm), and external cablehead tension and compression forces at the top of the tool string and

send this information to the acquisition unit via the 3510 Common Remote.


The Strain Gauge Load Cell of the Force Gauge portion of the 3981 XB has the capability to

Measure from -10,000 lbs (compression) to +14,000 lbs (tension). The electronic circuit in the

3510 XA, which processes the Strain Gauge signal, can accommodate a range of ±12,000 lbs.


The Temperature Sensor is an RTD probe with a range of -55ºC to 245ºC.


The Mud Resistivity Sensor is a cylindrical electrode array with geometry designed for extremely

shallow depth of investigation and a measurement range of 0.01 Ohm-M to 10.0 Ohm-M. The

corresponding output signal varies from 4.8 mv to 4.8 volts.


NOTE



The 3981 XB must be run above the 3510 WTS Common Remote Instrument.



A Remote Meter and cabling are available as optional equipment with the 3981 XB TTRm High

Strength Sensor Sub for use with pipe conveyed logging and coiled tubing conveyed logging

operations. See CHT Remote Meter operating instructions in CLS Operations Volume 5 for

further details.

FORCE GAUGE


Refer to Figure 945-1.


The strain gage load cell in the 3981 XB is comprised of four active strain gauge arms bonded

to a tensile member in a balanced Wheatstone Bridge configuration. Each sensing arm combines

two 350 ohm foil elements, in series, to yield the specified 700 ohm bridge.



The bridge excitation is supplied by the 3510 XA electronics as an active 10 VDC source. The

bridge node is sensed by another feedback line referenced to a precision voltage to maintain an

accurate 10 V supply.


The sensitivity of the bridge is about 0.1mV/V/1000 lbf or, 1mV/1000 lbf with the 10 V excitation.

The small signal is handled by a high gain instrumentation amplifier to reject any common mode

noise and cover the required ± 12000 lbf range.

BOREHOLE TEMPERATURE


A platinum Resistance Temperature Device was selected as the sensing element for borehole

temperature measurement. The RTD is wire wound inside a custom-made 1” long metal probe.

The resistance of the RTD element is specified as 500 ohm at 0ºC. The platinum wire has a

standard change in resistance of Alpha = 0.00385 ohm/ohm/0ºC. The temperature of the probe

is measured as a function of the change in its resistance. A constant current source supplied by

the 3510 XA electronics develops the corresponding measured voltage across the RTD. The 1mA

current is small enough to minimize self-heating of the probe to a negligible value.

MUD RESISTIVITY (Rm)


Some services require knowledge of the mud resistivity for computed logs. A miniature array of

cylindrical electrodes mounted around the lower third section of the Sensor Sub provides this

capability.


The electrodes are spaced 0.125” apart. Using the lateral principle from the electrolog, Rm is

measured across electrodes #2 and #3. Return electrodes #4 are only 0.625” away from center

electrode #1 to limit the depth of investigation to the surrounding mud and column.


The K factor for the electrode geometry in the 1 ohm-m homogeneous case is calculated to be

1.6522 ohm-m/ohm. The Zero and Cal values of the resistor arrangement in the 3510 Rm circuit

RISK OF DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT
Take care to ensure that the feed through wires are

Carefully unscrew and extract the Pull Rod [16] from the Center Sub [26].

Threaded Adaptor [10].

Remove from the Piston Assembly [13] the Retainer Ring [18] and Guide Bearing [19] and
inspect for signs of wear.

Strain Gauge Assembly.

Reposition the 3981 XB TTRm in the tool cart with the Bulkhead Adaptor Sub [38] now in
the chain vise. Unscrew the Center Sub [26] from the Electrode Sub [27].

Unscrew the Strain Gauge Assembly [21] from the Electrode Sub [27].

14. Removal and Disassembly of the Electrode Sub

Unscrew the Electrode Sub [27] from the Bulkhead Adaptor Sub [38].

Remove two Cover Plates [28] and [30] on the Electrode Sub [27] by removing eight Flat
Head Screws [29].

Disconnect three Cable Assemblies from the Rm Electrode Assembly [31].

Replace the Rm Electrode Assembly [31] every 100 trips into a well or five years or if wear
and tear adversely affects function.
Record installation date and trips in this ZARM. Inspect Rm Electrode Assembly for evidence
of cracks, pitting or other damage that will adversely affect performance. If necessary remove
the Rm Electrode Assembly [31] from the Electrode Sub [27].

Replace the Temperature Probe [33] every 100 trips into a well or five years or if wear and
tear adversely affects function. Record installation date and trips in this ZARM. Replace
Temperature Probe O-Rings every 100 trips into a well or three years.
Record installation date and trips in this ZARM. Inspect Temperature Probe for evidence of
cracks, pitting or other damage that will affect performance. If required, remove the
Temperature Probe [33] from the Electrode Sub [27].

If Temperature Probe was extracted from the Electrode Sub then remove and discard the
O-Rings (F259260009) on the Temperature Probe. Inspect Temperature Probe for
evidence of cracks, pitting or other damage that will adversely affect performance.
Install new lubricated O-Rings (F259260009) into the Temperature Probe lubricated O-Ring
grooves. Protect and set aside Temp probe assembly for later installation.
This completes the disassembly of the 3981 XB TTRm Force Gauge.

15. PM3 General Procedures

Inspect all wiring for nicks, cuts, pinholes, or abrasion. Check the wiring for electrical
leakage and continuity. Replace all defective wiring with new wires. PROTECT the wiring;
wrap them in protective cloth, paper or anti-static plastic Store in protective container and
put aside.

Inspect all electrical connectors and boots for chips, cracks, broken contacts, corroded
contacts, gas cut boots or any other damage that could adversely affect performance.
Drawing A3000542000, item 60, F190925000 is obsolete; use A1907385000.
Check integrity of contacts A1907385000 in the boots of the 10 cables that connect to the
Top sub using contact pin F104944000. Replace any defective contacts. Check for
electrical leakage and continuity.

Inspect all parts for evidence of damage, wear, and corrosion. O-Ring grooves shall not
have dust, dirt, scratches; pitting, corrosion and/or any damage or condition which can
seal failure.
Replace any parts that have excessive corrosion or wear or damaged threads that will
adversely affect performance.

Do NOT attempt any repairs to the Strain Gauge Bridge. It is acceptable only to make
repairs to the ends of the leads at the crimp joints of the socket connectors.

care not to cut into the insulation of the inner conductor. Push braided shield so that it bird
cages exposing the inner conductor insulation. Use wire cutters to cut braided shield so that it
folds back and flat over outside insulation approximately 1/4 inch. Apply a thin coating of RTV
[59] completely around all shield strand wires and approximately 1/16 inch over inner
conductor insulation where it comes out of shield wires. Install two 1 inch long pieces of
shrink tubing (F238363000) over exposed braiding. Heat-shrink shall fit tight and provide 1/8
inch to 1/4 inch protection over inner conductor. Strands of shield wire must not extend out of
shrink tubing.  Thermal strip off the insulation 3/16 inch from the end of each inner conductor
wire.

Refer to Figure 48. Socket contact Material number F190925000 is OBSOLETE. Install and
crimp one Socket contact A1907385000 on each wire using Crimp Tool F111870000 or
equivalent.


131051-953  Rev:  A

Effective Date: 2-Mar-2015
3981 XB TTRM Preventive Maintenance Level 3




Page 41 of 54

Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential
26. Bulkhead [44]

Refer to Figure 49. If the Bulkhead [44] is not already pre-stamped with its porthole numbers
use Figure 49, as a guide for marking the Bulkhead [44] holes. Note the orientation of the
Bulkhead   [44] in the picture. Rotate the Bulkhead [44] until an upside down “Y” pattern is
observed. Begin marking the holes with number “1” at the top and continue clockwise until
porthole number “15” is marked. Porthole number “16” then falls below porthole number “1”.
Continue in a clockwise pattern until porthole number “23” is marked. The inner circle hole
pattern is marked “24” at the top, followed clockwise by “25” and finally hole number “26”.



131051-953  Rev:  A

Effective Date: 2-Mar-2015
3981 XB TTRM Preventive Maintenance Level 3




Page 42 of 54

Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential

Refer to Figure 50. Apply a light coat of grease [23] to the O-Rings and gland surfaces of the
Bulkhead [44]. Install two O-Rings [51] on the external grooves of the Bulkhead [44].

Replace Bulkhead [44] feed thru plug’s O-Rings and pressure terminals every 100 trips into a
well or five years. Record installation date and trips in this ZARM. Inspect all pressure
terminals for evidence of cracks, chips, pitting or other damage.

You should not change Pressure Terminal Assemblies O-Rings; if needed you should install
new pressure terminals. This step does not have to be performed unless you are changing
feed thru plug [41] O-Rings [43] and/or Pressure Terminal Assemblies [34].
Apply a light coat of grease [23] to the O-Rings on the Pressure Terminal Assemblies [34] and
gland surfaces of feed thru plugs [41] and feed thru plug O-Rings [43]. Refer to Figure 51.
Install five O-Rings [43] on the five Feed Thru Plugs [41] and apply a light coat of grease [23]
on the O-Rings.
Install the five Feed Thru Plugs into the Bulkhead [44] port numbers 11, 12, 13, 16 and 26.
Observe the color code of the Wiring Diagram F147431-000. Install 21 Pressure Terminal
Assemblies [34] into the Bulkhead [44] as per assembly drawing A3000542000 using a 3/8”
deep well socket.

131051-953  Rev:  A

Effective Date: 2-Mar-2015
3981 XB TTRM Preventive Maintenance Level 3




Page 43 of 54

Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential

Perform this step if needed. Refer to Figure 52. Per Wiring Diagram F147431000, twist the
following wires together:
• 22 AWG YEL and GRN
• 22 AWG BLK and BRN
• 22 AWG VIO, GRY, and WHT
• 20 AWG ORG and YEL
• 20 AWG RED and GRN
• 20 AWG BRN and YEL

Baker Hughes—Company Confidential

Perform this step if needed. Refer to Figure 53. Cut length of the feed-through wires of the
Bulkhead [44] to 10 inches from the backside of the Bulkhead [44]. Strip off the insulation
3/16 inches from the end of each feed-through wire using thermal stripper (F226804000) or
equivalent. Crimp the feed-through wires to the pins of the 26-Pin Deutsche Connector [46].
Perform a visual inspection of the crimped joints. Give a slight pull to each wire’s contact to
ensure good connections.

Effective Date: 2-Mar-2015
3981 XB TTRM Preventive Maintenance Level 3




Page 45 of 54

Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential

Perform this step only if needed. Refer to Figure 54. As per Wiring Diagram F147431000,
install the pins into the 26-Pin Deutsche Connector [46]. Bundle the wires together with ties of
Lacing Cord [57] to form a pigtail cable. Perform continuity test from each socket to its
corresponding pressure terminal in Bulkhead [44]. Check Pressure Terminal Assemblies
electrical insulation @ 500 volts.

Effective Date: 2-Mar-2015
3981 XB TTRM Preventive Maintenance Level 3

Baker Hughes—Company Confidential

Refer to Figure 55. Cut 42 pieces of Heat Shrink Tubing (F238362000) to a length of 2-in.
Beginning with the inner circle pins (24 and 25) slide two pieces of Heat Shrink Tubing over
each connector and plug in the connector of each wire onto their respective Pressure
Terminal Assembly [34] on the Bulkhead [44] per Wiring Diagram F147431000, shrink the
Heat Shrink Tubing in place with the tubing pushed against Pressure Terminal Assembly [34]
as far as it will go. It should be against the pressure terminal Hex Head.

Refer to Figure 56. Apply a light coat of grease [23] to the two O-Rings [51] of the Bulkhead
[44]. Insert the feed through conductor and sensor wires of Bulkhead [44] into the bore and
rotate them into a coil or bundle to take up the slack. Take precautions to avoid pinching any
of the wires between the Bulkhead [44] and the Bulkhead Adaptor Sub [38]. Install the
Bulkhead [44] into the bore of the Bulkhead Adaptor Sub [38] using the Bulkhead Extraction
Tool (F150210000).

Sub [45]. Install two O-Rings [24] in the external grooves of the Bottom Sub.

cable and 26-Pin Deutsche Connector [46] through the center of the Bottom Sub [45]. Screw

joint to ensure it will not accidentally become loose.

The top end of the Upper Housing [25] should now be positioned, as shown in zone B-13 of
drawing A3000542000 within .06 inch (1/16th inch) from the upper shoulder of the Top Sub [6].
Rotate Top Sub / Threaded Adaptor Assembly if necessary to obtain this position.

Refer to Figure 61. Rotate the Top Sub [6] to align the threaded holes in the Top Sub [6] with
the slots in the Upper Housing [25]. Do NOT put RTV into the Top Sub screw holes. Apply a
liberal coating of RTV Silicone Adhesive [59] to the Socket Head Cap Screws [50] threads.
Install three Socket Head Cap Screws [50] and tighten to 40 lb-ft torque.

NOTICE
RISK OF DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT.
Check ONLY the TOP Sub connector to Housing !!! Do NOT
use a Megohmmeter on the Bottom Connector. High Voltage
will damage components.





Check Top Sub all 10 conductors  to the housing with Megohmmeter on 1000
volt scale. All conductors > 1000 Meg ohms (1 Gigohm).







29. Hydraulic Checks

Do NOT evacuate air and fill with oil yet IF you are going to be performing optional heat test.
If you are not performing optional heat test, vacuum air and fill the tool with Silicone Oil [39].
With the vacuum pump lines attached, elevate the tool so that the Top Sub [6] is at least 2-3
feet above the Bottom Sub [45]. Hold a vacuum for at least one hour and then circulate oil for
at least one hour or until almost no air bubbles are visible in the vacuum lines. After evacuating
most of the entrapped air, apply a light coat of grease [23] to both of the Port Plugs [8] O-Rings
[37]. Reposition tool as necessary. Remove oil cart hoses and adaptors. Install Port Plug [8]
and O-Ring [37] into the filler port of the Top Sub [6] and the Bulkhead Adaptor Sub [38] as per
on A3000542000.

Pump Silicone Oil [39] into the tool through the Check Valve [36] to expand the Piston [13] to
approximately 3.0 inches as shown in zone B-11 of A3000542000. Fill the Check Valve [36]
filler hole (outward of the valve) with Silicone Oil [39]. Apply a light coat of grease [23] to the
Check Valve Port Plug [8] O-Ring [37] and then re-install the Port Plug [8] into the Check Valve
Port.
30. Electrical Checks
Perform Continuity and Resistance checkout. Use a 5722 XA/XB "WEETECH" to verify the tool (if
available), if not use Fluke Multi-meter or equivalent.

Continuity Checks, Top connector to Bottom connector. All conductors are < 1 Ω.

Resistance Checks, Bottom connector to Bottom connector. Refer to checklist. Tolerances
are + 2 % except where noted.

NOTICE
RISK OF DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT.
Check ONLY the TOP Sub connector to Housing !!! Do NOT
use a Megohmmeter on the Bottom Connector. High Voltage
will damage components.

Insulation Checks. Check conductors at Only Top Sub connector to housing with
Megohmmeter on 1000 volt scale. All conductors > 1000 Meg ohms (1 Gigohm).

NOTICE
RISK OF DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT.
Do NOT use a Megohmmeter on the strain gauge load cell
wires or Temperature Probe wires. High Voltage will
damage these components. Check these components using
a Fluke Model 87 V digital multimeter or equivalent.

Bottom Sub Connector Insulation to Mass, use a 5722 XA/XB "WEETECH" to verify the tool
(if available), if not use Fluke Multi-meter or equivalent.

Mud Electrode Resistance. Use a Fluke Multimeter Model 87 V or equivalent to verify the
tool. For Continuity, check Bottom connector contacts to Mud Electrode rings and Bottom
Electrode Rings to Top Electrode Rings. For Insulation, verify > 3 Meg Ω between
Electrode rings to each other and Mass.

Refer to Figure 62. Apply a light coat of grease [23] to the external threads of the Bottom Sub
[45]. Install the Makeup Collar [48] on the Bottom Sub [45].

Apply a light coat of grease to bottom Thread Protector [49] O-Ring groove and external
threads and O-Ring [3]. Install O-Ring [3].

Refer to Figure 63. Install the Thread Protector [49] into the Makeup Collar [48].


131051-953  Rev:  A

Effective Date: 2-Mar-2015
3981 XB TTRM Preventive Maintenance Level 3

Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential

Refer to Figure 64 Apply a light coat of grease [23] to the O-Rings, gland surfaces, and the
external threads of the Top Sub [6].
Refer to Figure 65. Install the Thread Protector [1] onto the Top Sub [6].

All O-Rings that were removed SHALL have been replaced at this point.

This completes the mechanical assembly of the 3981 XB TTRm High Strength Force Gauge
Sensor Sub.
32. Heat Test is Optional

Heated tool.
Burning Hazard
•
Wear high temperature gloves
•
Safety glasses


If applicable, Heat Test the instrument with pressure housings on for 1 hour at no greater than

33. Post Heat Test Tasks

After the Heat Test, fill the Electrode Wire cavity with grease then replace the cover.

After the heat test evacuate air and fill instrument with oil.

After the heat test Perform continuity and resistance checkout per 3981 XB Level 1 Preventive
Maintenance Checklist.

After the heat test Clean and lubricate the remaining exposed threads. All
O-Rings that were removed should have been replaced at this point. Install thread protectors.

CHECKOUT PROCEDURE - 3996 NA ELECTRO-MAGNET FISHING TOOL
                                                                              
                                                                             
CHECKOUT PROCEDURES
3996 NA 6.75" O.D. Electro-Magnet Fishing Tool
1.
Electrical Insulation and Continuity Checks ( Meter )
Check the instrument for electrical continuity and leakage using an ohm
meter capable of reading 20 meg ohms or greater.  Electrical insulation
should exceed 20 meg ohms from pins 4 and 6 to pressure housing.
Electrical continuity between pins 4 and 6 should be checked using the
diode scale of a digital meter or a low (100 ohm) scale of an analog
meter.  Reversing meter polarity between pins 4 and 6 should result in
uniform readings within +/- 10 percent.  The continuity check can only
detect an open in the coil or diode leg.  It will not detect a shorted
winding in the coil.
2.
Electrical Continuity Check ( Voltage vs. Current )
Because the resistance of the magnet coil is low (approximately 24
ohms), and because the diodes are in series with the coil, it is not
possible to accurately check the coil for shorted windings using an ohm
meter.
To check for proper continuity, connect pins 4 and 6 of the electro-
magnet tool directly to a 2061 Power Supply.  Apply 1 amp. of current to
the magnet.  The voltage between pins 4 and 6 should measure 36 volts AC
+/- 10 percent.
