BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE - 4401 WTS ORIENTATION TOOL
P/N  130641-935
SEPTEMBER 1998
The 4401 XB Orientation Sub is a general purpose borehole orientation instrument.  It continuously
establishes the position of the toolstring with respect to vertical and magnetic north.
It provides digital acquisition of three orthogonal accelerometers, three orthogonal magnetometers, and
temperature which comprises the sensor package.  Additionally, several in-circuit quality control points are
monitored and reflected by the instrument status information command.  The instrument returns data to the
surface using the standard WTS communication protocol and operates only
on mode 2.

3.0  CPU BOARD 3
3.0  CPU BOARD
(Reference Drawing C153910-000)
The CPU board contains two independent sections.
The Analog section is electrically isolated from the digital section and it is made up of IC-7 and IC-8.  The
multiplexer (IC-7) is paralleled with the mux on the A/D board. This multiplexer is used to select signals
from the flask temperature and power supplies.  The Analog section also contains a 10 volt precision
voltage source (IC-8).  The voltage source is divided by R7 to a precise 4799 mV and transferred to the
main analog board to be used as a scale reference.
The digital section of the CPU board performs as follows:
IC-2 is the main oscillator supplying a 12 mHz clock to the CPU.  IC-3 is a power-on reset
circuit that releases the CPU for operation when the 5 v supply exceeds 4.5 volts.  IC-4 is a
serial EEROM that stores the tool asset number. This EEROM is wired for serial address 2
and is parallel via SCL and SDA with an identical part (address 0) embedded within the
sensor module.
IC-1 is a Intel 87 C51 Micro Controller incorporating RAM, EPROM, and I/O into a single 40 pin DIP.  I/O
is divided between the 4 ports on the micro-controller are as follows:
Port 0 emulates a bi-directional 8 bit data bus. IC-5 provides pull-up resistors for the open drain outputs of
port 0.  The data bus leaves the CPU board via a 16 conductor cable plugged into connector H1.  The data
bus goes directly to the telemetry board and nowhere else. Read Write control originates from port 2 and
also leaves the CPU board to the telemetry board via H1.
Port 1
1.
Supplies the A/D and sample/hold control signals, hold, start, and serial data bit.
2.
Supplies the clock for the serial EEROM (SCL) and the bi-directional data bit (SDA).
3.
Also senses communication sync type (command/data) from the telemetry board.
Port 2
supplies the 4 bit address used to control the 16 channel multiplexer.  These signals leave the CPU
board and are routed to the analog board via 16 conductor cable at H2.
Port 3
1.
Supplies a watchdog reset bit to IC-3 (WDI).
2.
Senses when the send buffer on the telemetry board is full.
3.
Senses and generates a system interrupt when a valid word is received by the telemetry
board.

4.0  TELEMETRY BOARD 4
4.0  TELEMETRY BOARD
(Reference Drawing B153909-100)
The telemetry board contains a bus driver IC-1, T1  and bus receiver IC-2, T2.  Manchester IC-4 encodes
and decodes the serial data as it enters and leaves the board.  IC-12 is the 4 MHZ telemetry oscillator.  IC-
13 divides the oscillator to the correct manchester frequencies.  IC-3 is a latch that is set to start the encoder
for a send transaction.  Two sections of IC-5 buffer the receive sync type.  IC-8 and IC-11 form the send
buffer.  IC-6, IC-9, IC-7, and IC10 form the double buffer receive section.

4.1  SEND TRANSACTIONS 4
4.1  SEND TRANSACTIONS
To send a word from the micro controller onto the instrument bus the following transactions will occur.
The MSB of the word being sent will be put onto the data bus. Write MSB (WMSB) will pulse low (2 micro
sec) to latch the data into IC-8. The LSB of the word to send will be put on the data bus.  Write LSB
(WLSB) will be pulsed low (2 micro sec) to latch the data into IC-11. WLSB also sets latch Q of IC-3 and
resets Q/ of IC-3.  Q/ of IC-3 immediately sets send busy (SB) IC-15 pin 8 indicating to the controller that
telemetry is now busy sending data.  Q of IC-3 sets encoder enable (EE) of the manchester which initiates a
send sequence. The manchester begins sending sync to IC-1 and to the instrument bus.  When the
manchester is ready to send the 16 bits of data previously stored in shift registers IC-8 and IC-11 SD of IC-4
goes high.  SD going high does 4 things.
1.
IC-15 is held busy independently of IC-3.
2.
IC-3 clocks a low onto the Q output releasing EE.  Q/ of IC-3 releases pre-busy on pin 10 of IC-15.
SB remains in the busy state via IC15 pin 9.
3.
SD at pin 1 of IC-14 allows the encoder shift clock (ESC) to pass to the clock inputs of shift
registers IC-8 and IC-11.  SD is connected to DR (Decoder Root).
4.
SD going high resets the manchester decoder effectively locking out all received signals.  When the
16 data bits have been shifted out SD goes low releasing send busy (SB) completing the send
sequence.

4.2  RECEIVE TRANSACTIONS 5 5.0  ANALOG BOARD 6
5.0  ANALOG BOARD
(Reference Drawing B153908-000)
The analog board contains 6 vector filters, multiplexer, sample-hold, and analog-to-digital converter.

5.1  FILTERS 6
5.1  FILTERS
The outputs of accelerometers Ax, Ay, Az and magnetometers Mx, MY, Mz found in orientation module
C119500-000 pass through the six channel filters before entering the 8-channel analog multiplexer.  Filters
designated IC-1 through IC-6 are identical and have a cut-off frequency of .2 Hz.  Each of the six filters has
a gain of 1 and is non-inverting.
Outputs from the orientation module depend on the earth's gravitational pull and magnetic field present at
the module.  The module is scaled 3 volts/g for the accelerometers and 8 volts/gauss for the magnetometers.
For axis definitions and expected polarities, refer to drawing C119500-000.
P/N 130641-945
SEPTEMBER 1998

5.2  A/D SYSTEM 7
5.2  A/D SYSTEM
(Reference Drawing 153908-100)
Multiplexer IC-7 is used to select one of the six orientation vectors ground or scale reference.  Mux channel
selection (channel 0-7) originates at the CPU and enters the analog board via a 16 conductor ribbon cable at
J1.  The Mux output is paralleled with an identical Mux on the CPU board and connected via the MX2
terminal.
The output of the mux is fed into the sample-hold circuit at IC-8.  The output of the sample-hold is supplied
directly to the A/D IC-9 pin 11.  All timing originates at the CPU.
NOTE
The A/D clock only operates during an acquisition cycle and is OFF
otherwise.
Data acquisition follows this sequence.
1.
The A/D clock is started (20 microsec clock).
2.
Mux channel is set into IC-7 via MUX0 - MUX3.
3.
Samp/Hold IC-8 put into SAMPLE mode.
4.
After 20 microsec samp/hold is set to HOLD mode.
5.
A/D START.
6.
12 data bits are clocked out ADAT to the CPU.
7.
A/D clock stopped.
There is NO offset or scale adjustment.  When operating under WTS protocol requesting SUBSET data
causes the CPU to sample Mux channel 0 (ground) and Mux channel 7 (REF).  The ground offset is
subtracted from each of the sampled channels.  No additional offset correction is required.  The REF
standard (4799 mV) is sent uphole as an entry in the subset table and is applied via the surface software to
make any necessary scale corrections.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 4401 WTS ORIENTATION TOOL
chunk_text:
1

P/N 130641-945
SEPTEMBER 1998
1.  POWER SUPPLY
2.  CPU
3.  A/D REFERENCE
4.  VECTOR FILTER
5.  TELEMETRY
The instrument requires +5 volts and ± 12 volts as supplied by the power supply section.  The power
supply is located on the main chassis.
The 4401 XB operates as a demand-response system utilizing WTS mode 2 protocol.  Telemetry encoding,
decoding, line drivers, and receivers are located on telemetry board B153909-000 on the main chassis.
The Analog board (within the heat flask) filters, multiplexes, and digitizes the 6 sensor vector outputs.
The CPU (within the heat flask) controls the instrument functions of telemetry, analog acquisition, and  tool
address decoding.

2.0  POWER SUPPLY CIRCUITRY
Three power supplies provide the necessary operating voltages for the 4401 XB electronics.
The ± 12 V supply provides power to circuits on: the analog board (C153908-000), the orientation module
(C119500-000), and the analog section of the CPU board (C153910-000).
The 5 V power supply provides power to the CPU, Telemetry, and A/D boards.
2.1  +5 V Power Supply
(Reference Drawing B153911-100)
The pink and tan windings of the transformer (T2) supply approximately 12 Vac to bridge rectifier BR2.
The resulting DC voltage is filtered by C6 and input to the 5 volt regulator.  The regulator output is
delivered to the 5 volt bus.  Noise immunity for the regulator is provided by C5.  Refer to Figure 945-1.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 4401 WTS ORIENTATION TOOL
chunk_text:
2

P/N 130641-945
SEPTEMBER 1998
Approximately 40 Vac from transformer T1 is supplied to bridge rectifier BR1, resulting in +22 Vdc being
delivered to the filter comprised of C1, L1, (mounted on backbone) and C1 (on filter board B153911-000).
Similarly, -22 Vdc is filtered by C2, L2 (backbone) and C2 (on filter board).  These unregulated positive
and negative voltages are fed to there respective regulators.  Capacitors C3 and C4 are used for regulator
stabilization.  Refer to Figure 945-2.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 4401 WTS ORIENTATION TOOL
chunk_text:
5

P/N 130641-945
SEPTEMBER 1998
When the 4401 is receiving a word on the instrument bus the following transactions occur.  As the word is
received on the instrument bus it is transferred through T2 and IC-2 to the UDI input of IC-4.  The sync type
of the received word is determined and reflected onto the CDS pin of IC-4.  At this point IC-4 is ready to
shift out serial data on the SDO pin and indicates this by raising take data (TD).  TD allows the DSC
through IC-14 to clock the serial data stream into shift registers IC-9 and IC-6.  The DSC is also clocking
CDS into IC-5 effectively delaying CDS by one DSC clock cycle.  When 16 bits have been shifted in TD
goes low.  TD going low latches the last value of CDS into IC-5 pin 5.  TD also transfers the contents of
shift registers IC-6 and IC-9 into tri-state latches IC-7 and IC-10.  The received word is now complete, the
manchester IC-4 checks the parity bit on the word just received, and if correct, it signals valid word (VW)
on pin 1.  VW is inverted, and then leaves the telemetry board via J1 to the CPU.  VW causes an interrupt
at the CPU.  The word just received is read a byte at a time from IC-7 and IC-10 by the CPU strobing
RMSB and RLSB.
NOTE
If the CPU is busy it can take up to 500 microseconds between VW
interrupt and when the CPU actually reads the 2 bytes.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 2.0 REFERENCE DRAWINGS NEEDED . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1 3.0 DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1
chunk_text:
REFERENCE DRAWINGS NEEDED
R-184128 Instrument Assembly 4401 XB
D-184130 Electronics with flask
C-153913 Electronics package w/heat sink 

HOUSING & SUBS 1

DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
Preparations include washing the unit to remove mud, grease, dirt, and other foreign material if the unit has
been run in a well.  Blow dry with compressed air or dry off the unit with clean rags or paper towels.  Each
step of the disassembly will include cleaning as required.

HOUSING & SUBS
(Reference Drawing R-184128)
a.
Remove the top thread protector (item 1) from the Top Sub.
b.
Remove the bottom thread protector (item 18) from the Bottom Sub.

REMOVING AIRBORNE CONNECTOR
(Reference Drawing R-184128)
a.
Pry the Retaining Ring (item 2) from the Top Sub using a small screw driver.   Pull the Airborne
Connector (item 3) from the Top Sub using the T-Handle Tool.
b.
Disconnect the Airborne Connector from the pigtail of the Electronics Section.   At this time, check
the Airborne Connector for electrical insulation and continuity using the multimeter.
NOTE
Normal preventive maintenance for the Airborne Connecters consists
of degreasing and drying the contacts and body using a Sure Shot
Sprayer, P/N 222638, and solvent such as Freon, P/N 230271.  Then
blow dry with compressed air.

BULKHEAD & BOTTOM SUB 2

ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
a.
Place the 4401 XB Orientation on tool stands. Using a Parmallay and hex wrench remove the Top
Sub (item 6) from the Pressure Housing (item 22).
b.
Using a pin wrench and parmalloy wrench, remove the pressure housing (item 22) from the adapter
sub (item 21), and then remove the adapter sub (item 21) from the pressure housing (item 13).  Be
careful not to damage the pigtail or connectors.
c.
Remove the three screws (item 11) to remove the retainer ring (item 10) sleeve (item 9) and spring
(item 8).  Be careful!  The spring is under compression.
d.
Pull the Electronics from the Pressure Housing using the T-Handle Tool.  Inspect the connectors at
both ends  of the Electronics, and if necessary clean and dry the contacts.
NOTE
At this time, the Electronics may be checked out.  Refer to the
Repair/Maintenance Procedures 130641-956.

BULKHEAD & BOTTOM SUB
a.
Remove the Retaining Ring (item 16) from the Bottom Sub (item 17) using the modified pliers.
Take care not to damage or scar the surface finish inside the bore of the Bottom Sub as it is an O-
ring seal surface.
b.
Pull the Bulkhead (item 15) from the Bottom Sub.  This will require using the Pulling Tool, P/N
150208.  First  screw the Pulling Tool into the center hole of the Bulkhead (item 15).  Gently knock
with the slide hammer to pull the Bulkhead.
NOTE
Support the Pulling Tool to preclude breaking off the 1/4-20 threaded
stud and to prevent damaging the threaded hole in the Bulkhead. Use
care when pulling the Bulkhead so the pins do not get bent or the glass
seals damaged.
Remove the Pulling Tool from the Bulkhead.
c.
Remove the Bottom Sub (item 17) from the Pressure Housing (item 13).

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 3.5 ELECTRONICS PACKAGE WITH FLASK ASSEMBLY . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3 3.6 HEAT SINK REMOVAL . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3
chunk_text:
ELECTRONICS PACKAGE WITH FLASK ASSEMBLY
(Reference Drawing D-184130)
a.
Remove flat ribbon connector by fully loosening the two screws that are part of the hardware.
b.
Remove the screws (item 9) that hold the Electronics Package in the Flask Assembly.
c.
Pull the Electronics Package out of the Flask Assembly (item 6). 

HEAT SINK REMOVAL
(Reference Drawing D-184130)
a.
Remove the screws (item 7) that hold together the  Electronics Package Assembly and the Heat
Sink (item 4).
b.
Remove the Heat Sink (item 4).

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 3.7 TENSOR REMOVAL . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3 3.8 ELECTRONICS BACKBONE DISASSEMBLY . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3
chunk_text:
TENSOR REMOVAL
a.
Remove 2 screws (item 8 on 184130) holding the Tensor module onto the chassis.
b.
Disconnect the pigtail (item 1 of 153913) by loosening the 2 screws on the pigtail. 

ELECTRONICS BACKBONE DISASSEMBLY
(Reference Drawings 153913-000 & 184130-000)
a.
Removing of the Electronics Backbone Assembly from the Heatsink.
1.
Remove power supply wires from PC boards (items 6, 7).
2.
Remover jumper (item 8).
3.
Unsolder wires from header (item 9).
4.
Remove the 5, screws (item 7 on 184130) that hold the Heatsink to the thermal isolator
(item 2).
5.
At this stage the Flasked electronics section (item 3) can be fully removed.

ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
(Reference Drawing R-184128)
a.
Study the assembly drawings and parts lists to become familiar with the layout of all the items in the
assembly.
b.
Verify that all required parts and all necessary tools and equipment are available.  Inspect all parts
for any dings or nicks in threads.  Small dings may be cleaned up with a thread file if necessary.
Inspect parts for cleanliness, and clean to remove all dirt and foreign particles.  Set aside cleaned
parts in a clean storage area.
c.
Secure a clean work area and work bench with a bench vise.  During the assembly process, do not
allow dirt or any foreign material particles to contaminate the parts.
WARNING
THIS INSTRUMENT MEASURES THE EARTHS MAGNETIC
FIELD.  DO NOT ALLOW CONTAMINATION BY MAGNETIC
METAL FILINGS ETC. OR BY SUBSTITUTION OF STEEL
PARTS IN PLACE OF ORIGINAL TITANIUM PARTS.
KEEP HANDS, TOOLS, AND WORK BENCH CLEAN.
d.
Trial fit all mating parts, without any O-Rings installed, to insure that all fits are free and that no
conditions exist that would prevent easy assembly.
e.
To reassemble the electronics follow the same procedure discussed above, in reverse order.

ADAPTER SUB ASSEMBLY
(Reference Drawing R-184128)
a.
Install four O-Rings (item 7) on the Adapter Sub (item 21).
b.
Install the Spring (item 8) in the Adapter Sub (item 21).  Slide the Sleeve (item 9) through the
SPRING and into the Adapter Sub.  Install the Ring Retainer (item 10) over the end of the Sleeve.
Hold the Spring and the Sleeve in compressed position and install the three Screws (item 11)
through the holes in the Ring Retainer and into the Adapter Sub.
c.
Set aside the Adapter Sub assembly at this time.

BOTTOM SUB ASSEMBLY
(Reference Drawing R-184128)
a.
Install two external O-Rings (item 7) on the Bottom Sub (item 17).  Lubricate the O-Rings and gland
surfaces with a light coat of Lubriplate Grease.
b.
Screw the Bottom Sub into the Pressure Housing
(item 13).  Tighten the Bottom Sub to 75 lb-ft torque.
The timing marks of the Pressure Housing and the
Bottom Sub should be aligned with each other.
c.
Install two external O-Rings (item 14) on the Pressure Bulkhead (item 15).  Lubricate the O-Rings a
gland surface with a light coat of Lubriplate Grease.
d.
Install the Bulkhead (item 15) into the Bottom Sub, using the Bulkhead Installation Tool.  First,
insert the Bulkhead carefully into the Bottom Sub.  Note that the correct orientation of the Bulkhead
is with the short alignment key towards the Pressure Housing.
Next, engage the slot of the Installation Tool with the long alignment key of the Bulkhead.  Push the
Bulkhead into the Bottom Sub until the O-Rings engage.  From this point it is necessary to use the
threaded collar of the Installation Tool to push the Bulkhead into its final seated position.  Orient the
alignment key with the internal slot in the Bottom Sub and engage the key into the slot by carefully
rotating the Installation Tool.  Seat the Bulkhead.
e.
Now install the Retaining Ring (item 16) in the Bottom Sub using the modified Pliers.  Take care
not to damage or scar the surface finish inside the bore of the Bottom Sub.

TOP SUB ASSEMBLY
a.
Install two O-Rings (item 4) on the slotted end of the Top Sub (item 21).  Install two O-Rings (item
7) on the threaded end of the Top Sub.
NOTE
The following split collar and spring are NONMAGNETIC titanium.
Do not substitute standards WTS parts.
b.
Lubricate the 2.5 inch wide collar groove of the top sub with a light coat of Lubriplate grease.
Remove the four screws from the split collar (item 5) and separate the two halves.  Install the two
halves in the collar groove of the top sub and replace the four screws in the split collar.  Make sure
the split collar is free to turn on the top sub.
c.
Set aside the Top Sub assembly at this time.

ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
(Reference drawing R184128-000)
a.
Slide the Electronics Assembly (item 12) into the Housing and, using a T-Handled Tool, carefully
rotate the Electronics Assembly to align with the alignment key of the Bulkhead.  You should be
able to feel the engagement of the alignment pin.  Carefully push with the T-Handled Tool to seat
the electrical contact pins.  When properly engaged, the Electronics will "bottom" on the internal
shoulder of the Bottom Sub (item 17).
b.
Remove the T-HANDLE TOOL from the Electronics Assembly

ADAPTER SUB INSTALLATION
a.
Lubricate the four O-Rings (item 7) on the adapter sub with Lubriplate Grease.  Guide the pigtail
cable of the Electronics Assembly through the adapter sub.  Take care not to damage or pinch the
pigtail cable.
b.
Screw the adapter sub into the Pressure Housing and tighten the thread joint to 75 lb-ft torque.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - 4.6 PRESSURE HOUSING AND TOP SUB INSTALLATION . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 6
chunk_text:
PRESSURE HOUSING AND TOP SUB INSTALLATION
a.
Thread the pigtail and connector through the pressure housing (item 22) and screw the pressure
housing onto the adapter sub.
b.
Lubricate the two O-Rings (item 7) on the top sub with Lubriplate grease.  Guide the pigtail cable of
the Electronics Assembly through the top sub.  Take care not to damage or pinch the pigtail cable.
c.
Screw the top sub into the pressure housing and tighten the threadjoint to 75 ft/lb of torque.
d.
Attach the pigtail cable of the Electronics Assembly to the Female 32-Pin Airborne Connector.
Lubricate the O-Ring and gland surfaces of the Airborne Connector with a light coat of Lubriplate
Grease.  Install the Airborne Connector into the Top Sub using a T-Handle Tool [P/N 056063].
e.
Install the Retainer Ring (item 2) in the groove of the Top Sub using a C-Ring Installation Tool
[P/N 147266]. Check the Airborne Connector (item 3) for electrical insulation resistance to verify
that no conductor wires were pinched.  Insulation resistance should be 1000 megohms or greater,
between each contact and the sub.
f.
Check the electrical continuity through the 4401 XB assembly per the Wiring Diagram (Drawing
153892-100).  End to end, the D.C. resistance should be 0.5 ohm or less on the feedthrough
conductors.

THREAD PROTECTOR INSTALLATION
a.
Lubricate the external threads of the Split Collar and the two O-Rings [P/N 201281] of the Top Sub
with a light coat of Lubriplate Grease.  Install the Box Thread Protector (item 1) on the Top Sub.
b.
Install the external O-Ring [P/N 201281] on the Pin Thread Protector (item 18).  Lubricate the O-
Ring and threads with a light coat of Lubriplate Grease.
Install the Thread Protector into the Bottom Sub.

CALIBRATION CHECK
a.
Check out and calibrate the 4401 XB Orientation as per Calibration Procedure (Section 130641-
997).  Retain a copy of the calibration records and file in the instrument folder.
Level
Center Line

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                            4401 WTS ORIENTATION TOOL 1.0 INTRODUCTION
chunk_text:
1





P/N 130641-956
NOVEMBER 2005 
INTRODUCTION

The following maintenance procedure is intended to give the technician some insight into the operation of the
4401. It is not a step-by-step procedure. However, it is arranged somewhat in the order that you would
proceed to diagnose any instrument problems. A set of scope pictures are supplied representative of the major
test points in the signal path. For a detailed description, also read the circuit descriptions in section P/N
130641-945.

CONTINUITY CHECKS

Refer to drawing P/N 182489-000 backbone feedthrough wiring diagram. Check between top sub and bottom
sub as necessary.

LAB ADJUSTMENTS

There are no adjustments necessary to the 4401. When table data is requested from the 4401 the ground or
zero value of the A/D system is read (mux IC-7 on P/N 153908-000). When active channels are sampled the
zero reference value is subtracted from the sample prior to the sample being set up hole (This procedure
replaced the offset pot). Note when using "send single channel" the zero offset is not subtracted from the
acquired data.  The technician can evaluate the instruments true condition.

The gain correction of the A/D system is not done down hole. A precision reference source (IC-8 & R7 on
P/N 153910-000) is supplied to the surface as one of the A/D channels. Surface software can then correct
gain errors.

INITIAL SETUP

Remove the 4401 from the housing as per disassembly procedure P/N 130641-955. Connect a WTS PCM
or a 5721 Telemetry Test System (P/N 140175-000).  Use 4401 Test Program (P/N 156616-000).  If sensor
problems are anticipated remove the Tensor unit from the instrument. Place the Tensor module into its test
stand (P/N 089670-000) and connect to the 4401 with umbilical cable (P/N 132302-000).  Power the
instrument string to 180 Vac.

ELECTRONICS TROUBLESHOOTING

The 4401 electronics is functionally grouped on 3 circuit boards:

P/N 153908-100

P/N 153909-100
can be obtained by analyzing the tool status returned from the instrument.  If the instrument is not sufficiently
operational to acquire the status proceed to the digital troubleshooting section.  Tool status can be analyzed
as follows in section 7.0 Tool Status & Function.

TOOL STATUS & FUNCTION

Normal status is 0000. The high 8 bits should always be zero. The lower 8 bits indicate the following
problems.

1)
1xxx xxxx  SET ON POWER FAIL
2)
x1xx xxxx  8751 RAM FAIL
3)
xx1x xxxx  8751 ROM CK_SUM NOT 00
4)
xxx1 xxxx  MODE2 BUFFER OVERFLOW
5)
xxxx 1xxx  EEROM TBL CK_SUM NOT 00
6)
xxxx x1xx  EEROM MALFUNCTION
7)
xxxx xx1x  MISSING OR BAD DATA
8)
xxxx xxx1  A/D REF CHNL OUT OF RANGE

1.
The power fail bit is set if the power monitor (IC-3 on CPU board) detects that the 5 V power
is less than 4.75 V or it is not being reset from the CPU.

2.
On power up, and only on power up the internal RAM of the CPU (8751) is verified as
operational. if the test fails this bit is set.

3.
On power up the ROM check sum is calculated. If in error it is marked bad in the status byte.

4.
If more than 5 commands are addressed to the 4401 before they can be serviced the input
que will overflow and will be indicated by this status bit.

5.
When a EEROM table is uploaded it's checksum is checked. If the check sum is incorrect
it will be marked in the status.

6.
When the EEROM is accessed and does not respond for any reason it will mark this
malfunction in the status byte.

7.
If downloaded data is corrupted for any reason the CPU will time out and indicate the
incorrect data count by marking the MISSING DATA bit in the status byte.

8.
The A/D self test checks the A/D reference. If it is out of range the A/D FAIL bit will be set
in the status byte.

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                            4401 WTS ORIENTATION TOOL 8.0 ANALOG TROUBLESHOOTING
chunk_text:
3





P/N 130641-956
NOVEMBER 2005 
ANALOG TROUBLESHOOTING

The analog section of the 4401 is essentially contained on the analog board (P/N 153908-000).
A second multiplexer, Voltage reference and divider is located on the analog section of the CPU
board (P/N 153910-000).

Using drawing P/N 153910-000, locate a check the following input voltages using a fluke meter.


Junction
R1, R2

+1.257 Vdc

Junction
R3, R4

+2.991 Vdc

Junction
R5, R6

-2.990 Vdc


REF output of R7
+4.799 Vdc


Using drawing P/N 153908-100 check each of the filters IC-1 through IC-6.

The filter input values correspond to the orientation sensor outputs and are in the range -4 V to +4 V.  The
output value should be within 1 millivolt of the corresponding input value. The sensor should be positioned
such that the voltage on the channel you are checking is at least 2 volts.

A/D MUX TROUBLESHOOTING

Select the single mode (Reference Drawing P/N 153908-100) of the PC test program. Select AX from the
menu. This will allow the same value to be measured at the input and output of the multiplexer IC-7. The same
value will also appear at the input and output of the sample & hold. The same value should be at the input
of the A/D IC-9, pin 14. The value measured should be displayed on the PC screen.

The second Mux (Reference drawing P/N 153910-100) can be checked in a similar manor by selecting an
analog channel such as +5 volts.

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                            4401 WTS ORIENTATION TOOL 10.0 DIGITAL TROUBLESHOOTING
chunk_text:
4





P/N 130641-956
NOVEMBER 2005 
DIGITAL TROUBLESHOOTING

CPU
(Reference drawing P/N 153910-100)

The first step in digital troubleshooting should be to verify that the CPU is powered up and in the idle loop.
This can be done by checking the following points on the CPU board.

1.
Check 5 Vdc on pin 40 of the CPU (IC-1)

2.
Check the master clock (12 mHz) from IC-2 is present on pin 19 of the CPU (Figure 956-35).

3.
Check that the CPU is not being held in reset. Pin 9 of the CPU should be low. If reset is high
or pulsing check the power monitor IC-3.



NOTE

The power monitor requires a feedback pulse from the CPU on the
WDI pin of IC-3.

4.
With no telemetry from the surface check the "Pulse" test point on the CPU board. See

5.
Select the single mode from the PC test program. Select GND0 from the menu. This will
continuously send 2 words down to the 4401 and receive a 1 word response. When telemetry
is being received by the CPU it is often not in the idle loop. This is indicated by the "Pulse"
signal having a asymmetric shape as indicated in Figure 956-2.

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                            4401 WTS ORIENTATION TOOL 11.0 INPUT DATA PATH
chunk_text:
5





P/N 130641-956
NOVEMBER 2005 
INPUT DATA PATH
(Reference drawing P/N 153909-100)

1.
Check that the two words being sent from the surface are being received by the manchester.
Check IC-4, pin 8 for a signal similar to that of Figure 956-3.

2.
If the words are decoded by the manchester correctly you will get 2 valid signals from IC-4,
pin 1 (Figure 956-5).

3.
If valid is not present check that DR is not being held low and that the decoder clock (Figure
956-29) is correct and at 250 KHz. Check other Manchester signals as required.

4.
With valid signal ok, check that two "take-data" signals (Figure 956-6) and one command
sync signal (Figure 956-9) are correct. Check that command sync is being delayed properly
(Figure 956-10). It is necessary to delay command sync such that it is extended beyond the
time where TD goes low. This is latched at IC-5, pin 5, and becomes commsync.

5.
Once VALID is detected by the CPU the CPU will issue a read strobe for the MSB, LSB,
and commsync of the word just received (Figure 956-7, 8, 11).

6.
When the instrument address is decoded by the CPU the following command will be put into
the CPU received data queue (internal RAM). Anytime a word is put into the queue it will
be signaled to the outside by a pulse on pin 5 of the CPU IC-1 (Ref. drwg P/N 153910-100).
This lets the technician know that the CPU has actually accepted data from the manchester
and shift registers.

7.
Use the manchester timing diagram (Figure 945-3) to verify that VALID and TAKE DATA
have the proper timing and that TD is gating DSC to IC-6 and IC-9 of the telemetry board.

TD should also latch the shifted data from IC-6 into IC-7 and IC-9 into IC-10.

OUTPUT DATA PATH
(Reference drawing P/N 153909-100)

With the surface simulator requesting the single A/D channel GND0 the 4401 instrument should be
returning one word to the surface (Figure 956-4).

1.
The CPU sends data by putting two 8 bit bytes of data onto the data bus and enables the
manchester.

2.
Check the data bus dbus0 through dbus7 for normal bus signature. Similar to Figure 956-32

typical rise time is 5 Micro sec.

3.
The CPU first writes to IC-8 (MSB Figure 956-12) then IC-11 (LSB Figure 956-13).

4.
WLSB also sets encoder enable (Figure 956-14) via the latch at IC-5. Once the manchester
starts SD (Figure 956-15) resets IC-3 and holds SB (Figure 956-16) active until the word

is sent.

5.
If multiple words are to be sent the output cycle starts over again.

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                            4401 WTS ORIENTATION TOOL 13.0 A/D CYCLE
chunk_text:
6





P/N 130641-956
NOVEMBER 2005 
A/D CYCLE
(Reference drawing P/N 153908-100)

With the surface simulator requesting the single A/D channel GND0 the 4401 instrument should be
returning one word to the surface (Figure 956-4).

1.
Check the A/D start pulse IC-9, pin 1 (Figure 956-18) on the analog board.

2.
Check the A/D clock for its relative timing IC-9, pin 24 (Figure 956-19), length (Figure
956-20) and shape (Figure 956-21).

3.
Check the output serial stream of the A/D IC-9, pin 3 (Figure 956-22).

4.
Check timing of the hold signal IC-4, pin 8 (Figure 956-23).

5.
Check that the Mux address corresponds to that selected.

LAB HEAT TEST PROCEDURES - 4401 WTS ORIENTATION TOOL
P/N 130641-959 
SEPTEMBER 1998
WTS ORIENTATION HEAT TEST
1. 
Restrict temperature to
0 to 200 deg C (maximum 1 hour) *
Maximum heating/cooling rate 5 deg C per min.
* NOTE
TEMP is the sensor temperature inside the flask.  It should NOT
EXCEED  70 deg C at any time.  The expected flask temperature rise
should be less than 10 deg C per hour.  DO NOT OPERATE
INSTRUMENT ON THE BENCH FOR EXTENDED PERIODS.
2. 
Remove Electronics from housing (ref section -955).
3. 
Place electronics complete with flask installed into oven.  Position instrument such that the top
black block exits the oven at one end.  Connect the instrument to a WTS test system.
4. 
Power up the instrument with 180 Vac.
5. 
Using the WTS Test Program (P/N 156616), continuously monitor the following parameters for any
abnormal change as the instrument heats up.  The sensor outputs Ax, Ay, Az, Mx, My, Mz will
vary during the heat test as the oven expands.  This is normal.  If sensor problems are suspected
refer to level 3 maintenance (section -953).
+ 5 Vdc
+12 Vdc
-12 Vdc
REF Vdc
TEMP deg C
Ax Vdc
Ay Vdc
Az Vdc
Mx Vdc
My Vdc
Mz Vdc
6. 
Start increasing the oven temperature.
7. 
Allow the electronics to cool.
8. 
Clean the inside of the housing with dry rags.  The sensor measures the earths magnetic field.  Be
careful to keep any magnetic particles (metal filings etc.) from sticking to the housing or any part of
the electronics.
9. 
Reassemble the electronics into the housing.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE LEVEL 3 - 4401 WTS ORIENTATION TOOL 1.0 GENERAL
chunk_text:
1

P/N 130641-953
SEPTEMBER 1998 1.0  GENERAL
1.
Remove electronics package & flask from housing as per section 955.
2.
Remove flask.
3.
Inspect the electronics for loose screws, pinched wires, cold solder joints, loose or broken
components, etc.
NOTE
If any of the following measurements are not within the recommended
tolerances, refer to section 956 for repair and adjustment.
4.
Connect the instrument to a WTS bus running software (PC based system or CLS).  Power up the
instrument with 180 Vac. Current should be less than 50 mA (without line).
5.
Check the +5 V, +12 V and -12 V power supplies for proper voltage within ±100mv
100mv (power bus on main chassis).
6.
Check the A/D voltage reference for a precise 4.799 Vdc at the REF terminal on the CPU
board (±2mv).
7.
Using a computer system acquire Sensor temperature. Compare it to ambient Sensor
temperature.
8.
Record Readings on Level 3 Preventive Maintenance Checklist.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE LEVEL 3 - 4401 WTS ORIENTATION TOOL 2.0 ORIENTATION CHECK
chunk_text:
2

P/N 130641-953
SEPTEMBER 1998 2.0  ORIENTATION CHECK
1.
Remove the tensor module form the main chassis (see section -955).
2.
Set up orientation test stand (P/N 089670-000) in a magnetically clear environment (at least
20 feet from all metal).
3.
Install the tensor into its test stand  and connect with umbilical cable (P/N 132302-000)
4.
Record value of quality check QA, and QM.
QA COMMAND
Using the command QA the vector sum of the 3 accelerometers will be displayed.  An acceptable
answer is 1000 milli-G's plus/minus 10 and should be read when the instrument is not moving.
This check can be done any time in the hole or on the catwalk.
QM COMMAND
Using the command QM the angle of the local magnetic dip of the earths field as calculated from
the 3 magnetometers will be displayed.  Contact your local LAC for the dip angle of your particular
longitude and latitude.  For example, the local magnetic dip for Houston 1989 is displayed as 59.8
degrees plus/minus 3.0.  This check can only be done in a magnetically clean environment.  It is not
valid on the catwalk, in casing or at the shop in a metal building, etc.
5.
Set test stand to select values of deviation, azimuth, and drift azimuth (DEV stops 0,1,9 deg
AZ, DAZ stops every 15 deg). Verify that computed value is the same as the physical
position of the sensor. Record maximum error on check sheet.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 3.0 MAGNETISM CHECK 4.0 REASSEMBLE INSTRUMENT
chunk_text:
3.0  MAGNETISM CHECK
Refer to Magnetic Properties Check for 1016 EA (Specification Sheet 059443) in Section -975 of this
document. 4.0  REASSEMBLE INSTRUMENT
1.
Reassemble the tool.  Use Loctite 242 each time that you replace a screw in its original position.
2.
Calibrate the tool and keep a record of the calibration.

INTRODUCTION


The 4430 XB Downhole Power Adapter is designed to provide large amounts of power (current)

for tool strings that demand it.  The 4430 XB provides 180 VAC and approximately 1.8 amps

for the STAR Imager tool string.  It can also be used in any tool string that uses 180 VAC and


consumes a maximum of 2.3 amps  of current.


The 4430 XB Downhole Power Adapter is made up of 3 transformers with the primary windings

wired in parallel and the secondary windings wired in parallel.  The three transformers wired in

parallel are designed to provide a 180 VAC output and a maximum current of 2.3 amps with

a 420 VAC input.


NOTE:

The cablehead voltage (CHV) recorded at the surface will be 180 VAC, (the voltage seen
at the bottom of the 4430 XB) while the voltage at the top of the 4430 XB will read 420 VAC.
A surface current meter will indicate 2.3 times less than at the bottom of the 4430 XB.


The 4430 XB Downhole Power Adapter must be the first tool in the tool string (i.e. attached

to the cablehead). If any tool is put between the cablehead and the 4430 XB, severe damage

to the tool can occur due to the 420 VAC at the cablehead.

INTRODUCTION


The 4430 XB Downhole Power Adapter is configured in one section, with a 10 pin female connector

on the uphole end and a 10 pin male connector on the downhole end.


NOTE:

DO NOT REPLACE THE 10-PIN CONNECTOR WITH A 28 PIN CONNECTOR.
THE 10-PIN CONNECTOR IS USED TO ASSURE THAT THE 4430 XB DPA CAN
ONLY BE CONNECTED DIRECTLY TO THE CABLEHEAD.

topic: Mechanical Description - 2.0 REFERENCE DRAWINGS 3.0 CHASSIS TRANSFORMER ASSEMBLY
chunk_text:
REFERENCE DRAWINGS


Related assembly drawings:


P/N
DESCRIPTION
191653-000
INSTRUMENT 4430 XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER MODULE
191655-000
CHASSIS, ASSY TRANSFORMER 4430 XB DPA 
CHASSIS TRANSFORMER ASSEMBLY

(Reference drawing P/N 191655-000)


The 4430 XB Downhole Power Adapter chassis transformer assembly consists of three transformers



wired in parallel and mounted inside a clam-shell aluminum chassis.  Terminals are provided to

connect the three transformer primaries in parallel and connect them to the uphole connector. The

terminals are provided to connect the three transformer secondaries in parallel and connect them to

the downhole connector.  The remaining 8 conductors are fed through the uphole connector to the

downhole connector via a channel in the chassis.


The clamshell aluminum chassis design contains rollers to facilitate the instrument assembly

installation and removal into the instrument housing.

1

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION                                        4430 XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER



CONFIDENTIAL                                  P/N 130786-945                                 NOVEMBER 2005



Title
Page 
INTRODUCTION

The 4430 XB Electronics includes the following Reference Drawings:


P/N
DESCRIPTION
191655-000
CHASSIS, ASSY TRANSFORMER 4430 XB DPA
191653-100
WIRING DIAGRAM, INSTRUMENT 4430 XB


A circuit description of this assembly is given in the following sections.

ELECTRONICS DESCRIPTION
(Reference drawings 191655-000 and 191653-100)


The 4430 XB houses three transformers in an aluminum clam-shell chassis.  The three transformers

are wired in parallel via terminals.  The primaries of the three transformers (T1, T2, and T3) are

connected in parallel to wireline conductors 1 and 4 on the uphole end of the tool, which are also

connected to pins A and D of the 10 pin connector J1.  The secondaries of the three transformers are

connected in parallel to wireline conductors 1 and 4 on the downhole end of the tool, which are also

connected to pins F and J of the 10 pin connector J2.  The center taps of the three transformers

on the line side are connected together and connected to downhole pin 9. The secondary are

connected together and left floating.


The feed-thru Conductors are 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10.


The transformers are designed for an input voltage of 420 VAC which produces an output voltage

of 180 VAC. An input voltage of 420 VAC across J1 pins A and D produces an output voltage of

180 VAC across J2 pins F and J.


To determine the output current (current at the bottom of the 4430 XB) read the surface current from

the AC supply and multiply by 2.3.  The maximum input current to the 4430 XB is 1 amp which

produces 2.3 amps output.

DC RESISTANCE
(Reference drawings 191655-000 and 191653-100)


The primary DC resistance of the three parallel transformers can be measured across pins A and

D of the 10 pin connector J1.  The DC resistance should be approximately 7.7 Ω.


The secondary DC resistance of the three parallel transformers can be measured across pins F

and J of the 10 pin connector J2.  The DC resistance should be approximately 2.1 Ω.

WARNINGS

DO NOT REPLACE THE 10-PIN CONNECTOR WITH A 28 PIN CONNECTOR.
THE 10-PIN CONNECTOR IS USED TO ASSURE THAT THE 4430 XB DPA CAN
ONLY BE CONNECTED DIRECTLY TO THE CABLEHEAD.


CABLEHEAD VOLTAGE RECORDED AT THE SURFACE WILL BE 180 VAC,

(THE VOLTAGE SEEN AT THE BOTTOM OF THE 4430 XB) WHILE THE VOLTAGE

AT THE TOP OF THE 4430 XB WILL READ 420 VAC.  A SURFACE CURRENT METER

WILL INDICATE  2.3 TIMES LESS THAN AT THE BOTTOM OF THE 4430 XB.

THE 4430 XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER MUST BE THE FIRST TOOL IN THE
TOOL STRING (I.E. ATTACHED TO THE CABLEHEAD).  IF ANY TOOL IS PUT
BETWEEN THE CABLEHEAD AND THE 4430 XB IT COULD BE SEVERELY
DAMAGED DUE TO THE 420 VAC AT THE CABLEHEAD.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION                                        4430XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION                                        4430XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER
chunk_text:

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION                                        4430 XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION                                        4430 XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER



CONFIDENTIAL                                  P/N 130786-945                                 NOVEMBER 2005




Since the center taps of the three transformers (primary and secondary) are connected together, the

primary to secondary DC resistance of the three parallel transformers can be measured from pin A

of the 10 pin connector J1 to pin J of the 10 pin connector J2.  The DC resistance should be

approximately 5.1 Ω.

ASSORTED ALLEN WRENCHES AND SCREWDRIVERS 

Transformer Chassis Assembly
Refer to drawing F191655000

1.
While supporting the transformer top chassis assembly (item 7), carefully position the transformer
bottom chassis assembly (item 13) over the top chassis assembly so that the pins on the bottom
chassis assembly align with the holes on the top chassis assembly.  Be careful not to pinch any
wiring, compress the top and bottom chassis together until they meet.

2.
Attach with twelve #1/4 - 20 socket head cap screws (item 25). Use loctite (P/N 244147) on the
screw threads.

Assembly of Lower Downhole Power Adapter
Refer to drawing F191653000

1.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) o-ring grooves on the lower downhole power adapter (item 12), and then
install o-rings (item 3).

2.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) the threads on the downhole end of the downhole power adapter (item 12).

3.
Thread collar (item 14) onto the bottom sub (item 12) making certain to match the threads of collar
and sub.  Allow 1/8 inch space between collar and sub after the collar has been fully threaded onto
the sub.

Assembly of Wireline Telemetry Top Sub
Refer to drawing F191653000

1.
Install the thermal expansion unit into the WTS Top Sub by first sliding the spring (item 8) into

the top sub (item 7).

2.
Next set the travel sleeve (item 5) into the center of the spring.

3.
The retainer ring (item 4) hole pattern allows for installation in one alignment configuration only.

Set the retainer ring over the travel sleeve with the countersunk holes facing upward.

4.
While compressing the spring, install the 3-flat head socket screws (item 9) to secure the retaining
ring. Use loctite (P/N 244147) on the screw threads.

5.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) the o-ring grooves on both ends of the WTS Top Sub (item 7).  Install both
o-rings (item 2) onto the uphole end of the top sub.  Install the o-rings (item 3) onto the other end.

ASSEMBLY of LOWER DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER SUB3 

INSTALLATION of CHASSIS into PRESSURE HOUSING 4

Removal of Chassis from Pressure Housing
Refer to drawing F191653000

1.
Remove the thread protectors (items 15 and 16) from both ends of the pressure housing.

2.
Remove the retainer clip (item 1) from the lower downhole power adapter sub (item 12).

3.
Remove the center pin from the lower downhole power adapter sub 10-pin block (item 13).

4.
Remove the 10-pin block (item 13) with a #10-32 T-handle puller (P/N 078902).  Disconnect

the black block from the pigtail.

5.
Remove the retainer clip (item 1) from the WTS Top Sub (item 7).

6.
Remove the 10-pin block (item 6) with a #10-32 T-handle puller (P/N 078902).  Disconnect the

black block from the pigtail.

7.
Secure the pressure housing (item 10) with a strap wrench.  Unscrew the WTS Top Sub (item 7)

with an open-end wrench.

8.
Screw a 20 T-handle puller (P/N 056036) into the upper sub downhole power adapter.  Slide

the electronics (item 11) out of the pressure housing.

Transformer Chassis Disassembly
Refer to drawing F191655000

1.
Remove the twelve #1/4 - 20 socket head cap screws (item 25).

Remove the 4 screws (Item 28) See section E-E of reference drawing F191655000

2.
While supporting the transformer top chassis assembly (item 7), carefully remove the transformer
bottom chassis assembly (item 13) from the top chassis assembly using a flat blade screw driver
being careful not to pinch any wiring.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly - ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 4430XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER    130786-955 ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 4430XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER    130786-955
chunk_text:
3

ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 4430 XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER    130786-955 4

ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 4430 XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER    130786-955

Installation of Chassis into Pressure Housing
Refer to drawing F191653000


Thus far, the subs are assembled and the threads lubricated as described in Section 4.2 and

Section 4.3.

1.
Secure the pressure housing (item 10) with a strap wrench.  Then, install the Lower Downhole

Power Adapter Sub (item 12) using a pin wrench to rotate the sub.

2.
Orient the key on the Lower Downhole Power Adapter Sub (item 12) in an up position for
installation of the electronics assembly.

3.
Insert the chassis (item 11) into the pressure housing (item 10) with the keyed snout entering first.
Do not pinch the lower pigtail.  Guide the lower pigtail through the lower downhole power adapter
sub (item 12) as the chassis is being inserted.  Connect the 10-pin connector (item 13) to the
connector on the end of the lower pigtail to keep the pigtail from recoiling back into the pressure
housing.

4.
The instrument electronics are now resting against the bottom of the housing.  Screw in the 20
T-handle puller (P/N 056036) into the upper sub downhole power adapter.  Rotate the chassis while
pushing inward until it keys-up with the bottom sub.  Push firmly on the assembly to ensure proper
seating.

5.
Begin top sub installation.  First feed the pigtail of the electronics assembly through the throat

of the WTS Top Sub (item 7).

6.
Hold the pigtail with slight tension while screwing the top sub into the pressure housing.

7.
Connect the 10-pin black block (item 6) to the pigtail.  Carefully, twist it back into the throat of

the WTS Top Sub while seating the block into the sub itself.

8.
Seat the retainer clip (item 1) into the lock ring groove to secure the black block.

9.
On the downhole end connect the 10-pin black block (item 13) to the pigtail.  Carefully, twist it
back into the throat of the lower downhole power adapter sub while seating the block into the sub
itself.

10.
Seat the retainer clip (item 1) into the lock ring groove to secure the black block.

11.
Lubricate (P/N 205933) the o-ring groove on the bottom sub thread protector (item 15).  Install

a single o-ring (item 2) onto the sub.

12.
Install thread protectors for the top sub (item 16) and the bottom sub (item 15) to protect and aid

in handling of the instrument.

topic: Lab Safety - LAB SAFETY                                                            4430XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER 1.1 HIGH VOLTAGES
chunk_text:
2

LAB SAFETY                                                            4430 XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER



CONFIDENTIAL                                   P/N 130786-954                               NOVEMBER 2005 
HIGH VOLTAGES


When the instrument is powered-up outside of the housing care is taken to avoid a HIGH VOLTAGE

shock from the following points (Reference drawing P/N 191653-000 and P/N 191653-100).


TERMINALS 1 & 2

Have 420 VAC across them.


TERMINALS 1 & 4

Have 420 VAC across them.


TERMINALS 3 & 2

Have 420 VAC across them.


TERMINALS 3 & 4

Have 420 VAC across them.


TERMINALS 7 & 8

Have 180 VAC across them.


TERMINALS 7 & 12

Have 180 VAC across them.


TERMINALS 11 & 8

Have 180 VAC across them.


TERMINALS 11 & 12
Have 180 VAC across them.


J1 PINS A & D

Have 420 VAC across them.


J2 PINS F & J

Have 180 VAC across them.

WARNINGS

DO NOT REPLACE THE 10-PIN CONNECTOR WITH A 28 PIN CONNECTOR.
THE 10-PIN CONNECTOR IS USED TO ASSURE THAT THE 4430 XB DPA CAN
ONLY BE CONNECTED DIRECTLY TO THE CABLEHEAD.


THE CABLEHEAD VOLTAGE RECORDED AT THE SURFACE WILL BE 180 VAC,

(THE VOLTAGE SEEN AT THE BOTTOM OF THE 4430 XB) WHILE THE VOLTAGE

AT THE TOP OF THE 4430 XB WILL READ 420 VAC. A SURFACE CURRENT METER

WILL INDICATE 2.3 TIMES LESS THAN AT THE BOTTOM OF THE 4430 XB.

THE 4430 XB DOWNHOLE POWER ADAPTER MUST BE THE FIRST TOOL IN THE
TOOL STRING (I.E. ATTACHED TO THE CABLEHEAD).  IF ANY TOOL IS PUT
BETWEEN THE CABLEHEAD AND THE 4430 XB IT COULD BE SEVERELY
DAMAGED DUE TO THE 420 VAC AT THE CABLEHEAD.

With thread protectors in place, thoroughly clean housing.

pins, worn or damaged sockets and deformed retaining rings. Ensure top and

gauge over banana pins and turn clockwise to ensure tightness. 
______ 
8. 
Remove used O-rings from uphole end of tool with brass O-ring extractor tool. Cut 
and discard used O-rings. Clean O-ring grooves with solvent. Inspect 0-ring grooves 
for dust, dirt, scratches; pitting, or corrosion. They shall not have any damage or 
condition which can cause seal failure. Apply Lubriplate 930 AA in O-ring grooves. 
______ 
9. 
Inspect new O-rings for defects and then apply a light coating of Lubriplate 930 AA 
around O-rings then install O-rings on top sub. 
______ 
10. 
Check that all subs are torqued to prevent accidental “backing off”. The timing marks 
on the Top and/or Bottom Sub should be close to or go past the Pressure Housing 
timing mark.  Do NOT back off sub to make alignment marks match !!! 
______

topic: Lab Safety - 1.0 INTRODUCTION 1.1 ELECTRICAL SAFETY PRECAUTIONS
chunk_text:
INTRODUCTION
The following safety guidelines apply to the 4490 XA HTHP Orientation Sub. 
ELECTRICAL SAFETY PRECAUTIONS



Possible death or serious injury
Risk of high-voltage shock
•
Turn off power when not required
•
Post appropriate warning signs
•
Avoid distractions while working on equipment with
power applied


When the instrument is powered-up outside of the housing, care must be taken to avoid a
HIGH VOLTAGE shock from the following points (Reference drawing F153892100.)
Flask Connector board F143328000
•
Terminal T3 to T23 = 180 Vac
Backbone Electronics Chassis
•
Terminal posts between transformers T1 and T2 = 180 Vac

GENERAL SAFETY GUIDELINES
Follow the general safety guidelines listed below when handling the 4490 XA.
•
Observe proper lifting techniques when handling this instrument.
•
Thread protectors should always be installed when transporting or handling the tool.
•
Steel-toe shoes must be worn while handling the tool assembly.
•
Wear safety glasses when soldering
•
Where static-guard wristbands when working around electronics

+5 V POWER SUPPLY 3

±12 V POWER SUPPLY 4

POWER SUPPLY CIRCUITRY
Three power supplies provide the necessary operating voltages for the 4490 XA
electronics.
The ±12 V supply provides power to circuits on: the analog board (A3002088000), the
orientation module (F119500000), and the analog section of the CPU board
(A3001307000).
The 5 V power supply provides power to the CPU, Telemetry, and A/D boards.

+5 V POWER SUPPLY
Refer to schematic F153911100.
The pink and tan windings of the transformer (T2) supply approximately 12 Vac to
bridge rectifier BR2. The resulting DC voltage is filtered by C6 and input to the 5-volt
regulator. The regulator output is delivered to the 5-volt bus. Noise immunity for the
regulator is provided by C5. Refer to Figure 1.



4
4490 XA HTHP WTS Orientation Sub – Circuit Descriptions
131021-945 / 4490 XA

±12 V POWER SUPPLY
Refer to schematic F153911100.
Approximately 40 Vac from transformer T1 is supplied to bridge rectifier BR1,
resulting in +22 Vdc being delivered to the filter comprised of C1, L1, (mounted on
backbone), and C1 (on filter board F153911000). Similarly, -22 Vdc is filtered by
C2, L2 (backbone), and C2 (on filter board). These unregulated positive and negative
voltages are fed to there respective regulators. Capacitors C3 and C4 are used for
regulator stabilization. Refer to Figure 2.



5
4490 XA HTHP WTS Orientation Sub – Circuit Descriptions
131021-945 / 4490 XA
NOVEMBER 2009
Baker Atlas

CPU BOARD
Refer to schematic A3001307 SCH.
The CPU board contains two independent sections.
The Analog section is electrically isolated from the digital section and it is made up of U7
and U8. The multiplexer (U7) is paralleled with the Mux on the A/D board. This multiplexer
selects signals from the flask temperature and power supplies. The Analog section also
contains a 10 volt precision voltage source (U8). The voltage source is divided by R7 to a
precise 4799 mV and transferred to the main analog board to be used as a scale reference.
The digital section of the CPU board performs as follows:
U2 is the main oscillator supplying a 12 MHz clock to the CPU. U3 is a power-on reset
circuit that releases the CPU for operation when the 5 V supply exceeds 4.5 volts. U4 is a
serial EEROM that stores the tool asset number. This EEROM is wired for serial address 2
and is parallel via SCL and SDA with an identical part (address 0) embedded within the
sensor module.
U1 is a Intel 87 C51 Micro Controller incorporating RAM, EPROM, and I/O into a single 40-
pin DIP. I/O is divided between the 4 ports on the micro-controller are as follows:
Port 0
Port 0 emulates a bi-directional 8-bit data bus. U6 provides pull-up resistors for
the open drain outputs of port 0. The data bus leaves the CPU board via a 16-
conductor cable plugged into connector H1. The data bus goes directly to the
telemetry board and nowhere else. Read / Write control originates from port 2
and also leaves the CPU board to the telemetry board via H1.
Port 1 1. Supplies the A/D and sample/hold control signals, hold, start, and serial data bit.

2. Supplies the clock for the serial EEROM (SCL) and the bi-directional data bit
(SDA).

3. Also senses communication sync type (command/data) from the telemetry board.
Port 2
Port 2 supplies the 4-bit address used to control the 16-channel multiplexer.
These signals leave the CPU board and are routed to the analog board via 16-
conductor cable at H2.
Port 3 1. Supplies a watchdog reset bit to U3 (WDI).

2. Senses when the send buffer on the telemetry board is full.

3. Senses and generates a system interrupt when a valid word is received by the
telemetry board.
RXD
Pin 10 is configured as a digital input. When connected to ground subset 0 and F
are re-configured to provide both the internal and external flask temperature.

4490 XA HTHP WTS Orientation Sub – Circuit Descriptions
131021-945 / 4490 XA
NOVEMBER 2009
Baker Atlas

TELEMETRY BOARD
Refer to schematic F153909100.
The telemetry board contains a bus driver IC1, T1 and bus receiver IC2, T2. Manchester
IC4 encodes and decodes the serial data as it enters and leaves the board. IC12 is the 4
MHz telemetry oscillator. IC13 divides the oscillator to the correct Manchester
frequencies. IC3 is a latch that is set to start the encoder for a send transaction. Two
sections of buffer IC5 receive sync type. IC8 and IC11 form the send buffer. IC6, IC9,
IC7, and IC10 form the double buffer receive section.

SEND TRANSACTIONS
To send a word from the micro controller onto the instrument bus the following
transactions will occur. The MSB of the word being sent will be put onto the data bus.
Write MSB (WMSB) will pulse low (2 µs) to latch the data into IC8. The LSB of the
word to send will be put on the data bus. Write LSB (WLSB) will be pulsed low (2 µs) to
latch the data into IC11. WLSB also sets latch Q of IC3 and resets Q/ of IC3. Q/ of IC3
immediately sets send busy (SB) IC15 pin 8 indicating to the controller that telemetry is
now busy sending data. Q of IC3 sets encoder enable (EE) of the Manchester, which
initiates a send sequence. The Manchester begins sending sync to IC1 and to the
instrument bus. When the Manchester is ready to send the 16 bits of data previously
stored in shift registers IC8 and IC11 SD of IC4 goes high. SD going high does four
things.
1. IC15 is held busy independently of IC3.
2. IC3 clocks a low onto the Q output releasing EE. Q/ of IC3 releases pre-busy on pin
10 of IC15. SB remains in the busy state via IC15 pin 9.
3. SD at pin 1 of IC14 allows the encoder shift clock (ESC) to pass to the clock inputs
of shift registers IC8 and IC11. SD is connected to DR (Decoder Root).
4. SD going high resets the Manchester decoder effectively locking out all received
signals. When the16 data bits have been shifted out, SD goes low releasing send busy
(SB), which completes the send sequence.


7
4490 XA HTHP WTS Orientation Sub – Circuit Descriptions
131021-945 / 4490 XA
NOVEMBER 2009
Baker Atlas

RECEIVE TRANSACTIONS
Refer to schematic F153909100 and Figure 3.
When the 4401 is receiving a word on the instrument bus the following transactions
occur. As the word is received on the instrument bus it is transferred through T2 and IC2
to the UDI input of IC4. The sync type of the received word is determined and reflected
onto the CDS pin of I-4. At this point IC4 is ready to shift out serial data on the SDO pin
and indicates this by raising take data (TD). TD allows the DSC through IC14 to clock
the serial data stream into shift registers IC9 and IC6. The DSC is also clocking CDS into
IC5 effectively delaying CDS by one DSC clock cycle. When 16 bits have been shifted
in, TD goes low. TD going low latches the last value of CDS into IC5 pin 5. TD also
transfers the contents of shift registers IC6 and IC9 into tri-state latches IC7 and IC10.
The received word is now complete, the Manchester IC4 checks the parity bit on the
word just received, and if correct, it signals valid word (VW) on pin 1. VW is inverted,
and then leaves the telemetry board via J1 to the CPU. VW causes an interrupt at the
CPU. The word just received is read a byte at a time from IC7 and IC10 by the CPU
strobing RMSB and RLSB.

Note: If the CPU is busy it can take up to 500 microseconds between VW interrupt and when the

4490 XA HTHP WTS Orientation Sub – Circuit Descriptions
131021-945 / 4490 XA
NOVEMBER 2009
Baker Atlas

ANALOG BOARD
Refer to schematic A3002088 SCH and Figure 4.
The analog board contains six vector filters, multiplexer, sample-hold, and analog-to-
digital converter.

FILTERS
The outputs of accelerometers AX, AY, AZ and magnetometers MX, MY, MZ found in
orientation module F119500000 pass through the six channel filters (Figure 4) before
entering the 8-channel analog multiplexer. Filters designated U1 A through U6 A are
identical and have a cut-off frequency of 0.2 Hz. Each of the six filters has a gain of 1
(one) and is non-inverting.
Outputs from the orientation module depend on the earth's gravitational pull and
magnetic field present at the module. The module is scaled 3 volts/g for the
accelerometers and 8 volts/gauss for the magnetometers.



A/D SYSTEM
Refer to schematic A3002088 SCH.
Multiplexer U8 selects one of the six orientation vectors ground or scale reference. Mux
channel selection (channel 0-7) originates at the CPU and enters the analog board via a
16 conductor ribbon cable at J1. The Mux output is paralleled with an identical Mux on
the CPU board, connected via the MX2 terminal.
The output of the Mux is fed into buffer U7 A then into Vin of the A/D U9. U9 contains
an integral trac and hold to capture the selected signal while conversion takes place. All
timing originates at the CPU.

Note: The A/D clock only operates during an acquisition cycle and is OFF otherwise.



9
4490 XA HTHP WTS Orientation Sub – Circuit Descriptions
131021-945 / 4490 XA
NOVEMBER 2009
Baker Atlas

Data acquisition follows this sequence.
1. The A/D clock is started (20 µs clock).
2. Mux channel is set into IC-8 via MUX0 - MUX3.
3. A/D START.
4. 12 data bits are clocked out ADAT to the CPU.
5. A/D clock stopped.
There is NO offset or scale adjustment. When operating under WTS protocol requesting
SUBSET data causes the CPU to sample Mux channel 0 (S1 ground) and Mux channel 7
(S8 REF). The ground offset is subtracted from each of the sampled channels. No
additional offset correction is required. The REF standard (4799 mV) is sent uphole as an
entry in the subset table and is applied via the surface software to make any necessary
scale corrections.

A/D SYSTEM 8 

TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT
Refer to drawings A3001281000, A3001282 WRD, A3001301000, and Figure 5.
Three temperature sensors, two active and one passive, are located in the 4490 XA. The
electronics flask internal temperature (Zone 1) is monitored by a temperature sensor
located inside the Tensor orientation module (F119500000).  The temperature outside the
electronics flask yet inside the housing flask (Zone 2) is monitored by RTD1000 located
on the power supply chassis (F153880000). Both of these temperatures are read and sent
to the surface while logging.
The third temperature sensor RTD100 is also located inside the housing flask (Zone 2) on
the power supply chassis in close proximity to RTD1000 and is connected to top sub pins
22 & 24 via flask cable A3001281000. This “passive” arrangement is read by connecting
a hand held meter to the top sub. The purpose of this measurement is to provide the
operator with the internal temperature so he can determine if the temperature is low
enough that the housing can be safely removed. Zone 3 temperature is exposed directly to

4490 XA HTHP WTS Orientation Sub – Circuit Descriptions
131021-945 / 4490 XA
NOVEMBER 2009
Baker Atlas

TEMPERATURE BOARD 10


FIGURES
±12 V Power Supply Schematic4
Sample Channel Filter 8


2
4490 XA HTHP WTS Orientation Sub – Circuit Descriptions
131021-945 / 4490 XA
NOVEMBER 2009
Baker Atlas
CIRCUIT OVERVIEW
The 4490 XA Orientation Sub is a general purpose borehole orientation instrument. It
continuously establishes the position of a tool string with respect to vertical and magnetic
north. It provides digital acquisition of three orthogonal accelerometers, three orthogonal
magnetometers, and temperature which comprises the sensor package. Additionally, several
in-circuit quality control points are monitored and reflected by the instrument status.. The
instrument returns data to the surface using the standard WTS communication protocol and
operates only on mode 2.
The 4490 XA instrument is similar in function and design to the 4401 XB orientation but is
rated for higher temperatures and pressures. The electronics and sensor are packaged within a
flasked pressure housing with the addition of both active and passive temperature sensors to
provide real time monitoring of the electronics environment and provide estimates of
remaining operating time down hole.
The 4490 XA is composed of six circuit categories:
•
Power Supply
•
CPU5
•
Telemetry
•
A/D Reference
•
Vector Filter
•
Temperature Monitoring
The instrument requires +5 volts and ±12 volts, both supplied by the power supply section.
The power supply is located on the main chassis.
The 4490 XA operates as a demand-response system that uses WTS mode 2 protocol.
Telemetry encoding, decoding, line drivers, and receivers are located on the telemetry board
(F153909000) on the main chassis.
The Analog board (within the heat flask) filters, multiplexes, and digitizes the six sensor
vector outputs.
The CPU (within the heat flask) controls the instrument functions of telemetry, analog
acquisition, and tool address decoding.



3
4490 XA HTHP WTS Orientation Sub – Circuit Descriptions
131021-945 / 4490 XA

TEMPERATURE BOARD
Refer to drawing A3000853000 and schematic diagram A3000853 SCH.
The purpose of this board is to convert the temperature sensed by RTD2 located on the
power supply chassis to a voltage. This voltage is supplied to a mux-A/D located on the
T2 communications board to be digitized and sent to the surface.
This board is powered from 24 Vdc supplied to terminal VIN. This 24 V is regulated down
to 5.1 Vdc by R1 and Zener D1. The resulting voltage is the supply for op amp U2 and
reference U3. Temperature sensor RTD2, a platinum 1000 ohm RTD is connected via
terminals Temp+ and Temp-. U3 provides a fixed voltage reference of 4.096 volts to the
input of U2 B, a voltage to current conversion circuit. The current supplied to the load
(RTD2) is IL = Vi/R3 or I=4.096/10k = 0.4096 ma. This current in conjunction with
RTD2 generates a voltage proportional to temperature. IC UB2 amplifies TEMP+ input
voltage by a factor equal to 5
5

to produce the output voltage VRTD. All PC Board terminals are protected by limiting
Zener diodes. (Note: Condition: RTD sensor’s resistance is much less than (R8+R9)).

INTRODUCTION
Refer to the Temperature Testing section of Manufacturing Test Procedure document
F131021856, located in this manual, for 4490 XA temperature testing procedure.

GENERAL
____  1.
Remove electronics package and flask from housing as per the manufacturing
assembly procedure F131021855.
____  2.
Remove flask.

Note: Dedicated Flask P/N A1007510000  (HOUSING, FLASK 30-KPSI, NON-MAG INNER
TUBE) should be used exclusively with the 4490 XA.

____  3.
Inspect the electronics for loose screws, pinched wires, cold solder joints, loose
or broken components, etc.

Note: If any of the following measurements are not within the recommended tolerances, refer to
Manufacturing Test Procedure F131021856 for repair and adjustment.


____  4.
Connect the instrument to a WTS bus running software (PC based system or
CLS). Power up the instrument with 180 Vac. Current should be less than 50 mA
(without line).
____  5.
Check the +5 V, +12 V and -12 V power supplies for proper voltage within ±100
mV (power bus on main chassis).
____  6.
Check the A/D voltage reference for a precise 4.799 Vdc at the REF terminal on
the CPU board (±2 mV).
____  7.
Using a computer system acquire Sensor temperature. Compare it to ambient
Sensor temperature.
____  8.
Record all Readings on Level 3 Preventive Maintenance Checklist.

GENERAL
4. Voltage 180 Vac, Current 50 mA
5. +5 V _____________ ( ±100 mV)
Ripple __________ < 50 mV

+12 V ____________ (±100 mV)
Ripple __________ < 5 mV

-12 V _____________ (±100mV)
Ripple __________ < 5 mV
6. REF V ____________ ( 4.799 Vdc ±100 mV)
7. Compare sensor temperature against ambient temperature. Sensor temp should match
ambient within ±5 degrees. ______(�)

ORIENTATION CHECK
____  1.
Remove the sensor module form the main chassis (see F131021855).
____  2.
Set up orientation test stand (P/N F089670000) in a magnetically clear
environment (at least 20 feet from all metal).
____  3.
Install the sensor into its test stand and connect with umbilical cable (P/N
F132302000)

2
4490 XA HTHP WTS Orientation Instrument – Level 3 PM – 131021-953
131021-953
REV A
____  4.
Record value of quality check QA and QM.
a. QA Command – Using the command QA, the vector sum of the 3
accelerometers will be displayed. An acceptable answer is 1.00 milli-G's ±10
milli-G's and should be read when the instrument is not moving. This check
can be done any time in the hole or on the catwalk.
b. QM Command – Using the command QM, the angle of the local magnetic
dip of the Earth’s field as calculated from the three magnetometers will be
displayed. Contact your local LAC for the dip angle of your particular
longitude and latitude. For example, the local magnetic dip for Houston is
1989 and is displayed as 59.8º ±3.0º. This check can only be done in a
magnetically clean environment. It is not valid on the catwalk, in casing or at
the shop in a metal building, etc


____  5.
Set test stand to select values of deviation, azimuth, and drift azimuth (DEV
stops 0º,1º,9º AZ, DAZ stops every 15º). Verify that computed value is the same
as the physical position of the sensor. Record maximum error on check sheet.

ORIENTATION CHECK
4. Record value of quality check QA and QM.
a. QA Command_________(±10 milli g)
b. QM Command_________(±3 degrees)
5. Set test stand to select values of deviation, azimuth, and drift azimuth (DEV stops 0,1,9
deg AZ, DAZ stops every 15 deg). Verify that computed value is the same as the physical
position of the sensor.
DEV ___________ (±0.25 deg)
AZ ___________ (±1.5 deg)
DAZ ___________ (±1.5 deg @ dev > 10)

REASSEMBLE INSTRUMENT
____  1.
Reassemble the tool per Manufacturing Assembly procedure F131021855. Use
Loctite 242 each time that you replace a screw in its original position. Use only
the exact hardware (screws, washers, etc.) specified in the BOMs. Substituting
different components may introduce magnetic or magnetized materials into the
instrument, which could affect directional measurements.
____  2.

4490 XA HTHP WTS Orientation Instrument – Level 3 PM – 131021-953

REASSEMBLE INSTRUMENT AND CALIBRATE
2. Verify successful calibration._____ (�)

Hughes). By accepting or accessing this document the recipient agrees this document (together with its contents) is confidential and is an unpublished copyright work with all rights

Hughes. It may not be used directly or indirectly in any way detrimental to Baker’s interest and is not rented, loaned or sold, either alone or in conjunction with equipment or product, and 
does not comprise a part of any customer project or service. 
Page 1 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
4912 / 4913 / 4914 / 4915 / 4917 MicroVertilog (VRTM) 
Description of Service 
1 General 
The MicroVertilog (VRTM or MVRT) service utilizes magnetic flux leakage (MFL) inspection 
technology to determine the location, extent, and severity of corrosion and other metal-loss defects 
in carbon steel tubulars. 
MicroVertilog tools employ a permanent-magnet circuit designed to produce high levels of magnetic 
flux within the tubing or casing body wall. Defects, such as internal or external corrosion pitting, 
cause flux perturbations (leakage) that are detected by a circumferential array of inductive coil (FL) 
sensors.  
The MicroVertilog tools also employ a circumferential array of discriminator (DIS) sensors, each 
aligned with a corresponding FL sensor, that respond only to flux anomalies occurring at the 
tubing’s inner surface. This combination of FL and DIS data allows the MicroVertilog to differentiate 
between internal and external features.  
The MicroVertilog system produces digital bipolar waveforms, allowing metal gain anomalies 
(centralizers, downhole hardware) verses metal loss (corrosion, mill defects) to be determined from 
the log signature. The preferred vertical data sampling resolution is 0.125 inches, or approximately 
8 samples per inch, per sensor at the recommended logging speed of 120 ft./min. 
The MicroVertilog mandrels currently operate within five different instrument series to cover the full 
range of nominal tubing/casing sizes indicated in the following sections. 
 
 
 
130684-935  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4912 / 4913 / 4914 / 4915 / 4917 MicroVertilog (VRTM) Description of Service 
 
 
 
Page 2 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
1.1 4911 (Common VRTM Electronics Section) 
 The 4911 serves as the telemetry and data acquisition electronics for all VRTM instrument 
mandrels. Two versions exist, the 4911 EB (standard) and 4911 EG (feed-thru).   
 The 4911 EG version can receive wireline power and ground and pass this through the VRTM 
mandrel to another instrument attached below the VRTM tool (for example, a caliper or 
temperature tool). (MVRT would run on battery power when utilizing this feed-thru functionality). 
 Both 4911 versions can run on internal battery pack power in support of full memory logging via 
slick line, coiled tubing, or adverse wireline conditions. 
1.2 4912 (Nominal 2-7/8-Inch OD Tubing) 
The 4912 deploys an overlapping array of 6 FL and 6 DIS sensors, providing 100% circumferential 
coverage for internal and external anomalies. 
1.3 4913 (Nominal 3-1/2-Inch OD Tubing) 
 The 4913 deploys an overlapping array of 6 FL and 6 DIS sensors, providing 100% 
circumferential coverage for internal and external anomalies. 
 The 4913 can be reconfigured with the 4913 MB magnetizer kit for inspection of 4-inch OD 
casing. 
1.4 4914 (Nominal 4-1/2-Inch OD Tubing/Casing) 
 The 4914 deploys an overlapping array of 8 FL and 8 DIS sensors, providing 100% 
circumferential coverage for internal and external anomalies. 
 The 4914 can be reconfigured with the 4914 MB magnetizer kit for inspection of 5-inch OD 
casing. 
 A power and ground wire feed-thru version of this mandrel is available to allow running wireline 
power to an instrument below the 4914. The 4911/4914 would be run on internal battery power 
when using the feed-thru. 
1.5 4915 (Nominal 5-1/2-Inch OD Casing) 
 The 4915 deploys an overlapping array of 10 FL and 10 DIS sensors, providing 100% 
circumferential coverage for internal and external anomalies. 
 Due to the wide range of wellbore configurations and body walls encountered in 5-1/2-inch 
casing, three different 4915 magnetizers have been developed in the following magnetizer 
diameters: 
 
4.25” 4915 MA/(MD) 
 
4.50” 4915 MB/(ME) 
 
4.63” 4915 MC/(MF) 
 A power and ground wire feed-thru version of the 4915 mandrel is available to allow running 
wireline power to an instrument below the 4915.  The 4911 EG/4915 would be run on internal 
battery power when using the feed-thru. 
 
130684-935  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4912 / 4913 / 4914 / 4915 / 4917 MicroVertilog (VRTM) Description of Service 
 
 
 
Page 3 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
1.6 4917 (Nominal 7-Inch OD Casing) 
 The 4917 deploys an overlapping array of 14 FL and 14 DIS sensors, providing 100% 
circumferential coverage for internal and external anomalies. 
 The 4917 can be reconfigured with a 4917 MB/(MF) magnetizer kit for inspection in 8-5/8-inch 
casing, a 4917 MC/(MG) magnetizer kit for inspection in 9-5/8-inch casing, or a 4917 MD/(MH) 
magnetizer kit for 7-5/8-inch and 7-3/4-inch casing. 
 A power and ground feed-thru version of this mandrel is available to allow running wireline 
power to an instrument below the 4914. The 4911/4914 would be run on internal battery power 
when using the feed-thru. 
 
The MicroVertilog tools are configured such that the FL sensors are all housed within a smooth 
cylindrical mandrel with dynamic wheeled centralizers located above and below the mandrel. The 
DIS sensors are conveyed to the tubing ID via spring-loaded shoe assemblies to maintain close 
proximity to the tubing inner wall during logging. 
2 Telemetry Mode 
The MicroVertilog electronics/telemetry system (4911 EB or 4911 EG) is designed to operate in one 
of three data acquisition modes, allowing for differences in wireline communication rates, operating 
conditions and deployment methods.  
In Wireline Telemetry Mode, a single conductor wireline (or 1 of 7 in the case of multiconductor) is 
required to supply tool power and transmit 100% of the log data to the PC based surface acquisition 
system. A “real-time” data display including all configured channels is presented on the system 
monitor during logging. Wireline Telemetry Mode is the preferred method of operation where 
wireline data transmission rates will allow. 
3 Full Memory Mode 
The second method of operation, Full Memory Mode, utilizes onboard memory for data storage and 
an onboard battery pack for tool power.  In Full Memory Mode, the downhole components do no not 
require any power or data communication to the surface system for logging operations, allowing the 
service to be run on slickline or sour service cables with reduced data transmission characteristics.  
A surface setup routine provides the downhole tool with all of the logging parameters prior to the 
job, and synchronizes the downhole tool and surface system processor clocks.  An encoder file 
(time vs. depth) acquired at the surface, and the downhole log file (data vs. depth) are merged post 
job to produce the final log presentation. While in Memory Mode, the logging engineer is essentially 
running “blind” with no surface data display. Memory operation is recommended for sour service 
applications or any application where slickline operation or coiled tubing conveyance is preferred. 
 
130684-935  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4912 / 4913 / 4914 / 4915 / 4917 MicroVertilog (VRTM) Description of Service 
 
 
 
Page 4 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
4 Dual Mode 
The third mode of operation is Dual Mode (Mixed Mode), whereby power is supplied to the tool via 
a single-conductor wireline during logging operations, and the complete data file is recorded to the 
onboard memory module. In Dual Mode, a fractional sample of the data being sent to onboard 
memory is also transmitted via telemetry to the surface system for “real-time” display. In this way, 
Dual Mode allows full resolution data to be recorded to memory while a decimated data sampling is 
sent to the surface, thereby eliminating the “blind” run necessary in Full Memory Mode. Dual Mode 
is recommended for applications where single conductor wireline will not support the data 
transmission rates required for Telemetry Mode operations, or otherwise whenever a surface 
display is desired but Telemetry mode is not possible.
