130673-945  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/30/2015 
4911 EB/EG Circuit Descriptions 
 
 
4 Governance Documents 
• BHI Quality Policy Manual 
• Control of Records 
5 Terms and Definitions 
Baker Hughes Enterprise Glossary 
• PHY: Physical Layer 
• LDO: Low Drop Out 
• TVS: Transient Voltage Suppressor 
• MUX24-R: Second Generation MicroVertilog Electronics circuit board set. 
• MUX24 D-R: PCBA, MUX24 D-R WIRELINE COMM, MEM & SYS CNTRL (A3003301000) 
• MUX24 A-R: PCBA, MUX24 A-R ANALOG TO DIGITAL, SENSOR ACQ.    (A3003302000) 
6 Description of Circuits 
6.1 General Description 
The MUX24-R is the second generation MicroVertilog electronics circuit board set and electronics 
architecture.  The Digital board (MUX24 D-R) is the primary system circuit board used in the 
4911 EB (F130673000) and 4911 EG (F131905000).  The MUX24 D-R controls the MUX24 analog 
board (MUX24 A-R), formats the data and sends the information up the wireline.  Additionally, during 
dual-mode or full-memory mode operation, the MUX24 D-R serves to store the system and sensor 
data to its on-board flash memory, where it can be downloaded from the electronics to a surface PC 
upon return of the MicroVertilog tool string to the surface. 
The MUX24 D-R circuit board assembly is shown below in Figure 1. 
Figure 1: MUX24 D-R Circuit Board Assembly Layout (A3003301000) 
 
 
Page 2 of 5 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130673-945  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/30/2015 
4911 EB/EG Circuit Descriptions 
 
 
6.2 Electrical System Description 
Figure 2 shows the functional block diagram of the MUX24 D-R Digital Wireline Communications, 
Memory and Systems Control circuit board. 
The MUX24 D-R board consists of the following functional sections: 
1. Voltage Clamp 
2. Battery Switches 
3. Power Supplies 
4. Wireline Communications Interface (PHY) 
5. Communications Processor 
6. System Processor 
7. Flash Memory 
8. Telemetry 
 
Figure 2: MUX24 D-R Functional Block Diagram (A3003301000) 
 
 
 
 
Page 3 of 5 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130673-945  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/30/2015 
4911 EB/EG Circuit Descriptions 
 
 
6.2.1 Voltage Clamp 
The voltage clamp consists of R8, R9, CR1, & Q1.  The voltage clamp keeps the wire line voltage 
that feeds the 12 V power supply from exceeding 37 volts.  R8 keeps PNP transistor Q1 turned off 
until the zener voltage is reached.  When the wire line voltage exceeds the zener by more than 
0.7 V, this will cause current to flow through the Emitter – Base junction of the transistor, turning the 
transistor on and clamping the voltage at ≈ 37 volts. 
6.2.2 Battery Switches 
The battery switches consist of 2 high side power MOSFET switches, IC U16 & U17.  The switches 
are turned ON & OFF by the system processor for logging when there is no wire line available.   
The output of the switches can be checked at TP13 (BATT1), TP14 (BATT2) & GND. 
6.2.3 Power Supplies 
The power supply section is made up of 5 different supplies.  When power is supplied by the wire 
line or batteries the first regulator (U18) is a PWM buck step-down regulator. It has a maximum 
input voltage of 42 VDC and the output set to 12 V by resistors R23 & R22.  This regulator is the 
main supply for the board and the other regulators.  The 12 V output can be checked at TP28. 
Regulator U12 is the same one used for U18 and takes the voltage from 12 V to 6 VDC.  It voltage is 
set by R18 & R17.  The 6 V can be checked at TP15. 
VR1 is a fixed LDO linear regulator.  Its input voltage is 6 V and the output is 5 V.  The 5 V can be 
checked at TP21. 
VR2 is the same series LDO as VR1.  Its input voltage is 5 V and the output is 3.3 VDC.  The 3.3 V 
can be checked at TP22. 
U4 is a regulated, adjustable 2x inverting charge pump. It is used to convert & regulate the 5 V input 
to -6 V out.  The output is set by R11 & R10.  Its output can be checked at TP16. 
6.2.4 Wireline Communication Interface (PHY) 
The PHY has 2 sections, the receive section and the transmit section.  The front end of the PHY 
has C1 & T1 for wire line isolation, TS2 (a TVS for voltage clamping) and R1 for impedance 
matching.  The receiving section uses U1 for demodulation, U2, U15 and diodes for wave form 
amplification, shaping / squaring, and TTL level forming.  After the received signal has been re-
squared to TTL levels it can then be sent to the communication processor and the system 
processor. 
The transmit section receives serial data and clock signals from the communication processor and 
clocks the serial data through U11 B NAND Gate and U3 D Flip-Flop.  U11 C & D receive the serial 
data and the signal from U3 and form a differential signal for the FET driver IC U10.  U10 drives 
transformer T1 to place the serial data on the wire line through capacitor C1. 
6.2.5 Communication Processor 
The communication processor U13 connects to the PHY and handles all the communications over-
head, serial-to-parallel & parallel-to-serial data, baud rate, CRC generation & checking, for the 
system processor. 
 
Page 4 of 5 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130673-945  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/30/2015 
4911 EB/EG Circuit Descriptions 
 
 
6.2.6 System Processor 
The system processor U14 controls the Digital & Analog Boards.  The system processor controls 
the channel scanning, the A/D conversions on the analog board.  It receives the telemetry data, 
stores the received data in the FLASH memory, and controls the communication processor for 
sending and receiving information on the wire line.  The system processor is programmed through 
connector PGM8515. 
6.2.7 Flash Memory 
The memory section consists of the 2 Gbit NAND Flash IC, U7 & U8 buffer IC’s, and the U6 OR 
Gate for setting the data direction.  The flash memory connects to the system processor and the 
communication IC through the buffer IC’s.  The Flash memory stores the logging data, battery 
voltages, wire line voltage, temperature, and telemetry data from the Analog board and the 
telemetry processor.   
6.2.8 Telemetry 
Telemetry section consists of a 3 axis accelerometer IC (ACC1) and microprocessor U9.  The 
output from the accelerometers will be 1.65 V when the axis (X / Y / Z) being tested is at a null 
angle, 2.31 V for + g’s, and 0.99 V for – g’s, with respect to earth’s surface. The voltage for each axis 
can be checked at TP26 (X axis), TP25 (Y axis), TP24 (Z axis).  The microprocessor reads the 
accelerometers and converters the voltage to an angle which is then sent to the system processor 
by the SPI port.  The telemetry processor is programmed through connector PGM8. 
7 Records 
None 
8 References

4911 EB/EG CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS; PCBA, MUX24 A-R ANALOG COLLECT A-D MUX 
 
 
 
Page 2 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
4 Governance Documents 
 BHI Quality Policy Manual 
 Control of Records 
5 Terms and Definitions 
Baker Hughes Enterprise Glossary 
 MUX24-R: Second Generation MicroVertilog Electronics circuit board set. 
 MUX24 D-R: PCBA, MUX24 D-R WIRELINE COMM, MEM & SYS CNTRL (A3003301000) 
 MUX24 A-R: PCBA, MUX24 A-R ANALOG COLLECT A-D MUX (A3003302000) 
6 Description of Circuits 
6.1 General Description 
The MUX24-R is the second generation MicroVertilog electronics circuit board set and electronics 
architecture.  The Analog board (MUX24 A-R) is the system circuit board used in the 4911 EB 
(F130673000) and 4911 EG (F131905000) to collect data from the MicroVertilog mandrels’ passive 
coil sensors (4912, 4913, 4914, 4915, 4917).  Additionally, once the data is collected from the coils, 
the MUX24 A-R board converts the analog signals to digital signals prior to passing the data to the 
MUX24 D-R board for storage and/or wireline transmission to the surface.  The general function of 
the MUX24 A-R Analog board is therefore to read the coil sensors in the mandrels, filter the signals, 
amplify the signals, digitize the signals and then send those digitized values to the MUX24 D-R 
Digital board. 
The MUX24 A-R circuit board assembly is shown below in Figure 1. 
Figure 1: MUX24 A-R Circuit Board Assembly Layout (A3003302000) 
 
 
130905-945  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4911 EB/EG CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS; PCBA, MUX24 A-R ANALOG COLLECT A-D MUX 
 
 
 
Page 3 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
6.2 Electrical System Description 
Figure 2, shows the functional block diagram of the MUX24 A-R Collector and A/D Mux board. 
The MUX24 A-R board consists of the following functional sections: 
1. Filter 
2. Multiplexer 
3. Amplifier 
4. Analog to Digital Converter 
Figure 2: A3003302000 Functional Block Diagram 
 
 
 
 
130905-945  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4911 EB/EG CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS; PCBA, MUX24 A-R ANALOG COLLECT A-D MUX 
 
 
 
Page 4 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
6.2.1 Filters 
The filters are simple RC filters consisting of resister networks RN10 - RN13, RN15 - RN19, RN21 
& capacitor networks CN2 - CN11. The filters filter out high frequency noise, (> 10 KHz), on the 
input lines. 
6.2.2 Multiplexers 
The multiplexers are controlled by the MUX24 digital board, and are used to select what input to 
send to the amplifier and A/D.  There are 32 hall inputs and 8 axillary inputs.  The multiplexer 
circuits consist of one D-latch (U22), used to select the multiplexer and input to send to the amplifier 
and A/D.  The multiplexers are U23, U24, U28, U29 (coil sensor inputs), and U27 for the auxiliary 
inputs. 
6.2.3 Amplifier Section 
The amplifier section has two op-amps, a ground switch, a latch, and an 8-to-1 multiplexer.  Op-
amp U31 A is a buffer for input signal to the U31 B op-amp.  Latch U21 is connected to multiplexer 
U1 for switching different resistors into op-amp U31 B to changes its gain from 0 to 8.0.  Switch U32 
is also controlled by latch U21 and switches in ground to the input of the buffer op-amp to measure 
offsets. 
6.2.4 Analog to Digital Converter Section (A/D) 
The A/D section has a 5 V regulator VR3 to supply 5 V to the A/D and a 2.5 V reference IC U25 to 
supply the reference to the A/D.  The A/D is a 12 bit converter.  It sends the data to the MUX24 
digital board through a serial link. 
7 Records 
None 
8 References

1 Purpose 
This document outlines the standard procedure for the assembling/testing the 4911 EB 
ELECTRONICS FLASK. Each numbered step is preceded by a line for check-off notation upon 
completion. 
2 Scope 
The document is applicable only to the level field Assembly/Disassembly procedures for the 
4911 EB Electronics Flask Assembly. 
3 Document Control 
 This document is under SAP/ECO control; all changes require ECO approval. Always check 
SAP to ensure that the latest revision of this procedure is in use.  
 Due to revision changes, some of the drawings in this document may appear differently from 
their true form; always refer to the latest released drawings. 
 The photographs in this document may depict materials that differ slightly from those in current 
use; do not rely on photographs alone. Always refer to the latest Bill of Materials (BOM) for the 
proper materials to use. 
4 Responsibility and Authority 
It is the responsibility of the local management team to: 
 Ensure that the latest AMO manual is implemented and followed in full 
 Review procedures for accuracy and submit Revise Document Requests as needed 
 Validate the training and competency of the individuals performing the work 
It is the responsibility of the individuals performing the work to: 
 Execute the tasks outlined in this manual according to their acquired and relevant competencies 
 Never attempt to execute instructions which exceed their level of competency 
It is the responsibility of the engineering team to keep this document properly up-to-date.

6 Terms and Definitions 
Baker Hughes Enterprise Glossary

MVRT or VRTM – MicroVertilog Casing Inspection 
MUX24 – MicroVertilog Electronics Architecture, usually referring to the electronics printed circuit 
board assemblies

wireline communication, system control and flash memory storage

digital conversion and sensor collection (sensor input/output)

and contract employees have the responsibility to make the safety of ourselves and our co-workers 
a fundamental concern.  With this in mind the following has been compiled as a reference of the 
possible safety risks associated with this operation.  Refer to the Stop Work Authority and other 
related Health, Safety, Environment and Security (HSE&S) Enterprise Operational Controls located 
on the HSE&S Management System website or through BHOS. Always consider that if more than 
one safety rule or standard exists then always default to the most stringent.

9 Quality Requirements 
All work performed is expected to conform to the instructions herein and to the procedures 
described in the company Workmanship Standards Manual (N80807). 
9.1 Compliance Inspections 
During testing of this product, specified assembly steps require inspection by QC or team 
personnel. The following symbols are located in the procedure where a QC inspection or team 
monitoring must take place: 
 
 
 
 
 
Indicates that a QC member must inspect the tool at this point in 
the process. Follow the review instructions recorded in the router 
sheets supplied with the assembly kit. Router signatures are 
required for QC steps contained within this procedure. 
 
 
9.2 Special Handling 
 To prevent damage to stranded Teflon wire, use only thermal wire strippers (F226804000), also 
called hot tweezers, to cut and remove insulation. 
 All AMO personnel must be adequately grounded before handling any electronic assemblies. 
Completed circuit boards must be stored in conductive-shielded packaging. 
 
 
NOTICE 
All static-guard wristbands must be connected to 
workbenches and worn by production personnel when 
handling assemblies with electronic circuitry and devices.

12 Assembly/Disassembly Procedure 
 
 
 
Note 
 
Numbers in Brackets [ ] in this document correspond to the item 
numbers on the BOM and numbers in Parenthesis ( ) correspond to 
part numbers. 
 
 
12.1 Seal Head Assembly, 4911 EB (F188603000) 
12.1.1 Assembly 
Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
1.____ 
Apply Lubriplate or an equivalent high-temperature grease to the four 
(4) AS-130 FKM Dur-95 Blue-Dot O-rings (F243095130) and the o-
ring grooves on 4911 Seal Head (F189390000).  Install the o-rings 
into the grooves as shown in Figure 1. 
Figure 1 
 
 
2.____ 
After applying Loctite or an equivalent thread locker to the extra fine 
threads of circular connector on the Seal Head Wiring Assembly 
(F189429000), thread the circular connector into the Seal Head after 
carefully sliding the wiring assembly through the seal head as shown 
in Figure 1. 
 
3.____ 
Apply Lubriplate or an equivalent high-temperature grease to the 
grooves on the Male Plug Electrical Bulkhead Pressure Connector 
(F189391000) and one AS-123 FKM Dur-95 Blu-Dot O-ring.  Install 
the o-ring into the groove on the bulkhead connector as shown in 
Figure 1.   
Prior to installing the pressure connector, verify that the connector has 
good insulation resistance using a megohmeter between conductors 
and to the connector body.  Check the insulation resistance for all 
conductors with the megohmeter set to 250 V.  Acceptable insulation 
resistance for each conductor should be greater than or equal to 1000 
MOhms. 
 
4.____ 
Carefully pull the PEEK connector (socket retainer) on the Seal Head 
Wiring Assembly (F189429000) out of the Seal Head.  Align the 
keyway on the socket retainer and the keyway on the Male Plug 
Electrical Bulkhead Pressure Connector (F189391000), and then 
push the pressure connector onto the socket retainer. 
 
 
130673-955  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4911 EB - MicroVertilog (MVRT) Electronics Flask Assembly/Disassembly 
 
 
 
Page 12 of 31 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used

Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
5.____ 
Thread the #4-40 x 1.25 inch long socket head cap screw 
(F250339000, pre-installed in the socket retainer) into the center 
threaded hole on the side of the pressure connector with pins in order 
to secure the parts together. 
 
6.____ 
Insert the Male Plug Pressure Connector into the Seal Head by 
aligning the keyways of the connector with that on the seal head, 
making sure not to pinch any wires and also verifying that the o-ring 
has properly sealed.  The connector will be fully seated when the 
snap ring groove in the seal head is fully visible. 
 
7.____ 
Using a set of snap ring pliers, install the SST Snap Ring 
(F265833000) as shown in Figure 1 to retain the pressure connector. 
 
8.____ 
Prepare to install the two 4912 split collars (F188633000) by applying 
Lubriplate or equivalent high temperature grease to the inner diameter 
and ends of the split nut collars as well as the bearing surfaces of the 
seal head as shown in Figure 2. 
Figure 2 
 
 
9.____ 
Complete the installation of the 4912 split nut collars (F188633000) 
onto the seal head (F189390000) by installing the two halves of each 
split collar over the bearing surfaces indicated in Figure 2 and 
securing the two halves together using the #4-40 x 0.375 inch long 
SST socket head cap screws (F230745000) included with the split 
collar. 
 
 
Note 
 
Do not mix the halves of the two split collars or the threads 
on the split collar halves will not align.  Each split collar 
assembly is provided as a matched, machined pair and the 
two halves must always stay together.

Using a DMM (Digital Multi-Meter), proceed with assembly final

12.1.2 Disassembly 
 
Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
1.____ 
Remove the 4912 Split Nut Collars (F188633000) by removing the two 
screws which secure the two halves of each split collar together.  
Using a pick or small flat blade screwdriver, pry the two halves of the 
split collar apart and remove from the seal head sub housing as 
shown in Figure 2. 
 
2.____ 
Remove the Snap Ring (F265833000) shown in Figure 1 and pull the 
Male Plug Electrical Bulkhead Pressure Connector (F189391000) 
using the VRTM Connector Insertion Removal Tool (F191034000).  
Use care not to pull the wiring harness out too far or wire damage may 
occur. 
 
3.____ 
Remove the #4-40 x 1.25 inch long socket head cap screw 
(F250339000) from the center hole of the PEEK Connector Socket 
Retainer shown in Figure 1.

5.____ 
Unthread the circular connector on the Seal Head Wiring Assembly 
(F189429000) from the 4911 Seal Head (F189390000).  Then, 
carefully pull the harness through and out of the 4911 Seal Head. 
 
12.2 Insulator/Heat Sink/Battery Chassis Assembly, 4911 EB (F188604000) 
12.2.1 Assembly 
 
Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
1.____ 
Insert the 4911 Insulator Wiring Assembly (F189425000) into the 
Battery Heat Sink Chassis (F189405000) as shown in Figure 4 below. 
Figure 4 
 
 
 
130673-955  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4911 EB - MicroVertilog (MVRT) Electronics Flask Assembly/Disassembly

Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
2.____ 
After applying Loctite or an equivalent removable thread locker, attach 
the 4911 Insulator Connector Cap (F189427000) to the base of the 
Insulator (F189407000) with three (3) #10-24 X .50 inch long SST 
Socket Head Cap Screws (F229883000) as shown in Figure 5.   
Apply Loctite to the external threads on the Insulator and then thread 
the insulator into the Battery Heat Sink Chassis (F189405000), making 
sure to pull the insulator wiring through the Insulator and Insulator Cap.  
Tighten the insulator securely by hand in order to prevent insulator 
breakage due to being over-torqued. 
Figure 5 
 
 
 
Note 
 
Make sure that none of the insulator wires are pinched and 
wires pass through the Insulator Cap. 
 
 
 
 
3.____ 
Per the Insulator Wiring Diagram (F188604100) pull the Black wire 
coming from the Socket Connector located in position “d” up through 
the Battery slot closest to the Insulator as shown in Figure 6. 
Figure 6 
 
 
4.____ 
Pull the Black wire coming from the Socket Connector located in 
position “e” up through the other Battery slot as shown in Figure 6. 
 
5.____ 
Trim the two (2) Black wires from steps 8 and 9 so that there is 
approximately 2 inch of excess wire available. 
 
6.____ 
Pull the two (2) Red wires emerging from connector location “a” and “b” 
respectively up through the center slot for the switch, as shown in 
Figure 6. 
 
 
130673-955  Rev:  A

Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
7.____ 
Trim the two (2) Red wires so there is approximately 1 inch to 1.5 inch 
of length in the wire which will extend outside of the battery heat sink 
chassis. 
 
8.____ 
Using thermal wire strippers, strip 1/8 inch of wire off the ends of the 
four wires from step 8, 9 and 11. 
 
9.____ 
Using low temperature leaded solder, solder the Red wires onto the 
C&K 2 P-2 T Switch (F265839000) as shown in the Wiring Diagram 
(F189425100).  Prior to soldering, place a 3/8 inch long piece of shrink 
tubing over the wire and shrink the tubing in place once the wires have 
been soldered to the switch. 
 
10.____ 
Cut two (2) 4 inch pieces of Teflon E 26 GA 600 V Red Wire 
(F222089002) and strip 1/8 inch of jacketing from either end. 
 
11.____ 
Using a low temperature solder, solder the two (2) Red extension wires 
onto the C&K 2 P-2 T Switch as shown in the Wiring Diagram 
(F189425100).  Prior to soldering, place a 3/8 inch long piece of shrink 
tubing over the wire and shrink the tubing in place once the wires have 
been soldered to the switch. 
 
12.____ 
Pull the Red wires through the Switch slot and into their appropriate 
Battery Slots, as shown in Figure 6. 
 
13.____ 
Attach the Switch to the Heat Sink Chassis with two (2) #4-40 X .25 
long SST Socket Head Cap Screws (F208565000) after applying 
Loctite as shown in Figure 4. 
 
14.____ 
Cut a 16 inch long piece of a #5 Varflex Non-Fray Sleeve 
(F265835000) and slide the sleeve onto the Insulator Wiring and pull it 
as far along the wires as possible. 
 
15.____ 
After applying Loctite, attach each of the four (4) Hold Down Tabs 
(F189414000) over the insulator wiring securing the harness to the 
battery heat sink chassis with two (2) #6-32 X .25 long SST Socket 
Head Cap Screws (F229970000) per hold down tab as shown in  
Figure 4.

16.____ 
Insert the Crimp Positioner (N790-500-047) into the Crimp Tool 
(F265823000) as shown in Figure 7 and then set the dial on the handle 
of the crimp tool to position #2. 
Figure 7 
 
 
17.____ 
Strip approximately 1/8 inch off of one end of all the wires that are 
emerging from the end of the Insulator Cap. 
 
18.____ 
Insert the stripped end of each wire into the Contact Pin (F265809000) 
and crimp the contact pin onto all wires from Step 22 as shown in 
Figure 7.  Fully squeeze the handles of the crimp tool until the 
mechanism releases the handle indicating that the crimp is complete.  
Repeat this process for all of the remaining wires in the bundle. 
 
19.____ 
Insert all of the pins into the 39 Conductor Circular Plug Connector 
(F265819000) in the locations indicated on the 4911 Insulator Wiring 
Diagram (F189425100).  The pins can either be inserted carefully by 
hand or with the aid of the Insertion/Removal Tool (F265817000) listed 
above.  Be sure to insert the pins until a mechanical lock can be 
established, recognized by a metallic click as the socket is fully seated 
within the connector. 
 
20.____ 
After applying Loctite, thread the 39 Conductor Circular Plug 
Connector into the open end of the Insulator Cap being careful not to 
damage the wiring as it is fed in. 
 
21.____ 
As shown in the Insulator Wiring Diagram, attach the two (2) Red wires 
and the two (2) Black wires (from both sides of the switch) to four (4) 
Female Crimp Terminals (F265838000) using Molex Crimp Tool 
63819-1300, 63811-1000 or equivalent.

23.____ 
Insert the two (2) 8-Cell Lithium Battery Packs (F189827000) into the 
Battery Heat Sink as shown in Figure 8, and then plug in the battery

Figure 8 
 
 
24.____ 
Check the battery voltages on the two (2) 8-Cell Lithium Battery Packs 
(F189827000) by using the battery check procedure in the 4919 NA 
Manual (F140472915). 
 
25.____ 
Place two (2) Battery Retainers (F189406000) onto the Battery Heat

26.____ 
Install the eight (8) AS-221 FKM Dur-95 O-rings (F259262221) into the 
grooves of the Battery Heat Sink Assembly as shown in the assembly 
drawing F188604000. 
 
27.____ 
Apply RTV to all fasteners once the assembly has been tested. 
 
12.2.2 Disassembly 
 
Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
1.____ 
Remove the eight (8) AS-221 FKM Dur-95 O-rings (F259262221) from 
the Battery Heat Sink Insulator Assembly. 
 
2.____ 
Remove the two (2) Battery Retainers (F189406000) as shown in 
Figure 8. 
 
3.____ 
Remove the two (2) 8-Cell Lithium Battery Packs (F189827000) from 
the chassis and unplug the connectors.

4.____ 
Remove the C&K 2 P-2 T Switch (F265839000) by removing its two 
retaining screws. 
 
5.____ 
Unsolder the wiring attached to the switch. 
 
6.____ 
Remove the Hold Down Tabs (F189414000) from the chassis in order 
to free the wiring harness by removing the retaining screws that are 
securing the tabs to the Battery Heat Sink Chassis. 
 
7.____ 
Remove the 39-Conductor Circular Plug Connector (F265819000) 
from the Insulator Connector Cap (F189427000) and then carefully 
pull the wire harness out far enough so that the contacts can be 
removed from the connector.  Remove all wired contacts from the 
connector using Contact Ins/Rem Tool M81969/14-10 (F265822000). 
 
8.____ 
Remove all wired contacts from the connector using Contact Ins/Rem 
Tool M81969/14-10 (F265822000). 
 
9.____ 
Carefully unthread the Modified 39-Socket Connector (F189328000) 
located on the 4911 Wiring Harness Assembly (F189425000) from the 
Battery Heat Sink Chassis and slide out the wiring harness from the 
chassis.

Bundle all of the wiring on top of the MUX24 D-R with TIE WRAPS and 
secure the bundle by wrapping Kapton tape around in various 
locations as shown below.  The Kapton tape should not wrap around 
over top of itself on the bottom side of the chassis.  Orient the ends of 
the tape at either the center bottom of the chassis (without overlap) or 
allow the ends of the tape to overlap on top of the circuit board. 
Figure 22 
 
 
 
Note 
 
Overlapping the tape on the bottom of the chassis could 
cause the tape to bunch up when installed in the 4911 
Flask Housing, causing the Electronics Card Sub to get 
stuck in the flask housing. The tape should be flat and free 
of bumps on the bottom side of the chassis. 
 
 
 
 
17.____ 
Secure the wiring harness on the MUX24 A‐R board by wrapping 
Kapton tape around in various locations as shown below. 
The Kapton tape should not wrap around over top of itself on the 
bottom side of the chassis.  Orient the ends of the tape at either the 
center bottom of the chassis (without overlap) or allow the ends of the 
tape to overlap on top of the circuit board. 
 
 
Note 
 
Overlapping the tape on the bottom of the chassis could 
cause the tape to bunch up when installed in the 4911 
Flask Housing, causing the Electronics Card Sub to get 
stuck in the flask housing. The tape should be flat and free 
of bumps on the bottom side of the chassis. 
 
 
Figure 23

18.____ 
Install the remaining three (3) AS-221 FKM Dur-75 2-Yellow Dot O-
Rings (F259262221) in the locations shown in Figure 24. 
Figure 24 
 
 
12.3.2 Disassembly 
 
Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
1.____ 
Remove the four (4) AS-221 FKM Dur-75 2-YLW Dot O-Rings 
(F259262221) as shown in Figure 24. 
 
2.____ 
Remove the Kapton Tape from overtop of the circuit boards. 
 
3.____ 
Remove the screws which retain the Contact Insulator to the 
Electronics Card Sub as shown in Figure 20. 
 
4.____ 
Remove the Brass Contact from the Brass Terminator as shown in 
Figure 20. 
 
5.____ 
Unsolder the Brass Terminator from the Red Wire that is attached to it 
and feed the Red wire back through the Card Sub. 
 
6.____ 
Remove the board to board wiring harness from between the two 
circuit boards using the Harwin Connector Separator Tool 
(A2008201000).    
 
NOTICE 
Failure to use the connector separator tool may 
result in breakage of the metal retainer clips on the 
Harwin circuit board connector headers.  The 
board or the header connectors would then need to 
be replaced.

Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
7.____ 
Using the Harwin Connector Separator Tool (A2008201000), remove 
the wire harness plug connectors from the circuit boards at connector 
P2 on the MUX24 D-R circuit board and connectors P5 and P6 on the 
MUX24 A-R circuit board. 
 
NOTICE 
Failure to use the connector separator tool may 
result in breakage of the metal retainer clips on the 
Harwin circuit board connector headers.  The 
board or the header connectors would then need to 
be replaced.  
 
 
 
8.____ 
Remove the 4911 electronics chassis wiring harness from the 
electronics card sub by unscrewing the Bendix connector from the 
downhole end of the Electronics Chassis Assembly as shown in 
Figure 13. 
 
9.____ 
Remove the MUX24 A-R and MUX24 D-R circuit boards from the 
chassis by removing all retaining screws. 
 
12.4 Single Conductor Top Assembly, 4911 EB (F189417000) 
12.4.1 Assembly 
 
Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
1.____ 
Using Lubriplate or equivalent high temperature grease, lubricate the 
AS-009 Viton Dur-95 Blu-Dot O-ring (F243095009) and the groove on 
the Single Conductor Top Center Rod (F189419000) as shown in 
Figure 25.  Then, carefully install the o-ring in the o-ring groove on the 
center rod. 
Figure 25 
 
 
 
130673-955  Rev:  A

Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
2.____ 
Using Lubriplate or equivalent high temperature grease, lubricate the 
AS-111 Viton Dur-95 Blu-Dot O-ring (F243095111) and the groove on 
the Single Conductor Top Bulkhead Insulator (F189418000) as shown 
in Figure 25.  Then, carefully install the o-ring in the o-ring groove on 
the bulkhead insulator. 
 
3.____ 
Insert the Single Conductor Top Center Rod (F189419000) into the 
Single Conductor Top Bulkhead Insulator (F189418000) as shown in 
Figure 25. 
 
4.____ 
Apply a small amount of removable thread locking compound Loctite® 
242 (F222043000) to the threads at both ends of the Single Conductor 
Top Center Rod (F189419000).  Next, thread the two WALS Plungers 
(F854868000) onto each end of the Single Conductor Top Center 
Rod. 
 
12.4.2 Disassembly 
 
Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
1.____ 
Remove one WALS Plunger (F854868000) from the downhole end of 
the Single Conductor Top Center Rod (F189419000) while only 
loosening the uphole plunger (leave the uphole plunger on for step 2).  
Refer to Figure 25.   
 
2.____ 
Pull the Single Conductor Top Center Rod (F189419000) out of the 
Single Conductor Top Bulkhead Insulator (F189418000). 
 
3.____ 
Remove the WALS Plunger (F854868000) from the uphole end of the 
Single Conductor Top Center Rod (F189419000). 
 
4.____ 
Remove the AS-009 FKM Dur-95 Blu-Dot O-ring from the Single 
Conductor Top Center Rod (F189419000) and then discard the o-ring. 
 
5.____ 
Remove the AS-111 FKM Dur-95 Blu-Dot O-ring from the Single 
Conductor Top Bulkhead Insulator (F189418000) and then discard the 
o-ring. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
130673-955  Rev:  A

4911 EB - MicroVertilog (MVRT) Electronics Flask Assembly/Disassembly 
 
 
 
Page 30 of 31 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
12.5 4911 EB ELECTRONICS FLASK ASSY (F188606000) 
12.5.1 Assembly 
 
Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
1.____ 
Thread the 39-Conductor Plug Connector on the Insulator/Heat 
Sink/Battery Assembly (F188604000) into the 39-Conductor Bulkhead 
Connector on the Seal Head Assembly (F188603000) in order to 
attach the two assemblies together as shown in Figure 26. 
Figure 26 
 
 
2.____ 
Thread the 39-Conductor Plug Connector on the Insulator/Heat 
Sink/Battery Assembly (F188604000) into the 39-Conductor Bulkhead 
Connector on the Electronics Chassis Assembly (F188605000) as 
shown in Figure 26. 
 
3.____ 
Using a ¾ inch deep well socket and a rachet, lightly thread the Single 
Conductor Top Assembly (F189417000) by hand into the Flask 
Housing (F189415000).  It may be necessary to stuff a small piece of 
paper towel or rag into the socket in order to have the ¾ inch hex of 
the single conductor top assembly’s insulator positioned at the end of 
the socket or the insulator’s threads may not reach to engage in the 
flask housing.   
 
NOTICE 
Do not over-tighten the Single Conductor Top 
Assembly.  The insulator is a plastic material which 
may break if over-torqued. Lightly hand-tighten 
until the o-ring on the insulator has fully seated in 
the flask.  Tightening past this point may cause the 
insulator to break and require replacement.  
 
 
 
4.____ 
Prepare to slide the sub-assembly created from steps 1 and 2 into the 
Flask Housing (F189415000) by first aligning the key on the Seal Head 
Assembly (F188603000) with the keyway in the Flask Housing.  Next, 
without rotating the sub-assembly, slide it carefully into the flask 
housing until the threads on the Split-Collar of the Seal Head Assembly 
can be engaged with the threads on the Flask Housing. 
 
5.____ 
Using the appropriate sized Pin/Spanner wrench (with a ¼ inch 
diameter pin), thread the split-collar into the flask housing making sure 
to tighten securely. 
 
 
130673-955  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4911 EB - MicroVertilog (MVRT) Electronics Flask Assembly/Disassembly 
 
 
 
Page 31 of 31 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
6.____ 
Place a AS-213 FKM Dur-95 Blu-Dot O-ring (F243095213) onto the 
Single Conductor Thread Protector (F041711000) and then install the 
thread protector into the uphole OTA/A3 field joint at the uphole end of 
the flask housing. 
 
7.____ 
Install a 4912 Female Thread Protector (F188651000) onto the 
exposed downhole field joint end of the 4911 EB Electronics Flask 
Assembly (F188606000). 
 
12.5.2 Disassembly 
 
Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
1.____ 
Remove the 4912 Female Thread Protector (F188651000) from the 
downhole end of the 4911 EB Electronics Flask Assembly 
(F188606000). 
 
2.____ 
Remove the Single Conductor Thread Protector (F041711000) from 
the uphole end of the 4911 EB Electronics Flask Assembly 
(F188606000). 
 
3.____ 
Use a pin/spanner wrench to fully unthread the 4912 split-collar 
(F188633000) located on the Seal Head Assembly (F188603000).  
Carefully pull the Seal Head Assembly (and the attached electronics 
chassis) out of the Flask Housing as indicated from Figure 26.  
  
 
Note 
 
Avoid rotating the electronics chassis when pulling it out of 
the flask housing.  This may cause the centralizing o-rings 
on the chassis to spin out of their grooves causing the 
payload to be stuck in the housing. 
 
 
 
 
4.____ 
Remove the Single Conductor Top Assembly (F189417000) from the 
Flask Housing (F189415000) using a ¾ inch deep well socket. 
 
5.____ 
Disconnect the Insulator/Heat Sink/Battery Assembly (F188604000) 
from the Seal Head Assembly (F188603000) by unthreading the  
39-Conductor Bulkhead Connector joint. 
 
6.____ 
Disconnect the Insulator/Heat Sink/Battery Assembly (F188604000) 
from the Electronics Chassis Assembly (F188605000) by unthreading 
the 39-Conductor Bulkhead Connector joint located between the two 
sub-assemblies as indicated in Figure 26.

4911 EB Preventive Maintenance Level 3 
Purpose 
The purpose of this document is to provide the procedures necessary to perform Level 3 
Preventative Maintenance (PM3) on the 4911 EB Electronics Flask Assembly (F188606000).  
Scope 
The document is only applicable to the level 3 preventative maintenance procedures for the 
4911 EB Electronics Flask Assembly. This preventative maintenance procedure focuses on 
employee safety, environmentally sound practices, and/or troubleshooting. This procedure does not 
serve as a substitute for critical thought and the experience of the Baker Hughes representative. 
It is not intended to be an overriding document, meaning that all local, customer, governmental, or 
occupational policies or procedures that are the most stringent must be followed. 
Responsibility and Authority 
These Preventative Maintenance Procedures are intended for use by Baker Hughes 
representatives qualified to perform the repairs and inspection tests as per the master qualifications 
list or competency list. The specific job title and reporting structure of the representative will be 
documented in the pre-job planning paperwork and defined prior to the beginning of each job.  
These procedures are to be performed and documented by qualified Assembly, Maintenance and 
Overhaul (AMO) personnel.  AMO management is responsible to schedule and ensure the 
performance of these procedures for each instrument on a routine basis as required per typical 
Baker Hughes PM frequency for downhole wireline equipment. 
Safety and Regulatory 
Safety is of primary importance in our operations. All of Baker Hughes management, employees, 
and contract employees have the responsibility to make the safety of ourselves and our co-workers 
a fundamental concern.  With this in mind the following has been compiled as a reference of the 
possible safety risks associated with this operation.  Refer to the Stop Work Authority and other 
related Health, Safety, Environment and Security (HSE&S) Enterprise Operational Controls located 
on the HSE&S Management System website or through BHOS. Always consider that if more than 
one safety rule or standard exists then always default to the most stringent.

The 4912, 4913, 4914, 4915, and 4917 inspection 
mandrels’ magnetizer assembly (used with 4911 EB) 
contain a very powerful permanent magnet circuit that 
cannot be turned off. The magnetic field around the tools 
may adversely affect pacemaker wearers or individuals 
with electrical/metallic medical implants. Magnetic field 
may be harmful to individuals with electrical/metallic 
medical implants 
 
Individuals with electrical/metallic medical 
implants should be prohibited from approaching 
within 3 ft. (1 m) of the MicroVertilog magnet 
assemblies 
 
 
 
 
 
>3 ft (1 m)  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The 4912, 4913, 4914, 4915, and 4917 inspection 
mandrels’ magnetizer assembly (used with 4911 EB) 
contain a very powerful permanent magnet circuit that 
cannot be turned off. Extreme care in handling must be 
observed at all times.  
Sharp magnetic particles may adhere to the tool and 
cause handling injury 
 
Remove particles before handling 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Ferromagnetic tools and other objects will be strongly 
attracted to the permanent magnets  
Magnets may cause ferromagnetic tools to be pulled 
away from the operator causing hand injury and/or 
equipment damage 
 
Keep all ferromagnetic objects 5 ft. (1.5 m) away 
from the MicroVertilog tools at all times.  
>5 ft (1.5 m) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The 4911 EB Electronics Flask Assembly contains lithium 
metal battery packs.  Care should be taken with the 
batteries to avoid electrical shock and/or battery rupture. 
Do not damage the batteries as fire or explosion may 
occur.  Do not overheat batteries. 
Electrical shock and/or battery rupture may result 
from battery mishandling 
 
Take care in handling the lithium metal batteries

4911 EB Preventive Maintenance Level 3 
 
 
130673-953  
Rev: A   
Effective Date:3/10/2015  
 
 
 
 
Page 5 of 8 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
Preventative Maintenance Level 3 Procedures 
Prior to beginning each step below, all parts should be thoroughly cleaned of any dirt, debris, 
residue or grease. 
1. F188606000 “ELECTRONICS FLASK ASSY, 4911 EB”: 
A. Remove the internal assemblies from the flask housing (F189415000) as per the 
disassembly procedures discussed in document F188606955.   
B. Inspect the flask housing (F189415000) for any signs of damage (dents, gouges, etc.) which 
could cause the flask to fail under external wellbore pressure.  Replace flask if damaged.  A 
heat test may be performed to verify the thermal performance of the flask following 
completion of the electronics test procedure by placing the completed 4911 EB into an oven 
and running at 150 degrees C for four hours.  The internal flask temperature (payload 
temperature) should stay below 75 degrees C at the end of four hours at 150 degrees C if 
the flask’s thermal performance is per specification. 
C. Carefully remove the single conductor top assembly (F189417000) from the flask housing 
(F189415000) and inspect the contact plunger assemblies (F854868000) to ensure the 
plunger does not bind up when compressed or get stuck when allowed to extend.  Replace 
the contact plungers if necessary.   
D. Disassemble the single conductor top assembly and replace the two sealing o-rings 
(F243095111 & F243095009).  Prior to re-assembly, coat the o-rings and grooves with 
Lubriplate® or equivalent high temperature grease.   
E. Disassemble the electronics flask assembly sub chassis sections from one another by 
disconnecting the sections via the 39 conductor connector (F189328000, F265819000) 
joints. 
F. Check the 39 conductor connectors (F189328000, F265819000) which connect the internal 
sub-assemblies together and verify that they have not loosened from their mating 
components and that they are free from damage.  Check the wiring in the backside of the 
connectors to make sure that no wires are broken and that all sockets/pins are securely 
locked into the connectors.  Tighten, repair or replace as required. 
 
2. F188603000 “SEAL HEAD ASSY, 4911 EB” 
A. Replace the sealing o-rings (F243095130) on the seal head assembly (F188603000). Prior 
to assembly, coat the o-rings and grooves with Lubriplate® or equivalent high temperature 
grease.  
B. Remove and inspect the 36 socket pressure bulkhead connector (F189391000) for bent, 
missing, or damaged connector pins. Straighten and repair bent pins if possible or replace 
connector.  
C. With a megohmeter, measure the insulation resistance between all connector pins and case 
(metal connector body).  Verify all conductors have insulation resistance greater than 1000 
MOhms.   
→ If leakage is present (< 1000 MOhms), soak the bulkhead connector in Isopropyl 
alcohol and allow to soak overnight.  Remove the bulkhead from the alcohol and allow to 
air dry.  Once the connector is dry, place it in an oven at 225 degrees Fahrenheit for one 
hour in order to drive off any remaining moisture in the connector.  Recheck step 5.  If 
insulation resistance is not restored to >1000 MOhms, replace the bulkhead connector. 
 
4911 EB Preventive Maintenance Level 3 
 
 
130673-953  
Rev: A   
Effective Date:3/10/2015  
 
 
 
 
Page 6 of 8 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
D. Replace the sealing o-ring (F243095123) on the 36 socket pressure bulkhead connector 
(F189391000) within the seal head assembly (F188603000). Prior to assembly, coat the o-
ring and grooves with Lubriplate® or equivalent high temperature grease. 
E. Inspect the seal head wiring assembly (F189429000) for loose or damaged components and 
check continuity of the wiring assembly’s conductors from end to end with a Fluke Multi-
meter set to measure resistance or continuity. Repair or replace components as necessary.  
F. Replace the sealing o-ring (F243095006) on the #4-40 socket head cap screw 
(F250339000) located within the seal head wiring assembly (F189429000). Prior to 
assembly, coat the o-ring and grooves with Lubriplate® or equivalent high temperature 
grease. 
G. Remove the 4912 Split Collar assemblies (F188633000) from the seal head assembly.  
Inspect the threads and bearing surfaces for damage or excessive pitting corrosion.  
Replace as necessary.  Clean and re-lubricate the split collar assemblies with Lubriplate® or 
equivalent high temperature grease prior to re-installation.  Verify that the split collar spins 
freely without binding after installation back onto the seal head. 
 
3. F188604000 “INSULATOR/HEAT SINK/BATTERY ASSEMBLY, 4911 EB”: 
A. Replace the centralizing o-rings (F259262221) which hold the battery retainers 
(F189406000) on the 4911 EB Insulator/Heatsink/Battery Assembly (F188604000). DO NOT 
apply lubricant to the chassis centralizing o-rings. 
B. Inspect the 4911 EB Insulator/Heatsink/Battery Assembly (F188604000) for loose or 
damaged electrical connectors or parts. Repair or replace components if necessary.  
C. Verify that the 2 P-2 T Battery Switch (F265839000) is functioning properly.  Replace the 
switch if not performing properly.  
D. Closely inspect the battery pack wiring on the insulator/heat sink/battery chassis assembly 
for any signs of pinches, cuts or other damage.  Repair as required. 
E. Inspect the battery packs (F189827000), as shown in Figure 1 below, for signs of damage 
and then measure the voltage of the pack using a 100 Ohm, 10 W resistor between the 
terminals of the battery pack connector.  If the measured voltage is less than 27 V, de-
passivate (stir) the battery pack by holding the 100 Ohm, 10 W resistor across the battery 
terminals for five seconds at a time.  If the battery pack voltage will not increase, replace the 
battery pack with a new one.  Avoid using battery packs which have exceeded 2 years from 
their manufacture date.  Battery pack voltage can also be measured using a 4919 NA Test 
Box (see manual F140472915), but the above procedure is recommended to ensure the 
battery pack is loaded with some resistance when taking the voltage measurement.   
Note 1: A battery pack which measures zero volts is not a sign that the battery pack is 
depleted.  A depleted battery pack will still measure some voltage (perhaps as little as 1 
volt, but never zero).  A measurement of zero volts on the battery pack is a sign that the 
fuse (on the battery pack’s positive lead under shrink tubing) has blown or has been 
damaged.  If zero volts is measured, replace the blown fuse with a new fuse (FUSE, 
AXIAL, FAST-BLOW, 125 V, 1 A, 0.25 W; Manf: LITTLEFUSE, Manf. P/N: 0251001.MXL). 
 
4911 EB Preventive Maintenance Level 3 
 
 
130673-953  
Rev: A   
Effective Date:3/10/2015  
 
 
 
 
Page 7 of 8 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
Figure 1 
 
Note 2: if a full memory job is not planned, it is recommended to remove the battery 
packs from the 4911 EB to reduce the risk of fire in the electronics if the tool should be 
stuck downhole in a hot borehole environment.  The battery may catch fire, explode or 
rupture if its temperature exceeds 200 degrees F (93 degrees C). 
 
4. F188605000 “ELECTRONICS CHASSIS ASSEMBLY, 4911 EB”: 
A. Inspect the Electronics Chassis Assembly (F188605000) for loose electrical connectors and 
components that might have become dislodged during logging operations.  Repair or 
replace components as necessary. 
B. Replace the chassis centralizing o-rings (F259262221) on the Electronics Chassis Assembly 
(F188605000).  DO NOT apply lubricant to the chassis centralizing o-rings. 
C. Inspect the beryllium copper EMI Gasket (F265828000) for damage. Repair or replace the 
component if necessary.  Secure the #4-40 button head cap screw (F246124000) gasket 
fasteners DOW Corning 3145 silicone RTV or equivalent. 
D. Verify that the #4-40 fasteners (F208565000 & F230745000), which secure the electronics 
circuit boards to the chassis, are intact and tight.  Secure the screws in place with DOW 
Corning 3145 silicone RTV or equivalent. 
E. Inspect the printed circuit board assemblies (A3003301000 & A3003302000) to ensure that 
no components have come loose or show any signs of damage.  Verify that the circuit 
boards are free of contaminants or debris which could cause electrical shorting or arcing.  
Clean, repair or replace the PCB assemblies as required.  Damage or non-functional PCB 
assemblies should be replaced (find fault to board and replace – do not repair at PCB 
component level). 
F. Verify the connectors for the harnesses are securely seated into the headers on the circuit 
boards and secured in place with DOW Corning 3145 silicone RTV or equivalent. 
G. Inspect the chassis wiring harness (A3003317000) and board-to-board wiring harness 
(A3003318000) for any signs of damage.  Repair any wiring, connectors or contacts as 
required.  Verify the cable harnesses are secured to the PCBs and/or chassis with kapton 
tape or DOW Corning Silicone RTV to ensure that the harness stay in place. 
 
4911 EB Preventive Maintenance Level 3 
 
 
130673-953  
Rev: A   
Effective Date:3/10/2015  
 
 
 
 
Page 8 of 8 
 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
H. Inspect the wiring to the brass terminator (F189396000) to ensure the wire is securely 
soldered to the terminator and free from damage.  Also, verify the brass terminator and the 
brass contact (F189394000) are free of tarnish or damage.  Clean any tarnish from the 
components or replace the components to ensure good electrical contact can be made to 
the single conductor top assembly contact plunger. 
5. Using the wiring diagram (F188606100), pin-out the individual electronics sub chassis sections to 
verify continuity of all wiring and that no wires are broken or damaged.  Once all wiring has been 
checked, reconnect the chassis sub sections back together using the 39-pin connectors at the ends 
of each chassis sub section as shown in assembly drawing F188606000. 
6. Follow the electronics test procedures in document number F188606956 following completion of the 
Level 3 PM procedures.

4912 / 4913 / 4914 / 4915 / 4917 MicroVertilog (VRTM) 
Description of Service 
1 General 
The MicroVertilog (VRTM or MVRT) service utilizes magnetic flux leakage (MFL) inspection 
technology to determine the location, extent, and severity of corrosion and other metal-loss defects 
in carbon steel tubulars. 
MicroVertilog tools employ a permanent-magnet circuit designed to produce high levels of magnetic 
flux within the tubing or casing body wall. Defects, such as internal or external corrosion pitting, 
cause flux perturbations (leakage) that are detected by a circumferential array of inductive coil (FL) 
sensors.  
The MicroVertilog tools also employ a circumferential array of discriminator (DIS) sensors, each 
aligned with a corresponding FL sensor, that respond only to flux anomalies occurring at the 
tubing’s inner surface. This combination of FL and DIS data allows the MicroVertilog to differentiate 
between internal and external features.  
The MicroVertilog system produces digital bipolar waveforms, allowing metal gain anomalies 
(centralizers, downhole hardware) verses metal loss (corrosion, mill defects) to be determined from 
the log signature. The preferred vertical data sampling resolution is 0.125 inches, or approximately 
8 samples per inch, per sensor at the recommended logging speed of 120 ft./min. 
The MicroVertilog mandrels currently operate within five different instrument series to cover the full 
range of nominal tubing/casing sizes indicated in the following sections. 
 
 
 
130684-935  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4912 / 4913 / 4914 / 4915 / 4917 MicroVertilog (VRTM) Description of Service 
 
 
 
Page 2 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
1.1 4911 (Common VRTM Electronics Section) 
 The 4911 serves as the telemetry and data acquisition electronics for all VRTM instrument 
mandrels. Two versions exist, the 4911 EB (standard) and 4911 EG (feed-thru).   
 The 4911 EG version can receive wireline power and ground and pass this through the VRTM 
mandrel to another instrument attached below the VRTM tool (for example, a caliper or 
temperature tool). (MVRT would run on battery power when utilizing this feed-thru functionality). 
 Both 4911 versions can run on internal battery pack power in support of full memory logging via 
slick line, coiled tubing, or adverse wireline conditions. 
1.2 4912 (Nominal 2-7/8-Inch OD Tubing) 
The 4912 deploys an overlapping array of 6 FL and 6 DIS sensors, providing 100% circumferential 
coverage for internal and external anomalies. 
1.3 4913 (Nominal 3-1/2-Inch OD Tubing) 
 The 4913 deploys an overlapping array of 6 FL and 6 DIS sensors, providing 100% 
circumferential coverage for internal and external anomalies. 
 The 4913 can be reconfigured with the 4913 MB magnetizer kit for inspection of 4-inch OD 
casing. 
1.4 4914 (Nominal 4-1/2-Inch OD Tubing/Casing) 
 The 4914 deploys an overlapping array of 8 FL and 8 DIS sensors, providing 100% 
circumferential coverage for internal and external anomalies. 
 The 4914 can be reconfigured with the 4914 MB magnetizer kit for inspection of 5-inch OD 
casing. 
 A power and ground wire feed-thru version of this mandrel is available to allow running wireline 
power to an instrument below the 4914. The 4911/4914 would be run on internal battery power 
when using the feed-thru. 
1.5 4915 (Nominal 5-1/2-Inch OD Casing) 
 The 4915 deploys an overlapping array of 10 FL and 10 DIS sensors, providing 100% 
circumferential coverage for internal and external anomalies. 
 Due to the wide range of wellbore configurations and body walls encountered in 5-1/2-inch 
casing, three different 4915 magnetizers have been developed in the following magnetizer 
diameters: 
 
4.25” 4915 MA/(MD) 
 
4.50” 4915 MB/(ME) 
 
4.63” 4915 MC/(MF) 
 A power and ground wire feed-thru version of the 4915 mandrel is available to allow running 
wireline power to an instrument below the 4915.  The 4911 EG/4915 would be run on internal 
battery power when using the feed-thru. 
 
130684-935  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4912 / 4913 / 4914 / 4915 / 4917 MicroVertilog (VRTM) Description of Service 
 
 
 
Page 3 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
1.6 4917 (Nominal 7-Inch OD Casing) 
 The 4917 deploys an overlapping array of 14 FL and 14 DIS sensors, providing 100% 
circumferential coverage for internal and external anomalies. 
 The 4917 can be reconfigured with a 4917 MB/(MF) magnetizer kit for inspection in 8-5/8-inch 
casing, a 4917 MC/(MG) magnetizer kit for inspection in 9-5/8-inch casing, or a 4917 MD/(MH) 
magnetizer kit for 7-5/8-inch and 7-3/4-inch casing. 
 A power and ground feed-thru version of this mandrel is available to allow running wireline 
power to an instrument below the 4914. The 4911/4914 would be run on internal battery power 
when using the feed-thru. 
 
The MicroVertilog tools are configured such that the FL sensors are all housed within a smooth 
cylindrical mandrel with dynamic wheeled centralizers located above and below the mandrel. The 
DIS sensors are conveyed to the tubing ID via spring-loaded shoe assemblies to maintain close 
proximity to the tubing inner wall during logging. 
2 Telemetry Mode 
The MicroVertilog electronics/telemetry system (4911 EB or 4911 EG) is designed to operate in one 
of three data acquisition modes, allowing for differences in wireline communication rates, operating 
conditions and deployment methods.  
In Wireline Telemetry Mode, a single conductor wireline (or 1 of 7 in the case of multiconductor) is 
required to supply tool power and transmit 100% of the log data to the PC based surface acquisition 
system. A “real-time” data display including all configured channels is presented on the system 
monitor during logging. Wireline Telemetry Mode is the preferred method of operation where 
wireline data transmission rates will allow. 
3 Full Memory Mode 
The second method of operation, Full Memory Mode, utilizes onboard memory for data storage and 
an onboard battery pack for tool power.  In Full Memory Mode, the downhole components do no not 
require any power or data communication to the surface system for logging operations, allowing the 
service to be run on slickline or sour service cables with reduced data transmission characteristics.  
A surface setup routine provides the downhole tool with all of the logging parameters prior to the 
job, and synchronizes the downhole tool and surface system processor clocks.  An encoder file 
(time vs. depth) acquired at the surface, and the downhole log file (data vs. depth) are merged post 
job to produce the final log presentation. While in Memory Mode, the logging engineer is essentially 
running “blind” with no surface data display. Memory operation is recommended for sour service 
applications or any application where slickline operation or coiled tubing conveyance is preferred. 
 
130684-935  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4912 / 4913 / 4914 / 4915 / 4917 MicroVertilog (VRTM) Description of Service 
 
 
 
Page 4 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
4 Dual Mode 
The third mode of operation is Dual Mode (Mixed Mode), whereby power is supplied to the tool via 
a single-conductor wireline during logging operations, and the complete data file is recorded to the 
onboard memory module. In Dual Mode, a fractional sample of the data being sent to onboard 
memory is also transmitted via telemetry to the surface system for “real-time” display. In this way, 
Dual Mode allows full resolution data to be recorded to memory while a decimated data sampling is 
sent to the surface, thereby eliminating the “blind” run necessary in Full Memory Mode. Dual Mode 
is recommended for applications where single conductor wireline will not support the data 
transmission rates required for Telemetry Mode operations, or otherwise whenever a surface 
display is desired but Telemetry mode is not possible.

4911 EB/EG Circuit Descriptions 
1 Purpose 
The purpose of this document is to provide the general overview and description of the circuits in 
the MUX24 D-R Wireline Communication, Memory and System Control circuit board assembly, part 
number A3003301000, as used in the 4911 EB and 4911 EG series MicroVertilog electronics.  This 
document is not designed to assist with component level troubleshooting and repair, but rather 
provide information for the general understanding of how the board is designed to work.  
Troubleshooting and repair should be limited to finding fault to the board and replacing the board. 
2 Scope 
The document is applicable to provide user understanding of the MUX24 D-R circuit board 
assembly.  A description of the circuits are described herein and are provided only to increase the 
users understanding of the board’s functionality but this document is not designed to provide 
direction for component-level repairs or troubleshooting.   
This manual focuses on employee safety, environmentally sound practices, and/or troubleshooting. 
This procedure does not serve as a substitute for critical thought and the experience of the Baker 
Hughes representative. 
It is not intended to be an overriding document, meaning that all local, customer, governmental, or 
occupational policies or procedures that are the most stringent must be followed. 
The target audience for this document is intended to be the Baker Hughes Assembly, Maintenance 
and Overhaul (AMO) personnel who are involved and responsible for the MicroVertilog telemetry 
system maintenance, trouble-shooting and repair. 
3 Responsibility and Authority 
Instruction Manuals are intended for use by Baker Hughes representatives qualified to run the tools 
or services as per the master qualifications list or competency list. The specific job title and 
reporting structure of the representative will be documented in the pre-job planning paperwork and 
defined prior to the beginning of each job.

Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130673-945  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/30/2015 
4911 EB/EG Circuit Descriptions 
 
 
4 Governance Documents 
• BHI Quality Policy Manual 
• Control of Records 
5 Terms and Definitions 
Baker Hughes Enterprise Glossary 
• PHY: Physical Layer 
• LDO: Low Drop Out 
• TVS: Transient Voltage Suppressor 
• MUX24-R: Second Generation MicroVertilog Electronics circuit board set. 
• MUX24 D-R: PCBA, MUX24 D-R WIRELINE COMM, MEM & SYS CNTRL (A3003301000) 
• MUX24 A-R: PCBA, MUX24 A-R ANALOG TO DIGITAL, SENSOR ACQ.    (A3003302000) 
6 Description of Circuits 
6.1 General Description 
The MUX24-R is the second generation MicroVertilog electronics circuit board set and electronics 
architecture.  The Digital board (MUX24 D-R) is the primary system circuit board used in the 
4911 EB (F130673000) and 4911 EG (F131905000).  The MUX24 D-R controls the MUX24 analog 
board (MUX24 A-R), formats the data and sends the information up the wireline.  Additionally, during 
dual-mode or full-memory mode operation, the MUX24 D-R serves to store the system and sensor 
data to its on-board flash memory, where it can be downloaded from the electronics to a surface PC 
upon return of the MicroVertilog tool string to the surface. 
The MUX24 D-R circuit board assembly is shown below in Figure 1. 
Figure 1: MUX24 D-R Circuit Board Assembly Layout (A3003301000) 
 
 
Page 2 of 5 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130673-945  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/30/2015 
4911 EB/EG Circuit Descriptions 
 
 
6.2 Electrical System Description 
Figure 2 shows the functional block diagram of the MUX24 D-R Digital Wireline Communications, 
Memory and Systems Control circuit board. 
The MUX24 D-R board consists of the following functional sections: 
1. Voltage Clamp 
2. Battery Switches 
3. Power Supplies 
4. Wireline Communications Interface (PHY) 
5. Communications Processor 
6. System Processor 
7. Flash Memory 
8. Telemetry 
 
Figure 2: MUX24 D-R Functional Block Diagram (A3003301000) 
 
 
 
 
Page 3 of 5 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130673-945  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/30/2015 
4911 EB/EG Circuit Descriptions 
 
 
6.2.1 Voltage Clamp 
The voltage clamp consists of R8, R9, CR1, & Q1.  The voltage clamp keeps the wire line voltage 
that feeds the 12 V power supply from exceeding 37 volts.  R8 keeps PNP transistor Q1 turned off 
until the zener voltage is reached.  When the wire line voltage exceeds the zener by more than 
0.7 V, this will cause current to flow through the Emitter – Base junction of the transistor, turning the 
transistor on and clamping the voltage at ≈ 37 volts. 
6.2.2 Battery Switches 
The battery switches consist of 2 high side power MOSFET switches, IC U16 & U17.  The switches 
are turned ON & OFF by the system processor for logging when there is no wire line available.   
The output of the switches can be checked at TP13 (BATT1), TP14 (BATT2) & GND. 
6.2.3 Power Supplies 
The power supply section is made up of 5 different supplies.  When power is supplied by the wire 
line or batteries the first regulator (U18) is a PWM buck step-down regulator. It has a maximum 
input voltage of 42 VDC and the output set to 12 V by resistors R23 & R22.  This regulator is the 
main supply for the board and the other regulators.  The 12 V output can be checked at TP28. 
Regulator U12 is the same one used for U18 and takes the voltage from 12 V to 6 VDC.  It voltage is 
set by R18 & R17.  The 6 V can be checked at TP15. 
VR1 is a fixed LDO linear regulator.  Its input voltage is 6 V and the output is 5 V.  The 5 V can be 
checked at TP21. 
VR2 is the same series LDO as VR1.  Its input voltage is 5 V and the output is 3.3 VDC.  The 3.3 V 
can be checked at TP22. 
U4 is a regulated, adjustable 2x inverting charge pump. It is used to convert & regulate the 5 V input 
to -6 V out.  The output is set by R11 & R10.  Its output can be checked at TP16. 
6.2.4 Wireline Communication Interface (PHY) 
The PHY has 2 sections, the receive section and the transmit section.  The front end of the PHY 
has C1 & T1 for wire line isolation, TS2 (a TVS for voltage clamping) and R1 for impedance 
matching.  The receiving section uses U1 for demodulation, U2, U15 and diodes for wave form 
amplification, shaping / squaring, and TTL level forming.  After the received signal has been re-
squared to TTL levels it can then be sent to the communication processor and the system 
processor. 
The transmit section receives serial data and clock signals from the communication processor and 
clocks the serial data through U11 B NAND Gate and U3 D Flip-Flop.  U11 C & D receive the serial 
data and the signal from U3 and form a differential signal for the FET driver IC U10.  U10 drives 
transformer T1 to place the serial data on the wire line through capacitor C1. 
6.2.5 Communication Processor 
The communication processor U13 connects to the PHY and handles all the communications over-
head, serial-to-parallel & parallel-to-serial data, baud rate, CRC generation & checking, for the 
system processor. 
 
Page 4 of 5 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
 
130673-945  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/30/2015 
4911 EB/EG Circuit Descriptions 
 
 
6.2.6 System Processor 
The system processor U14 controls the Digital & Analog Boards.  The system processor controls 
the channel scanning, the A/D conversions on the analog board.  It receives the telemetry data, 
stores the received data in the FLASH memory, and controls the communication processor for 
sending and receiving information on the wire line.  The system processor is programmed through 
connector PGM8515. 
6.2.7 Flash Memory 
The memory section consists of the 2 Gbit NAND Flash IC, U7 & U8 buffer IC’s, and the U6 OR 
Gate for setting the data direction.  The flash memory connects to the system processor and the 
communication IC through the buffer IC’s.  The Flash memory stores the logging data, battery 
voltages, wire line voltage, temperature, and telemetry data from the Analog board and the 
telemetry processor.   
6.2.8 Telemetry 
Telemetry section consists of a 3 axis accelerometer IC (ACC1) and microprocessor U9.  The 
output from the accelerometers will be 1.65 V when the axis (X / Y / Z) being tested is at a null 
angle, 2.31 V for + g’s, and 0.99 V for – g’s, with respect to earth’s surface. The voltage for each axis 
can be checked at TP26 (X axis), TP25 (Y axis), TP24 (Z axis).  The microprocessor reads the 
accelerometers and converters the voltage to an angle which is then sent to the system processor 
by the SPI port.  The telemetry processor is programmed through connector PGM8. 
7 Records 
None 
8 References

4911 EB/EG CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS; PCBA, MUX24 A-R ANALOG COLLECT A-D MUX 
 
 
 
Page 2 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
4 Governance Documents 
 BHI Quality Policy Manual 
 Control of Records 
5 Terms and Definitions 
Baker Hughes Enterprise Glossary 
 MUX24-R: Second Generation MicroVertilog Electronics circuit board set. 
 MUX24 D-R: PCBA, MUX24 D-R WIRELINE COMM, MEM & SYS CNTRL (A3003301000) 
 MUX24 A-R: PCBA, MUX24 A-R ANALOG COLLECT A-D MUX (A3003302000) 
6 Description of Circuits 
6.1 General Description 
The MUX24-R is the second generation MicroVertilog electronics circuit board set and electronics 
architecture.  The Analog board (MUX24 A-R) is the system circuit board used in the 4911 EB 
(F130673000) and 4911 EG (F131905000) to collect data from the MicroVertilog mandrels’ passive 
coil sensors (4912, 4913, 4914, 4915, 4917).  Additionally, once the data is collected from the coils, 
the MUX24 A-R board converts the analog signals to digital signals prior to passing the data to the 
MUX24 D-R board for storage and/or wireline transmission to the surface.  The general function of 
the MUX24 A-R Analog board is therefore to read the coil sensors in the mandrels, filter the signals, 
amplify the signals, digitize the signals and then send those digitized values to the MUX24 D-R 
Digital board. 
The MUX24 A-R circuit board assembly is shown below in Figure 1. 
Figure 1: MUX24 A-R Circuit Board Assembly Layout (A3003302000) 
 
 
130905-945  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4911 EB/EG CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS; PCBA, MUX24 A-R ANALOG COLLECT A-D MUX 
 
 
 
Page 3 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
6.2 Electrical System Description 
Figure 2, shows the functional block diagram of the MUX24 A-R Collector and A/D Mux board. 
The MUX24 A-R board consists of the following functional sections: 
1. Filter 
2. Multiplexer 
3. Amplifier 
4. Analog to Digital Converter 
Figure 2: A3003302000 Functional Block Diagram 
 
 
 
 
130905-945  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4911 EB/EG CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS; PCBA, MUX24 A-R ANALOG COLLECT A-D MUX 
 
 
 
Page 4 of 4 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
6.2.1 Filters 
The filters are simple RC filters consisting of resister networks RN10 - RN13, RN15 - RN19, RN21 
& capacitor networks CN2 - CN11. The filters filter out high frequency noise, (> 10 KHz), on the 
input lines. 
6.2.2 Multiplexers 
The multiplexers are controlled by the MUX24 digital board, and are used to select what input to 
send to the amplifier and A/D.  There are 32 hall inputs and 8 axillary inputs.  The multiplexer 
circuits consist of one D-latch (U22), used to select the multiplexer and input to send to the amplifier 
and A/D.  The multiplexers are U23, U24, U28, U29 (coil sensor inputs), and U27 for the auxiliary 
inputs. 
6.2.3 Amplifier Section 
The amplifier section has two op-amps, a ground switch, a latch, and an 8-to-1 multiplexer.  Op-
amp U31 A is a buffer for input signal to the U31 B op-amp.  Latch U21 is connected to multiplexer 
U1 for switching different resistors into op-amp U31 B to changes its gain from 0 to 8.0.  Switch U32 
is also controlled by latch U21 and switches in ground to the input of the buffer op-amp to measure 
offsets. 
6.2.4 Analog to Digital Converter Section (A/D) 
The A/D section has a 5 V regulator VR3 to supply 5 V to the A/D and a 2.5 V reference IC U25 to 
supply the reference to the A/D.  The A/D is a 12 bit converter.  It sends the data to the MUX24 
digital board through a serial link.

None 
8 References

on the 4911 EG Electronics Flask Assembly (A3003392000, revision B). 
2 Scope 
The document is applicable only to the level field test procedures for the 4911 EG Electronics Flask 
Assembly.  
3 Responsibility and Authority 
These Test Procedures are intended for use by Baker Hughes representatives qualified to perform 
the repairs and inspection tests as per the master qualifications list or competency list. The specific 
job title and reporting structure of the representative will be documented in the pre-job planning 
paperwork and defined prior to the beginning of each job. These procedures are to be performed 
and documented by qualified Assembly, Maintenance and Overhaul (AMO) personnel. AMO 
management is responsible to schedule and ensure the performance of these procedures for each 
instrument on a routine basis as required per typical Baker Hughes PM frequency for downhole 
wireline equipment.

6 Safety and Regulatory 
Safety is of primary importance in our operations. All of Baker Hughes management, employees, 
and contract employees have the responsibility to make the safety of ourselves and our co-workers 
a fundamental concern.  With this in mind the following has been compiled as a reference of the 
possible safety risks associated with this operation.  Refer to the Stop Work Authority and other 
related Health, Safety, Environment and Security (HSE&S) Enterprise Operational Controls located 
on the HSE&S Management System website or through BHOS. Always consider that if more than 
one safety rule or standard exists then always default to the most stringent. 
 Dangerous Goods Shipping and Transportation (DGST) 
 Electrical Safety (ELEC) 
 Equipment Safety (EQIP) 
 Hand Protection (HAND) 
 Laboratory Operations (LABO) 
 Lifting and Rigging (LIFT) 
 Lithium Battery Safe Handling (LBSH) 
 Lithium Battery Waste Accumulation and Management (LBAM) 
 Fire Prevention and Control (FIRE) 
 Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)

4911 EG Repair/Maintenance Procedures

8.1.1 Verify O-Rings 
Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
1.____ 
Verify that there is an O-ring located on the exterior of the 4911 EG 
Standard Single Conductor Top Assembly (A3003393000). 
 
2.____

4911 EG Electronics Chassis (A3003391000).  
 
 
Note 
 
When handling the electronics section, do not touch 
the cards. Observe proper ESD protection handling 
procedures with this assembly. Handle only the card 
holder portion. 
 
 
 
 
3.____

4911 EG Insulator/Heat Sink/Battery Assembly (A3003396000). 
 
4.____ 
Verify that there are two (2) O-rings located on either end of the 
4911 EG Seal Head Assembly (A3003397000).

Step/Initial 
Action 
Time/Step 
5.____

6.____ 
From the Settings menu, select System. 
 
7.____

not, select it, press OK in the window, then close and restart the 
program as prompted. 
 
8.____ 
From the File menu, select New Log: 
A. Verify that the Data Source is Tethered Tool and that the Units 
are English. 
B. Verify that the Tool Type is 7 inch, 14 FL – 14 DIS channel tool. 
C. Select the Company Name box. 
D. From the menu that comes up type in company, well, and field 
names (x will work in all three for testing purposes) and click OK 
twice, a warning screen will come up, click OK. 
 
9.____

10.____

11.____

plugged into the back of the 4921 Interface Panel. 
 
12.____ 
Attach a BNC cable to the Interface Panel Tool Connect. 
 
13.____ 
Attach the BNC-to-alligator connector at the other end of the cable 
using a BNC union. 
 
14.____ 
Place the red alligator clip onto the brass center conductor and the 
black alligator clip onto the SST socket HD cap screw securing the 
yellow/green wire and eyelet to the chassis. 
 
15.____

16.____ 
Click on view to verify communication is established and record the

17.____ 
Plug the sub adapter onto the seal head. 
 
18.____ 
Attach the sub-adapter cable from the sub to the 4919 Test Box. 
 
19.____ 
Turn on the power to the Test Box. 
 
20.____ 
Slowly rotate the switch from Channels 1 – 30, one channel at a time, 
verifying a continuous sine wave on the computer screen for each 
channel. Record the results in Table 1. 
 
21.____ 
Remove the covers from each battery section and verify that the wires 
are in their proper locations (not pinched) and that the batteries are 
fully seated in place. Re-attach the covers with their O-rings. 
 
22.____

23.____ 
Check the voltage of each battery by toggling the battery switch on the 
4919 Test Box up and down and record the voltages in their respective 
boxes of Table 1.  
 
 
Note 
 
The voltages should range between 28 and 30 
volts. 
 
 
 
 
24.____ 
Turn off the battery switch on the battery section.

4911 EG Preventive Maintenance Level 3  
1 Purpose 
The purpose of this document is to provide the procedures necessary to perform Level 3 Preventive 
Maintenance (PM3) on the 4911 EG Electronics Flask Assembly (A3003392000). 
2 Scope 
The document is only applicable to the level 3 preventive maintenance procedures for the 4911 EG 
Electronics Flask Assembly. This preventive maintenance procedure focuses on employee safety, 
environmentally sound practices, and/or troubleshooting. This procedure does not serve as a 
substitute for critical thought and the experience of the Baker Hughes representative. 
It is not intended to be an overriding document, meaning that all local, customer, governmental, or 
occupational policies or procedures that are the most stringent must be followed. 
3 Responsibility and Authority 
These Preventive Maintenance Procedures are intended for use by Baker Hughes representatives 
qualified to perform the repairs and inspection tests as per the master qualifications list or 
competency list. The specific job title and reporting structure of the representative will be 
documented in the pre-job planning paperwork and defined prior to the beginning of each job.  
These procedures are to be performed and documented by qualified Assembly, Maintenance and 
Overhaul (AMO) personnel.  AMO management is responsible to schedule and ensure the 
performance of these procedures for each instrument on a routine basis as required per typical 
Baker Hughes PM frequency for downhole wireline equipment. 
4 Governance Documents 
 BHI Quality Policy Manual 
 Control of Records 
5 Terms and Definitions 
Baker Hughes Enterprise Glossary

6 Safety and Regulatory 
Safety is of primary importance in our operations. All of Baker Hughes management, employees, 
and contract employees have the responsibility to make the safety of ourselves and our co-workers 
a fundamental concern.  With this in mind the following has been compiled as a reference of the 
possible safety risks associated with this operation.  Refer to the Stop Work Authority and other 
related Health, Safety, Environment and Security (HSE&S) Enterprise Operational Controls located 
on the HSE&S Management System website or through BHOS. Always consider that if more than 
one safety rule or standard exists then always default to the most stringent.

 Lithium Battery Safe Handling (LBSH)
