8 Preventative Maintenance Level 3 Procedures 
Prior to beginning each step below, all parts should be thoroughly cleaned of any dirt, debris, 
residue or grease. 
1. A3003392000 “ELECTRONICS FLASK ASSY, 4911 EG”: 
A. Remove the internal assemblies from the flask housing (F189415000) as per the 
disassembly procedures discussed in document A3003392955.   
B. Inspect the flask housing (F189415000) for any signs of damage (dents, gouges, etc.) 
which could cause the flask to fail under external wellbore pressure.  Replace flask if 
damaged.  A heat test may be performed to verify the thermal performance of the flask 
following completion of the electronics test procedure by placing the completed 4911 EG 
into an oven and running at 150 degrees C for four hours.  The internal flask 
temperature (payload temperature) should stay below 75 degrees C at the end of four 
hours at 150 degrees C if the flask’s thermal performance is per specification. 
C. Carefully remove the 4911 EG standard single conductor top assembly (A3003393000) 
from the flask housing (F189415000) and inspect the contact plunger assemblies 
(F854868000) to ensure the plunger does not bind up when compressed or get stuck 
when allowed to extend.  Replace the contact plungers if necessary.   
D. Disassemble the single conductor top assembly and replace the two sealing o-rings 
(F243095111 & F243095009).  Prior to re-assembly, coat the o-rings and grooves with 
Lubriplate® or equivalent high temperature grease.   
E. Disassemble the electronics flask assy internal sub chassis sections from one another 
by disconnecting the sections via the 39 conductor connector (F189328000, 
F265819000) joints. 
F. Check the 39 conductor connectors (F189328000, F265819000) which connect the 
internal sub-assemblies together and verify that they have not loosened from their 
mating components and that they are free from damage.  Check the wiring in the 
backside of the connectors to make sure that no wires are broken and that all 
sockets/pins are securely locked into the connectors.  Tighten, repair or replace as 
required. 
2. A3003397000 “SEAL HEAD ASSY, 4911 EG” 
A. Replace the sealing o-rings (F243095130) on the seal head assembly (A3003397000). 
Prior to assembly, coat the o-rings and grooves with Lubriplate® or equivalent high 
temperature grease.  
B. Remove and inspect the 36 socket pressure bulkhead connector (F189391000) for bent, 
missing, or damaged connector pins. Straighten and repair bent pins if possible or 
replace connector.  
C. With a megohmeter, measure the insulation resistance between all connector pins and 
case (metal connector body).  Verify all conductors have insulation resistance greater 
than 1000 MOhms. 
If leakage is present (< 1000 MOhms), soak the bulkhead connector in Isopropyl 
alcohol and allow to soak overnight.  Remove the bulkhead from the alcohol, 
carefully scrub with a soft bristle brush and allow to air dry.  Once the connector 
is dry, place it in an oven at 225 degrees Fahrenheit for one hour in order to drive 
off any remaining moisture in the connector.  Recheck step 5.  If insulation 
resistance is not restored to >1000 MOhms, replace the bulkhead connector. 
 
130905-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4911 EG Preventive Maintenance Level 3  
 
 
 
Page 6 of 8 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
D. Replace the sealing o-ring (F243095123) on the 36 socket pressure bulkhead connector 
(F189391000) within the seal head assembly (A3003397000). Prior to assembly, coat 
the o-ring and grooves with Lubriplate® or equivalent high temperature grease. 
E. Inspect the seal head wiring assembly (F189429000) for loose or damaged components 
and check continuity of the wiring assembly’s conductors from end to end with a Fluke 
Multi-meter set to measure resistance or continuity. Repair or replace components as 
necessary.  
F. Replace the sealing o-ring (F243095006) on the #4-40 socket head cap screw 
(F250339000) located within the seal head wiring assembly (F189429000). Prior to 
assembly, coat the o-ring and grooves with Lubriplate® or equivalent high temperature 
grease. 
G. Remove the 4912 Split Collar assemblies (F188633000) from the seal head assembly.  
Inspect the threads and bearing surfaces for damage or excessive pitting corrosion.  
Replace as necessary.  Clean and re-lubricate the split collar assemblies with 
Lubriplate® or equivalent high temperature grease prior to re-installation.  Verify that the 
split collar spins freely without binding after installation back onto the seal head. 
3. A3003396000 “INSULATOR/HEAT SINK/BATTERY ASSEMBLY, 4911 EG”: 
A. Replace the centralizing o-rings (F259262221) which hold the battery retainers 
(F189406000) on the 4911 EG Insulator/Heatsink/Battery Assembly (A3003396000). DO 
NOT apply lubricant to the chassis centralizing o-rings. 
B. Inspect the 4911 EG Insulator/Heatsink/Battery Assembly (A3003396000) for loose or 
damaged electrical connectors or parts. Repair or replace components if necessary.  
C. Verify that the 2 P-2 T Battery Switch (F265839000) is functioning properly.  Replace the 
switch if not performing properly. (Refer to the procedures in the 4919 NA manual, 
document no. F140472915).  Also, verify the socket head cap screws which retain the 
switch are secured with DOW Corning 3145 Silicone RTV. 
D. Closely inspect the battery pack wiring on the insulator/heat sink/battery chassis 
assembly for any signs of pinches, cuts or other damage.  Repair as required. 
E. Inspect the battery packs (F189827000), as shown in Figure 1 below, for signs of 
damage and then measure the voltage of the pack using a 100 Ohm, 10 W resistor 
between the terminals of the battery pack connector.  If the measured voltage is less 
than 27 V, de-passivate (stir) the battery pack by holding the 100 Ohm, 10 W resistor 
across the battery terminals for five seconds at a time.  If the battery pack voltage will 
not increase, replace the battery pack with a new one.  Avoid using battery packs which 
have exceeded 2 years from their manufacture date.  Battery pack voltage can also be 
measured using a 4919 NA Test Box (see manual F140472915), but the above 
procedure is recommended to ensure the battery pack is loaded with some resistance 
when taking the voltage measurement. 
 
 
Note 
 
A battery pack which measures zero volts is not a sign that the 
battery pack is depleted.  A depleted battery pack will still measure 
some voltage (perhaps as little as 1 volt, but never zero).  A 
measurement of zero volts on the battery pack is a sign that the 
fuse (on the battery pack’s positive lead under shrink tubing) has 
blown or has been damaged.  If zero volts are measured, replace 
the blown fuse with a new fuse (FUSE, AXIAL, FAST-BLOW, 125 V, 
1 A, 0.25 W; Manf: LITTLEFUSE, Manf. P/N: 0251001.MXL). 
 
 
 
130905-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4911 EG Preventive Maintenance Level 3  
 
 
 
Page 7 of 8 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
Figure 1:  
 
 
 
Note 
 
If a full memory job is not planned, it is recommended to remove the 
battery packs from the 4911 EG to reduce the risk of fire in the 
electronics if the tool should be stuck downhole in a hot borehole 
environment. The battery may catch fire, explode or rupture if its 
temperature exceeds 200 degrees F (93 degrees C). 
 
 
 
4. A3003391000 “ELECTRONICS CHASSIS ASSEMBLY, 4911 EG”: 
A. Inspect the Electronics Chassis Assembly (A3003391000) for loose electrical connectors 
and components which may have become dislodged or damaged during transport or 
logging operations.  Repair or replace components as necessary. 
B. Replace the chassis centralizing o-rings (F259262221) on the Electronics Chassis 
Assembly (A3003391000).  DO NOT apply lubricant to the chassis centralizing o-rings. 
C. Inspect the beryllium copper EMI Gasket (F265828000) for damage, such as missing 
contact petals. Repair or replace the component as necessary.  Secure the #4-40 button 
head cap screw (F246124000) gasket fasteners DOW Corning 3145 silicone RTV or 
equivalent. 
D. Verify that the #4-40 fasteners (F208565000 & F230745000), which secure the 
electronics circuit boards to the chassis, are intact and tight.  Secure the screws in place 
with DOW Corning 3145 silicone RTV or equivalent. 
E. Inspect the printed circuit board assemblies (A3003301000 & A3003302000) to ensure 
that no components have come loose or show any signs of damage.  Verify that the 
circuit boards are free of contaminants or debris which could cause electrical shorting or 
arcing.  Clean, repair or replace the PCB assemblies as required.  Damage or non-
functional PCB assemblies should be replaced (find fault to board and replace – do not 
repair at PCB component level). 
F. Verify the connectors for the harnesses are securely seated into the headers on the 
circuit boards and secured in place with DOW Corning 3145 silicone RTV or equivalent. 
G. Inspect the chassis wiring harness (A3003317000) and board-to-board wiring harness 
(A3003318000) for any signs of damage.  Repair any wiring, connectors or contacts as 
required.  Verify the cable harnesses are secured to the PCBs and/or chassis with 
kapton tape or DOW Corning Silicone RTV to ensure that the harness stay in place. 
 
130905-953  Rev:  A 
 
Effective Date:  3/10/2015 
4911 EG Preventive Maintenance Level 3  
 
 
 
Page 8 of 8 
Uncontrolled when printed—confirm the correct revision is used 
Baker Hughes—Company Confidential 
H. Inspect the wiring to the brass terminator (A1008815000) to ensure the wireline power 
input wire is securely soldered to the brass terminator and it is free from damage.  Also, 
verify that the brass terminator is securely fastened to the brass contact nut 
(A1008804000) and that both are free of tarnish or Clean any tarnish from the 
components or damage.  Replace the components to ensure good electrical contact can 
be made to the single conductor top assembly contact plunger. 
I. Carefully remove the Second Conductor Contact (A1008805000) by removing the two 
screws which retain it to the Contact Insulator (A1008812000), being careful not to pull 
the wire off from the back side.  Verify that the yellow/red wire is still attached to the back 
side of the second conductor contact with a ring terminal and #4-40 screw which is 
silicone in place.  Re-assemble the second conductor contact onto the electronics 
chassis assembly. 
5. Using the wiring diagram (A3003392 WRD), pin-out the individual electronics sub chassis 
sections to verify continuity of all wiring and that no wires are broken or damaged.  Once all 
wiring has been checked, reconnect the chassis sub sections back together using the 39-pin 
connectors at the ends of each chassis sub section as shown in assembly drawing 
A3003392000. 
6. Follow the electronics test procedures in document number A3003392956 following 
completion of these Level 3 PM procedures.

topic: Level 1 Preventive Maintenance - LEVEL 1 PREVENTIVE  MAINTENANCE -- 8255XA  TEMPERATURE - PRESSURE TOOL 1.0 GENERAL  INFORMATION
chunk_text:
1
LEVEL 1 PREVENTIVE  MAINTENANCE -- 8255 XA  TEMPERATURE - PRESSURE TOOL 
GENERAL  INFORMATION
It is recommended that production logging instruments have all O-rings changed after each job. This
may be impractical between consecutively run jobs.  However, washing the unit to remove mud,
grease, dirt, or other debris should be accomplished, and properly dried with clean rags or paper
towels.

PARTS LIST
Items needed at a field location to keep the instrument operational
Hand tools and supplies:
-  Medium flat blade screwdriver
-  Spanner wrench   P/N 104582
-  Scribe or small knife for removing O-rings
-  Adapter for grease fill (C150441-000)
-  Grease fitting (235107-000)
-  Grease gun (231212-000)
-  Silicone grease 16 oz. (237897-145)
-  Freon 11 solvent
-  Small flat file (smooth or second cut)

topic: Level 1 Preventive Maintenance - 1.2 ACTION PRIOR TO A JOB
chunk_text:
Instrument should be clean and functional.  Cleaning can be with warm water or Freon 11
solvent.  Functionality of the tool can be checked with the CLS or with the EXORCIZER test
box.  Remove shipping plugs (11) and check grease levels at pressure ports.  Install the two
pressure port fittings (10) if grease is OK.

Remove the top and bottom thread protectors and execute continuity check of through wiring of
the tool as per Table 951-1, using a digital multimeter (Beckman, Fluke or equivalent).

Check the two pressure sensing ports to assure them to be free of obstructions.  No large nicks or
protrusions should appear around the sensing ports.  Remove any protrusions with a file or emery



Temperature sensing probe should be tightly seated and not bent.

topic: Level 1 Preventive Maintenance - 1.4 POST JOB WELLSITE
chunk_text:
.1
Inspect tool for any damage.  Clean tool with Freon 11 or warm water and dry with rags or paper

Evacuate old grease. Remove pressure port fittings (10) and install grease plug (13) in one pressure
port. Connect grease gun to the grease plug via grease fitting (14).  Grease should be pumped
through the instrument until all old contaminated grease is replaced and no air bubbles are escaping
out the opposite pressure port.  Remove the grease plug and install blank shipping plugs (11) into the

Replace thread protectors on each end of the instrument.

GENERAL  INFORMATION
There are five primary circuits (* sensor circuits) in this component:
- Regulator circuit
* Temperature circuit
* RTD (pressure) circuit
* Pressure circuit
- Interface circuit
Non-critical electronic components that can be changed without Re-characterization of the tool are
listed in MISCELLANEOUS DATA
The three sensors circuits - Temperature, RTD, Pressure - each have a Troubleshooting Guide
and Troubleshooting Flowchart.
The Guide illustrates an overall troubleshooting approach for that sensor circuit.
The Interface circuit is verified for a * sensor circuit through the Troubleshooting Flowchart.

REPAIR  /  MAINTENANCE  PROCEDURES -  8255 XA  TEMPERATURE / PRESSURE TOOL

CALIBRATION - GENERAL INFORMATION
The instructions in CALIBRATION PROCEDURES are AWS assembly drawings, as indicated,
and are included here for reference and familiarization purposes.  Whenever a tool requires
calibration/characaterization it should be sent to the vendor indicated for that purpose.
Certain components are critical and their replacement must be followed by calibration /
characterization.  The critical components are itemized in MISCELLANEOUS DATA section.
The Temperature / Pressure electronics must be operated under dynamic conditions to obtain the
data necessary for characterization.  Characterization generates sets of coefficients that are used in
third and fourth order equations for curve fitting.
The three sensor circuits output three separate frequencies.  Each output has its own ground
connection to eliminate any "crosstalk":
The temperature circuit outputs a pulse rate that is approximately 10 X the sensed
temperature in degrees Fahrenheit (i.e.  150 F Y1500 Hz.)  This output value is not critical
o
because real values will be recorded during  the test and is only a guideline to determine
whether the circuitry is operating correctly.
The RTD (pressure transducer) circuit has an output approximately 10 X the sensed
temperature in degrees Fahrenheit.
The pressure transducer circuit output is a frequency with an initial offset value at 'zero'
(ambient) pressure and is approximately 4 X the applied pressure.
OFFSET + (PRESS * 4) = Pressure Frequency

CALIBRATION STANDARDS
To establish a consistent calibration reference, the tool must be calibrated by a National Institute
of Standards and Technology (NIST) traceable laboratory.  Atlas Wireline Services has designated
Clark Oilfield Measurement, Inc.
9 South 109th East Place
Tulsa, Oklahoma  74128
(918)/ 438-7272
as the vendor for this calibration.

CALIBRATION PROCEDURES
Preparation of the T/P Instrument for Characterization
* Item numbers (x) are from Assembly Drawing  R 152665-000.
* Item numbers [x] are from Calibration Kit  M 156235-000.
1.)
Insure that the bottom sub (36) is properly sealed from fluid entry with bull plug [09].
2.)
Remove top thread protector (38).
3.)
Unscrew the set screw (31) holding in the top connector (30).  Turn the top connector assembly 90o
and pull it away from top sub (26) sufficiently to disconnect the wiring.
4.)
The wiring is disconnected by turning the small 7 pin connector on the back of the connector
assembly counterclockwise.
5.)
The top sub (25) is now free to rotate without damage to wiring.  It is removed using a small pin
spanner wrench.
6.)
Next, the pressure housing (23) is removed to expose the electronics.
7.)
The normal wiring of the top 7-pin connector is not used, but rather additional wiring is installed
exclusively for the purpose of this calibration and is removed when the calibration is complete.
Calibration wiring harness WA #156232-000 is wired according to the following instructions:
a.
Attach (with high temp. solder) the yellow wire from pin 4 of the 13 pin connector to the
power end of the large chassis mounted dropping resistors.  (The other end of these resistors
attaches to the "30 V" terminal of PCB 145611 - DO NOT tie this yellow wire to this point!
! !)
b.
Attach the black wire from pin 7 of the 13 pin connector to the chassis ground lug located
near the regulator pass transistors.

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR  /  MAINTENANCE  PROCEDURES -  8255XA  TEMPERATURE / PRESSURE TOOL REPAIR  /  MAINTENANCE  PROCEDURES -  8255XA  TEMPERATURE / PRESSURE TOOL

REPAIR  /  MAINTENANCE  PROCEDURES -  8255 XA  TEMPERATURE / PRESSURE TOOL 21
REPAIR  /  MAINTENANCE  PROCEDURES -  8255 XA  TEMPERATURE / PRESSURE TOOL

PROCEDURE FOR 8255 XA TEMPERATURE AND PRESSURE CHARACTERIZATION
CALIBRATION SET-UP
These set-up procedures are required to dynamically test and retrieve data sufficient for generating the required
coefficients.
Assembly Drawing B 152665-002 / 5 of 5 illustrates the set-up configuration.  There are certain changes
which must be performed on the instrument before it is ready for characterization.  These changes are
described in specification AWS #152665-001.
This newly configured instrument is then connected to a calibration cable (AWS #156233-000) that interfaces
to a power supply and several frequency counters.
Pressure is applied via the pressure ports which interface the instrument to the dead weight tester.  A crossover
fitting ( / " NPT male) connection is installed for mating to the dead weight tester.  The temperature bath is
1
4
oil filled and stabilized to +_0.2 F before data is taken.
o
The circuitry is powered by applying +150 Volts DC (+_ 1 V) and ground to the appropriate yellow and black
wires of the calibration cable.  Current draw should be approximately 65 mA.
There is no pressure-tight seal through which the power and signal wires are routed and therefore the top of
the instrument must be kept above the surface of the oil bath.
The oil bath temperature should be well regulated and the electronics allowed to come to thermal equilibrium
before measurements are recorded.  One method of determining this equilibrium is to monitor the Temperature
and the RTD frequency outputs.
When they cease to drift or drift less than five hertz per hour, then equilibrium can be considered adequate for
measurement readings.   Insure that the bottom of the instrument is sealed to prohibit fluid entry before
submerging into the bath.
A very high-quality dead weight tester should be used to generate accurate and stable pressures.  It is required
that the dead weight tester have NIST traceability.  The weight table should be floating properly and pressures
allowed to stabilize.  Allow 5 minutes after stabilizing before recording the three frequency readings.
NOTE: At any time, if the pressure transducer is removed from the mandrel, its O-ring (07) should be replaced.
Also, be sure to use a calibrated torque wrench to re-install it.  The makeup torque of the pressure transducer
is 40 lbs ± 5.0 lbs .
CALIBRATION  PROCEDURE:
TEMPERATURE & PRESSURE
COEFFICIENT GENERATION
SH. 1 OF 5
152665 - 002

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR  /  MAINTENANCE  PROCEDURES -  8255XA  TEMPERATURE / PRESSURE TOOL
chunk_text:
22
REPAIR  /  MAINTENANCE  PROCEDURES -  8255 XA  TEMPERATURE / PRESSURE TOOL

INITIAL CHECK
This section is to quickly determine if the frequency readings are within a reasonable range before starting.
The electronic circuitry consists of three separate circuits which output three separate frequencies.  Each
output has its own ground connection to eliminate any crosstalk.
The borehole temperature circuit outputs a pulse rate that is approximately ten times the sensed temperature
in degrees Fahrenheit (i.e. - 150 F will have an output near 1500 Hz.)  This output value is not critical because
o
real values will be recorded during calibration.  It is mentioned only to provide an guideline as to whether the
circuitry is operating correctly.
The internal temperature of the pressure sensor circuit has an output approximately ten times the sensed
temperature in degrees Fahrenheit.
The pressure circuit output frequency has an initial offset value at zero pressure.  Added to this offset is the
frequency representative of the applied pressure and is approximately 4 Hz/PSI.  Each output should be
measured on a good-quality frequency counter with a gate time of no less than one second.
CALIBRATION
For characterization purposes, both temperature and pressure measurements should be taken at the following
temperatures: 100 F, 150 F, 200 F, 250 F, 300 F,  325 F, and 350 F.
o
o
o
o
o
o
o
The recording of a NIST traceable temperature standard measuring the oil bath temperature should accompany
the frequency readings.
Pressure frequency data should be recorded for the following pressures (in PSI), first ascending and then
descending, zero or atmospheric pressure; 1,000 up to 15,000 PSI and then back down to zero in 2,000 PSI
steps.
The data should be recorded in an orderly fashion so that it can be reviewed when necessary.
A NIST traceable pressure standard measurement reading should accompany each pressure point taken for
comparison purposes.
Keep in mind certain fundamental proceedings when doing these tests.  Purge the pressure line to eliminate
as much air as possible.
Do not allow the top sub connector assembly to be emersed in the oil as it will flood the tool.
Turn on the power supply and frequency counters and allow at least 30 minutes of warm-up time.  After this
initial wait, measurements can begin.
CALIBRATION  PROCEDURE:
TEMPERATURE & PRESSURE
COEFFICIENT GENERATION
SH. 2 OF 5
152665 - 002

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR  /  MAINTENANCE  PROCEDURES -  8255XA  TEMPERATURE / PRESSURE TOOL

REPAIR  /  MAINTENANCE  PROCEDURES -  8255 XA  TEMPERATURE / PRESSURE TOOL

COEFFICIENTS REQUIRED
Once the complete data set has been taken, it is to be used to generate coefficients that will be used in third
and fourth order equations for the purpose of curve fitting.  These coefficients should be in standard Hewlett-
Packard 20 coefficient format as illustrated below.
The equation for temperature as a function of frequency is a third order polynomial:
RTD
1)
T(F) = C  + C F + C F  + C F

0
1
2
3
2
3
Borehole temp. 2)
T(F) = C  + C F + C F  + C F
1.1a
0
1
2
3
2
3
The pressure is determined from the equation for frequency as a function of pressure and temperature which
is given by the a two dimensional cubic polynomial:
F(P,T) = G(T) + H(T)P + I(T)P  + J(T)P

2
3
These coefficients are determined by fourth order polynomials in temperature:
G(T) = G  + G T + G T  + G T  + G T

0
1

3
4

4
H(T) = H  + H T + H T  + H T  + H T

4
I(T) = I  + I T + I T  + I T  + I T

4
J(T) = J  + J T + J T  + J T  + J T

4

1.
The frequency data gathered from the pressure transducer RTD temperature sensor will be
used to generate C(F) temperature coefficients for a third order polynomial, equation 1.1.
A four coefficient set should be given for temperature in degrees F.
2.
The frequency data gathered from the wellbore temperature sensor will be used to generate
C(F) temperature coefficients for a third order polynomial, equation 1.1a.  A four coefficient
set should be given for temperature in degrees F.
CALIBRATION  PROCEDURE:
TEMPERATURE & PRESSURE
COEFFICIENT GENERATION

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR  /  MAINTENANCE  PROCEDURES -  8255XA  TEMPERATURE / PRESSURE TOOL
chunk_text:
24
REPAIR  /  MAINTENANCE  PROCEDURES -  8255 XA  TEMPERATURE / PRESSURE TOOL

PRESSURE COEFFICIENTS
The frequency data gathered from the pressure instrument will be used to generate coefficients in the HP
format (times 72) for a cubic polynomial, equation 2.1.
A twenty coefficient set should be calculated for each of the following three temperature variables.  Coefficient
sets should be given with pressure in PSIA and temperature in degrees F.
1.
Twenty pressure coefficients with respect to the corrected wellbore  temperature
measurement using the third order polynomial temperature.
2.
Twenty pressure coefficients with respect to the corrected pressure transducer RTD
temperature measurement using the third order polynomial temperature.
A  convenient print out of these coefficients should attend the instrument when it is returned to its sending
location.
CALIBRATION  PROCEDURE:
TEMPERATURE & PRESSURE
COEFFICIENT GENERATION
SH. 4 OF 5
152665 - 002

* Item numbers (x) are from 130411-975 /Instrument Assembly Drawing  BOM R 152665-000.

that process is left to the responsibility of the owning base and is to

calibration.
Any other preventative maintenance involved with this instrument is
the responsibility of the owning base.
1.)

and the original thread protector (37) installed.

connector in the calibration top sub [07].  Unscrew the 3 socket head cap screws

where they attach to the P.C. board or chassis components and set it aside.
7.)
Loosen the lacing cord tying down the 7-pin connector (17) of the original wiring, and
remove the Kapton tape from around the connector's metal body.

8.)
Re-install the pressure housing (23).
9.)
Re-install top sub (25) being careful not to pinch any wires.
10.)
Connect the 7-pin connector (17) and its wiring to the top connector assembly (30).
11.)
Carefully push the wiring back down into the top sub (25) until the top connector
assembly (30) mates with the slots in the top sub.
12.)
Once in place, the connector assembly (30) is rotated until pin A on the connector
block nearly aligns with the locating tab.  If properly rotated, the threaded hole of the
connector assembly (30) should be visible through the hole designated for the set
screw.
13.)
Lock the top connector (30) in place using the set screw (31).
14.)
Install the top thread protector (38).
15.)
Remove the blank plug (11) and the crossover fitting (12) from the pressure ports
and re-install the standard plugs (10).
16.)
Carefully place the instrument back into its carrying case (55) being sure to include
a copy of the recently generated coefficients.
17.)
The instrument is now ready to be returned to the owning base.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 8255XA TEMPERATURE-PRESSURE INSTRUMENT 1.0 GENERAL  INFORMATION
chunk_text:
1
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 8255 XA TEMPERATURE-PRESSURE INSTRUMENT 
GENERAL  INFORMATION
The Temperature/RTD Circuits each have five similar components:
Dual power supply (Common Temperature and RTD supply)
Constant current source
Amplifier stage
Voltage-to-Frequency Converter
PCM-counter/interface circuit
The Pressure Circuit has five components:
Dual power supply (Separate from Temperature and RTD supply)
+20 Vdc transducer supply
Amplifier stage
Voltage-to-Frequency converter
PCM-counter/interface circuit
All PCM tools use the 8248 Telemetry Tool to communicate with the surface data acquisition system -
CLS.

TEMPERATURE AND RTD CIRCUITS- Common power supply
The dual power supply for the Temperature and RTD circuits is a stable +23.4 Vdc and +11.7 Vdc
source.
150 Vdc, at the cablehead, is reduced to a regulated +30 Vdc supply and then routed (on PCB 145611)
through resistor R101 to two 11.7 V reference zener diodes, D101 and D102. This establishes a stable
+23.4 Vdc supply.
The junction of the two diodes, a pseudo ground, is the 11.7 Vdc source.  The 23.4 Vdc is 11.7 volts more
positive than this junction, and chassis ground is 11.7 volts below this junction, thus creating a dual
supply.
Filtering is provided across each zener by capacitors C101 and C102.
The output points of 23.4 V, 11.7 V and ground are all made into a bus structure across two terminals so
that multiple wires can be attached and routed to various branch circuitry.
Multiple bus connections are used to reduce the circulating currents between branch circuits making them
less noisy and reducing crosstalk because all current paths are returned directly to the source.

TEMPERATURE CIRCUIT
The constant current source/on PCB 145612 consists of U1/pins1-2-3, Q1, R1, R2 & R3.  Precision
resistors R1 and R2 set up a stable reference voltage for U1, which is configured as a voltage follower
with Q1 in its feedback path.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 8255XA TEMPERATURE-PRESSURE INSTRUMENT
chunk_text:
2
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 8255 XA TEMPERATURE-PRESSURE INSTRUMENT


1.2 -  continued
R3 establishes how much current (approx. 1mA) will flow through the temperature sensor which connects
across terminals P1 and P2.
The amplifier stage consists of U1/pins 5-6-7, and its associated resistors.
It amplifies the low level signal that is generated by the probe.
The summing junction (pin 6) controls both the offset and gain of the circuit.
The Voltage-to-Frequency Converter (U2) is a Burr-Brown VFC32 SM.
R11 provides isolation and, working with capacitor C7, U2 gives a full-scale output of 10 KHz for a
10 Vdc input signal.
Capacitor C6 provides a one-shot duration of 8 to 10 Fs.
R12 is a pull-up resistor for the output pulses.
C10, R13, and R14 make up a circuit that restores the pulses back to the chassis ground reference.
The PCM-counter/interface circuitry counts the pulses generated from the sensed temperature and sends
the data to the 8248 Telemetry Tool.
The Remote Unit Controller (RUC- U101 on PCB 145611) is used to count the pulses generated by the
temperature circuit and is the communication link to the telemetry tool.  The Precision Timer (U102 on
PCB 145611) is used in conjunction with the 2 MHz oscillator (U103) to establish an accurate timebase
for the temperature pulses.

RTD (in PRESSURE sensor) CIRCUIT
The constant current source/on PCB 145612 consists of U3/pins1-2-3, Q2, R15, R16 & R17.
Precision resistors R15 and R16 set up a stable reference voltage for U3, which is configured as a voltage
follower with Q2 in its feedback path.
R17 establishes how much current (approx. 0.25 mA) will flow through the RTD sensor, located in the
pressure transducer, which connects across terminals P3 and P4.
The amplifier stage consists of U3/pins 5-6-7, and its associated resistors.
It amplifies the low level signal that is generated by the RTD sensor.
The summing junction (pin 6) controls both the offset and gain of the circuit.
The Voltage-to-Frequency Converter (U4) is a Burr-Brown VFC32 SM.
R28 provides isolation and working with capacitor C15, U4 gives a full-scale output of 10 KHz for a
10 Vdc input signal.
C14 provides a one-shot duration of 8 to 10 Fs.
R26 is a pull-up resistor for the output pulses.
C17, R27, and R28 make up a circuit that restores the pulses back to the chassis ground reference.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 8255XA TEMPERATURE-PRESSURE INSTRUMENT
chunk_text:
3
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 8255 XA TEMPERATURE-PRESSURE INSTRUMENT


1.3  -  continued
The PCM-counter/interface circuitry counts the pulses generated from the sensed temperature and sends
the data to the 8248 Telemetry Tool.
The Remote Unit Controller (RUC- U104 on PCB 145611) is used to accumulate the pulses generated
by the RTD circuit and be the communication link to the telemetry tool.  The Precision Timer (U105 on
PCB 145611) is used in conjunction with the 2 MHz oscillator (U103) to establish an accurate timebase
for the RTD pulses.

PRESSURE CIRCUIT
The dual power supply for the Pressure circuit is a stable +23.4 Vdc and +11.7 Vdc source.
150 Vdc, at the cablehead, is reduced to a regulated +30 Vdc supply.
This +30 Vdc, filtered by C1, is routed (on PCB 145612) through resistor R40 to two 11.7 V reference
zener diodes, D1 and D2. This establishes a stable +23.4 Vdc supply.
The junction of the two diodes, a pseudo ground, is the 11.7 Vdc source.
The 23.4 Vdc is 11.7 volts more positive than this junction and chassis ground is 11.7 volts more negative
than this junction, effectively creating a dual supply.
A current imbalance is caused by having a common-source dual supply.  R41 is in parallel with D2 to
reestablish balanced branch currents.
The stable precision +20 Vdc transducer supply originates from the "30 Vdc" terminal on INTERFACE
PCB 145611.
A wire is routed from the "30 Vdc" terminal to MULTIFUNCTION  PCB 145612 where two cascaded
+10 V regulators, U7 and U8, generate a stable +20 Vdc.
Q3 is used as a pass transistor because U7 & U8 can not deliver sufficient current.
C2 filters the +20 Vdc for the second 10 V regulator-U7.
C3 filters the final +20 Vdc output for the transducer.
This +20 V is the strain gage excitation voltage located at terminals 'A' and 'D'(return) on PCB 145612.
Terminals 'B' and 'C' are the transducer signal outputs and route that signal to
U5/pins 1 & 2.
The amplifier stage magnifies the small signal generated by the pressure transducer.   Instrumentation
amplifier U5 (AD624) is a pin-programmable device configured with a fixed gain of 137.
C18 and C19 help to filter the power supply to U5.
Given a transducer excitation of +20 Vdc and a full-scale output of 50mV, a gain of 137 will equate to
a full-scale amplifier output of 6.85 Vdc - referenced to the +11.7 Vdc pseudo ground.
This amplifier output becomes the input signal to the VFC.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 8255XA TEMPERATURE-PRESSURE INSTRUMENT
chunk_text:
4
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION - 8255 XA TEMPERATURE-PRESSURE INSTRUMENT


1.4  -  continued
The Voltage-to-Frequency Converter (U6) is a Burr-Brown VFC32 SM.
R30 provides isolation so that U2 gives a full-scale output of 100 kHz for a 10 Vdc input signal.
Amplifier U5 maximum output is 6.85 volts.
There is a fixed offset voltage added to amplifier output to provide an output frequency when there is -
'zero'- ambient pressure.
This offset frequency becomes the "zero" or starting point and is created using R37, R38 and R39.  This
design consideration is due to the increasing threshold of the VFC with a temperature increase.
C21 works in conjunction with R30 to yield the final output frequency.
C22 provides a one-shot duration of 3-7 Fs.
R31 is a pull-up resistor for the output pulses.
C24, R32 and R33 make up a network that restores the pulses back to the chassis ground.
The PCM-counter/interface circuitry counts the pulses generated from the sensed pressure and sends
the data to the 8248 Telemetry Tool.
The counter/interface does the counting and the PCM circuitry transmits the data to the 8248 Telemetry
Tool.
The Remote Unit Controller (RUC- U107 on PCB 145611) is used to accumulate the pulses generated
by the pressure circuit and is the communication link to the telemetry tool.
The Precision Timer (U106 on PCB 145611) is used in conjunction with the 2 MHz oscillator U103 to
establish an accurate timebase for the pressure pulses.

1
DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
735 XA  PFC
P/N 130664-935
MAY 1996
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
This rugged Gamma Ray CCL tool is used with perforating guns when one run in the well is required. 
After depth has been verified, the gun may be fired with the Gamma Ray tool still on the line.  Both
polarities of dc voltage may be used to fire the gun (F2 circuit included). The tool features a scintillation
Gamma Ray detector shock mounted to withstand the blast of the perforator. The temperature rating of the
tool is 350  F (177  C).
o
o

1
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS 
735 XA  PFC
P/N 130664-945 
MAY 1996
INTRODUCTION
The PFC tool consists of two sections, the Gamma Ray and CCL. (See block diagram on next page)  The
tool can be divided into the following eleven sections:
Low Voltage Power Supply Provides .  +15 and  +35 volts to power the electronics
High Voltage Power Supply Provides  +1550 volts to power the detector
Detector Section Detects naturally occurring gamma rays from the formation
Pulse Amplifier Amplifies pulses from the detector
Discriminator Picks all gamma rays with an energy of approximately 40kev 
 or greater
Scaler /Pulse Shaper Can scale the counting rate by 1, 2, 4, or 8 and sets the pulse 
 width to 33 Fsec.  
Inverter Inverts the signal from a positive pulse to a negative pulse
Line Driver Low impedance cable driver
F2 Firing Circuit Allows the gun to be fired  with positive or negative voltage
CCL Amplifier Amplifiers the CCL signal and modulates the 85v power line

735 XA  PFC
P/N 130664-955 
MAY 1996
 DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES FOR 1 11/16" PFC TOOL
The following tools will be required for the disassembly of this tool:
1. Strap wrench (do not use pipe wrench)
2. 7/64 hex wrench 
3. 5/32 hex wrench
4. Small blade screw driver
5. Needle nose pliers
6. Soldering iron
SEE ASSEMBLY DRAWING FOR FOLLOWING PROCEDURES, P/N 158506-000
1. 
Remove CCL assembly with tandem adapter (Items 2 & 6) from PFC tool housing (Item 9) using
strap wrench or comparable wrench (do not use pipe wrench on housing).  To remove coil, magnet
and electronic assembly from CCL, remove both end subs and carefully push internal assembly
from the lower end of the CCL (tandem sub [Item 6] end) out of the CCL housing (Item 7).
2. 
To remove tool assembly from PFC housing (Item 9), use strap wrench and unscrew the bottom sub
(Item 13).  All the internal assembly is attached to the bottom sub.  Carefully slide the assembly out
of the housing onto a suitable work bench for further disassembly.
3. 
Unsolder the shielded cable on the bottom side and  upper end of the Chassis Assembly (Item 16)
and the red, yellow, and black wires from the lower end of the PC board assembly.  Remove the 3
screws attaching the Upper End Header (Item 10) to the Chassis Assembly and carefully pull the
shielded cable through the retainer loops on the Chassis.
4. 
Remove the 3 screws attaching the Heat Shield (Item 18) to the Upper End Header (Item 10).  Keep
some compression against the Upper Header while removing the screws because of the spring
tension from the Spacer Spring (Item 19).  Carefully slide the Heat Shield off the Detector
Assembly (Item 17) and pull the shielded wire through the hole in the Upper Header.  Next remove
the 3 screws attaching the Detector Assembly to the Upper End Header.  At this point you should
have just the Detector Assembly (Item 17) in hand.
SEE DETECTOR ASSEMBLY DRAWING, P/N 158517-000 FOR THE FOLLOWING
5. 
The Detector Assembly must be disassembled very carefully to avoid breaking the Crystal (Item 7)
or the Photomultiplier Tube (Item 5).  First, remove the 3 screws attaching the Top Heat Insulator
(Item 2) to the Detector Housing (Item 8) keeping some compression on this part because of the
Spring (Item 4).  Once these screws are removed the Top Heat Insulator, Spring, and
Photomultiplier Tube Assembly should come out together.  There will be some resistance because
of the "O" Rings on the PM Tube Assembly so gently pull on the 3 wires to the PM Tube while
also pulling with the Top Heat Insulator.  If it doesn't want to come out, don't force it.  The Top

DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
735 XA  PFC
P/N 130664-955
MAY 1996
6.
Next, to remove the Crystal (Item 7) remove the 6 screws attaching the Detector Housing End Plug
(Item 10) to the Housing and the "O" Ring at the lower end of the Crystal.  Carefully slide the
Crystal out of the Housing.  If the Crystal will not slide out, with a soft tipped rod, push from the
upper end to remove it.  Be careful not to damage the Optical Coupler (Item 6) or the face of the
Crystal.  If the Crystal comes out and the Optical Coupler remains in the Housing, use the same
method as above using a soft tipped rod to push it out the bottom end being very careful not damage
it.
7.
Before reassembly begins check all components, PM Tube, Optical Coupler, and Crystal, for any
damage or problems.  If the Crystal is cracked or cloudy it should be replaced.  Clean each item
with denatured alcohol and a lent free tissue and let them dry thoroughly before reassembly into the
Detector Housing.  Reassembly should occur basically in the opposite order of the disassembly.

LEVEL3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE 
735 XA  PFC
P/N 130664-953 
AUGUST 1998
1. 
Remove the gamma ray electronics from its housing by unscrewing the bottom sub.
2. 
Remove the CCL assembly from the housing.
3. 
Check the top sub and tandem adapter assembly for bent pins and loose contacts.  Check for leakage and
continuity.  Change O-rings.
4. 
Check CCL assembly for loose components, pins, and pinched wires.
5. 
Power up CCL, 85 volts at 10 mA.  Measure voltage at the drain of Q1ccl.  It should be approximately
42 volts.  R3ccl determines this voltage.
6. 
Simulate a collar by sliding a piece of ferrous metal across the coil.  Observe a DC baseline shift on an
oscilloscope or a voltage kick on the voltmeter of the power supply being used.
7. 
Power down.  Reassemble the tandem adapter, the CCL assembly, and the top sub onto the housing.
8. 
Inspect gamma ray assembly checking for loose components, screws, and pinched wires.
9. 
Remove the three socket head screws securing the bottom sub to the shock sub.
10. Slide the bottom sub off of the shock sub body.  Inspect the wire, boot, and contact button for damage.
11. Ensure that the ground wire is secured to the shock sub body.  Check screw for tightness and RTV it in
place.
12. Reassemble the bottom sub.
13. Power up the gamma ray assembly with 85 volts at 35 mA.  Using a DVM, check the 15 volt supply (top
of Q2).  It should be within ±1 volt.  Check the 35 volt supply (top of Q1).  It should be within ± 2 volts. 
14. Check the high-voltage regulator current at TP2 (1 Volt = 100 micro amps).  Current should be between
90 and 110 micro amps.  This value is set by R2.
15. Check the high-voltage power supply with a high-voltage probe across V2.  This should read 1550 ± 25
volts.
16. Place an Am241 source near the detector.  With an oscilloscope, verify the pulse shape and the amplitude
of the: discriminator, pulse shaper/scaler, inverter, and line driver.  See pages 4 through 6 of the -945
(Circuit Descriptions) section of this manual for appropriate waveforms.
17. Remove the source.
18. Connect a DVM across the bottom sub contact button & mass.  There should be no voltage present.  
19. Power down the gamma ray.
20. Momentarily apply approximately -100 volts DC at the top contact.  The same voltage should appear at

LEVEL3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE
735 XA  PFC
P/N 130664-953
AUGUST 1998
21. Momentarily apply +200 to +225 volts DC at the top contact.  The F2 relay will energize and the applied
voltage should appear at the bottom contact button.
22. Change the O-rings.
23. Reassemble the gamma ray onto the housing.
24. Power up the PFC using 85 volts at 42 mA.  Use an oscilloscope to verify operation of the gamma ray,
CCL, and firing circuit.
25. Using a rubber mallet, tap on the tool.  Ensure no spikes appear on baseline.  If spiking occurs, check for
loose grounds.
26. Power down the PFC.  Fill out an SRO and record in AIS.

SERVICE OVERVIEW
The 1114 XB Minilog is an 1114 XA Minilog that has been adapted to interface
with the Focus tool string.  Like the original design, this Minilog measures the
resistivity adjacent to the wellbore using a pad to primarily read mudcake
resistivity and/or flushed zone resistivity.  Short-spaced pad electrodes measure
laterally about 1.5 inches.  A set of long-spaced pad electrodes measures both
mudcake and formation resistivity up to 4.0 inches away from the pad.  A caliper
curve is recorded simultaneously with the resistivity data, showing mudcake
thickness and washouts.

The series 1114 XB Minilog instrument provides information necessary for
locating and evaluating porous and permeable formations penetrated by the drill
bit.  The pad electrodes are closely spaced, and are placed in contact with the
borehole wall to measure the resistivity of small volumes of formation adjacent to
the borehole.  These small diameter electrodes in a vertical line, spaced one inch
apart, are embedded in the center of an insulated, silicone oil-filled, rubber pad.
The electrode pad and opposing back-up arm are motor driven and operated by
surface commands.  When a log is being made, the pads are extended at the
bottom of the borehole.  Pressure is exerted on the pad to maintain a firm contact
with the borehole wall as the instrument moves toward the surface.

A caliper provides a continuous measurement of borehole variations from 6 to 16
inches, thereby indicating borehole enlargement or the presence of mudcake.
The borehole diameter curve is recorded on a scale calibrated in inches.

SERVICE PRINCIPLES

Minilog tools are used to locate porous and permeable zones and to measure
flushed zone resistivity (Rxo).  By measuring voltage and current through the
formation using two different spacings, a resistance can be calculated.  As the
curves are plotted, their behavior can be interpreted to show permeable zones
including the presence of hydrocarbons.

THEORY OF OPERATION

Operation of the Minilog begins with the sensing pad located on an extendable
arm.  This pad, when properly extended, comes in contact with the borehole wall
and signals recovered from its sensing buttons create the log as it is pulled
uphole.  See Figure 1 for a picture of the oil-filled pad and the button
arrangement.  See Figure 2 for a representative log produced from a Minilog

1114 XB Minilog – Training Supplement
130973-936 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas



1114 XB Minilog – Training Supplement
130973-936 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas
The pad buttons can be used in different configurations (via the setting of relays)
to obtain different measurements.  For standard logging, the 0 button injects a
current into the formation with reference to the backplane (BKP) of the pad.
Button 1 and button 2 tie to the inputs of the detecting circuitry to detect a voltage
that is a “lateral” measurement.  Button 2 with respect to the remote (surface
electrode or bridle) yields a “normal” measurement.  See Table 1 for a list of the
buttons and how they function with relation to the circuitry.  Nomenclature is
according to schematic 197670-100.

with reference to the pad’s backplane.  After traveling through the formation, a
portion of the signal is sensed by other electrodes and it is the voltage present
across a combination of two electrodes that is used to measure the resistance of
the formation and any mud cake that may be present.  The purpose of measuring
this resistance is to determine permeability of the formation.

Minilog tools are capable of detecting laminae less than 1 inch thick if mud cake
is thin and Rmf >> Rw.  A separation between the micronormal and microinverse
traces (resulting from the mud cake) clearly defines permeable intervals and their
boundaries.  Proper mud conditions are necessary in order to use the data
effectively.  The primary use of the data is to segregate porous, permeable strata
from other strata, but it can be used quantitatively to calculate Rxo in fresh mud
conditions.

CALIBRATION THEORY

Fixed resistor values are substituted into the inputs of the detecting circuits to
give a definable value.  For Zero, a 0.50 ohm resistor is used and for Cal, a 150

1114 XB Minilog – Training Supplement
130973-936 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas

ELECTRICAL OPERATION

This instrument operates on the Focus instrument bus and is powered using the
+28 VDC from this bus.  Current draw is typically 135 milliamps when not
motoring and up to 1 amp when motoring.
Internally, the 1114 XB uses the +28 VDC to power DC to DC converters that
provide power to the digital and analog circuits.  See the circuit description
section of this manual (130973-945) for details on how these circuits operate.
The motor control board 197671-000 interprets commands to extend and retract
the pad and backup arms.  Mechanical limit switches ensure that the range of
travel is kept within limits that prevent physical damage to the mechanical parts.
In an unrestricted, open-air condition, motoring the arms takes approximately 1
minute to open/close.
Current limiting firmware is installed to prevent potential damage to the motor.
Should there be a restriction that prevents the motor from properly closing the
arms causing the current to exceed a set value, power to the motor is interrupted.
Two conditions can occur that will set the firmware into action; they are:
!
If current reaches 1.2 to 1.8 amps, the motor is allowed to operate for 1
more second.  After 1 second, current is interrupted and the motor stops.
!
If current exceeds 1.8 amps at any time, the motor is shut off immediately.
Since this high current condition usually occurs during closing, closing the arms
can continue after restrictions are cleared (if possible).  One method would be to
open the arms and try to close again.

MECHANICAL OPERATION

The pad arm and the backup arm extend to form a two-arm caliper function.
They are extended and retracted using surface commands to open and close.

1 This ±5 V power supply checkout was originally written for the 1530 XA Induction.  This same checkout is 
used for the 1114 XB Minilog.

MINILOG CONTROLLER BOARD3
2.0 MINILOG CONTROLLER BOARD
The main function of the Minilog controller board is to measure the driving current,
potential between Button 1 and 2 of the pad, potential between Button 2 and the
Remote from which the normal and lateral curves can be obtained.  In addition, the
Minilog controller board monitors the caliper position and sends the command to
the Motor controller board to extend or retract the caliper arms.
The circuit consists of:
•
on-board power supplies,
•
a Digital Signal Processor (DSP),
•
flash memory,
•
an on-board temperature monitoring IC,
•
Wireline Telemetry System (WTS) communication ICs,
•
an Analog to Digital Converter (ADC) to monitor caliper position,
•
driving signal generator,
•
driving signal switching relays,
•
LOG/ZERO/CAL switchers,
•
signal conditioning circuits,
•
3 Channel 16-bit simultaneously sampling ADCs, and
•
interfacing Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGA)

The Minilog circuit is divided into two major portions: Main Controller Block (MCB)
and Minilog Acquisition Block (MAB).  The MCB gets the data from the MAB
through its serial port and performs stacking and DFT on them.  The MAB drives
current into the formation through the buttons on the pad, performs the
measurement and sends the data to MAB.  MCB and MAB are electrically isolated
to eliminate potential grounding loop problems and facilitate the future
development of other tools (e.g. Microlateralog) with the same main controller.

ON-BOARD POWER SUPPLIES
Power supplies are generated on-board to separate analog and digital circuits.
The main controller digital portion uses +5 V1 D from the +5 V supply (197679-
000) and the analog portion (ADC for caliper position) uses +5 V1 A resulting from
+5 V1 D with a ferrite bead and a filter to reduce the digital noise interference on
analog portion.
The Minilog Acquisition Block uses +5 V2 A and -5 V2 A from the ±5 V supply
(198345-000) for its analog portion and +5 V2 D resulting from +5 V2 A with a

1114 XB Minilog – Circuit Description
130973-945 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas

MAIN CONTROLLER BLOCK
Analog Device 32-bit, floating point DSP --- ADSP21061 (U16), is used as the
main processor because of the 16-bit ADC process and availability of the existing
firmware template.  Its program is stored in the flash memory (U41).  During
programming of the flash memory, the write line to the flash memory is delayed
from the write line of DSP through the FPGA to ensure the reliability of
programming, because the address latch mechanism of flash memory makes the
timing critical for the DSP.  The 24 MHz main clock for the DSP is generated from
an oscillator (U7).  A supervisory chip (U24) establishes a positive reset for the
DSP.
The DSP controls an ADC (U6) through its serial port 1 to activate its constant
current source, and switching A/D channel via multiplexer (U5) to measure up to
five caliper or motor positions.
On-board temperature monitoring IC (U14) is controlled by the FPGA (U31)
through the SPI (Serial Port Interface) to send back the temperature reading.
Whenever a new temperature is ready, the FPGA sends an interrupt request so
that the DSP can read back the temperature through the parallel port.
The circuits support Mode 2, Mode 5 and Mode 7 to communicate on the
instrumentation bus.  Mode 2 command input is interrupt-based while Mode 2, 5,
7 output is parallel port DMA-based (Direct Memory Access).  In normal
operation, the Minilog uses only Mode 2 to communicate.
The MCB is isolated from MAB through D25 and D32 - high speed digital
isolators.  The MCB can send 20-bit commands through its serial port 0 and
receive 20-bit status words or continuous 20-bit ADC bit values from SPORT
DMA.
The DSP can send commands to the FPGA through the parallel port and the
FPGA, in turn, transmits the commands through SPI to the isolated Motor
Controller to control the motor (to open or close caliper arms), and return the
motor controller status.

MAB FPGA CONTROLLER
The FPGA (U31) in the Minilog Acquisition Block accepts commands from the
isolated serial port from the DSP, decodes and executes them.  The FPGA
handles the following commands from the DSP:
•
Synthesizer control: FPGA accepts the command and 16-bit control
word and then sends the control word through its own serial port to the
synthesizer (U33).
•
Set the control register: FPGA has a 16-bit control register to set the
MUX attenuator (U9), Relay Control, LOG/CAL/ZERO Control, and ADC
Channel Enable Bits.
•
Acquisition Start: FPGA is put into Acquisition mode in which it
continuously sends sampling clock to the two 16-bit A/D converters, reads
5

1114 XB Minilog – Circuit Description
130973-945 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas
back from A/D channels which are enabled and then sends the 20-bit
data to DSP through the isolated serial port.  The acquisition starts at
transition of the square wave resulting from the driving signal so that the
ADC starting point of the sinusoidal waveform is always the same.
•
Return Status: FPGA returns the 20-bit Status Word to DSP.
•
Set sampling frequency register: FPGA sets the 16-bit sampling
frequency value received from DSP.  This register controls the sampling
rate of the ADC through the sampling clock.
•
Stop Acquisition: FPGA exits from the Acquisition Mode.

DRIVING CIRCUIT
The driving sinusoidal signal is generated from the synthesizer (U8).  The signal
is buffered (U18) to generate the square wave for a consistent sampling starting
point and is passed to the amplifier (U2 B) for a gain of 5.5.  Then it is filtered by a
3-pole low pass filter (U2 A & U2 D) and attenuated by a FPGA controlled
multiplexer (U9).  The driver is voltage feedback amplifier OPA548 T (U10).  The
driving current is measured through a high precision resistor R28.  Relays
controlled by the FPGA and the digital switcher put the current into either Button
0, 1 or a Calibration resistor network.

DATA ACQUISITION
The LOG/CAL/ZERO signals are routed into the instrumentation amplifier (U19
for channel 0 or U29 for channel 1) through the maze of relays controlled by the
FPGA.  The LOG signals are diode protected (U7).  The amplified outputs of U19
and U29 pass the RC anti-aliasing filters and are buffered (U27 A & B) before
entering the ADCs (U26 & U34).  The two Dual-Channel, 16-bit ADCs are
controlled by the FPGA to sample the signals and send the results to FPGA.

MOTOR CONTROLLER BOARD5
3.0 MOTOR CONTROLLER BOARD
The main function of the Motor Controller board is to operate the motor to open or
close the arms.  The motor controller communicates with the main controller
through the isolated SPI bus so that it may be used as a stand-alone unit that can
be used by other pad tools using DC motors.  In an unrestricted, open-air
condition, motoring the arms takes approximately 1 minute to open/close.
Current limiting firmware is installed to prevent potential damage to the motor.
Should there be a restriction that prevents the motor from properly closing the
arms causing the current to exceed a set value, power to the motor is interrupted.
Two conditions can occur that will set the firmware into action; they are:
�
If current reaches 1.2 to 1.8 amps, the motor is allowed to operate for 1
more second.  After 1 second, current is interrupted and the motor stops.
�
If current exceeds 1.8 amps at any time, the motor is shut off immediately.
6

1114 XB Minilog – Circuit Description
130973-945 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas
Since this high current condition usually occurs during closing, closing the arms
can continue after restrictions are cleared (if possible).  One method would be to
open the arms and try to close again.

POWER SUPPLY
The motor operates from 28 V DC and the digital circuitry of the controller uses
+5.1 V generated from 28 V DC using Zener D18. 

MICROCONTROLLER
Analog Devices Microcontroller U1 (ADuC812 BS) is used to receive commands
from the main controller through an isolated SPI bus to operate the DC motor.
Signals from the SPI bus are isolated by U11 and are shaped by Schmitt Trigger
device U12.
Power supplied to the motor is made available by control signal POWER ON.
When the main controller wishes to issue a command to operate the motor, it
must also issue a signal to turn power on.  When this signal is high, 28 V power is
not available.  It must go low for isolator chip Q6 to turn on and supply 28 V to the
motor control circuitry.
During operation, the microcontroller continuously monitors the voltage and
current of the motor, the status of 28 VDC, and the status of the two limit
switches.  The main controller can request the values of these monitored
parameters at any time.
•
Motor status for current is obtained via monitoring of current flow through
resistor R22.  Isolation is provided by R23, R24, R25 and R27 to the
inputs of differential amplifier U9.  The output of U9 feeds one of the
inputs (ADC_2) of the microcontroller’s internal A/D converter.
•
Motor status for the transistor collector voltage is obtained via the circuitry
comprised of R15, R16, C14, and D14.  The output of this circuit feeds
another one of the inputs (ADC_1) of the microcontroller’s internal A/D
converter.
•
The status for the 28 V supply is obtained via the circuitry comprised of
C9, R1, R2, C7 and D13.  The output of this circuit feeds another one of
the inputs (ADC_0) of the microcontroller’s internal A/D converter.
•
Detecting whether the top limit switch is open/closed is sensed by the
input of ADC_3 and the circuitry of R4, R7, R9 and C10.
•
Detecting whether the bottom limit switch is open/closed is sensed by the
input of ADC_4 and the circuitry of R5, R8, R10 and C11.
7

1114 XB Minilog – Circuit Description
130973-945 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas

topic: Circuit Description - 3.3 MOTOR CONTROL AND LIMIT SWITCHES .......................................................7
chunk_text:
MOTOR CONTROL AND LIMIT SWITCHES 7
APPENDIX A: DC POWER SUPPLIES 8

MOTOR CONTROL AND LIMIT SWITCHES
Isolated MOSFET switches Q1, Q2, Q3, and Q4 are controlled by the Micro-
controller U1 to control the direction of the motor.  When Q1 and Q4 are turned
on, the current will flow from MOT+ to MOT–, and conversely, when Q2 and Q3
are turned on, the current will flow from MOT– to MOT+.
The current of the motor is controlled by DAC_0 of microcontroller through
voltage follower U10 and transistor Q5 (BDP949).  When the microcontroller
receives the command to operate the motor, it will ramp up the voltage of its
DAC_0 slowly to control the current flowing through the motor to prevent a
voltage spike.  When the current reaches the required stable condition, DAC_0
keeps the same voltage output.  When the microcontroller receives the command
to stop motoring, it reduces the voltage so that the current of the motor will be
ramped down to prevent arcing.  In addition, the microcontroller will automatically
turn off the motor in the situation when there is very high current surge or
consistent high current in the motor.
The limit switches prevent the motor from never operating outside the range of a
specific physical distance.  The limit switches are in normally closed position and
open only when activated during operation.  As a result, +5 V power is interrupted
to Q1/or Q2 and will be turned off even though the microcontroller tries to turn
them on.  The motor will be stopped and can only operate in the reverse
direction.  Diodes D4 and D5 prevent voltage spikes or arcing when opening a
limit switch.  They provide the path to discharge the current in the motor.
8

1114 XB Minilog – Circuit Description
130973-945 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas
APPENDIX A: DC POWER SUPPLIES
The 1114 XB Minilog has two power supplies mounted on the electronics
backbone.  Along with one of the supplies is an EMI filter module to drastically
reduce interference and interaction between supplies of other Matrix instruments.
These self-contained, modular supplies mount on a heat-sinking channel and have
additional circuitry mounted on a PC board that is soldered directly to the pins of
the supply.  It is this additional circuitry that will be the topic of discussion for this
section.
Because the power supplies are modular, there is no repair of the unit.  It either
works or it doesn’t.  The only circuitry external to the module (U1) is some
inhibiting control and some additional output filtering.

+5 V Single Power Supply
See the schematic below for a typical configuration of these external components
for a single output power module.


Instrument power is defined as +28 volts for the Focus tool string.  This instrument
power first passes through an EMI filter module before being applied to a DC to
DC converter module; thus, the voltage at terminal E1 is a filtered +28 V.  E2 is tied
to the return line of the EMI filter output.  Pins 6, 7 and 8 are tied to chassis ground
which, in turn, is tied to cable armor.  Two independent windings of a choke, L1,
filter voltage spikes on the output of the converter module.  Provision is made at J1
for trimming the output voltage under expected loads.  In most cases, this
provision is left unused.  Additional output filtering is provided by capacitors C3, C4

1114 XB Minilog – Circuit Description
130973-945 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas
Dual 5 V Power Supply
In the case where a power supply module generates an output of dual polarity, the
associated circuitry is slightly modified.  See the schematic below.


Again, instrument power first passes through an EMI filter module before being
applied to any DC to DC converter module; thus, the voltage at terminal E1 is a
filtered +28 V.  E2 is tied to the return line of the EMI filter output.  Pins 6, 7 and 8
are tied to chassis ground, which is tied to cable armor.  Three independent
windings of a choke, L1, filter voltage spikes on the output of the module.  No
provision is made for trimming the output voltage.  Additional output filtering is
provided by capacitors C3, C4, C5, C6 and C7.

10

1114 XB Minilog – Circuit Description
130973-945 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas
Power Control Circuit
Associated with at least one of the DC to DC power supply modules is an EMI filter
module.  The PC board attached to this module performs several control functions.
These control functions are described below.
A +5 volt supply is generated for other chips on the PC board.  The supply
consists of a single dropping resistor (R3) and reference Zener diode (D1) to
establish the voltage.  This supply is connected to the output of the EMI filter
module (U1).  It is this +28 V EMI filter output that connects to the input of other DC
to DC converter modules within the instrument.  See the schematic below.


heart of the power control circuitry is a programmable microcontroller (U3).  Values
for resistor R7 and capacitor C3 have been selected to give an operating
frequency of approximately 1 MHz.  Supplied with +5 volts from the supply of
(1) A threshold voltage is established using chip U4.  The voltage divider
consisting of R6 and R8 are chosen such that when 20 volts or more (for
instrument power) is present on R6, the reset chip removes the LOW on pin 7
which in turn removes the reset from the microcontroller, U3, allowing it to do
its job.
(2) Jumper inputs to the microcontroller chip, U3, set different length delay
times.  Delay times are established for different tools to limit the current
demand when the Focus tool sting is first powered up.  Delay times, in
milliseconds, and their jumpers are shown in the table below.
11

(3) When power is first applied to the microcontroller, output RA1 of U3 pin 18
is floating (open collector circuit).  Resistor R4 pulls the base of Q1 HIGH
turning it ON.  This state applies a ground potential to all power supplies tied to
the Q1 collector.  Diodes (D2 – D4) form an OR function in the collector circuit,
allowing control over different power supplies.  By tying the INHIBIT pin (active
low) of each DC-to-DC converter module within an instrument to one of these
control terminals (E5, E6 or E7), you can independently control its ON/OFF
function.  With Q1 initially turned ON, no power supply module can turn ON.  It
is not until the time-out function is completed by U3 that output RA1 can
transition LOW, turning OFF Q1.  With Q1 turned OFF, power supplies are
allowed to turn ON because their INHIBIT is removed.  As the power supplies
turn ON, their current demand is confined to that particular instrument.  Again,

1114 XB Minilog – Circuit Description
130973-945 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas

1114 XB Minilog – Circuit Description
130973-945 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas
Refer to drawing 198384-100 for the complete schematic of the Power
Controller board.  As an added feature of this circuit, Power Supply #2 or
Power Supply #3 can be turned OFF by an external source via opto-isolator
U2.  Terminal E8 is tied to a positive voltage.  Taking control terminal E9 or
E10 LOW causes its respective switch to close.  This applies a ground potential
to the INHIBIT input of the supply that is tied to its control terminal, E6 or E7.
This LOW turns OFF the respective power supply.  Terminal E9 controls a
power supply (P.S.2) connected to terminal E6, while E10 controls a supply
(P.S.3) connected to terminal E7.  Thus, independent control is available if
needed.  Power supplies connected to E5 are solely controlled by the timing
function associated with the operation of transistor Q1.  See the schematic
below.

The 1114 XB Minilog Instrument is comprised of DC power supplies and two main
PC boards; one for motor control and the other for all other functions.  This pad-
type tool, when in contact with wellbore surfaces, transmits a 488 KHz sine wave
into the formation via a button that is mounted on the pad.  Receiver buttons
mounted on the same pad in close proximity to the transmitter button detect this
waveform after its interaction with the surrounding formations.  These signals are
phase-detected, amplified, filtered, processed, and sent to the surface computer
system by the circuitry in the electronics section.  A caliper circuit senses the
position of the pad and backup arm, when extended, by a 5 K potentiometer.
Please refer to the Block Diagram of Figure 1 to see the interconnection of these
major components.

1114 XB Minilog – Circuit Description
130973-945 / 1114 XB
JAN 2004
Baker Atlas


1

INTRODUCTION
Level 3 maintenance should be performed on the 1114 XB Focus Minilog Instrument
every four months to ensure the integrity of the service.  It would be extremely helpful
to know the status of the electronics before starting anything.  If electronics meets
the FUNCTIONAL checks described in A3000279 ATP then there are no electrical
parts to replace, but several components should be verified that they are secured to
prevent failure.  There are several O-Rings that must be replaced.  These and other
steps are listed below.  130973-843 lists only parts that must be replaced, other parts
which may be required for repair are listed in the spare parts list.

PROCEDURE
____  1.
Before disassembling the instrument, verify that the electronics is
functioning properly and meets the pass/fail criteria described in
A3000279 ATP checkout procedure.
____  2.
If the electronics passes, follow the assembly/disassembly procedure
to remove the weldment housing to verify wiring and other electronic
components within the instrument.  Check for such things as pinched
or broken wires, loose connectors, loose or missing hardware, hot
spots on PC boards, damaged parts, etc.
____  3.
Observe that all terminals and connectors are secured on the
electronics.  Observe that all wires to the terminals are secured and
have not weakened due to vibration.
____  4.
Observe that all roller shelves are secured.  Observe all rollers and
roller pins.  Replace all rollers that show sign of detoriation or dents.
All rollers should be in good shape to take vibrations until the next
Level 3 PM is done.
____  5.
Verify that all power supply assemblies are secured.
____  6.
Replace all external O-Rings, as needed.
____  7.
Visually inspect the rubber surface of the Minilog pad for cracks or
other signs of serious deterioration.
____  8.
Check for continuity from top connector block J1 to bottom connector
block J6.  Repair any wires that do not show continuity.

GENERAL SAFETY INSTRUCTIONS

•
WEIGHT: The weight of the 1114 XB Minilog instrument is 170 pounds (see 130973-
025).  Use two-person lifting techniques to avoid injury.  Use appropriate personal
protective equipment, like steel-toed shoes, protect against potential injury.
•
ELECTRICAL: Beyond precautions normal for electronic equipment, this instrument
does not require special considerations as far as safety goes.
•
MECHANICAL: When motoring open or closed, keep fingers and other body
extremities away from pinch points.
•
LIFTING: Several structural components have been compromised in utilizing the
previous XA design.  Although the instrument can be lifted from both ends, care
should be utilized not be make sudden movements that could crack or otherwise
damage the fragile older pieces of the mandrel.  VERTICAL MAKEUP IS
REQUIRED.  This instrument should be hoisted without other instruments, but then
assembled with other instruments vertically over the well to prevent damage and only
the 1530 XA induction should be operated beneath it.

LAB SAFETY

•
Caution: If the instrument is left with power applied and there is no communication
between the instrument and the surface system for two and a half minutes, the
instrument will issue a command to close automatically.  For this reason it is advised
to keep the arms always in the closed position and additionally always position the
instrument such that the arms can open and close without interference.
•
Silicon oil could leak out of the pad for several reasons.  This could be hazardous to
foot traffic.  Please take appropriate action by wiping up any leaks.

topic: Heat Test Procedures - 1.0 HEAT TEST PROCEDURE
chunk_text:
HEAT TEST PROCEDURE

•
In anticipation of use in a high-temperature environment (within tool specifications),
an instrument may be operated in an oven to verify performance.  Otherwise, no heat
test for this instrument is required.

topic: Level 1 Preventive Maintenance (Mandrel) - LEVEL 1 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE - 1239MA DLL-S (MANDREL)
chunk_text:
5
LEVEL 1 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE - 1239 MA DLL-S (MANDREL)
ELECTRONICS LOG CHECKOUT
In this section, the electronics will be checked for proper response to a wide range of formation
resistivities by using the Electronics Test Box and wiring Harness.  The electronics should be
connected to a surface computer system, ECLIPS or CLS, through a patch box and 3506 or 3516
telemetry.  See Figure  951-1   Electronics Test Hookup for proper setup.

1.3.1
Instrument Mode Selection
Switch the Shallow circuit to the desired Standard or Enhanced mode.  Power up the
electronics and place the deep circuit in the desired Standard Wireline or Groningen current
return mode.  The Procedure used to Switch DLL-S to Standard/Groningen return modes
depends on the Computerized logging system in use and the makeup of the tool string (3506
or 3516 PCM ).  If the instrument is to be checked out for the Groningen operating mode, a
banana plug must be placed between the #10 and #9 jack on the Test Box.
1.3.2
Initial Box Setting
Switch the toggle switch on the Test Box to "ELEC" and place the Rm switch to 0.1 ohmm
position.  Place the Rf switch to .2 and the GUARD switch to .2 on the ".1 GUARD side".

shallow.  Check the Table below for proper output levels of the internal CAL/ZERO signals.
These values are dependant on which mode the deep and shallow circuits have been placed
in.

Controlled document 130591-856 will serve as the master reference for these

1.3.4
Linearity Test
Switch to LOG and note the readings of the deep and shallow resistivity curves RD and RS
for all six positions of the Test Box for 0.1 Rm.  Readings should be within the following

topic: Level 1 Preventive Maintenance (Mandrel) - 1.4 EXTERNAL HARNESS CHECK
chunk_text:
EXTERNAL HARNESS CHECK
If the electronics and mandrel have checked okay in the preceding sections the 1239 DLL instrument is
ready for logging operations.  A final test of the complete DLL system: the instrument, iso sub,
telemetry instrument, bridle and wireline can optionally be performed using the DLL system tester:
181826-000 1239 Electronics Test Box
181827-000 Mud Shunt Simulator
180967-000 Guard Load Test Box
160445-000 20 ft Clamp Cable Assembly
160446-000 85 ft C-Clamp Cable Assembly
183762-000 Connector Cable, Female
183763-000 Connector Cable, Male
1.4.1
Harness Setup
For operations where the Deep current return is to the wireline, setup the 1239 tool string for
checkout as shown in drawings # 180970-000 or 180971-000.
For operations where the Deep current return is to the Groningen sub, setup the 1239 tool
string for checkout as shown in drawings # 180972-000 or 180973-000.
1.4.2
Calibrate
Perform Primary DLL-S calibrations using nominal values of 10, 10 K for both the Shallow
and Deep channels.
NOTE:
Values 10 and 10000 are entered for convenient checking of the DLL-S and do
not necessarily represent proper k-factors for the Deep or Shallow response in
any tool mode or configuration.

topic: Level 1 Preventive Maintenance (Mandrel) - LEVEL 1 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE - 1239MA DLL-S (MANDREL)
chunk_text:
8
LEVEL 1 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE - 1239 MA DLL-S (MANDREL)
1.4.3
Rf Check
Switch tool to LOG.  Both the Rs and Rd readings can be seen on the CRT.  For Rm of 0.10
they should be within the following tolerances:
Rf Position
Tolerance  Range
10

9.5 - 10.5
1 K

950 - 1050

Make sure that the Test Box switches are synchronized.
The other Rf positions are not checked for tolerance since the system tester cannot
completely duplicate the current patterns which develop in the borehole, especially at the high
and low resistivity values.

chunk_text:

181814-000
Instrument Electronics Package 
ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY REMOVAL
NOTE:  Numbers ( ) refer to items on drawing No. 181814-000
1.
Remove top thread protector (01).
2.
Remove retaining ring (02).
3.
Pull connector (04) using T-Handle 10-32 THD.
4.
Disconnect connector (04) from the pig tail.
5.
Remove sub (03) using Hex Wrench.
6.
Remove retaining ring (06) using Lock Ring Wrench.
7.
Remove electronics assembly (07) using T-Handle 1/4-20.

topic: Disassembly/Assembly Procedures (Electronics) - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239EA DLL-S  (ELECTRONICS) 3.0 ASSEMBLY - ELECTRONICS PACKAGE
chunk_text:
2
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239 EA DLL-S  (ELECTRONICS) 
ASSEMBLY - ELECTRONICS PACKAGE
1.
If bottom sub (08) is not on the pressure housing (05), install it first.
Install two new O-rings (12) on bottom sub (08).  Apply a thin coat of grease on the threads
of bottom sub (08) then screw sub onto bottom of pressure housing (05) using Spanner
Wrench.
2.
Insert the electronics assembly (07), male connector end first, into the pressure housing (05).
Using T-Handle 1/4-20 turn the electronics assembly (07) to locate the pin hole in the bottom
sub for the guiding pin located on  bottom of  electronics assembly (07).  Push/tap on the T-
Handle until the guiding pin is completely in the pin hole.
3.
Screw in retaining ring (06) using Lock Ring Wrench until Vlier springs on the electronics
assembly are completely depressed.  Now back off the retaining ring (06) about 1 1/2 turn.
4.
Apply a thin coat of grease on threads of top sub (03) and then install it on top of the pressure
housing (05), using Hex Wrench and carefully keeping the pig tail connector stretched out of
top sub.
5.
Install connector block (04) on the pig tail quick change connector.
6.
Guide and install connector block (04) in the top sub (03) using T-Handle 10-32 THD.
7.
Install retaining ring (02) in the groove of top sub (03).
8.
Install two new O-rings (11) on top sub (03).
9.
Apply thin coat of grease and install thread protector (01).
10.
Apply thin coat of grease on threads of collar (09) and screw it half way onto bottom sub
(08).
11.
Install one new O-ring (11) on thread protector (10).
12.
Apply thin coat of grease on threads of thread protector (10) and screw onto collar (09).  Half
of collar covers bottom sub and other half covers thread protector.
