topic: Disassembly/Assembly Procedures (Mandrel) - 1.2 REFERENCE DRAWINGS 1.3 DISASSEMBLY - UPPER PRESSURE HOUSING
chunk_text:
REFERENCE DRAWINGS
093703-000
Crimping Specifications
099194-000
Oil Filling Procedure
180155-000
DLL-S Mandrel Assembly (and -100 Wiring Diagram)
180635-000
Electrode Sleeve Assembly
180967-000
Assembly Guard Test Load Box (and -100 Schematic)
181815-000
Assembly Electronics 1239 EA DLL-S
181816-000
Chassis Pre-Assembly
181827-000
Assembly, Mud Shunt Simulator
183752-000
Cable Assembly (and -100 Schematic)
CAUTION:
DO NOT SET TOOL ON BOOTS; USE ONLY
STRAP WRENCHES ON NEOPRENE; and DO NOT
TORQUE THROUGH ELECTRODE SLEEVE. 
DISASSEMBLY - UPPER PRESSURE HOUSING
1.
Remove retainer ring (5) and female connector (4).  Unplug cable (6).
2.
Remove top sub (2) from housing (8).
3.
Remove stainless steel bands (10) from both ends of boot (26).  Drive a flat chisel between
clip and band to loosen clip.
4.
Drain oil from tool.
5.
Remove Neoprene covered pressure housing (8).  Be sure to support housing when removing.
Use ONLY strap wrenches on Neoprene parts.
6.
Remove boot (26).

topic: Disassembly/Assembly Procedures (Mandrel) - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239MA DLL-S (MANDREL) 1.4 DISASSEMBLY - LOWER PRESSURE HOUSING
chunk_text:
4
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239 MA DLL-S (MANDREL) 
DISASSEMBLY - LOWER PRESSURE HOUSING
1.
Remove retainer ring (5) and male connector (30).  Unplug connector (35).
2.
Remove lower sub (29) from housing (8).
3.
Remove stainless steel band (10) from both ends of boot (26).  Drive a flat chisel between
clip and band to loosen clip.
4.
Drain oil from tool.
5.
Remove Neoprene covered pressure housing (8).  Be sure to support housing when removing.
Use ONLY strap wrenches on Neoprene parts.
6.
Remove boot (26).
NOTE:  Most repairs can be made at this point.  For further disassembly, continue with
section 1.5.

HARNESS ASSEMBLY REMOVAL
1.
Unsolder wires (shielded twisted pair), from terminals (42) marked a and b.  Remove screws
(45) from bracket (17).  Remove cable clamp (39) from cable bundle and from bracket.
Unsolder wires (twisted pair) from backside of terminals (42) marked 2 and 2 N.  Unsolder
wires (twisted pair) from terminals (42) marked 3 and 3 N.  Slide bracket off the cable bundle.
2.
Remove contacts from lower connector (35) using contact removal tool (234656-000).   If any
wires are broken off, crimp a new contact socket (230462-000) in place.  Refer to crimping
spec. C-93703.
3.
Slip off cable clamp (39) from end of cable bundle.  Cable may now be pulled through center
of mandrel.
4.
On chassis assembly (38), unsolder three yellow wires from electrode #4 at terminal buss
marked 4.  Unsolder violet wire from electrode #4 A at terminal marked E.  Unsolder two
brown  wires from electrode #1 at terminals marked C and D.  Unsolder black wire from
electode #5 at terminal marked 24 and at terminal marked 25.  Remove 3 screws (40) holding
chassis assembly (38) to upper mandrel (23).
5.
Inside upper mandrel sub, remove 2 screw (27) and 2 ground lugs (28).
6.
Carefully slide wiring harness out upper end of mandrel.  Be sure lower end of harness goes
into hole and does not bind.

topic: Disassembly/Assembly Procedures (Mandrel) - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239MA DLL-S (MANDREL) 1.6 ELECTRODE SLEEVE ASSEMBLY REMOVAL
chunk_text:
5
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239 MA DLL-S (MANDREL) 
ELECTRODE SLEEVE ASSEMBLY REMOVAL
1.
Remove two set screws (25) from sub (24).
2.
Using spanner wrench, remove sub (24) from mandrel (23).  Do not Torque through electrode
sleeve (19).  Put backup wrench on top sub of mandrel (23).
3.
Unsolder wires (14) from three feed-through terminals (11, 12, and 53) at upper end of
mandrel (23).  Unsolder wires (14) from four feed-through terminals (43) at lower end of
mandrel (23).  Remove the four feed-through terminals (43) from lower end of mandrel.
4.
Slide mandrel straight out of electrode assembly.  The mandrel is pinned and cannot be
rotated.

topic: Disassembly/Assembly Procedures (Mandrel) - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239MA DLL-S (MANDREL) 1.7 DISSASSEMBLY - ELECTRODE SLEEVE (180635-000)
chunk_text:
6
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239 MA DLL-S (MANDREL) 
DISSASSEMBLY - ELECTRODE SLEEVE (180635-000)
1.
Use wire brush and/or course sandpaper to remove rust from area of electrode solder seams.
CAUTION:
USE APPROPRIATE MEASURES IN HANDLING
AND USE OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS.
2.
Apply Kester Flux #817 (8) to clean electrode solder joint of first electrode.
3.
Using electrode assembly clamp and leaving access to solder seam, loosely clamp electrode
to prevent sudden release and splatter of molten solder.
4.
Use 400 W soldering iron to apply heat until solder melts along electrode seam edges.
Remove molten solder, moving along length of seam until electrode edge is completely
desoldered.
NOTE:  Minimize heat input so as to not damage rubber.

5.
Slowly loosen electrode clamp to allow removal of electrode from copper bar.  Additional
spot heating may be required for complete disassembly.
6.
Discard electrode.
7.
Repeat steps for remaining eight electrodes.

ELECTRODE ASSEMBLY
1.
Using approved cleaning fluid, clean sleeve (1) electrode sections and dry.
CAUTION:
USE APPROPRIATE MEASURES IN HANDLING
AND USE OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS.
2.
Apply Kester Flux #817 (8) to clean #4 A copper bar.  Using 400 W soldering iron, tin entire
length of copper bar with ample solder (9).
3.
Spread .50 inch electrode (2) open and install over sleeve (1) to 4 A electrode section.
4.
Using electrode assembly clamp, clamp electrode around sleeve with the electrode edges
positioned closed and centered over the copper bar.
Note:  For longer length electrodes use two clamps as required.

7
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239 MA DLL-S (MANDREL)
5.
Use soldering iron to apply heat until tinned solder on copper bar melts and flows along
electrode edges.  Apply additional solder to seam to completely fill joint and build up a
solder bead.  Move along length of seam until electrode edge is completely soldered.
NOTE:  Minimize heat input so as to not damage rubber, but yet allow sufficient heat
input to ensure against cold solder joints.
6.
Apply spot heat and solder to seam of electrode as required to ensure a good solder joint and
solder bead.
7.
Repeat above steps for remaining eight electrodes.
8.
Using flux cleaner thoroughly clean solder seams of all flux residue.

ELECTRODE CHECKS
1.
Refer to 180635-000 and measure DC resistance of electrodes and solder joints between
noted test points.  Resistance measurements to be 100 miliohms maximum.
2.
Measure isolation resistance between each and/or any electrode when dry and at room
temperature.  Resistance measurements to be 20.0 megohms minimum.

topic: Disassembly/Assembly Procedures (Mandrel) - 2.3 ASSEMBLY - ELECTRODE SLEEVE AND MANDREL
chunk_text:
ASSEMBLY - ELECTRODE SLEEVE AND MANDREL
1.
Before installing electrode sleeve, wrap 2 layers of teflon tape (18) on mandrel (see Fig. 955-
3).
2.
Clean and tin 3 contact pins (16).  Cut three pieces of wire 3" long, 1 yellow 20 GA, 1 brown
20 GA, and 1 violet 20 GA.  Install one contact pin (16) on end of each wire.  Clean and
install shrinkable tubing (15).
3.
Install contact pin with brown wire into sleeve (19) connector attached to electrode #1.  Install
contact pin with yellow wire into sleeve (19) connector attached to electrode #4.  Install
contact pin with violet wire into sleeve (19) connector attached to electrode 4 A.
4.
Cut four pieces of wire (14) 6" long, 1 white 20 GA, 1 orange 20 GA, 1 black 20 GA, and 1
red 20 GA.

8
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239 MA DLL-S (MANDREL)
5.
Solder white wire to contact bar, located at lower end of sleeve (19) in circular groove,
connected to electrode #3, orange to electrode #3 N, black to electrode #2 N, and red to elctrode
#2.  Clean thoroughly with flux remover.
6.
Slide electrode sleeve (9) over  mandrel (23).  Be sure pins  are aligned with  alignment slots
in sleeve (9).  Replace the four feed-through terminals (43) in  mandrel (23).  Check terminals
for leakage; should be greater than 100 Meg Ohms.
7.
Connect red 20 GA wire (14) to pressure terminal (43) 2, black to 2 N, white to 3, and orange
to 3 N.  Clean thoroughly with flux remover to prevent leakage problems after assembly.
NOTE:  As pressure terminals (43) on lower end of mandrel (23) are not marked, it is
important to use proper wire color (Dwg. # 180155-100) for ease of terminal
identification.  Also, pressure terminals designated for 2 and 2 N should be located on
one side of mandrel (23); 3 and 3 N should be on opposite (180 E) side.
8.
Place new O-rings [-330 and -224] (21 and 22) in position (See Figures 955-4 and -5).

9
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239 MA DLL-S (MANDREL)
9.
Coat threads and O-rings [-224](22) with Lubriplate 930 AA-ID #205933.
10.
Secure the mandrel in a chain vise (See Figure 955-6).
NOTE:  Align the guide pins with slots inside the sleeve.  Slide the sleeve up until it
butts against the weld on the mandrel.  DO NOT, AT ANY TIME DURING
ASSEMBLY, CHAIN DOWN SLEEVE OR HOLD A BACK-UP ON THE SLEEVE.
11.
Screw lower adapter (24) onto mandrel.  Use spanner wrench to tighten.  (Refer to Figure
955-7.)
12.
Check for alignment of counter sunk holes.  Screw both set screws (25) into adapter and
tighten.  (See Figures 955-8 and -9.)

10
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239 MA DLL-S (MANDREL)
13.
Clean and tin pressure terminal pins (11, 12, and 53).  Check pressure terminal pins for
leakage resistance, should be greater than 100 meg ohms.  Replace if necessary.
14.
Install shrinkable tubing (15) on wires.  Use sleeve (13) to connect wire (14) to pressure
terminals (11, 12, and 53), or use optional method of wrapping connection with buss wire and
then soldering, leaving a loop for expansion.  Clean thoroughly with flux remover.  Shrink
tubing over connection.
15.
Coat pins and entire area around wires with Red Glyptol-ID #220591.  Let dry and apply a
second coat of Glyptol.

HARNESS ASSEMBLY INSTALLATION  (Refer to Dwg. 180155-000)
1.
Carefully slide cable assembly (6) into mandrel.  A pull wire will be useful in this operation.
2.
Connect ground lug (28) inside upper mandrel sub.  Be sure surface is clean and a good
ground connection is made.  (This is assuming that the two 20 GA, black twisted wires are
already attatched to chassis terminals labled "24" and "25" as per wiring diagram 180155-
100.)
3.
Connect chassis (38) with 3 screws (40) to mandrel at upper end.  Be sure all electrode wires
are through hole in chassis.
NOTE:  File the screw heads (40) off flush with the outside edge of the wire chassis (see
marked "4" on chassis (38), making sure that yellow wires from uphole connector pins 15 and
16 are also attached.  Solder the two brown wires from pressure terminal 1 (11) (electrode
#1) to terminals marked "C" and "D" on the chassis, making sure that brown wires from
uphole connector pins 22 and 23 are also attached.  Solder the violet wire from pressure
terminal 5 (53) (electrode #4 A) to terminal marked "E," making sure the violet wire from
uphole connector pin 17 is also attatched.  Clean flux from solder joints with flux remover.
5.
At lower end of mandrel, install cable clamp (39) and bracket (17) over wire bundle.  (See
from pressure terminal 3 N (43) to backside of terminal marked "3 N."  Install bracket on adapter
sub (24) with screws (45), spacers (44) and washers (41).

11
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239 MA DLL-S (MANDREL)
6.
Make-up cable clamp (39) tight on cable bundle.  Solder 2 K ohm resistor (60) from terminal
marked "2" to terminal marked "A."  Solder 2 K ohm resistor (60) from terminal marked "2 N"
to terminal marked "A."  Solder 2 K ohm resistor (60) from terminal marked "3" to terminal
marked "B."  Solder 2 K  ohm resistor (60) from terminal marked "3 N" to terminal  marked
"B."  Solder white wire (shielded, twisted pair) to terminal marked "A."  Solder yellow wire
(shielded, twisted pair) to terminal marked "B."
ASSEMBLY NOTE:  Insulate resistor (60) leads with shrinkable tubing (61) before
soldering in place.  Use RTV (62) to secure resistors to bracket (17).
7.
Assemble contacts into connector (35).  Refer to wiring diagram 180155-100.
8.
Measure leakage resistance and continuity.  (See Repair Maintenance Procedures, Section -
956.)

topic: Disassembly/Assembly Procedures (Mandrel) - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239MA DLL-S (MANDREL) 2.5 ASSEMBLY - LOWER PRESSURE HOUSING
chunk_text:
12
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239 MA DLL-S (MANDREL)
NOTE:  Refer to Drawing # 180155-000 for Sections 2.5, 2.6, and 2.7. 
ASSEMBLY - LOWER PRESSURE HOUSING
1.
Install O-rings [-229](7) on mandrel lower sub (24).  Coat threads and O-rings with Lubriplate
930 AA.
2.
Be sure new lower boot (26) is clean and free of defects.  Install boot (26) and two clamps
(10), on lower end of mandrel.  Use caution to not overtighten clamps and cut boot.  Refer to
Sec. 2.6.
3.
Install pressure housing (8) on mandrel using strap wrenches to tighten.
4.
Be sure lower sub (29) is clean and in good shape.  Install new O-rings [-229](7) and coat
threads and O-rings with Lubriplate 930 AA.  Pull harness connector through sub when
installing.  Install sub using strap wrenches to tighten.
5.
Connect 28 pin male connector (30) to lower cable connector (35).  Install connector and
retainer (5) in sub.

topic: Disassembly/Assembly Procedures (Mandrel) - 2.6 ASSEMBLY - UPPER PRESSURE HOUSING
chunk_text:
ASSEMBLY - UPPER PRESSURE HOUSING
1.
Install new O-rings [-229] (7) on upper mandrel sub. Coat threads and O-rings with
Lubraplate 930 AA.
2.
Be sure new upper boot (26) is clean and free of defects.  Install boot (26) and two clamps
(10) on mandrel upper end.  Use caution to not overtighten clamps and cut boot.  Refer to
Sec. 2.6.
3.
Install pressure housing (8) on mandrel using strap wrenches to tighten.  Pressure housing
must be supported.  Do not torque through electrode sleeve (19).  Put backup wrench on
lower housing (8) or lower sub (29).
4.
Be sure upper sub (2) is clean and in good shape.  Install new O-rings [-229] (7) and coat
threads and O-rings with Lubraplate 930 AA.  Pull harness connector through sub when
installing.  Install sub using strap wrenches to tighten.
5.
Connect female connector (4) to harness.  Install connector and retainer (5) in sub.

topic: Disassembly/Assembly Procedures (Mandrel) - DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239MA DLL-S (MANDREL) 2.7 BAND BOOTS
chunk_text:
13
DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - 1239 MA DLL-S (MANDREL) 
BAND BOOTS
1.
Place two bands (10) on boot.
2.
Be sure boot is in position with 1/8" clearance on each end.  Place band on boot so band is
over groove and not on edge.
3.
Tighten band with Punch Lok banding tool.  Boot will slide towards end while band is being
tightened.  This action stretches boot.
4.
Tighten band sufficiently to seal boot, but do not deform boot with excessive squeeze.  Hit
Punch Lok with hammer to lock band, but do not use excessive force.  Break excess band
with Punch Lok tool.
5.
Tighten other band on other end of boot in same manner.  Squeeze boot to remove bulges as
band is tightened.
6.
Perform electrical check on mandrel as per Repair/Maintenance (Section -956).

topic: % Repair/Maintenance Procedures (Electronics) - 2.3 VERIFY DC POWER SUPPLY
chunk_text:
VERIFY DC POWER SUPPLY
Reference Assembly # 181812 (± 15 V Power Supply) and # 181817 (Wiring Diagram DLL-S 1239
Electronics).
In this section the two (2) power supplies used in the 1239 will be checked out.
Additional parts needed for the tests described in this section:
-   2 ea 50 ohm, $5 Watts resistors (e.g. # 231742)
-   2 ea 90 ohm, $3 Watts resistors (e.g. # 241239)
Note:  Any electrical measurement instrument (unless battery operated) used for the DLL-S
1239 Setup and/or Checkout should be isolated from ground.
1.
De-solder the red (RED) wire that connects the pin #2 of VR1 to the +15 V buss of PS1 from
the buss.
2.
De-solder the orange (ORG) wire that connects the pin #2 of VR2 to the -15 V buss of PS1
from the buss.
3.
Rotate the back bone so that the side with the PS2 Power Supply board (# 181812) is facing
up.
4.
Locate the feedthru terminal (near VR1 and C6) with two ORG wires and the -ve lead of the
capacitor C6 connected to it.  De-solder, from the feedthru terminal, the ORG wire that is
connected to terminal PS1-VE of the Cal/Zero board.
5.
Locate the feedthru terminal (next to C6) that has two RED wires connected to it.  De-solder,
from the feedthru terminal, the RED wire that is connected to terminal +VE of the Cal/Zero
board (#181807).
6.
De-solder the RED, ORG, and GRY wires from terminals marked +15 V, -15 V, and COM
respectively of the PS2 board (#181812).
7.
De-solder the ORG wire from terminal PS2-VE of the PS2 board.
8.
Verify wires de-soldered in steps 1 thru 7 are not touching any components, boards, or
backbone.
9.
Apply 180 Vac to the electronics.
10.
Measure the COM1 buss voltage at RED wire de-soldered in step #1.  It should be +15 Vdc
±10 mVdc.  Look at this voltage with scope.  Ripple should be #5 mVpp.

VERIFY CLOCK SIGNALS
Reference # 181800 (Logic & Deep Reference).
In this section all the logic and clock signals will be checked for frequency and phase.
You will need a frequency counter for tests in this section.  Some handheld Multimeters (e.g. Fluke
79) also provide frequency measurement capability.
1.
Make sure the instrument is in SrtnDp/EnhSh mode.  Turn the instrument power on (.180
Vac).  Switch to internal CAL.
2.
On the Logic & Deep Ref. board, measure the frequency at terminal SH_CLK.  It should be
128 Hz ±0.1 Hz.  Using a scope, observe this signal to be a unipolar square wave with an
amplitude of 10 V.
3.
Similarly, check the terminal marked DP_CLK.  It should read 32 Hz ±0.1 Hz square wave
with an amplitude of 10 V.
4.
Leave one input of the scope connected to the DP_CLK terminal.  Connect the other channel
to terminal not QD90.  Synchronize scope to the channel with DP_CLK at its input.
Observe the not QD90 signal to be out of phase by 90 degrees w.r.t. DP_CLK (or QD).
%
5.
Measure the frequency of not QD90 signal.  It should be 32 Hz ±0.1 Hz.

VISUAL INSPECTION
_____

PREREQUISITES
1.
The electronics (P/N 181814-000) should be pulled out of the housing and laid out on a lab
bench at ambient temperature.
2.
Visual inspection as per section 2.1 of this procedure should have been performed.
3.

4.

5.

6.
The electronics is hooked up to either a CLS/ECLIPSE surface system, or to a 3619
Resistivity Test Box or equivalent equipment that would allow the control of downhole
power to the electronics and to perform CAL/ZERO/LOG switching.
Note:  Any electrical measurement instrument unless battery operated that is used for
DLL-S 1239 Setup and/or Checkout should be isolated from ground.

PREREQUISITES
_____

topic: % Repair/Maintenance Procedures (Electronics) - 3.3 DEEP REFERENCE SETUP AND CHECKOUT
chunk_text:
DEEP REFERENCE SETUP AND CHECKOUT
Reference Assembly # 181800 (Logic & Deep Reference) and Assembly # 181801 (Deep Driver).
In this section, the maximum Deep Source current along with the phase of the Deep current with
respect to Deep clock will be set.  The performance of the Deep reference and driver circuits will be
checked.
NOTE:  Any references to components and/or terminals without
specifying the board implies the Deep Reference & Logic Board
(# 181800).
1.
Make sure that the electronics is in the Standard Return Deep (SrtnDp) and Enhanced
Shallow (EnhSh) mode.
2.
Switch the electronics to internal CAL mode.
3.
Using a short clip lead, connect the V2 DD terminal to COM2 terminal.
4.
Using a dual trace scope; connect input of Ch1 to QD of the Deep Ref & Logic board.
Connect input of Ch2 to the output of the Bandpass Filter (pin #7 of U6) at terminal RED.
Connect the scope ground to COM2.  Synchronize the scope with respect to Ch1 (QD).
5.
Adjust the trimpot R2 to read .10 Vdc at its wiper.
6.
Using the trimpot R17 adjust the frequency/phase of the Bandpass Filter for the 32 Hz sine
wave signal at the terminal RED to be in phase with the Deep clock QD.
7.
Connect a DVM to the terminal RED.  Measure the Bandpass Filter output for AC voltage
`with respect to' (wrt) COM2.
8.
Re-adjust the trimpot R2 so that the Bandpass Filter output is 1.00 Vac.
9.
While continuing to monitor the voltage in step #8, put a short across the 1 K resistor R2 on
the Deep Driver board (# 181801) using a clip lead (connect terminal ORG to COM1 on the
Deep Driver board).  The change in voltage measurement should be less than 10 mVac.
10.
Remove the short from across R2 of the Deep Driver board.  Measure across the 5 ohm
resistor R1 on the Deep Driver (#181801) board.  This voltage should be within ±10 mVac
of the 1.0 Vac measured in step #8.
11.
Measure the dc voltage at the wiper of R2.  It should be 10.25 Vdc ±0.25 Vdc
12.
Disconnect all jumpers and scope leads.

DEEP REFERENCE SETUP AND CHECKOUT
_____

topic: % Repair/Maintenance Procedures (Electronics) - 3.4 SHALLOW REFERENCE SETUP AND CHECKOUT
chunk_text:
SHALLOW REFERENCE SETUP AND CHECKOUT
Reference Assembly # 181802 (Shallow Reference) and Assembly # 181803 (Shallow Driver).
In this section, the maximum available Shallow Source current in the Enhanced Shallow (EnhSh)
mode will be setup.  The phase of the Shallow source will be adjusted w.r.t. the Shallow clock QS.
Also, the performance of Shallow reference and driver circuits will be checked.
NOTE:  Any references to components and/or terminals without
specifying the board implies the Shallow Reference board (#181802).
1.
Make sure that the electronics is still in SrtnDp and EnhSh mode.
2.
Switch the electronics to internal CAL mode.
3.
Using a short clip lead, connect the V2 S terminal to COM2 terminal on the Shallow
Reference board (#181802).
4.
Using a dual trace scope; connect input of Ch1 to QS.  Connect input of Ch2 to the output of
the Bandpass Filter (pin #8 of U8) at terminal BRN.  Connect the scope ground to COM2.
Synchronize the scope with respect to Ch1 (QS).
5.
Adjust trimpot R3 on the Shallow Reference board so that the voltage at its wiper is .11.5
Vdc.
6.
Using the trimpot R21 adjust the frequency/phase of the Bandpass Filter for the 128 Hz sine
wave signal at the terminal BRN to be in phase with the Shallow clock QS.
7.
Connect a DVM across the 1 ohm resistor R3 on the Shallow Driver board (#181803).
Select the DVM to measure AC voltage.
8.
Adjust trimpot R3 on the Shallow Reference board so that the DVM in step #6 above reads
125 mVac.
9.
On the VEQ board (#181808), connect a short clip lead between terminals GRN and VIO.
The AC voltage measured in step #7 above should not change by more than 2 mVac.
10.
Using the same DVM as in step #7 and #8, measure the AC voltage between terminals BRN
and YEL on the Shallow Reference board.  This voltage should be within ±5 mVac of the
voltage measured in step #7 above.
11.
Measure the dc voltage at the wiper of trimpot R3 on the Shallow Reference board.  It
should read 11.75 Vdc ±0.25 Vdc
12.
Remove all clip leads and shorts.

SHALLOW REFERENCE AND CHECKOUT
_____

DETECTION CIRCUITS SETUP
Reference Assembly # 181804 (Voltage Pre-Amp), Assembly # 181805 (Current Pre-amp), and
Assembly # 181806 (PSD & Feedback).
In this section various bandpass filters will be adjusted for proper in phase detection of output
signals.
This will be done with the electronics in SrtnDp/EnhSh internal CAL mode and with the feedbacks
disconnected and by alternatively disabling the Shallow and Deep signals.  These adjustments
involve working with several boards.  Before installing a short or a jumper, please make sure
you clearly understand what board is being referred to.  It will provide a quick checkout of all
the gains in detection and feedback circuits.
1.
The electronics should be in SrtnDp/EnhSh internal CAL mode.
2.
On the Logic & Deep Ref board (#181800), connect the V2 DD terminal to the COM2
terminal.
3.
On the Shallow Reference board (#181802), connect the V2 S terminal to the COM2
terminal.
3.5.1
Setup of Deep Detectors
1.
On the Shallow Reference board (# 181802) using a small clip lead, put a jumper
across 232 ohm resistor R18.  This would effectively `kill' the Shallow reference
signal and makes the Shallow Driver output current to be zero.
2.
Using the dual trace scope, connect CH #1 input to DP_CLK (or QD). Synchronize
the scope on Ch #1.  (Scope should be battery operated or isolated).
3.
Connect Ch #2 input to the pin #13 of U2 on the PSD & Feedback board
(# 181806).  You can hook the scope probe to one side of 2 K resistor R3.  This
signal represents the full wave rectified Deep Voltage (ED).
4.
Adjust the trimpot R5 on the Voltage Pre-Amp board (#181804) to achieve the best
rectified (most symmetric) signal on Ch #2.
5.
Measure the Deep Voltage, terminal ED on the PSD & Feedback board (# 181806).
It should be 0.32 Vdc ±0.1 Vdc.
6.
Measure the Quadrature Deep Voltage, terminal QED on the PSD & Feedback
board.  It should be 0.0 Vdc ±0.05 Vdc.

DETECTION CIRCUITS SETUP

18
REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES  -  1239 EA DLL-S (ELECTRONICS)
7.
Now connect the Ch #2 of the scope to pin #13 of U1 on the PSD & Feedback
board.  You can hook the scope probe to the 2 K resistor R1.  This signal represents
the full wave rectified Lower Electrode Deep Voltage (LED)
8.
Adjust the trimpot R15 on the Voltage Pre-Amp board (# 181804) to achieve the
%
best rectified (most symmetric) signal on Ch #2.
9.
Measure the Lower Electrode Deep Voltage, terminal LED on the PSD & Feedback
board.  It should be 0.32 Vdc ±0.1 Vdc.
10.
Connect the Ch #2 of the scope now to pin #10 of U2 on the PSD & Feedback
board.  You can hook the scope probe to one side of 2 K resistor R4. This signal
represents the full wave rectified Deep Current (ID).
11.
Adjust trimpot R5 on the Current Pre-Amp board (# 181805) to achieve the best
rectified (most symmetric) signal on Ch #2.
12.
Measure the Deep Current, terminal ID on the PSD & Feedback board.  It should be
1.83 Vdc ±0.1 Vdc.
13.
Remove the jumper installed in step #1 above.  This should re-activate the Shallow
reference.  Again check the values of ED, QED, LED, and ID.  They should not
change by more than ±10 mVdc from their respective values.

19
REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES  -  1239 EA DLL-S (ELECTRONICS)
3.5.2
Setup of Shallow Detectors
1.
On the Deep Reference board (# 181800), using a small clip lead, put a jumper
across 499 ohm resistor R14.  This would effectively `kill' the Deep Reference
signal and makes the Deep Driver output current to be zero.
2.
Using the dual trace scope, connect CH #1 input to SH_CLK (or QS). Synchronize
the scope on Ch #1.  (Scope should be battery operated or isolated).
3.
Connect Ch #2 input to the pin #13 of U3 on the PSD & Feedback board
(# 181806).  You can hook the scope probe to one side of the 2 K resistor R5. This
signal represents the full wave rectified Shallow Voltage (ES).
4.
Adjust the trimpot R23 on the Voltage Pre-Amp board (# 181804) to achieve the
best rectified (most symmetric) signal on Ch #2.
5.
Measure the Shallow Voltage, at terminal ES on the PSD & Feedback board
(# 181806).  It should be 0.37 Vdc ±0.1 Vdc.
6.
Connect the Ch #2 of the scope now to pin #10 of U3 on the PSD & Feedback
board.  You can hook the scope probe to one side of the 2 K resistor R6.  This signal
represents full wave rectified Shallow Current (IS).
8.
Adjust trimpot R14 on the Current Pre-Amp board (# 181805) to achieve the best
rectified (most symmetric) signal on Ch #2.
9.
Measure the Shallow Current, at terminal IS on the PSD & Feedback board.  It
should be 1.36 Vdc ±0.1 Vdc.
10.
Remove the jumper installed in step #1 above.  This should re-activate the Deep
reference.  Again check the values of ES, and IS.  They should not change by more
than ±10 mVdc of their respective values.

chunk_text:
DRAWINGS REQUIRED
180155-000
Assembly DLL-S Mandrel
180155-100
DLL-S Mandrel Wiring Diagram
180635-000
Electrode Assembly
099194-000
Oil Filling Procedures 

ELECTRICAL CHECK OF MANDREL
NOTE:
Refer to Wiring Diagram D180155-100.  Steps 1 through 12 are
performed using a Fluke 79 or equivalent meter.
1.
Measure resistance between electrodes 2 and 2 N; should be 2 K ±5%.
2.
Measure resistance between electrodes 3 and 3 N; should be 2 K ±5%.
3.
Measure resistance between electrodes 4 and 4 N; must be less than 100 milliohms.
4.
Measure resistance between electrodes 4 A and 4 AN; must be less than 100 milliohms.
5.
Check continuity between electrode 1 and pins 22 and 23 in upper connector.
6.
Check for 2 K ±3% resistance between electrode 2 and pin 20 in upper connector.
7.
Check for 2 K ±3% resistance between electrode 2 N and pin 20 in upper connector.
8.
Check for 2 K ±3% resistance between electrode 3 and pin 21 in upper connector.
9.
Check for 2 K ±3% resistance between electrode 3 N and pin 21 in upper connector.
10.
Check continuity between electrode 4 and pins 15 and 16 in upper connector; must be less than
100 milliohms.
11.
Check continuity between electrode 4 A and pin 17 in upper connector; must be less than 100
milliohms.

topic: % Repair/Maintenance Procedures (Mandrel) - 4.0 EVACUATE AND FILL MANDREL . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 6
chunk_text:
EVACUATE AND FILL MANDREL
NOTE:
See drawing C99194; evacuate approximately 1 gallon of DC oil (37).
1.
Remove filler screws (20) and O-rings (31) from each end of electrode sleeve.
2.
Place filler fittings in each end of electrode sleeve.  Place mandrel on rollers on floor.
Mandrel must be level.
3.
Connect hose from circulating pump (valve 4) to filler fitting at upper end of electrode sleeve.
4.
Connect hose from vacuum (valve 2) to filler fitting at lower end of electrode sleeve.
5.
Close valves 3 and 4.  Open valves 1 and 2.  Turn on vacuum pump and evacuate mandrel
for 2 hours.
6.
Open valve 4.  Turn on circulating pump.  Circulate and evacuate until no bubbles show at
valve 2, (30 to 45 minutes).  Circulate and evacuate an additional 30 minutes.
7.
Close valve 1.  Turn off vacuum pump.
8.
Close valve 2.  Open valve 3.
9.
Remove hose from vacuum (valve 2) to filler fitting, at lower end of electrode sleeve.  A
small trickle of oil should be noted from filler fitting.  Remove filler fitting.  Install filler
screw (20) using new O-ring (31).
10.
After 15 minutes, close valve 4.  Turn off circulating pump.
11.
The mandrel has a slight overpressure.  It will be necessary to hold thumb over filler hole to
maintain as much of this pressure as possible.  Remove hose from circulating pump (valve 4)
to filler fitting, at upper end of electrode sleeve.  Remove filler fitting.  Install filler screw
(20) using a new O-ring (31).
12.
Perform electrical check of mandrel, as per section 2.0.
13.
Wash boots (26) clean of silicon fluid; wrap boots with tape (46) as shown.
14.
Place thread protectors on mandrel.

Maintenance Procedures (Section 130591-956).

procedure).

SWITCHING INFORMATION FOR STANDARD & GRONINGEN RETURN MODE

topic: % Level 3 Preventive Maintenance (Electronics) - 3.0 SWITCHING INFORMATION FOR STANDARD AND GRONINGEN RETURN MODE . . . . . . 3 3.1 ECLIPS . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3
chunk_text:
SWITCHING INFORMATION FOR STANDARD AND GRONINGEN RETURN MODE 3 

ECLIPS
WTS TOOL STRING
Refer to "Tool Control Window" and make appropriate selection to
switch tool string to Standard or Groningen return mode.
NON-WTS TOOL STRING
Turn the downhole power off.  Switch tool string to ZERO for
Groningen return mode.
Switch tool string to LOG for Standard mode.
After selecting Standard or Groningen return mode, turn downhole
power on and switch to desired mode (i.e., Log, Cal, Zero).

CLS
WTS TOOL
With Downhole tool power on, issue the following Commands:
STRING
For Groningen return mode
WCMD  85,14
ZERO  SLAM
WCMD  86,14
Desired DLL-S mode (i.e., Log, Cal, or Zero)
For Standard Return Deep mode
WCMD  85,14
LOG  SLAM
WCMD  86,14
Desired DLL-S mode (i.e., Log, Cal, or Zero)
NON-WTS
Turn the downhole power off.
TOOL STRING Switch tool string to ZERO for GRONINGEN return mode.
Switch tool string to LOG for STANDARD mode.
After selecting Standard/Groningen return mode, turn downhole power on
and switch to desired mode (i.e., Log, Cal, Zero).

ELECTRONICS CHECKOUT
1.
Remove Electronics Assembly from the pressure housing (see Section 130591-955).
2.
Visually inspect and correct any problems.
•  Loose mounting screws for PC boards, transformers, shelves, switches, connectors.
•  Loose or improperly seated I.C.s, op amps, relays, capacitors, resistors, terminals.
•  Pinched or cut wires, pigtail.
•  Broken or bent connector pins.
3.
With a digital meter, verify isolation (reading open on meter) between the chassis of Electronics
Assembly and
•  Three buses of power supply 1
•  Three buses of power supply 2
•  All pins of the cable connector (14)
•  All pins of the bottom connector (J02)
4.
Connect Electronics Assembly to a PC based test system or CLS or ECLIPS.
5.
Connect Electronics Assembly as shown in drawing # B183767-000 DLL-S, Electronics and Test
Box Hookup.
6.
Switch Electronics Assembly in Standard mode (see switching information above).
7.
Verify that Deep and Shallow are setup for maximum output, and all bandpass filters are also set
as described in Repair/Maintenance (Section 130591-956).

LINEARITY CHECK STANDARD RETURN DEEP and ENHANCED SHALLOW
1.
Header on VEQ board must be plugged for Enhanced Shallow.
2.
Perform complete linearity check as described in Manufacturing Final Assembly and Checkout
%
Procedures (Section 130591-856).  This will check electronic performance for Standard Return
%
Deep and Enhanced Shallow.  Readings taken must be within the range described.  If not, perform
Repair/Maintenance (Section 130591-956).  A copy of data sheet must included in the instrument
folder.

topic: % Level 3 Preventive Maintenance (Electronics) - 7.0 GRONINGEN DEEP MEASUREMENT CHECK . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 6
chunk_text:
GRONINGEN DEEP MEASUREMENT CHECK
(Reference 130591-856)
%
1.
Switch Electronics Assembly in Groningen Deep mode (see instructions above).
2.
On the Test Box, connect jacks 9 and 10.
3.
With tool power on, switch tool to log.
4.
Depending on the test system in use, compare "Rd" or "Ed" and "Id" (must be same as noted in
steps 5.0 or 6.0).  Also verify with different Guard Load positions on the Test Box.

LED and QED MEASUREMENTS CHECK
(Reference 130591-856)
%
Setup LED and QED outputs as described in Manufacturing Final Assembly and Checkout
%
Procedures (Section 130591-856).
%

The resistivity value of the uninvaded formation, Rt, is
critical for calculation of water saturation.  In a highly
conductive borehole and high resistivity formations,
galvanic tools consisting of an array of both current
injecting and voltage measuring electrodes, like the Rt
Explorer (RTeX), are the preferred instruments.
The complete Focus RTeX system consists of not only
the RTex electrode mandrel, but also the housings of
other instruments above and below.  The RTeX mandrel
contains the electrodes (center electrode and guards)
needed for the measurement of the shallowest resistivity
(MLR1) and two intermediate diameters of investigation
(MLR2 and MLR3).
Observe the instrument sketch on the right.  The guard
electrodes are symmetrical around the center electrode
A0, with M1, M2, A1, A2 and A3 situated on the mandrel
itself.  This system can be thought of as an array of four
laterologs, LL7 type, with increasing guard length from
shallow to deep.
The instruments immediately above and below the RTeX
mandrel (typically Acoustilog or Densilog above and
Focus Micro-laterolog below) become electrode A4 and
provide the guards for the deeper diameter-of-
investigation resistivity measurement.  On the uphole side
3

of the upper A4 electrode housing, and on the downhole side of the lower A4
electrode housing, Isolation Subs are installed to limit the A4 electrode size.
These Isolation Subs also separate the electrode A5 (upper and lower) from A4
and provide a means for the RTeX electronics to make connection to the A5
electrode.  The particular Isolation Sub used (FOCUS or WTS) depends on the
tool string being configured.
All electrodes on the RTeX mandrel are symmetrical around the center electrode
(A0) in number and size.  Each of the two A4, upper and lower, electrodes is
required to be 10 to 14 ft in length.  However, the upper A5 and lower A5 can be
quite different in length.
Additionally, electrodes A2 and A3 are bookended by small voltage-sense
electrodes.  The A1 electrode has one sense electrode (on the A2 electrode
side).
The Rt Explorer housing is isolated with a layer of fiberglass and the electrodes
are placed on top of this layer.  The isolation between electrodes is a ring of
rubber at each electrode end and more fiberglass in between.
Electronic circuitry for the system is located inside the RTeX mandrel.
Housing material is titanium to reduce the overall weight and allows the
instrument to be handled by a smaller logging crew.
In summary:
•
RTeX provides four apparent resistivity curves with different diameters of
investigation (approximately 18”, 26”, 38” and 74”).
•
It is a fully compatible Focus tool.
•
Environmental corrections can be applied to the apparent resistivity curves.
•
The measured data can be inverted in real-time to derive formation resistivity Rt,

PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION

To illustrate the principle of operation of the Rt Explorer (RTeX), a block diagram
of the electrode array and interface electronics is shown in Figure 1.  Only half of
the array is shown in the block diagram.  Please remember that for each one of
the electrodes shown, i.e. M1, M2, A1 - A5, there is a corresponding M1’, M2’,
A1’ - A5’ electrode.
Electrodes A0, M1, M2, A1, A2, and A3, are located on the RTeX mandrel.  The
instruments above and below the mandrel become part of the electrode system
and are referred to as electrodes A4 and A5.
Four sinusoidal sources, each at different frequencies ranging from 30 to 195 Hz,
are connected as indicated in the diagram.  Frequencies F1, F2, and F3 are
voltage sources and F4 is a current source.
A0 is the current measuring electrode.  The bucker amplifier injects sufficient
current through A0 into the formation to maintain the difference in potential
between M1 and M2 at zero for all four frequencies.  This prevents the I0 current
from flowing up or down the borehole, but rather is forced into the formation in a
“disk” shape, perpendicular to the instrument.  The voltage across the sensing
resistor is proportional to the I0 current.
Electrodes A1, A2, A3 and A4 provide guards of increasing length to electrode
A0.  At frequency F1 the guard is only A1; return for F1 is A2, A3 and A4.  At
frequency F2 the effective guard has increased in length, and is the combination
of A1 and A2 which focuses the frequency F2 currents deeper than the F1
currents.  Return for this mode is A3 and A4.  This pattern continues and the
guard for frequency F3 is the combined length of the A1, A2 and A3 electrodes
with the return being only A4.  Finally for frequency F4, the guard is A1, A2, A3
and A4 (with return being A5), providing the deepest measurement.  All four of
these frequencies are being emitted simultaneously to create the varying
diameters of investigation and are illustrated in Figure 2.
The voltage of electrode M1 combined with the current I0, both measured at the
four operating frequencies F1, F2, F3 and F4, provide the resistance seen by A0
under the respective focusing conditions and with increased diameter-of-
investigation from shallow to deep.  By applying the proper “k” factors, these
resistances are converted to resistivities at four diameters of investigation.
Normally a Micro-resistivity instrument, like MLL, is connected below the RTeX
and becomes the lower A4 electrode guard.  The MLL provides an Rxo measure-
ment that is used for RTeX data processing and inversion.

DATA ACQUISITION
The 1241 XA Rt Explorer (RTeX) is a galvanic resistivity tool with four diameters
of investigation.  Two measurements are required to determine resistivity: VM
and I0.  VM is a measurement of the voltage of the M1 electrode with respect to
surface remote, and I0 is the survey current entering/leaving electrode A0.  Both
signals are sampled by A/D’s on the preamp board and processed by the Digital
Signal Processor (DSP) on the Controller board.  If the tool only had to provide a
measurement for one diameter of investigation, there would be only one driver
operating at one frequency, and the resistivity could be determined simply by
examining the amplitudes of VM and I0.  However with four drivers operating at
different frequencies, the VM and I0 signals will each be a composite waveform
of four different sinusoids.  Now we can no longer just examine the amplitude of
the time-domain waveform.  Each waveform must first be decomposed into their
four constituent components.  The “decomposition” is done by performing a
Discrete-Fourier Transform (DFT) on the signals.  The DFT process provides the
amplitude and phase of the sinusoids comprising each waveform.  This
processing is performed downhole by the DSP, and the results are reported to
the surface for resistivity calculations.

The A/D sampling frequency is ~7.653kHz and the DFT is performed on sets of
512 samples.  To avoid spectral leakage, the four operating frequencies are
chosen to be integer multiples of a base frequency, 14.947 Hz.  These are
29.89 Hz (F4), 104.6 Hz (F1), 164.4 Hz (F3) and, 194.3 Hz (F2).  The operating
frequencies and A/D sampling frequency are derived from a common system
clock so they are precisely related to each other.

The DFT results from multiple cycles are stacked (or added) together.  The
stacked DFT results along with a stack count are reported in the subsets.  The
stack count indicates how many cycles were stacked in the DFT result.  An
averaged DFT result is determined by dividing the stacked results by the stack
count.  Typically, the time interval between “Acquire Subset” commands
determines how many cycles are stacked.  One cycle is 66.9ms (512 A/D
samples).  When the tool receives an “Acquire” command, it (1) waits for the
current cycle to complete, (2) transfers the contents of the stacking buffer to a
send buffer, and (3) clears the stacking buffer to start a new stack.  The “Send
subset” command starts transmission of data to the surface from the send buffer.
The default maximum stacking level is 60.  If the maximum stacking level is
reached, the stacking buffer will be transferred to the send buffer and a new
stack will be started.

In addition to the frequency-domain data (DFT results), the underlying time-
domain waveforms are stacked as well.  The full waveforms, each being 512
samples long, can be uploaded in Subset 4.  The waveforms are made available
for debugging purposes only, that is, they are not needed for processing.

Only VM and I0 are needed to determine resistivity, but the voltage and current
of each driver are measured as well for control purposes.  The DSP implements
a control algorithm used to determine the optimum driver output levels.  The goal
of the algorithm is to operate the drivers at the highest achievable drive level
8

1241 XA Rt Explorer – Training Supplement
131042-936 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
under varying borehole conditions.  Another goal of the algorithm is to maintain a
reasonable balance in the magnitude spectrum of the I0 signal so that one
spectral component does not over-power the measurement and compromise the
measurement of the other components.

The control algorithm periodically checks the measurements to see if they are all
within range.  If any waveform exceeds a high or low limit, the control algorithm
will incrementally decreases the driver output levels until all waveforms fall within
range.  VM and I0 are monitored to see if the signal levels are within the
measurement circuit’s input range.  The output current of the voltage sources are
monitored to ensure they are within design limits.  The output voltages of all the
power opamps are monitored to ensure their outputs are not clipping.

On power-up, the algorithm initializes all drive levels to a default value.
Afterwards, it examines I0 and determines the relative drive settings needed to
equalize the magnitudes of the four spectral components.  After determining the
relative drive settings, the algorithm searches for the maximum achievable drive
levels by incrementally increasing them until an out-of-range condition occurs on
any waveform.  Afterwards, the drive levels are reduced to bring all signals back
within range.  After finding the optimum drive levels, the control algorithm saves
the state of I0 for future comparison.  The algorithm may decide to search for a
new drive setting if a significant change occurs on I0.

The main operational subset is Subset 2.  This subset contains the frequency-
domain data for I0 and VM, which is needed to determine resistivity.  Additional
waveform data is reported as well for monitoring purposes.  Waveform data for
I0, VM, and the driver voltages and currents are reported.  In an effort to maintain
a reasonable subset size, only one waveform at a time is sent.  Each acquisition
sends a different waveform.  A wave ID parameter is included in the subset to
indicate which waveform was sent.  To further reduce the length of the subset,
the waveform is decimated to 128 samples.

LOGGING PROCEDURES
The shallowest diameter-of-investigation is ~ 18 inches, that distance makes the
curve MLR1 sensitive to borehole ruggosity; to improve the response of the tool it
is recommended to centralize the tool for small borehole sizes.  But for big
borehole sizes this curve is going to read mainly mud even when the tool is
centralized.  For that reason, for boreholes greater than 8.5”, it is better to run the
tool with 1.5 inch Stand-Offs.  Do not run the tool FREE.

APPLICATIONS
For the RTeX, the main purpose is to provide the description of the variation of
resistivity in invaded zones in salt saturated borehole fluids.
The RTeX interpretation uses the Rxo provided by the MLL in conjunction with
the four RTeX resistivities (MLR1, MLR2, MLR3, and MLR4) to produce a
corrected Rt and the length-of-invasion Lxo.

RTeX DELIVERABLES
Well site deliverables are the four apparent resistivities MLR1, MLR2, MLR3, and
MLR4 borehole corrected.  In addition to the normal environmental corrections
(through ENCOR program) a more advanced correction mechanism is available
for RTeX measurements.  The ABC (Adaptive Borehole Correction) processing
accounts for the tool position within the borehole beyond the two supposed
positions, centered and eccentered, that are available through ENCOR. The ABC
more properly corrects the curves for borehole effects and does not suffer from
the problem of over or under correcting that would be inherent in simple borehole
correction.  Additionally, the ABC utilizes data from all four curves simultaneously
and results inversion provides estimations of Rxo, Lxo, Rt and the tool
eccentricity within the borehole.  Normally MLL will be run in combination.  In this
case the MLL apparent resistivity will complement the four RTeX readings.
Please see RTeX log example in Figure 3.
The four MLR curves were designed to provide a clear indication of invasion.  To
accomplish this, diameter-of-investigation from very shallow (MLR1 ~ 18 inches)
to fairly deep (MLR4 ~ 74 inches) are required.  MLR1 is in particular helpful in
defining the invasion of relatively low resistivity encountered in a formation with
an oil-water contact.
These values of diameter-of-investigation are not fixed like we are accustomed to
seeing with induction resistivity instruments, but they change markedly with the
change in contrast between the resistivity of the formation and the borehole fluid.
Diameters-of-investigation for lateral tools are not fixed as they are for induction
type measurements, but are highly dependent on the contrast between the
formation resistivity and that of the resistivity of borehole fluid.  The diameter-of-
investigation becomes shallower as the contrast Rt/Rm increases.
The borehole correction also increases with the contrast Rt/Rm.  Furthermore,
borehole correction becomes greater as the instrument deviates from being
perfectly centered in the borehole.
RTeX borehole corrections are computed for two situations: (1) centered where
the tool is exactly in the center of the borehole, and (2) eccentered with 1.5”
standoff where the tool is on one side of the borehole wall and would be touching
the wall except for the standoffs.  The logs with centered tools would require less
correction than the eccentered ones for the same borehole size and Rt/Rm.
For large boreholes (12 ¼” bit size) and high contrast, the MLR1 borehole
correction becomes excessively large.  The uncertainty of the position of the
10

constant diameter over the length of the instrument, precludes an accurate

For these reasons, MLR1 is displayed only when the borehole correction is such
that it preserves the accuracy of the final result.

ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
Refer to Electronics Chassis assembly drawing A3001823000 for the location of

DC POWER SUPPLIES
All Focus instruments are powered from a downhole +28 volt power source.  This
voltage is part of the Instrument Bus that is supplied to each tool in the tool
string.
In the block diagram of Figure 2, all power supplies are denoted as the block
labeled “Power Supplies.”  For a detailed description of the PC boards and
circuitry associated with this block, see POWER SUPPLY CIRCUITRY.
Before the +28 volts is applied to a power supply module, it passes through a
special circuit used to filter noise from other instruments hanging on this common
power source.  It is the output of these filters that is applied as an input to the
power supplies.  For more detail, see section 2.6.3 of this document.
This filtered +28 volts is reduced to ±5 volts using a DC-to-DC converter module
A3000558000.  This voltage source provides power wherever a bipolar 5 V
supply is required.  The converter module is located on a heat sink installed on
the chassis.  For more detail on this dual supply, see section 2.6.1 of this
document.
This filtered +28 volts is also the source for five +3.3 volts converter modules
(A3000976000).  These supplies provide power to most of the remaining circuitry
in the instrument. They, too, are located on PC boards mounted to heat sinks.
For more detail on this supply, see section 2.6.2 of this document.

2.2.1 TELEMETRY COMMUNICATIONS

The 1241 XA Rt Explorer uses the Focus Telemetry protocol for
communication on the instrument bus.  It adheres to the specification
F198157000.

U9 is an Actel FPGA which contains a Manchester Decoder for decoding
commands on the instrument bus, and two Manchester Encoders.  One
encoder is dedicated for mode 2 data, and the other for modes 5 or 7.
The FPGA also provides an interface to the temperature sensor and
serial EEPROM.  All internal registers are selected with /MS3.  The
receiver (U12) for mode 2 commands and drivers (U10, U11, U14) for
mode 2, 5, and 7 are shown on sheet 4.  The instrument bus transformers
are located on a separate PC board (A3000773000).

Data transfer between the DSP and mode 2 encoder/decoder is interrupt-
driven using IRQ1.  Interrupt line IRQ1 is shared between the mode 2
decoder and mode 2 encoder.  A status register within the FPGA
indicates the source of the interrupt.  This register is read by the DSP to
determine which device generated the interrupt.  The decoder asserts
IRQ1 whenever it receives a command that is addressed to the tool.  The
interrupt notifies the DSP to read the command from the receive buffer
within the FPGA.  The mode 2 encoder can also be enabled to generate
an interrupt using /IRQ1.  When the DSP is ready to send data on mode
2, the encoder interrupt is enabled.  Once enabled, the encoder asserts
/IRQ1 whenever the transmit buffer is empty and ready to accept new
data.  The DSP writes a new word to the encoder in response to the
interrupt.  Figure 3 shows the tool receiving a “Send Subset E” command
and responding on Mode 2.



1241 XA Rt Explorer – Circuit Description
131042-945 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
A second encoder is used to transmit data on either mode 5 or mode 7.
Writes to this encoder is DMA driven using /DMAR2 and /DMAG2.  The
DMA request line (/DMAR2) is asserted by the FPGA when the encoder
is ready to accept new data.  In response, the DSP asserts /DMAG2 and
presents data on the bus (D[31:16]).  The data is latched in the encoder
transmit buffer on the rising edge of /DMAG2.  Bus control signals /MS1
and /WR are not active during the DMA transfer.  Figure 4 shows the tool
transmitting Subset E on Mode 5.  The bottom half of the capture is a
zoomed-in view of the first DMA transaction.  A second transaction
closely follows because the transmit buffer becomes ready immediately
after the encoder latches the data and begins transmitting.  Subsequent
transactions are spaced 171µs apart.  The last pulse may or may not be
present, depending on whether or not the DSP responds to an internal
DMA interrupt in time to disable the DMA before the last word has been
latched by the encoder.
2.2.2 DIGITAL SIGNAL PROCESSOR

U4 is an Analog Devices digital-signal processor (DSP).  Instruction code
for the device is stored in Flash memory (U5).  The DSP features 4 Mbits
of internal memory for storage of program and data.  After a power-on, or
software reset, the code is loaded from flash into internal memory.

The DSP can be booted from either the upper or lower half of flash
memory.  By default, the DSP boots from the upper half since the boards
are shipped without JP1 installed.  If JP1 is installed, the DSP will boot
from the lower half.  If necessary, new firmware updates can be
8

1241 XA Rt Explorer – Circuit Description
131042-945 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
downloaded using Benchmark software (A7000205 SW).  Updating the
firmware requires that the DSP re-program the flash memory.  If a
problem occurs during the download process and corrupts the boot
memory, the DSP can be re-booted from the backup copy in the lower
half of flash memory.

Much of the interfacing between the DSP and peripheral devices is done
through two Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGA), U9 and U16.  U16
is an Actel FPGA which contains the logic to interface with the drivers and
A/D’s.  U9 contains the interface for the instrument bus, serial EPROM,
and temperature sensor.

A heartbeat LED (D6) blinks once every second.  This LED is a useful
tool to help determine if the DSP is operating correctly.

Header P3 is a connector for an in-circuit emulator and used for
development purposes only.
2.2.3 DATA ACQUISITION

The output voltage and output current of each driver, as well as the output
voltage of the Bucker board, are measured and gathered as data in the
overall scheme of this instrument.  The chore of gathering the data and
sending it to the surface is one of the functions of the DSP.  Measurement
circuits are found on sheets 10 and 11.  Sheet 10 contains the four A/D
channels used to measure the output current of each driver.  Sheet 11
contains five A/D channels to the output voltage of the four drivers and
the bucker.

The following description starts at the top-right corner of sheet 10 to trace
the signal path of the mode 1 driver’s current measurement.  U38 is an
instrumentation amplifier used to measure the differential voltage across
a current sense resistor mounted on the chassis.  R177 sets the gain at
5 V/V.  Input over-voltage protection is provided by R175 and R176 and
clamping diodes D16.  After the instrumentation amplifier, the signal is
level-shifted and lightly filtered by opamp U123.  A 1.25 V offset is added
to center the signal within the 2.5 V input range of the A/D converter.  U55
is a 16-bit A/D converter.

Other A/D channels are similar to the previously described channel.
However, there are some differences in the first stage.  The mode 1, 2,
and 3 driver voltages are measured without the aid of an instrument
amplifier.

The reference voltage for the analog section is provided by U36.  It
generates a 2.5 V reference voltage.  A voltage divider (R147 and R156)
is used to derive a 1.25 V reference needed by the DDS chips.  U121 A
buffers the 2.5 V reference to provide a low impedance reference for the
9

1241 XA Rt Explorer – Circuit Description
131042-945 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
A/D’s.  A 625mV reference is also generated to bias the non-inverting
input of the opamp in each channel.

An A/D conversion is initiated by a rising edge on the CNV input (pin 6).
The CNV input of all the A/D’s are driven by the A/D sampling clock
(/MLL_AD_CLK) which is generated by FPGA U16.  The A/D sampling
clock is an inverted pulse generated every 130.7µs.  The A/D’s have a
serial interface consisting of a serial clock (SCK), serial data out (SDO),
and serial data in (SDI).  The A/D’s are daisy-chained by connecting the
SDO of one device to the SDI of another.  This configuration allows U16
to read all A/D’s, using only one data line, in one long serial bit stream.
FPGA U16 drives SCK and shifts in data from the SDO of U79.  SCK is a
discontinuous clock operating at 12 MHz.

The A/D timing is illustrated below in Figure 5.  After the FPGA pulses
/MLL_AD_CLK to initiate a conversion, it waits 4.6µs after the rising edge
to allow the A/D’s to finish the conversion.  After waiting for the
conversion to complete, the FPGA drives SCK for 160 cycles to shift out
the new A/D data.

The most involving task of the FPGA (U16) is to collect the A/D samples
and deliver them to the DSP.  Data from the A/D’s located on the
Controller board, as well as the A/D data from the Preamp board, are
collected and written to a FIFO for the DSP to read.  A block diagram of

FPGA.  The DMA (direct memory access) controller allows data to be
read from the FPGA without the direct involvement of the core processor,
freeing it to do more meaningful work.  DMA transfers occur through the
use of two handshaking signals: /DMAR1 (dma request) and /DMAG1
(dma grant).  The FPGA asserts /DMAR1 whenever there is data
available in the FIFO.  In response, the DSP asserts /DMAG1 while
reading one word from the FIFO in the FPGA.  Although the data bus
(D[31:16]) is used to transfer data, the memory-select (/MS2) and read
(/RD) signals are not active during the DMA read operation.  See diagram
of Figure 7.


1241 XA Rt Explorer – Circuit Description
131042-945 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
The FIFO is 16 bits wide.  Each A/D sample generates two writes to the
FIFO – one for the most-significant word and one for the least significant
word.  For the case of the 16-bit onboard A/D’s, the most-significant word
is 0000h.  For the 18-bit A/D’s on the Preamp, the most-significant word
includes the upper two bits of the A/D value; unused bit positions are
zero-filled.
clock (point A).  After waiting 4.6μs, the FPGA starts shifting in data from
the onboard A/D’s (point B).  Shortly thereafter, the Preamp starts
sending A/D data as well (point C).  The FPGA latches each Preamp
word on the rising edge of RFS and immediately writes the word into the
FIFO.  A DMA request occurs as a result of each FIFO write operation
(point D).
The data collected from the onboard A/D’s is not written into the FIFO
until the following sampling clock.  After shifting in the serial data, the
FPGA holds the data in the shift-register until the falling edge of the next
sampling clock.  The DMA requests resulting from the FIFO write
operations can be seen at point E.


The FPGA counts the number of words returned by the Preamp board.  If
the FPGA does not receive enough data from the Preamp board by the
end of the cycle, it will write zeroes into the FIFO in lieu of the missing
words.  On the other hand, if it receives too many words, it will inhibit
writing the extra words into the FIFO.  These measures are taken to
ensure the coherency of the data.  The DSP expects a certain number of
words each cycle.  Missing or extra words will cause the processing to

2.2.4 ELECTRODE DRIVERS

Reference Signals
Four identical circuits are used to create a sinusoidal reference signal for
each driver.  These circuits can be found on the top half of sheets 6, 7, 8,
and 9.  These circuits are physically identical to each other but they each
generate a different frequency.  Refer to page 6 of the schematic for the
following discussion of the reference signal generated for the mode 1
driver.
The signal chain begins with U21 which is a DDS chip used to generate a
105 Hz sine wave.  The frequency and phase of the sine wave is
programmed by the DSP during startup.  Pin 14 is the sine wave output.
The waveform at this point is unipolar, ranging from 0 to approximately
800mV.
This unipolar sine wave is ac-coupled by C311 and R245 to remove the
DC offset and create a bipolar waveform.  U102 A buffers the signal.
U102 B and its surrounding components form a 2nd order low-pass filter
needed to remove quantization noise.  The signal at TP59 is a clean sine
wave, centered at 0 V, with an amplitude of 400mV.  Afterwards, the
signal passes through a programmable attenuator.
The programmable attenuator is formed by multiplexer U25 and
surrounding resistors.  R72 is the bottom resistor of a voltage divider, and
the top resistor is selectable through U25.  The 8-to-1 mux allows for 8
levels of attenuation ranging from 1/1 to 1/128.  The attenuation settings
were chosen so that they vary by a factor of 2.  U102 C buffers the signal
after the attenuation stage.  Afterwards, the signal is ac-coupled with
C334 and R235 to remove any DC offset that may be added by the
previous stages.  U102 D buffers the signal again to drive transformer T5.
U101 is a comparator used to detect the zero crossing point of the
reference signal.  The comparator output feeds back into an FPGA (U16),
which waits for a rising edge on SQUARE_WAVE_F1 before updating the
mux enable (MUX_EN_F1) or mux select signals (MUX_A2_F1,
MUX_A1_F1, MUX_A0_F1).  This feature is included to minimize abrupt
changes in the reference signal when switching attenuation settings.  A
simplified sketch of the logic is shown below in Figure 9.  The DSP writes
the attenuation setting to a control register, but the new settings do not
take effect until a rising edge occurs at the comparator output.  A light RC

The bottom half of pages 6, 7, and 8 contain the active portion of the
voltage sources used to drive the guard electrodes.  The following

The output transformer and current sense resistor for the driver are

and A1* sense electrodes.  The sense electrodes can be thought of as
remote sense terminals that allow the voltage directly at the “load” to be
regulated.  The “load” in this case is the mud (or borehole fluid), which is
driven by electrodes A2 and A1.  Rather than sensing directly at the drive

regulation, separate sense electrodes are used instead.  The sense

separate the discussion into an AC analysis and DC analysis.  For AC
analysis, capacitors C331 and C337 are considered to be shorts and
resistors R294 and R295 are neglected because their impedance is much
greater than the impedance of the capacitors.  For DC analysis, the
capacitors are open and the effects of the resistors are considered.  At
0.159 Hz, the impedance of the capacitors equals the impedance of the
resistors.  At frequencies above 0.159 Hz, the effects of the capacitors
dominate and the resistors can be ignored.  This is especially true at the
four operating frequency of the drivers (30 Hz, 105 Hz, 165 Hz, and
195 Hz.), which is much greater than 0.159 Hz.

T5 is a 1:1 transformer that is used to translate the reference signal,
which is referenced to ground, into a floating source that can be used to
drive the (+) input of U31 with respect to the A1* sense.  Because of
negative feedback, the opamp adjusts its output to whatever voltage
necessary to make the voltage at the (-) input equal to that of the (+)
15

input.  A 6:1 step-down transformer (TF1) is used to couple the output to
the electrodes.  TF1 boosts the output current, which reduces the amount
of current that needs to be supplied by U31 and the power supplies.  R3
is a resistor used for measuring the driver’s output current.

Resistors R294 and R295 are needed to provide DC feedback for the
opamp.  These resistors provide a path for input bias currents and
establish the DC operating point of the opamp.  The opamp needs to be
biased so that its output rests at 0 V.  The DC offset at the output of the
opamp needs to be controlled because the transformer winding presents
a low resistance DC path to ground.

Before proceeding any farther, it should be mentioned that the driver
looks at the average voltage of the sense electrodes.  For the sake of
simplicity, the circuit illustrated in Figure 11 only presents the upper
electrode array.  Rather than just looking at A2*, the positive sense is
taken to be the average voltage of the A2* and A2’* electrode.  The
averaging is performed by R221 and R223.  These resistors can be found
on sheet 2 of the schematic.  Similarly, the negative sense is taken to be
the average of the A1* and A1’* electrode voltages.  This averaging is
performed by R222 and R224.

Again on sheet 6, U31 is a power opamp capable of driving high currents.
The output current limit is set by R94.  With 15.4kΩ for R94, the current
limit is set at 750mA.  An enable pin (pin 8) is provided to allow the
opamp to be disabled --- this places the output in a high-impedance state.
Disabling occurs by pulling pin 8 to the negative supply rail.  It is the task
of the DSP to disable the opamp while the tool is in the CAL or ZERO
mode.  The enable pin of all three power opamps used for the voltage
sources are controlled by the same signal (VDRV_EN).  An RC snubber
(R285 and C354) is attached to the output to suppress high-frequency
oscillations that may occur due to instability in the opamp’s output stage.

Note:  The schematic symbol indicates that the part has 48 pins.  In
reality, there are only 20 pins, which are shown on U31-1.  Pin 21 through
48 were added to the schematic symbol so that thermal vias could be
included in the footprint for heat sinking purposes.

2.2.5 PREAMP INTERFACE

All signals between the Controller and Preamp boards are transmitted
differentially.  U15, U97, and U17 are LVDS2 receivers and drivers used
to interface to the Preamp board.  The receive port (RCLK_B, DR_B,
RFS_B) feed into FPGA U16 so that the A/D samples can be collected
and written to FIFO.  Commands are sent to the Preamp board through
the transmit port (TCLK0, TFS0, DT0) which are directly driven by the
DSP’s serial port.  The system clock (MAIN_CLK) and A/D sampling clock
(/MLL_AD_CLK) are provided by FPGA U16.

2.2.7 MISCELLANEOUS

Several items on the Controller board have not been covered.  They are
discussed below.

Housing potential: U134 forms a unity-gain buffer used to drive the inner
housing at system common.  The input is taken from the Bucker board’s
common, and the output drives a contact assembly [A3001017000]
located on the chassis.

FPGA power: U1, Q1, and surrounding components form a 2.5 V
regulator to provide the core voltage for the two FPGA’s.


FPGA U9 Functions:

Memory: The FPGA also interfaces to the serial EEPROM (U8).  The
EEPROM is used to store hardware information and calibration tables.
Instead of using a hardware assisted SPI interface, the DSP directly
manipulates the EEPROM signals through a control register.

Glue logic: Glue logic for the flash memory (U5) chip-enable signal is
implemented in the FPGA.  The boot-memory select (/BMS) and
memory-select (/MS0) from the DSP are AND’ed together to generate
/FLS_CE.  On power-up, the DSP initially uses /BMS to load
instructions from flash memory.  After the initial boot process, /MS0 is
used to select the flash memory.  The flash write enable (/FLS_WE) is
generated by OR’ing the /MS0 and /WR signals.

DSP clock: The FPGA also contains a PLL that is used to generate a
32 MHz clock (DSP_CLK) for the DSP.

Temperature Sensor:  FPGA U9 also contains a serial interface for
the temperature sensor (U7).  The serial clock (TEMP_SCLK) runs at
12 MHz.  The FPGA reads the temperature sensor every 0.5 second
and generates an interrupt on /IRQ0.  In response, the DSP reads the
temperature from the FPGA; see timing diagram of Figure 14.

PREAMP BOARD
2.3.1 INTRODUCTION
The Preamp board (A3000644000) contains the signal conditioning and
A/D converters for measuring VM and I0 --- which are the two values
necessary to calculate resistivity.  The Preamp board is responsible for
sampling the VM and I0 signals and sending the A/D samples to the
Controller board (A3000643000).  Each signal is simultaneously
measured with three different gains to increase the dynamic range of the
measurements.  Two-way communication between the Preamp and
Controller is achieved with two synchronous serial ports; each consisting
of a clock, frame sync, and data line.  All signals between the Preamp
and Controller are transmitted and received differentially using LVDS
drivers and receivers.
2.3.2 I0 MEASUREMENT CIRCUITS
I0 current is measured by sensing the voltage across a 2Ω resistor
located on the Bucker board.  Starting at page 2 of the Preamp schematic
(A3000644 SCH), the I0 signal enters the board on pins 4 and 14 of
connector J3.  Resistors R82 and R84, along with diodes D5, form a
clamp to help protect the input from any damaging voltages that may be
present on the A0 electrode --- signal is denoted by A0_I+ and A0_I–.

On page 6 of the schematic, the signal then feeds into a dual, four-input
multiplexer (U21).  The multiplexer is used to select between LOG,
VERIFY, CAL, and ZERO inputs (signal is now CH0+ and CH0–).

Since the I0 measurement has a large amount of gain, it is important to
remove any DC offset in the signal.  The signal ultimately arrives on page
4, where the output of U21 feeds into an AC-coupling network formed by
capacitors C25 & C26, and resistors R108 & R109 to remove this DC
offset.

I0, at this point, is amplified with three different gains.  Three parallel
signal conditioning paths, are similar with the exception of having different
gains, are shown on page 4.  The following description will trace the
signal chain through the highest gain channel which begins with U46.
Keep in mind that the same action is occurring in the two other chains.

U46 is an instrumentation amplifier which amplifies the differential voltage
at its input and produces an output voltage referenced to ground.  The
gain of the device is determined by the value of R110.  With R110 at
49.9Ω, the gain of U46 is 991 V/V.  R111 and C110 form another ac-

1241 XA Rt Explorer – Circuit Description
131042-945 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
An additional gain of 4.01 V/V is provided by the non-inverting gain stage
formed by U57 B.  Afterwards, the signal is scaled and level-shifted by
U57 A.  This stage attenuates the signal by a factor of 2, and applies a
2.5 V offset.  At the output of U57 A, the signal will appear as a smaller,
inverted waveform centered at 2.5 V.

U57 D and its associated components form a Sallen-Key low-pass filter.
The Sallen-Key circuit, along with the pole introduced by capacitor C149,
forms a 3rd order Butterworth low-pass filter with a 4kHz cutoff frequency.

The low-gain channel begins with U22 and has a gain of 10.9 V/V.  The
medium-gain channel begins with U32 and has a gain of 100 V/V.  The
low and medium gain channels are similar to the high gain channel
except that no additional gain is applied after the instrumentation
amplifier.  U55 B and U59 B are simply used as unity gain buffers in their
respective circuits.

The low, medium, and high gain channels are successively sampled
using only one A/D converter.  U26 is a multiplexer used to switch the A/D
input between the outputs of the three channels.  A sampling clock,
provided by the Controller board, initiates three different A/D conversions
– one for each gain channel.  The three channels are sampled in quick
succession, only 6µs apart from each other.  Dual op amp U47 converts
the single-ended input signal into a differential signal (AD2 IN+ and AD2
IN–) that can be sampled by the A/D converter.

U27 is an 18-bit successive approximation analog-to-digital converter.  A
conversion is initiated by the falling edge on the /CNVST input (pin 35).
This edge causes the A/D to sample the input and begin the conversion
process which takes approximately 1.25µs.  While converting, the A/D
holds its BUSY pin (29) high.  When finished converting, the A/D brings
the BUSY pin low to indicate new data is available to be read.

A serial interface is used to read the A/D.  When reading data, the chip-
select (/CS) pin (32) is pulled low to enable the serial interface.  Data is
shifted out on the SDOUT pin (21) on the rising edge of the serial clock
provided on the SCLK pin (22).

The 2.5 V reference voltage needed by the A/D is externally supplied by
U17.  The A/D internally amplifies the supplied reference to create a
4.096 V reference for conversions.  The internally generated 4.096 V
reference is routed to pin 37 and decoupled by C136.
2.3.3 VM MEASUREMENT CIRCUITS
Two electrodes surround the A0 electrode – M1 and M1’.  These two
electrodes are averaged and buffered by the Bucker board
(A3001215000).  The buffered signal (M1) is fed into the Preamp board

1241 XA Rt Explorer – Circuit Description
131042-945 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas

Also seen on page 2 is the surface remote signal (REMOTE).  It enters
the board on pin 16 of connector P3.  The surface remote signal is filtered
by a 3rd order Butterworth low-pass filter formed by op amp U48 A and
U48 B --- refer to page 6.  The -3db frequency is 9kHz.  Filtering is
performed to remove any telemetry signals that may be present on
wireline conductor 7.

The REMOTE signal then feeds into a dual, four-input multiplexer (U11).
The multiplexer is used to select between LOG, VERIFY, CAL, and ZERO
inputs (signal is now CH1+ and CH1–).  The signal ultimately arrives on
page 5, where the output of U11 feeds into an AC-coupling network
formed by capacitors C17 & C18, and resistors R86 & R87.  These
components remove any DC offset in the signal.

The VM measurement circuit on page 5 is identical to the previously
described I0 circuit on page 4 with the exception of some resistor values.
Although three gain channels are available at the present time, only the
low-gain channel, which begins with U9, is used.  The front-end
instrumentation amplifiers (U12 and U44) for the medium and high-gain
channels are set to a gain of 1 V/V, because higher gains caused the
amplifiers to saturate and adversely affect the low-gain channel
measurement.  Although the A/D actively samples the medium and high-
gain channels, calculations do not utilize these channels.

The two A/D’s, U27 (for I0) and U18 (for VM), are daisy-chained so that
the FPGA can read both A/D’s using one data line.  The serial data output
of U18 (pin 21) feeds into the serial data input of U27 (pin 16).  The FPGA
shifts in data from the serial data output of U27.  In this manner, the
FPGA can read both A/D’s in one 36-bit long bit-stream --- U27 data first,
followed by U18 data.
2.3.4 A/D DATA RETRIEVAL
The sampling clock (/MLL_AD_CLK), provided by the Controller board,
initiates the conversion process for the A/D’s.  The differential clock inputs
enter the Preamp board on pins 23 and 11 of connector P2.  At U34, a
differential driver, it is converted into standard logic levels and routed to
the FPGA (page 3).

Refer to the timing diagram of Figure 15.  At point A, after the rising edge
of /MLL_AD_CLK, the FPGA (U29) collects three samples from each A/D
converter.  The AD_CNVST signal is pulsed low (point B) to initiate each
of the three A/D conversions.  On the falling edge of AD_CNVST, the
A/D’s sample their inputs and bring their respective busy lines high (point
C).  The FPGA monitors both busy lines and waits for them to go low
before reading the results from the A/D’s.  After the busy lines go low, the

16 illustrates the serial port in relation to the sampling clock.

The Preamp board sends twelve words instead of six.  The extra six
words are due to the fact that the FPGA was originally designed for a
board which had more channels.  Zeroes are transmitted in place of the
