The Preamp board can receive commands from the Controller board for
performing specific tasks.  This communication occurs through another
synchronous serial link consisting of TCLK, TFS, and DT.

TCLK operates at 12 MHz.  TFS is the frame sync and DT is the data line.
A command word is 16 bits long.  The Controller sends commands to…
1) enable the acquisition,
2) select the operating mode (LOG, VERIFY, CAL, or ZERO),
3) select the attenuation level for the cal signal, or
4) tell the Preamp to return a status word.
Differential signals from the Controller arrive at connector P2.  Clock
signals are found on pins 2 and 15; frame syncs are found on pins 3 and
16, and the data lines are pins 4 and 17.  These signals find their way to
U20, a LVDS chip (page 3).  U20 converts them into standard logic levels
useable by the FPGA, U29.
2.3.6 CALIBRATION CIRCUIT
A calibration signal (DRV_CAL±) is provided by the Controller board.
This signal arrives at the Preamp board via connector P3 pins 19 and 10.
The signal is a composite waveform created by summing four sinusoids
with frequencies of 30 Hz, 105 Hz, 165 Hz, and 195 Hz.  The calibration
signal, observed at the output of U9 while in the CAL mode, is shown
below in Figure 17.
The objective of the calibration routine is to determine the relative gain
and phase-shifts between the channels.  Absolute gain is not needed

1241 XA Rt Explorer – Circuit Description
131042-945 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
Hence, any common gain error between the two channels will be divided
out.  The VM low-gain channel is used as the reference for calibration.
The gain and phase of the low, medium, and high gain I0 channels are
determined with respect to the low-gain VM channel.


be applied to the calibration signal, depending on the gain of the channel
being calibrated.  The full cal signal is applied when calibrating the low-
gain VM channel.
When calibrating the I0 channels which have more gain, the cal signal
has to be attenuated to a level within the input range of the channel.  The
low-gain I0 channel is calibrated with the 1/21 attenuation.  The medium
and high-gain I0 channels are calibrated with 1/201 and 1/2001
attenuation, respectively.  Attenuation levels are selected by U41, a dual
4-to-1 mux.  The Controller board selects the attenuation level by
programming the appropriate bits of a control register in the FPGA.  The
enable input of the calibration mux allows the mux output to be tri-stated
when the tool is not in the CAL mode.  This feature helps reduce any
potential cross-talk.

Multiplexers (U21 and U11) at the front end of the measurement channels
provide support for the various tool operating modes: LOG, VERIFY,
CAL, and ZERO.  The Controller sets the operating mode by
programming the mode control bits in the FPGA’s control register.  The
mode control bits drive the mux select lines A_CAL_GAIN_SEL0 and
A_CAL_GAIN_SEL1.
In the CAL mode, both VM and I0 measure the cal signal.
In the ZERO mode, the inputs of each channel are shorted together.
Resistors R145 and R146 allow the inputs to be tied to common, but they

The LOG and VERIFY inputs for the I0 channel are the same.  In both
cases, the I0 channel measures the voltage across a 2Ω resistor on the
Bucker board.  For the VM channel, M1 is applied to the positive input in
both the LOG and VERIFY modes.  Surface remote is applied to the
negative input in the LOG mode, while in the VERIFY mode, the A5 node
of the verify network is applied to the negative input.
2.3.7 FPGA AND SUPPORT CIRCUITRY
On page 3 of the schematic is an Actel field programmable gate array
(FPGA), U29.
Among its functions are…
•
It contains the logic for collecting the A/D samples and sending them
to the Controller board.
•
It also contains a control register through which the Controller board
can set the operating mode (LOG, VERIFY, CAL, ZERO) and
attenuation setting of the calibration signal.
•
The system clock is obtained from MAIN_CLK because there is no
local oscillator on the board.
•
The FPGA is programmed to blink LED D9 once a second.  This may
be helpful in determining if the FPGA is functioning.

FPGA support features…
•
Connector P1: is a programming header used for programming the
FPGA.  It is intended for engineering use only.
•
Power Supply: the 2.5 V supply needed for the FPGA’s core is
provided by a low-dropout regulator formed by U35 and Q2 found on
page 2 of the schematic.  The 2.5 V reference is derived from the 3.3 V
supply using a voltage divider – R53 and R54.  Through feedback,
opamp U35 adjusts the base voltage of Q2 so that the voltage at its
non-inverting input equals the reference voltage presented at the
inverting input.  To prevent this supply from exceeding 3.3 V,
protection diode D18 is installed.
•
Isolation: the analog and digital sections of the board are isolated
from each other.  All signals between the FPGA and analog section
are isolated by U51, U52, U53, and U54.  These IC’s are digital
isolators that magnetically couple digital signals from one side to the
other.

LVDS: all signals between the Preamp and Controller are transmitted and
received differentially using LVDS drivers and receivers (U20, U34, and
U30).  Low-voltage differential signaling is a standard allowing for high
data rates with low power and low EMI.  The receivers detect differential
signals and convert them to standard logic.  Each receiver has a 100Ω
termination resistor across the input.  The differential voltage is typically
only ±310mV.

BUCKER BOARD

Refer to the schematic diagram (A3001215 SCH) of the Bucker board
(A3001215000) for the following description.

Survey current must enter/leave the A0 electrode horizontally into the formation
rather than vertically through the mud to obtain a formation resistivity
measurement.  This objective is achieved by minimizing the potential difference
between the M2 and M1 electrodes.  The Bucker board contains a high-gain
amplifier used to adjust this potential difference.  With negative feedback, and
assuming infinite gain, the Bucker amplifier forces the potential difference
between M2 and M1 to zero.

There are actually two sets of electrodes; M2 (P1-18) and M1 (P1-5) in the upper
array, and their complements M2' (P1-20) and M1' (P1-7) in the bottom array.  As
a result, the Bucker board amplifies the difference between the average voltages
of these two sets of electrodes.  RN1 and RN2 are precision matched resistors
used to determine the average voltage of M1 and M1' (IN+) and the average
voltage of M2 and M2' (IN–), respectively.  The average of M1 and M1' is
buffered by U5 A and routed off board (P1-9) so that it can be measured by the
Preamp board.  U5 B buffers the average of M2 and M2' but its output is not used.
Its sole purpose is to balance any loading U5 A may have on the M1/M1' input.

The overall frequency response of the Bucker is shaped to provide a high gain
within the frequency range of interest: 30 Hz to 195 Hz.  The gain is reduced at
frequencies outside of this region.  The overall gain is distributed among three
stages:
1) front-end instrumentation amplifier U1,
2) inverting amplifier formed by U2 B, and
3) a non-inverting amplifier formed by U2 A.

The first stage of amplification is U1.  It is an instrumentation amplifier which
provides a gain of 10 V/V.  The gain of this amplifier is determined by the value of
R5.
The output of U1 is AC-coupled to an inverting amplifier formed by U2 B.  The ratio
of R10 and R9 sets the passband gain of this stage to approximately 52.5 V/V.
The gain of this stage rolls off at frequencies above 214 Hz (F-3dB), as determined
by the values of C8 and R10.
U2 A forms a non-inverting gain stage.  Because of C5, the DC gain is limited to
1 V/V.  The value of R4 and R6 determine the passband gain, which is
approximately 16 V/V.  The gain of this stage also rolls off at frequencies above
214 Hz (F-3dB), as determined by the values of C7 and R4.

Finally, U3 is a power opamp with a high current output.  The output current limit
is programmable and set by resistor R14.  With R14 chosen to be 46.4kΩ, the
current limit is set at 250mA.  R8 is a precision current-sense resistor used to
29

1241 XA Rt Explorer – Circuit Description
131042-945 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
measure the output current of the Bucker circuit.  The resistor has 4 terminals for
a “four-wire” measurement.  The sense terminals are routed off-board so that the
survey current (I0) can be measured by the Preamp board.  R8 is enclosed within
the feedback loop of U3 so that the output voltage is not affected by the IR drop
through the sense resistor.

Note:  The schematic symbol indicates that the part has 48 pins.  In reality, there
are only 20 pins, which are shown on U31-1.  Pin 21 through 48 (labeled
U3-2) were added to the schematic symbol so that thermal vias could be
included in the footprint for heat dissipation.

Power amplifier U3 cannot be powered directly from the +5 V supply that powers
the other active circuit components of this board.  Due to its limited supply
voltage rating, U3 has ±2.75 V provided to it by separate voltage regulators.  The
+2.75 V regulator is formed by U7 A, Q1, and surrounding components.  The
+2.75 V reference is derived from the +5 V supply using a voltage divider – R27
and R28.  Through feedback, opamp U7 A adjusts the base voltage of Q1 so that
the voltage at its non-inverting input equals the reference voltage presented at
the inverting input.

A similar circuit is provided for the –2.75 V regulator.  It is formed by U7 B, Q2,
and surrounding components.  Its operation is similar to the +2.75 V regulator.

Relays K1 and K2 are provided to support the VERIFY mode.  In the VERIFY
mode, the Bucker’s inputs and output are redirected to connect to an internal
resistor network on the Controller board (A3000643000) instead of the
electrodes.  Refer to Figure 13 seen previously.

MISCELLANEOUS
2.5.1 OTHER PC BOARDS
Several other PC boards of relative insignificance reside in the 1241 XA.
Two of these boards are nothing more than tie points where wires attach
and make assembly/disassembly/repair easier.  The first one of these
(A3000877000) is at the uphole end of the instrument.  It is shown on the
The second one is located between the chassis-mounted transformers
and the Controller board; it is the Signal Distribution board, SDB,
(A3000755000).  Wires from this board connect the electrodes (contact
blocks) and from the Main Controller board.
Just to the downhole side of the Controller board is a small PC board
(A3000773000) containing the four signal transformers used for Focus
bus communications.  Although requiring more wire terminations, this
board relieves the Controller board from mounting these relatively bulky
and heavy items from the board containing sensitive electronics (vibration
issues).
A final set of two boards (A3001788000) are mounted on the fiberglass
rod assembly.  The main purpose of these boards is to control the path of
wiring to the monitor electrode (M1, M2, M1’, M2’) sockets.  Due to the
sensitive nature of the monitor electrodes to interference, a well-defined
route is required.  The PC boards were put in place to provide a clean
junction for the shielded twisted pairs and the socket leads.
2.5.2 CHASSIS TRANSFORMERS
Three step-down transformers are mounted on the chassis between the
upper power supplies and the Signal Distribution board.  They provide a
current boost for the voltage drivers, VF1, VF2 and VF3.  The wires from
the transformers connect to their related chassis components using
chassis terminals.  By boosting the output current by a 6 to 1 ratio, less
current is needed by the driver opamp and the power supplies.
2.5.3 CONTACTS
Electrical contact is made from the outside world (each electrode) to the
internal circuits by means of 22 special feedthrough pins.  The larger
diameter portion of this pin is threaded, and screws into the electrode to
make contact with it.  The narrower section is rounded on the end to fit
into a receptacle.  In between these two sections is an isolating section.
A ceramic coating is sprayed on this section to insulate the pin from
31

1241 XA Rt Explorer – Circuit Description
131042-945 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
accidentally shorting out to the housing as it passes through to the interior
contact block.
The receptacles or contact blocks, as mentioned earlier, are free-floating
in cavities of the fiberglass rod assembly.  Being magnetically coupled to
magnets mounted in the rod such that they attract, the contact blocks are
free to slide up/down inside their slot.  This movement not only allows the
block to automatically align with the pin (upon insertion), but also relieves
any stresses that occur during thermal expansion.
2.5.4 TOP/BOTTOM CONNECTORS
The top connector, J1, of the 1241 XA is a standard 18-socket Focus
connector.  Should it be required, replacement of this connector is made
easy because all wires coming from it terminate at the uphole terminal
board, TB1.
Likewise the bottom connector, J9, is a standard 18-socket Focus
connector.  However, it is augmented with a bottom sub and an 18-pin

POWER SUPPLY CIRCUITRY

backbone – one ±5 volts and five 3.3 volts.  Refer to the assembly drawing
A3001823000 and the associated PC boards A3000558000 (-SCH for schematic)
and A3000976000 (-SCH for schematic).
Along with the supplies are EMI filter modules that drastically reduce interference
and interaction between supplies of other Focus instruments.  Refer to drawing
A3000467000 (-SCH for schematic) to view the filter assembly board.

mount only on standoffs.

2.6.1 DUAL 5 V POWER SUPPLY
There is only one dual polarity power supply (PS6); its output is ±5 volts.
The Focus ±5 V Power Supply (A3000558000) supplies a regulated
output voltage of ±5.0 Vdc at 0.5 Amp load current, per output, from an
input voltage of 18 Vdc to 36 Vdc; 28 Vdc is typical.

kHz and employs a single-transistor discontinuous-mode flyback
topology.  Operation is controlled by a Pulse Width Modulator (PWM) IC
that controls chopping (switching) of the 28 Vdc input voltage at a fixed
frequency (300 kHz).  Each switching cycle is subdivided into three
operating intervals: conduction, flyback, and dead time.
Current flows in the primary of the flyback transformer and magnetic
energy is stored in the transformer’s air gap during the conduction
interval.  The power supplies’ output capacitors maintain the output
voltage.
When the conduction interval terminates, stored magnetic energy is
released to the secondary of the transformer and the power supplies’
output capacitors are charged.  The supply is designed such that the

power supply to maintain a constant output voltage.
The dead time interval commences when all stored magnetic energy is
depleted. Again the output capacitors maintain the output voltage.  The
dead-time interval ends on the rising edge of the next PWM clock, which
also marks the start of the next conduction interval.

the PWM re-adjusts ton to maintain a constant Vo.

Output voltage sensing or error detection compares the output voltage to
a stable reference voltage and a resulting error voltage is created on the
secondary side.  Magnetic coupling conveys the error voltage to the
primary side where the error voltage modulates the PWM and adjusts ton.
Magnetically-coupled feedback permits operation with the power supplies’
output return floating or isolated from the input return.

Detailed Circuit Description
Chip U1, a Vishay Si9110, provides the required PWM functions.
Resistor R2 sets the internal clock frequency of the PWM to
approximately 600 kHz, which is twice the chopping or switching
frequency (Figure 19).  The bias current of U1 is set by resistor R3.
Diode D15 and associated components shift U1’s soft-reference voltage
to improve operation at elevated temperature.
Transistor Q1 buffers the output of the PWM and provides the additional
current drive needed to rapidly switch mosfet Q2 on and off (Figure 20).
Mosfet Q2 controls the application of supply voltage to the primary of the
flyback transformer T2.  When Q2 is on, the primary current ramps up at
a rate determined by T2 and Vin.  Transformer T1, a 1:100 current
transformer, couples the primary current to diode D9 and resistor R9.
Resistor R9 converts the primary current ramp to a voltage ramp.
Resistor R8 and capacitor C18 filter the voltage ramp and apply it to U1
(Figure 21) at the “sense” pin.  The error voltage at U1-14 is internally

1241 XA Rt Explorer – Circuit Description
131042-945 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
Transformer T2 has four secondary windings; two windings provide power
supply operating voltages, while the third and fourth windings provide the
main ±5.0-volt outputs.  The secondary winding associated with rectifier
D13 provides approximately 5.0 Vdc for powering the circuitry on the
primary side of T2.  Rectifier D6 and associated components provide
approximately 5.0 Vdc for powering the circuitry on the secondary side of
T2.  Components D4, D5, C23, C24, C30, and C31 constitute the main
rectifier and filter circuit for the ±5.0 Vdc outputs.  The ±5.0 Vdc outputs
are further filtered by L3, C25, C32, C36, C26, C27, C53, C55, C33, C34,
C56, and C57 before application to output terminals E4, E5, and E6
(Figure 23).
Chip U5 and associated components constitute the output voltage
sensing or error detection circuitry.  Chip U5 compares the ±5.0 Vdc
output voltages divided down by R31 and R32 to the 2.5 Vdc reference
voltage provided by U2.  The output of U5 is buffered by Q5 whose
emitter drives T3.  Components R40, C49, and C50 provide negative
feedback to the inverting input of U5 to shape the loop gain, which
ensures stable operation and adequate transient response.  The voltage
at the emitter of Q5 is the error voltage.  To couple the DC error voltage
through T3, it is necessary to use amplitude modulation such that the
error signal can be magnetically coupled to the secondary side of T3.
Chip U4 provides a ~700-kHz carrier, which is amplitude modulated by
the error voltage applied through the center tap of T3.  Diode D12 with
C14 and R15 serve to demodulate or recover the magnetically coupled
modulated error voltage signal.  Components C52 and R42 provide
additional error voltage signal filtering (Figure 26).  Chip U3 with R12,
R35, R13, R14, R4, and C15 further amplify and filter the error voltage.
Due to the interleaving of the main secondary winding, the -5.0 Vdc
output closely tracks the +5.0 Vdc output, provided that the negative load
current is not less than 20% of the positive load current.
Transistor Q3, chip U3, and associated components provide a soft start
function, which ensures that the ±5.0-Vdc output ramps up in predictable
manner.  Transistor Q3 is on when INH (E3) is held low, which keeps C8
discharged.  Chip U3-7 is also low to maintain C11 discharged through
D7.  When Q3 is released, both capacitors are allowed to charge,
controlling the rate at which the ±5.0-Vdc output ramps up (Figure 25).
Transistor Q4, diodes D2, D1, and D8, and associated passive
components provide +10 Vdc start-up power for the primary side
components.  Once the power supply starts and the secondary outputs
come up, the winding associated with D13 provides the primary operating
power, i.e.; the power supply becomes self sustaining, producing its own
operating power.  The 5.0-Vdc output from D13 and D2 (5, 2) provide a
reverse bias to D2 (3, 4), which turns Q4 off for improved efficiency.
Capacitors C1, C2, C5 through C7 and C9 minimize the differential and
common-mode noise on the 28-Vdc line.  Also, C1 and C2 provide a low
inductance voltage source for the primary power circuit consisting of Q2
36

1241 XA Rt Explorer – Circuit Description
131042-945 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
and T2.  Capacitor C10 and resistor R16 serve to dampen the ringing on
the drain of Q2 at turn off.

Tracing Through A Cycle Of Operation
Assume that the output of PWM U1-4 has gone high, turning on Q2 and
marking the start of the conduction interval.  Vin (+28 Vdc) appears
across the primary of T2 and the primary current of T2 begins to ramp up
linearly.  Diodes D13, D4, D5, and D6 are reversed biased during this
interval since the secondaries’ polarity is inverted with respect to the
primary.  Output current from each secondary is supplied by capacitors
C44, C23, C24, C30, C31, and C39 during this interval.  As previously
discussed, the primary current is fed back to the PWM sense input (U1-
3), after being converted to a voltage.  The ramp voltage internal to the
PWM is compared to the error voltage and when the ramp voltage is
greater than the error voltage, the output of the PWM goes low, causing
Q2 to turn off.  This designates the end of the conduction interval and the
start of the flyback interval.
Since the current flowing in an inductor can not be instantaneously
stopped, current must continue to flow in T2 even though Q2 is off.
When Q2 turns off, the primary voltage reverses and increases until the
secondary rectifier diodes are forward biased and conducting (Figure 22).
Current that was flowing in the primary is now transferred to the
secondary.  The current that flows in each secondary winding is a
function of its turns ratio.  Secondary current primarily flows through
capacitors C44, C23, C24, C30, C31, and C39, restoring their charge.
Secondary current will continue to flow until all magnetic energy stored in
the air gap of T2 is transferred to the output capacitors (electric field
energy).
The dead-time interval now commences.  During this interval all power
switching components (Q2, D13, D4, D5, and D6) are off, hence the
name discontinuous mode (no switching current flows during the dead-
time interval).  The only current flowing is the load current, which is
provided by the output capacitors.  On the next clock edge the cycle
repeats.

This designates the end of the conduction interval and the start of the
flyback interval.

Since the current flowing in an inductor can not be instantaneously
stopped, current must continue to flow in T2 even though Q2 is off.
When Q2 turns off, the primary voltage reverses and increases until the
secondary rectifier diodes are forward biased and conducting (Figure 34).
Current that was flowing in the primary is now transferred to the
secondary.  The current that flows in each secondary winding is a
function of its turns ratio.  Secondary current primarily flows through
capacitors C44, C23, C24 and C39, restoring their charge (Figure 35).
Secondary current will continue to flow until all magnetic energy stored in
the air gap of T2 is transferred to the output capacitors (electric field
energy).
The dead-time interval now commences.  During this interval all power
switching components (Q2, D13, D4, and D6) are off and the output
capacitors maintain the load current.  On the next clock edge the cycle

2.6.3 INPUT FILTER BOARDS

There are two Input Filter boards for the six power supplies.  The Input
Filter and Delay Controller PCB Assembly (A3000467000) provides
common mode and differential mode filtering of the +28 Vdc input voltage
for up to three power supply modules.  It also provides low-voltage inhibit
and programmable start-up delays for the attached supplies.  Refer to
differential and common mode filter.  The filter attenuates switching
frequency harmonics of the power supply modules attached to connector
J1and prevents noise contamination of the 28 V bus.
The heart of the delay controller is a programmable microcontroller (U1).
Resistor R7 and capacitor C12 set the operating frequency at
approximately 1 MHz.  Diode D1 and R6 function as a simple Zener
power supply that provides 5 V for the microcontroller.
When enabled, U1 functions as a timer to control the turn-on time and
sequencing of the power-supply modules attached to connector J1.
There are basically three functions concerning this circuit: (1) a voltage
threshold, (2) the delay and sequencing circuit and (3), the control/inhibit
circuit.
(1)
A threshold voltage is established using a voltage divider
consisting of R4 and R5.  When the divider output exceeds 1.25 V
as detected by power fail input (PFI) U2-4, the RESET pin (U2-7)
goes high.  This happens when voltage on the 28 V bus exceeds
20 volts or more.  With U2’s reset pin high, U1’s MCLR (U1-4) is
pulled high, and U1 begins executing its internally stored program.
(2)
The delay provided by U1 is the time from when U1’s MCLR goes
high to the time INH1 (J1-4) goes high.  Different combinations of
jumpers JP1 – JP4 change U1’s delay time.  Delay times are
established for different tools to limit the current demand when the
tool string is first powered up.  Delay times, in milliseconds, and

In addition, jumper JP6 determines if INH2 (J1-7) and INH3 (J1-
10) go high simultaneously with INH1 or are staggered by 40
msec.  The two states of jumper JP6 are as follows:
•
JP6 jumpered = staggered High-to-Low transition of RA1 – RA3
•
JP6 not jumpered = Simultaneous High-to-Low transition of RA1
– RA3

(3)
When +5 volts is applied to the microcontroller, outputs RA1 –
RA3 of U1 are floating (open collector circuit).  Resistors R8, R12,
and R14 pull the bases of Q1 – Q3 HIGH respectively, turning on
Q1 – Q3, which result in INH1 – INH3 being pulled low.  This low
state inhibits operation of the power supply modules connected to
INH1 – INH3.  When U1’s time-out function is complete, outputs
RA1 – RA3 will transition LOW either simultaneously or staggered
as determined by jumper JP6, turning off Q1 – Q3, which activates
the power supply modules.

Because very little power is dissipated on this board, there is no need to
mount it on a heat sink.  Therefore, it is mounted to the electronics
chassis using standoffs.

INTRODUCTION
The Rt Explorer instrument for the Focus tool string is the series 1241 XA, whereas the
1249 XA is the WTS version.  In both cases the outward appearance is a series of guard
electrodes located on a specially designed titanium housing.  The electronics assembly is
located within the housing.  See sketch of Figure 1.


the electronics to be incorporated within the mandrel to reduce the overall length of the
instrument.
Electronics Chassis Assembly
Electronic circuits and discrete parts mount on an I-beam chassis and include the
following components.
•
Six DC power supplies,
•
Controller board containing communication interface, guard drivers, data
acquisition and control circuits, calibration and verification circuits, etc.
•
Preamp board containing circuits for measuring VM1 and I0 (read as I zero), as
well as a means for sending them to the Controller board,
•
Bucker board provides the survey current,
•
Various chassis mounted components.

Physical Attributes
For an overview of how the major instrument components electrically and sometimes
mechanically, tie together, see the block diagram of Figure 2.

Electrode Rings: Twenty one electrode rings encircle the housing and connect to the
inner electronics using feedthroughs.  Electrode pairs are spaced along the
mandrel at specific distances to achieve varying depths of investigation.  The
electrode rings have a mild steel surface to promote rusting and it is this rust that
makes a better electrical “contact” to the borehole fluids.  A fiberglass layer
isolates the electrode rings from the inner titanium housing.

1 VM is the voltage measurement of the M1 electrode relative to the surface remote.  I0 is the

A4 and A4': Metal end pieces of the housing also serve as electrodes, A4 and A4'.  Two
isolation joints within the housing separate these two end pieces from the inner
housing.  Instruments connected above and below the RTeX extend the electrical
length of the A4 electrodes.  Springs mounted on the top and bottom snorkel
sections of the chassis make contact to the end pieces through the electronics.
Fiberglass: A fiberglass assembly holds all the contact sockets that mate with the
feedthroughs.  Each contact is loosely held in place by a set of magnets so that it
has freedom to align with the feedthrough.
Copper Pipes: Copper pipes are attached to the bottom side of the fiberglass assembly.
Their purpose is to provide a low-resistance connection between the top and
bottom guard electrode pairs: A1-A1’, A2-A2’, A3-A3' and A4-A4'.  Each pipe has
a different outer diameter so that they fit inside one another.  Kapton tape is
wrapped around each pipe for insulation.  Connection to A5 and A5' is made with
a wire that runs through the center of these pipes.
Chassis Potential: A spring-loaded contact assembly on the chassis provides
connection to the inner housing.  Rather than leaving the inner housing floating, a
unity-gain buffer, found on the Main Controller board, is used to maintain the

topic: 1241XA Disassembly / Assembly Procedures ................... - 1.1 EXPOSING THE ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY ........................................ 2
chunk_text:
EXPOSING THE ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
Item numbers in brackets refer to drawing A3000646000 unless otherwise noted.

NOTICE:
To avoid damage to Feed-through Pins [15], remove all 22 of them first,
(use Feed-through Removal Tool [18]).  ACCOUNT FOR ALL 22 OF
THEM BEFORE PROCEEDING.

Each Feed-through Pin has additional hardware.  Be careful not to
lose any of the Grommets [14], Spacers [16] or O-rings [13].  See
View B on the drawing.

Anytime Feed-through Pins are removed, reassemble with new
hardware.  Discard the old O-rings [13], Grommets [14] and Spacers
[16]; do not reuse the old ones.

Inspect all Feed-through Pins [15] for cracks in the ceramic coating.
Be sure they are in good working condition, as they will be reused.
Replace if necessary.  These are all critical points for pressure
leakage and tool failure.  Only parts of good integrity should be used
when re-assembling the instrument.

_____1.
With all Feed-through Pins removed, remove the Pin Thread Protector
[3] from the uphole end by rotating the Split Collar [12] with a Spanner
Wrench.
_____2.
Remove the downhole Thread Protector [11] by unscrewing it.
_____3.
Rotate the Split Collar [5] until the Bottom Sub [8] is free and then
remove it.
_____4.
Remove the Chassis Lock Nut [4] using Lock Nut Tool [19].  This frees
up the chassis for removal.  Push the uphole connector with something
firm, yet soft, (like the wooden handle of a hammer) until the Chassis is
exposed on the downhole end sufficiently to grab.
_____5.
At the downhole end, pull the Electronics and Fiberglass Rod Assembly
[1] out of the Fiberglass Housing [2].

NOTICE:
Due to the length of this Chassis, removal is always a two-man operation.
To avoid damage to the Chassis, when the Chassis is approximately
halfway exposed, rotate the I-beam until it is oriented vertically --- this will
afford the greatest rigidity when handling.  Always carry with the I-beam

1241 XA Rt Explorer – Disassembly / Assembly
131042-955 / 1241 XA
JUNE 2013
_____6.
As the Chassis exits the Housing, be sure to support it to prevent
bending and avoid damaging any internal parts.  It is recommended to
place the Chassis on a suitable workbench to support it along its entire
length.  If placed on tool stands, use the Chassis Supports [24] at each
contact point, and support it with no less that four stands.
Note: If work is to be done on the Electronics or PC board assemblies, use proper
ESD safeguards.

topic: 1241XA Disassembly / Assembly Procedures ................... - 1.2 REMOVING FIBERGLASS ROD ASSEMBLY ......................................... 3
chunk_text:
REMOVING FIBERGLASS ROD ASSEMBLY
For this section, see assembly drawing A3001822000.
_____7.
In the rare event that a roller assembly or grounding assembly must be
replaced, the Fiberglass Rod Assembly [2] will have to be removed to
access their mounting screws.  Also, if the copper pipes must be
accessed for any reason, the Fiberglass Rod Assembly will have to be
removed.
_____8.
To remove the Fiberglass Rod [2], locate the several sets of screws
along the backbone that hold it to the chassis.  There is a set of four
fixed screws at the uphole end.  There are also three sets (two screws
each) of floating points in slotted holes used to fasten it to the Chassis
and allow for the difference in the rates of expansion between the
fiberglass rod and the metal chassis.  Locate and remove the ten screws
total holding it.
a. The fixed set of 4 screws is found on either side of the first (uphole)
roller assembly between two power supplies.  Using a nut driver,
hold the lock nuts [20] and unscrew the socket-head cap screws
[19].  Retain all hardware for installation later.
b. The first set of floating points is beneath the Main Controller PCBA
[13].  It will have to be removed first, before you can access the
screws [3] holding the rod.  See section A-A for details.
c. The second set is between the PreAmp PCBA [14] and the Bucker
PCBA [15].
d. The third set is next to the three solder terminals at the downhole
end of the chassis.

NOTICE:
To avoid breakage of the Fiberglass Rod while carrying it, support it along

topic: 1241XA Disassembly / Assembly Procedures ................... - 1.3 REMOVING THE FILTER / POWER SUPPLY ASSEMBLIES ................. 4
chunk_text:
REMOVING THE FILTER / POWER SUPPLY ASSEMBLIES 4

REMOVING THE FILTER / POWER SUPPLY ASSEMBLIES
For this section, see assembly drawing A3001823000.
_____1.
For Filter boards: see section C-C of the drawing for details.  The Filter
assembly [24] is now a single PC Board.  To remove it, unplug the
connector [53] and remove the screws [23] holding it to the standoffs.
_____2.
For Power Supply boards: see sections D-D, E-E and/or N-N.  To
remove the Power Supplies, unsolder wires going to terminal posts
(mark them so they can be reattached later).  Unscrew the six screws
[11] holding the Power Supply board to the heat sink --- in most cases it
is not necessary to remove the heat sink itself.  Retain all hardware for
replacement/repaired unit.  Note: For the 3.3 V power supply boards,
also remove the socket head screw [9] holding the heat-sinked diode
(E-E).  Access to this screw is through the board.

REMOVING PC BOARDS
For this section, see assembly drawing A3001822000.
_____1.
With the Electronics Chassis [1] removed from the housing, the PC
Boards are readily accessible for servicing.
_____2.
If there is need to remove any of them for troubleshooting (for instance,
to gain access to a point on the bottom of a board), simply unscrew the
screws [10] holding it to the standoffs.  Leave the connectors in place for
power and signal connections to remain intact --- simply flip the board
over.  Retain all hardware for reuse when installing the board again.
_____3.
If there is need to remove it for replacement, unscrew the screws.
Unscrew the Jack screws of connectors to remove them.

topic: 1241XA Disassembly / Assembly Procedures ................... - 1.5 REMOVING THE 18-SOCKET CONNECTORS ....................................... 4
chunk_text:
REMOVING THE 18-SOCKET CONNECTORS
For this section, see assembly drawing A3001823000.
With the Electronics Chassis removed from its housing, the 18-Socket
connectors [1] at each end of the instrument are exposed for servicing.

_____1.
To repair a broken wire, broken pin or to replace the entire connector,
unscrew the four screws holding the connector to the Chassis.  Take a
10-32 screw or T-handle inserted into the center pull hole to remove the
connector from the Chassis.  A service loop in the wiring should allow
you to expose enough of the wiring for repairs to be made.
_____2.
If a pin needs replacing, the connector has to be separated.  To do this,
unscrew the 4-40 lock nut on the rear of the connector.  This center post
holds the two halves of the connector together.  Separate the connector

JUNE 2013

NOTICE:
The uphole Snorkel consists of two pieces --- an isolator PEEK portion
[20] and a metal portion [2].  These two parts should not require
separation during the life of the tool; but if they are separated, putting
them back together can be tricky.  There are four distinct positions that
the Top Snorkel [2] can have in relation to the Isolation Snorkel [20]
because the four mating screw holes are exactly 90º apart.  Only one of
these four positions is correct.  Rotate the metal snorkel [2] such that pin
1 position of the Connector [1] matches the position of the key on the
Isolation Snorkel [20].  The other three positions, although possible, will
result in damage to the connector when mated to another tool.

REMOVING TRANSFORMERS
For this section, see assembly drawing A3001823000.

_____1.
Transformers [46] are removed by first unsoldering their wires at the
solder terminals.
_____2.
Each transformer sits in a base with a cap screwed to the top of it.  To
free the transformer, remove the screws holding the cap in place.
Retain all hardware, including the rubber, for installing a new

ASSEMBLY

Work found in this section needs only be done if the components were removed,
otherwise those steps can be skipped. 

INSTALLING TRANSFORMERS
For this section, see assembly drawing A3001823000.
_____1.
Reuse the rubber cushioning [47] surrounding the old transformer and
drop in the new transformer [46].  Orient the transformer such that the
wires going to the solder terminals are most direct (shortest route).  See
wiring diagram A3000646 WRD for details.
_____2.
See section G-G.  Place the cap [19] over the transformer and secure
with the screws [15] removed earlier.  Use a drop of Loctite on the
threads of the screws before installing.
_____3.
Cut to length and rewire the leads to the correct terminals.  See wiring
following the steps outlined in section 2.6.

rear of the connector.  Replace O-ring on O.D. if needed.
_____2.

threads of the screws before installing.

following the steps outlined in section 2.6.

Isolation Snorkel [20].  The other three positions, although possible, will

INSTALLING PC BOARDS
For this section, see assembly drawing A3001822000.

_____1.
Seat the PC Board onto its chassis standoffs in its proper orientation
and secure with the screws [10] and washers [7 & 8] removed earlier.  A
dab of RTV [5] should be applied to the heads of the screws and the
immediate PC board surface after they are installed to further ensure
they do not work loose.
_____2.
Install the mating connectors onto the boards.
_____3.
To complete instrument assembly, install the Chassis into the Housing
following the steps outlined in section 2.6.

To avoid breakage of the Fiberglass Rod while carrying it, support it along

used to fasten it to the Chassis and allow for the difference in the rates
of expansion between the fiberglass rod and the metal chassis.  Locate

d. The fixed set of 4 screws is found on either side of the first (uphole)

[13].  If the board is installed, you will have to remove it first.  Install

--- see drawing section A-A for details.
f.
The second set is between the PreAmp PCBA [11] and the Bucker

g. The third set is next to the three solder terminals at the downhole

chunk_text:
INSTALLING THE ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY 9

INSTALLING THE ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
Item numbers in brackets refer to BOM item numbers found on drawing A3000646000.

1. With any repairs made to the Electronics, install the Electronics Chassis [1] by
carefully sliding it into the Fiberglass Housing [2].

NOTICE:
Due to the length of this Chassis, installation is always a two-man
operation.  To avoid damage to the Chassis, carry the I-beam such that it
is oriented vertically as this will afford the greatest rigidity when handling.
Always carry with the I-beam vertical.

2. Keep the I-beam vertical until it is mostly installed.  Place the Chassis Installation
Tool [17] onto the downhole end and push the Chassis in as far as possible.
Rotate the Chassis until you feel the locating pin match with its mating slot, then
push the Chassis in until it bottoms out.
3. Look into each Feed-through hole to ensure that the Contact Block associated
with it is aligned with the hole before proceeding further.  If the Contact Block
cannot be aligned with a scribe or dental tool, pull the Chassis back out and try to
better center the Block in its cavity before sliding it back in.  These Blocks must
be in place for the Feed-through to be installed later.
4. This step assures that contact blocks are properly aligned before proceeding to
next steps of installing Contact pins [15].  Using Socket Alignment tool [29], insert
into each hole and capture its contact block.  Then screw it in until it hits bottom.
When it hits bottom, flat part should be flush with the housing as shown below.



of the instrument.

6. At the downhole end of the instrument, orient and install the Bottom Sub [8] by
rotating the Split Collar [5] with a Spanner Wrench.
10

1241 XA Rt Explorer – Disassembly / Assembly
131042-955 / 1241 XA
JUNE 2013

7. Lubricate all O-rings [13] with silicone oil [31]. This is most easily accomplished
by dipping the O-rings in a small cup filled with silicone oil. Afterwards, remove
O-rings and place them on a paper towel to absorb excess oil.

Note: The silicone oil will help seat the O-rings into the ports and make it
easier to push the pins [15] through the O-rings. If not properly lubricated,
the O-ring may be damaged as the contact pin [15] is pushed through the
O-ring.

8. Install a lubricated O-ring [13] in each of the 22 electrode ports. See Figure 3.

a. Manually insert the O-ring into the port. Gently press the O-ring into
the port to get it started.

b. Use the O-ring installation tool [30] to press on the O-ring and fully
seat it in the port. See Figure 4.

Note: It is highly recommended to use the O-ring installation tool [30] to
seat the O-rings. Use of any other tool or object may result in nicks or other
damage to the O-ring.

9. Insert a new Spacer [16] in each of the electrode ports. See Figure 3.

10. Take a new Grommet [14] and slide it over the Contact Pin [15] so that the broad
shoulder is up against the head of the Pin (see View B on drawing). Apply a thin
film of synthetic grease [22] around the base of the grommet. See Figure 2.

Note: Ensure grease encompasses the entire 360°. This is important for
creating a good seal.
11. Repeat these steps for all 22 Feed-throughs.
12. After all Feed-throughs are installed (confirming no leftover parts), finish
tightening with a torque screwdriver set to 36 in-lb.  Allow the Pins to sit overnight
and tighten again using the 36 in-lb setting.  This allows time for the grease to
settle and allows the Pin to bottom out on the Spacer.  Note: when completed
correctly, the Contact Pin should not extend beyond the O.D. of the housing.



1241 XA Rt Explorer – Disassembly / Assembly
131042-955 / 1241 XA
JUNE 2013


Sub [8]. Use new O-ring [7] and Lubriplate [20] as needed.
14. Install the top Thread Protector [3] by rotating the Split Collar [12] with a Spanner
Wrench.

HOUSING CHECKS

If performance has deteriorated over time, it could be that the specially designed housing has developed
leakage that is out of specification.  Remove the electronics from the housing and perform the following
checks.

_____1.
When removing the electronics, remove all feedthroughs and save them for later use.
Clean them before reuse.
_____2.
Concerning the feedthroughs, remove all O-rings, grommets, and spacers.  Discard the
O-rings and grommets --- new ones will be installed upon reassembly.  Clean the
spacers and save them for later use.
_____3.
Continue the disassembly process using the procedure found in manual section 131042-
955.
_____4.
Use a Megohmmeter to measure the resistance between adjacent electrode pairs listed
in Table 1 below.  Use the shiny edges of each electrode for contact points.  Verify that
all readings are greater than 100 KΩ.  Test at 500 V --- do not test at voltages greater
than 500 V.
Definition: an electrode for this instrument is a band that encompasses the outer diameter of the housing.
It is a machined surface (shiny) that has been impregnated with a coating in its center that rusts.  Thus, it
appears as a rusted surface surrounded by two thin bands of shiny metal (see Figure 1 for proper
positioning of meter leads to perform this test).  Each electrode is isolated from the adjacent electrode by
a rubberized insulator.  It is the insulator properties that we are seeking to measure.

MULL ELECTRONICS CHECK PROCESS14
11.0 MULL ELECTRONICS CHECK PROCESS

The following test is a good check of the Preamp Board.  The test involves running a test sequence that
collects data from the tool in the ZERO and CAL modes.  In the CAL mode, a test signal from the
Controller Board is measured by the Preamp.  Based on the results from the Preamp measurements,
Benchmark computes the relative gain and phase shift of all the I0 channels with respect to the low-gain
VM channel.  The calculated gains and phase-shifts are then compared against limits specified in a file.
All parameters that lie within the specified limits will have their respective boxes checked.

_____1.
If testing the electronics outside of the housing, install a jumper between electrode
contacts A1 and SA1 as shown in Figure 8.  Otherwise, skip this step.
_____2.
In the Workspace Explorer pane, double-click the MULL Electronics Check module.

_____3.
In the dialog box, click the “Load Limits…” button.  Locate and select the limits file,
“1241 XA_Limits.txt”.

_____4.
Start the sequence Test Sequence.

_____5.
Wait for the sequence to complete.  The sequence will take approximately 50 seconds.
The progress field in the MULL Electronics Check dialog box will periodically
update while the sequence is running.  After the sequence completes, a matrix of
checkboxes will appear in the dialog box.

_____6.
Verify that all checkboxes are checked and that the message “Electronics OK!”
appears in the textbox.

DEC 2009

12.0 LOG MODE

The tests described in this section require the use of an external load network.  There are two types of
load networks.  One is designed for testing the electronics assembly by itself without a housing.  The
other network is designed for testing a fully-assembled instrument.  With the exception of the first steps
involving the setup, the following instructions are applicable to both configurations.  Depending on your
configuration, perform whichever step 1 applies.

_____1.
If testing the electronics outside of housing…
a. Follow steps 1 through 4 in Appendix A on page 30 for setup instructions.
Initially, tests will only use PIECE 1.
Note:
Leave the contact pins and test clips attached to PIECE 2 disconnected for
now.  They will be connected to the electronics later.  Also, do not make the
connections between PIECE 1 and PIECE 2 (shown in VIEW C).
b. Verify that all binding posts are tight to ensure a good contact with the resistors.
… OR …
_____1.
If testing a fully-assembled instrument…
a. Follow steps 1 through 6 in Appendix B on page 32 for setup instructions.
Note:
Leave the Lower Guard Assembly off for now.  It will be used later.
b. Verify that all binding posts are tight to ensure a good contact with the resistors.
_____2.
Remove R8 and RTEST from the test fixture and set them aside for later use.
_____3.
Turn ON tool power.
_____4.
Set the driver levels.  To do this…
c. Double-click on the Driver Levels command.
d. Set all parameters as shown in Figure 13 below and click OK.

APPENDIX B – ASSEMBLED INSTRUMENT TEST SETUP

Refer to A1906937 FTP for test configuration, and perform the following setup instructions:



_____1.
Place the tool on wooden saw horses and rotate the tool so that the majority of the
feedthroughs are facing up.
_____2.
Attach the upper guard load assembly (A3001985000) to the tool:
a. Align assembly so that the hose clamps are centered on electrodes A1, A2, and A3.
The end labeled “UPHOLE” should be facing uphole.
b. Secure the assembly to the tool using the nylon straps.
c. Fasten the hose clamps around the tool and tighten the bands so that good contact
is made to the electrodes.
d. Inspect the spring-loaded plungers and verify they are in contact with the
feedthroughs on the other electrodes.
e. A fourth hose clamp is attached to the assembly by a wire.  Attach this hose clamp
to the top sub.
_____3.
Attach the center shunt assembly (A3001984000) to the tool:
a. Position the assembly so that the hose clamp is centered on the A0 electrode.  The
end labeled “UPHOLE” should be facing uphole.
b. Secure the assembly to the tool using the nylon straps.
c. Fasten the hose clamp around the A0 electrode and tighten.
d. Inspect the spring-loaded plungers and verify they are in contact with the
feedthroughs on the other electrodes.
_____4.
Connect E17 on the center shunt assembly to E16 on the upper guard load assembly.
_____5.
Connect E1 on the upper guard load assembly to conductor 16 on the breakout box.
_____6.
Connect E2 on the upper guard load assembly to conductor 17 on the breakout box.
_____7.

PROCEDURE
Item numbers appearing in brackets [  ] refer to items of drawing A3000646000 unless
otherwise noted.
_____1.
With thread protectors on, thoroughly wash the instrument.
_____2.
Inspect the fiberglass housing for damage.  Inspect fiberglass for cracks.
Inspect rubber molding on edges of the electrodes for pitting.
_____3.
Remove the electronics from the housing (follow disassembly procedure
found in manual section 131042-955).  In summary:
a. Remove thread protectors.
b. Remove all 22 feed-throughs [15].  Discard O-rings [13], Grommets [14]
and PEEK washers [16].
c. Remove top Chassis Nut [4].  Replace O-ring [6] on nut.
d. Remove Bottom Sub [8].
e. Remove electronics.
_____4.
On the housing, thoroughly clean the feed-through ports.  Use cotton swabs
and warm water.  Remove all grease, borehole fluid, salt crystals, etc.  Be
sure to clean the threads on the electrodes.
_____5.
Inspect the inside of the housing for debris or accumulation of grease.
Clean if necessary.  Also clean the threads on the downhole end of the
housing.
_____6.
Use a Megohmmeter to measure the resistance between the electrode pairs
listed in the table below.  Verify that all readings are greater than 100 KΩ
when testing at 500 V.  Do not use voltages greater than 500 V.

_____7.
Using a Megohmmeter, measure the resistance between the electrodes and
the inner housing.  Test at 500 V.  All readings should be greater than 5 MΩ.
Check all 21 electrode bands to inner-housing.

Note:
The inner housing is only accessible through the feedthrough holes.  The top and bottom
sections of the mandrel are isolated from the inner housing.  See Figure 1 for proper
positioning of meter leads to perform this test.


131042-953 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas

_____8.
Using a Megohmmeter, measure the resistance across the top isolation
joint.  Measure from the top section of the housing to the inner housing.
Test at 500 V.  The resistance should be greater than 1 MEGΩ.


Using a Megohmmeter, measure the resistance across the bottom isolation
joint.  Measure from the bottom end of the housing to the inner housing.
Test at 500 V.  The resistance should be greater than 1 MEGΩ.


1241 XA Rt Explorer – Level 3 PM
131042-953 / 1241 XA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
_____10. Thoroughly clean all feedthroughs.  Use solvent to remove grease.  Be sure
to clean the threads.
_____11. Inspect the feedthroughs.  Inspect the ceramic coating on the pins for any
chips or cracks.  Inspect the threads.  Replace any defective feedthroughs.
_____12. Replace the two O-rings [7] on the housing.
_____13. Remove the bulkhead Connector [9] from the Bottom Sub [8].  Check for
any bent pins.  Replace the two O-rings [23] on bulkhead connector.
_____14. Clean and inspect the Bottom Sub [8].  Be sure to keep the inside surface of
the bottom sub clean to ensure good electrical contact with the spring on
the chassis’ bottom snorkel.
_____15. Install two new O-rings [7] on Bottom Sub [8].  Re-install bulkhead
Connector [9] into bottom sub.
_____16. Inspect the electronics for loose or damaged parts.  Verify that all rollers are
working and in good condition.  Also check the grounding assembly [item 21
on dwg. A3001823000] that is located near the center of the chassis.  The
assembly has two spring-loaded plugs that are used to connect to the inside
of the housing.  Verify the plugs move freely and are in good condition.
Replace any missing or damaged parts.
_____17. Inspect the top and bottom 18-pin female connectors [item 1 on dwg.
A3001823000] on the chassis.  Check to ensure they are free of debris.
Use a male pin to test-fit each socket for a snug fit.
_____18. Inspect the sockets [item 3 on dwg. A3001824000] that mate with the
feedthroughs.  Clean if necessary.  Use one of the removed feedthroughs to
test-fit each socket for a snug fit.  Verify magnets hold sockets in place.
_____19. Check that all PC boards and power supplies are properly mounted with
hardware and RTV.
_____20. On the top and bottom snorkels, remove the springs and clean the grooves
to ensure good electrical contact.  Discard old springs and replace with new
ones --- top snorkel spring [49] and bottom snorkel spring [50] on drawing
A3001823000.
_____21. Re-assemble tool according to the assembly procedure.  Complete the
assembly except thread protectors.  Note: Follow assembly instructions
explicitly and be sure to use synthetic grease on grommets for each contact
--- this is very important for making a good seal.
_____22. Apply Lubriplate grease to the top spin-collar and lightly grease O-rings.
_____23. Perform continuity checks and functional testing according to the Repair/
Maintenance section of this manual.  See section 6.0 for the continuity
checks and sections 9.0, 10.0, 11.0 and 12.0 of document 131042-956 for
functional tests.
_____24. Install top and bottom thread protectors.

INTRODUCTION
Level 3 maintenance should be performed on the 1241 XA Rt Explorer Instrument
every four months to ensure the integrity of the service.  It would be extremely helpful
to know the status of the electronics before starting anything.  If electronics meets
the Communication test and functional testing described in 131042-956, there are no
electrical parts to replace.  However, several components should be verified that they
are secured to prevent failure.  There are several O-Rings that must be replaced.
These and other steps are listed below.  Parts list 131042-843 shows only those
parts that must be replaced, other parts that may be needed for repair are listed in
the spare parts list, 131042-841.

HEAT TEST PROCEDURE

In anticipation of use in a high-temperature environment (within tool specifications),
an Rt Explorer instrument may be operated in an oven to verify performance.
Otherwise, no heat test for this instrument is required.

INTRODUCTION


Brief specifications:
With 1241 PA
Length:

The 1241 XB Hybrid RTeX is a converted Focus 1241 XA
RTeX.  Its conversion allows it to operate mechanically and
electrically in a WTS tool string, but only at Focus
temperatures.  Since the design was originally DC powered, it
must convert the WTS AC-supplied source to Focus DC using
a crossover adapter.  Connected above the instrument, the
crossover 1241 PA adapter (131068000) performs this power
conversion and provides the mechanical WTS connection.
The bottom connector is both mechanically and electrically
WTS compatible as well.  Other than these differences, the
service provided is the same as the Focus 1241 XA Rt
Explorer.
Note: the top of the 1241 XB is a Titanium spin collar
that should only mate with the 1241 PA and should not
be broken at the wellsite; it is not a “field joint.”
The resistivity value of the uninvaded formation, Rt, is critical
for calculation of water saturation.  In a highly conductive
borehole and high resistivity formations, galvanic tools
consisting of an array of both current injecting and voltage
measuring electrodes, like the Rt Explorer (RTeX), are the
preferred instruments.
The complete Focus RTeX system consists of not only the
RTeX electrode mandrel, but also the housings of other
instruments above and below.  The RTeX mandrel contains
the electrodes (center electrode and guards) needed for the
measurement of the shallowest resistivity (MLR1) and two
intermediate diameters of investigation (MLR2 and MLR3).
Observe the instrument sketch on the right.  The guard
electrodes are symmetrical around the center electrode A0,
3

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Description of Service
131067-936 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
with M1, M2, A1, A2 and A3 situated on the mandrel itself.  This system can be
thought of as an array of four laterologs, LL7 type, with increasing guard length
from shallow to deep.
The instruments immediately above and below the RTeX mandrel (typically
Acoustilog or Densilog above and Micro-laterolog below) become electrode A4
and provide the guards for the deeper diameter-of-investigation resistivity
measurement.  On the uphole side of the upper A4 electrode housing, and on the
downhole side of the lower A4 electrode housing, Isolation Subs are installed to
limit the A4 electrode size.  These Isolation Subs also separate the electrode A5
(upper and lower) from A4 and provide a means for the RTeX electronics to
make connection to the A5 electrode.  The particular Isolation Sub used for WTS
operation is the series 4485 XA (F131238000).
All electrodes on the RTeX mandrel are symmetrical around the center electrode
(A0) in number and size.  Each of the two A4, upper and lower, electrodes is
required to be 10 to 14 ft in length.  However, the upper A5 and lower A5 can be
quite different in length.
Additionally, electrodes A2 and A3 are bookended by small voltage-sense
electrodes.  The A1 electrode has one sense electrode (on the A2 electrode
side).
The RTeX housing is isolated with a layer of fiberglass and the electrodes are
placed on top of this layer.  The isolation between electrodes is a ring of rubber
at each electrode end and more fiberglass in between.
Electronic circuitry for the system is located inside the RTeX mandrel.

In summary:
•
RTeX provides four apparent resistivity curves with different diameters of
investigation (approximately 18”, 26”, 38” and 74”).
•
Based on the preliminary success of the Focus 1241 XA Rt Explorer, the intent of
this project was to quickly provide a WTS version.  The resulting hybrid
combination of the 1241 PA crossover adapter and the 1241 XB Rt Explorer was
the solution.  This hybrid combination is both mechanically and electrically
compatible with other WTS tools.
•
Environmental corrections can be applied to the apparent resistivity curves.
•
The measured data can be inverted in real-time to derive formation resistivity Rt,

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Description of Service
131067-936 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas

PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION

To illustrate the principle of operation of the Rt Explorer (RTeX), a block diagram
of the electrode array and interface electronics is shown in Figure 1.  Only half of
the array is shown in the block diagram.  Please remember that for each one of
the electrodes shown, i.e. M1, M2, A1 - A5, there is a corresponding M1’, M2’,
A1’ - A5’ electrode.
Electrodes A0, M1, M2, A1, A2, and A3, are located on the RTeX mandrel.  The
instruments above and below the mandrel become part of the electrode system
and are referred to as electrodes A4 and A5.  Keep in mind that the 1241 PA
placed on top of the mandrel makes up part of the upper A4 electrode.
Electrodes A5 must be isolated from the rest of the system using Isolation Subs.
Four sinusoidal sources, each at different frequencies ranging from 30 to 195 Hz,
are connected as indicated in the diagram.  Frequencies F1, F2, and F3 are
voltage sources and F4 is a current source.
A0 is the current measuring electrode.  The bucker amplifier injects sufficient
current through A0 into the formation to maintain the difference in potential
between M1 and M2 at zero for all four frequencies.  This prevents the I0 current
from flowing up or down the borehole, but rather is forced into the formation in a
“disk” shape, perpendicular to the instrument.  The voltage across the sensing
resistor is proportional to the I0 current.
Electrodes A1, A2, A3 and A4 provide guards of increasing length to electrode
A0.  At frequency F1 the guard is only A1; return for F1 is A2, A3 and A4.  At
frequency F2 the effective guard has increased in length, and is the combination
of A1 and A2 which focuses the frequency F2 currents deeper than the F1
currents.  Return for this mode is A3 and A4.  This pattern continues and the
guard for frequency F3 is the combined length of the A1, A2 and A3 electrodes
with the return being only A4.  Finally for frequency F4, the guard is A1, A2, A3
and A4 (with return being A5), providing the deepest measurement.  All four of
these frequencies are being emitted simultaneously to create the varying
diameters of investigation and are illustrated in Figure 2.
The voltage of electrode M1 combined with the current I0, both measured at the
four operating frequencies F1, F2, F3 and F4, provide the resistance seen by A0
under the respective focusing conditions and with increased diameter-of-
investigation from shallow to deep.  By applying the proper “k” factors, these
resistances are converted to resistivities at four diameters of investigation.
Normally a Micro-resistivity instrument, like the MLL, is connected below the
RTeX and becomes the lower A4 electrode guard.  The MLL provides an Rxo
measurement that is used for RTeX data processing and inversion.

AUG 2009

DATA ACQUISITION
The 1241 XB Rt Explorer (RTeX) is a galvanic resistivity tool with four diameters
of investigation.  Two measurements are required to determine resistivity: VM
and I0.  VM is a measurement of the voltage of the M1 electrode with respect to
surface remote, and I0 is the survey current entering/leaving electrode A0.  Both
signals are sampled by A/D’s on the preamp board and processed by the Digital
Signal Processor (DSP) on the Controller board.  If the tool only had to provide a
measurement for one diameter of investigation, there would be only one driver
operating at one frequency, and the resistivity could be determined simply by
examining the amplitudes of VM and I0.  However with four drivers operating at
different frequencies, the VM and I0 signals will each be a composite waveform
of four different sinusoids.  Now we can no longer just examine the amplitude of
the time-domain waveform.  Each waveform must first be decomposed into their
four constituent components.  The “decomposition” is done by performing a
Discrete-Fourier Transform (DFT) on the signals.  The DFT process provides the
amplitude and phase of the sinusoids comprising each waveform.  This
processing is performed downhole by the DSP, and the results are reported to
the surface for resistivity calculations.

The A/D sampling frequency is ~7.653kHz and the DFT is performed on sets of
512 samples.  To avoid spectral leakage, the four operating frequencies are
chosen to be integer multiples of a base frequency, 14.947 Hz.  These are
29.89 Hz (F4), 104.6 Hz (F1), 164.4 Hz (F3) and, 194.3 Hz (F2).  The operating
frequencies and A/D sampling frequency are derived from a common system
clock so they are precisely related to each other.

The DFT results from multiple cycles are stacked (or added) together.  The
stacked DFT results along with a stack count are reported in the subsets.  The
stack count indicates how many cycles were stacked in the DFT result.  An
averaged DFT result is determined by dividing the stacked results by the stack
count.  Typically, the time interval between “Acquire Subset” commands
determines how many cycles are stacked.  One cycle is 66.9ms (512 A/D
samples).  When the tool receives an “Acquire” command, it
(1) waits for the current cycle to complete,
(2) transfers the contents of the stacking buffer to a send buffer, and
(3) clears the stacking buffer to start a new stack.
The “Send subset” command starts transmission of data to the surface from the
send buffer.  The default maximum stacking level is 60.  If the maximum stacking
level is reached, the stacking buffer will be transferred to the send buffer and a
new stack will be started.

In addition to the frequency-domain data (DFT results), the underlying time-
domain waveforms are stacked as well.  The full waveforms, each being 512
samples long, can be uploaded in Subset 4.  The waveforms are made available
for debugging purposes only, that is, they are not needed for processing.

8

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Description of Service
131067-936 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
Only VM and I0 are needed to determine resistivity, but the voltage and current
of each driver are measured as well for control purposes.  The DSP implements
a control algorithm used to determine the optimum driver output levels.  The goal
of the algorithm is to operate the drivers at the highest achievable drive level
under varying borehole conditions.  Another goal of the algorithm is to maintain a
reasonable balance in the magnitude spectrum of the I0 signal so that one
spectral component does not over-power the measurement and compromise the
measurement of the other components.

The control algorithm periodically checks the measurements to see if they are all
within range.  If any waveform exceeds a high or low limit, the control algorithm
will incrementally decreases the driver output levels until all waveforms fall within
range.  VM and I0 are monitored to see if the signal levels are within the
measurement circuit’s input range.  The output current of the voltage sources are
monitored to ensure they are within design limits.  The output voltages of all the
power opamps are monitored to ensure their outputs are not clipping.

On power-up, the algorithm initializes all drive levels to a default value.
Afterwards, it examines I0 and determines the relative drive settings needed to
equalize the magnitudes of the four spectral components.  After determining the
relative drive settings, the algorithm searches for the maximum achievable drive
levels by incrementally increasing them until an out-of-range condition occurs on
any waveform.  Afterwards, the drive levels are reduced to bring all signals back
within range.  After finding the optimum drive levels, the control algorithm saves
the state of I0 for future comparison.  The algorithm may decide to search for a
new drive setting if a significant change occurs on I0.

The main operational subset is Subset 2.  This subset contains the frequency-
domain data for I0 and VM, which is needed to determine resistivity.  Additional
waveform data is reported as well for monitoring purposes.  Waveform data for
I0, VM, and the driver voltages and currents are reported.  In an effort to maintain
a reasonable subset size, only one waveform at a time is sent.  Each acquisition
sends a different waveform.  A wave ID parameter is included in the subset to
indicate which waveform was sent.  To further reduce the length of the subset,
the waveform is decimated to 128 samples.

LOGGING PROCEDURES
The shallowest diameter-of-investigation is ~ 18 inches, that distance makes the
curve MLR1 sensitive to borehole ruggosity; to improve the response of the tool it
is recommended to centralize the tool for small borehole sizes.  But for big
borehole sizes this curve is going to read mainly mud even when the tool is
centralized.  For that reason, for boreholes greater than 8.5”, it is better to run the
tool with 1.5 inch Stand-Offs.  Do not run the tool FREE.

9

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Description of Service
131067-936 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas

APPLICATIONS
For the RTeX, the main purpose is to provide the description of the variation of
resistivity in invaded zones in salt saturated borehole fluids.
The RTeX interpretation uses the Rxo provided by the MLL in conjunction with
the four RTeX resistivities (MLR1, MLR2, MLR3, and MLR4) to produce a
corrected Rt and the length-of-invasion Lxo.

RTEX DELIVERABLES
Well site deliverables are the four apparent resistivities MLR1, MLR2, MLR3, and
MLR4 borehole corrected.  In addition to the normal environmental corrections
(through ENCOR program) a more advanced correction mechanism is available
for RTeX measurements.  The ABC (Adaptive Borehole Correction) processing
accounts for the tool position within the borehole beyond the two supposed
positions, centered and eccentered, that are available through ENCOR. The ABC
more properly corrects the curves for borehole effects and does not suffer from
the problem of over or under correcting that would be inherent in simple borehole
correction.  Additionally, the ABC utilizes data from all four curves simultaneously
and results inversion provides estimations of Rxo, Lxo, Rt and the tool
eccentricity within the borehole.  Normally MLL will be run in combination.  In this
case the MLL apparent resistivity will complement the four RTeX readings.
Please see RTeX log example in Figure 3.
The four MLR curves were designed to provide a clear indication of invasion.  To
accomplish this, diameter-of-investigation from very shallow (MLR1 ~ 18 inches)
to fairly deep (MLR4 ~ 74 inches) are required.  MLR1 is in particular helpful in
defining the invasion of relatively low resistivity encountered in a formation with
an oil-water contact.
Diameters-of-investigation for lateral tools are not fixed as they are for induction
type measurements, but are highly dependent on the contrast between the
formation resistivity and the resistivity of borehole fluid.  The diameter-of-
investigation becomes shallower as the contrast Rt/Rm increases.
The borehole correction also increases with the contrast Rt/Rm.  Furthermore,
borehole correction becomes greater as the instrument deviates from being
perfectly centered in the borehole.
RTeX borehole corrections are computed for two situations: (1) centered where
the tool is exactly in the center of the borehole, and (2) eccentered with 1.5”
standoff where the tool is on one side of the borehole wall and would be touching
the wall except for the standoffs.  The logs with centered tools would require less
correction than the eccentered ones for the same borehole size and Rt/Rm.
10

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Description of Service
131067-936 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
For large boreholes (12 ¼” bit size) and high contrast, the MLR1 borehole
correction becomes excessively large.  The uncertainty of the position of the
instrument, as well as the departure from the borehole being a cylinder of
constant diameter over the length of the instrument, precludes an accurate
correction.
For these reasons, MLR1 is displayed only when the borehole correction is such
that it preserves the accuracy of the final result.

2.0 ELECTRONICS ASSEMBLY
Refer to Electronics Chassis assembly drawing A3002161000 for the location of
components cited in the following circuit descriptions. 

DC POWER SUPPLIES
This mandrel electronics is powered from a downhole power converter in the
1241 PA that converts 180 VAC to a +28 volt power source.  This voltage is locally
supplied only to the 1241 XB through dedicated pins.  See additional information
on the 1241 PA Power Adapter in this manual.
In the block diagram of Figure 2, all power supplies are denoted as the block
labeled “Power Supplies.”  For a detailed description of the PC boards and circuitry
associated with this block, see POWER SUPPLY CIRCUITRY.
Before the +28 volts is applied to a power supply module, it passes through a
special circuit used to filter noise from other instruments hanging on this common
power source.  It is the output of these filters that is applied as an input to the
power supplies.  For more detail, see section 2.6.3 of this document.
This filtered +28 volts is reduced to ±5 volts using a DC-to-DC converter module
A3000558000.  This voltage source provides power wherever a bipolar 5 V supply
is required.  The converter module is located on a heat sink installed on the
chassis.  For more detail on this dual supply, see section 2.6.1 of this document.
This filtered +28 volts is also the source for five +3.3 volts converter modules
(A3000976000).  These supplies provide power to most of the remaining circuitry
in the instrument. They, too, are located on PC boards mounted to heat sinks.  For
more detail on this supply, see section 2.6.2 of this document.

2.2.1 TELEMETRY COMMUNICATIONS

The 1241 XB Rt Explorer responds to the WTS Telemetry protocol for
communication on the instrument bus.  It adheres to the tool interface
specification F059448000.

U9 is an Actel FPGA which contains a Manchester Decoder for decoding
commands on the instrument bus, and two Manchester Encoders.  One
encoder is dedicated for mode 2 data, and the other for modes 5 or 7.  The
FPGA also provides an interface to the temperature sensor and serial
EEPROM.  All internal registers are selected with /MS3.  The receiver
(U12) for mode 2 commands and drivers (U10, U11, U14) for mode 2, 5,
and 7 are shown on sheet 4.  The instrument bus transformers are located
on a separate PC board (A3000773000).

Data transfer between the DSP and mode 2 encoder/decoder is interrupt-
driven using IRQ1.  Interrupt line IRQ1 is shared between the mode 2
decoder and mode 2 encoder.  A status register within the FPGA indicates
the source of the interrupt.  This register is read by the DSP to determine
which device generated the interrupt.  The decoder asserts IRQ1 whenever
it receives a command that is addressed to the tool.  The interrupt notifies
the DSP to read the command from the receive buffer within the FPGA.
The mode 2 encoder can also be enabled to generate an interrupt using
/IRQ1.  When the DSP is ready to send data on mode 2, the encoder
interrupt is enabled.  Once enabled, the encoder asserts /IRQ1 whenever
the transmit buffer is empty and ready to accept new data.  The DSP writes
a new word to the encoder in response to the interrupt.  Figure 3 shows
the tool receiving a “Send Subset E” command and responding on Mode 2.



1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Circuit Description
131067-945 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
A second encoder is used to transmit data on either mode 5 or mode 7.
Writes to this encoder is DMA driven using /DMAR2 and /DMAG2.  The
DMA request line (/DMAR2) is asserted by the FPGA when the encoder is
ready to accept new data.  In response, the DSP asserts /DMAG2 and
presents data on the bus (D[31:16]).  The data is latched in the encoder
transmit buffer on the rising edge of /DMAG2.  Bus control signals /MS1
and /WR are not active during the DMA transfer.  Figure 4 shows the tool
transmitting Subset E on Mode 5.  The bottom half of the capture is a
zoomed-in view of the first DMA transaction.  A second transaction closely
follows because the transmit buffer becomes ready immediately after the
encoder latches the data and begins transmitting.  Subsequent
transactions are spaced 171µs apart.  The last pulse may or may not be
present, depending on whether or not the DSP responds to an internal
DMA interrupt in time to disable the DMA before the last word has been
latched by the encoder.
2.2.2 DIGITAL SIGNAL PROCESSOR

U4 is an Analog Devices digital-signal processor (DSP).  Instruction code
for the device is stored in Flash memory (U5).  The DSP features 4 Mbits of
internal memory for storage of program and data.  After a power-on, or
software reset, the code is loaded from flash into internal memory.

The DSP can be booted from either the upper or lower half of flash
memory.  By default, the DSP boots from the upper half since the boards
are shipped without JP1 installed.  If JP1 is installed, the DSP will boot
from the lower half.  If necessary, new firmware updates can be
8

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Circuit Description
131067-945 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
downloaded using Benchmark software (A7000205 SW).  Updating the
firmware requires that the DSP re-program the flash memory.  If a problem
occurs during the download process and corrupts the boot memory, the
DSP can be re-booted from the backup copy in the lower half of flash
memory.

Much of the interfacing between the DSP and peripheral devices is done
through two Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGA), U9 and U16.  U16 is
an Actel FPGA which contains the logic to interface with the drivers and
A/D’s.  U9 contains the interface for the instrument bus, serial EPROM, and
temperature sensor.

A heartbeat LED (D6) blinks once every second.  This LED is a useful tool
to help determine if the DSP is operating correctly.

Header P3 is a connector for an in-circuit emulator and used for
development purposes only.
2.2.3 DATA ACQUISITION

The output voltage and output current of each driver, as well as the output
voltage of the Bucker board, are measured and gathered as data in the
overall scheme of this instrument.  The chore of gathering the data and
sending it to the surface is one of the functions of the DSP.  Measurement
circuits are found on sheets 10 and 11.  Sheet 10 contains the four A/D
channels used to measure the output current of each driver.  Sheet 11
contains five A/D channels to the output voltage of the four drivers and the
bucker.

The following description starts at the top-right corner of sheet 10 to trace
the signal path of the mode 1 driver’s current measurement.  U38 is an
instrumentation amplifier used to measure the differential voltage across a
current sense resistor mounted on the chassis.  R177 sets the gain at
5 V/V.  Input over-voltage protection is provided by R175 and R176 and
clamping diodes D16.  After the instrumentation amplifier, the signal is
level-shifted and lightly filtered by opamp U123.  A 1.25 V offset is added to
center the signal within the 2.5 V input range of the A/D converter.  U55 is a
16-bit A/D converter.

Other A/D channels are similar to the previously described channel.
However, there are some differences in the first stage.  The mode 1, 2, and
3 driver voltages are measured without the aid of an instrument amplifier.

The reference voltage for the analog section is provided by U36.  It
generates a 2.5 V reference voltage.  A voltage divider (R147 and R156) is
used to derive a 1.25 V reference needed by the DDS chips.  U121 A buffers
the 2.5 V reference to provide a low impedance reference for the A/D’s.  A

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Circuit Description
131067-945 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas

An A/D conversion is initiated by a rising edge on the CNV input (pin 6).
The CNV input of all the A/D’s are driven by the A/D sampling clock
(/MLL_AD_CLK) which is generated by FPGA U16.  The A/D sampling
clock is an inverted pulse generated every 130.7µs.  The A/D’s have a
serial interface consisting of a serial clock (SCK), serial data out (SDO),
and serial data in (SDI).  The A/D’s are daisy-chained by connecting the
SDO of one device to the SDI of another.  This configuration allows U16 to
read all A/D’s, using only one data line, in one long serial bit stream.  FPGA
U16 drives SCK and shifts in data from the SDO of U79.  SCK is a
discontinuous clock operating at 12 MHz.

The A/D timing is illustrated below in Figure 5.  After the FPGA pulses
/MLL_AD_CLK to initiate a conversion, it waits 4.6µs after the rising edge
to allow the A/D’s to finish the conversion.  After waiting for the conversion
to complete, the FPGA drives SCK for 160 cycles to shift out the new A/D
data.

The most involving task of the FPGA (U16) is to collect the A/D samples
and deliver them to the DSP.  Data from the A/D’s located on the Controller
board, as well as the A/D data from the Preamp board, are collected and
written to a FIFO for the DSP to read.  A block diagram of the data path is
