FPGA.  The DMA (direct memory access) controller allows data to be read
from the FPGA without the direct involvement of the core processor,
freeing it to do more meaningful work.  DMA transfers occur through the
use of two handshaking signals: /DMAR1 (dma request) and /DMAG1 (dma
grant).  The FPGA asserts /DMAR1 whenever there is data available in the
FIFO.  In response, the DSP asserts /DMAG1 while reading one word from
the FIFO in the FPGA.  Although the data bus (D[31:16]) is used to transfer
data, the memory-select (/MS2) and read (/RD) signals are not active
during the DMA read operation.  See diagram of Figure 7.


1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Circuit Description
131067-945 / 1241 XB

Baker Atlas

The FIFO is 16 bits wide.  Each A/D sample generates two writes to the
FIFO – one for the most-significant word and one for the least significant
word.  For the case of the 16-bit onboard A/D’s, the most-significant word is
0000h.  For the 18-bit A/D’s on the Preamp, the most-significant word
includes the upper two bits of the A/D value; unused bit positions are zero-
filled.
clock (point A).  After waiting 4.6μs, the FPGA starts shifting in data from
the onboard A/D’s (point B).  Shortly thereafter, the Preamp starts sending
A/D data as well (point C).  The FPGA latches each Preamp word on the
rising edge of RFS and immediately writes the word into the FIFO.  A DMA
request occurs as a result of each FIFO write operation (point D).
The data collected from the onboard A/D’s is not written into the FIFO until
the following sampling clock.  After shifting in the serial data, the FPGA
holds the data in the shift-register until the falling edge of the next sampling
clock.  The DMA requests resulting from the FIFO write operations can be
seen at point E.


The FPGA counts the number of words returned by the Preamp board.  If
the FPGA does not receive enough data from the Preamp board by the end
of the cycle, it will write zeroes into the FIFO in lieu of the missing words.
On the other hand, if it receives too many words, it will inhibit writing the
extra words into the FIFO.  These measures are taken to ensure the
coherency of the data.  The DSP expects a certain number of words each
cycle.  Missing or extra words will cause the processing to become

2.2.4 ELECTRODE DRIVERS

Reference Signals
Four identical circuits are used to create a sinusoidal reference signal for
each driver.  These circuits can be found on the top half of sheets 6, 7, 8,
and 9.  These circuits are physically identical to each other but they each
generate a different frequency.  Refer to page 6 of the schematic for the
following discussion of the reference signal generated for the mode 1
driver.
The signal chain begins with U21 which is a DDS chip used to generate a
105 Hz sine wave.  The frequency and phase of the sine wave is
programmed by the DSP during startup.  Pin 14 is the sine wave output.
The waveform at this point is unipolar, ranging from 0 to approximately
800mV.
This unipolar sine wave is ac-coupled by C311 and R245 to remove the DC
offset and create a bipolar waveform.  U102 A buffers the signal.  U102 B
and its surrounding components form a 2nd order low-pass filter needed to
remove quantization noise.  The signal at TP59 is a clean sine wave,
centered at 0 V, with an amplitude of 400mV.  Afterwards, the signal passes
through a programmable attenuator.
The programmable attenuator is formed by multiplexer U25 and
surrounding resistors.  R72 is the bottom resistor of a voltage divider, and
the top resistor is selectable through U25.  The 8-to-1 mux allows for 8
levels of attenuation ranging from 1/1 to 1/128.  The attenuation settings
were chosen so that they vary by a factor of 2.  U102 C buffers the signal
after the attenuation stage.  Afterwards, the signal is ac-coupled with C334
and R235 to remove any DC offset that may be added by the previous
stages.  U102 D buffers the signal again to drive transformer T5.
U101 is a comparator used to detect the zero crossing point of the
reference signal.  The comparator output feeds back into an FPGA (U16),
which waits for a rising edge on SQUARE_WAVE_F1 before updating the
mux enable (MUX_EN_F1) or mux select signals (MUX_A2_F1,
MUX_A1_F1, MUX_A0_F1).  This feature is included to minimize abrupt
changes in the reference signal when switching attenuation settings.  A
simplified sketch of the logic is shown below in Figure 9.  The DSP writes
the attenuation setting to a control register, but the new settings do not take
effect until a rising edge occurs at the comparator output.  A light RC filter

Voltage Sources
The bottom half of pages 6, 7, and 8 contain the active portion of the
voltage sources used to drive the guard electrodes.  The following

discussion describes the operation of the mode 1 driver circuit shown on
page 6.  The other drivers on pages 7 and 8 operate in a similar manner.
The output transformer and current sense resistor for the driver are
mounted on the chassis.  A simplified schematic of the entire driver is
shown in Figure 11 below.  The function of the circuit is to impose a
reference signal, presented on the primary winding of T5, across the A2*
and A1* sense electrodes.  The sense electrodes can be thought of as
remote sense terminals that allow the voltage directly at the “load” to be
regulated.  The “load” in this case is the mud (or borehole fluid), which is
driven by electrodes A2 and A1.  Rather than sensing directly at the drive
electrodes, where IR drops and contact impedances can affect the
regulation, separate sense electrodes are used instead.  The sense
electrodes are located close to their respective drive electrodes on the
housing.

When discussing the operation of the driver in qualitative terms, it helps to
separate the discussion into an AC analysis and DC analysis.  For AC
analysis, capacitors C331 and C337 are considered to be shorts and
resistors R294 and R295 are neglected because their impedance is much
greater than the impedance of the capacitors.  For DC analysis, the
capacitors are open and the effects of the resistors are considered.  At
0.159 Hz, the impedance of the capacitors equals the impedance of the
resistors.  At frequencies above 0.159 Hz, the effects of the capacitors
dominate and the resistors can be ignored.  This is especially true at the
four operating frequency of the drivers (30 Hz, 105 Hz, 165 Hz, and 195 Hz.),
which is much greater than 0.159 Hz.


T5 is a 1:1 transformer that is used to translate the reference signal, which
is referenced to ground, into a floating source that can be used to drive the
(+) input of U31 with respect to the A1* sense.  Because of negative
feedback, the opamp adjusts its output to whatever voltage necessary to
make the voltage at the (-) input equal to that of the (+) input.  A 6:1 step-
15

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Circuit Description
131067-945 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
down transformer (TF1) is used to couple the output to the electrodes.  TF1
boosts the output current, which reduces the amount of current that needs
to be supplied by U31 and the power supplies.  R3 is a resistor used for
measuring the driver’s output current.

Resistors R294 and R295 are needed to provide DC feedback for the
opamp.  These resistors provide a path for input bias currents and
establish the DC operating point of the opamp.  The opamp needs to be
biased so that its output rests at 0 V.  The DC offset at the output of the
opamp needs to be controlled because the transformer winding presents a
low resistance DC path to ground.

Before proceeding any farther, it should be mentioned that the driver looks
at the average voltage of the sense electrodes.  For the sake of simplicity,
the circuit illustrated in Figure 11 only presents the upper electrode array.
Rather than just looking at A2*, the positive sense is taken to be the
average voltage of the A2* and A2’* electrode.  The averaging is performed
by R221 and R223.  These resistors can be found on sheet 2 of the

Again on sheet 6, U31 is a power opamp capable of driving high currents.
The output current limit is set by R94.  With 15.4kΩ for R94, the current
limit is set at 750mA.  An enable pin (pin 8) is provided to allow the opamp
to be disabled --- this places the output in a high-impedance state.
Disabling occurs by pulling pin 8 to the negative supply rail.  It is the task of
the DSP to disable the opamp while the tool is in the CAL or ZERO mode.
The enable pin of all three power opamps used for the voltage sources are
controlled by the same signal (VDRV_EN).  An RC snubber (R285 and
C354) is attached to the output to suppress high-frequency oscillations that
may occur due to instability in the opamp’s output stage.

Note:
The schematic symbol indicates that the part has 48 pins.  In
reality, there are only 20 pins, which are shown on U31-1.  Pin 21 through
48 were added to the schematic symbol so that thermal vias could be
included in the footprint for heat sinking purposes.



Current Source
The deep driver is a 30 Hz current source used to drive the A5 electrode.

2.2.5 PREAMP INTERFACE

All signals between the Controller and Preamp boards are transmitted
differentially.  U15, U97, and U17 are LVDS2 receivers and drivers used to
interface to the Preamp board.  The receive port (RCLK_B, DR_B, RFS_B)
feed into FPGA U16 so that the A/D samples can be collected and written
to FIFO.  Commands are sent to the Preamp board through the transmit
port (TCLK0, TFS0, DT0) which are directly driven by the DSP’s serial port.
The system clock (MAIN_CLK) and A/D sampling clock (/MLL_AD_CLK)
are provided by FPGA U16.

2.2.7 MISCELLANEOUS

Several items on the Controller board have not been covered.  They are
discussed below.

Housing potential: U134 forms a unity-gain buffer used to drive the inner
housing at system common.  The input is taken from the Bucker board’s
common, and the output drives a contact assembly [A3001017000] located
on the chassis.

FPGA power: U1, Q1, and surrounding components form a 2.5 V regulator
to provide the core voltage for the two FPGA’s.


FPGA U9 Functions:

Memory: The FPGA also interfaces to the serial EEPROM (U8).  The
EEPROM is used to store hardware information and calibration tables.
Instead of using a hardware assisted SPI interface, the DSP directly
manipulates the EEPROM signals through a control register.

Glue logic: Glue logic for the flash memory (U5) chip-enable signal is
implemented in the FPGA.  The boot-memory select (/BMS) and
memory-select (/MS0) from the DSP are AND’ed together to generate
/FLS_CE.  On power-up, the DSP initially uses /BMS to load
instructions from flash memory.  After the initial boot process, /MS0 is
used to select the flash memory.  The flash write enable (/FLS_WE) is
generated by OR’ing the /MS0 and /WR signals.

DSP clock: The FPGA also contains a PLL that is used to generate a
32 MHz clock (DSP_CLK) for the DSP.

Temperature Sensor:  FPGA U9 also contains a serial interface for the
temperature sensor (U7).  The serial clock (TEMP_SCLK) runs at
12 MHz.  The FPGA reads the temperature sensor every 0.5 second
and generates an interrupt on /IRQ0.  In response, the DSP reads the
temperature from the FPGA; see timing diagram of Figure 14.

PREAMP BOARD
2.3.1 INTRODUCTION
The Preamp board (A3000644000) contains the signal conditioning and
A/D converters for measuring VM and I0 --- which are the two values
necessary to calculate resistivity.  The Preamp board is responsible for
sampling the VM and I0 signals and sending the A/D samples to the
Controller board (A3000643000).  Each signal is simultaneously measured
with three different gains to increase the dynamic range of the
measurements.  Two-way communication between the Preamp and
Controller is achieved with two synchronous serial ports; each consisting of
a clock, frame sync, and data line.  All signals between the Preamp and
Controller are transmitted and received differentially using LVDS drivers
and receivers.
2.3.2 I0 MEASUREMENT CIRCUITS
I0 current is measured by sensing the voltage across a 2Ω resistor located
on the Bucker board.  Starting at page 2 of the Preamp schematic
(A3000644 SCH), the I0 signal enters the board on pins 4 and 14 of
connector J3.  Resistors R82 and R84, along with diodes D5, form a clamp
to help protect the input from any damaging voltages that may be present
on the A0 electrode --- signal is denoted by A0_I+ and A0_I–.

On page 6 of the schematic, the signal then feeds into a dual, four-input
multiplexer (U21).  The multiplexer is used to select between LOG,
VERIFY, CAL, and ZERO inputs (signal is now CH0+ and CH0–).

Since the I0 measurement has a large amount of gain, it is important to
remove any DC offset in the signal.  The signal ultimately arrives on page
4, where the output of U21 feeds into an AC-coupling network formed by
capacitors C25 & C26, and resistors R108 & R109 to remove this DC
offset.

I0, at this point, is amplified with three different gains.  Three parallel signal
conditioning paths, are similar with the exception of having different gains,
are shown on page 4.  The following description will trace the signal chain
through the highest gain channel which begins with U46.  Keep in mind that
the same action is occurring in the two other chains.

U46 is an instrumentation amplifier which amplifies the differential voltage
at its input and produces an output voltage referenced to ground.  The gain
of the device is determined by the value of R110.  With R110 at 49.9Ω, the
gain of U46 is 991 V/V.  R111 and C110 form another ac-coupling stage

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Circuit Description
131067-945 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas

An additional gain of 4.01 V/V is provided by the non-inverting gain stage
formed by U57 B.  Afterwards, the signal is scaled and level-shifted by
U57 A.  This stage attenuates the signal by a factor of 2, and applies a 2.5 V
offset.  At the output of U57 A, the signal will appear as a smaller, inverted
waveform centered at 2.5 V.

U57 D and its associated components form a Sallen-Key low-pass filter.
The Sallen-Key circuit, along with the pole introduced by capacitor C149,
forms a 3rd order Butterworth low-pass filter with a 4kHz cutoff frequency.

The low-gain channel begins with U22 and has a gain of 10.9 V/V.  The
medium-gain channel begins with U32 and has a gain of 100 V/V.  The low
and medium gain channels are similar to the high gain channel except that
no additional gain is applied after the instrumentation amplifier.  U55 B and
U59 B are simply used as unity gain buffers in their respective circuits.

The low, medium, and high gain channels are successively sampled using
only one A/D converter.  U26 is a multiplexer used to switch the A/D input
between the outputs of the three channels.  A sampling clock, provided by
the Controller board, initiates three different A/D conversions – one for
each gain channel.  The three channels are sampled in quick succession,
only 6µs apart from each other.  Dual op amp U47 converts the single-
ended input signal into a differential signal (AD2 IN+ and AD2 IN–) that can
be sampled by the A/D converter.

U27 is an 18-bit successive approximation analog-to-digital converter.  A
conversion is initiated by the falling edge on the /CNVST input (pin 35).
This edge causes the A/D to sample the input and begin the conversion
process which takes approximately 1.25µs.  While converting, the A/D
holds its BUSY pin (29) high.  When finished converting, the A/D brings the
BUSY pin low to indicate new data is available to be read.

A serial interface is used to read the A/D.  When reading data, the chip-
select (/CS) pin (32) is pulled low to enable the serial interface.  Data is
shifted out on the SDOUT pin (21) on the rising edge of the serial clock
provided on the SCLK pin (22).

The 2.5 V reference voltage needed by the A/D is externally supplied by
U17.  The A/D internally amplifies the supplied reference to create a
4.096 V reference for conversions.  The internally generated 4.096 V
reference is routed to pin 37 and decoupled by C136.
2.3.3 VM MEASUREMENT CIRCUITS
Two electrodes surround the A0 electrode – M1 and M1’.  These two
electrodes are averaged and buffered by the Bucker board
(A3001215000).  The buffered signal (M1) is fed into the Preamp board on

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Circuit Description
131067-945 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
Also seen on page 2 is the surface remote signal (REMOTE).  It enters the
board on pin 16 of connector P3.  The surface remote signal is filtered by a
3rd order Butterworth low-pass filter formed by op amp U48 A and U48 B ---
refer to page 6.  The -3db frequency is 9kHz.  Filtering is performed to
remove any telemetry signals that may be present on wireline conductor 7.

The REMOTE signal then feeds into a dual, four-input multiplexer (U11).
The multiplexer is used to select between LOG, VERIFY, CAL, and ZERO
inputs (signal is now CH1+ and CH1–).  The signal ultimately arrives on
page 5, where the output of U11 feeds into an AC-coupling network formed
by capacitors C17 & C18, and resistors R86 & R87.  These components
remove any DC offset in the signal.

The VM measurement circuit on page 5 is identical to the previously
described I0 circuit on page 4 with the exception of some resistor values.
Although three gain channels are available at the present time, only the
low-gain channel, which begins with U9, is used.  The front-end
instrumentation amplifiers (U12 and U44) for the medium and high-gain
channels are set to a gain of 1 V/V, because higher gains caused the
amplifiers to saturate and adversely affect the low-gain channel
measurement.  Although the A/D actively samples the medium and high-
gain channels, calculations do not utilize these channels.

The two A/D’s, U27 (for I0) and U18 (for VM), are daisy-chained so that the
FPGA can read both A/D’s using one data line.  The serial data output of
U18 (pin 21) feeds into the serial data input of U27 (pin 16).  The FPGA
shifts in data from the serial data output of U27.  In this manner, the FPGA
can read both A/D’s in one 36-bit long bit-stream --- U27 data first, followed
by U18 data.
2.3.4 A/D DATA RETRIEVAL
The sampling clock (/MLL_AD_CLK), provided by the Controller board,
initiates the conversion process for the A/D’s.  The differential clock inputs
enter the Preamp board on pins 23 and 11 of connector P2.  At U34, a
differential driver, it is converted into standard logic levels and routed to the
FPGA (page 3).

Refer to the timing diagram of Figure 15.  At point A, after the rising edge
of /MLL_AD_CLK, the FPGA (U29) collects three samples from each A/D
converter.  The AD_CNVST signal is pulsed low (point B) to initiate each of
the three A/D conversions.  On the falling edge of AD_CNVST, the A/D’s
sample their inputs and bring their respective busy lines high (point C).
The FPGA monitors both busy lines and waits for them to go low before
reading the results from the A/D’s.  After the busy lines go low, the FPGA

In addition to reading the conversion results after the busy lines go low, the
FPGA also updates the mux select lines for U26 and U16 to select the next
gain channel in preparation for the next conversion.  The gain channels are

samples are being transferred to the Controller board.  Refer to the timing

before sending the samples.  The samples are sent to the Controller board

RCLK is a serial clock running at 24 MHz.  RFS is a frame sync which goes

The Preamp board sends twelve words instead of six.  The extra six words
are due to the fact that the FPGA was originally designed for a board which
had more channels.  Zeroes are transmitted in place of the channels that

The Preamp board can receive commands from the Controller board for
performing specific tasks.  This communication occurs through another
synchronous serial link consisting of TCLK, TFS, and DT.

TCLK operates at 12 MHz.  TFS is the frame sync and DT is the data line.
A command word is 16 bits long.  The Controller sends commands to…
1) enable the acquisition,
2) select the operating mode (LOG, VERIFY, CAL, or ZERO),
3) select the attenuation level for the cal signal, or
4) tell the Preamp to return a status word.
Differential signals from the Controller arrive at connector P2.  Clock
signals are found on pins 2 and 15; frame syncs are found on pins 3 and
16, and the data lines are pins 4 and 17.  These signals find their way to
U20, a LVDS chip (page 3).  U20 converts them into standard logic levels
useable by the FPGA, U29.
2.3.6 CALIBRATION CIRCUIT
A calibration signal (DRV_CAL±) is provided by the Controller board.  This
signal arrives at the Preamp board via connector P3 pins 19 and 10.  The
signal is a composite waveform created by summing four sinusoids with
frequencies of 30 Hz, 105 Hz, 165 Hz, and 195 Hz.  The calibration signal,
observed at the output of U9 while in the CAL mode, is shown below in
resistance is calculated by dividing the VM and I0 measurements.  Hence,

any common gain error between the two channels will be divided out.  The

be applied to the calibration signal, depending on the gain of the channel

When calibrating the I0 channels which have more gain, the cal signal has
to be attenuated to a level within the input range of the channel.  The low-
gain I0 channel is calibrated with the 1/21 attenuation.  The medium and
high-gain I0 channels are calibrated with 1/201 and 1/2001 attenuation,
respectively.  Attenuation levels are selected by U41, a dual 4-to-1 mux.
The Controller board selects the attenuation level by programming the
appropriate bits of a control register in the FPGA.  The enable input of the
calibration mux allows the mux output to be tri-stated when the tool is not in
the CAL mode.  This feature helps reduce any potential cross-talk.

Multiplexers (U21 and U11) at the front end of the measurement channels
provide support for the various tool operating modes: LOG, VERIFY, CAL,
and ZERO.  The Controller sets the operating mode by programming the
mode control bits in the FPGA’s control register.  The mode control bits
drive the mux select lines A_CAL_GAIN_SEL0 and A_CAL_GAIN_SEL1.
In the CAL mode, both VM and I0 measure the cal signal.
In the ZERO mode, the inputs of each channel are shorted together.
Resistors R145 and R146 allow the inputs to be tied to common, but they

The LOG and VERIFY inputs for the I0 channel are the same.  In both

2.3.7 FPGA AND SUPPORT CIRCUITRY
On page 3 of the schematic is an Actel field programmable gate array
(FPGA), U29.
Among its functions are…
•
It contains the logic for collecting the A/D samples and sending them
to the Controller board.
•
It also contains a control register through which the Controller board
can set the operating mode (LOG, VERIFY, CAL, ZERO) and
attenuation setting of the calibration signal.
•
The system clock is obtained from MAIN_CLK because there is no
local oscillator on the board.
•
The FPGA is programmed to blink LED D9 once a second.  This may
be helpful in determining if the FPGA is functioning.

FPGA support features…
•
Connector P1: is a programming header used for programming the
FPGA.  It is intended for engineering use only.
•
Power Supply: the 2.5 V supply needed for the FPGA’s core is
provided by a low-dropout regulator formed by U35 and Q2 found on
page 2 of the schematic.  The 2.5 V reference is derived from the 3.3 V
supply using a voltage divider – R53 and R54.  Through feedback,
opamp U35 adjusts the base voltage of Q2 so that the voltage at its
non-inverting input equals the reference voltage presented at the
inverting input.  To prevent this supply from exceeding 3.3 V,
protection diode D18 is installed.
•
Isolation: the analog and digital sections of the board are isolated
from each other.  All signals between the FPGA and analog section
are isolated by U51, U52, U53, and U54.  These IC’s are digital
isolators that magnetically couple digital signals from one side to the
other.

LVDS: all signals between the Preamp and Controller are transmitted and
received differentially using LVDS drivers and receivers (U20, U34, and
U30).  Low-voltage differential signaling is a standard allowing for high data
rates with low power and low EMI.  The receivers detect differential signals
and convert them to standard logic.  Each receiver has a 100Ω termination
resistor across the input.  The differential voltage is typically only ±310mV.

BUCKER BOARD

Refer to the schematic diagram (A3001215 SCH) of the Bucker board
(A3001215000) for the following description.

Survey current must enter/leave the A0 electrode horizontally into the formation
rather than vertically through the mud to obtain a formation resistivity
measurement.  This objective is achieved by minimizing the potential difference
between the M2 and M1 electrodes.  The Bucker board contains a high-gain
amplifier used to adjust this potential difference.  With negative feedback, and
assuming infinite gain, the Bucker amplifier forces the potential difference between
M2 and M1 to zero.

There are actually two sets of electrodes; M2 (P1-18) and M1 (P1-5) in the upper
array, and their complements M2' (P1-20) and M1' (P1-7) in the bottom array.  As
a result, the Bucker board amplifies the difference between the average voltages
of these two sets of electrodes.  RN1 and RN2 are precision matched resistors
used to determine the average voltage of M1 and M1' (IN+) and the average
voltage of M2 and M2' (IN–), respectively.  The average of M1 and M1' is buffered
by U5 A and routed off board (P1-9) so that it can be measured by the Preamp
board.  U5 B buffers the average of M2 and M2' but its output is not used.  Its sole
purpose is to balance any loading U5 A may have on the M1/M1' input.

The overall frequency response of the Bucker is shaped to provide a high gain
within the frequency range of interest: 30 Hz to 195 Hz.  The gain is reduced at
frequencies outside of this region.  The overall gain is distributed among three
stages:
1) front-end instrumentation amplifier U1,
2) inverting amplifier formed by U2 B, and
3) a non-inverting amplifier formed by U2 A.

The first stage of amplification is U1.  It is an instrumentation amplifier which
provides a gain of 10 V/V.  The gain of this amplifier is determined by the value of
R5.
The output of U1 is AC-coupled to an inverting amplifier formed by U2 B.  The ratio
of R10 and R9 sets the passband gain of this stage to approximately 52.5 V/V.
The gain of this stage rolls off at frequencies above 214 Hz (F-3dB), as determined
by the values of C8 and R10.
U2 A forms a non-inverting gain stage.  Because of C5, the DC gain is limited to
1 V/V.  The value of R4 and R6 determine the passband gain, which is
approximately 16 V/V.  The gain of this stage also rolls off at frequencies above
214 Hz (F-3dB), as determined by the values of C7 and R4.

Finally, U3 is a power opamp with a high current output.  The output current limit is
programmable and set by resistor R14.  With R14 chosen to be 46.4kΩ, the
current limit is set at 250mA.  R8 is a precision current-sense resistor used to

29

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Circuit Description
131067-945 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
measure the output current of the Bucker circuit.  The resistor has 4 terminals for a
“four-wire” measurement.  The sense terminals are routed off-board so that the
survey current (I0) can be measured by the Preamp board.  R8 is enclosed within
the feedback loop of U3 so that the output voltage is not affected by the IR drop
through the sense resistor.

Note:  The schematic symbol indicates that the part has 48 pins.  In reality, there
are only 20 pins, which are shown on U31-1.  Pin 21 through 48 (labeled
U3-2) were added to the schematic symbol so that thermal vias could be
included in the footprint for heat dissipation.

Power amplifier U3 cannot be powered directly from the +5 V supply that powers
the other active circuit components of this board.  Due to its limited supply voltage
rating, U3 has ±2.75 V provided to it by separate voltage regulators.  The +2.75 V
regulator is formed by U7 A, Q1, and surrounding components.  The +2.75 V
reference is derived from the +5 V supply using a voltage divider – R27 and R28.
Through feedback, opamp U7 A adjusts the base voltage of Q1 so that the voltage
at its non-inverting input equals the reference voltage presented at the inverting
input.

A similar circuit is provided for the –2.75 V regulator.  It is formed by U7 B, Q2, and
surrounding components.  Its operation is similar to the +2.75 V regulator.

Relays K1 and K2 are provided to support the VERIFY mode.  In the VERIFY
mode, the Bucker’s inputs and output are redirected to connect to an internal
resistor network on the Controller board (A3000643000) instead of the electrodes.

MISCELLANEOUS
2.5.1 OTHER PC BOARDS
Several other PC boards of relative insignificance reside in the 1241 XB.
Two of these boards are nothing more than tie points where wires attach
and make assembly/disassembly/repair easier.  The first one of these
(A3000877000) is at the uphole end of the instrument.  It is shown on the
The second one is located between the chassis-mounted transformers and
the Controller board; it is the Signal Distribution board, SDB,
(A3000755000).  Wires from this board connect the electrodes (contact
blocks) and from the Main Controller board.
Just to the downhole side of the Controller board is a small PC board
(A3000773000) containing the four signal transformers used for WTS bus
communications.  Although requiring more wire terminations, this board
relieves the Controller board from mounting these relatively bulky and
heavy items from the board containing sensitive electronics (vibration
issues).
A final set of two boards (A3001788000) are mounted on the fiberglass rod
assembly.  The main purpose of these boards is to control the path of
wiring to the monitor electrode (M1, M2, M1’, M2’) sockets.  Due to the
sensitive nature of the monitor electrodes to interference, a well-defined
route is required.  The PC boards were put in place to provide a clean
junction for the shielded twisted pairs and the socket leads.
2.5.2 CHASSIS TRANSFORMERS
Three step-down transformers are mounted on the chassis between the
upper power supplies and the Signal Distribution board.  They provide a
current boost for the voltage drivers, VF1, VF2 and VF3.  The wires from
the transformers connect to their related chassis components using chassis
terminals.  By boosting the output current by a 6 to 1 ratio, less current is
needed by the driver opamp and the power supplies.
2.5.3 CONTACTS
Electrical contact is made from the outside world (each electrode) to the
internal circuits by means of 22 special feedthrough pins.  The larger
diameter portion of this pin is threaded, and screws into the electrode to
make contact with it.  The narrower section is rounded on the end to fit into
a receptacle.  In between these two sections is an isolating section.  A
31

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Circuit Description
131067-945 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
ceramic coating is sprayed on this section to insulate the pin from
accidentally shorting out to the housing as it passes through to the interior
contact block.
The receptacles or contact blocks, as mentioned earlier, are free-floating in
cavities of the fiberglass rod assembly.  Being magnetically coupled to
magnets mounted in the rod such that they attract, the contact blocks are
free to slide up/down inside their slot.  This movement not only allows the
block to automatically align with the pin (upon insertion), but also relieves
any stresses that occur during thermal expansion.
2.5.4 TOP/BOTTOM CONNECTORS
The top connector, J1, of the 1241 XB is a standard 27-socket Focus
connector.  Should it be required, replacement of this connector is made
easily, because all wires coming from it terminate at the uphole terminal
board, TB1.
The bottom connector, J9, is a standard 32-socket WTS connector.
However, it is augmented with a bottom sub and a 32-pin WTS bulkhead

Because of the open design of the power supplies, repair is possible but a
thorough understanding of their circuitry is needed before attempting any repairs.

2.6.1 DUAL 5 V POWER SUPPLY
There is only one dual polarity power supply (PS6); its output is ±5 volts.
The ±5 V Power Supply (A3000558000) supplies a regulated output voltage
of ±5.0 Vdc at 0.5 Amp load current, per output, from an input voltage of 18
Vdc to 36 Vdc; 28 Vdc is typical.

Output voltage sensing or error detection compares the output voltage to a
stable reference voltage and a resulting error voltage is created on the
secondary side.  Magnetic coupling conveys the error voltage to the
primary side where the error voltage modulates the PWM and adjusts ton.
Magnetically-coupled feedback permits operation with the power supplies’
output return floating or isolated from the input return.

Detailed Circuit Description
Chip U1, a Vishay Si9110, provides the required PWM functions.  Resistor
R2 sets the internal clock frequency of the PWM to approximately 600 kHz,
which is twice the chopping or switching frequency (Figure 19).  The bias
current of U1 is set by resistor R3.  Diode D15 and associated components
shift U1’s soft-reference voltage to improve operation at elevated
temperature.
Transistor Q1 buffers the output of the PWM and provides the additional
current drive needed to rapidly switch mosfet Q2 on and off (Figure 20).
Mosfet Q2 controls the application of supply voltage to the primary of the
flyback transformer T2.  When Q2 is on, the primary current ramps up at a
rate determined by T2 and Vin.  Transformer T1, a 1:100 current
transformer, couples the primary current to diode D9 and resistor R9.
Resistor R9 converts the primary current ramp to a voltage ramp.  Resistor
R8 and capacitor C18 filter the voltage ramp and apply it to U1 (Figure 21)
at the “sense” pin.  The error voltage at U1-14 is internally compared to the

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Circuit Description
131067-945 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas

Transformer T2 has four secondary windings; two windings provide power
supply operating voltages, while the third and fourth windings provide the
main ±5.0-volt outputs.  The secondary winding associated with rectifier
D13 provides approximately 5.0 Vdc for powering the circuitry on the
primary side of T2.  Rectifier D6 and associated components provide
approximately 5.0 Vdc for powering the circuitry on the secondary side of
T2.  Components D4, D5, C23, C24, C30, and C31 constitute the main
rectifier and filter circuit for the ±5.0 Vdc outputs.  The ±5.0 Vdc outputs are
further filtered by L3, C25, C32, C36, C26, C27, C53, C55, C33, C34, C56,
and C57 before application to output terminals E4, E5, and E6 (Figure 23).

Chip U5 and associated components constitute the output voltage sensing
or error detection circuitry.  Chip U5 compares the ±5.0 Vdc output
voltages divided down by R31 and R32 to the 2.5 Vdc reference voltage
provided by U2.  The output of U5 is buffered by Q5 whose emitter drives
T3.  Components R40, C49, and C50 provide negative feedback to the
inverting input of U5 to shape the loop gain, which ensures stable operation
and adequate transient response.  The voltage at the emitter of Q5 is the
error voltage.  To couple the DC error voltage through T3, it is necessary to
use amplitude modulation such that the error signal can be magnetically
coupled to the secondary side of T3.  Chip U4 provides a ~700-kHz carrier,
which is amplitude modulated by the error voltage applied through the
center tap of T3.  Diode D12 with C14 and R15 serve to demodulate or
recover the magnetically coupled modulated error voltage signal.
Components C52 and R42 provide additional error voltage signal filtering
(Figure 26).  Chip U3 with R12, R35, R13, R14, R4, and C15 further
amplify and filter the error voltage.  Due to the interleaving of the main
secondary winding, the -5.0 Vdc output closely tracks the +5.0 Vdc output,
provided that the negative load current is not less than 20% of the positive
load current.

Transistor Q3, chip U3, and associated components provide a soft start
function, which ensures that the ±5.0-Vdc output ramps up in predictable
manner.  Transistor Q3 is on when INH (E3) is held low, which keeps C8
discharged.  Chip U3-7 is also low to maintain C11 discharged through D7.
When Q3 is released, both capacitors are allowed to charge, controlling the
rate at which the ±5.0-Vdc output ramps up (Figure 25).

Transistor Q4, diodes D2, D1, and D8, and associated passive
components provide +10 Vdc start-up power for the primary side
components.  Once the power supply starts and the secondary outputs
come up, the winding associated with D13 provides the primary operating
power, i.e.; the power supply becomes self sustaining, producing its own
operating power.  The 5.0-Vdc output from D13 and D2 (5, 2) provide a
reverse bias to D2 (3, 4), which turns Q4 off for improved efficiency.

Capacitors C1, C2, C5 through C7 and C9 minimize the differential and
common-mode noise on the 28-Vdc line.  Also, C1 and C2 provide a low
inductance voltage source for the primary power circuit consisting of Q2
36

1241 XB Hybrid RTeX  –  Circuit Description
131067-945 / 1241 XB
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas
and T2.  Capacitor C10 and resistor R16 serve to dampen the ringing on
the drain of Q2 at turn off.


Tracing Through A Cycle Of Operation
Assume that the output of PWM U1-4 has gone high, turning on Q2 and
marking the start of the conduction interval.  Vin (+28 Vdc) appears across
the primary of T2 and the primary current of T2 begins to ramp up linearly.
Diodes D13, D4, D5, and D6 are reversed biased during this interval since
the secondaries’ polarity is inverted with respect to the primary.  Output
current from each secondary is supplied by capacitors C44, C23, C24,
C30, C31, and C39 during this interval.  As previously discussed, the
primary current is fed back to the PWM sense input (U1-3), after being
converted to a voltage.  The ramp voltage internal to the PWM is compared
to the error voltage and when the ramp voltage is greater than the error
voltage, the output of the PWM goes low, causing Q2 to turn off.  This
designates the end of the conduction interval and the start of the flyback
interval.
Since the current flowing in an inductor can not be instantaneously
stopped, current must continue to flow in T2 even though Q2 is off.  When
Q2 turns off, the primary voltage reverses and increases until the
secondary rectifier diodes are forward biased and conducting (Figure 22).
Current that was flowing in the primary is now transferred to the secondary.
The current that flows in each secondary winding is a function of its turns
ratio.  Secondary current primarily flows through capacitors C44, C23, C24,
C30, C31, and C39, restoring their charge.  Secondary current will continue
to flow until all magnetic energy stored in the air gap of T2 is transferred to
the output capacitors (electric field energy).
The dead-time interval now commences.  During this interval all power
switching components (Q2, D13, D4, D5, and D6) are off, hence the name
discontinuous mode (no switching current flows during the dead-time
interval).  The only current flowing is the load current, which is provided by
the output capacitors.  On the next clock edge the cycle repeats.

2.6.2 + 3.3 V POWER SUPPLY
The 1241 XB RTeX +3.3 V Power Supply Assembly (A3000976000)
supplies a regulated output voltage of 3.3 Vdc at 1.7 Adc load current from
an input voltage of 18 Vdc to 36 Vdc; 28 Vdc is typical.

OVERVIEW
Refer to the block diagram in Figure 27 and schematic drawing
A3000976 SCH during the following discussions of the 3.3 V power
supplies.

The +3.3 V power supply is a switching power supply that operates at 300
kHz and employs a single-transistor discontinuous-mode flyback topology.
Operation is controlled by a Pulse Width Modulator (PWM) IC that controls
chopping (switching) of the 28 Vdc input voltage at a fixed frequency (300
kHz).  Each switching cycle is subdivided into three operating intervals:
conduction, flyback, and dead time.
Current flows in the primary of the flyback transformer and magnetic
energy is stored in the transformer’s air gap during the conduction interval.
The power supplies’ output capacitors maintain the output voltage.

When the conduction interval terminates, stored magnetic energy is
released to the secondary of the transformer and the power supplies’
output capacitors are charged.  The supply is designed such that the
conduction interval (ton) varies according to the demand placed on the
power supply to maintain a constant output voltage.
The dead time interval commences when all stored magnetic energy is
depleted.  Again the output capacitors maintain the output voltage.  The
dead-time interval ends on the rising edge of the next PWM clock, which
also marks the start of the next conduction interval.

2.6.3 INPUT FILTER BOARDS

There are two Input Filter boards for the six power supplies.  The Input
Filter and Delay Controller PCB Assembly (A3000467000) provides
common mode and differential mode filtering of the +28 Vdc input voltage
for up to three power supply modules.  It also provides low-voltage inhibit
and programmable start-up delays for the attached supplies.  Refer to
harmonics of the power supply modules attached to connector J1and
prevents noise contamination of the 28 V bus.
The heart of the delay controller is a programmable microcontroller (U1).
Resistor R7 and capacitor C12 set the operating frequency at
approximately 1 MHz.  Diode D1 and R6 function as a simple Zener power
supply that provides 5 V for the microcontroller.
When enabled, U1 functions as a timer to control the turn-on time and
sequencing of the power-supply modules attached to connector J1.  There
are basically three functions concerning this circuit: (1) a voltage threshold,
(2) the delay and sequencing circuit and (3), the control/inhibit circuit.

(1)
A threshold voltage is established using a voltage divider consisting
of R4 and R5.  When the divider output exceeds 1.25 V as detected
by power fail input (PFI) U2-4, the RESET pin (U2-7) goes high.
This happens when voltage on the 28 V bus exceeds 20 volts or
more.  With U2’s reset pin high, U1’s MCLR (U1-4) is pulled high,
and U1 begins executing its internally stored program.
(2)
The delay provided by U1 is the time from when U1’s MCLR goes
high to the time INH1 (J1-4) goes high.  Different combinations of
jumpers JP1 – JP4 change U1’s delay time.  Delay times are
established for different tools to limit the current demand when the
tool string is first powered up.  Delay times, in milliseconds, and

In addition, jumper JP6 determines if INH2 (J1-7) and INH3 (J1-

(3)
When +5 volts is applied to the microcontroller, outputs RA1 –
RA3 of U1 are floating (open collector circuit).  Resistors R8, R12,
and R14 pull the bases of Q1 – Q3 HIGH respectively, turning on
Q1 – Q3, which result in INH1 – INH3 being pulled low.  This low
state inhibits operation of the power supply modules connected to
INH1 – INH3.  When U1’s time-out function is complete, outputs
RA1 – RA3 will transition LOW either simultaneously or staggered
as determined by jumper JP6, turning off Q1 – Q3, which activates
the power supply modules.

Because very little power is dissipated on this board, there is no need to
mount it on a heat sink.  Therefore, it is mounted to the electronics chassis
using standoffs.

This Rt Explorer instrument is a Focus tool adapted to run in a WTS tool string and
requires a crossover adapter on the top (1241 PA) to convert the AC power to a DC
source.  This WTS version is series 1241 XB.  The outward appearance is a series of
guard electrodes located on a specially designed housing.  The electronics assembly is
located within the housing with the exception of the above mentioned crossover adapter.
See sketch of Figure 1.  For 1241 PA circuit description, see 131068-945.


allow the electronics to be incorporated within the mandrel to reduce the overall length of
the instrument.  Mechanical WTS compatibility is achieved via the 1241 PA top sub and
the 1241 XB bottom sub.
Electronics Chassis Assembly
Electronic circuits and discrete parts mount on an I-beam chassis and include the
following components.
• Six DC power supplies,
• Controller board containing communication interface, guard drivers, data acquisition
and control circuits, calibration and verification circuits, etc.
• Preamp board containing circuits for measuring VM1 and I0 (read as I zero), as well
as a means for sending them to the Controller board,
• Bucker board provides the survey current,
• Various chassis mounted components.

Physical Attributes
For an overview of how the major instrument components electrically and sometimes
mechanically, tie together, see the block diagram of Figure 2.

Electrode Rings: Twenty one electrode rings encircle the housing and connect to the
inner electronics using feedthroughs.  Electrode pairs are spaced along the
mandrel at specific distances to achieve varying depths of investigation.  The
electrode rings have a mild steel surface to promote rusting and it is this rust that

makes a better electrical “contact” to the borehole fluids.  A fiberglass layer
isolates the electrode rings from the inner titanium housing.
A4 and A4': Metal end pieces of the housing also serve as electrodes, A4 and A4'.  Two
isolation joints within the housing separate these two end pieces from the inner
housing.  Instruments connected above and below the RTeX extend the electrical
length of the A4 electrodes.  Springs mounted on the top and bottom snorkel
sections of the chassis make contact to the end pieces through the electronics.
Fiberglass: A fiberglass assembly holds all the contact sockets that mate with the
feedthroughs.  Each contact is loosely held in place by a set of magnets so that it
has freedom to align with the feedthrough.
Copper Pipes: Copper pipes are attached to the bottom side of the fiberglass assembly.
Their purpose is to provide a low-resistance connection between the top and
bottom guard electrode pairs: A1-A1’, A2-A2’, A3-A3' and A4-A4'.  Each pipe has
a different outer diameter so that they fit inside one another.  Kapton tape is
wrapped around each pipe for insulation.  Connection to A5 and A5' is made with
a wire that runs through the center of these pipes.
Chassis Potential: A spring-loaded contact assembly on the chassis provides
connection to the inner housing.  Rather than leaving the inner housing floating, a
unity-gain buffer, found on the Main Controller board, is used to maintain the

INSTRUMENT CIRCUITS2
2.0 INSTRUMENT CIRCUITS

Refer to wiring diagram A3001976 WRD.

Since WTS tools are powered using a nominal 180 Vac at the cablehead, this power
adapter is no exception.  As is typical, this AC voltage is delivered to the top connector
(J1) on pins 1 and 4.

The object of the 1241 PA power adapter is to take the supplied voltage and convert it to
a nominal +28 Vdc.  To start this process, the voltage must be reduced to a lower level ---
that’s the function of chassis-mounted, step-down transformer TF1.  Its secondary is tied
to the only PC board (A3001978000) found in the adapter.  This board contains the
remaining circuitry.

POWER SUPPLY PC BOARD 2
3.0 POWER SUPPLY PC BOARD

Refer to assembly drawing A3001978000, its BOM and schematic A3001978 SCH for
the following descriptions.

The only PC board of this simple instrument rectifies the AC and controls the passing of
DC power to the attached load; in this case, only the 1241 XB RTeX.

The board receives AC on terminals E1 and E2.  Alternating current is rectified by a full-
wave bridge composed of diodes D1 – D4.  This rectified output is heavily filtered using
capacitors C1 – C8.  Resistors R1 – R3 are also connected across the rectified output to
assist in bleeding off the charge on the capacitors after AC power is removed.

Unregulated DC voltage is provided as the output on two terminals E3 (+) and E4 (–).
This output voltage is available to the load (1241 XB RTeX) exiting out the bottom
connector (J2) on pins 11 (+) and 12 (–) --- see the tool wiring diagram A3001976 WRD.

This unregulated DC output swings between 23 – 36 Vdc over an input operating range
of 150 to 220 Vac.  Cut-off circuits reduce this output to zero volts when input voltages
are outside this range.  This protects the regulated power supplies found in the RTeX
from low/high input voltage should something unexpected occur.

The over/under protection is provided by the supervisory circuits of U1 and U2 found on

AUXILIARY POWER
Before discussing the protection circuits, let’s look at how the
chips associated with them get their power.
After the full-wave rectifier creates a raw DC voltage source, it
is heavily filtered with a bank of capacitors.  From this raw DC,
a simple zener diode circuit (R4, D6 & C9) provides power for
the four IC’s U1, U2, U3 and U5.  See Figure 1.  This circuit
provides a crudely regulated 5 Vdc over the entire input
operating voltage range.


monitoring circuitry.  This circuitry holds their /RESET output pin low until their
supply voltage exceeds 4.40 Vdc.  For our circuit, this feature prevents power from
accidentally being applied to the load.  More details about under-voltage operation
are found in the next topic.

UNDER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION
The circuit components chosen to surround supervisory chip U2 (Analog Devices
ADM706) establish under-voltage protection --- see Figure 2 below.
Voltage divider network (R6 and R9) keeps the input voltage for the Power-Fail
Input (PFI) at a sufficiently low level as to not trip the internal comparator until the
filtered DC voltage exceeds approximately 23 volts.  (Note: expressed voltages
are for discussion only and are subject to tolerances of manufactured components,
wireline length, AC loading and +28 V loading.)
As long as this input remains below this threshold (anything less than 150 Vac for
CHV), the output voltage to the RTeX is effectively zero.  When the PFI input
remains below 1.25 V at the voltage divider connection, it keeps the comparator in
an untripped state --- the Power-Fail Output (PFO) stays low under this condition.
With PFO tied to the chip Manual Reset pin (MR), it keeps the chip out of reset
mode and the /RESET pin is low --- test point TP2 is provided for checking this
logic level.  This low level output provides a low to one of the inputs of the NAND
gate, U5 B.  See logic levels in Figure 2 below and Table 1.  Notice that anytime
one of the inputs to the NAND gate is low, the output is high.

You can see from Table 1 the unique logic condition of U5 that exists for controlling
the pass transistor Q1.  Q1 is inhibited for all conditions except when both inputs of
the NAND gate are high (U5 pin 3 output is low).  This occurs only after being
inverted again by U3 --- this high on the inverter output enables the transistor and
allows current to flow.
For under-voltage protection, the high level output of the U5 NAND gate connects
to the inputs of driver/inverter U3.  With a low on the output of U3, the gate of FET
Q1 is kept biased in an OFF state and the return path of the unregulated DC
voltage is interrupted; that is, no current can flow through the attached RTeX load.
Thus, with Q1 biased OFF, under-voltage protection is provided.  The only time
that current can flow is shown in the bottom row of the table, when both inputs are
high and Q1 is turned ON --- this unique condition only occurs for the normal
operating range which we will discuss later.
A similar cutoff response occurs for the situation when too much voltage is applied.

OVER-VOLTAGE PROTECTION
The circuit components chosen to surround the other supervisory chip U1 (Analog
Devices ADM706) establish over-voltage protection.
Voltage divider network (R7 and R8) keeps the input voltage for the Power-Fail
Input (PFI) at a sufficiently low level as to not trip the internal comparator until the
filtered DC voltage exceeds approximately 36 volts.  (Note: expressed voltages
are for discussion only and are subject to tolerances of manufactured components,
wireline length, AC loading and +28 V loading.)
As soon as this voltage divider network exceeds 1.25 V at the input, it trips the
comparator --- the Power-Fail Output (PFO) goes and stays high under this
condition.
With PFO tied to the chip Manual Reset pin (MR), it keeps the chip in reset mode
and the /RESET pin is high --- test point TP1 is provided for checking this logic
level.  U5 A is used as an inverter and provides a low to one of the inputs of the
NAND gate, U5 B.  Remember, anytime one of the inputs of the NAND gate is low,
the output is high --- again, see Table 1.
The output of the U5 B connects to the inputs of driver/inverter U3.  With a low on
the output of U3, it keeps the gate of FET Q1 biased in an OFF state and the
return path of the unregulated DC voltage is interrupted, that is, no current can
flow through the RTeX.  Thus, with Q1 biased OFF, over-voltage protection is
provided.



1241 PA RTeX Power Adapter – Circuit Description
131068-945 / 1241 PA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas

NORMAL OPERATING VOLTAGE RANGE
The secret to allowing the operating voltage (+28 Vdc - nominal) to be passed to
the 1241 XB RTeX is in knowing how the two protection circuits behave through the
normal operating range --- we have already observed how they work for their
respective protection in cutting off current flow.
Part of this secret is the fact that, for normal operation, both protection circuits
place a high on the inputs of NAND gate U5 B during this time --- see Figure 4,
and remember Table 1.  This condition ultimately provides a high on the output
pins of U3 (driver/inverter) and thus the gate of Q1.  With a high placed on the gate
of Q1, the return path for the unregulated DC voltage is completed so that current
can flow through the load.

To further explain this operation, let’s consider the circuit is at its optimum
operating voltage of +28 Vdc.








1241 PA RTeX Power Adapter – Circuit Description
131068-945 / 1241 PA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas

Let’s look at the over-voltage circuit first.  Considering the voltage divider attached
to the PFI pin of U1, the voltage at the junction of R7 and R8 is 0.95 Vdc when 28
volts is present.  This is below the comparator threshold of 1.25 V, so /PFO is low.
This makes /RESET low also.  The inverter of U5 A places a high on one of the two
inputs of U5 B (pin 6).
The opposite condition exists for U2.  The voltage divider of R6 and R9 is at
1.38 Vdc.  This is above the comparator threshold and makes /PFO high.  This
makes the /RESET pin high also.  Since the second input pin of U5 B (pin 5) ties to
this reset pin, there are now two highs on the inputs of the NAND gate.  This
condition results in a low at the output pin (3) of U5 B --- see logic levels of
The many inputs of U3, all paralleled, tie to output pin 3 of U5 B.  Since the output
pins of driver/inverter chip, U3, ties to the gate of transistor Q1, the high output
turns ON Q1.  Test point TP3 is provided to easily check the state of this condition
--- see Figure 5.  With Q1 turned ON, current is allowed to pass freely through
source and drain.
Thus, it can be seen that when the voltage is within the operating thresholds of the
two protection circuits, Q1 passes the necessary power to the 1241 XB RTeX.  And
when the applied voltage is outside this range, Q1 acts like an open circuit to

1241 PA RTeX Power Adapter – Circuit Description
131068-945 / 1241 PA
AUG 2009
Baker Atlas

HYSTERISIS
One last point in the description of these protection circuits is the hysteresis that is
designed into them.
A problem exists when the circuit applies power to the load, the surge in current
can cause a sufficient dip in the raw DC voltage (remember it is unregulated) that
the circuit will trip back OFF.  Right at the circuit threshold, an ON-OFF oscillating
condition can occur as it applies power and then the dip removes it.  To prevent
this from happening, a resistor is added into each circuit to provide hysteresis.
Let’s consider the under-voltage circuit.  Resistor R11 is added from the /RESET
pin (/CLR) back around to the voltage comparator input (pin 4).  When /CLR is low,
R11 is effectively in parallel with R6, establishing the “trip point” for the
comparator.  With sufficient voltage applied, as soon as the comparator trips and
/CLR is high, the connection to R11 raises the threshold and prevents accidental
tripping back OFF.
This same solution applies to the over-voltage circuit with the use of R12 as the
feedback resistor.
The effect of altering the trip point means that once tripped ON/OFF, the DC
voltage must be reduced beyond the trip point before being active again.  To
illustrate this, see Table 2 below.

see wiring diagram A3001976 WRD.  This +28 Vdc output, along with its return path, is
provided out bottom connector J2 on pins 11 and 12, respectively.

This AC to DC power adapter is provided as a DC supply and sits atop the 1241 XB Rt
Explorer (or RTeX).  When connected in this configuration, it allows a specially modified
“Focus” Rt Explorer instrument to be operated in a WTS tool string.

The top connector is a standard WTS configuration so that it can tie into a WTS tool
string.  The bottom connector is a standard Focus connector to interface with the RTeX
instrument.  The specially modified “Focus” RTeX instrument is the 1241 XB.  It has been
modified from the “XA” version with a bottom WTS configuration so that it can connect to
additional WTS tools beneath it.

BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
1311 XA GAMMA RAY
P/N 107846-935
MARCH 2000
The 1311 Gamma Ray (G/R) instrument is a single-conductor tool used to distinguish between
various rock formations.  A scintillation detector, composed of a crystal and a photomultiplier
(PM) tube, detects and measures the level of natural gamma radiation in the formation.  The
intensity of radiation gives an indication as to the type of rock along the well bore.
The G/R electronics assembly, which processes this information, divides into two sections.  The
lower electronics is encased in a protective vacuum flask and includes the:
• scintillation detector
• discriminator module 118175
• heat sink assembly
Urethane in the flask acts as a coolant to protect these heat-sensitive devices for several hours in
wells whose temperatures can rise as high as 400°F (204°C).  (However, when the instrument has
operated for several hours at 200°F or higher, and the tool is to be used further with little time
between jobs, the heat sink assembly should be removed and allowed to cool outside the flask.)
The upper electronics package is attached to the vacuum flask and contains the following:
• power supply for high and low voltages
• flip-flop module 89174
• line driver module 100145
• polarity switch
The G/R tool may be combined with the 2302 CCL and the 2421 instruments to form the 2404
CCL-G/R-Neutron instrument.  Figure 1 shows the G/R tool in combination with the CCL
instrument.  See Equipment Specifications Sheet (107846-925) for the length dimensions with

BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
1311 XA GAMMA RAY
P/N 107846-935
MARCH 2000
Figure 1:     G/R Instrument Configuration

INTRODUCTION1
1.0 INTRODUCTION
The following is a brief explanation of the major circuits in the G/R tool.  The drawings and
schematics referenced in the descriptions may be found in the Field Reference Drawings and
BOMs section of this manual (107846-975).  Figure 1 (at the end of this section) shows the
signal flow between circuits.  For a more detailed overview, see system schematic 079402-
000.
2.0 POWER SUPPLY 78339:  Refer to Schematic D79402
The power supply, located in the upper electronics package, provides both the low and high
voltages required by the instrument.  The low-voltage supply (24 Vdc) powers the
discriminator, flip-flop, and the line driver modules.  The high-voltage supply provides the
detector with the required 1550 Vdc operating voltage.
150 Vdc feeds the power supply circuit from the cablehead.  Protective diode D201 allows
only positive DC voltage to pass from the cablehead to the power supply.  An oscillating
circuit, composed of the two primaries of transformer T201, transistor Q301, and other
associated components, converts the 150 Vdc source into an AC voltage, which is then
applied across the upper and lower secondaries of T201 for the low and high voltage circuits,
respectively.  Inductor L401 and capacitors C201 and C202 prevent the oscillating voltage
from backing up the 150 volt line.

POWER SUPPLY 78339 1 
LOW-VOLTAGE CIRCUIT1
3.0 LOW-VOLTAGE CIRCUIT
The upper secondary of T201, which connects across a full-bridge rectifier (D105), steps
down the oscillating voltage.  The voltage is rectified back to DC by D105, filtered by resistor
R103 and capacitors C104 and C105, regulated by zener diode D301 to 24 Vdc, and then sent
to the various modules.

HIGH-VOLTAGE CIRCUIT1
4.0 HIGH-VOLTAGE CIRCUIT
The lower secondary of T201 steps up the oscillating voltage, which is then half-wave
rectified by diodes D101 and D102, filtered by R104, C203, and C204, regulated to 1650 Vdc
by shunted regulator V101, and finally sent to the detector circuit in the vacuum flask.
There, a second voltage regulator, V501, steadies the detector voltage to 1550 Vdc.

DETECTOR CIRCUIT 2 
DISCRIMINATOR MODULE 118175 2

FLIP-FLOP MODULE 891743 
LINE DRIVER MODULE 1001453

POLARITY SWITCH (SW201) 3 
CEMENT BOND GATING CIRCUIT4
1311 XA  GAMMA RAY
P/N 107846-945
MARCH 2000

2

1311 XA  GAMMA RAY
P/N 107846-945
MARCH 2000
5.0 DETECTOR CIRCUIT:   Refer to Detector Schematic B77497
The G/R detector, housed in the vacuum flask, consists of a scintillation cesium-iodide
crystal, coupled to a photomultiplier (PM) tube.  Gamma rays from the formation enter the
crystal where they ionize and give off energy.  This ionization energy is converted into tiny
flashes of light (photons).  In the PM tube, these photons are changed into electrical pulses
that are amplified through a series of twelve dynodes.
The pulse height from the tube is proportional to the energy of the incident gamma rays.
Since different levels (i.e., count rates) of gamma radiation are associated with different types
of rock, the information from the detector can be used to indicate formation lithology.
6.0 DISCRIMINATOR MODULE 118175: Refer to schematic B118176
The discriminator module, also housed in the vacuum flask, filters the detector signal.
Pulses from the PM tube enter the module on pin 4, while 24 Vdc powers the discriminator
on pin 3.  Capacitor C1 couples the input signal to emitter-follower Ql, which lowers the
signal impedance before passing it on to comparator-amplifier A1.  At pin 7, located between
Ql and Al, the emitter-follower output may be observed.
Al blocks the passage of low-amplitude signals (such as noise from the PM tube) by acting
as an on-off switch in the following manner.  Al compares the pulse observed at pin 7 to a
reference voltage determined by Rselect.  In the low-level hook up for the discriminator,
Rselect is a lK potentiometer connected across pins 1 and 5, with the wiper connected to pin
8 (refer to schematic A106333).  An approximate trigger voltage is measured between pins 5
and 8.  When the pulse at pin 7 is larger in amplitude than the voltage between pins 5 and 8,
the comparator turns "on" and outputs (at module pin 6) a negative pulse of approximately
12 volts.  Conversely, when the pulse at pin 7 is smaller in amplitude, A1 switches off and no
voltage appears at the module output.
The width of the output pulse at pin 6 is determined by the duration that the pulse exceeds
the trigger voltage.  The discrimination range for low-level hook up is approximately 40 to
1000 mV.

3

1311 XA  GAMMA RAY
P/N 107846-945
MARCH 2000
7.0 FLIP-FLOP MODULE 89174: Refer to Drawing B89174
The flip-flop module is located in the upper electronics package.  The low-voltage
power circuit supplies the module with 24 Vdc at pin 5.  Resistor R1 and diode D1 reduce
and regulate this voltage to the 12 Vdc supply needed to power the CMOS binary counter,
IC1.
Pulses from the discriminator enter the module at pin 2, where the binary counter reduces
the pulse rate by a factor of two.  That is, for every two pulses in, the module outputs only
one pulse at pin 7.  Scaling down the pulse rate in this way reduces both the power required
by the line driver and the number of pulses sent up the logging cable to the surface.
8.0 LINE DRIVER MODULE 100145: Refer to Drawing B 100145
The line driver is located in the upper electronics package.  The module produces pulses of
uniform width for transmission to the surface electronics.  Pin 1 of the line driver couples the
module to the flip-flop output.  A power supply of 24 Vdc enters on pin 5.
Rl and Cl differentiate the input signal.  When the voltage of the differentiated pulse rises to
approximately a of the supply voltage at pin 5, the pulse triggers a one-shot multivibrator
(Al).  The triggering produces a steep-sloped, positive-going pulse at pin 10 on Al.  Time
components R2 and C2 set the width of the pulse (nominally 30-35 microseconds wide).
This pulse switches on transistor Ql, which amplifies the signal and induces a pulse-voltage
in the secondary of transformer T1.  The transformer matches the impedance of the signal to
that of the logging cable, making it possible to transmit pulses to the surface through long
lines.
Diodes D2 and Dl protect Ql from damaging voltage reversals.  Steering diodes D3 and D4
are connected to pins 3 and 8 for pulse-polarity selection.  Negative pulses leave the module
between pins 4 and 8.
9.0 POLARITY SWITCH (SW201): Refer to Schematic D79402
The polarity switch, located in the upper electronics package (see drawing D78886), routes
the pulses from the line driver to the cablehead connector.  During G/R logging operations,
only negative pulses are transmitted to the surface.
The following circuitry is incorporated into the G/R electronics only when auxiliary
instruments or adapters are attached to the G/R tool.

4

1311 XA  GAMMA RAY
P/N 107846-945
MARCH 2000
10.0 CEMENT BOND GATING CIRCUIT:
Refer to Drawing D78886 and Schematic
D79402
This circuit controls a gating pulse that is received from a Cement Bond Locator (CBL)
instrument when it is attached to the G/R instrument.  The components for the circuit are
mounted on the line driver shelf.
The pulse from the circuit feeds into pin 6 of the line driver, turning the module off for
1800 microseconds.  During that period, the cement bond information is routed through
the G/R tool and sent to the surface via pin 3 at the top connector.  This 1800-microsecond
gate allows the G/R and CBL logs to be run simultaneously on a single-conductor logging
cable.

5

1311 XA  GAMMA RAY
P/N 107846-945
MARCH 2000

Calibration procedure
7.2.1 Completely reassemble the tool into the housing.
7.2.2 With the test box, apply power to the instrument and record the
background count rate.
7.2.3 Position C933 calibrator at the 2404 mark on the detector end of housing.
Record the count rate.
7.2.4 The differential between the two counts should be 5510 to 6090 counts
per minute (CPM).

Test Set-up

the electronics and detector assemblies.

79154.
9.2.4 Place the DVM across discriminator pins 5 and 8.  Connect the scope
across discriminator pin 7 to ground.
9.2.5 Place Am-241 source near the detector crystal.  Position it for a
reasonable counting rate.
NOTE:
Placing the source too close to the detector yields a count rate that
is too high.
9.2.6 Power the electronics with 150 Vdc.  Adjust the discriminator trimpot to
obtain a DVM reading of 500 mV.
9.2.7 Observe the scope.  The pulses should be between 100 and 200 mV at the
energy peak for Am-241.
NOTE:
If the pulses differ greatly from this range, the PM tube may need
to be replaced.

1

1311 XA  GAMMA RAY
P/N 107846-956
MARCH 2000 
INTRODUCTION
The checkout procedures divide into separate sections.  Section 2.0 lists the equipment
needed for sections 3.0 through 6.0.  Section 3.0 is a continuity check that includes some
disassembly instructions.  Section 4.0 provides further disassembly instructions plus
procedures for power supply connections.  Section 5.0 is a voltage checkout with a table of
test points and their respective meter readings, while section 6.0 provides a signal-
processing check of the modules.  Section 7.0 outlines an instrument calibration procedure
using the C933 G/R calibrator.  Section 8.0 provides a checkout of the line driver module,
and section 9.0 details a discriminator adjustment procedure.
In some instances, assembly drawings are referenced in the procedures.  The numbers in
parentheses are the numbers associated with those drawings.

Count Rate Monitoring
9.3.1 Adjust the discriminator trimpot to obtain a 50-mV reading on the DVM.
With the test box, monitor a 200-second count.  Record the count rate
and voltage setting after 200 seconds.
9.3.2 Continue monitoring as follows:
1. Readjust the trimpot to increase the DVM in 50-mV increments.
2. At each voltage setting, observe a minimal 200-second count.  Record the
count rate and voltage reading.

Final Adjustment
9.4.1 Plot a statistical curve of the voltage setting versus the count rate.  The
Curve should be similar to the sample curve in Figure 4.
9.4.2 Plot a differential curve alongside the statistical curve using the following
method:
1. Note the change in count rate between consecutive voltage settings.
2. Plot each count rate change against the midpoint of the respective voltage
settings.  (See the example in Figure 4.)  The resulting plot is a differential
curve.

12

P/N 107846-956
MARCH 2000
9.4.3 From the differential plot, determine the voltage setting at the energy
peak of Am-241.
9.4.4 Set the discriminator trimpot to the DVM reading corresponding to the
peak.
9.4.5 Turn off the instrument power.  Remove the DVM, scope, and test box.
Reassemble the tool.
9.4.6 Recheck the instrument calibration per the instructions in Section 7.0.

topic: Brief Description of Service/Equipment - BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE          1329XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG 1.0 GENERAL INFORMATION
chunk_text:
1
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE          1329 XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG 1.0 GENERAL INFORMATION
The Atlas Wireline Services Spectralog was first introduced to the oil industry for commercial use in
1969.
The 1329 XA/XB SPECTRALOG tool is used for (a) lithology identification, (b) determination of clay
type and clay content, (c) measuring bed thickness, (d) locating uranium by-product buildup in a cased
well, and (e) identifying potential fracture zones.
The 1329 XB instrument incorporates additional feed-thru wires to support RCI motoring.  Current
production supports the 1329 XB, but 1329 XA instruments can be modified by completing FMN 96-39,
if necessary.
Currently, the RCI is the only instrument that requires the additional wiring of the 1329 XB, but it may
also be run in all other standard combinations.
There are many radioactive sources.  Potassium(K), uranium(U), and thorium(Th) are of particular
interest to the oil/gas industry.  Virtually all of the gamma radiation detected by downhole instruments
can be classified in one of these three categories.

topic: Brief Description of Service/Equipment - 1.1 LITHOLOGY INTERPRETATION
chunk_text:
The 1329 XA/XB SPECTRALOG differs from a gamma ray instrument - which records total gamma
rays as a function of depth - in that it also measures the discrete energy of each gamma ray detected.
The discrimination of the total gamma ray signal into discrete energy levels or windows, infers the
individual amounts of potassium(K), uranium(U), and thorium(Th).  As a result, certain lithology
ambiguities can be resolved which often exist when using only total gamma ray signal.
Example:
Given a high total gamma ray count over a 40 foot interval, the signal could could be indicative of
a shale zone.  If that signal was mostly composed of uranium gamma rays, it could be indicative of
a fault plane where uranium carrying fluid had migrated.
For a high uranium and moderate thorium gamma ray content, the same signal could be indicative
of phosphatic rock.
In yet another case, high potassium and low uranium and thorium, the signal could indicate illite
clay.
In general, the potassium(K), uranium(U), and thorium(Th) contents of rocks yield strong clues as to
formation identity.

topic: Brief Description of Service/Equipment - BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE          1329XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG 1.2 INSTRUMENTATION
chunk_text:
2
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE          1329 XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG 1.2 INSTRUMENTATION
The 1329 XA/XB SPECTRALOG contains a high resolution 2 x 12 inch Cesium Iodide (CsI) crystal
optically coupled to a photomultiplier tube (PMT).
An advantage of a CsI crystal over other crystal detectors is the severe conditions of shock and
vibration it can withstand.
When a gamma ray of specific energy (measured in Million electron Volts - MeV's) interacts with the
crystal it is converted to a light pulse (photon).  The intensity of this light is proportional to the gamma
ray's energy.
The light pulse is converted into an electronic pulse and amplified by the PMT of the detector section.
The crystal and photomultiplier tube, along with other critical electronic components, are housed in
a vacuum flask for temperature control.
The outer diameter of the instrument is 3-5/8 inches.
PMT output voltages -proportional to gamma ray energy levels- are passed through a filter and linear
amplifier, digitized by a multichannel microprocessor-controlled spectrum analyzer, and stored in
spectrum-memory locations.
Each 16 bit memory address (1 word), for a given energy level, is one channel within a 256 channel
spectrum.  Each channel can store a maximum of 64 K pulses.
For each spectrum sample, some channels may have a zero value because no gamma radiation was
detected for that energy level.
There are typically 4 spectrum samples/ft at a typical logging speed of 10 ft/min.  The sample rate can
be changed.  If SPL II acquisition software is used the typical logging spped is 30 ft/min.
As the sampling continues (CsI is constantly bombarded) and more gamma rays are detected, each
excitation voltage (discrete energy level) is stored in a designated memory address (channel) for that
energy level.
This digitization process takes place within the instrument so that analog pulses do not travel over long
logging cables which can easily degrade signal voltages.

1
DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE          1329 XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG
1.0 GENERAL CIRCUIT  DESCRIPTION (see Figure 936-2)
When a gamma ray of specific energy interacts with the crystal it is converted to a light pulse (photon).
The light intensity will be proportional to the gamma ray's energy.  The light pulse is converted into an
electronic pulse and amplified by the PMT of the Detector circuit (see Figure 936-1, balloon 1).
The pulse is conditioned through the Preamp PCB (see Figure 936-1, balloon 2) that outputs a positive
voltage pulse.  This pulse corresponds to the energy level of that gamma ray.
The Pulse Height Analyzer PCB (see Figure 936-1, balloon 3) samples the peak of that pulse, and outputs
an 8-bit word equivalent.
The digitally converted pulse is strobed through the FIFO section (see Figure 936-1, balloon 4), so that no
data will be lost if microcontroller 2 is doing other tasks.  
The 1 K x 8-bit Spectrum RAM (see Figure 936-1, balloon 5) stores data for two spectrums.  Under normal
conditions, one spectrum will be collected until a depth interrupt occurs.  That first spectrum is stored and
the second will begin to be generated in a different spectrum memory location.  The first spectrum is
transmitted while the second spectrum is collecting.
The Spectrum Analyzer PCB will create a spectrum of 256 channels.  Each channel can hold up to 64 K
pulses.
Pre-programmed microcontroller 2 (µC 2) (see Figure 936-1, balloon 6) coordinates all the tasks on the
spectrum analyzer PCB. 
When µC 2 issues a transmit data command , a timing logic is initialized by loading the shift registers and
latches (see Figure 936-1, balloon 7).
The timing logic controls the shift registers speed, so that data will be synchronized to the transmission rate
of T5 Mode Manchester IC (see Figure 936-1, balloon 8).  The timing logic also allows for the transfer
of the 16-bit words to the Manchester without intervention of µC 2.
After the transmission of each word to T5 Mode Manchester IC, a new word is loaded to the shift registers
from the latches by the timing logic, an interrupt is sent to µC 2, and this causes µC 2 to load a new word
into the latches.
The I/O PCB (see Figure 936-1, balloon 9) conditions data for transmission onto the wireline, and recovers
signals from the wireline for T2 Mode Manchester IC to decode.
MicroController 1 (see Figure 936-1, balloon 10) has an internal counter that stores the number of pulses
that the PHA board converts.  µC 1 receives its commands through T2  Manchester IC (see Figure 936-1,
balloon 11).  µC 1 also transmits through T2 when necessary, and communicates via its serial port with µC
2.  This is a one way communication, called half duplex.  µC 1 also controls a dual Digital/Analog
converter (see Figure 936-1, balloon 12).
The dual D/A provides the discrimination level for the PHA board, and the voltage control for the Venus
High Voltage power supply.
