topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG
chunk_text:
1

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329 XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL                                        P/N 130373-945                                         MAY 2007
1.0 WTS INSTRUMENT BUS (drawing 148666-100)

WTS-IB is an eighteen conductor bus that provides instrument and motoring power to the tool string, passes
commands from the acquisition system via WTS Common Remote (WTS-CR), passes the data from the tools to
the WTS-CR, and provides for electrode and reference lines.

All WTS instruments are required to support the WTS-IB.  All tools in the string are connected in parallel to the
bus, which is created in the WTS-CR.

The Bus Terminal PCB (148666) is a passive board that receives the WTS bus coming from the top connector
and routes it to the bottom connector.  All of the wiring interface between the tool and bus takes place on this
board.


2.0 LOCAL TERMINAL PCB  (drawings 148667-100 and 148982-100)

The Local Terminal PCB connects the electronics package with the rest of the tool.  All the regulated voltages
of the tool and the buffered Manchester's input/output can be found on this board.


3.0 DETECTOR CIRCUIT  (drawing 152111-000)

The Photo Multiplier Tube (PMT) is a very sensitive device, suitable for gamma radiation detection when used
with a scintillation detector.  When a gamma ray passes through a CsI detector crystal, a discrete flash of light
is produced due to an exchange of energy inside the crystal.  The intensity of such scintillation is a function of
the energy of the gamma ray.

A spring mechanically maintains the PMT & PMT-socket against the crystal.

The Cesium Iodine crystal is optically coupled to the PMT cathode, which is a photo-electric transducer.  The
emitted electrons are directed by an electric field to the first dynode.  A number of secondary electrons are
emitted at this dynode and are directed to each progressive dynode.  A final amplification of approximately 106
is achieved.

The electrons from the last dynode are collected by the anode which provides the signal current.  This current
produces a voltage pulse when passing through R13.  The voltage pulse, which is negative going, is applied to
the Linear Pre-Amplifier through coupling capacitor C13 (P8/pin3).

The rest of the resistors and capacitors contained in the PMT socket are necessary to adjust the gain of the
PMT.

The K-15 Venus power supply is the high voltage source required by the PMT.  This device is a variable
DC/DC converter that produces a 300 to 1500 Vdc output from an input of 3 to 15 Vdc.  Using this
configuration, the gain of the PMT can be adjusted to compensate for different drifts that may appear in this
circuit or the rest of the tool.

VENUS POWER SUPPLY is filtered on High Voltage Filter PCB 141047.  This board is attached to the PMT
socket.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG
chunk_text:
2

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329 XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL                                        P/N 130373-945                                         MAY 2007

4.0 LINEAR PRE-AMPLIFIER CIRCUIT (drawing 148654-100)

IC2 is an inverting amplifier.

R28, C11 and R18 perform a common remote differentiation with pole-zero cancellation.  The pole-zero
cancellation is used to cancel undershoot caused by the RC inter stage coupling between amplifier stages.  If
left uncorrected, the under shoot will cause a baseline shift and affect the quality of the measured data.

R18 is used to adjust the amplitude of the pulse before it enters the final stage of gain.  Any variation of the
gain is controlled by the microprocessor of the tool.  Gain is varied by controlling the high voltage bias of the
PMT.

IC3, a non-inverting amplifier, integrates the input signal to obtain a semi-quassian pulse shape.  C15 is the
coupling capacitor to the output of IC3.

Q6, Q7, D1 and D2 set the voltage baseline of the pulses.  This active baseline regenerator keeps the baseline
from shifting.  Variation in the baseline will affect the accuracy and quality of the data.  This is especially
important in spectroscopic circuits where baseline shifts correspond to shifts in energy levels.


5.0 PULSE HEIGHT ANALYZER CIRCUIT (drawing 148655-100)


3507

OSCILLATOR

IC-6

2.5 Mhz CLOCK
AD7572

HIGH SPEED 12-BIT ADC
54 HC244


IC-8

TRI-STATE BUFFER

The Pulse Height Analyzer (PHA) receives an analog pulse and converts the peak amplitude to a digital value.
When a pulse enters the PHA PCB on J1/pin16 (SIG-IN) it will be present at +Vin of IC5 ready for sampling.
The sampling will take place when the pulse develops maximum amplitude.  IC1, IC2, IC3 and IC4 provide the
timing logic.

Pulse width is approximately 8 μs with maximum amplitude of 5 volts.

IC1 output feeds the inverting input of IC2a and the non-inverting input of IC2b.  IC2a has a threshold voltage
of 54 mv, a greater input pulse amplitude will drive its output LOW.  When the output of IC2a goes LOW it
triggers the one shot IC3a.  The duration of the output pulse (PEAK DETECT) is variable between 3 μs and 4
μs because the value for VR1 is not exactly equal for each tool.  See Repair /Maintenance Procedures -956 for
this adjustment.

The inverting input of IC2b is from software controlled Digital/Analog Converter that is used to adjust the point
of low level discrimination.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG
chunk_text:
3

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329 XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL                                        P/N 130373-945                                         MAY 2007

The output of IC2b (LLD OUT) is used to turn on IC3b, the sample logic.  The falling edge of Peak Detect and
a HIGH on LLD cause the output of IC3b/pin9 to fall to LOW and trigger IC4a and IC4b.

When IC4a triggers, Q output (pin 6) goes HIGH and sets two conditions:


1)
Disables IC4a & IC4b from being re-triggered.

2) Switches IC5 to SAMPLE & HOLD mode, to capture incoming pulse peak.

When IC4b triggers, Q output goes HIGH for about 3 μs.

The falling edge of Q HIGH (start conversion) enables IC7.  IC7 converts the analog signal on pin 1 into a 12-
bit digital value.  The least significant bits (D0 - D3) of IC7 are discarded, and bits D4 - D11 are buffered
through IC8.

When IC4 a times-out, the IC4/pin7 (HOLD NOT signal) flips from LOW to HIGH, indicating the end of the
conversion.


6.0 SPECTRUM ANALYZER CIRCUIT (drawing 142768-100)

Each pulse from the PHA is converted into an 8 bit data word and strobed by EOC
___ into U6.

The signal EF
__ shows the status of U6.  As long as data is present in U6 the signal EF
__ will stay HIGH.  U1
(μController) is constantly monitoring EF
__  and, if HIGH, it will generate an ACQUIRE pulse which will strobe
each DATA WORD out of U6 and into latch U3.  The DATA WORD now becomes the lower 8 bit address of
RAM RANK1
_____.  The U1 reads the contents of that RAM address, adds one to the contents value, and writes that
value back into the same RAM address.

Should an overflow occur, the U1 writes "00000000" to the address, flips ON the HIBYTE, increments by one
this address, and flips OFF the HIBYTE.

Two locations are associated with each data word; one is obtained with HIBYTE - LOW and one with HIBYTE
- HIGH.

A maximum (64 K-1) pulses for any channel can be stored in RAM.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG
chunk_text:
4

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329 XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL                                        P/N 130373-945                                         MAY 2007

The Spectrum Analyzer PCB receives commands from the communication PCB using the serial interface
embedded in U1/pin10.  Periodically, U1 receives a FREEZE SPECTRUM command.  When this occurs U1
toggles a signal to RANK0
_____ (RANK0 equals address bit 9 (A9) in RAM).  In this way, a new spectrum is
accumulated in the same manner as in DATA WORD description and the previous spectrum is "frozen".

Under normal operation a TX FROZEN SPECTRUM command will follow the FREEZE SPECTRUM
command.  To collect a 2nd spectrum and transmit the first one, U1 alternates between latching the data from
U6 to RAM, and then latching the data from the RAM to input registers U7/U8.  In the first case the pulses
control the address lines of the RAM.  In the second case, μC1 itself controls the address lines. To obtain the
control of the address lines, μC1 turns LOW P2.3 (U1/pin24), activating U2 and deactivating U3.  Access to
external data memory is time-multiplexed in U1.  ALE is used to latch the address byte into U2.  RD
__ and WR
__
are used to strobe the memory.


NOTE


Itemized (Pt x) description of the Manchester transmission is depicted in Figure 945-1

and the remaining text.

U1 activates ENABLE I/O (Pt 1), reads two bytes corresponding to the first channel of the spectrum, and then
deactivates ENABLE I/O.  This action loads the LSB and the MSB of this first channel to the input latches of
U7 and U8 respectively (Pt 6).

LOAD
____ / CTS (Pt 2) is LOW, thus U12 is in the load mode.  ALE is used just for clocking purposes. "11111111"
are loaded into U12.  U1 toggles LOAD
____ / CTS (Pt 2) is HIGH.  This has the following effects:


a)
Single shot U17 is triggered (Pt 5).  U17 consists of an 8 bit storage latch feeding a parallel-in, serial-
out 8 bit shift register.  The pulse generated by U17 causes a transfer of DATA WORD from U7/U8
input latches to U7/U8 shift registers (Pt 6).


b)
U12 goes from LOAD to COUNT mode and U10 is ENABLED to begin a sending sequence.


c)
An interrupt is generated -signal INT0 (Pt 4).  This interrupt will be used by μC1 to load a new
channel into the input registers of U7/U8 and increment an internal counter.

These events (a, b, and c) happen before the transmission of the first channel occurs.

U3 (Manchester IC) now controls the transmission.  U12 will generate an interrupt each time 16 bits have been
sent.  U1 will stop the pulse acquisition, load and reset a new channel, increment the internal counter, until all
the channels have been sent.  U1 will then toggle LOAD
____ / CTS to LOW, finishing the transmission.

The communication PCB performs the following tasks:


·
All communications that take place in T2 Mode.


·
Decodes all command words and data words coming from the surface interface.


·
Controls input to the Venus Power Supply.


·
Senses different analog voltages present in the tool; ie, temperature inside the flask.

These tasks are coordinated by U1 - μController.  This device has separate address space for the entire
program and data memory (EPROM).

Port 0 serves as a multiplexed address/data bus.  It provides two external interrupts INTO (P3.2) and INT1
(P3.3).  These interrupts are used to control U3 Manchester encoder communication.

Two 16-bit internal counter registers are available.  One of these counters (T0 - P3.4) is used to collect pulses
from PHA.  This is the Total Gamma Ray Counter.  The other counter register is not used.

A full duplex UART is embedded in U1.  This feature is used to transmit commands from the communication
PCB to the spectrum analyzer PCB.

TXD (P3.1) on the communication PCB is connected to RXD (P3.0) on the spectrum PCB.  TXD (P3.1)  is not
connected on the spectrum PCB.  This means the spectrum PCB cannot send any message to the communication
PCB.

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG
chunk_text:
7

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329 XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL                                        P/N 130373-945                                         MAY 2007

8.0 COMMUNICATION PCB - CLS COMMUNICATION (drawing 3000913sch)

U1 controls the Manchester circuit. Most of the control signals in the Manchester are tied directly to the I/O
ports of U1.  U9/pin2 is normally LOW, so DECODER SHIFT CLOCK will be able to propagate and interrupt
U1 only if a COMMAND DATA SYNC arrives.  As soon as U1 decodes the address, it compares this address
with the one for the tool (or the universal one: 00).  If true, it continues decoding the rest of the Manchester
word.  If false, U1 generates a MASTER RESET pulse.  In that way U3 disregards the rest of COMMAND
DATA SYNC and begins waiting for another one.  If the tool receives a command that requires a Manchester
data word, U1 toggles U9/pin2 HIGH.  Now the DECODER SHIFT CLOCK signal will be able to propagate
through U8 and generate the corresponding interrupt.

U19 is a buffer that protects the Manchester chip.

T5 Mode signals from U10 on the spectrum analyzer PCB (P3/pin19- BZO5 and P3/pin20- BOO5) are fed into
this board just for buffering purposes.


9.0 COMMUNICATION PCB - DIGITAL TO ANALOG CONVERTER (drawing 3000913sch)

U4 provides the analog voltage that powers the Venus Power Supply.  It is a 12-bit precision DAC loaded with
three 4-bit nibbles.  U1 updates the analog voltage values executing external write instructions.


10.0  COMMUNICATION PCB - ANALOG to DIGITAL CONVERTER (drawing 3000913sch)

Different analog voltages are sensed by the tool and are available if requested from the surface interface.  All
these voltages are sampled by U6.  This IC can constantly sample up to 8 voltages.  One of these voltages is
the tool's internal temperature.  This temperature is sensed by U16.  U16 generates a current that is proportional
to the absolute temperature (1 µA/K).

U15 provides a reference voltage of 2.5 volts. This voltage is subtracted by U11b from the voltage generated
through R3.  This circuit is designed to achieve a value of 0 Vdc for TEMP IN when temperature is close to -
25°C and approximately 5 Vdc when temperature is close to 100°C.


11.0 I/O PCB (drawing 148652-100)

The I/O PCB is the interface between the WTS BUS and the tool. Three sub-circuits make up this circuit:


·
COMMAND BUS

·
MODE 2 DATA BUS

·
MODE 5 DATA BUS

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG
chunk_text:
8

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329 XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL                                        P/N 130373-945                                         MAY 2007

12.0 COMMAND BUS (drawing 148652-100)

This section of the bus receives commands from the WTS-CR.  Two lines, CMD - (P4-6) and CMD +
(P4/pin13), are connected to the brown and yellow wires of bus coupling transformer T1 (X-1258-B).  T1 is
also connected to a resistive biasing network for the input of U1 (DS78 C20).  Termination resistor R1 is
between the gray and green wires of T1.  R1 provides bus termination to minimize ringing and crosstalk pickup.

Resistors (R2, R3, R4 and R5) provide a voltage divider network connected to the differential inputs of U1.
This bias voltage causes the negative input of U1 to be 100 mV higher than the positive input.  This bias
voltage also causes the output of U1 to be normally LOW in an idle state between commands.  U1's output goes
to COMMUNICATION PCB connecting to a buffer and the output of this buffer connects to the UDI input of
the 6408 Manchester decoder (U3).

13.0  MODE 2 DATA BUS (drawing 148652-100)

This section of the bus transmits the MODE 2 data from the tool to the WTS-CR.  WTS-IB lines MODE 2+
(P4/pin9) and MODE 2- (P4/pin8) are connected to bus coupling transformer T2 (X-1258-B) on the green and
gray wires.

The transformer is also connected to U2 (DS1633 J) through a resistor/diode combination to the brown and
yellow wires.

U2 is a peripheral driver and acts as a current path to ground when active.  The current flows from the +5 V on
the RED wire of T2 through whichever half of the transformer is active.  R6 or R7 and D1 or D2 act as current
limiting and protection for which ever side of the driver chip is active.

The inputs of U2 are connected to output drivers on COMMUNICATION PCB.  The inputs of these drivers are
connected to the outputs BZO
___ and BOO
___ of the 6408 Manchester encoder (U3 on COMMUNICATION PCB).

14.0 MODE 5 DATA BUS (drawing 148652-100)

This section of the bus transmits MODE 5 data from the tool to the WTS-CR.  WTS-IB lines MODE 5+
(P4/pin11) and MODE 5- (P4/pin10) are connected to bus-coupling transformer T3 (X-1258) on the green and
gray wires.  The transformer is also connected to U3 (DS1633 J) through a resistor/diode combination to the
brown and yellow wires.

U3 is a peripheral driver and acts as a current path to ground when active.  The current flows from the +5 V on
RED wire of T3 through whichever half of the transformer is active.  R8 or R9 and D3 or D4 act as current
limiting and protection for which ever side of the driver chip is active.  The inputs of U3 are connected to
output drivers on COMMUNICATION PCB.

The inputs of these drivers are connected to the outputs BZO
___  and BOO
___ of the 6409 Manchester encoder (U10 on
SPECTRUM ANALYZER PCB)

topic: Circuit Description - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG
chunk_text:
9

CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                   1329 XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL                                        P/N 130373-945                                         MAY 2007

15.0 DOWNHOLE POWER SUPPLY  (drawing 150336-100)

The downhole power supply is an AC/DC power supply that provides the regulated voltages needed to power
the instrument.

When powered with AC, 180 V is applied through Wireline 1 and Wireline 4 to the primary of transformer T2.
The output of the transformer is rectified and filtered by BR1 C9 & C10.  The voltage should be close to 150 V
at the input of L1.  An auxiliary winding in T2 energizes the coil of K1 and disconnects AC Mtr Pwr, +DC Mtr
Pwr and -DC Mtr Pwr from the tool.

L1, R4, C7 and C8 provide a smooth voltage to the input of the single-transformer, square wave power
oscillator converter.  This circuit (called a Royer Oscillator) has the input wave drive arrive from a feedback
winding on main power transformer T1.  The heart of this circuit is the square magnetic hysteresis loop
transformer core, which determines the operating frequency.  The different output windings of the transformer
are attached to full wave rectifiers and filter capacitors C1, C2 and C3.  IC1, IC2 and IC3 are series-pass, fixed
output, voltage regulators that provide the +5 V, +15 V and -15 V required by the tool.

A non regulated voltage, the input to IC2, is also present at the output of the power supply.  This output is
required by T2 COMMUNICATION PCB to generate a reference voltage, needed by DAC.

4.0  ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES - GENERAL INFORMATION
* These procedures are primarily for manufacturing *
1.
Obtain a copy of the calibration check-out records for the file and verify that the detector
crystal has passed the qualification requirements.
2.
Record the Serial Number of the PMT and detector crystal, and record the Instrument Asset
Number.  Attach this information to the Instrument History File (IHF).
3.
Inspect parts for any burrs or nicks on threads.  Small burrs may be removed with a thread
file.
4.
Inspect parts for cleanliness and foreign particles.  Set aside cleaned parts in clean area.
5.
Do not allow dirt or any foreign particles to contaminate the parts during assembly.
6.
Trial fit all mating parts without O-Rings installed.
7.
Stamp the Asset Number and the Series Number on the O.D. of pressure housing (11).  Use
low stress, dot pattern steel stamps with 1/8" high figures.  Place the numbers in the relief
band or the identification band.

5.0  ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
5
5.1  TOP SUB ASSEMBLY  (drawing 146872-000)
5
5.0  ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
5.1  TOP SUB ASSEMBLY  (drawing 146872-000)
1.
Install two O-Rings (9) on the slotted end of top sub (1).  Install two O-Rings (10) on the
threaded end of top sub.
2.
Lubricate the 2.5 in. collar groove of top sub with a light coat of Lubriplate grease.
Remove the screws from split collar (2) and separate  the two halves.  Install the two
halves in the collar  groove and replace the screws in split collar.  Make sure split collar
(2) is free to turn on top sub (1).
3.
Install spring (4) in top sub.  Slide sleeve (3) through spring (4) and into top sub.  Install
ring retainer (5) over the end of sleeve (3).  Compress and hold the spring and sleeve
while installing three screws (6) through holes in ring retainer (5) and into top sub (1).
4.
Set aside top sub assembly.
5.2  BOTTOM SUB ASSEMBLY  (drawings: XA, 148982-000; XB, 161984-000)
1.
Install two external O-Rings (6) on bottom sub (13).  Lubricate O-Rings and gland
surfaces with a light coat of Lubriplate grease.
2.
Screw bottom sub into pressure housing (11).  Tighten bottom sub to 75 lb-ft torque.
The timing marks of pressure housing and bottom sub should align with each other.
3.
Install two external O-Rings (18) on pressure bulkhead (14).  Lubricate O-Rings and
gland surface with a light coat of Lubriplate grease.
4.
Install bulkhead (14) into bottom sub using bulkhead installation tool.  Insert bulkhead
carefully into bottom sub; correct orientation of bulkhead is with short alignment key
towards pressure housing.
5.
Engage the slot on bulkhead installation tool with the long alignment key on the
bulkhead.  Push the bulkhead into bottom sub until the O-Rings engage.
6.
Use the threaded collar of bulkhead installation tool to push bulkhead (14) into seated
position.
7.
Orient the long alignment key with the internal slot in bottom sub, engage the key into
the slot, and by rotating the bulkhead installation tool, seat bulkhead.
8.
Install the retaining ring (12) in bottom sub using the modified pliers.  Be careful to not
damage or scar the inner surface finish of bottom sub.
5.3  ELECTRONICS BACKBONE ASSEMBLY  (drawing 151577-000)
1.
Assembly is the reversal of the disassembly steps.  Start at the last step and proceed
forward.

1.

rotate electronics assembly to align with the alignment key of bulkhead (14). Push with
the T-handle tool to seat the electrical contact pins.  When properly engaged, the
electronics assembly will seat on the internal shoulder of the bottom sub (13) and the
visible end of electronics assembly should be recessed 2.66 in. from the upper end of
pressure housing (11).
2.
Remove T-handle tool from electronics assembly.

5.10  TOP SUB INSTALLATION
7
5.10  TOP SUB INSTALLATION
1.
Lubricate two O-Rings (6) on top sub with Lubriplate Grease.
2.
Guide pigtail cable of electronics assembly through top sub using pigtail pulling tool P/N
148154.
3.
Screw top sub into pressure housing.  Tighten joint to 75 lb-ft torque.  Timing marks on
pressure housing and top sub should be aligned.
4.
Remove pigtail pulling tool from pigtail cable.
5.
Attach pigtail cable to female 32-pin Airborn connector.  Lubricate O-Ring and gland
surfaces of Airborn connector with a light coat of Lubriplate grease.
6.
Install Airborn connector into top sub using T-handle tool.
7.
Install retainer ring (1) in the groove on top sub using  C-ring installation tool.  Check
Airborn connector pins for electrical insulation resistance to verify that no conductor
wires were pinched.  Insulation value should be 1000 M  or greater
8.
Do a tool end-to-end continuity check.  Resistance should be 1.0 ohm or less.

5.11  THREAD PROTECTOR INSTALLATION
7
5.11  THREAD PROTECTOR INSTALLATION
1.
Lubricate the external threads of split collar and two O-Rings on top sub with a light coat
of Lubriplate grease.
2.
Install box thread protector (3) on top sub.
3.
Install external O-Ring on pin thread protector (3).  Lubricate O-Ring and threads with a
light coat of Lubriplate grease.  Install thread protector into bottom sub.

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                                 1329XA WTS SPECTRALOG 1.0 REQUIRED TOOLS
chunk_text:
1

REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                                 1329 XA WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL                                         P/N 130373-956                                         MAY 2007 1.0   REQUIRED TOOLS


Nut driver set, P/N 257624

3-32 Allen head screw driver

5-64 Allen head screw driver

5-32 Allen head right angle screw driver

Potentiometer tweeker

Screw drivers - various sizes

Loctite #242

Red GLPT insulating varnish

Canberra Spectrum Analyzer (or equivalent)

Dual trace oscilloscope (O-scope)

1 watt 500 Ω resistor

High input impedance amplifier (gain x 5)

Cesium radioactive source

Thorium radioactive source

High voltage source (1200 Vdc)

2716 EPROM w/socket - programmed with a known pattern

2.0   POWER SUPPLY  (see drawings XA: 150336-000, XB: 161985-000)


1.
Disconnect J7 and J6.


2.
Apply 180 VAC between pins 1 and 4 of the black block.


NOTE

Tool ground is connected to the power-supply backbone through lug (51).  Be certain that this
connection is correct.  Without it, noise can be produced at the input of the pre amp.  This
noise is created by the switching of the power supply and is electromagnetically coupled to the
input of the pre amp. Be certain that no other connection exists between tool ground and
chassis to avoid ground loops.


3.
When powering up with VAC, a "click" should be heard when relay K1 is energized.  This relay


disconnects lines "AC Mtr Pwr", "+DC Mtr Pwr" and "-DC Mtr Pwr" from the rest of the tool.


4.
Attach the ground of an oscilloscope or voltmeter to J6-A or J6-E.


5.
Measure the outputs of the Power Supply:



J6-Y or J6-CC = +5 V



J6-AA or J6-DD = +15 V



J6-Z or J6-BB = -15 V


Output waveforms should be smooth and stable.


6.
Measure the unregulated voltage at J6-U.  It should be smooth and more negative than -22 Vdc
(range is -22 to -30 Vdc).

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                                 1329XA WTS SPECTRALOG
chunk_text:
2

REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                                 1329 XA WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL                                         P/N 130373-956                                         MAY 2007

7.
Load each of the regulated outputs with a 500 Ω resistor and repeat step 5.


NOTE



If there is a short in one of the outputs, typically the oscillator won't work and an


abnormally low current is observed when the power supply is energized.


A characteristic high pitched sound can be faintly heard when the power supply


operates correctly.

1.
Follow the disassembly procedure in -955 to access the detector section.


2.
Attach a high input impedance amplifier (gain x 5) between pins 3 (signal) and pin 9 (ground)


of connector P-8.


3.
Apply 1000 Volts between pins 1 (high voltage) and 9 (ground) of connector P-8.  This will
energize the PM Tube.  Be certain that no environmental light can reach the photocathode.


4.
Attach the output of the amplifier to the PHA input of a Canberra Spectrum Analyzer (or
equivalent).


5.
Position a Cesium source close to the detector section (about 9").

6.
Collect the Cesium source spectrum for 100 seconds.  Calculate the resolution of the crystal.

It should be close to 12.5% and not exceed 15% if tool is to be run as a Spectralog.


NOTE




Alternately, internal pre-amp board, PHA and spectrum analyzer can be used to
calculate the resolution of the detector section.  This procedure can be used if
tool works and has been correctly adjusted.  See Preventative Maintenance
(Level 3) – 953.


4.0 PRE-AMPLIFIER PCB  (see drawing 148654-000)


1.
Follow the disassembly procedure in -955 to access the pre-amp board.


2.
Energize the instrument and verify that +15 V and -15 V are at the board.  These voltages should
look clean on an O-scope.


3.
Place a Thorium source or mixed bucket near the crystal.


4.
Attach the probe of the O-scope to terminal T5.

topic: Repair/Maintenance Procedures - REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                                 1329XA WTS SPECTRALOG
chunk_text:
3

REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                                 1329 XA WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL                                         P/N 130373-956                                         MAY 2007



5.
Energize the PMT.  Voltage should be close to 1150 (check valve). (Gain defaults to 3000).

6. Gain pot (R18) and cancellation pot (R28) should be adjusted to position Thorium peak in
channel 188 on X-Y display. No undershoot or ringing should exist. (see Figure 956-1)


















NOTE




If other adjustments are made to the instrument, this step must be repeated
for proper operation.



7.
Remove the radioactive source from proximity to the tool.  Be certain that the tool is far from
other sources.  Switch the vertical input of the scope to DC.  Adjust R29 until the baseline of
the output pulses is set at ground reference (0 Vdc).

1.
Energize the instrument and verify that +15 V and -15 V are at the board.  These voltages should
look clean on an O-scope.


2.
Energize the PMT.  Voltage should be close to 1150.  (Gain defaults to 3000).


3.
Attach O-scope probe to IC5/pin8.  This is the output of the sample and hold circuit.  Adjust
VR1 to catch the pulse at its peak value (see Figure 956-2).



REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                                 1329 XA WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL                                         P/N 130373-956                                         MAY 2007


















6.0 SPECTRUM ANALYZER PCB  (see drawing 3001276-000)


1.
No adjustments are required on this PCB.


2.
Serial communication; put the evaluation system in standby mode.  Verify that a serial word is
arriving to the board via SER COM (P2/pin18 or U1/pin10).


3.
Manchester communication; put the evaluation system in standby mode.  Verify that a
Manchester burst is coming out from U10/pin19, U10/pin18 or P2/pin19, P2/pin20.


NOTE







The next step applies only if a malfunction is suspected.



4.
Spectrum memory communication; replace RAM U4 with a 2716 EPROM programmed with a
known pattern.  Put the evaluation system in standby mode.  Verify that the pattern arrives to the
surface equipment.

5.
FIFO Check-out:




Put the evaluation system in standby mode.



Apply gain to the PMT (e.g. 3000).



Verify that the EOC strobe arrives to the board and to the FIFO (U5/pin10).



If no source is close, the tool should be counting background.



Verify that signal EF (U6/pin21) is flipping.






REPAIR/MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES                                 1329 XA WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL                                         P/N 130373-956                                         MAY 2007

7.0 COMMUNICATION PCB  (see drawing 3000913-000)


1.
No adjustments are required in this board.  Verify that the different supply voltages are arriving
to the board.


2.
Manchester communication; put the evaluation system in standby.  Verify that the Manchester
burst is arriving to the board and to the Manchester encoder / decoder chip (U3/pin8).  Check
signal VW (U3/pin1) to make sure that valid words are arriving.


3.
Serial communication; put the evaluation system in standby mode.  Verify that a serial word is
being sent by the controller via SER COM (P3/pin18 or U1/pin11) to the spectrum analyzer
PCB.


4.
PMT control; send different gain commands to the tool and check the output of the high voltage
supply.  Verify that the output varies linearly between gains of 200 and 3300.  The μC checks
the gain sent from CLS and limits the gain to 3328 if a larger gain entry is attempted.

5.
LLD Control; LLD has a fixed value of 70.

1.
No adjustments are required to this board.  Verify that the different supply voltages are present.


2.
If a malfunction is suspected related to T1, IC1 or T3 and IC3, put the evaluation system in
standby and track the signals with an O-scope.  The tool should be receiving in T2 mode and
sending in T2 and T5 mode.


3.
If a malfunction is suspected related to T2 and IC2, "acquire" temperature repeatedly and track
the propagation of the signal with an O-scope.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE                            1329XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG 1.0 GENERAL INFORMATION
chunk_text:
1


LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE                            1329 XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL



P/N 130373-953


AUGUST 2013 1.0 GENERAL INFORMATION


NOTE



If any of the measurements are not within the recommended tolerances,


refer to component -956 for repair and adjustment.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 2.0 REQUIRED EQUIPMENT 3.0 ELECTRONICS CHECKOUT
chunk_text:
* Not all tools and drawings indicated will be used.

Tools and drawings listed in -955 for disassembly/assembly

Tools and drawings listed in -956 for electronics testing

Cesium source

Thorium source

Heat or cold source

Acquisition system and software or PC with SPL software 3.0 ELECTRONICS CHECKOUT


1.
Remove power supply, electronics package & flask from housing (see component -955).


2.
Remove flask, and verify flask functionality.


3.
Inspect the heat sink for leaks and cracks.


4.
Inspect the PCB's for loose screws, pinched wires, cold solder joints, loose or


broken components.


5.
Connect the instrument to a test system - PC based system or ECLIPS.


6.
Power up the instrument with 180 VAC. Current should be 75 mA ± 10 % without


a long wireline.


7.
Check the +5 V, +15 V and -15 V power supplies for proper voltage within +/- 1%


(LOCAL TERMINAL PCB 148667).


8.
Check that -22 Vdc signal is more negative than GND (range is -22 Vdc to -30 Vdc).


This voltage is not regulated and will be influenced by cablehead voltage.


9.
Collect a spectrum.  Verify that no pulses appear below channel 4.


10. Place a 10 μcurie Thorium source close to the detector.


11. Energize the PMT.  Verify the shape of the pulses from pre amp PCB.

topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE                            1329XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG
chunk_text:
2


LEVEL 3 PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE                            1329 XA/XB WTS SPECTRALOG



CONFIDENTIAL



P/N 130373-953


AUGUST 2013



12. Collect a spectrum with default gain of 3000, and then adjust gain via R18 on Pre-Amp


PCB so as to place the main peak of Th in channel 188.


13. If you are using the PC based software, collect a spectrum for about 10 minutes and


create an ASCII file of the spectrum.


14. Increment the PMT voltage in order to place the Thorium peak in channel 220.



Increment the voltage slowly.



If the increment commands do not increase the PMT gain.  Check the detector circuit for poor
coupling between detector and crystal, defective PMT, a damaged crystal, bad power supply or
D/A converter.


15. Repeat step 8 and verify that Thorium peak is in channel 188.


16. Remove the Thorium source and place a 10 μcurie Cesium source 8 in. from the center of the
crystal.


17. Collect a spectrum for about 1 minute.  Cesium peak should be in channel 48 +/- 1.  Record this
value.


18. If you are using the PC based software, create an ASCII file of the spectrum.


19. Calculate the resolution of the crystal. It should be close to 12.5% and not exceed 15% if tool is to
be run as a Spectralog.


20. From the PC/ECLIPS system, monitor the temperature. The value should be close to ambient
temperature. The reading can be modified by changing the temperature (touching with ones finger)
of U16 on T2 Mode Communication PCB 3000913.


21. Reassemble the tool. Use Loctite 532 (P/N F244147000) each time that you replace a screw in its
original position. Use RTV 3145 (P/N F223376000) to secure the screws on PC boards.


22. Calibrate the tool and keep a record of the calibration.

topic: Brief Description of Service - 1.0 BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
chunk_text:
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
The 1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray (GR) tool is compatible with the WTS AC
power and Instrument bus communication protocols on Mode 2 and 5.
As with other G/R detectors, hardware consists of a detecting crystal, coupled to a
photomultiplier (PM) tube. Gamma rays from the formation enter the crystal where they
ionize and give off energy. This ionization energy is converted into tiny flashes of light
(photons). These photons are changed into electrical pulses that are amplified through a series
of dynodes in the PM tube.
Voltage variations from the tube are proportional to the energy of the incident gamma rays.
Since different levels of gamma radiation (i.e., count rates) are associated with different types
of rock, the information from the detector can be used to indicate formation lithology. Higher
gamma ray count rates are commonly associated with the presence of shale.
The tool counts the number of PMT pulses acquired between acquisition commands and
keeps track of the elapsed time in milliseconds within the downhole processor.
Internal circuit board temperature and PMT high voltage measurement are also returned to
the surface as diagnostic parameters.
The electronics are fashioned after previous GR instruments, beginning with detecting the
pulses from the photomultiplier tube, sending them through a discriminator circuit, and then
to a counter where data can be ultimately sent to the surface.
The 1330 XA uses a microprocessor to handle the counts, A/D conversion, high voltage gain
control, elapsed time measurement, temperature measurement, and communications with the
surface.

DEC 2006
Baker Atlas

INTRODUCTION
The 1330 XA Gamma Ray (GR) tool is compatible with the WTS AC power and Instrument
bus communication protocols on Mode 2 and 5.
The tool provides a digital count of pulses from a photomultiplier tube (PMT) and sodium
iodide (NaI) crystal module over a given period of time. The tool returns the elapsed time in
milliseconds of the time the counts occurred so a counts / second curve can be accurately
generated.
1330 XA internal circuit board temperature and PMT high voltage measurement are also
returned to the surface as diagnostic parameters.

GAMMA RAY PCBA CIRCUITRY
The electronics are fashioned after many of its G/R predecessors. It begins with detecting the
pulses from the photomultiplier tube, sending them through a discriminator circuit and then to
a counter where data can be ultimately sent to the surface.
It uses a microprocessor to handle the counts, A/D conversion, high voltage gain control,
elapsed time measurement, temperature measurement, and communications with the surface.



131137-945 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
3
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Circuit Descriptions

MICROPROCESSOR
The heart of the Gamma Ray PC board is the microprocessor, U3, which controls all of
the action of the circuit. This unique microprocessor contains several counters, an A/D
converter, and inputs/outputs necessary to handle communications. It also has internal
ROM that contains processing firmware and internal RAM for holding data.
Support devices of the microprocessor are:
•
Y1 – a 12 MHz oscillator,
•
U9 – flash memory for holding tool parameters,
•
U4 – a precision voltage reference for the A/D converter, and
•
U6 – FPGA implementing Manchester Encoder/Decoder functions.

COMMUNICATIONS
Communications with surface equipment is accomplished using Manchester words.
The Instrument Bus (IB) carries commands for all tools of the tool string. Only when a
command contains the correct address for a given tool does it respond. Commands enter
the gamma ray PC board on pins 8 and 9 of connector J1. Commands are transformer-
coupled (T2) to the differential receiver U8. The circuit between T2 and U8 level-shifts
the common mode and amplitude of the received signal to the input range specified by
the datasheet of U8. The output of U8 connects to the UDI input of FPGA U6. Decoding
commands, the FPGA determines whether the word is valid, and if so, updates internal
registers to reflect that a valid word is present. The microcontroller polls this register
status and reads the 16-bit word from the FPGA. Firmware in the microcontroller
determines if the address of the command matches its address and responds appropriately
to the command.
If answering that command requires sending data back to the surface, the microprocessor
writes data to the FPGA registers over the 8-bit data bus. The data word is encoded into
Manchester format, it is clocked out the BZO\ and BOO\ outputs to driver chip U5 (mode
2) or U7 (mode 5). This chip drives MOSFETS that are connected to transformer T1 for
mode 2 or T3 for mode 5. These transformers directly drive the IB (instrument bus). The
IB data lines are tied to connector J1, pins 3 and 4 for mode 2, and pins 11 and 12 for
mode 5.
Data Subset 0 and Subset 1 transmit GR counts, elapsed time (ms), HV measured, and
temperature. Subset 0 is transmitted on mode 2 and Subset 1 is transmitted on mode 5.
Data Subsets 2 and 3 are reduced subsets and transmit only GR counts and elapsed time.
No checksum or header information is added to these subsets. (Only two words are sent.)
Subset 2 is transmitted on Mode 2 and Subset 3 is transmitted on mode 5.
131137-945 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
4
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Circuit Descriptions

DETECTING PULSES
As with other GR detectors, hardware consists of a detecting crystal, coupled to a
photomultiplier (PM) tube. Gamma rays from the formation enter the crystal where they
ionize and give off energy. This ionization energy is converted into tiny flashes of light
(photons). These photons are changed into electrical pulses that are amplified through a
series of dynodes in the PM tube.
Voltage variations from the tube are proportional to the energy of the incident gamma
rays. Since different levels of gamma radiation (i.e., count rates) are associated with
different types of rock, the information from the detector can be used to indicate
formation lithology. Higher gamma ray count rates are commonly associated with the
presence of shale.

Pulses from the PM tube enter the GR circuit at terminal E8 and are capacitor-coupled
from its high-voltage source to the input of amplifier U10. Calibrating terminals E14 and
E15 are used to adjust the signal strength to give a 2 V peak at TP1 when a Cesium 137
source is brought near to the detector. Once the resistance value is found a leaded resistor
is soldered between these terminals.
The amplified pulses are then sent to discriminator U11 to eliminate base noise and shape
the valid pulses into a square-wave signal. It is the output of U11 that is coupled to an
internal counter of microprocessor U3. Here the pulse count accumulates until the
acquisition cycle stops counting. A free running, millisecond timer reports the elapsed
time between acquisition commands from the surface. Both the elapsed timer and the GR
counter are reset after each acquisition.

GAIN STABILIZATION
During actual operation, increased downhole temperatures cause the gain of the
photomultiplier tube to decrease. This drop in gain must be corrected to keep the detector
sensitivity to gamma rays constant. This correction is accomplished by increasing the
high voltage applied to the PM tube in a quantity that is proportional to the temperature
change. Two relationships – gain vs temperature, and gain vs high-voltage – are
characteristic of a particular tube type and stabilize the gain by means of a control loop.
Below is a discussion of the various parts of this loop.
2.4.1 Temperature Sensing
U4 contains a high precision voltage reference circuit. However, it also contains a circuit
that compensates the voltage output with variations in temperature. The output of this
circuit is available as a voltage that is proportional to the absolute temperature (°K) that it
senses. This voltage is amplified at U2 A and becomes a signal that is measured by an
input of the microprocessor’s internal A/D converter. Firmware within the
microprocessor handles the processing of the data. Eventually this data is sent to the
surface as part of Subset 0.
131137-945 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
5
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Circuit Descriptions
2.4.2 High Voltage Monitor
The next stage of the control loop monitors the high voltage. This stage consists of
amplifier U2 B and associated components. The amplifier ties to the lower end of the
resistive voltage divider network that biases the dynodes (also the PM tube cathode
connection) and has a gain of 11. The output of this amplifier is fed into one of the inputs
of the A/D converter internal to the microprocessor. Capacitor C28 provides low
impedance to the A/D converter input.
2.4.3 High Voltage Control
The High Voltage Power Supply (HVPS) is a commercial item that is housed in modular
fashion. It has an input pin that allows circuitry to control the output voltage level. The
HV output is inversely proportional to the voltage applied to this control input.
The HVPS control signal is derived from a Pulse Width Modulated (PWM) output of the
microprocessor. The average value of the pulse train is amplified by U1. The amplifier
output connects through resistor R3 to terminal E5, which ties to the control pin of the
HVPS.
The microprocessor uses the measured temperature to determine the proper value of the
high voltage for that temperature. The high voltage set points, required for a given
temperature, are listed in a lookup table that resides in the firmware. This set point is
compared to the measured HV value and a PWM correction amount is calculated. The
PWM correction amount to fully adjust the HV to its set point value is divided by two
before it is applied to the PWM. This is done to reduce the speed of the correction and
prevent the possibility of overshoot. This process repeats every 500 ms.
In addition there is a slew rate limit imposed on the HV adjustment to reduce the
maximum step size of the HV, if the set point is far from the measured value.
2.4.4 Start-Up
When the tool is powered up at high temperatures (i.e. downhole) the initialization
portion of the downhole software applies an approximate initial value to the PWM
circuitry to provide for a fast turn-on. The control loop described in the previous
paragraph takes over from this point to keep the system gain stabilized.

HV ON / OFF5

HV ON / OFF
The PMT high voltage can be turned off via a command from the surface. This command
opens a relay (K2) that disconnects the HVPS input power. This feature was implemented
to reduce the stress on the PMT when gamma measurements were not needed.
131137-945 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
6
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Circuit Descriptions

SELF TEST
A constant frequency of 1.0 kHz is fed to a second counter input of the microcontroller
(pin 23). These counts replace the detector counts in the tool data block when requested
by the surface system. This constant frequency checks to ensure proper communications
and basic tool functionality.

POWER SUPPLY
The 1330 XA has a basic 60 Hz AC power supply consisting of a 60 Hz AC transformer,
diode bridge full-wave rectifier, filter capacitors, and linear voltage regulators.
The power supplies provide regulated 3.3 Vdc and ±12 Vdc to PC boards and the HV power
supply. Nominal input voltage is 180 V RMS at 60 Hz.

POWER SUPPLY PCBA6

FIGURES




131137-945 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
2
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Circuit Descriptions

POWER SUPPLY PCBA
The Power Supply PCBA (A3001593000) supplies a regulated output voltage of 3.3 Vdc
from an onboard linear regulator. This voltage is for the digital circuitry and is available
at pin 20 of the P2 connector. Digital ground for this regulated voltage is available on pin
19 of P2.
Regulated +12 volts is available on pin 14 of P2 and –12 volts is available on pin 16 of
P2. The voltage regulators are Micropac TO-3 packaged voltage regulators. These
regulators are mounted directly to the chassis for heat-sinking. The PCBA supplies
rectified raw input voltage to these regulators on pins 1 and 12 of P2. Diodes D11 and
D12 protect the Micropac linear regulators from being reverse biased. Analog ground is
common to +12 and -12 V and is available on pin 18 of P2.
Analog ground and digital ground are isolated from each other by the secondary windings
on the AC transformer.
Refer to the schematic drawing A3001593 SCH during the following discussions.
The +3.3 V regulator is a linear regulator that employs a NPN transistor Q1 as a pass
element. U1 provides a voltage reference of 2.5 V for the error amp U2. U2 compares the
output voltage sampled between R5 and R6 to the 2.5 V reference to determine the
amount of drive needed at the base of Q1 to provide 3.3 V at the output. Components Q2,
R10 and R3 provide a current limit circuit. When the output is shorted or overloaded, the
current increases to approximately 300 mA and develops 0.6 V across R3. This voltage
turns on PNP transistor Q2, which shunts drive current from the base of Q1 and attempts
to turn it off. In this condition, the output current is clamped at ~300 mA until the fault is
cleared or the overload condition subsides. Diodes D5 and D10 prevent reverse biasing of
Q1 and Q2.

131137-945 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas

INTRODUCTION
The 1330 XA 175° C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray Instrument Assembly should never need to
be completely disassembled. This procedure disassembles the 3985 XA to the point where
trouble-shooting, repair, parts replacement, routine maintenance, and level 3 preventive
maintenance can be easily done.

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 4.1 REMOVE TOP SUB, ELECTRONICS CHASSIS, AND BOTTOM SUB....................3
chunk_text:
REMOVE TOP SUB, ELECTRONICS CHASSIS, AND BOTTOM SUB3

REMOVE TOP SUB, ELECTRONICS CHASSIS, AND BOTTOM SUB
Refer to drawing A3001561000 during this disassembly procedure. Item numbers in
brackets [  ] are references to item numbers on the this assembly drawing and it's BOM
unless otherwise specified.
____  1.
Thoroughly clean and dry the 1330 XA before disassembling.
____  2.
Remove the top and bottom thread protectors [1 and 2]. Remove and
discard the O-Ring [12] on the OD of the bottom thread protector.
____  3.
Place the 1330 XA in a chain vise and lock it down.
____  4.
Remove the two socket-head cap screws from the split collar [4] and
remove the split collar from the top sub [9]. Clean the OD threads and ID
surfaces of the split collar halves and the mating surface on the top sub. Set
aside the split collar halves and two socket head cap screws.
____  5.
Remove the retainer ring [10] from the top end of the top sub [9]. Set aside
the retainer ring.
____  6.
Use the 1/4-20 T-handle tool to carefully pull the 32-pin female connector
[14] from the top sub and disconnect from the 32-pin cannon connector [1,
A3001575000] at the top of the cable assembly [5, A3001562000].Remove
and discard the O-Ring [12, 180006-000] on the OD of the 32-pin female
connector.
____  7.
Use 3-1/4-inch wrench to loosen the top sub [9]. Finish unscrewing by
hand and carefully slide the top sub off the cable assembly. Remove and
discard the O-Rings [12 and 13] from the OD of the top sub. Set aside the
top sub.
____  8.
Screw a 1/4-20 T-handle tool into the threaded hole in the top ring [2,
A3001562000] and pull the electronics chassis assembly [6] straight out of
the pressure housing [3]. Place the electronics assembly on tool chocks.
____  9.
Remove the retainer ring [10] from the ID of the bottom sub [8]. Set aside
the retainer ring.
____  10.
Screw a 1/4-20 T-handle tool into the center tapped hole in the bottom 32-
pin bulkhead connector [7] and pull the connector straight out of the
bottom sub [8]. Remove and discard the two O-Rings [11] and set aside the
connector.
____  11.
If the bottom sub O-Rings [13] need replacing, use a spanner wrench to
unscrew the bottom sub from the pressure housing. Remove and discard
the O-Rings.
131127-955 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
4
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Disassembly / Assembly

TOP SUB DISASSEMBLY
Unless parts internal to the top sub [9] require replacement, disassembly is not necessary.
Refer to drawing A3001561000 and it's BOM during this disassembly procedure. Item
numbers in brackets [  ] are references to item numbers on the this assembly drawing and
it's BOM.

The retainer ring [15] that will be removed in the next step is under light spring
tension. Hold the retainer ring firmly while removing the three flat-head screws
[19].

____  1.
Unscrew and remove the three flat-head screws and carefully remove the
retainer ring [15]. Set aside the screws and retainer ring.
____  2.
Remove the compressor sleeve 17] and spring [16] from the ID of the top
sub [9]. Clean the compressor sleeve, spring, and the top sub OD and ID.
Set aside these parts.

REMOVE GAMMA RAY MODULE
Refer to assembly drawing A3001562000 and it's BOM during this procedure. Item
numbers in brackets [  ] are references to item numbers on the this assembly drawing and
it's BOM unless otherwise specified.
____  1.
Unscrew and remove the four axel wheel roller pins [33] and roller wheels
[32] from the roller shelves [34] closest to the chassis adapter ring [6].
Unscrew the two screws and remove the two roller shelves closest to the
chassis adapter ring. Set aside parts.
____  2.
Disconnect the 14-pin connector [31 from the gamma ray PCBA [3,
A3001563000].
____  3.
Unscrew and remove the two 6-32 X 1.25-inch hex socket screws [16]
from the top end of the chassis adapter ring [6]. Set aside the screws.
____  4.
Cut the Kapton tape [13] at both edges of the gamma ray backbone [7]. Cut
ONLY the tape at the three 360° tape channels on the detector housing [1,
A3001563000].
____  5.
Unscrew and remove the three 10-32 X 0.625 flat head screws [10] (one
near the center of the backbone and two at the bottom of the gamma ray
module on side 1 of the assembly) that secure the gamma ray module [9] to
the gamma ray backbone [7]. Carefully lift off the gamma ray module. Set
aside the hardware.
131127-955 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
5
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Disassembly / Assembly

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 4.4 GAMMA RAY MODULE DISASSEMBLY ..................................................................5
chunk_text:
GAMMA RAY MODULE DISASSEMBLY
Refer to assembly drawing A3001563000 and it's BOM during this procedure. Item
numbers in brackets [  ] are references to item numbers on the this assembly drawing and
it's BOM.
____  1.
Place the gamma ray module on a stable work surface.
____  2.
Unsolder the following wires from the gamma ray PCBA [3]. Leave all
other wires attached unless the gamma ray PCBA must be replaced.
•
Black wire at E10
•
Black / white wire at E9
•
Shielded wire at E8
•
Red wire at E7
•
Red 22 gauge HV wire at E6
____  3.
Hold the PMT housing [1] and detector housing [2] together and remove
the four 10-32 X 0.625-inch flat head screws [19]. Be careful, the PMT
housing is under light spring tension. Set aside the screws.
____  4.
Carefully slide the PMT housing [1] off the detector housing [2]. Avoid
damaging the PMT wires. Remove the two O-Rings [27] from the PMT
housing and discard. Clean and set aside the PMT housing.
____  5.
Remove the PM tube plug [20], spring [21], and PM tube assembly [26].
Thoroughly clean the PM tube assembly with an approved cleaner and
cloth. Cover the PM tube assembly to protect it from dust and other
contaminates and set aside the PM tube plug, spring, and PM tube
assembly.
____  6.
Slide the Mu-metal shield [24] out of the detector housing [2] and discard
the O-Ring [25]. Clean and set aside the Mu-metal shield.
____  7.
Carefully slide out the detector crystal assembly [28]. Thoroughly clean the
detector crystal with an approved cleaner and cloth. Cover the detector
crystal to protect it from dust and other contaminates and set aside.
____  8.
Slide the spring [23] and detector plug [22] out of the detector housing [2].
Clean and set aside the spring and detector plug.
____  9.
Thoroughly clean the ID of the detector housing [2] with an approved
cleaner and cloth. Set aside the detector housing.
131127-955 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
6
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Disassembly / Assembly

ASSEMBLY
Inspect all parts and ensure that all parts and supplies are available before assembly begins. 

GAMMA RAY MODULE
Refer to assembly drawing A3001563000 and it's BOM during this procedure. Item
numbers in brackets [  ] are references to item numbers on the this assembly drawing and
it's BOM.
____  1.
Stand the detector housing [2] on its end, open end up. You must hold the
detector housing upright or lock it in a vise.
____  2.
Insert spring [23] over detector plug [22] and drop this assembly into the
detector housing [2] in the orientation shown on the assembly drawing. Use
a dab of RTV 3145 adhesive [15] to secure the spring. You may remove
the plate to help with installation.
____  3.
Apply a thin coat of optical coupling grease [35] onto the coupling surface
of the detector crystal [28]. Carefully slide the detector crystal into the
detector housing [2].
____  4.
Carefully slide the MU metal shield [24] into the detector housing [2].
____  5.
Carefully slide the photomultiplier (PM) tube [26] into position against the
detector crystal [28], wire end up.
____  6.
Insert the spring [21] over the PM tube plug [20]. Use a dab of RTV 3145
adhesive [15] to secure the spring.
____  7.
Pass the wires from the PM tube [26] through the center hole of the PM
tube plug [20] and position the plug on top of the PM tube.
____  8.
Apply a thin coat of Lubriplate grease [10] and insert the two O-Rings [27]
into the O-Ring grooves in the ID of the PMT housing [1].
____  9.
Apply Lubriplate grease [10] to the O-Ring [25] and slide it onto the OD of
the PMT housing [1] as shown on the assembly drawing.
____  10.
Carefully slide the PMT housing [1] over the PM tube [26]. Rotate the two
pieces until the five screw holes located in each piece align. The backbone
channels should be aligned. Apply slight pressure to compress the springs
sufficiently to install the four screws [19]. A fifth hole (at the bottom) does
not receive a screw at this time. Apply thread lock adhesive [29] to the
threads of the screws before installing.
____  11.
Place the gamma ray module on a stable work surface, gamma ray PCBA
[3] facing up.
131127-955 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
7
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Disassembly / Assembly

____  12.
Solder the following PM tube [26] wires to the gamma ray PCBA [3].
•
Red 22 gauge HV wire to E6
•
Red wire to E7
•
Shielded wire to E8
•
Black / white wire to E9
•
Black wire to E10

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 5.2 GAMMA RAY MODULE INSTALLATION ..................................................................7
chunk_text:
GAMMA RAY MODULE INSTALLATION
Refer to assembly drawing A3001562000 and it's BOM during this procedure. Item
numbers in brackets [  ] are references to item numbers on the this assembly drawing and
it's BOM unless otherwise specified.
____  1.
Orient the gamma ray module [9] as shown on the assembly drawing and
rest it on the gamma ray backbone [7].
____  2.
Plug the 24-pin connector [31] into the top end of the gamma ray PCBA [3,
A3001563000].
____  3.
Secure the gamma ray module to the bottom chassis adapter ring [6] with
two 6-32 X 1.25-inch socket-head cap screws [16] as shown in Section C-
C of the assembly drawing. Apply thread lock adhesive to the screw
threads before installing.
____  4.
Secure the gamma ray module to the gamma ray backbone and downhole
snorkel with three 10-32 X 0.625-inch flat-head screw [10]. Apply thread
lock adhesive to the screw threads before installing.
____  5.
Install the two roller shelves [34] onto the electronics chassis, immediately
above the chassis adapter ring [6] and secure with two 8-32 X 0.75-inch
socket-head cap screws [35]. Apply a drop of thread-lock adhesive [48]to
the threads of the two screws before installing.
____  6.
Individually install the four roller shelf wheels [32] and secure in place
with the four axel wheel roller pins [33]. Apply a drop of thread-lock
adhesive [48] to the threads of the axel wheel roller pins before installing.
131127-955 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
8
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Disassembly / Assembly

TOP SUB ASSEMBLY
Refer to assembly drawing A3001561000 and it's BOM during this procedure. Item
numbers in brackets [  ] are references to item numbers on the this assembly drawing and
it's BOM unless otherwise specified.
____  1.
Insert the spring [16] into the bottom ID of the top sub [9].
____  2.
Insert the compressor sleeve [17] into the ID of the spring [16].
____  3.
Slide the retainer ring [15] onto the OD of the compression sleeve [17] and
up against the bottom of the top sub [9].

The retainer ring [15] that will be installed in the next step will be under light spring
tension. Hold the retainer ring firmly while installing the three flat-head cap screws
[19].

____  4.
Apply thread lock adhesive [20] to the threads of the three 6-32 x 0.375-
inch flat-head screws. Align the screw holes in the retainer ring [15] with
the threaded holes in the bottom of the top sub [9]. Screw in and tighten the
three 6-32 x 0.375-inch flat-head screws.
____  5.
Install the two O-Rings [13] into the O-Ring grooves in the OD of the top
sub [9], just above the bottom threads.
____  6.
Lubricate the fine threads closest to the bottom OD of the top sub [9] with
Lubriplate grease [5].
____  7.
Install the two O-Rings [item 5] into the top two O-Ring grooves in the top
sub [9].
____  8.
Liberally lubricate the ID of the split collar [4] and the mating OD surface
of the top sub [9] with Lubriplate grease [5]. Apply thread lock adhesive
[20] to the threads of the socket head cap screws supplied with the split
collar. Secure the split collar to the top sub with the socket head cap
screws.

topic: Disassembly / Assembly Procedures - 5.4 BOTTOM SUB, ELECTRONICS CHASSIS, AND TOP SUB.....................................8
chunk_text:
BOTTOM SUB, ELECTRONICS CHASSIS, AND TOP SUB8

131127-955 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
2
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Disassembly / Assembly

BOTTOM SUB, ELECTRONICS CHASSIS, AND TOP SUB
Refer to drawing A3001561000 and it's BOM during this disassembly procedure. Item
numbers in brackets [  ] are references to item numbers on the this assembly drawing and
it's BOM unless otherwise specified.
____  1.
Place the pressure housing [3], alignment marks facing up, on a tool dolly
equipped with a chain vise and lock in place.
____  2.
Install two O-Rings [13] just below the threads at the top of the bottom sub
[8].
____  3.
Lubricate the O-Rings and the OD threads with Lubriplate grease [5] and
screw the bottom sub [8] into the bottom of the pressure housing [3]. Use a
torque wrench / spanner wrench to tighten the bottom sub to 75 lbf-ft.
131127-955 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
9
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Disassembly / Assembly
____  4.
Align the index key and insert the 32-pin female bulkhead connector [14]
into the 32-pin bulkhead installation assembly [25].
____  5.
Align the alignment mark on the bottom sub [8] with the alignment pin on
the 32-pin female bulkhead connector [14] and install the connector
straight into the bottom sub using the 32-pin bulkhead installation
assembly [25]. Verify that the 32-pin female bulkhead connector is fully
seated.

Note: Alternatively, you can use a 1/4-20 T-handle tool [22] to install the 32-pin female bulkhead
connector [14] into the bottom sub [8].


____  6.
Lubricate the roller wheels [32, drawing A3001562000] on the electronics
chassis assembly [6] and gamma ray module with Lubriplate grease [5] to
facilitate inserting the electronics chassis assembly [6] into the pressure
housing [3].
____  7.
Align the alignment pin on the downhole snorkel [8, A3001562000] with
the mark at the top of the pressure housing [3] OD and carefully slide the
electronics chassis assembly [6] straight into the pressure housing until it
bottoms. Make sure that the electronics chassis is fully seated in the
pressure housing.
____  8.
Push the 32-pin Cannon connector, with attached cable assembly, up
through the topsub [9].
____  9.
Screw the top sub [9] into the top of the pressure housing [3]. Hold the
pressure housing stationary with a strap wrench or chain vise and tighten
the topsub to 75 lbf-ft using a torque wrench.
____  10.
Plug the cannon connector [5], A3001562000] into the bottom of the 32-
socket female WTS connector assembly [14] and rotate to the lock
position.
____  11.
Lubricate the O-Ring on the 32-socket female WTS connector [14] with
Lubriplate grease [5].
____  12.
As viewed from the top of the tool assembly, make three clockwise twists
in the wire harness, align the 32-socket female WTS connector [14] with
the top of the topsub [9], and insert the 32-socket female WTS connector
into the topsub.
____  13.
Lock the 32-socket WTS connector [14] into the topsub [9] with the
retainer ring [15]. Use the retaining ring tool [23] to install the retaining
ring.
____  14.
Apply Lubriplate grease [5] to the threads of the top thread protector [1]
and install.
____  15.
Install the O-Ring [12] onto the OD of the bottom thread protector [2].
Apply Lubriplate grease to the O-Ring and the threads and install.

INTRODUCTION
This procedure provides the step-by-step instruction necessary to perform a thorough test of
the 1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray Instrument, P/N 131127-000.
Other important things to remember are:
•
A measurement in which lead polarity is important is indicated by positive (+) and
negative (−) symbols.
•
Continuity is assumed to be ≤ 1.0 ohm during all continuity testing unless otherwise
specified.
•
If any measurement is out of tolerance, do not proceed to the next step until the problem
has been found and repaired.

CONTINUITY AND RESISTANCE CHECKS
Perform all insulation checks with a Megger. Perform all continuity checks with the DMM
set in the relative (REL) mode. The REL setting will null the resistance of the test leads. After
deducting test-lead resistance, continuity is defined as ≤ 1.0 Ω. Open is defined as ≥ 40 MΩ.

the following checks.

topic: Repair / Maintenance Procedures - 6.2 HIGH VOLTAGE CHECK AND GAIN ADJUSTMENT.............................................11
chunk_text:
HIGH VOLTAGE CHECK AND GAIN ADJUSTMENT11
6.2.1
HIGH VOLTAGE CHECK AND GAIN ADJUSTMENT
Any individual(s) directly handling nuclear sources must be fully qualified and
thoroughly familiar with the RADIOLOGICAL SAFETY procedures.
Build Variable Resistor
If you do not have an assembled variable resistor, build one at this time.
1.
Cut two 2.0-inch 20-gauge wires and solder them to the variable resistor (P/N
N730-000-700) as shown in Figure 6. Slide a piece of 0.125-inch shrink tubing
over each solder connections and shrink in place. Do not use another type (part
number) of variable resistor or use wires lengths longer than 2.0-inches. DO NOT
twist wires.



2.
Solder the free-wire ends to clip leads. See Figure 6.
3.
Connect a DMM to the clip leads and use a small screwdriver to adjust the
resistance of the variable resistor to ~50 kΩ. Set aside the assembled variable
resistor until needed.
131127-956 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
12
1330 XA 175 C No Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

6.2.2
High Voltage Check and Gain Adjustment
All tests performed in this section will be performed on the gamma ray PCBA
(A3001033000). Normally, gain adjustments are done on aged PM tubes and crystals, or
after replacing the PM tube and crystal.
Keep all unauthorized personnel away. Only the person directly involved with
source handling should be in the immediate area. All other personnel remain clear.
Post the appropriate warning signs.
1.
Connect the J6 connector.
2.
Turn on power to the tool and allow voltage to stabilize (~10 seconds)
3.
Use a high-voltage probe to verify that the voltage measured between E7 (HV) and
E9 (AGND) is 1,360 Vdc ±10 Vdc.
4.
Turn off tool power.
5.
Set up the oscilloscope as shown in Figure 7 and as follows:
•
set trigger to channel 1, -1 Vdc, negative edge, normal mode
•
set channel 1 for 1 V/div and 1 µs/div,
•
and set scope in infinite persistence mode (may be called analog persistence on
some digital scopes).



DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
13
1330 XA 175 C No Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

6.
Connect the channel 1 scope probe to TP1 (E12) and the ground probe to E13 on
the gamma ray PCBA.
7.
Turn off all other scope channels.
8.
Turn on tool power.
9.
Place a cesium-137 lab source (145920-004) close to the center of the scintillation
crystal (~8.5-inches from the bottom end of the downhole snorkel [8,
A3001562000]).
10.
Clear analog persistence traces.
11.
After 10 to 20 seconds the scope display should show a well defined band amongst
the background scatter as shown in Figure 7. This is the cesium peak. Use the
center of this band as your measure point for the rest of this procedure.
12.
Adjust channel 1 level so that the voltage before the pulse is even with a division
line. The cesium peak should be two divisions below the baseline (peak amplitude
of 2 V).
13.
Use the following gain adjustment procedure to adjust the gain if the cesium peak
is less than 1.8 V in amplitude.

Note: If the peak is greater than 2.4 V, determine the cause and repair before proceeding.


A. Remove the resistor currently installed between terminals E14 and E15 of the
gamma ray PCBA.
B. Connect the variable resistor between terminals E14 and E15 of the gamma ray
PCBA as shown in Figure 8.
C. Clear the persistence traces periodically after making gain adjustments, or if
the screen gets cluttered. Wait 10 to 20 seconds for traces to become well
defined as shown in Figure 7.
D. While monitoring the scope, adjust the variable resistor with a small
screwdriver until the center of the cesium peak is 2.0 volts.

Note: This is a multi-turn potentiometer, so its response will be slow. Turn the adjusting screw
clockwise to decrease the pulse height and counterclockwise to increase the pulse height.


14.
Once the cesium peak is adjusted to 2.0 volts, turn off tool power and remove the
variable resistor from the gamma ray PCBA.
131127-956 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
14
1330 XA 175 C No Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Repair / Maintenance Procedures



15.
Use a DMM to measure the resistance of the variable resistor. If the resistance is
less than 500 ohms, determine the cause and repair before proceeding. Otherwise,
select a RN55 resistor from the following table with the closest standard value to
the variable resistor resistance value.

131127-956 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006

1330 XA 175 C No Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

16.

not the correct value.
17.
Install and solder the resistor between E14 and E15 on the gamma ray PCBA.
18.
Use an approved cleaner to remove excess flux and inspect the board area around
the resistor and terminals for solder splashes and other contaminants.
19.
Turn on tool power and verify that the cesium peak is 2.0 V ±0.2 V.
20.
If the cesium peak is >2.2 V, remove the currently installed resistor and replace it
with the next higher value resistor from the table above. If the cesium peak is
<1.8 V, remove the currently installed resistor and replace it with the next lower
value resistor from the table above. Repeat this step until the correct peak voltage is
obtained.
21.
Turn off tool power and disconnect scope leads.
22.
Return the cesium source to its shielded storage container and return to storage.
Source will not be needed for remainder of this test procedure.

ACQUIRE MODE 2 DATA

desktop.

panel to the uphole end of the 1330 XA instrument.

Note: Power should be applied through the 4509 XA Panel using the power cable (F156144011)
from J2 on the 4509 XA to the appropriate connector on the 2020/2021 AC power supply.

DEC 2006

16

12.

topic: Repair / Maintenance Procedures - 6.5 VERIFYING AND UPDATING TABLES...................................................................19
chunk_text:
VERIFYING AND UPDATING TABLES
Verify and update calibration tables each time you calibrate the 1330 XA. Update the
hardware rev table after replacing the PM tube, crystal, gamma ray PCBA, or
updating gamma ray firmware.
1.
Right click Calibration Data Table in the Documents pane. See Figure 12.




DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
20
1330 XA 175 C No Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

2.
Select Manage from the pull-down menu.
3.
A Calibration Data Table dialog box will open.
4.
Clear all VALUE fields shown in Figure 13.
5.
Click the From Tool button and confirm that all data is correct. Click the Exit
button.




6.
Right click Hardware Rev Table in the Documents pane. Select Manage from
the pull-down menu.
131127-956 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
21
1330 XA 175 C No Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Repair / Maintenance Procedures

7.
A Hardware Rev Table will open. Enter any instrument information outlined in
the rectangle that has changed in the appropriate VALUE field and then click the
To Tool button. See Figure 14.



8.
Clear all VALUE fields located inside the rectangle in Figure 14.
9.
Click the From Tool button and confirm that tool information you entered
reappears and is correct. Click the Exit button.

HEAT TEST
Remember, heat testing degrades the PM tube and crystal. Do not heat test the 1330 XA
unless it is required for a high-temperature job.
1.
Place the instrument on high temperature tool stands in the oven. Route the WTS
Instrument test cable (A3000332000) so that it cannot be damaged by closing the
oven door.
2.
Use a thermometer to measure the temperature in the oven. Place the probe from
the thermometer in the center of the oven and close the oven door.
3.
Turn on the 4509 XA test panel and the computer.
4.

1330 XA Preventative Maintenance Level 1 Checklist

1. Mechanical Checks:  
   Can also be performed at the wellsite. 
 
Step 
Action 
Initials 
1. 
Verify instrument model and equipment/serial numbers are legible. 
______ 
2. 
Thoroughly clean the instrument.  
______ 
3. 
Visually inspect threads and exterior surface for signs of damage and/or wear. 
______ 
4. 
Check top and bottom connectors for moisture, debris, misaligned, broken or 
worn pins, worn or damaged sockets and deformed retaining rings. Ensure top 
and bottom connector retaining rings are in place. Clean the top connector and 
bottom bulkhead with solvent. 
______ 
5. 
Check integrity of sockets in the Uphole connector using Test Gage F181967000 
or WTS Pin contact F189564000. 
______ 
6. 
Remove used O-rings from uphole end of tool with brass O-ring extractor tool. 
Cut and discard used O-rings. Clean O-ring grooves with solvent. Inspect O-ring 
grooves for dust, dirt, scratches; pitting, or corrosion. They shall not have any 
damage or condition which can cause seal failure. Apply Lubriplate 930 AA in O-
ring grooves. 
 
NOTICE 
RISK OF DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT. DO NOT USE a 
screwdriver to remove O-rings it will scratch the O-ring 
groove. Use brass O-ring extractor tool. 
 
______ 
7. 
Inspect new O-rings for defects and then apply a light coating of Lubriplate 
930 AA around O-rings then install O-rings on top sub. 
______ 
8. 
CHECK FOR RESIDUAL MAGNETISM.  
Use MAGNETOMETER F234256000 to check for magnetism by holding the 
magnetometer against and perpendicular to the instrument, then slowly move 
the magnetometer along the length of the instrument. The housing and subs 
should not exceed ± 3 gauss within 12” of PM tube and should not exceed ± 10 
gauss for the rest of the instrument. If readings are out of tolerance, instrument 
should be sent to lab to be demagnetized. 
 
NOTICE 
RISK OF DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT.  
Do not demagnetize the housing with electronics installed. 
 
______ 
9. 
Check that all subs are torqued to prevent accidental “backing off”. The timing 
marks on the Top and/or Bottom Sub should be close to or go past the Pressure 
Housing timing mark.  Do NOT back off sub to make alignment marks match !!! 
______

1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Level 3 PM 
PROCEDURE
This procedure should be performed on the 1330 XA every 6 months, or as needed.
____  1.
Gather and inventory parts against Level 3 PM Parts list 131127-843.
____  2.
Thoroughly clean the entire OD of the tool with the thread protectors
installed.
____  3.
Remove the thread protectors.
____  4.
Remove the electronics chassis / gamma ray module and bottom 32-pin
female bulkhead connector from the pressure housing as instructed in the
Disassembly / Assembly section (131127-955) of this manual.
____  5.
Remove and discard all O-rings. Replace with new O-rings.
____  6.
Inspect all wiring for nicks, cuts, pinholes or abrasion. Check the wiring for
electrical leakage and continuity. Refer to A3001561 WRD. Replace all
defective wiring with new wires.
____  7.
Inspect all electrical connectors for damage: chips, cracks, water absorption,
broken contacts, corroded contacts or gas-cut. Check for electrical leakage
and continuity. Replace any electrical connectors that are not fit for service in
the downhole environment.
____  8.
Inspect all mechanical parts for evidence of damage, wear, and corrosion on
critical O-ring seal surfaces and threads. Replace parts that show excessive
wear, damage, or are otherwise unfit for use.
____  9.
Check high voltage power supply and if necessary adjust the gain per the
High Voltage and Gain Adjustment section of Repair / Maintenance section
131127-956.
____  10.
Reassemble the instrument as instructed in the Disassembly / Assembly
Procedure section (131127-955) of this manual.
131127-953 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas
3
1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS Gamma Ray – Level 3 PM


____  11.
Set up the Lab PC Test System as shown in Figure 1. Start test system
software.


____  12.
Perform the tests found in the Final Test section of the Maintenance / Repair
section (131127-956) of this manual.
____  13.
Verify the G/R using instructions in the Gamma Ray Calibration section of
the Maintenance / Repair section of this manual.
