topic: Level 3 Preventive Maintenance - 5.0 LEVEL 3 PM CHECKLIST

chunk_text:
INTRODUCTION
High voltage and neutron radiation are both present in the 1330 XA 175 C No-Flask WTS
Gamma Ray Instrument at various times. Both are discussed in the following paragraphs
along with some general safety guidelines for safe handling of the tool.

ELECTRICAL SAFETY PRECAUTIONS
High voltage (≥1,350 Vdc) is present at various points on the electronics chassis when
the pressure housing is removed and power is applied to the instrument. The following
precautions apply.
•
Clear the area of all non-essential personnel and post the appropriate electrical
warning signs.
•
Never leave the tool unattended while power is on.
•
Turn off power to the tool if it not necessary to the task being performed.
RADIATION SAFETY PRECAUTIONS
At times a low-yield gamma ray source is used in the lab environment. The following
safety precautions apply.
•
Sources should only be handled by personnel that are trained in radiation safety.
•
Store sources in their correct storage container when not in use.
•
Clear the area of all personnel not directly involved in the installation, removal, or
other activities involving the nuclear source.
•
Post the appropriate warning signs and visual indicators when sources are out of their
storage containers.
•
Remember, radiation exposure is directly related to exposure time and distance from
the source.
GENERAL SAFETY GUIDELINES
Follow the general safety guidelines listed below when handling the 1330 XA.
•
Observe proper lifting techniques when handling this instrument.
•
Thread protectors should always be installed when transporting or handling the tool.
•
Steel-toe shoes must be worn while handling the tool assembly.
•
Wear safety glasses when soldering
•
Where static-guard wristbands when working around electronics

131127-954 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas

INTRODUCTION
Refer to the Heat Test section of Repair Maintenance document 131127-956, which is located
in this 1330 XA manual.
131127-959 / 1330 XA
DEC 2006
Baker Atlas

1
1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL -- DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
P/N 130363-936
JUNE 1998
1
INTRODUCTION
The 1424 Segmented Bond Tool (SBT), used with the 1633 EA Acoustic Electronics, is a unique cement
bond logging tool.  The SBT can find and define channels in the cement annulus which could result in a poor
hydraulic seal.  Conversely, the SBT can reliably find zones of uniform bonding over only a few feet of
casing.  Under conditions where a short bonded interval produces an adequate hydraulic seal, unnecessary
squeeze jobs can be avoided.
The SBT quantitatively measures the quality of the cement bond in six angular segments around the casing. 
The tool utilizes acoustic transducers mounted on six pads to make  compensated acoustic attenuation
measurements which are not affected by mud weight, gas cut, fast formation effects, casing surface conditions
or moderate tool excentering.  
The six angular measurements made over casing sectors allow one to distinguish clearly between two
situations:
-
a strong cement bond over a portion of the casing circumference resulting in hydraulic communication
between zones
-or-
-
a moderately strong cement bond completely around the casing resulting in a good hydraulic seal.
Conventional bond tools or bond tools which rely on point measurements yield ambiguous results in this
regard.  (See Figure 936-1.)  Since the measurement is quantitative,  conventional interpretative procedures
can be directly applied to the data.
Figure 936-1  Ambiguous Results from Conventional Bond Tools
2
1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL -- DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
P/N 130363-936
JUNE 1998
Figure 936-2  Unfolded Pad Configuration
2
TOOL CONFIGURATION
The attenuation of sound along the casing has long been used as a reliable indication of cement-to-casing
bond.  The SBT utilizes sonic transducers mounted on six pads to make a compensated measurement of the
bond condition in six azimuthal segments around the casing.  Because the transducers are mounted on pads,
the measurement is unaffected by gas in the borehole, fast formations, or heavy mud conditions.  Exact
centering is not required.  Figure 936-2 shows the pad configuration unfolded.
A separate unit provides a "steered-beam" VDL.  Two transmitters, one fired immediately after the other,
enhance the amount of energy available (in the direction of the receiver) to produce a better definition of
pipe-to-cement and cement-to-formation interface.  Hence interpretation of the VDL is easier.
Two accelerometers determine the low point of the well.  If the tool is perfectly vertical the reading is
ambiguous, but this seldom happens.  If the deviation is 1 degree, the orientation can be determined to within

STEERED TRANSDUCERS
The SBT employs "steered" acoustic transducers techniques to enhance the sound output of both the pad
transmitters and the VDL transmitter.  
The sound power a transducer can radiate is directly proportional to the area of the transducer; bigger
transducers put out more sound.  If, on the other hand, a transducer dimension is larger than 1/4 wavelength
at the frequency of interest, the radiation pattern of the transducer is no longer ommidirectional and it may not
put out an adequate sound level in the direction required.
A way to increase the sound output and at the same time control the directional characteristics of the
transducer is to use two transmitting elements, each 1/4 wavelength long.  In operation,  the first element
furthest from the desired sound is fired.  The second element is fired when the sound from the first element
passes the second element.  The sound is reinforced in the desired direction.  (See Figure 936-3.)  Because the
sound intensity varies as the square of the amplitude, the effective sound power is increase by a factor of four.
The VDL is particularly enhanced by this technique.  Interpretation of the VDL is simplified.  VDL are often

1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL -- DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
P/N 130363-936
JUNE 1998
FIGURE 936-3; Sound Reinforcement with Two Transmitting Elements
4
COMPENSATED MEASUREMENT
The attenuation in each segment is measured in two directions using a pair of acoustic receivers and two
transmitters.  The two measurements are combined to form a compensated result which does not depend on
the receiver sensitivities or transmitter output power.  The attenuation measurement has a dynamic range of
22 dB/ft and is fully compensated over the entire range.
5
SPREADING LOSSES 
Because of the geometry of the transducer arrangement, the sound level at the near receiver is higher than the
level at the far receiver even if there is no attenuation.  As shown in Figure 936-5, the acoustic power present
at cross sections A and B is the same, but since B has a larger area the acoustic intensity or power per unit
area is smaller at B than at A.  This effect is called spreading loss and is a consequence only of the geometry
of the tool.  This effect is removed mathematically from the measurement before the attenuations are
presented.
The SBT is controlled by the 1633 EA Common Acoustic Cartridge.  The downhole computer and digital
telemetry system within the 1633 EA ensures that the data is unaffected by the wireline.  Any of the
waveforms can be digitized downhole and displayed at the surface.
The SBT is 3-3/8 inches in diameter, and can run at 350 F and 20,000 psi.  Casings between 4-1/2 and 16
o
inches can be logged.  Deviations to 90 degrees have been logged. 
4
1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL -- DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
P/N 130363-936
JUNE 1998
Figure 936-4; Compensated Attenuation Measurement
Figure 936-5; Spreading Loss Effect

1
1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL -- MECHANICAL DESCRIPTION
P/N 130363-946 
JUNE 1998
1
SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
The 1424 Segmented Bond Tool is housed in a 3.38-diameter, 18-foot mandrel.  Six pairs of articulated arms
hold the pads that contain the acoustic transducers.  Springs at each end of the arms lift the pads and press
them against the casing wall.  A DC  motor located at the downhole end of the mandrel actuates a pull rod that
opens and closes the tool.  
A fluid-to-air bulkhead sub connects the pad section to the electronics section.  The electronics chassis is
mounted onto the bulkhead.   A second bulkhead sub connects the pad section to the motor section.
The SBT is designed to operate in casing from 4.5 to 16 inches in diameter.  The tool body and housings are
constructed of titanium.  A Shear Screw connects the center portion of the mandrel to the bottom of the tool. 
In the event the tool gets stuck in the casing, shearing this screw causes the arms to collapse.  Pulling the
wireline with a force exceeding the strength of the Shear Screw snaps the screw, allowing the arms to close and
frees the tool.
The top and bottom field joints are WTS 32-pin connectors, but only nine conductors are available at the
bottom joint.  Five of these wires drive the VDL sub; the remaining four were provided in the event some

1424 PA VDL SUB FOR 1424 SBT
The VDL Sub (PN 130401) for the SBT is 3.38 inches in diameter and 8 feet long.
The acoustic transducers (receiver and transmitters) are housed inside thin wall cylinders and spaced 5 feet
apart. The transducer housings are connected by a wire tube. 
The tool is oil filled and pressure compensated by a floating piston, located between the receiver and
transmitters.  The top and bottom tool joints are WTS compatible (32-pin connectors). A slotted housing
protects the transmitters/receiver assembly.
The VDL sub is designed to work exclusively with the Segmented Bond tool.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                1424XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL 1.0 INTRODUCTION
chunk_text:
1
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
CONFIDENTIAL                                     P/N 130363-945                                      JANUARY 2009 
INTRODUCTION
The upper head of the Segmented Bond Tool is a standard 32-pin WTS connector designed to connect
only to the 1633 Common Acoustic Cartridge.

The SBT has only two outputs--UREC and LREC--which connect to the A/D converters of the 1633
Common Cartridge. The UREC line carries the analog output of the upper pad receivers of the tool.
The LREC is a misnomer in that, in addition to the lower pad receiver signals, the VDL and X and Y
Accelerometer signals are also multiplexed on this line.

A digital data line, a clock line, and a latch line serially transfer digital data to the SBT from the
Common Cartridge. An additional line allows firing of the SBT transmitters by the Common Cartridge.
These are further explained below.

The wireline passes through a choke in the Common Cartridge to prevent any interference to the
telemetry communication by the tools below the common. This line, termed "filtered 150" or 150 VF,
is used in the SBT and passed through to the bottom of the SBT for use by tools below the SBT.

Two WTS, PCM communication lines are also routed through the tool for control of tools below the
SBT.

Seven circuit boards are employed in the SBT. These are described in the following paragraphs.
The descriptions are intended to be used together with the circuit diagrams included in FIELD
REFERENCE DRAWINGS AND BILL OF MATERIALS P/N 130363-975 or 130627-975

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 2.0 POWER SUPPLY BOARD P/N 142765-000
chunk_text:
POWER SUPPLY BOARD P/N 142765-000

The power supply board converts the 150 V filtered line voltage to 300 volts for the transmitters and a
regulated 5, 15 and -15 volts for the SBT electronics.
When the power supply is first turned on, FET Q3 is on supplying 7-10 volts to buffer U1 and Flip-Flop U2.
A section of the buffer, R3, and C4 form an 80-kHz oscillator. The Flip-Flop divides the frequency by two
and produces two symmetrical, out-of-phase square waves at U2-1 and U2-2. These voltages drive the push-
pull power circuit (Q1 and Q2) producing a 300-volt square wave at their drains.

The bridge CR3-CR6 supplies ±18 volts to voltage regulators U3 and U4. The secondary of the supply is
floating at analog ground. If the board is being checked out when disconnected from the tool, care must be
taken to ground the AGND terminal. +5 V is regulated down by VR1 from voltage divider formed with R13
and R14.

When the output voltages are established, the +15 volts is feedback via CR8 to supply U1 and U2. The -15
volts via R12 turns off FET Q3 and prevents power dissipation in R13.

The transformer is used as an auto-transformer to generate the 300 volts (150-volt line voltage plus a 150
volt boost). CR1, CR2, C1, C2, and R2 shape the waveform and suppress spikes.

R1 and L1 keep the switching voltage off the 150-volt line and hence provide noise suppression and prevent
interference with the telemetry system.

CR9 disconnects the supply if the line voltage is negative.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                1424XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL 3.0 CAPACITOR BOARD P/N 148434-000
chunk_text:
2
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
CONFIDENTIAL                                     P/N 130363-945                                      JANUARY 2009 
CAPACITOR BOARD P/N 148434-000

The capacitor board contains the two firing capacitors for the "now" and "delayed" VDL transmitters.
C1 A, B, C, D are wired in parallel to collectively form a 2-µF cap for the "now" transmitter. Similarly
C2 A, B, C, D are used for the delayed transmitter. These capacitors are charged from the 300-volt
supplies via R1 and R2 and are discharged at the firings.

R3 and R4 are the charging resistors for Pad firing caps C3 and C4 (which are two 1-µF tubular caps,
mounted on the chassis).

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 4.0 RECEIVER BOARD P/N 184286-000 4.1 PREAMPLIFIERS
chunk_text:
RECEIVER BOARD P/N 184286-000 
PREAMPLIFIERS

The receiver board has seven identical preamplifiers. These are hybrid, balanced input, instrumentation
opamps configured for a gain of 20. The coupling cap and resistor at their output provides a low
frequency roll-off at 15 kHz.

Preamplifiers U2, U3, U4 are used for the three upper pad receivers. One of these is selected by the analog
switch U5. This output is filtered by the two-pole 110-kHz filter (U13 A) and buffered by U13 B to provide
the upper pad receiver output UREC to the Common Cartridge. The total gain from input to output of the
receiver board is 100. The 15-volt logic levels require at U5 to select each of the receivers is shown on
identical to that of the upper pad receivers except that the output is fed to the multiplexer U12 instead of
being sent directly to the Common Cartridge.

Preamplifier U1 is used for the VDL receiver. The output is rolled off at about 30 kHz by the amplifier
U10 A and additional high-pass filtering is provided by U10 B to prevent road noise from interfering with
the VDL signal. The output of U10 is also routed to the U12 multiplexer.

MULTIPLEXERS

Multiplexer U16 is used to either route the output of the X and Y accelerometers to U17 or to short the
inputs of U17 to ground for calibration purposes. U17 A and B, in combination with C3 and C4 mounted
on the chassis, integrate (low-pass filter) the outputs of the accelerometers. The integration time is about
0.1 seconds.

The LREC multiplexer (U12) is used to select:
(1)
the VDL,
(2)
a lower pad receiver,
(3)
or one of the accelerometer channels

to send to the Common Cartridge.

SHIFT REGISTERS

The logic code is received from the Common Cartridge via U14 and U15. The input data (D IN) read
into these two shift registers at each clock pulse (CLK). When 16 bits have been shifted in, the Latch line
is pulsed by the Common Cartridge and the bits are latched. This process is repeated for each firing and
at each read of the accelerometers.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                1424XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
chunk_text:
3
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
CONFIDENTIAL                                     P/N 130363-945                                      JANUARY 2009

U15 also decodes the three bits (SEL0, SEL1 or SEL2) used to select: 1) one of 6 pad transmitters,
2) the VDL transmitter, or 3) no transmitter. The resistor network is provided to reduce the levels to
5 volt for the transmitter board and to provide places to short these bits to ground for test purposes.

Motor control signals M0 and M1 are also supplied by U15. These signals must be held in a disabled
state during initial power on, or when the 1633 EA cartridge is not connected to the tool. U18 disables
the outputs of U15 (selects tri-state high impedance output) when the 1633 EA is not connected to the
SBT, or during initial power on (LATCH from the 1633 EA is high during the first five to seven
seconds on power on)

A complete logic chart is shown in Figure 945-1.


VDL TRANSDUCER DRIVER BOARD P/N 148793-000

The VDL driver board has two identical high-level output circuits consisting of FET's Q2 and Q4 and
their respective drivers Q1 and Q3. In operation, the VDL capacitors located on the capacitor board are
discharged through Q2 or Q4 and the transducer transformers to provide the 300-volt pulses necessary
to drive the VDL transformers (VDL PRIM HI NOW and VDL PRIM HI DLY).

The input fire pulse for the VDL transmitter is routed to one-shot delay U2, which produces the 25-µs
pulse width necessary to drive the "now" element of the VDL transducer (XDUCER).

The input fire pulse also goes to another one-shot (U3) which generates the delayed fire pulse. After the
12µs delay, the second half of U3 generates the 25-µs pulse required to drive the "delayed" element of the
VDL transducer.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                1424XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
chunk_text:
4
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS                                                1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
CONFIDENTIAL                                     P/N 130363-945                                      JANUARY 2009

Resistors (R7 and R9) and test points (VDL-N and VDL-D) are provided to allow shorting either the
"now" or the "delayed" pulse for test purposes. The VDL output should drop at least 30% when either
is shorted.

Also located on this board are the one-shots (U1 and a section of U2) that produce the 5-µs pulses for
both the "now" and delayed pad transducers (PAD NOW PLS and PAD DLY PLS).

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 6.0 PAD TRANSDUCER DRIVER BOARD P/N 148794-000
chunk_text:
PAD TRANSDUCER DRIVER BOARD P/N 148794-000

The Pad Transducer Driver board contains twelve identical high-level driver circuits to drive both the
inner and outer ("delayed" and "now") transducer stacks on each of the six pads. The circuits are arranged
so that the 300 VDC, used to charge Pad Transmitter capacitors C2 and C1 (mounted on the chassis), is
not constantly on the wiring which must be in the mud. The high-level FET's (the IRF740) are each driven
by the lower level FET's (the IRFD120's) through coupling transformers.

Two 3-to-8 decoder chips (U1 and U2) select the transmitter by decoding SEL0, SEL1, and SEL2 (XMSO,
XMS1, XMS2). One chip is used for the "now" transmitter and the other for the "delayed" transmitter. The
output of these chips is enabled for 5 µs each firing by the PAD NOW PULSE and the PAD DLY PULSE
from the VDL driver board. Figure 945-1 shows the logic for the decoder chips. Basically the chips select:
1) one of the six pads, 2) the VDL transmitter, or 3) no transmitter.

Resistors R2 and R3 and test points PAD-N and PAD-D are provided to allow shorting the fire pulses for
testing purposes.

MOTOR CONTROL BOARDS P/N 154444-000 & P/N 154445-000

The motor control boards have two virtually identical circuits consisting of three FETS to control the
application of power and ground to the motor. Circuit board 1 (P/N 154444-000) contains the additional
logic to prevent both the open and close control signals from becoming active (high) at the same time.
When signals M0 and M1 are both low (ground), the output pins 3 and 4 of IC1 are both low. When
signals M0 and M1 are both high, output pins 3 and 4 of IC1 are both low. Diodes D8 and D9 insure that
one of the control lines (M0 or M1) must be low before allowing a high output from either IC1-4 or IC1-3.

A high signal on IC1-4 will allow Q3 to conduct to supply ground through switch S1 to the MOT2
connection of the motor. The same high signal from IC1-4 is delayed about 2 millisecond by R4 & C2
before applying the 150 V power through Q1 to the MOT1 connection of the motor. The motor will now
run until the upper limit switch S1 is opened.

The motor control circuits should be returned to the idle or neutral state before sending a close command
to the tool. When the close command is issued, IC1-3 goes high. This signal is connected to Motor Control
Board 2 (P/N 154445-000) and controls the FETS Q4, Q5, and Q6 just as the open signal controlled the
FETS Q1, Q2, and Q3 on board one. Diode D1 protects the board from havings a negative voltage applied
to it. D2 zener supplies the 15 volt reference for the M0 and M1 input logic circuits.

The motor circuits can be operated from a motor control box (P/N 154455-000) plugged into the tool
downhole connector as long as the 1633 EA common is not connected to the tool at the same time. The motor
control box supplies the 150 VDC Power and applies ground to the control line it does not want to activated.
This is done because without the 1633 EA connected the shift register output on the receiver board is in the
tri-state output condition. The control lines M0 and M1 are both high impedance outputs.

FINAL ASSEMBLY OPERATION

For the following (unless otherwise stated), refer to drawings R149158 and C149160.

1.
Finish wiring the tool according to schematic drawing C149160.  Connect the wires to their respective
feed-thru terminals at the top and bottom bulkheads.

2.
Install wire covers [13] and [14] into the slots of upper and lower slotted housings.

3.
After the tool is wired a check on the adjustments of the motor limit switches must be made.  The tool
can be controlled via the PCM test system or by a motor control box from the bottom of the tool.  Adjust
the microswitch actuator pins as follows:

CAUTION
PERFORM THIS OPERATION VERY CAREFULLY TO PREVENT ANY
DAMAGE TO THE LINKAGES OR MOTOR DRIVE PARTS.

-
Motor the tool until the arms are fully closed.  Move the pin until the microswitch is actuated.
Microswitch must be actuated as soon as the pads are closed.

-
Motor the tool open and adjust the other pin until it actuates the microswitch.  The microswitch must be
actuated before the crossover [12] hits the 12-pin bulkhead.

4.
Slide the pressure housing [item 42 on R149154] over the motor assembly and screw onto the 12-pin
bulkhead.

5.
Fish the bottom connector [45 on R149154] through the bore of bottom sub [46 on R149154].  Screw
the sub onto the housing approximately 1 turn.  Connect the 32-pin connector onto the 32-pin bulkhead
[47 on R149154].  Unscrew the bottom sub and insert the 32-pin bulkhead into the bore of it until the
32-pin connector is into the small bore at the top of the sub.  While holding the 32-pin bulkhead with
one hand to prevent its rotation, screw the sub into the pressure housing until it shoulders.   Remove
your hand and insert the installation tool [62] and finish installing the 32-pin bulkhead.

Note

The alignment mark on the sub must align with the key of the 32-pin bulkhead.

6.
Once the bulkhead is in place install the retaining ring [57] using modified pliers [64].

7.
Perform the final checkout.

8.
Pack the top and bottom bulkhead cavities until the boots are covered with silicone grease [4], wrap with
kapton tape and install the split covers [3] and [12] with screws [2].

9.
Screw the pressure housing [4] to the bulkhead.  Screw the top sub assembly [6] on to the tool.  Install
the black Airborn connector and secure with snap ring [2].

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XA) - 2.2 ASSEMBLY AND WIRING FOR 12-PIN BULKHEAD/MOTOR SECTION
chunk_text:
2.2   ASSEMBLY AND WIRING FOR 12-PIN BULKHEAD/MOTOR SECTION
1.
Crimp a terminal [69] to each pressure feed-thru [8] and attach a wire 60 inches long to the crimp
terminals per wire list.  Slide a piece of shrink tubing over the connections.
2.
Lubricate the O-rings of each pressure feed-thru and install them into the respective holes on the 12-pin
bulkhead [7], per wiring schematic. Feed the wires through holes of the 12-pin bulkhead.  TAKE CARE
NOT TO DAMAGE THE WIRES.
3.
Install the insulator weldment [9] inside the bulkhead and secure in place with retaining ring [56].
TAKE CARE NOT TO DAMAGE THE WIRES.
4.
Install O-rings [10] onto 12-pin bulkhead.  Lubricate O-rings and glands with Lubriplate grease.
5.
Screw the motor assembly into the 12-pin bulkhead and tighten using a spanner wrench.
6.
Route the wires into the slots on the threaded portion of the bulkhead and--while holding the wires below
the root diameter of the threads--fill the slots with RTV adhesive [51].  Let adhesive cure, and clean any
excess that might have flowed over the threads.
7.
Install the motor control boards [40 and 61] using eight screws [39], eight washers [20], and Loctite
[50].
8.
Connect the wires to the micro switches per wiring schematic C149160.
9.
Route all the wires from the bulkhead over the o.d. of the shroud, through the slots on the bearing
housing and motor sleeve.  Hold wires in place with Kapton tape or RTV where necessary.
10. Connect wires to the motor control boards using hi-temp solder [54].
11. Install gland nut [41] onto lower flange of motor chassis weldment [37].
12. Feed all remaining wires through the gland nut and make a pigtail using expandable sleeve [70].  Wrap a
few turns of silicone tape over the sleeve at each end.  Cut the wires approximately 2 inches past the
bottom sub [46] (approximately 14 inches from the gland nut).  Strip wires and crimp onto the pins of
the bottom connector [45].  Insert pins into connector body per wiring diagram.  Put all pins into the
connector body (32 total).
13. Install the O-rings [4] over the seal bushing [66]. Lubricate O-rings and bushing surfaces with
Lubriplate grease [55].
14. Install backup rings [6] and O-ring [5] into the seal bushing [66].  Install seal retainer [3] and secure in
place with screws [2].
15. Install backup rings [6] and O-ring [5] into the bore at the top end of 12-pin bulkhead.
16. Screw seal bushing, previously assembled, into 12-pin bulkhead until it is firmly tight.

and install pull rod [1] through seal bushing bore VERY CAREFULLY TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO
THE O-RINGS, and thread into the crossover [12].  Tighten the pull rod applying torque to it with a flat

5.
Insert the internal linkage--the one with the hanger [2] attached to it--into the top slotted housing [16]
and thread until the hanger [2] bottoms.  Back off approximately 1/4 turn, until the slot in the hanger [2]
can be seen through the last set screw hole in the top slotted housing [16].  Install a set screw [1] using
Loctite [39] and tighten. (Figure 955-38.)


Insert the other internal linkage into the bottom slotted housing [32]. Note orientation in Figure 955-39.


Screw the motor section previously assembled into the bottom slotted housing.  Pull rod must be inserted
into the coupler [35 on R149155] and slider [34 on R149155] while turning the motor section.  Note:
The motor must be in the open position to connect the coupler.
8.
Once the motor section is fully threaded back it off until the slot in the threads of the 12-pin bulkhead
aligns with the threaded holes on the slotted housing.  Install screws [8 on Dwg. R149158] using Loctite
and tighten.
9.
Install set screw [11 on Dwg. R149158] into coupler to secure pull rod to the slider.  Use Loctite to

1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL -- DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES



3.5 ASSEMBLY OF PAD, ARM, and LINK
The parts needed for this assembly are shown in Figure 955-40.  All parts, except transducer housing, should
be thoroughly cleaned in varsol prior to assembly.


Thread the set screw [19] into the pivot [12] using Loctite [39].  Insert the link [4] into the slot in the arm
[20]. Place the pivot [12] into the opening, note the orientation, and tighten set screw [19] using the
access hole located behind the link [4].  (Figure 955-41.)  Do this for all 12 assemblies.  Not required by
level III maintenance if the arm and link are not disassembled.



1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL -- DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES

1.
The arm assembly, constructed in step 1 of section 3.5, can now be connected to the transducer housing
[24].  This assembly should be laid out prior to connecting the transducer. (Fig. 955-42.)


Install the large pin [21] into the transducer housing [24] and through the arm [20] until the 0.078-inch
diameter cross hole aligns with the hole on the center of the arm.  DO NOT   install roll pin [51] through
the arm and pin at this time.  Do this for all six assemblies.  Take care not to damage the wires.
3.
(Refer to Dwg. C-149160) Note:  When installing boots over pressure terminals, fill the boot with
silicone grease to ensure no air is trapped inside the boot.  Install boots and connectors on one end of a
3-conductor cable and on one end of the 2-conductor cable.  Plug them into the three pressure terminals
located on the transmitter side, and the 2 pressure terminals located on the receiver side.  (Figure 955-
43.)  Do this for the three identical assemblies.  Refer to Figure 955-44 for the other three assemblies.




1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL -- DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES


4.
The arm cover [48] can now be installed.  Make sure there is enough of a loop
between the arm [20] and transducer housing [24] so that the wire is never
under strain.  Once this has been achieved, fasten the arm cover [48] using
spacers [52] and the flat head screws [49] and Loctite [39].  (Figure 955-45.)
The spacers insure that the arm cover is not pinching the wires.

5.
The wire can now be run out of the arm [20] and thru the top of the link [4].
To install the tunnel [6], position the assembly as shown in Figure 955-46.
Insert the wire into the channels of the tunnel [6] and line up the holes in the
tunnel [6] with the holes in the link [4].  Fasten with flat head screws [47]
using Loctite [39].  Note that with the tunnel installed in the position
mentioned above, the wire can flex when the tool is finally operated.



Before beginning to install, make sure the tool is approximately 3 feet off of the bench, properly
supported and able to turn 360 degrees.

Align the slots in the yokes [14] and washers [7] with the slots in the top slotted housing [16]. The
position for the two sets of the these three pad assemblies will be determined by the flats on the
mandrel [18]. The long flats on the mandrel [18] will house the long side of the transducer
housing [24] and visa versa.

Insert the link part of the assembly into the correct slot and let the wire lay outside for the time being.

Install one transducer assembly arm in upper yoke and one transducer assembly arm in lower yoke.
Depress arm in the upper yoke so pad is in closed position.  The pad should lie in the flats of the
mandrel.  Distance from the end of the mandrel to the end of the arm should be 29 3/8 inches.  Perform
same test on arm in lower yoke.  The distance from end of the mandrel to end of the arm should be 37
3/4 inches.  If arm distances are not correct and the pads do not line up properly in the flats of the
mandrel the tool will not close completely.  The adjustment or setting made in section 3.2-12 will
have to be changed.  Also check the distance between the top of the upper (odd number) pad and
the top of lower (even number) pad.  The distance must be 8 3/8 inches, ± 1/16".  The distance
should be correct if the assembly of the internal linkage (section 3.2) was correctly performed.

16

1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL -- DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES



If the adjustment is correct, install the remaining four transducer housings on the tool.  Be sure to
orientate them properly so they will lie in the flats of the mandrel when the tool is closed.  Install the
yoke screw [15], using Loctite to secure the arm assemblies.

The six remaining arm and link assemblies can now be installed into the bottom slotted housing [32].
Align the linkage previously installed in the bottom slotted housing [32] by making sure the 3 slots in
yokes [14] and flanges [5] line up with the 3 slots in the bottom slotted housing [32].  (Figure 955-47.)


[15] by lightly compressing the spring to align hole in arm [20] with hole in yoke [14].  Tighten yoke
screw [15] using loctite [39].  (Figure 955-48.)  Repeat for all the slots in the bottom slotted housing.
Install the large pin [21] into the transducer housing [24] and through the arm [20] until the 0.078-inch
diameter cross hole aligns with the hole on the center of the arm.  Install roll pin [51] through the arm
and pin.  Do this to both ends of all six assemblies.



Thread the electronics bulkhead assembly [1] into the top slotted housing until it shoulders.  Then back
it off until the slot in the threads of the bulkhead aligns with the threaded holes on the top slotted
housing. Install three set screws [8] and tighten with Loctite.

Note
Notice that pad no. 1 Transmitter side is oriented toward the top of the tool.  Pad
no. 1 Wires will run in groove 1 which is stamped on the bulkhead.

17

1424 XA/XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL -- DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES


8.
Once the bulkhead has been installed, the remaining wire can now be run.
Use the short wire covers [45] for the short slots and the long wire covers [46]
for the long slots in the top slotted housing [16].  Insert the wire into the
channels of the covers.  Make sure that there is enough of a loop between the
tunnel [6] and the cover so the wire can flex freely upon tool operation.
(Figure 955-49).  Fasten the covers with screws [47] using Loctite [39].
Insure that there are no wires pinched under the wire covers when the covers
are screwed down.

9.
NOTE:  These two steps may performed after the final checkout to
insure there are no problems with the tool.  However, a check of all pads
must be made after the covers are installed to insure no wires were
pinched or shorted while mounting the covers.

After routing the wire, the transmitter cover [25] and the receiver cover [26]
can be installed using the flat head screws [23].  Make sure the wire is not
pinched in any way by the covers.  You may have to form the wire as it
exits the transducer housing [24] and goes into the arm [20].  The area
around the pressure terminals should be packed with silicone grease.
(Figure 955-50.) Install the SOC screws [32] to complete the cover mounting.


18

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XA) - 5.1 CLEANING OF TOOL FOR DISASSEMBLY
chunk_text:
1.
NOTE: Motor control box must not be used if tool is connected to the 1633 EA.  Also, M0 & M1
must be disconnected at the 12 pin bulkhead (SLOT 8-3 and SLOT 9-3) if the receiver board is
not XE or higher.   Using the Motor control box from the bottom of the tool, or by connecting the tool
to the 1633 EA and the PCM test system, motor the tool to the open position.

2.
Remove the covers from the receiver and transmitter on each of the six pad assemblies. [25 and 26 on
R149155]

3.
Remove the split shell covers [3 and 12 on R149158] from the pressure bulkheads and remove the
kapton tape that is wrapped around the tool.  The connections to the pressure bulkhead cavities and the
six pad assemblies can now be cleaned of all silicone grease.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XA) - 5.2 REMOVAL OF UPPER ELECTRONICS HOUSING

NOTE

On 1424 XB, see drawings 183856-000 and 183858-000 for details of 42 pin bulkhead
assembly.  Give attention to notes 3, 4, and 5 on drawing 183856-000.

1.
Remove the snap ring [2] and pull the black Airborn connector from the top sub assembly. Remove the
Airborn connector from the cable. Level 3 maintenance replace o-ring SIZE 031 on connector before
assembly.

2.
Unscrew the top sub assembly [6] from the tool. Level 3 maintenance replace o-rings SIZES 230 & 231
before assembly.

3.
Unscrew the pressure housing [4] from the bulkhead [13].  Level 3 maintenance replace  o-rings SIZE

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XA) - 5.3 REMOVAL OF MOTOR SECTION AND THE 32 PIN BULKHEAD
chunk_text:
(REFER TO DWG.R-149158 & R149154)
1.
Using the Motor control box from the bottom of the tool, or by connecting the tool to the 1633 EA and
the PCM test system, motor the tool to the closed position.
2.
Install two hose clamps around the pads and motor the tool open.  The hose clamps around the pads
will prevent the arms from opening and will allow the motor linkage to be disconnected.
3.
Remove power from the tool and remove the motor control box or the 1633 EA from the tool.  The tool
can now be disassembled without any additional power required.
4.
Remove 1/2-13 set screw [11] to release the pull rod.
5.
For Level 3 Maintenance go to STEP 10.
6.
Remove the 3 wire covers [14 on R149158].  Remove the wires from the 12 pin bulkhead and tape the
wires back so they will not be damaged when the motor section is removed.
7.
Remove the 3 set screws [8 on 149158] from bottom slotted housing and unscrew the motor section
assembly.
8.
Remove the 3 wire covers [13 on R149158].  Remove the wires from the bulkhead and tape the wires
back so they will not be damaged when the bulkhead is unscrewed.
9.
Remove the 3 set screws [8 on R149158] from the top of the slotted housing and unscrew the
bulkhead/electronics assembly.  This completes removal of the motor section and the
bulkhead/electronics section from the tool.
10. From the bottom of the tool remove retaining ring [57] using modified pliers [64].
11. Screw the T-Handle puller (148954-000) into the 32-pin bulkhead [47 on R149154] and pull the
bulkhead from the bottom sub [46 on R149154].  This is difficult as the bulkhead has o-rings.
12. After the 32-pin bulkhead is free from the bottom sub, disconnect the 32-pin black connector from the
bulkhead.  The bottom sub [46 on R149154] can now be unscrewed from the pressure housing for the
motor section.  Take care to feed the bottom connector through the bore of the bottom sub as it is being
removed.  Level 3 maintenance replace the o-rings SIZE 229 on the 32-pin bulkhead and SIZE 231 on
the bottom sub before assembly.
13. The pressure housing for the motor section [42 on 149154] can now be unscrewed from the 12-pin
bulkhead. Level 3 maintenance replace o-rings SIZE 231 on 12 pin bulkhead before assembly.
14. Remove the three wire covers [14 on R149158].  Remove the wires from the 12 pin bulkhead.  Level 3
maintenance may just cut the wires off as they will be replaced.
15. Remove the three set screws [8 on 149158] from bottom slotted housing and unscrew the motor section
assembly.
P/N 130363-955
21
1424 XA SEGMENTED BOND TOOL -- DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES
16. Remove the pull rod [2 on 149154] by unscrewing using a 1/8 piece of steel or a very large screwdriver.
The crossover rod threads will have to be heated as the pull rod is secured with high temp Loctite.
17. Remove the pull rod [2]. Remove the seal bushing [66] by unscrewing.
18. Remove the seal retainer [3] by removing the four screws [2].  Remove the backup rings [6] and the o-
rings [5] from both the seal bushing and the bore at the top of the 12 pin bulkhead.
19. Install the O-rings [4] SIZE 125 over the seal bushing [66]. Lubricate O-rings and bushing surfaces with
Lubriplate grease [55].
20. Install backup rings [6] and O-ring [5] SIZE 110 into the seal bushing [66]. Install seal retainer [3] and
secure in place with screws [2].
21. Install backup rings [6] and O-ring [5] SIZE 110 into the bore at the top end of 12-pin bulkhead.
22. Screw seal bushing, previously assembled, into 12-pin bulkhead until it is firmly tight.
23. Slide the coupler [72] onto the pull rod such that the head of the pull rod is inside the coupler.  Lubricate
and install pull rod [1] through seal bushing bore VERY CAREFULLY TO PREVENT DAMAGE
TO THE O-RINGS, and thread into the crossover [12].  Tighten the pull rod applying torque to it with a
flat piece of steel 1/8-inch thick. Secure rod with Loctite.
24. Remove the three wire covers [13 on R149158].  Remove the wires from the bulk head. Level 3
maintenance may just cut the wires off as they will be replaced.
25. Remove the three set screws [8] from the top slotted housing and unscrew the bulkhead/electronics
assembly.

(REFER TO DWG. R-149155)
1.
With tool fully open and the wire covers [25] and [26] removed from the pads and disconnect all the
boots.  If the tool was opened and the pads held closed with hose clamps great care must be taken to
prevent injury when removing the clamps as the springs are pushing the arms to the open position.
Level III maintenance should have already removed the pad covers to allow cleaning.
2.
Level III maintenance should only remove the pad assembly from the lower arm assembly.  Using a
0.078-diameter punch, drive out the roll pins [51], taking care not to damage the wires unless the
wires are being replaced. Remove the 0.375-diameter pins [21] to remove the pads.  An alternate method
of removing the pin is place the arm of the transducer on a solid surface and drive out the .375-diameter
pin [21] using a .3 diameter punch.  This will shear off the small roll pins [51].

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XA) - 5.5 REMOVAL OF ARMS AND LINKS
chunk_text:
(REFER TO DWG. R-149155)
1.
Remove the screws [15] from the yokes [14] and arm/link assemblies from the bottom slotted housing
[32].
2.
Remove the wire covers [45] and [46] from the top slotted housing [16]. Remove the screws [15] from
the yokes [14] and the arm/link assemblies (with wires) from the top slotted housing.
P/N 130363-955
22
1424 XA SEGMENTED BOND TOOL -- DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XA) - 5.6 REMOVAL AND SEPARATION OF INTERNAL LINKAGES
chunk_text:
(REFER TO DWG. R-149155)
1.
Remove set screw [1] from top slotted housing [16].
2.
Unscrew the hanger [2] and remove the top linkage assembly from the slotted housing.
3.
Unscrew the shaft [13] from the nut of the top assembly to separate the top and bottom assemblies.  The
top yoke [14] can now be removed.
4.
Unscrew the hanger [12] from the top assembly.  Remove the hex nut [41] from holdup [3].  Remove the
flange [5], and the washer [7].
5.
Unscrew the holdup [3] from the nut [11] which is inside the sleeve [9].  The spring [8] can now be
removed from over the sleeve[9].  NOTE: The sleeve assy for the top section is different than the bottom
section as it has set screw [53] in the nut.  Do not get these parts reversed on assembly.
6.
Unscrew the bolt [17] from the nut [11] on the bottom part of the top assembly.  The yoke [14] can now
be removed from the sleeve [9].  Unscrew the shaft [13] from the nut [11] and the spring can be removed
from over the sleeve [9].
7.
Grab the slider [34] and remove the bottom linkage assembly from the bottom slotted housing [32].
8.
After the assembly is removed from the tool, remove the set screw [31] and unscrew bolt [30] on the
upper assembly from the stem [29] on the lower assembly.  Be sure to mark which assembly is the lower
and which is the upper, as the lower stopper has set screw [54] inside.
9.
Unscrew the stem [29] from both assemblies to remove the yokes [14].
10. On the bottom assembly, remove set screw [33] before unscrewing the slider [34].
5.7 SEPARATING THE MANDREL AND THE SLOTTED HOUSINGS (Dwg.R149155)
1.
Remove the shear screw [28] from the housing and the bottom slotted housing [32] can be pulled free
from the mandrel [18].  The shear screw should be replaced on assembly.
2.
Remove the three set screws [1], which hold the top slotted housing in position on the mandrel [18].
The top slotted housing [16] can then be unscrewed from the mandrel [18].
P/N 130363-955

chunk_text:

ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424 XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL 
MOTOR SECTION ASSEMBLY

Note-1: For manufacturing procedures, please refer to the following documents:
•
1424 XB SBT Manufacturing Assembly Procedures (F130627855)
•
1424 XA/XB SBT Manufacturing Documentation (1424-SBT-AMO-MNTDOC)






Note-2: Numbers in brackets [ ] in this section correspond to the item numbers and the
numbers in parenthesis ( ) are the part numbers on the BOM for DWG. F149154000

BALL SCREW ASSEMBLY

1.
Thoroughly clean all parts for the motor section assembly, except the bearings, in Varsol
as shown in Figure 955-1.





2.
Verify the ball nut [17] has a cardboard tube inside that is fastened with tie wrap.


Do not remove the cardboard tube from the ball nut.
Removing the tube allows the bearing balls to fall out.

3.
Apply a generous amount of ML-7 [43] grease on the outside of the cardboard tube and
work it in and out until all of the bearing balls stick to the major inside thread diameter
of the ball nut.  See Figure 955-2.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
chunk_text:

ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424 XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL

4.
After verifying that all bearing balls stick to the inside thread diameter of the ball nut,
clip the tie wrap to release the cardboard tube. Before removing the tube, add a little
more grease to the tube OD to ensure the bearing balls will not fall out and will not
stick to the tube.

5.
Slowly remove the cardboard tube by pushing it with the ball screw [19]. The ball screw
should thread into the nut. Verify the correct orientation of each piece as shown below.


pin [23] into them – making sure equal lengths (if any) protrude on each side. Thread the
crossover [12] into the other end of the ball screw and insert a Spirol pin [16]. (Figure 955-4)


(See Figure 955-5)

the bearing [29] over the ball nut adapter and fasten with the nut [26] as shown below.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL 2.2 NOBAK DEVICE ASSEMBLY
chunk_text:
5

ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424 XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL 
NOBAK DEVICE ASSEMBLY

Before assembling the Nobak device into the bearing housing, the procedure below should
be followed. Refer to drawing P/N F197056000 and BOM.

1.
Stack the springs [4], one on top of the other, using grease to hold them in place.  Install
them into the slot in the wedge [5], face down.

2.
Insert the wedge (complete with springs) on the top of either one of the bearings [1], making
sure the springs lay against the extended inner race of the bearing.

3.
Set the spacer bearing [3] over the wedge.  Insert the pin [2] into the groove in the spacer
bearing using grease to hold it in place.

4.
Use needle-nose pliers to lower the bearing into the bearing housing (P/N 149109-000),
making sure the pin [2] in the spacer bearing mates properly with the keyway in the
housing. Push down as uniformly as possible until the bearing bottoms on the shoulder.






5.
Install the remaining bearing into the bearing housing, making sure the extended inner race
mates properly with the wedge.


Refer to drawing P/N F149154000 and BOM.
6.
Insert the adapter [35], with the raised face down, on top of the bearing housing [27] and
fasten with set screws [32] using Loctite [50].

7.
Slide the motor spline shaft adapter [31] over the motor shaft and fasten with it the retainer
nut [28].

8.
Slide the motor spacer [67] over the motor [36].  Insert the motor into the bearing housing
[27] making sure the key engages properly. Press four standoffs [38] into the holes in the
chassis [37]. Install the other four standoffs [65].

9.
Slide the chassis weldment assembly [37] over the motor [36], making sure the slots are
oriented correctly, and fasten with cap screws [33] using Loctite [50]. (Figure 955-7)







P/N 130627-955

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
chunk_text:
6

ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424 XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
10.
Insert the ball screw assembly into the other end of the bearing housing [27] making sure
that the bearing is seated properly.



Thread the shroud [13], the end with the least amount of threads, into the bearing housing
[27]. Clamp the shroud in a vise using a spanner wrench to tighten the housing. See
Unscrew the crossover [12] all the way out until flush with the end of the shroud [13]. Screw
it back in until the grooves in the crossover line up with the slots in the shroud.

13.
Install the cranks [15] to both sides of the crossover, and fasten them with cap screws [14]
and Loctite [50].  (Figure 955-10)


Drive the Spirol pins [18] into the cranks [15], and leave them centered inside the cranks

for later adjustment.

P/N 130627-955

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
chunk_text:
7

ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424 XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL


15.
Discard the screws that came with the Actuator Kit [59] and install the 2 Limit Switches [11] and 2
actuators to the OD of the shroud using 2 screws P/N F228494000 and the 2 lock washers provided
in the kit to secure each limit switch. The figure below shows the installation of one of the limit
switches.

12-PIN BULKHEAD ASSEMBLY

1.
Crimp a terminal [69] to each pressure feed-thru [8] and attach a wire 60 inches long to the

crimp terminals per wire list.  Slide a piece of shrink tubing over the connections.

2.
Lubricate the O-rings of each pressure feed-thru and install them into the respective holes
on the 12-pin bulkhead [7], per wiring schematic. Feed the wires through holes of the 12-pin
bulkhead, being careful to avoid wire damage.

3.
Install the insulator Weldment [9] inside the bulkhead and secure it in place with retaining
ring [56].  Install O-rings [10] onto 12-pin bulkhead. Lubricate the O-rings and glands with
Lubriplate grease. Screw the motor assembly into the 12-pin bulkhead and tighten using a
spanner wrench.

4.
Route the wires into the slots on the threaded portion of the bulkhead and while holding
the wires below the root diameter of the threads, fill the slots with RTV adhesive [51].
Clean any RTV that flowed into the threads and let the adhesive cure for 24 hours in open
air before proceeding.

5.
Install the motor control boards [40 and 61] using eight screws [39], eight washers [20],
and Loctite [50].

6.
Connect the wires to the micro switches per wiring diagram F183855000.

7.
Route all the wires from the bulkhead to the O.D. of the shroud, through the slots on the
bearing housing and motor sleeve.  Hold wires in place with Kapton tape or RTV where
necessary.

8.
Connect wires to the motor control boards using hi-temp solder [54].

9.
Install gland nut [41] onto lower flange of motor chassis weldment [37].

10.
Feed all remaining wires through the gland nut and make a pigtail using expandable sleeve
[70]. Wrap a few turns of silicone tape over the sleeve at each end.  Cut the wires about 2
inches past the bottom sub [46] and about 14 inches from the gland nut.

11.
Strip wires and crimp onto the pins of the bottom connector [45]. Insert pins into connector
body per wiring diagram.  Put all pins into the connector body (32 total).

P/N 130627-955

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
chunk_text:
8

ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424 XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL

12.
Install the O-rings [4] over the seal bushing [66]. Lubricate O-rings and bushing surfaces
with Lubriplate grease [55].  Install backup rings [6] and O-ring [5] into the seal bushing [66].
Install seal retainer [3] and secure in place with screws [2].

13.
Install backup rings [6] and O-ring [5] into the bore at the top end of 12-pin bulkhead. Screw
the seal bushing, previously assembled, into 12-pin bulkhead until it is firmly tight.

14.
Slide the coupler [72] onto the pull rod such that the head of the pull rod is inside the coupler.
Lubricate and install pull rod [1] through seal bushing bore, being careful to avoid damaging
the O-rings, and thread into the crossover [12].

15.
Tighten the pull rod applying torque to it with a flat piece of steel 1/8-inch thick steel and

secure the rod with Loctite.

Note: For manufacturing procedures, please refer to the following documents:
•
1424 XB SBT Manufacturing Assembly Procedures (F130627855)
•
1424 XA/XB SBT Manufacturing Documentation (1424-SBT-AMO-MNTDOC)

FINAL ASSEMBLY
Note: For manufacturing procedures, please refer to the following documents:
•
1424 XB SBT Manufacturing Assembly Procedures (F130627855)
•
1424 XA/XB SBT Manufacturing Documentation (1424-SBT-AMO-MNTDOC)



Refer to drawings F183859000 and BOM, and wiring diagram F183855000.

1.
Finish wiring the tool according to wiring diagram F183855000. Also, install terminal
[22] and O-ring [23] to the 42 pin Bulkhead Assembly [1]. Apply grease [4] on outside
threads of the terminals prior to installation on the 42 pin bulkhead. Connect the wires
to their respective feed-thru terminals at the top and bottom bulkheads.

2.
Install wire covers [13] and [14] into the slots of upper and lower slotted housings.

3.
Perform a check on the adjustments of the motor limit switches. The tool can be controlled
via the PCM test system or by a motor control box from the bottom of the tool. Adjust the
microswitch actuator pins as follows.


PERFORM THIS OPERATION VERY CAREFULLY TO PREVENT ANY
DAMAGE TO THE LINKAGES OR TO THE MOTOR DRIVE PARTS.

4.
Motor the tool until the arms are fully closed. Move the pin until the microswitch is actuated.
Note: The microswitch must be actuated as soon as the pads are closed.

5.
Motor the tool open and adjust the other pin until it actuates the microswitch. The microswitch
must be actuated before the crossover (149122-000) hits the 12-pin bulkhead.

6.
Slide the pressure housing (149135-000) over the motor assembly and screw onto the 12-pin
bulkhead.

7.
Fish the bottom connector (180009-000) through the bore of bottom sub (146773-000). Screw
the sub onto the housing approximately 1 turn.

8.
Connect the 32-pin connector onto the 32-pin bulkhead (145245-000). Unscrew the bottom sub

and insert the 32-pin bulkhead into the bore of it until the 32-pin connector is into the small bore
at the top of the sub.

9.
While holding the 32-pin bulkhead with one hand to prevent its rotation, screw the sub into
the pressure housing until it shoulders. Remove your hand and insert the installation tool
(150196-000) and finish installing the 32-pin bulkhead. The alignment mark on the sub must
align with the key of the 32-pin bulkhead.

10.
Once the bulkhead is in place, install the retaining ring (146770-000) using modified pliers
(186097-000).

11.
Perform the final checkout.

12.
Pack the top and bottom bulkhead cavities until the boots are covered with silicone grease [4],
wrap with Kapton tape and install the split covers [3] and [12] with screws [2]. Screw the
pressure housing to the bulkhead.



P/N 130627-955

PAD SECTION ASSEMBLY

1.
Pre-cut new wires for the pad section to an eleven feet length, and the wires for the pad
transducers to a seven feet length.

2.
Clean all parts thoroughly with Varsol.

3.

4.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL 3.5 PAD INSTALLATION
chunk_text:
16

ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424 XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL 
PAD INSTALLATION

1.
Lay out all arm assemblies.


Install the large pin [21] into the transducer housing [24] and through the arm [20] until the
0.078" diameter cross hole aligns with the hole in the center of the arm. DO NOT install the
roll pin [51] through the arm and pin at this time.

3.
Repeat step 2 for all six assemblies, making sure to avoid damaging the wires.

NOTE: When installing boots over the pressure terminals, fill the boot with silicone grease
to ensure no air is trapped inside the boot.

4.
Install the boots and connectors on one end of a 3-conductor cable and on one end of the
2-conductor cable. Plug them into the three pressure terminals located on the transmitter side,
and the 2 pressure terminals located on the receiver side. (Figure 955-35)



P/N 130627-955

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
chunk_text:

5.
Repeat step 4 for the other three assemblies.



Verify there is enough of a wire loop between the arm [20] and the transducer housing [24]
so the wire is not under strain.

7.
Fasten the arm cover [48] using spacers [52], flat head screws [49] and Loctite. Run the wires
out of the arm and through the top of the link.

8.
Position the assembly as shown in Figure 955-37, then insert the wire into the channels of the
tunnel [6], and line up the holes in the tunnel with the holes in the link.


Fasten flat head screws [47 with Loctite. Make sure the tool is about 3 feet off the bench,

properly supported and able to turn 360 degrees.

10.
Align the slots in the yokes and washers with the slots in the top slotted housing [16]. The

position for the two sets of the these three pad assemblies will be determined by the flats

on the mandrel [18]. The long flats on the mandrel house the long side of the transducer

housing [24] and visa versa.

11.
Insert the link part of the assembly into the correct slot and let the wire lay outside for the

time being.

12.
Install one transducer assembly arm in the upper yoke and one transducer assembly arm in
the lower yoke.

13.
Depress the arm in the upper yoke so the pad is in the closed position. The pad should lie in
the flats of the mandrel. The distance from the end of the mandrel to the end of the arm should
be 29-3/8".
P/N 130627-955

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL

14.
Perform the same test on the arm in the lower yoke. The distance from the end of the mandrel
to the end of the arm should be 37-3/4".

NOTE
If arm distances are not correct and the pads do not line up properly in the flats
of the mandrel, the tool will not close completely. The adjustment or setting made
in the section Pad Section Assembly must be changed. Also check the distance
between the top of the upper (odd number) pad and the top of lower (even number)
pad. The distance must be 8-3/8" ± 1/16". The distance should be correct if the
assembly of the internal linkage was correctly performed.

15.
If the adjustment is correct, install the remaining four transducer housing on the tool. Be sure
to orient them properly so they lie in the flats of the mandrel when the tool is closed.

16.
Install the yoke screw [15], using Loctite.

17.
Install the six remaining arm and link assemblies into the bottom slotted housing [32].

18.
Align the linkage previously installed in the bottom slotted housing [32] by making sure the 3
slots in yokes [14] and flanges [5] line up with the 3 slots in the bottom slotted housing [32].







screw by lightly compressing the spring to align hole in arm with hole in yoke. Tighten the
yoke screw and use Loctite. (Figure 955-39)  Repeat for all the slots in the bottom slotted
housing.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL

2. Install the large pin into the transducer housing and through the arm until the 0.078-inch
diameter cross hole aligns with the hole on the center of the arm. Install the roll pin [51]
through the arm and pin. Do this to both ends of all six assemblies.


3.   Thread the electronics bulkhead assembly [1] into the top slotted housing until it shoulders.
Then back it off until the slot in the threads of the bulkhead aligns with the threaded holes
on the top slotted housing. Install three set screws [8] and tighten with Loctite.

Notice that pad no. 1 Transmitter side is oriented toward the top of the tool.
Pad no. 1 wires will run in groove 1 which is stamped on the bulkhead.

4.   Once the bulkhead has been installed, the remaining wire can now be run. Use the short
wire covers [45] for the short slots and the long wire covers [46] for the long slots in the
top slotted housing.

5. Insert the wire into the channels of the covers. Make sure that there is enough of a loop
between the tunnel and the cover so the wire can flex freely upon tool operation.

6. Fasten the covers with screws [47] using Loctite. Ensure there are no wires pinched under
the wire covers when the covers are screwed down.

Note: These two steps may be performed after the final checkout to ensure there
are no problems with the tool. However, a check of all pads must be made
after the covers are installed to ensure no wires were pinched or shorted
while mounting the covers.

7. After routing the wire, install the transmitter cover [25] and the receiver cover [26] using the
flat head screws [23]. Make sure the wire is not pinched in any way by the covers. You
may have to form the wire as it exits the transducer housing and goes into the arm.

8.
Pack the area around the pressure terminals with silicone grease.



10.  Use RTV to hold the wires in the channels between the receiver and transmitter on each pad.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - 5.0 DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 5.1 CLEANING OF TOOL FOR DISASSEMBLY
chunk_text:
DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 
CLEANING OF TOOL FOR DISASSEMBLY

1.
NOTE: Motor control box must not be used if tool is connected to the 1633 EA. Also,
M0 & M1 must be disconnected at the 12 pin bulkhead (SLOT 8-3 and SLOT 9-3) if the
receiver board is not XE or higher.  Using the Motor control box from the bottom of the
tool, or by connecting the tool to the 1633 EA and the PCM test system, motor the tool to
the open position.

2.
Remove the covers from the receiver and transmitter on each of the six pad assemblies
[25 and 26 on P/N F149155000].

3.
Remove the split shell covers [3 and 12 on F183859000] from the pressure bulkheads and
remove the kapton tape that is wrapped around the tool. The connections to
the pressure bulkhead cavities and the six pad assemblies can now be cleaned of all silicone
grease.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - 5.2 REMOVAL OF UPPER ELECTRONICS HOUSING
chunk_text:
REMOVAL OF UPPER ELECTRONICS HOUSING

NOTE

On 1424 XB, see drawings F183856000 and F183858000 for details of 42-pin bulkhead
assembly. Give attention to notes 3, 4, and 5 on drawing F183856000.

1.
Remove the snap ring and pull the black Airborn connector from the top sub assembly and
remove the Airborne connector from the cable. Level 3 maintenance replace O-ring SIZE
031 on connector before assembly.

2.
Unscrew the top sub assembly from the tool. Level 3 maintenance replace O-rings SIZES
230 & 231 before assembly.

3.
Unscrew the pressure housing from the bulkhead.  Level 3 maintenance replace O-rings
SIZE 231 on bulkhead before assembly.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - 5.3 REMOVAL OF MOTOR SECTION AND THE 32-PIN BULKHEAD
chunk_text:
REMOVAL OF MOTOR SECTION AND THE 32-PIN BULKHEAD

1.
Using the Motor control box from the bottom of the tool, or by connecting the tool to the
1633 EA and the PCM test system, motor the tool to the closed position.

2.
Install two hose clamps around the pads and motor the tool open. The hose clamps around the
pads will prevent the arms from opening and will allow the motor linkage to be disconnected.

3.
Remove power from the tool and remove the motor control box or the 1633 EA from the tool.
The tool can now be disassembled without any additional power required.

4.
Remove 1/2-13 set screw (P/N 250796-000) to release the pull rod.

5.
For Level 3 Maintenance go to STEP 10.


P/N 130627-955

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
chunk_text:
22

ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424 XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
6.
Remove the 3 wire covers (P/N 149143-000).  Remove the wires from the 12 pin bulkhead
and tape the wires back so they will not be damaged when the motor section is removed.

7.
Remove the 3 set screws (P/N 203051-000) from bottom slotted housing and unscrew the
motor section assembly.

8.
Remove the 3 wire covers (P/N 149142-000).  Remove the wires from the bulkhead and
tape the wires back so they will not be damaged when the bulkhead is unscrewed.

9.
Remove the 3 set screws (P/N 243051-000) from the top of the slotted housing and
unscrew the bulkhead/electronics assembly. This completes removal of the motor section
and the bulkhead/electronics section from the tool.


(Refer to drawing F149154000 and BOM)

10.
From the bottom of the tool remove retaining ring [57] using modified pliers [64].

11.
Screw the T-Handle puller (P/N 148954-000) into the 32-pin bulkhead [47] and pull the
bulkhead from the bottom sub [46].  This is difficult as the bulkhead has O-rings.

12.
After the 32-pin bulkhead is free from the bottom sub, disconnect the 32-pin black connector
from the bulkhead.  The bottom sub can now be unscrewed from the pressure housing for the
motor section. Take care to feed the bottom connector through the bore of the bottom sub as
it is being removed. Level 3 maintenance replace the O-rings SIZE 229 on the 32-pin bulkhead
and SIZE 231 on the bottom sub before assembly.

13.
The pressure housing for the motor section [42] can now be unscrewed from the 12-pin

bulkhead. Level 3 maintenance replace O-rings SIZE 231 on 12 pin bulkhead before assembly.

14.
Remove the three wire covers (P/N 149143-000).  Remove the wires from the 12 pin bulkhead.
Level 3 maintenance may just cut the wires off as they will be replaced.

15.
Remove the three set screws (P/N 243051-000) from bottom slotted housing and unscrew the
motor section assembly.

16.
Remove the pull rod [1] by unscrewing using a 1/8 piece of steel or a very large screwdriver.
The crossover rod threads will have to be heated as the pull rod is secured with high temp
Loctite.  Remove the pull rod and the seal bushing [66] by unscrewing.

17.
Remove the seal retainer [3] by removing the four screws [2].  Remove the backup rings [6]
and the O-rings [5] from both the seal bushing and the bore at the top of the 12 pin bulkhead.

18.
Install the O-rings [4] SIZE 125 over the seal bushing [66]. Lubricate O-rings and bushing
surfaces with Lubriplate grease [55].

19.
Install backup rings [6] and O-ring [5] SIZE 110 into the seal bushing [66]. Install seal retainer
[3] and secure in place with screws [2]. Also install backup rings [6] and O-ring [5] SIZE 110
into the bore at the top end of 12-pin bulkhead.

20.
Screw seal bushing, previously assembled, into 12-pin bulkhead until it is firmly tight.





P/N 130627-955

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
chunk_text:
23

ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424 XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
21.
Slide the coupler [72] onto the pull rod such that the head of the pull rod is inside the coupler.
Lubricate and install pull rod [1] through seal bushing bore VERY CAREFULLY TO PREVENT
DAMAGE TO THE O-RINGS, and thread into the crossover [12].  Tighten the pull rod applying
torque to it with a flat piece of steel 1/8-inch thick. Secure rod with Loctite.

22.
Remove the three wire covers (P/N 149142-000).  Remove the wires from the bulk head.
Level 3 maintenance may just cut the wires off as they will be replaced.

23.
Remove the three set screws from the top slotted housing and unscrew the bulkhead /
electronics assembly.

REMOVAL OF PADS

(Refer to drawing F149155000 and BOM)

1.
With tool fully open and the wire covers [25] and [26] removed from the pads and disconnect
all the boots. If the tool was opened and the pads held closed with hose clamps great care must
be taken to prevent injury when removing the clamps as the springs are pushing the arms to the
open position. Level 3 maintenance should have already removed the pad covers to allow
cleaning.

2.
Level 3 maintenance should only remove the pad assembly from the lower arm assembly. Using
a 0.078-diameter punch, drive out the roll pins [51], taking care not to damage the wires unless
the wires are being replaced. Remove the 0.375-diameter pins [21] to remove the pads.  An
alternate method of removing the pin is place the arm of the transducer on a solid surface and
drive out the .375-diameter pin [21] using a .3 diameter punch. This will shear off the small roll
pins [51].

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - 5.5 REMOVAL OF ARMS AND LINKS
chunk_text:
REMOVAL OF ARMS AND LINKS

1.
Remove the screws [15] from the yokes [14] and arm/link assemblies from the bottom slotted
housing [32].

2.
Remove the wire covers [45] and [46] from the top slotted housing [16]. Remove the screws
[15] from the yokes [14] and the arm/link assemblies (with wires) from the top slotted housing.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - 5.6 REMOVAL AND SEPARATION OF INTERNAL LINKAGES
chunk_text:
REMOVAL AND SEPARATION OF INTERNAL LINKAGES

1.
Remove set screw [1] from top slotted housing [16].

2.
Unscrew the hanger [2] and remove the top linkage assembly from the slotted housing.

3.
Unscrew the shaft [13] from the nut of the top assembly to separate the top and bottom assemblies.
The top yoke [14] can now be removed.

4.
Unscrew the hanger from the top assembly.  Remove the hex nut [41] from holdup [3].  Remove
the flange [5], and the washer [7].

5.
Unscrew the holdup [3] from the nut [11] which is inside the sleeve [9].  The spring [8] can now
be removed from over the sleeve[9].  NOTE: The sleeve assy for the top section is different than
the bottom section as it has set screw [53] in the nut.  Do not get these parts reversed on assembly.



P/N 130627-955

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
chunk_text:
24

ASSEMBLY/ DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                    1424 XB SEGMENTED BOND TOOL
6.
Unscrew the bolt [17] from the nut [11] on the bottom part of the top assembly.  The yoke [14]
can now be removed from the sleeve [9]. Unscrew the shaft [13] from the nut [11] and the spring
can be removed from over the sleeve.

7.
Grab the slider [34] and remove the bottom linkage assembly from the bottom slotted
housing [32].

8.
After the assembly is removed from the tool, remove the set screw [31] and unscrew bolt
[30] on the upper assembly from the stem [29] on the lower assembly.  Be sure to mark
which assembly is the lower and which is the upper, as the lower stopper has set screw
[54] inside.

9.
Unscrew the stem [29] from both assemblies to remove the yokes [14].

10.
On the bottom assembly, remove set screw [33] before unscrewing the slider [34].

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424XB) - 5.7 SEPARATING THE MANDREL AND THE SLOTTED HOUSINGS
chunk_text:
SEPARATING THE MANDREL AND THE SLOTTED HOUSINGS

1.
Remove the shear screw [28] from the housing and the bottom slotted housing [32] can
be pulled free from the mandrel [18].  The shear screw should be replaced on assembly.

2.
Remove the three set screws [1], which hold the top slotted housing in position on the
mandrel [18]. The top slotted housing [16] can then be unscrewed from the mandrel [18].

INTRODUCTION

This procedure provides the information needed for complete assembly of the Baker Hughes
1424 PA VDL Sub (P/N 149767-000). It must be used with the 1424 XA/XB SBT instrument.

NOTE
•
When using an extension on a wrench (parmelee or pin), the torque values must
be adjusted accordingly.
•
When using an extension with a torque wrench, it is extremely important that the
extension and wrench remain inline with each other.
•
To prevent damage to stranded Teflon wire, only use thermal wire strippers (hot
tweezers) P/N 226804-000 to cut and remove insulation.

PREASSEMBLY PREPARATIONS

1.
Study assembly drawing P/N 149767-000 and BOM to become familiar with the layout of
all the items in the assembly. Study also the wiring diagram P/N 183855-000. Verify that all
required parts and all necessary tools and equipment are available.

2.
Secure a clean area and work bench with a bench vise. During the assembly process, do not
allow dirt or any foreign material particles to contaminate the parts.

3.
Inspect all parts for any dings or nicks in threads. Small dings may be cleaned up with a thread
file if necessary. Inspect parts for cleanliness, and clean if necessary to remove all dirt and
foreign particles. Set aside cleaned parts on a clean work area.

4.
Trial fit all mating parts, without any O-rings installed, to insure that all fits are free and that
no conditions exist that would prevent easy assembly.

5.
Assemble ceramic transducer [item 28] as shown on drawing P/N 148613-000.

ASSEMBLY
(Refer to drawing P/N 149767-000 and BOM)

RECEIVER ASSEMBLY

1.
Mount receiver buffer [25] onto receiver mounting shaft [30] and secure it in place with a
screw [26].

2.
Install one crystal mounting plate [24] over the receiver mounting shaft [30] until it stops
against the receiver buffer [25]. Back up the crystal mounting plate approximately one full
turn and secure with Thread Lock  #532 [62].

3.
Install crystal insulator [27] over crystal mounting plate [24].

4.
Install a piece of 0 .125” shrink tubing [61] over each transducer wire [28].

5.
Carefully feed the transducer wires through the receiver buffer [25] and receiver shaft slots [30]
toward upper end of assembly, making sure to avoid damaging the wires. Slide transducer over
insulator, guiding the wires through insulator slot. Feed wires toward the top end of the shaft.
Twist both wires together and slide a piece of metal braid over the wires.

6.
Hold the transducer in place while installing the crystal insulator over receiver shaft.

7.
Install crystal insulator [27] over the mounting plate [24], then apply Thread Lock #532 to the
mounting plate and screw it on until the insulator bottoms out against the transducer. Tighten the
mounting plate very carefully to prevent damage to the transducer.

8.
Mount Teflon damper [22] on top of the crystal mounting plate using four screws [23] and Thread
Lock #532 [62].

with a screw [26].

buffer [46]. Back up the crystal mounting plate, approximately one full turn. Secure in place with
Thread Lock #532 [62].

3.
Install crystal insulator [27] over crystal mounting plate [24].

4.

5.
Carefully feed the transducer wires through the transmitter buffer [46] and receiver shaft slots [48]
toward upper end of assembly, making sure to avoid damaging the wires. Slide transducer over
insulator, guiding the wires through insulator slot.

6.
Hold the transducer in place while installing the crystal insulator and the transmitter separator [47]
over the transmitter shaft [48].

Install the wave spring washer [81] over the wires and install into the top adapter sub. Use a

8.
Install O-rings [5] and [6] onto the top sub [4], then lubricate the O-rings and sub surfaces and

Feed the 32-pin connector through the sub, screw the sub onto the top adapter sub [12], and
carefully tighten to 150 ft-lb torque.

10.
Install [10], [9], [8] and [11].  Pull the connector [8] and connect it to the 32-pin connector [2].

Insert the 32-pin connector into the top sub. Install the retaining ring [7] into the top sub groove.

chunk_text:

ASSEMBLY/DISASSEMBLY PROCEDURES                                                      1424 PA VDL SUB
CONFIDENTIAL                                    P/N 130401-955                                              MARCH 2014 
FINAL ASSEMBLY

1.
Check that all screws are tight.

2.
Check electrical leakage between conductors and case, using Simpson 260 meter. Conductor
#18 is ground.

3.
Check the continuity between the top and bottom connectors (conductors 11, 12, 27, and 28).

4.
Connect a signal generator set at 5-kHz sine wave between conductors 2 and 3, 5 and 3, and
21 and 22. The tool must hum in all the indicated connections.

5.
Install the top thread protector.

6.
Stamp the asset numbers (over slotted housing) on both sides of the tool.

7.
Send the tool to the test pit with instructions for 16 kpsi and 320 F. After the pressure test,
connect the tool to the vacuum pump and circulate oil to check for water contamination.

8.

Send the tool to Q.C. for final check-up.

topic: Assembly/Disassembly Procedures (1424PA) - 4.0 DISASSEMBLY 4.1 REMOVAL OF INTERNAL ASSEMBLY FROM SLOTTED HOUSING
chunk_text:
DISASSEMBLY 
REMOVAL OF INTERNAL ASSEMBLY FROM SLOTTED HOUSING

1.
Remove top thread protectors and bull plug. Remove oil filler plugs and drain oil.

2.
At bottom of tool, use modified pliers (PN 150259) to remove retaining ring [53]. If the tool
has a bull plug, remove the spacer. There will be no retaining ring.

3.
Remove 32-pin bulkhead connector [51] using T-Handle puller (PN 148954). Disconnect
contact block from 32-pin bulkhead connector [51].

4.
Unthread bottom sub [52]. Remove flat head screws [20] at the bottom of the tool to disengage
bottom adaptor sub [50].

5.
At uphole end of tool, remove retaining ring [7]. Use T-Handle tool (PN 078902) to remove
32-pin connector [2]. Disconnect Amphenol plug from black block.

6.
Unthread top sub [4].

7.
With T-Handle or T handle pull tool, pull 10-pin bulkhead [13] from adaptor sub [12] and
disconnect rubber boots. For LEVEL 3 maintenance, the crimp pins and rubber boots can be cut
off as the wires will be replaced. Remove the spring washer [81] from behind the bulkhead.

8.
Remove flat head screws [20] and socket head screws. Remove internal assembly from slotted
housing [31]. The internal assembly is pulled out of the top of the slotted housing. Be careful
and avoid damaging the metal tube [32] or centralizers, or the receiver and transmitter sleeves.

9.
Place the internal assembly on a bench for further disassembly.

Remove the crystal [28].
