topic: Brief Description Of Service/Equipment - GEOMETRIC FACTOR, CONTINUED
chunk_text:
15 AUGUST 1997
15 AUGUST 1997

For a given coil configuration, this geometric factor is a function of the radius of the loop, and
its position along the axis of the tool.  So we can consider it a 2-dimensional function.  Figure 2
shows this 2-dimensional function for the 2-coil array illustrated in Figure 1.  The "z" axis
shows distance along the tool or borehole axis.  The "r" axis shows radius or distance from the
tool axis.  As we can see, the system is sensitive to a wide region around the instrument, but the
maximum sensitivity is between the receiver coils and at a radius between a half (½) and one (1)
times the coil spacing.  Note also that there is significant sensitivity close to both the receiver
and transmitter coils.
15 AUGUST 1997
15 AUGUST 1997
If we take the geometric factor and integrate or total the values for a given position along the
borehole, this gives the sensitivity of the system to a thin layer of formation at that position.
This is called the Vertical Geometric Factor (VGF) which is illustrated for the DPIL deep and
medium array in Figure 4.
A common definition of vertical resolution is the distance between the 5  and 95  percentiles at
th
th
the main lope of the Vertical Geometric Factor.  In the case of the DPIL medium, this is 48
inches, and for the deep it is 56 inches.  Note however that the deep VGF has long tails
extending on either side of the central lobe.  This shows that the DPIL deep curve has
significant "shoulder-bed effect."

If we take the geometric factor and integrate or total the values within a given radius, this gives
the sensitivity of the system to a cylinder of the formation with that radius.  This is called the
Integrated Radial Geometric Factor (IRGF), illustrated for the DPIL deep and medium arrays in

topic: Brief Description Of Service/Equipment - 1.0 GENERAL DESCRIPTION
chunk_text:
GENERAL DESCRIPTION
HDIL (High Definition Induction Log) is our next generation induction logging instrument.  It
is a direct competitor to the Schlumberger Array Induction Tool (AIT), and uses multi-spacing
and multi-frequency measurements to acquire a complete set of data from the formations
surrounding the borehole.
The multi-spacing measurements allow improved conductivity measurements in complex
environments.  The short-spacing measurements (as short as 6-inch spacing) allow improved
correction for borehole, rugosity and invasion effects.  The long-spacing measurements (up to
94-inch spacing) are useful in deep invasion situations.  The multiple-frequency measurements
allow for an improved skin-effect correction and data quality checking.
HDIL allows us to characterize invasion profiles, even in oil-based muds.
HDIL is a full feedthrough, WTS tool.

topic: Brief Description Of Service/Equipment - 2.0 ENVIRONMENTAL CORRECTIONS AND SIGNAL PROCESSING
chunk_text:
ENVIRONMENTAL CORRECTIONS AND SIGNAL PROCESSING
Focusing, skin effect correction and borehole corrections are integral to the HDIL system.  The
borehole correction is controlled through the Proc., General Parameters screen.

topic: Brief Description Of Service/Equipment - 3.0 THEORY 3.1 GEOMETRIC FACTOR
chunk_text:
THEORY 
GEOMETRIC FACTOR
Key to understanding both the design of induction instruments and the processing of induction
data is the concept of the geometric factor proposed by Doll in 1949.  In geometric factor
theory, we think of the earth being divided into circular ground loops of unit cross-sectional
area coaxial with the tool.  Figure 1 shows this concept graphically for a 2-coil induction
logging system.  An alternating current in the transmitter coil induces a voltage in the ground
loop.  This voltage is 90 degrees out-of-phase with the current in the transmitter.  The voltage
causes an eddy current to flow in the loop proportional in magnitude to the conductivity of the
formation in the loop.  This current induces a voltage in a receiver coil which we can detect.
This voltage is 90 degrees out-of-phase with the voltage and current in the ground loop.
According to this theory, the received voltage is proportional to the conductivity of the
formation in the loop.  The constant of proportionality varies with the radius and position of the
loop along the tool axis, as well as the position and construction of the coils.  This constant of

BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE/EQUIPMENT — 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-935

topic: Brief Description Of Service/Equipment - 3.2 REAL AND QUADRATURE SIGNALS
chunk_text:
REAL AND QUADRATURE SIGNALS
From the above model we can also deduce the received signal has undergone two 90-degree
phase shifts with respect to the current in the transmitter.  It is therefore back in-phase with this
current.  (In fact, it is 180 degrees out-of-phase, but we treat this as in-phase with a sign
change).
We call this in-phase signal the "Real Signal."  This phase relationship is convenient because
there is also a signal in the receiver that is coupled directly from the transmitter.  This signal is
large, but unaffected by the formation conductivity.  We call this signal the "direct-coupled" or
"Mutual Signal."  This signal is 90 degrees out-of-phase with the transmitter current, so we can
separate it from the desired in-phase signal by using phase-sensitive detection.
There is also a signal which is 90 degrees out-of-phase with the current, which is affected by the
formation conductivity.  We call this the "Quadrature Signal."
3
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE/EQUIPMENT — 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-935

topic: Brief Description Of Service/Equipment - 3.3 HARDWARE FOCUSING
chunk_text:
HARDWARE FOCUSING
By selecting our coil arrangements carefully, we improve the response of the instrument.
concentrates its response in a smaller region than a 2-coil array (see Figure 2).  However, there
is still significant sensitivity close to each coil which will lead to a cave effect or undesirable
response at changes in diameter of the borehole.
130551-935

topic: Brief Description Of Service/Equipment - 3.6 SOFTWARE FOCUSING
chunk_text:
SOFTWARE FOCUSING
It is a fact that, although we can vary the focusing of an induction instrument by modifying the
coil array to achieve greater depth of investigation or resolution, we can do very little to reduce
the cave effect.  There will always be a peak in sensitivity close to nearly every coil.  To reduce
cave effect, and the possible artifacts caused by high contrast in the invaded zone, we will need
to go to software focusing.  In software focusing, the measurements are made by several simple
coil arrays and their signals are combined, in software, to achieve focusing.  The advantage of
this technique is measurements can be combined from arrays at different points in the well.  It is
this fact which enables us to reduce the cave effect.  There is no single ideal focusing scheme.
So, another advantage is different focusing schemes can be used in different circumstances.
The process of focusing is actually applying predesigned filters to the raw signals to achieve a
more desirable 2-D geometric factor for the result.  The steps are as follows.
1.
Apply a predesigned filter to each raw data curve.
2.
Combine these filtered curves to generate a curve with the desired 2-D geometrical
factor.
3.
Repeat the process, with different filters, for each output curve.
investigation and can also observe that, compared to the DPIL deep or medium response, the
curves have less near-borehole sensitivity or cave-effect.

SOFTWARE FOCUSING, CONTINUED
130551-935

topic: Brief Description Of Service/Equipment - 3.7 BOREHOLE CORRECTION
chunk_text:
BOREHOLE CORRECTION
We have seen that the software focusing process does a great deal towards removing the
borehole effect from the final curves.  However, it is still the case that if we know the borehole
conductivity and size, we can improve the rejection of the borehole signal.  This can be done in
the same way as conventional borehole corrections for induction tools.  Since there are so many
more measurements, however, it is essential this is performed by the software.

topic: Brief Description Of Service/Equipment - 3.8 SKIN EFFECT
chunk_text:
SKIN EFFECT
The above geometric factor theory assumes the response caused by a particular loop of
formation is independent of all other loops of formation, and that the total response can be
found by totaling all of the individual responses.  In fact the signal is attenuated, and delayed,
by conductive formations between the transmitter, the earth loop, and the receiver.  This
attenuation is commonly called the "skin-effect."  The consequence of this is that the received
signal is usually less than predicted by the Doll theory, and also the detailed shape of the 2-D
geometric factor changes with conductivity.  To deal with this we apply a form of skin-effect
correction, and we also use a filtering technique called "adaptive filtering" which is described in
greater detail later.

topic: Brief Description Of Service/Equipment - 3.9 SKIN-EFFECT CORRECTION
chunk_text:
SKIN-EFFECT CORRECTION
There are various ways to perform the skin-effect correction.
In previous tools, the correction was based on the assumption the tool was in a homogenous
environment.  The relationships then between the true conductivity and the measured
conductivity was fairly well defined and a correction algorithm was defined using just the in-
phase, or real, signal.  This technique presents problems at high conductivities, for instance,
below about one (1) ohm-m, for a 20kHz induction measurement, the results become less
reliable.
Another technique used to some extent in the DPIL is the quadrature curve.  The quadrature
signal, after the direct coupled signal is removed, can be shown to be very closely related to the
skin-effect, and corrections based on the quadrature signal are straight-forward to apply and
overcome the difficulty described above for in-phase only schemes.  The problem is that at low
conductivities, the quadrature signal is unreliable and sensitive to properties other than
conductivity such as magnetic permeability variations.  In the DPIL, we therefore use various
combinations of the in-phase only and quadrature based corrections.
A third technique is based on the observation that skin-effect is also a function of the frequency
of operation.  The rate of change of signal with frequency can also be shown to be closely
related to the skin-effect.  We use this fact to perform skin-effect correction in HDIL.  We
calculate not only the apparent conductivity at each frequency, but also the rate of change of
conductivity with frequency.  This form of correction is similar in performance to the
quadrature based correction, but does not have the same problems at low conductivity.
12
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE/EQUIPMENT — 1515 EA/MA HDIL

ADAPTIVE FILTERING
An undesirable consequence of the skin-effect is the 2-D geometrical factor of each
measurement varies with the conductivity environment.  This means filters designed for a low
conductivity environment will not work in a higher conductivity environment.  For this reason,
several sets of filters are designed for various background conductivities.  The filters are chosen
by first estimating the average conductivity in the region, and then choosing the appropriate
filter set based on this value.  As you can see, with each filter set being as much as 50-feet long,
and with different filter sets for every target response and background conductivity, there are a
large number of filter coefficients to handle.  That is why this is an "ECLIPS Only Tool."

topic: Brief Description Of Service/Equipment - 3.10 RESOLUTION MATCHING
chunk_text:
RESOLUTION MATCHING
It can be shown theoretically, and it is also intuitively believable, the deeper into the formation
we try to focus our measurements, the poorer the vertical resolution we can achieve.  This can
be seen by examining the geometric factors in Figure 7.  In each case we have tried to achieve
as ideal a vertical resolution as possible for a given depth of investigation.  We can see the
deeper investigating responses are spread out more and have poorer vertical and radial
resolution.  In a sense, these responses represent the best resolutions which can be achieved
while maintaining low sensitivity to near borehole conductivity.  We call these curves "true-
resolution" logs and consider them our basic measurement which we can offer the customer.
However, although true-resolution curves are in many ways the "best" measurement, they do
have one undesirable feature.  Because they each have different vertical resolutions, in thin and
even not so thin impermeable beds, they will separate and give the appearance of significant
invasion.  This is illustrated in Figure 9 which shows the true-resolution curves from our test
well.  This well is cased with plastic pipe so, apart from a different conductivity seen by the
shallowest measurement, we would expect all of the other curves to stack and indicate no
invasion.  They do not.  Some customers do not like this and prefer logs which stack in thin,
impermeable zones.
We can satisfy our customers the same way our competitors do by taking high resolution data
from our shallow measurements and adding it to the deeper ones to give the same apparent
vertical resolution.  When we do this we create what we call "resolution-matched curves," and

BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE/EQUIPMENT — 1515 EA/MA HDIL

RESOLUTION MATCHING
Remember when we do this we are adding high resolution data from close to the borehole.  We
have not changed our ability to resolve changes in conductivity far from the borehole.  The
average affect of this extra data is negligible near the borehole, so the depth of investigation
does not change.  The full effect can be seen by examining the geometric factors in Figure 10
which are for a resolution-matched curve set.  We see that near the borehole they all have
similar responses, so the high resolution shape of the curves will be the same.  Further from the
borehole we see what is left of the original "true-res" responses which give the depth of
investigation in thicker beds where the near-borehole effects cancel out.
There are a few things to be aware of when using the resolution matched curves.
1.
In a thin invaded bed, all curves will respond according to the invaded zone profile.
We cannot measure Rt in a thin invaded bed.
2.
In thicker invaded beds, where for instance the invasion is more conductive than the
shoulder bed and the un-invaded zone is resistive, there is the likelihood of spikes and
other artifacts at the bed boundaries.
3.
We have reintroduced the cave effect.
For this reason the matched resolution curves should be used with caution, and preferably when
caves, and the invasion profiles described above, are not present.

RESOLUTION MATCHING, CONTINUED

GENERAL
The 1515 High Definition Induction Log is a feedthrough, WTS instrument, so it can
theoretically be combined with any other WTS instrument.  The following issues should be
considered when selecting possible combinations.

topic: Combination Logging - 1.1 CURRENT CONSUMPTION 1.2 TELEMETRY LIMITATIONS
chunk_text:
CURRENT CONSUMPTION
Its current consumption is around 260mA, so this should not be a limiting factor. 
TELEMETRY LIMITATIONS
With the release of ECLIPS Release 3.0, Subsets 1 and 2 sample-per-foot acquisition was
implemented.  HDIL should NOT be the limiting factor due to loggin speed.  The tool is able to
switch from Mode 5 to Mode 7.  But due to limitations in uphole software, the Mode 7 black
block is still required to switch the tool to transmit data on Mode 7.

TOOL STRENGTH
HDIL's tensile strength (50,000 lbf.) and compressive strength (12,800 lbf. in an 8-inch hole)
allow tools to be run below it.  However it is not as strong as some other instruments so the
weight of tools run below HDIL should be kept as low as possible.  Local and customer policies
should be reviewed before running a tool containing a R/A source below HDIL.

TESTED COMBINATIONS
HDIL may be combined in almost any standard WTS string.  The exceptions are:
!
Do not run HDIL in combination with DIFL.
!
Do not run HDIL above MRIL.  It must be run below the MRIL.

topic: Analyses Software - 2.0 UNITS AND SAMPLING RATE 3.0 USING HDIL PROCESSING
chunk_text:
UNITS AND SAMPLING RATE
Unless otherwise specified, the unit of conductivity is in mS/m, the borehole diameter is in inch,
and the resistivity is in ohm-m.  A sampling rate of 3 inches, or 4 points per foot, is assumed
for this version. 
USING HDIL PROCESSING
This section shows how to input the necessary parameters for HDIL processing.
To use the processing software under eXpress, start from "Analysis" and then "HDIL" in the
eXpress menu bar.  Double click on "HDIL", and the "HDIL Processing Functions Dialog" is
then launched.  In this window, there is a list of input variables and choices of processing.
1)
Input the XTF file name and the processing depth interval as in any other eXpress
applications.  To select the proper XTF name, the user may also go to the "File" menu
of the launched window and choose "Open XTF file...".
2)
Select the processing functions.  There are six (6) processing functions: preprocessing
(PREP), skin-effect correction (SEC), borehole correction (BHC), true resolution
filtering (TRF), vertical resolution matching (VRM), and the synthesis of DPIL curves
(SYN).  These functions can be run individually or consecutively.  The order of
processing is: (1) PREP, (2) SEC, (3) BHC, (4) TRF, (5) VRM, and (6) SYN.  It is
suggested to run them together by highlighting all of them.  If the user wants to use any
curve name other than the defaults, the change can be performed at this time.
3)
Select the temperature correction flag.  The default is OFF.  Use ON if the data is from
ECLIPS 2.1 or earlier.  In the "ON" case, the mandrel asset number and the

ANALYSES SOFTWARE — 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-980

PROCESSING FUNCTIONS
This section explains the processing functions and their associated parameters described in the
previous section.  The functionalities of each processing function are also explained.  The input
and output curve names are defined such that the results from individual functions can be
checked if the user wants to.

HDIL PREPROCESSING
This function performs some preprocessing of the raw measurements.  It corrects for the
measurement drift caused by temperature variation during logging.  It also eliminates single-
point bad point (e.g. a bad point caused by temporary telemetry malfunction).
Input variables:
PRPIN0, PRPIN1, PRPIN2, PRPIN3, PRPIN4, PRPIN5, PRPIN6 ) the real and
quadrature components of the apparent conductivities for subarrays 0 to 6 respectively
(in wave format).  Each contains responses at eight frequencies (10, 30, 50, 70, 90,
110, 130, 150 kHz).  The default inputs are SGMi where i=0,1,...,6.
Output variables:
PRPOUT0 R, PRPOUT1 R, PRPOUT2 R, PRPOUT3 R, PRPOUT4 R, PRPOUT5 R,
PRPOUT6 R ) the real part of apparent conductivities (in wave format).  The default
curve names are SGMiR where i=0,1,...,6 corresponding to subarrays 0 to 6
respectively.
PRPOUT0 Q, PRPOUT1 Q, PRPOUT2 Q, PRPOUT3 Q, PRPOUT4 Q, PRPOUT5 Q,
PRPOUT6 Q ) the quadrature part of apparent conductivities (in wave format).  The
default names are SGMiQ where i=0,1,...,6 corresponding to subarrays 0 to 6
respectively.  These quadrature components are available but presently not used in the
processing.
Temperature correction input variables:
If you are processing data acquired through ECLIPS 2.2 software, please bypass this
part.  The temperature correction option is included in eXpress because the ECLIPS 2.1
software does not perform the correction.  The following parameter and curve are
needed for the purpose:
ASSETN ) the mandrel asset number (a six digit number) for retrieving the temperature
correction coefficients which are unique for each tool.
TPCRVN ) the temperature curve name (default input is RXTEMP) from the
temperature sensor at the receiver end.  If there is no temperature curve available,

ANALYSES SOFTWARE — 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-980

HDIL SKIN-EFFECT CORRECTION
The purpose of SEC is to have apparent conductivity equal to the true conductivity in a
homogeneous formation.  It also improves the linearity of the tool response with respect to the
formation conductivity such that simpler focusing algorithm can be applied.  SEC combines the
apparent conductivity at eight frequencies into one skin-effect corrected apparent conductivity
for each subarray.
During SEC, the function also generates for all subarrays the responses at the frequency
corresponding to that of DPIL (typically 20 kHz) for the purpose of DPIL synthesis.
Input variables:
SECIN0, SECIN1, SECIN2, SECIN3, SECIN4, SECIN5, SECIN6 ) the real part of
apparent conductivities.  The default input names are SGMiR where i=0,1,...,6
corresponding to subarrays 0 to 6 respectively.  Each SGMiR contains 8 frequency
responses in eXpress wave-format.
PFREQ ) the operating frequency of the synthesized DPIL tool responses.  It is
typically 20,000 Hz, but can be 10 kHz or 40 kHz.
Output variables:
SECOUT0, SECOUT1, SECOUT2, SECOUT3, SECOUT4, SECOUT5, SECOUT6 )
skin-effect corrected conductivities.  The default inputs are SECiA where i=0,1,...,6
corresponding to subarrays 0 to 6 respectively.
CiSmF ) synthesized apparent conductivities of subarrays 0 to 6 at the frequency of 10,
20, or 40 kHz as denoted by m=1,2 or 4. And i=0,1,...,6 corresponding to subarrays 0
to 6.
SECQUA0, SECQUA1, SECQUA2, SECQUA3, SECQUA4, SECQUA5,
SECQUA6, ) quality indicators from the relative error of subarrays 0 to 6 (i=0,1,...,6)
averaged over all frequencies of the same subarray.  The default names are QUAiA for
i=0,1,...,6. The indicators are for internal use only.
5
ANALYSES SOFTWARE — 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-980

HDIL BOREHOLE CORRECTIONS
The purpose of BHC is to explicitly eliminate the borehole contribution to the apparent
conductivity measurements.  This step is needed because we want to incorporate any known
information such as the mud conductivity and the borehole diameter from other types of
measurements.
NOTE
This version of borehole correction can handle a tool centered in a borehole or a
tool with 1.5" standoff.  A new version for tools operating with standoffs of any
other size(s) will be available soon.
Input variables:
BHCIN0, BHCIN1, BHCIN2, BHCIN3, BHCIN4, BHCIN5, BHCIN6 ) skin-effect
corrected conductivities.  The defaults are SECiA, where i=0,1,...,6 corresponding to
subarrays 0 to 6 respectively.
CALCRVN ) caliper curve used in borehole correction.  Default input curve name is
CAL.
BHDIA ) bit size in inches.
RM ) resistivity of mud in ohm-m at the bottom of the borehole.  If it is oil-based mud,
select "oil-based mud".
Output variables:
BHCOUT0, BHCOUT1, BHCOUT2, BHCOUT3, BHCOUT4, BHCOUT5,
BHCOUT6 ) borehole corrected conductivities.  The default input curve names are
BHCiA, where i=0,1,...,6 corresponding to subarrays 0 to 6 respectively.
6
ANALYSES SOFTWARE — 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-980

topic: Analyses Software - 4.4 HDIL TRUE RESOLUTION FILTERING
chunk_text:
HDIL TRUE RESOLUTION FILTERING
This function combines the apparent conductivities from different subarrays within a depth
interval to form the focused conductivities of various depth of investigations.  The resolution
enhancement is achieved within the limit set by the induction physics, i.e. the shallower the
focusing the better is the resolution of the focused curve.
Input variables:
TRFIN0, TRFIN1, TRFIN2, TRFIN3, TRFIN4, TRFIN5, TRFIN6 ) borehole
corrected conductivities.  The default inputs are BHCiA, where i=0,1,...,6
corresponding to subarrays 0 to 6 respectively.
Output variables:
TRFOUT1, TRFOUT2, TRFOUT3, TRFOUT4, TRFOUT5, TRFOUT6 ) focused
conductivities.  The default curves are TkI, where k=10, 20, 30, 60, 90, 120
corresponding to the focusing depth of 10, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 inches of radius.
Control button:
Choice of the number of subarrays used in the focusing.  It can be seven (0 through 6)
or six (1 through 6) subarrays.  Currently, we use the six-subarray choice as the default.

topic: Analyses Software - 4.5 HDIL VERTICAL RESOLUTION MATCHING
chunk_text:
HDIL VERTICAL RESOLUTION MATCHING
This function provides resolution matching to the TRF conductivities such that the curves
focused to various radial depths will be of the same apparent vertical resolution.  It is based on
the fact that in a stratified formation the shallow curves can be used to enhance the vertical
resolution of the deep ones.  The vertical resolutions for data with six subarrays (1 through 6)
are 2 ft. and 4 ft.  The choices for data with seven subarrays (0 through 6) are 1 ft., 2 ft., and 4
ft.
Input variables:
VRMIN1, VRMIN2, VRMIN3, VRMIN4, VRMIN5, VRMIN6 ) focused
conductivities.  The default input names are TkI, where k=10, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120
corresponding to the focusing depth of 10, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 inches of radius.
Output variables:
VRMOUTkn ) vertical resolution matched conductivities.  The default names to use are
VkInV, where: k=10, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 corresponding to the focusing depth of
10, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 inches of radius, and n=1,2,4 corresponding to 1, 2, and 4
ft. of vertical resolutions.
7
ANALYSES SOFTWARE — 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-980

topic: Analyses Software - 4.6 DPIL SYNTHESIS FROM HDIL
chunk_text:
DPIL SYNTHESIS FROM HDIL
This function synthesizes the deep and medium induction tool responses from the array
induction tool.  The measurement frequency is 20kHz by default and could also be 10 or 40 kHz
if needed.  The synthesized curves are skin-effect corrected using the conventional correction
algorithm.  The deep induction also has a three-point deconvolution applied.  The reason for
skin-effect correction and three-point deconvolution is to conform to the standard DPIL
processing procedures.
Input variables:
DPILIN1, DPILIN2, DPILIN3, DPILIN4, DPILIN5, DPILIN6 ) the synthesized
apparent conductivities.  The default inputs are CiSmF for the frequency of 10, 20, or
40 kHz as denoted by m=1,2 or 4 and subarrays 1 through 6 as denoted by i=1,...,6.
Output variables:
DPILOUT1, DPILOUT2 ) deep and medium apparent conductivities of the synthesized
DPIL responses.  The default names for them are DPILD, DPILM.
8
ANALYSES SOFTWARE — 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-980

PROCESSING QUALITY ASSURANCE
The processing quality has to be verified according to the induction physics and the
measurement objectives.  Following is a list of suggestions on quality assurance:
!
Check self-consistency among the responses for various subarrays of the same
frequency.  The curves should have "smooth" transition from short to long subarrays.
A short subarray has more variations than a long one.
!
Inspect the curves of different frequencies (or spectrum) of the same subarray.  The
curves should be in good order from low to high frequencies.  Usually the higher the
frequency the smaller the apparent conductivity (this is also an indication that the
temperature correction has been applied correctly).  In extremely conductive formation,
the apparent conductivity at the high frequency end might be negative.
!
The resulting curves after skin-effect correction already have quite good correlation
among each other as well as with the true formation conductivity distribution.  These
curves usually have good "ordering" from short to long subarrays.
!
During the skin-effect correction, quality control curves are generated to show at each
depth the percentage of misfit between the measured and the predicted apparent
conductivities.  These quality indicators usually have a few percent at most.  In very
resistive or very conductive formations, the percentage could be larger.  These
indicators are for internal use only.
!
The true resolution focused curves should also have good relationship among the
shallow to deep focusing.  A deep one is normally smoother than a shallow one.
!
The vertical resolution matched curves should be examined more carefully.  Usually if
there are high contrast between neighboring layers and/or invasion zone(s), there would
be over enhancement or sometimes even spike in the focused curves.  If it is purely 1 D
(horizontal layers without invasion) and moderate contrast (less than 10's) the curves
should not show any abnormal features.
!
The curves should agree in impermeable zone.  Failure to agree could be improper
borehole correction, calibration or temperature correction.  It is also possible that a
small amount of invasion has occurred which is not detected by normal logging tools.
In permeable zones, the invasion profiles should be reasonable as discussed above.
!
Efforts are made to minimize the spikes and artifacts.  However, in some rare situations,
spikes can be caused by: (1) borehole rugosity at high conductivity contrast between
borehole and formation; (2) deep conductive invasion near bed boundaries; (3) irregular
sampling caused by stick and pull; (4) boundaries of high contrast beds; and (5) large
relative dip.

topic: Log Quality Control. - 1.0 LOG QUALITY CONTROL
chunk_text:
LOG QUALITY CONTROL
The real-time log quality control procedure is described in detail in the ECLIPS Operating
procedures.  Quality control on the end product, i.e. focused curves, is an extension of the
normal techniques used for Log Quality Control of resistivity data.

FOCUSED RESISTIVITIES
The focused conductivities can be checked for agreement with what is expected in the well. That
is:
!
Curves should agree in impermeable zone.  Failure to agree could be improper borehole
correction, calibration or temperature correction.  It is also possible that a small amount
of invasion has occurred which is not detected by normal logging tools.
!
Curves should be free of unexplained spikes and artifacts.  Spikes can be caused by:
-
Borehole rugosity
-
Deep conductive invasion near bed boundaries
-
Stick and Pull
-
High contrast bed boundaries.
-
Large relative dip
NOTE
If the raw data contain, for instance, one isolated bad sample, this will appear on
the focused curves as an anomaly which may be 50 or more feet long, because of the
length of the focusing filters.
!
Invasion profiles should be reasonable in permeable zones.

LOG DIAGNOSTICS
In the case of a "problem log," that is one with unexpected behavior, ECLIPS provides a
number of ways to examine the tool data in order to help determine the cause of the anomaly.
If the problem is suspected to be in processing, the mitre.diag.log presentation is an excellent
place to begin.  Following are some of the things you can look for in each of the views shown in
These windows show data sent by the tool with very little processing applied, and therefore are
the best place to check that the tool is functioning correctly.  Once characteristic signatures are
familiar, the identification of certain anomalous situations in the tool will become easier in these
windows than after the data have been converted to the frequency domain.
The mitre.wave window has the curves scaled so that their amplitudes are proportional to the
voltages going into the A/Ds.  With the default values (ie, 100% Y scaling), they are scaled
with one (1) volt between each baseline.  This presentation is best when thee are suspected
problems in the digital part of the instrument.
For example, if an A/D stacker is not providing data, the wave form will display -2.048 Volts
for that channel.  Any noise being picked up after the pre-amplifiers would tend to have the
same amplitude on each channel.  However, due to short space channels having loser gain than
the longer channel — They have a wider dynamic range. — the tendency will be to read the
lower amplitudes in a uniform formation.
The mitre.input.wave window is scaled so that the amplitudes are proportional to the voltages
coming out of the coils.  Now the signatures will be about the same amplitude if the tool is in a
uniform formation.  Referring to Figure 984-01, the area under the pulses is proportional to
conductivity so even in this window a uniform progression should be seen, depending upon
whether the borehole is conductive or resistive.  The skin effect can also bee seen, which causes
the pulses to broaden, and this effect should become more pronounced with longer spacings.
The wave windows are not delayed, so features in the well will go past the arrays one-by-one,
beginning with array 6.  By comparison, faults or events within the tool will affect all channels

LOG INTERPRETATION — 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-984

SPECTRUM WINDOW
In this window, expect to see the following:
!
All curves decreasing as frequency increases, especially on longer spacings.  The
shorter spacings will normally appear almost horizontal.
!
Excessive curvature of curves at low frequencies and shorter spacings may indicate a
calibration or temperature correction problem.  The 10 and 30kHz curves are not
normally very good on the short spacings, and are not used.  However, they are good
diagnostic values since they are often the first ones to go wrong if there is a problem.
!
At very low conductivities (< 20mS/m), noise and other errors may cause spectra to
have abnormal shapes.
!
Smooth variation from channel to channel.
!
This windows is also the most obvious place to see the notorious 90kHz noise exists.  If
it is restricted to channel 6 at 90kHz, the log should be alright.  If it is bleeding over
into other frequencies or channels, the log may be noisy and show poor curve
agreement.
!
If glitches or erratic behavior is seen in the spectrum window which cannot be seen in
the wave windows, suspect the temperature measurement.  If RXTEMP is misbehaving,
record the log with the temperature correction OFF.  The shallow curves will read too
low conductivity, but the deep measurements have almost no temperature effect so they
can still be used.

MITRE.DIAG.LOG
This is probably the most useful presentation for diagnosing a problem log.  It displays the skin-
effect corrected curves (msecA).  If these look good, the tool is functioning correctly.  It shows
the borehole effect corrected curves (mbhcA), allowing the borehole correction to be checked
and parameters adjusted if necessary.  It also shows the true resolution focused curves (mOrD
and mOcD) in order to check whether the focusing is the source of the problem.  Displayed are
all three types of curves on a linear scale.  This makes it easier to distinguish between offset
type errors and real spikes.  An offset can shift a curve towards zero or even negative.  This will
appear as a spike when the linear scale is also the best way to examine borehole corrections
since they are approximate shifts.
The skin-effect corrected curves should be free of excessive noise or spikes.  They should be in
a reasonable order, that is, there should be a smooth progression from array to array.  These
curves are uncorrected so the order should reflect the borehole conductivity or invasion profile
and deeper curves may have shoulder-bed effect.  At this stage they should have no negative
values except momentarily if there are conductive wash-outs.
Once the borehole correction is applied, arrays 0, 1 and 2 are expected to read approximately
the same since they are each reading the conductivity of the formation just beyond the borehole.
Array 0 will be very inaccurate after borehole correction because most of its signal is borehole.
However, if Array 0 begins to approach Array 1, there is a good chance the borehole correction
parameters are correct.  In ECLIPS 2.2, Release 2, Array 0 is not available for the msec and
mbhc curves, so use Coils 1 and 2 instead.
4
LOG INTERPRETATION — 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-984

MITRE.ALL.LOG
The mitre.all.log presentation allows for comparisons in the various resolution options of the
processing.  If there are problems with the true-resolution curves, it will lead to difficulties and
aggravation in the resolution enhancement process.  In some cases, true-resolution curves may
be the only curves worth processing.  In ECLIPS 2.2, the resolution matching is likely too
aggressive and may cause excessive spiking in resistive structures (>20 ohm-m).

LOG INTERPRETATION — 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-984

LOG PRESENTATION
The standard presentation will be to show the true resolution curves (m0rY), or the resolution-
matched curves (m4rY, m2rY) on a standard 4-cycle or 2-cycle logarithmic grid.  See Figure
996-01.  The "Y" in the curve name refers to the depth of investigation (1=10",
2=20",...x=120").  The curve presentations are as follows:

topic: Lab Safety - LAB SAFETY -- 1515 EA/MA HDIL 1.0 GENERAL SAFETY INSTRUCTIONS
chunk_text:
1

130551-954 
GENERAL SAFETY INSTRUCTIONS
!
WEIGHT : The combined total weight of the 1515 EA and MA sections is 433 pounds
(see 130551-025).  Titanium has been utilized for all structural components in an effort
to reduce the total weight of the instrument(s).  Never hoist or lift the tool when the
Electronics and Mandrel are connected together unless properly supported at three or
more points.  THE EA AND MA SHOULD BE ASSEMBLED VERTICALLY OVER
THE WELL TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE MANDREL.
!
PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE : A pressure relief valve is designed into the system to
allow the technician to manually release the 7.0 psi internal oil pressure prior to
disassembly.  If the tool is heated in an oven where no hydrostatic pressure is present to
reduce the expansion of the oil, the port plug labeled "FILL" should be removed (while
in the oven).
!
BELLEVILLE SPRING and EQUALIZER SPRING : The stored energy in the Belleville
spring stack is 336 in./lbs.  This spring is completely enclosed in a shroud.  The stored
energy in the hydraulic equalizer is 43.6 in./lbs.  This spring is completely enclosed in
the equalizer housing.  Though both areas are enclosed, exercise caution.
!
ELECTRICAL : Beyond precautions normal for electronic equipment, this tool does not
require special considerations as far as safety goes.  No high voltages are generated in
the tool.  Transformers are used to reduce the 180 V in the WTS bus to relatively small
values.  The exception may be the transmitter section where ±55 Volts are generated.
!
HOUSEKEEPING : When filling the mandrel with silicone oil, any oil spilled on the
floor should be quickly cleaned up or covered with an oil absorbent material to prevent
slipping and falling hazards.

1
LAB HEAT TEST PROCEDURES — 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-959
15 AUGUST 1997
CAUTION
IF THE TOOL IS HEATED IN A LAB OVEN, THE PORT PLUG LABELED
"FILL" MUST BE REMOVED WHILE THE TOOL IS IN THE OVEN.  FAILURE
TO DO SO WILL RESULT IN DAMAGE TO THE TOOL SINCE THE
COMPENSATION SECTION IS NOT LARGE ENOUGH TO ACCOMMODATE
THE INCREASED OIL VOLUME WITHOUT THE PRESENCE OF
HYDROSTATIC PRESSURE.  PLACE A CONTAINER UNDER THE TOOL TO
CATCH THE OVERFLOW.  WHEN THE TOOL HAS COOLED TO ROOM
TEMPERATURE, REFILL THE TOOL WITH SILICONE OIL AS PER THE
PROCEDURES LISTED IN SECTION -955 OF THIS MANUAL.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 1.0 GENERAL DESCRIPTION 2.0 HDIL TRANSMITTER CONTROLLER BOARD, P/N 164807-100 . . . . . . 5
chunk_text:
GENERAL DESCRIPTION
1 
HDIL TRANSMITTER CONTROLLER BOARD, P/N 164807-100 5

HDIL TRANSMITTER CONTROLLER BOARD, P/N 164807-100
NOTE
Distinguish which number board you are using, 164807-000 or 187984-000, before
proceeding with the following circuit descriptions.
An SAB80 C166 (from now on referred as SAB166) µController is the nucleus of the board.
Timers embedded in the chip generate the PAT_i signals required by the transmitter of the tool
to work.  The part has two serial ports.  One of these ports (SERIAL 1) is used to receive
commands from the EA electronics (P3.9) and transmit status and data (P3.8).  Serial
communication is asynchronous: 1 start bit, 8 data bits and 1 stop bit.  Baud rate is 9600.
PDS 301 (U2) provides the EPROM and RAM and associated glue-logic required by the
Controller to operate properly.  The SAB166 has 2 K of internal RAM memory but this memory
is used for stack purposes.
U13 and U15 are A/D converters.  These chips sample the signals generated by two RTDS
(connected to TMP1_RTD+ and TMP2_RTD+).  The RTD associated to TMP2_RTD is placed
close to the Transmitter Coil.  The other RTD is placed between the main and bucker coils of
subarray 6.  A shielded, twisted-pair wire takes the signal of this RTD through the Preamplifier
Section into the BeCu pipe to the Transmitter Controller Board.  The method used to measure
temperature is based on an Improved Holland Current Source.  Basically, the first stage of U12
provides a source of current.  This current generates a voltage which varies with temperature
when applied to the RTD.  The voltage is amplified by the second stage of U12.  U11 provides
an offset voltage in order to maximize the dynamic range of the measurement.
Part of Port 1 (P1.0 - P1.4) is used to generate signals required to switch latch relays.  Most of
these relays are placed in the Preamplifier section of tool.  They are used to route different
signals to the electronics channels on the upper side of the mandrel.  One latch relay is placed in
the transmitter controller board and it is used to select the reference signal as will be explained
later.
Latch relays require pulses to be switched from one state to another.  Pulses of approximately
50 msec are generated by the controller to switch the relays.  U9 (MC14160), Q3 and Q4
provide the required driving capability.
For analog signal measurements, a 10-bit A/D converter with 10 multiplexed input channels and
a sample and hold circuit has been integrated on chip in the SAB166.  Several auxiliary signals
which show the status of the tool are sampled by this A/D through U16.
A timer in the SAB166 (T1) generates a 500 KHz square signal (P3.1/T1 OUT).  Edges of this
clock are used to generate a 1 MHZ signal at the output of U18.  CC2 IO is used to enable or
disable the 1 MHZ signal, and is generated as a request from the upper electronics and
ultimately from the Surface System.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 2.1 HDIL TRANSMITTER CONTROLLER BOARD, P/N 187984-100 . . . . . . 6
chunk_text:
HDIL TRANSMITTER CONTROLLER BOARD, P/N 187984-100 6

HDIL TRANSMITTER CONTROLLER BOARD, P/N 187984-100
NOTE
Distinguish which number board you are using, 164807-000 or 187984-000, before
proceeding with the following circuit descriptions.
This board upgrades the original, 164807-000 XC.  Some "clean up" can be determined
concerning the digital section of this board.  However, all of the functions are the same.  See
section 2.0.
Features which are unique to this board include a new serial EEPROM which has been added.
This EEPROM contains 1 K bytes of data used to characterize parameters of the mandrel (e.g.
serial number, temperature coeff., etc.).  A WTS command (0x15xx) supports the reading of
this EEPROM.  Eclips or WinMitre cannot write to this memory (the writing process cannot be
performed thru WTS, to avoid "accidents").  The EEPROM must be programmed during the
mandrel manufacturing process, and is mounted in a DIP socket.  If the Transmitter Controller
Board is replaced, the EEPROM must be unplugged and placed on the new board.  The
EEPROM always remains with its mandrel.
The temperature measurement circuitry has been changed in order to achieve better precision.
Description of one of the circuits follows, the other is identical.  U13/Q6 are a source of
current.  Approximately 2mA are forced thru the Temperature Sensor.  Voltage at the drain of
Q6 will be (5 Volts - 2mA.Rt).  U13 behaves as a amplifier and an offset generator to optimize
the dynamic range of the A/D converter.  At room temperature (25 EC), the signal at the input of
the A/D converter is slightly negative (-1.4 Volts).  At 200 EC, the signal will be approximately
8.1 Volts.  Observe that R15/R16 provide offset reference to both circuits.  And U10 provides a
single reference for the two sensors.  OP07's have been used due to their almost 0 offset voltage
specification.  These OP-Amps buffer the reference from the rest of the circuit without sacrifice
of precision.  R6/R7 and R13/R14 are 0.1 % tolerance resistors to minimize errors in the
gain/offset process.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 2.2 TYPICAL ACQUISITION SEQUENCE . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 7 3.0 PREAMPLIFIER BOARD WITH BALANCED OUTPUT . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 8
chunk_text:
TYPICAL ACQUISITION SEQUENCE 7 

1515 TRANSMITTER DRIVER, P/N 164802-100 9

1515 TRANSMITTER DRIVER, P/N 187985-100 10

PREAMPLIFIER BOARD WITH BALANCED OUTPUT, P/N 164630-100
Three (3) sources of signals can be applied to the input of each channel of the preamplifier
board.  These sources are:
1)
Subarray Receiver coils;
2)
A “CAL” Signal (a Reference Signal, generated by the Transmitter Section of the tool,
is attenuated and injected at the input of the Preamplifier);
3)
A Zero signal.  In this mode the amplifiers' inputs are connected to the Be-Cu pipe (the
common of the tool).
Latching relays route these different sources to the preamplifiers' input stage.
Required processing gain varies according to the particular subarray.  Subarrays placed far from
the transmitter require more gain than those placed nearby.  The first stage of the preamplifier
board is a very low-noise, broad-band amplifier.  The gain of this stage is different for each
channel.
The second stage is a 4-pole Bessel low-pass filter with a gain of one (1) in the pass band region.
Frequency cutoff is around 200 KHZ.  Bessel’s filters have very little ringing (linear phase
shift) to the step response.
The last stage is a differential-output buffer amplifier that converts a single-ended input signal to
a balanced output signal pair with high output drive.  The SSM-2141 is capable of driving
difficult loads, yielding low-distortion performance despite long cables.

topic: Circuit Descriptions - 5.0 INTERFACE BOARD FOR 1515 SPECTRAL ARRAY INDUCTION
chunk_text:
INTERFACE BOARD FOR 1515 SPECTRAL ARRAY INDUCTION, P/N 164809-100
This board takes care of minor chores required by the electronics to perform correctly.  These
chores are described next.
As mentioned before, all communication links between the Transmitter Controller and the
Upper Electronics are digital and meet all of the requirements of EIA Standard RS-422.
The BURST1/BURST2 signal is converted to an unbalanced unipolar signal by U6.  This signal,
now called SMPCLK has three functions:
1)
It passes through a buffer (U8).  The output of the buffer is called SMPCLK1, and this
signal strobes all the A/D converters in the Acquisition Boards.
2)
It is used to strobe constantly a retrigerable one-shot.  This one shot times out if
SMPCLK is missing for more than 4 µseconds, generating a high -to-low transition in
START1.  This signal, after passing through a driver stage and being renamed START,
re-initializes all of the Acquisition Modules.  START and SMPCLK are covered in
detail in the Acquisition Board description.
3)
It passes through another buffer (U3) and, as SMPCLK2, it is applied to a counter
embedded in the C30 DSP chip in the C30-Based Digital Controller.
When the C30-Based Digital Controller, P/N 164816-000, has to communicate with the
Transmitter Controller Board, it does so serially, generating a signal ASYCTX.  This is an
unbalanced (unipolar) signal.  The INTERFACE BOARD receives this unbalanced signal and
retransmits it balanced as TX1/TX2 meeting Standard RS-422.
RX1/RX2 is an asynchronous serial signal coming from the Transmitter Controller Board.  It is
converted to an unbalanced, unipolar signal named ASYCRX by U5 (DS2631).  This signal is
applied to the input of a UART located inside U1.  The UART detects the signal and retransmits
it to the C30-Based Digital Controller using OUT_SCLK, OUT_SDAT and OUT_EOC.  The
protocol used is described in detail in the description of the C30-Based Digital Controller, but is
basically a serial-synchronous protocol which uses OUT_EOC to mark the end of each
transmitted word.

ACQUISITION BOARDS (164815-100, 185337-100) 12

ACQUISITION BOARD, P/N 164815-100
Each Acquisition Board includes four (4) modules.  Each module is virtually identical to the rest
so only one of them will be described.
From the Analog perspective, a signal coming from the preamplifier is received by an SSM-
2141.  This is an integrated differential amplifier intended to receive balanced line inputs, with
very low distortion.  The output of the differential line receiver is applied to a non-inverting
stage that has a gain of five (5).  Finally, the signal goes through a level-shifting process and
into the A/D converter.
A description of the manner in which the level-shift takes place follows:
The A/D converter requires unipolar signals with amplitude between 0 and Vref.  In this
application, Vref is 4.096.  Vref is divided by two, with two 5-Kohm resistors.  This voltage is
added to the signal at the input of the buffer driving the input of the A/D.  It can be seen that
when no signal comes from the Preamplifier, the input of the A/D converter will be a DC level
of Vref/2.
From the digital perspective, a one MegaSample per second A/D Converter and an Analog
Devices 2101 DSP component take care of the Stacking Process.  Two kinds of events take
place in the Acquisition Module: Data Acquisition and Signature Transfer.
Data Acquisition
Two (2) signals control the Acquisition Process.  One of them is START.  A High-to-Low
transition of START initializes all of the functions of the DSP 2101.  Notice that Start is
actually an interrupt signal for the 2101.
The other control signal is SMPCLK.  This is a normally high signal.  Each transition from high
to low of this signal starts a digitizing process in the A/D.
For the next discussion take a look at Figure 945-05.  SMPCLK is applied to the S/H pin of the
A/D and that is the way it has been labeled on the figure.  A few nanoseconds after the start of
the conversion, EOC goes low generating an interrupt to the DSP processor.  The 2101, during
the conversion time, reads the data corresponding to the previous conversion.  You can see
when the 2101 is reading the A/D data bus because a PMS signal is generated by the DSP chip.
By the time EOC goes high, the DSP chip has already finished the reading process.  This
process continues as long as the SMPCLK’s keep strobing.  The DSP chip will build up a
signature according to the process described in the General Description of the tool.
CIRCUIT DESCRIPTIONS - 1515 EA/MA HDIL
130551-945

ACTEL FPGA FUNCTIONALITY
7.2.1
Control Register & IFP Data Shifters
The C-30 "sees" the FPGA as a set of registers that can be read or written.  These registers are
memory-mapped at locations 804400/03.  These addresses correspond to the expansion bus of
the C-30.
A 16-bit control register is provided to control various aspects of the external/internal operation
of the Actel part.  This control register is memory-mapped at 0x804403 on the expansion bus of
the TMS320.  The control bits are as follows:
Bit
Signal Name
Description

CPU FUNCTIONALITY 22
7.3.1 Power-on Reset 22
7.3.2 Manchester Interface 23

CPU FUNCTIONALITY
Reference drawing 164816-100
The CPU board has two distinct bus systems.  The primary address bus (A0 - A23) and data bus
(D0 - D31) provide a zero wait state high speed bus for program and data storage.  The
secondary address bus (XA0 - XA12) and data bus (XD0 - XD31) provide an auxiliary bus for
slower transactions.  The two busses are totally independent of one another, with their own
control signals.
7.3.1
Power-on Reset
Upon power up, a reset supervisor chip (U15) provides a 200 mS reset hold off, holding the
TMS reset pin (F1) low while the power supplies stabilize.  The interrupt vectors are in low
memory, and the reset vector is fetched from location 0x000000 on the primary bus. See Figure
945-07 below showing the +5 VD relative to U15 Pin 7 (RESET/).

An auxiliary port is provided via connector J1.  This is an 8 bit port with 3 address lines and a

transfers.  It is currently not used with the HDIL.

An ANICO PC-232 UART interface chip is shown on the schematic as U1.  This device enables
the TMS320 to communicate with an RS-232 port.  The component is not used by HDIL.

2.1 ASSEMBLY  PROCEDURES
2.1.1 UPPER PRESSURE SUB INSTALLATION

NOTE

All item numbers (Item ??) refer to materials contained on the BOM for drawing 164350-

000 unless otherwise stated.

1. Install two (2) O-rings (Item 10) on the outside diameter of the lower end of the Upper

Pressure Transition Sub (Item 9).   Install two (2) O-rings (Item 115) on the inside diameter of

the Upper Pressure Transition Sub.

2. Install three (3) port plugs (Item 39) into the Upper Pressure Transition Sub.

3. Install two (2) O-rings (Item 128 and 129) on the Bleed Valve (Item 127), and install the Bleed

Valve into the Upper Pressure Transition Sub.

4. Thread the Upper Pressure Transition Sub on to the mandrel.   Make certain the keys on the

Adjuster (Item 15) engage in the keyways on the Sub.   A pin wrench can be used in the holes

of Spacer 6 B (Item 109) as a back up when tightening the Upper Pressure Transition Sub to

the copper mandrel.

5. Tighten the Adjuster Collar (Item 16) against the Belleville Springs until the timing groove on

the outside diameter is flush with the end of Spacer 6 B (Item 109).   Install the Retaining Ring

(Item 110) against the Adjuster Collar.
2.1.2 COIL SECTION WIRING

1. Install seven (7) Receiver Pressure Terminal assemblies (item 130) and one Temperature/SP
Pressure Terminal (item 112) into the eight (8) holes in the Upper Pressure Transition Sub
(item 9).   Note that the Pressure Terminal assembly for the Temperature and SP should be
inserted in the hole labeled "T".   The labels for the holes are located on the upper end of the
sub.

2. Run a Temperature cable (item 152) from the Pressure Terminal (item 112) through the wire
groove to the Temperature Sensor (item 25).   Solder the wires to each terminal (item 24).

3. Place the SP contact assembly (item 20) in Spacer 6 A (item 106).   Run the SP wire in the
same groove with the Temperature wire up to the Upper Pressure Transition Sub.

4. Slide 5" of Shrink Tubing (item 171) over the uphole end of each of the nine cables   from the
Receiver Coils section.   Slide . 75" of Teflon Tubing (item 159) over the end of each wire of
the twisted pair.   Solder the two wires of each twisted pair to the Pressure Terminals as
indicaded below:

Coil 0 to Pressure Terminal 0.
Coil 1 to Pressure Terminal 1.
Coil 2 to Pressure Terminal 2.
Coil 3 to Pressure Terminal 3.
Coil 4 to Pressure Terminal 4.
Coil 5 to Pressure Terminal 5.
6 to Pressure Terminal 6.
Temperature twisted pair to Pressure Terminal T. SP
wire to Pressure Terminal T.

5. Slide the Teflon Tubing (item 159) over each solder joint to cover the joint.

6. Slide . 75" of Teflon Tubing (item 159) over the shield of each cable.  Solder the shields of the
receiver wires (Coil 0 thru 6) to the third pin of each pressure terminal. Slide the Teflon
Tubing over each solder joint to cover the joint.

7. Slide the Shrink Tubing (item 171) up to the solder connections.   Shrink the Tubing
around the cables.

8. Install the Retainer Ring (item 111) over Pressure Feed-thrus and secure with four (4)
socket head cap screws (item 113).

9. Install two (2) Solder Lugs (item 150) on the Retainer Ring with two (2) screws (item 151).

10. Solder the Temperature and SP Shield Wires to the Solder Lug (item 150) on the Retainer
Ring.   The other Solder Lug will be used for the Electrostatic Shield Wire.
2.1.3 RECEIVER ELECTRONICS INSTALLATION

1. Install two (2) O-rings (Item 4) on the OD of the upper end of the Upper Pressure
Transition Sub (Item 9).

2. Slide the Receiver Electronics Assembly (Item 6) on to the wire tube of the Sensor
Section Assembly.   The pins on the triangular chassis fit in the holes in the Upper
Pressure Transition Sub.   Tighten the set screws (Item 7) to secure the chassis.

3. Locate the seven (7) sets of coil wires which are routed through the Upper Pressure
Transition Sub (Item 9).   Solder the coil wires to the pre-amp PC Cards on the triangular
chassis.

4. Slide the Temperature and SP wires through Hole "B" which runs through the length of the
Triangular Chassis.   Solder the Temperature wires to the Mandrel Terminal Board. Solder the
SP wire to the WTS Terminal Board.

5. Plug in the connectors between the mandrel wire bundle and the WTS Terminal Board, and
Mandrel Terminal Board.

6. Screw the Pressure Housing (Item 8) on to the Upper Pressure Transition Sub.

7. Install the Spin Collar (Item 3) on the Top Sub (Item 1).   Install four (4) O-rings (Item 2 and
4) on the Top Sub.

8. Screw the Top Sub on to the Pressure Housing.

9. Rotate the 45-pin Connector (Item 125) until the holes in the connector housing (Item
120) align with the holes in the Top Sub.   Install the three (3) cap screws (Item 121).
2.1.4 MASS ISOLATION INSTALLATION

1. Install two (2) O-rings (Item 82 and 84) on both Zirconia insulators (Item 85).

Lubricate with silicone grease.

2. Insert both Zirconia insulators into the bore of the Mass Isolation Sub (Item 29) and push
all the way to the bottom of the bore.

NOTE


Orient the insulators so the outside diameter O-ring goes into the Mass Isolation

bore first.

3. Insert the Polypak seal (Item 86) into the bore of the Mass Isolation Sub (Item 29) and push all the
way to the insulators.

NOTE


Orient the Polypak so the flat side goes into the Mass Isolation bore first and the O-

ring side enters last.
2.1.5 OUTER FIBERGLASS SLEEVE INSTALLATION

1. Install two (2) O-rings (Item 28) on the uphole end of the Mass Isolation Sub.

2. To install the Outer Fiberglass Sleeve (Item 19), line up the SP electrode contact insert with the
"SP" label on the Mass Isolation Sub. Slide the sleeve over the Mandrel Assembly until the O-
rings engage on the sleeve' s inside diameter.

3. Screw the Sleeve Assembly Tool (Item 137) on to the Mass Isolation Sub. Use the Sleeve
Assembly Tool to push the Outer Fiberglass Sleeve over the O-rings until the three holes in the
sleeve align with the threaded holes in the Mass Isolation Sub. Remove the assembly tool.

4. Install three socket head cap screws (Item 83) in the Mass Isolation Sub to secure Outer
Fiberglass Sleeve.

5. Install the SP Contact Pin (Item 21) and O-ring (Item 22) into the SP insert located on the Outer
Fiberglass Sleeve.
2.1.6 LOWER PRESSURE TRANSITION SUB INSTALLATION

1. Insert the Ceramic Thrust Ring (Item 80) into the Mass Isolation Sub (Item 29).

2. Install two (2) O-rings (Item 35) on the Lower Pressure Transition Sub (Item 76). Grease with
Lubriplate #930-AA Grease,  P/N 205933-000.

3. Install the three (3) Pressure Feed-thru assemblies (Items 156, 157 & 158) in the Lower
Pressure Transition Sub (Item 76). Make sure the orientation slot in each Feed-thru is pointed
in the correct direction.

4. Slide the Lower Pressure Transition Sub over the mandrel wire bundle and into the Mass
Isolation Sub (Item 29).  Rotate so the four (4) holes in the Sub are aligned with the holes in the
Mass Isolation Sub. The three (3) Pressure Feed-thrus should be aligned with the three (3) wire
channels of the Transmitter Spacer (Item 89).
2.1.7 TRANSMITTER SECTION WIRING
2.1.7.1 Transmitter Wiring
1. Solder the wire from the outer layer of the Transmitter Coil (item 90) to the downhole

terminal (item 24) on the Transmitter Spacer (item 89). Solder the wire from the inner

layer of the Transmitter Coil to the uphole terminal on the Transmitter Spacer.

2. Slide the Transmitter cable from the Pressure Terminal (item 156) through the nearest

wire hole in the Mass Isolation Sub (item 29).

3. Strip outside teflon cover back 1. 25".

4. Trim all shield material back flush with teflon cover.   Strip teflon cover to expose 0.

25" shield.   Fold shield back over cover.

5. Cut a 5" length of flat braid (item 160) and wrap one turn around shield and solder.

Solder the other end of the braid to the ground lug (item 164) on the mandrel.

6. Strip and solder the black wire to the uphole terminal (item 24) holding the end of the

coil which comes from the inner layer winding of the coil.

7. Strip and solder the white wire to downhole terminal holding the end of the coil

which comes from the outer layer winding of the coil.

2.1.7.2 B-Field Wiring
1. Cut one red 24 awg (item 166) to a 72" length.

2. Face the instrument so the downhole end is to your right.   Loop the wire (near its

midpoint) around the center turn of Transmitter Coil (item 90) coil.   Tag or mark the

end of the wire (+ ) which is on the BOTTOM of the Transmitter coil so this end can be

identified later.

3. Join ends of the wire in a knot.   Grab the knot with a drill motor and twist until the

wire becomes tight against Transmitter Coil.
2.1.8 PRESSURE COMPENSATION SECTION

1. Install two (2) O-rings (Item 33) on to the downhole end of the Mass Isolation Sub (Item 29).

2. Screw the Lower Transition Housing (Item 75) on to the Mass Isolation Sub.   The Lower
Housing will shoulder on Lower Pressure Transition Sub (Item 76) and a 0. 05" gap will
remain between the Lower Housing and the Outer Fiberglass Sleeve (Item 19).

3. Install the two (2) set screws (Item 32) in the Lower Transition Housing.   Install the Port
Plug (Item 39) and two (2) O-rings (Item 4) on the Lower Transition Housing.

4. Install two (2) O-rings (Item 74) on to the Piston Shaft (Item 47).   Slide the Shaft over the
mandrel wire bundle and install in the Lower Pressure Transition Sub.

5. Install the Inner Wear Ring (Item 143) into the Spring Weldment Assembly (Item 41).

Slide the outer Oil Displacer (Item 73) over the Spring and against the threaded collar. Secure
the Displacer to the spring with the three (3) set screws (Items 148).   Make sure the Displacer
is centered around the Spring Assembly.   Screw the Spring Assembly into the Piston (Item 43),
HAND TIGHT ONLY.   Install the set screw (Item 42) in the Piston to secure it to the spring.
Install the Outer Wear Ring (Item 72) on to the Piston. Install outer T-seal (Item 44) on Piston.
Install the Outer Wiper (Item 45) on the piston. Install the Inner T-seal (Item 71) into the
Piston.   Install the Inner Wiper (Item 46) into the Piston.
2.1.9 TRANSMITTER ELECTRONICS SECTION

1. Feed the wires from the mandrel wire bundle through the upper end of the Transmitter
Backbone Assembly (Item 51), and screw the Spin Collar (Item 147) into the Hydraulic
Equalizer Sub (Item 67).   Tighten the set screw (Item 146) on the Spin Collar.

2. Plug in the connectors from the mandrel wire bundle to the PC boards on the  Transmitter
Backbone Assembly.   It is easier to remove the screws holding the boards to the backbone and
lift the boards up when plugging in the connectors.

3. Solder the AC Power wires from the mandrel wire bundle to the WTS Bus Terminal Board
on the Transmitter Backbone Assembly.   Solder the Transmitter wires to the terminals on
the Backbone.

4. Plug in the two In-line connectors coming from the connector on the Transmitter
Controller Board to the two (2) connectors in the Mandrel wire bundle.

NOTE


Before proceeding, ensure the Transmitter Electronics is functioning properly.
2.1.10
SILICONE OIL FILLING PROCEDURES
1.  Verify that the Oil Fill Vacuum Cart (F185123000) is in proper working condition. Refer
to document F1899900000 for maintenance and checkout of the oil fill/vacuum system.

2.  Refer to document 189569000 which provides general guidelines for the proper operation
of the oil fill/vacuum system.
3.  Connect the Silicone Oil Pump "output" (Pressure or Vacuum) to the port labeled FILL on
the Sub (Item 9).

4. Connect the Silicone Oil Pump "input" (Return From tool) to the port in the Lower Transition
Housing (Item 75).
2.1.11
LOWER WTS CONNECTOR ASSEMBLY

1. Screw the Pressure Housing (Item 52) on to the Hydraulic Equalizer Sub (Item 67).


2. Install four (4) O-rings (Item 4) on to the Lower Sub (Item 53).   Screw the Lower Sub on to
the Pressure Housing.

3. Rotate the WTS Connector (Item 60) into position and install three (3) socket head cap
screws (Item 61).

4. Screw the Bottom WTS Sub (Item 57) on to the Lower Sub.

5. Install two (2) O-rings (Item 55) on the Pressure Bulkhead (Item 54).   Install the Pressure
Bulkhead into the WTS Sub.   Install the Retaining Ring (Item 56) in the WTS Sub.

DISASSEMBLY  PROCEDURE 9
2.2.1
LOWER WTS CONNECTOR DISASSEMBLY 9
2.2.2
TRANSMITTER ELECTRONICS REMOVAL 9
2.2.3
PRESSURE COMPENSATION SECTION 10
2.2.4
OUTER FIBERGLASS SLEEVE REMOVAL10
2.2.5
LOWER PRESSURE TRANSITION SUB REMOVAL 11
2.2.6
MASS ISOLATION REMOVAL 11
2.2.7
RECEIVER ELECTRONICS DISASSEMBLY 12
2.2.8
UPPER PRESSURE TRANSITION SUB REMOVAL 12
3. 1515 ELECTRONICS SECTION 13
2.2 DISASSEMBLY  PROCEDURE
2.2.1 LOWER WTS CONNECTOR DISASSEMBLY

1. Remove the bottom thread protector (Item 58).

2. Remove the Retaining Ring (Item 56) from the WTS Bottom Sub (Item 57).

3. Remove the Pressure Bulkhead (Item 54) from the WTS Bottom Sub.

4. Unscrew the Bottom WTS Sub from the Lower Sub (Item 53).

5. Remove the three (3) socket head cap screws (Item 61) which secure the Connector
Housing to the Lower Sub.

CAUTION


Failure to remove these screws will result in twisting of the wires from the 32-

pin connector when the lower sub is unscrewed.

6. Unscrew the Lower Sub (Item 53) from the Pressure Housing (Item 52).

7. Unscrew the Pressure Housing (Item 52) from the Hydraulic Equalizer Sub (Item 67).

The Transmitter Electronics will now be exposed.
2.2.2 TRANSMITTER ELECTRONICS REMOVAL

1. Unplug the connectors on the mandrel wire bundle from the PC boards on the Transmitter
Backbone Assembly.   It is easier to remove the screws holding the boards to the backbone and
lift the boards up when unplugging the connectors.
2.2.3 PRESSURE COMPENSATION SECTION

1. Remove the Port Plug labeled BLEED from the Upper Pressure Transition Sub (Item 9).

Aim this port toward a catch bucket.   Open the Valve (Item 127) on the Upper Pressure
Transition Sub and bleed the fluid until the Piston comes to rest.

2. Unscrew the Hydraulic Equalizer Sub (Item 67) from the Piston Housing (Item 69).

CAUTION


Do not proceed to the next step until all pressure has been bled.

3. Unscrew the Piston Housing (Item 69) from the Lower Transition Housing (Item 75).

CAUTION


Older versions of the piston housing have an oil-fill hole and a port plug.   Do not

remove the piston housing with the port plug installed.   As the piston housing is

unscrewed, the port plug will drag across the piston seals and damage them.

4. Unscrew the Spring Weldment (Item 41) and Piston from the Lower Transition
Housing.

5. Pull the Piston Shaft (Item 47) out from the Lower Transition Sub (Item 76).   A groove is
provided to pry it out with a screwdriver.   Slide the Shaft over the mandrel wire bundle and
remove.

6. Remove the two (2) set screws (Item 32) from the Lower Transition Housing (Item 75).
Unscrew the Lower Transition Housing from the Mass Isolation Sub (Item 29).
2.2.4 OUTER FIBERGLASS SLEEVE REMOVAL

1. Remove the SP Contact pin (Item 21) from the SP insert located on the Outer Fiberglass
Sleeve (Item 19).

CAUTION


Failure to remove this pin will result in the pin being sheared and possible damage

to the sleeve when the sleeve is removed from the mandrel.
2.2.5 LOWER PRESSURE TRANSITION SUB REMOVAL

1. Locate the three (3) sets of wires routed through the Mass Isolation Sub (Item 29) - Transmitter,
B-Field and Temperature.  Unsolder these wires from the terminals located on the Transmitter
Spacer (Item 89).

2. Remove the three (3) socket head cap screws (Item 78) and lock washers which secure the Lower
Pressure Transition Sub (Item 76) to the Mass Isolation Sub (Item 29).

3. Carefully slide the Lower Pressure Transition Sub over the mandrel wire bundle.

4. Remove the Ceramic Thrust Ring (Item 80) from the Mass Isolation Sub.
2.2.6 MASS ISOLATION REMOVAL

1. Unscrew the nut (Item 34) on the end of the copper wire tube with the assembly tool (Item 136).

2. Pull the Mass Isolation Sub (Item 29) off the copper wire tube, and over the wire bundle and
connectors.

3. Remove the two (2) O-rings (Item 87) from the inside of the Mass Isolation Sub. The
Zirconia insulators (Item 85) will not pass over these O-rings.

4. Use the Insulator Removal Tool (Item 139) to push both Zirconia insulators and  the Polypak seal
(Item 86) out from the Mass Isolation Sub. Use a press if necessary. DO NOT USE A
HAMMER.
CAUTION


Do not hammer on the assembly tool to remove the insulators.
The ceramic material

is brittle and may crack.
2.2.7 RECEIVER ELECTRONICS DISASSEMBLY

1. Remove the Top Thread Protector (Item 126).

2. Remove the three (3) cap screws (Item 121) from the 45-Pin Connector Housing (Item 120) which
secure the connector to the Top Sub.

CAUTION


Failure to remove these screws will result in twisting of the wires from the 45-pin

connector when the lower sub is unscrewed.

3. Pull the connector out of the Top Sub approximately one-half inch using the T-Handle (Item
134).

4. Unscrew the Top Sub (Item 1) from the Pressure Housing (Item 8) while holding the
connector to prevent it from rotating.

5. Unscrew the Pressure Housing from the Upper Pressure Transition Sub (Item 9). The
Receiver Electronics (Item 6) will now be exposed.

6. Unplug the connectors between the mandrel wire bundle and WTS Terminal Board, and the
Mandrel Terminal Board.

7. Locate the wires routed through the Triangular Chassis through Hole "B. "   Unsolder the
Temperature wires from the Mandrel Terminal Board.   Unsolder the SP wire from the WTS
Terminal Board.

8. Locate the seven (7) sets of coil wires routed through the Upper Pressure Transition Sub (Item
9).   Unsolder the coil wires from the Pre-amp PC Cards on the triangular chassis.

9. Loosen the set screws (Item 7) which secure the chassis to the Wire Tube.   Slide the
Receiver Electronics Assembly off the wire tube and over the wire bundle and connectors.
2.2.8 UPPER PRESSURE TRANSITION SUB REMOVAL

1. Remove the Retainer Ring (Item 111) over Pressure Feed-thrus by removing the four (4) socket head
cap screws (Item 113).

2. Remove the eight (8) Pressure Feed-thrus (Item 11) from the Upper Pressure Transition Sub
(Item 9) by placing a screw driver behind the flange and prying out.   It is unnecessary to
unsolder the wires from the Pressure Feed-thrus since they have been unsoldered at the PC
Boards.

3. Open the Snap Ring (Item 110) on the Adjuster (Item 15) and slide it up.   Screw the Adjuster
Collar (Item 16) all the way up on the Adjuster to release the compression on the Belleville
washers (Item 17).

4. Remove the two Retainer Keys (Item 154).

GENERAL ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES 13
3.1 GENERAL ASSEMBLY PROCEDURES

1. Study the assembly drawings and parts lists to become familiar with the layout of all the items in
the assembly.

2. Make up a file folder for each 1515 EA.   Record the instrument Asset Number.

3. Verify that all required parts and all necessary tools and equipment are available.

Inspect all parts for any dings or nicks in threads.   Small dings may be cleaned up with a thread
file if necessary. Inspect parts for cleanliness and clean to remove all dirt and foreign particles.   Set
aside cleaned parts in a clean storage area.

4. Secure a clean work area and work bench with a bench vise.   During the assembly process, do
not allow dirt or any foreign material particles to contaminate the parts. Keep hands, tools, and
work bench clean.

5. Trial fit all mating parts, without any O-rings installed, to ensure that all fits are free and that no
conditions exist that would prevent easy assembly.

6. All fasteners (screws) should be installed with Loctite #532 (Item 28) applied to the threads to
prevent loosening due to vibration.

CAUTION

Be extremely careful when sliding the electronics chassis into the pressure housing.
This procedure can damage the insulation of the wires running through the electronics,
or damage the ribbon cable outside the flask.   Make sure the flat cable is fastened
securely to the flask with "root beer" tape, and make sure the cable is flat along the
entire length.

TOP SUB ASSEMBLY 14
3.2 TOP SUB ASSEMBLY

1. Insert the Spring (item 8) and Sleeve (item 9) in the Top Sub (item 6).

2. Compress the Spring by pushing on the Sleeve and secure the Ring (item 10) to the Top Sub with
screws (item 11).

3. Install two O-Rings (item 3) on the upper end of Top Sub (item 6).   Install two O-Rings (item 7) on
the threaded end of the Top Sub.

4. Remove the cap screws from the threaded Split Collar (item 5) and separate the Collar into its two
halves.   The two halves are held together with tight fitting dowel pins and a screw driver may be
required to pry them apart.   Be careful not to damage the threads.

5. Reassemble the Split Collar around the Top Sub and install the cap screws.   Make sure the Split
Collar is free to turn on the Top Sub.

6. Set aside the Top Sub assembly at this time.

FLASK SECTION 14
3.3 FLASK SECTION

1. Slide the Flask Electronics (item 14)  into the Flask (item 15).

2. The Flask Electronics should bottom out on the closed end of the flask and compress the rubber pad
on the end of the Electronics.   If not, glue on an additional pad.

3. Attach the Flask to the Chassis using screws (item 27).

4. Attach the Power Supply Assembly (item 13) to the Flask using screws (item 27).

5. Plug in the connectors of the Flat Cable assembly (item 29) to the connectors at each end of the
Flask.

6. Secure the Flat Cable Assembly (item 29) to the Flask with Tape (item 30).

7. Attach the Cable Clamps (item 16) at both ends of the Flask with screws (item 17).

CAUTION

Make sure the flat cable is fastened securely to the flask and make sure the cable is flat
along the entire length of the flask.   If the cable is buckled anywhere, it may be damaged
later when the flask is slid into the pressure housing.

PRESSURE HOUSING AND ELECTRONICS 15
3.4 PRESSURE HOUSING AND ELECTRONICS

1. Install two O-Rings (item 7) on the Bottom Sub (item 22).   Lubricate the O-Rings with a light coat
of Lubriplate Grease.

2. Screw the Bottom Sub into the Pressure Housing (item 12).   Tighten the Bottom Sub to 75 lb-ft
torque.

3. Note the position of the keyway inside the Bottom Sub (item 22) and the position of the pin on the
Electronics Chassis (item 14).

4. Slide the Electronics (item 14) into the Pressure Housing (item 10) with the pin in line with the
keyway in the Bottom Sub.

CAUTION

Be extremely careful when sliding the electronics into the pressure housing.   This
procedure can damage the ribbon cable outside the flask.   Make sure the flat cable is
fastened securely to the flask with tape and make sure the cable is flat along the entire
length.

5. Screw the T-Handle (item 25) into the Electronics Chassis (item 13).

6. Using the Wrench, carefully push the Electronics into the Pressure Housing until the pin engages in
the keyway in the Bottom Sub.   When properly engaged, the Electronics  (item 14) should shoulder
on the Bottom Sub and the Connector (item 18) should be  flush with the shoulder inside the Bottom
Sub.

7. Remove the T-Handle from the Electronics Chassis.

PRESSURE BULKHEAD INSTALLATION 15
3.5 PRESSURE BULKHEAD INSTALLATION

1. Install two O-rings (item 19)on the Pressure Bulkhead (item 20).

2. Lubricate the O-rings with a light coat of Lubriplate Grease.   Push the Pressure Bulkhead into the
Bottom Sub (item 22) with the key on the Bulkhead in line with the keyway in the Sub.

3. Use the Assembly Tool (item 33) to push the Bulkhead all the way to the shoulder inside the Bottom
Sub.

4. Use the Pliers (item 31) to install the Retaining Ring (item 21) in the Bottom Sub.

TOP SUB INSTALLATION 16
3.6 TOP SUB INSTALLATION

1. Check to make sure the Electronics is pushed all the way into the Pressure Housing (item 10).

2. Lubricate the O-rings and threads on the Top Sub (item 6) with a light coat of Lubriplate
Grease.

3. Slide the Connector and Cable assembly (item 4) through the Top Sub (item 6).

4. Plug the Connector (item 4) into the Connector Assembly (item 2).

5. While holding the Connector Assembly stationary, screw the Top Sub into the Pressure Housing.
Do NOT allow the Connector Assembly to rotate.   As the Top Sub is screwed into the pressure
housing, the Spring (item 8) will be compressed.   The Top Sub must shoulder against the Pressure
Housing.   Tighten the thread joint to 75 lb-ft torque.

6. Insert the Connector Assembly (item 2) into the Top Sub and install the Retaining Ring (item 1).

7. Check the electrical continuity through the 1515 EA assembly per the Wiring Diagram.

End to end, the D. C. resistance should be 1. 0 ohm or less on the feed-thru conductors.

THREAD PROTECTOR INSTALLATION 16
3.7 THREAD PROTECTOR INSTALLATION

1. Lubricate the O-rings (item 3) on the Top Sub (item 4) and threads on the Split Collar (item 5)
with a light coat of Lubriplate Grease.   Install the top Thread Protector (item23) on the Top Sub.

2. Install the external O-Ring (item 3) on the bottom Thread Protector (item 26).

Lubricate the O-Ring and threads with a light coat of Lubriplate Grease.   Install the Thread
Protector into the Bottom Sub.

1. GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS

1.
Study the assembly drawings and parts lists (BOM) to become familiar with the layout of all the
items in the assembly.

2.
Verify that all required parts and all tools and equipment necessary are available.  Inspect all parts
for dings or nicks in the threads. Small dings may be cleaned up with a thread file. Inspect parts for
cleanliness; clean and remove all dirt and foreign particles. Set aside cleaned parts in a clean
storage area.

3.
Trial fit all mating parts, without O-rings installed, to ensure that all fits are free and that no
conditions exist that would prevent easy assembly.

4.
All fasteners (screws) should be installed with Loctite applied to the threads to prevent loosening
due to vibration, except the screws to fasten the boards in the 1515 MA.
2. MANDREL DISASSEMBLY/ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS
REFERENCE DRAWINGS
Assembly 164350-000
Wiring Diagram 164350-100

6. Install two (2) Retainer Keys (Item 154) on the Upper Pressure Transition Sub (Item 9) with

screws (Item 155).
