4. Install two (2) O-rings (Item 87) in the inside of the Mass Isolation Sub.   Grease with
silicone grease.

5. Install three (3) screws (Item 88) into the outside diameter of the Flange (Item 26).

6. Slide the Mass Isolation Sub over the wire bundle and on to the mandrel assembly.  Rotate so the
three (3) wire holes and one (1) oil-flow hole in the Sub are aligned with the holes in the
Flange on the Mandrel Assembly.

7. Insert the Fiberglass Thrust Bearing (Item 81) into the Mass Isolation Sub.

8. Grease the threads on the nut (Item 34) with Lubriplate #930-AA Grease, P/N 205933-000, and
tighten the nut with the assembly tool (Item 136) to 15-20 ft/lbs of torque.

5


1515 EA/MA HDIL   130551-955

130551-955
REV A
5. Install three (3) socket head cap screws (Item 78) and lock washers (Item 79) to secure the
Lower Pressure Transition Sub.

CAUTION


A 0.040" gap will exist between the lower pressure transition sub and the mass

isolation sub.   There should not be contact between these two subs.   If there is

contact between the  two subs, disassemble and ensure items 80, 81 and 34 have

been installed.   Failure to install any of these items will result in damage to the

mandrel.

6. Install the Retainer (Item 36) above the Pressure Feed-thrus.   Secure the two halves of the
Retainer together with screws (Item 37).

6


1515 EA/MA HDIL   130551-955

130551-955
REV A
4. Secure the loop to the Transmitter Coil using two turns of kapton tape.

5. Run the twisted cable down the wire groove in the Transmitter Spacer (item 89).

6. Solder the marked (+ ) wire to the uphole terminal at the end of the wire groove.    Solder


the other wire to the downhole terminal at the end of the wire groove.

7. Slide the B-Field wires from the Pressure Terminal (item 158) through the wire hole

in the Mass Isolation Sub (item 29).

8. Strip, tin, and solder GREEN (+ ) wire to the uphole terminal.

9. Strip, tin, and solder BLUE wire to the downhole terminal.

2.1.7.3 Temperature (RTD) Wiring
1. Solder the leads of the RTD (item 25) to the terminals (item 24) in the

Transmitter Spacer (item 89).

2. Run twisted cable down the wire groove in the Transmitter Spacer (item 89).

3
Slide the Temperature wire from the Pressure Terminal (item 157) through the

center wire hole in the Mass Isolation Sub (item 29).

4. Strip, tin, and solder red wire to one terminal holding the RTD.

5. Strip, tin, and solder brown wire to other terminal holding the RTD.

7


1515 EA/MA HDIL   130551-955

130551-955
REV A
6. Grease the Piston Shaft (Item 47) and Piston (Item 43) outside diameter with a liberal
coating of silicone grease.

7. Screw the Spring Weldment and Piston into the Lower Transition Housing.

8. Screw the Piston Housing on to the Lower Transition Housing.   Install the Port Plug and
Grease Plug (Item 68) in the Piston Housing.

CAUTION


Older versions of the piston housing have an oil-fill hole and a port plug.   Do not

install the piston housing with the port plug installed.   As the piston housing is

screwed on, the port plug will drag across the piston seals and damage them.

9. Install six (6) O-rings (Item 4 and 50) on to the Hydraulic Equalizer Sub (Item 67).

Install two (2) Spacers (Item 49) on the face of the sub with screws (Item 48).   Screw the Sub on
to the Piston Housing.

8


1515 EA/MA HDIL   130551-955

130551-955
REV A
5. Elevate the end of the tool connected to the "Return from Tool" hose a minimum of 5 inches
Make sure the tool is secure and cannot roll off the device on which it is resting.

6. Pull a vacuum on the 1515 mandrel for one (1) hour. After an hour, circulate oil through the
mandrel for four (4) hours while maintaining a vacuum.

7. Turn off the circulating and Vacuum pumps.


FOR EXTERNAL PISTON COMPENSATOR:

8.  Remove the return line from the lower? Transition Housing and install a port plug.

9. Turn the Circulation Pump on and use the pump pressure to position the piston shoulder so that
it aligns with the Oil Fill Mark, +/- 1/8", scribed on the Equalizer Housing, Item 205.

10. Remove the fill line and quickly install the Port Plug.







NOTE
If the tool is overfilled with oil and the piston reaches maximum travel, the tool will dump the
excess oil. This is not a fault in the tool. Bleed off the excess oil and position the piston as
described in Step 9 of this section.



FOR RUBBER BLADDER COMPENSATOR:


11. Remove the return line from the lower Transition Housing and install a port plug.

12. Turn on the Circulating Pump for five minutes and inflate the Bladder to 5 psi. Turn off
the pump and hold the pressure for 10 minutes.

13. Bleed the pressure down to 1 to 2 psi.

14. Remove the fill line and quickly install the Port Plug.


FOR INTERNAL PISTON COMPENSATOR:

15. Remove all Pump Hoses from the Mandrel and install the Port Plugs.

16. Connect the Hand Pump bucket, P/N 106604-000, to the port labeled CHECK using the
quick connects (items 131, 134). This line in the mandrel has a check valve which allows
oil to flow in, but not out. Add silicone oil to the Mandrel using the Pump Bucket until
the Piston (Item 43) moves down and can be seen through the grease port (item 68). Stop
at this point to avoid over-stressing the spring.






CAUTION
Do not add oil while the dipstick is inserted in the piston housing

RELAY CHECK-OUT, continued
This
completes the Preventative Maintenance, Level 3 Procedure.  Reassemble the 1515 MA and fill with
silicone oil per the assembly instructions found in section 130551-955.
Calibrate the tool and complete an SRO form.

OVERVIEW
When addressing Maintenance problems on the 1515 HDIL Tool, some important issues must be
understood.
The tool does not require any electrical adjustment.  Other than the "nulling" of the subarrays (a
mechanical procedure that takes place during manufacturing) this tool has NO adjustments.
Critical communications between assembly modules uses twisted pairs of wire for BALANCED
transmission.  This applies to ALL the Analog Signals through the tool and most of the Digital
Signals.  An unbalanced scope probe is not recommended to view the balanced signals coming
into or out of each board.  In the case of analog signals related to the measurement, these
twisted pairs are shielded if the signal level is very low or the length of the link justifies it.
Measurement of signals on Surface Mount (SMT) Boards is not recommended if the tool is
operating properly.  This statement means that the software tools provided should be adequate
enough to monitor the performance of the instrument.  In fact, the 1515 EA Acquisition System
is the best measurement tool that you'll ever find to diagnose any problem that occurs.  Because
of the level of modularity (8 independent identical channels to measure each of the 8 signals of
interest), it is relatively easy to track an offending signal.
It is not recommended to replace surface mount components in the Field.  SMT boards should
be debugged to the "board level" and only if a very minor problem is detected, should a fix be
attempted.
The Backbone of the Pre-Amp section (the triangular chassis) can be used as a common for
unbalanced signals measurements.  The Backbone of the EA can be used as a common for
unbalanced digital signal measurements (even though it is not recommended!).  The Backbone
of the Transmitter Section Electronics (bottom of the tool) CANNOT BE USED as a common
for any signal measurements.  The entire lower section of the tool is "DC floating" for reasons
related to the measurement of the SP.
When using backbones to attach oscilloscope ground leads, make sure that good contact is
achieved.  Remember that aluminum is a good conductor but anodization, in most of the cases,

130551-953

2.

topic: Test Systems Guide - 1.0 HDIL TOOL CONTROLLER FOR WINDOWS . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1 1.1 OVERVIEW . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1
chunk_text:
HDIL TOOL CONTROLLER FOR WINDOWS 

OVERVIEW
The HDIL tool controller for windows (referred to as Winmitre) is a PC-based system for
operating the WALS high definition induction tool.  The tool, which uses an array of seven
receivers to sense the conductivity of downhole formations, is controlled and guided by
Winmitre, for testing purposes and for temperature characterization of newly manufactured
instruments.
The Winmitre program's purpose is to act as a user interface to the tool, allowing high-level
user control by automating low-level tool commands.  The program gathers, interprets, and
displays (in text and graphics) data which the tool sends uphole.  It uses Fourier transformation
techniques to process the voltage information it receives into the frequency domain for better
analysis.  It stores the data on disk and can play back this stored information.  The program is
also responsible for keeping track of the calibration information which the tool is capable of
producing and uses that information to process tool data.
This program is used in the laboratory environment to test and debug the tool.  It is also used to
perform a temperature characterization during final assembly and test of a tool.  Direct control
of most tool  functions is allowed at a low level, although at the same time the program has the
ability to run in an automated and user-friendly manner.

topic: Test Systems Guide - 1.2 INSTALLATION AND GETTING STARTED . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1
chunk_text:
INSTALLATION AND GETTING STARTED
1.
Hardware Requirements
!
IBM PC, or PC clone, with a 386 or faster CPU and at least 4 Megabytes of random
access memory.
!
A WTS1 PC Interface Card, P/N 150690-500, must be plugged into one of the
expansion slots on the PC to provide the digital telemetry interface for the 1515 EA.
!
A 5721 Analog Interface Test System, P/N 151759-000, provides an interface to the
WTS instrument bus.  The 5721 panel should be switched to the WTS Instrument Bus
mode using the switch on the front of the panel.  A WTS umbilical must be connected
from the WTS-IB connector (J1) on the back of the panel to the top of the 1515 EA.
The 37-pin connector at the back of the WTS1 PC card, located on one of the expansion
slots of the PC, must be connected to the 37-pin D-type connector in the front of the
5721 test system using a ribbon cable.  Power is applied to the tool using a 2061 Power
Supply connected to the 5721 test panel at the 2061 connector (J3).

topic: Test Systems Guide - 2.0 USING WINMITRE . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3 2.1 THE TCC WINDOW
chunk_text:
USING WINMITRE 
THE TCC WINDOW
3
2.1.1
Transmitter on/off 3
2.1.2
Tool Mode Selection
3
2.1.3* Monitor Selection 3
2.1.4
Number To Acquire 4
2.1.5

THE TCC WINDOW
The Tool Command and Control (TCC) window is used to issue commands to the tool.  It can
be fetched at any time from the Windows menu, and can be dismissed at any time by clicking the
Dismiss Window button or using the close menu item in it's resizable frame.  It can be
minimized by the minimize button in the upper right corner.  If dismissed or minimized, it can
be restored by selecting TCC Window under the Windows menu of the text viewer in the
background.
The TCC window controls several tool commands and keeps itself up to date on the current state
of the tool by periodically polling the tool's status.  It also indicates whether or not the current
data is being saved to a file by displaying NOT SAVING or SAVING IN <file> in an edit box at
the bottom of the window.
2.1.1
Transmitter on/off
These radio buttons allow the user to select the state of the transmitter.  When clicked, the
buttons send the tool a command to switch the transmitter on or off and check to see if it has
happened.  If not, an error is reported and the buttons go to an indeterminate state in which no
button is pressed to indicate that the computer does not know which state the tool is in.
2.1.2
Tool Mode Selection
These buttons allow the user to select whether the tool is in ZERO, CAL or LOG mode.  The
mode determines what data will be collected during an acquisition.  ZERO mode is an all-
inputs-grounded amplified signal used to measure noise from the electronics for calibration
purposes.  CAL is the mode in which a known signal is sent through each channel to facilitate
measuring the gain of the electronics for calibration.  LOG is the standard mode wherein the
receiver coils monitor the response of the formation or surroundings to the signal transmitted by
the tool.  These buttons have a self-checking feature like the transmitter controls, reporting
error if the command failed.
2.1.3* Monitor Selection
There can be two methods of monitoring the transmitters output: a monitor of the voltage
applied to the transmitter coil (Driver) and a monitor of the magnetic field produced by the
transmitter (Sense Coil).  The tool uses a magnetic field monitor, therefore the Sense Coil is the
default and should always be the one selected.

topic: Test Systems Guide - 2.2 THE TOOL STATUS VIEWER . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 4
chunk_text:
THE TOOL STATUS VIEWER
The tool status viewer window displays several pieces of information.  In the upper left corner it
shows the source of the sample (this will either say TOOL if the sample came from a tool, or a
filename and subset number if the sample came from a file while in the PLAYBACK mode).  To
the right of that it shows the time the sample was taken.  Below these displays it shows a set of
information which comes from the header of each acquisition (Subset 0 or Subset 1) which is
sent uphole.  This information includes the status of the tool at acquire time, some temperature
readings from the tool, and some voltage readings.
The box displaying a specific piece of information lights up red if the reading is out of its
allowed range, which is displayed at the bottom of each box.
The information in the status boxes comes from the header of each acquisition.  This header is
32 words long.  The button labeled Extra Info shows the first 20 of these additional words from
the header in their hexadecimal form for debugging purposes.
This window can be dismissed, minimized, and restored in the same manner as the TCC
window.

THE TOOLBAR
The toolbar is the bar of buttons under the menu bar in the main view window.  The buttons on
it are mapped to certain menu items to provide easier access to those commands which are most
useful.  It also contains an important display box which tells the user whether or not the data is
being saved to a file and whether the tool is in the PLAYBACK mode (this mode will be
discussed later).  The buttons in the toolbar are (from left to right)
File... Playback (Open)
File... Next Acquisition
File... Saving
Acquire Subset (0 or 1)
View Hex
View Volts
View Frequency Data
View MRAT
View Conductivity
Graph Voltages
Graph Frequencies
Graph Conductivities
Graph Temperature Profile
Graph Conductivity vs Temperature
File... Print
Stop Timers or Process
For information on these commands, see the sections on menu commands below.

ACQUIRING DATA 6
2.4.1* Data Settings 6

ACQUIRING DATA
To get data from the tool simply select the subset you wish to get under the Acquire menu.  It
will be sent to the surface on the communication channel determined by the mapping selected in
the TCC window (subset 0 and 1 are actually only supported on Mode 5), and displayed in the
main view.  Once there is valid information in the computer's memory, the menu items (and
corresponding buttons) for graphing and view selection become enabled.  The user can now
choose a view other than the default (Frequency Data), and the screen will update to show it.
By choosing Graph... Voltages, or its button counterpart, the user can bring up a display of the
voltage signatures as they might look on an oscilloscope.
2.4.1* Data Settings
The menu item Data Settings, under the Settings menu, controls some of the factors that affect
the way acquisition takes place.  Selecting Data Settings brings up a dialogue box to allow input
of several things.
!
Number of samples per set: This sets the number of samples which should be defaulted
to 96.
!
Number of harmonics in FFT: This sets the number of harmonics to calculate in the
Fourier transform when processing the data.  This should not be changed unless the user
is prepared to change all of the calibration data as well (the calibration information is
fixed at 16 harmonics).
!
Nominal DC offsets for A/Ds:  There are eight (8) boxes for input of nominal DC offset
for each receiver.  These are used to convert the values sent uphole by the A/D boards
on the tool into voltage readings.  There is an Update button under these eight (8)
boxes.  When the button is pressed, the program calculates all of the DC offsets based
on the last acquisition and updates the data in the boxes.  The next acquisition will use
these updated DC offsets.  These offsets are stored and updated in the file calcoeff.sav.
Updating the DC offsets is useful when looking at the waveforms in the voltage graphs,
particularly when looking at the Zero-mode waveforms using a zoom of 1,000 or so.  If
you do NOT update, the program used the old offsets which are in calcoeff.sav, and
these may even be from a different tool which might have significantly different DC
offsets.
!
File Extension: This permits changing the binary data file extension name from the
default which is: <....>.dat

topic: Test Systems Guide - 2.5 USING THE GRAPHS
chunk_text:
USING THE GRAPHS
7
2.5.1
The Voltage Graph and its Controls 7
2.5.2* The Frequency Graph and its Controls 7
2.5.3
The Close-Up Window 8
2.5.4 The Conductivity Plots 9
2.5.5* The Edit Conductivity Plots 10
2.5.6* The Temperature Profile Plot 11
2.5.7* The Conductivity versus Temperature Plot

USING THE GRAPHS
When a subset is loaded into memory from the tool (or from a file), a good way to see its
contents is not in the view window but in a graph window.  By choosing Graph... Voltages or
Graph... Frequencies the user can view a display of the data in a compact visual form.
2.5.1
The Voltage Graph and its Controls
Considerable functionality is available through this window.  It pops up and can be
moved/dismissed/restored in the same way as the TCC window and other windows.  It contains
a display of the time the sample was taken if the sample came from the tool, or of the filename
and number of the sample if the program is in PLAYBACK mode.  It also displays any text
associated with the sample (added when entering SAVE mode, or read when loading a file).
The window has several controls.  Each graph displays a plot of voltage versus time for one
receiver.  By clicking on any of these graphs, a new window pops up displaying graphs con-
taining more information on the particular receiver.  This new window is described in the
section on the close-up window.  The button labeled Zoom redefines the magnification factor of
the Y axis in the graphs of receivers 0 through 6.  (The Reference display signal is not zoomed
with the others because it is usually a different order of magnitude from the rest of the
receivers.)  If the Zoom button is clicked, it brings up a dialogue box for setting a new
magnification of the Y axis.  The first field in the dialogue is for a DC offset.  The number here
is the voltage (in millivolts) the graphs are centered about.  The second field is the
magnification factor to apply.  In a non-conductive environment a magnification of around 50 to
100 is appropriate for looking at the signals in LOG mode.  A zoom of 1,000 is useful for
examining the Zero signal for noise or cross-talk, etc.
There are Acquire Subset and Next Playback buttons as well.  By pushing Acquire Subset you
tell the tool to get a new sample for viewing.  This screen will automatically update itself to
show the new data.  By pushing Next Playback, you ask to see the next sample in the currently
open file.  If the program is not in PLAYBACK mode (see below), pushing the button will cause
an error message.

topic: Test Systems Guide - 2.6 FILE INPUT AND OUTPUT . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 12
chunk_text:
FILE INPUT AND OUTPUT 12
2.6.1
The SAVE Mode 12
2.6.2

FILE INPUT AND OUTPUT
The Winmitre program supports a logging-style saving of data to files on disk, as well as
playback from files.  Each data file also contains up to 100 characters of user-defined text
describing the data set.  Files consist of all data samples acquired while the program was in
SAVE mode.  Each sample includes the raw data acquired from the tool, the header information
which is shown in the Tool Status Viewer window, and the complete calibration state of the
program at the time the sample was taken.
The entire calibration state is saved to ensure that everything can look exactly the same when it
is played back as when it was saved.
The toolbar has a display that can show any of the following: Saving, Not Saving, or Playback.
This section will describe how to make use of the SAVE mode to store data to disk files and the
PLAYBACK mode to read it back later.
Files are stored in binary format, unreadable except by the Winmitre program itself.  However,
since it is sometimes necessary to export data into other programs (Mathcad, for example), the
ability to generate an ASCII text output of any sample is provided in the File menu.
2.6.1
The SAVE Mode
SAVE mode may be turned on at any time by selecting the Saving item under the file menu, or
alternately by clicking the button that looks like a diskette on the toolbar.  Doing this toggles
the SAVE mode ON and OFF.  If the menu item for saving has a check mark next to it, the
toolbar should indicate Saving (unless the PLAYBACK mode is also in operation) and the SAVE
mode will be on.  Selecting Saving now turns it off.  If there is no check by Saving, the toolbar
should indicate Not Saving and SAVE mode is off.  Selecting it now will turn it ON.
When the SAVE mode is ON every time a Subset 0 or Subset 1 is acquired from the tool, it is
automatically saved at the end of the currently saving file along with the calibration
information.  Other actions, such as loading a data set from another file, have no effect on the
file.  However, since zeroing or otherwise calibrating the tool requires acquiring a Subset 0 or
Subset 1, that data will be appended to the file.  Thanks to the header information displayed in
the Tool Status Viewer, the user will be notified during playback what mode the data was
acquired in, so there will be no confusion between the CAL and LOG modes.
Immediately upon activating the SAVE mode, the user is prompted for a text description of the
data that is to be acquired.  This blurb of text will be placed in the first 100 bytes of the file.
From then on the file grows with every acquisition until the user turns the SAVE mode OFF.
The user is then prompted for a filename of the form mitreXX.dat, where XX is a number
between 1 and 99.  The computer prompts the user with the next logical filename.  If cancel is
pressed in this file dialogue box, the SAVE mode is left off and the file is not created.

CALIBRATION 13
2.7.1
Zero and Cal 14
2.7.2* Air and Loop 14
2.7.3* The Cal Window 14
2.7.4* The Coefficients Panels - Cal and Sigma 15

CALIBRATION
Using the HDIL tool requires a lot of computer-managed calibration.  The Winmitre program
attempts to perform as much of this as is possible.  In normal circumstances, calibration using
internal ZERO and CAL is sufficient.  The AIR and LOOP calibration is not necessary if the
default calibration is adequate.
There are several arrays of complex numbers the program uses to obtain values for apparent
conductivity from the raw data.  In the program these are named VREZ, GER, KFAC, MM,
and AM.  VREZ and GER are used to compensate for electronic noise and electronic gain and
phase shift.  KFAC converts from receiver voltage to apparent conductivity based on the tool
design configuration.  MM and AM are used to compensate for the gain and phase shifts
introduced by the mandrel.
GER and VREZ are obtained by selecting Zero and Cal under the Cal menu.  KFAC is
calculated from the tool design parameters.  MM and AM are acquired from primary
calibration.

THE MENU COMMANDS
There are a number of menu commands which have not been mentioned yet.  This section will
explain each of them and how they can be used.
2.8.1
The File Menu
!
Saving:  This turns the SAVE mode on or off, depending on its current state, as
discussed above.  A check mark by this item indicates that the program is currently in
SAVE mode.
!
Playback(Open):  This turns the PLAYBACK mode on or off, depending on its current
state, as discussed previously.  A check mark by this item indicates the program is
currently in PLAYBACK mode.
!
Next Subset 0:  If in the PLAYBACK mode, this menu item loads the next data set from
the currently loaded file.
NOTE
This works for either Subset 0 or Subset 1.
!
Skip To Sample:  Allows the user skip to any point in the currently open file and read
that subset.
!
Voltages -> ASCII:
VRE -> ASCII:
MRAT -> ASCII:
Cond -> ASCII:
GER -> ASCII:
HEX -> ASCII:
AM/MM -> ASCII:
JNORM/AT-> ASCII:
These menu items convert a set of saved information in a file into an ASCII text file of a
similar name.
!
Print:  This causes the user's choice of views to be printed on the currently selected
printer.  It brings up a print box window entitled Which Dataset?.  All available options
are shown as buttons.  In the print box, there is a useful button called Print Clip-Board
Graph.  It directly prints whatever is in the clipboard.  A window that needs to be
printed is captured by pressing two functional keys, Alt and Print Screen.  A copy of the
current active window visible on the screen is stored in the clipboard.
!
Print Setup:  This allows the user to choose a printer and set the print options.
!
Exit:  This menu item ends the program and closes all the windows related to the
Winmitre program.

Action

Inspect outer body and components for signs of significant damage.

–––––– 
4. 
Check top connector and bottom bulkhead for moisture, debris, misaligned, 
broken or worn pins, worn or damaged sockets and deformed retaining rings. 
Ensure top connector snap ring and bottom bulkhead truarc ring is in place. 
Clean the top connector and bottom bulkhead with contact cleaner. 
 
 
 
 
–––––– 
5.

F181967000 or if unavailable use WTS male contact pin F189564000.

Remove used O-rings from uphole end of tool with O-ring extractor tool. Cut 
and discard used O-rings. Inspect O-ring grooves; they shall not have dust, 
dirt, scratches; pitting, corrosion and/or any damage or condition which can 
cause seal failure. Apply a little Lubriplate 930 AA in O-rings grooves. 
 
 
 
 
–––––– 
7. 
Inspect new O-rings for defects and then apply a light coating of Lubriplate 
930 AA around O-rings then replace O-rings on top sub. 
 
 
–––––– 
8. 
Check that all subs are torqued to prevent accidental “backing off”. The timing 
marks on the Top and/or Bottom Sub should be aligned to or go past the 
Pressure Housing timing mark. Do NOT back off sub to make alignment marks 
match!

topic: Brief Description of Service - 1.0 BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
chunk_text:
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF SERVICE
Refer to 1590 Series Equipment Specification Sheet F131024025 for tool application and
measurement principles.

GENERAL SAFETY GUIDELINES
The following are the safety guidelines for handling the 1590 EA HTHP HDIL Main Electronics.
•
Wear required safety equipment when handling or servicing the 1590 EA.
•
Turn off electrical test equipment before connecting or disconnecting.
•
Always install thread protectors when tool is not in use and when transporting.
•
Wear safety glasses when soldering.
•
Where static-guard wristbands when working around electronics.

Electrical Safety Precautions
High voltage (180 Vac) is present at various points on the electronics chassis when the pressure
housing is removed and power is applied to the instrument. The following electrical safety
precautions apply.



High voltage in use
Potential Electrical Shock
•
Turn off power when not required
•
Post appropriate warning signs
•
Avoid distractions while working on equipment with
power applied
•

Tool Weight
The 1590 EA section weighs 306 pounds (see F131024025). Titanium has been utilized for all
structural components in an effort to reduce the total weight of the instrument(s). Never hoist or
lift the tool when the Electronics and Mandrel are connected together unless properly supported
at three or more points. THE EA, FA, AND MA SHOULD BE ASSEMBLED VERTICALLY
OVER THE WELL TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE MANDREL.






Instrument is heavy.
Possible death or serious injury
•
Wear safety boots
•
Use proper lifting methods and equipment to
lift and move instrument


131023-954
JULY 2010

HDIL TRANSMITTER CONTROLLER BOARD
Refer to assembly drawing A3001485000 and schematic drawing A3001485 SCH.
An SAB80 C166 (from now on referred as SAB166) μController (U1) is the nucleus of the board.
Timers embedded in the chip generate the PAT_i signals required by the transmitter of the tool to
work. The part has two serial ports. One of these ports (SERIAL 1) is used to receive commands
from the EA electronics (P3.9) and transmit status and data (P3.8). Serial communication is
asynchronous: 1 start bit, 8 data bits and 1 stop bit. Baud rate is 9600.
PDS 301 (U2) provides the EPROM and RAM and associated glue-logic required by the
Controller to operate properly. The SAB166 has 2 K of internal RAM memory but this memory is
used for stack purposes.
U13 and U15 are A/D converters. These chips sample the signals generated by two RTDS
(connected to TMP1_RTD+ and TMP2_RTD+). The RTD associated to TMP2_RTD is placed
close to the Transmitter Coil. The other RTD is placed between the main and bucker coils of
subarray 6. A shielded, twisted-pair wire takes the signal of this RTD through the Preamplifier
Section into the Beryllium copper (BeCu) pipe to the Transmitter Controller Board. The method
used to measure temperature is based on an Improved Holland Current Source. Basically, the first
stage of U12 provides a source of current. This current generates a voltage that varies with
temperature when applied to the RTD. The voltage is amplified by the second stage of U12. U11
provides an offset voltage to maximize the dynamic range of the measurement.
Part of Port 1 (P1.0 - P1.4) generates signals required to switch latch relays. Most of these relays
are placed in the Preamplifier section of tool. They route different signals to the electronics
channels on the upper side of the mandrel. One latch relay is placed in the transmitter controller
board and it selects the reference signal as will be explained later.
Latch relays require pulses to be switched from one state to another. Pulses of approximately 50
msec are generated by the controller to switch the relays. U9 (MC14160), Q3 and Q4 provide the
required driving capability.
For analog signal measurements, a 10-bit A/D converter with 10 multiplexed input channels and a
sample and hold circuit has been integrated in the SAB166 chip. Several auxiliary signals that
show the status of the tool are sampled by this A/D through U16.
A timer in the SAB166 (T1) generates a 500 kHz square signal (P3.1/T1 OUT). Edges of this
clock generate a 1.0 MHz signal at the output of U18. CC2 IO enables or disables the 1.0 MHz
signal, and is generated as a request from the upper electronics and ultimately from the Surface

Circuit Description
1590 MA HTHP WTS HDIL Induction Mandrel
131024-945
JULY 2010

The 1.0 MHz signal (U20-pin 3) and CC2 IO are applied to the inputs of a NAND gate (U19). The
output of this gate is called BURST. The BURST signal is ultimately used to strobe the A/D's of
the Acquisition Modules in the Upper Electronics. All of the communication links between the
transmitter Controller and the Upper Electronics are digital and meet all the requirements of EIA
Standard RS-422. U7 and U8 are designed to provide unipolar differential drive to twisted pair
transmission lines. DS2631 (U8) is a High-Speed Differential Line Driver designed for digital
data transmission over-balanced lines. The DS2632 (U7) is a quad-differential line receiver that
offers optimum performance when used with the DS2631.
Features that are unique to this board include a new serial EEPROM which has been added. This
EEPROM contains 1 K bytes of data used to characterize parameters of the mandrel (e.g. serial
number, temperature coeff., etc.). A WTS command (0x15xx) supports the reading of this
EEPROM. Eclips or WinMitre cannot write to this memory (the writing process cannot be
performed through WTS, to avoid "accidents"). The EEPROM must be programmed during the
mandrel manufacturing process, and is mounted in a DIP socket. If the Transmitter Controller
Board is replaced, the EEPROM must be unplugged and placed on the new board. The EEPROM
always remains with its mandrel.
The temperature measurement circuitry has been changed to achieve better precision. Description
of one of the circuits follows, the other is identical. U13/Q6 are a source of current.
Approximately 2.0 mA are forced through the Temperature Sensor. Voltage at the drain of Q6 will
be (5 Volts – 2 mA Rt). U13 behaves as a amplifier and an offset generator to optimize the
dynamic range of the A/D converter. At room temperature (25° C), the signal at the input of the
A/D converter is slightly negative (-1.4 Volts). At 200° C, the signal will be approximately 8.1
Volts. Observe that R15/R16 provide offset reference to both circuits. U10 provides a single
reference for the two sensors. OP07's have been used because of their almost 0 (zero) offset
voltage specification. These OP-Amps buffer the reference from the rest of the circuit without
sacrificing precision. R6/R7 and R13/R14 are 0.1 % tolerance resistors to minimize errors in the
gain/offset process.
Typical Acquisition Sequence
When a Stop/Start Command is received by the SAB166 (U1), CC2 IO goes low (if it is NOT
already low) and after a short period of time (used for synchronization purposes) it activates (goes
high), initiating an acquisition period. By default, CC2 IO will remain active for around 400 ms,
but if another Stop/Start Command is received, CC2 IO will be forced low, and after an additional
short period of time, required for synchronization, will activate again, repeating the cycle.
Each time CC2 IO activates (CC2 IO is active high), an acquisition cycle takes place. As
mentioned, the length of CC2 IO by default is approximately 400 ms, but it can be varied by
software (in that way, the length of the BURST is changed). An interesting case occurs when the
length of CC2 IO is set to 96 μsec. In this case the BURST signal will be 96 pulses (μsec) long.
The reception of just one transmitter period will be digitized. This will be "unstacked", "raw"
data, and it gives a feeling of the kind of signals present at the input of the A/D (normally quite

Circuit Description
1590 MA HTHP WTS HDIL Induction Mandrel
131024-945
JULY 2010

PREAMPLIFIER BOARDS
Three preamplifier boards are used in the 1590 MA instrument they are:
•
F188001000 – Channels 0, 1, 2
•
F188006000 – Channels 3 and 4
•
F188007000 – channels 5 and 6.
These three board are all functionally identical and only a general description is provided.
Three (3) sources of signals can be applied to the input of each channel of the CH0, 1, 2
preamplifier board, while two sources can be applied to the CH3, 4, and 5. These sources are:
•
Subarray Receiver coils,
•
“CAL” Signal (a Reference Signal, generated by the Transmitter Section of the tool, is
attenuated and injected at the input of the Preamplifier), and
•
Zero signal. In this mode the amplifiers' inputs are connected to the Be-Cu pipe, which is the
common of the tool.
Latching relays route these different sources to the preamplifiers' input stage.
Required processing gain varies according to the particular subarray. Subarrays placed far from
the transmitter require more gain than those placed nearby. The first stage of the preamplifier
board is a very low-noise, broad-band amplifier. The gain of this stage is different for each
channel.
The second stage is a four-pole Bessel low-pass filter with a gain of one (1) in the pass band
region. Frequency cutoff is around 200 kHz. Bessel’s filters have very little ringing (linear phase
shift) to the step response.
The last stage is a differential-output buffer amplifier that converts a single-ended input signal to
a balanced output signal pair with high output drive. The SSM-2142 is capable of driving difficult
loads, yielding low-distortion performance despite long cables.

1530 TRANSMITTER DRIVER
Refer to assembly drawing F187985000 and schematic drawing F187985100.
The Transmitter Driver receives control signals from the Controller Board and drives the
transmitter coil.
PAT1 and PAT2 are signals intended to drive the gate of FET's Q1 and Q2. T1 and T2 are
transformers intended to "float" the driving of the gates. Q3/Q4 and Q5/Q6 are transistor pairs
that drive the transformers.
For the next discussion, we assume the voltage on the drain of Q1 is 55 volts and the voltage on
the source of Q2 is -55 volts. In other words, we are neglecting the voltage drop on R9 and R10.
These 0.2 ohm resistors are there to avoid current spikes, and voltage drop through them is
negligible.
If Q1 is on, (55 - VdsQ1) volts are applied to the transmitter coil. (VdsQ1 is the voltage drop
through Q1.) When Q1 is turned off, a large amount of current is circulating through the coil.
This current will have to continue to circulate, and it will do so through D4 (there is no physical
way to switch the current circulating through an inductor from a large value to zero
instantaneously). Voltage on the coil will change fast from +(55 - VdsQ1) to -(55 + VdD4), Vd
being the voltage drop on the diode (voltage on a coil can change fast). Current through the coil
will start to decrease slowly. If Q2 is turned on, there will be a moment when current will no
longer circulate through D4, and it will start circulating through Q2. By then, -(55 - VdsQ2) Volts
will be applied to the coil.
When Q2 is turned off, a large amount of negative current will be circulating through the coil,
and D2 will now be turned on to comply with the principles of Kirchhoff's Law. Voltage through
the coil will change from -(55 - VdsQ2) Volts to (55 + VdD2). If Q1 is turned on, there will be a
moment when current will no longer circulate through D2, and it will start circulating through
Q1, (55 - VdsQ1) volts will be applied to the coil and we are back to the beginning.
The square waveform rise time or fill time can be controlled with C3 and C4. These two
capacitors have been chosen to have 1.8 μsec transition time, when transition time is the time
required by the square waveform to go from 10% to 90% of its value.
U1 and U2 are programmable regulators. By choosing the correct value of resistors and Zener
diodes, a wide range of output voltages can be achieved. For this application, the regulators
provide the plus and minus (+/-) 55 volts required for the transmitter to operate properly.

Circuit Description
1590 MA HTHP WTS HDIL Induction Mandrel
131024-945
JULY 2010

INTERFACE BOARD
Refer to assembly drawing A3001439000 and schematic drawing A3001439 SCH.
This board takes care of minor chores required by the electronics to perform correctly. These
chores are described next.
As mentioned before, all communication links between the Transmitter Controller and the Upper
Electronics are digital and meet all of the requirements of EIA Standard RS-422.
The BURST1/BURST2 signal is converted to an unbalanced unipolar signal by U6. This signal,
now called SMPCLK has three functions:
1. It passes through a buffer (U8). The output of the buffer is called SMPCLK1 and this signal
strobes all the A/D converters in the Acquisition Boards.
2. It strobes a retrigerable one-shot constantly. This one shot times out if SMPCLK is missing
for more than 4.0 µsec, generating a high -to-low transition in START1. This signal, after
passing through a driver stage and being renamed START, re-initializes all of the Acquisition
Modules. START and SMPCLK are covered in detail in the Acquisition Board description.
3. It passes through another buffer (U3) and, as SMPCLK2, it is applied to a counter embedded
in the C30 DSP chip in the C30-Based Digital Controller.
When the C30-Based Digital Controller PCBA, P/N A3001304000, communicates with the
Transmitter Controller Board, it does so serially, generating a signal ASYCTX. This is an
unbalanced (unipolar) signal. The Interface Board receives this unbalanced signal at U5 pin 15
and retransmits it balanced as TX1/TX2 meeting Standard RS-422.
RX1/RX2 is an asynchronous serial signal coming from the Transmitter Controller Board. It is
converted to an unbalanced, unipolar signal named ASYCRX by U6. This signal is applied to the
input of a UART located inside U1. The UART detects the signal and retransmits it to the C30-
Based Digital Controller using OUT_SCLK, OUT_SDAT and OUT_EOC. The protocol used is
described in detail in the description of the C30-Based Digital Controller, but is basically a serial-

Circuit Description
1590 MA HTHP WTS HDIL Induction Mandrel
131024-945
JULY 2010

ACQUISITION BOARD
Refer to assembly drawing F185337000 and schematic drawing F185337100.
Each Acquisition Board includes four modules. Each module is virtually identical to the rest so
only one of them will be described.
From the analog perspective, a signal coming from the preamplifier is received by an SSM-2142.
This is an integrated differential amplifier that receives balanced line inputs, with very low
distortion. The output of the differential line receiver is applied to a non-inverting stage that has a
gain of five. Finally, the signal goes through a level-shifting process and into the A/D converter.
A description of the manner in which the level-shift takes place follows:
The A/D converter requires unipolar signals with amplitude between 0 and Vref. In this
application, Vref is 4.096. Vref is divided by two, with two 5k-ohm resistors. This voltage is
added to the signal at the input of the buffer driving the input of the A/D. It can be seen that when
no signal comes from the Preamplifier, the input of the A/D converter will be a DC level of
Vref/2.
From the digital perspective, a one Mega Sample per second A/D Converter and an Analog
Devices 2101 DSP component take care of the Stacking Process. Two kinds of events take place
in the Acquisition Module: Data Acquisition and Signature Transfer.

Data Acquisition
Two signals control the Acquisition Process. One of them is START. A High-to-Low transition of
START initializes all of the functions of the DSP 2101. Notice that START is actually an interrupt
signal for the 2101.
The other control signal is SMPCLK. This is a normally high signal. Each transition from high to
low of this signal starts a digitizing process in the A/D.
For the next discussion take a look at Figure 4. SMPCLK is applied to the S/H pin of the A/D
and that is the way it has been labeled on the figure. A few nanoseconds after the start of the
conversion, EOC goes low generating an interrupt to the DSP processor. The 2101, during the
conversion time, reads the data corresponding to the previous conversion. You can see when the
2101 is reading the A/D data bus because a PMS signal is generated by the DSP chip. By the time
EOC goes high, the DSP chip has already finished the reading process. This process continues as
long as the SMPCLK’s keep strobing. The DSP chip will build up a signature according to the

Signature Transfer
The DSP is always working with two buffers. One buffer is the one that builds the signature. The
other buffer is ready to be transmitted to the C30-Based Digital Controller.
The 2101 provides a complete synchronous serial interface. Serial port 0 has a 5-pin interface,
consisting of the following signals: SCLK, RFS, TFS, DR and DT. Only three of these signals are
used by the Acquisition Module: TFS, SCLK, and DT. In this application, the clock is driven by
the C30-Based Digital Controller. The serial transfer starts when a TFS (TFS0) is received by the
DSP chip. The serial port has a feature known as auto-buffering with Single-Cycled Overhead.
This means the serial port can automatically receive or transmit the contents of an entire data
buffer with only one overhead cycle per data word. This feature transfers the signature data from
the internal DSP memory to the C30-Based Digital Controller. The whole buffer is transferred,
transparent to the program that is running into the DSP Chip component. Once the buffer has
been sent, an internal interrupt occurs that terminates the transfer sequence between this module
and the C30-Based Digital Controller. Transistor 2 N7002 provides driving capability. The drain
on all the modules is connected to a 1 K pull-up resistor in the Interface Board.

mux with the proper address will propagate the TFS signal to the correct DSP chip. Notice four
jumpers are present on each board. These jumpers distinguish between channels 0, 1, 2, 3 and
channels 5, 6, 7, R. Channel 0 processes subarray 0, channel 1 processes subarray 1, etc. The
reference is processed by channel R.
The 2101 has an internal data memory and an internal program memory, and executes the
stacking program from internal RAM. Booting circuitry provides for loading on-chip program
memory automatically from byte-wide external memory. After reset, an EEPROM is used as an
external boot memory. Once the EEPROM has been read, it is no longer needed and it goes to a
low-power mode. This happens when BMS/ on the DSP chip goes high. BMS/ is the signal on the
DSP chip that controls the booting process.

C-30-Based Digital Controller Board Specifications and
Descriptions
Processing Unit –
Texas Instruments TMS 320 C30 GEL Digital Signal Processor @ 20 MHz.
(U18)
Firmware –
Four Cypress Semiconductor CY7 C266-25, 8 K x 8 EPROMS configured
as 8k x 32 @ 25 nS access (U23, U25, U27, U29)
Static Ram –
Four Integrated Device Technology IDT71256 S-25 TP, 32 K x 8 SRAMS
configured as 32k x 32 @ 25 nS access (U22, U24, U26, U28)
Telemetry –
Three modes of transmission M2, M5 & M7 at standard WTS transmission
rates of:
M2 - Command
20.8 Kb/sec
M2 - Data
41.6 Kb/sec
M5 - Data
93.0 Kb/sec
M7 - Data
93.0 Kb/sec
Serial Channels –
One high-speed serial channel that accepts input from the Interface Board.
The second high-speed serial channel is not used by HDIL.

One low-speed serial link provides control output to the Interface Board. (3
wire system)
Interrupt Control –
Four potential interrupts to the processor:
Interrupt 0 –
Configured to be interrupted at the end of Acquisition by the Interface
Board. An interrupt is generated at the end of the stacking cycle (a one-to-
zero transition of STOP/START signal in the Interface Board).
Interrupt 1 –
Manchester communications interrupt (All Modes Transmit & Receive)
Interrupt 2 –
High-Speed Serial link from the Interface Board
Interrupt 3 –
Serial link 2 (not used)
External Bus –
An 8 bit bi-directional external bus provided for auxiliary connection to an
external peripheral. Not used by HDIL.
C30 Serial Ports –
C30 Serial 0 (zero) is used to emulate RS232 for command transmission to
the Transmitter Controller Board.

7.2.1 Control Register & IFP Data Shifters
The C-30 "sees" the FPGA as a set of registers that can be read or written. These registers are
memory-mapped at locations 804400/03. These addresses correspond to the expansion bus of the
C-30.
A 16-bit control register controls various aspects of the external/internal operation of the Actel
part. This control register is memory-mapped at 0x804403 on the expansion bus of the TMS320.

GENERAL CIRCUIT DESCRIPTION
The 1590 EA/MA/FA High Definition Induction Log, HDIL is similar in function and design to
the 1515 EA/MA WTS HDIL, but is rated for higher temperatures (up to 500º F) and pressures
(up to 30, 000 psi). The electronics and sensors are packaged with flasked pressure housings
along with additional active and passive temperature sensors. To allow the mandrel electronics to
be installed inside a flasked pressure housing, the 1515 MA was separated into two sections
(1590 MA and 1590 FA). The 1590 MA mandrel section contains the measurement coil array. The
1590 FA contains the mandrel electronics chassis. The 1590 EA electronics chassis remains
unchanged from the 1515 EA, but installed into a new Flasked housing.
The 1590 is designed to operate in a 500º F  environment for up to 6 hours, in some cases even
longer. To get the maximum longevity at this temperature the operator needs to know what the
internal tool temperature is and how fast it is rising. The tool string is outfitted with 10
temperature sensors (4 from the EA section, 4 from the MA, and 2 from the FA). These readings
are transmitted to the surface and displayed on a comprehensive plot showing present
temperature, temperature rise, and remaining time to reach critical maximum temperature.
The 1590 High Definition Induction Log transmits a complex magnetic waveform into the
formation. Different arrays of coils detect this complex waveform. The received signals are
processed by the tool and then sent to a surface computer.
The heart of the tool is the transmitter section (1590 FA). This section generates all the timing
signals required by the tool to work properly. Setup parameters concerning the operation of the
instrument can be changed through commands to this section. The communication between the
transmitter section and the rest of the tool takes place serially through balanced twisted pair lines.
The major functions of the transmitter controller are:
•
Generate the logic to drive the transmitter,
•
generate the synchronization logic that will be sent to the acquisition system,
•
generate the logic that switches the tool to the different operating modes (ZERO, CAL,
LOG),
•
measure temperatures at two points on the mandrel, main electronics, and transmitter
electronics sections, and
•
select the kind of reference signal. The reference is a signal that characterizes the complex
waveform transmitted into the formation. Several points in the electronics monitor this signal.
A command can be sent to the transmitter controller to switch between two monitor points.
This command is useful mainly for testing purposes.
•
Save calibration data related to the mandrel. This feature gives you the ability to swap

Circuit Description
1590 MA HTHP WTS HDIL Induction Mandrel

As mentioned before, the signal coming from the formation are detected by sets of coils. Each set
of coils, plus the transmitter, is a measuring unit known as subarray. The transmitter is common to
all subarrays. The tool has seven subarrays, with subarray 0 (zero) having its detector coils closest
to the transmitter.
Each set of receiver coils has two components: the bucker coil (closest to the transmitter) and the
main coil. Figure 1 below shows the way each subarray works:


interaction is the one measured. There is also a direct "transformer effect" between the transmitter
and receiver that is useless for logging purpose. The bucker coil is there to cancel this direct
interaction.
Each subarray has a preamplifier channel associated with it as seen in Figure 2. The components
of the preamplifier channel are:
•
a balanced input amplifier,
•
a broad band band-pass filter, and
•
a balance output driver.



JULY 2010
3
Circuit Description
1590 MA HTHP WTS HDIL Induction Mandrel

The preamplifier section of the tool, placed in the upper area of the mandrel (1590 MA), contains
all of the preamplifier channels. A triangular chassis holds three (3) preamplifier boards with each
board capable of holding up to three (3) preamplifier channels. Only one board processes three
(3) channels, while the other two boards process two (2) channels each.
Once the signals from each subarray have been amplified, they are sent to the main electronics
(1590 EA section of the tool) through shielded twisted-pair wires. Seven DSP-based Acquisition
Modules sample and process the signals from each subarray. The processing is called stacking
and, as a result, seven (7) Signatures are generated. A signature is a 96-point buffer, and each
point is characterized by a 32-bit number.
Refer to Figure 3 to better understand the way the stacker works.


JULY 2010
4
Circuit Description
1590 MA HTHP WTS HDIL Induction Mandrel

The transmitter creates a repetitive signal. The received signal contains the information being
sought, but is normally buried by noise. If we add up or "stack" 1, 2 and 3, etc., assuming the
noise is random, the true signal will "clean up". It is clear that the more we stack, the better the
signal looks. Limitations to the method will be imposed by the logging speed and the size of the
register used to save the summation. The process must be fast enough so we can consider that the
formation doesn't change. The period of the transmitted signal is 96 µsec. The Acquisition
Module acquires data at 1.0 Mega-samples per second. This means that one transmitter period
will be sampled 96 times. The 96-point sampled signal is "stacked up" for a variable period of
time. The C30-Based Digital Controller tracks this time together with the SAB166 Controller
(U1), or the Transmitter section of the tool. In this manner it is possible to figure out how many
stacking processes took place.




It is important to notice that normally the transmitter runs all the time while the stacking
process takes place only on command. The whole stacking process can be controlled
from the surface.

The transmitter can be turned off with a command from the surface, but this command is issued
only for debugging and testing purposes.
An eighth DSP-based module samples the reference and a signature of the reference is also
generated.
Two boards contain the Acquisition Modules (F185337000). Each board has four acquisition
modules. The boards are indistinguishable and a set of four (4) jumpers (per board) enables
communication with one board or the other.
A Main Electronics board (F164825000), based on floating point DSP chip (TMS320 C30)
serially collects all of the signatures. Functions of the Main Electronics board are:
•
Communication with surface (decode commands, transmit and receive data), and
•
acquisition of the signatures and eventually, further process them (compression scheme).
The Main Electronics Board cannot handle asynchronous serial reception efficiently. Neither can
it address each of the DSP acquisition channels. An Interface board (A3001439000), based on an
8xC51 controller, handles all of these tasks. This board is located in the 1590 EA Instrument and
provides:
•
Control lines required to address the Acquisition Modules,
•
serial-balanced drivers and receivers required to communicate the C30-Based Digital
Controller with the transmitter, and
•
temperature sensors to monitor the temperature inside each tool section.
A UART embedded in the controller receives asynchronous data from the transmitter electronics
and converts this data into a protocol understood by the C30-Based Digital Controller.

INTRODUCTION
The 1590 EA HTHP WTS HDIL Main Electronics can be heat tested, if necessary. Remove the
Flask Housing from the Electronics Chassis before heat testing. Do not exceed the maximum
operating temperature and time limits of 320° F for one hour.

Mechanical Disassembly
1. Remove the main electronics chassis from the flask housing (See Manufacturing Assembly
Procedure document F131023855.)
2. Remove the flask assembly from the electronics chassis.
3. Remove and discard all O-Rings listed in Level 3 Parts List (F131023843). Inspect backup
rings for cracks chipping and other signs of damage. Discard backup rings if damaged.
4. Inspect the peek rings on the heat sink and chassis assembly. Units have Teflon tape under
the peek rings. Replace tape if they have taken a compression set.

Electronics Checkout
1. Inspect the PC boards for loose screws, pinched wires, cold-solder joints, loose and broken
components.
2. Perform 1590 EA tests in the Functionality Test section of Manufacturing Test Procedure
document F131023856.

Mechanical Assembly
1. Replace all parts listed in the Level PM3 Parts list (F131023843).
2. Use Loctite #532 each time that you replace a screw in it original position. Use RTV 3145
Adhesive to secure wire bundles and hardware as needed.
3. Reassembly the tool per Manufacturing Assembly Procedure F131023855.
4. Lubricate threads, O-Rings, and split collar with Krytox grease.

GENERAL PROCEDURES
1. Check for new FMNs and OTBs related to the 1590 EA tool series.
2. Order parts required for PM3 level preventive maintenance per Level 3 Parts List
F131023843 and Spare Parts List F131023841.
3. Check operation of the instrument. Connect the 1590 EA/FA/MA together for testing.
Repair as needed.

Note: If any of the measurements are not within the recommended tolerances, refer to component
F131023856 for repair or adjustment.
